https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.main_headline: CYPRUS NEEDS A UNIVERSITY, BUT GETS TALK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.print_headline: CYPRUS NEEDS A UNIVERSITY, BUT GETS TALK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.body_text: **********Nicos Zittis, a Greek Cypriot, is trying to get a scholarship or a loan to study electronics at an American university. **********Dilek Onem, a Turkish Cypriot, set aside her dream of being a dentist on failing to get a scholarship for study in the United States or France; she is working here in a bank. **********Both had their sights on going abroad because there is no college or university on this island of 600,000 people.  Some 14,000 Cypriots are now studying overseas, 3,000 of them in the United States. But since it is increasingly difficult and costly to do so, there are pressures on all sides to establish a university in Cyprus. **********The issue, however, is highly charged politically, as it involves tensions stemming from the division of the island into increasingly estranged zones of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots. Need for University **********For the last two decades, or almost since this island received its independence from Britain in 1960, both Greek and Turkish Cypriots have been saying that there is a need to set up a university. One of the main champions of such an institution for Cyprus is Lellos Demetriades, Mayor of the Greek Cypriot side of the capital, who wants to convert some of the abandoned buildings in the buffer zone separating the two sides into university faculties open to the two communities. **********An interministerial committee set up by the Greek Cypriot Government to study the question concluded in 1976 that a university was both ''necessary and feasible,'' Nicos J. Vakis, a physiologist at the Agricultural Research Institute in Nicosia, said. Dr. Vakis heads a group called the Friends of the University, which includes representatives of Parent-Teacher Associations and students. **********In 1981 the Greek Cypriot House of Representatives adopted a resolution in favor of the university. Last year the Greek Cypriot Ministry of Education said the matter was urgent, and the interministerial committee has now drafted a 14-page amendment to its 1976 report. **********''We hope the university can get off the ground this year,'' Dr.  Vakis said, pointing out that publicly everyone agrees on the need.  Panos Adamides, director general of education, who has headed the interm@inisterial committee from the start, said in a recent interview that agreement had been reached in principle that a university serving both Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots was needed. Goal Is to Open by 1985 **********He said the decisions to date envisioned a university for about 6,000 students, with both Greek and Turkish Cypriots represented in the faculty and administration as well as in the student body. The goal, he said, would be to open by 1985. **********Mr. Adamides said that history and civilization would be taught in Greek and Turkish and that English would be used for ''culturally neutral subjects'' such as the sciences and technology. He said the university would be autonomous, though financially controlled by the state, and situated on a campus accessible to both communities. **********''One question remains,'' he said, adding that it was whether to ''proceed with the declaration of intent to invite the Turkish community to participate when they are ready, or to wait and include the university as another item of negotiation in the intercommunal talks.'' **********He said the ''prevailing attitude'' favored moving ahead without waiting for a political solution of the division of Cyprus into two sectors. Unlikely That Turks Will Join **********But it appears unlikely that the Turkish Cypriots will accept any invitation to join what they see as a Greek Cypriot plan to establish a university. **********''We are ready to discuss the university as an intercommunal institution when we have formed a federal state,'' Rauf Denktash, leader of the Turkish Cypriots, said in a recent interview. ''But how can we start when we cannot even go to the Greek side? What right have they to set it up when they have not even asked us our views?'' **********Mr. Denktash, President of the proclaimed Turkish Federated State of Cyprus, predicted that the Greek side was going to set up a Greek university and suggest that the Turkish Cypriots could respond easily by upgrading the Higher Technological Institute, on the outksirts of the northern port of Famagusta. Now Has 200 Students **********The institute, which began with 78 students in 1979 and now has 200, is situated on a 50-acre stretch of barren land. It consists of five modern blocks, and work has begun to level ground for the administration building. With a present capacity of 600 students, there are plans to build a dormitory and a cafeteria. **********''Few universities have such a wide range of modern equipment,'' Onay Fadil, secretary general of education in the Turkish zone, said as he took visitors on a tour of the electronics, hydraulics, electrical machinery and mechanical laboratories and workshops. He said most of the equipment was American and English and had been bought with a $2.6 million contribution from the United Nations High Commission for Refugees and a $1 million grant from the Islamic Development Bank. **********Mr. Fadil said preparations were under way to introduce a fouryear university program next September.  Ahmet Aker, an adviser to the Turkish Cypriot Department of Education who is on leave from the Johns Hopkins University branch in Bologna, Italy, said he thought it feasible to establish a university on the Turkish Cypriot side for 1,500 to 2,000 students.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/busin.main_headline: CURB ASKED ON TRADE TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/busin.print_headline: CURB ASKED ON TRADE TO SOVIET
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/busin.body_text: **********The President's national security adviser, William P. Clark, has endorsed a proposed tightening of controls over exports to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today. His action intensifies an interagency conflict over Washington's response to the Soviet downing of a Korean Air Lines plane on Sept. 1. **********Mr. Clark's intervention came in a letter to Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige. The Commerce Department enforces the export controls and heads an interagency committee that makes policy recommendations. **********The Clark letter supported the committee's recommendation of Sept. 13 that a more restrictive export standard be applied to 17 categories of oil and gas equipment. **********A similar letter was sent to Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who reportedly has been furious over the Sept. 13 recommendation. In that letter, dated Sept. 19, Mr. Clark wrote: ''Although this process was proceeding independent of the K.A.L. shootdown, the recommendation for this adjustment for these high-technology strategic items could be timely.'' **********The Administration officials said a Cabinet-level body, called the Senior Interagency Group on International Economic Policy and headed by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, planned to take up the matter Friday. **********Secretary Baldrige said through his press spokesman, B. Jay Cooper, ''We won't comment on a classified document.'' Robert B. Sims, the press liaison officer for Mr. Clark, declined comment. **********It was unclear whether Mr. Clark was acting personally or for the President. **********Officials said a tightening of export controls would not affect sales to the Soviet Union of pipe-laying equipment made by the Caterpillar Tractor Company of Peoria, Ill. President Reagan approved the removal of such equipment from the restricted list on Aug. 20, in response to a recommendation from Mr. Baldrige and Mr. Shultz. **********Because Mr. Reagan approved decontrol of the pipelayers, the interagency committee did not include them in its recommended tightening, but it decided not to extend decontrol to related equipment, such as pipe-laying barges.  Contents of Baldrige Letter **********Those who saw copies of the Clark letter to Mr. Baldrige said it urged him to let stand the bulk of the recommendations that were taken Sept. 13 by a sub-Cabinet interagency committee. The chairman of that group was Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, a leading opponent of trade with the Russians. He has been supported by Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense. **********Mr. Brady's position is in sharp contrast to that of his superior, Mr. Baldrige. Mr. Baldrige and Secretary Shultz have generally favored trade in all but the most sensitive products on the ground that the Russians can buy most items in other countries. **********Mr. Shultz and Mr. Baldrige have been working with American allies to make export controls international, in order to make them more effective. But Europe and Japan are reluctant to sever trade with the Russians. **********The recommended export policy, unless overturned by the Cabinet and the President, would deny an export license for $40 million worth of oil exploration equipment and would place 17 products for oil and gas exploration under more rigorous national security export controls. **********Under national security controls, the Defense Department, which has generally opposed most trade with the Russians, has a major say. Under foreign policy controls, in which these products are now listed, the State Department has a major say. **********The advisory group that made the recommendations is made up of the Departments of Commerce, Energy, State and Defense, the National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency. **********The group's action was originally described as ''technical'' and was taken unanimously. However, two Administration officials, commenting separately and asking that they not be identified, said the impact could be far-reaching.  Earlier Presidential Action **********They explained that the items that would be shifted to the national security control list included many that were banned by President Reagan last year when he tried to discourage European support for the pipeline to bring natural gas from Siberia to Western Europe. **********In June 1982, the President extended a ban on the sale of American pipeline equipment to the licensees and subsidiaries of American companies abroad. Equipment involved included General Electric turbines and Dresser Industries compressors made in Western Europe. **********The European governments then ordered the companies within their jurisdiction to ship the equipment despite the American ban. President Reagan followed by imposing sanctions against the European suppliers.   Compromise Last November **********American relations with the Europeans became increasingly tense until November, when Secretary Shultz worked out a compromise in which the Allies agreed to press for making the controls international through the Coordinating Committee of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********A State Department official said: ''I am afraid that we may be embarking on the same course as we were last June.'' **********An official from another agency, who asked that neither he nor the agency be identified, said, ''We were sandbagged by the hawks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Elie Salem of Lebanon said today that Syria would probably negotiate on troop withdrawals from Lebanon soon despite its initial rejection of an Israeli-Lebanese accord. **********''We are fully convinced that we will have no major problem with Syria, that once this cloud passes, we and the Syrians will get together, hopefully in the coming few weeks, and solve it together,'' Mr. Salem said at a news conference at his Paris hotel. **********The Lebanese Minister spoke at the end of a brief tour of Italy, West Germany and France to gain support for the United States-backed agreement. **********Syria has said the accord undermines Lebanese sovereignty by allowing joint Lebanese-Israeli patrols to operate in southern Lebanon and rewards the Israelis for their invasion of Lebanon last year. **********Israel has said it will not withdraw its troops from Lebanon under terms of the agreement until Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization agree to pull out their forces as well. Asserts Syria is Bargaining **********Mr. Salem suggested that Syria's rejection of the withdrawal plan, signed by Israel and Lebanon last Tuesday, was a bargaining position dictated by its need to present itself as a defender of Arab nationalism. **********The Lebanese Foreign Minister said Lebanon was ready to work out arrangements with President Hafez al-Assad to guarantee Syria's security and long-term interests in the region. **********Mr. Salem said Lebanon never expected Syria to approve any accord signed with Israel. But, he added, ''I do not believe the Syrian position is final.'' **********''We believe that Mr. Assad will discuss the agreement with the Lebanese in great detail,'' he went on.  ''I cannot conceive that Syria will remain adamant in its present position and expose Lebanon to the infinite dangers that we face,'' he said.  ''The choice is between withdrawal with this agreement or the extinction of Lebanon.'' **********If the accord is not carried out in a month or two, it will die a natural death, Mr. Salem said. ---- Syria Urged to Withdraw **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22 (Reuters) - Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan urged Syria today to withdraw its troops from Lebanon and to test Israel's pledge to pull out its troops. **********''If for whatever reason there is no Israeli withdrawal, the effect on the general conditions in Lebanon and the region as a whole will be of the utmost gravity,'' Mr. Wazzan said in an interview with a Lebanese magazine. **********Mr. Wazzan said that if Lebanon had not signed the agreement, Israel would have appeared in Western eyes as a thwarted peacemaker.  ''Should Syria agreee to help us, only then will it be known whether Israel will withdraw or not,'' Mr. Wazzan said.  ''We hope and we tend to believe that our sister Syria cannot but understand the reality of the Lebanese position and will therefore help us to remove the Israeli occupier from our country,'' the Prime Minister said. **********Asked about suggestions that Syria might break relations with Lebanon and close their borders, Mr. Wazzan replied: ''We hope Syria will not reach that stage. We cling to Lebanese-Syrian brotherhood and we are sincerely and earnestly striving to settle all the difficulties that may arise.'' ---- Habib Arrives in Beirut **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22 (Reuters) - The special United States envoy, Philip C. Habib, arrived in Beirut today for a further effort at breaking the deadlock over the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon. **********Lebanese officials said Mr. Habib arrived from Israel to brief Lebanese officials on the results of his visits to Jerusalem, Cairo and Riydah. **********Earlier in Jerusalem, Mr. Habib met Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and told him he remained optimistic that Syria would ultimately agree to a troop withdrawal, according to a report on the Israeli radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/08/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Chilean Groups Form Opposition Alliance
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/08/world.body_text: **********The head of Chile's Christian Democratic Party, Gabriel Valdes, has announced the creation of a five-party opposition Democratic Alliance. **********Mr. Valdes said the alliance had called on President Augusto Pinochet to step down in favor of a provisional government that would start an economic revival program and prepare for free elections within 18 months. **********Mr. Valdes, who was Foreign Minister in a Christian Democratic administration in the late 1960's, called on President Pinochet to resign ''for the good of the fatherland.'' **********The 67-year-old President led the 1973 coup against Salvador Allende Gossens. His term is to last until 1989 under a 1980 constitutional amendment. **********Alliance members are the Democratic Rightists, Social Democrats, Christian Democrats, Radicals and Socialists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Shortly after the General Motors Corporation introduced the redesigned 1984 Chevrolet Corvette in California in late March, the company's chairman, Roger B. Smith, received some unexpected first-hand evidence that the new sports car was quickly becoming a hit. He was awakened at his Bloomfield Hills, Mich., home at 1 A.M. one night by a phone call from an exuberant Corvette buyer in California who wanted to compliment him on G.M.'s newest product. **********The caller is not alone in his admiration for the new car.  Analysts say that not since the Chrysler Corporation reintroduced the convertible in the winter of 1981 has a new American auto sparked such enthusiasm. **********In fact, dealers around the country report difficulties in keeping the expensive car, which carries a base sticker price of $21,800, in the showroom. Even Chevrolet's announcement in early July that it was recalling the first 10,000 1984 Corvettes to replace defective brake components has not appeared to slow sales. **********''All of the Corvettes we've gotten in have been sold out before they even arrived,'' said Russ Barr, a salesman at Mike Maher Chevrolet in Grosse Pointe, Mich. **********And in suburban San Diego, Claude Hunter, a salesman at Dick Grihalva Chevrolet, says: ''We can't keep them in stock. We've got a waiting list. Whenever one comes in, we just call a customer to come down and pick it up.'' He added that since the dealership could not keep a demonstrator on the lot, customers were buying their Corvettes without test-driving them. **********Between April and June, Chevrolet sold 10,110 Corvettes, including some leftover 1982 models. That was up 50.5 percent from sales of 6,717 in the period last year. (The company did not build a 1983 Corvette in anticipation of the early introduction of the 1984 version). **********Including cars in transit to dealers, G.M. had only about a 20-day supply of Corvettes in late June. A 60-day inventory is considered normal in the auto industry. The low supply is one indica-tion of how sold out dealers are, said David Healy, automotive analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert. Output Is Limited **********Chevrolet has added to the tightness in supply by limiting production at its assembly plant in Bowling Green, Ky. As a result, its output of about 100 Corvettes a day is just keeping pace with sales, said Ralph Kramer, a Chevrolet spokesman. Furthermore, the company plans to build only 37,000 Corvettes in the 1984 model year, which extends to the fall of 1984. **********Chevrolet officials say privately that their production plans remain cautious because they are not convinced that the strong demand will continue. **********For G.M., the Corvette represents only a small part of the company's auto output, which is expected to reach more than 3.9 million cars this year. But the Corvette's real value, analysts say, is its ability to lure curious customers into showrooms and at the same time help improve the image of other Chevrolet cars. **********''It does not mean a hell of a lot for G.M.'s profitability,'' said Joseph Philippi, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''But there is no question that it is a traffic builder.'' **********The Corvette, first introduced by Chevrolet in 1953, has long had a cult following. This was true even in the late 1970's and early 1980's, when it became clear that with its dated, rather gaudy design and lackluster performance, the Corvette was losing some of its market to European and Japanese sports cars, such as the Porsche, Datsun 280-Z and the Mazda RX-7. First Big Change Since '68 **********But the long-awaited 1984 Corvette model, the first completely redesigned Corvette since 1968, has been praised by leading auto magazines. With its sleek styling, video-game-style dashboard electronics, and its overhauled engine and drive train, the car is winning back many who had defected to the imports. **********''We're getting people who drive Mercedes and Porsches - doctors and lawyers,'' said Nick Bartos, sales manager at Merollis Chevrolet in East Detroit, Mich. **********Industry analysts agree that it is still too early to gauge whether the Corvette will make permanent inroads in the upper-income market dominated by high-performance European sports cars. **********''I would have been surprised if it hadn't had this kind of initial reception,'' said Harvey Heinbach, auto analyst with Merrill Lynch. ''But I don't think you can judge anything by the first couple of months. The question is staying power.'' The Typical Buyer **********Analysts also wonder whether the new Corvette has not been priced out of its area of traditional strength, the youth-oriented market, and into one of older professionals. Preliminary data indicate that the typical buyer of the 1984 Corvette is a male in his mid-30's or early 40's who earns more than $50,000 a year, said Jack Madejehick, Chevrolet's director of marketing information. **********''Because of the Corvette's price, Chevrolet is going to have to go after higher-income buyers than in the past,'' said David Power, president of J.D. Power & Associates, a consumer research group that specializes in the auto industry. ''And in the long run, I don't think you can steal that many Porsche drivers away.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.print_headline: No Word on Kidnapped Girl As Deadline Passes in Rome
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********A midnight deadline passed early today with no word on whether kidnappers had fulfilled their pledge to kill the abducted daughter of a Vatican messenger unless Mehmet Ali Agca, the papal assailant, was freed. **********The abductors had demanded the release of Mr. Agca in their first contact with authorities days after the 15-year-old schoolgirl, Emanuela Orlandi, was seized at a Rome bus stop June 22. In their final message before the deadline, they renewed the threat to kill Miss Orlandi at midnight unless Mr. Agca was turned over to them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Samuel J. Heyman, the dissident GAF Corporation shareholder, claimed an ''overwhelming victory'' yesterday in his proxy contest against the company's management and said that he had filed a suit in a Wilmington, Del., court to force GAF to close off stockholder voting. **********''The election is not final until it has been certified by the inspectors of election,'' a GAF spokesman said.  The two-month battle between Mr. Heyman and GAF's chairman, Jesse Werner, was expected to end at the GAF annual meeting in Charlotte, N.C., last Thursday. But before the meeting the GAF board of directors decided to extend the voting of proxies until May 13, the date set for the certification. Mr. Heyman and other dissidents hope to bar GAF from soliciting further votes during the two-week period before May 13 by closing the polls as of 2 P.M. April 28, the date of the annual meeting. **********14.3 Million Shares **********The dissidents maintained that the management move was illegal. But until the court acts, GAF shareholders who may have abstained will be allowed to cast their votes and shareholders who have already voted can change their vote by sending in another proxy. **********Mr Heyman, a Connecticut real estate developer, said his committee for new management received about 8.43 million shares, or 6l.2 percent, of the shares cast as of Thursday. About 5.36 million shares, or about 38.8 percent, were estimated to have been cast for GAF's present management. **********''There may be some duplications and some revocations,'' Mr. Heyman said, adding that he believed the outcome would not be altered even if some shareholders did switch. ''Considering GAF's conduct last week, shareholders may wish to change their votes in our favor,'' he said. **********The bitter proxy contest has focused on the company's recent decision to liquidate by selling its two major businesses: building products and chemicals. Mr. Heyman objects to the proposed sale of the company's building products division to the Southwestern General Corporation for $140 million. He said it is the wrong time, the wrong price and the wrong buyer. He does not object to the sale of the chemical unit to the Allied Corporation for $410 million, although he said the company might possibly have made a better deal if the transaction had not been negotiated during the proxy fight. Stock Price Erosion Cited **********In his statement to shareholders last week, Mr. Werner said that the liquidation plan was aimed at maximizing the value of the company's stock and returning some of the company's value to shareholders. The dissidents charged that during the last 20 years - the period that Mr. Werner has been chief executive of the company - GAF's stock has lost more than 80 percent of its value. **********At the annual meeting on Thursday, Mr. Werner said that GAF would not pay a quarterly dividend on common stock, though it would pay a quarterly dividend of 30 cents to holders of convertible preferred stock. The common dividend omission, Mr. Werner said, resulted from restrictions in the company's loan agreements.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/14/world.body_text: **********ANCE TIGHTENS SECURITY AROUND ITS TO P OFFICIALS **********PARIS, Dec. 13 - The French Government has taken precautionary measures to head off possible attacks by Middle Eastern squads on President Francois Mitterrand and other leaders. **********Gates at the presidential palace have been shut, and the streets where some officials live are being heavily patrolled. **********At the same time, the Government has given no hint about whether it plans reprisals for the bomb attack Monday on the French Embassy in Kuwait or the ambush in a Beirut street today that took the life a French paratrooper on patrol. **********The Government condemned the ''odious act'' in Kuwait and expressed confidence that the Kuwaiti authorities would hunt down and try the attackers. **********Because the attack caused only two slight injuries at the French Embassy, the French Government's statement calling attention to Kuwait's responsibility was taken here as a sign that no reprisals were contemplated. **********The precautionary measures against a raid in Paris have gradually become apparent since the bomb explosion in Beirut on Oct. 23 that killed 58 French paratroopers. An almost simultaneous explosion at the United States Marine headquarters killed 240 American servicemen. **********Several weeks after the attack, Mr. Mitterrand told a national television audience that it would not go unpunished, and French aircraft struck at the installations of a Shiite militia group near Baalbek in Lebanon a month after the original raid.   One Lane Is for the Palace **********Officials decline to enumerate the new security measures, but the heavy green steel doors at the main entrance to Elysee Palace, the official presidential residence, are now shut at all times, opening only for announced official visitors. Previously, the doors were left open, allowing passers-by on Rue Faubourg St. Honore a glimpse at the comings and goings of guests at the palace, although the public was not allowed to enter. **********Traffic on the street has been routed so that a special lane is for cars entering Elysee Palace. **********The police have also tightened controls for entrance to some ministries and have closed Rue de Bi evre on the Left Bank where Mr. Mitterrand has a private apartment. **********Heavy barricades and police details have also appeared on other small streets, and officials have privately suggested that they relate to tightened security for members of the Cabinet. **********No specific threats against French leaders have been officially reported, although the press here has quoted Teheran newspaper articles containing intimations that more attacks of the kind in Beirut might be expected. **********Since the French contingent joined the multinational force in Lebanon in September 1982, 78 of its members have been killed, according to published totals. The pattern here has been for attacks related to the French presence in the Middle East to raise the level of public interest only briefly. **********Attention in the press has quickly subsided, and no firmly rooted campaign to pull the troops out has developed, although opposition politicians frequently accuse the Government of having no clear policy on Lebanon and of being too closely tied to United States actions there.   Attacks Linked to Gulf War **********Newspaper commentaries and opposition politicians often connect attacks by Shiite or other Islamic militants, such as the bombing of the French Embassy in Kuwait, to French help for Iraq in its war against Iran. **********Mr. Mitterrand has publicly said France is helping Iraq to prevent its defeat by the Iranian Government of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. **********The future of the Palestinians was reported to have been the chief topic of an hourlong conversation today between Mr. Mitterrand and King Hussein of Jordan. **********The King said afterward that Mr. Arafat ''is always welcome, without conditions, in Jordan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/busin.body_text: **********With only five days remaining before the deadline for filing Federal personal income tax returns, financial institutions in New York City and around the country are reporting a last-minute surge in depositors opening Individual Retirement Accounts to qualify for a deduction on 1982 taxes. **********''They've really been coming in in waves, especially since April 1,'' said Cynthia Bailey of the Chase Manhattan Bank. Some other I.R.A.-sponsoring institutions have been reporting averages of 5,000 to 7,000 new accounts a day in recent weeks, as savers seek to beat the April 15 tax deadline. **********The institutions are encouraging this rush to open the retirement accounts in nationwide promotional campaigns. Big newspaper display advertisements and spots on radio and television are touting the investment and tax opportunities offered by I.R.A.'s. **********The ads are getting results: more than half the accounts Merrill Lynch has started since Jan.1 - 171,000, as of late last week - will have been opened in the month before April 15, one executive of the brokerage house estimated. Lures Take Many Forms **********Some securities firms have done more than advertise to lure I.R.A.  investors. In New York City, for example, Merrill Lynch has twice held an ''I.R.A. Night at the Waldorf,'' in the Empire Room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. A rival brokerage house, Dean Witter Reynolds, is offering a ''round-the-clock'' telephone message center until midnight Friday, for those who wish to sign up for I.R.A.'s and ''reduce your 1982 taxes legally.'' **********Up-to-date figures on how much money has been poured into I.R.A.'s is not available. But by the end of February, investments in I.R.A.'s and Keogh retirement plans totaled $55.4 billion, a 73 percent increase over the same month last year, according to the Federal Reserve Bank. Keogh plans are for the self-employed and represent a small portion of the total. **********Joseph R. Coyne, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve, said its figures represent at least 90 percent of the total money that has been placed in these accounts before March 1. He said that $50.4 billion, or 91 percent of the most recent compilation, had been made in commercial banks and thrift institutions. Such deposits are among those protected by Federal deposit insurance. **********While financial officers were hailing the ''very healthy growth'' in I.R.A. investments, Daniel S. Buser, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association, observed that ''there's still a tremendous potential out there'' because only 1 out of every 10 eligible wageearners had participated. He said that Internal Revenue Service projections for the 1982 tax year indicate that more than 7 million new I.R.A.'s and Keogh plans will be added to the 3.1 million that existed in 1981. **********This year's promotional campaign is far more subdued than at the start of 1982, when the right to open an I.R.A. was extended to all workers with earned income of at least $2,000. Financial advisers have widely recommended that anyone who could afford to open an I.R.A. do so. **********Absent from the current promotions is last year's heavily advertised assertion that a young wage-earner could expect to accumulate more than $1 million by putting aside $2,000 annually for 40 years at an assumed annual interest rate of 12 percent. Today's interest rates for many investments are well below that figure. A Myriad of Options Available **********The financial institutions scrambling to offer I.R.A.'s are commercial banks, savings and loan associations, mutual savings banks, credit unions, insurance companies, mutual fund concerns and brokerage houses. **********These institutions are enticed by the prospect of handling the deposits of 110 million wage-earners, each of whom is permitted to set aside up to $2,000 annually - $2,250 for an individual with a nonworking spouse and $4,000 for a working couple - in the tax-free retirement accounts. **********The earliest that withdrawals can be made from an I.R.A. without penalty is when the saver is 59 1/2 years old. All income earned from I.R.A.'s is taxed at ordinary income rates when withdrawn. Early withdrawals bring an additional 10 percent penalty. **********In order to qualify for a 1982 tax deduction, said Ellen Murphy, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service, ''you have to establish the I.R.A. and make the contribution by April 15,'' although an automatic four-month extension to Aug. 15 is available to those who file tax form 4868 by Friday. If a person has already filed a return but wishes to open an I.R.A. before the deadline, the deduction can still be claimed by opening an account and filing an amended return on form 1040X. **********One action not permitted by the I.R.S., Miss Murphy said, is to file a tax return that claims an I.R.A. contribution as a deduction before it has actually been made. She said that no reporting to the agency of an I.R.A. opening is now required. More Information Available **********For the average saver, the right choice to make among a veritable smorgasbord of packaged I.R.A. options can be baffling. There are passbook accounts, fixed or variable rate certificates, mutual funds, money market accounts, insurance annuity contracts, stocks and bonds, or any combination of these from which to choose. **********Cecilia Sobanski, who attended one of Merrill Lynch's I.R.A.  sessions at the Waldorf, said the sponsoring institutions were far better informed than a year ago when she first opened an account. **********''We're really giving high priority this year to providing customer understanding of the basics,'' agreed Cynthia Bailey, who manages a financial advisory program at Chase Manhattan. ''One frequent misconception was that you had to put the maximum $2,000 in every year to have an account.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.main_headline: BETTER SALES HELP CBS NET JUMP 35.9% IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.print_headline: BETTER SALES HELP CBS NET JUMP 35.9% IN QUARTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc., citing improved sales by its records business and stringent cost controls, yesterday reported significantly higher income for the second quarter. **********The company said its net income for the three months ended June 30 rose 35.9 percent, to $58.7 million, or $1.98 a share, from $43.2 million, or $1.55 a share on fewer shares outstanding, in the same period a year ago. **********Second-quarter revenues rose 6.4 percent, to $1.06 billion, from $996.4 million a year earlier.  The company said its net income in the latest quarter reflected foreign exchange losses of $10 million, of which $8 million occurred in its international records business, mainly in Brazil. The loss was partly offset by increased interest income in Brazil. **********Thomas H. Wyman, CBS's chairman, president and chief executive, said that the results were ahead of company projections and marked the start of ''a solid earnings turnaround at CBS this year.'' **********In last year's second quarter, CBS discontined CBS Cable, a programming venture, and sold Pacific Stereo, a chain of high fidelity retail stores. As a result, income from continuing operations was $48.6 million, or $1.74 a share, a year ago. Earnings Growth from Records **********Most of the earnings growth in the latest quarter came from the records group, which had its best second quarter ever. Pretax income was $28.2 million on revenues of $280.3 million, compared with pretax income of $3.4 million on revenues of $257 million in the same period a year ago. **********Domestic record sales were strong, propelled by such best-selling albums as Michael Jackson's ''Thriller'' and Men at Work, the Australian rock group. But the records group also benefited from several cost-cutting measures taken last year, including plant and branch office closings and layoffs, according to J. Garrett Blowers, a CBS spokesman. **********CBS's broadcast group reported pretax income of $103.3 million on revenues of $563.2 million, compared with $102.7 million in pretax income on revenues of $545.1 million in the second quarter of 1982. Erosion in Television Income **********Television income was eroded because the network, anticipating strong advertising demand last spring, held back an unusually large amount of its inventory - commercial time - rather than selling it before the season began. CBS's gamble failed to pay off when demand proved unexpectedly soft for the held-over time. **********Acknowledging this, Mr. Wyman said that the broadcast group's flat profits in the face of a weak demand for advertising time during the quarter ''demonstrates the effectiveness of the group's cost management efforts.'' In the quarter, the group's expenses rose only 4 percent, an exceptionally low increase. **********''The burning question is whether they can keep costs at 4 percent for the next six months,'' said John McConville of Morgan Stanley.  Cost control may continue to be very important, because advertisers have so far been reluctant to accept the networks' prices and make commitments up front for next season, he said. **********Revenues and profits also improved for the CBS/Columbia group, which includes the Ideal Toy Corporation, acquired last August, and for the publishing group, which includes consumer magazines and textbooks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/25/world.body_text: **********Some scientists said today that President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear attack may never be technically feasible, but that it would be strategically ''dangerous'' if it was ever made workable.  Other scientists defended the concept. **********Dr. Wolfgang Panofsky of Stanford University, who was invited to dine at the White House with Mr. Reagan Wednesday night but declined, said he found the President's request that scientists join in an intensive effort to build a workable defensive shield against ballistic missiles to be ''somewhat spiritually troubling.'' **********The President made his request in a speech later Wednesday night.  Dr. Panofsky and a number of other figures in American science said they doubted that scientists could be marshaled into an effort resembling the Manhattan Project that produced the first nuclear weapon in World War II. **********In his speech, Mr. Reagan said he was seeking a ''vision of hope'' that nuclear weapons could be made ''impotent'' by the development of a practical defensive shield. Aides said the President was not betting on any single technology but wanted intensified research both in space-based stations harboring directed-energy weapons that might shoot down missiles and land-based antimissile systems. The President said it might require decades to achieve workable systems. Called 'Extremely Dangerous' **********Dr. Victor Weisskopf of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, one of the scientists who did meet with the President Wednesday night at the White House, said he believed the President's goal would be ''extremely dangerous and destabilizing.'' **********A number of other scientists and nonscientists took the same view.  In contrast to President Reagan's argument that a nuclear warfare defensive system would make for a safer world, these critics argued that any success in developing antimissile defenses would undermine deterrence of nuclear war, lead to a stepped-up arms race and eventually to pre-emptive warfare in space to destroy the proposed defensive platforms there. **********Several of the scientists also expressed the view that present ''support'' or ''benign'' military uses of space that enhance United States military security would be endangered by moves to place weapons and countermeasure devices in space. Such support applications now include the use of satellites for sensor stations to warn of hostile missile launches, highly detailed reconnaisance and surveillance of the Soviet Union and the rest of the world, and a complex network of communications. **********Critics also asserted that the President's plan would endanger the prospects for nuclear arms control agreements with the Soviet Union by undermining the 1972 treaty limiting antiballistic missile defenses and accelerating a race to achieve a workable complex of such defenses. 'Pie in the Sky' **********Jeremy Stone, director of the Federation of American Scientists, said ''the ABM treaty is not only the most important treaty we have, but it is the foundation for future treaties on offensive weapons.'' **********He added: ''If either side thought the other was going to withdraw from the ABM treaty there would be no way at all to get agreement on offensive arms treaties; each side would have to reserve the right to build whatever weapons it needed to penetrate the defense.'' **********As Secretary of Defense in the 1960's, Robert S. McNamara championed the view that it was against the national security interests of both the United States and the Soviet Union to seek a nuclear warfare defense. In a broadcast this morning he called Mr.  Reagan's proposal ''pie in the sky.'' **********Dr. Edward Teller, who led the effort to develop thermonuclear weapons, is one scientist who has urged a program much like that discussed by the President Wednesday night. Dr. Teller is close to Mr. Reagan's science adviser, George Keyworth. Continuing Research Backed **********Even the critical scientists said they approved of past and continuing research and development efforts to explore ballistic missile defense and space-based military applications so as to prevent ''technological surprise'' by the Soviet Union. **********''But,'' said Dr. Weisskopf, ''I can't understand why the President put it on the front burner with so much fanfare unless his purpose was political, to sell his military budget to Congress.'' **********''I won't exclude that such a system might work,'' he added, but said it would not be practical for a very long time. He said that if the Soviet Union developed a missile defense first, ''we would be completely defenseless.'' He added, ''Either side would have to shoot down what the other side had in space -it would be the beginning of a nuclear war.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/13/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation reported a deepening first-quarter loss today of $28.8 million, compared with a loss of $24.9 million last year. It said the results primarily reflected difficult circumstances facing its aluminum business during the period. **********Revenues for the quarter were down 15.9 percent, to $644.4 million, from $766.3 million. **********Cornell C. Maier, Kaiser chairman, said, ''There was no actual improvement in prices realized during the quarter.'' He said, ''The cost burden of carrying idled production facilities rose as our average primary operating rate dropped to 37 percent of capacity from 47 percent in the fourth quarter, and we suspended production at a major raw materials plant.'' **********Aluminum shipments for the first quarter were 179,700 tons, compared with 202,000 tons shipped in the first quarter of 1982. In the final quarter of 1982, the company's shipments totaled 221,300 tons. **********Results from diversified activities were mixed in the first three months of 1983, and contributed aggregate earnings similar to those of the 1982 period, the company said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.main_headline: U.S. SAYS TREATY PROPOSAL DOESN'T SEEM TO BE NEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.print_headline: U.S. SAYS TREATY PROPOSAL DOESN'T SEEM TO BE NEW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration said today after studying the Warsaw Pact's call for an East-West nonaggression treaty that, ''at first glance, it does not seem to represent anything new.'' **********The long Soviet bloc statement was under study by State Department, White House and Defense Department experts, some of whom noted that it was yet another in what is expected to be a year of conciliatory statements by the Soviet Union and its allies aimed at heading off the planned deployment of new American missiles in Europe. **********The Administration's formal response, in a statement read by John Hughes, the State Department spokesman, avoided an outright rejection of the proposal, but made clear the American skepticism. It is difficult for Washington to reject outright the idea of the Warsaw Pact and North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreeing on renunciation of use of force because NATO has often stated that it is a defensive alliance and would not be the first to attack. **********Moreover, former President Jimmy Carter revealed in his recent memoirs that he made a similar proposal for an East-West ban on the first use of force when he met with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the former Soviet leader, in Vienna in June 1979. Zbigniew Brzezinski, Mr.  Carter's national security adviser, said Mr. Brezhnev showed interest in the idea, but nothing came of it at that time. Idea First Saw Light in 1955 **********The idea for such nonaggression pacts between the rival blocs was first put forth in 1955 at the summit meeting attended by the leaders of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. Nikolai V. Bulganin, the Soviet Prime Minister, proposed it as a step toward dissolving both alliances. It was rejected by the Western allies as a ploy to weaken NATO and separate West Germany from the West. **********Mr. Hughes, addressing the Warsaw Pact proposal, observed that as President Reagan said at his news conference on Wednesday night, ''We will consider this proposal in consultation with our allies.'' **********''Peace with justice must always be this nation's highest priority,'' he said. ''We are, and will continue to be, receptive to ideas which would genuinely promote peace and peaceful settlements of disputes. Our discussions with our allies will consider whether this is such a proposal.'' **********Mr. Hughes said that, at the Bonn summit talks last year, the NATO leaders pledged that none of their weapons would ever be used except ''in response to aggression.'' **********''Indeed, the principle of nonagression is a key provision of the United Nations Charter,'' he said. 'We Will Look at It' **********''At first glance, it does not seem to represent anything new,'' Mr. Hughes said of the Warsaw Pact plan, ''but as the President said, we will look at it.'' **********He added: ''We learned from bitter experience between the two world wars that simple declarations of peaceful intent are not enough. What we need are concrete results, which not only reduce the danger of war, but which contribute to an atmosphere of increased trust. To this end, the proposals we have made in the Geneva and Vienna negotiations on both nuclear and conventional forces are designed to achieve genuine, substantial cuts in the arsenals of both sides, as well as measures to enhance mutual confidence.'' **********While the Reagan Administration seemed unenthusiastic about the Warsaw Pact statement, the candidate for Chancellor of West Germany's main opposition party was much more positive. **********Hans-Jochen Vogel, of the Social Democratic Party, in Washington for talks with Mr. Reagan on Friday and Secretary of State George P.  Shultz today, told reporters that the nonaggression proposal was ''in the direction I agree with.'' **********''I have positive feelings, but I have to go into the details,'' Mr. Vogel said. ''Use of military force should be abandoned in all directions.'' Missiles Are Crucial Issue **********The Social Democrats, who were ousted from power last year, are trying to regain control of the Bonn Government in elections set for March 6. Mr. Vogel's assessment was consistent with his party's general willingness to look upon conciliatory Soviet statements more favorably than the Reagan Administration does.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.main_headline: THIRSTY SOVIET'S GRAND DESIGN: TAP ARCTIC WATERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.print_headline: THIRSTY SOVIET'S GRAND DESIGN: TAP ARCTIC WATERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.body_text: **********Muddy and swollen with melting snow, the Vologda River takes a sharp bend under the high cupolas and ancient walls of the city whose name it shares, then straightens out for the 24-mile run to the Sukhona River. **********The Sukhona gathers strength as it meanders eastward through the sparsely settled swamps, forests, fields and timeless log settlements of the Russian north, and empties into the broad Northern Dvina. **********The Dvina rolls on north through the taiga and tundra to Arkhangelsk, where it yields its fresh waters to the Arctic Ocean.  It is a geographic pattern repeated across the breadth of the Soviet Union. Such is the tilt of the land that more than four-fifths of the country's 4,300 cubic kilometers of river water flow north into the Arctic - and away from the more southerly heartland, where three-quarters of the Soviet population lives and four-fifths of its industrial and agricultural production is situated. And it is here, in the prototypical Russian landscape of endless fields, slow rivers, ornate cabins and white birches, that Soviet planners have decided to start correcting what has been referred to as nature's ''mistake'' by channeling some of the waters from the unproductive north to the sunny, fertile south. **********Two Decades of Planning **********It is an idea that has intrigued Russian engineers for more than a century, and one on which at least 60 technical institutes have been hard at work for the last two decades. The project - actually two projects, one for each side of the Ural Mountains - is as enticingly simple as it is staggering in scope. If realized, it would rank as one of the boldest manipulations of nature ever attempted. **********On the European side of the Urals, the plan calls for ''throwing'' waters from several major northern rivers across the watershed near Vologda and into the south-flowing Volga River through an array of dams, pumping stations, reservoirs, lakes and canals. **********The Siberian project calls for nothing less than a canal some 1,500 miles long - the distance from New York to New Orleans - to channel water from the Irtysh River, a tribuary of the Ob, south to the parched plains of the republics of Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. **********The colossal projects have provoked about as rancorous and public a debate as the Soviet Union has ever known or tolerated. The heated polemics have spilled from the closed rooms of technical institutes and party caucuses and into public halls, the national press, unofficial tracts and the streets. Northerners Resist Plan **********Russians from the economically depressed north have assailed what they see as a crippling blow to the cradle of their culture.  Leaders of the Central Asian republics and the European south have lobbied extraordinarily hard for what they consider their fair share of the country's water, arguing that with it they could become the breadbasket of the Soviet Union while without it they will be unable to sustain a teeming population expected to double by the end of the century. **********Environmentalists have raised the alarm that toying with nature on so monumental a scale will have consequences that no scientist can predict -the Arctic Ocean may ice over, climates will change all across the Soviet Union and Europe, large areas will turn to swamp and others may dry up. **********Economists and scientists have been divided. Proponents speak enthusiastically of each cubic kilometer of diverted water providing 500 million rubles, or about $700 million, in new revenues and 50,000 jobs, of millions of acres of fertile lands brought into production, of saving the shrinking Caspian and Aral seas, of guaranteeing sufficient water for navigation and hydroelectric plants along the Volga. Opponents have accused the others of succumbing to the classic Soviet addiction to gigantism, and they have produced their own figures to argue that the cost of so enormous a project - economic and environmental - will outstrip any conceivable gain. The Go-Ahead Is Given **********Successive party conclaves cautiously authorized more studies and plans - until last May. Then, buried in the Communist Party's Food Program, a long-term agricultural plan, came the almost incidental directive ''to realize by 1990 the construction necessary for the first stage of the diversion of part of the flow of northern rivers to the Volga River basin.'' It was, in effect, the first concrete directive to begin work on the project. **********According to officials and engineers in Vologda, actual work on the dams, canals and pumping stations has yet to begin, and they said it was unlikely the resources would be made available until the next five-year plan starting in 1986. **********But in an interview published recently in the trade union newspaper Trud, Nikolai S. Grishchenko, head of the institute for research and development of the river diversion project, declared that the experts were no longer divided. ''Their conclusions,'' he said, ''are quite definite - the diversion of the flow of northern and Siberian rivers is possible and essential.'' **********Mr. Grishchenko insisted that the impact on the environment and on historical sites would be minimal, but he conceded that some price would be paid. ''First of all,'' he said, ''however we may wish this, we are powerless to stop scientific-technical progress just because it leads to certain changes in the natural balance.'' Lands Sacred to Russians **********Although the first stage envisioned in the food program is a relative drop in the total plan, it is here in northern Russia that resistance to the project has taken some of its strongest and most emotional forms. To Russians, especially those of a nationalist bent, these are sacred lands. It is here, along the endless waterways of the north, that Russian culture took root in the great monasteries whose whitewashed walls still tower over many a lake and stream, and in the towns of fanciful wooden houses still surmounted by innumerable onion domes of former churches. **********Russian artists and writers still flock here to commune with the surviving spirit of ancient Russia, and not surprisingly the most impassioned opponents of the diversions have included writers of rural Russia. Huge Cost an Obstacle **********Many critics have found little comfort in the assurances of experts that historial monuments such as the 14th-century Kirillov Belozersk monastery, whose tall walls rise from the banks of Lake Siverskoye, or the churches of Kargopol, or such local peculiarities as the translucent snetka fish of Lake Beloye will not suffer from the changed water levels. An engineer working on the project said even his own mother had berated him for making designs on Russia's rivers. **********Despite Mr. Grishchenko's assurances that the debate is over, the arguments are certain to continue. For the present, most analysts believe the staggering cost, more than arguments about cultural legacy or environmental consequences, will delay a final commitment to the project. Though estimated costs have not been published, students of the project believe that the initial stages alone would cost around $40 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/19/busin.body_text: **********GAF Shows 58.7% Drop The GAF Corporation, which **********has been trying to sell its two **********remaining principal businesses, roofing and chemical, **********reported a 58.7 percent drop in **********third-quarter net income, to **********$6.9 million, or 43 cents a share. **********from $16.7 million, or $1.12 a **********share, a year ago. **********Sales were **********$183.5 million, up slightly from **********$179.2 million a year earlier. The company said that a 7.5 **********percent improvement in the results of its chemical operations **********and a slight rise in building materials profits improved the **********company's operating profits **********for the quarter. But, $600,000 of **********expenses associated with the **********company's proxy contest **********against a real estate developer, **********Samuel J. Heyman, were **********charged against the quarter. In June, a Federal judge ordered a new vote in the GAF **********proxy contest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/15/world.body_text: **********The death toll in a weekend landslide at Phupan in the Himalayan foothills has risen to 84, a Government spokesman said today. The landslide hit the village, about 150 miles north of Islamabad, early Saturday morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Prime Computer Inc. said it expected to report that net income for the first quarter fell about 20 percent from a year earlier, although it expected to post higher sales. In the 1982 quarter, Prime earned $10.6 million on revenues of $103.2 million. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Prime plunged $7, to $34, on volume of 2,090,000 shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/31/busin.body_text: **********The stock market ended one of its best years in history yesterday with minor price changes in less active trading. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the day, fell 1.52 points, to 1,258.64. In the overall market, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that declined by 959 to 676. **********For the entire year, the Dow average, which is made up of 30 major companies, soared 212 points, or 20.3 percent. Volume on the exchange climbed to 21.6 billion shares, eclipsing the former high of 16.5 billion posted in 1982. **********Analysts attributed the market's performance this year mostly to the stronger-than-expected recovery and the decline in interest rates in the first half of the year. As a result, by June 16, the Dow average had set 23 new closing highs. **********When rates seemed to stabilize in midyear and then appeared to be moving up, some of the secondary issues came under pressure. One of the hardest-hit groups were the high- technology issues, the early leaders in the bull market that began on Aug. 12, 1982. Many of the technology equities had become overpriced, vulnerable to the least bit of bad news. **********Contributing factors for the market's lackluster performance in the later months of this year were apprehension over the huge Federal budget deficit and the deteriorating situation in the Middle East. **********Despite these concerns, the Dow average of blue-chip stocks still managed to close at a record 1,287.20 on Nov. 29, although many of the secondary issues declined. Since then, equity prices have been mostly easing as year-end tax selling became another negative factor. **********The two other major equity markets also enjoyed a successful year. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index rose 52.7 points, a gain of 31.7 percent, while, in the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index climbed 46.2 points, or 19.9 percent. **********Looking ahead to next year, most analysts expect stock prices to continue to advance, but not by as much as in 1983. **********Turnover on the exchange yesterday contracted to 71.8 million shares, from 86.6 million Thursday, as many investors began the holiday weekend early. For the week, turnover fell to 307.9 million shares, from 436 million the week before, while the Dow average rose 8.13 points. There were only four trading days because of the Christmas holiday on Monday. **********The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common equities rose 0.15, to 95.18, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up 0.07, to 164.93. **********The market shrugged off the cut yesterday in the broker loan rate by Bankers Trust, to 11 percent, from 11 1/2 percent, and the news of a rise in farm prices for December. **********Getty and Chris-Craft Rise **********Getty Oil, which was heavily traded, rose 5/8, to 98 1/8. On Wednesday the issue soared 19 5/8 points after Pennzoil offered to buy 20 percent of Getty's stock at $100 a share. Pennzoil closed unchanged yesterday at 34. **********Chris-Craft was up 3 5/8, to 30 1/8, following the news Thursday that it planned to acquire more than 25 percent of Warner Communications and Warner will acquire a 42.5 percent interest in Chris-Craft's television unit. Warner advanced 1 1/8, to 26 7/8. **********Federal Paper Board, which rose 2 5/8 points on Thursday, rose 1, to 45 3/4. There was no corporate news to account for the rise. **********Some of the railroad issues made impressive gains. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.body_text: **********IF you have a spare million, you can still buy a few minutes on the 1984 Olympic Games. ABC has $32 million worth of time, or 2 percent of its 4,859 30-second spots, looking for an advertiser. **********That is not bad for broadcasts that are six months away (or, in the case of the summer Olympics, nearly a year) and are charging $260,000 for a 30-second spot in prime time. That compares with $180,000 for 30 seconds on ABC's ratings hit ''Dynasty.'' **********''We're very pleased,'' said John T. Lazarus, the 42-year-old vice president of sports marketing and sales at the ABC Television Network. ''If there were a timetable, we're way ahead.'' **********Altogether, ABC, which paid $315 million for the rights to broadcast the two Olympic Games, expects to raise $625 million in advertising. It still has to pay for producing the Games, A.T.& T. line charges and, of course, agency commissions, but ''somewhere, there will be a nice, fair profit for us,'' the understated Mr. Lazarus said. **********Mr. Lazarus, who has been a media supervisor at both Grey Advertising and Foote, Cone & Belding, joined ABC in 1970 as an account executive for network sports sales. He has been with the network ever since, except for a year out as director of broadcasting for Bowie Kuhn, the baseball commissioner. **********In terms of advertising, the Olympic Games have the longest lead time of any television programming. In 1981, ABC set a price of $215,000 for 30 seconds, for advertisers who got in on the ground floor. Since then, there have been two price increases, ''a combination of supply and demand,'' Mr. Lazarus said. **********At the start, the ABC people drew up a list of potential advertisers who would want to be associated with the Olympics and who would pay accordingly. ''In prime time and daytime, the world is your oyster, but in sports, it's confined to certain kinds of advertisers,'' said Mr. Lazarus's boss, Jake Keever, who is in charge of all advertising sales. ''So you go down the line and come up with a selling plan: how much for beer, how much for soft drinks, and so on.'' For the first time, computer manufacturers made the list. **********Coca-Cola took over the entire soft- drink category, for $42 million. Anheuser-Busch and Miller divided the $40 million beer category, while Sears and K Mart split retailing. For the winter Olympics, the sole car maker will be Chevrolet; for summer, General Motors will share the category with Datsun. **********What role, if any, advertisers will play in the 1988 summer Olympics in South Korea remains to be seen. The Koreans and the Olympic committee are rumored to be putting together a package priced at $750 million to $1 billion. That is not strictly comparable to the $225 million Los Angeles price tag since it would include a number of additional revenue sources, such as sponsors' licenses to use the Olympics logotype. **********Still, the notion of a $1 billion Olympics has led some people to speculate that Los Angeles might be the last summer Olympics on advertiser-supported free television. (The 1988 winter Olympic Games from Calgary, Alberta, are expected to be handled traditionally.) ''It isn't reasonable to think that a network could spend that kind of money and make a profit,'' Mr. Lazarus said. Furthermore, Seoul's distance from the United States will mean a 24-hour broadcast delay, conceivably reducing viewer interest. **********One solution could be a joint venture between a network and a cable channel, such as ABC and ESPN, the man from ABC said. Each would show exclusive and original programming, but such major attractions as women's gymnastics, say, would be reserved for ESPN subscribers. ''It's still the Olympic Games, and it's only every four years,'' Mr. Lazarus said. ''We'll be in there fighting harder than anyone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that El Salvador's human rights record met the legal requirements for continued foreign aid, but that its record ''falls short of the broad and sustained progress'' sought by Congress and the Reagan Administration. **********Under the law, aid to El Salvador can be appropriated only if the Administration certifies every six months that progress is being made in various areas of human rights. **********In his introduction to the State Department's recertification report issued today, Mr. Shultz gave an unenthusiastic endorsement.  He said he was ''particularly concerned'' by the Salvadoran failure ''to achieve more positive results in establishing discipline over the security forces and in assuring that those, military or civilian, who commit gross violations of human rights will be brought to justice and held accountable under the law.'' **********''An especially compelling aspect of this concern for me as Secretary of State,'' he said, ''is the slow progress made thus far by the Salvadoran authorities in bringing the murderers of United States citizens to justice.'' Remains Opposed to Cutting Aid **********Although he described human rights progress as ''disturbingly slow,'' Mr. Shultz made it clear that he nevertheless was opposed to cutting aid. **********''The evolution of democracy is a long and difficult process,'' he said, ''especially when there are concerted efforts to defeat it.'' ''Our disappointment over the pace of change should not obscure the fact that change is occurring,'' he said. ''The people of El Salvador deserve our support in their effort to achieve a truly democratic society, which will provide the best and most lasting safeguard of human rights.'' **********The report said the number of civilian deaths reported in the press and attributed to political violence rose from 160 a month on the average in the last six months of 1982 to 177 a month in the first six months of this year. This compares to more than 300 a month in late 1981 and early 1982. There were about 39 civilian ''disappearances'' a month in the past year, it said. 'Without Fear of Official Reprisal' **********The report also said the Salvadoran armed forces were being ''more sensitive'' to the treatment of civilians and of prisoners. But it said the Government was still not able to control fully the actions of the security and armed forces. And it has failed, it said, to create a program ''to identify and punish those responsible for abuses that still take place.'' **********''As a result, those elements of the society which operate outside the legal and stated policy restrictions of the Government, including some members of the security forces, generally act without fear of official reprisal,'' the report said. **********Several human rights groups have criticized the Administration for continuing to assert that enough progress had been made in human rights to warrant continued aid. **********The Council on Hemispheric Affairs said this afternoon that the latest certification report ''proves, once again, that no governmenttolerated abuses, no matter how grisly, will sway the United States Government from its goal of military victory in El Salvador.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.main_headline: U.S. ASKS ISRAEL TO TAKE PRO-NAZI TIED TO ANTI-JEWISH RIOTS IN 1941
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.print_headline: U.S. ASKS ISRAEL TO TAKE PRO-NAZI TIED TO ANTI-JEWISH RIOTS IN 1941
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/28/world.body_text: **********The Justice Department has asked Israel to accept a former Nazi sympathizer who has been ordered deported from the United States because he incited anti-Jewish riots in Rumania in World War II. **********American officials have been looking for a country willing to take the man, Valerian Trifa, a Rumanian Orthodox Archbishop, since a Federal court stripped him of his naturalized American citizenship in September 1980. **********Switzerland, Italy and West Germany have refused, according to Neal M. Sher, acting director of the Justice Department's Office of Special Investigations, who arrived in Israel today. Rumania has not indicated its position, he said. ''We've been in contact with a lot of different countries,'' he explained. ''We are working very, very hard to try to find a place.'' **********Israeli Says U.S. Asked **********Mr. Sher declined to say whether Israel had been approached, but Yitzhak Feinberg, the spokesman for Israel's Justice Ministry, said the request had been made and that Israeli officials would meet with Mr. Sher to discuss this and other cases in the next few days. **********(In Washington, John Russell, a Justice Department spokesman, said that Mr. Sher was in Israel for a variety of reasons, one of which was to ask the Israelis to take Archbishop Trifa.) **********The Israelis will make a decision, Mr. Feinberg explained, only after examining the evidence to see if Archbishop Trifa could be tried here, as was Adolf Eichmann, Hitler's chief of operations, in 1961. The Hitler aide was kidnapped by Israeli intelligence agents in Argentina and brought by force to Israel, where he was executed. **********''It would be foolish to bring over somebody knowing you have no case against him,'' Mr. Feinberg added.  An Israeli involved in gathering evidence against former Nazis said that the Justice Ministry's initial decision, now being reconsidered, was to reject the American request. Mr. Feinberg denied the report.  ''When they turned to Israel,'' he said, ''we didn't say no. We can't say no to something like this. And we started to look into the matter.'' **********American law has no provision for prosecuting former Nazis unless they committed crimes against the United States or against American citizens. Therefore, since the Office of Special Investigations was set up in 1979 to hunt down former Nazis who had taken refuge in the United States, it has sought to show that the individuals made false declarations - hiding their Nazi past -when entering the United States. **********This has served as a basis for stripping them of their naturalized citizenship. A subsequent step has been to seek deportation orders against them. More than 200 individuals are being investigated. **********Consequently, if Israel agrees to receive the deported Archbishop Trifa, the case could be only the first in a long series.  Efraim Zuroff, a researcher here for the Justice Department, said the next one is likely to be Ivan John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian who has been stripped of his citizenship for having operated the gas chamber at the Treblinka death camp. Now living in Cleveland, he is due to receive a court ruling soon on his deportation. **********Archbishop Trifa, now in his late 60's, is the spiritual leader of 35,000 members of the Rumanian Orthodox Episcopate, based in Grass Lake, Mich. **********The Government produced evidence that in 1941, when he was active in an anti-Semitic Bucharest organization called the Iron Guard, he wrote inflammatory newspaper articles and gave speeches that incited pogroms. Corpses of Jews were hung in a slaughterhouse and labeled, ''kosher meat,'' according to Mr. Zuroff, although there has been no finding that Archbishop Trifa killed anyone himself. Membership Concealed **********The Government showed that when he entered the United States in 1950, he concealed his membership in the Iron Guard and said that he had been confined in Nazi concentration camps. In fact, the Government maintained, he had lived in Nazi Germany in comfortable housing. **********Although he fought the denaturalization proceedings in a protracted court battle, he dropped his resistance to deportation last October and asked Switzerland to accept him. When the Swiss Government refused, he and American officials appealed to Italy, where he had reportedly lived after the war.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA JAILS BLACK OVER A BANNED BOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA JAILS BLACK OVER A BANNED BOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/08/world.body_text: **********A prominent black journalist recently drew an unusually heavy prison sentence of two and a half years for possession of a single banned book. The sentence was a result of plea bargaining that suddenly cut short the trial of nine people charged with being underground activists of the outlawed Pan Africanist Congress. **********The journalist, Joe Thloloe, a former reporter whose newspaper career had been suspended by a Government ''banning'' order that made it a crime for him to write for publication, had originally faced far more serious charges of conspiracy to commit terrorism and furthering the aims of an illegal organization. **********Of the eight people charged with him, seven had reportedly given the police statements after being held without charge for interrogation. One, a former exile, had pleaded guilty to being sent back into the country by the Pan Africanist Congress to help lay the groundwork for acts of sabotage. **********The trial was regarded as having unusual significance, for it was the first in several years involving the activities of the Pan Africanist Congress, a rival as a movement of resistance to white rule of the more prominent African National Congress. The Pan Africanist Congress had almost slipped from view in South Africa during a period in which its exile organization was reportedly plagued by dissension. **********The 40-year-old Mr. Thloloe, who was honored for his reporting by Harvard University's Nieman Foundation two years ago, had ties with the movement before its banning in 1960. In that year, as a youth of only 17, he was arrested and charged with the Pan Africanist Congress's founder and leader, the late Robert Sobukwe, in a protest march against the law the requires blacks to carry special passes, or ''reference books,'' when they are in supposedly ''white'' areas. **********The terrorism charges, which he denied, said a small machine gun had been found hidden in the roof of his home in the black township of Soweto at the time of his arrest last June. **********But the elaborate machinery of prosecution stalled when the first witness, Sipho Ntshingane, indicated he was prepared to testify that he had been tortured by the security police until he agreed to put his name to a false statement. **********In a highly unusual verdict scarcely two weeks before Mr.  Ntshingane indicated his readiness to defy the police, a magistrate in a suburb called Kempton Park acquitted four blacks on terrorism charges on the ground that state witnesses had been assaulted or otherwise intimidated to give evidence against them. **********In an effort to avoid further embarrassment to the police in the Thloloe case, the prosecution agreed to drop charges against five of the accused, including Harrison Nogqekele, the man who had originally pleaded guilty, if the remaining four would plead guilty to the lesser charge of possessing banned books. Normally that charge is considered relatively minor and results in either a suspended sentence or fine, but on April 20 Magistrate Theo Kleinhans gave Mr.  Thloloe the two-and-a-half-year sentence for possession of a single Pan Africanist Congress publication, ''The New Road.'' **********Two others, Sipho Mzolo and Nhlanganiso Sibanda, got three years because they had more than one publication; a fourth man, Sipho Ngcobo, also got two and a half years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Barclays Bank Appoints Chief for North America
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.body_text: **********Barclays Bank International, which has expanded rapidly in the United States in the last decade, has named a new chief executive officer for North America. **********He is Brian G. Pearse, 50, who succeeds A. Richard P. Carden, 44, who had held the post for five years.  Mr. Carden has returned to London to become a director and a general manager of Barclays Bank International, which is a subsidiary of Barclays Bank P.L.C. He will be responsible for operations in the Far East. **********Mr. Pearse, who will be based in New York, will oversee the bank's operations in the United States. They comprise some $12 billion of the parent company's $85 billion in assets. Assets in the United States have doubled in the last few years. **********Mr. Pearse has been a general manager and a director of Barclays Bank U.K. and responsible for retail banking in Britain.  Barclays first entered New York banking in 1925 and began its retail operation in 1965. Although it has expanded quickly in the United States, backed by the financial clout of its British parent, its profits have not matched those of the British operation. The company has said, however, that its investment in the United States would prove itself in the long term. **********The North American operations include Barclays Bank of New York, Barclays Bank of California, Barclays Bank of Canada and a finance company, the BarclaysAmerican Corporation. **********Mr. Pearse joined Barclays in 1969 when Martins Bank, where he was employed, merged with Barclays. He is also a director of Barclays Bank International, which runs the bank's operations in some 80 countries.
