https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/19/busin.body_text: **********AMERICAN business is engaged in a major organizational transformation. This transformation is an effort to accommodate the instability and uncertainty that has marked the economic environment of the last 10 years. **********It represents the abandonment of a strategy of mass production of standardized products for stable, mass markets in favor of more flexible and adaptable systems of production and marketing. This in turn requires a reorientation in our thinking about national economic policy. It is too early to assess the full implications of this change in business strategy, but some things are already clear. **********First, the pressures producing these changes are not inevitable or irreversible. The business environment of the earlier postwar period was produced by an institutional structure designed to stabilize the domestic economy and insure its expansion. The instability of recent years is largely attributable to the increasing internationalization of markets and the absence of institutions capable of stabilizing the world economy. **********Through the debt crisis of the major developing countries, the United States has now acquired the leverage to impose the requisite stability on the international ecomomic order. But we have used that leverage to thwart the development of stabilizing institutions. **********We have opposed measures that would stabilize commodity markets, restore fixed exchange rates and promote international expansion, insisting instead on policies of restraint and contraction. We have thus favored an environment in which American business organization as now constituted is least able to compete and, in this way, we have forced the reorientation of organization and productive technology now under way. **********Second, protectionism will not remove the pressures generating these changes. The problem is that United States markets are too small, too unstable and growing too slowly to sustain existing organizational and technological structures. More trade, not less, would thus be required to make those structures viable. **********To the extent that protectionism is incomplete, moreover, it is likely to increase the advantage of competitors like Japan, whose technology and organization already have the flexibility that our businesses are seeking to introduce. On the other hand, given the reorientation now under way, protection is unlikely to have the dire consequences for our standard of living that its opponents foresee. As the structural changes are completed, our industry will be increasingly less dependent for productivity gains on economies of scale that only large international markets can sustain. **********Third, given the direction in which we are moving, ''industrial policy'' in the form of a Federal effort to provide direction to national economic development does not make sense either. Such a policy would be meaningful as part of an effort to restore the dynamic of mass production through a new international economic order and to negotiate the United States position within it. **********Without this effort, what is required is a social policy to ease the transition away from mass production to the emergent alternative. The inherent flexibility and adaptability of this alternative obviates the need for the kind of national planning that the concept of industrial policy implies. **********What is required for the success of the emergent economic alternative is the reassertion of the legitimacy of much more conventional forms of communal activity and governmental action. The new structures appear to require institutional supports modeled on traditional structures now under attack: the public educational system, land grant colleges, the agricultural extension service, Social Security, the national railroad and highway programs, and the protections the Federal Government has provided in the past for trade union organization. **********The policy of the Reagan Administration is one reason to be concerned about such communal institutions. But a more profound reason for concern is the incentive structure inherent in the emergent forms of organization and technology compared to that inherent in the old. Two aspects of those incentives are important. **********First, in mass production, both equipment and labor skills are highly specialized to a particular make and model and production occurs in large, integrated organizations. This enables the organization to capture the returns to investments in training, research and development and the provision of much of the overhead capital. Since the business concern reaps the return, it is generally willing to make the investments. **********In flexible forms of production, labor and equipment are more general, organizational units are smaller, and both labor and technology circulate more freely among different enterprises. The private incentive to provide training and research is thus much weaker and these things must be provided by the community if they are to be provided at all. **********Second, communal institutions are required to channel competition. Competitive pressure is much greater in the new economic environment than it was in the old. The pressure will lead to growth only if business responds through innovations in the product and in the production process. Such innovation, moreover, requires a close collaboration between labor and management and between contractors and subcontractors. The importance of collaboration is underscored by Japan, which provides the model for the organizational reforms under way. **********But the competitive pressures are such that unless limited by communal institutions like trade unions and social regulations, they sooner or later force business to cut wages to labor and payments to subcontractors. Competition through exploitation then becomes an alternative to genuine innovation and destroys the collaborative relationship required for such innovation to occur. The kind of market pressure that public policy is now seeking to promote will thus prove destructive of economic progress in the long run. Leonard Silk is on vacation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.main_headline: TRADERS CONFUSED BY THE FED'S MOVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.print_headline: TRADERS CONFUSED BY THE FED'S MOVES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.body_text: **********In recent years, investors and Wall Street firms have tried a full range of tactics - from hiring former Federal Reserve Board economists to conducting their own surveys of bank deposits - in an attempt to divine the future course of interest rates. **********But all the brain power that securities dealers and investors can muster does not enable them to consistently predict changes in Federal Reserve monetary policy or the weekly money supply data that help determine the Fed's policy. **********Last week was a good example of how imperfect is the knowledge of economists and traders. Early in the week, a drop in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market to 9 1/8 percent, plus predictions of a large decline in money supply, was enough for some analysts to conclude that the Fed was easing monetary policy. As a result, the 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013 rose to as high as 104 19/32, to yield 11.43 percent. **********By late Friday, however, the Fed had dashed hopes of an easing by temporarily draining reserves from the banking system on Thursday and then announcing a much smaller than expected $200 million decline in the basic money supply. By the end of the week, the 12 percent Treasury bond was offered at 102 14/32, to yield 11.69 percent.   Markets 'Overreacting' **********''While the Fed has been trying to steer a steady course,'' said Victor Change, director of marketing and research at Ehrlich-Bober Government Securities Inc., ''the markets have been overreacting in both directions.'' While last week's speculation centered on the possibility that the Fed was easing, as recently as late July and early August there had been widespread concern that the Fed might tighten policy and send overnight interest rates above 10 percent in an effort to reduce money supply growth. **********Mr. Change described last week's euphoria about a Fed easing as ''a bubble based on unrealistic expectations about how fast the Fed would change policy.'' **********Imperfect Guide **********The fluctuations in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market - to 9.17 percent Aug. 25 from 9.85 percent Aug. 15 - should remind investors that trading in the Federal funds market is not a perfect guide to the central bank's monetary policy. Because Federal funds are traded in a market where borrowers and lenders are influenced by expectations of future rate changes, the rate on any particular day may not be the same as the rate that will eventually emerge from the Fed's policy. **********''The weekly Federal funds rate will probably trade a bit under 9 1/2 percent when fears of Fed tightening subside and slightly above 9 1/2 percent when concerns over Fed tightening reappear,'' David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, said in an Aug. 29 newsletter. For the near future, Mr. Jones said he expects the Fed to hold policy stable while it waits for more data about money supply growth and the economy. **********Attitudes Slower to Change **********While traders focus on the short- term outlook, investor attitudes do not change so rapidly. Since early August, there has been heavy buying of Treasury bonds at yields ranging from 12 1/8 percent to 11 3/4 percent, and analysts say that many buyers are still optimistic that yields will go lower. So long as the economy does not seem likely to overheat and rekindle inflation, the primary roadblock to lower interest rates is the Federal budget deficit and huge Treasury borrowings. **********Already many analysts are anticipating the late September sales of 4- ,7- and 20-year Treasury issues totaling $14 billion or more. If the auctions come after a few weeks of rapid money supply growth, they worry about a sharp increase in interest rates to the levels of early August or higher. **********Among those analysts who expect interest rates to come down, Michael Bazdarich, a vice president at Claremont Economic Institute, estimated that yields on Treasury bonds could drop to 10.8 percent by early October and as low as 9 percent during this business cycle. ''A slowdown in the recovery with no surge of inflation still point to lower yields,'' he said. **********But, Mr. Bazdarich said, the decline in yields have been slow to come ''because investors need evidence that their fears are not as bad as the reality.'' The Claremont economist acknowledged fears about excessive money supply growth in September ''could make for a dead market for the next few weeks or so.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.main_headline: 4 Senators See Reagan At Mideast Crossroads
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.print_headline: 4 Senators See Reagan At Mideast Crossroads
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.body_text: **********Four senators said today that President Reagan's Middle East policy had reached a crossroads, but expressed doubt Congress would order United States Marines out of Lebanon. **********The four senators, in various television interviews, expressed concern that Mr. Reagan had not clearly or adequately defined the purpose of the American troops committed to peacekeeping duty and the consequences of recent United States casualties. **********Questions have also been raised about whether the Marines' assignment falls under the limits of the 1973 War Powers Resolution. **********''The last thing America wants is to get embroiled in their civil war,'' said Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas. **********Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said, ''What we need to do is decide what is our policy going to be in the Middle East and what role, if any, will the American military have to play and how will that relate to other countries and to the total risk.'' **********Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said: ''I think it's obvious the situation requires the application of the War Powers Act. There is no question that there are hostilities.'' **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, disputed the need to invoke the war powers measure on the ground the United States position is ''clearly defensive,'' but agreed the issue is debatable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.main_headline: BEATING THE QUOTA ON SUGAR IMPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.print_headline: BEATING THE QUOTA ON SUGAR IMPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Ice cream and candy companies do it. Small bottlers do it. Even the bakers and ketchup makers do it. With prices for sugar in the United States three times as high as the world price, industrial users are finding ingenious ways around domestic sugar quotas - one example of how protectionist fences erected by the Government are sometimes circumvented. **********In this instance, the trick is blending. Only imports of pure sugar, defined as 100 percent sucrose, are governed by quotas, which were reimposed by President Reagan last May to reinforce a domestic structure of higher prices. But if the sugar enters as 94 percent sucrose and 6 percent fructose, or 90 percent sucrose and 10 percent dextrose - blends making up much of the imports from Canada - it is just another sweetener, as far as Customs is concerned, and there is no limit to the amount that can enter the United States. **********Many American companies are taking advantage of that fact. They are using the Canadian connection to bring in liquid and dry blends from such refiners as Atlantic Sugar Ltd. of Saint John, New Brunswick; Red Path Sugars Ltd. of Toronto, and West Cane Ltd. of Oshawa, Ontario. Buffalo and Detroit are the main points of entry. **********The growing traffic in blended sugar to avoid the import restrictions is eliciting complaints from American sugar producers who want the White House to shore up the sagging quota system.  Canada, on the other hand, defends the sugar blend traffic. **********What makes it worthwhile for sugar users to go to the trouble of ordering special blends is the difference in prices between domestic sugar and imported sugar. The domestic support price for raw sugar is 21 cents a pound, compared with less than 7 cents a pound for the world price. Quotas had last been in effect in 1974 when they were dismantled during a world shortage that sent prices much higher. **********There are no limits to the imagination of the operators who have explored this loophole. The sucrose has been mixed with honey, chocolate, corn syrup and even fresh maple syrup. **********The importer pays a small tariff of 2.4 percent, and suddenly he has a product in the United States that is considerably cheaper than, and nearly equivalent to, the sugar he would otherwise have to buy from an American refiner. **********Market specialists said the blends were being offered in this country for a nickel to a dime a pound less than comparable sugar from American refiners, who have to process the high-priced domestic raw sugar. 'Windfall' Profits **********Not only are there savings for American users but there are also big ''windfall'' profits for the Canadian refiners. Canada has no quotas and minuscule tariffs on imported sugar. **********Latest import numbers show that in February, nearly as much blended sugar came into the United States as in all of 1982. The February total of 9,206 metric tons compared with 6,562 tons in January and only 10,300 tons in all of 1982. In January 1982 the total was 5 tons. Most came in from Canada. Very small but increasing amounts were also coming from Mexico, trade officials said. A metric ton is about 2,204 pounds. **********The numbers are still relatively small compared with the 2.9 million tons that enter under quota, and with total American consumption of about 10 million tons. **********But the sharp rise in imports is causing alarm in the councils of domestic growers and refiners. ''If we don't put a stop to this, it will mushroom,'' said Nicholas A. Kominus, president of the United States Cane Sugar Refiners' Association. ''It is having an adverse effect on the whole sugar trade.'' 'Trade Barriers' Opposed **********Not surprisingly, Canadian officials are quietly lobbying to keep the gates open. ''We don't want any more trade barriers,'' one Canadian representative said. **********''It's really an example of the complexities involved in trying to manage a market as diverse and slippery as the U.S. sweetener market,'' said Thomas C. Earley, vice president of Schnittker Associates, a consulting firm of agricultural economists based in Washington. **********President Reagan is being asked by the domestic industry to close the loophole by ordering quotas on the blended sugar on top of the quotas on the raw sugar. **********The White House announced Monday that the President was reviewing quotas governing imports of sugar from Central America, and some officials expect that the issue of blended sugar will be taken up as well in this review. **********Agriculture Department officials said they had begun an investigation of the blended sugar question but had not yet made a recommendation to the President. **********Many analysts, however, expect that the department will ask the President to take emergency action under Section 22 of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1933, which authorizes the President to mandate relief against anything seen as undermining domestic price supports. **********The United States International Trade Commission is already gearing for action. The 1933 statute requires that it make a recommendation to the President. But the law empowers the President to take immediate, emergency action without waiting for a commission recommendation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.main_headline: FOR A SOVIET ENVOY AND SON, 'WHAT A WEEK' FINALLY ENDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.print_headline: FOR A SOVIET ENVOY AND SON, 'WHAT A WEEK' FINALLY ENDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.body_text: **********After the Berezhkovs arrived in Moscow, the Government issued a protest over the incident. Page 3. **********PARIS, Aug. 19 - ''Let's relax,'' Valentin M. Berezhkov said, to no one in particular. ''What a week.'' **********The Soviet diplomat loosened his tie, rolled up his sleeves and sighed. After asking a flight attendant for a drink - ''a Beefeater martini'' - he turned to a neighbor and said, ''We deserve a good drink.'' **********It was all over now, or so he said as the sky darkened and Trans World Airlines' Flight 890 made its way from Washington to Paris, the first leg of the Berezhkov family's return to Moscow. Mr. Berezhkov, who has just finished a five-year tour as a First Secretary at the Soviet Embassy in Washington, was sitting in the 12th row. Beside him was his 16- year-old son, Andrei, who eight days ago disppeared with the family car, touching off an international incident over the issue of whether this was an attempt to defect.  Andrei, with his mother, Valeriya, and a Soviet official sitting behind him, smoked cigarette after cigarette. He sipped soft drinks, twirled his hair between his fingers, adjusted his stereo headset. **********''It will be good to get away,'' Andrei's father said. ''There has been too much publicity, too much for a lifetime. It will be quiet now. Life will be normal.'' **********'I'm a Russian Kid' **********According to an account provided by the Soviet Embassy, Andrei, who had been visiting his parents in Washington for the summer, returned home with the car in less than a day. Hours later a handwritten letter that began, ''I'm a Russian kid,'' was delivered to The New York Times. It contained a plea for help to remain in the United States and was signed ''Andy Berzhkov.'' **********The father said his son had not written the letter, which went on, ''I hate my country and it's rules and I love your country.'' The whole thing, Mr. Berezhkov said, was some terrible mistake. His son would be ''all right,'' the family would endure. **********But Mr. Berezhkov was determined to set something to rest - the reports in the American press that there had been trouble between him and his son. ''There is no conflict between us,'' he said to the members of the press aboard the flight, who numbered fewer than 10. ''There is no generation gap. Certainly I was always very busy - writing, traveling and working hard. Sometimes I would not see him for a month. But we were always close.'' **********''I think now we're even closer,'' he continued, running his fingers through his white hair. ''This was a great experience for him, for us, for everybody. In general, I am sorry for the fact that many of our friends have spent so much time on this instead of on so many problems that really exist in the world. As if there was nothing more important than this silly thing.''  'E.T.' and the Rolling Stones **********As the hours passed, the son wearied of his headphones and began to talk, speaking of tennis and soccer, of Loretta Lynn and science fiction, of television, Home Box Office and friends. He talked about ''E.T.,'' a movie he said he had seen four times, and about the Rolling Stones, whom he heard in concert in Landover, Md., and about going home to Moscow and learning to be an actor. **********''It has always been my dream,'' he said. ''I like many professions, and only an actor can be in many professions. They play all different professions.'' **********He said he had been in a movie, a documentary of sorts, a film about ''trade between our country and some American millionaire.'' He played the millionaire's grandson. **********''I'm tired,'' he said later. ''It's so strange. I'm only a child. It's been too much.'' **********Just as the family was settling into its seats, a passenger slipped a note into Mr. Berezhkov's pocket. Midway through the flight, he unfolded it. ''We wish you well,'' an acquaintance had written. ''We will see you in the Soviet Union.'' **********Mr. Berezhkov smiled. He said he would go back to the Institute of the United States and Canada, the Soviet research and consulting center, where he had worked before. Perhaps, he said, he will even visit the United States again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/world.print_headline: U.N. URGED TO HELP ARRANGE ETHIOPIA TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/world.body_text: **********Fourteen religious and lay leaders in the United States have asked the Secretary General of the United Nations to help arrange a cease-fire in Ethiopia so relief supplies can reach famine- stricken areas. **********The appeal was made in a letter that the 14 sent yesterday to the Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. The signatories included Bishop James Armstrong, President of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the United States, and Lawrence Pezzullo, executive director of Catholic Relief Services, the major American assistance agency working in Ethiopia since 1974. **********The letter is the latest effort by the organizations to draw attention to the deteriorating situation in Ethiopia created by the drought, famine and war. These organizations say the most serious drought conditions are in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, where combat between anti- Government guerrillas and Ethiopian troops impedes the distribution of foodstuffs and medicines. **********An estimated 7 million Ethiopians are threatened by the famine and war, according to Bread for the World, the citizens group that initiated the appeal to the Secretary General and has been lobbying in Congress for increased American aid.   Pressing for Aid Increase **********The religious groups and private American aid agencies have been pressing the Reagan Administration to increase aid since December, when field workers and United Nations agencies warned that conditions were deteriorating rapidly and could develop into a widespread famine. **********Initially, the Administration was reluctant to involve itself further because the Ethiopian Government has close ties to the Soviet Union and continues to buy Soviet arms to try to put down the nationalist movements in the north. The United States was helping Ethiopian refugees who had fled to Somalia and the Sudan and was conducting a feeding program for 138,000 women and children in Ethiopia. **********The Administration reassessed its position in June and decided to provide an additional $3 million for aid. In August the Agency for International Development authorized another $6.7 million for humanitarian assistance. Some of that money will be used for transportation; an airlift to reach remote areas in mountainous Tigre Province is under discussion. Fighting Impedes Distribution **********A number of United Nations agencies are trying to improve the distribution of relief supplies but report the fighting has impeded their efforts. United Nations authorities say they have no official contacts with insurgent groups, which causes questions about any cease-fire initiative from the Secretary General. Efforts have been made through intermediaries to improve the distribution of relief. **********These 12 people also signed the letter: Rev. Warren Magnuson, general secretary of the Baptist General Conference, Dr. Avery D. Post, president of the United Church of Christ, The Rev. David Stow, executive vice president of the United Church of Christ Board for World Ministries, Dr. Foy Valentine, executive director of the Christian Life Commission of the Southern Baptist Convention, Norman Barth, director of Lutheran World Relief, Dr. Robert C. Campbell, general secretary of the American Baptist Church in the United States, Bishop Frank Reid, president of the Council of Bishops, African Methodist Episcopal Church, The Rev. James E. Andrews and William Thompson, interim co-stated clerks of the General Assembly, Presbyterian Church of the United States, The Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, director of the office of International Justice and Peace, United States Catholic Conference, Bishop Reuben L. Speaks, chairman of the Board of Overseas Missions, African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, Bishop C. Dale White, bishop of the New Jersey area of the United Methodist Church.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.main_headline: KEY PROMOTION IS EXPECTED AT ABC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.print_headline: KEY PROMOTION IS EXPECTED AT ABC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.body_text: **********Frederick S. Pierce, executive vice president of the American Broadcasting Companies, is to be appointed president of the corporation on Monday, senior executives said last night. **********The appointment would put the 49-year-old Mr. Pierce in line to eventually succeed Leonard Goldenson as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Goldenson, 77, founded ABC and is the company's largest stockholder. **********Just as William S. Paley has been closely identified with CBS, so has Mr. Goldenson been the most visible executive at ABC since its formation in 1953. While Mr. Paley has announced his retirement effective in April, Mr. Goldenson is expected to participate in ABC management for the foreseeable future. **********Mr. Pierce would succeed Elton H. Rule, who has been the corporate president and chief operating officer since 1972. Mr. Rule, 65, is expected to be appointed vice chairman of the board, the officials said. **********Mr. Pierce's current job is not expected to be filled at this time. ''It was created for him as a holding position,'' said one top ABC official who declined to be identified. **********For a long time, Mr. Pierce, the youngest of ABC's three top executives, has been expected to step into the presidency as the final move before succeeding Mr. Goldenson. He has been executive vice president since April 1979 and has worked at ABC since 1956, his entire career. **********Mr. Pierce first came to the attention of Mr. Goldenson in the 1960's, when he was a junior executive in ABC's advertising sales department. Mr. Goldenson would phone him every day at 4 P.M. to ask how much advertising had been sold during the previous 24 hours. It was Mr. Goldenson's way of charting the network's fortunes, a ritual akin to box-office tallies in the film business. **********After that initial contact, Mr. Pierce moved up rapidly, holding 13 jobs in 18 years, until he arrived at the presidency of ABC television in 1974. **********Although he worked with little publicity, he was instrumental in ABC's rise to first place in the prime time ratings in 1976, after years in third place. Analysts said he did this largely by bringing action series, such as ''Baretta'' and ''S.W.A.T.,'' to the network.  He also hired Fred Silverman as president of ABC Entertainment in 1975, luring him away from CBS, where he had been a highly successful programming chief, a role he repeated at ABC. **********ABC Television lost its top ranking to CBS during the 1979-1980 season. Changes Were Expected **********The top-echelon shifts, which must be approved by ABC directors at their meeting on Monday, have long been expected. One strong indication came in July 1981, when Mr. Pierce relinquished the ABC Television presidency and assumed a greater corporate role. **********Mr. Goldenson made the line of succession clear at the annual meeting of the ABC affiliated stations last May. ''He indicated very strongly that Fred Pierce was the heir-apparent to the top corporate responsibilities,'' said a senior ABC official, who declined to be identified. **********Neither Mr. Pierce nor Mr. Rule would comment on the reports of Mr. Pierce's impending appointment.  In the past few years, Mr. Pierce, who was trained as an accountant, has been responsible for the corporation's expansion into new video technologies, such as developing cable programming in news, the arts and daytime talk and information shows. His manner is described as direct but reserved. Under a four-year contract signed in 1981, Mr. Pierce earns about $900,000 a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.main_headline: COMPUTER STOCKS: LIFE AFTER THE PCJR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; COMPUTER STOCKS: LIFE AFTER THE PCJR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.body_text: **********FOR investors in personal computer stocks, **********Oct. 18 is now referred to as ''Black Tuesday.'' That was the day when I.B.M. announced two powerful new microcomputers - one that could be linked to I.B.M. mainframes, and another with a multiple-function screen. Oct. 18 was also the day that mighty Digital Equipment stock dropped $21 a share, because of all the money it was losing in personal computers. **********That double-barreled blast sent stocks of other personal computer companies tumbling, even though they already had been on the skids since early summer. More than that, the events of Oct. 18 epitomized investor concern about the intense competition in the industry, I.B.M.'s juggernaut presence and the inevitable shakeout that is already in its nascent stages. **********Indeed, few stock groups have performed as poorly over the past six months as the dozen or so publicly owned companies that primarily build computers in the $1,000 to $5,000 price range. Even the best and the brightest of the personal computer industry are suffering. **********Apple Computer, for instance, is down from $63.25 a share to less than $20. Convergent Technologies is up from its low, but at $25 is still $15 off its high for the year. And the stocks of half a dozen concerns that went public within the last year are now at or near their bottoms. They include Altos Computer, Fortune Systems, Victor Technologies, TeleVideo and Eagle Computer. **********Most investors are still too jumpy to do any bargain hunting in the personal computer minefield. But several Wall Street analysts say they are getting a clearer picture of where some companies went wrong and which ones are doing the right things to insure that they will be around tomorrow. Peter Wright, director of research for the Gartner Group in Stamford, Conn., said he was impressed with Apple's new business strategy, as well as by the big line-up of orders that Convergent Technologies has to build microcomputers for Burroughs, N.C.R. and a number of other computer giants to sell under their labels. **********Other analysts, such as David Lawrence of Montgomery Securities, San Francisco, favor TeleVideo because as a low-cost producer it could survive price wars that may well break out a year or so from now. In addition, at the upcoming Comdex computer exposition in Las Vegas next week, Mr. Lawrence expects TeleVideo to introduce two new products that are ''perfectly'' compatible with I.B.M. software. **********To be sure, the market for personal business computers is huge and growing fast. By the end of 1988, it will be a $24 billion-a-year market in the United States, compared with the $6 billion of business personal computers that will be sold this year, according to William Ablondi, vice president of Future Computing, a research firm in Richardson, Tex. **********The trouble is that such growth has attracted most of the established office-equipment manufacturers as well as a host of newcomers. At latest count, more than 150 companies were producing personal computers for the business market. **********I.B.M., despite entering the field in late 1981, is already generating almost one-third of the industry's revenues. And some analysts expect that it will continue to gain market share. **********There is little doubt that the wayside will be littered with fallen companies. ''The P.C. business is an exploding growth market, but the whole vendor side of it is imploding,'' said Mr. Wright. **********Peter Labe of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company estimates that the business can support only up to five ''mainline'' players, of which I.B.M. is already one. Only a relative handful will survive and prosper, Mr. Labe believes, because in the corporate environment, I.B.M. already has the dominant presence and the decision-makers are not likely to consider more than a few alternatives. Similarly, he noted, ''at the retail level, only a limited number of lines can be inventoried and sold knowledgeably.'' MANY of the personal computer companies have gotten in trouble because they either tried to grow too fast or their market strategy was off-target. Digital Equipment, say analysts, has stumbled because of overly ambitious plans to tap business customers beyond its traditional base. Apple, they say, relied too much on the strength of its name to reach users. **********Victor Technologies, on the other hand, spent too much building up its own direct-sales marketing force, when it should have been wooing dealers to sell its products. (Last week Victor reported a $37 million third-quarter loss.) And Fortune Systems has learned the hard way that a company should not promise software for its computers if it cannot deliver on time. **********Some P.C. companies, however, are not showing much in the way of earnings because they are plowing everything into building a stronger base for the future. Eagle Computer, said Gregory Kelsey, senior technology analyst with Hambrecht & Quist, San Francisco, is ''spending a lot of money for research and development and marketing rather than maximizing quarterly earnings.'' In addition to Eagle's range of I.B.M.-compatible products, Mr. Kelsey is impressed by the company's emphasis on lining up big distribution chains such as Businessland on the West Coast to carry its products. He is not recommending Eagle or any of the other P.C. stocks until he sees further developments, including what is revealed at the upcoming Comdex show. **********Apple Computer is also now on the right track, according to some analysts. Although the company's earnings will be depressed over the next two quarters by heavy research and development and marketing outlays, James McCamant, co-editor of the California Technology Stock Letter, a San Francisco advisory newsletter, said he was ''recommending aggressive purchase.'' **********Mr. McCamant also considers Apple's planned introduction of its McIntosh computer in January to be the industry's ''next new exciting product.'' Expected to retail for $2,500 to $3,000, it will be compatible with I.B.M.'s P.C., plus it will have its own software and it will offer all the ease-of-use features pioneered by Apple's Lisa model, he said. Mr. Lawrence of Montgomery, however, remains negative. on Apple. He sees the ''real possibility'' that it will lose money in the next quarter and that sales of the McIntosh, which he considers critical to Apple's future, will be disappointing. **********Until the dust settles, of course, investors may be reluctant to go back into Apple or one of the hot new issues that they have been burned on. **********But a true test of whether their appetite is sated for new offerings should come up in a few weeks. That is when Compaq, the thus-far successful maker of I.B.M.-compatible portable computers, will go public. The deal is slated to raise at least $90 million. And last week, its underwriters, L. F. Rothschild and E. F. Hutton were priming the market with road-show meetings between management and potential investors. **********Fred R. Bleakley writes on finance from New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Sharp price cutting and a subpar crop of 1983 grapes have eased a worrisome oversupply for many California wine producers, but here on a pastoral Mendocino County hillside, a more appealing problem persists for the Fetzer Vineyards. **********Fetzer is straining to keep up with demand. **********''We ran out of a lot of wine this year,'' John E. Fetzer, the winery's 36-year-old president, said, more with a touch of guilt than surprise. ''We're trying to get the new wine into bottles and start selling again.'' **********Shipments Up 18.5% **********The winery's shipments are up 18.5 percent this year, while the California wine industry over all is having a much tougher time, with analysts projecting a disappointing 4 percent gain over the flat level of 1982. **********The state's wine inventories swelled with a record grape crop in 1982 as sales flattened during the recession. Moreover, the strong dollar made European labels more affordable for Americans. **********Fetzer is riding high in part because of a widening reputation, one it shares with other midsized wineries such as Chateau St. Jean, Sonoma Vineyards, Beaulieu and Ridge, for palate-pleasing yet inexpensive premium table wines. Fetzer's two most popular wines are Sundail chardonnay at $6.50 a bottle and Lake County cabernet at $4.99 a bottle. **********Growing Loyalty **********Robert Berning, wine buyer for Trader Joe's Inc., the biggest specialty retailer for wine in southern California, said more of Trader Joe's ''intellectually affluent, budget-conscious'' customers are growing loyal to the Fetzer label. **********''We'll do about 50 cases a week in Fetzer, compared with 15 for Paul Masson,'' he said. ''They are really on top of what's happening.'' **********The Seagram Company owns Paul Masson, and together with the Wine Spectrum, which it acquired last month, is the second-largest wine marketer in California. Paul Masson is a big seller in supermarkets, where Fetzer is rarely found, along with labels from E.& J. Gallo, the industry leader, which expects to ship 62.4 million cases this year. **********Fetzer has been unusually aggressive, unconventional and disciplined for a winery its size, according to Ed Everett, a wine wholesaler and importer who also edits a newsletter, The Wine Trade. **********''They have a reputation for being very buttoned-down,'' Mr. Everett said. ''Given the youth of these kids, it's amazing to see how professional they are.'' **********The winery, situated about 120 miles north of San Francisco, has grown at about 20 percent a year for eight years, Mr. Fetzer said. Marvin Shanken, an industry analyst and publisher of Market Watch, a wine trade magazine, expects Fetzer to top $34 million in sales this year and he anticipates another 20 percent jump in 1984, to 560,000 cases. Fetzer does not disclose sales and profits. **********Fetzer now ranks No. 25 among California's 600 wineries, a surprisingly rapid ascent for a family-run company that got into the business 15 years ago. Forty percent of Fetzer's sales are to restaurants, which helps its premium image. This year, half of its sales are coming from outside California, compared with an average of about 30 percent for California wineries, according to Mr. Fetzer. **********Growing Northeast Market **********''The Northeast is our big thrust for next year, New York especially,'' he added. That is a tall order. European imports have grabbed a bigger share of the East Coast wine business with extraordinarly low prices. Nationally, shipments of imported wine are up 7 percent. **********The Fetzer family has bucked the industry pattern by creating its own sales force. This bypasses the single- broker channel favored by most small wineries, and keeps Fetzer in closer touch with retailers than many of the state's major wineries, Mr. Berning said. **********They regularly install advanced wine-making machinery, scouted out in Europe by James Fetzer, 32 years old, the wine-making operations manager, to cut labor costs and increase output. **********Distinctive Operations **********Fetzer was one of the first wineries to segregate the crush of red and white wines into separate wine-making equipment, which the Fetzers believe improves the clarity of the bouquet.  The winery buys about three- fourths of its grapes from other vineyards, a ratio meant to keep its land costs and interest costs in check. **********Fetzer is also among a handful of wineries that identify wines not only by the grape but also by the vineyard. It has five zinfandels, for instance, and three chardonnays. ''The consumer looking for something more distinctive gets attracted to these wines,'' said Paul Gillette, publisher of the Wine Investor. **********Still, the proliferation of wines under its Fetzer and Bel Arbres labels - the total is 25 - gives Fetzer a problem in vying for retailer shelf space. **********The Fetzers blend their wines for a sweeter taste than most wineries, ''because although people talk dry, they drink sweet,'' James Fetzer said. **********He put a wine glass to a tap at the side of tall, steel storage tank in one of the winery's cavernous warehouses, a tank filled with chilled gew "urztraminer, and drew a sample for a visitor. Gew"urztraminer is a semisweet grape, native to the Alsace region of West Germany. **********Marketing Problems **********The Fetzer clan got into the winery business in 1968, after the mail-order grapes they sold from their 230-acre ranch here drew rave reviews. **********The family patriarch, a regional executive for the Masonite Corporation named Bernard Fetzer, was a stickler for frugality and hard work. Analysts said he had a good grasp of production, but like most smaller wineries, lacked a feel for marketing. **********Mr. Fetzer died, from a heart attack, in 1981. John Fetzer has put much more effort into marketing since then, Mr. Gillette said. **********''It was one of those situations where the father imposed his will,'' he said. ''John had his own ideas and now he's really moving to execute. It's a sound, really well-run operation.'' John Fetzer, however, said he is merely following through on his father's original concept. **********The wine business has brought failure to many small vineyards and wineries that have misjudged its high costs for labor, machinery and and wine barrels for aging, according to George Vare, an industry analyst in San Francisco. **********The Fetzers say they overcame the odds by stressing reinvestment in new machinery and capacity, limiting their own grape harvest and by holding back on personal luxuries - aside from the Mercedes cars that some members of the family drive, James Fetzer said. **********''We can afford the costs of the bu siness and still keep our prices low because we put profits back into expansion without taking much out for ourselves,'' he added. ''This is really a first generation business and we want to see it grow.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/05/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON ALVIN M. MARKS and Mortimer Marks, New Yorkers who for years have provided equipment for the three-dimensional display of motion pictures, are patenting a new projector attachment. The invention is described as approximately doubling the output light, creating a larger, brighter picture for the best three-dimensional effects. **********Patent 4,372,656 will be granted next week for the attachment, which is still in the research stage. Rights will be held by the Marks Polarized Corporation, in Whitestone, Queens, which the brothers control. **********In 1974, apparatus to convert standard projectors to display three-dimensional movies was patented for Marks Polarized and trademarked the Polarator. The company has also provided theaters with 3-D viewing devices including glasses intended for one-time use by members of the audience. **********The Polarator has been used successfully with a number of motion pictures. According to Alvin Marks, the picture entitled ''Friday the 13th -Part III'' has grossed more than $50 million, and he expects that other productions filmed with the converter will be even more successful. **********The new invention is described as providing a high-efficiency polarized light source, adaptable to standard motion picture projectors. The projected beam is compressed closer to the rectangular shape of the aperture, so that less light is lost. The company also manufactures and distributes optical components for the aerospace industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/world.main_headline: SHULTZ IS IN SYRIA TO PRESS PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/world.print_headline: SHULTZ IS IN SYRIA TO PRESS PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz has apparently made little headway in his effort to find a formula for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. **********Mr. Shultz flew here today for a meeting Wednesday with President Hafez al-Assad after receiving a modest endorsement of his efforts from Saudi Arabia this morning and a gentle prod from Lebanon later to get Israel to move ahead with its agreement to withdraw from Lebanon. **********Mr. Shultz, in his public comments, struck an upbeat note about his meetings with Saudi and Lebanese leaders and spoke favorably about the prospects for talks with Syria on ''mutual interests that go beyond'' the issue of Syrian withdrawal from Lebanon. **********But senior American officials traveling with Mr. Shultz said that they saw little prospect of breaking the impasse over the withdrawal of foreign forces from Lebanon. They suggested that barring some unexpected concession from Mr. Assad, Mr. Shultz would return to Washington on Friday with a fairly bleak assessment of the situation. **********Syria has refused to discuss withdrawal with Lebanon the way Israel did this year. Mr. Shultz was an intermediary in the Lebanese-Israeli talks, which led to a security agreement between the two nations and a commitment by Israel to pull its forces out of Lebanon if Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization did also. Talks in Saudi Arabia **********Early today, Mr. Shultz met in Saudi Arabia with King Fahd. Mr.  Shultz later described the talks, which took place from midnight to 2 A.M., as ''worthwhile and constructive.'' He said, ''It was gratifying to see with King Fahd that we continue to share the objectives of the removal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.'' **********The United States has sought Saudi help in trying to bring Syria to the bargaining table. In brief remarks at the Jidda airport before Mr. Shultz left, the Saudi Foreign Minister, Saud al-Faisal, said that his nation ''has cooperated in the past and will cooperate in the future'' in efforts to help Lebanon achieve ''its independence and territorial integrity.'' **********But as he had done when Mr. Shultz arrived on Monday, Prince Saud pointedly mentioned an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon as an important step in the peace process but did not talk about a Syrian withdrawal. **********Asked why he had singled out Israel, Prince Saud said: ''We don't equate the two forces. The Israel forces are occupying forces.'' The comment was consistent with previous Saudi statements that reflect the view among Arab nations that Syrian forces in Lebanon were invited in by the Lebanese Government to restore order and should not be treated the same in withdrawal talks as Israeli troops.  'Engaged' but Unenthusiastic **********Mr. Shultz, speaking to reporters on the flight from Saudi Arabia to Lebanon, described the Saudis as ''fully engaged'' in the effort to achieve a withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. But officials traveling with Mr. Shultz said the Saudis were less than enthusiastic participants. **********Specifically, they said, the Saudis object privately to the Israeli-Lebanese security agreement because it contains elements of official recognition of Israel and calls for trade and other commercial ties between Israel and Lebanon. **********The Saudis, however, according to the American officials, do want to see the restoration of an independent Lebanon and are willing, up to a point, to press Syria to get out. **********Mr. Shultz landed in Beirut amid tight security provided in part by United States marines in the multinational force there. During his four-hour visit, Mr. Shultz met with Lebanese leaders, including President Amin Gemayel and Foreign Minister Elie Salem. **********A senior Lebanese official who briefed reporters while the meetings were in progress indicated that Lebanon was growing impatient about carrying out the agreement with Israel, which was signed in May. **********''We'd like to hear from the United States on proper measures to have the agreement implemented,'' the official said. He added, ''We have no doubt about U.S. intentions or objectives, but we'd like to see the measures and a clear strategy.'' 'For Total Withdrawal' **********The official said Lebanon did not want Israel to withdraw just part of its forces on its own unless such a step was the first stage of a full withdrawal. The Reagan Administration has considered setting a schedule for a step-by-step Israeli withdrawal in the hope that this would increase the pressure on Syria to withdraw as well. **********The official said, ''Sentimentally, we are for any withdrawal, but we are for total withdrawal.'' After the official talks, Mr. Salem, while praising the United States for its help on the withdrawal issue, said he hoped Mr.  Shultz's visit might produce ''speedier results.'' **********Mr. Shultz, discussing the possible form of Syrian withdrawal talks, said on the flight to Beirut that such negotiations would probably involve direct talks between Syria and Lebanon without the United States serving as an intermediary. **********He said that any Syrian-Lebanese talks would not require changes in the agreement between Israel and Lebanon. ''We don't have any intention to go back and urge anyone to renegotiate the agreement,'' he said. **********Asked whether the Reagan Administration was prepared to offer Syria aid or other inducements to negotiate, Mr. Shultz said: ''The Syrians have said publicly that they look forward to more of a dialogue with the U.S. I want to see that too.'' **********But Mr. Shultz, who looked weary by the end of the day, added, ''I don't have a basket of things to offer or anything of that kind.'' Mr. Shultz is scheduled to meet with President Assad and Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam on Wednesday morning. He will then fly to Israel, the last scheduled stop on his Mideast trip.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.main_headline: CAPITOL HILL OUTCRY SOFTENS AS PUBLIC'S SUPPORT SWELLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.print_headline: CAPITOL HILL OUTCRY SOFTENS AS PUBLIC'S SUPPORT SWELLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.body_text: **********A week after the invasion of Grenada, most members of Congress have either sided with President Reagan or muted their criticism, according to Democrats and Republicans here. **********''There's no question the President is on a high with Grenada,'' Senator Charles C. McC. Mathias, Republican of Maryland, said. ''We're looking at the benefits now in the short run but the problems that will flow from it are some ways down the pike.'' **********The House Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., and individual senators, including Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the Connecticut Republican, have sharply criticized the President for resorting to what Mr. O'Neill called ''gunboat diplomacy'' in Grenada. **********A few others have raised questions about an intelligence failure in properly estimating Cuban strength on the island, about the accidental military bombing of a civilian hospital, about what some termed ''the press blackout,'' and negative reactions in Western Europe and at the United Nations.   Wave of Patriotic Pride **********But many lawmakers seem to sense a public wave of patriotic pride over the Grenada operation, and have responded to it. **********''The move is popular and therefore there's no disposition in the Senate to be opposed to it,'' said Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, one of a handful of outspoken critics. ''This is a success and people don't want to hear about mistakes that were made,'' said a Senate Republican leadership aide, requesting anonymity. **********Last week some in Congress began to question the legality of the action or whether Americans in Grenada were actually in danger before the invasion. But some officials say that faded after pictures were published of returning students kissing American soil and after Administration claims that American forces had uncovered warehouses of Soviet-supplied arms. **********Nonetheless, the Senate voted 60-to- 24 last Friday and the House voted 403- to-23 on Tuesday to impose a 60-day deadline on involvement of American troops in Grenada. Now many members describe those votes not as opposition to President Reagan's action but assertions of Congressional prerogatives and pressure on the Administration not to make an open-ended commitment of forces.   Withdrawal Is an Issue **********''People wanted to go on record as wanting to get American troops out,'' said Senator Mathias. ''They want to keep the sword of Damocles over the President's head so that if there were any temptation to stay, that idea would be nipped in the bud.'' **********As President Reagan suggested to reporters this morning, the Administration hopes to defuse that issue now that the fighting has ended, by getting American troops out of Grenada by the end of this month. **********A successful military operation, many legislators agree, has put President Reagan more confidently on the offensive and less ready to brook criticism. This morning he seemed visibly irked at any comparison between the American invasion of Grenada and the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. ''Well, for heaven's sake,'' he retorted heatedly, ''anyone who would link Afghanistan to this operation. . .'' His anger trailed off. **********In Congress, some Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders anticipate more favorable attitudes toward Administration positions on Central American policy generally if the Grenadian operation is quickly concluded.   Nicaragua Issue Shelved **********For example, Senate opponents of covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels decided in the current climate not to make a fight against that program on the Senate floor. Even on Lebanon the Administration got new backing Wednesday from a lopsided majority in the House that defeated an effort to cut off funds for the Marine Corps presence next March 1. **********Members of the President's commission on Central America assert that new evidence of heavy Cuban involvement in Grenada may cause the commission to make bolder proposals on security and military aid to Central American countries than they would have otherwise done. **********Over the longer run, some politicians warn that diplomatic problems with Western Europe, Latin America and at the United Nations may cut into the Administration's political and diplomatic gains. **********''The President had a major uplift from Grenada,'' said Robert Strauss, former Democratic national chairman and member of Mr. Reagan's Central American commission. ''He's doing better in this country politically, but worse in Europe,'' he added. ''When you look at the reaction of Canada, Helmut Kohl in Germany, Margaret Thatcher in Britain, we paid a very heavy price.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/busin.body_text: **********uf916 **********Elizabeth E. Bailey is dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration, Carnegie- Mellon University, and former member and vice chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. Leonard Silk is on vacation. **********Economic SceneElizabeth E. Bailey Quantum Leap In Productivity **********AT the White House Productivity Conference, held recently at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, it was stated that the time of introduction of important scientific advances into actual production could be reduced to 12 to 15 months from 12 to 15 years. **********Such a reduction would permit a quantum leap in productivity. Then there would be an outpouring of new products, techniques for reducing costs and raising productivity and a restoration of the United States economy to primacy in the world. The times when this has occurred - in Britain in the mid-19th century and in the United States during World War II - give some hint of what might be achieved. **********The question becomes how to produce such changes. What provides the basis for a dramatically different way of doing things? I believe that the recent deregulation experience can provide three helpful lessons. **********Lesson 1: There must be a consensus that incrementalism will not work, that a large change toward a new economic arrangement must be undertaken. In the regulatory process, well-intentioned people had mapped out airline routes based on the technology of railroads. Carriers were granted linear east-west or north-south route systems. **********But the technology of air transportation is such that economic efficiency leads to sunbursts of hubs-and-spokes rather than linear systems. This is just one example of well-meaning government intervention that induced productivity loss. **********In setting the stage for reform, there had to be a recognition that the heavy hand of government was harming productivity. There also had to be a critical stock of knowledge about unintended perverse effects of regulation. **********Lesson 2: There must be a basis for change within the institutional structure. In the case of deregulation, new ideas were accommodated within the existing political process and within the existing regulatory agencies. **********One method used in the deregulation movement was to appoint as heads of the regulatory commissions persons whose backgrounds were suited to making the called-for changes. Economists were found to preside at both the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Interstate Commerce Commission during the critical reform periods. Such leadership meant not only that reform from within could proceed but also that there was an openness to ideas that would eventually change the nature of the institutions. **********Lesson 3: Major change proceeds more effectively if there is a basis for change in ideas. Advances in applied micro-economics research provided valuable insights to policy makers as well as to professional economists about how to go about deregulating. Take the idea of ''contestable markets.'' **********Traditionally in economics the strength of competition has been perceived to be a function of numbers - the fewer the number of actual competitors, the more the discipline of market forces is diminished. The new theory of ''contestable markets'' finds that where exit and entry are cheap and easy, even an oligopoly company must behave like a competitive one, for it is vulnerable to entry by competitors.  The ease of entry or exit depends not on the absolute costs of capital required for entry but on how much capital must be invested that cannot be easily moved elsewhere. If the requirements for sunk capital are high, new competitors are less likely to enter a market, and this may signal the need for regulatory intervention. **********By contrast, where large capital equipment is mobile or resalable, the new theory tells us that regulation should be unncessary. This theory was readily translated into practice in the airline industry. **********These lessons may be pertinent to the problem of converting science into technology. There appears to be a consensus that incremental improvements in the speed of introducing new technology will not restore American economic primacy. **********Thus Lesson 1 is in place. Lessons 2 and 3 are more difficult. **********The relation between the Government and the companies it regulates is a lot clearer than the relationship between universities and industry. New institutional arrangements, such as joint ventures between the two groups, are only in their formative stages. New management paradigms also appear to be necessary. **********Industry and academe have been more comfortable with analysis of how to move in a measured fashion to nearby techniques rather than with planning for a wholly new technology or a wholly new idea of how to deliver a product. **********We need ideas for how to take a quantum leap. The Japanese are providing a few. The challenge is to search further for solutions that will work within our institutions even as the institutions, in turn, are altered.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.main_headline: OIL LEASING IN A FAMILIAR PITCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.print_headline: OIL LEASING IN A FAMILIAR PITCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.body_text: **********As the slump in energy markets has deepened in the past couple of years, the nation's leading oil companies have reduced spending for exploration and production. But on Wednesday, they are expected to put frugality aside for a day and bid furiously at a Federal auction of oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico. **********The sale, to be held here, will be the first in the Gulf under the Interior Department's accelerated leasing program, which is intended to reduce the nation's reliance on foreign oil by making more acreage available for drilling in Unites States waters. **********Oil industry executives say the auction, focused on the central Gulf, promises to be the most important lease sale in the United States this year and could be the biggest ever in terms of tracts leased. **********''There's a very broad interest in this sale,'' said Philip Oxley, president of the Tenneco Exploration and Production Company, a division of Tenneco Inc. D.G. Garrott, a manager of exploration operations for the Exxon Company U.S.A., agreed that the auction would be ''very significant.'' 'Open-Leasing' Policy **********One reason for the excitement is that the oil companies, through years of drilling, have become intimately familiar with the central Gulf, and feel confident that they know where the good prospects are. The Government's new ''open-leasing'' policy is another reason. **********In the past, bidding at lease sales was limited to a specific number of tracts, typically 75 to 175, selected by Interior Department officials from nominations by the oil companies. But under the new rules, which were first applied at a sale of leases off the Middle Atlantic coast in April, companies can substitute their judgment for the Government's and bid on any unleased tracts in large, designated areas. **********At Wednesday's sale, exploration companies are expected to submit bids on 400 to 500 tracts, industry officials said. According to the Interior Department, the record for the number of tracts leased at an auction is 411, set at a two-day Gulf sale in 1962. **********A total of 7,300 tracts, covering 39.9 million acres off the coast of Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama, will be offered at the sale.  But oilmen said that most of the acreage was in water deeper than they were accustomed to working in and would be too expensive to try to develop now. Strategies Changed **********Nonetheless, the sheer volume of available tracts has changed the procedures and strategies in preparing bids at many companies, industry officials said. In recent months, some companies have formed special committees to evaluate the tracts. Industry officials said the tracts included in Wednesday's sale contained mostly natural gas prospects, but also had a few significant oil deposits. **********The companies are also approaching the sale with a ''now-ornever'' attitude. They believe the most promising tracts will be taken this year. Thus they feel that if they do not act now they will be bidding only for less desirable tracts in the future. **********''This creates a great deal of concern,'' said Tenneco's Mr. Oxley. ''You don't want to overlook things that the other guys see and buy up.'' **********One question is whether the industry slump and apprehension about future oil and gas prices will temper enthusiasm at the sale.  A recent survey of more than a dozen oil companies by Ruddick Research International Inc., a Tulsa, Okla., consulting firm, quoted several executives as saying that current price uncertainties would not affect their bidding because it would take four to seven years to put any of the tracts into production. Other executives, however, said that concern about future prices might prompt them to submit lower bids. 'Golden Years' **********Oil service companies, suffering from depressed conditions in the Gulf this year, are counting on the lease sales to spark a revival in drilling activity for the next several years. **********In the late 1980's, ''I would imagine that the Gulf of Mexico ought to see its golden years,'' said Earl A. Stolz, an oil service analyst at Howard, Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs, a New Orleans brokerage house. **********A sale of leases in the western Gulf in August is also expected to draw significant interest, although not as much as the central Gulf sale on Wednesday. A sale of eastern Gulf leases in November is not expected to attract much bidding because companies have not had much success in that area. **********The Interior Department has also scheduled lease sales this year for acreage in the South Atlantic and off central and northern California. Federal officials also plan to hold sales in 1984 off Alaska and southern California, and in the North Atlantic. **********In all, the Interior Department plans to offer one billion acres for lease over the next five years. By contrast, only 56 million acres have been offered since the Federal leasing program began in 1954. But industry officials said that only a fraction of the total acreage offered would be leased over the next five years, mainly because much of it lies in risky frontier areas or in very deep water. **********At a lease sale, the companies make cash offers for the right to drill on specific tracts. If they find oil or gas, they also pay royalties to the Government. Typically the leases have stipulated that companies must begin drilling within five years or forfeit the lease. To encourage drilling in the very deep or risky areas, the Government will also offer 10-year leasing periods at Wednesday's sale on tracts in 2,800 feet of water or deeper.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.main_headline: Belgian Civil Servants Protest Austerity Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Belgian Civil Servants Protest Austerity Plan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/16/world.body_text: **********Civil servants across Belgium went on strike today to protest a Government austerity plan. The wildcat walkout halted or sharply curtailed services ranging from public transport to weather reports. **********Most foreign airlines rerouted their flights to neighboring countries. Sabena Belgian World Airlines continued to operate but said timetables could not be guaranteed. The only train that was allowed to enter Belgium was a special convoy returning people from the shrine at Lourdes in France. **********Deputy Prime Minister Jean Gol, who is heading the Government in the absence of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, who is recovering from heart surgery, said he did not understand the walkout because the Government had announced it was ready to discuss the proposed austerity measures. **********Hospitals did not seem greatly affected by the two-day workout and the police continued to work but said they would express their dissatisfaction with the proposed plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/18/busin.body_text: **********Investigations into three Canadian trust and loan companies whose $2 billion (Canadian) in assets were seized two weeks ago by the Ontario government have disclosed breaches in lending regulations and inaccurate records, a provincial official said today. **********Using emergency legislation, Ontario took control Jan. 4 of Greymac Trust, Seaway Trust and Crown Trust in what it said was a move to protect the interest of depositors, shareholders and creditors.  Accountants were sent to examine the companies' books. In a related action, Canada's federal Government seized the assets of the Greymac Mortgage Corporation and the Seaway Mortgage Corporation. **********Speaking to the Ontario Legislature today on its return from the Christmas recess, Robert Elgie, the province's Minister for Consumer and Commercial Relations, said that on the day control was taken Crown Trust ''did not appear to be in compliance with certain liquidity, investment and borrowing requirements.'' Without an injection of capital, he said, ''the company could not be considered a viable concern.'' **********The books and records of Seaway and Greymac Trusts, he said, have been found to be ''seriously lacking in accuracy and completeness and are not up to date.'' **********But Mr. Elgie said, ''The preliminary assessment of Seaway Trust and Greymac Trust indicate they are in a more difficult financial position than Crown Trust, but it is too early to say with certainty what might happen to them.'' Plan for Depositors Urged **********Mr. Elgie said he had recommended an arrangement that would allow Crown Trust depositors to withdraw money without restriction; currently they may withdraw only $20,000. Trust and loan companies manage estates and are large residential mortgage lenders, but in recent years they have become increasingly active in commercial property development. **********At the time the three trust companies were temporarily put into the hands of Ontario's Registrar of Trust and Loan Companies, all three were the subject of a government inquiry into their role in financing a series of transactions involving the sale of 11,000 Toronto apartments formerly owned by an international property developer, Cadillac Fairview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; EG&G Founder Argues Views in Nuclear Book
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Bernard J. O'Keefe, chairman of EG&G Inc. and head of the National Association of Manufacturers, calls himself a ''card-carrying member of the military-industrial complex.'' Some of his colleagues in the defense industry were surprised by the recent publication of his book ''Nuclear Hostages,'' which decries the arms race. It urges, among other things, that the United States not deploy Pershing II missiles in Europe. **********Mr. O'Keefe, in a telephone interview yesterday from his Wellesley, Mass., office, conceded that few businessmen are willing to speak out on arms control. ''Not anywhere near enough,'' said Mr. O'Keefe, who is 63. ''But to my surprise, my colleagues have reacted very well. Even those who would lose a lot if we cut the defense budget haven't said anything critical to me.'' **********According to his book, American business links to the Soviet Union and the Government's ability to negotiate arms controls are closely related. **********''Only with economic ties can we learn to live with the Russians,'' Mr. O'Keefe said. ''But we are headed in the wrong direction. First, there was the grain embargo under Carter, and then there was the pipeline embargo under Reagan.'' In recent months, Mr. O'Keefe said, his travels around the country have convinced him that American executives ''are realizing that the biggest deterrent to the Russians is a healthy economy in America.'' **********Mr. O'Keefe said he had waited to write his book until a time when he thought it would have maximum impact. ''Only now do I have credibility as a businessman in addition to my scientific background,'' he said. ''That combination makes me unusual enough so that I am getting attention.'' **********Trained as an engineer, Mr. O'Keefe has been involved with nuclear weapons since they began. In the Navy, he was assigned to the team at Los Alamos, N.M., that designed the detonation system for the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August 1945. Today EG&G, which he helped found in 1947, gets about 40 percent of its revenues and 20 percent of its earnings from defense contracts. **********Next month Mr. O'Keefe's term as chairman of the N.A.M. expires, and in two years he will retire from his company. Until then, he said, he plans to keep writing and to push for the opening of negotations between the United States and the Soviet Union for joint action against the threat of terrorists trying to use nuclear weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/08/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc., citing losses from discontinued operations, reported yesterday that net income for the fourth quarter of 1982 fell 11.9 percent, to $35.7 million, or $1.27 a share, from $40.5 million, or $1.45 a share, a year earlier. **********The company's broadcast, records, publishing and musical instruments divisions all reported declines in profits. The toy division, which last year acquired Ideal Toy, reported higher profits. **********The company attributed the broadcast group's lower profits to ''both a lackluster sales environment and first-year costs'' from investments in expanded television news and sports programming, and in a new radio service. **********Thomas H. Wyman, president, said the company had taken ''painful and, in the short term, costly'' steps to strengthen its broadcasting business and other areas. ''We are now well positioned for an important turnaround in 1983,'' he said. **********R. Joseph Fuchs, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, said, ''CBS is still speculative in terms of the ability of its management to unwind from some areas and control others, such as records, as well as to redeploy its assets into new areas, such as movies.'' **********For the year, net income fell 30.9 percent, to $112.5 million, or $4.01 a share, from $162.8 million, or $5.83 a share, in 1981.  Fourth-quarter revenues rose 8 percent, to $1.22 billion, from $1.13 billion a year earlier. Full-year revenues rose 4 percent, to $4.12 billion, from $3.96 billion. **********For the quarter, income from continuing operations fell 23.2 percent, to $52.5 million, or $1.87 a share, from $68.4 million, or $2.45 a share. The loss on discontinued operations was $16.8 million; this including the disposition of Pacific Stereo, CBS's retail electronics chain, which is to be sold. **********For the full year, income from continuing operations was $150 million, or $5.35 a share, down 25.1 percent from $200.2 million, or $7.17 a share, in 1981. Full-year losses from discontinued operations were $37.5 million, including the termination of CBS Cable.
