https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/busin.body_text: **********SMALL ''niche'' industries often do very well for their stockholders. One example is the funeral-related business, consisting of a handful of publicly owned companies. **********Service Corporation International is the largest funeral service and cemetery operator in North America. In 1980 its shares traded as low as 3 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange. In February the stock sold at a record price of 41 3/4. Yesterday, it rose 1/2 for the day, to 36 3/4, **********The company's rapid earnings growth in recent years, noted Standard & Poor's, has been supported by an aggressive acquisition program. **********Hillenbrand Industries, a leading maker of burial coffins, saw its stock rise on the Big Board from 13 1/8 three years ago to a record high of 47 3/4 last month. Yesterday, it fell 1/2, to 44 1/2. **********Amedco Inc., smaller in size than the other two companies, also supplies products and services for the funeral industry. Last week, Amedco reported 1982 profits of $1.30 a share, up from $1.27 the previous year. Six years ago, the stock sold under $1 a share. It recently hit a record price of 31 3/8 on the American Stock Exchange. Yesterday, Amedco was unchanged at 30. **********Climbing stock prices have produced higher price-earnings ratios than usual for these companies. However, the Value Line Investment Survey still believes that Service Corporation and Hillenbrand will outperform the market over the next 12 months. Value Line does not follow Amedco. **********Two basic considerations have worked in favor of the funeral business. In terms of sheer demographics, the death rate per 1,000 people is projected by the Bureau of the Census to continue increasing for the remainder of this century. Second, the funeral companies have taken various steps, including acquisitions, to improve their profitability. **********For the fiscal year ending April 30, Value Line estimates that Service Corporation will earn $2.15 a share, up from $1.86 the previous year. ''Service Corporation is riding a tidal wave of success,'' said Eliot S. Laurence, an analyst for the investment advisory service. ''Because the funeral service business has high fixed costs, operating profits generally grow faster than volume. We think the company's funeral service business can support at least 10 to 15 percent annual earnings growth by itself.'' **********In addition, Mr. Laurence views the profit potential of the company's ''pre-need sales'' as outstanding. ''A pre-need sale allows the consumer to lock in his funeral service costs at current prices, so that inflation is no longer a worry,'' he said. ''Service Corporation invests the money generated by these sales in long-term investments - through its life insurance subsidiary - and flows the dividend and interest income, after subtracting its indirect selling costs, down to the bottom line.'' **********Hillenbrand earned $3.09 a share in the 1982 calendar year. Value Line estimates profits for this year at $3.05 a share. Coffins - one company trademark for this line is called Omega - generally provide most of the company's earnings. But Hillenbrand is also a major manufacturer of equipment for furnishing hospital patient rooms. Its American Tourister division is an important factor in the luggage manufacturing field. **********Elliot Schlang, a senior vice president with the Cleveland-based brokerage firm of Prescott, Ball & Turben, has been recommending Hillenbrand to clients since March 1981, when the stock was trading at the equivalent price of 18. ''I still regard it as a core holding for growth-oriented accounts,'' he said this week. ''The company has a strong balance sheet and earnings should do very well, thanks to the four-year, $40 million expansion program at its casket division that was funded internally and is now nearing completion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Despite its progress in developing heavy industry, South Korea is still straining to become an industrial nation. **********While its path to prosperity appears the same as Japan's two decades earlier - sending a flood of manufactured goods into foreign markets - the business practices of its East Asian neighbor may hinder its development. **********In any case, in today's world of slower economic growth, increased trade barriers and accelerated technological change, the ascent is expected to be far more difficult for South Korea than it was for Japan. **********''It's been said that the world was fooled once - by Japan,'' said Chung Mong-Joon, president of Hyundai Heavy Industries, a major shipbuilder that is part of Korea's largest industrial group. ''It isn't going to happen again. Climbing up the ladder to become an industrialized nation by exporting manufactured goods will be far more difficult for South Korea.'' **********Economic Reforms **********To overcome the obstacles, the South Korean Government has begun major economic reforms. It is opening up the country's sheltered domestic market to foreigners. It is prodding companies and investors to shift away from export-oriented industries, such as construction, steel and shipbuilding, that have fueled its rapid growth, and toward high-technology industries such as semiconductors, computers and telecommunications. **********And gradually, it is moving away from a centrally controlled economy of five-year plans with funds channeled into strategic industries - a Government-business partnership that has been called Korea Inc., much like Japan Inc. - and toward an economy in which the private sector has greater control. **********''The circumstances have changed, so our industrial strategy must change,'' said Sakong Il, president of the Korea Institute for Industrial Economics and Technology, a Government-backed research organization. ''Before, we had a Government- led development strategy. But now that our economy is becoming more complex, the market is a better mechanism for making decisions. We have to undo some of what we have done in the past.'' **********In the past, however, South Korea's strategy has served it well. Since the early 1960's, when the country was still agrarian, per-capita income of its 40 million people has jumped twentyfold. No. 2 Shipbuilder **********More than Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore - the other so-called ''new Japans'' - South Korea has developed its heavy industry. It is the world's No. 2 shipbuilder, after Japan. Its steel industry is growing rapidly and increasingly competing successfully against Japanese companies. **********The country's young auto industry is projected to triple its output by 1986, to 288,000 vehicles, according to the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. In 1985, Korean-made cars are scheduled to make their debut in the American market. **********To pay for the industrial buildup, South Korea has borrowed heavily. Its foreign debt of $37.4 billion is the highest in Asia. **********To attain the growth necessary to meet its debt, keep unemployment down and maintain a high level of military spending in its face-off with Communist North Korea, South Korea must constantly increase its exports. To grow at 5 or 6 percent a year, economists estimate, export volume will have to expand to $100 billion a year by the early 1990's, up from $21 billion last year. **********To achieve this, analysts say, South Korea must take two key steps. First, it must improve the competitiveness of its goods and, as labor costs rise, move into higher-technology fields to become less dependent on industries where competitiveness depends on cheap labor. Second, it must open its market to foreign goods and services if it hopes to get continued access to markets abroad. Ban Ended on 200 Items **********To open the country's market, The Government last month removed more than 200 items from its list of banned foreign goods. The ratio of goods that can be imported to all those offered is now 80 percent. By 1986, the Government says, it will be more than 90 percent. **********Once an item is removed from the ban, however, it is typically protected with high tariffs. Still, as a Western diplomat said, ''This is certainly a step in the right direction.'' In other respects, too, the Government is relinquishing control over the economy. To increase competition and efficiency in the financial sector, the Government has sold its majority interest in the country's leading commercial banks. **********Last March, South Korea's first joint-venture bank, the Koram Bank, was opened. The Government approved the venture, which includes Bank of America and several Korean investors, because it hopes the American management will modernize Korean banking. Support for High Technology **********Most of the Government supports for heavy industry have been dropped. But Government help for high-technology industries, especially new ventures, will be given. Last month, for example, the Government announced that as many as 500 venture companies in high-technology fields would receive financial and technical assistance. **********With Government encouragement, major Korean corporations are starting to spend heavily to develop semiconductors, computers and telecommunications equipment. Three large companies - Daewoo, Gold Star and Samsung - already make semiconductors, mostly such simple types as diodes and transistors, and some basic integrated circuits. **********Particularly notable among the newcomers is Hyundai, which plans to become a large producer of sophisticated memory chips. **********Few oppose the Government's plans to open up the Korean market and to give the private sector more responsibility for economic development. But there is considerable debate about the pace at which the transition should occur. The Two Views **********The strongest advocates of the new program are a group of Western-educated free-market economists, both inside and outside of government. Asked which businesses should still be considered ''infant'' industries and remain protected, Kim Duk-Choong, a professor of economics at Sogang University, said, ''I don't think you should protect anything. With no protection, the needed process of industrial adjustment is much faster.'' **********On the other side are those who advise slow import liberalization and who are quite reluctant to see a wholesale transfer of economic power from the Government to private companies. **********''I am not in favor of transferring everything to the private sector,'' said Lee Kyung-Hoon, president of the Daewoo Corporation, one of the country's leading industrial groups. ''How can the private sector develop a five-year economic plan? That is the job of the Government.'' **********One of the aims of the Government's economic reforms is to promote small and medium-sized businesses. During the 1970's the stress on heavy industry worked to the advantage of Korea's industrial groups, concentrating economic power in a small number of organizations. The Japanese Competition **********In a few key fields, Korean industrialists believe they have already caught up to Japan. Shipbuilding is one such area, according to Mr. Chung of Hyundai. ''In technology, productivity and price, we are competitive with anyone, including Japan,'' he said. **********Yet precisely because it is following most closely in Japan's footsteps, South Korea is likely to have a difficult time. The West's trade barriers, erected against the Japanese, will also keep out some Korean goods. Furthermore, ''the last country in the world that wants another Japan is Japan,'' said a Western diplomat in Seoul. ''The Japanese will cut off Korea if they can.'' **********One way for Japan to do that is to stop the flow of its technology to South Korea. One test of Japan's position on this issue will involve a planned second steel mill for South Korea, to be built for the Pohang Iron and Steel Company. **********For the first steel works in Pohang, 290 miles southeast of Seoul on the Sea of Japan, Japanese steelmakers supplied much of the technology. Now, however, many are opposed to doing so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/17/busin.body_text: **********sown grains and soybeans proceeding at a rapid pace under ideal weather conditions, and with the Government's latest crop estimates, issued Tuesday, producing no surprises, the major questions now facing the trade are: How much demand will there be for the crops, which were sharply cut back this year by the drought and Government acreage reduction programs? Will the higher prices caused by the smaller harvests reduce demand by in effect rationing supplies? **********Based on current projections, the corn supply will be more than ample to meet the reduced domestic and export needs between now and the 1984 harvest, while the soybean supply may just barely cover projected demand. **********Most of the wheat crop was unaffected by the acreage reduction programs and had been largely harvested when the drought took hold in mid-July, so supplies are considered more than sufficient. **********Last Tuesday, the Agriculture Department's estimates, based on Oct. 1 conditions, put the corn crop at a 10- year low of 4.26 billion bushels, compared with the record 8.4 billion in 1982, and the soybean crop at 1.52 billion bushels, down from the year-ago record 2.27 billion. The 1983 wheat crops totaled 2.41 billion bushels, compared with the record 2.81 billion harvested in 1982. **********The figures matched those issued a few days earlier by Conrad Leslie, a leading crop forecaster associated with E. F. Hutton & Company, who noted: **********''When the statistical corn year ended Sept. 30, there were 3.4 billion bushels on hand from the previous years' harvests, giving us a total supply of nearly 7.8 billion bushels. The soybean situation is something else.'' **********Indeed, on Aug. 31, when the soybean year ended, the carryover was only 387 million bushels, which means a total supply of 1.9 billion bushels. The nation's fats and oils manufacturers and livestock feed processors use about 100 million bushels a month. **********Even with reduced soybean and bean product exports, the carryover next Aug. 31 is expected to be a mere 69 million bushels, less than one month's domestic usage. **********John A. Schnittker, who heads a Washington consulting organization, said Friday that he expected several factors to cut demand in addition to the relatively high prices. **********''It is ironic that today has been designated as World Food Day by the Agriculture Department, because our Government has drastically cut back shipments of grain to needy lands overseas and replaced the food with loads of advice on how to provide their own foodstuffs. Many have taken this advice.'' **********For example, he said, the Soviet Union will again buy 80 percent of Argentina's feed-grain crops when they are harvested next February and March. Mr. Schnittker added: **********''I would not be overly concerned about the supply-demand situation, because we expect American farmers to plant fence-to-fence next spring, just as the winter wheat growers are doing now. The next figures to watch are those from the Southern Hemisphere, where the harvests will begin next February.'' **********Another leading expert who expects a dramatic rise in food output next year, barring natural or political disasters, is Emil S. Finley, president and chief executive officer of the International Commodities Export Corporation, a leading exporter of fertilizers and farm chemicals, who said Friday: **********''After three sales years that could at best be described as dismal, we have begun to see sizable foreign orders, particularly from India, Pakistan, China and Ethiopia. Our friends in the domestic fertilizer business also report a sharp rise in demand, which started with the winter wheat planting season late in August'' **********But the sudden surge in demand for fertilizers and chemicals used to combat weeds, insects and plant deseases has caught the manufacturers unprepared, Mr. Finley said. **********''Many fertilizer and farm chemical plants were either shut down or had their output reduced during the past three years because domestic farmers were squeezed between rising interest rates and falling prices for the record crops they produced,'' he said. ''Foreign buyers said they didn't have the dollars.'' **********Now that grain and soybean prices are strong and the Federal acreage reduction programs appear to have been shelved, domestic farmers are expected to vastly increase their plantings, just as the winter wheat growers have. **********After three years of cutting back, domestic farmers can no longer count on residual amounts of fertilizers in their soils to sustain the kind of yields they now want. But farmers now face fertilizer costs running 10 to 25 percent above the levels of only five weeks ago, Mr. Finley said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/17/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO SPEECH REVIEWING SOVIET UNION'S FOREIGN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/17/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO SPEECH REVIEWING SOVIET UNION'S FOREIGN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/17/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from a speech by Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko before the Supreme Soviet yesterday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency. **********The special importance of the Soviet-American accords in the field of strategic arms that were reached before the coming to power of the present Administration in the United States, should be stressed.  Operating to this day is the treaty on the limitation of antiballistic missile systems and the treaty on the limitation of strategic arms (SALT I). As to the SALT II treaty, which today is being heaped with abuse in Washington by its opponents, it also could have become a serious accomplishment both for the Soviet Union and for the United States, and for the whole world. **********As before, the Soviet Union comes out for normalizing relations with the People's Republic of China on the basis of reciprocity, searching for possibilities of a gradual expansion of bilateral ties and contacts. We stand for continuing the Soviet-Chinese political consultations that have begun and would like them to lead to positive results. We are convinced that normalization and improvement of relations between them accords with the cardinal interests of the peoples of both countries. **********The class adversary is placing stress on weakening and, if possible, splitting the socialist community, and although this invariably ends in failure, there is no end to importunate attempts to achieve this aim. Ideological Subversion Assailed **********Hostile actions of a political and economic nature are being taken against the countries of socialism, ideological subversion is being carried out against them, and resort is made to subversive actions and other methods that are impermissible in the practice of intercourse among states. This is seen with particular clarity in the policy of the West with respect to the Polish People's Republic. **********Poland, as it has been stressed by its leadership, and this has been repeatedly stated also on behalf of its allies, the countries of the Warsaw Treaty, has been and remains an inalienable part of the socialist community. Only those who have become hopelessly ossified in their hostility to socialism can fail to understand this. This hostility impairs their sight and obscures the real state of affairs from them. **********Despite the desire of the imperialist circles for military superiority over the countries of socialism throughout the postwar period, a balance of forces has been achieved between the Warsaw Treaty Organization and NATO. It is this military-strategic parity that has served and continues to serve as a reliable guarantee of international stability. Need for Arms Curbs Avowed **********The Soviet Union is in favor of proceeding, on the basis of the existing parity, along the road of arms limitation and reduction so that at any given moment the balance is preserved but on an increasingly lower level. This would mean using the existing parity for purposes of peace and not letting slip by the truly historic opportunity it offers. **********Our country is doing and will continue to do everything to maintain parity. This was once again affirmed by Yuri V. Andropov at the Central Committee meeting just ended. This position is realistic, politically and scientifically substantiated, and meets the interests of both sides. **********It would seem that all those who bear the responsibility for resolving the acute problems arising before mankind would adopt a similar stance. Those in Washington, however, think not in terms of parity, but in terms of superiority. They count on changing the strategic alignment of forces in their favor. **********They should know that there will be no winners in a nuclear war.  This is the opinion of scientists, of serious political figures, and of all those who, without hiding the truth, take a realistic approach to assessing the formidable danger of a nuclear conflict. 'Militarist Intoxication' in U.S. **********Today a militarist intoxication, one may say, pervades the political atmosphere in the United States. Nuclear war is pronounced to be permissible and even feasible. The thought being hammered into the heads of people is that such war would not be so horrifying. **********The antinuclear and antiwar movement that has arisen in the West is a kind of a popular referendum. Its participants have no hesitation when it comes to issues of war and peace. They pronounce themselves for peace, against preparations for war and against continuation of the mad arms race. **********It has been suggested that this movement heeds the hand of Moscow.  To us, naturally, it is flattering that actions for peace should be associated with the policy of the Soviet Union. But the hand of Moscow has nothing to do with it. The broad public circles engaged in antiwar actions spontaneously reflect the people's desire to defend their right to live. **********The Soviet Union rejects the very idea of nuclear war as reckless, and the calls for it as criminal. We proceed from the assumption that everything must be done to keep nuclear weapons from ever being used. This is the conviction of the Soviet leadership, of the whole of our party, and of the whole of the Soviet people. U.S. Record on War and Peace **********And what is the record in this respect that the United States can show today?  It has derailed the SALT II treaty and broken off a whole set of negotiations that were gathering momentum or were close to achieving practical results. **********It refuses to resume talks on the complete and universal prohibition of nuclear weapon tests, on limiting the shipments and sales to other countries of conventional weapons, on limiting military activity in the Indian Ocean and on a number of other issues. **********It simply does not want to engage in negotiations. And this is precisely what it says: We do not want to and that's that! This alone speaks for itself. **********From what has been said about the difficulties encountered in the struggle to end the arms race and to achieve disarmament, it does not at all follow that this struggle must be relaxed. On the contrary, it must be pursued with even greater energy and persistence; we and our allies have both. The problems that remain outstanding and the existence of the threat to peace obligate us to this. **********The U.S.S.R. has repeatedly stated and states once again that in the present situation it would be senseless for anyone to count on attaining military superiority. The U.S.S.R. has never striven and does not strive for this. And we do not recognize any other's right to military superiority. Our country has all the necessary resources - material and intellectual -to prevent this from happening. And the Soviet Union shall prevent it. Need for Acceptable Solutions **********For responsible leaders, the more so for those standing at the helm of the policy of states, it should be clear that there is no other reasonable road and that mutually acceptable solutions must be sought and found. Only such a path is reliable. **********The main condition is to conduct honest talks, not to try to outwit the partner, not to try to present deceit for truth and vice versa.  Agreements must be based on the principle of equality and equal security. The Soviet Union will not retreat from this principle. And it would be good if those in Washington realized this. **********It is impossible to overstate the importance of solving problems of limiting and reducing strategic arms, and also of limiting nuclear arms in Europe. The United States Administration is pursuing an obstructionist line at the Soviet-American talks on these questions that are going on in Geneva. To counter our position of deep mutual reductions in delivery vehicles and warheads to agreedupon levels, the Soviet Union is being offered unacceptable unilateral disarmament. **********Couched in the same spirit is the renovated position on strategic arms that was announced recently by the American President in an attempt to present it as an expression of flexibility at the talks.  This position is tailored entirely to suit the current expansion of American military programs. Selective Approach by U.S. **********Washington's approach remains unchanged: to apply limitations only to those components of strategic forces that suit the American side while leaving other components outside the framework of agreement, simply turning a blind eye to them. In effect, the United states would like to disrupt the existing structure of the Soviet strategic potential while retaining a free hand to build up its own corresponding armaments. **********So the flexibility here is purely for show. The American position does not offer a path to mutually acceptable agreements. Judging by everything, no such aim is set in the first place. The plan is to lull, to be more precise, to deceive public opinion, to neutralize the mounting opposition to Washington's militaristic preparations. **********Neither can the proposals on confidence-building measures advertised by Washington gloss over the unconstructive and lopsided nature of the line pursued by the United States. The point is that the American proposals, as opposed to the much more far-reaching proposals made by us, do not limit the military activity of the sides in any way and come down simply to an exchange of information between them on some types of activity. Soviet Proposals Rejected **********Besides, the American side hushes up the fact that it is rejecting the U.S.S.R.'s proposals, which provide for preventing the origination of crisis situations and for the strengthening of trust. **********In short, the Soviet Union stands for preventing dangers and crisis situations, while the United States proposes simply to exchange information. **********It is becoming increasingly clear that the present American Administration is pursuing a course not of reaching agreements but of fulfilling its programs of building up strategic arms and deploying new medium-range missiles in Western Europe. **********This course is clearly visible also in the statement adopted late in May at the meeting in Williamsburg and in the communique of the just ended session of the NATO Council. They contain many pompous words about the West's striving for talks with the Soviet Union, for arms reductions and for lessening the danger of war. But these words do not change the militaristic, aggressive essence of the course steered by the United States and NATO. **********The interests of the security of the U.S.S.R. and its allies compel us, as the Soviet Government warned in its statement of May 28, to take measures in response to strengthen our defense capability. Retaliatory Measures Explained **********These, however, are forced measures. Their sole aim is to prevent a disruption of the existing balance of forces. While making this warning, the Soviet Union at the same time affirms its unvarying, principled approach both to the limitation and reduction of strategic arms and to the limitation of medium-range nuclear arms in Europe. **********It is not too late to stop the dangerous development of the international situation if the United States and its NATO allies were to respond to the constructive proposals of the U.S.S.R. We would like to hope that the common sense of our partners will prevail. **********The Soviet Union thinks that mesures must be taken to prevent the arms race from developing in new directions. We proposed this to the United States Government: Let Soviet and American scientists, specialists in the field, get together and discuss the possible implications of establishing a large-scale ABM system. So far we have received no answer from the United States Administration. **********It would be a tragedy for mankind if outer space became a source of quarrels between states, and, worse still, a sphere of military clashes. Only with a total misunderstanding of one's grave responsibility and extreme recklessness can one pursue the line that would make the space above the head of mankind carry a threat to its existence. Need for Curbs on Space Arms **********The priority task in this connection is to conclude an international treaty on the nondeployment of weapons of any kind in outer space, as proposed by the Soviet Union. We are prepared to go even further - to agree on banning in general the use of force both in space, and from space against the earth. We are prepared to enter such talks without a moment's delay. **********The realities of the present international situation call for the exercise of restraint not only in the field of arms and military policy, but in all spheres of relations between states, above all between countries with different social systems. **********Neither group of states - nor the world as a whole, for that matter -stands to benefit if, in the relations between them, antagonism is artificially fueled, different kinds of provocations and unseemly methods are used, mistrust and suspicion are sown, and when even a minimum accepted comity is not observed in relations between states. **********Concern for peace should now be put above everything else. It is the duty of all those who are involved in taking major political decisions. The world expects the leadership of the United States to show greater responsibility and common sense. The solution of acute international problems can be achieved only by ending the arms race and improving the world political climate, by the relaxation of tension. Need for Normal Relations **********Attempts to offer approaches that meet only the interests of the United States and the NATO bloc and prejudice the legitimate interests of the U.S.S.R. and its allies are hopeless. **********The Soviet Union is consistently advocating normal and stable relations with capitalist countries. These relations benefit both those states and us. **********We want smoother relations with the United States in the knowledge that this is important to prevent war. It is our belief that the United States should also proceed from the objective need to maintain normal relations with the U.S.S.R. The common interests of both countries would be promoted by the removal of the threat of nuclear catastrophe. All the peoples, the states on all continents have a vital interest in this. **********Attempts to impose anti-Arab deals and to advance plans for a Middle Eastern settlement that ignore the legitimate interest of the Palestinian people are causing growing Arab opposition. This policy has brought about the situation in which Lebanon is being torn apart before everyone's eyes and in which it has been forced at gunpoint into capitulatory agreements with Israel. **********Syria, which is strengthening its defenses and pursuing a principled policy in the Middle East, has become a target of pressure and open threats. Soviet Not Merely an Onlooker **********The role of the Soviet Union in that region, adjacent to our borders, is not merely that of a passive onlooker. Our country has formulated fair principles for a political settlement, including the proposal to convene an international conference on the Middle East.  They are known to the whole world. **********Washington and Tel Aviv are creating obstacles in the way to a Middle Eastern settlement. Peace can be brought to the Middle East by a settlement that, instead of imperialist arbitrariness and Israel's actions with impunity, backed by expansionist ambitions, would produce the liberation of all occupied Arab lands and insure the establishment of an independent Arab Palestinian state. Much depends on the Arab countries themselves, on their cohesion in the struggle against the forces of aggression. **********The conflict between Iran and Iraq is senseless. The continuation of the conflict only plays into the hands of the imperialist forces who have an interest in the weakening of both states. For Amity With Iraq and Iran **********We are linked by relations of friendship with Iraq. We stand for normal relations of friendship with Iran as well. The Soviet Union would like to continue to see it an independent state and has always striven for relations of goodneighborliness with it. Regrettably, actions like those recently taken by the Iranian side with regard to a group of employees of Soviet missions in Iran do not at all contribute to the development of such contacts between our countries. In short, the U.S.S.R. will act with regard to whether Iran wishes to reciprocate its actions and maintain normal relations with us or whether it has different intentions. **********The Soviet Union affirms its full support for the program of political settlement set forth by the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan. On this basis it is possible to reach agreement on the solution of questions related to the external aspect of the Afghan problem. Precisely the external aspect, since internal matters must be solved by the Afghans themselves. **********We hope that the contacts established between Afghanistan and Pakistan through the representative of the United Nations Secretary General will bring positive results. **********Our country hs been and will continue to be a good friend of Afghanistan, an independent, nonaligned state.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/busin.body_text: **********Braniff International left the door open yesterday for further negotiations to revive part of the airline while meeting a court deadline to submit a plan of reorganization. **********The plan, which was filed in a bankruptcy court in Fort Worth, calls for liquidation of most of Braniff's assets, leaving only a small company that would provide ground services employing about 200 people and with sales of about $12 million a year. **********However, the plan also states that the board of directors will continue until May 16 ''to develop and propose a flying operation'' using up to 31 of its Boeing 727-200 aircraft to be leased at market prices. Braniff can amend its reorganization plan as long as the changes are made within 60 days, and still allow time for the 50,000 Braniff creditors to vote on it. **********The action means that the directors, management and secured and unsecured creditors of the airline may continue further negotiations on a proposal by Jay Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, to revive the airline and rehire about 2,000 Braniff workers. **********The plan of reorganization was approved during a directors meeting held in Braniff's headquarters at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. At a news conference afterward, Braniff's chairman, Howard D. Putnam, said the airline was still open to an offer by Mr. Pritzker. **********''If a flight operation can be put together, it will be added to the reorganization plan,'' Phillip Guthrie, Braniff's chief financial officer, said at the news conference, Dissatisfaction With Proposal **********Both Mr. Putnam and Braniff's secured creditors have been dissatisfied with a proposal made by Mr. Pritzker last Friday in a meeting with the secured creditors at the Union League Club in Manhattan. **********The 39 secured creditors, who hold $467.5 million of Braniff's debt, have taken a particularly tough stance toward the sweetened proposal. ''There is a strong feeling that he is not putting up enough,'' one of the creditors said. **********He also said that Mr. Putnam and other Braniff executives had told the secured creditors last Friday that there were several attractive offers from other airlines for the 31 planes that remain in Braniff's fleet. **********The creditor, who spoke with the understanding that he would not be identified, said that the cash offers were higher than the $4.2 million a plane that People Express last month agreed to pay for 20 Braniff aircraft. **********''The market has changed,'' he said, referring to an upturn in airline traffic and a decline in fuel prices in the past several months that have made the planes a more attractive buy. **********Thus the secured creditors have the attractive option of supporting liquidation and selling the planes, the source said, unless Mr. Pritzker considerably improves his offer of last Friday. **********He added that the creditors did not want to put up the $10 million that Mr. Pritzker has sought and want a more favorable arrangement for leasing the 31 planes. New Holding Company **********At the meeting last Friday, Mr. Pritzker increased the amount of money he would invest, from his original offer of $10 million, to $20 million plus $15 million in loans. **********According to creditors and sources close to Mr. Pritzker, the $20 million would be lent to a new Braniff International, which as a holding company would buy $20 million worth of stock in a new subsidiary, Braniff Airways. The subsidiary would operate the airline; Mr. Pritzker would own 80 percent of the new stock. **********He would also lend $15 million to Braniff Airways, but it would be secured by engines and other Braniff collateral such as an Eastern Airlines note issued for equipment purchases. **********To reach the estimated $60 million that would be needed to start up the airline by next July, Mr. Pritzker asked the secured creditors to put up $10 million and the unsecured creditors $15 million. **********Mr. Pritzker's proposal, according to creditors and those close to the negotiations, seeks to lease the planes from the secured creditors for $70,000 a plane per month and 17.5 percent of the profits, up to $100,000 a plane per month. **********It is basically the same offer that was made earlier this year by PSA Inc., an airline based in California. That bid was barred by an appeals court because the emerging airline would have been a subsidiary of PSA and not entitled to Braniff landing slots at Dallas-Fort Worth. **********According to sources close to Mr. Pritzker, he structured the deal to resemble the PSA offer, since Braniff's directors and the two creditor groups had approved the PSA offer and thus he expected they would be favorably disposed toward his plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Morocco Reports Repelling Sahara Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.body_text: **********Moroccan forces killed 50 Polisario guerrillas and wounded many others who attacked Moroccan positions in Western Sahara, the official Moroccan press agency reported today. **********It said two Moroccan soldiers were killed and 30 wounded. **********The attack began early Sunday along a Moroccan line about nine miles south of the town of Messeied, the agency said. It said the fighting, the first major Polisario attack in 18 months, lasted four hours before the guerrillas were pushed back. **********Several hours later, the guerrillas attacked new Moroccan positions northwest of Messeied and again were pushed back, the agency reported. **********Polisario representatives in Algiers said ''initial reports from the battlefield indicate that the fighting is still going on today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.main_headline: NEW CRISIS KNOCKS LISBON OFF COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.print_headline: NEW CRISIS KNOCKS LISBON OFF COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/world.body_text: **********In the streets of Lisbon and towns and villages across the country, every available inch of wall space is plastered with peeling political posters and faded slogans. **********They are a reminder of the numerous times the Portugese people have voted since 1974, when a group of left-wing officers overthrew the 30-year-old dictatorship of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar and Marcello Caetano. The newest posters date from last month's municipal elections, in which the governing coalition of Social Democrats, Christian Democrats and Monarchists lost ground to the Socialists of Mario Soares. **********With tensions rising in the coalition because of its poor showing and with the economy deteriorating, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, a Social Democrat, resigned as Prime Minister two weeks ago. His was the 14th Government Portugal has had since 1974. **********Now the coalition itself appears to be falling apart. Diogo Freitas do Amaral, the Christian Democratic leader, who is said to dislike Mr. Balsemao's relaxed political style, rejected his selection of Vitor Pereira Crespo, a former Education Minister, as the next Prime Minister and resigned the leadership of his party in protest. Another Election Is Urged **********''I do not think it is a choice that is likely to reignite public enthusiasm and confidence,'' Mr. Freitas do Amaral wrote in his letter of resignation. **********The worsening crisis has also brought immediate opposition calls for President Antonio Ramalho Eanes to dissolve Parliament and call yet another election, even though the coalition still has a comfortable majority and a mandate to govern until 1984. **********The conservative daily O Dia said the resignation had ''left the alliance adrift'' and made new elections '' almost inevitable.'' The Communist paper O Diario said new elections were justified because the ruling alliance was ''without any of its founders and historic leaders.'' **********''The crisis is unfortunate because it delays what has to be done,'' said Jacinto Nunes, the governor of the Portugese Central Bank. He was speaking of the interruption of the Balsemao coalition's campaign to reinvigorate Portugal's flagging economy and to undo what it has denounced as the left-wing excesses of the 1974 revolution. **********This nation of barely 10 million inhabitants has the highest inflation rate in Europe - 26 percent - and a ballooning trade deficit. Moreover, the Portuguese people have the lowest standard of living in Western Europe, with an average annual income of only $1,790. Budget Is a Casualty **********The first casualty of Portugal's latest political upheaval is the austerity budget that the Balsemao Government planned to introduce this year. The budget was intended to strengthen the economy by curbing the explosive growth of public spending that has taken place since the 1974 revolution, reduce inflation and bring the country's $3 billion a year external deficit under control. **********''Austerity is needed for the economy's good, but when will it start?'' asked J.M. Ferreira do Amaral, vice president of the Foreign Invesment Institute. **********Another casualty is the coalition's campaign to roll back the vast wave of nationalizations that began after the 1974 revolution, when most of the country's basic industries, banks, insurance companies and many shops and other businesses were all taken over by the Government. Big farms were occupied by the workers. **********At the same time, Portugal adopted a Constitution under which the decisions of an elected Parliament were subject to veto by the President and a Revolutionary Council of left-wing officers. **********During the Balsemao administration's two years in power, the Constitution was revised, depriving the President of much of his power and abolishing the Revolutionary Council. In addition, the Balsemao Government committed Portugal to a free-enterprise economy and membership in the European Common Market. Nationalization Is Pledged **********To obtain Socialist support for these changes, it was forced to concede ''irreversible'' state ownership of nationalized companies in seven sectors, including banking, brewing, steelmaking and transportation. But Mr. Balsemao reportedly planned to water this down by selling off other nationalized companies belonging to the banks, by allowing new private banks and companies to compete with state ones and by inviting private firms to manage companies ''irreversibly'' nationalized in return for a share of their profits. **********This policy was described by Mr. Ferreira do Amaral as ''backdoor denationalization.'' The future of this denationalization program appears in doubt as a result of the Government's fall. Sales of some state-owned companies have begun, but it is uncertain whether they will continue. **********Mr. Nunes, the Central bank governor, said that without new legislation he could not authorize any of the 30-odd applications on his desk from foreign banks eager to set up shop in Portugal in competition with the nationalized institutions. **********Private bids have already been invited for a contract to manage the state-owned Settenave shipyards. But plans to do the same for the nationalized breweries are on ice.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/world.body_text: **********President Luis Alberto Monge proclaimed a policy of ''permanent'' and ''unarmed'' neutrality today, but said Costa Rica would continue its traditional role in regional politics and promotion of democracy. **********In a proclamation signed at San Jose's ornate National Theater, Mr. Monge said: ''The neutrality of Costa Rica will be active. As a consequence, Costa Rica reaffirms its faith in the political and social belief it has held and shares with the Western democracies.'' **********Costa Rica has been a democracy since 1899 with only two major interruptions - the most recent a civil war that followed charges of election fraud in 1948 and took 2,000 lives. Democratic procedure was restored in 1949, the standing army was abolished, and a 7,000-member civil guard now maintains order and security. **********Officials have said repeatedly that if Costa Rica is invaded, it will rely for help on the Organization of American States and the 1947 Inter-American Treaty of Mutual Assistance, also called the Rio Treaty. They say the neutrality declaration does not lessen Costa Rica's right to aid under those agreements.   'Systems of Collective Security' **********''The neutrality of Costa Rica will not be an armed one,'' Mr. Monge said. ''Its external security will continue to be based on the free will of its people, in the rules of international law and in the systems of collective security of which it is a part, none of which demands armed force by Costa Rica to solve the warlike conflicts facing other countries.'' **********Although the United States and Costa Rica are close friends, Mr. Monge has emphasized in recent weeks that their ties must not involve Costa Rica militarily in the region's conflicts. **********He recently turned down United States invitations to observe military exercises in Honduras and to send Costa Rican Civil Guard agents to a regional military training center the Americans run there. **********Mr. Monge also denied a United States request to carry out naval maneuvers in Salinas Bay, close to Costa Rica's Pacific Coast border with Nicaragua, and refused to take part in talks aimed at reviving the Central American Defense Council. **********Impact on Pastora **********WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 - Mr.Monge's renewed declaration of neutrality is not likely to stop the military operations of Eden Pastora Gomez, the Nicaraguan exile guerrilla commander, according to a Central American familiar with Costa Rican policy and with Mr. Pastora's Democratic Revolutionary Alliance. **********He said in a telephone interview from Costa Rica today that the declaration of neutrality was not aimed directly at Mr. Pastora. **********The informant added that the Costa Rican Government might clamp down on political activities by Mr. Pastora's group inside Costa Rica, and could limit Mr. Pastora to his present level of military operations - thought to be about 3,000 guerrillas inside Nicaragua and along the Costa Rican border. **********He said that the Costa Ricans, without an army of their own, would not be able to completely stop Mr. Pastora's military operations in the isolated border area and may not even try.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/16/world.main_headline: Solo Trek to North Pole Fails

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.main_headline: SHCHARANSKY SAYS HE HAS ENDED FAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.print_headline: SHCHARANSKY SAYS HE HAS ENDED FAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/world.body_text: **********The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned dissident, said today that she had received a letter from him confirming that he had abandoned a hunger strike after four months. **********According to the woman, Ida P. Milgrom, Mr. Shcharansky said in a letter dated Feb. 7 that he resumed eating Jan. 14. He wrote that he was gaining weight and that headaches and dizziness were abating, but that he was suffering from heart pains, she said. **********Mr. Shcharansky, who is completing the fifth year of a 13-year sentence on conviction of espionage for the United States, went on a fast Sept. 27 to protest the interception of letters. Mrs. Milgrom subsequently learned that he was being fed by force and that his health had deteriorated. She said Mr. Shcharansky wrote that he had ended his hunger strike after authorities at his prison in Chistopol had allowed him to exchange messages with her. Visit Was Canceled in January **********The exchange of messages occurred in January when she was in Chistopol for the visit that prison regulations allow twice a year.  This time the meeting was barred by the prison authorities on the ground that Mr. Shcharansky was still on a hunger strike. **********Mrs. Milgrom, who is 74 years old, insisted on seeing the warden, the prison's doctor and her son. Finally on Jan. 14, the authorities permitted an exchange of notes, and it was this exchange that prompted Mr. Shcharansky to end his fast. **********The first news came a week later, when Georges Marchais, the French Communist leader, said he had received a letter to that effect from Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. But Mrs. Milgrom refused to put faith in the reports until she heard from her son. **********According to Mrs. Milgrom, her son said that he first wrote in January, but that the first letter was confiscated by the authorities. This time, however, they allowed him to write again. Shcharansky Getting Vitamins **********Mrs. Milgrom said Mr. Shcharansky had not been hospitalized and was receiving vitamins and unspecified injections. She said most of the letter was personal, and much of it was intended for his wife, Avital, who lives in Israel and travels about the world mobilizing support for her husband. Mrs. Milgrom said that the letter was a great relief, but that the heart pains he mentioned worried her because her husband died three years ago of heart disease. **********Mr. Shcharansky, an activist in the human rights and Jewish emigration movements, was arrested March 1977 and sentenced to three years in prison followed by 10 years in labor camps. After he was transferred to a camp, he was repeatedly incarcerated in a punishment cell and finally, in late 1981, was sentenced to spend three more years of his term in prison ''for failing to work at rehabilitation and continuing to consider himself innocent.'' **********Mrs. Milgrom said letters had been cut off soon after he was transferred back to Chistopol. She was allowed a visit with him on Jan. 4, 1982, but the next scheduled visit in July was refused, as was the one last month. Mrs. Milgrom said she will now try to arrange a meeting as soon as possible.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.main_headline: NIGERIAN PRESIDENT ELECTED TO A SECOND TERM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.print_headline: NIGERIAN PRESIDENT ELECTED TO A SECOND TERM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.body_text: **********President Shehu Shagari has won a second four-year term, according to election results announced early today. **********The presidential elections, held last Saturday, were the second since 13 years of military rule ended in 1979. They were the first to be conducted under civilian supervision in nearly 20 years. **********According to an announcement by the Federal Electoral Commission, the incumbent received 12,047,638 votes, while his closest rival, Chief Obafemi Awolowo, received 7,885,434 votes. **********Under the Nigerian electoral system, to be declared the winner a presidential candidate must not only win the plurality of the votes but must also take no less than 25 percent of the votes in 13 or more of Nigeria's 19 states. The President won 25 percent of the vote in 16 of Nigeria's 19 states, while Chief Awolowo won 25 percent of the vote in 7 states.   Results Under Challenge **********On Wednesday, when it began to be apparent that Mr. Shagari would emerge the winner, the leaders of the opposition parties moved to challenge the results, charging irregularities in the voting. The counting of ballots had been under way since Saturday. **********In the elections of 1979, Mr. Shagari defeated Chief Awolowo by fewer than one million votes. **********Ebenezer Babatope, a spokesman for Chief Awolowo's party, the Unity Party of Nigeria, told reporters Wednesday that the voting had been ''crudely manipulated.'' Two other candidates have gone to court to seek injunctions against the announcement of voting results in states where they say irregularities occurred. **********''Whether they accept or don't accept the results is immaterial,'' Dr. Umaru Dikko, Mr. Shagari's campaign manager, said in an interview Wednesday morning. **********Dr. Dikko said that despite organizational difficulties on the part of the Electoral Commission, he believed the voting had been both free and fair.   Missing Lists and Other Problems **********A group of foreign journalists who visited three cities in different parts of the country on election day found that a substantial number of voters had trouble casting their ballots because of missing registration lists or other problems. But it was not possible to ascertain how many of these voters could not or did not vote as a result. **********''My guess is that as many as five million people did not get to vote because of muddled organization,'' said Sale Jambo, a prominent supporter of and spokesman for the National Party of Nigeria, Mr. Shagari's party. **********''But if you look at where the problems were most severe,'' he said, ''you'll find that it was largely in the northern states where Shagari has his strongest support. The N.P.N. suffered as much, if not more, than any other party because of them.'' **********The Electoral Commission says there are more than 65 million registered voters in the country, but that number is widely viewed as inflated. Based on the results, Mr. Jambo estimated that 20 million people voted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.main_headline: New Crisis in Bolivia As 3 Quit Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; New Crisis in Bolivia As 3 Quit Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/world.body_text: **********The resignation of three Cabinet ministers has plunged Bolivia's left-wing Government into its second political crisis since it ended nearly 17 years of military rule seven months ago. **********Foreign Minister Mario Velarde and Rural Affairs Minister Zenon Barrientos announced their resignations Wednesday night; Javier Luppo Gamarra, Minister for Industry, Tourism and Commerce, quit Tuesday. **********Official sources said Mr. Velarde suffered a mild heart attack last week. Mr. Luppo has said he resigned for family reasons while Mr.  Barrientos said he was ''returning to the struggle alongside peasant masses.'' **********The new crisis came three months after the Movement of the Revolutionary Left withdrew its six members from the Cabinet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/14/busin.body_text: **********A group of dissident shareholders of the GAF Corporation, led by Samuel J. Heyman, won 58.3 percent of last month's proxy vote, Mr.  Heyman said yesterday. **********Mr. Heyman, a Connecticut real estate developer, said he had been told by the Corporation Trust Company, which inspected the election, that his group garnered 7,472,554 of the voting shares to GAF's 5,337,512 shares. **********A spokesman for GAF said that the company had not been notified of the totals and that as a result of a ruling by a Federal judge last week the numbers were ''immaterial.'' **********Last Wednesday, a judge ordered a new vote in the bitter contest between GAF and Mr. Heyman. The court found that Mr. Heyman had withheld information about a suit brought by his sister against him from his proxy material. That information, the judge said, might have cast doubt on Mr. Heyman's fitness to serve as a director of GAF. **********A three-judge panel is expected to rule today on Mr. Heyman's request for an expeditious hearing on his appeal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/world.print_headline: Bomb Explodes at Residence Of French Envoy in Brussels
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/world.body_text: **********Bombs exploded tonight at the French Ambassador's residence and at an Air France office in downtown Brussels, the police reported. **********They said the Ambassador, Roger Vaurs, was not at his residence when the bomb exploded against the wooden front door, but a guard standing behind the door received a cut on his forehead. **********About 25 minutes later, a bomb went off at Air France's main Brussels office, on Boulevard Adolphe Max, shattering its floor-toceiling windows. **********Just before that blast, two policemen spotted a parcel tied to the doorknob of the airline office and, suspecting a bomb, retreated to their patrol car to summon explosives experts. The explosion shattered the windshield of their patrol car but the officers were not hurt, the authorities said. **********The police said no one has taken responsibility for the blasts.
