https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/29/busin.body_text: **********HOW many of you insular New Yorkers realize that for almost a century, while you and your kind were enjoying the melted butter in the nooks and crannies, the rest of your country was doing without Thomas's English muffins. **********Equal muffin opportunity did not begin to come to the land of the free and the home of the brave until after CPC International purchased S. B. Thomas Inc. That was in 1976, when there was a single bakery serving metropolitan New York. Now there are four - with a fifth opening any moment near Chicago - and the ''original English muffin'' is available to 53 percent of the United States population. **********And this expansion - with more planned - is the reason that the Totowa, N.J., company brought its advertising to Young & Rubicam, America's largest agency, according to Nina Henderson, vice president, product manager, of S. B. Thomas. She was at the agency yesterday in the office of John Ferrell, senior vice president, group creative director, and possessor of one of the nation's finest collections of miniature bow ties. He wears them. **********Y.& R. will handle the account on a full-service basis, which will be unlike the situation that existed previously when D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius did the creative work and Dancer Fitzgerald Sample bought the media. Dancer, by the way, is working on a new product assignment as well as doing advertising for Sahara pita bread. **********In June, Y.& R. was assigned the English muffin, the Toast-r-Cakes and protein bread. And on Monday, it will break the first of its advertising for the muffins, exclusively on spot television in 64 markets west of Washington and north of Chicago, and in California and Nevada. The budget will be about $10 million, with 54 percent of the spending in prime time programming. **********The advertising will, in the words of Mr. Ferrell, ''celebrate the experience of eating a Thomas's English muffin.'' **********It can best be called a fun campaign, one in which the fast-moving, vignette-style commercials are spiced by a particularly lively jingle with words by Jennie Fields and music by Jake Holmes of the HEA music house that reminded one previewer of the catchy one for Peek Freans cookies. **********As the commercials were previewed, Mr. Ferrell stood by his TV set with one foot tapping and tiny bow tie aquiver and became even more animated when the final frame appeared on screen with its long tagline. ''Twelve words,'' he said somewhat awed, ''A tagline with 12 words.'' And here it is in all its glory: ''The original, one and only, funny lookin', tasty cookin', Thomas's English muffins.'' **********That is right, the old ugly but endearing approach with the commercials in both 30-second and 10-second spots. ''The advertising grew out of a violent agreement that that we had an exceptional product,'' Mr. Ferrell said. **********Miss Henderson said the advertising was ''a return to a focus on the product.'' **********''And we didn't have to create a product personality,'' Richard Kahn, vice president, account supervisor, added. ''It was already there.'' **********The agency has also created a 10- second spot to introduce the raisin version of the muffin, which Thomas's is finally getting around to even though some of its newcomer competitors are already out there with them. **********Miss Henderson, who said that Thomas's had been available in this country for 103 years, estimated that national, annual retail sales of English muffins are about $250 million and that what Thomas's pulls in accounts for more than half of them. And there's nothing funny-looking about that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.main_headline: FOR ZAMBIA, OLD FRIEND BECOMES EMBARRASSMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.print_headline: FOR ZAMBIA, OLD FRIEND BECOMES EMBARRASSMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.body_text: **********Just opposite the golf club here, in a leafy part of town, lie the ruins of a house that was once a nerve center of war. Chickens and crab grass compete for the space among the debris these days but, not long ago, the villa was home to Joshua Nkomo, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, who fled his own country this week. **********Lusaka, the tranquil Zambian capital, was his headquarters during the seven years of guerrilla war that preceded Zimbabwe's independence in 1980. But from the perspective of Zambia and others among southern Africa's ''frontline'' countries, Mr. Nkomo's political fortunes, like his onetime residence, are beyond repair and, officials said, he would not be welcome if he eventually tried to return here. **********Once supported by a broad front of nations, Mr. Nkomo, many officials say, has now become an embarrassment. The risks involved in embracing him are too great and, in the African context, there is rarely a place in the conclaves of the victor for those who have faltered in the struggle for power. Neither are there many African leaders who are prepared to entertain their neighbor's foes, since the fear is that such hospitality could draw unwelcome reciprocation. It is also a guiding principle of the Organization of African Unity that a neighbor's affairs should not be interfered with lest vengeance be taken and wider frailties be exposed. Zambia Arrests Nkomo Followers **********Two rival nationalist guerrilla forces fought for Zimbabwe's independence. Zambia and Botswana were associated mainly with Mr.  Nkomo; Mozambique and Tanzania were more closely aligned with Robert Mugabe, who is now Prime Minister. **********Since Zimbabwe's independence, a Western diplomat said, President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has ''leaned over backward'' to try to convince Mr. Mugabe of his good faith and to assure him that his support for Mr. Nkomo in the war will not be transformed into backing for subversion in times of peace. **********Lately, Western sources said, Zambia has arrested up to 50 of Mr.  Nkomo's followers who have tried to cross the Zambezi River and seek sanctuary in their former rear base in Zambia. Some are in custody and others, the sources said, have been handed over to Zimbabwe. **********But still, Zimbabwe's suspicions linger, confronting Zambia, a poor and landlocked former British possession, with a potential problem.  ''Nkomo must not embroil Zambia,'' a senior Zambian official said when asked whether the Zimbabwean might eventually find refuge here. Dependent on Railway Line **********Zambia is dependent on the rail line that runs south from its copper mines, through Zimbabwe, to South African ports and the arteries of world trade. **********There is an alternative line - the Chinese-built Tazara railway running northeast to Dar es Salaam, the Tanzanian port and capital, but it is unreliable and cannot carry all Zambia's imports and exports. **********Zaire, too, is heavily dependent on the ''southern route'' and Western diplomats said the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko there is also deeply concerned about events unfolding in Zimbabwe. **********Over the last year Zambia has been increasingly concerned by the threat to the route posed by an insurgency in Zimbabwe's southwestern province of Matabeleland where renegade soldiers who once fought under Mr. Nkomo's banner in the war against white rule have killed more than 120 people, while Government forces, in a campaign against them, are reported to have killed a thousand civilians. The railroad runs straight through the troubled province, and Bulawayo, the focal point of Mr. Nkomo's support, is the hub of the Zimbabwean rail network. **********''In the last month or two, Zambia has been more and more nervous'' about the situation in Matabeleland, a Western diplomat said, for the fear is that dissident sabotage, or full-scale civil war, could sever the lifeline. 'Sad and Tangled Mess' **********The depth of Zambia's worries was illustrated in an editorial today in the officially owned Times of Zambia. ''It would be grossly wrong for Zambia to embroil itself in the already sad and tangled mess'' surrounding Mr. Nkomo's self-exile, the newspaper said. **********During the war, Mr. Nkomo was hailed here as the patriarch of the Zimbabwean nationalist movement, but attitudes toward him have hardened. ''He cannot come here,'' a Zambian businessman said. ''We did enough for him during the war.'' **********The allusion was to Rhodesian raids and reprisals that Zambia attracted by harboring Mr. Nkomo's Soviet-supported guerrilla force.  It was during a Rhodesian raid in 1979 that Mr. Nkomo's house, a bare half-mile from Dr. Kaunda's official residence, was wrecked. Later a demolition squad razed it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.main_headline: DAON'S BID TO RAISE NEW CASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.print_headline: DAON'S BID TO RAISE NEW CASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.body_text: **********The financially troubled Daon Development Corporation, one of the high-flying Canadian realty groups that expanded aggressively into the United States in the mid-1970's, has surprised the property market in Canada with its plans to raise $165 million (Canadian) of new capital following a reorganization of its debt. A Canadian dollar is worth about 81 United States cents. **********Analysts are questioning why investors should be prepared to put up new cash for a company near bankruptcy that, to survive, is offering shares to its bankers and debenture holders in place of interest payments. **********''It's so flabbergasting,'' said Ira Gluskin, property analyst with Brown, Baldwin & Nisker, a Toronto stock brokerage firm. **********'Rights Issue' **********Daon, based in Vancouver, is planning to raise the money from a ''rights issue'' - one offered first to shareholders and then, if they are not interested, to institutions. The issue would be put together outside Canada, with a London merchant banker, Kleinwort Benson, acting as lead manager and Laurie Millbank as the broker. **********Analysts say that given the complex structure of Daon's $1.9 billion of debt, it was an achievement for the company to have worked out the restructuring with its major lenders. ''To add to it some foreign investors prepared to put up $165 million is a noble effort,'' Mr. Gluskin said. **********The rights issue will only go ahead if the restructuring program is agreed upon, but analysts believe Daon's creditors have little choice but to approve it. **********Daon's debt is backed by equity of only $72 million. Its stock now trades at around $1.80 a share; the price has been as high as $13.62 a share. The company ceased paying dividends and repurchasing preference shares more than a year ago. **********Arrangements with its major bankers for the restructuring of its debt take account of the priority that would have been given to differing classes of creditors had the company been forced into a formal receivership. Interest and some principal repayments arising between Aug. 1, 1982, and Oct. 31, 1986, are to be satisfied by the issue of new common shares. Later principal payments are to be part of a new debt schedule and debenture holders are to be given an option to convert into the new shares. Better Balance Sheet **********Meetings to approve the plan are proposed for mid-October. If it goes through, Daon's balance sheet will be improved, but the company will still carry a heavy debt burden. **********However, William H. Levine, the company's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview from Vancouver that after the restructuring the company will have a significant value. **********''Our properties are good properties,'' he added. ''Our problem has been too much debt.'' **********Daon's problems arose as its rapid debt-financed expansion ran into the high interest rates of 1981, which saw the Canadian prime rate rise to 23 percent. Its strategy was to use debt to finance property and land sales in an inflationary market, using profits from trading on the increased values of land and apartments to service debts while building up a substantial, high value, income-producing commercial portfolio. **********For a while the strategy worked. In 1980, residential sales were 49 percent of revenues and land sales 29 percent, while profits, at $51.3 million that year, had grown from $10.3 million in 1977. Led by Jack W. Poole, its president and chief executive officer, Daon's assets increased fivefold, to $2.37 billion, between 1977 and 1981. Move into United States **********In the mid-70's, Daon began its aggressive move into the United States, acquiring residential apartments in California, across the Sun Belt and in Florida. The apartments were converted into condominiums and sold. At the same time, the company built up land banks in California and in the fast-growing, oil-rich Canadian province of Alberta. **********''They did very well for a number of years, but they held on for too long,'' said Harry Ranala, property analyst of Merrill Lynch Royal Securities. **********Daon was buying and developing its commercial portfolio at what proved to be the top of the market. In 1981, it continued to invest heavily, buying a 47-story office block in Montreal for $85 million, a 40-story office block in Philadelphia and a half-interest in the Omni complex in Atlanta. **********While interest rates were soaring, Daon was still using debt to increase its assets that year by 41 percent. Then the bottom dropped out of condominium sales, both in Canada and the United States, land sales dropped off in California, and the oil and gas boom in Alberta collapsed. By August 1982, the company could no longer service its loans, and for the year it lost $85.5 million. **********Negotiations over the restructuring of the debt have taken 18 months, during which the company has been realizing cash by selling nearly all of its residential properties. **********Analysts say Daon retains some quality commercial properties and potentially salable land, but they are awaiting the detailed restructuring plan to assess the company's prospects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/08/busin.main_headline: EX-TYPIST FOR WACHTELL ACCUSED OF INSIDER TIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/08/busin.print_headline: EX-TYPIST FOR WACHTELL ACCUSED OF INSIDER TIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/08/busin.body_text: **********A former typist at a New York law firm that is one of the nation's specialists in corporate mergers was accused today of illegally passing tips about pending mergers to friends and relatives who were said to have used the information to make $2.7 million in the stock market. **********The Securities and Exchange Commission brought the charge principally against Manohar Lal Madan, 48 years old, who joined Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz in the 1970's as a typist, a job he held until his dismissal last November. **********The commission said, in effect, that Mr. Lal Madan passed information about planned mergers that he came across as he typed.  The S.E.C. also filed charges against the friends and relatives. **********The friends and relatives, using this information, were able to buy stocks in companies soon to be the targets of takeover bids, the S.E.C. said. When the bids were announced, the stocks of these companies rose in price and Mr. Lal Madan's group sold at a profit, the commission charged. They traded in the stocks of 29 companies this way and earned the $2.7 million over five years, the S.E.C.  said. **********The commission said Mr. Lal Madan had an agreement with the others under which he shared in the profits from the transactions, which it said were based on illegally obtained insider information. In one instance, the S.E.C. said, one of those involved paid Mr. Lal Madan about $25,000. Pabst and Marshall Field **********The companies he was said to have recommended included such recent takeover targets as the Pabst Brewing Company and Marshall Field & Company. The 29 companies were either clients of Wachtell or were under consideration by clients as possible targets of tender offers or mergers, the commission said. **********The S.E.C. began investigating Mr. Lal Madan last fall, after receiving an anonymous tip that his son had traded in Pabst stock while the law firm was representing the brewery, a Wachtell spokesman said. **********Just before Thanksgiving, the S.E.C. notified Wachtell officials that it was beginning an investigation. It also asked for and received information on Mr. Lal Madan's assignments for the firm, according to the firm's spokesman. On Nov.30, Mr. Lal Madan was dismissed by Washtell in the course of its own investigation. **********According to Wachtell, Mr. Lal Madan was hired in May 1976 and had previously worked for two other New York law firms - Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and Poletti Freidin Prashker Feldman & Gartner. Wachtell said lawyers from those firms sent ''very good'' letters of recommendation about Mr. Lal Madan. Wachtell also said that Mr.  Madan was born in Pakistan and, according to his resume, had once worked as an ''assistant/secretary'' for senior government officials in India. Assets Frozen **********This afternoon, Federal Judge Morris Lasker of the United States District Court in New York granted the commission's request for a temporary freeze on the assets of the defendants. The agency is also seeking an injunction against further violations of the Federal securities laws, and wants the defendants to give up any illegal profits. **********In rare instances, the S.E.C. has recommended criminal prosecution for insider trading.  In addition to Mr. Lal Madan, the defendants, as listed in the S.E.C. complaint, included Darshan Madan, his wife, and their son, Akshay Madan, all of Queens; Sudesh and Vishvinder Madan, Melville, L.I., residents who are not related to Mr. Lal Madan, and Romesh and Satish Wadhwa, brothers, and Amul Shah and Mahendra Shah, said to be friends of Mr. Lal Madan. Romesh Wadhwa lives in Downers Grove, Ill., and Satish Wadhwa lives in Rochester, Minn. Amul Shah lives in Queens and Mahendra Shah lives in Manhattan. The Shahs are not kin. **********Also named were Asha Enterprises, a travel agency owned by Amul Shah and Mahendra Shah, and its subsidiaries, Asha Investors and Avm Investors; Krishan Taneja, of Queens, and L.R. Chadda, the father-inlaw of Mr. Taneja. **********All of the individuals named in the complaint, except Mr. Chadda, are either naturalized citizens or permanent residents of the United States. Mr. Chadda was last known to be living in London. All of the defendants were born in either Pakistan or India. Dirks Decision Recalled **********Gary L. Lynch, associate director of the agency's enforcement division, said today in a telephone interview: ''The commission believes that the theories that are being advanced in this case are consistent with the language set in the Supreme Court's decision in Dirks.'' **********Last week, in the Dirks decision, the High Court set new limits on the legal liability of those who make use of nonpublic information they receive from a corporate insider, usually an officer, director or major stockholder. The Court said the duty of a person who receives an insider tip depends entirely on whether the source of the tip has himself breached a legal duty to the corporation's shareholders. **********Whether the insider has breached a duty, the Court said, depends in turn on his motive and on whether he stands to gain from passing the information further along the chain. **********According to the S.E.C.'s complaint, from May 1976 through Nov.30, 1982, Mr. Lal Madan routinely typed drafts of documents related to possible mergers. **********The complaint specifically noted that Mr. Lal Madan knew that Wachtell maintained ''stringent policies concering the confidentiality of client information.'' It added that he ''made Wachtell a victim of the fraud perpetrated by him.'' **********The long S.E,C. complaint lists numerous transactions in which the defendants jointly participated. For example, in late 1982, Wachtell began drafting documents relating to a proposed merger between Pabst, its client, and the G. Heileman Brewing Company, in which Heileman would make a tender offer for Pabst. **********On Oct.21, 1982, and continuing intermittently through November, the complaint charges, Mr. Lal Madan worked on documents related to the proposed offer. During this period, the S.E.C. said, he disclosed to the other defendants information of the takeover, and they purchased large quantities of Pabst shares. **********One defendant, Romesh Wadhwa, for example, was said to have purchased $115,949 in shares and, following Heileman's announcement of its tender offer, sold the shares for $150,023. **********Steven Barna, a partner with Watctell, said in a telephone interview, ''Unfortunately, no rule, no matter how strict, can provide an insurance policy against this kind of conduct by a person who is willing to run the risk of violating the securities laws.'' Chiarella v. U.S. **********In 1980, in another, somewhat similar insider case before the Supreme Court, Chiarella v. U.S., the Court reversed the securities fraud conviction of a printer who profited from his advance knowledge of takeover bids from documents he handled. **********The defendant in that case, Vincent F. Chiarella, had, over a 14-month period, made $30,000 by buying stock in the target companies and then selling the shares as soon as the takeover bids were made public. **********The Court ruled, however, that insider trading violates the securities laws only if the trader breaches a pre-existing relationship of trust with the other party to the transaction. **********Mr. Chiarella, said Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell, ''was not a fiduciary, he was not a person in whom the sellers had placed their trust and confidence. He was, in fact, a complete stranger who dealt with the sellers only through impersonal market transactions.'' **********Apparently in an attempt to distinguish the case against Mr. Lal Madan from Chiarella, the S.E.C. said today that Mr. Lal Madan ''enjoyed a special relationship of trust and confidence with Wachtell and its clients.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.main_headline: OPERATION ON GRENADA: HOW FORCES PERFORMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.print_headline: OPERATION ON GRENADA: HOW FORCES PERFORMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.body_text: **********MilitaryAnalysis **********With resistance on Grenada apparently lessening, United States intelligence and operations officers are about to reassess the strengths and weaknesses of the armed services that took part in the invasion of the island.  One question likely to be raised, according to an officer who did not wish to be identified, is why it took the Americans more than two days to defeat a thousand Cubans and a Grenadian Army of just over 2,000 soldiers. After the 800 men of the 82d Airborne Division landed Wednesday, there were nearly 3,000 American soldiers and marines deployed, backed by helicopter gunships. **********The 300 men contributed by seven Caribbean nations were reportedly used for police duties. **********A military rule of thumb is that an attacking force should have a superiority of 3 to 1. The Americans, in numbers at least, had no such advantage when they landed. But they did have more and better weapons and had undergone long training.   Error in Intelligence Is Seen Some officers suggested that there had been an intelligence error. American officials said about 1,000 Cubans had been discovered in Grenada, 400 more than were said to have been engaged in building the Point Salines Airport. The Cubans proved to be well-trained and fought stubbornly. **********Some of them were construction workers probably drawn from the Youth Labor Army, a component of the armed forces that numbers 100,000 men. But the soldiers who gave the Americans the most trouble apparently were regulars stationed in Grenada. **********Some informants said the large amounts of military equipment and ammunition found in Grenada were evidence that Cuba intended to strengthen its garrison. The conclusion they drew was that the American invasion had come just in time. **********The Cubans apparently lacked the one weapon that could have checked the assault. They reportedly did not have, or at least did not use, portable, heat-seeking antiaircraft missiles.   Copters Operate With Impunity **********As a result, American helicopter gunships were said to have operated with impunity, destroying, with heavy casualties, the main Cuban position at the Point Salines airfield, at the southwest tip of the island. **********The Grenadian Army had reportedly been equipped with Soviet-made mobile antiaircraft guns. But these were not employed either against the helicopters or against the transports that fed the attacking forces with ammunition, reinforcements and supplies. **********Another factor likely to be studied is the behavior of troops who had previously had little or no combat experience. **********Many senior noncommissioned officers had served in the Vietnam War. So did many of the officers from the rank of major up. But the enlisted men of that war have been replaced by volunteers, most of whom have entered the Army and the Marine Corps in the last four to six years. **********Officers say that these men are ready for any mission. But the officers point out that the first shock of combat is likely to slow reactions and occasionally force mistakes.   Best Units in West Germany **********The consensus among the Atlantic allies is that the United States Army's best units are with the Seventh Army in West Germany. One exception is the 82d Airborne Division, which is considered one of the best such divisions. **********The Americans did fight under a handicap. Strongpoints in the area of St. George's, the Grenadian capital, such as Fort Frederick and Richmond Hill prison, could have fallen earlier had the invaders been able to call in bombers or use heavy artillery. But senior officers ruled out the use of such weapons to avoid killing civilians. **********The helicopter gunships gave the infantry the support it needed when it faced Cuban strongpoints. C-130 and C-5A transports landing at the new Point Salines Airport provided logistical support. **********In this respect it was a picture book operation. Officers say the operation would have been more difficult and the role of the United States Air Force more constrained if Soviet-made MIG jets had been deployed on the new airstrip or antiaircraft missiles had been used.   Cuban Threat Called Averted **********Defense officials said that, if the United States had not invaded Grenada and Cuban planes had begun to use the 9,000-foot runway at Point Salines, the strategic balance in the Caribbean could have changed. Fighter operations could then have expanded to cover Central America and parts of northern South America. This, the officials said, would have required a reinforcement of United States Air Force resources in the area. **********Some allied officers questioned the size of the American force deployed and in reserve. They used the word ''overkill.'' **********But Americans responded by pointing out that no country ever lost a battle by being too strong. In the case of Grenada, the Americans argue, the vigor of the Cuban resistance showed that the Pentagon was correct in employing a relatively large force with abundant reinforcements. **********No one, an officer said, has forgotten the lesson of the abortive rescue attempt in Iran in April 1980. That lesson, he said, was ''too little and too late.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/busin.body_text: **********SATURDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1983 **********Companies Texas Instruments is halting production of its 99/4A home computer and withdrawing from the field. The company reported a loss of $110.8 million in the third quarter following one of $119.2 million in the second. The more than a million owners of the 99/4A may now find it harder to obtain servicing and new programs. (Page 35.)  Delta Air Lines elevated David C. Garrett Jr., 61 years old, to the post of chairman, succeeding W.T. Beebe, 68. The airline, which recently posted its first full-year loss in 36 years, said the changes were brought on wholely by retirement pressures. (37.) **********Aetna Life and Casualty reported a 16.9 percent drop in operating earnings in the third quarter. It cited $38 million in claim costs after hurricane Alicia. Goodyear Tire and Rubber's net fell 21 percent despite a 2.5 percent rise in revenues. (45.)  GATX said it will show a loss for 1983.  The rail equipment maker cited a fourth-quarter writeoff of some $100 million. (36.) **********Markets Stock prices plunged after Moscow accused the U.S.  of firing on its embassy in Grenada earlier this week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 18.59 points, to 1,223.48. Analysts said high interest rates and the military intervention in Grenada have left many investors uneasy. For the week, the Dow was off 25.40 points. (35.)  The basic measure of the money supply dropped $2.4 billion for the week ended Oct. 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported. The decline, which was greater than expected, was welcomed by economists and the credit markets. In effect, it offset an unexpectedly large increase announced a week earlier. (35.)  The dollar was mixed, while gold prices rose 75 cents an ounce, to $386.75, in New York. (43.) Grain futures prices were mixed. (43.) The Economy The leading economic indicators rose a strong 0.9 percent in September, their 13th consecutive gain, the Commerce Department reported. Though the increase for the third quarter was the smallest of the year, experts saw the slackening pace as healthy. (38.)  A Senate effort to raise the debt ceiling by Monday stalled as individual members used the bill as a vehicle for a series of unrelated amendments. The delay could cause the postponement of several scheduled Treasury securities sales totaling $16 billion. (38.)  The Administration rejected a plan to reduce Federal budgets by $120 billion over the next three years. The plan, put forward by Bob Dole, Senate Finance Committee chairman, had too few spending cuts and too many new taxes, officials said. (38.)  Union pay raises averaged just 1.7 percent in the first nine months, a record low figure, the Labor Department reported. (16.)  The G.A.O. is studying reports that poor-quality grain is being shipped to farmers under the payment-in-kind program. (13.)  The resignation of William F. Baxter , head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, is expected by his friends and some Government officials. Mr. Baxter may go back to Stanford. (36.)  An internal report urged the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to eliminate mismanagement from the nuclear industry. (12.) **********International Many foreign bankers are skeptical of Manila's assertion that it has its economic crisis under control. They say the refusal of the Marcos Government to mollify its critics makes it a less attractive candidate for help with its $19 billion foreign debt. (35.)  The foreign trade deficit narrowed to $5.8 billion in September, the Commerce Department reported. (45.)  Foreign banks in Canada have won support from a parliamentary committee in their bid to remove restrictions now curbing expansion of their share of the market. (43.) **********Today's Columns Central asset accounts are adding Federal deposit insurance as an option. Many customers have voiced a preference for the extra security of the guarantee, and brokers have arranged with banks and savings associations to meet the demand. Your Money. (36.)  A more flexible way to halt a nuclear reactor has been devised for use during an emergency. The invention is said to make stoppage possible even if a rod crucial to the procedure has been jammed by an earthquake or bomb damage. Patents. (47.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/07/world.main_headline: GRENADA WAS TOLD OF INVASION PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/07/world.print_headline: GRENADA WAS TOLD OF INVASION PLAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/07/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Edward Seaga of Jamaica said today after a meeting with President Reagan that Gen. Hudson Austin, the leader of Grenada before the United States-led invasion of the island, had been told of the invasion plan nearly 36 hours before it was carried out. **********The disclosure was made by one of the Caribbean nations that participated in the decision, but it did not include the precise timetable, Mr. Seaga said. **********''Therefore,'' he said, ''the harm done turned out to be minimal.'' **********The invasion was carried out in the predawn hours of Oct. 25. Mr. Seaga said the Grenadians were notified late on Oct. 23, but would not say by whom. **********The Jamaican Prime Minister, a leading force behind the invasion decision, said he had been ''deeply worried'' by the disclosure and said it had added to concern about the safety of more than 1,000 Americans on Grenada.   'Brutalities' Cited **********However, he said, Grenadians and the Americans on the island, including hundreds of medical students, faced a possible threat of being taken hostage or killed ''whether there was an invasion or not, bearing in mind the brutalities that were being carried out by General Austin, who turned out to be an Idi Amin-type character.'' **********''When one is dealing with that kind of character,'' he said, ''one can expect anything to happen.'' **********Mr. Reagan and Mr. Seaga met for about an hour, joined by Vice President Bush and a handful of other United States and Jamaican officials. **********Mr. Seaga, whose country has about 200 troops in Grenada, said he and President Reagan ''discussed the necessities of stabilizing the country,'' including the need for aid and jobs in Grenada.   U.S. Withdrawal Expected **********And while United States troops can begin a phased withdrawal ''without endangering security,'' he said, the multinational force that remains until elections are held probably will require American equipment. **********''We have to have some equipment and we don't have it there,'' he said. **********The unusual Sunday meeting was initiated by the White House, which has gone to great lengths to portray the Caribbean nations as solidly behind the invasion. **********Mr. Seaga was the third Caribbean leader invited to the White House in the last two weeks. Today's meeting was his fourth with Mr. Reagan. **********Mary Eugenia Charles, the Prime Minister of Dominica and chairman of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States, was at Mr. Reagan's side when he announced the invasion on Oct. 25. John Compton, the Prime Minister of St. Lucia, was at the White House voicing his support for the operation just hours before Mr. Reagan's televised address to the nation two days later.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/busin.body_text: **********Even two years ago, the Beaufort Sea was still a dream of vast oil riches being successfully promoted on Wall Street by John P. Gallagher, the chairman of Dome Petroleum. **********Mr. Gallagher, who was called ''Smiling Jack,'' is now gone, Beaufort oil seems, at best, a dream deferred, and Dome's prospects are no brighter. **********This summer marked the shortest Beaufort drilling season ever, with ice allowing only 76 days for it, 50 fewer than last year. And last year was also disappointing. **********Thus, after more than a decade of drilling, enough oil to justify commercial exploitation has not yet been found. Known reserves total only 700 million barrels, against a potential estimated at more than nine billion, nearly the size of Alaska's Prudhoe Bay. **********''We haven't been quite as successful as we'd anticipated,'' R. A. W. Hoos, a Dome executive, said recently, conceding that the company's earlier hope of beginning Beaufort production by 1985 or 1986 was now impossible. **********Which would require large amounts of oil revenue, of course, and that possibility seems to be fast receding. Evidence of the changed view is a skittishness among smaller companies involved in the Beaufort. Canterra Energy Ltd., for instance, recently pulled out of its small share of Gulf Canada's $75 million well in the Pitsiulak region. **********''Until results show forth, the Beaufort will not command the high profile it once did,'' said Ian M. Doig, a Calgary, Alberta, oil analyst. **********Environmental Review **********The hearing here was testimony to an earlier vision of the Beaufort. In the expectation of a bonanza by the mid-1980's, the principal companies operating in the area - Dome, Imperial Oil and Gulf Canada - three years ago asked the Canadian Government to begin a major review of the environmental effects of a huge program to pump and ship the oil. So far, the companies say they have spent $20 million, and the Government several million more for the the review. Hearings are being held across the Arctic. **********The hearing here was limited to environmental issues, but the discussion behind the scenes revolved around economic issues. ''The question should be is it economic?'' said Murray Coolican, an Arctic expert working with the Inuit Tapirisat, one of the main groups of Arctic natives opposing development. **********The answer, companies agree, is that it would not be economic without the huge grants given by the Canadian Government, under the Petroleum Incentive Payments program, to promote Canadian exploration in frontier areas. **********Last year, Ottawa gave companies $501 million to drill in the Beaufort, more than double the previous year's outlay of $244 million. The Beaufort grants in 1982 were 38 percent of the total incentive payments program of $1.3 billion. And an increase in spending is expected this year. **********''We would not be exploring in the Beaufort at the rate and level we are'' without the grants, said Patrick Shaw, an Imperial spokesman. **********A Drilling Disappointment **********Obviously, a big discovery could reverse the equation, but last year's conclusive results were worse than this year's inconclusive ones. Five wildcat wells were completed last year to test unexplored formations. Only two encountered oil, and only one found enough to generate any enthusiasm. That was the Nerlerk structure, covering 90,000 acres and needing further appraisal. **********That Dome success, however, was overshadowed by the disappointment of the Tarsiut formation, where an evaluation well last year failed to find any oil. Mr. Hoos said that if the well had proved successful, Dome would have had a billion-barrel oilfield instead of its present estimate of 350 million barrels. **********Mr. Hoos said that would be enough to be commercial in milder environments, but he added that, in combination with three other fields, ranging from 50 million to 200 million barrels, some type of development might be possible sooner that most analysts expected. The prevailing view has been that it would take at least one big find to allow for the construction of a transportation system that would permit overall Beaufort development to proceed. **********''We're now looking at ways of optimizing recovery from a grouping of small fields,'' Mr. Hoos said. ''There are several options available to us.'' **********Imperial's Gains **********Gulf is involved with Dome in Tarsiut and several other Beaufort efforts. But in the view of many analysts, it is Imperial, 70 percent of which is owned by the Exxon Corporation, that has been most successful. **********Since the mid-1960's, Imperial has drilled on the MacKenzie River Delta, creeping slowly into the Beaufort. Its many small discoveries are estimated by outsiders to be capable of producing about 40,000 barrels of oil a day, and represent the only firm success in the Beaufort to date. **********''It could be 15 to 20 years before anybody but Imperial produces any oil,'' said Stanley Kanik, a Canadian Government geologist attending the hearing. **********Although Imperial says it is willing to use tankers if that would offer the greatest benefit to all oil drillers, many analysts suggest that the company is most interested in a pipeline. They estimate oil could be flowing to an Edmonton refinery by 1990 through such a line. **********Mr. Kanik says Imperial has been more successful because it apparently has a better appreciation of how oil accumulates under delta regions. He says oil tends to gather in small pools in and near deltas, citing the mouths of the Niger and the Mississippi as examples. **********Canada's Arctic oil thrust is related to a Government estimate that 75 Arctic wells might produce as much crude as 22,000 in Alberta, Canada's main petroleum province. But the discovery rate has picked up in Alberta, while expectations have not been met in the Northwest Territories. **********Moreover, the pace of oil sands development in Alberta has been picking up. This has led to questions about the wisdom of concentrating so much drilling resources and Government money in the Beaufort. **********''No matter how you cut it, Alberta is where our oil and gas supplies are for the foreseeable future,'' Jim Grey, executive vice president of Canadian Hunter Exploration Ltd., said when asked about the Beaufort. ''We just have staggering amounts.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday that second-quarter earnings plunged 52.8 percent, to $93 million, or 47 cents a share, from $197 million, or $1.02 a share, in the quarter a year before.  Revenues for the period remained the same, at $2.73 billion, for the company, which is based in Midland, Mich. **********In last year's second quarter, Dow had an extraordinary gain of 62 cents a share, from the sale of Asahi-Dow. Without that gain, earnings in the latest quarter would have increased 7 cents a share. **********''We had been projecting 50 to 55 cents a share for the second quarter,'' said Theodore S. Semegran, vice president of research at Shearson/ American Express. ''Dow definitely showed a cyclical recovery in the latest quarter versus the first quarter of this year and the company continues to be helped by its domestic chemical businesses.'' **********Mr. Semegran said that Dow's foreign operations are doing well but that the currency translation effects of the strong dollar continue to affect earnings. Historically, the company has derived about half of its sales from foreign operations. **********Paul F. Oreffice, president and chief executive of Dow, the country's second-largest chemical concern after the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said that ''in May, business started to benefit from the U.S. economic recovery and June was our best month since June 1981.'' He added: ''We believe that the recovery is real and will continue to have a favorable effect on the results of the company. **********Dow, citing a pickup in basic chemicals, noted that specialties such as ion exchange resins, Styrofoam-brand plastic foam products and commercial films recorded particularly strong performances during the latest quarter. Schlumberger **********Schlumberger Ltd., the world leader in well-logging services to the petroleum drilling and exploration industry, said yesterday that net income in the second quarter fell 19.6 percent, to $286.4 million, or 98 cents a share, from $356.3 million, or $1.21 a share, in the comparable quarter last year. Second-quarter revenue declined 11.2 percent, to $1.43 billion, from $1.61 billion. **********Schlumberger said revenue from oilfield services for the second quarter dropped 20 percent, to $841 million.  The company said that the rig count in North America has shown signs of recovery since late April, after having fallen steadily for the previous 15 months. However, offshore rigs in the Gulf Coast and deep drilling on land are still declining, it said. **********Outside North America, Schlumberger said, activity has remained strong in the North Sea, the Far East and part of the Middle East, but has slowed further in South America and Nigeria. Burlington Industries **********Burlington Industries, the Greensboro, N.C., textile company, said net income in its third quarter increased more than twofold, to $30 million, or $1.05 a share, from $12.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 13 percent, to $812.8 million, from $719.4 million, over the same period. **********William A. Klopman, Burlington's chairman and chief executive, said stronger demand in many of the company's markets resulted in higher volume and associated capacity gains.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.body_text: **********The Austrian Socialist Party designated the country's Education Minister today to succeed Chancellor Bruno Kreisky after the veteran politician announced Sunday night that he was resigning. **********A brief meeting of the party leadership ratified Mr. Kreisky's choice, Education Minister Fred Sinowatz, as Chancellor-designate, with a mandate to form a coalition government. **********Sunday night, after the Socialists lost the parliamentary majority they had held since 1971, the 72-year-old Mr. Kreisky stunned the country by declaring that because of what he called ''a defeat'' he was resigning. **********Mr. Kreisky, who was expected to submit his resignation formally to President Rudolf Kirchschlager on Tuesday, will remain party chairman until a special congress in the fall. This interval is evidently designed to give the 54-year-old Mr. Sinowatz, who was also Deputy Chancellor in the Kreisky Government, time to consolidate his position. Still the Largest Party **********Despite their loss of five seats in Sunday's election, the Socialists remain the largest single party in the 183-member Parliament, with 90 seats. They are expected to try to forge a coalition with the small rightist Freedom Party, which won 12 seats. **********Mr. Kreisky, who is a member of a four-man Socialist coalition negotiating team, appears eager to exclude the opposition People's Party, which won 81 seats, from a share of power. But most politicians here predicted prolonged horse-trading before a coalition is put together. **********It was this prospect of tedious coalition bargaining that appeared to have persuaded Mr. Kreisky, who suffers from a kidney condition, to step aside after 13 years as Austria's leader. **********Before Sunday's vote, Mr. Kreisky had repeatedly warned that he would leave if his party fell short of a majority, but few politicians believed he would abandon power so swiftly. A Plucked Bird Out of Reach **********''An era is at an end,'' said the conservative daily Die Presse, showing the Chancellor in a cartoon slumped over an election urn, a bunch of feathers in his hand. A plucked bird labeled ''absolute majority'' flutters out of reach. **********In their election post-mortems today, politicians and journalists cited a number of reasons for the Socialists' setback, including an economy stuck in recession; new and unpopular taxes that the Kreisky Government had promised to impose, and controversy over a modern and costly Vienna conference center that was criticized as extravagant. **********If Mr. Sinowatz succeeds in putting together a coalition with the Freedom Party, which has never been in government, he is expected to make few major changes, though some deficit-cutting measures are viewed as inevitable. **********A portly and well-respected figure, Mr. Sinowatz is a standardbearer of the Socialists' left wing, which is exceedingly moderate by Western European standards. With little experience in foreign affairs, he is viewed as likely to concentrate on domestic matters. **********The next Austrian government, according to many here, is likely to concentrate on reviving the economy and, in foreign affairs, on strengthening its European ties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.print_headline: AM CHARGED IN S.E.C. FRAUD CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged AM International Inc., the old Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, with engaging in a wide-ranging fraud to inflate its financial statements in violation of Federal securities laws. **********The company, which filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws last year, immediately settled the complaint, without admitting or denying the allegations.  But in a highly unusual statement included in the court documents, the S.E.C. said it was continuing its ''private investigation'' of the company. **********The complaint filed today did not name any of AM's past or current management, accountants or outside auditors in the reportedly fraudulent practices. But it dealt with the 1980 and 1981 fiscal years. During most of that the company was headed by Roy L. Ash. Mr.  Ash was chief executive of AM for four years, and before that served as director of the Office of Management and Budget from 1972 through 1975 in the Nixon and Ford Administrations. **********He resigned from AM International in February 1981, following a clash with directors over acquisition policies that have also been blamed for AM's financial difficulties. **********Mr. Ash was succeeded by Richard B. Black, a turnaround specialists who attempted to put AM International back on its feet, in part through divestiture of some of Mr. Ash's acquisitions. But Mr. Black resigned 13 months later after filing a suit against AM International. The suit accused AM, Price Waterhouse and several former AM executives of misrepresenting the company's finances, inducing him to join AM and personally invest $3 million in its stock. **********Reached at his New York home, Mr. Black said that he had not seen the S.E.C. charges and had not talked to the investigators. He added that he did not believe the findings had anything to do with his tenure at the company, which started six months before the end of the 1981 fiscal year, but that they may bolster his charges. ''There was just massive misrepresentation there,'' he said. **********Mr. Ash could not be reached for comment.  The financial troubles of the Chicago-based company, one of the nation's oldest and best-known suppliers of office equipment and information processing systems, began with its inability to keep up with the technology war in the mid-1960's among makers of electronic addressing machines and copiers. Mr. Ash's acquisition campaign had been intended to solve this technology problem. In April 1982, when AM filed for reorganization, it attributed the action to its negative net worth and its $254 million in debt. Suit by Former Chief **********In a prepared statement, Joe B. Freeman Jr., who took over from Mr. Black in early 1982 as chairman and chief executive officer, said: ''The commission's investigation had focused primarily on AM's previous internal controls and past financial reports.'' As part of the settlement, he said, ''AM has agreed to appoint two additional directors within 90 days after confirmation of its eventual plan of reorganiztion to serve on the audit committee of the company's board of directors and to have its independent auditors for the next three years review its accounting system and procedures.'' **********At the heart of today's action, filed in the United States District Court here, are allegations that as AM's financial condition deteriorated during the fiscal year 1980, the company's management applied increasing pressure on its operating divisions to meet performance goals. **********''Such pressure consisted of, among other means, threatened dismissals, actual dismissals and ad hominem attacks on certain of the divisions' senior management,'' the complaint asserts. **********''These pressures,'' the complaint continues, ''were motivated, in part, by the desire of AMI to have a public offering of its securities in the fall of 1980.'' In response to these pressures, the S.E.C. charges, various divisions of the company ''engaged in widespread and pervasive accounting irregularities.'' Throughout this period, the company's corporate headquarters learned of numerous instances of accounting irregularies, but continued to pressure its divisions, according to the S.E.C. **********Among the improper accounting techniques employed, the S.E.C.  charges, was the practice of recording products that had not yet been shipped as sales. Also, the S.E.C said the company's Jacquard division had engaged in a series of improper practices in the fiscal year 1980, including keeping the company's books open at the end of the fiscal period and deliberately double-billing for products shipped. During this period, the complaint charges, Jacquard recognized about $1 million in revenues as a result of improperly keeping its books open. Auditors Discharged **********Another division, Multigraphics, was also accused of numerous improper accounting practices, leading to a $5.5 million overstatement in pretax results for the 1980 fiscal year. **********The company was also accused of artificially structuring certain transactions to reduce its foreign income taxes.

O'Kelley.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/busin.body_text: **********''MR. WALL STREET'' himself, the legendary Sidney J. Weinberg, made his reputation by being one of the canniest wizards of finance and also by sitting on no fewer than 35 boards of directors. In his 60-year career, he watched over the management of the bluest of the blue chips, a list that included such giants as General Electric, Ford and B. F. Goodrich. **********The reputation of Mr. Weinberg, a partner in Goldman, Sachs & Co. until his death in 1969, may live on. But his practice of sitting on dozens of boards - as many as 31 at one time - has not. Even his sons don't come close. One son, John L. Weinberg, co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, today sits on a mere six boards, while his other son, Sidney J. Weinberg Jr., a Goldman, Sachs partner, sits on only five. **********Boards of directors have changed, and so have those who sit on them. Busy executives have cut down on their board engagements, not only to concentrate their effectiveness but also because board responsibilities have become weightier. Outside directors - those with no financial ties to the company - have increased in number with a corresponding decrease in insider directors. Board committees, particularly the audit and nominating committees, have become more common and more important. And new groups - minorities, women and academics - are showing up more and more. **********Whether these changes have caused boards to become more critical and vigilant overseers of a company's management is open to question - and it is a question that is impossible to answer since most board actions take place behind closed doors. Clearly, management has the upper hand since it has the day-to-day knowledge of the company's inner workings while directors spend only a limited number of hours a month on their board tasks. **********Moreover, much of the information directors receive is prepared by management, and only a diligent director will make inquiries beyond these management presentations. Yet, some say the mere fact that these structural changes in boards are slowly coming about makes substantive changes in the quality of board actions inevitable. **********''The changes in peformance have been rather modest, but in a constructive direction,'' said Elliott J. Weiss, a visiting professor of law at the Cornell Law School and a specialist in corporate responsibility. ''The way people think about boards and those who serve as directors make it likely that boards are a bit more assertive, a bit less compliant, a bit more inclined to ask questions. But how big of a bit it is, I just don't know.'' **********Many of the changes that have taken place resulted from widespread discussion in the mid-1970's about corporate governance - the public responsibilities of a corporation and its board - which focused more attention on what directors should do. **********This followed disclosures that some American companies, such as Lockheed and Exxon, made questionable payments to foreign governments, raising the issue of whether directors of those companies knew about the payments and, if so, what they should have done. At the same time, some consumer activist groups were demanding broader representation on corporate boards, and Harold M. Williams, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission from 1977 to 1981 and an advocate of outside directors, was campaigning to increase the oversight responsibilities of corporate boards. **********The discussion in the mid-70's ''contributed to the independence of directors,'' Mr. Williams said. ''My main hope now is that individual boards look at themselves, reassess their responsibility and how well they are discharging it.'' **********Jeremy Bacon, a senior research associate at The Conference Board, points to three changes that have taken place since the mid-1970's: The increase in outside directors, greater use of committees and a change in attitude in which more corporations feel that a strong, independent board is a concept whose time has come. **********''This is something that's very widespread,'' said Mr. Bacon. ''Chief executives at corporations now talk with greater conviction of improving boards.'' **********Said Kenneth R. Andrews, editor in chief of the Harvard Business Review: ''Boards today may often be selected by the chief executive officer, but they are not beholden to him.'' **********To assess how these changes have affected certain aspects of board membership, The New York Times, using information compiled by Disclosure Inc., a computerized data base of S.E.C. documents, surveyed 8,500 publicly held companies to see how many people sit on multiple boards. Unlike the senior Mr. Weinberg's era, it is rare to find any person on more than a dozen boards. In the Disclosure survey, no one was found on more than 11 public boards - and there were only 17 people with 8 or more directorships. Of this group, a large proportion are retired executives, while a smaller proportion are active executives. **********The list of 17 includes Fred R. Sullivan, the retired chairman of Kidde Inc.; Samuel A. Casey, retired chairman of the Great Northern Nekoosa Company, and George Kozmetsky, former dean of the University of Texas business school. One black - Jerome H. Holland, chairman of the American Red Cross and former Ambassador to Sweden - and one woman - Juanita M. Kreps, former Secretary of Commerce - were also in the top 17. **********The list indicates that more outsiders are sitting on boards. The argument against inside directors - those from management as well as lawyers and investment bankers hired by the company - is that they cannot offer truly objective views. And, even more so, the growth of committees has been heralded by some as a way of, structurally at least, shifting important duties away from corporate insiders. The audit committee, for instance, oversees the audit of the company's books by an outside firm, the nominating committee recommends new directors and the executive compensation committee examines the compensation of top management. **********A survey by Korn/Ferry International, an executive search firm, of 660 major corporate boards shows that senior executives are still the most common board members - 88.2 percent of all - but the proportion has remained flat over the years. The survey also shows a drop in the percentage of directors with close ties to the company - between 1973 and 1982, attorneys hired by the company on whose boards they served fell to 28.2 percent from 51.7 percent; commercial bankers fell to 33.6 percent from 55.4 percent; investment bankers to 23.7 percent from 37.3 percent, and major shareholders to 30.4 percent from 43.1 percent. **********At the same time, other groups rose: Women board members increased to 41.2 percent from 10.7 percent; minorities to 23.2 percent from 8.9 percent, and academics to 50.4 percent from 34.9 percent. **********Still, some question whether it is all simply window dressing. Robert C. Townsend, author of ''Up the Organization,'' and former chief executive of Avis Inc., claims that in the 80 hours a year or so that board members devote to their activities, it is impossible properly to oversee a company. Indeed, he sees boards as meaningless, at best a gathering spot for retired executives. ''Boards are pastures for old horses in business,'' he said. ''They're uncomfortable anywhere but on the board or playing golf. All they are really doing is enjoying a form of a country club.'' **********Although most companies still prefer to choose executives of high standing - preferably chief executives - that's not always the best way, some say. **********William H. Donaldson, founder of the brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and former dean of the Yale School of Management, feels that corporations should look beyond the top executive in seeking board members. ''Companies should dip down and take someone who is not a chief executive,'' he said. ''An executive vice president, for instance, often has more time to give than a chief executive and can be more effective.'' **********But, cautions Gerald Roach, president and chairman of Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm, many companies resist that argument and stick with tradition. ''You worry about having unknowns because you are loath to have surprises,'' he said. ''You don't want an irascible individual who's a constant irritant and always throwing in a monkey wrench. Yet almost every board has one.'' **********Chief Executives **********Communications entrepreneur Karl Eller, now chairman and chief executive of the Circle K Corporation, a Phoenix-based chain of 1,200 convenience stories, is an active chief executives who serves on six boards. He says he likes strong boards whose members are ''willing to comment and speak up.'' **********He finds being an active chief executive important. ''I learn new ways of doing financing, new approaches to the business, new ways of doing acquisitions,'' he said. ''You learn a lot from being on boards that help you with your own company.'' **********The board taking up most of his energy right now is Eastern Air Lines, which is facing severe financial problems. ''When something like that happens, you become more involved,'' he said. ''Meetings are tripled or quadrupled and we help management make key decisions. We're a sounding board for management - trying to keep them in the right directions, adding a little bit of stability and still trying to protect the shareholder.'' **********Blacks, Women **********When Andrew F. Brimmer left the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve to start his own economic consulting firm in 1974, he had 57 offers to sit on corporate boards. He ultimately chose six. Jerome H. Holland, the former president of the Hampton Institute in Virginia, was invited to sit on 60 boards after he stepped down as United States Ambassador to Sweden. He chose 10 of these. **********The two have somewhat different views on minority board memberships. ''Members of corporate boards are members of an institution that is designed to make money and not to be an instrument of social change,'' said Mr. Brimmer. ''When a company is faced with a question of investing in new plants and equipment, I don't see how a member could take a different view depending on whether they are white or black, man or woman,'' he said. **********Mr. Holland, however, said that he has added a black perspective to his boards. ''There are times when I felt the recruitment of minority students has not been aggressive enough and I met with the personnel people,'' he said. ''This work is something I've been interested in for years. But when I graduated from college, the corporate world was virtually closed.'' **********Juanita M. Kreps, former Secretary of Commerce, who sits on 10 boards, said the ''point is past'' when corporations sought women for boards simply because they ''wanted representation from both sexes. Being a woman does a certain amount of signalling,'' she said, ''but the issues that one deals with are corporate issues and, for the most part, boards do not deal with sex-related questions.'' **********Retirees Donald S. Perkins, former chairman of the Jewel Companies, a Midwest chain of supermarkets, and Samuel A. Casey, the retired chairman of Great Northern Nekoosa, are typical of many retired executives who prefer flying to board meetings to a more sedate retirement. **********Mr. Perkins finds his board activities so time consuming that he has trouble getting away for a vacation. ''Being involved gives you pespective,'' he said. ''What you see in one area, can be helpful in another.'' Mr. Perkins added he ''doesn't want to be on a board unless the chief executive wants help,'' Nor is he afraid of the exposure to risk: ''I worry a lot more about the quality of management. I don't spend a lot of time worrying about shareholders suits.'' **********Mr. Casey proclaims to have ''no great natural aptitude for golf or fishing and I find membership on boards stimulating.'' He recoils at those who dismiss board memberships. ''If I felt I were a rubber stamp, I wouldn't serve,'' he said. ''I think the concept that board memberships are a fraternity is greatly exaggerated. Board memberships are important and serious and I work hard at it.'' **********REASON ANDPRUDENCE **********The main task of directors is to oversee the management of the companies they serve. No Federal statutes specifically define a board's duties, but most states have laws generally saying that a director must exercise ''due care'' or act as a ''reasonable and prudent person.'' **********Directors are protected from liability by ''business judgment'' case law, which suggests that a director who uses a rational basis for a decision is not liable if that decision proves wrong. **********Federal laws affect directors indirectly. The Securities and Exchange Commission, for example, requires directors to sign registration statements every time their company issues securities, and also governs directors' use of insider information. **********For all this, plus the dozen or so board meetings a year they attend, directors are paid, on average, about $30,000. Fees range from about $15,000 for small companies to $70,000 for major ones.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/busin.main_headline: IACOCCA GETS BONUS TO STAY AT CHRYSLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/busin.print_headline: IACOCCA GETS BONUS TO STAY AT CHRYSLER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Lee A. Iacocca, who has been working without a contract since he joined the Chrysler Corporation in 1978, has agreed to remain its chairman for at least three more years in return for substantial bonuses of stock and stock options. **********The agreement, which was announced today after the auto maker's board of directors met in New York, calls for Mr. Iacocca to receive 150,000 Chrysler shares - worth about $4.2 million at the present market price - three years from now plus 50,000 more shares if he stays with the company an additional year or more. **********He will also get options to buy 300,000 shares at the current price of $28 a share, to be exercisable after three years, and options for an additional 100,000 shares, exercisable after four years. **********Talk of Retirement Ended **********The action appears to settle any questions about Mr. Iacocca's future with the company. In the past he had suggested he might retire once the $1.2 billion in Government-guaranteed loans that saved the company from bankruptcy in 1979 and 1980 were repaid. **********Lately, however, he has been saying he enjoys his job now that Chrysler's fortunes have improved, and he has told associates he intends to stay. The loans were paid off this year, seven years before coming due. **********The company said its outside directors had offered the stock-and-option package to Mr. Iacocca. ''Our agreement with Lee should remove any doubt that he plans to stay with Chrysler,'' said Jean DeGrandpre, chairman of the compensation and benefits committee, in a statement. **********Comment: 'I Feel Honored' **********''His importance to the company cannot be overstated,'' Mr. DeGrandpre continued. **********In response, Mr. Iacocca said: ''I feel honored they want me to stay on board for four more years. This ought to put an end to the rumors.'' **********Analysts have given Mr. Iacocca a lot of the credit for reviving the car manufacturer. **********''I think they need him now but not as much as they did,'' said David Healy, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''Back when they were in trouble, the television commercials he did and the leadership he provided in cutting the company in half without killing it was essential.'' **********Mr. Iacocca's appearance in TV ads for Chrysler-made cars apparently helped the company's sales when its prospects looked bleak. **********First Big Chrysler Payoff **********The stock bonuses three years hence will be the first big payoff Mr. Iacocca will receive from Chrysler. He was given a bonus of $1.5 million to join the company, but that merely replaced benefits he had accumulated as president of the Ford Motor Company and had to leave behind in moving to a rival company. **********From Sept. 1, 1979, to Sept. 1, 1980, during the worst of Chrysler's financial crisis, he worked for $1 a year.  Then he resumed his salary of $360,000 a year. In 1982, according to this year's proxy statement from Chrysler, he was paid $365,676. **********In addition, he already has options to buy 902,000 Chrysler shares at prices ranging from $6.25 a share to $30.38 a share. None of them had been exercised by last July, when the last disclosure on the subject was made.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/world.main_headline: U.S. Mother Hails Soviet's Aid for Son
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; U.S. Mother Hails Soviet's Aid for Son
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/17/world.body_text: **********An American teen-ager who has undergone therapy here for a rare degenerative eye disease has such improved vision from the first treatment that he is a superb video-game player, his mother said today. **********Betty Cantrell, mother of 13-year-old Todd of Dalton, Ga., said in an interview that since her son's first treatment for retinitis pigmentosa at Moscow's Helmholtz Institute in December 1981, his expertise at video games had become ''astounding.'' **********The Cantrells brought their son back to Moscow on Saturday to receive another round of treatment for the disease, which can lead to blindness. United States doctors say it is incurable. The treatment in the Soviet Union involves injections into the eyes and hips of ribonucleic acid, a protein. **********''Todd's doctor was very shocked about some of the things he is able to do now,'' Mrs. Cantrell said. ''He said the tests don't show that he should have these abilities, but I think maybe the tests just aren't showing what these injections are doing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/08/busin.body_text: **********The former owner of Spain's largest private business empire has been charged in a Madrid court with a series of financial crimes. **********Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, the former owner of the giant holding company Rumasa, was indicted Wednesday on charges of currency smuggling, false bookkeeping and defrauding the social security system. **********Mr. Ruiz Mateos, who has lived in London since the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez nationalized his conglomerate last February, has so far ignored all summons requesting him to answer the charges. Spain has not asked to have him extradited from Britain because the two countries have no extradition treaty. **********The Government took over Rumasa's holdings on Feb. 21, saying the move was necessary to avert a huge economic collapse and to protect the interests of the holding company's stockholders and some 60,000 employees. **********Rumasa's empire consisted of 20 banks and 200 industrial, commercial and financial companies. It also controlled 32 hotels in Spain, many of the country's most important department stores, plus 20 farming companies and about 80,000 head of livestock.
