https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.main_headline: U.S. ARMY CHIEF OPPOSES SENDING COMBAT FORCES TO AID EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.print_headline: U.S. ARMY CHIEF OPPOSES SENDING COMBAT FORCES TO AID EL SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.body_text: **********Gen.  Edward C. Meyer, the Army's Chief of Staff, said today that he would oppose sending United States combat forces to El Salvador because Americans would not support them and Salvadorans were not fully committed to defeating leftist insurgents there. **********The general, in response to a series of questions during a breakfast meeting with reporters, said the United States might have to consider intervention with troops if there was turmoil after the elections in El Salvador later this year. **********But he said that option should be considered only if there was a clear identification of political purposes, statement of military objectives, and public understanding of the costs in military manpower, weapons, money and time. **********The general said his views reflected those of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the military advisers to the President. His comments were the most forthright public expression so far of the reasons senior military officers have opposed sending combat forces to Central America. **********Reaction to Vietnam Recalled **********Drawing on the lessons of Vietnam, General Meyer said it would be wrong to have ''soldiers at the end of the string without having the support of the American people.'' He said that support does not exist now, and that he would protest to the President if he saw a move toward sending troops to Central America. **********General Meyer told reporters the United States could not defeat an insurgency where ''that nation isn't fully committed to the resolution of its internal problem.'' That commitment has not been evident in Salvador, he said. **********The Reagan Administration has said American troops would not be sent to Central America except as trainers and advisers. But members of Congress and others have expressed fears that the United States would edge into Central America as it did into Vietnam 20 years ago. **********General Meyer, who will step down on June 21 after four years as the Army's top officer, said that he would recommend sending troops if he thought that would solve the guerrilla problem, but that economic assistance was more important now. **********The general, who fought in the wars in Korea and Vietnam, said: ''If I thought the 82d Airborne going there would be a solution to the problem, I would probably recommend that right now. I don't think it would be.'' **********He said that having been in a guerrilla war in Vietnam, ''I realize that unless you have the commitment of the people, of the indigenous forces, you're not going to solve a guerrilla war.'' **********General Meyer said publicly what other military officers have said privately that ''there has been a crying need to pull together the economic, political, as well as the military arms of government so that we're applying to Central America coherent programs.'' **********He said the President ''is headed in that direction'' with the naming of a special envoy for Central America and other shuffling within the Administration. The overall approach, the general said, was to wean Nicaragua from Havana and Moscow; to assist Honduras, Costa Rica and Panama to ward off leftist incursions, and to assist El Salvador through political, military and economic aid. Economic Aid 'Very Critical' **********He said that economic assistance ''is very critical because guerrilla war is based on the legitimate concerns of the people.'' He said that ''the better the nations in that area are able to respond to those legitimate needs,'' the better they would be able to prevent insurgency. **********Referring to the reluctance of Congress to approve more economic aid for Central America, General Meyer said he thought that was equally or more important than military aid. ''That's why I worry about the inability to get the economic package through that will provide support to countries in that region,'' he said. **********General Meyer contended that limiting the number of United States military advisers in El Salvador, as they are limited now to 55, was a mistake. ''I don't believe that there should be a stated ceiling on how many military go down there,'' he said. ''That provides everybody with a fixed view of exactly how you're going to handle the problem.'' **********He added that if the military needed ''sufficient advisers to do a specific job, you ought to put in that number of advisers.'' He said that the military should be able to ''surge to a larger number when you needed to perform a specific training mission.'' Consensus Called Vital **********Questioned closely on the issue of sending combat forces to El Salvador, General Meyer said, ''There should be no uncertainty in the minds of those involved that whatever is necessary, if that poses a threat to us, we are willing to do.'' **********But he said ''there will have to be a consensus within the United States populace that what we are doing is sufficiently important that American soldiers go to war.'' He added: ''You can't send soldiers off to war without having the support of the American people.'' **********He said that if the military services are not permitted to employ sufficient forces, ''then we should stand up and say we can't do that with the forces involved.'' **********''We didn't do that in Vietnam,'' General Meyer said. ''We inched our way in. Then all of a sudden we were there.'' The general, who served twice as a field officer in Vietnam, said, ''I was a bit confused as to why I was over there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********The board of Gulf and Western Industries announced yesterday that it had named Martin S. Davis as its chairman **********and chairman of the executive **********committee. Mr. Davis is **********G.& W.'s chief executive.  The post of chairman had **********been left vacant until now in **********honor of G.& W.'s founder and **********chairman, Charles G. Bluhdorn, who died in February.  Mr. Davis's appointment formalizes his control at G.& W., **********where he has put the company **********through major changes since **********taking over after Mr. Bluhdorn **********died.  Mr. Davis, 56 years old, consolidated seven operating **********groups into three - entertainment and communications, **********financial services, and consumer and industrial products **********- and named three presidents **********and chief operating officers to **********head them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply plunged $2.4 billion for the week ended Oct. 19. The decline was wider than expected and was welcomed by economists and the credit market. **********In effect, the decline came close to erasing the jump in the money supply announced a week earlier. That unexpected increase, revised yesterday by the central bank, brought $2.6 billion of new money into the nation's financial system. **********''Last week's number was a surprise on the upside and this week we have a surprise on the downside,'' said Robert A. Schwartz, senior financial economist for Merrill Lynch & Company. **********He added that the decline in M-1 - a measure that includes currency in circulation and checking and check- like deposits - may have been influenced by a change in Federal banking regulations. As of Oct. 1, the interest- rate ceiling on most certificates of deposits was removed, encouraging transfers of funds from checking accounts, which fall in to the M-1 category, into high-yielding certificates of deposit, which do not. **********Nonetheless most analysts, including Mr. Schwartz, said they had expected a smaller decline. **********''I don't expect this to trigger any immediate change in Fed policy, but it has to be regarded as good news,'' said Maury Harris, economist at Paine Webber Inc. **********In the credit market, response to the drop in money supply was subdued, with traders saying they were reluctant to expand their holdings now because of a major offering of Government securities scheduled for next week. In a regular quarterly sale, or refunding, of securities, the Treasury Department is expected to offer $16 billion in bonds. **********'Too Much Paper to Unload' **********''The reaction was muted because of the Treasury issues coming to market soon,'' said one trader. ''This is too much paper to unload at these prices, and there is not enough investor demand for it yet.'' **********But in a modest price reaction to the Fed's announcement, the bellwether 12 percent bond due in 2003 was offered at 102 12/32 for a yield of about 11.71 percent, compared to 11.69 percent on Thursday. **********The securities that will be offered in the refunding were mostly unchanged, with the three-year note offered at 10.89 percent late yesterday, the same as on Thursday. The 10-year note was offered at 11.66 percent, down from 11.68 percent, and the 12 percent bonds were quoted with a yield of 11.73 percent, unchanged. **********3-Month Bill at 8.58% **********The rates on the shorter Treasury issues moved slightly lower, with the three-month bill offered late yesterday at 8.58 percent, down from 8.61 percent. The one-year bill was offered at 8.95 percent, down from 9 percent late Thurday. **********The $2.4 billion decline in the money supply, which lowered the total M-1 to $517.4 billion, leaves the nation's basic supply of currency on the low end of the target range set by the Fed. The target is for an annualized growth rate of between 5 and 9 percent, starting at the end of the second quarter. The decline reported yesterday means that the rate of M-1 growth, which had previously been at 7 percent, is now running at 5.7 percent. **********''It means we are into the lower end of the target and gives the Fed greater latitude in easing credit,'' Mr. Schwartz said. But while lower interest rates would be welcomed by many businessmen, Mr. Schwartz and other economists said they did not expect the Fed to make any moves to ease credit soon because the economy was expanding rapidly and because lower interests might spark higher levels of inflation. **********The economists pointed to yesterday's Commerce Department report that the nation's index of leading economic indicators for September had accelerated from the previous two months, advancing nine-tenths of 1 percent in September, a signal of strong expansion. **********''If we see another decline of over $2 billion'' in M-1, ''people will start speculating about the Fed easing credit,'' Mr. Harris said. But, he added, ''slow money growth is only one prerequisite. You have to see a slowdown in the economy as well.'' **********'Good News' for Short Term **********Kathleen Cooper, a senior economist for the Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles, characterized the decline in the money supply as ''good news, but probably only for the short term.'' She said she expected the money supply to expand in the coming weeks, thus eliminating any rationale that the Fed might have for easing credit.  ''Most likely, the gains we have seen this week will be lost over the next two weeks,'' she said. **********Separately, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday that United States commercial and industrial loans fell $458 million in the week ended Oct. 18, to $215.45 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.main_headline: LEBANON, IRKED, WITHDRAWS INVITATION TO KOCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.print_headline: LEBANON, IRKED, WITHDRAWS INVITATION TO KOCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.body_text: **********Mayor Koch said today that the Lebanese Government had withdrawn its invitation to visit Beirut because he entered southern Lebanon today in an Israeli Army helicopter without clearance from the Lebanese authorities. **********Speaking by telephone from Haifa, the New York City Mayor said that he had been informed of the Lebanese decision by the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv. **********The State Department had reportedly warned him that he would get no official reception in Beirut if he entered Lebanon through Israel.  The Lebanese Government is sensitive to the symbolic nature of tours conducted by the Israelis, whose forces have been occupying southern Lebanon since June. **********To solve the problem, the State Department had arranged for Mayor Koch to fly Friday by helicopter to a United States aircraft carrier in the Mediterranean, and from there to Beirut. Today's visit to southern Lebanon was a separate trip, which the Mayor said had been arranged and announced eight days ago, before the Lebanese Government extended its invitation. **********The Lebanese authorities told him today, he said, that he could still visit Beirut, but only as a private citizen, without any official meetings. **********''This would not be as productive,'' he declared, adding that he had been hoping to meet with a cross-section of leaders in Lebanon, as he has in Israel, where he arrived Friday. Without such an opportunity, he felt, he might as well go back to New York. **********Mr. Koch said Monday, after a meeting with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, that he found good sense in Israel's position on Lebanon - both in the rationale for the invasion to end the Palestinian threat to northern Israel and in the determination now to withdraw simultaneously with Syria. **********He said that he was impressed, on his visit today to the Israeli border town of Qiryat Shmona, with the difference between the tranquil life at present and the town's previous vulnerability to rocket attacks from across the Lebanese border. He said he had visited an underground shelter and heard accounts of the attacks that plagued the community in years past. **********An Israeli helicopter then took him to Nabatiye, Sidon and Tyre, but the Mayor portrayed his encounters with some of the Lebanese officials under Israeli occupation as uninformative. In Nabatiye, he said, Mayor Mustafa Jaber was ''not very communicative,'' and Lebanese reporters who questioned Mr. Koch were ''quite hostile.'' **********In Sidon, he said, ''the Mayor didn't show.'' A Deputy Mayor did appear, but Mr. Koch said that ''no matter what I asked, he was noncommittal, saying, 'I don't know.' '' **********He said that he had learned more in Tyre, a former stronghold of the Palestine Liberation Organization. There, the Mayor and the area's governor were ''both very outgoing, very forceful, responsive,'' Mr. Koch said. **********''What they said was that, prior to the Israeli invasion, the P.L.O. was the government,'' he reported. ---- Koch in Exchange With Reporters **********NABATIYE, Lebanon, March 1 (AP) - Mayor Koch was asked angry questions today by Lebanese reporters who said the Israeli invasion had killed civilians here, but he replied that Israel had acted to stop attacks by the Palestine Liberation Organization on Israeli border towns. **********When asked why the United States had provided the shells that caused the civilian deaths, Mr. Koch said: ''If the P.L.O. locates itself in civilian areas, then whoever comes to destroy the P.L.O.  regrettably but understandably is going to cause civilian casualties.'' **********He recalled his own army days in World War II when he served as an infantry sergeant in Europe, saying that civilians had been killed because the Germans had hidden weapons among them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Japan and the Soviet Union have agreed to meet on trade problems, the Foreign Ministry said today. **********Tokyo had suspended annual trade talks with the Russians as part of Western sanctions, imposed over the situation in Poland. **********The ministry said that Japan was not prepared to resume the annual talks, last held in January 1981, but was willing to discuss bilateral trade problems. **********Trade between the two countries totaled $5.6 billion in 1982, the ministry said, adding that in the first half of this year trade had fallen by 20 percent, to $2.4 billion, from the comparable period in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.main_headline: Rowdyism Blamed for Deaths Of 2 Women in London Crowd
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.print_headline: Rowdyism Blamed for Deaths Of 2 Women in London Crowd
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.body_text: **********Witnesses blamed rowdyism for the trampling to death of two women early today during New Year's Eve celebrations in Trafalgar Square. **********The London Ambulance Service said that a young man in the surging crowd of revelers also died of a heart attack during the disturbances. **********A spokesman said the two women were crushed after they fell when a crowd barrier collapsed. Thirty-six other people, 25 men and 11 women, where injured in the surge. **********Witnesses said the traditional New Year's revelry, which drew a crowd of more than 100,000, turned ugly, with a lot of drunkenness, hooliganism, bottle-throwing and fights. Scotland Yard said 50 people had been arrested for offenses against public order. **********Volunteer first aid workers said they had treated 502 people in the square. The ambulance service said 115 had been taken to hospitals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.body_text: **********The nation's first two-way home electronic information system started formal operations here today, backed by a $1.5 million advertising campaign. **********Industry analysts are not sure how consumers will respond. **********Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., publishers of The Miami Herald and other daily newspapers, is spending $29 million to start Viewtron, a computer controlled service providing text and graphics over telephone lines to a user's television set. **********Customers paying $600 for a terminal made by the American Telephone & Telegraph Company can issue instructions to Viewtron that include selecting news items, playing games, ordering airplane tickets, checking sports scores and making deductions from a checking account to pay bills. **********''Viewtron is instantaneous text - all the information I can imagine when I want it, the 21st century genie,'' said Morton Goldstrom 3d, director of marketing for the Viewdata Corporation of America, the Knight- Ridder unit that developed Viewtron. **********Full-Color Graphics **********Viewtron is part of the technology known as videotex. Teletext, which presents words on a screen without graphics, is already available for home computer owners. Knight-Ridder and other publishers planning entries into videotex are convinced that the addition of full-color graphics will make videotex more attractive to both advertisers and consumers. **********After seven years of development, Viewtron became available to the public last week. The ad campaign that started today to promote the system is being supported equally by Knight-Ridder and A.T.& T. **********Knight-Ridder hopes to sign up 5,000 customers during the first year in three south Florida counties, which have a population of three million. The $600 terminal, named Sceptre, is being sold at department stores, A.T.& T. Phone Center stores and video and computer retailers. **********In addition to the terminal, customers pay $12 a month to Viewdata for the Viewtron service and $1 an hour to Southern Bell, the local telephone company, for access to the system. **********Uncertainty Over Prospects **********Industry analysts are uncertain of the prospects for Viewtron, which is competing with teletext systems available to home computer owners. Home computers cost less and are more versatile than the Sceptre, according to some analysts. **********''A knowledgeable buyer would not buy a Sceptre terminal because it's expensive and will soon be obsolete,'' said Mark R. Kriss, an analyst with the Yankee Group in Boston. ''If Sceptre were selling for $79.95, I would have a very different overall assessment of Viewtron.'' **********''I don't think the Sceptre terminal has a very long life,'' added David Simons, a consultant with Digital Video Corporation of New York. ''By 1987, virtually every home computer on the market will have videotex capabilities.'' **********But Albert J. Gillen, president of Viewdata, said market tests in 1980 and 1981 showed that customers would be willing to pay $600 for a Viewtron terminal. Also, he noted, Viewtron provided the equivalent of $1,400 to $1,800 a month in programming for just $12. **********Turnover Rate and Daily Use **********The measure of Viewtron's success, industry watchers say, will be the subscriber turnover rate and the amount of daily use once the initial ''novelty effect'' wears off. **********Viewdata executives and industry analysts agree, however, that Videotex will undergo many changes in the next few years. **********''Viewtron is a beautiful baby, but by the time it grows up the industry will look very different,'' said Gary Arlen, publisher of International Videotex Teletext News in Bethesda, Md. Knight-Ridder has tentative agreements with newspaper publishers in 17 other cities to expand Viewtron if the south Florida system draws sufficient consumer interest. **********Keycom, a videotex system developed by Field Enterprises Inc., publisher of The Chicago Sun Times, the Centel Corporation and the Honeywell Corporation, is scheduled to start on April 15 in the Chicago area. **********The Times-Mirror Corporation, publisher of The Los Angeles Times, and Infomart of Toronto are planning a Videotex system named Gateway in Orange County, Calif., in mid-1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.body_text: **********HIGH TECHNOLOGY and military spending are providing new jobs in the New England states, but some other industries have yet to experience a recovery, according to economic experts. **********''There are definite signs of strength, but the boom times are not here just yet,'' said Dennis M. McSweeney, assistant regional commissioner at the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics in Boston. The July unemployment rate for all of New England was 6.8 percent, according to the bureau's figures, 2.6 percent below the national figure. **********Nashua, N.H., and Burlington, Vt. - both centers for high-technology companies - have experienced strong job growth over the last several months. Massachusetts, with its strong high-technology and service industries, has the lowest unemployment rate of the 10 largest industrial states - about 5.6 percent. **********Job prospects in Massachusetts are good for accountants, auditors, high-technology consultants, nurses and doctors; such services are growing the fastest of any sector, according to Mr. McSweeney.  According to the Massachusetts Division of Employment Security, the outlook through 1990 is also very good for electrical engineers, systems analysts and computer programmers. **********Massachusetts still has pockets of high unemployment, however. Fall River, an old textile mill town, and Pittsfield, a machine-manufacturing center, still have double-digit jobless rates. **********Employment in the machinery and fabricated-metals industries remains low, affecting skilled blue-collar workers in western Massachusetts as well as much of Connecticut, New Hampshire and Vermont. Lynn E. Browne, vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, said such durable-goods manufacturing was ''associated with investment spending and so typically lags in a recovery.'' **********Mrs. Browne said New England's recovery was lagging partly because the recession was not very severe here to begin with, and partly because the region is active in exports, which have been low. **********Many companies with military contracts, however, are doing well. General Dynamics is expanding its Quincy, Mass., shipyard and hiring some experienced workers in Rhode Island and Connecticut, according to a company spokesman. Bath Ironworks in Maine, a Navy contractor, laid off 700 workers in the last few months, a company spokesman said. But he added that its new repair facility in Portland would open next month and by 1986 hire 1,000 people, from systems analysts to shipfitters. **********Construction is also beginning to pick up elsewhere in Maine, which should benefit not only carpenters and painters but also workers in the state's lumber industry, according to Carl E. Veazie, a research economist at the University of Southern Maine. He said the wood and paper industry, which employs highly skilled machine operators, lost some 500 jobs in the year ending in July.  Janelle Conaway **********THIS region is one of the more diverse economic sections of the country, ranging from the bustling high-technology Baltimore- Washington corridor with its concentration of aerospace-research centers dubbed ''Satellite Alley'' to the hard-hit northwestern section of Pennsylvania, where communities are still waiting for the steel industry to bounce back.  Maryland and Virginia, with a heavy dependence on Federal contracts that tend to make them recession-proof, are both doing well with the Reagan Administration's emphasis on a military build-up. But officials in most states are preoccupied with taking advantage of the growth in high technology to decrease unemployment. **********In Virginia, for example, Gov. Charles S. Robb is devising plans for a center for innovative technology in the northern part of his state. And in Pennsylvania, Gov. Richard L. Thornburgh has announced a $38 million Ben Franklin Partnership plan, where the state's top universities help small businesses with new technology. **********But high technology is not without its critics. Norman Robertson, chief economist at Pittsburgh's Mellon Bank, said he did not believe that high technology offered ''the sort of employmant panacea that many people seem to believe.'' **********''The high-technology industries really do not generate that many employment opportunities, and, what's more, the pay scales of those jobs are often very much below the manufacturing ones that they may have displaced.'' he said. **********Brooks Robinson, president of the Regional Industrial Development Corporation in Pittsburgh, said that the northwestern part of Pennsylvania was still doing poorly, but that some small businesses - those taking advantage of high technology - were thriving. **********Some of the states have also tried encouraging businesses to relocate to their more depressed sections, often by restructuring their tax codes to offer businesses financial attractions, as Governor Thornburgh is trying to do. ''In a time of recession, it doesn't make sense to increase business taxes,'' said Walter Plosila, a deputy secretary in Pennsylvania's Department of Commerce. Evan Schuman **********RECOVERY in the Middle West is not quite keeping up with the pace in the rest of the nation.  Service and high-technology industries are gradually filling the employment gap left by heavy-industry shutdowns or slowdowns. But openings for new jobs in general are expected to be below the national average, according to the Manpower Inc. Employment Outlook Survey. **********But the publication also states that ''hiring intentions in the Midwest are far ahead of past fourth quarter figures,''and ''are much better than those of one year ago.'' **********The strongest surge is expected to be in wholesaling and retailing, with a third of the businesses in those categories expected to hire more employees, said Manpower Inc. **********The region is busy with job-retraining programs for many of the 2.6 million unemployed workers - nearly a fourth of the nation's total - in Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin. **********Service jobs that some companies considered ''frills'' during hard times are making a comeback, according to Ellen Kirk, president of the Plaza Inc. employment agency, which specializes in advertising, marketing and public relations. ''Now, they're saying, 'We need to catch up,' '' she said, ''and specialists in this area are being courted in 60 different directions.'' **********Michigan, with 13 percent unemployment, has a lion's share of the region's long-term unemployed. About a quarter of its 300,000 jobless having been out of work for more than six months. **********Von Logan, director of the Bureau of Research and Statistics for the Michigan Employment Security Commission, said those going into or switching to the expanding high-technology and service industries will be more likely to find jobs if they go beyond basic training. Among the growing employment categories are equipment-repair services, secretarial, especially for those with word-processing skills; engineering and health But, he cautioned,''I don't want to leave the impression that anyone who is trained in those areas is going to just walk into a job.'' **********In Indiana, Theodore Popoff, of the Indiana Occupational Information Coordinating Committee, is somewhat more optimistic. ''Employment is picking up,'' he said. Communications, including computer information, is a a growing field, he said, and agribusiness needs more workers in nurseries, gardening, farm-equipment sales and repair. **********Mr. Popoff said that while manufacturing jobs were not increasing, robotization had not made the dent in the work force that was expected. ''We're finding that we still need people who know how to watch the robots,'' he said. Also, he noted, smaller firms find that if they robotize one section of a plant, it can create a jam up in other areas, ''because the robots work faster.'' **********In Minnesota, a 40 percent growth by 1985 is expected in the need for for architects, health aides, office machine and radio and television repairers, buyers and shippers of farm products, retail buyers, bankers, legal and medical secretaries, dental hygienists and child-care workers, among other fields. **********Things are ''picking up a little'' in Wisconsin, said Tom Rondou of the state's Department of Industry, Labor and Human Relations. The best prospects are in the service industries and retail sales, and the state's heavy-machinery and paper-manufacturing industries are showing a small increase. Susan Saiter **********WITH some exceptions, job prospects in the Southwest will remain dim for as long as the slump in the oil industry continues. And most economic observers are cautious about how long that will be. ''There will be some improvement, but anyone who's expecting a remarkable turnaround is kidding himself,'' said Robert Fumston, director of the Oklahoma Employment Security Commission. **********The decline in the once fast-growing and highly attractive regional job market could not have been more striking. Last year, for example, the number of jobs in Texas fell by 110,500, after having increased at an average annual rate of close to 200,000 the previous four years. In July, the unemployment picture was glum throughout the region with a 12.4 percent jobless rate in Louisiana the worst. **********The biggest losses continue to come in the energy-related fields. Everyone from petroleum engineers to finance managers who do business with oil companies to geologists has been hit hard. **********Droughts have dealt heavy blows to once promising farming job opportunities in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisana and Arkansas. And along the Mexico-United States border, the devaluation of the peso has all but devastated border towns like Laredo, Tex., where unemployment stood at 26.2 percent last July, the highest in the nation. **********But the Southwest has not lost its luster entirely, particularly in areas with economies not tied to the energy industry. In Arkansas, for example, manufactoring jobs are up for the first time in two years. Arizona is making a comeback in construction and tourism and is also experiencing a boom of sorts in high technology. **********A similar boom is being felt along the so- called ''Silicon Gulch'' corridor running from Dallas to San Antonio, where electronics engineers, computer technologists and skilled assembly-line workers are in demand.  Even many of the more economically troubled sections of the Southwest are beginning to benefit from an array of personal-service jobs spurred by the region's spiraling population. **********Opportunities in health care, accounting, wholesale and retail sales and real estate are emerging in some cities that are otherwise suffering. Nurses and health-care specialists are in sharp demand in the major medical centers in Houston and New Orleans. **********Still, the predominant economic force in the region is energy, an industry battered by softening oil pices and by the national recession. Few economists are holding out much hope for a speedy recovery and point to such companies as Hughes Tool Inc. of Houston, an oilfield-equipment producer that has been forced to lay off 7,000 employees the last 14 months. Jonathan Dahl **********ECONOMISTS in this region agree that the Southeastern seabord states were less affected by the national recession and will recover more quickly. Unemployment rates in these states fell below the 9.3 percent national level. However, while the three inland states of Alabama, Mississippi and Tennessee showed some improvement, they remained in the double- digit range. **********Economists disagree on how long the current rally will last. Donald Ratajczak, director of the economic forecasting project at the Atlanta-based Georgia State University, sees it waning rapidly. On the other hand, Lewis R. Jones, associate economist for The Trust Company of Georgia, predicts it will run a good year and a half. **********The total job force in the Southeast is about 14.5 million up a little less than a 1/4 million over last year (and a good 3 million shy of a 1978 Labor Department report that asserted that come 1985 some 17.5 million people would be employed in the region). ''Nobody predicted the severity of the recession, '' says Donald M. Cruse, Atlanta- based regional commissioner of the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********On the positive side, the national surge in housing construction has brought record employment in the carpeting business centered on Dalton in northern Georgia (up 10 percent in July from a December level of 27,500 workers). It augurs well for the lumber and wood-products industry mainly in Florida (up 8.5 percent this August over last August's figure of 13,000). The furniture industry in Tennessee and the Carolinas also made substantial gains (up 5.8 percent over the August l982 work force of 150,700). **********However, textiles, especially important in North Carolina, have not snapped back as much as expected (up only 2 percent this past July from December's 219,000 workers). The reason is a decline in exports traceable to the strength of the dollar. **********Even in the most troubled areas, with 75 percent of the population covered either by government or private insurance plans, employment in health services is doing well. **********Because of Florida's demographics - a large elderly population that is the most frequent consumer of medical care - that state is again the leader in this field. Out of 900,000 service-sector jobs, 250,000 are in health-related areas. Most of the new workers are low-paid attendants in extended-care facilities such as nursing homes. There is also a big demand for practical nurses. **********Other expanding fields include work for defense contractors and business products such as computers, which are expected to grow by 10 percent in Florida over the next five years. Also, as the economic scene begins to clear, experts once again expect improvement in manufacturing with a slow comeback of industrial machinery in Mississippi and small appliances in Tennessee. Continued growth in the service sector, finance and insurance is also expected. Kerry Gruson **********THE shutdown of huge energy development and mining projects in the Rocky Mountain West has spun the region into the downside of its historic pattern of boom and bust. Some states have been hurt worse than others. **********Wyoming, for instance, has had to ''bite the bullet,'' according to Charles Skinner, a statistical analyst for the Employment Security Commission in Casper. **********''Wyoming depends heavily on oil, gas, coal and uranium,'' said Mr. Skinner. ''Now, because of surpluses and because the public has been screaming against nuclear energy, the other states aren't calling for us. We lag behind the rest of the country by 6 to 18 months. He noted that Wyoming's unemployment rate, the lowest in the nation until 1981, is now between 10 and 11 percent. **********In Colorado, where Exxon canceled the largest shale-oil development in the country, energy unemployment runs high. ''There is a redundancy of geologists and engineers,'' said Kenneth McNulty, an economist with the Division of Employment Training. Yet Colorado, with a projected economic growth rate of 3 percent in the next year, fares better than its neighbors because its economy is more diversified. **********Mr. McNulty said the state would experience vigorous growth in the health-services and business-services sectors. Computer and information-systems companies will remain strong, he said. The mining industry is expected to remain depressed for at least another 12 months, Mr. McNulty said, although he predicted a growth rate of nearly 2 percent. ''Juxtaposed against recent past growth rates of 10 to 15 percent, that's not very good,'' Mr. McNulty said. **********Utah is ''coming slowly out of the recession,'' according to Ronald Ahlstrom, supervising economist of the occupational division of the state's Labor Market Information office. Unemployment is down from a high last October of 9 percent to 7.2 percent as of August, and an unemployment rate of about 7.8 percent is anticipated in the coming year. ''All areas are recovering except for the mining of primary metals such as copper,'' Mr. Ahlstrom said. **********In Idaho, James Day, research director of the state's Department of Employment, said that ''we have been hit by the worst depression since the 1930's,'' The lack of demand for the state's lumber because of rising interest rates and declining construction pushed the unemployment figures in some areas to about 50 percent, Mr. Day said. Idaho's best growth has been in the computer field, and the Boise-based Hewlett-Packard operation has expanded its work force every year. Dyan Zaslowsky **********AFTER months of battering by a recession that bruised even the traditionally stable industries, the job market in the Western states is showing new signs of life. Modest turnarounds in key manufacturing and gaming industries in California and Nevada have buoyed the related service and business fields that employ the bulk of the region's workers. **********Employment prospects in California look best for those with skills in high-technology, electronics and health-care fields. With its seasonally adjusted unemployment rate of 9.8 percent in August, down from the previous August's 10.3 percent, the state has few areas that have shown absolute gains. **********But in recent months, the slides in manufacturing and construction have leveled off, and wholesale and retail trade have nearly returned to their record highs of 1981. Aerospace and technology industries, helped by government contracts and resurging markets, expect to leave last year's slump behind. **********National Semiconductor, a ''Silicon Valley'' giant that lost 1,000 total jobs last year, has hired back most of those laid off in the area and currently has about 650 job openings. It also has announced plans for a new $75 million research center. ''Things look very, very high now,'' said Susan Peterson, employment manager. **********Northrop Corporation, an aircraft, electronics and aerospace firm, has opened its new $52 million expansion in its electronics division, and has broken ground for an electro-mechanical laboratory in Orange County. **********''We've experienced growth in all three sectors,'' said Maria Oharenko, a company spokesman. ''There are openings throughout the company, mostly for engineers and skilled assemblers.'' **********Nevada's unemployment rate, after peaking in January at 11.9 percent, has dropped to 9.3 percent, and analysts expect the downward trend to continue. ''We found for the first time that the recession did affect the gaming industry, but it was the last area of the state to go,'' said Jim Avance, chairman of the state's Gaming Control Board. **********''Tourism has picked up dramatically, as shown by sales-tax revenues and tourist indicators,'' said Robert Murdock, a state labor analyst. Gaming and its related services such as hotels, restaurants and recreation employ 45 percent of all workers statewide. ''Construction permits have skyrocketed, and even though that doesn't translate into dollars spent, it's a good sign.'' **********Mr. Murdock said the job slump had caused the state to reassess its marketing, and many businesses are competing for the renewed flow of tourist dollars. Several hotels and casinos, including the Hilton, the Mint, the Sahara Tahoe and the Union Plaza, are remodeling or expanding. **********''We think the recession has bottomed out, and that things should go up slowly from here,'' Mr. Murdock said. **********Pauline Yoshihashi **********THE Northwest is slowly pulling out of its economic slump, but creation of new jobs is not expected in the near future. A year ago the region's unemployment was one of the highest in the nation, and its major industries - aerospace, forest products, construction and agriculture - wallowed in a severe downturn. Those industries, however, are starting to show modest rebounds with the upturn in the nation's economy. **********In July 1982 unemployment in the state of Washington was the sixth highest in the nation as a result of the recession. This summer the state recovered a bit, moving up to 13th in percentage of unemployed. **********But employment consultants advise that because of the 10.5 percent jobless rate, industries that are taking on personnel in months to come most likely will be rehiring those laid off earlier. Creation of new jobs is not expected until well into 1984. ''Job availability is improving,'' said Ron Wahlers, an economist with the Washington State Employment Security Office. ''We are in a lot better shape now than last year at this time,'' **********The slight upturn in housing nationally should help accelerate the moderate pickup that the Northwest's forest-products industries are experiencing. The growth depends on low interest rates nationally, and job growth in this industry could ebb if interest rates rise in the months ahead. **********Electronics, a new industry for the Northwest, is also experiencing a moderate upturn. But creation of new technical jobs is not yet in sight. Most electronics jobs today are at the entry level, and companies prefer to train people for the available jobs - mostly assembly-line work. **********Moderate improvement also is expected in the construction industry, but labor analysts are unenthusiastic about the immediate outlook for jobs. Local hires are expected first, and out-of-state workers are not expected to be drawn to the region for another year, when work picks up on highway construction. **********Demand for experienced nuclear-plant craftsmen and technical workers could develop in 1984 if construction resumes on one nuclear reactor of the Washington Public Power Supply system, on which construction has been slowed. Short-term layoffs will continue on the state's financially beleaguered nuclear-plant construction program. The only jobs being created are for lawyers: virtually every major law firm in the Northwest is enmeshed in a myriad of lawsuits surrounding the Supply System in the wake of its default on $2.25 billion in bonds floated to construct two nuclear plants. **********Health services still remain strong, with a demand for nurses and clerical support staff. Industries such as aluminum also are showing upturns. Retail and service sectors are showing steady improvement as the region slowly pulls out of the recession. **********Mr. Wahlers said, ''Aerospace seems to be our only big problem right now.'' Layoffs have nearly bottomed out at the Boeing Company in Seattle, where 8,800 people have been furloughed so far this year, and an increase in airplane orders is expected only to stabilize the existing aerospace work force rather than create new jobs. Harriet King

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.main_headline: U.S. BACKS BANK SEAT FOR CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.print_headline: U.S. BACKS BANK SEAT FOR CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration has decided to support China's request to join the Asian Development Bank, but it is trying to prevent the expulsion of Taiwan, Administration officials said today. **********A State Department official said that Peking's request to replace Taiwan in the bank, of which Taiwan was a charter member in 1966, poses a major problem for the Administration. The bank, supported by contributions from both Western and Asian countries, provides development assistance in Asia. **********Washington has decided that as part of its normalization accord with Peking in 1979, it must support Peking's application to represent the Chinese people in the bank. But it has informed the bank's board of directors that it regards Taiwan as a major economic force in Asia and that this should be recognized. **********Moreover, in 1980 Congress passed a joint resolution requiring a review of American participation and financing for the Asian bank if Taiwan were expelled. 'Serious Implications' **********''How this issue will be resolved is not clear,'' a State Department official said today. ''However, we have made it clear that the expulsion of Taiwan would have serious implications for continued United States participation and funding for the Asian Development Bank,'' he added. **********The comments represented the first expression of American policy on the matter since the Chinese made their request known through bank channels several months ago. **********The United States has contributed $1.4 billion since the bank's founding in 1966, of which $274 million was actually paid to the bank. The rest was so-called callable capital, which does not leave the United States Treasury but serves as collateral for private loans. **********In addition, the United States has paid $774 million in cash to the Asian Development Fund, which provides so-called soft loans to developing nations at a 1 percent interest rate. The bank itself provides so-called hard loans at 11 percent. **********The American contributions to both the Asian Development Bank and the Asian Development Fund amount to 16.3 percent of the capital. U.S. Argument **********China has succeeded in expelling Taiwan from both the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. **********But Administration officials said there was a difference in trying to remove Taiwan from the Asian Development Bank. They said that Taiwan, or the Republic of China, as it officially calls itself, was a member of the I.M.F. and World Bank when they were founded at the end of World War II, and the Nationalists were the legal Government of all China. **********Thus, they said, an argument could be made, as it was in the United Nations when Peking replaced Taiwan in 1971, that the Peking Government should replace Taiwan since it represented the bulk of the Chinese population. **********But the Administration officials said that the Nationalist Government had helped to found the Asian bank in 1966, when it controlled only Taiwan and some other islands, and was clearly not in control of the mainland. Thus, they said, Peking cannot claim that Taiwan is posing as the representative of all the Chinese people. **********Nevertheless, Peking seems eager to replace Taiwan in all international organizations. And a State Department official said, ''The United States recognizes the People's Republic of China as the sole, legal government of China and as the representative of China in international organizations.'' **********''According to the bank, the P.R.C. meets the criteria for membership in the bank,'' it said. ''We would not support a status for Taiwan in which it appeared to represent China.''''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/09/busin.body_text: **********W.R. Grace & Company, already the nation's largest operator of home improvement stores, will announce today the start of a new division, House Works, with five new, deluxe home center stores to open in the New Orleans market by May 1. Three of the stores, which will have an average of 55,000 square feet compared with an average of 30,000 square feet in Grace's existing stores, will be in former Woolco stores that have been closed by the F.W. Woolworth Company. **********The venture, starting March 16 with the opening of the first store, will operate as an independent chain in the central region of Grace's home centers division. Grace will spend more than $40 million to open the five stores. **********Last year, Grace had sales of $875 million in its home centers, which include Channel, Handy Dan, Handy City, Angel's and Orchard Supply stores. Daryl Lansdale, president of Grace's central region of home centers, said the House Works stores would be fully enclosed stores situated in strip centers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Pros and Cons Of O-T-C Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Pros and Cons Of O-T-C Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.body_text: **********ADHERING to the mandate of Congress and the blessing of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the National Association of Securities Dealers has broadly expanded its Nasdaq national market system. The move adds 100 stocks to the 84 already trading in the advanced system. **********The N.A.S.D. regulates the over-the-counter market in unlisted securities and, through its Nasdaq subsidiary, operates an electronic communications network for 3,700 stocks. **********But the national market system, called NMS, is the more revolutionary sector. Far more than a communications network, it provides trade reports within 90 seconds of a transaction as well as current volume. Until the system went into operation last April, this type of data was available only for securities traded on stock exchanges. **********Quotations for the 3,500 other Nasdaq stocks are disseminated through dealers acting as market makers.  Starting yesterday, The New York Times began carrying the daily volume, trading range, last price and net change from the previous trading day for stocks on the enlarged list. **********Newcomers to NMS include such diverse companies as Genentech, Goulds Pumps, Bob Evans Farms, Rival Manufacturing, Longview Fibre, Micom Systems, Equity Oil, Olympia Brewing and Kinder-Care Learning Centers. **********Already on board were, among others, Intel, Pabst Brewing, Tampax, Apple Computer and MCI Communications (the undisputed volume champion of over-the-counter issues). **********Stocks are selected for the list if they maintain certain levels of trading volume at prices above $5 a share at year-end.  ''The powerful appeal of NMS is that it gives companies and investors the best of both worlds,'' said Gordon S. Macklin, president of the N.A.S.D., when he announced the expanded roster.  ''It provides the continuous transaction data of the exchanges and the vigorous competition among multiple market makers that is the unique strength of Nasdaq.'' **********But, as often happens, responses toward any structural change - to use a phrase favored by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan when he headed Merrill Lynch -''depend upon whose ox is gored.'' **********In this case, many over-the-counter dealers who negotiate the transactions are decidedly unhappy about the Nasdaq national market system. **********''They'd better come up with a better system,'' said one irate trader for a large member firm of the New York Stock Exchange. ''This one hurts the traders and it confuses the public. ''The last-sale price in the NMS often does not truly reflect the inside market of bid-and-asked prices.'' **********Another complaint is that pension funds and other institutional investors sometimes use the last-sale data as negotiating leverage when they want to transact business. ''Such tactics,'' an N.A.S.D.  official acknowledged, ''do not improve the profitability of traders.'' **********At another large brokerage firm, the head of the over-the-counter trading desk complained that the national market system had led to much narrower spreads between bid and asked prices for some stocks - a development that impairs dealer' profits but often means better prices for investors. **********''We trade a lot of MCI Communications with a spread of one-eighth of a point, and it's basically become a loss leader for us,'' he said. ''When you get an over-the-counter stock that has to be researched and then promoted, you want, say, a half-point spread as an incentive to do business.'' **********The system, furthermore, requires the constant entry of trade reports, which consumes employee time but does nothing to enhance profits for a brokerage house. **********The litany of complaints at trading desks in Wall Street and elsewhere even extends to the equipment. ''There's an awful lot of down time on the terminals,'' one trader said. **********Some institutional investors, however, offer praise for NMS.  ''It's much easier to get a feel for the trend of a stock through the volume and last-sale reports,'' a trader for a bank trust department said. ''However, maybe 5 or 10 percent of the time the reported last sale is not reflective of the true market in a stock.  I'd have to say that last-sale prices on the New York Stock Exchange are more within the framework of the actual market.'' **********Despite the complaints, the Nasdaq national market system is here to stay, and it seems destined to expand. Meanwhile, it is the expressed long-range aim of Congress for listed and unlisted securities meeting certain criteria to be traded competitively by both exchange specialists and off-board market makers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/world.print_headline: Around the World; Turkey Tightens Curbs On Political Foes
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/05/world.body_text: **********Turkey's ruling generals today gave local martial law commanders the power to expel from their areas people they regard as a threat to national security or public order. **********The new law appeared intended to stop political activity by suspected extremists or banned politicians before a general election scheduled for Nov. 6. **********It allows local commanders to confine people to their home districts or to other restricted areas.  Those expelled from one martial law region would be forced to live for five years in another region designated by the Interior Ministry.  A decree this week confined 16 politicians, including former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel, to the Dardanelles port of Canakkale until the election.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.main_headline: Chief's Son Moves Up To No. 2 Spot at Beker
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief's Son Moves Up To No. 2 Spot at Beker
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.body_text: **********One company that is making the line of succession to its top executive position clear is Beker Industries, a manufacturer of phosphate-based fertilizers. Yesterday, Erol Beker, the company's 64-year-old founder, chairman and chief executive officer, announced the promotion of his son, Erol Y. Beker, 27, to president and chief operating officer. **********In an interview, the senior Mr. Beker, who had been president, said his son is indeed being groomed as his successor. The junior Mr. Beker received a master's degree in business administration from Columbia University when he was 20 and joined the company, based in Greenwich, Conn., in 1979. He has moved through a succession of jobs in purchasing, marketing and financial planning, and most recently held the position of executive vice president and assistant to the chief executive officer. **********Cecil D. Andrus, the former Secretary of Interior and a member of the Beker board, said yesterday that the younger Mr. Beker had ''passed every test well'' at the company. And the senior Mr. Beker said that ''as of today, my son runs the operations and I set the policy'' of Beker. **********The company was founded by Mr. Beker in 1971 when he purchased two fertilizer plants from the Hooker Chemical Company, which had been ordered by the Justice Department to divest itself of them in connection with its acquisition by the Occidental Petroleum Company. Recently, Beker has been hurt by depressed conditions in the agricultural market. It earned $304,000, or 3 cents a share, in the second quarter, after two years of steady losses. **********For his part, the junior Mr. Beker rebuffed the suggestion that his authority at the company may be handicapped by his youth. ''Every key operations man has already been hired by me,'' he said, ''and that answers that.'' **********An unanswered question for Beker, however, is when its current chairman will elect to retire. ''I have no retirement plans and I don't plan to slow down,'' the senior Mr. Beker said. ''They may have to carry me out feet first.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.main_headline: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. RESPONSE TO ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.print_headline: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. RESPONSE TO ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from the text of a statement issued by the State Department Wednesday night in reply to new arms proposals by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader: **********The Androvpov interview contains several elements. It contains certain proposals regarding I.N.F. negotiations about which we will seek additional information and clarification when they are presented in Geneva. **********The public presentation of these proposals before they were presented in the negotiations in Geneva shows that the Soviet intention is to split the allies and their public. **********In other respects, the interview appears to have little new and continues to misrepresent the facts and to attach unacceptable conditions for any agreement. **********Regarding the specifics in the Andropov statement: **********The offer for a freeze on Soviet SS- 20 levels in the Asian U.S.S.R. seems to entail Soviet acceptance of our longstanding views that L.R. I.N.F. missiles must be treated on a global basis. **********The proposal regarding aircraft is too vague to evaluate at this point. As the President said in September, we are prepared to explore possible limitations on I.N.F. aircraft and to hear Soviet views on how such limitations could be formulated within the framework of our criteria for an agreement. Thus we hope the Soviets will be prepared to explain the Andropov statement on aircraft. **********However, the Soviet position outlined by Andropov contains a number of critical shortcomings: **********It involves no change whatsoever from the Soviet position that there should be no U.S. deployments and that the Soviets must be compensated for British and French forces. **********The Soviet offer to reduce to about 140 missiles in Europe suggests Soviet recognition that a balance does not now exist, and should be established through Soviet reductions. The Soviet Union still seeks however, a monopoly on I.N.F. missiles which would leave it with some 750 warheads on launchers while the U.S. had none. **********It seeks to legitimatize the buildup of SS-20's in the Far East. There is no justification whatever for the Soviet SS-20 buildup in Asia. The offer of a freeze additionally contains a number of loopholes and ambiguities which make it unclear that Soviet deployments would actually be affected. **********On the offer for unilateral reductions of I.N.F. missiles, if the U.S. and allies accepted a delay in their own deployment schedule, the Soviet offer would apply only to obsolescent SS-4 missiles, which are in any case being removed, not the SS-20's. Given the apparent Soviet concept of a moratorium, the Soviets whould be free to continue deploying SS-20's within range of Europe. **********Finally, the Soviet threat to end the negotiations with the appearance of U.S. missiles in Europe is totally unjustified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, with longterm bond prices falling more than a point, while Treasury bill prices dipped enough to raise rates by more than a tenth of a percentage point in some cases. **********The drop in the Treasury bond market came just one day after the closely watched 10 3/8 percent issue due in 2012 had flirted with its peak price of 100 1/2 set early last November. According to many analysts, the Treasury market had rallied too far too fast, leading many traders to sell their holdings and lock in profits. As recently as April 4, the 10 3/8 percent bond was offered as low as 97 1/2 to yield 10.65 percent. Yesterday, it closed at 99 6/32 to yield 10.46 percent. **********Prices began declining as soon as trading began, analysts said, partly because some dealers had received sell orders from Far Eastern investors late Monday evening. While the drop in prices was an obvious sign that there were more sellers than buyers yesterday, many participants in the Treasury market said that the price changes came on modest volume. Bleak Budget Outlook **********Many traders and salesmen attributed the price declines to the Federal budget impasse between legislators and the President. The already bleak outlook for reducing Federal deficits from the $210 billion expected in the fiscal year 1984 was made even bleaker by reports that the Administration might try to run the Government without agreement on a budget resolution setting spending limits for the fiscal year 1984. **********''Without the resolution, you don't know the big picture because Government spending will be done item by item, appropriation by appropriation,'' said Maury Harris, an economist at Paine Webber Inc. ''It tells me that the Government is not working like it is supposed to.'' **********The budget problems reminded market participants that the current lull in Treasury financing would not last long. After today's auction of $7.75 billion of new two-year Treasury notes, which were offered to yield 9.61 percent late yesterday, Government securities dealers will begin preparing for a major financing in early May. On April 27, they expect the Treasury to announce plans to sell about $6.5 billion of three-year notes, $4.5 billion of 10-year notes and $3.5 billion of 30-year bonds. Volcker Reports Cited **********News reports - later denied - that Paul A. Volcker would not be reappointed as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board were also cited as a reason for lower prices for debt securities. Although many investors are still not fully convinced that the economic recovery can be achieved with price stability, they approve of Mr. Volcker's anti-inflationary monetary policy during the last four years. **********Analysts also had a host of technical reasons why the credit markets weakened. First, they noted that the cost of financing inventories of Treasury securities rose modestly to 8 3/4 percent. **********Also, they said that the failure of the Federal Reserve to buy Treasury notes and bonds for its own account was a disappointment to some who were hoping that the Fed's purchases would reduce their inventories. Although it is still possible that the Fed might buy securities later this week, hopes are fading. Analysts said that the Fed's decision on whether to buy would probably not be a signal of any shifting of monetary policy. **********Instead, they said it depended on how much credit was drained from the banking system by the buildup of the Treasury's balances. The Fed traditionally buys securities about this time of year to supply reserves to the banking system and offset the funds that are drained by tax collections. **********In the tax-exempt market, underwriters at Merrill Lynch have still not announced terms for a $460 million issue of Aa-rated Alabama bonds. Investment bankers said that the underwriters wanted to wait until the bonds could be sold with a maximum yield of about 8 3/8 percent for the 2001 maturity. **********In secondary market activity, prices of long-term tax-exempt bonds fell about half a point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/busin.body_text: **********In the 1850's, when aluminum sold for $545 a pound, Napoleon III used it to serve royalty at state dinners, relegating lesser guests to gold and silver. Later in the century, after two young men hit upon a process for producing the metal in quantity, the price plummeted to 57 cents a pound - a level that made aluminum better suited to soda cans than dinner service. **********While far less dramatic than a century ago, sharp price fluctuations are still the bane of aluminum manufacturers. Now, as the industry enjoys a sharp upturn after its deepest recession in more than three decades, company executives and industry analysts say that maintaining stable, relatively high prices is crucial to sustain the industry's recovery. **********''Everything seems to be headed in the right direction,'' said A.S. Hutchcraft Jr., president of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, one of the companies hardest-hit by the downturn in aluminum prices over the past two years. Prices Rebound **********Indeed, prices - which dropped below 43 cents for a pound of ingot, or unfabricated aluminum, last year from more than 90 cents a pound in 1980 - have rebounded strongly in recent months. At 76 cents a pound, some potlines - where raw alumina is converted into aluminum - are again operating at a profit. Worldwide aluminum inventories have declined sharply since January. Most major producers have restarted many of the potlines idled two years ago. **********Alcoa, the industry giant, is now running at 91 percent of capacity, and it started buying aluminum on the spot market in recent weeks to fill its heavy orders. Thomas G. Langton, director of metal services at Chase Econometrics, says, ''The outlook is for continued price increases,'' particularly if demand for new housing, automobiles and consumer durables remains strong. **********More evidence of recovery came last week, when Alcoa reported second-quarter earnings of $34.6 million, up 129 percent from the comparable quarter in 1982. **********The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum manufacturer, lost $69.1 million but $52.7 million was a one-time write-off for discontinued plants. The company said its orders trend suggested a return to profitability in the second half of the year. **********Kaiser, running at about 40 percent of capacity, lost $51.3 million, but that was an improvement over recent quarters, and the company said it should become profitable in the fourth quarter. **********While the results are less than lustrous, they look better when compared with those in other metals industries. Copper orders have remained depressed, for example, and the steel industry, still reeling from record losses last year, has shown few signs of improvement. 'A Tremendous Problem' **********Still, aluminum manufacturers are plagued by doubts, most of which center on the volatility of prices. **********''It has been a tremendous problem, particularly in the past few years,'' said C. Fred Fetterolf, Alcoa's president. ''Aluminum has acted more and more like a commodity.'' He attributes the recent increase in price instability largely to the fact that there are now more government-owned aluminum smelters around the world. At such facilities, ''it is definitely in the interest of the owners to run the potlines even when the price falls off,'' he said. **********Without the profit motive to regulate worldwide supply and demand, Mr. Fetterolf and other executives say, aluminum inventories have soared even when orders have stopped. As a result, price instability grew more extreme. **********Analysts agree that government ownership has caused problems, both for the aluminum industry and the copper industry. But some also blame the manufacturers for their apparent inability to predict demand and adjust their production accordingly. **********Only four years ago, demand was so strong that Alcoa stopped accepting orders for ingots from new customers. When aluminum fetched 90 cents a pound in early 1980, a modern high, manufacturers kept all potlines running full time, and continued the pace even after mounting evidence of a coming recession. In 1981, they misjudged the brief recovery, and kept producing at high levels well into the second, and more severe, phase of the recession. **********''There is no question that they set themselves up for a fall,'' said George Cleaver, a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. Concerns About Recovery **********Should the current recovery last only 12 or 18 months, like the one that followed the 1980 recession, Mr. Cleaver and other experts say the industry's most recent crisis could be repeated. ''If this is a short cycle, it's going to be trouble,'' Mr. Cleaver said. ''But if it is a long cycle, by the top of it the aluminum companies should be making a pile of money.'' **********Industry officials deny they are repeating past mistakes. ''I don't think the industry is bringing capacity on too rapidly,'' said Mr.  Hutchcraft of Kaiser. ''I think everybody believes that the price increases we are seeing are real and lasting.'' **********Still, companies are seeking to protect themselves from price instability. Kaiser has been expanding its activities in chemicals, oil and gas. Alcoa is placing greater emphasis on its fabricating operations. The company plans to step up manufacturing of containers and packaging. **********But there are sharp differences over the industry's ability to expand its markets significantly in the next decade, also considered a hedge against price fluctuations. **********Mr. Langton of Chase Econometrics, echoing the view of most analysts, says that ''there is no question that the industry has matured.'' While aluminum manufacturing grew quickly in the 1960's, on the strength of new markets for beverage cans and lightweight parts for autos, ''we do not see any new, large markets in the future,'' he said. Most predictions for annual growth rates in the next 10 years average around 3 percent. Overseas Growth Seen **********In contrast, Mr. Fetterolf and other industry executives say that food storage cans and other new markets may spur significant growth.  And in South America and Japan, he said, ''there are still relatively few aluminum beverage cans. These are areas of great potential.'' **********The other imponderable is the cost of energy, mostly hydroelectric power. Alcan, the Canadian-based producer that sells much of its aluminum in the United States, enjoys hydroelectic rates of about 4 cents per pound of aluminum, less than a quarter of rates in the United States. Thus, its profit margins may be among the best in the industry with the recent upturn in aluminum prices. **********Alcoa, Reynolds and Kaiser have also benefited from lower power costs in the past few months. Caught with an excess of water spilling over its hydroelectric dams, the Bonneville Power Administration offered to sell additional power to aluminum manufacturers at less than half the normal rate if they restarted their potlines. **********As for the industry's outlook, analysts expect aluminum to lead other metals in the recovery. ''There is no doubt that in the next 12 months it looks better for aluminum than for copper, zinc and the others,'' Mr. Cleaver said. ''That is not to say it looks very good.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/world.body_text: **********A visitor to a Peking municipal office was recently barred from entering because her hair touched her shoulders. The doorkeeper, in justification, pointed to a posted edict that said women who work in the office must not wear long hair, makeup or jewelry. **********The woman protested that she did not work there, but the doorkeeper let her through only after she had pulled her hair back and fastened it with a rubber band that he provided. When she finished her call, he took back the rubber band. **********A columnist named Zhang Wen, who related the story in The China Daily, said the woman asked him afterward: ''Why is a rubber band so important in judging my ideology? Do you think that black, straight hair hanging loose on my shoulders is poisonous to others' minds?'' **********Mr. Zhang acknowledged that he had no reply, since the newspaper China Youth had just assured its readers that nothing was wrong with fashionable hairdos and bright clothing.   Painful Memories Stirred **********The incident suggested the extent of confusion engendered by a war on ''spiritual pollution.'' Actual casualties have been few, and some diplomats have already concluded that the campaign is a flop. But it has given leftists a pretext for acting against Western influences and has unsettled intellectuals with painful memories of the Cultural Revolution. **********China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, started the war on spiritual pollution two months ago, apparently to show that his new economic policies, which have swept China into uncharted terrain, would not undercut the totalitarian primacy enjoyed by the party for the last 34 years. **********Some diplomats say they believe that Mr. Deng devised the campaign to pre- empt the opposition of leftists who will be targets of a new ''rectification'' campaign, or bloodless purge of the party. Other diplomats contend that it shows the real sentiments of the 79- year-old leader.   Leadership Seemingly Unsure **********Definitions of ''spiritual pollution'' have been so muddled as to suggest that the leadership is not sure what it wants, beyond a return to conformity and selective nostalgia for Chinese customs. People's Daily quoted Mr. Deng as telling the party's Central Committee in an otherwise unpublished speech in October that ''spiritual pollution essentially means the spreading of various decadent and declining ideologies of the bourgeoisie and other exploiting classes, and the spreading of sentiments of distrust regarding the cause of socialism and Communism and the leadership of the Communist Party.'' **********A lot of time has since been spent restraining those who took the call to arms too seriously and decided all Western influence was the enemy. The State Science and Technology Commission has declared that Western scientific ideas and technology, which are key to China's modernization strategy, must not be considered ideological contamination. China's President, Li Xiannian assured the visiting Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, that religion and cultural contamination were altogether different. **********In the most sweeping exclusion, the party's senior propagandist, Deng Liqun, announced that the spiritual pollution campaign would not extend to the countryside, leaving China's 800 million peasants free to pursue their mandate to get rich.   Disagreement on What's Left **********The leadership has been unable to agree on what is left to attack, beyond pornography and anti-Communism. Peng Zhen, chairman of China's nominal Parliament, the National People's Congress, said this month that a standing committee was adjourning without enacting guidelines for the spiritual pollution campaign because conditions were not ripe for such an important decision. **********The criticism of the spiritually polluted has not been vindictive. Zhou Yang, an elderly cultural minister, confessed that he had acted too hastily in writing that alienation could exist in China's Marxist society, but he never really recanted his thesis. Some minor literary magazines have been closed, and a few writers have been castigated for unseemly individualism. **********The most excitement was caused by last month's shake-up at People's Daily, in which its director, Hu Jiwei, and the deputy chief editor, Wang Ruoshui, were replaced. No motive was given, but there were rumors that Mr. Hu objected to the spiritual pollution campaign and that Mr. Wang was responsible for reprinting Zhou Yang's offending article on alienation in People's Daily in March. Some diplomats speculated that the party organ had become too independent for the old guard, including Mr. Deng.   Pornography Is Attacked **********The hard-liners have taken the campaign as a license to condemn whatever they do not like. Enough denunciations of pornography have appeared to suggest that China is awash in smut, though some exists in the eye of the beholder. A worker named Zhang Jun complained to the newspaper China Youth that his boss had seized his book of famous paintings and ordered him to make a self-criticism because it included works like Botticelli's ''The Birth of Venus.'' **********The newspaper assured Mr. Zhang that his director ''doesn't study policy very well,'' since Western art was not spiritual pollution. But it also suggested that ''if you buy these paintings just for reference, you had better keep them at home.'' **********''If you show them openly,'' the paper said, ''deviating from the sober themes the paintings express, it would not be proper.'' **********Sillier salvos have been fired in the war on spiritual pollution. A radio announcer was criticized by his trade union boss for playing the ''Blue Danube'' and other waltzes. Some army company commanders have been tearing pictures of attractive young women out of magazines sent to their units so the troops will not become contaminated.   'Weak-Willed Youths' **********Wang Zhaoguo, the head of the Communist Youth League, explained that the campaign was necessary to protect ''weak-willed youths'' who are ''easily affected by bourgeois ideas.'' But it also seems to have contributed to their cynicism. **********A man returning from a southern city said the local movie theater there was jammed every night after it was rumored that the Japanese feature film would be withdrawn because it was spiritually polluting. He and his friends lined up, too, he said, though the film was not very good. The theater subsequently extended the film for another month to meet the increased demand. **********''The spiritual pollution campaign has been a disaster,'' a Western European diplomat said. ''If it was meant to criticize the rightists, it has failed. If it was meant to draw out the leftists and cut them off at the roots, it has failed.'' **********One Chinese said that some work units overdid the campaign and that others ignored it. He said he expected the Government to let it grind on for another month or so and then declare a face-saving victory.
