https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.print_headline: MARINES IN LEBANON START NEW PATROL ROUTINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/20/world.body_text: **********United States marines today started twice-a-day patrols that will eventually take them into East Beirut regularly. **********Officials said the marines joined French and Italian units of the multinational force supporting Lebanese Government troops in security duties in the capital. **********A spokesman for the 1,200-man American contingent said four jeeps containing a total of 15 marines and one Lebanese Army liaison officer set out from the Marine headquarters near the international airport south of Beirut. **********The patrols were restricted in their first day to areas close to the airport, such as the suburbs of Hadath, Hazmiye and Baabda, and Martyrs Square between East and West Beirut. Lieut. Col. Walt Deforest said that in the next few days the patrols would go as far as Nahr al Mot just north of Ashrafiye, the main part of East Beirut. Nahr al Mot is three miles from the center of town and about eight miles north of the headquarters of the marines. **********On Tuesday three brigades of the Lebanese Army, totaling 4,000 soldiers, took over security duties from the Christian militias that had controlled East Beirut for eight years. The army thus brought the entire capital and its suburbs under the sovereignty of the central Government of President Amin Gemayel. **********United States marines, French paratroopers and Italian soldiers arrived here at the and of last September to help the Government expand its authority and sovereignty. One hundred British soldiers joined the force this month, and it now has 4,500 troops. Some Previous Patrols **********The force arrived after Israel withdrew from West Beirut, handing it over to the Lebanese Army.  The marines have been sending occasional patrols into certain sections of East Beirut since November. Altogether, 12 marines were involved in those patrols. Now, two patrols a day are planned, Colonel Deforest said. **********The French and Italian troops have established stationary checkpoints alongside the Lebanese Army in East Beirut, but the marines will operate only mobile patrols. **********Reports in the press here said this was because the marines wanted to avoid friction with Israeli troops patrolling the capital's suburbs. Asked if these reports were accurate, an American Embassy spokesman said, ''Not to my knowledge.'' **********An Israeli patrol of two tanks broke through a Lebanese Army checkpoint in East Beirut on Wednesday. The next day, an Israeli patrol tried to pass through another Lebanese barricade, then turned back. **********The marines recently had a confrontation with Israeli troops when the Israelis tried to go beyond an American checkpoint.  A Marine spokesman said the marines would show the flag and report disturbances to the headquarters of the multinational force and the Lebanese authorities. ''It is not our mission to perform police work,'' he said.

Volume totaled 15,859 contracts of 42,000 gallons, or 1,000 barrels, each. The previous record, 15,332 contracts, was set Oct. 28. **********Futures prices of light crude oil and leaded gasoline posted smaller declines in active trading.  Stocks Are Generous **********Joel Faber, who heads a major energy futures brokerage company bearing his name, said the supply-demand picture had been clouded by the recent arrivals in New York Harbor of ''distress cargoes'' from Europe ''that are seeking to find a home in an area that is loaded with unsold gasoline, heating and crude oil.'' **********''However,'' he added, ''nonrefinery storage tanks are empty because distributors are simply not buying. A year ago, they gambled that the region would have a mild winter and they won. Now they think they can again save financing costs by operating with low stocks. They may win again if we have a mild winter, but if it is a cold one, the primary stocks will vanish quickly.'' **********Andrew Lebow, energy futures analyst at Shearson/American Express, observed: **********''The endless summer that everyone in the trade is talking about has broken down technical and chart price support levels. What was left of these calculations was dramatically demolished today. Based on the key December contracts, heating oil's major price support level on the charts was 85.80 cents, and when that level was broken, the selling became pronounced. The same happened in the crude oil and gasoline futures pits.'' **********Mr. Lebow said the technical factors that betrayed many traders were in large part predicated on the market situation in June, July and August, when demand for physical products was running well above levels a year earlier. ''Many calendar watchers naturally expected the demand would rise in September,'' he said, ''but it hasn't happened. In fact, fuel oil distributors show little eagerness to buy, especially after a day like today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/busin.body_text: **********DESPITE the flurry of year-end tax shelters being advertised these days, or perhaps because of it, investors should be particularly careful of these investments. **********This is the traditional time of the year when such offerings are heavily promoted, especially to individuals anxious to generate more deductions before 1983 comes to an end. And because of the rush, many buyers may succumb to the purchase of illegal, dubious or uneconomic shelters this year that they will deeply regret in the future. **********''A good number of the public deals that come out late in the year are lousy,'' said Donald Ercole, a partner of the certified public accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company. ''The shelter industry knows that people who examine shelters do it earlier in the year.'' **********The pressure to buy at this time is especially heightened by deals offering write-offs as large as 8 to 1, which are prominently featured in newspaper ads for such shelters in real estate, oil and gas and equipment leasing. A tax-shelter write-off is a current deduction that persons claim on their tax returns against investments. A 1-to-1 write-off means $1 deducted for every $1 invested, while an 8-to-1 write-off means $8 deducted per $1 invested.  Many financial advisers warn that those looking for shelters should stay away from such high write-offs because they are unrealistic. Some say that even late offers with write-offs as low as 2 to 1 should be spurned because of the inability of most people to investigate the economic aspects of the transaction in this brief year-end period. **********''You should concentrate on the economic or financial aspects of the investments before you even take a look at the tax benefits,'' said William G. Brennan, publisher of Brennan Reports, a tax shelter newsletter. ''Some shelters require investors to assume an awful lot of liability.'' **********This liability is sometimes in the form of a commitment to make further payments after the initial funds are invested, if the tax shelter itself does not generate sufficient cash to do so. ''You may be lulled into thinking that the deal is going to throw off enough cash to pay the debt, but more than likely, it is not going to happen,'' Mr. Brennan added. **********For example, one person who invested $50,000 in an end-of-the-year cattle tax shelter was faced with a bill from the promoter the next year for an additional $80,000. He negotiated a postponement of that liabiity with the hope that the shelter would soon thereafter become economically viable, but such was not to be the case. **********His debt in the following year increased to a whopping $125,000, which he could not afford to pay. As a result, he lost his cattle and his tax shelter - and was still obligated to the promoter for more cash. **********The difficulties of last-minute tax shelter investments have been exacerbated, moreover, by the strict new penalties imposed by the 1982 tax law. Effective for 1983, involvement in an abusive shelter - essentially an artificial transaction with little or no economic reality - is more hazardous than ever. **********If a tax return is examined by the Internal Revenue Service and a tax deficiency is assessed, the taxpayer is responsible not only for the tax due and interest on the underpayment, but also for significant penalties. And when that possibility is combined with the new nationwide program by the I.R.S. to identify and investigate abusive shelters at their marketing stage, this type of investment has undoubtedly become riskier. **********''The anticipated tax benefits of the tax shelter in a particular situation may not always be realized,'' Mr. Ercole said. Referring to investors in the 50 percent tax bracket, he said, ''I would rather pay the Government my 50 cents at the most because at least I'd still have 50 cents in my pocket.'' **********Thus, the year-end urgency to participate in a tax shelter frequently becomes an exercise in futility. Perhaps most people with an interest in a tax shelter would do better to use the remainder of 1983 to plan their investments for 1984. **********Next: Securities trading.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.main_headline: CHINA AND BRITAIN PLAN MORE TALKS ON HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.print_headline: CHINA AND BRITAIN PLAN MORE TALKS ON HONG KONG
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.body_text: **********China and Britain today ended a two-day round of talks on the future of Hong Kong with an announcement that their delegations would meet here again in two weeks. **********Both sides refused to reveal any details of the sensitive negotiations, which are aimed at reaching an eventual consensus on Hong Kong's status after the British lease over most of the colony runs out in 1997. **********The agreement to hold another round of talks was expected and did not necessarily signal progress on what is considered the most difficult issue in Chinese-British relations. But the decision to meet later this month after the two delegations have reviewed the results of the latest session suggested some slight movement beyond the stalemate that originally existed. **********After the talks, which went on for three hours today in a state guest house that was once the Hungarian Embassy, Deputy Foreign Minister Yao Guang, who heads the Chinese delegation, emerged to tell waiting reporters, ''All I can say is that the talks are useful and constructive and we'll resume our talks on July 25 and 26 in Peking.'' Discussions Kept Confidential **********Mr. Yao said that the two delegations had agreed to keep the contents of their discussions confidential.  In reply to questions from reporters who had come here from Hong Kong, Mr. Yao said that Sir Edward Youde, the colony's Governor, would continue to take part in the talks as a member of the British delegation. **********Sir Edward participated in the meetings this week with the British delegation. The Chinese objected to his earlier contention that he was representing the people of Hong Kong, contending that the talks were strictly between London and Peking. **********China's position has been that its sovereignty over Hong Kong is not negotiable and that, by implication, it represents Hong Kong's 5.2 million residents. **********Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, has refused to yield publicly on the question of Hong Kong's sovereignty, contending that the 19th-century treaties giving it to Britain are still valid, though there are unconfirmed reports that her position has eased privately. China has insisted that the treaties were imposed by force and are therefore illegal. 'Second Phase' of Talks **********The current talks were described in an earlier joint announcement as a ''second phase'' in the search for a solution that got under way after Mrs. Thatcher paid an official visit to China last September. **********Because of the complexity of the Hong Kong issue, the talks are not expected to produce any substantial agreement in the near future. Instead, they are understood to be concentrating mostly on finding a mutually agreeable framework in which to thrash out a solution. **********Britain and China share a stake in preserving the prosperity of Hong Kong, whose financial institutions have been undercut by widespread uncertainty about the colony's future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.body_text: **********Canada's refusal to admit more than 5,000 Jewish refugees between 1933 when Hitler came to power and 1945 when Germany was defeated has been brought to light in a book that has become a best seller. **********''I think we must have hit a vital nerve,'' said Harold Troper, one of the authors.  Relying largely on official, once-confidential documents and the diaries of politicians and civil servants, the book, ''None Is Too Many,'' published by Lester & Orpen Denys, establishes that from 1933 to 1945 Canada, a huge land then thought of as underpopulated, admitted only a trickle of the millions of Jews who hoped to flee Europe. **********During the same period, the authors, Mr. Troper and Irving Abella, wrote, ''the United States accepted more than 200,000 Jewish refugees; Palestine, 125,000; embattled Britain, 70,000; Argentina, 50,000; penurious Brazil, 27,000; distant China, 25,000; tiny Bolivia and Chile, 14,000 each.'' **********'Holier-Than-Thou Mythology' **********''At the moment,'' Mr. Troper, who teaches history of immigration at the Ontario Institute for Studies in Education, said in an interview, ''there is a lot of historical revisionism going on, and one of the Canadian myths has been that as a nation we have been more tolerant, less bigoted than the Americans. Now, as we are examining our dealings with native peoples, with the Japanese who we detained and banished during the war, we are puncturing that holier-than-thou mythology. **********''Our book, which is selling beyond the Jewish community, touches on these national attitudes and that probably accounts for its popularity. We certainly didn't expect this kind of response for what is after all an academic effort with 30 pages of footnotes.'' **********The book, now in its fourth printing, has been on both major national best seller lists for three months. It has been serialized in The Globe and Mail, Canada's nationally distributed newspaper. It continues to be discussed on radio talk programs. As a result of the research, the annual report of the Ministry of Immigration deleted a section it had regularly included citing Canada's contribution to the refugee problems caused by World War II. **********Mr. Abella, who teaches labor history at York University, said that there had been many responses to the book. 'Worst Record' of Western Nations **********''After all,'' he said, ''it is quite shocking for people who rightfully pride themselves on having provided refuge to more than 30,000 Hungarians after the suppression of the 1956 uprising and to more than 60,000 Vietnamese, to learn that their Government and their leaders had the worst record of any Western country for providing refuge for European Jewry.'' **********The authors, both 40-year-old Canadian-born Jews, acknowledged that they themselves had been shocked by their findings. Mr. Troper said that though he had been stunned by ''the attitude of the Canadian Government from 1933 to 1939, when Jewish fears were being dismissed as alarmist,'' he had been even more appalled to discover that the objections to Jewish immigration had persisted even when accounts of the death camps became known. **********The book cites scores of individual cases in which even wealthy and influential Canadian Jews failed in attempts to have relatives admitted. Among these was the case of two aunts of the United States Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter, who sought Canadian visas to escape from Vienna. Though an appeal was made by United States diplomats to the Canadian authorities, it, like many others, was denied. Applicants Rebuffed **********Applicants who said they would work as farmers or as domestic servants were told by Canadian consulates that they were unacceptable because Jews would always gravitate to urban centers. One high-level civil servant is quoted as having urged that Jewish migration be stemmed ''lest it might foment an anti-Semitic problem.'' **********The authors, however, assert that despite the bigotry and anti-Semitism of key civil servants and Anglophiles, the major blame for the policies lay with top officials - Prime Minister W.L.  Mackenzie King, Vincent Massey, the patrician Ambassador to Britain who was to become Canada's first native-born Governor General, and Lester W. Pearson, then a diplomat who later became Canada's internationalist Prime Minister. **********The book depicts Mr. Mackenzie King as a cunning and cynical politician eager to appease what the authors describe as widespread anti-Semitism in Quebec. He did so, the authors say, by continuing to consult with Jewish organizations, holding out hope and making pious pronouncements but working behind the scenes to block any attempts to bring Jewish refugees to Canada. Massey Depicted as Anti-Semite **********Mr. Massey is depicted as a snobbish anti-Semite who once urged Canada to offer sanctuary to the ''Aryan Sudeten Germans'' after Hitler's annexation of the Czech region because ''it would put us in a much stronger position in relation to later appeals from and on behalf of non-Aryans.'' **********As for Mr. Pearson, his role appeared limited to blocking discussions with allied nations on the question of Jewish immigration. Mr. Troper said in his interview that he felt that Mr.  Pearson, at this stage, appeared to be an ambitious civil servant who avoided counseling politicians with anything they did not want to hear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.main_headline: SEVEN SUE EXXON UNIT ON SEX DISCRIMINATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.print_headline: SEVEN SUE EXXON UNIT ON SEX DISCRIMINATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/busin.body_text: **********Seven women, present and former employees of Exxon Office Systems, have filed a class action lawsuit against the company, charging a pattern of sex discrimination in pay and promotions. **********Lawyers for the women say the suit could affect thousands of past, present and future employees of the company or its three predecessor companies, Qwip Systems, Qyx and Vydec, which merged in January 1981, to form Exxon Office Systems. **********According to the complaint, filed earlier this month in Federal District Court in Hartford, Exxon Office Systems gave its male employees better promotions, better pay and better sales territories than its female employees. **********The complaint asks for back pay, punitive damages and the development of an affirmative action program. **********''We won't discuss matters in litigation, but obviously we think the allegations are without merit,'' said a spokesman for Exxon Enterprises.  Exxon Office Systems is a division of Exxon Enterprises, which is a division of the Exxon Corporation. **********James Morakis, head of media relations for Exxon, said he was not aware of any other large sex discrimination suits against Exxon, either past or present. **********Sexual Harassment Charged According to the complaint, one of the women named, Gioia Ambrette, was told there were no managerial openings available at a time when six such positions opened and were given to men with inferior sales records, usually through what the complaint calls ''a male-oriented company grapevine.'' In addition, the complaint says, Miss Ambrette was sexually harassed by a male marketing manager and a branch office manager. **********''What's going on at that company is a crime,'' said Kathleen Douel, another woman named in the complaint under her former name, Kathleen Davis. ''Many women who have left are still so scarred and hurt about what happened to them that they are afraid to come forward and talk about their experiences. Over the last two years, I've talked to a good 50 or 75 women with their own stories of sex discrimination at Exxon, and if I've talked to that many, I'm sure there are double or triple the number who don't know this case has been filed, and haven't had a chance to tell their own stories yet.'' **********''When I was first interviewing for a job as a sales representative, it took seven interviews for me to get serious consideration, because I was a divorced female,'' said Mrs. Douel, who has left Exxon to set up her own business. ''What the interviewers wanted to talk about was what would happen if my ex-husband called and wanted to come back - wouldn't I leave the job?'' **********According to the complaint, Mrs. Douel acted as branch manager of the company's Baltimore Qwip office from December 1979 until October 1980, without getting the pay and benefits of the male branch managers at other branches. And even after October 1980, when she was officially given the title of branch manager, the complaint says, Mrs. Douel was still not paid as much as the male branch managers. Then, at the time of the merger, the complaint says, Mrs. Douel applied to be the manager of the merged office, but the job went to a less-qualified man. **********''When the three companies merged, Exxon looked around to see who should staff the new management jobs, and they turned overwhelmingly to males,'' said Herbert Teitelbaum, one of the lawyers representing the women. ''I have never seen so many competent women so angry at the treatment they received at the hands of their employer. If the court agrees with only part of what these women are alleging, the recovery will be very substantial.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.body_text: **********It is still impossible to say how many civilians died this month at O Smach, a Cambodian refugee and guerrilla camp that was shelled and overrun by Vietnamese troops. It is also not known with certainty how they died. **********Former Prime Minister Sonn San of Cambodia charged last week that hundreds were slain when Vietnamese soldiers herded people into trenches and threw hand grenades at them. Some witnesses said Cambodian soldiers also threw grenades at civilians. **********Part of the problem of obtaining information is that most of the refugees now in Thailand have been isolated by the Thai Army.  But six civilians from the camp, speaking April 10 at the International Committee of the Red Cross Hospital near Kap Choeun, said they were in bunkers that Vietnamese soldiers attacked with grenades. **********Ngach Mov, 34 years old (top right photo, center rear), and his wife, Sok Nang, 31 (far left), said seven soldiers herded them into a bunker April 3. They said their daughter, Van Pen, 12 (foreground), was wounded in the elbow; Lok Ngoeut, 11 (right), a relative, was wounded in the right side. Their son, Mov Soka, 3, was blinded in the left eye. **********Klord Ang, 24 (lower right), said she and 5 of 14 other people in a bunker were injured by a grenade.  A grenade seriously wounded Kong Leon, 10 (top left), in the abdomen, feet and elbow. He said four or five others in his bunker were also hurt. His parents were in the same bunker but were not injured, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/25/busin.body_text: **********A reviving economy, lower interest rates and drastically pared operating costs are beginning to have a healthy impact on corporate profitability. **********All the results for the first quarter are not yet in. Major retailers and the oil companies, which account for about one-third of corporate profits, have not begun to report, for example. But earnings reports released thus far have led economists and other analysts to project that after-tax profits in the first quarter are likely to register the first year-to-year increase since the second quarter of 1981. **********''The economy is better, and final sales are picking up slightly,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University. ''Production schedules are still below desired levels, but are higher than they were. And a lot of fat has been taken out of management and distribution systems.'' Annualized $129 Billion **********As a result, Mr. Ratajczak estimates that after-tax corporate profits were an annualized $129 billion in the first quarter, up 9 percent from the fourth quarter and 12 percent from a year earlier. **********M. Kathyrn Eickoff, executive vice president at Townsend-Greenspan & Company, an economic consulting firm, said that many companies benefited from an improved foreign exhange position. **********''Some people really got hurt by their exposures in countries like Mexico during the second half of last year,'' she said. ''In some cases in the first quarter foreign exchange losses were far less than what had orignially been anticipated.'' **********The profits picture may be brighter, but it is far from uniform. Lingering Effects **********The recession's lingering effects are most easily seen among primary metal and steel producers, where product prices and operating rates are still at low levels and companies are still deep in the red. Chemical manufacturers are making money, but weak domestic and international demand kept earnings well below the levels of a year earlier. And analysts said that the oil companies, whose earnings reports should begin to appear this week, had a particularly dismal quarter. **********Much of the good news on earnings has come from two of the recession's most prominent victims: autos and housing. In those sectors, profits of many companies were up sharply. **********Improvement was not limited to those areas, however, as some high technolgy companies saw earnings rise sharply and major drug companies continued to post healthy gains. Financial service companies continued to ride the wave that began last August, when stock prices began their big climb. Reflecting the Administration's military priorities, some defense-related companies chalked up large earnings gains. **********Following is a breakdown of some important sectors: Autos **********The effects of cost-cutting on profits are perhaps best seen in Detroit, where the General Motors Cororation and the Chrysler Corporation both reported sharp increases in earnings despite only a modest increase in the number of units sold. **********At Chrysler, earnings for the first quarter were the highest on record, $172.1 million, up 14.8 percent from a year before, despite a mere 3.8 percent increase in auto sales. At G.M., auto sales rose just 2.2 percent from the first quarter of 1982, but the company made $653 million in the latest quarter, its largest quarterly profit in more than four years. Analysts expect that this week the Ford Motor Company will report earnings of about $200 million for the period. **********''There is some evidence of recovery here,'' said Maryann N.  Keller, an analyst at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. ''But you cannot dismiss the fact that a meaningful proportion of the earnings at Chrysler and G.M. came from non-auto related sources like interest income and their financing companies.'' Housing **********The sharp increase in housing activity was dramatically reflected in the earnings reports of a number of housing-related companies in the first quarter. **********The U.S. Home Corporation, for example, lost $1.4 million in the first quarter last year, but it reported net income of $8.6 million in the latest quarter. Willamette Industries Inc., a wood and paper products manufacuter that lost $4.6 million in the first quarter of 1982, reported net income of $3.7 million for the latest quarter. And the Boise Cascade Corporation said its net income rose 98.2 percent from the first quarter of last year, to $11.1 million. **********Profits at the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, however, plunged 80.6 percent, to $30 million, and the Weyerhaeuser Company reported that earnings dropped 78%, to $22.5 million. Steel **********Despite increases in production and the number of employed steelworkers, weak product prices are keeping the nation's steel manufacturers in the red. **********To date, four of the eight major companies - Armco Inc., the Inland Steel Company, the National Steel Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation - have reported a combined loss of $218.6 million for the first quarter. Analysts said that when the other four - the U.S.  Steel Corporation, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation and Jones & Laughlin Steel Inc., a unit of the LTV Corporation -announce results this week, the size of the industry's loss will almost certainly rise. High Technology **********High technology companies posted mixed results for the first quarter.  At one end of the spectrum were such companies as the International Business Machines Corporation, which posted a 23.7 percent earnings gain from a year before, to $976 million; Apple Computer Inc., up 73.2 percent, to $23.9 million, and Wang Laboratories Inc., up 44.9 percent, to $36.8 million. **********But the Control Data Corporation saw its profits drop 12.5 percent, to $33.5 million. Net income at Honeywell Inc. fell 60 percent, to $22.2 million, and the Burroughs Corporation reported that net income declined 47.2 percent, to $29.8 million. Military Contractors **********The Rockwell International Corporation and the Lockheed Corporation, two major military contractors, reported strong earnings growth in the first quarter from a year earlier. Two others, the Martin Marietta Corporation and the Raytheon Company, saw profits slip. **********Lockheed's advance was the most impressive. Net income rose 37.6 percent, to $51.6 million. At Rockwell, earnings topped $100 million, a 5.8 percent rise from a year earlier. Martin Marietta's earnings dropped 12.7 percent, to $13.8 million, while Raytheon reported net income of $73 million, down 8.1 percent. Consumer-Oriented **********The somewhat sluggish expansion in retail sales in the first quarter was big enough to benefit the bottom line of many manufacturers of consumer durable and nondurable items. **********At the General Electric Corporation, profits were up 12.7 percent from last year's first quarter, to $425 million. The Whirlpool Corporation recorded a 43.6 percent rise in earnings, to $40.5 million. The Tandy Corporation's net income rose 26.4 percent, to $57.4 million. And Rubbermaid Inc., the housewares manufacturer, registered a 23.1 percent increase in net income, to $8 million. Financial Services **********With record-setting volume accompanying the stock market's rally, earnings on Wall Street continued to surge.  Thus far, the E.F. Hutton Group Inc. has claim to the most spectacular individual gain: first quarter earnings for the brokerage house rose more than twelvefold from a year before, to $37.3 million. Paine Webber Inc. recorded a more than sixfold increase, with profits rising to $23.1 million. The American Express Company said net income in the first quarter rose more than 37 percent from a year before, to $162 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.print_headline: 7 DEAD IN LISBON IN ARMENIAN RAID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.body_text: **********Gunmen identified as Armenians stormed the Turkish Ambassador's residence here today and, after keeping Portuguese policemen at bay with gunfire for an hour and a half, blew it up. Seven people died in the attack - five gunmen, a hostage and a policeman who had entered the residence during the siege. **********The hostage was identified by Turkish Embassy officials as Cahide Mihcio@glu, the 42-year-old wife of the charge d'affaires. Her 17-year-old son was also taken hostage, but escaped with a gunshot wound in the leg by leaping off a first-floor balcony from the blazing building shortly after the explosion. A second policeman was also wounded. **********Four gunmen died in the explosion. The fifth had been shot and killed in the opening moments of the attack.  A little-known Armenian group, the Armenian Revolutionary Army, said in a typewritten note delivered to news agencies here that it was responsible for the assault. The note arrived after the attack had begun. **********It was the third act of terrorism claimed by Armenian extremist organizations in the last two weeks, marking a sudden upsurge in what they assert is a campaign to avenge massacres by the Turks under the Ottoman Empire and to gain self-determination for the Armenian people. **********On July 15 a bomb exploded in a suitcase at a Turkish Airlines check-in counter at Orly Airport in Paris, killing seven people and wounding more than 50. A group calling itself the Armenian Secret Army for the Liberation of Armenia said it had planted the bomb, and French policemen are holding a 29-year-old Syrian citizen of Armenian descent who they say has confessed. **********The day before the Orly bombing, the Armenian Revolutionary Army - the group involved in the attack here - said it had been responsible for the shooting death of a Turkish diplomat, Dursun Aksoy, in Brussels. **********In the note delivered today to the offices of Reuters and The Associated Press, the group said it had turned to ''armed struggle'' because peaceful means for ''the pursuit of our just cause'' had failed. ''The wall of silence built around our cause was too thick to be pierced,'' it said. **********The note ended: ''We have decided to blow up this building and remain under the collapse. This is not suicide nor an expression of insanity, but rather our sacrifice to the altar of freedom.'' **********The blast, apparently from explosives carried into the two-story, concrete-and-glass residence by the gunmen in what witnesses described as a large leather bag, wrecked the building and set it ablaze. Tried First to Take Embassy **********Witnesses said the gunmen originally tried to seize the embassy, set back from the tree-lined Avenida de Descobertas in the exclusive Restelo suburb of Lisbon. But they were driven off by gunfire from a Turkish security guard, who shot and killed one of them, and ran down a cobbled driveway to take the Ambassador's residence instead. **********The family of the charge d'affaires, Mustafa Mihcioglu, had moved into the house only recently for reasons of security. The Ambassador, Ismail Soysal, had completed his tour of duty and returned to Turkey on July 17. **********Witnesses said the gunmen arrived at about 10:30 A.M. in two cars, a red one that remained out front and a white Ford Escort that entered the driveway. The Ford Escort aroused the suspicions of a Portuguese security guard because it had been there the day before. **********On that occasion, according to Turkish Embassy sources, two men emerged from the car. When challenged by the Ambassador's bodyguard, they said they had come for visas. But when asked to produce their passports, they left hurriedly. Turks Asked Extra Protection **********Because of this incident, the Turkish Embassy requested extra police protection from the Portuguese authorities, the sources said.  One additional policeman was stationed on the road outside early today. **********The Turkish bodyguard was alerted by the Portuguese security man when the white car returned today. As he approached it, an exchange of gunfire took place. One gunman died on the spot and a policeman was wounded by submachine-gun fire. **********The gunmen then regrouped to take the nearby residence, where they found their hostages. A force of some 170 riot policemen surrounded the building, cordoning off the area and hiding behind cars and trees to avoid sporadic gunfire from within. One report said the gunmen had threatened over the telephone to blow up the building if the police tried to retake it. **********What happened next is not altogether clear, but at about noon an explosion occurred. It was followed by two or three lesser explosions, witnesses said, and the building went up in flames. Cabinet in Emergency Session **********The Portuguese Cabinet, under the new Prime Minister, Mario Soares, went into an emergency session during the siege and decided to send in an elite police detachment, the Special Operational Group. It was the first time that this British-trained force, which was formed last autumn, had been used. **********The group began an assault on the burning building at 1:40 P.M. and found five bodies on the upper floor. One of them turned out to be a policeman, identified as Manuel Pacheco. **********A spokesman for the Interior Ministry said later that the policeman, who was familiar with the embassy, had rushed to the scene after hearing about the attack over his radio. He climbed into the room where the gunmen had taken refuge, the spokesman said. Whether this might have prompted them to detonate the explosion could not be determined. **********The ministry said later that the two cars were filled with food and explosives, suggesting that the gunmen had laid in preparations for a long siege. **********The last attack on Turkish diplomats in Lisbon occurred in June 1982. Then the commercial attache, Erkut Ackbay, was shot and killed outside his home. His wife was wounded in the attack, for which Armenian terrorists claimed responsibility. **********One embassy official theorized that the terrorists had chosen Lisbon because it was ''an easy target.'' The embassy, built 10 years ago, has seven full-time employees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/24/world.main_headline: EFFORTS TO OUST THE SANDINISTAS HELD INEFFECTIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/24/world.print_headline: EFFORTS TO OUST THE SANDINISTAS HELD INEFFECTIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/24/world.body_text: **********After more than a year of intense activity, the Honduran-based rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government have failed to achieve significant military gains or to cause a serious political threat to the Government, foreign diplomats and Nicaraguan officials here say. **********While the United States-backed rebels have harassed the Government and caused hundreds of civilian and military deaths and an estimated $70 million in damage, the officials say, they have been unable to hold any town or valuable territory here for any length of time. **********This reported lack of military success has deepened the Nicaraguan Government's fears that the Reagan Administration may now feel compelled to take harsher measures in its opposition to the Managua regime. **********Another key factor, as government officials see it, is that while economic sanctions imposed by Washington have hurt, they are not likely to paralyze the Nicaraguan economy for several years. This is in part because Nicaragua continues to receive assistance from the Soviet bloc and a number of Western European countries, including France. **********Nicaragua's fears of a major step-up in activity against it by the Reagan Administration apparently motivated a conciliatory gesture last Tuesday, when the Government announced it was now willing to take part in regional peace talks and no longer insisted on direct talks with Honduras. The gesture, diplomats here said, appeared to be aimed at broadening support in the United States Congress and among Nicaragua's sympathizers in Western Europe and Latin America. **********''We are in more danger now because the 'contras' are being repulsed,'' a senior Nicaraguan official said, referring to the rebels. ''The U.S. will need to choose options that guarantee success.'' **********Several key foreign diplomats said they shared this view. They said the rebel campaign, designed to employ rapid action and based on the assumption that it would gain wide popular support, instead was becoming more like a long but very limited war of attrition. **********These diplomats, who were openly critical of the Sandinista Government, said they believed that the overall strategy of the Reagan Administration in Nicaragua was faltering and that the lack of rebel success was an important part of the process. **********''It was stupid for Washington to think they could mount a successful campaign in one year,'' said one diplomat who said he had no sympathy for the Nicaraguan revolution. ''The Sandinistas will probably not change enough to resolve the situation in the area, but the whole concept of fast diplomatic, financial and rebel pressure could never do the trick. There's no short-term solution here.'' **********President Reagan, in a news conference last Thursday, said it would be ''extremely difficult'' to bring stability to the area if the Sandinistas remained in power. **********In the eyes of the Sandinista leadership, the United States is already at war with Nicaragua through the ''contras.'' In late 1979, the rebels were formed from among the defeated remnants of the National Guard that had served the regime of Anastasio Somoza Debayle before it was overthrown earlier that year.  They have grown into a well-trained and well-equipped fighting force estimated at 7,000 former guardsmen, peasants and Indians. **********With the encouragement of the United States, several small groups founded the Nicaraguan Democratic Front in 1981. The front's political leaders include former supporters of the Somoza regime, lawyers and businessmen who opposed the Sandinistas' leftist policies. The fighting force took serious form in early 1982, after the Reagan Administration approved $19 million for ''covert action'' to support it . **********Since then the rebels, by their own admission often with support from the Honduran Army, have attacked military and civilian targets and destroyed bridges, farms and equipment in a broad area along Nicaragua's northern frontier. **********But the task forces that ventured deeper into Nicaragua on at least four occasions in the past seven months have been stopped by the Sandinista military from achieving their aim of controlling towns or strategic areas, Nicaraugan officials say. **********Foreign diplomats monitoring the war said the Sandinistas at first sent poorly trained militia to fight along the border areas. But since last March, the diplomats say, the response has been on a larger scale, at times involving up to 6,000 of the Government's 22,000 troops. **********The Government has described the rebels in the north as its primary problem, and few troops have been sent to the southern border, where the former Sandinista commander Eden Pastora Gomez operates with a rebel force he has said numbers 2,200 men. **********One senior military official said the rebels in the south posed ''no serious threat'' because during the Sandinista guerrilla war, the nearly impassable swamps and jungles in the south obliged them to move elsewhere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/11/busin.body_text: **********A reported $2 billion drop in the money supply delighted the credit markets late last week; bond prices soared and interest rates plunged almost a third of a percentage point. Most market participants had expected a jump in the money supply of as much as $1 billion. The drop in M-1 - currency in circulation plus all check-like deposits - placed money growth within the Fed's current target range. It seemed to allay fears that the central bank would have to tighten credit and boded well for those looking for lower interest rates. ''This is the best money-supply picture we've had in the last 12 months; everything is on target,'' was the reaction of one market analyst. **********The stock market also put in a positive week, approaching its record highs. Despite fairly quiet trading, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up more than 24 points, to 1,240.04. **********Kiss and Make Up. **********After breaking off talks in July, Chrysler and the United Auto Workers agreed on a new wage package that will raise union workers' pay by $2.42 an hour over the next two years. The settlement was $1.01 an hour higher than Chrysler's previous offer, but it still gives the No. 3 auto maker a slight labor- cost advantage over G.M. and Ford. Chrysler's primary concern was avoiding any work stoppage in January, when it plans to introduce two new models. And even though the increase will amount to about 29 percent over two years, the auto industry revival and Chrysler's new-found profitability should offset it. **********To the chagrin of Lee Iacocca, the Treasury is going ahead with its sale of 14.4 million Chrysler warrants, which allow the holder to buy Chrysler stock for $13 a share. Chrysler's chairman had all but pleaded with the Government to sell the warrants back to the company, but to no avail. The sale will take place Tuesday at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. **********The summer's drought and scorching heat is affecting wholesale prices faster than anticipated. The Producer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, driven by a similar increase in food prices. Analysts had predicted that food prices would not be pushed up until next year and were surprised by August's figures. Yet, for the first eight months of this year, producer prices have been flat, and 1983 could see the slowest price rise since the mid-1960's.  Shuttle Econonics. **********It's a lucrative job, cleaning up the space shuttle between flights. In fact, over the next six years it will be worth about $2 billion to Lockheed and Grumman. After a bidding contest with a group of companies led by Rockwell International - the shuttle's original builder - NASA awarded the Lockheed group the contract for launching and landing services, now done by 15 separate contractors. The job could extend as long as 15 years, with a value of $6 billion. Analysts were not completely surprised by the outcome. The Government has had a number of complaints against Rockwell about overcharging for shuttle work.  Boeing Economics. **********The world's largest maker of commercial airliners received a $640 million order from Australia's Qantas Airways for six 767's and three 747's. Particularly pleasing to Boeing was the fact that four airlines traveling the so-called silk route - between the Middle East and the Far East - will now be flying the 767, which has had very stiff competition from Airbus.  General Economics. **********In another huge aerospace contract, Turkey decided to buy 160 F-16 fighter jets from General Dynamics over a 10-year period. The contract will be worth between $3.5 billion and $5 billion. It was the first time in almost a decade that the F-16 had won a major international contract over the McDonnell Douglas F-18. But other contests are coming up. Greece should decide soon on an order for as many as 125 fighter planes. The F-16, F-18 and France's Mirage 2000 are in the running. **********Kohlberg Kravis & Roberts struck again, making another leveraged buyout bid. This time the target was the Hyster Company, a maker of forklifts and other heavy equipment. The price: $383 million, or $63 for each of Hyster's 6.1 million shares outstanding. Though Kohlberg was mum on why it was interested in Hyster - just last July it was bidding for Norton Simon - analysts noted that Hyster's balance sheet was almost irresistible, with $43 million in cash and very modest debt. **********The takeover of Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan by the Federal Home Loan Bank board was ruled an abuse of the bank board's authority. The decision by a Federal district judge came in a case filed by Kaufman & Broad, a Biscayne shareholder, after the bank board seized Florida's sixth-largest thrift unit on April 6 and placed it in receivership. The seizure did not jeopardize the thrift's deposits, but reduced the value of its stock to nothing. The judge ordered shareholders and bank board officials to meet and try to reach an agreement on returning ownership of Biscayne to the shareholders. **********Coleco's long-awaited Adam computer was at last ushered on stage. Coleco will charge about $600 for the home computer, which comes with a slow, letter-quality printer, computer console, keyboard and tape-driven memory system. The company said demand was so great that it halted production of its popular ColecoVision video games to open production capacity so it could fill the 400,000 firm orders it already has for Adam. But Coleco did not know for sure when it would begin shipments. It has yet to get approval from the F.C.C. **********One day after the Adam announcement, Coleco and A.T.& T. announced a joint venture to market video games and entertainment software to consumers by telephone. Dakota or Bust. **********BankAmerica, joining Citibank, Security Pacific and First Interstate, has applied for a charter in South Dakota to buy a bank and begin insurance operations. Recent legislation there allows out-of- state banks to buy local units and permits those local banks to underwrite insurance. BankAmerica's move underscores the drive by the banking community to break down its traditional boundaries, at a time when it is being squeezed by nonbanking entities such as the large insurers entering the commercial lending business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/13/busin.body_text: **********The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's thirdlargest aluminum producer after the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $123.4 million for 1982, compared with the 1981 quarter's much slimmer deficit of $16 million. The company attributed the loss to continuing weakness in the aluminum industry. **********Kaiser, based in Oakland, Calif., said that its revenue in the latest three months rose six-tenths of 1 percent, to $774.5 million, from $769.5 million. **********For the full year, Kaiser said it had a loss of $115 million, contrasted to earnings of $132.9 million in 1981. Revenue slipped 1.8 percent, to $3.28 billion, from $3.34 billion in 1981. **********Cornell C. Maier, chairman, said that the poor results in the latest quarter continued to reflect the combined effects of weak demand, poor prices, higher production costs and low operating rates. **********Kaiser said that shipments for all of last year fell 8.5 percent, to 845,900 tons, from the 924,900 tons shipped in 1981. Results for both the fourth quarter and the full year include an after-tax gain of $14.3 million, or 33 cents a share, from the previously announced sale of Kaiser's interest in Comalco Ltd., a large aluminum producer based in Australia. **********Kaiser said that, among other adjustments, its results followed an after-tax charge of $15 million, or 35 cents a share, stemming from a litigation agreement and an after-tax loss of $27.4 million, primarily resulting from an adjustment for the anticipated disposition of some aluminum manufacturing operations. Colt Industries **********Colt Industries announced that net income in the fourth quarter of 1982 plunged 29.8 percent, to $14.6 million, or 59 cents a share, from $20.8 million, or 75 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter year earlier. Sales fell 21.9 percent, to $329.4 million, from $421.9 million. **********For the full year, the diversified industrial concern said that it had a loss of $161.4 million, contrasted to earnings of $109.6 million in 1981. Sales for 1982 dropped 14.6 percent, to $1.51 billion, from $1.77 billion. **********On March 10, 1982, Colt announced its decision to dispose of its Crucible Stainless and Alloy division in Midland, Pa. On Aug. 17, 1982, the company announced its decision to close its Midland operations effective Oct. 15, 1982, and, on Nov. 24, 1982, Colt announced the signing of an agreement for the purchase by Jones & Laughlin, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation, of the Midland steelmaking facility. The sale, subject to review by the Department of Justice and to certain closing conditions, is expected to be completed early this year. ---- Earnings tables, page D13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/19/world.main_headline: O.A.U. Panel Suggests A Meeting in Ethiopia
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/19/world.print_headline: O.A.U. Panel Suggests A Meeting in Ethiopia
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/19/world.body_text: **********A 12-nation panel recommended today that the Organization of African Unity move its 19th meeting of heads of government from Libya, where it collapsed twice last year, to the O.A.U.'s headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. **********The recommendation was made by a committee set up to resolve differences over Chad's new pro-Western Government and over the Polisario independence movement in Western Sahara. **********A Moroccan-led boycott over the admission of the Polisario Front as the organization's 51st member prevented a quorum at the meeting scheduled last August in Tripoli, Libya. The Polisario is fighting Morocco for control of the former Spanish Sahara. **********The Polisario agreed to stay away from a rescheduled meeting in November, but Libya raised a new problem by refusing to admit the new Chadian Government of President Hissen Habre. Libya had backed the Government Mr. Habre ousted. **********A statement read today by Foreign Minister Robert Ouko of Kenya gave no indication that the committee had settled the problems, but it said the committee recommended that the meeting be held in Addis Ababa in May or June. **********Western diplomats said the move had been discussed for some time and was no great surprise.  The heads of state of Congo, Ethiopia, Kenya, Nigeria, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia took part in the meeting today. Angola, Lesotho, Libya, Mali and Mozambique were represented by Cabinet ministers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/24/world.print_headline: WOMEN IN THE NEWS; CANADA'S NEXT GOVERNOR GENERAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/24/world.body_text: **********Jeanne Sauve, who was nominated today by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau to be the first female Governor General of Canada, was once regarded as something of a political outsider by many of her male colleagues.  That was three and a half years ago, when she was Canada's first Speaker of the House of Commons to be a woman. There was, some recalled, a palpable atmosphere of resentment toward her in the male-dominated lower house. **********The 61-year-old Mrs. Sauve was widely viewed as something of an outsider, a former member of the Cabinet with no great knowledge of procedural rules nor any close ties to the clubby fraternity that had administered the bureaucracy around Parliament. **********But Mrs. Sauve, who will take over the largely ceremonial viceregal duties when Edward R. Schreyer ends his five-year term in January, has through her often stormy term as Speaker won the admiration even of backbench politicians who once sent her opera glasses to dramatize their complaint that she never called on them to speak.   Born in Saskatchewan Mrs. Sauve was born Jeanne Benoit on April 26, 1922, in Prud'Homme, Saskatchewan, and, after a convent education and studies at the Universities of Ottawa and Paris, she settled into the fashionable society of Montreal in the 1950's, working as a journalist. In 1948 she married Maurice Sauve, a businessman and Liberal politician who was a Member of Parliament before her and once served as Minister of Mines and Rural Development. They have one son, who is 24. **********After working with organizations of writers and actors, she was herself first elected to the House in 1972. After a very short backbench career she was named to the Cabinet by Mr. Trudeau. She served as Minister of Environment, Minister of Communication and junior Minister of State for Science and Technology before being installed as Speaker on April 14, 1980. **********On that day, as she walked down the center aisle of the House dressed in a black wool Speaker's uniform she had designed by Serge de Real of Montreal, the resentment against her may have had more to do with her Cabinet ties than her gender. **********The bureaucracy around the Cabinet had grown in size and power under Mr. Trudeau and the Commons was feeling itself subordinated to the executive. In a Liberal Party convention Mrs. Sauve had backed John Turner, a rival of Mr. Trudeau for the leadership, and there was some thought that she was being banished to the Speaker's job with an idea of further humiliating the Members of Parliament, who, Mr. Trudeau once remarked, were ''just nobodies'' once they were 50 yards from Parliament Hill.   Maintenance of Order **********In the first two years of her term, Mrs. Sauve, whose duties as Speaker involved maintaining order in the chamber, may have agreed that someone was being humiliated. **********Parliamentary experts barraged her with points of order and points of privilege to the point of distraction. Although it is traditional never to criticize the Speaker, according to Ian Deans, a Member of Parliament, ''The fact that she's a woman clouded the objectivity of certain members. They would never have questioned a man's judgment in the same way.'' **********At the same time Mrs. Sauve did her homework. At one point she studied photographs of the 282 members of the House so she could call on them by name and constituency. She memorized the hundreds of standing orders and parliamentary procedures of the Commons, and eventually adopted her own system of keeping tabs on who had spoken. The worst moments came in March of 1982 when the Progressive Conservative opposition paralyzed the House for two weeks by quorum calls. ''I felt I couldn't act,'' she has recalled, ''because it would have looked as though I tipped my hand in one direction or another.'' **********She endured criticism and went on to win wide respect. ''She doesn't brook much nonsense now,'' said Walter Baker, once one of her major Conservative critics. **********In addition to her highly visible role as Speaker in the televised Commons procedings, Mrs. Sauve has also had to administer a burauacracy of 3,000 people, which just after she took office was the subject of a highly critical Government audit. Within two years, Mrs. Sauve was able to trim $18 million from her budget and had pared the payroll by 100 workers. **********In her new post as Governor General, to which she will be formally appointed by Queen Elizabeth II, Mrs. Sauve can expect little controversy. Essentially, the job entails serving as the head of state in residence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/busin.body_text: **********Consumers took on $3.39 billion more in installment debt in August than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board said today. **********The net increase in credit represented an annual growth rate of 11.25 percent, compared with a rate of 16.5 percent in July, the Fed reported. **********July's net increase of $4.84 billion was a monthly record. **********Auto loans accounted for three- quarters of the August increase despite a drop in car sales during the month, the Fed reported. It said outstanding debt for car loans grew $2.5 billion in August, compared with $2.4 billion in July. **********Economists, however, said the gain could have reflected financing that was approved in August for purchases that had been made and recorded earlier in the year. **********The Fed also said that debt from revolving credit cards - bank and store credit cards and gasoline cards - expanded $313 million after rising $821 million in July. Other credit, such as cash loans from banks and savings and loans, rose by $484 million after jumping $1.5 billion in July. **********The report includes most short- and medium-term lending but excludes long-term credit, such as home loans. **********All figures are adjusted for seasonal variations. Before adjustment, the Fed said, consumers had $364 billion in debt outstanding, up from $335 billion a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/04/busin.body_text: **********C. Calvert Knudsen, who in 1977 took the helm of MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., British Columbia's giant forestry products company, is stepping down Oct. 1 as chairman and chief executive, the company said yesterday. **********Chairman to Leave MacMillan Bloedel Mr. Knudsen, who is 59 years old, will be succeeded by Raymond Smith as chief executive officer. Mr. Smith, 57, who has been with the company since 1957, will continue in his post as president. **********Mr. Knudsen had been hired to stabilize management and stem losses at the company. He succeeded so well that he was forced to fend off takover attempts by Domtar Inc. and Canadian Pacific Ltd. However in 1981, Noranda Mines Ltd. bought a 49.6 percent interest, despite company opposition. **********Adam Zimmerman, currently president of Noranda and vice chairman of McMillan Bloedel, will become chairman of the forestry company. Mr. Knudsen, who was not available for comment, will continue as vice chairman. **********''He had indicated two years ago that he was considering giving up some responsibilities. But when the recession threatened the survival of the company, he stayed at the helm,'' said Nancy Scott, company spokesman. Mr. Knudsen, she said, has indicated he intends to stay actively involved in the company, but ''wanted to spend more time managing his investments in his Knudsen-Erath winery in Oregon.'' **********Noranda seized control of the then $2.2 billion company in April 1981. By summer, the downturn hit the forestry products industry. The company reported $3.3 million in earnings that year, but in 1982 reported a net loss of $57.3 million, on sales of $1.8 bllion. **********In the just-ended second quarter, the company posted profits of $11.7 million, the first gain since the second quarter of 1981 that was not related to extraordinary items such as the sale of assets. **********Industry sources said that Mr. Knudsen is highly regarded in the industry and in Vancouver, where the company is headquartered. He encourages co-workers to call him Cal. **********''We're going to miss him, and the reason he is not leaving immediately is to provide an orderly succession,'' Mrs. Scott said. **********Mr. Knudsen, a lawyer, formerly was with Weyerhaeuser, the Seattle- based forestry products company, where he had been senior vice president for corporate growth. He was vice chairman of the Evans Products Company of Portland, Ore., before moving to Weyerhaeuser in 1969.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/23/world.body_text: **********The Government has rejected a request from Greece's largest-selling newspaper for an investigation of six Western journalists on charges that they are involved in a conspiracy against ''the freedom and interests of the Greek people.'' **********The Government said there was no evidence to support the accusations, made in an editorial by the newspaper Ethnos. **********The journalists had appeared as character witnesses for a Cypriot reporter, Paul Anastasiades, who was sentenced on Friday to two years in prison on charges of having defamed and libeled the publisher of Ethnos. **********The case centered on Mr. Anastasiades's book ''Take the Nation in Your Hands'' and a promotional press release he had written. They said Ethnos had links with the ''disinfomation department'' of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence service, and that the publisher, George Bobolas, was ''an agent of influence'' for the Soviet Union. **********Journalists Had Protested **********Ethnos said in an editorial Saturday that the witnesses for Mr. Anastasiades had been ''moving easily under the protective cloak of international journalism while in reality being organs of dark forces who are viciously fighting the freedom and interests of the Greek people.'' **********The journalists protested to the Foreign Press Association here on Monday, and the association made a formal protest on their behalf to the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou. The reply was delivered today to the six journalists - Michael Skapinker of Maclean's Magazine of Canada, Albert Coerant of Dutch Radio and Television, John Rigos of United Press International, Werner Rieder of Der Tagesspiegel of Berlin, Lee Stokes of The London Sunday Mail and U.S.A. Today, and this correspondent. **********The Government's reply was contained in a letter to the Foreign Press Association by the Under Secretary of Press and Information, Dimitris Maroudas. It said of the journalists: **********''There is no evidence whatsoever to support allegations that they exercise any profession or activity other than that of correspondent. **********''The Government does not approve of these allegations. But on the contrary the Government disapproves of the attacks which occur from time to time against foreign correspondents, and it is determined to defend their integrity of all accredited foreign correspondents and the free exercise of their profession in this country.'' **********The journalists' protest to the Foreign Press Association cited what they described as their unfair treatment at the trial and the ''tendentious and incorrect'' reports by Ethnos. **********The penal court trial was held as a result of a libel and defamation suit brought by Mr. Bobolas, whose attorneys denounced the defendant as a ''foreigner'' with no right to comment on Greek newspapers. **********Mr. Anastasiades writes under the name Paul Anastasi as a correspondent for The Daily Telegraph of London and a part-time correspondent for The New York Times. Along with his witnesses, he was accused by Mr. Bobolas's attorneys of being a foreign agent implicated in a plot against the Greek people. **********One of the attorneys, Stathis Alexandris, a former Minister of Justice in the Papandreou Government, described Mr. Anastasiades's witnesses as petty agents representing suspect publications and said there should be an investigation of their presence in Greece. **********After a four-day trial, the three judges convicted Mr. Anastasiades of slanderous defamation, or spreading libel knowing that it was untrue. The court did not contest the evidence in the defendant's book but ruled there was insufficient proof to conclude that the Ethnos publisher was ''an agent of influence'' for the Soviet Union. **********Countersuit Is Rejected **********The court also rejected a countersuit brought by Mr. Anastasiades charging character defamation. It ruled that articles in Ethnos calling Mr. Anastasiades a conspirator and an agent of the United States Central Intelligence Agency could be viewed as justified indignation over the book. **********In Greek law, a libel suit may come before a civil or criminal court. In a civil action, if the defendent is found guilty, he must pay damages, but the case can drag on. In a criminal court, verdicts are usually speedy, and the plaintiff who wins gets the satisfaction of sending his defamer to jail. **********Mr. Anastasiades, 33 years old, is free pending appeal of his sentence, which includes symbolic damages of $300. He said in a recent interview that he would urge the Foreign Press Association, the Greek Journalists Union and the London-based International Press Institute to send observers to the proceedings of the Court of Appeals, expected to begin in three months. **********Ethnos, Greece's first mass tabloid, has a national circulation of 200,000. It was started in 1981 by Mr. Bobolas, a businessman who has been involved in large trade deals with the Russians. **********Mr. Anastasiades wrote that its three main foreign correspondents were all associated with Communist parties and that its reports about Soviet-bloc countries were usually highly favorable while its coverage of the United States and its policies was negative. **********He said his main source for charges of links between the publisher and the Soviet Union was Mr. Bobolas's former partner, Yannis Yannikos, a Communist Party member. Mr. Yannikos said on being called as a witness in the libel suit that he was ill. He did not appear.
