https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/25/world.main_headline: ANXIETY UNDERLIES GRENADA'S SENSE OF RELIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/25/world.print_headline: ANXIETY UNDERLIES GRENADA'S SENSE OF RELIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/25/world.body_text: **********Despite a sense of relief among many Grenadians that life on this Caribbean island is returning to normal, there is also a underlying uneasiness here. **********The anxiety is over the possibility that elements of the former leftist Government, or its friends abroad, will ''return to claim their own,'' as one detainee of the former regime said. **********''There's a fear that there are people with guns outside who are awaiting their opportunity,'' a Grenadian diplomat said. **********As a result - although there is no evidence to substantiate these concerns - both United States and Caribbean forces on the island have been on an increased alert. About 300 United States soldiers are carrying out mostly police duties along with 500 members of the seven-nation Caribbean force that joined in the invasion and 250 Grenadian policemen. **********The chairman of Grenada's interim Government, Nicholas Braithwaite, said in an interview that the police had confirmed that former members of the Grenadian military underground were holding meetings. **********''We have their names, and some of them have recently been released from detention,'' he said. ''The record of these people convinces one that we cannot ignore the possibility of subversive action.'' Though their numbers are believed to be small, he said, ''you will appreciate that in a country as small as this, 100 people with guns could cause a great deal of confusion.'' **********Mr. Braithwaite said Grenadian police leave had been canceled for the holiday period and the United States Ambassador, Charles A. Gillespie, said United States and Caribbean forces were on ''increased alert'' in the light of ''reports of possible violence.'' **********Since the fighting that accompanied the Oct. 25 United States-led invasion ended in early November, there have been no reports of armed resistance by supporters of the old Government. The invasion began days after a hard-line faction toppled the Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who was later killed by Grenadian soldiers. **********Most members of the People's Revolutionary Army, the military arm of the former Government, have been released after being detained and questioned. It is partly their presence among the population that has given rise to fears of reprisals after the last United States forces leave. **********''These guys are still around,'' said Bryan Haynes, a former political detainee who is now unemployed. ''They would have made contingency plans in case they lost.'' **********''I'm not worried about the P.R.A. per se,'' said Lloyd Noel, a lawyer who was imprisoned by the former Government for more than three years. ''My fear is of the socialist countries by some means or other attempting to return to claim their own. **********''As for the former oppressors,'' Mr. Noel said, ''people are clearly afraid of the friends they have, the links they made, and the fact that having lost their positions of power they would spare no chance to regain it or at least to embarrass those who now hold it.'' **********''I wouldn't put it past Castro,'' another former detainee, Leslie Pierre, said, referring to the Cuban leader. ''These people were humiliated and embarrassed as they have been nowhere else. They are not the type to accept that with their tail between their legs and run home.'' **********Gaston Diaz, the only diplomat allowed to remain in the Cuban Embassy, told a visitor this week: ''We are not interested in being here. That chapter is closed to us for the time.'' **********Although no Cuban has been found hiding on the island in the past month, Col. D. C. M. Ormsby, commander of the Caribbean forces here, said frequent reports of sightings testify to people's nervousness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.main_headline: U.S. PRESS CURBS IN GRENADA MAY AFFECT INTERNATIONAL DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.print_headline: U.S. PRESS CURBS IN GRENADA MAY AFFECT INTERNATIONAL DEBATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.body_text: **********Some American reporters and press organizations say the Reagan Administration's restrictions on the press in covering the invasion of Grenada may damage Washington's position in a continuing international debate over controls on the gathering and dissemination of news. **********Western news organizations and most Western countries, including the United States, have been fighting proposals for press controls proposed by the Soviet Union and many developing countries. Those proposals, advanced in the last decade in forums of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, include giving governments a right to force the press to report positively about government actions and licensing journalists as a way to protect them in war zones. **********In a move broadly criticized by press groups, the Defense Department barred reporters from covering the first two days of fighting in Grenada and then provided limited guided tours of some parts of the island for two more days. The Pentagon said the limitations were initially needed to prevent advance disclosure of the operation and were later retained because the military could not assure the safety of correspondents. **********On Sunday, the man who approved the news restrictions, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said he would create a panel of officers and journaliists to review the restrictions in the first days of the invasion.   Unesco Conference in Paris **********Leonard R. Sussman, executive of director of Freedom House, a New York organization that has fought against press restrictions, said he anticipated the news controls in Grenada would be cited this week at the Unesco conference in Paris. Mr. Sussman is a member of the United States delegation to that meeting, which is scheduled to discuss a range of communications proposals, including a Soviet resolution that among other things affirms the right of governments to control some kinds of news. **********An official in the State Department's Office of Communications and Unesco Affairs said the delegation to the Paris meeting had been instructed on the Grenada news-control question because ''it is likely some mention will be made'' of the issue. He declined to say what the instructions were. **********Mr. Sussman said that although he thought the controls were wrong, he intended to respond to any criticism by noting that the controls were less restrictive than those routinely imposed by other nations and that they were finally lifted after an ''uproar in the press of the kind that only happens in a free society.'' He said the issue would be raised ''more as a matter of rhetoric by countries that are year-round censors themselves.''  'Prejudices the Position' **********Seymour Topping, managing editor of The New York Times, said, ''The extraordinary restriction imposed on the press in the coverage of the Grenada invasion prejudices the position the United States has taken in international forums on freedom of the press.'' Mr. Topping is chairman of the international communications committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which, like other press groups, protested the controls. **********He said the Western arguments to be made in Paris ''inevitably will suffer as a consequence of the example set by the Defense Department in denying access to correspondents in the coverage of the Grenada operation.'' **********''We cannot effectively preach freedom of the press abroad unless we practice it at home,'' Mr. Topping said.   Resistance to Information Order **********The Reagan Administration, like its predecessors, has resisted the ''new world information order'' that has repeatedly been proposed by third-world and Soviet bloc nations in Unesco meetings. By coincidence, on the first day American marines landed in Grenada, Mr. Reagan repeated his stand that ''accurate, objective information is necessary to the preservation of democracy and freedom.'' **********In a message congratulating the Foreign Press Association on its 65th anniversary, Mr. Reagan noted his opposition to ''restrictions on the right of journalists to report events and information as they see fit, free of authoritarian restrictions and official or ideological guidelines.'' **********Journalists were particularly critical of the Defense Department's reasoning that reporters should not be allowed in Grenada until their safety could be assured. Unesco has debated the issue of identification cards to journalists as a way to protect them in combat zones, but the Western press has said, as it did in Grenada, that reporters are responsible for their own security and that the proposed cards could easily turn into a system for governmental licensing of journalists.   An Insult, Publisher Says **********R. M. White 2d, publisher of The Mexico (Mo.) Ledger and chairman of the American Committee of the International Press Institute, said the idea of protecting journalists was an insult to the memory of war correspondents killed ''so that the American public could have an accurate accounting'' of the progress of fighting. **********Dana R. Bullen, executive director of the World Press Freedom Committe, based in Washington, said the Grenada invasion was a reminder that press curbs ''are bad whether its our Government or Zimbabwe.'' **********The restrictions surprised the Western press because in other situations the press has had almost totally free access to scenes of fighting. In the battles around Beirut, for example, American correspondents have been able to reach both sides. Some reporters interviewed Druse militiamen under fire from American warships. **********In Grenada, however, almost all foreign reporters were expelled after Prime Minister Maurice Bishop was overthrown a week before the invasion. **********Dwight Whylie, a Canadian Broadcasting Corporation reporter, filed reports until he was expelled the day before the invasion. He was in St. George's helping train the staff of the Government- run Radio Free Grenada under a program sponsored by Unesco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.main_headline: REAGAN PLANS TO CERTIFY RIGHTS PROGRESS IN SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.print_headline: REAGAN PLANS TO CERTIFY RIGHTS PROGRESS IN SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.body_text: **********Administration officials said today that despite the military crisis in El Salvador caused by the rebellion of a province commander, President Reagan plans to certify to Congress in the next few weeks that the Central American nation is making progress in human rights and political and economic changes. **********The officials said the dispute between the Salvadoran Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, and the province commander, Lieut. Col. Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, had complicated the issue of certification, which is required every six months by Congress as a condition for continuing aid to Salvador. But they said there was virtual unanimity at the moment in the State Department and White House on supporting certification. **********''I don't see a basis for opposing certification at this point,'' a ranking State Department official said. The Administration must make its certification decision by Jan. 28. Proposed aid to El Salvador this years totals $126 million. **********Concern Over Defense Chief **********State Department officials privately expressed concern over the future of General Garcia, who has supported American efforts at land redistribution in El Salvador and generally maintained close ties with American diplomats. The Defense Minister's departure, one official said, would be a setback for United States efforts in El Salvador. **********''We would not like to see him lose his post,'' he said.  At the moment, according to the official, United States diplomats in El Salvador are ''still betting on Garcia, but the bets are hedged.'' **********''He's still got a majority of high commanders with him, but the question is whether that support will erode.'' The State Department was reported surprised by the rebellion of Colonel Ochoa. ''Nobody saw this coming,'' an official said.  The colonel began his rebellion Thursday after receiving orders transferring him to a diplomatic post in Uruguay. He declared he no longer recognized the authority of General Garcia and demanded his resignation for the way he had handled the three-year-old guerrilla war. 'Internal Army Dispute' **********Officials here are concerned over Colonel Ochoa's apparent links to the Salvadoran rightist leader, Roberto d'Aubuisson, the president of the Constituent Assembly. Mr. d'Aubuisson strongly opposes land redistribution and other changes and his name has been linked to the violent activities of rightist squads. **********The present conflict, an official said, ''seems to be an internal army dispute involving institutional and military officials.'' Even if General Garcia leaves his defense post - he is to complete 30 years of military service this month -it is doubted here that it will solidify the power of the rightists and lead to Colonel Ochoa's advancement, at least for the moment. **********One official said that Mr. d'Aubuisson was not especially popular with senior army officers and that ''one of the things going against Ochoa is that he's too close to d'Aubuisson.'' The official said Colonel Ochoa, in attacking the institutional authority of General Garcia, weakened his own position in the military. **********Some human rights activists and Latin American experts disagree, saying that General Garcia's departure would buoy Mr. d'Aubuisson and Colonel Ochoa and bring an upheaval in the armed forces at a time when leftist guerrillas appear to be pressing their offensive in the countryside. Some Criticism Expected **********President Reagan's planned certification of aid to El Salvador is expected to be criticized by some human rights activists as well as members of Congress and will also meet the opposition of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. An affiliate of the labor group, the American Institute for Free Labor Development, has been involved in El Salvador for years, especially in efforts among peasants to reorganize the land system. **********Jack J. Heberle, a spokesman for the institute, said today that the organization would oppose certification because of a ''lack of progress'' in the murder of two Americans working for the A.F.L.- C.I.O. and a Salvadoran union leader who headed the land redistribution effort. The three were fatally shot at the Sheraton Hotel in San Salvador. **********Two former Salvadoran corporals have confessed to the killings, but two officers and a businessman who have been implicated in the murders - and who are well-connected to Salvadoran military and judicial figures - have gone unpunished. Salvador Rights Group Speaks Out **********SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 10 (AP) -The Salvadoran Human Rights Commission asked President Reagan today to stop putting arms in ''assassins' hands.'' **********In a letter made public here, the group urged Mr. Reagan not to certify that the Salvadoran Government was making progress in its human rights record. **********The rights group appealed to Mr. Reagan to support negotiations to end the war. The letter said such support would be a ''sign of hope that the war might reach an end.'' **********It said 38,000 civilians had been killed since the start of the war and 5,000 were reported missing.  The commission, which the Salvadoran Government says favors the leftists, attributed nearly all the deaths and disappearances to the Salvadoran armed forces. **********Commission members, many of whom live in exile, are mostly former professionals who were forced to abandon their regular jobs because of the civil war. **********The letter said American support for the Salvadoran Government made it ''responsible for tens of thousands of families suffering from the absence of at least one of its members.'' **********It added that political persecution had caused almost half a million people to flee for refuge in other countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/busin.main_headline: HEAD OF REALTY CONCERN DISMISSED AFTER 11 DAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/busin.print_headline: HEAD OF REALTY CONCERN DISMISSED AFTER 11 DAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/busin.body_text: **********William D. Foote, president and chief operating officer of Institutional Investors Trust, a real estate company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, has been dismissed after 11 days on the job. **********Mr. Foote, a California developer, said the dismissal came in a 5:30 A.M. phone call yesterday from Anthony J. Gumbiner, chairman and chief executive of Institutional Investors and also a European businessman who has his headquarters in Monte Carlo. He said it had followed a major policy disagreement between the two men. **********Mr. Foote, who received the Monte Carlo call at his home in Newport Beach, Calif., said the disagreement was ''over whether some things should be revealed to the regulatory authorities,'' but declined to elaborate on his statement. **********Allen E. Katz, who is senior vice president and general counsel for Institutional Investors Trust, said, ''I am not aware of what he is referring to.'' Earlier, Mr. Katz said he was not in a position to comment on why Mr. Foote had been ousted. Sale of Stake Reported **********The dismissal came on a busy day at Institutional Investors Trust.  In other developments yesterday, the enterprise was changed from a real estate trust to a corporation, and a real estate company in Toronto said it had an agreement to buy Mr. Gumbiner's interest in Institutional Investors Trust. **********Mr. Foote, who is 48 years old, left his job earlier this month as president of Cadillac Fairview Homes West to take the job with Institutional Investors Trust. The company was a debt-laden real estate trust that had incurred losses for a number of years. **********Mr. Gumbiner, a Briton, was described as a specialist in corporate reconstructions. The company's debt was bought out at discount and converted to equity, leaving it in an almost debt-free position, a source close to the transaction said. **********Mr. Gumbiner's company, Hallwood Holdings N.V., is an offshore company based in Monte Carlo.  Yesterday, the Unicorp Canada Corporation said it had an agreement to acquire 8 million to 10.4 million shares of Institutional Investors at $1.125 a share from Hallwood Holdings and certain institutions. A spokesman said he believed the shares represented Mr. Gumbiner's entire position. Institutional Investors has some 38 million shares outstanding. The stock closed yesterday at $1.375, up 12 1/2 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.body_text: **********D.A. McGee, a 79-year-old geologist and business manager who has retained tight control of the Kerr-McGee Corporation for more than 35 years, announced yesterday that he was stepping down as the company's chairman and chief executive officer. **********Kerr-McGee, a large oil, natural gas and coal producer based in Oklahoma City, named Frank A. McPherson, president of the company since 1980, as Mr. McGee's successor. **********Oil industry analysts said they were not suprised by the selection of Mr. McPherson, a 50-year-old petroleum engineer. Since his appointment as president three years ago, they said, Mr. McPherson had gradually taken on more responsibility in the company's operations and had been regarded both inside and outside the company. **********Mr. McGee joined the company in 1937 when it was small contract drilling concern known as the Kerlyn Oil Company. He was appointed its board of directors in 1947, and immediately took charge of its day-to-day operations while Robert Kerr, who was then the company's chairman and Oklahoma's governor, devoted an increasing amount of his time to state and national politics. **********Mr. McGee was named chairman of the company in 1962.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/14/busin.body_text: **********Two top tax experts in Congress said today that President Reagan's refusal to agree to any tax increase could doom the Federal Government to budget deficits approaching $300 billion by the end of the decade. **********Senator Bob Dole, Republlican of Kansas and chairman of the Finance Committee, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said Congress was ready to start reducing the current $200 billion deficit with a mix of spending cuts and tax changes. **********But, they added, Mr. Reagan would not cooperate. **********''The main player on the ballfield isn't there, and that's the President,'' Mr. Rostenkowski said on the ABC- TV program, ''This Week With David Brinkley.'' **********''I don't think Congress can set the pace or direction with which we're going to attack the problem,'' he added. **********Mr. Dole, speaking later on the same program, said the President appeared to be concerned with holding the line on taxes primarily to insure re-election next year. He suggested that such a view was short-sighted. ''The White House looks at 1984 and says we're in good shape, we'll address this problem in 1985,'' he said.  ''But it may be that the economy will start to stagnate then and we won't be able to address it in 1985 with either spending cuts or revenue changes.'' **********Mr. Rostenkowski said Congressional estimates showed that the deficit would remain well above $200 billion and gradually rise to at least $289 billion by 1989.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/27/busin.main_headline: THE TWILIGHT OF THE INDUSTRIAL RUHR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/27/busin.print_headline: THE TWILIGHT OF THE INDUSTRIAL RUHR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/27/busin.body_text: **********OBERHAUSEN, WEST GERMANY ALONG Essenerstrasse, a highway **********that slices through the heart of the **********Ruhr Valley, there's a cracked and weathered sign that reads, ''We Are Hiring.'' **********But the fence on which it hangs is rusted; the building behind it is boarded up. Everywhere the remains of dismantled blast furnaces lie like the bleached bones of dinosaurs in knee-high weeds. The Ruhr, once the powerful engine of Germany's industrial juggernaut, has run out of steam. **********Just 10 years ago, businessmen from around the world flocked to the grimy cities of this valley to buy the huge machines and equipment that have made its name synonymous with industrial quality. Oberhausen, the gray and gritty home of 240,000 people, is one of those cities. Back then, Thyssen, Germany's biggest steel company, kept 14,000 workers busy turning out heavy steel plate, light steel sections and wire for machine builders, shipyards and construction companies. **********But then the world plunged into a troubled era of high energy costs, recession and stop-go growth from which it has yet to emerge. Cash-strapped customers from the developing nations put their expansion plans in limbo and stopped buying. The West European building slump squeezed demand for sections and wire, and the decline of the Continent's shipyards and oil refineries slimmed demand for the heavy plate used to build hulls and storage tanks. **********Today, despite reducing the work week to a bare 20 hours, Thyssen has had to pare its workforce at Oberhausen to 6,000. And on Friday, the steel giant approved plans to shut down a press works. The company tried to soften the blow by adding that it would keep steel plate production going ''for the time being.'' Thyssen says the decision will mean the loss of 600 jobs but union leaders figure 2,100 jobs will eventually be lost. That would be a harsh blow to this town where the unemployment rate already is 15.9 percent. **********The Oberhausen pattern is repeated throughout the depressed Ruhr, a patch of hill country - no bigger than Washington, D.C. - that tucks into the angle of northwestern Germany created by the borders of the Netherlands and Belgium. The region's huge steel companies - Thyssen, Hoesch, and Krupp - are cutting back their basic operations and have even talked merger. Ruhrkhole, the big energy company whose coal mines fire the steel mills, will lose $226 million this year because of falling demand. More than 13 percent of the Ruhr's workers, some 255,000 people, are unemployed. **********The fundamental question confronting West Germany's economic strategists is whether the Ruhr's afflictions are cyclical, and thus likely to be remedied by the arrival one day of a sustained economic recovery, or structural, and therefore destined to remain a problem no matter what good turns the business cycle should take. **********Those who espouse the latter view say the Ruhr's misfortunes are symptomatic of a malaise afflicting other basic **********German industries such as textiles and shipbuilding, which have been doubly hurt in recent years by recession at home and fierce competition from lower-cost producers abroad. They also view the Ruhr as a mirror of troubles afflicting most developed nations today - the United States included - which are struggling to salvage heavy, basic industries under attack from low-cost foreign producers and from substitute materials, such as plastic and aluminum. **********If the structuralists are right, the Ruhr must sharply reduce its dependence upon its weakened basic industries and diversify into more sophisticated industries with greater growth potential. Policy has begun to take baby steps in this direction. Bonn and the State Government of North Rhine-Westphalia, where the Ruhr flows on its way to the Rhine, are pumping several billion dollars into subsidies for existing industries and into efforts to attract high technology companies to the region. **********For politicians, the Ruhr's fate could turn out to be critically important. The right-wing Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl won a landslide victory in national elections last March on the promise to revive West Germany's flagging economy and create jobs. Many Ruhr workers, who traditionally lean to the political left, apparently voted for the conservatives in desperation. If the Ruhr continues to slide they may switch back to the Socialist Democrats. **********The Ruhr, of course, has been down and out before. During World War II, British and American bombers flattened the huge steel and armament producing plants situated in the Those raids destroyed roughly 30 percent of the region's steel mills and damaged other factories beyond repair. To prevent the resurgence of what Allied leaders had come to view as militaristic Germany's industrial Hydra, Treasury Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. sent a memorandum to President Franklin D. Roosevelt proposing that the Ruhr be totally de- industrialized by tearing down all of its industries and returning the valley to farming and sheep grazing. **********Resistance to the plan by European leaders, mainly in Britain and the Netherlands (roughly three-fourths of the port of Rotterdam's traffic before the war involved goods from the Ruhr), enabled the valley to revive and help fuel the remarkable economic growth that West Germany generated after its recovery from the ruins of World War II. High-quality iron ores from Sweden, Brazil and Australia came barging down the Rhine to Duisburg, whose maze of docks and arching cranes make it Europe's biggest inland port - a clearing house for raw materials coming in and finished steel and industrial goods going out. **********The post-World War II era was marked by a curious entangling of the industrial and political forces that controlled the region. The Ruhr's steel barons increasingly had to share their power with the powerful Social Democratic Party and its close allies, the labor unions. Thus Dortmund's Social Democratic mayor, G"unter Samtlebe, is an influential union member and an employee of Hoesch, the steel concern. The Social Democrats' parliament member from Duisburg is an engineer at Thyssen.  The most pernicious effect of this paternalistic control was the atrophy of small innovative business in the shadow of the coal and steel giants, says Theo Siepert, business editor of the Neue Ruhr Zeitung, the region's most influential daily. The steel giants, moreover, failed in the 1970's to develop the new technologies required to compete against the steel industries of such emerging industrial nations as Spain, Brazil, and South Korea. In addition, the relentlessly blue-collar tinge of the region mitigated against the development of institutions of higher education in the valley. The first university in the Ruhr was not founded until the 1960's. **********The ramifications of that coalition are now ravaging the Ruhr. ''If we cannot get the drive back into the region,'' said Dieter Hockel, an economist at Germany's trade union Federation in D"usseldorf, ''then Morgenthau has won out in the end.'' **********To remedy what they believe to be structural problems, policy makers like Reimut Jochimsen, the economics minister of North Rhine-Westphalia, are backing a five-year, $2.7-billion, government program to transform the valley by attracting high- tech companies with cash grants, low-cost property and improved university facilities that, it is hoped, will eventually spew forth new research and a skilled work force. ''A region that was founded on basic products - steel, coal, ores - a key region for 150 years, is now in a process of adjustment at a time of slow growth,'' says Mr. Jochimsen - and it needs Government help. **********BUT if the problem is primarily cyclical, as some West Germans still believe, such sweeping changes may not be needed. Industries that are suppliers for machinery and machine tool makers, automobile and plant builders could be expected to burst back to life automatically once the West German economy revives. **********''The giant steel companies have some dead branches, but they have lively products too, with state-of-the- art technology,'' says Theo Siepert, of the Neue Ruhr Zeitung, an optimist in the current debate. ''The Ruhr is not Belgium. It is not dead or in intensive care.'' **********Analysts of Mr. Siepert's stripe argue that the Ruhr's traditional businesses must be kept largely intact to take advantage of eventual economic recovery. And recover it must, they believe, if West Germany is to remain the industrial powerhouse of Europe. **********The farmers and their sheep are unlikely to reclaim control of the Ruhr any time soon. But the industrial barons and those other post- World War II powers in the Ruhr, the trade unions, have lost some of their once unshakable grip. The steel fiefdoms of Thyssen and Krupp are particularly shaky. Their mighty mills will produce barely 30 million tons of steel this year, a far cry from the postwar peak of 53 million tons in 1974. And even tougher times lie ahead. Thyssen, for example, plans to slash its annual crude steel capacity of 16 million metric tons by about one- third. Krupp, another of the region's major steel producers, has announced capacity cuts that will eliminate 4,000 of its 34,000 steelmaking jobs by the end of 1985. What's more, steel company executives predict that the industry will lose about $1.2 billion, or roughly $40 for every ton it produces in 1983. **********STEEL'S problems have spread **********to other industries. The coal **********mining industry, too, is in deep trouble, despite huge Government subsidies - $235 million this year alone. Industry leaders and Government officials agree that lower demand from steelmakers and utilities has built up such huge coal reserves that production cuts and worker layoffs are inevitable. **********In steel towns like Dortmund and Duisburg - trim, modern cities that still reflect three decades of unbroken prosperity - unemployment is above 15 percent, nearly twice the national average. Now it seems bound to rise even higher **********That jobless figure is rendered all the more dramatic by the wave of emigration that has drained the Ruhr in recent years. During the 1960's, when cheap oil from the Middle East began to undercut the viability of the Ruhr coal industry, some 300,000 people left the region for jobs in the faster-growing south German cities of Stuttgart and Munich, where electrical companies like Siemens or Bosch and auto makers like Daimler-Benz were thriving. Between 1970 and 1980 a further quarter of a million Ruhrites followed suit. **********The unemployment picture is likely to get worse before its gets better. The steelmakers are slashing the production of bulk steel and other traditional items that can no longer compete on world markets. (Like most West German industries, steel is heavily dependent upon the export market.) To take up the slack, the companies are concentrating upon sophisticated, higher value-added products, ranging from precision machinery and electronics to turnkey factories. But world markets for even these products remains soft. **********The program to attract high-tech companies is enjoying some success. Although its major production facilities will remain in southern Germany, Hewlett-Packard has opened a regional center near D"usseldorf, and a new service center in Dortmund. Also in Dortmund, Hoesch Steel expanded its software consulting subsidiary, M.B.P., helping to triple the number of jobs in the region's computer industry, to 1,500, since 1975.Farther to the east, the 3M Company is expanding a factory it built in Kamen in the 1970's to make plastic jackets for computer diskettes and video cassettes. **********But even ardent supporters of such tactics concede that the high-tech newcomers have had minimal effect in easing unemployment. Reinhard Bischof, vice president of the Economic Development Corporation for North Rhine-Westphalia, an agency that helps settle companies in depressed areas like the Ruhr, said an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 steelworkers could be laid off over the next three to four years. ''We don't know how to replace those jobs,'' he said. ''We need new companies with 200 to 300 employees. Those we're getting average 20 to 100.'' **********Much more needs to be done before the strategy to attract high-tech companies can be fairly judged, say its proponents. Andreas Schlieper, an economist with the Essen-based Federation of Ruhr Cities, would have the region's banks supply more of the venture capital small companies need in high-risk sectors like electronics or bioengineering. In addition, he wants local governments to imitate the British by creating ''sheltered environments'' for companies, by offering low tax rates and other business benefits. He also suggests expanding the region's cable communication and transportation networks, thus creating both new investment and jobs. **********German economists who lean to the cyclical argument warn against moving too far from the region's traditional industries. ''Policy that starts with the employment rate of individual concerns is dangerous,'' contends Willi Lamberts, an economist at the Rhenish-Westphalian Research Institute located in Essen. ''My fear is that the adjustments we are undertaking are having the effect of destroying the structure of the region. It is de-industrialization.'' **********Those of Mr. Lamberts' persuasion believe that selective surgery rather than wholesale industrial transplanting is all that is needed in the region. They say that too sweeping a dismantling of the Ruhr's traditional industries could sap the big companies' strength, rendering them unable to meet the needs of West Germany's sophisticated automobile, shipbuilding and construction industries, if the world economy returned to sustained growth. **********As in Youngstown, Liverpool, in Britain, or Charleroi, in Belgium's steelmaking Meuse Valley, a sense of helplessness is spreading. Yet so far, the Ruhr has accepted its blows quietly. In Belgium, barely 100 miles to the west, red banners and occupations of factories have become commonplace. Here, discontent finds its voice in an occasional demonstration and, in last March's general election, a marked shift at the polls to the conservative Christian Democrats, whose promises of austerity evidently struck many workers as a useful remedy for West Germany's, and the Ruhr's, economic ills. **********ONE possible reason is the inborn caution that comes from living under the protective wings of strong companies, unions and political parties. Another possible explanation is the almost total financial support that the unemployed in West Germany receive in the first year off the job. The former employer and the local municipality provide benefits and the federal Government pays 68 percent of the last year's salary. **********Long accustomed to secure jobs, company housing, and the generous health and pension plans that were the result of a far-reaching consensus between business and labor, the Ruhr's workers tend to look patiently to employers and unions for solutions. Now, however, there is a spreading sense that corporate profitability is being maintained at the expense of jobs. Moreover, as the unemployed remain without jobs for more than a year, their benefits diminish markedly. **********''We don't want soup kitchens like in Detroit,'' said Friedrich Kinnigkeit, a former coal miner who is the Deputy Mayor of Essen. ''In the 20's and 30's, the Ruhr was a center of unrest. Today it's a stabilizing factor. But that could change if hopelessness spreads. We cannot pull ourselves out of this mess by our own hair.'' **********Will the Ruhr recover? As on the remedies, so do opinions vary vaguely on the long-term prognosis. ''The Ruhr's importance will persist,'' said Gangolf Weiler, a Thyssen executive in Duisburg. ''There will be financial and fiscal problems. The cities may have to close swimming pools, theaters and ice rinks. But the Rhine is there and will always be there. There are first-class highways and rail lines. The people are realists - dry, perhaps, but good workers.'' **********Others are less sure. ''What do people in Detroit do?'' another steel executive asked. ''They go South, they go to California. People will insist that Dortmund or Oberhausen must remain steel cities. They say that's where the Ruhr was born. I can only say, 'Why?' '' **********FLOWERS AMIDFOUNDRIES **********BONN Mention the Ruhr to most Americans and they think of those smoke-belching blast furnaces and sooty gray settlements for coal miners and foundry hands that Allied bombers strafed in old B-movies. And there is no denying that even today, the Ruhr does have its scruffier corners, like rundown areas of Gelsenkirchen or backwater neighborhoods of Duisburg that are favored by the area's Turkish migrant workers for their cheap rents and proximity to the mills. **********But the Ruhr has its attractive side. The ride up Route 52 from D"usseldorf to Essen, crossing the meandering Ruhr River near a town called Kettwig, evokes the pastoral serenity of the Sawmill River Parkway rather than the industrial grittiness of the Pulaski Skyway. **********The steel cities themselves, most of them rural farming towns in the 19th century, have spent heavily on parks, flowers and trees. Years ago, public-spirited city fathers enacted tough laws on the recovery of coal mining land and the foresting of the mountainous refuse dumps created by the coaling coke furnaces of the steel mills. **********This year, Duisburg, the biggest inland port on the Rhine and the gateway to the Ruhr basin, was host to the European sculling championships on a stretch of harbor water whose lush green backdrop must have reminded even Britain's Oxford-based oarsmen of home. **********By their own admission, some of the Ruhr's cities don't shy from deviousness to achieve their greening. When Dortmund recently applied for Federal funds to put some of its jobless to work on public projects, the money was granted on condition that nothing be produced that would compete with local industry. To comply, the city set its unemployed to work planting trees and flowers in local parks. **********The project did not do much to prevent unemployment from climbing to its current 16 percent level, concedes G"unter Samtlebe, Dortmund's Mayor. On the other hand, he adds, ''We're probably the city in the Ruhr with by far the most trees per square mile.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.print_headline: WHAT'S NEW IN JAPANESE ROBOTICS; TRACKING THE SMART MACHINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Robot experts here often speak in terms of generations and the third -and latest - one that has drawn widespread attention is the robot with artificial intelligence, a development far more sophisticated than mere movement. Aided by sophisticated sensors and computer software, these ''smart'' machines are being developed to respond to outside changes, make judgments, communicate with human operators and process information. **********Now, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry is preparing to initiate a seven- to eight-year research project in thirdgeneration robotics. The government-and-industry project will begin this year and, tentatively, the government seed money will be $85 million. **********Government officials say that the program should develop robots that can do hazardous work, such as cleaning up nuclear plants, rescuing disaster victims and working deep underwater. But, the application for the technologies they want to nurture will have countless commercial applications well beyond the potentially hazardous tasks. **********''These robots must have the sensing and dexterity almost the equal of human beings, so they can take the place of human beings,'' explained Masakazu Kobayashi, director of the ministry's robot project. **********The rationale for Government involvement, he said, is that the cost and risk of developing sophisticated technology is too great for private companies to bear alone. Moreover, he noted that the market for some of the projects is small, such as nuclear cleaning robots, even though development costs are great. The ministry will invite companies to join the project in September or October, based on proposals the companies will submit. **********Mr. Kobayashi said foreign companies are not excluded from the project, as long as they have research or manufacturing facilities in Japan. But, he conceded, ''from a practical standpoint it may be difficult for foreign firms to participate'' because of the requirement about having a facility in Japan. **********The robot with artificial intelligence follows the firstgeneration, so-called playback robot and its relatives, which have memory capacity and play back the simple job they have learned.  These pioneer robots were born more than a decade ago and the market is now deemed to be mature. The second-generation, ''adaptive'' robots adjust to minor changes in their surroundings and have just started being used in industrial manufacturing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.body_text: **********The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said today that it had completed a $250 million debt refinancing package with its six major banks. **********The company's total debt, which reached a peak of $528 million a year ago, is now $133 million. **********''I never dreamed that in a year and a half we would have come as far as we've come,'' Frank Rothman, chairman and chief executive, said in an interview. Mr. Rothman was named to the post in February 1982, by Kirk Kerkorian, MGM/UA's controlling stockholder. **********A budget limit of $8.5 million average per movie, ordered by the banks a year ago, was lifted. MGM/UA also will pay no more than the prime lending rate on its remaining debt. **********MGM/UA's finances have brightened with the popularity of its two current releases ''War Games'' and ''Octopussy,'' both of which were being developed before Mr. Rothman arrived. The films have taken in $42.9 million and $43.3 million, respectively, at the box office through Tuesday. **********''War Games'' barely survived Mr. Rothman's own cost-cutting.  ''One of my first edicts was to cancel it,'' when the picture appeared to be exceeding a projected $12 million budget, he said.  But after assurances from its producer, Leonard Goldberg, that the picture could be made for that figure, and after major script and personnel changes, Mr. Rothman said, he agreed to go forward. **********The film was delivered on budget, he continued. Although the bank limit on budgets has been lifted, Mr. Rothman said he is determined to maintain the discipline internally, averaging about $10 million a film. **********''Psychologically this feels good, but my philosophy hasn't changed,'' he said. ''I don't want to take the company back into the trouble we just got out of.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/11/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company, continuing a strategy of reducing its dependence on photographic products in favor of more high-technology areas, introduced a blood analyzer designed for doctor's offices. **********The new Ektachem DT-60 analyzer, a smaller version of the company's high-volume analyzers used in hospitals and laboratories, is about the size of a typewriter and can produce test results in 5 minutes, Kodak said. The dry-chemistry device will sell for under $6,000 and will come to market late next year, it said. **********The Boehringer-Mannheim Diagnostics Corporation, of Indianapolis, is also coming to market with a similar product, the Reflotron. The company said the unit would likely be priced lower than Kodak's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Citicorp is joining forces with leading supermarkets in Florida and California to give its credit card holders easy access to cash. The nation's largest bank holding company also expects similar accords soon in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area. The move is seen as a further dilution of Federal laws that prohibit interstate banking. **********Citicorp has already signed agreements with Safeway Stores Inc. in California and Publix Super Markets Inc. in Florida. Its potential partner in the New York area has not been identified. **********The move into supermarkets is viewed by some banking analysts as a dramatic new step in Citicorp's effort to provide a full range of banking services to customers throughout the country. They said the trend could speed the process toward interstate banking and could increase pressure on banks that operate large and costly branch systems. **********'National Banking Is Here' **********''National banking is here,'' said Ira S. Rimerman, senior vice president in charge of Citicorp's credit card activities. **********Unlike accords in which banks in different parts of the country have agreed to share teller machines for the convenience of travelers, Citicorp's strategy is to develop a comprehensive consumer banking business in local areas nationwide. **********Currently, Citicorp offers Mastercard and Visa credit cards, as do other banks. But it also is in the travel and entertainment card business through its ownership of Carte Blanche and Diner's Club. Holders of all these Citicorp cards will have access to the supermarket machines. **********A bank that can deliver banking services more cheaply by using machines, telephones and the mail can present formidable competition to banks still operating expensive branch networks, which require a lot of real estate and employees. **********''It's a powerful idea,'' said James Wooden, an analyst of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc., referring to Citicorp's move into supermarkets. ''It's part of a grand design to extend Citicorp's range of machines throughout the country. It could fill the missing link.'' **********Everything but Cash **********That link is getting cash to Citicorp's five million or so credit card holders across the country. Through the cards, the mail, and toll-free phone numbers, Citicorp already offers its customers just about any other banking service. **********For the past two years, it has been soliciting deposits through the mail by offering high-yielding money market accounts. And through its credit cards, Citicorp customers around the country can automatically get loans, some as large as $50,000. Federal laws that prohibit interstate banking merely bar banks from taking deposits through out-of-state offices. **********A few years ago that seemed like a major problem. But today, with mail and phone solicitation, ''taking deposits through a retail branch is a relatively minor function,'' said Mr. Wooden of Merrill Lynch. The big problem now is getting cash to the public, and an automated teller machine, or A.T.M., is one solution. **********For the supermarkets, the primary motive is to lure more customers into their stores. Supermarkets are making their A.T.M.'s available to all financial institutions that agree to pay a fee for each transaction. Thus, a single machine in one supermarket could be used by customers of many financial institutions nationwide. **********'We Know More About Lettuce' **********''We're not doing it because we want to be a bank, but because we want to be a better grocer,'' said Shaun P. Pond, consumer financial services coordinator for Safeway. ''We know more about lettuce than banking, we just want something to bring more people into our stores and give them better service. It's a feature we'd like to see in as many of our 1,900 stores as possible.'' **********Publix, one of the biggest supermarket chains in Florida, has installed 183 A.T.M.'s and plans to install another 120 or so within a year. ''We thought we'd give our customers additional service,'' said Howard Jenkins, vice president. **********Mr. Jenkins said the program has cost Publix about $10 million. The chain, he said, charges banks between 30 and 40 cents per cash withdrawal. More than 300 banks, savings and loan associations and credit unions within Florida have joined the Publix network. There also are two out-of-state participants, Citicorp and the American Express Company. **********Unlike Publix, Safeway does not own or maintain the machines itself. It merely provides space to an outside company, National Transactions Systems Inc., of El Segundo, Calif., which was formed in 1982 by Frederick W. Field, an heir to the Marshall Field fortune. **********So far, National Transactions has installed 50 machines in Safeway stores in Southern California. It soon will install another 50 in the Bay Area. It splits the fees it receives from the financial institutions with Safeway. The fees are 75 cents for each withdrawal, 40 cents for each account transfer and 20 cents for each balance inquiry. Each financial institution decides whether to pass these costs on to the consumer. **********Trend Said to Be Growing **********James W. Brubaker, National Transactions' chief executive officer, said the trend toward cash machines in supermarkets and other retail outlets is growing. His company, he said, has reached agreement to install teller machines in Safeway stores in Arizona, and talks are being held with a ''convenience store and a major department store in California.'' **********Mr. Brubaker also said that National Transactions is holding talks with a large supermarket chain in the New York metropolitan area and that Citicorp already has agreed to participate if that arrangement materialized. Mr. Brubaker declined to name the chain. Citicorp confirmed Mr. Brubaker's information, but also declined to identify the chain. **********For some banks, the installation of teller machines in retail stores is both a threat and an opportunity. It allows banks to vastly expand cash-dispensing and money-transfer services without having to invest millions of dollars. And it gives small banks the opportunity to have large networks they could not otherwise afford.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.main_headline: TEST FOR MITTERRAND IN FRENCH VOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.print_headline: TEST FOR MITTERRAND IN FRENCH VOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/02/world.body_text: **********France will hold nationwide municipal elections Sunday that are widely regarded as a referendum on the performance of the 21-month-old Socialist Government of President Francois Mitterrand. **********The elections, the first nationwide balloting since the Socialists took power, are for local governments in France's 36,400 cities, villages and hamlets. **********The center-right opposition, looking for major gains, is urging voters to use the elections to give a ''warning'' to the Socialists, to send a message of opposition to the Government's policies. **********The Socialists and Communists are, in effect, urging voters to stay the course, while also counting on the popularity of some of their incumbent mayors to prevent a sweep by the center-right. Another factor working in favor of the leftist coalition is that while their policies are not especially popular, the polls indicate that the ideas and leading personalities of the opposition are not too popular, either. **********Poor January Figures **********The Socialists' campaign was jolted this weekend by the release of two statistics: Government figures showed that prices rose ninetenths of 1 percent in January, which project an annual inflation rate of more than 10 percent, suggesting that it will be difficult for Finance Minister Jacques Delors to meet his objective of holding inflation to 8 percent for 1983. And the deficit in the country's balance of trade in January was 9.58 billion francs, about $1.4 billion, up from 5.9 billion francs in December. **********The opposition immediately seized on the numbers, which are expected to play a major role in their final campaign salvos against the Government. **********''The latest public indices confirm our worries: France is in a bad state,'' former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing declared today during a campaign swing in Vincennes. ''It is sad when dreams are disappointed, but we can replace the dream with confidence.'' **********The elections will be held in two rounds, the first on March 6 and a runoff on the 13th in cities and districts where no party list gets a first-round majority. The first round is expected to be decisive in many localities; in most cities, the Communists and Socialists are running as a single ticket against right-of-center slates that include neo-Gaullists, Giscard followers and centrists. Left Goes on Defense **********In almost every city and town, the neo-Gaullists led by the Mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac, have erected billboards declaring: ''City by city, let us win back France.'' **********In the past, conservatives argued that the municipal elections were local matters. This was a natural argument for the right to make, since conservative local politicians are usually well-known ''notables'' who do better on their own than as part of a national movement. This year, however, the center-right has, in the parlance here, ''politicized'' the local balloting around national issues, sensing a trend against the Socialists. **********On the other side, the Communist Party has put out posters calling for ''a union against the right.'' Two years ago, the catch phrase was ''the union of the left,'' and the shift to negative and defensive campaigning tells something about the state of the Government's popularity. **********The left alliance is faced with the problem of defending a sharp turnaround in its economic policy.  When he first took office, President Mitterrand began by nationalizing key sectors of the economy and embarked on a program of active Government intervention in the economy in an effort to stimulate it. Shift to Austerity Measures **********The Government program included increasing the buying power of lower middle class Frenchmen by raising the minimum wage, cutting the workweek by an hour, increasing taxes on the well-to-do and giving workers new rights. This policy did result in economic growth, but also drew in a flood of imports, aggravating the country's trade deficit. **********So the Government shifted to an austerity policy, including wage and price controls and some budget cuts. The Government has argued that overall, it has managed to reduce inflation, while holding the unemployment rate below that of other Western countries. **********But most French economic analysts and voters expect still more austerity after the election, and possibly another devaluation of the franc. And from a political standpoint, the Government's shift in policy appears to have alienated some of its working class supporters. Government Faces Trouble **********Christophe Riboud, president of a French polling agency, said the Government faces political trouble on both fronts.  First there are the ''disappointed voters,'' mainly the young and blue collar workers. Both groups hoped for major improvements in their standard of living, improvements which by and large did not materialize. For the young, continuing high unemployment is a particular burden. **********''But these voters won't necessarily switch sides,'' Mr. Riboud said. Most workers will still vote for the left, and those who are unhappy will protest by staying home. **********However, Mr. Riboud said the right is likely to pick up votes among the younger ''new middle class'' professionals. These voters, particularly working women, liked the sound of Mr. Mitterrand's promises for social change, but may now be ready to realign with the traditional middle class, Mr. Riboud said. **********The main battles are being fought in the 219 cities in France with populations of 30,000 or more. The left alliance posted major gains in the 1977 municpal elections and now controls 154 of these cities.  Just over half of these have Socialist mayors or the center-left Movement of Left Radicals; the rest are led by Communists. **********Pierre Martin, a top Socialist campaign official, argues that the left coalition did so well in 1977 that losses are inevitable. This line of reasoning will help the Socialists rationalize anything but a catastrophic loss - something over 50 cities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.main_headline: PALESTINIANS AND ISRAELIS WELCOME THEIR PRISONERS FREED IN EXCHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.print_headline: PALESTINIANS AND ISRAELIS WELCOME THEIR PRISONERS FREED IN EXCHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.body_text: **********Six Israeli soldiers, held prisoner for more than 14 months by the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon, returned home today to a tumultuous, passionate welcome. **********Crowds of family and friends hugged the returning soldiers, poured champagne on their heads and carried them above the throngs after they flew into Sde Dov Airport near Tel Aviv. **********In exchange, Israel completed the release of 4,500 Arab prisoners, including some who were serving life sentences for terrorist attacks on Israeli civilians. It also closed the Ansar camp, a detention center built in southern Lebanon after the 1982 invasion. **********Freed in Algeria and Lebanon **********About 3,400 Arab prisoners were set free in Lebanon, and 1,100 were flown in three Air France jumbo jets to Algeria, the Israeli Army said. The P.L.O.'s archives, seized in West Beirut during the 1982 Israeli invasion, were also returned. **********The release of so many Palestinian guerrillas prompted Israeli reporters to ask Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir if the move nullified the gains of Israel's invasion of Lebanon, which sought to destroy the P.L.O. and reduce terrorism.  ''We paid a high price for the release of the six,'' Mr. Shamir replied, ''but in the negotiations we were faced with the fact that their lives were in peril, and that at any moment the worst could happen.'' The six soldiers were being held in Tripoli, Lebanon, by the forces of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the P.L.O., who has been under fierce attack from rival Syrian-backed rebel Palestinians. **********Whether broader political strategies figured in the Israeli decision could not be immediately determined. The sudden release of thousands of guerrillas could bolster the Arafat forces in their fight against the rebels in Tripoli, but it was not clear whether this was an Israeli goal. **********At a news conference in Tel Aviv, Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the releases could exacerbate Israel's security problems in southern Lebanon. ''This certainly is a cause for concern,'' Mr. Arens said, ''but it was a decision we had to take, and any delay in bringing them back could have been disastrous. We have problems, we will have problems, and we don't rule out the possibility that they will be harder.'' **********Deputy Foreign Minister Yehuda Ben-Meir said Israel's willingness to free a large number of guerrillas underscored ''the value which is at the heart of the uniqueness of the Israel Defense Forces, the fact that every soldier knows that no matter what may happen, the entire people of Israel and the Government of Israel, with all the might and ability and resources that we have, will stand behind him and that we will go to all lengths in the world to bring him home.'' **********Today's release left at least five Israelis and 300 Syrians still in captivity as a result of the Lebanon fighting. Two or three Israelis are being held in Damascus by a radical P.L.O. faction led by Ahmed Jabril, and three are prisoners of Syria, the army says, and are reportedly being held in severe conditions. Five Israelis are missing. Israel has said that it is anxious to exchange the 300 Syrians.   Red Cross Aid **********The Red Cross evacuated the Israelis early this morning, and also took charge of the Palestinian prisoners being released from Israel and from Ansar. **********The Army's announcement said that a second stage would involve discussion with the Jabril faction on the release of the Israelis being held by that group. **********Today's prisoner exchange followed the pattern of such exchanges in past wars. After the 1967 war, according to the army's figures, 6,718 Arabs were exchanged for 15 captured Israelis. After the 1973 war, 8,811 Arabs were released for 299 Israelis. **********Initially, Israel demanded the return of all prisoners at once, but changed tactics as fighting flared in Tripoli and threatened the lives of the six, Mr. Arens said. **********Negotiations were conducted in Geneva under the auspices of the International Committee of the Red Cross, an Israeli Army announcement said. The Israeli delegation was led by former Justice Minister Shmuel Tamir and Brig. Gen. Amos Yaron, head of manpower for the Israeli Army. A Red Cross official also traveled between Tripoli and Tel Aviv, serving as an intermediary between Mr. Arafat and Mr. Arens, the Israeli radio reported.   Release Recommended **********Mr. Tamir, speaking at a news conference in Tel Aviv, said that one of the six prisoners had suffered psychological problems during recent shelling. Under the terms of the Geneva Convention, he was examined by two Red Cross doctors and two from the P.L.O., all of whom recommended his release, Mr. Tamir said. but the P.L.O. did not comply. General Yaron identified the man as Private Danny Gilboa, 20 years old, but said he was now all right. **********All the men, ranging in age from 19 to 21, were captured in September 1982 when their outpost north of Bhamdun, in central Lebanon, was overrun. They were taken by fishing boat in the early hours of this morning from Tripoli to a French vessel, then transferred to an Israeli naval vessel, which docked in Haifa. From there, they were flown by helicopter to Sde Dov. They looked thin, pale and exhausted, and they replied to reporters' questions mostly with one-word answers. **********According to Mr. Tamir, the P.L.O. initially demanded that in addition to the approximately 4,400 prisoners held at the Ansar camp, another 1,250 convicted Palestinian terrorists be freed from Israeli prisons. The final swap included 100 such prisoners, 37 of whom had been seized recently by the Israeli Navy as they tried to make their way from Cyprus to Tripoli. **********Neither Mr. Arens nor other officials would give the names of any of the other 63, who were serving sentences for terrorist attacks. But Bishara Bahbah, editor-in-chief of Al Fajr, a Palestinian newspaper based in East Jerusalem, said that his reporters had been told by relatives that several well- known figures were among those freed.   Bombing, Hijacking Figures **********According to Dr. Bahbah, they included Ziad Abu Eian, who was extradited from the United States in December 1981 and sentenced to life in prison for a bombing in Tiberias that killed 2 Israeli teenagers and wounded 36 other people. **********Another of those freed, Dr. Bahbah said, was Therese Halasse, whom he identified as a hijacker of a Sabena airliner to Israel in 1972. The editor's information could not be confirmed. **********Other Palestinian journalists reported the release of three of the four P.L.O. terrorists who attacked a crowd of Jewish worshipers in Hebron in 1980, killing 6 and wounding 16. Those freed were said to include Adnan Jaber, the squad's commander, who was trained in the Soviet Union. Israeli officials would not comment on the reports. **********The P.L.O. archives, which were captured when the Israeli Army entered West Beirut in September 1982, were turned over to the Red Cross, the army said. **********The head of the P.L.O.'s research center in Beirut, Sabry Juryis, had said the files contained only historical information on Arab families and villages in pre-1948 Palestine, and he said that microfilms had been made of everything except some old and valuable books. **********The Israelis have said that the research center was less an academic than an intelligence organization, and that much of the data could be used in planning terrorist attacks. **********In any event, Israel's concessions caused considerable pain here. ''It hurt to see the terrorists climb the Air France gangway,'' said General Yaron, ''because I know how much it has cost us to bring the terrorists to Ansar or to Israeli prisons.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.main_headline: U.S. EASES SOME CURBS AGAINST POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.print_headline: U.S. EASES SOME CURBS AGAINST POLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/world.body_text: **********The White House announced today what it called ''two limited steps'' easing the economic sanctions against Poland imposed in the days after the imposition of martial law in December 1981. It accompanied this move, however, with a sharp attack on the Polish Government for what it said were the continuing human rights abuses in that country. **********Reagan Administration officials said the announcement had been held up for two days because of the White House's concern with the critical reaction of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The labor union has said that no sanctions should be removed until all political prisoners are released and a free labor union restored. **********The ''limited steps'' announced by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, were in response, he said, ''to a very modest improvement in the human rights situation in Poland.'' He said these included the successful visit of Pope John Paul II last June to Poland and ''the release of the majority of political prisoners in Poland.'' **********''We are waiting for the Polish Government to take definitive action to restore the human rights of the Polish people - rights which belong to them from birth and which are not Government's to take away,'' he said.   Curb on Fishing Eased As a result of the steps announced today, Poland will be able to open discussions with private American fishing companies about receiving permission to resume fishing in American waters. The Poles had prior to the imposition of sanctions been allowed to harvest 220,000 tons a year. But Mr. Speakes said that even though talks will be allowed to be held, ''no actual allocation of fish will be provided at this time.'' **********''Rather, any future allocation of fish at the end of the discussions will be contingent on the Polish Government's actions on human rights,'' he said. **********The other step taken was an agreement to join with other Western nations to discuss rescheduling of part of Poland's overall debt of some $11 billion to Western governments. **********Mr. Speakes emphasized that no new credits were being extended to Poland nor was Poland's entry into the International Monetary Fund being supported.   'Very Serious Problems Remain' **********The other sanctions remain in place, Mr. Speakes said. These include: suspension of landing rights for the Polish airline LOT, a freeze on new credits, suspension of Poland's ability to receive normal tariff treatment, a ban on sale of high technology items to Poland and suspension of scientific exchanges. **********Mr. Speakes said ''very serious problems still remain'' in Poland. **********''The Polish Government continues to defy the wishes of the majority of the Polish people,'' he said. ''A number of political prisoners are still incarcerated and indictments have been brought against certain of these prisoners, free labor unions have not been rereforms have been implemented and stringent censorship still exists.'' **********Nevertheless, the limited steps were regarded by State Department officials as a signal of American willingness to continue efforts to normalize relations. Mr. Speakes said, ''In the hope of inducing the Polish Government to begin pursuing a path of national reconciliation and restore free trade unions, the President has endorsed two limited steps.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/busin.body_text: **********Penalties Are Smaller On Washington Bonds **********The State of Washington paid a higher interest rate on its latest bond issue as a result of the $2.25 billion default by the Washington Public Power Supply System, but the penalty was not so severe as at the state's previous sale on Aug. 8. **********Underwriters led by Salomon Brothers offered the Washington bonds, rated A/AA-, with maximum yields of 10.3 percent for bonds due in 2008 and 10.2 percent in 2001. **********For serial bonds, yields ranged from 5.75 percent for 15 percent bonds due in 1984, which were offered at a steep premium price, to 8.75 percent for 13 percent bonds due in 1990. Among serial bonds priced at par, yields ranged from 8 1/2 percent in 1991 to 10 percent in 1998. **********George Friedlander, a municipal bond market analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, estimated that the Washington bonds yielded about 20 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than comparable bonds with similar A/AA- ratings. At the state's previous sale on Aug. 8, analysts estimated the penalty at half a percentage point. **********''After the last sale, the Washington bonds outperformed the rest of the market,'' so underwriters reduced the penalty, he said.  On Aug. 8, while The Bond Buyer Index of 20 general-obligation bonds was 9.74 percent, Washington's 1998 bonds were offered with a 10 1/2 percent yield, while bonds due in 2008 carried a yield of 10 3/4 percent. Since then, the index has declined only six basis points, to 9.68 percent, but yields have declined to 10 percent for Washington bonds due in 1998 and 10.3 percent in 2008.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.print_headline: Advertising; An Agency Decides to Go Public
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.body_text: **********ALLY & GARGANO, which pulled back from going public a decade ago, announced yesterday that it planned to make the move in December and had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The 21-year-old agency ranked 49th in Advertising Age's list of American agencies in 1982, with revenues of $16.96 million on billings of $126 million. Amil Gargano, president and chief executive, said the agency will end 1983 with billings of $185 million and is currently billing at an annual rate of $240 million. **********Its clients include Federal Express, whose advertising campaign could well be the most honored in recent years, as well as MCI Communications, Timberland outdoor footwear, Calvin Klein apparel and sportswear, Dunkin' Donuts of America, Midway Airlines, National Distillers and Travelers Insurance. **********The agency plans to offer 1,080,460 shares of common stock for sale, 74,000 of which are coming from the agency itself, with the rest coming from the company's 46 employee- shareholders. After the sale, there will be 2,220,000 shares outstanding. Mr. Gargano said the shares in the offering should have an asking price of from $14 to $17 each. **********Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. and Wertheim & Company will co- manage the underwriting. **********The agency, back in June 1972, when it was known as Carl Ally Inc., filed a preliminary prospectus with the S.E.C., seeking to offer 300,000 shares. **********The company withdrew the request, Mr. Gargano said, because the new-issues market was poor and agency stock considered ''unattractive,'' unlike now. Agency stock generally has been getting good press in financial publications, he said. **********Of the 15 biggest United States ad agencies, 10 - three of which are in the Interpublic Group of Companies - are public. Among the smaller shops, almost none, with the exception of subsidiaries, have sold stock publicly. **********The first modern agency to take the step - Papert, Koenig, Lois - did it in 1962. The agency has since gone out of business. **********According to the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the last major agency to offer shares to the public was BBDO International, the parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, in October 1973. **********However, more recently McCaffrey & McCall, which had once been public and then bought itself back from the public, in effect went public again when it was acquired by Saatchi & Saatchi, the same publicly held British ad agency that owns Compton Advertising. And Kenyon & Eckhardt in effect went public when it was acquired by Lorimar Productions, a public company. **********Then there are the various agencies that were acquired by the Mickelberry Corporation, an ad agency holding company, whose main components are Cunningham & Walsh; Laurence, Charles & Free, and Nadler & Larimer. As a matter of fact, Advertising Age speculated this week that the Nadler shop is on the verge of acquiring Calet, Hirsch & Spector. All principals were out of the office yesterday.
