https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.main_headline: BACKBONE OF ALLEGHANY IS THE I.D.S. FUND GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.print_headline: BACKBONE OF ALLEGHANY IS THE I.D.S. FUND GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Beginning in 1940, salesmen from Investors Diversified Services Inc. fanned out through America, urging people to save for their future by buying mutual funds. The pitch worked, and through the 1960's and early 1970's the company was the nation's largest mutual fund group. **********I.D.S., the main subsidiary of the Alleghany Corporation, ultimately lost that distinction when it failed to keep pace in a rapidly evolving financial world. But now the American Express Company, in buying Alleghany's businesses, is adding a financial services concern that some analysts think has successfully diversified into insurance and may be on the rebound. **********''I think it's a dynamic company,'' said Michael A. Lipper of Lipper Analytical Services, which follows mutual funds. However, in a reference to the brokerage arm of American Express, he added: ''It's not as entrepreneurial as Shearson.'' **********American Express yesterday announced that it would issue common stock, worth $1.01 billion at yesterday's closing price, to buy two Alleghany businesses: Investors Diversified Services, the main attraction to American Express, and MSL Industries, a steel products company. 13 Employees at Headquarters **********Alleghany, which has only 13 employees at its New York headquarters and has always been very decentralized, will continue to trade on the New York Stock Exchange, although virtually its only assets, at least for the time being, would consist of 15.25 million shares of American Express. **********Last year, Alleghany reported net income of $62.8 million, or $6.38 a share, down from $68.1 million, or $6.47, in 1981. Revenue slipped to $1.35 billion, from $1.37 billion. Financial services contributed 71 percent of revenues and 95 percent of profits. **********I.D.S., based in Minneapolis, runs 14 mutual funds with total assets of $9 billion, and manages another $4.1 billion in pension money. It also has $13.5 billion worth of insurance in force, and outstanding investment certificates with a face value of $2.5 billion. **********Investment certificates were the company's original product, first sold in 1894. People would invest a certain amount of money and be able to cash in the certificate 10 to 50 years later for the principal, plus a fixed amount interest. But their popularity has declined because of changes in tax rules. **********Despite its years of leadership, I.D.S. today ranks only eighth in mutual fund assets - both stock and money market funds - according to the Investment Company Institute. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., for comparison, runs stock and money market mutual funds with more than four times the assets in the I.D.S. funds. Slow to Change **********Although all mutual funds took a beating during the slow stock market of the late 1970's, I.D.S. in particular lost ground when it was slow to diversify into money market funds, which attracted billions of dollars because of their high return, Mr. Lipper said. **********In addition, he said, I.D.S.'s mutual funds had not been ''super performers'' in recent years. But recently, the company's newer funds that invest aggressively in small growth companies have done well, Mr. Lipper said. I.D.S. which lost money on its mutual fund operation as recently as 1981, is now showing a profit in that area. **********The company has also suffered because it has been slow to lower the fees that it charged investors to join its funds. In an age when many funds charge no such fees, I.D.S. charged up to 8 percent as late as last week, when it finally lowered the rate to a maximum of 5 percent. **********Analysts, though, said the company has been quicker to pick up on its middle-class clientele's developing taste for a variety of insurance policies. **********''I think they've made an improvement in their product line,'' said Gary E. Fegley of the annuity-insurance department of Dain Bosworth Inc., a Minneapolis brokerage firm. He noted the addition of annuities and term life insurance. **********The company also offers American Express a sales force trained to sell a wide variety of products. I.D.S. says its prime customers today are those earning between $30,000 and $75,000 a year. Serving them are 4,484 salesmen working out of 160 offices in every state but Alaska.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.main_headline: Ford Splits Shares And Raises Payout
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ford Splits Shares And Raises Payout
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company, citing a favorable outlook in the auto industry, said today that it is raising the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 15 cents, to 45 cents a share. **********The company also announced a 3-for-2 stock split, which will be in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend. Both the stock split and the dividend increase will be payable Dec. 1 to shareholders of record Nov. 1. **********Ford said the 45-cent dividend will be based on current shares, so the fourth-quarter cash payout will be the equivalent of 30 cents a share after the stock split. Ford will have about 181.5 million shares of common stock outstanding after the split, compared with about 121.1 million now, the auto maker said. **********''The stock dividend is expected to broaden interest in Ford shares,'' Philip Caldwell, Ford's chairman, said in a statement. ''The company's dividend actions are consistent with the earnings increases experienced to date and the favorable outlook for both the company and overall industry sales.'' **********On the New York Stock Exchange today, Ford jumped $2.375, to $68.625.In July, Ford announced it was reinstating dividend payments of 30 cents a share after skipping them for seven quarters because of slumping United States car sales. The move came as Ford earned $753.4 million in the first half of 1983, compared with a $97.1 million loss in the first half of 1982. **********Ford also announced that Michael D. Dingman, president of the Signal Companies, and John B. Connally, a former Treasury Secretary who is a member of Signal's board, were elected directors. The two had been Ford directors from May 1981 to May 1983 but did not stand for re-election earlier this year because of a ''possible conflict of interest'' resulting from their affiliation with Signal, which owned 80 percent of Mack Trucks, a Ford competitor. **********Signal, however, has sold all but 10 percent of its interest in Mack, which is now under the operational control of the French auto maker Renault, Ford said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.body_text: **********IS Leonard Sugarman, the English import running Foote, Cone & Belding's creative department, bringing about the dramatic changes that were expected of him? One outsider who has viewed a reel of new television commercials, and some recent print advertising, would say Yes. **********Generally, even to a non-professional, they do seem relevant, they do contain elements of the unexpected and they are expertly made. And those were exactly the qualities he told his troops that he was looking for when he took over as executive vice president and executive creative director almost two years ago. **********New Yorkers are not aware of a lot of the advertising, because it is running out of town. For example, there are a couple of spots for Serengeti and Chameleon, the two new lines of Sunglasses by Corning, its first entry in the field. These spots do have a European look, and Len Sugarman is importing European directors. **********Then there are the spots for Miss Clairol; Frito-Lay's O'Grady potato chips and Grandma's cookies; Sunkist Orange Juice and Sunkist Fruit Rolls for Lipton, and one you might have seen, the public service commercial for the Boy Scouts, which shows a woeful-looking youngster being stripped of all of his merit badges. **********The reel also included the first TV commercial for Bermuda, which will probably run only on cable in the Northeast.  The print exposition included a magazine effort for Western Electric with particlarly strong graphics, and the TDI, or commuterline, posters for U.S. News & World Report. **********Also included was the ''Locker Room'' campaign for Kent that unites a couple of Kent brands whose previously independent dramatic advertising, Mr. Sugarman said, failed to create an image of the smoker that in turn becomes the image of the brand. Case in point: the Marlboro cowboy. One of the past Kent efforts was that strange combination of food and butts, which could have been called the Kents-on-a-roll campaign. **********The tall, heavy-set executive said that, until recently, he was ashamed to show the New York office's advertising product. Now things have obviously changed. It wasn't easy. **********One of his first moves - in November 1981 - was an announced ban on 10 of the more popular forms of television advertising. ''I want you all to understand that derivative advertising, formula advertising, may be good enough to score in research, but it will not score with me. I will not approve it,'' he wrote. **********That pronouncement led to the departure of some of the work force, contributing to a drop to 45 on the staff, from more than 65.  Mr. Sugarman, who was telling his tale in his little conference room jam-packed with audio-visual equipment, said that before he could really get his new broom in operation he had to do a lot of missionary work among the clients, who in the long run would have to give the final approval. **********''Some just didn't go for it,'' he said, noting that he thinks that this was at least partially responsible for Plough and Life Savers removing themselves from the client list. But Clairol, for the first time in 30 years, went into the marketplace with a TV commercial that wasn't put through any copy-testing procedure. No small victory. **********It's been a tough couple of years and the 43-year-old Mr. Sugarman is quick to acknowledge it. Not quite like just switching jobs back in London town. Here he had the extra chore of absorbing the competitive atmosphere. That meant a lot of overtime laboring. **********But, using his London experience as a guide, he is quite explicit about setting September 1984 as the time when his turnaround job will be finished. By that time his people, he promised, will have won their share of creative awards, proving to clients that that which was said to be creative is indeed creative. **********Len Sugarman is in New York because he helped make the London office F.C.& B.'s best office in terms of growth, profitability, new business acquisition and creativity. And, he said, his management in the world's eighth-largest agency is among those who believe that the future of the business will see a few huge multinational agencies dominate. They intend to be one of them. **********Most multinational companies are American, and most of them are New York-based. So it is vital that the creative output of the New York office be showcase stuff.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said today that the American-inspired ''anti-Soviet hysteria'' over the shooting down of a Korean airliner would be short-lived and have no lasting effect on the country's ties abroad. **********The Soviet press, in articles aimed at reassuring its domestic audience, said that American efforts to fan international outrage over the affair had failed in the face of widespread acceptance of Soviet explanations that the Korean Air Lines 747 was spying. **********Commentaries on the state television and in the official press also maintained that the ''peace campaign'' by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, had survived the incident, along with what one television commentator called ''the structure of detente.''  Soviet Silent on Boycott **********Meanwhile, the Soviet press continuted to withhold any mention of an international air boycott that has been announced by numerous Western pilots associations and air controllers. **********Western diplomats here said the Soviet assessment seemed to be that Western reaction would be confined to an air boycott of limited time, and that Mr. Andropov would soon be able to resume efforts to put the Reagan Administration on the defensive on other issues, primarily nuclear weapons.  The Soviet leader's continued silence on the downing of the airliner tended to support this interpretation. The defense of Soviet actions has been left mainly to a Government statement and to a news conference by Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the armed forces' general staff. Although Mr. Andropov was reported to have broken off a vacation and returned to Moscow to manage the crisis, he has said nothing about it publicly. **********Diplomats here believed that this was likely to have been an effort to isolate Mr. Andropov personally from the damage sustained by the Soviet Union internationally.   Moscow May Have Been Informed **********It was noted by diplomats here that Marshal Ogarkov's explanations of how the decision was reached to shoot down the airliner did not rule out the possibility that the leadership in Moscow knew of the airliner's intrusion before it was shot down. **********The Marshal told the news conference that the decision to destroy the airliner was taken by a commander of the air defense district in the Far East under standing orders empowering him to destroy intruding aircraft. When asked whether Moscow was informed before or after the plane was shot down, he gave no direct reply but answered: ''At an apropriate time.'' **********After Marshal Ogarkov's effort to prove that the airliner was spying, three pilots involved in intercepting it were interviewed on television on Saturday and claimed that they, too, were convinced that it was on an intelligence mission.   General Appears on TV **********The only elaboration on this came from a general who appeared on television today to repeat the contention that it was impossible for Soviet pilots or ground tracking stations to distinguish between the Boeing 747 and a RC-135 spy plane, a version of the Boeing 707 that the United States uses for intelligence-gathering. **********Another type of converted airliner used as an airborne command post is the E-4, a version of the Boeing 747. However, theere has never been any mention of this plane by the Soviet Union. **********Col. Gen. Nikolai V. Moskvitelev, deputy commander in chief for aviation of the Air Defense Forces, who oversees fighter operations, said that the 747 and the RC-135 are ''of one type'' and could not have been distinguished by Soviet officers monitoring the 747 on radar. **********''They have an identical form and geometrical dimension,'' General Moskvitelev said. ''They have identical flight speeds. They can be distinguished in the air visually only by day and at a close distance. To do this at night is impossible.''  Western Attaches Astonished **********The statement astonished Western air attaches, who noted that the 747 is much larger than the RC-135 and has a dome in its forward fuselage. **********One British officer said: ''It may be impossible for a Russian pilot to tell the difference but I don't know of any other pilot in the world who would find it difficult.'' **********Like other Soviet statements, General Moskvitelev's remarks implied a degree of bungling by the Soviet air defenses, an unusual tack for the Kremlin, which generally presents the armed forces as highly efficient. **********This has led some diplomats to wonder whether the Kremlin's approach has not been to deflect allegations of aerial murder by imputing a degree of confusion to the air defenses that was greater than actually occurred. **********''Let's imagine the worst case,'' one diplomat said, ''that they knew it was the Korean 747, that they realized it was carrying several hundred passengers, and that somehow the word came down from Moscow to shoot it down anyay. **********''Once they realized the enormity of it, you could hypothesize that they decided it was better to let a local commander and a bunch of pilots take the heat than to admit that the blunder was approved at the top,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.print_headline: Giscard Received by Reagan For Talk on the Missile Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.body_text: **********Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France told President Reagan today that the Atlantic allies must keep pressing for arms control after new medium-range missiles are deployed in Western Europe later this year. **********The meeting was in the Oval Office. **********The former French leader said he had also talked with Mr. Reagan about the world economic situation, praising the President for backing an increase in contributions to the International Monetary Fund. **********Mr. Giscard d'Estaing met with Mr. Reagan, Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz for about half an hour.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration's efforts to destabilize the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua through a variety of economic and military measures is being viewed cautiously by United States businesses and banks that operate in the war-torn country. **********The Administration's policies have included vetoes of loan projects from such multilateral lending institutions as the Inter-American Development Bank, a sharp reduction in United States purchases of Nicaraguan sugar and an almost complete cutoff of official aid. **********Executives from several American-based multinational companies questioned last week say that, in spite of the problems, it has been pretty much business as usual. But they are worried about the future. **********''The Nicaraguans, who realize that the smartest thing in the world for them to do is act responsibly, have been making their payments on time,'' said a senior vice president for a major consumer products company, who asked not to be identified. **********And American bankers, who are gathering with their European and Canadian counterparts in Panama today and are expected to approve the rescheduling of $180 million in Nicaraguan short-term debt, characterize the Nicaraguan Government's approach to its financial problems as pragmatic. **********Every year since 1980 various parts of what is estimated to be $900 million in foreign debt has been rescheduled. And until last March, when the Government missed a $4 million payment, the debt payments had been made on time. **********Still, business executives say they are concerned about the possibility that the Reagan Administration's hostility to the Nicaraguan Government could unleash an outpouring of anti-American sentiment. **********And they say they are concerned about a marked shift in the direction of Nicaragua's trade toward a variety of other nations, including many in the Communist bloc. **********The banks say that Washington has applied no direct pressure to private financial institutions to stop lending to Nicaragua. But given the relative small size of Nicaragua's debt, its economic prospects and the country's refusal to go to the International Monetary Fund for assistance, no pressure has been required. **********''The banks are looking at a hostile United States policy vis- a-vis Nicaragua, and that tells them that the economy will deteriorate,'' said Richard Feinberg, a senior fellow at the Overseas Development Council in Washington. ''At this point, any other sort of signal is not really necessary.'' **********With the exception of some guaranteed, pre-export credit deals that were made last year, Nicaragua has received no fresh bank loans since 1979. Sugar Quota Cut **********The Administration's move in May to cut by nearly 90 percent the amount of sugar Nicaragua could sell in the United States illustrates how the Administration's actions narrow the banks' search for solutions.  That decision was taken a day after commercial bank lenders gathered in New York on May 8 to to meet with top Nicaraguan finance officials, including Luis Enrique Figueroa, president of the central bank. **********''They told us that since the beginning of 1983 they had experienced a number of financial difficulties, including floods, with damages as high as $500 million, and drought, which had hurt the cotton and sugar cane crops,'' said a banker who was at the meeting. ''And the invasion by Somosista forces had cost the Government about $58 million in damages and additional purchases through April.'' **********Largely as a result of those factors, last month Mr. Figueroa told bankers that Nicaragua would miss a $45 million payment due in July on its private bank debt, and requested that debt payments be suspended until June 1984. **********''This request hardly falls under the definition of a moratorium,'' the banker said. But he admitted that ''many moons shall pass before they can start servicing their debt again. There is no question that the suspension of the sugar quota, which provided Nicaragua with anywhere from $45 million to $60 million in foreign exchange, has been a blow.'' **********American companies have a similar view of the future. 'Economic Aid is Needed' **********''Companies with operations in the region are intensely anti-Communist, but there is a feeling that what Reagan is doing is not good for business, and that economic aid is needed down there,'' said Gary L. Springer, an analyst who tracks developments in Nicaragua for the Business International Corporation, a research, publishing and consulting firm. ''Businessmen are worried that they will end up bearing the brunt of an invasion.'' **********At the end of 1981, the most recent figures available, the Commerce Department put the level of direct foreign investment by American companies in Nicaragua at $87 million. Interviews with executives from several companies with operations in Nicaragua suggest that, in spite of their problems with local businessmen, the Sandinista Government has maintained good relations with foreign investors. **********But since the leftist government came to power in 1979, it has been seeking diversification of trading partners. Treasury and State Department officials could not provide any statistics on the size of the bilateral trade, but Inforpress CentroAmericana, a newsletter published in Guatemala that tracks economic and political trends in the region, estimated that in 1982, Nicaraguan exports to the Communist bloc amounted to 6 percent of the total, nearly triple what they were two years earlier. By contrast, exports to the United States amounted to 24 percent of the total, a slide of 6 percentage points from 1980 levels. **********''A couple of our people were in Nicaragua recently and were surprised with the extent the shelves in stores will filled with Eastern goods,'' the consumer products executive said. ''They said it looks like a completely converted economy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/10/busin.body_text: **********The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has pared its long-term debt to a ''very manageable'' level, the company's chairman and chief executive said Saturday, using the proceeds from the sale of its music publishing unit and a portion of its pay television and home video subsidiary, plus two highly successful feature films. **********The company also announced that after-tax profits rose 7.1 percent in the first quarter, ended Nov. 30, to $10.5 million, or 21 cents a share, from $9.8 million, or 20 cents, a year earlier. Revenues fell 2 percent, to $204.1 million, from $208.4 million. **********Frank Rothman, a longtime Hollywood lawyer who has headed MGM/ UA since last March, said long-term debt had been cut to $326 million, from $528 million. Mr. Rothman added after the company's annual shareholders' meeting that his goal was to reduce the total by an additional $100 million by the end of August. **********''I don't have a specific plan,'' he said. ''We're asset-rich here, and there are many things we can do.'' He noted that the success of the 19 feature films the MGM and United Artist studios plan to release this year will influence the debt-paring actions. **********Friday's announcement that three film studios and two companies involved in satellite entertainment would join in operating the Showtime and the Movie Channel pay-TV channels left MGM/UA and 20th Century-Fox as the two studios without an ownership role in the leading pay television outlets. Mr. Rothman, however, disputed the idea that MGM/UA might suffer. Negotiating for 'Rocky IV' **********MGM/UA has taken in more than $250 million in worldwide box office receipts from ''Rocky III'' and ''Poltergeist.'' Mr. Rothman disclosed for the first time that negotiations were ''well along'' with Sylvester Stallone to star in another sequel, ''Rocky IV.'' **********The public offering last month of 15 percent of its pay TV and home video subsidiary, MGM/UA Home Entertainment Group Inc., netted $54 million. An agreement to sell its music publishing operations to CBS Inc. for $68 million was completed last week. **********Mr. Rothman also said that Alexander P. Haig, the former Secretary of State, had been hired as a consultant for $25,000 a year, in addition to his compensation as an MGM/UA director. General Haig was elected to the company's board following the annual meeting. **********MGM/UA's shares have traded in the narrow range of $5 to $8.50 over the past year, and closed Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $7.375, down 12 1/2 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/23/busin.body_text: **********R. H. Macy & Company said that November sales for its stores open more than a year are running 16 to 17 percent ahead of last November, and that new stores are contributing another 3 to 4 percent to the total corporate sales gain. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive, said before the company's annual meeting that if the sales trend continued, profits in the second quarter, ending Jan. 28, would improve ''significantly'' from the year before. **********He said at the meeting that Macy's first Florida store, in North Miami Beach, will have first-year sales of about $55 million, ''well above our plan,'' and that the company will proceed with its program of opening 10 stores in Florida and Texas by the end of the decade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/busin.body_text: **********When the stock market began climbing last August like an inspired mountain goat, Carol A. Ruth didn't rush right out and buy something. In fact, she waited until April before making her choices. **********''Three weeks ago I bought 100 shares of Chrysler at 20,'' said Miss Ruth, the senior vice president of a Manhattan public relations firm. ''It's about 26 now, which isn't a lot, but I think it's terrific.'' She laughed in describing her $600 profit, adding, ''I'm excited.'' **********Miss Ruth confided her success as she stopped by the Merrill Lynch Investment Information Center on the concourse of Grand Central Terminal. The glass booth is situated almost directly under Taurus, the bull that is part of the constellation decorating the concourse ceiling. And even at 2:15 on a recent afternoon, it was too crowded with people checking on their stocks for the investor to squeeze in. **********''Look at this, everybody's here all of a sudden,'' she said.  The crowd has indeed grown, according to Steven Mekler, a Merrill Lynch account executive, and many who find their way there tell stories that surpass Miss Ruth's. **********In all, she and the rest of the nation's 30 million shareholders have earned about $500 billion in the stock **********Stocks went up yesterday, with the Dow gaining 4.64 points, to close at 1,212.65. Page D10. market over the last year, according to the Wilshire Associates' 5,000 Equity Index. And much of that new wealth was created since Aug. 13, when the Dow Jones average began its ascent. **********''It's great,'' William Martin said of the rally. The Bronxville salesman bought 125 shares of Sears at $15 and saw the price rise as high as $42.125. He is holding that stock and others and building a nest egg. ''I'm looking for long-term growth, and then I'll reinvest that money,'' he said. **********Thomas Aylward of Westchester said that he had made $40,000 in the rally, buying mutual funds as well as individual stocks. One stock that has performed well is A.T.& T. ''A couple of years ago I bought 400 shares at 42,'' he recalled. ''Now it's at 67. That's $25 profit a share.'' **********For Rodolfo Lopez, a retired mechanic from Puerto Rico, the rally has translated into a $10,000 profit on one stock alone, that of the Masco Corporation, which makes faucets and other products. A conservative man who started with utilities stock 20 years ago, Mr.  Lopez will hold on to what he has. ''I just pick stocks and invest and happen to be lucky,'' he said. **********Like poker players shrugging off a bad hand, several investors saw Monday's dip in the market as temporary and predicted the Dow would reach 1,500 or 1,700 in time. **********''I think there's a long way to go,'' said Keith L. Stransky, the research director for a Connecticut financial consulting firm. He said he had nearly doubled his money, to $10,000, since the rally began and had sold very little. ''I bought 100 shares of General Nutrition before the rally at around 11 7/8 and sold it recently at 25,'' he said. ''It's now at 48, but we won't talk about that,'' he added, laughing. **********This is the most money Mr. Stransky, 31 years old, has ever made in the market, and he's glad to see it. ''I had lost a lot of money before,'' he said. ''I was down $5,000. Now I'm up $5,000.'' **********Chandrasen Shah is also putting his money back in the market. An unemployed accountant and bookkeeper who lives in Queens, Mr. Shah estimates he has made $5,000 to $10,000 during the rally, chiefly on I.B.M., Digital and Honeywell. He said he has used some of it to pay his living expenses, however. ''If I had money I could make money,'' he said, voicing a common lament. **********At least Mr. Shah has been coming out ahead. Leaning on the outside of the Merrill Lynch booth, Thomas J. Corrigan forlornly disclosed that he had lost $7,000 by buying put options -a speculative technique that can produce profits when stock prices are falling. He bet the wrong way on I.B.M. and on Delta. ''I made more in the bear market than the bull market, can you imagine that?'' the liquor salesman marveled. ''I've watched this rally very closely so when the next one comes I'll be ready.'' **********As she licked yogurt from a pink plastic spoon, Maryellen Moll calculated that she and her husband had made $4,000 in the rally, with all of the profit still on paper. ''My family's always bought stock,'' she said. ''It makes for good conversation at Thanksgiving dinner.'' **********James Caruso converted his paper profits to something more material. He opened his own import-export company a month ago with the aid of $10,000 he had made in the market. Some of the money came from 200 shares of American Airlines stock, which he said he bought at $18 and sold at $27.50. He also bought 10 contracts for call options on E.F. Hutton at $2.50 and sold them at $8. **********Hutton's gain, along with that of other brokerage stocks, is one reflection of the new business the rally has brought in. At Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., Richard D. Berlin said that people who had pulled out of the market were coming back. In addition, said Mr. Berlin, the Penn Plaza office manager, accounts are being opened by first-time investors. **********The insiders have their own stories to tell. Robert L. Grossmann, who recommends stocks at the brokerage Cantor, Fitzgerald & Company in Beverly Hills, Calif., has seen his choices go up 80 percent in price since he joined the firm in mid-June. **********Mr. Grossmann said he bought 10,000 shares of the First Executive Corporation himself at $8.50; it is now at $22, for a $135,000 paper profit. ''That's not unusual in today's market,'' he said. **********Then there is Gordon Yale, secretary-treasurer of the Janus Fund, a Denver mutual fund. Mr. Yale said the stock held by the fund had gone up 71 percent since the rally began, outstripping the Dow's 60 percent. But he himself has had no such luck. **********''Here I am in the mutual fund business, and except for two months I haven't had a nickel in the market,'' he lamented. ''Two guys in the office bought Hyde tennis shoe in July at $6 and the last time I looked, it was selling at $42, and I missed that. It makes you sick to your stomach, doesn't it?

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/world.body_text: **********The African National Congress took responsiblity today for two bombings in South Africa on Thursday, the eve of the 22d anniversary of the guerrilla group's decision to take up arms against white minority rule. **********In a telex statement from its office in Lusaka, Zambia, to The Associated Press in Johannesburg, the guerrilla group said the bombings ''constitute an affirmation of our determination to intensify and extend our armed offensive against the Pretoria regime.'' **********A bomb extensively damaged the first four floors of a Foreign Ministry building in Johannesburg Thursday night, slightly wounding seven people. The African National Congress has said it was responsible for three bombings of Government offices in Johannesburg in the last week. **********Also on Thursday night, three bombs went off on a street near the beachfront in Durban, 300 miles southeast of Johannesburg. No one was wounded.   'Shattered the Myth' **********The guerrilla group said its recent attacks in South Africa had ''shattered the myth of the invincibility of the Pretoria regime.'' **********The statement marked the founding on Dec. 16, 1961, of the military wing of the African National Congress. To White South Africans the day marks the 1838 victory by white settlers against an overwhelming Zulu force at Blood River. **********The police had warned of a likely increase in guerrilla sabotage in the holiday season. **********Security policemen in Johannesburg announced the arrest of a man Thursday night whom they described as ''a trained black A.N.C. terrorist'' and said a quantity of arms had been seized. The man was the third guerrilla suspect arrested in the last week, the police said, and all the arrests led officers to arms caches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/03/busin.body_text: **********High-technology companies often start with a few people working in a garage. American Bell Inc. will open for business today with 28,000 employees working in 700 buildings. **********Such a grand beginning is appropriate for a company that is opening a new era of competition in the telephone business.  American Bell, a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was established to market telephone equipment and computerized services at unregulated prices. It is expected to bring a vast array of products to market, from office computers to computerized department store systems, able to handle such tasks as bridal registry. **********Starting today, consumers wanting telephones and other phone equipment will buy them from either American Bell or one of its competitors. The local telephone companies, such as New York Telephone and New Jersey Bell, will no longer provide equipment for lease under state regulation, once their current inventories run out. **********Competitors Have Doubts **********For the new company's competitors, the birth of American Bell, once known as Baby Bell, is also momentous. American Bell, because of its large size and the backing of its giant parent, will be a potent market force. **********But there are risks for the company, too. Indeed, as ribbon-cutting time drew near, an industry that at first had feared the coming of Baby Bell was expressing some doubt that the new subsidiary would be successful. **********Precisely because of its huge size, American Bell must do extremely well to become profitable. It is also unclear whether an offshoot of a regulated monopoly will be agile enough to compete in the open market. **********''It's like trying to turn around a 500-pound marshmallow,'' said one A.T.& T. marketing official who recently left the company. Harry Newton, president of the Telecom Library, a publisher of telecommunications information, agreed: ''I think it's the greatest gamble in American history. I think there's a very serious question about whether they will make it.'' Moving Into a New Field **********American Bell's formation is the result of a 1980 order of the Federal Communications Commission. The decision allowed A.T.& T. to enter the data-processing industry and to sell telephone equipment and computers if it set up a separate, arms-length subsidiary to insure that the business would not be subsidized by local phone service, which continues to be a regulated monopoly. **********That decision is not related to the settlement of the Federal antitrust suit, announced last January, that will cause A.T.& T. to divest itself of its local operating companies by Jan.1, 1984. **********The need for a separate subsidiary meant that the new company had to be started from scratch. Some 700 office sites had to be found for the company, since American Bell employees could not share buildings with the rest of A.T.& T. Separate computer systems to handle billing and payroll had to be established, and new phones ordered for everyone. **********Such a huge task met with some unexpected difficulties. For example, the New England Telephone Company demanded a deposit before beginning phone service for American Bell, despite the fact that both companies are part of A.T.& T. Headquarters in New Jersey **********Because of its quick formation, American Bell could not find one building big enough for the head offices of the company and its divisions. So the company's headquarters will be in Morris Township, N.J.; the consumer products division, which will handle sales to residences and small businesses, will be in nearby Parsippany, and the advanced information systems division, handling sales to larger businesses, will be in Morristown, N.J. **********To complicate matters further, about six weeks ago officials of Morris Township changed the name of the street where the headquarters will be located. Fortunately, the company had not yet printed a lot of stationery, said Robert E. McNulty, vice president of corporate planning and operations for American Bell. **********American Bell officials, however, say the organizing is just about finished. ''I certainly think we're ready, absolutely without question,'' said Randall L. Tobias, president of the consumer products division. The company was apparently ready enough that Charles Marshall, chief executive of American Bell, and Archie J.  McGill, president of the advanced information systems division, were taking vacations last week. Deficits at First **********Whether the company is ready to compete is another question. With 28,000 employees and no customers, it is certain to start out losing large sums of money. Ivan L. Wolff, who follows A.T.& T. for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, estimates that losses in the first year might reach $500 million. **********But the company will have great resources to draw on. Baby Bell officials hope it will reach about $2 billion annual revenues in either its first or second year. Its capital expenditures between 1983 and 1985 will be $5.1 billion, with most of that coming from its parent. And A.T.& T., which is expected to report 1982 revenues of about $65 billion and profits of more than $7 billion, is able to absorb the losses and investments without too much pain. **********American Bell would be helped greatly if the F.C.C. agreed to A.T.& T.'s request to transfer the equipment now being leased to customers by the local Bell operating companies to American Bell. That would give American Bell a huge customer base and source of revenues. The F.C.C. is expected to act on the request in the next few months. **********American Bell will be relying on the vast research expertise of Bell Laboratories and the manufacturing capability of the Western Electric Company, which are other subsidiaries of A.T.& T. **********One new service offered by American Bell is a sophisticated datacommunications network called Net 1000. If successful, it will cut sharply into the International Business Machines Corporation's grip on corporate data processing. But the network had been announced several years ago, only to be withdrawn when Bell could not get it to work. Even if it is successful this time, it will not be a significant contributor to profits for years, according to Harry Edelson, an analyst with First Boston Corporation. Fighting for PBX Sales **********More crucial will be the market for business switchboards, or PBX's. American Bell has already started to test its new computerized PBX, the Antelope, in the field. The model will be able to handle data as well as voices. The company's current product, the Dimension, has been steadily losing market share to aggressive companies such as Rolm, Northern Telecom and Mitel. **********American Bell also has developed a super-minicomputer that could put the company into competition with manufacturers such as Digital Equipment. It is not clear in what form the product will be marketed, however. The company also is looking at office work stations - desktop machines that are combinations of computers and telephones and are able to handle such tasks as electronic mail and word processing. American Bell officials have made it clear that they will lean toward marketing complete automation and communications systems for offices. **********On the residential side, the company will inherit 461 of A.T.& T.'s 1,500 Phonecenter stores. It has also arranged to sell phones through Sears, Roebuck. In the next two weeks, American Bell will announce other retailing arrangements and a new line of sophisticated electronic telephones. The Marketing Challenge **********Despite the companies' vast resources, some analysts question the ability of American Bell, Bell Labs and Western Electric to get products to market fast enough. **********''They research things to death,'' said George M. Pfister, a former A.T.& T. marketing official who is now president of Perspective Telecommunications Group, a Paramus, N.J., consulting firm. ''It is an incredible place to get a decision made.'' **********There are already areas where A.T.& T. has had to look outside for products, analysts say.  The Bell operating companies have been ordering central office switches, the machines which route telephone calls, from Northern Telecom because they got tired of waiting for Western Electric's own new switch. And American Bell announced it would sell a voice mail system -which allows voice messages to be stored in a computer and transmitted at a later time - made by I.B.M., which is expected to be its biggest rival.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher won a major victory today when the Trades Union Congress, the powerful central body of British labor, withdrew its support for a proposed 24-hour strike by a printers' union against all the national newspapers. **********The strike had been scheduled for Tuesday night as part of the National Graphical Association's struggle to impose a closed shop on a chain of weekly giveaway newspapers published in the Manchester area by Selim Shah. **********It was postponed on Tuesday morning after the employment committee of the union congress voted by only 9 to 7 to support the stoppage and Lionel Murray, the organization's general secretary, took the unusual step of publicly repudiating the committee's position because the proposed strike had been ruled illegal by the courts. **********Mr. Murray has been working quietly since the general election this summer to re-establish discussions between the Government and the union movement. No such discussions took place during Mrs. Thatcher's first term, and Mr. Murray considered it folly to persist in that attitude for five more years. As part of his effort, he has been trying to steer his organization away from a policy of confrontation with Mrs. Thatcher over the restrictive 1980 and 1982 labor laws and toward a policy of grudging acceptance of court decisions delivered under the laws.   Key Test of the Laws **********The Shah case, which began on a very small scale far from the big papers of Fleet Street, has become the key test of the new laws and of the response to them by the militant but hard-pressed unions. **********After his defeat in the employment committee, Mr. Murray began an all- out effort to persuade his organization's general council to reverse the committee's decision. Left-wing, anti- Murray unions also organized furiously, and some of them suggested that Mr. Murray would be ousted unless he won the crucial council vote. **********He did so this afternoon, by a vote of 29 to 21, after a meeting that began with National Graphical Association demonstrators jeering right-wing officials as they entered the meeting room and continued for more than six tumultuous hours. The printers would be supported, Mr. Murray said later, only if such assistance ''does not involve the general council in unlawful action.'' **********Joe Wade, the printers' leader, reacted furiously to the decision. He said his union and all other British trade unions had been ''sold down the river'' by Mr. Murray. He said that today ''was a black day in the long and glorious history of trade unionism,'' and added, ''We are being offered tea and sympathy, and nothing more than that.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/13/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, bolstered by favorable signs that inflation was still under control and by the robust performance of the bond market. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, rose 8.44 points, to 1,182.83. For the week, the key barometer dipped 0.46 points. **********Helping to trigger the upswing was the Labor Department report before the opening that producer prices in July rose only a tenth of 1 percent,less than had been expected by most economists. In June, producer prices climbed five-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts said the report buoyed investors' hopes that the economic recovery could proceed further without a resurgence of inflationary pressure. **********In the credit markets, long-term bond prices made large gains, as yields fell sharply. Short-term bond prices rose moderately. **********Volume Edges Up **********In the stock market, advancing New York Stock Exchange issues outscored those that fell by 946 to 576.  Turnover on the Big Board rose slightly to 71.8 million shares, from 70.6 million shares the day before. **********For the week, volume amounted to 378.2 million shares, compared with 400.9 million shares the previous week. **********Reflecting yesterday's improved performance, the exchange's index of 1,500 common stocks rose 0.44, to 93.84, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was up 0.61, to 162.16. **********Many investors remained on the sidelines yesterday awaiting the Federal Reserve's report on the money supply. The money supply has soared during the past several months, and the Fed has tightened credit somewhat, which pushed interest rates higher. **********After the close, the market received some good news when the Fed reported that the money supply for the week ended Aug. 3 rose only $400 million, or considerably less than expected. **********Despite the bullish report, Richard D. Rippe, senior vice president and economist of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that the market over the near term ''will weaken due to continued concern over rising interest rates.'' **********However, Mr. Rippe noted that this pressure should diminish by early fall, with the market resuming its advance ''when investors shift their attention to the expected rising trend of improved corporate profits.'' Bull Market a Year Old **********It was just a year ago that the market began its record-breaking advance, which saw it soar 471 points to close at a record 1,248.30 on June 16 - before rising interest rates began eroding some of its gains. The Dow is now up 405 points from the point it was at on Aug. 12, 1982.  One of the bigger losers yesterday was the Allegheny Corporation, which dropped 4 points, to 67, in heavy trading. Trading in the stock was halted by the exchange at 2:39 P.M., when the stock was off 3 points because of a order imbalance. Trading in the issue resumed at 3:17 P.M. **********The weakness in the issue resulted from reports that some officials of American Express are having second thoughts over problems they may encounter in meshing their operations with those of Investors Diversified Services, the unit of Allegheny that they recently agreed to acquire for $1 billion. **********After the close, officials of American Express said that nothing has changed in the company's plan to acquire I.D.S., the large mutual fund and insurance company. American Express gained 7/8, to 43 1/2. Metromedia Up 20 **********Metromedia rose 20, to 445, after having advanced 35 points in the previous two sessions. In the first two sessions this week, the stock tumbled 110 points, following an article in Barron's magazine that questioned the company's accounting practices. **********In the stronger blue-chip category, International Paper advanced 1 3/4, to 52 1/2; Minnesota Mining rose 1 5/8, to 78 1/2; United Technologies was up 1 1/4, to 67 3/4, and DuPont, 7/8, to 48 1/8. **********Some of the depressed energy related issues also posted impressive gains. Amerada Hess, which was heavily-traded, climbed 2 1/2, to 34 5/8; Halliburton added 1 3/4, to 42 7/8;, Getty, 1 3/8, to 64 1/8, and Ashland Oil, 1, to 31 1/2. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index advanced 1.12, to 229.73. Dillard Department Stores Class A stock climbed 4 3/4, to 54 1/4, after the company announced that its second-quarter net ended July 30 rose to 84 cents a share, from 44 cents a year earlier. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index was up 2.02, to 299.58. Booth Financial, which last week announced a 2-for-1 stock split and sharply higher profits for the six months ended June 30, rose 3, to 59 bid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/busin.main_headline: SHAD ASKS STIFF PENALTY FOR INSIDER VIOLATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/busin.print_headline: SHAD ASKS STIFF PENALTY FOR INSIDER VIOLATIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/busin.body_text: **********John S.R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today urged approval of a bill that would allow assessment of triple damages for insider trading violations. **********But Mr. Shad indicated to the House Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Finance that he could accept important changes that might weaken the proposal that the commission voted to support last year. **********The changes involve inserting a definition of insider trading, which could narrow the scope of prosecutions, and stiffening the legal standard for proving the charge of insider trading. The possible shift in position caught some subcommittee members by surprise. **********Despite these differences, commission officials; members of the subcommittee, whose chairman is Representative Timothy E. Wirth, Democrat of Colorado, and industry representatives all agreed that raising the penalties for insider trading was necessary. **********''Despite vigorous enforcement efforts, insider trading continues because it presents an opportunity to reap huge profits with little risk,'' Mr. Shad said. ''We must provide a sufficient deterrent,'' Mr. Wirth said, ''so that people will think twice before they engage in what all of us would call thievery.'' **********Insider trading involves the improper use of corporate information, such as data on earnings or dividends, or market information, such as knowing of a takeover attempt or tender offer, to buy or sell stocks to make a profit or avoid a loss. **********Under current law and regulations, the S.E.C. can bring a civil enforcement action against an individual but can force him only to disgorge the profits made on the use of the insider information. This proposal would allow the commission to seek penalties up to three times the profit from the insider trading. **********Mr. Shad, in explaining his willingness to consider changes, said that people in the industry had raised serious questions about the proposal since the commission endorsed it last fall. He also contended that his was standing behind the original proposal. But Mr. Wirth said, ''We're seeing some potential backsliding.'' No Exact Definition **********Mr. Shad, under questions from several committee members, agreed to work out a definition for insider trading that could be applied when the commission was seeking damages under the new triple-penalty proposal. Several representatives of industry, including a spokesman for the Securities Industry Association, also urged this approach, contending that, since these would be punitive damages, the definition should be very clear. Under current law, there is no exact definition except that based on decisions in the courts. **********Mr. Wirth, however, said this move to define insider trading was being advocated by ''a number of people out there who are going to make sure that, if there are treble damages, they will write a definition that will handcuff the S.E.C.'' and would ''raise the possibility of enormous loopholes.'' **********On the second key issue, John M. Fedders, director of the division of enforcement, said that he could accept a stiffer standard for proving insider trading. Currently, the commission must show ''a preponderance'' of evidence. The S.I.A. and others suggested that for the triple damamges the commission should have a standard of ''clear and convincing.'' **********But Bevis Longstreth, a commissioner who was asked to comment by Mr. Wirth, said that, ''if the Congress were now to increase the burden of proof for this violation,'' it would ''make it more difficult for the commission to succeed in this case.'' **********Mr. Wirth said that he expected to begin writing a bill in a month and would have one pased by the House this year. But the questions raised today, a key Senate aide said, may make it difficult to move quickly on a bill in the Senate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Nu-West Group Ltd., a Calgary, Alberta, real estate developer, today announced a large loss for 1982 and said it and its lenders had agreed that Nu-West would stop making interest and principal payments on $562 million of loans. **********The loss totaled $255.2 million, and followed a profit of $4.6 million, or 9 cents a share, for 1981. **********The 1982 loss included a $72.3 million write-down and a $66.3 million loss from Carma Ltd., a company in which Nu-West owns a 48.4 percent interest. **********Garnet Wells, vice president, said the lenders' formal agreement comes in the wake of Nu-West's inability to repay either principal or interest since Oct. 31, 1982. The pact is thus retroactive to Nov. 1. **********The announcement represents further evidence of the weakness that has plagued Canadian real estate developers for more than a year.  Banking sources say that of about $2 billion of losses on loans last year, most were on real estate. Nu-West said it sold $345 million of real estate assets last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.body_text: **********In a joint announcement yesterday, the Puritan Fashions Corporation and Calvin Klein, the designer, said that Puritan had deferred its decision on Mr. Klein's $60.2 million takeover offer and that Mr. Klein had extended the offer until next Monday. **********The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight yesterday, but the announcement was an indication that Puritan and Mr. Klein were negotiating. Mr. Klein has offered $16.50 a share for Puritan's stock, which closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at $16, unchanged. Mr. Klein and his business partner, Barry Schwartz, own about 10 percent of Puritan's 3.65 million shares. The Calvin Klein license to make jeans and jeans-related clothing provides about 95 percent of Puritan's $246 million in sales. **********Until the announcement yesterday, Puritan's directors had been silent about the offer. Analysts had speculated that Puritan might hold out for a higher price, but they had not been optimistic about the company's chances of fighting a takeover. ''The company isn't much without Calvin Klein,'' said Jeffrey Morris, an analyst for Evans & Company. **********Puritan said the delay was necessary to allow its investment bankers to present their report. But analysts believe that the delay may be aimed at working out a way to ease 27-year- old Andrew Rosen out of his job as president. The Rosen family owns about 10 percent of Puritan. **********In his letter to directors last week, Mr. Klein said that the company's 60 percent earnings drop in the third quarter raised questions about the abilities of Puritan's management. **********Litton and Core Litton Industries said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had acquired 606,180 shares, or 10.2 percent, of the common stock of Core Laboratories Inc. Core, based in Dallas, provides services to the petroleum and mining industries. Litton, a conglomerate based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said it paid about $9.4 million to establish its equity position in Core.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/03/busin.body_text: **********British Name Railroad Chief **********LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) - The Government today named Bob Reid, a veteran railroad executive, as chairman of British Rail, Britain's state-run railways, for the next three years. **********The announcement by the Transport Secretary, Tom King, was praised by the industry, which had feared the appointment of an outsider unsympathetic to public transportation. **********Mr. Reid, who started in the industry as a traffic apprentice, succeeds Sir Peter Parker. Sir Peter will retire on Sept. 11 after seven years as chairman. He predicted last month that the 11,000-mile line - one of the world's largest and busiest - would break even this year for the first time since 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.main_headline: 25,000 IN ARGENTINA PROTEST MILITARY'S PLAN FOR AMNESTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.print_headline: 25,000 IN ARGENTINA PROTEST MILITARY'S PLAN FOR AMNESTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/world.body_text: **********More than 25,000 Argentines marched here today to protest a proposed amnesty that would protect the military against prosecution for the disappearances, deaths and tortures that occurred in the antiterrorist campaign in the 1970's. **********The march, called by the country's eight major human rights groups, was boisterous but peaceful as it crawled the 12 blocks from a downtown corner to Congress. **********The junta of three service chiefs is reportedly on the verge of declaring the amnesty, which is widely seen as the single most explosive issue in the path of the country's promised return to democracy. **********National elections are scheduled in October, and the military, after nearly eight years in power, has promised to yield to the new elected government in January.   Military Seeks Immunity **********But the military is seeking to protect itself from future prosecution over the reported disappearance of more than 6,000 people in the hands of state security forces, plus the thousands of others who were killed or tortured. **********The junta refers to the amnesty in communiques as the Law of Pacification, a name that the opposition widely sees as an implicit threat of a coup if it is not accepted. About the only people the law would pacify, opposition leaders have said, is the military. **********''Peace will be impossible if immunity is granted to those responsible for terrorism by the state,'' the human rights groups said in a joint statement calling the march. Among the groups were the Center for Legal and Social Studies, the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, and the Permanent Assembly for Human Rights. **********''It must be the first time in the history of law that those accused of a crime enact a law absolving themselves,'' Ernesto Sabato, one of Argentina's leading writers, told reporters, voicing what appears to be a common sentiment held by many intellectuals.   Terms of Amnesty Law **********The wording of the proposed amnesty has yet to be made final, according to the junta. But Argentine military sources said it would likely apply to all servicemen, police and intelligence agents acting under orders in the anti- terrorist campaign. It would also include the commanders who issued the orders. **********The sources said there may be some clause allowing for prosecution, possibly by military courts, of unsanctioned excesses, such as stealing from the homes of the disappeared. **********Maj. Gen. Llamil Reston, the Interior Minister, told some opposition leaders three weeks ago that between 150 and 200 members of the armed forces were already in jail for such excesses, but he declined to give any other details. **********The proposed law would also probably free a number of convicted or suspected terrorists, the sources said. According to General Reston, 360 convicted people are in jail for terrorist-related crimes, and 185 suspected terrorist are being held without charges. Abroad, he said, there were 216 people convicted of terrorist-related crimes and another almost 3,000 people who could be charged if they returned. **********Almost all of the country's leading presidential contenders have said that, if elected, they will annul the amnesty. **********While all branches of the armed forces agree some form of legal protection is needed, divisions among them over how it should be carried out have delayed the issuing of the law for months, the military sources said. **********The navy is said to oppose releasing convicted terrorists, while the air force favors waiting to try to negotiate the amnesty with the newly elected Government before it takes office. But the army is the dominant service and is pushing to issue the law as soon as possible, the sources said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.main_headline: Market Place; The Pattern Of the Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.print_headline: Market Place; The Pattern Of the Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.body_text: **********FOR investors, it was like watching their favorite movie all over again. For the third time in as many weeks, stock market indicators finished Friday at record highs. **********As the week's main feature, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 29.90 points, to 1,226.20. Volume averaged 101 million shares daily on the New York Stock Exchange. The starting point for this rally - whose unflagging strength has amazed amateurs and professionals alike - was a close at 776.92 last Aug. 12. **********Trading has acquired a rather distinct pattern in recent sessions.  Stocks often moved erratically early in the day, only to finish with a burst of energy and higher prices. **********Basically, the stock market remains engaged in a variant of demandpull inflation, a process economists define as too much money chasing too few goods. On Wall Street, too much money - or excessive liquidity, to use a currently fashionable term - has been chasing too few stocks. The stock market's chase will end, temporarily at least, when investors and traders run out of money to spend - or decide to do something else with their cash. **********In fact, almost the worst thing that could happen to the equity market now is a roaring business recovery that channels liquidity into other areas and, at the same time, causes interest rates to rise. **********''Liquid funds seeking the best return in a declining-interestrate, excess-plant-capacity world seek out higher returns from longer-term financial assets,'' according to Robert J.  Farrell, head of Merrill Lynch's market analysis department. ''This is why demand for stocks - and bonds -has been so persistent.'' Predicting the Market 'Top' **********Like many another market professional, Roy M. Blumberg of A.G.  Becker-Paribas expressed frank amazement at the sheer upward momentum of stock prices in April. With a trace of wonderment in his voice, the technical analyst noted on Thursday that the Dow industrials had climbed about 100 points in 17 trading days, scarcely pausing along the way up. (On Friday, the average added nearly 7 points more to its tally.) **********In late March, for example, some money managers were predicting that stocks were likely to tumble in April, following portfolio switches made by pension fund and other institutional investors just prior to the end of the 1983 first quarter. Instead, prices dipped briefly in early April and then commenced their breathtaking ascent.  At the same time, contributions to I.R.A. and Keogh accounts by individual investors kept new cash flowing into equities. **********''What has kept sending the market higher is the basic investor fear of missing the bandwagon,'' Mr. Blumberg noted. ''Still, I think we'll start an intermediate decline within the next few weeks and could see the industrials drop perhaps 125 to 150 points. A classic 'blow-off' buying panic might trigger such a decline.'' **********But, like most market professionals, he is quite bullish for the long term. In fact, Mr. Blumberg is more optimistic than most other analysts. ''I expect the industrial average to reach a high between 1,600 and 1,700 before it finally tops out,'' he asserted. ''The market top should occur in late 1984 or early 1985.'' The G.E. Guessing Game **********On the final Friday in January 1983, General Electric's stock ''broke par,'' as they say in Wall Street, going over 100 for the first time. It traded as high as 100 3/4 before finishing at 99 5/8, up 4 3/8 points for that stirring session. The Dow industrials, which include G.E. as a component, closed the same day at 1,064.75. **********Propelling the stock was an agreement by G.E. to sell most of its Utah International subsidiary to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia for $2.4 billion in cash. The present expectation is that the deal will be consummated later this year. G.E. followers predicted that would swell the company's war chest of cash and marketable securities to around $5 billion. **********G.E. had expressed its intention to expand into high technology and other rapid-growth areas of the economy. Thus, as soon as the sale was announced, the guessing game began. What high-tech company might G.E. buy as its entrance fee into a new field? **********Last Wednesday, rumors flew that the target was the Data General Corporation, which makes general purpose computers and also does a bit of business with G.E. That day, Data General's stock jumped 10 1/4 points. On Thursday, after G.E. issued a categorical denial of any such plans, Data General dropped 6 3/8 points. **********G.E.'s shares, which traded last year as low as 55, finished the week at 111 7/8, up 2 3/4, while Data General closed at 66 5/8, up 3 1/4. Meanwhile, it's a good bet that other G.E. takeover rumors lie ahead to send the blood of speculators racing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.body_text: **********Eight men detained after Friday's wave of bombings in the capital by Corsican separatist guerrillas will probably face charges, police officials said today. A total of 22 people were reported detained in France and Corsica. **********The police said that in rounding up suspects, believed to belong to the Corsican National Liberation Front, they found bomb-making equipment and $100,000 in counterfeit United States money. **********Police officials said two of those detained had admitted taking part in the attacks on four mainline railroad stations and an Air France terminal. **********Marseilles, Aix-en-Provence and Alfortville were also hit by bombs as the guerrillas broke a two-year truce with the Government in mainland France. Fifteen explosions caused serious damage but no casualties. **********The police officials said the authorities learned by chance of the group's plans late Thursday, only a few hours before the explosions, and mobilized scores of officers to try to prevent the attacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.main_headline: T.W.A. CHIEF CALLS UNION PACTS CRUCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.print_headline: T.W.A. CHIEF CALLS UNION PACTS CRUCIAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.body_text: **********C. E. Meyer, the president and chief executive officer of Trans World Airlines, said yesterday that $51 million in concessions that leaders of its pilot union had agreed to was an important first step in reaching the $197 million needed to make the airline profitable next year. **********Speaking at the airlines headquarters here a day after the board of directors of the Trans World Corporation had decided to spin off the airline, he also said that without the support of the parent, the company would find it more difficult to raise credit. **********The 55-year-old president, however, also saw some pluses. He said the move would help dispel the illusion among the airline's three major unions and employees that ''the parent is there to take care of us.'' **********''So the spinoff,'' he added, ''makes everybody face reality.'' **********There is a lot of reality-facing ahead for many of T.W.A.'s 29,500 employees. **********Mr. Meyer estimated that the airline needs $197 million in various forms of concessions from its employees to become profitable in 1984. **********This week he said the leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association agreed to a package that would provide $51 million in concessions, the amount that he had sought from the union. **********The package, the details of which he refused to disclose, will be presented to the 2,800 pilots of the union for ratification. If they ratify the agreement, he said, ''it would be a major step in getting the relief we need.'' **********Other Unions Consulted **********He added that he has already begun talks with the International Association of Machinists, made up of 9,300 members, from which he is seeking $60 million in concessions. Next will be the Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, made up of 5,700 members, who will be asked for $33 million in concessions. **********The 11,700 salaried nonunion employees have already agreed to concessions of $53 million. **********Some analysts said that the airline, which has had yearly pre-tax losses since 1979, can turn around if Mr. Meyer can get the unions' support. **********''They've got to look for a Band-Aid to buy time so they can get wage and productivity improvements,'' said John V. Pincavate, an analyst for Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins. **********If Mr. Meyer is able to get such concessions, the analyst predicted that the airline could then build up its balance sheet next year, when he expects most airlines to make money. This would enhance the company's ability to survive a future recession. **********In addition to the concessions, the airline is cutting 3,500 employees by the end of the year. **********Rise in International Flights **********Mr. Meyer said that the carrier planned to increase its international flights slightly next year. He added that this would mean more work for the remaining employees. **********He added that decisions had not been made on the airline's domestic system, which has been losing money, offsetting some of the profits of its international corporations. A study of what to do is under way, he said. **********The Trans World Corporation said yesterday that it would continue to guarantee some of the airline's credit, including a $200 million bank credit that runs through 1987 and dividend payments through May 1985 on its $2.25 cumulative preferred stock. **********The company set Dec. 28 as the date for the stockholders' meeting to vote on the separation, which would become effective Feb.  1, 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, sold $70.3 million of 12 1/2 percent mortgage participation certificates yesterday at an average price of 99 6/32 to yield 12.38 percent. The yield was up slightly from about 12.3 percent a week earlier. **********The certificates are backed by a pool of conventional home mortgages whose monthly principal and interest payments are passed through to the investor. The certificates are backed by the mortgages, which are privately insured, and the corporation also guarantees principal and interest. **********As a rule, Freddie Mac participation certificates yield slightly more than similar securities of the Government National Mortgage Association, which are guaranteed by the Federal Government. Freddie Mac is a federally chartered institution that helps maintain a secondary market for home mortgates. Its obligations are not guaranteed by the Government.
