https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/busin.body_text: **********On June 10, a Japanese freighter, the Satu Maru, left the southern Brazilian port of Paranagua with a cargo of vegetable and other edible oils. Ordinarily, such news would cause hardly a ripple in the vast sea of commerce in commodities. **********But from the moment the ship's manifest and ports of call were made known, the Satu Maru became a symbol of the plight of American agriculture and the cargo added a new dimension to the global banking crisis. **********The ship's cargo includes 10,730 metric tons of cottonseed oil bound for Memphis, where it will be processed by Hunt-Wesson Foods, a division of Norton Simon Inc., into cooking and salad oils and many other products. **********It will mark the first significant import of an agricultural product in which the nation has long been the dominant exporter. In the latest crop year ended last Sept. 30, for example, the United States exported 384,000 tons of cottonseed oil, or 77 percent of the total of 496,000 tons that was exported by producers worldwide. **********''The shipment is not only the ultimate insult to American farmers, but also to our nation's biggest industry -agribusiness,'' said Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the biggest processor of edible oils in the nation. **********Morton S. Sosland, publisher and editor of Milling & Baking News, a leading trade journal, said last week: ''I would compare the Satu Maru's voyage to a long string of freight cars moving flour to a baking company right here in Kansas City, which is in the midst of the biggest grain producing area in the country. **********''It is even more bizarre when one thinks of the billions of dollars being spent by Washington to bolster farm income by providing farmers, including those who grow cotton, with costly incentives to cut back their acreage this season and, at the same time, ignoring the dumping of foreign subsidized farm products on our markets.'' **********On April 1, shortly after the ''payment-in-kind'' and other programs aimed at sharply reducing planted acreage took form, the Federal Office of Mangement and Budget estimated that the programs would cost $21.8 billion during the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. A year ago, crop-loan and other programs were projected to cost $1.8 billion. Banks Said to Demand Exports **********However, Mr. Andreas of Archer-Daniel-Midland attributed the cause of the problem to banks locked into foreign loans they cannot collect, noting: **********''Our banks lend dollars to these nations to use in any way they see fit, and then these same banks demand that these countries export at any cost in order to earn dollars. **********''Given this situation, I see these indebted nations demanding that they be permitted to dump all kinds of goods here, claiming that they must have open access to our markets in order to raise the dollars to pay off their creditors. One doesn't have to be particularly bright to see where this could lead us.'' **********Mr. Andreas said the cottonseed deal was more than a ''coals-to-Newcastle'' affair, which he asserted would be both uneconomic and illogical were it not for the fact that Brazil can easily subsidize its exporters with cruzeiro it creates by fiat. **********The symbolism begins with the fact that the ship carrying the oil to Memphis is Japanese. Ten years ago this month, President Nixon embargoed all exports of soybeans and products including edible oil because his farm experts told him the crop that season would be insufficient for domestic needs. The 1973 crop proved more than adequate. Japanese Invest in Brazil **********The Japanese were shocked because they depend on soybean sauces as a major source of protein. They then invested heavily to vastly expand Brazil's soybean, cotton and other farm products, and that country is now the world's second-largest exporter of edible oils.  Japan is now investing additional large sums to expand Brazilian exportable oilseed and other crops. **********The Satu Maru's destination is also symbolic, Mr. Andreas noted, because Memphis has been a leading cotton market since the days when ''King Cotton'' was the nation's top cash crop. Today, cotton is the fourth major crop after corn, wheat and soybeans in that order. Much of the crop is now produced on irrigated acreage in California and Arizona as well as in the South's traditional Cotton Belt. **********''It is also symbolic,'' Mr. Andreas added, ''that the Satu Maru is due in Memphis on July 3, the day before our national holiday.'' Perhaps it is also symbolic that Mr. Andreas was chosen by President Reagan two weeks ago to be chairman of the International Private Enterprise Task Force. The group was formed last Nov. 20 to advise the President and various Federal agencies on how to implement the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, which is aimed at helping poorer countries improve their economic conditions by stimulating trade.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/07/world.body_text: **********An independent conservative party took a commanding lead early today over the military-backed party in Turkey's first general election since the armed forces seized power three years ago. **********The party in the lead in Sunday's election, the Motherland Party, is headed by Turgut Ozal, the chief architect of Turkey's economic recovery program. The party was leading in both rural and urban areas around the country. **********The liberal Populist Party, set up by a former civil servant, Necdet Calp, as a loyal opposition, was in second place, ahead of the military's favorite, the Nationalist Democracy Party, which is led by a retired general, Turgut Sunalp. **********With 85 percent of the vote counted, according to broadcasts early today, Mr. Ozal's Motherland Party was well ahead, with 44.8 percent of the vote. Mr. Calp's Populist Party had 30.5 percent and Mr. Sunalp's Nationalist Democracy Party had 23.5 percent.   Possible Blow to President **********If Mr. Ozal's party were to win, many officials have said it would be seen as a blow to the President, Gen. Kenan Evren, who in a pre-election speech clearly came out in support of Mr. Sunalp's party and was sharply critical of Mr. Ozal, although no names were mentioned. **********General Evren called a special session of the ruling National Security Council Sunday night. No details of what went on were made public. **********Despite rain, Turkish voters turned out in large numbers. Nearly 20 million people are eleigible to vote. **********The election was being held to elect a 400-member Parliament. Under the terms of a new Constitution approved last November, General Evren is to remain President. The candidate whose party wins a majority in Sunday's voting will become Prime Minister. **********Mr. Ozal, 56 years old, an engineer and former Deputy Prime Minister, is respected in international business and financial circles for his successful stabilization program. **********He was able to reduce Turkey's inflation rate from 120 percent in March 1980 to about 35 percent the next year. He also doubled the country's exports and ended widespread shortages. He fell out of favor with the military and resigned last year when interest rates shot upward.   A Show of Independence **********If Mr. Ozal wins, many Turkish politicians say, it will have been because of his his show of independence from the military, proven competence at the head of the economy, charismatic personality and good party organization. **********The election process has been carefully controlled from the outset. The country's two main parties, the conservative Justice Party and the moderate leftist Republican People's Party, have been abolished and their leaders, former Prime Ministers Suleyman Demirel and Bulent Ecevit, have been barred from politics for 10 years. **********Only 3 new parties out of 15 were allowed to take part in the election after the military screened their candidates and the founders and programs. **********The three-week election campaign was limited, from the size of buttons to the number of rallies. Even public- opinion polls were banned when it appeared that Mr. Ozal was well in the lead.   'Glad to Get Back' **********A civil servant said, explaining the large voter turnout, said, ''We've missed elections and are glad to get back to democracy.'' **********Another reason, he said, was the $10 fine for not voting. A friend added, ''We hope that with the help of God the new government will do more to solve our economic problems.'' **********The atmosphere at the polls was generally serious, and it was clear that, after three years of military rule, Turks consider voting an important event. **********In a tour of polling places in the capital and several outlying villages, there were no overt signs of attempts to influence the voters. There was no evidence of military presence near the polls. Turkish news agencies reported no incidents of any significance. **********Each voter was given a stamp that said ''Evet'' - ''Yes'' in Turkish and then went into a booth or an empty room, marked the party of his choice, folded the ballot and put it into an envelope and deposited it in a ballot box. **********The only irregularity observed was clearly unintentional, and in fact acted against the authorities. It was noted that if the ink on the stamp was still wet when the ballot was folded, more than one party would be marked, thereby invalidating the ballot. **********In a sampling of voters at the polls in well-to-do, middle-class and poor districts in Ankara and at several nearby villages, few people said they favored Mr. Sunalp's party.   Speech May Have Backfired **********Most said they supported Mr. Ozal's party, and several people in the poorer districts said they had voted for Mr. Calp. At least in the Ankara area, President Evren's pre-election speech in indirect support of Mr. Sunalp seemed to have backfired, as some businessmen, professional people and even civil servants said they had decided to vote for Mr. Ozal after General Evren's speech. **********In the fashionable neighborhood of Cankaya, where most of the members of the ruling military council live, some voters went out of their way to stress that their own parties were absent from the ballot and that they had voted for ''the least bad of the three'' or had voted for all the candidates, invalidating their ballots in protest. **********A senior civil servant, asked how he had voted, answered, ''Demirel.'' He said that since the Justice Party and its offshoot, the True Path Party, had been barred from the election, he had made up his own ballot with his candidate. Several university students and professionals voting in Cankaya said they had deliberately voided their ballots by stamping ''yes'' for all the candidates. **********In Ankara's ancient Castle district, a muhtar, or local headman, said he would vote for Mr. Sunalp and was sure his party would win because ''he has the support of the generals.'' **********It was difficult, however, to find any voters for Mr. Sunalp in the Altindag district, a vast area of squatter houses on the edge of town, where chickens, cats and children rule the alleys and cars rarely venture. **********''People are poor here, and the poor people will vote for the Populist Party,'' a retired schoolteacher said.

John Gummere, 55, was named chief executive, suceeding Robert T.  Jackson, 65, who is retiring after 43 years with the company.  Mr. Gummere is no newcomer either. **********He joined Phoenix Mutual in 1949 in the actuarial department upon graduation from Yale.  Phoenix Mutual Life, with $3.5 billion in assets, is the nation's 20th-largest life insurance company and has expanded into the financial service industry. **********The company has entered the casualty business with the purchase of New York Casualty, a company in Watertown, N.Y.; it has entered the casualty reinsurance business in New York, and it has purchased a New England regional brokerage and investment banking firm, Burgess & Leith. In addition, it has purchased some insurance agencies. **********Mr. Gummere said no further acquisitions were planned at this time.  ''How we are going to assimilate all of this is the big question before the house,'' Mr. Gummere said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/busin.print_headline: REAL ESTATE; HOUSING CONSTRUCTION NEAR EAST RIVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/busin.body_text: **********New York City's housing developers are saying ''Dig we must'' these days in Consolidated Edison's own backyard.  Nowhere in Manhattan does Con Ed have a stronger presence than along the stretch from 41st Street to 35th Street on Franklin D.  Roosevelt Drive. The properties include the inactive Kips Bay generating station east of First Avenue between 35th and 36th Street and the active Waterside generating station on the superblock from 38th to 41st Streets. **********As in so much of Manhattan, however, locations are no longer purely industrial, commercial or residential. In transition areas there has been a shift toward housing, especially on waterfront sites where high-rise construction provides an opportunity for expansive views. **********Ground was broken Monday for Rivergate, a 34-story, 700-unit rental structure that Donald Zucker is building on the square block formerly occupied by a Coca-Cola bottling plant east of First Avenue from 34th to 35th Streets. It is a natural extension toward the East River of residential development along 34th Street, much of it done by Mr. Zucker. **********Two blocks to the north, the Glick Construction Corporation will start demolishing a Texaco station and an old warehouse in May or June, in preparation for construction of a 35-story condominium with 487 apartments and 6,000 square feet of commercial space. Its tentative name is Manhattan Place. The 40,000-square-foot site is on the east side of First Avenue between 36th and 37th Streets. **********The immediate area is not entirely industrial. Across First Avenue is the landscaped ground surrounding the entrance to the Queens Midtown Tunnel. Another neighbor is St. Vartan's Park, formerly known as St. Gabriel's Playground, which occupies a full square block. **********Jeffrey Glick, a partner in Glick Construction, said in an interview that the assemblage of the site and the rezoning it required took three years. As with Rivergate, the Glick project involved months of negotiations with the City Planning Commission and Community Board 6. One outcome was that the building will face southwest instead of northeast, as originally planned, so that the landscaped area in front will face St. Vartan's Park. **********More unusual was the developer's decision, following a suggestion of Planning Commissioner Martin Gallent, to make a $427,000 contribution to help Phipps Houses provide 75 apartments for Bellevue Hospital nurses at below-market cost in a prospective development on First Avenue at 29th and 30th Streets. **********This is a $50 million venture that will produce about 400 apartments, most of them market-rate, in a conversion of the hospital's former pathology laboratory and its current psychiatric hospital. Hospital employees are to get first choice in buying or renting, depending on whether a condominium or rental is built.  Nurses earning about $20,000 will be able to afford the subsidized apartments. **********''They didn't say I had to do it,'' Mr. Glick said, ''but we liked the idea.'' The apartments at Manhattan Place will have floor-to-ceiling bay windows running the full width of the living rooms, and 8-foot, 6-inch ceilings. Ribbons of glass and brick will encircle the jagged facade of the building, which is shaped like a giant rectangle with triangular ends. The architect is C.A. Kondylis of Philip Birnbaum & Associates. **********On the top floor there is to be an 8,000-square-foot glass-enclosed health club for tenants, surrounded by an indoor jogging track around the perimeter. **********Opening prices are expected to be about $240 a square foot. The apartment mix as currently planned is to be 10 percent efficiencies of 655 square feet, 75 percent one-bedrooms or larger one-bedrooms of 715 to 760 square feet, 10 percent two-bedrooms averaging 1,030 square feet and 5 percent larger two-bedrooms of 1,275 square feet.  Thus, $182,400 would be a typical opening price for a 760-square-foot one-bedroom apartment. **********The mix of apartments may change, depending on sales experience, as it already has at another Glick condominium project: Baybridge, on 30 acres off Bell Boulevard at 108th Place near the Throgs Neck Bridge in Bayside, Queens. **********Baybridge is a low-rise condominium development built in a Georgian style. Construction started two years ago. The original plan was to build 700 1,200-square-foot simplex (single-level) units, one to a floor in the three-level buildings. These units are now on the market at prices of $95,000 to $157,000. **********But the developer has made a design change, and newer buildings are to contain two duplex units rather than three simplexes. The apartment size will be about 1,800 square feet, Mr. Glickman said.  Prices will range from $180,000 to $230,000, buyers will typically be older, and the total number of units at Baybridge should turn out to be about 600 instead of the 700 originally planned, he said. **********Similarly, buyer preferences could lead to a change in the mix at the First Avenue building. ''If the market wants more larger apartments, we can change the mix to more twos or threes,'' Mr. Glick said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/busin.body_text: **********To help reduce the cost gap between Japanese and American automobiles, Detroit is scrambling to automate its factories, increase quality and improve labor relations. **********But auto executives say that more efficient plants are only part of the answer to the cost gap. Also important, they say, are the advantages that the Japanese companies enjoy from an undervalued yen and tax forgiveness on exported products. **********The cost gap was put at $1,000 to $1,500 a car by a Federal Government study in 1980. Subsequent Government studies have put the gap at $1,500 to $2,000 on a typical subcompact car. This cost disadvantage, more than any other factor, has cast an ominous cloud over the American auto industry, once considered the most productive in the world. **********Philip Caldwell, chairman of the Ford Motor Company, describes the situation this way: ''Using the landed cost advantage number of $2,000, as we see it, the yen is about $700, the tax burden is about $600 and the balance of it is everything else. So if you call it one-third, one-third, one-third, then I would say two-thirds of the problem is wrapped up in areas which only governments can do something about.'' **********Mr. Caldwell's contentions, if not his exact breakdown of the amounts involved, are supported by other auto industry executives and those in related fields. **********Lee L. Morgan, chairman of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, which is facing stiff competition from Komatsu Ltd., the Japanese heavy equipment maker, recently called for a surcharge on Japanese products sold in this country. The surcharge, he said, would offset the difference between the present value of the yen, about 235 to the dollar, and the rate of 200 yen to the dollar that he said was the Japanese currency's true value. **********However, Martin L. Anderson, director of an automobile study program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said the effect of the currency difference on the price of Japanese cars was overstated by Detroit executives. Only about $3,000 of a car selling for $7,000 in the United States represents costs incurred in yen, he said. Thus an increase in the value of the yen would affect less then half the value of a car. Although few auto executives make the charge, there is a suggestion in their discussions that some-how the Japanese are cheating and maintaining the yen at an artificially low value to capture still larger shares of export markets. W. Paul Tippett, chairman of the American Motors Corporation, asked the Treasury Department last year to ''launch a thorough investigation'' into the yen-dollar relationship. **********The Reagan Administration has done just that, said Michael Driggs, the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Automotive Industry Affairs. ''Our experts continue to tell us they cannot find any evidence of manipulation,'' he said. ''They can't fully explain why it is happening, but they don't find manipulation.'' **********John Williamson, an exchange rate specialist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the major problem was that the dollar was too strong in relation to most other currencies, a situation, he said, that would correct itself in time. The Shift to Small Cars **********Before 1979 the relative values of the dollar and yen did not matter greatly to the United States automotive industry, since most Americans bought big cars manufactured only in this country. The shift in consumer taste to smaller vehicles came at a time when Japanese car makers were rapidly expanding. Automobiles accounted for $13 billion of this nation's $20 billion merchandise trade deficit with Japan last year. **********Similarly, before America became part of the world car market, the difference in the tax systems that evolved here and in other countries was not as important to the companies involved. Japan, like most European countries, relies more heavily on a form of sales tax, known as a value added tax, rather than on income taxes, which raise the bulk of revenue for the United States Government. **********Under international trading rules, countries may forgive the value added tax on products to be exported while imposing it on imported products. In the United States, corporate income taxes are built into the cost of cars and other products and there is no tax incentive for export. **********Since the Japanese value added tax on small autos is 17.5 percent on smaller cars, the forgiveness feature combined with the low United States auto tariff of 2.8 percent gives Japanese cars an advantage of about $735 on a $6,000 car, American auto executives charge. An American product shipped to Europe or Japan would pay taxes both at home and abroad. U.S. Action Asked **********''In the example of trade between the U.S. and Japan, where Japan relies on commodity taxes which exempt exports but are imposed on imports, the U.S. manufacturers are disadvantaged by our unwillingness to use a similar system,'' Frank P. Stafford, chairman of the economics department at the University of Michigan, wrote in an article on United States-Japan trade. **********Some auto executives have called for Government action to offset what they say are the ''unfair'' currency and tax advantages of the Japanese. The Administration, however, seems disinclined to act, evidently out of concern that any easing of the pressure from imports would slow the industry's efforts to hold down costs.  Instead, it is relying on the ''voluntary'' import quotas negotiated with the Japanese Government, and overall economic improvement to restore the auto companies' fortunes. **********''The appropriate role of government is to encourage and help the industry to be as competitive as it can in all segments of the market,'' said Mr. Driggs of the Commerce Department. ''The real test of the ability to compete lies with the industry, with management and labor.'' **********Mr. Anderson of M.I.T., who has studied auto operations in Japan, Europe and America, agrees. ''The fundamental problem is that the U.S. is the high-cost producer,'' he said. ''It still costs more to make a car here than in Japan, regardless of exchange rates or taxes.'' **********Mr. Caldwell of Ford, however, notes that the European affiliates of Ford and General Motors have been more successful against the Japanese than the parent companies in their home market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/world.main_headline: CHAD, CALLING AID INADEQUATE, URGES FRANCE TO 'WAGE WAR'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/world.print_headline: CHAD, CALLING AID INADEQUATE, URGES FRANCE TO 'WAGE WAR'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/23/world.body_text: **********The Chadian Government urged France today to ''wage war'' against Libyan regulars and rebel forces who have occupied the northern third of the country and who were reported today to be continuing a buildup of heavy arms in the oasis of Faya-Largeau. **********At a routine briefing for reporters, Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia, striking a familiar chord, said French assistance to Chad in combating the Libyan-sponsored drive had been ''inadequate.'' Libya denies that its troops are directly involved. **********France has committed 3,000 troops, antiaircraft missiles and at least 10 combat aircraft to Operation Manta - the code name for the deployment in Chad and the neighboring Central African Republic to counter the Libyans. **********French officials insist, however, that the operation is a ''training mission'' and that the aircraft, Jaguar ground- attack planes and Mirage F-1 interceptors, have been sent here only to protect the French ground forces. **********Mr. Soumalia said Chad wanted France, the former colonial power and protector of successive governments here, to ''alter its concept of its role.'' **********''When we are ready, we will ask France to help us'' in a drive to dislodge the 3,500 Libyans in the north, the Minister said. He added: ''We will ask France to be more clear. We will ask France to wage war.'' **********Most Explicit Call for Direct Aid **********The Minister's statement today was the most explicit demand for direct French intervention since Paris embarked on its own buildup last week. **********As part of that buildup, French forces in Ndjamena came under the command of Brig. Gen. Jean Poli tonight. General Poli arrived here in a French military DC-8, accompanied by 90 paratroopers. **********Since the capture of Faya-Largeau on Aug. 10, the desert confrontation in northern Chad has been a stand-off. **********Western diplomats said Libya had continued a buildup of ''enormous amounts of equipment in Faya-Largeau'' and had repaired the dirt runway there, enabling American-built C-130 military transports from the Libyan Air Force to ferry in supplies. **********The diplomats said the Libyan force in Faya-Largeau had patrolled near the town but had not launched a southward advance. **********''This whole thing has escalated to a point where a possible loss of face by a lot of people is involved,'' one Western official said. **********Mr. Soumalia today accused Libya of stepping up the forced recruitment of Chadians working in Libya into an ''Islamic legion'' of non-Libyan Africans. He said they were being trained in Faya-Largeau after being coerced ''in a more brutal manner than before'' to join the force. **********Western military experts here discount the legion as a powerful fighting force because its members are seen as unwilling participants. **********''What is really of concern now,'' a Western official said, ''is what the Libyans intend to do.'' The Libyan resupply of Faya-Largeau could be used for either defensive or offensive purposes, the official said, but there had been ''no Libyan withdrawal, no evidence of declining Libyan interest in northern Chad.'' **********Ostensibly, the Libyans are fighting to install a pliant Government under former President Goukouni Oueddei in Ndjamena, but the Chadian interpretation is that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi wishes to annex his southern neighbor. **********The Western-backed President, Hissen Habre, has asked for an urgent meeting of the Organization of African Unity's ad hoc committee on Chad to discuss the conflict. **********Some Western analysts assert that unless there is decisive action soon the conflict could become a ''creeping war'' that will involve both sides in a protracted commitment to their respective proteges. **********U.S. May Withdraw Awacs **********LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22 - The Reagan Administration has decided to withdraw the two Awacs surveillance planes sent two weeks ago to track the Libyan-backed invasion of Chad, a White House official indicated today. **********The chief White House spokesman, Larry M. Speakes, said ''no final decision has been made'' about withdrawing the planes. Another Administration official said, however, that the decision had been made. **********''The Awacs have achieved their goal,'' this official said. ''The French now have become involved.'' He said the need for the Awacs had eased since the Libyan advance has halted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.main_headline: A TEXAS BANK'S TIES TO OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.print_headline: A TEXAS BANK'S TIES TO OIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.body_text: **********The search for a buyer of the Midland bank is narrowing. Page D4. **********MIDLAND, Tex., Oct. 13 - The First National Bank here took pride in being an Oil Patch bank, an institution that loaned money to the industry on a handshake. And now that it is failing, there is an outpouring of emotional support from those it has helped over the years. **********First National is only the most recent of several banks that have foundered because many loans to the slumping oil industry are not being repaid. But its failure is perhaps the most dramatic because of its identity with West Texas oil. **********This city, 350 miles west of Dallas, sits atop the oil-rich Permian Basin, the vast geological reservoir that supplies one-fifth of the nation's oil production. **********But last week, after First National announced a loss of $121 million through August of this year and a staggering $314 million in nonperforming loans, a quarter of its total portfolio, small depositors staged a run on the bank. **********Then, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced Wednesday that it would lend $100 million to the essentially insolvent bank to keep it afloat until the Federal agency can find a buyer. This would most likely be a stronger bank that would pick up First National's sound assets while the F.D.I.C. took over the bank's nonperforming assets. **********The bank, whose major stockholders are energy industry executives, had scheduled a shareholders' meeting for Friday to vote on a new stock issue to raise as much as $100 million, perhaps enough to avoid a forced merger. But today the bank canceled the meeting as ''no longer appropriate.'' **********The bank's 3.2 million shares outstanding have a book value of about 30 cents a share, according to a recent proxy statement. **********Despite these woes, more than a thousand Midland residents, joined by Gov. Mark White, filled the Civic Center here to overflowing on Tuesday in a nostalgic testimonial to a financial institution that has been a mainstay of the large and small depositor and borrower for almost a century. **********'Mother Midland' **********Old-timers queued up to tell of the time when ''Mother Midland'' made them loans when no one else would. Governor White declared the bank ''one of the great institutions in the state,'' which had ''helped a lot of people to make a lot of money.'' The Young Odessa Businessmen pledged a $500,000 deposit, and lapel stickers proclaimed ''I Support The First National Bank.'' **********Many blamed the overheated oil economy and the flood of amateurs that poured into the oilfields for the industry's sudden collapse, which most oil executives still refer to as a shakedown. **********''It was greed,'' said a driller here who has been in business 17 years and only once, by his testimony, ever hit a dry hole. ''There were tennis pros, college professors, all kinds of people who never did have any knowledge or any business in drilling, who got into it because of the gold they saw lying in the street. That's what did it.'' **********But beyond the unexpected shattering of the oil economy and Midland's good-ol'-boy penchant for writing a loan on faith, a handshake and an oil lease, there were possibly darker problems as well. **********Two Investigations Under Way **********Midland said in its proxy statement that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Office of the Comptoller of the Currency were investigating the bank. **********The S.E.C. is investigating the bank's statements for accuracy about its financial condition in recent months, and has also suggested that the bank exceeded its loan limits, lent money to its executives on favorable terms, violated laws relating to security and record-keeping and failed to file reports on loans from correspondent banks. **********The Comptroller, the bank said, had found that the bank's precarious condition resulted from ''inadequate supervision and departure from prudent lending practices'' as well as ''violations of laws, rules and regulations.'' **********The bank also noted that possible legal violations ''could result in significant civil money penalties and other liabilities'' and could subject board members to ''liabilities in connection with such losses.'' First National bank has been attributing its weakened financial condition to the superheated state of the oil and gas industry in the late 1970's, a fervor that has been chilled over the past 18 months by an oversupply that forced oil and gas prices downward and put a number of energy companies in financial trouble. **********The problem has plagued other Texas banks, among them the Metro Bank of Midland, which was declared insolvent last July and was reorganized as Mid-Cities National, and the National Bank of Odessa, in Midland's sister city, which was closed by the Comptroller of the Currency two weeks ago and then merged and reopened as the First State Bank of Odessa. **********And the problems reach beyond Texas. The 1982 failure of Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma as a result of uncollectable energy loans sent shock waves throughout the banking community. **********The Penn Square failure in turn hurt Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company in Chicago, which nevertheless was able to maintain its independence. But the Seafirst Corporation, which owned Seattle First National, was forced by the burden of loans bought from Penn Square to merge with the BankAmerica Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/07/busin.main_headline: Cook County Issue Cut by $44 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/07/busin.print_headline: FINANCE NEW ISSUES; Cook County Issue Cut by $44 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/07/busin.body_text: **********A Cook County bond issue that was rejected last week by the Continental Illinois National Bank was restructured and reduced to a $61.5 million issue, tentatively priced yesterday with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1984 to 9.90 percent in 1997. **********The bond issue was trimmed from $105.5 million after only one bid was received for the offering at an average cost of 9.98 percent to Cook County, which contains Chicago. Today's interest rate averaged 9.17 percent. **********The new issue has serial bonds maturing from 1984 through 1997.  The serial bonds due in 1984 were given a 10.5 percent coupon and were priced at a premium to yield 6 percent. Last week the coupon was 11.5 percent. **********The serial bonds due in 1993 were given a 9 percent coupon and were priced at 98.66 to yield 9.20 percent. Last week they were priced at 98.33 to yield 9.25 percent. **********The serial bonds due in 1997 were given a 9 3/4 percent coupon and were priced at a discount to yield 9.90 percent. Last week the coupon was 10 percent. **********Proceeds from the bonds will be used for a variety of purposes, including a forensic medical institute, improvement of facilities at police headquarters and a new three-story building. The $44 million for renovating the Cook County Hospital, which was included in the rejected issue, was eliminated to reduce the size of the present bond offering. **********The bonds, a general obligation of Cook County, are backed by its pledge to levy property taxes to pay for the issue. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and are not rated by Standard & Poor's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Spendthrift Farm, one of the world's leading breeders and trainers of thoroughbred race horses, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares. **********The offering, expected for early November, would be for slightly more than 10 percent in the company. At an anticipated price of $15 to $17 a share, the offering would raise about $25 million for expansion purposes, the company said. Controlling interest would remain in the hands of Spendthrift's founder, Leslie Combs 2d, and his family. A group of 35 investors bought about one-third of the company last summer through a private transaction that was estimated to be worth more than $30 million.
