https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.main_headline: DOZENS HURT IN ORANGE DAY PARADE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.print_headline: DOZENS HURT IN ORANGE DAY PARADE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Protestants marched in Northern Ireland's Orange Day parades today after overnight street battles injured more than two dozen police officers. **********Thirty-thousand policemen were on the streets as parades wound through Belfast, Londonderry and 17 other cities and towns in the annual commemoration of the Protestant victory over Roman Catholics at the Battle of the Boyne in 1690. **********The parades are usually the year's biggest display of pro-British fervor among Protestants and underline the hatreds and religious divisions that have torn the province for decades. **********A Five-Hour Disturbance **********Several hours before the marches began, about 500 Protestant youths hurled gasoline bombs, rocks and bottles at police officers in a pitched battle in the village of Ballynahinch, south of Belfast, the police said. **********Sgt. Jim Clarke said the Belfast police had moved in to prevent the youths from attacking homes of Catholics in the predominantly Protestant village. **********The police said rioters used rocks to shatter windows of houses, stores and offices in the five-hour disturbance. There was no estimate of damage. **********Officers in riot gear fired plastic bullets to quell the rioters.  The police said 31 officers and 2 civilians were injured. Twenty-six officers required medical treatment and three were admitted to hospitals. **********Although attacks by Protestant groups on suspected Catholic militants are not uncommon, the police said large-scale rioting seldom occurs in Protestant areas of Northern Ireland, where the one million Protestants outnumber Catholics 2-1. Fights in Londonderry **********In Londonderry, the province's largest city after Belfast, Catholic youths threw about 80 gasoline bombs at police officers in an hourlong attack on the headquarters of the Orange Order, an extremist Protestant organization, near a Catholic residential area. **********The police said the trouble broke out a few hours after the traditional parties and lighting of bonfires on the eve of Orange Day celebrations. **********The celebrations commemorate the defeat of King James II's Roman Catholic army by the Protestant forces of William of Orange, a victory that established Protestant supremacy in Northern Ireland. **********Fire departments reported being called out Monday night to fight more than 100 fires that burned out of control and threatened houses.  A Festive Atmosphere **********Despite fears that the Irish Republican Army might try to disrupt the parades, a carnival atmosphere prevailed as Orangemen in bowler hats, orange sashes and ceremonial swords led the processions to the beat of giant drums and the music of fife and drum bands. **********British soldiers, rifles at the ready, stood nearby.  This year's celebrations came as the British Parliament was preparing to vote Wednesday on the restoration of the death penalty in Britain and Northern Ireland. Capital punishment was abolished in 1969. **********Secretary James Prior, the Government's top administrator in Northern Ireland, has said he strongly opposes capital punishment in Northern Ireland on the ground it could make martyrs of convicted Irish Republican Army killers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Sealed in plastic, clearly labeled and laid out in neat rows along the rack, they are reminiscent of a display of vegetables in a supermarket. **********Far from it: They are 500-pound engines pulled from wrecked automobiles, and they are for sale at Robertson's Auto Salvage in this southern Massachusetts town. **********Robertson's, like much of the rest of the nation's $4 billion-a-year junkyard industry, is trying to upgrade its image. And with the help of improved marketing techniques, greater attention to customers and sophisticated business methods, a change for the better appears to be taking place. **********''You no longer have to walk down muddy paths, be attacked by snarling dogs and scowled at by a menacing owner in order to get a greasy part with no guarantee,'' said Barry Isenberg, a Cupertino, Calif., consultant to the industry. **********Grossed $6 Million Last Year **********Indeed, junkyards have become a big business for some dealers. Robertson's grossed $6 million last year, and was No. 456 on one listing of the nation's 500 fastest-growing companies. **********During the recession, lagging new-car sales helped the used-parts business as people repaired rather than replaced their cars. The average age of cars on the road in 1982 was 7.2 years, compared with 5.7 years in 1972. **********But the recession proved double-edged, for while people kept their cars longer and bought more used parts, fewer cars were junked and used parts were more expensive and harder for dealers to find. **********The shortage of junked cars, along with fewer wrecks because of the lower speed limit and tougher drunken-driving laws, has raised the purchase price of salvage cars for junkyards. ''Where we used to spend $500 for a junk car, we now spend up to $5,000,'' Scott Robertson said. **********Now, with new-car sales increasing, the industry is counting on its spruced-up image to help keep sales steady. And for the customer, the changes are unmistakable. **********Some Parts Come With Warranty **********The most noticeable change is undoubtedly the now nearly universal practice of dismantling used parts before sale. The days are gone when a junkyard owner would wave vaguely toward the acres of rusty heaps out back and say: ''I think there's a wheel on the Chevy out in the corner there. If you can find it you can have it for $10.'' **********Parts are removed, cleaned, tested and often displayed in bright, greaseless showrooms - frequently with a 90-day warranty attached. At Robertson's, salesmen in blazers and ties can show customers candy jars filled with used dome lights, axles for four-wheel-drive vehicles stored in cardboard tubes, and displays of windshield-wiper motors. **********In the warehouse, 600 plastic-wrapped engines - ''It keeps them dry and the nuts and bolts intact,'' Mr. Robertson said - are stored on a three-tiered frame. Out back, hundreds of doors and ''noses,'' the hood and front fender assembly, are displayed on numbered racks. **********Used parts run anywhere from 25 to 75 percent of the cost of new parts. In Baltimore, for example, the fender of a 1980 Chevrolet Monte Carlo costs $287 new and about $125 used. Besides saving money, buyers of used parts avoid the wait for shipment of a new part from the factory. **********Aggressive Marketing Plans **********The industry's improved image is also reflected in aggressive marketing plans, including advertising that is no longer limited to the Yellow Pages. Schram Auto Parts, in Pontiac, Mich., runs seasonal television advertising campaigns promoting the sales of used antifreeze in the fall. Robertson's has a glossy brochure describing its operations, including a prepaid postcard that puts customers on the company's computerized mailing and telephone sales list. Brandywine Auto Parts, Brandywine, Md., has an advertising budget of $500,000 a year. **********The effort to forge a new image extends to the name of the industry association, which eschews any reference to junkyards: The Automotive Dismantlers and Recyclers of America. **********The industry has also been changed by the use of computers, which are proving invaluable to businesses that may stock more than 350 different kinds of parts from countless numbers of automobile models. Mr. Robertson has an I.B.M. 34 computer that can tell him the location of every dismantled part he has, as well as the make, year and mileage of the car it was taken from. **********Not only does this guide him in filling out his inventory when purchasing parts at salvage auctions, but it also prevents the loss of sales because his staff did not know whether a part was in stock. **********Benefits for Insurance Industry **********''You have to have the ability to make the quick connection between what someone needs and what you have,'' said Russell McKinnon of the industry association. ''Before computers, you needed a counter man with a great memory.'' **********The difficulty is compounded because the same part may be used in a number of models. For example, the power steering gear on a 1970 American Motors Hornet is the same one used in a 1976 Chevrolet Camaro. Computer software developed for the industry cross-checks for these interchangeable parts. **********Some analysts expect computers to revolutionize the auto insurance industry as well by providing a nationwide locater service of used parts. ''Insurance adjusters make 50 to 70 million requests a year for parts, parts that could be replaced by used parts if they could be found,'' said Howard Nusbaum, president of AutoInfo Inc., a New York company that sells and services computer systems to auto wreckers. ''If everything were computerized to match requests with availability, repair costs and insurance rates would go down.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/busin.body_text: **********A committee of state insurance commissioners was formed yesterday to work with the Baldwin-United Corporation to develop solutions to its financial problems. **********The committee was formed after a day-long mmeeting at the headquarters of the National Investors Life Insurance Company, one of Baldwin's insurance units. National accounted for $1.6 billion of Baldwin-United's $3.6 billion in revenues last year, mostly through sales of single-premium deferred annuities. The company has suspended sales of these annuities as a result of its problems.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/03/busin.body_text: **********The former chairman of the Texas International Company, George Platt, and Barry Switzer, the football coach at the University of Oklahoma, were among 13 people accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of making an illegal $700,000 profit by trading on insider information in the stock of Phoenix Resources, an Oklahoma oil and gas company. **********According to the complaint, filed late Tuesday in the Federal District Court in Oklahoma City, Mr. Platt, while a director of Phoenix and chairman of Texas International, an Oklahoma City gas and oil exploration company, helped devise a plan under which Phoenix would liquidate its assets. **********The plan was developed about June 4 or 5, 1981, the commission said, but was not publicly announced until June 10. Before the announcement, Mr. Platt bought shares of Phoenix stock and told his son, Stephen, also named as a defendant, about the impending liquidation, the commission said in its complaint. **********The commission said that Mr. Platt then told Mr. Switzer about the liquidation plan while the two were attending a track meet. Mr.  Switzer then told several of his friends, who were included as defendants in the suit. **********In a prepared statement, lawyers for Mr. Switzer and several of the defendants, said they were ''outraged'' by the commission's action. Mr. Switzer contended that he merely overheard talk the impending Phoenix deal, and did nothing illegal. **********''The S.E.C. is attempting to test a new theory,'' the statement said, ''that it should be illegal for anybody to buy stock in a company if he happens to be in a public place and by mere chance, overhears a conversation about that company.'' Lawyers for Mr. Platt have also denied the accusations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/29/world.main_headline: ANDROPOV ATTACKS U.S. MISSILE PLAN AS UNACCEPTABLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/29/world.print_headline: ANDROPOV ATTACKS U.S. MISSILE PLAN AS UNACCEPTABLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/29/world.body_text: **********Yuri V. Andropov said today that President Reagan's new proposals for limiting medium- range nuclear weapons in Europe were unacceptable. **********In a highly unusual and strongly worded personal statement, the Soviet leader raised questions about the entire spectrum of Soviet-American relations under the Reagan Administration. **********It was the first direct response by a Soviet leader to proposals on medium- range missiles announced Monday by Mr. Reagan at the United Nations. The response was coupled with a warning that the deployment of American missiles in Europe, scheduled for December, would be ''a step against peace.'' **********Response on Arms Not Specific **********Mr. Andropov's remarks about the Reagan proposals were general in nature and contained no specific comment on the new American ideas.  Mr. Reagan had agreed to a Soviet demand that the negotiations cover bomers as well as missiles and he had offered to deploy fewer of the Pershing 2 missiles that have been a principal Soviet concern. **********Mr. Andropov said that while Moscow still sought accords at the missile talks in Geneva, it would offer ''an appropriate response'' to any American effort to upset what he called ''the existing military-strategic balance.'' **********The statement came a day after Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said that ''lopsided proposals'' put forward by the West could only mean that it wanted to block agreement on missile reductions. Although Mr. Gromyko did not refer specifically to Mr. Reagan, his remarks appeared to be an oblique reponse to arms proposals offered by the President at the United Nations.  U.S. Said to Pose a Threat **********Mr. Andropov accused the Reagan Administration of posing a threat to peace by an arms buildup, by expanding the American military presence around the world, and by efforts to enlist the backing of Western Europe and Japan. **********The Soviet leader, saying that the Reagan Administration had imposed a militaristic state of mind on the nation, questioned whether the United States had become a fit host country for the United Nations. **********He said the American leaders, in striving to justify their policies, had resorted to slandering the Soviet Union and its Communist system. Mr. Andropov said it was absurd to inject ideology into Soviet-American relations in this nuclear age. **********''Responsible statesmen have only one choice - to do everything possible to prevent a nuclear catastrophe,'' he said. ''Any other position is short-sighted; more so, it is suicidal.'' **********The statement included Mr. Andropov's first public comments on the shooting down of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1, with the loss of all 269 aboard. **********The Soviet leader said responsibility for the loss of life rested with the United States for having sent the airliner on a spying mission, as the Russians have charged, and he mocked the ''humanism'' of Mr. Reagan, who he said had used the incident to argue the need for a further arms buildup. **********''One must say bluntly that it is an unattractive sight when, with a view to smearing the Soviet people, leaders of such a country as the United States resort to what almost amounts to obscenities alternating with hypocritical preaching about morals and humanism,'' Mr. Andropov said. **********His criticism was balanced by a renewed pledge to seek agreement in the parallel Geneva talks on medium-range and strategic, or long-range, weapons and to work for a relationship of peace with the United States.   Malicious Attacks' Charged **********Mr. Andropov said that while the ''malicious attacks'' by the Reagan Administration had aroused indignation, ''our nerves are strong and we do not base our policy on emotions.'' **********''It rests on common sense, realism and profound responsibility for the destinies of peace,'' Mr. Andropov said. **********It has been rare in recent years for such bitter statements about the United States to be made directly by a Soviet leader. The criticism was all the more notable coming from Mr. Andropov, who has generally struck a calm and unpolemical tone in commenting on Soviet-American affairs. **********The importance attached to the statement by the Kremlin was indicated by the fact that it was made by itself, without the context of a dinner speech for a visiting dignitary or an interview with Pravda, the leading Soviet newspaper. **********An introductory passage suggested that the statement was thought of particular moment for both domestic and foreign consumption. **********''The Soviet leadership deems it necessary to make known to the Soviet people, to other peoples and all those who are responsible for shaping the policy of states its assessment of the course pursued in international affairs by the present United States Administration,'' the statement started out.   Kremlin's Resentment Reflected **********Western diplomats, noting that there was little of substance in the document that had not been said before, suggested that it might have been prompted by a mood of anger and resentment at the worldwide condemnation that followed the downing of the South Korean airliner. **********Mr. Andropov's remarks suggested that the Kremlin had been particularly stung by Mr. Reagan's speech at the United Nations, attacking Soviet policies on arms control and human rights. The Soviet leader called Mr. Reagan's speech ''grandiloquent'' and said his statements about the United States' desire for peace and the self-determination of peoples around the world ''can convince no one.'' **********''Even if someone had any illusions as to the possible evolution for the better in the policy of the present Americanu Administration, the latest developments have finally dispelled them,'' Mr. Andropov said. ''For the sake of its imperial ambitions, it goes so far that one begins to doubt whether Washington has any brakes at all preventing it from crossing the mark before which any sober-minded person must stop.''  Reference to Plane Incident **********Mr. Andropov mentioned the South Korean plane, shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1 with the loss of 269 lives. He called the incident a ''sophisticated provocation'' by United States intelligence services and ''an example of extreme adventurism in politics'' by the Reagan Administration. He said the responsibility of the United States had been demonstrated, regardless of ''what false versions'' Washington might put forward. **********He said the United States leadership had followed up this ''criminal subversion'' by pushing through Congress a program of ''colossal military spending.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.main_headline: OPERATING FOR PROFIT AT HOSPITAL CORP.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.print_headline: OPERATING FOR PROFIT AT HOSPITAL CORP.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/29/busin.body_text: **********WALTERBORO, S.C., is a poor, sleepy, rural community of 6,100 peoples et about 50 miles from Charleston. It was named for the Walters b rothers, who migrated there in the late 1700's to escape the m osquitoes farther south. Getting sick, though, was what modern day inhabitants dreaded most. That meant checking into the red-brick building over on Lemacks Street - the Colleton Regional Hospital, the only hospital in the county. **********It was a dim affair. Rooms leaked when it rained. Plaster was peeling off the walls. Squadrons of roaches, mice and rats competed for space. Some of the equipment seemed fit for a museum. Well-to-do denizens simply hopped in their cars and drove to Charleston and were healed there. **********Then, near the end of 1980, corporate medicine came to Walterboro.  And last March, a spiffy new 145-bed hospital opened its doors on Robertson Boulevard. Its proprietor is not the community, but the Hospital Corporation of America, a for-profit public company that rules over the nation's largest hospital system. **********The coming to town of H.C.A. or one of its powerful rivals in the burgeoning hospital business - Humana, American Medical International, National Medical Enterprises or Lifemark - has been duplicated recently in a wide scattering of communities. Their arrival reflects a profound change in the delivery of health-care in the nation, and it raises difficult questions about how far to let the profit incentive spread into health care. **********Privatization, as it is called, has begun to creep into a number of social welfare areas, such as police protection and sanitation, once deemed fit only for public authorities. Now corporations say that they can heal the sick better than governments or other dogooders and make profits at it, too. The Reagan Administration has struggled to reassert the marketplace wherever possible, providing a fertile time for such systems to grow. **********The phenomenon of the profit-making hospital chain has arisen on such a broad scale so swiftly that it is difficult to analyze.  Opinions about them are rampant; research on them is not. Still, with the drying up of government funds to build hospitals, it seems clear that this is the future toward which American medicine is headed. **********Hospitals run for profit have, of course, existed for decades, even centuries, though they usually have been tiny, individually-operated facilities owned by doctors. But in the late 1960's, hospital chains owned and operated by sizable corporations appeared for the first time. The major impetus was the passage of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965, which made health care lucrative to providers, interesting to investors. They have thrived ever since. Proprietary multi-hospital systems now own about 11 percent of the country's 5,900 community hospitals and 8.5 percent of their beds. **********During the 1970's, these networks grew while the total number of hospitals dwindled slightly. More recently, the industry has begun to bunch into fewer and bigger chains. Some health-care experts boldly predict that the profit-making chains could double in size during the 1980's and claim 20 percent of the industry. **********The emergence of these sprawling corporate empires has showered undeniable gifts on many hamlets that have traditionally had a brutal time getting able medical care. But it has also stirred up debate about their effect on the ethos of medical treatment. **********THE for-profit systems argue that they can run a hospital efficiently and thus put a lid on rocketing health costs even while extracting a healthy profit. Their enormous reach into the capital markets enables them to construct facilities and buy advanced medical equipment that communities with empty tills cannot afford. At the same time, though, their tilt toward people who can pay to be mended and their avoidance of the utterly poor, non-welfare patient may be undercutting the assumption that everyone has a right to decent medical services. **********''Health care is not a commodity like a pair of shoes or a used car or a refrigerator,'' complains Dr. Arnold Relman, editor of the New England Journal of Medicine. He fears that these hospital-management companies are fomenting a dual system of health care: ''We're going to see a very commercial type of arrangement where those who can afford to pay get the best treatment. We're getting back to a sort of survival of the richest.'' **********In addition, these for-profit systems have - until recently - exhibited little commitment to research or to educating the doctors of tomorrow. They have been attacked for eschewing services that fail to fatten their wallets. There are fears that doctors will be pressured to adopt a corporate profit-making mentality. **********Not surprisingly, H.C.A.'s president and chief executive officer, Thomas Frist Jr., disagrees: ''People say we're going to skim the cream,'' he says curtly. ''That's a stupid public.'' **********Back in the 1950's, his father, Thomas Frist Sr., was a cardiologist practicing in Nashville. Fed up with the sorry state of local hospitals, he founded a 50-bed facility called Park View Hospital. By the early 1960's, unable to raise money to expand, he and fellow doctors went the for-profit route. In time, several Tennessee hospitals asked the senior Dr. Frist for help and he sniffed the advantage of stringing hospitals together. **********In 1968, joined by his son, serving as a United States Air Force surgeon, and by Jack Massey, a long-time patient of Dr. Frist's, who had developed the Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant chain, the senior Dr. Frist founded H.C.A. Within six months, 11 hospitals came under its control. **********People howled their upset. Making money off the sick, was immoral, some reasoned. But Dr. Frist plowed steadfastly ahead. He knew the concept would work, he said, ''because I saw Holiday Inn, Kroger and the A & P. I saw everything joining together to save expenses.'' **********H.C.A. now owns or manages a serpentine trail of 364 hospitals boasting 52,134 beds, almost quadruple the network run by American Medical International, its closest competitor. H.C.A. heals the sick in such far-flung places as Trinidad, Colo., Metairie, La., Iron River, Mich., and Grundy, Va. A decade ago, it managed just 57 hospitals. **********Everything about H.C.A. seems to keep getting bigger. Its revenues last year topped $3.5 billion, and it turned a profit of $171.9 million, a 55 percent improvement over 1981. H.C.A.'s stock could be bought for less than $7 in 1978; now it costs roughly $50. Numbers like these have helped the company attract a following among healthcare analysts who see it as one of the best-managed of the hospital empires. And financially-strapped communities that once scorned it are now summoning H.C.A. Tom Frist Jr. speaks of his company swelling to perhaps 500 hospitals before the decade is out and becoming one of the biggest corporations in America. **********But a major test of corporate medicine, which could have enormous impact on H.C.A., will come in October, when a new ''prospective payment'' system of Medicare reimbursement begins to be phased in over a four-year period. Medicare now pays hospitals all reasonable costs. Under the new arrangement, the Government will pay hospitals a flat fee set in advance for each patient with a particular illness.  Then, if a hospital does a shoulder replacement cheaper than the fixed rate, it will pocket the difference. **********Such a change could greatly affect H.C.A.'s profit picture, since it derives roughly 41 percent of its patient revenues from the aged under Medicare. The for-profits, including H.C.A., favor the new incentive, contending that they will now be able to strut their stuff. *********** * * H.C.A.'s glass-sheathed headquarters in Nashville befits a prospering corporation. Thus far, H.C.A. has flourished on hospitals alone, but it forsees the day when it will blossom into a healthcare conglomerate. Already under its corporate umbrella is a Seattle ambulance service, as well as stakes in a California nursing home company and an artificial organ firm. **********Tom Frist Jr. likes to talk about what he sees as a critical edge that the public corporations have: the ability to drum up money.  Non-profit hospitals (which H.C.A. likes to call ''non-tax-paying hospitals'') must rely on philanthropy and tax-exempt bonds to grow, while the for-profit chains (H.C.A.'s calls them ''investor-owned'') can issue stock and tap sources like the Eurodollar market. Money helps when ground is broken on a new hospital about every four weeks - as in H.C.A.'s case. **********Drawing analogies between for-profit and non-profit hospitals is no simple exercise. Two years ago, the consulting firm of Lewin & Associates published an often-cited study of 53 pairs of similar for-profit and non-profit hospitals in three states. Based on 1978 data and not meant to speak truths for the entire country, the study concluded that the for-profits charged 17 percent more per admission than voluntary hospitals. **********It also found that, for Medicare and Medicaid payers, costs were 8 percent higher at the for-profits. While the matched pairs varied little in charges for routine things like bed and board, the study reported that the for-profits sharply marked up ancillary services like drugs and supplies. Although Lewin felt that the for-profits were more efficient in areas such as housekeeping, it found that they demonstrated no edge at all in many other areas. **********H.C.A. said the study was flawed. While Mr. Frist agrees that it will often cost somebody more per day to get rid of a hangnail or have a baby at an H.C.A. hospital, he says that the total bill you pay when you leave is going to be cheaper. H.C.A. gets the sick back on their feet faster, he said. **********H.C.A. prefers that patients to go home after the first two or three days, since by then the most profitable procedures like X-rays and lab tests are over. The national average for patient stays is 7.6 days; at H.C.A. facilities it was 6.4 in 1980, the last period reported. **********Others, however, suggest that H.C.A. and its brethren treat a different mix of patients. Less costly ones, says David Ott, a member of the hospital consulting firm of J.X. Reynolds & Co. ''If you were to get an acute pain in your midsection right now and were rushed off to a for-profit hospital, you'd be cared for right away and you'd rest in your nice comfortable room with the wallpaper and you'd be home in a couple of days. However, if your appendix burst and your upper colon was damaged and there were other complications, that for-profit hospital might take one look at you and say you need more elaborate care and send you over to the local university hospital.'' *********** * * Who will care for the poor? That is the obligatory question in debates over the hospital chains. H.C.A. makes no bones about the fact that it wants dollars and not promises from patients.  Preadmission checking is done to see if patients have deep enough pockets. Deposits are often demanded. While it will treat any emergency patient until he is stabilized, H.C.A. is loathe to admit nonemergency uninsured patients. **********Say an uninsured person with empty pockets shows up with a gall bladder that needs removing. H.C.A. will check to see if the person qualifies for Medicare or Medicaid and will help him sign up. If he doesn't qualify, it will recommend a bank loan (though not arrange one). If that does not work, it will point the way to the nearest voluntary hospital and wish the patient luck. **********In a monopoly situation like Walterboro, the county typically signs a contract with H.C.A. agreeing to reimburse the company for indigent care. In Walterboro, H.C.A. paid $2.3 million for the old hospital's equipment and to lease the building while constructing a new one. The county set aside a special fund of $2 million and and used the income from investing it in the financial markets to pay for up to $200,000 a year for poor patients. **********Dozens of non-profit hospitals in fact indulge in the same practices that the for-profits are accused of: spurning the indigent and eschewing research and education. Indeed, non-profit hospitals have learned from the for-profits and many have begun to combine into regional networks of their own. ''I think you're going to see everybody look pretty much alike 10 years from now,'' suggests David Ott. *********** * * Most hospitals work on the Robin Hood principle. They make money off privately-insured patients and apply it to the costs of the indigent. Even non-profit hospitals aim to make a profit; they just call it a surplus. What alarms many about for-profit systems, however, is that as their facilities siphon more and more insured patients from voluntary hospitals, while shuttling the needy to them, the voluntary hospitals will no longer have enough rich for Robin Hood to do his work. The taxpayers would have to make up the difference. **********But there is no mistaking the health value of the dollars that an H.C.A. has to put to work. ''Whether someone likes them or dislikes them for being publicly-owned and profitable,'' says Peter Frishauf, the editorial director of Surgical Care Publications and a long-time observer of the medical scene, ''the bottom line has to be, do they provide high-quality health care. And the answer, by and large, has to be yes.'' **********So far, of course, the chains have basked in rosy times and haven't often faced hard choices that might suggest where their hearts are.  Asked what would occur if a clash developed between economic and social concerns, Donald MacNaughton, H.C.A.'s chairman and the former head of Prudential Life Insurance, replied, ''You cut down on people, cut down on space, cut down wherever you can. If you still can't solve the problem, you try to find out if there are abuses. You let some of the doctors go. If you feel you're doing too much indigent care, you just put a cap on the level of indigent care you will accept. It might be that that hospital ought not exist and if so you get rid of the hospital.'' *********** * * You won't find H.C.A. in downtown Detroit or Newark. The settings it favors are advantageous to insuring black bottom lines. It skirts the inner-cities, with their heavy concentrations of poor. It likes the Sunbelt, where population growth is, and it likes communities where younger people, with private insurance, settle. If it can't have that, it can find bliss in a setting like Walterboro where it's the only game in town; it enjoys such monopoly status in 50 communities. Climates unfettered by insurers who review the equity of rates also get its juices going. The chains are almost invisible in the heavily-regulated Northeast. In South Carolina, on the other hand, Blue Cross pays pretty much whatever a hospital asks. **********By relying on just four builders and prototype designs, H.C.A.  boasts that it can build a hospital 30 to 40 percent cheaper than a community can. H.C.A. staffers have also devised the optimimum configuration for every room in a hospital. Whether a private-patient room is in Utah or Kentucky, for example, it will always have the bed four-feet-nine inches from the window, leaving space for a chair that is 31 inches long by 27 inches wide. **********Hospital chains differ widely in the authority they bestow on individual units. Humana's president once declared that he wanted to provide a product as uniform as a McDonald's hamburger. H.C.A.  prides itself on allowing hospital administrators broad ''local perogative.'' **********Its corporate staff has devised an array of cost-effective systems - to buff the floors, serve the food, run the pharmacy - that are available to its hospitals but not mandatory. Budgets are worked up locally, though they must be approved by headquarters. Further, the corporate materials management staff has 473 discount supply contracts - covering everything from desks to drugs - to offer individual hospitals. The savings are often 15 to 20 percent. After all, H.C.A. buys 6.1 million aspirins a year and 4.3 million syringes and needles. **********H.C.A. expects its administrators, despite their freedom, to perform and perform well. Every month, hospitals are sized up according to a battery of yardsticks: man-hours per adjusted patient day, bad debt expense, occupancy. The company expects its administrators to shoot for a 5 percent net profit margin. In the computer industry in recent years margins have been running at about 10 percent. In the more mature auto industry, the figure is under 5 percent. **********H.C.A. gets administrators to shine by pitting them against each other. (H.C.A. takes pains to point out that administrators don't get bonuses tied to performance; but, of course, sweeter salaries are rarely doled out for sloppy work). **********Mike Law is a curly-haired, effervescent man in his mid-30s with a college degree in hospital administration. He runs H.C.A.'s Southern Hills Hospital in Nashville. No one had to drill the competitive drive into him. His father sold bib overalls for a living. ''Every month, he'd get a listing of all salesmen that would show how they were doing,'' his son recalled. ''If my dad was not in the top five, it'd kill him.'' His father's compulsion has rubbed off. ''I want to be No. 1,'' he admits. **********The pressure on administrators may get heavier under the overhauled Medicare system. It might also implant some strain in H.C.A.'s network, which tends to defer to doctors in the choice of equipment and supplies. Clayton McWhorter, H.C.A.'s executive vice president, explains: ''In the past, if we had a contract on a catheter and a doctor at one hospital didn't like the catheter, he threw it away.  Well, with the changes, the hospital administrator who knows there's a 20 percent savings on the catheter is going to talk to that doctor and sell him on how good that catheter is. He's not going to allow ego and little turf-protecting types of things to interfere.'' *********** * * Marching bands didn't welcome H.C.A. to Walterboro. Agitation for a private company was set in motion by disgruntled doctors and county politicians, but the community split into antagonistic factions. A public referendum finally decided the matter in November 1980. The board of the old county hospital retained a public relations firm to oppose H.C.A. **********Meanwhile, physicians and politicians were whisked to other hospitals in the chain by H.C.A. in the company's two corporate planes. They also threw a barbecue bash in Walterboro. Some of the scuttlebutt going around town was that H.C.A. didn't employ any black doctors, so some black doctors affiliated with other H.C.A.  hospitals were brought to the barbecue as proof. **********After H.C.A. prevailed, Don Caldwell was appointed the new administrator. The belt was tightened. Bad debts were shaved by sending delinquent bills to collection agencies and by demanding deposits from questionable patients. Staff shifts were shortened during sluggish occupancy months. Supply costs were lowered. Some of the dead wood of the staff was dismissed and, to keep the mood pleasant all employes were put through courtesy seminars. **********Patients are a hospital's meal ticket, and thus Mr. Caldwell is actively wooing specialists to compete against Charleston hospitals.  One of the services he can tap is an H.C.A. computer bank of some 600 doctors with information on where they would like to practice. An obstetrician is due in town shortly. To get him, Mr. Caldwell offered him a year's free office space and guaranteed him a first-year income of $60,000, enticements likely to endear him to H.C.A. **********Mr. Caldwell spent 13 years in the non-profit world and hopes never to revisit it. He remembers answering to board members who couldn't read or write. **********Patients seem pleased by the new comforts - the carpeted, spacious rooms, a television set for every bed.  Ile Stacey, an elderly woman who arrived at the hospital with ''a little heart problem,'' was sitting alongside her bed. Flowers reposed on her window ledge. ''I think it's a wonderful little hospital,'' she said. ''It's like home.'' **********John Kinard Jr., a general surgeon in Walterboro, his legs stretched out in his spacious new H.C.A.-built office, remarked: ''It's certainly a much better place to practice. I'm not flying by the seat of my pants as I was on some operations in the old hospital.'' He said he finds that the ''country-club types'' who used to commute to Charleston are now coming to him. ''It's the hospital,'' he said. **********Charges at Colleton have risen mildly so far, but they doubtlessly will increase further after the new hospital gets a better fix on its costs. Its monthly electric bill, for instance, is $14,000, compared to $6,000 at the old hospital. **********There are still crucial questions that are likely to lack answers for some time to come. By any measure, H.C.A. holds a great deal of thus-far dormant power. What is to stop it from boosting rates to the moon or from stopping to deliver babies if it costs too much? **********Chris Bickley, the city manager, pondered the question in his City Hall office. ''It concerned me having a proprietary company coming in and being given an unregulated monopoly. Thinking it through, I realized that people in Colleton County are used to going to Charleston for their health care. If H.C.A. prices itself out of the market, we won't hesitate to get back in our cars and drive down the road.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/14/busin.body_text: **********ALL across the country, there is talk about decay of the infrastructure - defined broadly as bridges, highways, railroads and airports, dams and reservoirs, flood control projects, underground pipes and sewage systems, and hazardous waste facilities. **********Putting off maintenance has long been popular to conserve money, so much so that, in the Depression, few civil engineers could find jobs. And in the latest recession local governments cut back on civil engineering and inspection staffs. **********Now, however, the emphasis is changing, and the demand for civil engineers is on the upswing. **********Walter Blessey, former president of the American Society of Civil Engineers, said yesterday: ''I absolutely agree that we still need more civil engineers. In the early 1940's, I would crawl under bridges and notice erosion and rust. Nobody in government wanted to put money into what they couldn't see. We don't have the technical people to maintain our structures.'' **********At Tulane University, where he is head of the school's civil engineering department, Professor Blessey has been discouraged from talking to freshmen about the advantages - and the fun - of being a civil engineer in the last four years because the university wanted to increase other engineering departments. **********''Many students have been seduced into glamorous areas like bioengineering and computer science,'' he said. ''This year, the dean is permitting me to talk to freshmen. I haven't seen more interest in majoring in civil engineering yet, but it could be a delayed reaction.'' **********If Professor Blessey gives his talks, he thinks enrollment in civil engineering could increase. He will talk of such dramatic opportunities as building structures in the Alaskan ice field and designing offshore platforms but will stress that the real need is for rehabilitation of the infrastructure. **********''Nobody likes to be a Jean Valjean and inspect sewers,'' Robert E. Price, president of Openaka Corporation, said. He added that there was ''no obvious glamour'' to much of the needed rehabilitation. His company specializes in investigations and repairs of concrete specialty pipelines. **********He cited several problems. ''No. 1 is that the supply of civil engineers went down when interest rates went up and capital spending went down, both private and public,'' Mr. Price said. ''I think that now people are taking a second look at the field'' because of such recent problems as the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge at Greenwich, Conn, he said. **********''A second problem,'' Mr. Price said, ''is that the supply of experienced engineers to make judgments on repairs is too small, and it will take young engineers several years to gain experience.'' Meanwhile, Mr. Price has difficulty finding able young engineers at the going rate of about $25,000 a year. **********At the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Prof. Joseph M. Sussman adds another perspective: ''The extraordinary opportunities in computer and electrical engineering have driven down the number of civil engineers so that there is an undersupply. I don't have finger tip data, but I think the shortage will increase as we see renewed interest in building up the infrastructure.'' **********Professor Sussman, who heads M.I.T.'s civil engineering department, defined infrastructure as the nation's ''physical underpinnings.'' **********At M.I.T., students usually pick a major at the start of sophomore year, and Professor Sussman found more interest recently in civil engineering. ''I can sense a pickup in interest from the number of students who drop in to talk to me,'' he said. ''The data is just coming in, but I think this year the number of sophomores picking civil engineering at M.I.T. will be more than 50 percent higher than in recent years.'' Sophomores choosing civil engineering might number about 30, up from 18 in recent years, he said. **********What about the many civil engineers who work for internationl construction companies that have been building infrastructure in underdeveloped nations, such as Saudi Arabia? ''I don't think the bloom is off that rose, but there might be a slight slowdown in demand for civil engineers working overseas,'' Professor Sussman said. **********A problem in most engineering fields for students and professors is the fast obsolescence of technical knowledge. It has often been said that an engineer's knowledge becomes largely outdated every five years, requiring refresher courses. ''We try to give students basic tools so that as the field changes they have the needed strengths to build on,'' Professor Sussman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.main_headline: INTERIOR DESIGN INDUSTRY STUDYING A MOVE TO QUEENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; INTERIOR DESIGN INDUSTRY STUDYING A MOVE TO QUEENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.body_text: **********One of the most ambitious real estate deals in recent history is taking shape in the city. Leaders of the interior design industry - the wholesalers of furniture, fabrics, wall coverings, lighting and carpeting - are talking about joining together and moving to a new location. **********The industry is made up of 450 businesses, employing 30,000 people and using six million square feet of space in Manhattan. Most of the companies are small, family business, but the industry also includes major international concerns. **********Such a large shift probably has not taken place in New York since the wholesale produce industry was moved from the West Side of Manhattan to the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx. Getting even half of the interior design companies to agree to move would be a major accomplishment. **********At the moment, many of these companies have their showrooms on the East Side in the 50's and 60's and rising rents have become a critical problem for many of them. Typically, leases are rising to $35 to $40 a square foot from $12 to $15, according to Donald Schnable, a real estate consultant with Julien J. Studley Inc. who has been hired by the industry. **********Among the buildings now used by the industry are the Decorator and Design Building at 979 Third Avenue, the Architects and Designers Builidng at 964 Third Avenue, the Decorative Arts Center at 305 East 63d Street and the New York Design Center at 200 Lexington Avenue.  Showrooms typically require far more space than offices, but there is no distinction in rents. **********Edwin Bitter, president of Scalamandre Silks Inc., is the head of an ad hoc committee made up of industry leaders who are studying a move. ''Rents are so high we're being forced out of buildings and the industry is fractionalizing,'' he said. Companies lose business if they are not geographically concentrated, he argued. **********The city is encouraging the industry to move across the 59th Street Bridge to Long Island City, Queens, where Lazard Realty Inc. is rehabilitating the American Chicle Building and the Bucilla Building. The two buildings have more than a million square feet of space. The site has a development potential of four million square feet. **********A year ago Lazard was planning to convert the buildings to backoffice spaces, but the concept failed. Then about six months ago Lazard, at the urging of city officials, switched strategy and decided to turn the property into an international design center, much like the Chicago Merchandise Mart or the Pacific Design Center in Los Angeles. **********Both of these centers have proved to be successful from a real estate as well as a marketing point of view. Like other design centers around the country, the attraction is a kind of one-stop shopping market for the architects and interior designers who patronize the industry. **********Most people in the industry argue that New York needs a design center. The question is whether it would work in Long Island City, or any location outside Manhattan. **********To promote the idea, Lazard hired impressive companies to make its proposal work. I.M. Pei & Partners, the architectural firm, will prepare the master plan. Massimo Vignelli of Vignelli Associates will do graphics. And Joseph Paul D'Urso Design is planning the interior public spaces. **********Just yesterday, Lazard signed its first lease for the design center. John Stuart/John Widdicomb Inc., a furniture company, has taken 30,000 square feet of space and will move from 979 Third Avenue. Harvey Schulweiz, president of Lazard Realty, said he believed the project was ''over the hump right now.'' But he said it would be a recognized success when about 250,000 square feet of space was leased, which also is the amount needed to get permanent financing for the project. **********Lazard and industry leaders - both proponents and opponents of a move - agree that relocation of the industry will work only if the major companies in the business take space in a new area. **********Lynn Berman, president of Designfriends Ltd., a wall covering and fabrics company, and another member of the ad hoc committee, said that the committee had talked to 13 or 14 developers about new locations for the industry, ranging from the Bronx to the Meadowlands in New Jersey. ''We'll listen to anybody, and we are definitely entertaining any offers,'' she said. ''But I think Lazard is the first developer to approach us with anything that comes near meeting our needs.''She also said that a move to Long Island City would be ''pioneering'' and that many companies were afraid to make such a shift. **********Edward Epstein, President of Stendig International Inc., the furniture company, represents the skeptical crowd. Lazard, he said, was the only company ''truly developing a property for the purpose as a design center.'' But, he added: ''Will the industry move to Long Island City? I can't believe it.'' In his own case, he said, he would not want to move. But Stendig, unlike some other companies, he said, can afford East Side rents. **********At the same time, however, Mr. Epstein said he thought that Lazard could rent about two million square feet of space to companies in the design business. ''Lazard hired all the right people,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/busin.body_text: **********The index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to forecast the direction of the economy, rose 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department reported today. **********The increase was smaller than in earlier months of the economic recovery, which started in November. Malcolm Baldrige, the Commerce Secretary, said the figure was ''still strong and above average,'' though showing that growth was starting to ''subside to a more sustainable pace.'' **********The index rose 1.2 percent in May, 1.3 percent in April and 2 percent in March. A Fear of Too-Strong Growth **********Some private economists agreed with Mr. Baldrige's assessment. They have expressed a fear that too rapid a rate of economic growth could spawn a new round of inflation. In the second quarter, the economy grew at a strong 8.7 percent annual rate. **********Allen Sinai of Data Resources Inc. said, ''This is the first hint that the pace of the expansion is going to slow.'' The index of leading economic indicators is a compilation of a dozen economic statistics. The June report said a decline in initial claims for unemployment benefits accounted for most of the increase in the index. **********Six indicators rose of the 10 that were available, compared with seven of 11 in May and nine of 11 in April. Those that rose in June included stock prices, permits for future construction and money supply, all sensitive to interest rates. They would decline if interest rates were to rise in coming months. **********Other indicators that contributed to the rise were the average workweek and business formations.  Indicators that fell were manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials; contracts and orders for plants and equipment, and prices of sensitive materials. **********An indicator index reflecting the speed of orders being filled was unchanged, and an indicator reflecting inventories on hand and on order was unavailable. Credit figures, which include business and consumer borrowing, were also unavailable. 10th Gain in a Row **********Mr. Baldrige noted that the June advance in the index was the 10th in a row, making it ''the longest uninterrupted rise since 1975, when the economy was on its way toward five years of expansion.'' He said last month's improvement brought the indicator increase for the second quarter to 3.6 percent, after a 6.8 percent jump in the first three months of the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.main_headline: NICARAGUA EVACUATES PORT RAIDED BY REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.print_headline: NICARAGUA EVACUATES PORT RAIDED BY REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/13/world.body_text: **********The 25,000 residents of Nicaragua's main oil port were evacuated from the city today after anti-Government rebels attacked fuel storage tanks, setting off major fires, officials here said. **********The rebels attacked in the predawn hours Tuesday, initially blowing up five fuel storage tanks. Government officials said at least 3.2 million gallons of gasoline and other fuel had gone up in flames in as many as eight fuel tanks. **********Officials said firefighters in the Pacific coast port of Corinto succeeded in bringing the flames under control today. **********(Some inhabitants began returning to Corinto from Managua, United Press International reported.) **********Red Cross officials and others said 12 people were injured, including three Koreans aboard a South Korean ship docked at the port. The ship was reportedly hit in the attack. **********In Honduras, the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, a rebel group backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, took responsibility for the attack, saying its aim was to ''paralyze the war apparatus of the leftist regime.'' **********The Government called the attack ''criminal'' and sent a note to Secretary of State George P. Shultz protesting United States aid to the rebels, the Foreign Ministry said. Deputy Foreign Minister Nora Astorga summoned the American Ambassador, Anthony Quainton, to hear a charge that the attack was ''part of the plans of the Central Intelligence Agency,'' a Government statement said. **********The attack came shortly before members of President Reagan's commission on Central America met in San Jose, Costa Rica, with Alfonso Robelo Callejas, a leader of a Nicaraguan rebel group based in that country. Mr. Robelo, leader of the Revolutionary Democratic Alliance, is the former owner of the Oil and Tallow Company, which lost a tank of cooking oil in the Corinto attack. **********Before taking off from San Jose for El Salvador today, the head of the Reagan commission, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, told reporters he was not aware of the attack when he talked with Mr. Robelo. ''The only discussion with Mr. Robelo,'' he said, ''was about the political situation and about the possibilities, as he saw them, of elections and democratic evolution in the area.'' **********Mr. Robelo's guerrilla organization, which is distinct from the group that carried out Tuesday's attack, has taken responsibility for several military actions against Nicaragua, including the recent bombing by light planes of Managua's airport. **********Corinto, about 110 miles northwest of Managua, was apparently attacked by a rebel force in speedboats and small planes. Reports from local officials and civilians said the rebels fired on the oil tanks from speedboats after positioning them behind the South Korean ship. **********Daniel Ortega, coordinator of the three-man junta that runs the country, hinted on nationwide television that further rationing of already scarce fuel supplies could be expected. **********Corinto is Nicaragua's main port. Oil unloading facilities at Puerto Sandino, 30 miles west of the capital, were wrecked in a rebel attack Sept. 9. Benjamin Zeledon, on the Atlantic coast, is now the only oil unloading port available. Rebels on Sept. 8 destroyed 400,000 gallons of fuel there.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/world.main_headline: TWO DIE IN GUNFIGHT IN IRELAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/world.print_headline: TWO DIE IN GUNFIGHT IN IRELAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/world.body_text: **********Gunmen opened fire on police posts at two points near the border with the Irish republic today. Two officers were wounded and two attackers were killed, the police said. **********At a guard post in Dungannon, about 12 miles from the frontier, one policeman was wounded and two gunmen were killed. Two other attackers escaped. In Markethall, about 13 miles from the border, two gunmen opened fire on a policeman manning a checkpoint. The policeman was slightly wounded and the gunmen fled. **********The shootings occurred as Protestants gathered for the annual march by members and supporters of the militant Protestant Apprentice Boys of Derry. **********In 1969, the annual march by Protestants through Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second largest city, triggered three days of riots that marked the start of sectarian violence that has claimed at least 2,306 lives over the last 14 years. **********The police said Roman Catholic youths bombarded the police in Londonderry Friday with at least 60 gasoline bombs, injuring one officer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.main_headline: Salvador Rebels In Touch With Regime
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Salvador Rebels In Touch With Regime
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/world.body_text: **********Salvadoran rebel leaders got in touch with the Government's Peace Commission today, according to a member of the commission. The contact came two days after the United States special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, failed to meet with guerrilla leaders in Costa Rica. **********The member refused to give any details about the contact, which came from the Democratic Revolutionary Front, the political arm of the five guerrilla groups. It was the first time the leftist opposition had sought to deal directly with the commission. **********The head of the Peace Commission, Dr. Francisco Quinonez, said today that while El Salvador appreciated help from ''friendly countries'' such as the United States, the commission will conduct the final talks with rebel leaders about their possible participation in the country's presidential elections, which are tentatively scheduled for the end of this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/15/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; Mortgage Certificates Attract Pension Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The nation's largest-ever securities offering, $1.5 billion in mortgage participation certificates issued by the Los Angeles-based Financial Corporation of America, quickly sold out yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation and Bear, Stearns & Company. **********The sale was part of the corporation's program to exchange $5 billion of mortgages held by its subsidiary, the American Savings and Loan Association, for mortgage-backed securities issued by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation or the Federal National Mortgage Association. The savings and loan expects to sell another $5 billion of securities backed by new mortgages it originates during the next 15 months. **********Yesterday's offering consisted of 37 pools of conventional home mortgages that carried rates ranging from 6 1/4 percent and a price of 69 3/8 to 14 percent and a price of 102 1/8. Yields on the securities will depend on how fast they are prepaid, but would be about 13 1/4 percent assuming an average life of 12 years. **********Underwriters said the new financing was notable because it attracted more buying than normal from public and private pension funds, the largest category of institutional investors in the country. Analysts said an inflow of pension fund money into mortgage-backed securities would significantly increase the supply of funds to the housing market and help keep home mortgage rates lower than they would be otherwise. **********''This financing bodes well for the housing industry,'' said Irving M. Geszel, a partner at Bear, Stearns. **********William McCauley, a vice president at First Boston, said pension fund investors were attracted by the low coupon rate of the mortgage pools, ''which offer them a consistency of repayment that they can not count on with high-rate pools.'' The yield on low interest rate pools is more predictable because homeowners are less likely to prepay seasoned, low-rate mortgages. **********The certificates are guaranteed by the F.H.L.M.C. and are insured by private companies. Monthly payments of principal and interest by homeowners are passed through to holders of the certificates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Who Pays for Bankruptcies?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Who Pays for Bankruptcies?
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.body_text: **********DETERMINING what is in the consumer's interest often is not so easy as it seems. The bankruptcy laws are a good example. The Senate recently passed a bill that would make significant changes in the 1979 revision of Federal bankruptcy law, which was based on the premise that debtors should be enabled to have a ''fresh start'' by being relieved of all their debts. **********Since enactment of the 1979 revision, the rate of personal bankruptcies has soared. Before the change became effective, there had been 180,000 to 200,000 personal bankruptcies a year. Since then, the rate has more than doubled, to 450,000. **********Under the 1979 revision, an individual who files for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 is relieved of all unsecured debts, while under Chapter 13 he would be required to pay back at least a part of what he owes over a period of time. The key change in the bill recently passed by the Senate would give a judge the ability to force a debtor who filed for bankruptcy under Chapter 7 into Chapter 13. **********Emotions run high on the issue, and the facts are murky. Those who oppose the change, such as Representative Don Edwards, the California Democrat who was a designer of the 1979 bill, contend that the problem is not the bankruptcy law itself but profligate lending by banks and finance companies. ''They loaned like they were drunken sailors,'' Mr. Edwards said in a telephone interview yesterday. **********Mr. Edwards denied that the 1979 revision had anything to do with the subsequent surge in bankruptcies. He attributed it to the recession, soaring consumer credit and a Supreme Court ruling allowing lawyers to advertise. Many lawyers have been aggressively advertising for bankruptcy cases, which has increased public awareness of the possibility of seeking protection from the bankruptcy laws. **********Those who have been pressing hardest for a toughening of the bankruptcy laws - the lenders - acknowledge that most individuals seeking bankruptcy, even under Chapter 7, are justified in doing so.  But the lenders contend that a minority has abused the law and forced a sharp cutback in overall consumer lending, at least to people who cannot put up their homes as collateral. **********In addition, the lenders contend that they have had to increase the interest rates they charge on all consumer loans to offset the losses from consumer bankruptcies. **********''Most consumers, 75 percent, take bankruptcy for legitimate reasons - sickness, loss of job or actual overextension of credit,'' said F.M.W. Caspersen, chairman of the Beneficial Corporation. ''The remaining 25 percent have the ability, at least in part, to repay.  Our objection is to those who can pay and, in fact, don't.'' **********He added: ''We have effectively withdrawn from the ordinary unsecured lending market. In the last four years, we have dropped more than 30 percent of our customers.'' **********Last year, Beneficial lost $50 million as the result of personal bankruptcies, Mr. Caspersen said. He estimated that half that amount represented ''justified'' bankruptcies. To compensate for these losses, Beneficial increased the interest rates it charged on consumer loans by about a percentage point, he said. **********Most other consumer lenders have taken similar steps. Citicorp, one of nation's biggest lenders to consumers, reduced its consumer-loan loss rate to 0.93 percent last year from 1.33 percent in 1980. This was largely the result of a shift to loans secured by real estate, including mobile homes. **********A number of studies have been made of the effects of the 1979 revision of the bankruptcy law, each giving somewhat different results. According to a study by the Credit Research Center of Purdue University of 1,199 Chapter 7 bankruptcies, half were unable to pay anything, 20 percent could have repaid all they owed within a three-year period and the remaining 30 percent could have paid a portion of what they owed. This study was paid for by a group of lending institutions, and questions about its accuracy have been raised by supporters of the present law. **********A more recent study, conducted by Philip Shuchman of Rutgers University, indicated that the great majority of consumers who declared bankruptcy were not well off, despite a number of wellpublicized cases in which wealthy individuals, such as professional football players, have declared bankruptcy. **********The question that remains is which set of consumers should ultimately pay for bad consumer loans. Opponents of the Senate bill contend that it might be unconstitutional to force people to work off their debts. But someone will ultimately have to pay, and that someone will end up being a consumer. ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Leonard Silk is on a special assignment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/busin.print_headline: DPCC FAILS TO GET DR PEPPER METTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/busin.body_text: **********Dr Pepper said yesterday that it had turned down a request by the DPCC Acquisition Corporation, which has offered to buy Dr Pepper, to attend Dr Pepper's special board meeting today in Dallas. **********A Dr Pepper spokesman, Jim Ball, said it is standard company policy to limit board meetings to directors and their advisers. **********DPCC, which is owned by Castle & Cooke Inc., a Honolulu-based food products company, and other, undisclosed, investors, said its representatives would still be available in Dallas should Dr Pepper change its mind. **********The $670 million merger bid from DPCC was presented to Dr Pepper on Monday, the day after the soft-drink company had reached a $624 million merger agreement with Forstmann Little & Company, a private investment firm based in New York. **********The Forstmann Little bid, for $22 a share in cash plus assumption of $110 million in debt, was presented to Dr Pepper's directors on Nov. 17. The DPCC bid is for $24 a share plus assumption of the debt. Dr Pepper has 23.3 million shares outstanding. **********Dr Pepper said yesterday that it had been told that Forstmann Little had completed arrangements for financing the proposed acquisition, having signed a definitive loan agreement with a group of banks. **********Dr Pepper earned $14 million, or 60 cents a share, in the first nine months of the year, down from $16.5 million, or 79 cents a share, in the first three quarters of 1982. Its revenues totaled $423.5 million in the first nine months of this year, up from $392.4 million in the comparable period last year. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Dr Pepper shares closed at $21.75, up 12 1/2 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Federal banking regulators today invited bids for at least five Tennessee banks shaken in the collapse earlier this year of a state banking and finance empire headed by two brothers, Jake and C.H. Butcher Jr. **********Government officials who declined to be identified said the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, at a meeting here today with bankers and state regulators from Tennessee and neighboring states, provided potential buyers with bidding information on the five banks. **********Additional details of the bidding process are expected to be announced within the next few days.  According to regulators who asked to remain unnamed, four of the banks are controlled by C.H. Butcher. Two, the City and County Bank of Knox County, Mr. Butcher's lead bank, and City and County of Anderson County, the group's second largest, lost a combined $17.5 million in the first quarter. **********Mr. Butcher's 12 Tennessee banks combined lost $30.3 million in the quarter, state records show.  The regulators identified the fifth bank as the United America Bank of Chattanooga. It was controlled by Jake Butcher until shortly after his cornerstone holding, the United America Bank of Knoxville, was shut by Federal regulators in mid-February. **********Mr. Butcher, a politician and financier known for his personal flamboyance, has since sold all of his bank holdings or, in the case of U.A.B. Chattanooga, lost control to outside investors from Texas. **********His brother, C.H., however, still controls 23 banks in Tennessee and Kentucky through the C & C Interstate Financial Corporation.  Another of his holdings, the Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, a finance company, is in bankruptcy reorganization because of problems related to the failure of U.A.B. Knoxville. **********The collapse of U.A.B. Knoxville, the nation's fourth-largest commercial bank failure since the Depression, was felt throughout the region's tightly knit bank system. According to Tennessee regulators, at least six banks in the state remain in a seriously weakened condition because of their earlier ties to U.A.B. Knoxville, and others have been damaged to a lesser extent. **********The bank, the largest in eastern Tennessee, had estimated loan losses of $60 million and another $190 million in ''substandard'' loans outstanding when it was closed on Feb. 14. This compared with assets of $760 million and deposits of nearly $600 million. **********Under a deal worked out by the F.D.I.C., it was immediately taken over by the state's largest bank company, First Tennessee National.  Today's meeting was called after F.D.I.C. officials rejected a bid by Union Planners National Bank of Memphis to purchase five of C.H.  Butcher's banks, including the Knox and Anderson County units. **********F.D.I.C. officials said they did not consider the cash and securities offer, worth an estimated $35 million, adequate enough to provide new capital for the bank. **********W.C. Adams, Tennessee's State Banking Commissioner, said before the meeting that the talks would focus on problems that have arisen in the state's banking network since the collapse of U.A.B. Knoxville. **********Mr. Butcher was not invited to today's meeting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/busin.body_text: **********For the third consecutive week, analysts are reporting an unusually light debt calendar. Higher interest rates are keeping many corporations out of the bond market, and many municipalities have slowed their borrowing because of the elimination of bearer, or nonregistered, bonds, analysts said. **********The Treasury, however, will continue to borrow heavily, albeit no heavier than in recent weeks. Today, the Government is expected to borrow $6.2 billion in three-month bills and another $6.2 billion in six-month bills. Of the $12.4 billion total, about $11.8 billion will be used to retire maturing debt, the remainder being additions to the Government's debt. **********''There really is nothing unusual in these numbers that should upset the markets,'' said David Jones, a senior credit market analyst at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Government securities dealer.  ''It's just a continuation of the heavy borrowing we began to see in the July-to-September quarter last year.'' **********In active trading Friday, the three-month bill closed at 9.05 percent, down 0.11 percent. The six-month bill closed at 9.26 percent, down 0.06 percent. And the one-year bill closed at 9.33 percent, down 0.05 percent. **********Most corporations, however, continued to avoid the credit markets, discouraged by a recent swing up in borrowing rates and by uncertainty over future Federal Reserve policy. Salomon Brothers, the investment bankers, said that $121 million in new corporate issues are scheduled to come to market his week. This compares to $376 million last week and to $60 million two weeks ago. A normal week's worth of borrowing is considered more than $1 billion, Salomon says. **********''It's just not a market in which borrowers feel comfortable floating debt,'' says Steven Blitz, a financial economist at Salomon.  The calendar for municipal bonds will also remain light this week.  According to Salomon; roughly $958 million in new city and state issues will come to market. In April, by comparison, new municipal issues averaged nearly $2.5 billion weekly. **********Since July 1, municipalities must register the names of the owners of their bonds. Many municipalities said the bearer notes were easier and cheaper to issue since they required less paperwork. **********The following new fixed-income securites are scheduled this week: TAXABLE ONE DAY DURING WEEK **********Southdown Inc., $50 million of sinking fund debentures, due 1995, with 9 1/2 year average life, NR/Baa3/BBB. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/24/world.main_headline: South Africa Postpones Vote on Charter Changes
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; South Africa Postpones Vote on Charter Changes
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/24/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister P.W. Botha has postponed a referendum on his proposed constitutional changes, which would allow Asians and people of mixed race to be represented in a new Parliament alongside whites. **********He said the referendum, which had been scheduled for later this year, would not be held until there was a break in drought conditions in South Africa. Mr. Botha's action means that the referendum will probably not be held until next year, since what would normally be the rainy season is now almost over. **********Mr. Botha told Parliament on Thursday that he did not want to subject the country to the kind of energy drain that such a referendum would consume in the drought, which has been called one of the worst in this century. **********But there was speculation in political circles that Mr. Botha's announcement was actually prompted by his fear that the right-wing opponents of his National Party were making major inroads into his support in a series of by-elections scheduled for May 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/busin.body_text: **********The first issues of currency exchange warrants were sold to investors by Salomon Brothers International, on behalf of Phibro-Salomon Inc., the issuer. **********The warrants to buy or sell pounds sterling follow the introduction last month by various securities firms of options to buy or sell bonds of the United States and Canada. **********The offering included 100,000 call warrants, priced at $55 each, giving the holder the right to buy pounds sterling at a price of $1.52 a pound during the next year. Each warrant would cover $:1,000. **********Another 100,000 put warrants, priced at $46 each, give the holder the right to sell pounds sterling at a price of $1.46 a pound during the next year. **********In the case of the call warrants, the value of the pound would have to rise to $1.57 from the current level of about $1.47 for the holder of a warrant to break even. For put warrants, the value would have to fall to about $1.41.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/27/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********The headline on your Investing column of Nov. 6, ''Not Many Grandmas Buy New Cars,'' expresses a negative stereotype of older women in particular, of older people in general. The article itself does not require that headline. To me the headline reveals insensitivity to a group of human beings to which many of us will one day belong - older women. **********The article ends with the quotation, ''. . . how many 85-year-olds drive a car?'' While it may be true that not all 85-year-olds drive a car, it is also true that not all grandmas are 85 years old. **********I first became a grandmother nine years ago at the age of 52. I owned and drove a car then. I have purchased several cars since then. Today I have five grandchildren, I own and drive a car, and I expect to own and drive a car for many years to come. I cannot say whether I will still be driving a car when I am 85 years old but between now and then I will probably purchase four new cars. I do not consider myself unique. **********OWL (the Older Women's League) and the Gray Panthers are organizations concerned with negative stereotyping of older people in the media - OWL with the stereotyping of older women, the Gray Panthers with the stereotyping of older people in general. As a member of both organizations and simply as an older woman, an older human being, I urge you to become more sensitive to readers as persons. It is not necessary to write at the expense of any segment of our population. Each of us is an individual, not a stereotype. **********AMY GOLDSTEIN ADAMS Fresh Meadows, N.Y., Nov. 6 **********The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

Redfern, president and chief executive officer. **********Mr. Redfern noted in a statement over the weekend, ''The demand we foresee for cement and the capital-intensive nature of our industry will continue to require substantial debt and equity financing.
