https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.main_headline: Supermarkets General Appoints a New Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Supermarkets General Appoints a New Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/08/busin.body_text: **********Directors of the Supermarkets General Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest food chain, yesterday elected Leonard Lieberman chief executive officer, succeeding Herbert Brody. The 54-year-old Mr.  Lieberman has been president since 1982 and will also retain that post. **********The company said that the change was recommended by Mr. Brody, who is 68 and who remains vice chairman and chairman of the executive committee. Alex A. Aidekman, who is also 68, remains chairman. **********Supermarkets General, although a diversified retail company, has its major operations in the 121 Pathmark supermarkets in New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Delaware and Connecticut. Last year, the supermarkets yielded 84 percent of the company's total $30.3 million in earnings and 88 percent of its $3 billion in sales. The company's 34 Rickel Home Centers in New Jersey, New York and Pennsylvania accounted for 9 percent of profits and 6 percent of sales. The department store division, consisting of the Howland/Steinbach and Hochschild, Kohn department stores, had 7 percent of the company's profits and 6 percent of its sales. **********A lawyer who received his degree from Columbia Law School in 1953, Mr. Lieberman joined Supermarkets General in 1963 as vice president, general counsel and a director; he later occupied a variety of operating posts. He was chairman of the Pathmark division from 1977 through 1979, became chief administrative and financial officer and was named executive vice president in 1981 and president in 1982. **********He could not be reached for comment late yesterday. But in a February talk before securities analysts, he said that the Pathmark chain was concentrating on operating larger stores that could provide the consumer with ''great choice and easily perceived value for the food dollar.'' He said that the so-called super-supermarket ''offered the inherent flexibility to adapt to ever-changing consumer preferences as well as ever-changing economic conditions and challenges.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/world.body_text: **********Unemployment in West Germany increased in February to 2,535,836 people, or 10.4 percent of the labor force, the Government said today. **********It was the highest level since World War II. **********The announcement came three days before the national elections.  The recession has been a major campaign issue. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.print_headline: Market PlacePhillip H. Wiggins Junior Growth Stocks Viewed
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.body_text: **********MANY trackers of junior growth stocks expect the bearishness that marked much of that sector in 1983 to give way early next year to a renewal of investor enthusiasm. **********From August 1982, when they hit bottom, until the end of June 1983, emerging growth issues - usually companies doing less than $100 million in annual sales with a compounded earnings growth rate of at least 15 percent - far outperformed the general market. Since then, the group has been in what analysts call a severe corrective vein, perhaps aggravated recently by tax-loss selling. **********But in the opinion of John Westergaard, publephone lisher and editor for Equity Research Associates, an advisory service specializing in junior growth stocks, 1984 ought to be a banner year. **********''We think the economy is going to outstrip all expectations,'' Mr. Westergaard said the other day, ''and we believe that the force of that economy, particularly earnings and cash flow, will drive the averages to new highs, creating a very positive environment for most of the junior companies we deal with.'' **********Mr. Westergaard is naturally optimistic about the small high-technology companies he follows for Equity Research Associates, a division of Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. Since Oct. 1, 1976, he has recommended 105 stocks in his newsletter; 92 of them went up, and 13 went down. **********At this time, he has several favorites for 1984, including Digital Switch, Vishay Intertechnology, National Micronetics, Monolithic Memories and Eagle Computer. All are traded over the counter. **********Mr. Westergaard believes Digital Switch is positioned to take advantage of the A.T.&T. divestiture. It should benefit, according to Mr. Westergaard, if other common carriers expand their 3 percent market share of the long-distance telephone market to a projected 35 percent by 1990. **********Third-quarter results reached record levels at Digital Switch, with $35 million in revenues and 27 cents a share in earnings. Mr. Westergaard expects the company to earn $1.50 a share in 1984. The final bid for its stock yesterday was 35 1/4. **********Vishay Intertechnology is the world leader in strain gauges for materials stress analysis, with 70 percent of the market. It grew at a 25 percent annual rate before 1980, then overspent for what it thought would be a strong economy. **********''With the economy on the upswing, we would expect Vishay to resume its 25 percent growth rate over the next few years, leading to earnings of $1.70 a share in 1984 and $2.15 in fiscal 1985,'' Mr. Westergaard said. It closed at 18 3/4 yesterday. **********''National Micronetics seems poised to experience strong growth during calendar 1984,'' he said. ''Two-thirds of the company's sales are 5.25-inch Winchester disk-drive products, and it is no longer dependent on the I.B.M.-compatible drive market, which had been hurting National Micronetics' profitabilty during the last year.'' **********Mr. Westergaard believes the company will benefit from the sale of Winchester disk-drive original-equipment manufacturer heads, growing from sales of $26 million in the fiscal year ended June 30 to more than $50 million in the present fiscal year. Yesterday's close was 13 3/4. **********Monolithic Memories, which manufactures high- performance integrated circuits, reported record sales of $105 million and earnings of 60 cents a share for its fiscal year ended Oct. 2. Equity Research Associates is estimating 50 percent growth in revenues and earnings of $1.20 a share in the fiscal year 1984. Yesterday the stock ended at 27 1/2. **********Eagle Computer markets personal microcomputer systems. For the fiscal first quarter, ended June 30, the company announced sales of $14.3 million and earnings of 1 cent a share. **********Eagle's profit margins improved during the fourth quarter and are expected to increase with volume purchases from equipment manufacturers instead of through intermediaries. Eagle's management projects earnings of 35 cents a share for the fiscal year 1984. The stock was 8 3/4 yesterday. **********Another champion of emerging growth issues in 1984 is Eugene K. Collins, director of research at Laidlaw Adams & Peck Inc. Two he particularly likes are Vega and Comtech, also O-T-C stocks. **********Vega, a biotechnology company, is the leading supplier of instruments for peptide synthesis. The long-term outlook for peptide drugs - natural drugs used in treating a wide variety of human ailments - is promising, with major pharmaceutical houses now in the early stages of commercial production. Vega closed at 4 1/2 yesterday. **********Comtech is a supplier of satellite and troposcanner communications, microwave components and communications-compression equipment. In yesterday's trading, Comtech shares ended at 6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.main_headline: STOCK SPLITS - NOT ALWAYS A BONANZA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; STOCK SPLITS - NOT ALWAYS A BONANZA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.body_text: **********I n April, after one of the more spectacular run-ups of the bull market, Metromedia Inc. had become the subject of mounting interest among a peculiar breed of investor: those who try to anticipate stock splits. **********At the New Jersey-based broadcasting company, there was ample cause for good cheer. Metromedia stock, which traded around $150 a share in early 1982, had risen to a breathtaking $560. Thus, it had become the most expensive issue on the New York Stock Exchange. **********But at the same time, ''for most small investors, Metromedia was unbuyable,'' said Alan J. Gottesman of L.F. Rothschild. ''A stock split was as inevitable as a volcano melting rocks.'' **********So, on May 10, with its shares at $551, Metromedia followed the example of I.B.M., Superior Oil and other companies that had seen their stock rise to extrordinary heights. It announced a stock split of 10 new shares for every share held as of July 15, to be distributed as of Aug. 15. And in a separate move to share its good fortune, Metromedia raised its quarterly dividend to $1.90 from $1.75, or 19 cents a share after the split. **********Although it may be the outstanding example, Metromedia is one of more than 100 major corporations that have announced or completed stock splits in the last 10 months. Other examples include General Electric, Lockheed, Commodore International, and R.H. Macy. **********And while analysts maintain that stock splits are inevitable in any rising market, there remains much disagreement about when a stock should be split and whether investors can expect to make money by anticipating splits. Technically speaking, a stock split is nothing more than an accounting change in which the assets of a company are redistruted in a greater number of shares. **********''If the fundamental value of a company remains unchanged, it shouldn't matter if the stock is trading at $5 or $500,'' said Arthur E. Rockwell of Crowell, Weeden & Company of Los Angeles. But he added that there was ''almost always a difference between what should technically be true and what investors believe; and it's what the investor believes that counts.'' **********For both the shareholders of stocks that split and the companies that split them, there are often some measurable benefits. But analysts maintain that stock splits are often immersed in as much phychology as sound business judgment. **********In most cases, directors decide to split their stock ''to keep it trading in a range that does not discourage the small investor,'' said Robert Willard, a senior vice president of Prudential-Bache Securities. Mr. Willard regularly consults corporations on when and why they should split their shares. **********For example, he said, many individual investors would be more reluctant to buy shares trading at $80 a share than at $40, even if two of the lower-priced certificates represented an equal holding in the company. This attitude, he added, is often supported by small investors' tendency to buy stock in round lots of 100 shares. **********For companies, a broad base of ownership of their shares among individuals can be an important factor in discouraging takeover attempts. Moreover, such broad ownership tends to moderate the sharp downward swings in stock prices that occur when companies, suddenly faced with bad results, find their institutional shareholders rushing to sell off their holdings. Some analysts said that had Texas Instruments' stock been split prior to the company's announcement last month that it would lose $100 million the second quarter, the resulting drop in its price - by about one-third of its value -would not have been nearly as great. **********But Mr. Willard maintained that it was not always bad policy for companies to allow their shares to trade far higher than most other issues. ''Even though it limits some investors, a high-priced stock can still connote a blue-chip security,'' he said. **********THAT view, however, is not universally held. Exceptionally highpriced stock ''means management is on an ego trip,'' said Fred Anschel of Dean Witter Reynolds. And Samuel Hayes, a professor of finance at the Harvard Business School, said that companies with extraordinarily high-priced stock ''are thumbing their noses at the small investors.'' **********Generally, when companies split their stock, the most tangible benefit to shareholders comes with increased dividends. Often quarterly dividends are increased, as in the case of Metromedia. **********Many believe, however, that the mere announcement of a stock split tends to increase its trading price, regardless of what happens to the dividend. ''Some of it is instinct, some is psychology, but most people think it's easier for a stock to move from $10 to $20 than from $50 to $100,'' said Mr. Anschel. ''And they invest accordingly.'' **********But neither he, nor a half dozen other experts in the field who were asked about the subject, said they would recommend the purchase of shares simply because they expected a stock split. ''It is true that stocks tend to split when companies are doing well,'' said Anne Gregory, publisher of the Merrill Lynch Market Letter. ''If the fundamentals look good, the stock is attractive. But the stock split itself means little more than another piece of paper.'' **********If the splits announced recently have had any impact on the price of the stocks, it has been varied and impossible to measure.  Metromedia shares, for example, appear to have registered little benefit since the announced 10-for-1 split. Last week, the stock was trading at about 545 a share, down $15 from the day of the announcement. **********The Lockheed Corporation, another company that had been expected to announce a stock split, did so last Monday. The aerospace concern, whose shares were trading at $125.50 before the disclosure, said it would seek sharehold approval for a 3-for-1 split to be distributed in August. Its stock has since fallen in the wake of last week's market troubles and closed Friday at $123 a share. **********Meanwhile, examples of companies that may have benefited from splitting their stock can be found on a list prepared by Mrs.  Gregory. In January, her market letter listed 16 companies that it predicted would split their stock before the end of the year, So far, 12 of them have done so. Those on the list that have not include Economics Lab, Federal Express, Standard Motor and Subaru of America. **********The Standard Register Company, one of the companies on the Merrill Lynch list, announced its 3-for-1 stock split on Feb. 17 when its shares were trading at $73. Immediately after the announcement, the shares rose in value, and have continued to hold their advances. By June 2, the day before the new certificates were distributed, Standard Register traded at $101. **********Otto Stock, Standard Register's corporate secretary, said that it was ''impossible to know if the stock split, in itself, was at all responsible'' for the run-up in the stock price. Nonetheless, he added that the stock's performance ''has obviously been very good, and the split could not have hurt.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.main_headline: Gold Futures Advance; Silver Prices Also Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; Gold Futures Advance; Silver Prices Also Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.body_text: **********Gold futures prices advanced yesterday amid increasingly bullish short- and long-term market factors.  Dealiers attributed the gains partly to an easing of short-term interest rates, which caused those who had sold gold and silver short last Friday to buy out of their positions yesterday. **********As a result, the spot April gold futures on New York's Commodity Exchange rose $9.80 an ounce, to $431.50, with the most active delivery, the near June, up $9.60 at $436.80. Last week, by comparison, the spot month advanced $5.80 and the June contract climbed $5.20. **********On world bullion markets gold prices climbed almost $10 an ounce.  In Hong Kong gold rose $4.19, to $427.71 a troy ounce. Gold climbed to $430.00 in London, from $421.25 on Friday, and in Zurich it hit $427.50, up from $420.75 on Friday. **********In New York trading gold was bid at $430.50 at Republic National Bank, a gain of $9.50 from Friday.  Comex silver followed gold, with the spot futures rising 32.3 cents an ounce, to $11.308, and the active May contract up 32 cents at $11.36. Last week, spot silver futures gained 30.3 cents, and the May contract 29 cents. **********''More important than today's advance in gold is that the market now expects the supply of newly mined bullion to be tight for the rest of 1983,'' said Jeffrey A. Nichols, director of precious metals research at J. Aron & Company, a division of Goldman, Sachs & Company. As a major international bullion broker, J. Aron takes no market position in precious metals or other commodities. **********Basically, Mr. Nichols expects the global output of gold this year to rise less than a million ounces, to 40.7 million ounces.  Meanwhile, the world's jewelry makers and industrial users are expected to increase their consumption to 31.3 million ounces from 27.9 million in 1982, ''provided the worldwide economic situation remains sluggish for the rest of this year,'' he said. **********With demand from central banks, the International Monetary Fund and other global agencies expected to be unchanged at a million ounces this year, the net supply of newly mined bullion available to investors worldwide would be only 8.4 million ounces. **********Last year, private investors took 10.7 million ounces, much of it in Krugerrands and other bullion coins, as well as bars. Since Jan.  1, 1975, when Americans were again able to own gold, the global stock of newly mined bullion available to private investors ranged from 22.3 million ounces in 1979 to the 8.4 million projected for this year. **********''If the global demand from private investors exceeds 8.4 million ounces this year, then they will have to, in effect, bid the metal away from industrial users and each other,'' he said. **********Commenting further on J. Aron's latest survey of the gold market, Mr. Nichols said that bullion prices should also be bolstered by a continued easing of interest rates, explaining: **********''High interest rates reduce gold's attractiveness as an investment and also inhibits industrial users from holding much in the way of inventories and, indeed, reduces consumer demand for jewelry and other items.'' **********The Chicago Board of Trade is also confident that gold will be attractive to investors. Today, the nation's biggest commodity market will start trading futures in one-kilogram (32.15 troy ounces) gold bars. The standard gold futures contract traded on the Comex and other domestic exchanges consists of 100 ounces.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/busin.main_headline: Ford and Chrysler Show Higher Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Ford and Chrysler Show Higher Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/07/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation reported today that new car sales rose in the March 21-31 period, by 3.6 percent and 9 percent, respectively. They reported their sales a day after the General Motors Corporation, which had a 5 percent decline. For the Big Three as a group, sales fell 1 percent in the reporting period. **********Sales are computed on a daily selling-rate basis, with 10 selling days in the period this year and 9 last year.  For the month of March, sales for the three were up 2.8 percent while sales industrywide, including the American Motors Corporation and Volkswagen of America, were up 3.8 percent. **********Sales of imported cars, meanwhile, rose 5.6 percent from last March, to an estimated 210,00 units, giving the imports a 26 percent share of the domestic market for the month. In February the imports had a 29.7 percent share of the market; they had 25.6 percent a year ago. 'A Disappointment' **********For the month, the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was set at 6.3 million domestic cars and 2.2 million imports. **********Harvey E. Heinbach, an automotive analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., said that with sales ''stuck around the 6 million rate, where we were at the beginning of the year,'' the most recent reports were ''a disappointment, relative to what the manufacturers and outside observers have been looking for. **********''We still think the economy will improve throughout the year,'' he continued, ''and we might see renewed growth in auto sales in the second half, but we still could end up with a full year of sales just not as good as we had expected.'' Strong Gains for A.M.C. **********American Motors again showed a huge gain in sales in the late-March period, up 141.1 percent on sales of 9,035, or 904 daily this year, compared with 3,378, or 375 a day, last year. A.M.C. today announced a new retail financing program on its Renault products. The Renault Alliance is primarily responsible for the company's recent strong sales. The company is offering 9.9 percent or 11.9 percent financing, depending on the duration of the loan, and the company is continuing dealer incentive programs on its other products. The programs expire at the end of May. **********Chrysler's 9 percent increase amounted to 38,671 deliveries, or 3,867 daily this year, against 31,935, or 3,548 daily, last year.  Ford's 3.6 percent gain came with 63,123 deliveries, or 6,312 units sold daily, this year, against 54,824 deliveries, or 6,092 daily, last year. **********Volkswagen's sales continued down, declining 36.6 percent on sales of 3,226, or 321 a day, compared with 4,552, or 506 daily, last year.  Sales Up in First Quarter **********In the month, with 27 selling days this year and last, G.M. sales of 351,166 were up five-tenths of 1 percent; Ford sales of 139,779 were up 3.4 percent; Chrysler sales of 82,150 rose 13.1 percent; A.M.C. sales of 18,285 jumped 120.9 percent, and VW was down 36.7 percent, selling 6,325 new cars. Total domestic new car sales were 597,705, up 3.8 percent. **********The first quarter closed with domestic sales up 3.7 percent on total sales of 1,451,824, somewhat less than analysts had predicted at the start of the year. **********The manufacturers, however, were optimistic in their recent reports. Philip E. Benton Jr., Ford's vice president for sales, said in a prepared statement, ''First-quarter industry sales aren't setting records, but they're clearly ahead of a year ago this time and they're every bit as strong as we had expected.'' **********In the Jan.1-March 31 period General Motors, with a 59.8 percent share of the domestic market, sold 867,196 cars, up 2.2 percent.  Ford sold 333,889 cars in the quarter, up three-tenths of 1 percent for a 23 percent market share. Chrysler sales of 186,289 were up 7.4 percent, giving Chrysler 12.8 percent of the market. A.M.C., with a market share of 3.2 percent, sold 47,045 new cars, up 117.3 percent in the year-to-date period, while Volkswagen dropped 21.7 percent on sales of 17,405, giving VW a market share of 1.2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.body_text: **********The Chrysler Corporation is considering expanding its current four-cylinder gasoline engine and also building a V-6 engine to keep up with consumer demand for performance vehicles, an industry report said. **********Metalworking News, a trade journal, said an expansion of Chrysler's current 2.2-liter, four-cylinder engine made in Trenton, Mich., would allow the engine to displace about 2.5 liters. The larger engine could be made at Trenton, the report said. The V-6, probably to be made at a Detroit engine facility, would displace about 3.9 liters, the periodical said. The Detroit plant now makes 5.2-liter V-8's. Chrysler officials could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/busin.body_text: **********Dome Petroleum Ltd. is continuing to prepare its own financial restructuring plan that will likely involve a large share issue, according to banking sources. **********A foreign banking source said Dome's newly appointed chairman, Howard MacDonald, was at a meeting recently in New York with some of Dome's foreign lenders to present an update on a new refinancing plan. The banking source said Dome's plan would involve the sale of more than $500 million (Canadian) in shares to the public. Dome, with debts of some $6 billion, has been receiving regular extensions on certain debt payments while negotiations with its bankers continue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/18/world.body_text: **********A leading Soviet expert said today that any American compromise proposal for deployment of a reduced number of United States medium-range missiles in Western Europe would be a ''propaganda trick'' and would be rejected. **********The warning, in a Pravda article by Georgi A. Arbatov, the Soviet Union's senior expert on the United States, struck a pessimistic tone and said failure to ''make appreciable progress'' on arms this year would make a new round of the arms race unstoppable. **********He said that the present balance of medium-range nuclear forces in Europe was one favoring the United States and its allies, which he said did not need the 572 new American missiles the Atlantic alliance plans to deploy starting later this year. Mr. Arbatov said that, if the Soviet Union were to insist on equality, it would have to deploy missiles near border of the United States. Response to Orlando Speech **********Mr. Arbatov said ''American leaders tell lies'' when they assure the public that the deployment of the United States missiles will induce the Soviet Union to conclude arms-control agreements. He said the truth was that pressures of that kind would only force the Russians into ''developing new missiles of our own,'' however reluctantly. **********The article was a response to President Reagan's speech in Orlando, Fla., describing Moscow as ''the focus of evil in the modern world.'' Although Mr. Reagan told his audience of Evangelical church leaders that he would do all he could to persuade the Russians of his desire for arms reduction, he adopted an anti-Soviet tone echoing an earlier phase of his Administration. **********Mr. Arbatov said Mr. Reagan was ''ignoring all the rules of propriety'' in international relations by condemning Soviet leaders as men who reserved the right to break promises in the pursuit of their Communist goals.'' 'Outright Medievalism **********Referring to the Orlando speech, Mr. Arbatov said that ''frenzied calls are being made for crusades that smack of not just the 'cold war,' but of outright medievalism. And all this is covered up with hypocritical talk about faith and God, about morality, eternal good and eternal evil.'' **********Some Western diplomats saw the Arbatov article as marking a toughening of Soviet attitudes, pulling back from the positive tone struck by Yuri V. Andropov after becoming the Soviet leader four months ago. He then spoke of a possible meeting with Mr. Reagan and appealed to the United States to restore detente and to avoid making arms a test of the two political systems. **********Mr. Arbatov said that, with Mr. Reagan's popularity dropping in the opinion polls, ''the stench of failure hangs over the White House.'' He said that the Reagan team was characterized by provincialism and outright ignorance, adding that some specialists advising the Administration on military policy held such extreme views that they had ''been found to be in need of medical help.'' 'Sobering Up' Is Now Doubted **********Mr. Arbatov said there had been predictions in the West that the Reagan Administration would be forced to ''sober up'' by pressures from the United States' allies, by Congressional opposition to military spending and by the approach of the 1984 election. **********He expressed doubt that the United States would return to ''common sense'' after having deserted it for so long, but he pledged that, if genuine changes did come, the Soviet Union would ''notice them in time'' and ''be a reliable partner in honest talks.'' **********The sort of compromise proposals on the European missile issue being talked of in Washington do not constitute such a change, Mr.  Arbatov said. He said that, from what was known, the so-called intermediate solution being prepared '''will again be nothing more than a propaganda trick,'' since its effect would still be to justify the new missile deployments in Western Europe. **********''Washington will never succeed in persuading the Soviet Union to 'bless' such attempts, to affix its signature to the policy of the arms race and of sharpening tension,'' Mr. Arbatov said. ''If such a course of events proves unavoidable, let its real culprits bear the responsibility for this.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/busin.body_text: **********The United States's historic trade surplus with Communist countries has virtually disappeared, according to a new report from the United States International Trade Commission. **********For the spring quarter, April through June, the American surplus with 13 Communist countries was down to $115 million. **********For the first half of the year it was almost $2 billion less than in the first half of 1982. **********At the same time American shipments to the Soviet Union, China and other Communist countries were declining, United States imports from those countries rose 4 percent in the winter quarter and 10 percent in the spring. **********In United States trade with the world as a whole, the deficit widened to $7.2 billion for the month of August alone. Trade with the Communist countries is only a small part of the total. **********Much of the decline in the surplus with the Communist countries was attributed to Soviet cuts in purchases of American grain and soybeans. **********It was also significant that China stopped buying soybeans, almost stopped buying American cotton and man-made fiber, and sharply cut buying of wheat - all in retaliation for American limits on purchases of Chinese cloth and clothes. This spring marked the first quarterly United States deficit in trade with China since 1977.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.main_headline: CHASE AND IRAN IN ACCORD ON CLAIMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.print_headline: CHASE AND IRAN IN ACCORD ON CLAIMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had settled its disputed accounts with Iran that stemmed from the hostage crisis of three and a half years ago. **********Chase said it had received $92 million from Iran in settlement of loans that had been in dispute since November 1979, when Islamic militants took 52 Americans hostage in Teheran. **********The New York bank in turn paid $121 million to Iran's central bank, Bank Markazi, to settle Iran's claims against Chase for interest on blocked Iranian accounts. **********As a result of the hostage crisis, precipitated when the Shah of Iran was admitted to the United States for medical treatment, President Carter froze Iranian deposits held by American banks, and Iran refused to repay loans outstanding to the banks. David Rockefeller, Chase's chief executive at the time of the abduction of the hostages, had been friendly with the Shah and influential in his admittance to the United States. **********The hostages were released Jan. 20, 1981, the day President Reagan was inaugurated.  Chase was the 14th of 44 American banks to settle claims with Iran. The largest settlement so far was by Citicorp's Citibank unit, which received $125 million from Iran and paid out $132 million. The biggest claims involve the Bank of America, which has not yet settled and which accounted for $2.4 billion of the nearly $7.9 billion in Iranian deposits held by the American banks. The Bank of America accounts for $91 million of the $130 million in interest payments originally under dispute. **********Since Chase had set aside funds to cover a settlement with Iran, the bank said, the effect of the agreement will add $11 million to second-quarter net income. The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the bank's parent company, has not yet reported results for the quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.body_text: **********When Monford A. Orloff, chief executive officer of the Evans Products Company, learned that Victor Posner had begun to purchase a sizable number of shares in his company, his first thought was to resist a takeover. **********But then he found there was no ready means of blocking Mr. Posner, and decided to give the Miami financier a free rein in pursuing the company, which lost $65 million on sales of $1.2 billion in 1982. **********Now, two years later, Mr. Posner owns 43 percent of the Evans stock, and Mr. Orloff is still in charge of the company, which runs a major building materials retail chain and produces truck trailers and rail cars. Mr. Posner, named chairman of the board last April, appears content for now to leave the task of restructuring Evans to its current management. **********''We are confident that the existing management can turn this company around,'' said Steven Posner, Mr. Posner's 40-year-old son and the vice chairman of the Evans board. **********Merger With Sharon Dropped **********Originally, Mr. Posner wanted to merge Evans, which lost $15 million in the first quarter this year, with his Sharon Steel Company. But when the 22 major lenders to Evans rejected the deal last spring, he instead sought a majority representation on the Evans board. **********Since Mr. Posner joined the board, the company, after changing its mind several times, has reaffirmed its original intention to raise cash through the sale of its 340-store retail division, which accounted for $790 million of the company's total sales and $56 million in operating profits last year. The division, which operates stores under the names of ''Grossman's,'' ''Lindsley'' and ''Moore's,'' posted revenue of $155 million in the first three months of 1983, up 12 percent from the first quarter last year. **********Last September, Evans had put its most profitable division on the block, hoping to use the proceeds from the sale to pare its long-term debt of nearly $500 million. Unable to find a buyer willing to meet its stiff price, however, the company has now decided to spin off the retail group as a publicly held company. Analysts Favor Retail Plans **********Evans intends to retain 20 percent ownership of the newly formed retail concern, which will be called Grossman's Inc. The company plans to file its offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission later this month. **********The move must still be approved by Evans's lenders, but analysts say their approval is likely.  ''This could create a company with a market value of over $500 million,'' said Steven Albert, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody in New York, who last week recommended buying Evans stock. ''In one shot, Evans would double the book value of the retail division and get enough cash to almost wipe out its debt.'' **********Nonetheless, Mr. Albert and other analysts agree that Evans is certainly headed for another year in the red. They also agree, however, that the company's prospects, which were dismal last fall, have lately brightened. **********''Admittedly, the jury is still out,'' said Jeffrey Grayson, president of Capital Consultants, a Portland investment firm. ''But Evans is structured to do well in a recovery.'' **********Even with a lift from the recovery in housing, however, Evans may need to sell some of its money-losing operations. The company, which spent $85.3 million last year servicing its debt, must cut $100 million from the principal it owes lenders by March of next year. **********''Evans needs to go through a major reorientation,'' said Dr.  Abraham Zaleznik, a professor at the Harvard Business School, who just left the Evans board to make way for a Posner associate. ''The company has to decide what businesses it wants to remain in.'' Custom Home Unit Terminated **********Evans has already discontinued what was once a major operation.  Last December, the company terminated its custom homes division, which as recently as 1981 was the eighth-largest seller of new single-family homes in the nation. Last year alone, the division lost $31.9 million. **********The main problem with the division is that it lost badly on the construction and long-term loans it made to buyers of the precut homes. ''We lost money on the financing,'' Mr. Christopherson said, ''because we misjudged interest rates.'' **********Even after realizing that mortgage rates were soaring, however, Evans was unable to put a cap on its home-loan portfolio, which increased from $108 million in 1978 to $290 million by the end of 1981. **********''I don't understand how they let it go that far,'' said David Wilson, an analyst with Shearson/American Express in New York.  ''After the 1974-75 recession, they said they would never warehouse mortgages again. But they did.'' **********''It was a Catch-22 situation,'' recalled George Porter, a former Evans comptroller now with Nike Inc. ''To sell the homes, you had to offer attractive financing.'' Greater Emphasis on Leasing **********With the homes operation gone, Mr. Orloff has said Evans plans to concentrate its resources on such profitable areas as the retailing of building materials and the manufacturing and leasing of rail cars and truck trailers. **********Although the rail car business is worse off now than in more than four decades - Evans's rail car shipments declined 60 percent in 1982 - this approach has been approved by Mr. Posner. He has told Mr. Orloff that he favors a continuation of the unusual combination of retail and rail cars because it allows Evans to reduce its tax liability through the sale of investment tax credits. **********With the outlook for rail cars gloomy, however, some analysts doubt that Mr. Posner will have the patience to rebuild Evans. They expect him to seek to recoup his more than $100 million investment in the company by breaking it up. **********''It's not inconceivable,'' said Mr. Albert of Kidder, Peabody, ''that the spinning off of the retail division could be the beginning of a wholesale liquidation of the company.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/10/busin.main_headline: Mobil Official to Head Alternative Energy Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/10/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Mobil Official to Head Alternative Energy Unit
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The Mobil Corporation yesterday announced the formation of an alternative energy division and the appointment of Jerome F.  Trautschold Jr. to be president of it. **********The division, which does not represent a new commitment to alternative energy, will combine three previous Mobil units: uranium and minerals; mining and coal, and synthetic fuels. **********''The formation of the synfuels division was a combination of planning and management, and that's how I got into it,'' Mr.  Trautschold said. **********Mr. Trautschold, 45, had been general manager of the synthetic fuels division. In his new position, he will report to Richard F.  Tucker, president of Mobil Diversified Businesses, which is responsible for Mobil's business activities outside of oil and gas. **********Mobil, Mr. Trautschold said, has some 4 billion tons of coal reserves, 34 million pounds of uranium reserves and 1.2 billion tons of recoverable shale oil. The company is developing a shale oil project in Colorado and has an operating open-pit coal mine, Caballo Rojo, in Wyoming. **********''In the scheme of an oil company, it's not a gigantic operation,'' he said, adding that 550 people were involved in the new division.  ''Everybody has scaled back,'' Mr. Trautschold said of the development of alternative energy. ''Our synthetic fuels project is progressing, albeit slowly. We continue to remain excited about the long-term prospects and feel that synfuels are critical for the longer term.'' **********Mr. Trautschold, a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and the University of Chicago's business school, joined Mobil in 1965 as a planning analyst. Before joining the synthetic fuels division, he served as general manager of Mobil's Caribbean and Benelux operations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/busin.print_headline: HUGHES TOOL FALLS 83.&%; DIGITAL ALSO OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/busin.body_text: **********The Hughes Tool Company reported yesterday that the sharp drop in domestic oil drilling caused earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 to plunge 83.7 percent and sales to decline by 29.4 percent. **********Hughes, the world's largest manufacturer of drill bits for oil wells, said that net income in the latest three months fell to $11.8 million, or 21 cents a share, from $72.6 million, or $1.31 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales dropped to $334.4 million, from $473.6 million. **********For the full year, the Houston-based company said that net income slid 42.2. percent, to $147.6 million, or $2.65 a share, from $255.2 million, or $4.60 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 29.4 percent, to $334.4 million, from $473.6 million. **********James R. Lesch, chairman and chief executive of Hughes Tool, said that the gross profit margin rate for the year was 32.2 percent, compared with 38.3 percent in 1981, because of the steepest one-year drop ever recorded in domestic drilling activity. **********''While our sales and and margins in the drilling and services markets were severely impacted, we were able to improve sales and maintain margins in the those markets related to production tools,'' Mr. Lesch said. ''Despite the decline in U.S. drilling activity, the company had its second-best year ever, in terms of sales and income.'' **********Hughes Tool said recently that the decline in drilling last year had forced it to impose sharp cost-cutting measures. From January to November 1982, the company reduced its work force by about 15 percent, to 17,000. **********''Margins will remain under pressure in 1983,'' according to a recent report on Hughes Tool in The Value Line Investment Survey.  ''Despite the projected climb in U.S drilling activity, average drilling activity will still likely be 15 percent below 1982's pace.'' The report added that a tremendous overcapacity in such areas as drilling fluids and pumping services would work against a ''profit revival'' for Hughes this year. Digital Equipment **********The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that net income in its fiscal second quarter of 1983, ended Jan. 1, fell 38.4 percent, to $61 million, or $1.08 a share, from $99.1 million, or $1.79 a share, in the 1982 quarter. Operating revenue advanced 3.5 percent, to $1.02 billion, from $965.8 million. **********Alfred M. Bertocchi, vice president, finance and administration, said that the data-processing equipment maker's sales were hurt by depressed capital-equipment markets both in the United States and abroad. He added, however, that the company, based in Maynard, Mass., was ''encouraged by a strong improvement in customer demand during the quarter'' domestically and internationally. Burlington Northern **********Burlington Northern Inc., operator of the nation's largest railroad system, said that earnings in the fourth quarter edged up 2.9 percent, to $81.5 million, or $2.13 a share, from $79.2 million, or $2.06 a share, in the last quarter of 1981. Revenue slipped 2.7 percent, to $1.10 billion, from $1.13 billion. **********For the full year, the Seattle-based concern said that net income rose 4.3 percent, to $283.8 million, or $7.39 a share, from $272.2 million, or $7.02 a share, in 1981. Revenue was off 7.1 percent, to $4.20 billion, from $4.52 billion. **********Burlington said that its oil and gas and its coal and minerals operations showed an operating loss in the latest three months, but that its operating income from forest-products management exceeded 1981's for both the latest quarter and the full year. Crown Zellerbach **********The Crown Zellerbach Corporation announced that it had a loss of $146.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1982 contrasted to earnings of $29.2 million, or $1.01 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981.  Sales dropped 7.2 percent, to $713.8 million, from $769 million. **********For the full fiscal year, the company reported a loss of $112 million, primarily as a result of unusual charges related to selling Crown Zellerbach Canada Ltd. and restructuring its domestic operations. In 1981, Crown Zellerbach had earnings of $75.3 million, or $2.47 a share. Sales in 1982 fell 6.3 percent, to $2.95 billion, from $3.15 billion. Singer **********The Singer Company, citing the impact of the worldwide recession and the impact of the major devaluations of the Mexican peso, reported a loss of $3.2 million, contrasted to earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 of $3 million, or 11 cents a share. Sales dropped 4.5 percent, to $621.7 million, from $651.2 million. **********For the full year, the Stamford, Conn., company said that it had a loss of $2.9 million, contrasted to earnings of $33.4 million, or $1.93 a share, in 1981. Sales dropped 7 percent, to $2.52 billion, frm $2.71 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/24/world.main_headline: MOSCOW REPORTS RIGHTING A CASE OF INJUSTICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/24/world.print_headline: MOSCOW REPORTS RIGHTING A CASE OF INJUSTICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/24/world.body_text: **********Yuri V. Andropov's drive to root out official malfeasance gained a new hero today when the Minister of the Interior offered what amounted to a public apology to a 29-year-old merchant marine mechanic who had been the victim of a five-year vendetta by the police. **********The minister, Col. Gen. Vitaly V. Fedorchuk, who is a former head of the state security agency, published a letter on the front page of Literaturnaya Gazeta conceding that the prosecution of the seaman, Nikolai Rozovaikin, had been ''absolutely unfounded.'' Literaturnaya Gazeta is a weekly newspaper often used to reveal wrongdoing that the authorities want corrected. **********In the latest case, Mr. Rozovaikin, a graduate of a merchant marine school in Odessa, set out 10 years ago to find out how several thousand rubles belonging to students had disappeared. His efforts brought him 20 months in jail, dismissal from the party, and three years of work as a sweeper on the docks. **********Friends' pleas finally caught the attention of someone at Central Committee headquarters, and an inquiry began. Today, General Fedorchuk listed half a dozen policemen and lawyers who had been reprimanded or otherwise disciplined, and he described the outcome as a harbinger of what the public could expect from Mr. Andropov's drive ''to strengthen socialist legality.'' **********Mr. Rozovaikin was said to have regained his party membership, work as a shipboard mechanic and admission to the seamen's academy. The inquiry into the missing money was said to have been reopened. **********Some Russians may regard the case as something of an exception that proves the rule. Literaturnaya Gazeta acknowledged how heavily the odds counted against a person seeking redress, even at a time when Mr. Andropov has asked people to come forward with complaints about wrongdoing. **********Speaking of Mr. Rozovaikin, the paper said: ''He generated a wave, and the storm nearly destroyed him.'' His troubles began in 1973, when he graduated with honors from the merchant marine school. He led a group of students to the prosecutor's office to demand an investigation into the disappearance of money earned in summer jobs after an inquiry at school had dragged on for months. **********When he returned to Odessa after a period at sea, he found that several instructors sympathetic to the original inquiry had been transferred or retired. **********Fresh attempts to revive the inquiry led to what the newspaper described as a smear campaign based on the fact that Mr. Rozovaikin had recently been divorced and on his subsequent dismissal from the academy. He was also dismissed from a paid job as an organizer at the Young Communist League. **********When he traveled to Moscow to seek redress, he was arrested by the police after the Odessa police had asked for his return as a ''dangerous criminal.'' **********For 20 months, he was in custody awaiting trial on charges of ''parasitism'' and ''malicious hooliganism.'' The case was based on an incident in which housing inspectors investigating a complaint against newighbors of the Rozovaikins were said to have been abused by Mr. Rozovaikin and physically attacked by his brother, Viktor. **********''Whoever concocted this indictment knew perfectly well that Viktor Rozovaikin had been paralyzed since early childhood, was helplessly incapacitated and physically incapable of attacking anyone,'' the newspaper commented. **********After a six-day trial, the brothers were finally acquitted.  Nikolai Rozovaikin was working as a night sweeper on the docks when the Party Control Commission in Moscow, a watchdog body, took up the case. It finally acted against the policemen, ordering the reprimands, transfers and demotions that were announced today. **********Referring to the Odessa police, General Fedorchuk, the Interior Minister, said, ''Their inquiry was conducted in a superficial manner and on a low professional level that produced gross violations of socialist legality.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/world.main_headline: ISRAEL AND LEBANON SIGN AGREEMENT AT 2 CEREMONIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/world.print_headline: ISRAEL AND LEBANON SIGN AGREEMENT AT 2 CEREMONIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/world.body_text: **********Israel and Lebanon signed a security agreement today that is intended to lead to the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and continuing Israeli involvement in policing the country's southern region. **********The agreement came nearly a year after Israel invaded Lebanon on June 6, 1982, with the stated goals of helping to install a Government more acceptable to the Israelis, diminishing Syrian influence in Lebanon and ousting guerrillas of the Palestine Liberation Organization from their military bases and political headquarters. **********In the hope of consolidating these gains, Israel has made its troop withdrawal and the carrying out of the rest of the agreement contingent upon the withdrawal of P.L.O. and Syrian forces from the north and east of Lebanon. The return of all Israelis held as prisoners of war and an accounting of Israelis missing in action are also prerequisites for an Israeli pullout. **********The agreement will be technically completed upon the exchange of instruments of ratification, a formality said to involve another approval by Israel's Cabinet and Lebanon's Parliament. Officials expect this to take place within a week. **********But no aspect of the accord is to go into effect until the Israeli withdrawal. Successful but Fragile **********The agreement, which the United States endorsed as a witness, was a step less than a full peace treaty. But it was the second Israeli success in recent years in concluding a formal agreement on peaceful relations with an Arab neighbor, lending it a symbolic weight much like the Israeli-Egyptian Camp David accords of 1978. **********The signing, at consecutive ceremonies in Lebanon and Israel, took place in a spirit of fragile accord, however, with no certainty that the volatile situation of Lebanon would let the pact be fulfilled.  The choice of the sites for the ceremonies and the cautious remarks of the heads of the delegations testified to the potential for ultimate failure. **********Syria has vehemently denounced the accord and has pledged to block it, although Western and Middle Eastern diplomats see some chance of a Syrian pullout if Damascus obtains a defense treaty with Lebanon, security arrangements at least as extensive as Israel's and generous financial grants from Saudi Arabia. **********In the agreement and its supplements, Israel and Lebanon pledge ''to live in peace with each other,'' ''declare the termination of the state of war between them,'' define the border as inviolable, require each country to prevent the use of its territory by armed bands for attacks on the other and bar hostile propaganda against each other. The 2 Ceremonies **********The first signing ceremony today was at Khalde, a seaside town just south of Beirut where Syrian and Israeli forces fought a tank battle during the Israeli drive to Beirut last summer. Then the delegations flew by helicopter to Qiryat Shemona, the Israeli border town that had lived for years under sporadic rocket and artillery attacks from P.L.O. bases in southern Lebanon. **********The agreement was signed in four languages - English, French, Hebrew and Arabic - by the men who had represented their countries in the five months of negotiations: Antoine Fattal, a retired Lebanese diplomat who was once Acting Director of the Foreign Ministry, and David Kimche, Director General of Israel's Foreign Ministry. Morris Draper, an American special envoy who participated in all the negotiations, signed as a witness. **********The United States is reportedly committed to giving Israel a memorandum, which will be kept secret at Lebanese insistence, pledging American efforts to have the agreement carried out and expressing American understanding of Israel's intention to remain in Lebanon pending a Syrian pullout. **********In brief remarks, all three representatives took note of the uncertain future and portrayed the agreement as but a first step.  Mr. Draper praised the meshing of Lebanese and Israeli objectives, saying, ''They are crossing the threshold of a more satisfactory and sensible relationship.'' He acknowledged ''the obstacles ahead'' and pledged American help in overcoming them. Sacrifices on Both Sides **********''Both countries have been victimized,'' Mr. Draper declared.  ''Their peoples over the years have made enormous sacrifices, and not only in blood and property. There is no one here among either the Lebanese or the Israeli delegations who has not somehow been touched by past tragedies.'' **********Mr. Fattal also said Israel and Lebanon had an obligation to tackle the obstacles still on the horizon. Lebanon was not abandoning the Arab world, he asserted, but was taking ''a step toward a just and lasting peace,'' a phrase, he noted, that appeared in the May 1974 disengagement agreement between Syria and Israel. **********Mr. Kimche made an explicit call on Syria to withdraw. ''I know that the signatures that we have affixed on the agreement are just the beginning of a new chapter in our histories,'' he said, ''that many obstacles still stand in our paths and that there are many who would wish to render the agreement we are signing meaningless. **********''I would like to say to all of those who castigate the agreements and who see peace as a betrayal of their cause, I would like to say to them that you cannot go against the will of the people. And the people of Lebanon, who have proven their strength of determination by maintaining their independent character from the time of the Phoenicians, these people of Lebanon are in favor of this agreement just as our own people are.'' Terms of Accord **********The accord establishes a security region in southern Lebanon running 20 to 37 miles north of Israel's northern border. It is to be patrolled by a maximum of eight Lebanese-Israeli teams and two Lebanese Army brigades maintaining direct communications with Israeli Army officers. Two headquarters are to be staffed by Lebanese commanders and Israeli liaison officers. Lebanese military deployment in the south is to be restricted in numbers of troops and types of weapons. **********A Joint Liaison Committee, including the United States as a participant, is to oversee carrying the agreement out. In that body, a Security Arrangements Committee is to deal with military matters. **********Although the agreement does not establish diplomatic relations, it says each country may, if it wishes, set up a liaison office in the other, a device Israel sees as creating the embryo of an embassy. **********If the agreement leads to an Israeli troop withdrawal, negotiations are to begin within six months after the pullout on normalizing the movement of goods and people across the Israeli-Lebanese frontier.  The agreement says nothing about the interim, but Israeli officials are confident the border can remain relatively open, as it is now, at least to commerce. Sharon's Role in Accord **********Much of the groundwork on the agreement was done last fall by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, the chief architect of the war, who met secretly with a still unidentified confidant of President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon and drew up a document outlining an accord. Mr.  Sharon then publicized the document, damaging Israeli-Lebanese trust and, in the opinion of Israeli and American officials, setting back the negotiations. **********The final agreement represents some compromise of Mr. Sharon's demands, and he has denounced it as inadequate. Still, it contains many elements of the original Israeli proposal. **********The former Defense Minister demanded limits on Lebanese weapons in the south; the restrictions, scaled down slightly, are in the accord.  Mr. Sharon wanted five outposts in southern Lebanon manned by a total of 750 Israeli soldiers and intelligence agents who would have the right to enter houses and detain civilians in search of P.L.O.  guerrillas. The idea was rejected by Lebanon and finally abandoned by Israel, but joint patrols under Lebanese command were approved. Issue of Major Haddad **********In addition, Israel wanted its longtime client and ally, Maj. Saad Haddad, as the commander of a southern Lebanese Army brigade that would patrol a security zone north of the Israeli border. Major Haddad, who left the Lebanese Army during the 1975-76 civil war to set up his own militia with Israeli arms and training, is not mentioned in the agreement; Lebanon has reportedly offered to make him a deputy commander. **********Major Haddad, it was believed, would open the door to extensive, clandestine Israeli involvement in the region, as he did along a narrow border zone he controlled for years. Through the major, Israel itself could effectively command the southern brigade, creating favorable conditions for the operations of its intelligence agents and elite antiterrorist units. **********In practice, the agreement need not preclude such extensive, clandestine Israeli involvement. Indeed, the accord appears to be less a ceiling on the Israeli role than a foundation for its day-today evolution into a close Israeli-Lebanese military and intelligence partnership. Presumably, Lebanon will send to the south a brigade commander who shares Israel's desire to keep the P.L.O. out and who will therefore welcome quiet Israeli help in doing so. **********The Lebanese have made it clear throughout the negotiations that they would be more comfortable with unwritten understandings along such lines. Lebanese negotiators told their Israeli counterparts repeatedly that there was no need to put everything down on paper, that an oral agreement was enough - and more desirable in terms of Lebanon's ties to the Arab world. **********To help this development of a close, discreet relationship, Israel has selected an old hand at the game to coordinate its relations with Lebanon. He is Uri Lubrani, who has served as the senior Israeli representative in some difficult places, including Uganda, Ethiopia and Iran. **********Mr. Lubrani is reputed to be an official of Mossad, Israel's civilian intelligence agency, who developed a close friendship with the Shah of Iran that enabled extensive Israeli construction contracts, arms trade and other commerce with Iran when Teheran maintained the fiction that there were no relations at all. Israel is counting on him to use his skills in Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.main_headline: SPOT OIL PRICES DIP IN LONDON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.print_headline: SPOT OIL PRICES DIP IN LONDON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Prices quoted for most crude oil fell nearly $1 a barrel today on London's spot market. Activity was light, as traders waited for Saudi Arabia and other oil producers on the Persian Gulf to respond to price cuts by Nigeria, Britain and Norway. **********On short-term contracts, North Sea Brent and Forties crudes fell to an indicated price of $28.10, down from $29 Friday. The unsettled mood extended well beyond that market, analysts and industry sources said. **********A spokesman for the British National Oil Corporation, when asked if buyers had responded positively to its proposed price cut, said, ''I don't think anyone wants to wait.'' But he added, ''No one is in a position to move until they see what happens in the Gulf.'' The Government-owned company proposed price cuts Friday of $3 a barrel for North Sea oil sold under long-term contract, and Nigeria followed on Saturday with a price cut of $5.50. Advantage to Nigeria **********Nigeria's cut put its Bonny Light at $30 a barrel. That would give it a price advantage over North Sea crudes of similar quality, which would trade at $30.50 under B.N.O.C.'s proposed change. **********The widely expected response by Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf states is a cut of $4 or more a barrel, with matching moves by other important producers, such as Mexico and Venezuela. The Saudi benchmark price currently is $34 a barrel. **********However, rumors here suggested that the Saudis might attempt a $7 cut, to $27. That would put the Saudi benchmark crude $3 below Nigeria's higher-quality oil, restoring a differential the Saudis think should exist. Nigeria's Stance **********In announcing Nigeria's price move Saturday, Mallam Yahaya Dikko, the nation's presidential adviser on petroleum and energy, said the nation was committed to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. But he also said Nigeria would respond to price cuts by other producers. **********Analysts such as Walter Newton, head of Petroleum Economics Ltd., said they interpreted that remark to mean that Nigeria would act if the Saudis cut their price below $28.50. Nigeria has argued that the maximum price differential with the Saudis should be $1.50 a barrel, the analysts note. **********North Sea oil would continue to have the advantage in most of Europe because of transportation costs, the analysts agreed.  According to Mr. Newton, ''The competition would come in the United States.'' **********The analysts also said it may be several days before it is possible to get a reliable idea of what effect the cuts are having.  It is not clear how quickly oil buyers can shift their purchasing patterns once they determine where the best deals are offered.  Longterm contracts vary widely. Typically, in the North Sea, they resemble B.N.O.C.'s arrangement in which buyers have an annual or multiyear agreement to buy certain quantities of oil, with a provision allowing them to request a renegotiation of the price on a quarterly basis. That renegotiation is involved in B.N.O.C.'s proposed cut. When Cut Would Take Effect **********Buyers dissatisfied with the proposal, after comparing it with other opportunities, can ask for further negotiations. The price cut becomes effective when about 90 percent of B.N.O.C.'s buyers are satisfied. Those that are still unhappy have a month to find other supplies and bow out of the contract. **********Companies can also plead unforeseen circumstances and seek interim price changes. If an agreement cannot be reached in 14 days, the companies can escape from the contract. The Gulf Oil Corporation is said to have cited this provision as a basis for refusing two shipments of B.N.O.C. oil in the weeks before the proposed price change. **********''Prices are crumbling steadily,'' said a trader at one of the larger trading houses here. ''But there is hardly any market activity. It was even slower today because New York was closed'' for Washington's Birthday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/24/world.body_text: **********Jutting out on a hillside overlooking the fields of Cheshire, St. John's is a simple Anglican parish church. **********In its graveyard there is a marker remembering the 155 men and boys from Alsagers Bank who died in a mine explosion in 1918. A brass plaque on the church wall lists 47 men from the village killed in World War I under the inscription ''Faithful Unto Death.'' **********Elsewhere there is another list with the names of the vicars who have served the parish since St. John's was built by a wealthy landowner in 1875. The last name on the list is that of Leslie Hamlett, and in Alsagers Bank and through the entire realm of the Church of England, that name now inspires intense and divided feelings. **********Last month Father Hamlett gained sudden notoriety when he announced he was leaving the Church of England to become a Roman Catholic. Other Anglican priests before him have made the same decision, but what made the announcement so unnerving was his statement that he was taking 40 of the parish's 42 active members with him. **********This defection to the Catholic Church is believed to have been unprecedented in the 449 years since Henry VIII defied the Pope and set himself up as head of a state church.   A Precipitous Decline **********Those who have watched the surge of interest by ''Anglo Catholics'' inside the Anglican clergy for a reconciliation with Rome were not completely surprised by the priest's change of faith. But the decision by the congregation to follow him was unsettling to those already worried by the Church of England's precipitous decline in a country in which it claims to be the official state religion. **********Their defection comes at a particularly bad time for the Church of England, which is facing a decline in active membership and financial resources, while the clergy continues to clash over articles of faith, liberalizing trends and the church's mission. **********While nearly 30 million people in Britain have been baptized as Anglicans, only 1.8 million remain active in the church, a figure that has fallen from 3 million in 25 years. **********In the last century church attendance and Anglican influence in English society seemed as natural a combination as the tea and cakes that followed a Sunday service. Only the English monarch was required by law to be a member of the Church of England, but in terms of social, economic and educational networks it was an indispensable asset. Yet on a typical Sunday today fewer than three-quarters of a million worshipers go to church.   Methodism, Too, Is Slipping **********A decline in church attendance is not an exclusive problem of Anglicanism. Methodism, the other great Protestant voice competing for the souls of the British, has also weakened. **********It is the Roman Catholic Church, which is much closer to Anglicanism in structure and ritual than the Anglicans are to the Protestant evangelical faiths, that has been prospering in England. The number of Catholics in England has doubled since 1930 to nearly 5 million. **********Moreover, the Anglo-Catholic renewal movement inside the Church of England is now thought to embrace one-third of the active church membership and clergy. **********Several Anglican parishes in the Stoke-on-Trent area, which includes the village of Alsagers Bank, already use the Roman Catholic service and hear confessions, and some vicars like Father Hamlett are Roman Catholics in all but name. Their practices are tolerated if not shared by the leadership. **********Many of the villagers in Alsagers Bank are not as charitable. They suspect that Father Hamlett ''brainwashed'' his congregation from the day he took over the parish 17 years ago. Others who did not like his services elected to attend the Anglican church in the next village.   Attempt at Rebuilding **********Now some like Frank and Mary Webb are trying to rebuild St. John's along the traditional lines that they feel were neglected by Father Hamlett. **********''By the time he left there were not a lot of village people left in his church,'' said Mrs. Webb. **********Father Hamlett, an intense man of 55 years with bushy eyebrows and a trim gray beard, now meets with his breakaway flock for daily masses in a center for the handicapped, or in the house that he and his wife and three children live in on the far side of Stoke-on-Trent. **********He denies he disguised his beliefs. ''I've done nothing subversive,'' he said in an interview in his home, a large house along rows of industrial row dwellings behind the old factories that for more than a century have turned out some of the world's best china under names like Wedgwood and Spode. **********His intentions, he said, were fully outlined three years ago in a letter to the Archbishop of Canterbury. **********He said he left the Church of England instead of working with fellow Anglo- Catholics ''from the inside'' because of the liberalizing trends that he said introduced obstacles to communion with Rome. **********In Alsagers Bank the villagers who stayed away from St. John's during Father Hamlett's tenure are now trying to save the church. **********But the verdict on whether they can stay together may have to await the end of feelings of enmity some feel for Father Hamlett. All across the English countryside, in villages that are virtual copies of Alsagers Bank, small parish churches like St. John's stand empty and unattended, admired from a distance by passing tourists and ignored by most of the townspeople.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.print_headline: CITICORP NET UP 17.5%; BANK AMERICA OFF 19.6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********Despite sharp increases in its problem loans, Citicorp, the nation's largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 17.5 percent, to $228 million, from the $194 million earned in last year's first quarter. **********In California, the BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's secondlargest banking concern, reported a 19.6 percent decline in net income, to $120.3 million, from $149.6 million. But BankAmerica asserted that its net income in the first quarter last year was distorted upward by $31 million because of a retroactive accounting change. **********It contended that a truer picture of its year-to-year results would be obtained if the $31 million were deducted from its net income in the first quarter of 1982. On that basis, BankAmerica's earnings rose 1.4 percent. **********The main element in the strength of Citicorp's profits was a $214 million rise in net interest income, the difference between the amount of interest Citicorp paid for its funds and the amount of interest it received on its loans and investments. This resulted from a $9 billion increase in outstanding loans and a rise to 3.87 percent, from 3.31 percent, in the ''spread'' between what it paid for its funds and the yield it received on its assets. **********Another key factor in Citicorp's earnings growth was a $44 million rise in foreign-exchange trading profits, which increased to $98 million in the first quarter of 1982, from $54 million in the comparable period of 1981. **********On the negative side, the provision for loan losses surged by $46 million, to $136 million, up from $90 million in the first quarter of 1982. Actual charge-offs rose to $106 million, from $63 million. **********In addition, nonperforming commercial-loan assets soared by $862 million over the year, to $1.9 billion, representing 2.3 percent of total commercial loans, compared with 1.4 percent at the end of March, 1982. **********Citicorp said the year-to-year increase in its problem loans ''is predominantly from overseas offices, with Mexican and other Latin American private sector borrowers representing the largest component of the increase.'' **********On a per-common-share basis net income rose 15.2 percent, to $1.74, from $1.51 in the first quarter of 1982.  Citicorp's annual rate of return on each $100 of average total assets, a key indicator of a bank's basic profitability, rose to 71 cents in the first quarter of 1983 from 67 cents in the comparable period of 1982. BankAmerica **********At BankAmerica, per-share net income dropped 27 percent, to 73 cents in the first quarter from $1 in the same period last year.  In the latest quarter, the provision for loan losses rose to $95.5 million, up from $60.9 million in the comparable period of 1982.  Actual loan losses amounted to $71 million, up from $62.1 million.  Problem loans rose 24 percent, to almost $3 billion, from $2.4 billion. Such loans represented 4 percent of BankAmerica's total loans. **********Its annual rate of return on each $100 of total assets dropped to 39 cents, from 50 cents in the 1982 quarter. Bankers Trust **********At Bankers Trust, net income rose 15.3 percent, to $61.1 million, in the first quarter of 1983, from $53 million in the comparable period of 1982. Net income per common share rose to $2.03, from $1.88, up 8 percent. **********The provision for loan losses, at $15 million, was unchanged.  Problem loans rose to $476 million, from $423 million, and represented 2.3 percent of total loans, up slightly from 2.2 percent in the 1982 period. Bankers Trust's annual rate of return on each $100 of average assets increased to 63 cents from 61 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; HARLEM CO-OP CONVERSION PLAN FALTERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/busin.body_text: **********When a plan to convert the 536-unit Dunbar Apartments in Harlem to a cooperative was announced last year, it seemed assured of success. **********The $11.8 million renovation of the complex was being underwritten by two banks and the city. Federal housing funds were to help those low-income tenants who chose to buy or remain as renters under the noneviction plan. A leading Harlem-based real estate firm was hired as the managing agent. And hundreds of nonresident families had expressed interest in buying apartments there. **********The 150 vacant one- and two-bedroom apartments that were to be available to outsiders ranged from 498 square feet to 935 square feet and were to cost from $7,000 to $12,000. **********And conversion of the Dunbar - which occupies the square block bounded by 149th Street, 150th Street, Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and Frederick Douglass Boulevard - conforms to its history. The development, with apartments around a spacious courtyard, was built in 1927 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. as the city's first large cooperative for blacks. **********Although that cooperative failed during the Depression and the apartments have been rented since, the current conversion plan seemed to be a no-fail proposition. It has not failed, but now it seems much less promising. The buoyant optimism among the Dunbar's owners and city officials has disappeared amid a welter of accusations and countercharges. **********The imbroglio has prompted the state Attorney General's office to delay acceptance of the conversion plan. It has brought about a rent strike by some tenants and a tenant- versus-owner suit in Manhattan Civil Court. It has led the managing agent to seek to withdraw from the project. It has forced one bank to miss mortgage payments on the project to another bank. And it has raised the question of whether the completion of the renovation will meet the deadline for the use of Federal money. **********Basically, the many-sided dispute centers on whether the owner, the Goldome Bank for Savings, has properly maintained and renovated the complex. **********Tenants such as Mary Ann Holmes, a 15-year resident, charge that maintenance has deteriorated since the conversion plan was announced. Dissident tenants, most of whom apparently do not want the building converted, also complain that Goldome officials have deliberately not rented vacant apartments to make it easier to gain tenant approval of the proposed conversion. **********But Frances Levenson, vice president of Goldome, insists that the repair and renovation work done thus far has met city standards. She said the vacant apartments were not rented because they were to be sold as co-ops. **********Both sides agree that many tenants oppose the conversion plan, even on a noneviction basis, because the necessary renovation entails a restructuring of the rents. **********The top rent for a two-bedroom apartment is now under $400; in the conversion plan, it could rise to $530. **********Although the city has pledged the use of Federal and other housing funds to help eligible tenants meet the increased rents, the restructuring would mean a rise in the amount all tenants pay for rent. **********Miss Levenson said a combination of the Dunbar's relatively low rents, the nonpayment of rent by striking tenants and the lack of income from the vacant apartments had brought about a severe shortfall of operating funds. **********The shortfall, estimated to be at least $50,000 a month, has forced Goldome to go into arrears on its payments to the National Consumer Cooperative Bank and on its own mortgage. The Washington-based institution had contributed $5 million to the project with the understanding that it would become a cooperative. **********Other money for the $11.8 million renovation to prepare the complex for conversion came from Goldome itself and from the city's low-interest Participation Loan Program. **********The tenants' lawsuit asks the court to take direct responsibility for the building's management from Goldome and to give it to a court-appointed administrator. The suit is to reopen Monday before Judge Ralph W. Sparks after a month's hiatus. **********An informal meeting Wednesday between Judge Sparks and representatives of the dissident tenants and the savings bank has left open the possibility of a settlement. **********It was at that meeting that George Brooker, president of Webb & Brooker, the managing agent, said in exasperation that his firm would cease its involvement in the Dunbar. **********''I hope something good happens to it because it's a valuable piece of property,'' he said later during an interview. ''But we're not going to waste any more energy on it.'' **********Miss Levenson of Goldome, however, was more optimistic. Whether the property is converted to a cooperative, she said, is ''a minor issue.'' She declared, ''The important point is that the property is made viable and provides good housing for the people who live there.''
