https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Construction spending in the United States slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent in September from August's level, after five consecutive monthly increases, the Commerce Department said today. **********The September decline reflects smaller outlays for public construction projects. **********Private construction outlays remained about the same, the department said. **********The September drop, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $272.7 billion, followed a rise in August of 1.9 percent, to an annual rate of $274.8 billion, according to revised figures issued today. The August rise was originally put at 2.4 percent. **********Last Year's Figures Topped **********Despite the September decline, spending on private and public construction projects during the month was 18.2 percent higher than in September of last year, shortly before the end of the recession. **********The report said new private construction was put in place at an adjusted annual rate of $222.2 billion in September, up from $221.4 billion in August and $178.2 billion in September 1982. **********Within the private sector during September, spending for residential building declined 1.5 percent while outlays for nonresidential projects advanced 1.8 percent. **********Spending on public undertakings declined 5.2 percent in September, to an adjusted rate of $50.6 billion, after increasing 4.5 percent in August, the report said. **********Compared with September of last year, public construction spending was 3.6 percent lower. **********Within the public sector, spending for state and local government-owned construction fell about 6 percent, while outlays declined about 4 percent for federally owned projects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.body_text: **********RETAILING, the field that employs the largest number of Americans 16 million - is so vast, so segmented and so far-flung that opportunities inevitably arise as others are foreclosed. This holds true for data processing, a technical area that is increasingly indispensable to the widespread sales and inventory requirements of retailers. **********While the processes may be similar, corporate policies may vary widely. For example, Sears Roebuck & Company, the world's largest retailer, will be hiring between 40 and 100 new people a year in the next few years for its data-processing operations. But few will need computer-science degrees, since Sears has found that math, English and home-economics majors - and its own people - fit its training and salary requirements better. **********The J.C. Penney Company, on the other hand, the nation's third largest general merchandise retailer after Sears and K Mart, will seek out computer-science graduates for the 60 recruits it expects to hire annually after having largely dropped its training program. The New York-based company had an elaborate training activity, involving liberal arts and math and other majors, but found that it had ''a lot of people on board who were not productive,'' according to its systems chief. **********The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, however, wants more experienced people with better management skills but not necessarily a better formal education, but will continue to hire some entry-level people. The big New York based-retailer, which operates Lord & Taylor, Caldor discount stores and the J.W. Robinson department stores in California among others, is expanding its in-house training of data-processing personnel but wants them to come in with a strong background. **********If these varying needs and criteria seem confusing to entry-level applicants or young careerists looking for a job change, they need not be dismayed. In fact, although the nation's retailing has hardly been one of the growth sectors during the two-year recession, its employment potential for data-processing personnel may be brighter than any other major segment in the economy. Two major reasons are the continuing expansion into new stores and increasing sophistication of store computers and their applications. **********CHARLES A. Carlson, vice president for data processing and communications at Sears, said that ''Generally, I see a bright potential for employment in this field. In retailing in the 1980's,'' he added, ''we are changing the way we do business. We are getting the information that data processing gives us to the points where it needs most to be used. That will make better merchants of us. On sales input and inventory replenishment, for example, we will be ableto fill our pipelines from up-to-date information rather than on data that is days and weeks old.'' **********At Sears, which last year had revenues of $25 billion, almost every possible major application has already been made of data processing, including accounting, payroll, order processing, inventory management and credit. **********''But there are better ways of doing all those things,'' Mr.  Carlson said, ''We have to take advantage of having all that information at our fingertips and we think that's a great opportunity for us at Sears.'' **********As a result, at his company and at most other retailers, he feels that the data-processing job potential is quite promising.  Penney's has been encouraged in its quest for better-trained people by the fact that ''some schools are doing a fine job in their computer-science programs,'' according to Robert Capone, vice president and director of systems and data processing. He said that Penney recruiters typically visited those schools, held parties and gave students a rundown on what Penney's processing facilities are like. **********Schools Mr. Capone cited that have computer-science programs near Penney's data-processing facilities include Hofstra University on Long Island, only 20 miles from Penney's Manhattan headquarters; Marquette University in Milwaukee, where Penney operates its catalogue, distribution and stores-data facility; and the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, where the company has its pointof-sale data center. About 150 people are employed in each data center, Mr. Capone said, each of which hires between 15 and 20 people a year. **********THE big push in retailing systems activity, especially the refinement of internal communications, is of great interest to Associated Dry Goods Corporation, which will stress this factor in its enhanced in-house training. Peter F. Gundell, director of systems planning for Associated, noted that a growing number of universities were offering degrees, not only in computer science, but also in management-information systems. He gave as examples the State University of New York at Albany and the University of California at San Diego. **********An integral part of that extension into communications, Mr. Gundell feels, is the move of retail systems into two-way information exchange, known as an interactive system. ''This, of course,'' he said, ''eliminates the former keypunch operator, who was a link in a system that was reiterative and wasteful.'' Now, he said, the user is both entering and retrieving information quickly. Keypunch people are being retrained, and many are finding new careers in a changed technology.'' **********Yet while the opportunities for entry at the major retailers are obviously growing, there are some developments that create opportunities for those who already work there. At Sears, for example, a centralization policy in the merchandising operations has created a ''pool of people available for reassignment,'' according to Mr. Carlson. Assignments are being changed as the company seeks to ferret out the most promising people within its ranks - those who already know both data processing and the way the company works. **********Training sessions at Sears, in which about 35 ''students'' meet at the company's Sears Tower in Chicago, last 16 weeks. They involve both classroom and store-application training. ''We tried to cut the course to 12 weeks,'' Mr. Carlson said, ''but found that it hurt the quality level.'' **********How high can a successful Sears applicant climb? ''They all start from a common base of programmer,'' Mr. Carlson replied, ''and go as high as national manager - and even higher.'' But because Sears will be trying to transfer more of its existing staff into systems operations, the entrant will be competing with Sears regulars.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/02/world.body_text: **********A strike of Quebec government workers, protesting wage cuts of up to 20 percent, started falling apart today after thousands of hospital workers returned to their jobs. **********The hospital workers, who joined 120,000 other government workers in the week-old walkout Monday, quit the strike after the government announced a ''framework for settlement'' with their union. **********Although the government will not end the wage cuts, the union's president, Yves Lessard, said he would ask the 85,000 members to approve the agreement. The agreement covers striking health clinic, social services and day care workers, who are also returning to work today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Grumman Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter nearly tripled to $22.6 million, or $1.60 a share, from $7.6 million, or 55 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, which was restated for discontinued operations and a change in the method of accounting for investment tax credits. **********Grumman, which has its headquarters in Bethpage, L.I., said that its first-quarter sales totaled $509.1 million this year, a 7.6 percent rise, from $473 million in 1982. **********The company said the main difference between this year and last was that this year's statement did not carry a loss on the Flxible bus subsidiary, which stopped manufacturing the troubled Model 837 bus during the first quarter of 1982. The Model 837 was hobbled by cracked frames almost as soon as it went into service in New York City, and the company is now negotiating to sell the Flxible subsidiary to the General Automotive Corporation of Detroit. **********The company said that the 1983 first-quarter results also reflected improvements in the company's military aircraft sales, including the EF-111A program, and higher profits from Grumman Data Systems Corporation, a computer subsidiary. **********This year's first-quarter statement also carried a $7.5 million charge against income from the negotiation of claims arising from a Boeing subcontract. Grumman builds wing parts for both the 757 and 767 jetliners. **********Grumman said that its first-quarter consolidated interest costs were lower this year because its total borrowings were less than in 1982 and interest rates were lower. In addition, the company's $4.3 billion backlog at the end of the first quarter is the largest in Grumman's 54-year history.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 dipped 2.2 percent, while sales edged up 3.2 percent. **********The Pittsburgh-based company, the nation's second-largest electrical products manufacturer after the General Electric Company, said that net income in the latest three months fell to $100.8 million, or $1.13 a share, from $103.1 million, or $1.20 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales increased to $2.61 billion, from $2.53 billion. **********For the year, Westinghouse said, net income rose 2.5 percent, to $449.3 million, or $5.16 a share, from $438 million, or $5.10 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 4.1 percent, to $9.75 billion, from $9.37 billion. **********The company said that operating earnings in the latest three months were significantly higher than in the 1981 quarter primarily because of large gains by its Power Systems and Public Systems operations.  Operating profits of its Broadcasting and Cable operations remained level with a year ago while operating profits of its Industry Products group rose sharply. **********Other income declined in the fourth quarter, due principally to lower interest income from marketable securities and provisions made for planned business portfolio changes. **********''Given the economic conditions in 1982, Westinghouse had a good year with increased sales and earnings,'' said Robert E. Kirby, the company's chairman. ''Even though the near-term economic outlook remains uncertain, we see some signs that indicate the recession is bottoming out.'' **********Some analysts are optimistic about the outlook for Westinghouse in 1983. ''The defense business should again lead the way,'' said a recent research report in The Value Line Investment Survey. ''In addition, we look for an improving trend in Industry Products, which will lag the economic rebound by a quarter or two.'' Norton Simon **********Norton Simon Inc. reported that net income in the fourth quarter dropped 43.4 percent, to $14.5 million, or 43 cents a share, from $25.6 million, or 77 cents a share, in the 1981 period. Revenues slipped 4.3 percent, to $739.5 million, from $772.7 million. **********''As we expected, unrelenting recessionary pressures on world economies as well as unfavorable foreign-currency exchange rates continued to reduce profits,'' said David Mahoney, chairman and chief executive. ---- Earnings tables, page D17.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.main_headline: TOOL ORDERS SURGE, BUT STAY LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.print_headline: TOOL ORDERS SURGE, BUT STAY LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Machine tool orders, which plunged precipitously during the recent recession, rose 80 percent in September over the 1982 month, according to the industry's trade association. **********But, in a report released yesterday, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association said the September orders of $156 million, which were also 14 percent above August's levels, remained depressed by historical standards. **********''Although modest, a recovery seems to be firmly established in the machine tool industry,'' said James A. Gray, the association's president. He noted, however, that industry shipments of $134 million in the month, down 51 percent from September 1982, were still ''especially weak.'' **********This weakness in shipments stems from the extremely depressed level of orders last year. Orders fell to $1.5 billion in 1982, down from $2.9 billion in 1981 and a record $5.6 billion in 1979. **********Although orders for the first nine months of this year are running just 1 percent above a year earlier, analysts said that because the pace of the recovery was increasing, the total for 1983 might exceed 1982 by as much as 10 percent. **********'1982 Was a Bloodbath' **********''Machine tool numbers have been up for several months,'' said Laura Conigliaro, an analyst with Prudential Bache. ''But you have to put things in perspective. The numbers are going up from a very low base.  You must remember that 1982 was a bloodbath.'' **********One reason for the industry's nosedive was the recession. ''We just went through the worst recession since World War II,'' said James A. D. Geier, chairman of Cincinnati Milacron, a major machine tool manufacturer. ''It went on so long that people just stopped buying machinery.'' **********A second reason was imports. Their share of the domestic market has jumped to 33 percent, up from 21 percent in 1979. **********Looking Ahead **********Noting that industry orders - an important part of capital goods spending - lag behind the rest of the economy by six to eight months, Mr. Geier predicted that they will continue to pick up in future months. **********Mrs. Conigliaro forecasts that in 1984, orders may reach $3 billion, comparable to 1981 levels. **********But David G. Sutliff, an analyst with Salomon Brothers, doubts that orders will soon approach their historical highs. ''In the cycle of capital goods spending in the late 1970's,'' he said, ''three of the largest machine tool customers - automobile, aerospace and oil and gas - were very heavy spenders. This was especially true with the auto industry's retooling for smaller cars. Their orders just won't be as large this time around.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Lois Agency Creates Knoware Campaign
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/busin.body_text: **********As you might have guessed, George Lois and his Lois Pitts Gershon agency are behind that new company called Knoware Inc., that will soon begin selling instructional disks for personal computers that will eliminate complicated directions. **********When the Fifth Avenue agency got the account a few months back, the Cambridge, Mass., client, still in its infancy, was using the temporary name: Adventures in Learning. No pizazz there. **********Mr. Lois, chairman, explained Friday that what was needed was a memorable name devoid of any semblance of technology. And since the advent of Apple made a ''loony'' name acceptable, Knoware was born. **********Of course, the company name without its second line ''The Knowledge Company,'' is also the name of the product and that allows for a lot of cutesy advertising much in the vein of the stuff the agency did for Qwip, the telecopier from Exxon Office Systems. **********A headline such as ''First there was Hardware. Then there was Software. Now there is Knoware,'' is now possible. Others include: ''American businessmen, American students, American homemakers, are getting Knoware fast!'' and ''I.B.M. and Apple Personal Computers are going Knoware.'' The founders of the company and the brains behind the concept are John J. Donovan and Stuart E. Madnick, professors at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management. Rothschild Venture supplied the capital and the chairman, Archie B. Towers, a former American Telephone and Telegraph Company executive, who continues as a Rothschild president. **********The Knoware president is Thomas B. Towers, 45-year-old former vice president, marketing, of Visicorp, maker of Visicalc, and a pioneer in computer software. **********When Mr. Towers finally got to the agency after enduring a rainy traffic tieup in the Bronx, he said that the media spending for the remainder of the year will be $775,000, while next year's will be $1.5 million. **********Three-quarters of the budget will be aimed at business executives who are the most likely possessors of the 3.5 million personal computers (not to be confused with the less expensive home computers); 15 percent at data processing professionals and the remaining 10 percent at the computer retail trade. **********The consumer advertising will first run in the executive edition of the Oct. 24 Newsweek, then in Time's top executive edition; Business Week, Forbes and Fortune, and also in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.main_headline: Chief of Hyster Backs Kohlberg Buyout Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chief of Hyster Backs Kohlberg Buyout Bid
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.body_text: **********William H. Kilkenny, chairman and chief executive of the Hyster Company of Portland, Ore., was surprised by the recent, unsolicited proposal of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York for a leveraged buyout of his company. **********But he seems well disposed toward the idea, and an independent committee of his board is studying the offer and is expected to act soon. **********However, Mr. Kilkenny and Hyster, internationally known for its forklift trucks, have been courted by many suitors in recent years, despite an earnings downturn attributed to the lackluster world economy. Revenues in 1982 were $422 million. **********''We've had many acquisition offers. We are viewed as a premier company in the durable capital goods field and have a very strong balance sheet,'' said the chief executive, who has spent his entire business career at Hyster, starting as a parts clerk in 1946. He was named president in 1971, chief executive in 1974 and added the title of chairman in 1975. **********''I feel very good about what I'm doing,'' Mr. Kilkenny said, referring to taking his public company private. He and other Hyster senior executives would receive equity positions if the proposal is accepted. And, he said, Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts intends ''to keep in place the people who built the company. I do not intend to retire next year when I'm 65.'' **********Mr. Kilkenny said he believes in studying his competitors closely, and imitating them when necessary. Paraphrasing William James, he said, ''To fight another entity, you must become like that entity itself.'' **********A native of Portland and the son of a lumber mill worker, Mr. Kilkenny was graduated with a degree in economics from Willamette University. Instead of entering law school as planned, he joined the Navy in 1941 and soon was using forklift trucks as a stevedore on the docks in Guam. The Navy sent him to Harvard's Graduate School of Business and later to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********After the war, Mr. Kilkenny said, ''I knew I wanted to be involved with forklift trucks and materials handling. So I came back to my hometown and applied for a job with Hyster, the only company there in that business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/busin.body_text: **********SAN FRANCISCO I n the 1970's, when its upstate New York division needed a facelift, Citicorp sent in Betty Sue Peabody, a tough-minded Texan.  Within five years, she helped turn around the retail banking operation. Working with community bankers, she encouraged them to take on small business and personal loans that were profitable, and to bring in low-cost deposits. She set up a processing center in Rochester for government-guaranteed student loans and she won the respect of her colleagues. **********Now Citicorp, with a more complicated problem, has turned once again to Mrs. Peabody. In acquiring the failed Fidelity Savings and Loan Association of San Francisco last September and transforming it into a new entity called Citicorp Savings, the Eastern corporation inherited an operation with deposit losses of $350 million and a constituency bitter about Fidelity's past lending policies and the lending in South Africa by Citibank. Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, also faced a torrent of protest when it crossed the state line into California. The problem was turned over to Mrs. Peabody, who was named president and chief executive. **********''Citicorp recognized this as a troubled company,'' says Mrs.  Peabody, who at 41 years of age is one of the highest ranking women at Citicorp. ''Our primary focus is to get on the road to recovery and back into the loan market.'' That revival has begun. **********The takeover was much contested by the California thrift industry and others concerned about the impact of the Eastern giant on the California market. Citicorp won Federal Reserve Board approval last September to become the first United States bank holding company to acquire an out-of-state savings and loan association and the first New York bank to be able to collect consumer deposits in the lucrative California market. **********Fidelity, with 80 branches in central and northern California, many in inner-city neighborhoods, had assets of $2.9 billion. In renaming it Citicorp Savings, Citicorp barely avoided a restriction imposed by the Federal Reserve Board on it not to use the word ''bank'' in the name. **********Now, said Mrs. Peabody, deposits are up by $153 million, the company has re-entered the mortgage market and is now offering the new consumer products allowed by Federal rules that went into effect Dec. 14. Expansion to the lucrative southern California market is a major item on the agenda for the future. **********''She was sent to California to do the same job that she did upstate,'' said Will Sparks, director of Citicorp's advertising and public affairs and Citibank's external affairs. ''She was the obvious person to do it. She was not sent because she's a woman, but because she's a good banker. She's a tough administrator but she works hard herself.'' **********In fact, Mrs. Peabody decries reference to her being a woman. ''We are people in business,'' she said, emphasizing the word ''people.'' She added: ''Sex doesn't matter.'' **********Mrs. Peabody is terse and businesslike, with a tomboyish quality and a penchant for purple and smart suits. She is a good listener, cordial and economical with words. A male colleague, who asked not to be identified, said that Mrs. Peabody had come up through male ranks at a time when it was unusual for women to do so, which may account for her no-nonsense demeanor. **********She is characterized by former co-workers at W.R. Grace and colleagues at Citicorp - the only two places where she has worked since receiving an M.B.A. in finance from the University of Virginia in 1963 and a B.A. in economics from Rice University - as demanding, and a team player who is not afraid to speak out and to whom her colleagues listen.BORN in Longview, Tex., the daughter of a building supply company o wner and a high school algebra teacher, she and her brother, Joe, w ho is now an executive for Exxon in London, got their first taste ofb usiness when they worked in the family lumber yard. **********Mrs. Peabody maintains a long-distance marriage with Arthur W.  Peabody, 39, a strategic planner for the Allied Corporation, whom she met at W.R. Grace and married in 1970. They have maintained separate homes since 1978, when she moved to Rochester. He owns a house in Morris Plains, N.J. She has purchased a three-bedroom condominium in Orinda, Calif., which is 15 minutes from her Oakland office. **********In changing jobs, Mrs. Peabody's responsibilities widened. In upstate New York, she was in charge of 35 branches with assets of $2 billion and a work force of 650 people. At Citicorp Savings, she runs an operation with $2.9 billion in assets, 80 branches and 900 employees. **********She believes in listening to community leaders - potential customers - and her subordinates. But some community activists in minority-dominated Oakland remain cautious about what they expect from the new owners of Fidelity, which had been accused in the past of having the worst ''red-lining'' record in California. **********''We hope they don't come out here and run roughshod over us and shoot 'em up,'' said Paul Cobb, executive director of the Oakland Citizens Committee for Urban Renewal. His organization, the Alameda County Legal Aid Society, a public interest law firm known as Public Advocates, and other groups presented testimony before the Federal Reserve Board at the takeover hearings in October, asking the new owners to ''remedy'' what Mr. Cobb called Fidelity's ''neglect'' of the minority community. The groups also are angry over Citicorp loans to South Africa. **********''Our concern was that Fidelity had a terrible lending record, and whoever took it over had an obligation to correct it,'' said Clifford Sweet, the Alameda County Legal Aid Society's director. **********At a meeting Dec. 6 with Citicorp, the group advocated a program that included development of affirmative action loans, a minority member on the Citicorp board and a minority committee to advise Citicorp Savings. Mrs. Peabody was not at that meeting, however, nor were other top Citicorp officials whom she was shepherding on a visit to the new acquisition. Their absence prompted Angela Blackwell, an attorney with Public Advocates, to wonder aloud whether Citicorp was taking their concerns seriously. **********Mrs. Peabody says it is. ''They may not like everything we tell them, but we are looking at their concerns seriously,'' she said.BANKERS and savings and loan executives in California are publicly c alling the arrival of Citicorp Savings healthy competition.  P rivately, some are fearful that smaller savings and loans may be h ard-pressed to match what former California Savings and Loan C ommissioner Linda Tsao Yang, called the potential for ''ruthless c ompetition.'' **********Mrs. Yang was suspended from her job for eight days last fall after voicing opposition to the takeover. She fears that Citicorp is in a position to program losses over a long time to gain market share at the expense of California competitors. ''My concern is the people of California,'' she said. ''Is it to their advantage to set up this kind of ruthless competition? A number of small S.&L.;'s may be forced to combine with others or go out of the business.'' **********On the surface, at least, the competition is not acting scared.  Hallam Dawson, president of Crocker Bank of San Francisco, said, ''We thought this was not the way to go about it,'' he said, referring to Citicorp being allowed to cross state lines by regulatory action rather than by legislation. After the Citicorp takeover, Congress passed legislation allowing ailing thrift units to be merged with institutions from other states. **********William Mortensen, president of First Federal Savings and Loan of Santa Monica, and past president of the California Savings and Loan League, believes that consumers will benefit. But, he added, ''almost all of us have a twinge when competition increases. It probably will sharpen up competition.'' He does not believe smaller savings and loans will be driven out of business by Citicorp Savings, but he admits that a lot of league members do not agree. **********''We're waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' said Marian Sandler, president and chief executive officer of World Savings and Loan of Oakland, with operations in Kansas and Colorado. ''You can't just plunk down a New York operation in California unless you're willing to spend a lot of money. They may at the worst take a little bit of business from everybody.'' **********Although she has never lived in California, Mrs. Peabody plans to bring her Eastern expertise to bear in Citicorp's new market. And she has taken to California with enthusiasm. Although her life revolves around her work, she plans to take up golf again - she shoots in the 90-handicap range when playing well. She relaxes with spy novels and traveling, preferably to quiet beaches. And she plans to stay in California for a while. ''I like California very much. I like the people. I think it might be a good place to retire. It fits in with my lifestyle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.main_headline: Market Place; How Fertilizer Group Is Doing
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.print_headline: Market Place; How Fertilizer Group Is Doing
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/21/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a two-year slump, fertilizer issues are one of the best-performing groups in the stock market. Standard & Poor's index of four fertilizer stocks, in fact, has increased 55 percent so far in 1983. Meanwhile, brokerage house comments on shares of fertilizer producers, along with recommendations on other farm-related stocks, have generally been favorable. **********For example, two leading producers of fertilizer - the Williams Companies and the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation - have been recommended by Shearson/American Express. Oppenheimer & Company has also recommended Williams. And International Minerals has been cited by Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden Inc. as ''worthy of consideration as a beneficiary of rising farm incomes.'' **********Even some stock market letters have issued favorable comments on the fertilizer sector. The Professional Tape Reader, a publication based in Hollywood, Fla., mentions Beker Industries and the First Mississipi Corporation in its list of stocks that ''can be selectively bought on weakness.'' **********The stock issued by the aforementioned companies are the four components of the fertilizer group index, although there are other chemical companies that depend to a lesser extent on fertilizer for earnings. The worst drought in nearly 50 years has sharply reduced this year's corn and soybean crops, and that is viewed by industry analysts as enhancing the prospects for phosphate, nitrogen and other fertilizers.  But a new appraisal by the Value Line Investment Survey takes a less optimistic view of this group in terms of potential price gains in the stock market from now on. In particular, the investment advisory service warns that price/earnings multiples for these companies are ''high,'' even when based on next year's estimated profits. **********''These stocks, buoyed by continuing hopes, may well perform as well as the market averages for the next six months or longer, but we think the current price/earnings ratios are unsustainable over any considerable length of time,'' Value Line said. ''The optimists, or those who have bid the stock prices up, think that resurgent fertilizer demand will push fertilizer prices up to the point where producers will be making a lot of money. **********''The less sanguine - and we count ourselves among them - agree that demand will recover. However, considering the more-than-ample capacity for all fertilizer materials, the competition for market share, the loss of export markets because of the dollar's strength and the encouragement of imports by that same strength of the dollar, we are less inclined to expect a significant rise in fertilizer prices.'' **********Value Line also said that margins within the industry currently are so thin that many producers are losing money on fertilizer. ''More volume at tissue-thin margins,'' it added, ''won't produce any bonanza.'' **********Meanwhile, Standard & Poor's Outlook suggested this week that, after recent price advances in fertilizer stocks, ''the group may require a period of consolidation before extending its gains.'' The Outlook expects aggregate earnings of the four producers in the index to drop about 30 percent this year, with this forecast skewed adversely by the results for Beker Industries. A ''gradual recovery'' in industry profits is envisaged for 1984. **********In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Beker was unchanged at 12, while First Mississippi fell 3/8, to 13 5/8. Meanwhile, International Minerals closed at 45, down 5/8. Williams Companies last traded on Friday when the stock rose 3/8, to 26 1/4. **********In a current technical commentary on these stocks, Justin E. Mamis, a consultant to Wertheim & Company, said he continues to regard the fertilizers as ''still an O.K. group.'' He went on to observe, however, that the group ''needs a rest.'' **********Standard & Poor's Outlook also took a look at other stocks related to the farm economy. ''At current prices, we believe Deere is fully valued on an interim basis,'' it said. ''International Harvester and Massey-Ferguson are viewed as high-risk speculations and should be avoided by the average investor. However, Allis-Chalmers, a diversified machinery maker that is less dependent on sales to agricultural markets than its major competitors, is worth holding speculatively.'' **********On the Big Board yesterday, Deere slipped 3/8, to 39 3/8. Harvester closed at 9 1/4, unchanged, while Massey-Ferguson finished at 5 3/4, also unchanged, and Allis-Chalmers inched up 1/8, to 18 5/8.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/13/world.main_headline: CANADA'S NEW TORY LEADER: BILINGUAL AND STYLISH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/13/world.print_headline: CANADA'S NEW TORY LEADER: BILINGUAL AND STYLISH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/13/world.body_text: **********Brian Mulroney, a 44-year-old lawyer and businessman who defeated former Prime Minister Joe Clark late Saturday in a contest for the leadership of the Conservative Party, has sought to project himself as a model Tory and a new kind of Canadian politician. **********For one thing, in a party that has had its share of high-born patricians, Mr. Mulroney has stressed his working-class roots as the son of an electrician in the pulp and paper town of Baie Comeau, north of Quebec City. **********For another, in a party that has scorned French-speakers and been scorned by them in return, he has made his bilingual fluency his major selling point. And finally, in a party and country where politicians have worked their way up through the ranks, he has never sought or won elected political office. **********Mr. Mulroney's victory came after four months of often divisive campaigning that intensified as public opinion polls showed that Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his Liberals were lagging behind the Conservatives in popularity. A Good Image on Television **********Pierre Berton, a journalist and Canada's foremost popular historian, noted that Mr. Mulroney was a different kind of leader from any who had preceded him, and suggested that his image may be well suited to the television age. Many agree that Mr. Mulroney, well-coiffed, well-tailored, with a resonant voice, has the television presence of an Academy Awards show host. **********He is married to the former Mila Pivnicki, the Yugoslav-born daughter of a Montreal psychiatrist. They have three children.  All during the three-day convention Mr. Mulroney seemed instinctively aware of the cameras, smiling and pointing at some friend in the crowd just as the cameras zoomed in on him. **********All of this is in stark contrast to Mr. Clark, the man he defeated, whose closest aides regarded his lack of television presence as his largest liability. Mr. Clark, who comes from Alberta, endured often brutal criticism during his seven years at the party's helm, most of it based on his often awkward appearances on television. When he took over the reins of the party as a largely unknown 37-year-old he was dubbed ''Joe Who.'' **********No nicknames have yet emerged for Mr. Mulroney. It is the popular conception of his followers that his forceful style will lead the party to victory against the Liberals who have ruled Canada for the last 20 years except for the nine months that Mr. Clark was in power. A general election has to be called within a year and a half. **********Despite this appearance of aggressive toughness, Mr. Mulroney has kept most of his options open on most issues. Like all of the other Tory candidates, he has come out for freeing and expanding the private sector of the economy, for encouraging foreign investment, for improving relations with the United States and for testing the United States cruise missile in Canada. He has also favored the reimposition of capital punishment. **********But on issues of constitutional change, in which he once differed with the Conservative provincial premiers, his position was diplomatically amorphous. Similarly, on the economy, he has stressed both job-creation and deficit-cutting. **********He explained part of the ambiguity of his responses by harking back to his experience as a labor lawyer and negotiator, saying ''You never give anything away before you sit down at the bargaining table.'' **********The key, however, to Mr. Mulroney's successful campaign was his stress on his Quebec origins and ability to speak French. A graduate of Quebec City's Laval University, Mr. Mulroney kept repeating at virtually every meeting that in Canada there are 102 federal constituencies in which at least 10 percent of the population speaks French, and that in the 1980 election Mr. Trudeau's Liberals took all but two. ''You give Pierre Trudeau a head start of 100 seats and he'll beat you 10 times out of 10,'' he said. Election Challenge Ahead **********Such statements and his claim to dent Liberal dominance in Frenchspeaking Canada may soon be tested. Mr. Mulroney, having won the party leadership, will now try to win a seat in Parliament. The Liberals, who control 74 of the 75 seats in Quebec, may force byelections in some of those seats, in effect taunting Mr. Mulroney. **********Mr. Mulroney's aides have said they would resist that temptation, preferring to run in districts of their choosing rather than in those selected by Mr. Trudeau. Mr. Mulroney, the aides suggested, will probably run in a safe Conservative district outside Quebec where a current Conservative Member of Parliament will step aside for him. **********Though he has not run for elective office, Mr. Mulroney has been active in Tory politics since his college days.  He has worked as a specialist in labor law and came to prominence as a member of a bipartisan commission in Quebec that investigated graft and corruption in the construction industry. Since 1978, he had been the president of the Iron Ore Company of Canada, where he was credited with restoring positive labor relations that led to heightened productivity and record profits.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Various Taxes On Municipals
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Various Taxes On Municipals
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.body_text: **********MANY investors in municipal bonds who buy them primarily for their exemption from Federal taxes are unaware that such bonds are nevertheless taxable in other ways. **********A major development recently in the taxation of municipal bonds - debt obligations of states, cities, authorities and other jurisdictions that are exempt from Federal income taxes by virtue of a doctrine specifically stated in the Constitution - appeared in the 1983 Social Security Act Amendments. **********These amendments will make some Social Security benefits subject to Federal income tax for the first time beginning next year. In determining whether these benefits will be taxed, tax-free interest income from bonds and other sources is included in modified adjusted gross income, with the new tax levied on those whose income exceeds certain thresholds. **********While the inclusion of municipal bond income in computing the Social Security benefits tax is new, state and local taxation of this income has long been in effect. And the degree and categories of state and local taxation can be confusing to both holders and potential holders of municipal bonds. **********Forty-four states and the District of Columbia levy some kind of tax on individual owners of municipal issues. Most states, moreover, provide at least limited advantages to in-state municipals over out-of-state bonds by wholly or partially exempting in-state bonds from state taxes. Yet the extent of state taxes is not so great as it may seem, because of the difference between the nominal tax rate and the effective tax rate. **********Take the case of state income taxes on municipal bonds. The nominal, or posted, rate is the level legislated by the state - and such maximum rates range from a low of 2.2 percent in Pennsylvania to a high of 17.6 percent in Minnesota. The effective, or actual, rate, though, is normally much lower since the real cost of these taxes is derived by allowing for the tax savings by deducting them from gross income on your Federal return. **********For example, the nominal maximum tax rate in New York State is 14 percent for annual incomes of more than $23,000, with an additional maximum of 4.3 percent in New York City for annual incomes of more than $25,000. But a taxpayer in the top 50 percent Federal income tax bracket would have an effective rate of 7 percent for state tax and 2.15 percent for city tax - a total effective tax rate of 9.15 percent. **********''The lower the Federal marginal tax bracket, the more expensive the state tax,'' said Steven J. Hueglin, executive vice president of Gabriele, Hueglin & Cashman Inc., a securities firm. ''That's because the value of your deduction is less with a lower Federal bracket.'' **********Therefore, municipal bond investors should compare the effective after-tax return on in-state bonds with the effective after-tax return on out-of- state municipals. For the advantage of purchasing in-state bonds depends principally on the weight of the state tax burden. **********''If the nominal tax rate is 10 percent or higher, it's enough of an advantage to stay with in-state bonds,'' Mr. Hueglin asserted. His reasoning is that a nominal rate of 10 percent is equivalent to an effective rate of 5 percent for someone in the 50 percent Federal tax bracket. **********Although the income tax on municipals, the annual tax on coupon return, is familiar to most persons, there are two other lesser-known kinds of taxes on these securities - those levied on personal property and those on capital gains. Personal property taxes are populist in origin and are imposed by about a dozen states, primarily in the Middle West, and excluding New York. **********Depending on the state, such a tax typically ranges from $1 to $5 for each $1,000 of par or market value. Portfolios are generally evaluated at the end of each year to calculate the amount of the tax. **********Capital gains taxes on municipals, applicable in most states, should be evaluated independently of income taxes. The tax on capital gains is paid just once when the bonds are sold or mature and is often due even in many of the states that exempt income from in-state or out-of-state bonds from state income taxes. **********Furthermore, with the maximum long-term Federal capital gains rate at 20 percent, the state capital gains tax on municipal bonds is usually at a different effective rate than the state income tax. For instance, the maximum New York State capital gains rate is 2.8 percent - 20 percent of the top 14 percent rate - and the maximum New York City capital gains rate is 0.86 percent - 20 percent of 4.3 percent. The effective tax rate on capital gains then for a New York City resident is 3.66 percent. **********''The state taxability of a municipal bond plays an important part in many investment decisions,'' Mr. Hueglin said. ''Awareness of the cost of state taxes, and of the cost of avoiding them with double- exempt bonds, is essential in today's market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON AN electrical device patented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has money-saving potential for private users. The unit, an improved power factor controller, senses the current and voltage of an operating electric motor and reduces the power input to what is actually needed to run it. **********The improvement also permits gradual motor start-ups, avoiding the wasteful surges of current that otherwise occur. **********Patent 4,404,511, issued this week, was assigned to NASA by the inventor, Frank J. Nola, a staff member at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. Patents have been applied for in 23 countries. **********A hand-held instrument that was also patented this week for NASA displays three-dimensional images created by X-rays and gamma rays. Lo I. Yin, an astrophysicist at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md., obtained patent 4,404,469 for the viewer. **********The new instrument, or camera, offers an improvement over the Lixiscope previously invented for NASA and licensed for use in industry and nuclear medicine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.main_headline: MARCOS WARNS OF TOUGH STEPS TO END CLASHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.print_headline: MARCOS WARNS OF TOUGH STEPS TO END CLASHES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would be compelled to order ''extreme measures'' if there were any resumption of the anti-Government rioting of Wednesday night and early today. **********The statement, delivered over national television, was taken as a warning that he would reimpose martial law, under which he ruled from 1972 to 1981. **********Mr. Marcos said his Government held ''the opposition and its leaders responsible for the unfortunate incidents last night and early this morning.'' According to the police, the clashes between security forces and demonstrators left 11 dead and about 200 wounded. **********Do Not Force My Hand' **********''I warn the opposition, do not force my hand,'' Mr. Marcos said in angry tones. ''Do not compel me to move into the extreme measures that you know of. If necessary, I will do so.'' **********Opposition leaders reacted angrily to the President's statements, charging that the Government had created the conditions that had led to civil disturbances. **********(In Washington, a White House official said the clashes might make it ''very difficult'' for President Reagan to proceed with his visit to the Philippines in November. But Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, said the State Department was recommending that Mr. Reagan go ahead with the trip.  He said that the Philippine civil rights situation had improved since the killing of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the opposition leader, and that there was now ''a very real amount of free speech, free press and free assembly.'' Page A8.) New Protests Planned **********Former Senator Salvador H. Laurel, leader of an opposition coalition, said demonstrations against the President would continue. Another opposition leader, former Senator Jose Diokno, said at a news conference that plans were being made for boycotts, sitdowns and civil disobedience campaigns to bring pressure on Mr. Marcos to resign. **********Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila, said in an interview that President Marcos should schedule new presidential and parliamentary elections soon as ''the only solution'' to the country's political unrest. **********In his television speech, Mr. Marcos announced a new ban on the possession of firearms outside the home, and warned that violators would be prosecuted ''to the full extent of the law.'' He said he was conferring with his military and police commanders on arming the security forces, which he said he had instructed earlier to ''exercise extreme tolerance'' in handling demonstrations, avoiding the use of guns. **********''I have ordered them to defend themselves,'' he continued, referring to forces assigned to monitoring political demonstrations in the future.   'Day of National Sorrow' **********The clashes began Wednesday night as several thousand students, armed with rocks, bottles and homemade explosive devices, attempted to march on the presidential palace after a large but peaceful rally in central Manila called to mark a ''day of national sorrow'' over the death of former Senator Aquino. He was slain Aug. 21 as he left a plane under military escort at the Manila International Airport on his return from three years of self-exile in the United States. **********''It was the first time I had seen businessmen at such a demonstration,'' Cardinal Sin said today of the rally, held in front of the central post office in Plaza Bonifacio and attended by crowds estimated to total 500,000 people. It was also an anti-Marcos event, marked by incessant shouting of slogans demanding that the President resign. **********The date, Sept. 21, was chosen for the rally because it was the 11th anniversary of the imposition of martial law by Mr. Marcos, and also a month to the day since Mr. Aquino's death. **********Opposition leaders today accused the Government security forces of unnecessarily attacking the students with clubs and then opening fire. The marchers were finally stopped a quarter of a mile from the presidential palace, but bonfires blazed in various sections of the city through the night, and there were a few separate incidents of looting and burning.   'Proper Reception' for Reagan **********''Responsibility for the violence that rocked Manila last night rests solely with the Government,'' said Mr. Diokno, leader of an opposition umbrella group called Justice for Aquino, Justice for All. **********He also said that the opposition groups planned ''a proper reception'' for President Reagan when he arrives in Manila on an Asian tour in November, but did not elaborate. Opponents of the Reagan visit have urged him not to come, arguing that his appearance would be viewed as support for Mr. Marcos and his authoritarian rule. They have also expressed fears that security measures would not be sufficient to protect the President. **********The prelate said in today's interview that new elections would be a successful antidote for the political unrest provided that they were seen to be conducted in a ''clean and honest'' manner. The first step, he said, must be to replace all the present election officials, who he said had ''lost their credibility.'' **********He also urged scrapping the present Constitution, which puts no limit on the number of six-year terms the President may serve and makes no provisions for a successor if the chief executive dies or becomes incapacitated. President Marcos has been in office since 1965; his present term ends in 1967. **********The prelate said there should be a return to the 1935 Constitution, which was drawn on the American model and provided for a vice president who would be next in line for the top office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.main_headline: FLICK TAX EXEMPTION REVOKED BY GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.print_headline: FLICK TAX EXEMPTION REVOKED BY GERMANY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.body_text: **********The West German Economics Ministry said today that it had revoked tax exemptions awarded to the Flick industrial group in 1976 and 1978 when it acquired its stake in W. R. Grace & Company of New York. The announcement widened the impact of a major investigation into influence peddling within the Government and the financing of political parties. **********The Government spokesman, Peter Boenisch, said the tax exemptions, which were granted to Flick because it reinvested in Grace the bulk of $690 million in capital gains from the sale of shares in the Daimler-Benz automobile company, were based on ''incorrect circumstances.'' **********Manfred Kiesewetter, a Flick spokesman in D"usseldorf, denied this, and said Flick would challenge the decision before an administrative court. If upheld, the decision would require Flick to pay an estimated $163 million in back taxes, in addition to possible interest payments. Tax experts estimate the entire bill could reach $254 million. **********In a statement, the ministry said Flick had received tax exemptions under German laws that permit such rulings for companies that reinvest capital gains abroad in ways ''beneficial to the national economy.'' It said Flick contended that potential close links between its subsidiaries, including the Dynamit-Nobel chemical company, and units of Grace, would favor development of Germany's energy industry. **********But the ministry said its investigation, which was begun after a study of documents supplied by the Bonn prosecutor, brought to light ''no significant cooperation in noteworthy areas or of noteworthy dimension.'' **********Sale of Grace Stake **********The prospect of heavy back taxes has raised the question of whether Flick will be forced to sell its stake in Grace to raise needed cash. Mr. Kiesewetter denied Flick had any intention of selling those stocks. **********''We would not have gone to court if we did not intend to treat Grace in the future as we treated her until now,'' Mr. Kiesewetter said. **********The Government decision is closely related to charges brought earlier this month by the Bonn prosecutor against Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff and his predecessor, Hans Friderichs, who is now chairman of the Dresdner Bank. **********The prosecutor said he had determined that to obtain tax waivers on the capital gains arising from the 1975 sale of a 29 percent interest in Daimler-Benz, Eberhard von Brauchitsch, Flick's former deputy chairman, paid Mr. Friderichs $140,740 in cash between 1975-77 and paid Mr. Lambsdorff $50,000 in 1977 and 1980. **********Mr. von Brauchitsch, who kept records of the payments, was indicted, as were Horst Ludwig Riemer, a former Free Democratic Economics Minister in North Rhine-Westphalia state, and Manfred Nemitz, another former Flick employee. **********Mr. Friderichs, as Economics Minister, allowed a tax waiver in 1976, when Flick paid about $140 million for its first stake in Grace. Mr. Lambsdorff, who became Economics Minister in 1977, granted a further concession in 1978, after Flick paid about $250 million to raise its share in Grace to 25.1 percent. Both men have denied any wrongdoing. **********Economics Ministry officials could not say how, if at all, the tax decision would affect the pending criminal case. Officials of the prosecutor's office were away from their offices for the Christmas holiday and not available for comment. **********Through subsequent acquisitions, Flick has increased its Grace holding to 13.6 million shares, or 28 percent. **********In a statement released today in D"usseldorf, Flick attributed the failure of planned projects between Grace and its other affiliates to the ''changed world economic situation, a fact that lay outside the sphere of influence of both companies, and was unforeseeable for all parties, including the ministry.'' Flick also argued that the ministry failed to meet a Nov. 30 deadline for revoking the tax exemption. **********Mr. Kiesewetter said Flick had pursued cooperative projects with Grace in coal-processing technology that the companies were forced to drop after falling oil prices made coal-derived energy products uncompetitive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/07/world.body_text: **********A British information officer admitted today that that he lost secret Government documents in a London subway train. **********Extracts from the documents, which the officer was taking to a European Economic Community meeting, were later published in a radical weekly London magazine. **********Robin Gordon Walker, 36 years old, a senior officer with the Central Office of Information, was fined the equivalent of $883 at Bow Street Magistrates' Court after admitting a violation of the Official Secrets Act. **********''It seems to me that you have been a fool rather than a knave,'' the magistrate, Ralph Lownie, told him as he passed sentence.  Mr. Gordon Walker's father, Patrick, was Foreign Secretary from October 1964 to January 1965 in the Labor Government of Harold Wilson before being raised to the peerage as Lord Gordon-Walker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.main_headline: U.S. AND GRENADA AIDES EXCHANGE TAUNTS AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.print_headline: U.S. AND GRENADA AIDES EXCHANGE TAUNTS AT U.N.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.body_text: **********A United States challenge to the credentials of Grenada's delegate in the General Assembly prompted a sharp exchange today between the American and Grenadian delegates. **********In the dispute, the Grenadian delegate, Caldwell Taylor, challenged the American to remove him from his seat physically. **********The United States representative, Jose S. Sorzano, taking the floor on a point of order, said the Governor General of Grenada, Sir Paul Scoon, has already incidated in letters and telephone calls to the United Nations that no one is now authorized to represent Grenada at the United Nations. **********''We raise a formal objection to the individual who is sitting in the seat of Grenada,'' Mr. Sorzano said.   Laughter and Applause **********A murmur of laughter and then loud applause by some of the delegates ensued as Mr. Taylor, speaking immediately after Mr. Sorzano, replied: **********''At this point I have no idea where the Governor General of our country is. I do not know if he is being held hostage. I certainly do not know that he has asked me not to sit here. And if anybody, particularly the person who spoke before me, feels like removing me from this seat, then he can do so physically.'' **********Sir Paul, in a telephone conversation last week with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar reportedly said that he had closed all of Grenada's diplomatic missions abroad and that no one was authorized to speak for Grenada at the United Nations. **********The President of General Assembly, Jorge Enrique Illueca of Panama, ruled that in accordance with United Nations practice, the Grenadian representative would be allowed to sit in the General Assembly until the credentials committee ruled on the United States challenge.   Consulted With Cubans **********Mr. Taylor, who has been the chief delegate of Grenada since December 1980, had dropped from sight for several days following the takeover of Grenada by a military council and the subsequent United States-led invasion of the island. On Thursday he reappeared at United Nations headquarters where he held consulations with members of the Cuban delegation and told a news conference that he had gone into hiding because he feared for his life. **********Despite Mr. Taylor's reappearance last week, Grenada had until today been represented by the deputy representative, Ian Jacobs. **********Last Thursday, after a United States challenge to Grenada's right to take part in Security Council debates, Mr. Jacobs, who was representing Grenada, was asked to vacate the seat pending a decision on his credentials by the United Nations legal advisor. **********The exchange today between the United States and Grenada delegations preceded a vote by the General Assembly in which five countries were elected to be nonpermament members of the Security Council. The five are Upper Volta, India, Egypt, Peru, and the Ukranian Soviet Socialist Republic. **********There are five permament members of the Council - the United States, Soviet Union, France, Britain, and China - all of whom have veto powers. In addition, there are 10 other voting members elected for five-year terms. The nonpermanent members are distributed among the major regional groups, so that the nonpermanent members of the Council always include five countries from Africa and Asia, two from Latin America, one from East Europe and two from West Europe and other states. **********The departing members of the Security Council, whose terms end on Dec. 31 this year, are Togo, Zaire, Poland, Jordan, and Guyana.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/24/busin.body_text: **********THE news took even James J.  Morgan's friends by surprise.  When the 41-year-old executive vice president for marketing at P hilip Morris Inc. announced July 8 that he was quitting to become t he new chairman and chief executive of Atari Inc., many were s tunned. ''I uttered an expletive,'' said James C. Bowling, Philip M orris's director of corporate affairs. Added William Ruder, p resident of the public relations firm that bears his name: ''I a lmost dropped dead.'' **********And, to hear him tell it, no one was more surprised than Mr.  Morgan himself. ''It was fate,'' said Mr. Morgan, who had worked at Philip Morris for 20 years, almost since the day he left Princeton.  ''I honestly believe with all the bones in my body that this is probably the only situation that could have gotten me out of Philip Morris.'' **********Indeed, his decision to make the drastic shift from cigarettes to computers is a striking one and raises the question: Can a consumer goods marketer who is successful with one product - Mr. Morgan made his mark with Marlboro, Merit and Virginia Slims cigarettes - duplicate that success with a totally different product in a completely different industry? **********Mr. Morgan, clearly, thinks he can, come Sept. 6 when he moves to Atari. ''The universal principles of marketing to the consumer far transcend individual nuances between different industries,'' said Mr. Morgan, while puffing on a Merit cigarette. ''Once the consumer has elected to use a product, it's my job to convince him to use my brand.'' **********But it is more than simply switching products. For starters, Philip Morris and Atari are vastly different companies. Philip Morris, with sales of $11.7 billion, is pure Eastern establishment. It traces its lineage to turn-of-the-century England, where a predecessor company was the tobacconist for King Edward VII. In modern times, it is credited with some of the shrewdest marketing of consumer goods, including Miller beer, Seven-Up soft drinks and a cigarette lineup that includes Marlboro, Merit, Benson & Hedges, Lark and Parliament.  It is characterized by stability and deep ranks of well-trained managers. **********Atari, on the other hand, is a California upstart. Less than a decade old, it traces its origins to a coin-operated video game called Pong. Initially run by entrepreneurs and engineers in Tshirts, Atari was once one of the fastest-growing companies in the nation, climbing to about $2 billion in sales on the crest of the video game craze. It is a company without much of a corporate heritage. **********The differences in the cultures of the two companies are striking, and Mr. Morgan is not the first person to make the transition from a consumer packaged goods company to computers. Earlier this year John Sculley moved from the presidency of Pepsico's Pepsi-Cola Company subsidiary to become Apple Computer's president and chief executive. **********But what compounds the challenge for Mr. Morgan is that he is taking over the reins of a deeply troubled company. Its breakneck growth came crashing to a halt last December as oversupply and new competition shattered the company's core home video game and home computer business. **********The company recorded stunning losses - after a record of 31 consecutive profitable quarters - and turmoil spread through management ranks. In the first quarter of 1983, Atari had an operating loss of $45.6 million, which mushroomed to $310.5 in the second quarter, a striking contrast to the $111.8 million profit it posted in the second quarter of 1982. Atari's most recent quarterly loss was cited by its parent company, Warner Communications, as the cause of its own much-larger-than-anticipated loss of $283.4 million. **********At least 1,700 manufacturing and 1,000 white-collar workers out of some 7,000 domestic employees have lost their jobs in Atari's effort to cut costs. **********In the midst of the troubles, Mr. Morgan's predecessor Raymond E.  Kassar resigned under a cloud. Mr. Kassar, who was known as a mercurial executive, is now being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission for insider trading violations after he had sold 5,000 shares in Atari's parent, Warner Communications, immediately before the announcement of a sudden earnings drop at Atari. **********Largely because of these many differences, Mr. Morgan believes that his job is cut out for him. ''My goal is to get Atari to be like Philip Morris,'' said Mr. Morgan, who works out of a modest office overlooking Grand Central Station that has few decorations except for a poster-sized photograph of Cheryl Tiegs in a Virginia Slims advertisement. ''The biggest challenge is to transfer the culture of Philip Morris into a company that got too big, too fast and hasn't yet understood how to be a big company and a successful big company.  I know how to do it. I've been part of building and executing the management philosophy here.'' **********But why would a successful executive in his prime - and one, according to all accounts, with a chance of one day heading Philip Morris - give up this stability for the turmoil and uncertainty of Atari? ''I think I reached the point in life when the idea of doing something different was compelling,'' said Mr. Morgan, a trim man with a quick smile, who nearly bursts out of his chair with his animated style of talking. IN fact, it was a decision that almost crept up on Mr. Morgan w ithout his really knowing it. ''This came right at a time that I wasm ost primed,'' he said. ''A combination of factors had happened that s et me up to take the big step.'' Among those factors, he recalled, w as that he had passed age 40, and ''I realized I was no longer in t he first half of my life,'' he said. **********And, just prior to the Atari offer, he had attended his 20th class reunion at Princeton, which gave him a chance to look at the unexpected twists and turns that the lives of others had taken. Then, one day, he heard the news that a close journalist friend had been reported killed in Central America along with two other journalists.  The news that his friend was among those killed later turned out to be unfounded, but ''I lived through the death and resurrection of a friend,'' he said. **********So, when Gerard R. Roach, chairman of the executive recruiting firm of Heidrick & Struggles, called, Mr. Morgan, who had steadfastly turned away all such recruiters, agreed to have lunch with Steven J.  Ross, Warner's chairman. ''On one hand I felt I was being very adventuresome to have lunch,'' said Mr. Morgan, ''but I was equally upset because I was cheating on the company I loved. I felt guilty.'' **********The rest happened quickly. That Wednesday lunch was followed by another the next day with Warner top executives and by Friday, Warner made an offer - for a reported $10 million over a seven-year contract. Mr. Morgan would not comment on the financial details, except to say his compensation was tied to the profits of Atari, while Mr. Roach would only say that the $10 million figure was ''conservative.'' **********Mr. Morgan, who said he owned a video game but was not familiar with computers when he was named to his new job, said he was attracted to Atari primarily for nonmonetary reasons -the strong personal chemistry he felt with Warner's top management, the chance to head a company and the numerous challenges that are inherent in trying to turn around a company with as many problems as Atari. **********''The whole thing moved like the speed of light,'' said Mr. Roach, who added that Mr. Morgan's departure ''shook Philip Morris because he had a dead shot at the top.'' Those at Philip Morris certainly agree. Said Philip Morris's Mr. Bowling, who has known Mr. Morgan since Mr. Morgan came to the company: ''This is not something we are accustomed to. We've never lost anyone.'' **********Added Kenneth S. Olshan, chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene Worldwide, the advertising agency for both Philip Morris and Atari: ''Jimmy was a lifer at Philip Morris. It took a one-in-a-million opportunity just to get him to talk.'' **********To the financial community, Mr. Morgan is an unknown and he is the subject of much speculation. ''I can't say his moving to Atari is that far-fetched,'' said Emanuel Goldman, an analyst with Montgomery Securities. ''Both are technologically driven marketing companies.  The process of cigarette making has become very high tech and Morgan's move to Atari is not that far afield from the environment he came from.'' Added Christopher Kirby, an analyst with Sanford C.  Bernstein & Company: ''The biggest thing needed at Atari is discipline. They don't know where the company is or is going. He's got to be the riveting factor for all the arms of Atari.'' **********Mr. Morgan's friends are confident he will do just that. ''Knowing Jimmy, he'll create order,'' said Mr. Olshan.  In his years at Philip Morris, Mr. Morgan rose through the ranks and ultimately was associated with some of the company's most memorable cigarette campaigns. He started as a salesman in 1963, fresh out of college with a wife and baby daughter in tow (he now has two daughters), and made his mark by becoming so well versed in sales figures that even the chairman would call him when he needed a quick statistic. He moved up to become a brand manager for various cigarettes, including Marlboro, which was by then an established product, and later assumed the top cigarette marketing position. **********He helped introduce Merit, a low-tar, full-flavored cigarette. In doing so, Philip Morris entered a market in which such cigarettes had never before delivered on their taste promises. In fact, 90 percent of the smoking public had tried - and ultimately rejected - low-tar cigarettes that promised, but failed to deliver on, their taste claims. **********''Our problem was: How do you go back to the well one more time?'' said Mr. Morgan. In the face of such deep consumer skepticism, he helped develop the ''Merit Taste Test'' campaign, in which the results of taste tests showing a preference for Merit were widely advertised. The cigarette went on to become a huge success. HE also helped mastermind the introduction of Marlboro Lights, in w hich he had to make sure that the new cigarette would not take s mokers away from regular Marlboros. The campaign - which was pitchedt o non-Marlboro smokers and stressed the differences in the c igarettes - accomplished just that. ''Our fear was that we could h ave undermined Marlboro,'' he said. **********While he said his plans for Atari are still being formulated, he already has some thoughts. After his first visit to Atari, he was surprised to find the company housed in a series of separate buildings, some 20 miles apart. His first task will be to bring management together, through daily meetings in one spot and, eventually, perhaps to build a single headquarters building. He wants to move the company more into home computers, which now represent about 21 percent of sales, as well as educational tools, and make Atari less dependent on games. which represent about 77 percent of sales. At the same time, however, he wants to retain the ''fun'' aspect that games provide and adapt this quality to a more educational setting, making these computers more ''user friendly.'' **********As his first order, he wants Atari to define exactly which businesses it is in and which it wants to be in, and he wants to provide an organizational stability so that employees can stop worrying about personnel turmoil and focus instead on the tasks at hand. And he said he will stress quality -''My goal isn't to be the biggest, it's to be the best. And if you are the best, size will take care of itself,'' he said. **********While concerned about the larger issues of Atari, he also plans to take some time out to get a personal sense of consumers' wants. He's already planning to spend about three days roaming consumer electronic stores to watch people buy home computers and listen to their thoughts. And he plans to spend a brief stint as a clerk in a computer store. He will be doing this after relocating to California from his home in Old Greenwich, Conn., where his wife and one of his daughters will remain for about a year until the daughter graduates from high school. (The older daughter is in college.) In all, Atari is providing the personal change he sought - but not without some mixed emotions. ''I'm depressed about leaving Philip Morris,'' he said. ''But I'm exhilarated with what I'm going to and that exhilaration outweighs my depression.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.main_headline: DISPUTED CITIZENSHIP LAW IN EFFECT IN BRITIAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.print_headline: DISPUTED CITIZENSHIP LAW IN EFFECT IN BRITIAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/02/world.body_text: **********Britain's Nationality Act, which creates three separate categories of British subjects, went into effect today. **********The new rules on citizenship, a principal feature of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's election platform, have been criticized by many as a racist attempt to clean up the nonwhite ''debris of empire.'' **********Home Secretary William Whitelaw said in January 1981 when the legislation was introduced in Parliament that ''we are doing nothing new in suggesting our citizenship should be given a better idea of where people actually belong.'' He called it a long-needed rationalization of the laws. But opponents called it a blunt message to nonwhites to keep out of the British mainland. **********Ends 'Right of the Soil' Tradition **********In creating the citizenship categories, the act consigns 4.5 million of Her Majesty's loyal subjects - most of them nonwhite, the majority in Hong Kong - to a limbo of citizenship without any right of living in mainland Britain. **********It also ends the seven-century-old legal tradition of ''ius soli,'' or ''right of the soil,'' by which any child born in Britain was automatically eligible for citizenship. The act replaces the old Citizenship of the United Kingdom and Colonies statute. **********The Archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, spiritual leader of the Church of England, said, ''The act will result in injustice, greatly increase the number of stateless men, women and children, create uncertainties and feelings of insecurity and exacerbate racial tensions.'' **********Under the new rules, all citizens of Britain, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man plus colonies ''closely connected'' with Britain become British citizens, with the right to live in Britain and pass this right on to their children. **********By special vote, the 1,800 residents of the Falkland Islands were included in this category after the war last summer to reclaim the colony from Argentina. In an earlier vote, Gibraltar and its 30,000 people gained the top status. **********The other two, lesser categories have no automatic right of residence.  Citizens of British Dependent Territories include 3 million people in Hong Kong, Bermuda, Belize, the British Virgin Islands and a handful of other far-flung island and Antarctic territories. **********For Hong Kong's residents, the right of moving to Britain is a crucial issue, with the lease of the New Territories from China running out in 1997 and Peking apparently determined to reclaim sovereignty. **********But those in the British Overseas Citizen category are even worse off. About 1.5 million people contained in it, mainly members of Chinese and Asian minority groups who opted for British citizenship when independence was granted to Britain's east African colonies and Malaysia, cannot pass citizenship on to their children without approval from London. Category Is 'Transitional' **********The Government says the category is ''transitional'' and is designed to be phased out. Critics call it a shabby way of cleaning up ''the debris of empire.'' **********Alex Lyon, a Member of Parliament, said it would mean that ''every black woman who has a baby is going to have to bring her status before the authorities every time she has a child.'' **********''A white woman will not be in that position,'' he said.  The original postwar citizenship law, passed in 1948, conferred citizenship on what are now some 950 million people in the entire 47-nation Commonwealth of Britain and its former colonies. **********Of the 57 million people living in Britain, 2.2 million, or about 4 percent, are nonwhite. These are mainly immigrants or descendants of the Indians, Asians, Africans and West Indians who came here during the 1950's when Britain welcomed their cheap labor. **********Since the original act, the British economy has tightened up and successive governments have eliminated residence rights for most colonials. **********For those immigrants seeking naturalized citizenship, the new law requires five years' residence and that the applicant be of good character and able to speak English.
