https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/world.body_text: **********The military Government has recently taken a series of actions against Turkish newspapers and journalists in what appears to be a tightening of press controls before parliamentary elections scheduled for November. **********Istanbul martial law authorities closed the influential conservative daily newspaper Tercuman earlier this month for an indefinite period and on Aug. 16 took the same measure against the centrist daily Milliyet, which was allowed to reappear on Saturday while court action was initiated against two columnists, Metin Toker and Teoman Erel. **********Last weekend, the Istanbul martial-law prosecutor summoned Mr. Toker and a Tercuman columnist, Nazli Ilicak, for questioning along with their respective news editors. **********Mrs. Ilicak, who spent three months in jail last fall and could face a new prison sentence because of her campaign to restore democracy in Turkey, was informed that legal proceedings had been initiated against her on charges of inciting the people to rebellion and insulting the Government, with the risk of 18 months to eight years in prison.   Criticism of Council Banned **********Mr. Toker was told that he had been called in for what was described as his infringement of a regulation barring all criticism of the decisions of the National Security Council. **********Meanwhile a columnist for the leftist daily Cumhuriyet, Oktay Akbal, began a three-month sentence in Istanbul's Sagmalcilar prison on Friday for an article published last fall entitled ''Our Duties as Citizens'' that criticized the draft constitution. Earlier this year, Cumhuriyet was shut down for three weeks and its publisher was sentenced to a four months in prison, pending an appeal. **********In another action, the martial law authorities shut down the popular political weekly Nokta last Tuesday without specifying the reason. Some Turkish journalists suggested that the probable motive for closure was a recently published interview with a leader of the conservative True Path Party, which is seen as an offshoot of former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel's prohibited Justice Party, and which has been eliminated by the military from the Nov. 6 election. **********Milliyet was closed because of a recent article by Mr. Toker that warned the military authorities that Western organizations such as the Common Market and the Council of Europe would not accept Turkey as a real democracy if the new Social Democratic Party was not allowed to take part in the forthcoming elections. Last month the Istanbul martial law prosecutor started an investigation against Mr. Toker for violating the ban on criticism of the military rulers, but later the action was dropped.   Series of Articles **********The action against Tercuman follows a series of articles by Mrs. Ilicak denouncing dictatorships and praising parliamentary democracy. ''Turkey has spent 100 years fighting for democracy. Sometimes the sun of democracy has disappeared but later reappeared because each night always comes between two days,'' Mrs. Ilicak wrote just before the paper was seized and shut down. **********In general, however, most journalists have recently appeared cautious and subdued, saying that they are waiting for the parliamentary elections and do not want to do anything that would jeopardize them. **********''We're just trying to survive,'' one well-known editor said the other day. **********The actions taken against Turkish newspapers and journalists have been criticized by the London-based International Press Institute, which has said that Turkey's international obligations required the Government ''to respect press freedom and the freedom of expression.''  Military Seizure of Power **********When Turkey's military seized power on Sept. 12, 1980, to end what it termed political chaos, it immediately abolished publications of the radical right and left and kept a close check on the rest of the press through a system of self-censorship.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********The Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that sales in the Feb. 11-20 period fell 14.2 percent from the comparable period of 1982. **********The General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation had a combined daily selling rate of 15,491, off from 18,056 a day last year. Last year's period was a time of brisk selling, spurred by a round of industrywide rebates. **********Industry analysts said that a snowstorm in the Northeast played a minor part in the sales decline, which produced the lowest sales rate for the period since 1961. And Harvey Heinbach of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith said, ''The impact of the interest-rate incentive programs is starting to wear off.'' **********New car sales, which had been climbing since mid-October, began to drop in the early February period. But with the seasonally adjusted annual selling rate currently at 5.7 million domestic units, analysts were not troubled by the latest decline. **********''Sales seem to be holding steady in the six-million-rate area, even though the recent 10-day period is a little under that,'' Mr.  Heinbach said. ''I would say they are stalled, but not getting any worse.'' **********Mr. Heinbach also said that when the interest-rate subsidy programs were introduced last fall, they drew some sales from the 1983 first quarter. **********Another analyst, Arvid Jouppi of Arvid Jouppi Associates Inc. in Detroit, said, ''We're still on the uptrend.'' But the industry is facing a new problem in the showroom, he said. The customer ''does not know whether to plan for $1-a-gallon gasoline or $2-a-gallon gas. Therefore the mix of cars available among dealers is wrong for the moment. Customers still want big cars.'' **********In the 10-day period, which had eight selling days this year and nine last year, General Motors reported sales of 76,697 new cars, or 9,587 a day, compared with 103,743, or 11,527 daily, last year, a drop of 16.8 percent. Ford dealers sold 32,396 cars, or 4,050 a day, in the latest period, down 13.6 percent from the 42,206, or 4,689 a day, in the 1982 period. **********Chrysler reported a slight increase in sales, eight-tenths of 1 percent. Early in February, Chrysler announced an incentive program, offering customers the choice between financing below market rates and a cash rebate. It helped the company sell 14,837 units in the period, a daily rate of 1,855, compared with 16,556, or 1,840 daily, last year. **********Among smaller producers, the American Motors Corporation remained a bright spot in the sales picture. An estimate of sales by that company of 4,400 units, or 550 a day, meant an 89 percent increase over last year's report of 2,615, or 291 daily. **********Volkswagen of America, despite a generous cash rebate program, said its sales fell 26.3 percent on a daily rate basis, to 1,366 units this year against 2,090 last year, or 171 a day against 232 in 1982. **********Total sales by the five major domestic manufacturers were 129,696, or 16,212 daily, off 12.7 percent from 167,210, or 18,579, last year.  In the Jan. 1 to Feb. 20 period, with 42 selling days this year and 43 last year, sales totaled 680,267, down from 677,563 a year ago.  That represented a 2.8 percent drop on a daily rate basis. **********G.M. sales in that period were 414,711, or 9,875 a day, up 2.5 percent. Ford sales were off 3.7 percent, with deliveries of 155,110, or 3,693 daily. Chrysler sales of 78,788, or 1,876 a day, were up 3.1 percent and sales at **********In the year-to-date period, G.M. held 61 percent of the domestic market, Ford 22.8 percent, Chrysler 11.6 percent, A.M.C. 3.4 percent and VW 1.2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/05/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE Transportation Department is looking **********hard for ways to allow the General Motors **********Corporation and the Ford Motor Company to avoid heavy fines for violating the Government's fuel economy standards. **********The two auto makers have said they will probably not be able to meet the requirements this year and in the next few years because their bigger models are selling unexpectedly well. Thus, the companies seem to face a choice of either restricting sales of their most profitable models or paying millions of dollars in fines. **********One idea under study at the Transportation Department is to permit the companies - G.M.'s situation is considered much worse than Ford's - to include high-mileage light trucks when calculating their status under the corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, rules. Another idea is to allow the auto makers to borrow against future credits. There is more flexibility than generally acknowledged in administering the standards, one official insists. **********The auto makers must meet a requirement this year of 26 miles per gallon, which rises to 27 m.p.g. in 1984 and 27.5 in 1985 and succeeding years. The companies are already drawing down credits earned when they substantially exceeded the standards for earlier years, but a G.M. official said last week that revised estimates for sales of big cars make it unlikely the company would be able to build up any future credits. **********The Transportation Department is eager to find a way to resolve things - short of scrapping the standards. **********The department may have another option in current law. The law gives the department the right to roll back the 27.5 m.p.g. standard to as low as 26 m.p.g., and, subject to Congressional veto, to below 26. Since the Supreme Court ruled earlier this year that the legislative veto is unconstitutional, the Administration may now have complete freedom of action. **********Payment-in-Kind Decision **********In the next few weeks the Administration must make a crucial decision on whether or not to renew the payment-in-kind crop program, under which farmers this year could obtain corn and other products from Government-controlled surpluses in return for not growing them. **********The program has proved to be a bonanza for most farmers who participated, but it is regarded by many in the Administration as a disaster. These critics complain that the idea is totally contrary to the supply-side philosophy of encouraging production rather than discouraging it. **********A month ago it was decided to renew the program for the winter wheat crop. But a general extension seems face long odds. **********The Sept. 12 crop report, an Agriculture Department official indicated, will probably put an end to the payment-in-kind program. The department estimated on Aug. 1 that this year's corn crop would be 5.2 billion bushels, but because of a drought in the primary crop states, it's now expected to be only between 4.5 billion and 4.8 billion. **********President Reagan has vetoed a bill that would have required a decision by Oct. 1, but the Administration wants to make an announcement as soon as possible, well before the Nov. 15 deadline and perhaps by early October. **********Deficits May Be LowerThis could be the month that those Federal budget deficits, far and away the biggest in history, may finally be turning down. Not much, perhaps, but turning. In its midyear review of the 1984 budget figures in July, the Reagan Administration projected a deficit for the current fiscal year of $210 billion, slightly above its January estimate of $208 billion. **********But with only September remaining in the current fiscal year, the Office of Management and Budget now thinks the figure may be more like $207 billion, largely because defense spending is a bit less than expected. The deficit should keep heading down as the recovery continues to generate new tax revenues. Next year, the Administration has predicted, the figure should drop to $180 billion. That level, however, would still be three times greater than the last deficit of the Carter Administration. **********Briefcases **********- The Occupational Safety and Health Administration says the number of its inspections climbed 14 percent, to 32,093, in the first half of the 1983 fiscal year. Inspections of high-hazard workplaces - the construction industry is the most dangerous - rose nearly 25 percent, to 27,814, it said. **********- Alice M. Rivlin, who resigned last week after eight years as the founding director of the Congressional Budget Office, has been chosen by Harvard University to give the 1984 round of Godkin lectures. Mrs. Rivlin, who is back at the Brookings Institution, as director of economic studies, says she has not yet fixed on a topic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/world.body_text: **********The commander of the northern province of Cabanas said today that ''they will have to come in here and take me out dead'' to end his rebellion against the Defense Minister. **********''We are at a critical moment,'' the commander, Lieut. Col.  Sigifredo Ochoa Perez, said in an interview at the command headquarters here. **********The 40-year old colonel, who commands 1,200 soldiers, refused to obey orders transferring him to the post of military attache at El Salvador's Embassy in Uruguay. He has demanded that the Minister of Defense, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, resign. **********Minister 'a Little Hitler' **********In an interview with reporters, Colonel Ochoa, looking tired and nervous, used strong language to describe General Garcia, calling him corrupt. ''The Minister of Defense is a little Hitler, a dictator,'' he said. **********(In San Salvador, General Garcia said that Colonel Ochoa was ''corrupted by ambition'' and that the rebellion was harming El Salvador's efforts to establish democracy, according to The Associated Press. **********(''Ochoa has forgotten that he is a military man and a soldier,'' the Defense Minister said in his first public comment on the rebellion. ''Soldiers obey orders.'' **********(He added, ''We have promoted the democratic system and now is no time for opportunistic soldiers to try to block out the efforts of the people and of an institution which under my command has begun democracy in El Salvador.'') **********Colonel Ochoa was flanked by nine soldiers carrying M-16 rifles during the interview in the office of the second in command in Sensuntepeque, 40 miles northeast of San Salvador. 'Not a Political Move' **********''They think we are making a political move, but this is not a political move,'' Colonel Ochoa said. ''Garcia is a manipulator, we are soldiers. The soldiers have asked me to stay and the people have asked me to stay.'' **********On Friday thousands of townspeople attended a rally in support of Colonel Ochoa at which he explained his reasons for not obeying the transfer orders. **********He said the Defense Minister had accused him of being aligned with both the guerrillas and the National Republican Alliance, the party of the far right known as Arena. Roberto d'Aubuisson, the president of the Constituent Assembly, is the leader of Arena. **********Colonel Ochoa said that although Mr. d'Aubuisson was a friend, he was also a ''politician'' and ''I am a soldier.'' ''I support all the parties and all the people,'' Colonel Ochoa said. ''We are not breaking with the democratic process; we are breaking with the Defense Minister.'' **********Only a few soldiers were stationed along the narrow road to Sensuntepeque Friday. One roadblock was set up before the turnoff to Cabanas and the soldiers there turned back some travelers. Beyond this roadblock, Colonel Ochoa's men had set up two others and were searching buses before they passed through. **********Colonel Ochoa said today that he was in contact with Colonel Adolfo Blandon, a representative of the military high command who spent two hours with him Friday in Sensuntepeque, but that the colonel had not offered any solution. He added that he had called Col. Jose Domingo Monterrosa of the Atlacatl Battalion in San Salvador and that the colonel had said he would remain neutral. **********Colonel Ochoa also said that the Air Force commander, Col. Juan Rafael Bustillo, had expressed his support.  Colonel Bustillo could not be reached for comment. **********As Colonel Ochoa talked, more than 700 peasants from the province were being bused in a group to a rally in the town square. People Express Support **********Some carried signs saying their city or party supported Ochoa. ''He has the support from the biggest man here to the littlest,'' said Luis Hernandez Segovia, a 44-year-old farmer. **********As Colonel Ochoa walked out to the square, the crowd began to chant: ''Ochoa! Ochoa! Ochoa!'' The colonel spoke to the crowd for about 10 minutes, reaffirming his intention to remain in Cabanas. ''I want to stay here to help the people of Cabanas,'' he said. ''I have received calls from members of the armed forces and I have their support.'' **********The farmers of the province, who help Colonel Ochoa's troops by forming civil defense units, have not been bothered by the guerrillas since June, and most interviewed said they supported the colonel.  Colonel Ochoa said about 800 peasants participated in the local defense units. 'All Happy With Him' **********''We are all happy with him,'' said Rosa Amana. As the people heard her talking to a reporter they began to gather around and nod as the 78-year-old woman said that she only wanted Colonel Ochoa to protect Cabanas. **********Some people in Sensuntepeque were unhappy with the standoff between Colonel Ochoa and the military command. ''These colonels are just substituting one power for another,'' said a young supermarket worker who said she attends college in San Salvador. ''We are the ones that are left here, we are the ones that end up getting killed.'' **********Colonel Ochoa, who has been critical of the American military advisers in El Salvador, said he wanted the people of the United States to ''understand that our struggle is against the Minister of Defense.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/busin.body_text: **********Air Florida System Inc. has announced that it had a deficit of $29.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1982, compared with a loss of $19.3 million in the fourth quarter of the preceding year. **********Operating revenues dropped 26.5 percent, to $50.1 million, from $68.2 million. **********The Miami-based company said that it had a loss of $93.4 million for the full year, compared with a deficit of $5.9 million in 1981.  Revenues declined 7.1 percent, to $281.8 million, from $303.3 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/busin.main_headline: CABLE CATALYST: JANE DEKNATEL THE IN-HOUSE MOVIE MAKER AT HBO
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/busin.print_headline: CABLE CATALYST: JANE DEKNATEL THE IN-HOUSE MOVIE MAKER AT HBO
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/26/busin.body_text: **********JANE DEKNATEL is under siege, Hollywood-style. Her modest Century City office in central Los A ngeles is bombarded by scripts and movie ideas from producers and w ould-be producers. She ''takes'' endless meetings, interrupting themf or telephone calls from the other coast, Europe and Australia. **********The reason for Mrs. Deknatel's popularity is that she has some $85 million to spend next year on a new category of entertainment: the made-for-pay-TV movie. **********Mrs. Deknatel is the 40-year-old vice president of made-for-pay motion pictures at Home Box Office, which, with 12 million subscribers, is the largest single cable channel and the most aggressive new force in entertainment. Established in 1981, HBO Premiere Films, as the new venture is called, has already underwritten a handful of movies. **********The first, ''The Terry Fox Story,'' about the young Canadian who lost a leg to cancer and then tried to run cross-country to raise money for cancer research, was shown on HBO last month to a sizable audience. The Time Inc. subsidiary plans to bankroll some 24 films next year that will be shown in the United States exclusively on HBO. **********''We'll wait to see how successful they are,'' said Mrs. Deknatel in a recent interview. ''Within the next four or five years, it might be possible to do about 50 a year.'' **********Last week, HBO Premiere Films' ambitions got an important boost when Metromedia, one of the nation's fastest-growing broadcast companies, agreed to acquire at least eight of the films HBO makes over the next two years, and to assist in future productions. The arrangement, which will give Metromedia films to run on a movie network of independent television stations that it hopes to link up by January, should increase Mrs. Deknatel's already substantial budget while reducing the venture's risk. **********At first glance, the British-born Mrs. Deknatel would seem to be something of an anomaly in Los Angeles's gaudy show business world.  Attractive and well-spoken, she presents a marked contrast to the fast-talking New Yorkers who often seem to populate Hollywood. **********But in fact, Mrs. Deknatel's quiet determination also made her something of an anomaly in Britain when she was growing up. The daughter of a trade union organizer, she left Britain 19 years ago because ''there were very few opportunities for a woman in the U.K.  in 1964,'' she said. Some friends sacrificed their careers and ''I wasn't about to have that happen to me.'' Divorced, she has two daughters, aged 11 and 13. **********In the United States, she worked in international management consulting and acquired a master's degree in business administration from Simmons College in Boston. Her first job in the entertainment industry was as a speechwriter for CBS in New York. But the jobs became increasingly high-powered: director of docu-drama for the CBS Broadcast group in Los Angeles, then vice president of NBC's movies and mini-series operation. Before joining HBO in 1981, she was in charge of developing and producing television and feature films for David Susskind. **********''She's a very talented lady,'' said Michael Fuchs, who is president of the HBO Entertainment Group and who hired Mrs. Deknatel. ''In a town that sometimes has a different set of values, she's direct, straightforward and all business. Once we choose a project, no one works harder than Jane.'' **********By underwriting its own movies, HBO is following the lead taken by the television networks in 1969 when, after relying heavily on studio features, they introduced the made-for-television movie. Since then, the television movie has become a network standard, often costing less and getting better ratings than Hollywood's fare. **********HBO dismisses the possibility that, like the television networks, it will eventually replace most of Hollywood's movies with its own.  ''We've always felt that you can't replace the big, pre-sold movies,'' said Mr. Fuchs. Still, he added, ''there's not too many movies out there. To fill our time, we have had to buy a certain amount of product that we've not always been proud of.'' As a result, he said, if HBO Premiere Films proves successful, ''we will buy less'' from Hollywood. **********Showtime, the runner-up to HBO, is making made-for-pay-television movies, too, but with a difference. ''Basically, they serve as pilots,'' said Jim Miller, vice president of Showtime's program planning and feature films. Showtime hopes to underwrite films from which a character or two can be spun off as the basis of several more 90-minute films. ''Continuing characters will be very important for pay television,'' said Mr. Miller. Nonetheless, he added, ''we're not ruling out a one-shot, HBO-type project, if it were right.'' **********To a large degree, what distinguishes the made-for-pay-TV movie from the television movie and the theatrical film is its price tag.  The production of the average theatrical film currently exceeds $12 million, and takes two months or more. By contrast, the television networks allocate about $2 million, and three weeks, to cobble together a movie. The made-for-HBO movie costs about $4 million, and is produced in about a month. **********''Our movies can't look like movies-of-the-week,'' said Mrs.  Deknatel. Nor should they sound like television movies, which are designed mainly to lead into and out of commercials. With longer scenes and more complex dialogue, HBO movies will more nearly resemble theatrical films, she said. BUT the resemblance can go only so far. Financially, Mrs. Deknatel c onceded, ''we can't compete with the major features. We can't afforda Robert Redford or a Goldie Hawn,'' or the special effects of a ' 'Close Encounters of the Third Kind.'' The stars bought by HBO also t end to be slightly less glittery: Elizabeth Taylor and Carol B urnett in ''Between Friends,'' a story of two middle-aged divorced w omen; Bette Davis and James Stewart in ''Right of Way,'' about an e lderly couple threatened by illness, and Jodi Foster in ''The Blood o f Others,'' a dramatization of the Simone de Beauvoir novel. **********The subjects tread a line somewhere between the topicality of television movies and the broader themes of feature films. ''We deal with subjects that aren't subjects of the moment,'' said Mrs.  Deknatel. The reason is partly pragmatic: While a network movie is likely to be retired after it is shown twice in one year, HBO expects to run each of its movies repeatedly over a five-year period. Thus, ''they have to stand up,'' she said. Furthermore, HBO must choose subjects and treatments that differentiate it from free television and justify its fee. **********Accordingly, the subject of rape -which sometimes appears to be the theme of the movie-of-almost-any-week - will be shunned. But incest, a subject still too sensitive for most television programmers, may appear in the HBO lineup. ''We'll handle subjects that the networks won't touch because they are pleasing their constitutents - advertisers as well as viewers,'' Mrs. Deknatel said. **********Still, it might be argued that many of the HBO movie storylines sound suspiciously like movies-of-the-week. Initial reactions to the Terry Fox project were ''it's another disease-of-the-week,'' Mrs.  Deknatel recalled. But she defends it, noting that it contains ''some fairly grueling moments in the cancer ward'' that a television movie would have omitted. **********Similarly, ''Between Friends'' presents another popular TV-movie theme, divorce. But the actual subject, Mrs. Deknatel said, is the developing friendship of two mature women - the sort of theme and characters that are rarely examined by either Hollywood or the networks. ''Most people in television don't admit that people over 50 exist,'' she said, ''while theatrical films, generally, are made for teen-agers.'' **********At this point, HBO maintains, it has no plans to acquire the films it bankrolls. ''It's not a little movie company,'' said Mr. Fuchs.  ''We're licensing them, just the way ABC licensed 'Winds of War' from Paramount.'' But HBO is usually the largest investor in each project, contributing between 50 and 80 percent of production costs and, depending on the size of its investment, sometimes has broader distribution rights. And ''we have full creative control,'' said Mrs. Deknatel. She and her staff look at the daily rushes and the various cuts of a film as it is edited. **********The remaining financing comes mainly from abroad, an unusual source for American television networks. Because most of the films are expected to be exhibited in theaters outside the United States, the ventures have attracted foreign broadcasting companies and venture capitalists interested in box-office revenues. Among the investors, for example, is Goldcrest, the British company that helped finance ''Chariots of Fire'' and ''Gandhi.'' Goldcrest will own, and probably release in cinemas overseas, ''The Far Pavilions,'' a miniseries starring Ben Cross and Amy Irving. In this country, it will appear only on HBO. **********Under current arrangements, HBO will have no share of cinema grosses overseas. Its real interest, however, is in expanding and maintaining its market share in the United States. If the made-forpay-television movies are good, Mrs. Deknatel said, ''it will be another reason to buy HBO.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/busin.body_text: **********IN 1962, a California woman bought a picture at a garage sale for $ 4, largely because she liked the frame. Last month the picture was a uctioned by Sotheby Parke Bernet for $57,750. At the same auction, a school district in Seneca Falls, N.Y., collected $286,000 for a p icture that a janitor had been told to throw away 25 years ago but c hose to save. **********Such stories only fuel visions of converting household heirlooms and pieces of art into piles of cash. But most people do not even know how to attempt such conversions. They are familiar with the low end of the collecting market - the world of garage sales and notices on supermarket bulletin boards. And most people have read about the upper end, where vast collections of old masters are sold for six and seven figures. **********But what if you think the silver teapot your great aunt left you warrants more than a tag sale, yet is unlikely to interest Sotheby Parke Bernet or Christie's? There are mechanisms for selling a range of items of more than utilitarian value. There are not only broad resale markets for art, antiques and jewelry, but also for rare books, rugs and carpets, fine wines, classic cars and a vast assortment of memorabilia and collectibles. **********If you think you've got something of value and want to sell it, the first step is to get it appraised. Indeed, obscure and subtle distinctions - the upside-down number on a postage stamp, for example -may give items added value, but only in the right marketplace. ''The essential and pivotal issue is to know what you have before you begin attempting to sell it,'' says Victor Wiener, executive director of the Appraisers Association of America.  Appraisers, who can estimate the market value of nearly anything, are listed in most local Yellow Pages. Moreover, Mr. Wiener's organization, and other appraisers' groups, will provide names of appraisers classified by locality and specialties. **********As an alternative to paying an appraiser, many auction houses and art dealers will provide a free appraisal. Sotheby Parke Bernet, for example, has experts in 50 areas who will appraise anything within those areas brought into the company's Manhattan headquarters. They will also appraise something if you send in a picture, a good description of the item and what you know of its history. **********Once an appraisal is completed, an item's owners may find big surprises - or disappointments. ''It's a wonderful fantasy, but one doesn't usually have a Rembrandt in the attic,'' says Arnold Glimcher, president of the Pace Gallery in New York City. **********If your items are indeed worth something, and you decide to sell them, there are three main alternatives: offer them to a dealer, sell them to collectors or go to an auction house. **********In looking for a dealer, pay attention to specialties. If you have pictures to sell, don't just go to an art gallery; find one specializing in what you've got - etchings or lithographs, Impressionists or Surrealists, etc. If you can't find one by asking around, ''call the Art Dealers Association of America to see who handles what you have,'' says Mr. Glimcher, a member of the organization's board. Similarly, you should go to an antique dealer specializing in the period or kind of item that you want to sell. **********Going in armed with an appraisal gives you some sense of what your item is worth, but it's definitely a negotiating situation. The appraisal is an estimate of what the dealer could sell your item for, but the dealer is going to offer considerably less than what he can get for the item. **********If you do not like the offers you get, a dealer may take an item on consignment. In that case, ''when he sells it you'll get the selling price, minus a 10 or 15 or 20 percent commission, depending on the dealer,'' says Mr. Glimcher. Over all, he notes, ''You may get more by selling on consignment than through an outright purchase,'' but because it may take time to find a buyer, he warns that ''you may have to wait several months for the money.'' **********A second way to sell an item is to go directly to collectors. This works best with memorabilia and collectibles, where dealers are less institutionalized. If you have clay crocks, postcards or old baseball cards, you may be able to sell them at gatherings of collectors or through newsletters. But if you are an outsider in the arcane world of collectibles, ''it's not always easy to understand the nuances of the market,'' says David S. Cohen, who buys and sells stamps from his Wisconsin home through advertisements in stamp publications. **********A third alternative is to use an auction house. The pre-eminent names in the fields are Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's. ''Our specialty is the upper end of the market,'' says Sotheby's deputy public relations director, Lyn Snodden, but ''we have things here that sell for less than $1,000.'' In deciding what to accept, Beverly Miller, Sotheby's fine arts representative, says, ''It's hard to put a dollar amount on it. We use our own discretion.'' But art dealers say an item must usually be worth well into four figures for major houses to take it seriously. PAINTINGS likely to fetch $1,000 to $1,500 and other small-ticket i tems are sold in ''Arcade Auctions'' at Sotheby's. These are held ont he ground floor at the same time that similar, bigger-ticket, items a re sold upstairs. But Miss Snodden says these clients still benefit f rom ''an extensive worldwide marketing effort,'' a catalogue and thec achet of the houses. Of course, you pay for this. **********How much? ''As a general rule of thumb,'' says Miss Snodden, ''the consigner is charged 10 percent of the hammer price for anything sold for more than $3,000. For less than $3,000, we would charge 15 percent.'' If the item doesn't sell, Sotheby's still charges 5 percent of the ''reserve'' - the minimum price that the seller and Sotheby's agreed to accept. ''The minimum for anything that doesn't sell is $50,'' she adds, and in addition to the commissions, there is a minimum handling charge of $80. **********There are, of course, local auction houses that tend to have narrower specialties or a smaller customer base. Mr. Glimcher says many of these ''are excellent for less noticeable items.'' **********How do you choose between local and national auction houses? ''If you're dealing with middling items, it's probably not worth your while to send them off to New York,'' says Mr. Wiener of the appraisers' group, but ''important collections deserve a national house. You rarely read about astronomical prices reached in local settings.'' **********The channels you choose for cashing in on your valuables depend on how fast you want the cash and how much you want to involve yourself in the selling. But there are markets for a surprising range of things, and if you've been brooding about treasures buried in your basement, Lyn Snodden says, ''Let the marketplace decide what it's really worth.''  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Harvey D. Shapiro is a New York writer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia has begun an intensive series of consultations with neighboring Arab countries aimed at laying the groundwork for a meeting of their top leaders next month. **********Western and Saudi officials said in interviews this week that the prospects for a 14th Arab summit meeting depended to a large extent on whether Saudi Arabia and its representatives could resolve the most bitter policy and personality disputes among key Arab participants. **********The Saudi Press Agency reported Tuesday that King Fahd met with his Cabinet on Monday to discuss preparations for a meeting that the agency said was scheduled to be held here in November. King Fahd was quoted last week as saying that the aim of the meeting was to unify Arab ranks, and that it could be held at any time. **********But Western diplomats here said they doubted that a meeting would take place unless progress was made soon in mending some of the myriad rifts within the Arab world.   Saudis Seeking Consensus **********The agenda at such a meeting would be long and would contain potentially divisive topics, one diplomat said. The Saudis are seeking political consensus, he noted, and if it is not there they may well decide that this is not a suitable time for such a gathering. **********The Saudis have placed special emphasis on easing the differences between Syria and Iraq, which are ruled by rival factions of the Baath Party. **********Specifically, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and other Persian Gulf countries have tried in recent weeks to persuade Syria to prevent an intensification of the war between Iran and Iraq by reopening a pipeline that once carried Iraqi oil across Syrian territory to the Mediterranean. Such a move would enable Iraq to more than double its oil exports, which have fallen sharply because of the war to about 700,000 barrels a day. **********Iranian oil exports, by contrast, are estimated at 1.8 million barrels a day, and Iraq has warned that it considers this situation unacceptable.   Oil Installations Threatened **********The Gulf countries have argued that a reopening of the pipeline could persuade Iraq not to use French-built Super Etendard jets armed with Exocet missiles to strike at oil installations in Iran. **********Syria is said to be studying the proposal, but diplomats here said they doubted it would make such a concession. Damascus has consistently backed Iran during the war, which is now entering its fourth year. **********In addition, diplomats said, there are deep ideological divisions between President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, as well as longstanding personal enmity. **********The divisions in the Arab world over the Iranian-Iraqi war were further underscored by a report today that the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, had said his Government would ''not stand idly by'' if Iran blocked shipping in the Gulf.   Interview Published in Kuwait **********In an interview published today in the Kuwaiti newspaper Al-Siyasa and quoted by United Press International, Mr. Mubarak reportedly said that ''if Iran carries out its threats to attack the Gulf ports or close the Hormuz Strait, the situation will require us to revise our stand in consultation with political leaderships in the region.'' **********Along with the pipeline issue and the Iranian-Iraqi war, an Arab meeting would have to address the situation in Lebanon, officials said. **********The Lebanese President, Amin Gemayel, has demanded the withdrawal from his country of all foreign forces - Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian. Although Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states have supported his position, Syria, according to Western diplomats, feels that the balance of power is in its favor and has refused. **********Syria has been highly critical of the agreement the Lebanese Government signed with Israel on May 17, calling for withdrawal of all Israeli forces if Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization will also pull out. Hence, consensus on Lebanon is unlikely, diplomats said.   P.L.O. Split Would Be Issue **********Another potentially divisive issue at any meeting would be the split within the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********Farouk Kaddoumi, the head of the P.L.O.'s political department, who remains loyal to Yasir Arafat, the chairman, said Tuesday that Mr. Arafat was seeking by all possible means to normalize relations with Syria. But Libya and Iran are said to be supporting a rebel faction in Damascus that has gained considerable strength of late.  Finally, officials said, the Arab countries would have to take up the overall Middle East peace process, yet another potential source of disunity. **********Syria and several other Arab states have been critical of a peace plan put forward by President Reagan a year ago, while Saudi officials have continued to express some support for the American approach.   Arab Plan Adopted **********At their meeting last September in Fez, Morocco, Arab leaders adopted an eight-point peace plan similar to one proposed the year before by King Fahd, who was Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince at the time. **********One Western diplomat said that Saudi Arabia's failure to win support for its plan at the 1981 meeting had made it more reluctant to proceed with pan-Arab meetings in the absence of political consensus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.print_headline: IRAN'S NEW ATTACK: LITTLE ROOM FOR FLAIR; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.body_text: **********Iran, which began an offensive against Iraq on Sunday, has shown ''little imagination'' in its attacks so far, according to a report from a Western military observer in Iraq. **********Western intelligence officials in the United States and at North Atlantic Treaty Organization headquarters in Belgium say the Iranians have been using weapons bought in Eastern Europe and North Korea as well as tanks and artillery salvaged from the defeats of last summer and autumn. The officials say Iraq remains superior in weapons despite Iran's effort to narrow the gap. **********The analysts say Iran's major problem is having opened the offensive at one of the strongest points on the Iraqi front: the battleground on the frontier of Iraq's Missan province west of the Iranian town of Dizful. **********One intelligence source suggested that this familiar and unprofitable battle plan was the result of a compromise between the two rival elements in the Iranian high command. One represents the remains of the old imperial army, the other the newly made officers of the Revolutionary Guards. **********In any event, these officials said, Iran is running out of choices. The area south of the present front is marshy and unsuitable to tracked or wheeled vehicles. Since last summer, the Basra position near the Persian Gulf, already strong, has been reinforced. Any offensive further north and closer to Baghdad would suffer from the absence of suitable roads on the Iranian side. **********The Iraqis, fighting on their own soil, have the advantage of a network of subsidiary roads, some newly built, over which reinforcements can be moved to meet Iranian offensives. What Faces the Iranians **********Intelligence officials in this country and abroad agree that Iran's only choice, given its resources, is a campaign of attrition to inflict serious casualities and encourage a revolutionary movement in Iraq. **********The officials say that to attack Iraq's extremely strong positions in the area, the Iranians, moving from a hilly area, have to cross a treeless plain and attack two lines of entrenched infantry supported by dug-in tanks, artillery and short-range surface missiles. **********A third line, built by bulldozers and hundreds of soldiers, lies just to the rear.  The officials say the Iranians will have to break through all three lines before they are within reach of their main objective.  This is believed to be the main eastern highway running from Basra to Baghdad. At the northern end of the offensive, which opened on an 18-mile front, the Iranians would be about 20 miles from the highway. **********The significance of the operation has been obscured by the extravagant claims made by both sides. Western military attaches in Baghdad know the general scope of the offensive but have not been permitted to visit the battle zone. High Casualty Reports **********Iran's claims to have retaken 60 square miles of territory in Missan and to have killed or wounded more than 5,000 Iraqi troops are viewed with considerable reserve by intelligence sources. These sources are equally dubious about Iraq's claims to have killed 3,200 Iranians, although some pointed out that, fighting from strong defensive positions, the Iraqis probably inflicted heavy casualties on the Iranians, who attacked without significant air support. **********Ever since last summer, when five major Iranian attacks on Basra were repulsed with heavy losses in men and materiel, Teheran has been buying weapons wherever it can. A NATO report said weapons were bought from Eastern Europe and North Korea, and in both cases the weapons were old. In addition they have to be fed into an army and air force trained largely on American-made weapons. The problem of maintaining a half dozen types of weapons systems from East and West must be ''horrendous,'' one American intelligence source commented. The Balance in the Air **********The Iranians have had some success, this source noted, in restoring tanks and artillery damaged early in the war. They have not been as successful in repairing aircraft or finding spare parts for the American F-4's and F-14's that were the air force's cutting edge at the start of the war. **********Estimates of the number of Iranian aircraft now operational vary from 40 to 50. The Iraqis are superior in numbers and, today, in pilot training, but intelligence sources noted that their planes had stayed well away from targets guarded by the American Improved Hawk missile. These targets include Teheran, Isfahan and Qum. **********Cutting the north-south highway would be a tactical setback to Iraq, intelligence officials said, but it would not knock the country out of the war. The western Basra-Baghdad highway would then have to absorb much of the heavy traffic moving from the southern cities north and this would increase Iraq's logistical problems. **********The outlook, however, is for more Iranian offensives in the area west and southwest of Dizful. ''It's not much of an option,'' one source said, ''but it's the only game in town.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/busin.body_text: **********-Point, to 12 1/2% **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) - The Department of Housing and Urban Development today announced a drop of one-half percentage point in the interest rate on mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration, to 12 1/2 percent. A similar reduction was announced by the Veterans Administration for V.A.- guaranteed loans. **********Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, cited ''improved market conditions'' for lowering the rate from 13 percent. The rate was last changed in August, when it was reduced from 13 1/2 percent. **********Contributing to the housing market's generally more positive mood, Mr. Pierce added, is ''the spreading conviction that interest rates may have already hit their 1983 peaks and that the trend for at least the remainder of this year will be downward.'' **********Housing mortgage rates generally follow the trend of yields on Treasury bonds, which have declined since their peaks of early August. **********The Secretary said he was especially pleased that the F.H.A. rate could be dropped because it opens the opportunity for home ownership to more families. **********W. Calvert Brand, general deputy assistant secretary for housing, noted that H.U.D.'s latest weekly poll of the 30 largest mortgage banking companies found that the points being charged by lenders to make F.H.A.- backed loans at the current level was 2.12 points for level-payment loans, with some mortgage bankers charging as little as one-half point.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.main_headline: DR. PEPPER BIDDING RAISED BY DPCC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.print_headline: DR. PEPPER BIDDING RAISED BY DPCC
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The DPCC Acquisition Corporation, an investment group that includes Castle & Cooke Inc., yesterday increased the bidding for the Dr Pepper Company by offering $560 million, or about $24 a share, through a leveraged buyout. **********The offer tops the bid of $512.5 million, or $22 a share, that was made last month by Forstmann Little & Company and members of Dr Pepper's own management. **********Forstmann Little is a Wall Street firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts. The soft-drink company and Forstmann Little signed a definitive merger agreement on Sunday. **********Castle & Cooke, based in Honolulu, is a food, real estate and manufacturing concern. **********''Unlike the earlier deal, this does not sound like a friendly offer,'' said Emmanuel Goldman, a beverage analyst for Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''The pivotal factor in this bid is Ian Wilson, and his extensive knowledge of the soft-drink industry.'' **********Mr. Wilson, a former top executive at the Coca-Cola Company, joined Castle & Cooke last March as chief executive officer. **********Reached by telephone at his home in New York, Theodore Forstmann, a principal at Forstmann Little, would not comment on the new offer. Officials at Dr Pepper could not be reached for comment. **********The new offer was made after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Dr Pepper's stock yesterday rose 37 1/2 cents, to $21.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.main_headline: A NOVICE IN JOBS, HE IS A QUICK LEARNER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.print_headline: A NOVICE IN JOBS, HE IS A QUICK LEARNER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/world.body_text: **********When the Senate Foreign Relations Committee held hearings in 1981 to confirm William P. Clark in the second ranking post at the State Department, his ignorance startled even supporters of the new Reagan Administration. **********Mr. Clark could not name the heads of government of South Africa or Zimbabwe, said he knew little about developments in the British Labor Party and could offer no information on European reaction to the proposed deployment of nuclear missiles. **********Less than three years later, even critics of the self-proclaimed foreign policy novice regard him as the most influential foreign-policy figure in the Reagan Administration. **********In his posts - first as Deputy Secretary of State and then as the President's national security adviser - Mr. Clark has earned a reputation as a ''quick study'' and has become the chief instrument for insuring a hard line in foreign policy. **********To Learn Field in a Hurry **********Once again Mr. Clark, who was nominated yesterday to replace James Watt as Secretary of the Interior, will have to learn a new field in a hurry. He has little more background in interior policy than he did in foreign policy at the time of the Senate hearings.  A fifth-generation Californian, William Patrick Clark was born in Oxnard on Oct. 23, 1931. Although his Roman Catholic family was well off, he worked as a youth, helping to support himself as a ranch-hand, house painter and athletic coach. **********In high school, he was a good student and popular football player who did well enough to get accepted at Stanford University. But the school's elite social scene and academic competition did not agree with the quiet student working his way through college. **********For the next two decades he tried a variety of occupations. He studied for the priesthood at the Augustinian Novitiate in New Hamburg, N.Y. Then he returned to California, working as an insurance adjuster during the day and studying law at night. In 1958 he was admitted to the California Bar. **********Returning to Oxnard, Mr. Clark was active in the family-owned Clark Land and Cattle Company of Ventura County, serving as president from 1963 to 1973. He also helped found the law firm of Clark, Cole & Fairfield. **********Although his family had been prominent on behalf of the Democratic Party, Mr. Clark switched parties in the mid-60's and headed Ronald Reagan's gubernatorial campaign in Ventura County. **********After the election, Mr. Reagan called on the 35-year-old lawyer to join him in Sacramento. Mr. Clark first served as Cabinet secretary, coordinating state agencies, and later as executive secretary. **********Beginning in 1969, Mr. Reagan appointed Mr. Clark to a series of seats on the California bench, each time dismaying the legal establishment, which regarded him as unqualified. **********When Mr. Reagan won the Presidency in 1980, Mr. Clark was sounded out by the transition team as a possible candidate for several appointments, including those of Secretary of Agriculture, Attorney General and director of the Central Intelligence Agency. **********He declined all the offers. But after being pressed, he agreed to serve as the President's eyes and ears at the State Department. The announcement of his appointment unleashed another storm of controversy, which was exacerbated by his assertions of ignorance about foreign affairs. **********But as Deputy Secretary he impressed colleagues by working 15-hour days and spending little time with his wife, the former Joan M. Brauner, and their five children. He soon earned a reputation as an effective student of diplomacy. **********By early last year, when Mr. Reagan called on him to replace Richard V. Allen as national security adviser, Mr. Clark had proved himself adept enough in foreign policy that the move was generally applauded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.main_headline: U.S. POSITIONING 2,000 MARINES OFF BEIRUT COAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.print_headline: U.S. POSITIONING 2,000 MARINES OFF BEIRUT COAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/world.body_text: **********President Reagan today ordered a 2,000-member Marine force into the Mediterranean to position itself off Beirut so ''that all necessary measures'' could be taken to ''assure the safety'' of the 1,370 marines already on shore. **********Pentagon officials said the additional marine contingent would sail Friday from Mombasa, Kenya, and anchor off Lebanon in about a week. The officials said there were no plans now to send the additional marines ashore. **********The announcement of the President's decision was made in California, where Mr. Reagan is vacationing, by Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman. It came during a week when two marines were killed and 14 wounded in Beirut as leftist Moslem militiamen battled the Lebanese Army. **********While the army succeeded on Wednesday in taking control of major points of West Beirut from the militiamen, reports from Lebanon said fighting continued today as soldiers hunted snipers still in place on roofs and in buildings. **********There was scattered shelling of Christian East Beirut areas by militia men in the hills, and shells reportedly landed in suburban Yarze near the residence of the American Ambassador, Robert S. Dillon, and on the grounds of the nearby Lebanese Defense Ministry. No casualties were reported.  Mr. Speakes told reporters that the President had directed ''that all necessary measures be taken to assure the safety of the marines in Beirut, including the deployment of an additional naval amphibious force in the Mediterranean.'' He said Mr. Reagan had also directed that the aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower, which is already in the Mediterranean, remain off Beirut ''for an undetermined period of time, ready to assist our forces as needed.'' **********The President's action affirmed the Administration's commitment to support the fragile Lebanese Government of President Amin Gemayel as some members of Congress are questioning keeping the marines in Beirut now that they have been fired upon. **********''We are involved in Lebanon,'' Mr. Speakes said, ''because our effort is indispensable to the sovereignty and integrity of that country and to the Government's ability to restore order and stability throughout its territory.'' **********The 2,000-member Marine contingent is from the 31st Marine Amphibious Unit, which is based in Hawaii. Officials here said the unit includes the amphibious assault ship Tarawa, the amphibious transport ship Duluth and the tank landing ship Frederick. **********There is growing sentiment in Congress that Mr. Reagan should declare that the marines in Beirut are in imminent danger of hostilities. Mr. Reagan declined to do this in a message to Congress on Tuesday.   The Role of the Marines **********Such a declaration, under the War Powers Resolution of 1973, would require the President to withdraw the marines within 90 days unless Congress approved keeping them in Lebanon. **********Administration officials and some diplomats say the marines, who are part of a multinational force that also includes French, Italian and British troops, are essential to enhancing the Gemayel Government's attempts to create a central authority that would bring cohesion to the conflicting factions of Lebanon. **********Critics of the American presence in Beirut say the precarious relative calm that prevailed in Lebanon in recent months - despite attacks and killings in the Shuf Mountains, the Bekaa, the city of Tripoli in the north and in towns and villages in the south - is fast dissolving and that the United States should cut loose from involvement in any major new civil strife. **********The first contingent of marines arrived in Beirut on Aug. 25, 1982, and stayed 16 days to help oversee the withdrawal of Palestinian fighters from West Beirut. **********On Sept. 29, 1982, marines arrived in Beirut again, this time after the assassination of President-elect Bashir Gemayel and after the massacre of hundreds of Palestinian civilians by Phalangist Christian militiamen in the refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila.   A Brief Honeymoon **********Amin Gemayel, a Maronite Christian, came to power after his brother's death and some cooperation came from Moslem Lebanese leaders and from Palestinians who were fearful of their fate in the divided country. **********In West Beirut, Lebanese Moslem leaders muted public criticism of the fact that a minority, the Lebanese Christians, was in control of the new attempt to create a central government. But the discontent was never far below the surface and last December, in a rare street protest, both Sunni and Shiite Moslems, by no means generally united, marched through the streets together. **********Threat to Marines Voiced **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 1 (AP) - Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, said today that his forces would attack the marines and other members of the multinational peacekeeping force ''unless they remain neutral'' in the Lebanese crisis. **********In remarks to reporters in Damascus, Syria, Mr. Jumblat accused the marines of siding with the Christian- dominated Lebanese Army. **********''The mere fact that they are providing the Lebanese factional army with logistic support, expertise and training is enough for us to consider them enemies,'' the Druse leader said. **********Nabih Berri, head of the Shiite Moslems' Amal militia, said in a separate statement that the marines had ''turned into a fighting force against Moslems in Lebanon.'' **********United States spokesmen say the marines fired only on Shiite and Druse gun positions that attacked them in the fighting this week. **********Both Mr. Jumblat and Mr. Berri rejected President Amin Gemayel's invitation to join him and nine other political leaders in talks on national reconciliation. **********Mr. Jumblat said two other anti-Gemayel leaders - former President Suleiman Franjieh, a Christian, and former Prime Minister Rashid Karami - agreed with his position on talks. The Druse leader said also his Progressive Socialist Party considered itself in a ''state of war'' with Mr. Gemayel after the Lebanese Army's sweep into West Beirut.  Libya Makes a Threat TRIPOLI, Libya, Sept. 1 (Reuters) - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi reiterated tonight that, if any American naval unit entered the Gulf of Sidra along Libya's Mediterranean coast, it would be attacked and destroyed ''and then let happen what will.'' He said that if American troops land in Libya, ''we will bomb all American bases in Europe as far as we can reach.'' Speaking on the 14th anniversary of the Libyan revolution, he called for revolution in neighboring Egypt and the Sudan, which he described as American colonies.  He said they need not fear direct Libyan attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/busin.main_headline: GLAXO SAYS ULCER DRUG HAS APPROVAL OF F.D.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/busin.print_headline: GLAXO SAYS ULCER DRUG HAS APPROVAL OF F.D.A.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/busin.body_text: **********Glaxo Holdings Ltd. said today that it had received provisional approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration for a popular anti-ulcer drug that would compete with the hugely successful Tagamet on the American market. **********Tagamet is a product of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation.  Glaxo must still submit proposed labeling for the drug, called Zantac, an application that normally takes six weeks to two months.  Zantac has already been approved in 31 countries, and in 18 months has taken a large share of the expanding anti-ulcer market in several of them. Zantac's popularity has slowed the growth of Tagamet, a sixyear-old drug that has made SmithKline one of the world's most profitable pharmaceutical companies. **********Safety of Drugs Cited **********Zantac is several times more powerful than Tagamet and is said to have fewer side effects, although both drugs are considered so safe that physicians have prescribed them for a far wider range of gastric complaints than the companies have suggested. **********The F.D.A.'s action covered the use of Zantac in tablet form for the short-term treatment of duodenal ulcers - by far the most common kind - and a condition involving the excess secretion of gastric acid. Glaxo said it would now seek approval for Zantac's use in longterm treatments against gastric ulcers and in injectable forms. **********The anti-ulcer market passed the $1 billion sales mark last year and is growing at a strong pace, according to analysts here. About 45 percent of sales of anti-ulcer drugs are in the United States. American Sales Agreement **********To promote sales in the United States, Glaxo has entered a joint promotion agreement, on undisclosed terms, with Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., increasing Zantac's American sales force to 1,200, from about 400. **********''I expect Zantac to expand the U.S. market and for Glaxo to end up with a large part of that expansion and perhaps a bit of Tagamet's existing market,'' said Christopher Clark, an analyst here with Scrimgeour Kemp-Gee. Mr. Clark predicted sales for Zantac of about $70 million during its first full year in the United States. **********''One key question is what price Zantac will be launched at,'' he said. ''It has typically been sold at a premium of up to 20 percent over Tagemet.'' SmithKline Growth in Japan **********Mr. Clark said SmithKline, meanwhile, could expect strong growth in the large Japanese market, where it recently received approval.  Glaxo's application there is thought to be at least a year away from acceptance. **********Robert A. Holland, manager of corporate information at SmithKline, said that marketing of Tagamet would not change as a result of Zantac's introduction in the United States, but declined further comment on Glaxo's announcement. **********Tagamet, which was introduced in Britain in 1976, and in the United States in 1977, makes up the bulk of SmithKline's sales of gastrointestinal products, which in turn make up nearly a third of the company's total sales. Last year the division recorded $857 million in sales, up from $776 million in 1981. SmithKline's total sales in 1982 were $2.97 billion. **********Ronald J. Stern, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation, estimated that Zantac would capture 20 percent of the available market within a year, ''depending on the thrust they get from Hoffmann-La Roche.'' Since Zantac is not sold in an injectable form, which accounts for about 15 percent of anti-ulcer drug sales, its ''available'' market is about 85 percent of the anti-ulcer drug market as a whole, Mr. Stern pointed out. Glaxo Shares Up in London **********Although American sales would not affect Glaxo in the current financial year, which ends June 30, today's news sent Glaxo shares soaring 50 pence, to 9.10 on the London Stock Exchange. The pound has been trading at $1.58. Glaxo's American depositary receipts, traded over the counter, closed down 1/4, at 12 1/2. **********''American interest has been strong in Glaxo for the last six months, and after today's buying I would guess that about 15 percent of the company's shares are held by American investors,'' said Roben Gilbert, an analyst at James Capel & Company. **********Last month, Glaxo reported that sales for the six months to Dec. 31 rose 24 percent, to about $792 million at current exchange rates, while net income jumped 55 percent, to about $83.5 million. **********On the New York Stock Exchange today SmithKline stock slid 2 3/8, to 69 1/2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.main_headline: HELMS DELAYS CONFIRMATION OF AMBASSADOR TO SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.print_headline: HELMS DELAYS CONFIRMATION OF AMBASSADOR TO SALVADOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/world.body_text: **********In a move that has angered the White House and left the State Department ''extremely upset,'' Senator Jesse Helms has abruptly delayed confirmation hearings on the newly appointed Ambassador to El Salvador. **********Administration officials predicted that President Reagan's nominee, Thomas R. Pickering, would eventually be confirmed. But the delay means, they added, that the envoy will probably not be able to take up his post in San Salvador until September or later. **********The delay comes at a time when issues involving El Salvador and Central America dominate foreign policy. It leaves the embassy in El Salvador in the hands of a deputy when issues like elections, discussions with the left and a new constitution are on the agenda. **********Administration officials and Senate aides indicated that Mr.  Pickering, a career diplomat, was in essence caught in an ideological tug-of-war between Mr. Helms, a right-wing Republican from North Carolina, and the State Department. Helms Busy With Farm Bills **********Aides to Mr. Helms said that the Senator was involved with two agricultural bills and would probably not have time to get to Mr.  Pickering's confirmation hearings - despite Administration pressures - before the scheduled Aug. 5 summer recess. **********''One man's delay is another man's priority,'' one aide commented.  Mr. Helms, who is chairman of the Foreign Relations Commiteee's subcommittee on Western Hemisphere affairs, has told Administration officials and Senate aides that he wants to question Mr. Pickering on the his role in the Law of the Sea Conference and also on a Presidential commission report, drawn up during the Carter Administration, that advocated family planning measures in the third world. **********Beyond this, Administration officials and Senate aides believe the main reason Mr. Helms wants to delay the confirmation is to use the issue as a lever to call Secretary of State George P. Shultz before his subcommittee. Helms Checking on 1962 Accord **********Administration officials said that Mr. Helms had made it clear he wanted to question Mr. Shultz - as he has sought to question Shultz predecessors in recent years - on details of the agreements reached in October 1962 between President Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev, the Soviet leader, to resolve the crisis over Soviet deployment of missiles in Cuba. **********''It's assumed that Cuba and the Soviet Union agreed that there would be no offensive weapons build-up in Cuba if the U.S. did not try to destabilize the Cuban regime,'' a Helms aide said. ''This has a fundamental impact on Carribean and Central American policy today.  We have followed our side of the bargain. But have they followed theirs?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/05/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Utility Payout Tax Incentives
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/05/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Utility Payout Tax Incentives
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/05/busin.body_text: **********WHEN a tax break was offered in the 1981 tax law to participants in public utility dividend reinvestment plans, there were some doubts as to how it would be received. But the results after slightly more than a year indicate that investors have been attracted to the idea. **********The Edison Electric Institute, the trade association for the nation's electric utilities, estimates that its members raised almost $2 billion in 1982 through dividend reinvestments, up from more than $1.3 billion the previous year. Ted Gradin, the institute's director of finance, says the new tax benefit is the principal factor in the big increase. **********''It's certainly been very popular and there's been a tremendous interest out there,'' said Charles Stathas, a security analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds. ''I would take advantage of it.'' **********''It really has worked,'' added John Kellenyi, an analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''It's a nice little extra kicker to have.'' **********The Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 included a section allowing exclusions from income taxation of up to $750 a year in dividends for single taxpayers and $1,500 in the case of joint returns, if invested through a utility dividend reinvestment plan. In such a plan, investors get additional shares of stock instead of cash dividends. **********This exclusion, which stockholders can elect covering dividends received in the period from Jan. 1, 1982, through Dec. 31, 1985, is, however, only for plans that qualify under rules imposed by the Federal Government. Thus the portion of a utility dividend that is treated as a tax-deferred return of capital does not qualify for the exclusion. The reason is that Washington does not want stockholders to obtain two separate tax benefits for the same investment. **********For instance, John J. Jones, a utility analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, noted that 100 percent of the dividends from the Long Island Lighting Company last year represented a return of capital and therefore was ineligible for the exclusion, while 100 percent of the dividends from the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was ordinary income and therefore qualified. As an example of a dividend with both considerations, he cited the American Electric Power Company, with 24 percent a return of capital and the remainder ordinary income. **********There are two other tests that a company must meet to have its shares qualify for the dividend exclusion. First, the shares issued to participating shareowners must be newly issued stock, rather than existing stock purchased in the open market. **********Second, at least 60 percent of the depreciable property acquired by the utility during the last 10 years must have been public utility property. Because of this last requirement, the stock of most telephone and natural gas utilities does not qualify. **********Interest in utility dividend reinvestment picked up in the second half of 1982, analysts report, in keeping with the overall decline in short-term money market rates. With the average utility yield now at 10.3 percent - and all or part of this dividend tax sheltered through reinvestment -many investors bought utility stocks with funds obtained by selling their shares in money market funds. By contrast, the most recent 7-day average yield for money market funds, as tablulated by Donoghue's Money Fund Report, was 7.8 percent. **********An added fillip is that some utilities offer stock to participants in dividend reinvestment plans at discounts from prevailing market prices. These discounts usually range from 3 to 5 percent of the current price level. **********The full benefit of this provision in the law is felt by investors who hold their reinvested stock for at least a year. In such situations, the full proceeds are taxed, when the stock is sold, at the long-term capital gains rate - with a maximum rate of 20 percent. Otherwise, the proceeds are taxed as ordinary income, with a top rate of 50 percent. **********A negative of such dividend reinvestments -even with the tax break - is that investors do not have the use of the cash from their dividends until they sell the stock. And for those who need the income on a regular basis, this type of delay might create a severe or unmanageable financial burden. As Mr. Jones of Oppenheimer said, ''It's basically for the under-65 shareholders.'' **********In addition, there is generally considered to be greater risk in purchasing utility stocks than buying money market funds. The funds have a fixed share value of $1 a share with a yield that changes daily, while utility company share prices fluctuate based on market conditions with dividends determined each quarter. **********The utility dividend exclusion is scheduled to end on Jan. 1, 1986. However, Mr. Gradin of the electric institute said that ''it's such an excellent capital formation device, I'm sure the industry would love to see it extended.'' So would many utility stockholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/busin.body_text: **********In a historic turnabout in East-West trade, the West last year recorded its first trade deficit with the Soviet bloc in two decades, according to a United Nations agency report released today. **********The report by the United Nation's Economic Commission for Europe said the Western deficit was just under $2 billion in 1982, compared with a surplus of about $2 billion in 1981. **********It said the Soviet Union alone had a merchandise trade surplus with Western nations of about $1 billion last year. The rest of the bloc's merchandise trade surplus with the West totaled slightly less than $1 billion in 1982. **********The report cited reduced import levels, resulting from substantial debt service burdens and restricted access to Western credit, as the main reasons for the turnabout. **********The U.N. agency attributed the Soviet Union's trade surplus with the West in 1982 to rising sales of oil and oil products, priced below Western levels, and noted that the Soviet Union had improved exports despite Western economic sanctions imposed after the declaration of martial law in Poland in 1981. **********Nevertheless, the report said the bloc's room for economic expansion was hurt by continuing difficulties in servicing interest on foreign debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher opened her campaign for re-election today, unveiling a Conservative Party program that she promised would improve living standards and ''insure that Britain remains a steadfast ally in an uncertain world.'' **********The party's manifesto for the June 9 vote pledged that in a second term the Tories would pass tough laws to place further curbs on the power of the trade unions, would remove one layer of local government entirely, would sell off major parts of nationalized industries and would cut income taxes and continue to cut inflation. **********At a crowded news conference, beneath a banner bearing the slogan ''Britain strong and free,'' the Prime Minister said that in four years under her leadership Britain had recovered its confidence and self-respect and the admiration of other nations. Her program for the next five years, she added, is equally ''robust and responsible.'' **********''The choice before the nation is stark,'' she asserted, ''either to continue our present steadfast progress towards recovery or to follow policies more extreme and more damaging than those ever put forward by any previous opposition.'' On Dealing With Unemployment **********As she has since taking power, Mrs. Thatcher refused any suggestion of direct action to deal with unemployment, which she called ''the universal and most intractible'' problem. ''The answer is not bogus social contracts and Government overspending,'' she said, ''the Government's role is to keep inflation down and offer real incentive for private enterprise.'' **********The paradox of the campaign so far is that the Conservatives remain well ahead despite opinion poll showings that a large majority of the public considers unemployment the dominant problem and prefers Labor's policy of economic stimulation to the Prime Minister's hands-off approach. In a survey by Market and Opinion Research International, published in Tuesday's issue of The Daily Star, the Tories' lead was put at 7 points. The poll gave them 44 percent to 37 percent for Labor, 17 percent for the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance and 2 percent for others. **********That is a smaller lead than in previous surveys, and Labor strategists hope it means they are breaking down the public's belief that there is nothing to be done about the jobless. With unemployment at 3.2 million, or 13.3 percent of the work force, the highest rate in the country's history, Labor has pledged to spend enough to create 2.5 million jobs during the next Parliament. **********Michael Foot, the opposition leader, has begun to draw large, emotional crowds at rallies. He attacked the issue again today, declaring on a radio program that ''if there is anything worse than mass unemployment, it is the Tories' complete misapprehension - to use a very polite word for it - that there is no alternative.'' Dr.  David Owen, of the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance, said the country would not accept the prospect of a further rise in unemployment under Mrs. Thatcher. Decidedly Right-Wing Tone **********The Conservatives' 47-page manifesto had a decidedly right-wing tone, as expected, especially with regard to the trade unions. Among other things, a new Thatcher Government would be committed to guaranteeing by law a secret ballot for union elections and the right for union members to decide whether they wanted part of their dues to go to the Labor Party. Unions would also be required to hold secret ballots before calling strikes if they wished to retain legal immunity. **********Among the state-owned businesses that Mrs. Thatcher promises to sell off are Rolls-Royce, the automobile makers, and British Airways, as well as large parts of British Steel, British Leyland and British Shipbuilders. This will be possible, the Tories privately concede, only if the businesses involved can demonstrate consistent profitability. **********On local government, the document attacks the metropolitan councils and the Greater London Council, which in the 1970's took over much of local government's responsibility from district and borough councils. A number of them, including London's, have been dominated by Labor left-wingers. **********''The metropolitan councils and the Greater London Council have been shown to be a wasteful and unnecessary tier of government,'' the Conservative manifesto said. ''We shall abolish them and return most of their functions to the boroughs and the districts.'' **********Stressing that British jobs and investments were directly linked to Britain's membership in the European Economic Community, Mrs.  Thatcher declared that ''we need to fight on'' within the organization. Labor is committed to withdraw from it as soon as possible.
