https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Having determined that younger media buyers are probably not media readers, The New Yorker has returned to television after a decade's absence in an attempt to reach advertisers and agencies. **********Starting this week, The New Yorker is running 180 spots over the next month in the New York metropolitan area, on ABC, CBS, NBC and the independent stations, mainly around the news shows. **********To pay for its $250,000 TV blitz, The New Yorker has cut out its editorial campaign for the rest of the year. That campaign is also directed at the advertising community. **********''It's our feeling that the younger people in media-buying don't read as much as people in other functions, especially creative, or the older generation,'' said Hoyt Spelman, the magazine's publication director. ''They belong to the television generation.'' **********The four ad formats, designed by Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, emphasize the elite nature of The New Yorker, which is billed as ''the working magazine of the reading class.'' One commercial shows a pair of hands folding a Eustace Tilley cover into a paper airplane, which in turn becomes a fast-moving jet. **********The New Yorker? Yes, The New Yorker.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/16/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; RATES MIXED; DATA AWAITED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates were mixed yesterday as market participants waited for new developments that might point toward higher or lower interest rates. **********''A lot of people are waiting for this week's economic data to decide whether the rally is for real or not,'' one trader of Treasury notes said. **********The catalyst for last week's rally, which carried bond prices up four points from their mid-week low of less than 98 1/2, was a report that retail sales in July were weaker than expected. This week's economic statistics, however, are not expected to point so clearly toward a weakening economy as the retail sales for July would suggest. **********Figures will be released today on industrial production for July. Most analysts expect a rise greater than June's 1.1 percent. **********Estimates for July's housing starts, also scheduled for release today, vary widely. John MacAuley, an economist at the Chemical Bank, said starts probably fell to an annual rate of 1.65 million units, from 1.75 million in June, because ''we may already be seeing some impact from the higher mortgage rates.'' Other analysts said that higher mortage rates were hurting the housing industry but that the increases were too recent to have affected starts during July. Traders Scrutinize Figures **********Economic data are closely watched by participants in the credit markets. They expect that a continuation of the second quarter's rapid growth would bring higher interest rates. A less robust expansion would delay the onset of higher rates and also would help keep inflation subdued, analysts said. **********By late yesterday, long-term bonds were the only sector of the Treasury market with generally lower prices. The 12 percent issue due in 2013 closed at about 102 1/8, down 3/8 point, to yield 11.74 percent. Dealers said institutional demand was modest, though there was still a good flow of orders from smaller investors buying less than $1 million. **********The 12 percent bonds, like the 3- and 10-year Treasury notes sold earlier this month, are all trading at prices well above the average levels set at the auction. Although much of the rapid rise in prices last Friday was caused by speculative buying by Wall Street firms and other traders, analysts said that securities dealers' holdings of the Treausry issues were not burdensome. Overnight financing costs of 9 5/8 percent, they noted, mean that there are profits to be made from holding Treasury issues - so long as prices are stable or rising. Yields Dip for Treasury Bills **********For Treasury issues due in 20 years or less, prices rose modestly by about one-eighth point. Traders were not discouraged by Friday's rise in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, to 9 7/8 percent, from 9 5/8 percent. **********In the short-term market, new three- and six-month Treasury bills were auctioned yesterday at average rates that were more than one-eighth percentage point less than at last week's auctions. The three-month bill sold at about 9.4 percent, down from 9.57 percent, while the six-month bill sold at about 9.55 percent, down from 9.7 percent. **********Based on the auction results, the maximum rate for new six-month savings certificates offered by banks and thrift institutions will decline today to 9.80 percent, from 9.95 percent. The top rate for three-month certificates is the same as the average for three-month Treasury bills. **********While rates declined for three- and six-month savings certificates, rates rose for longer-term ''small saver'' certificates, which have a maturity of 18 months or longer. The Treasury Department announced that the maximum rate for these certificates offered by thrift institutions rose to 11.05 percent, from 10.7 percent, while banks may offer a top rate of 10.8 percent, up from 10.45 percent. The rate for small saver certificates changes every two weeks, according to changes in the yield for Treasury notes due in about 30 months. Tax-Exempt Area Affected **********Although the higher interest rates for home mortgages may not have affected the housing starts to be reported today, they have already had a noticeable impact on the market for tax-exempt securities, where the supply of housing revenue bonds has grown rapidly in recent weeks. **********By selling tax-exempt bonds, states and local governments can borrow at rates low enough so they can then arrange for low-cost mortgages to be made available to home buyers. For example, a $140 million issue by the Louisiana Housing Finance Agency was tentatively offered by an E. F.  Hutton & Company group with a maximum yield of 10.58 percent for interest-bearing bonds due in 2011. At yield levels set yesterday, underwriters estimated that the financing would result in home mortgage rates of about 10 5/8 percent. **********Another recent example was the Massashusetts Housing Finance Agency, which is using proceeds of a $100 million bond financing to provide 11 percent mortages to qualified first- time home buyers in the state. Bernard Singer, chairman of the agency, compared the 11 percent rate for a fixed-rate, 30-year loan with home mortgage rates of 14 to 14 1/2 percent now being charged by many local lenders. **********Following are results of yesterday's auctions of new three- and six- month Treasury bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] **********Both these issues are dated Aug. 18. The three-month bills mature Nov. 17 and the six- month bills, Feb. 16, 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.main_headline: AUTOS END A POOR 1982 ON THE RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.print_headline: AUTOS END A POOR 1982 ON THE RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.body_text: **********The automobile industry closed the books today on its worst sales year in almost two decades, recording total car sales of 7,978,487, a 6.3 percent decline from 1981 and the weakest performance since 7.55 million were sold in 1963. **********The year did end on an upbeat note: In the final 10 days, sales rose 28.5 percent for the Big Three auto companies. It was the seventh consecutive 10-day selling period to show an improvement over the previous year. **********Robert D. Lund, vice president for sales at the General Motors Corporation, said the increase was the result of ''improved consumer confidence and better conditions in the overall economy.'' **********Companies Are Cautious **********Still, most auto executives remained cautious about the outlook for sales in 1983, their rosy predictions of the past three years having been proved false. That caution was signaled by the decision to continue cut-rate financing incentives until March 31 in an effort to lure reluctant customers into showrooms. **********''The consumer's ability and willingness to buy is the key to any sustained recovery, and that requires an economic recovery and interest rates no higher than they are now,'' said David Healy, an auto industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., an investment firm. Asked if the sales upturn in the past two months represented fundamental demand or simply a reaction to incentives, he replied: ''If January sales stay up, I'll become a believer.'' **********Analysts said the 1982 sales slump, which continued a decline that began in mid-1979, was attributable to the decline in economic activity, high interest rates, high unemployment and steep car prices, which have increased by an average of 33 percent since 1979. Overall Industry Profit **********Nevertheless, because of vigorous cost cutting, the industry over all is expected to be profitable for the year, largely on the strength of G.M.'s expected earnings of more than $1 billion. The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are expected to report losses, as they did in 1981, but much less than in 1980, when the industry over all lost almost $4 billion. **********Imports took a record share of the American car market, with 27.8 percent of all sales, up from 27.1 percent in 1981, despite restrictions on imports of Japanese cars, which accounted for about 80 percent of the imports. **********The numbers and kinds of cars sold in 1982 reflected the nature of the recession, which has resulted in widespread blue-collar layoffs while leaving professionals and other higher-income groups relatively unscathed: Sales of bigger cars and luxury imports increased, while those of smaller economy cars, usually the choice of less affluent buyers, slipped. **********Mercedes-Benz, BMW, Volvo and Jaguar, none of which has a model priced under $10,000, all reported gains, as did Cadillac and Buick; sales of Chevrolet's bottom-of-the-line Chevette, which has a base price of $4,997, declined by a third. 'Rich Folks' Still Buying **********''There's no question that the rich folks haven't been hurt,'' said Harvey Heinbach, a vice president at Merrill Lynch. ''Those people who did not have to worry about losing their job situation went ahead and spent. But the unemployment put a scare in a lot of others. The ability to spend was there in many cases, but the unemployment situation affected confidence.'' **********Similarly, the strength in full-size and intermediate-size cars was attributed to their attraction to older buyers with more secure incomes. These models increased their market share to 53 percent of the sales by domestic manufacturers, from 46.2 percent in 1981. **********Sales by the Big Three domestic producers rose to 152,130 in the final 10 days of the year, from 118,343 in the 1981 period. The total for all five domestic producers rose 27.8 percent, to 161,823. **********For December the Big Three sold 428,260 cars, up 26.4 percent. The annual selling rate for the industry was 8.5 million: 5.9 milllion domestic and 2.6 million imported. **********For the year, total Big Three sales fell 6 percent, to 5,553,059. Unit Drop for Imports **********The shrinkage in the auto market during the year was further illustrated by import sales, which dropped to 2,221,829 units, from 2,309,100. **********Ford improved its share of the market for domestically built cars to 23.4 percent for the year, from 22.2 percent, while Chrysler's share rose to 12 percent, from 11.8 percent. G.M. slipped to 61.1 percent, from 61.2 percent; the American Motors Corporation dropped to 1.9 percent, from 2.2 percent, and Volkswagen of America fell to 1.5 percent, from 2.6 percent. **********Ford also rebounded sharply in the final 10 days of the year, selling 41,759 cars, an increase of 58.4 percent. Chrysler sold 23,256 autos, up 29.8 percent, while G.M. sold 87,115, a gain of 17.6 percent. **********For all of December, Ford posted a 53.5 percent increase, to 110,578 units. Chrysler sold 60,954 cars, up 26.9 percent. G.M.'s sales rose 17.4 percent, to 256,728. A.M.C., buoyed by the acceptance of its new Alliance model, was up 77.7 percent, to 13,757, but Volkswagen's sales of domestically produced cars fell 45.6 percent, to 6,031. **********Total car sales for the year represented a 30 percent decline from the industry's peak of 11.4 million in 1973. The decline for domestic manufacturers was greater - 42.6 percent from the 9.67 million posted in 1973.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.main_headline: STOCKS IN BEST GAIN IN NEARLY 8 MONTHS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.print_headline: STOCKS IN BEST GAIN IN NEARLY 8 MONTHS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The credit markets snapped out of the doldrums yesterday and interest rates declined sharply in early trading on hopes that the Federal Reserve Board's revised growth targets for the nation's basic money supply will allow short-term rates to remain stable or even decline slightly. **********The morning enthusiasm quickly waned, however, and interest rates rose during the afternoon, ending the day only slightly lower. Since early this month, trading had been very quiet as many investors stayed on the sidelines. **********Several Government securities dealers noted that anticipation of the adjustment in money supply growth targets announced yesterday by Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, was strong enough for foreign and domestic customers to start trading well before the traditional 9 A.M. opening. **********'The Place Was Hopping' **********''When I got in at 7:30 the place was already hopping,'' commented Elliott Platt, a money market economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. Earlier trading hours may become a regular feature in the Treasury market since two major brokers plan to begin trading at 8 A.M. today. **********The three-month Treasury bill rate, which mirrors changes in Fed policy, quickly fell by one-tenth of a percentage point, to a low of 9 percent, but then rose to about 9.08 percent late in the day. In the long bond market, the 10 3/8 percent Treasury issue rose almost 1 1/4 points early in the day, to as high as 93 1/2, but then retreated to an offered price of 92 3/8, up 2/32, to yield 11.27 percent. **********At the regular monthly auction of two-year Treasury notes, the average yield was 10.62 percent, down from 10 3/4 percent estimated earlier in the week. Early in the day, dealers traded the two-year issue with a yield of 10.47 percent, but said that investor demand was nil at that yield. Fed's New Target Range **********The changes in the Fed's growth target for the basic money supply measure, M-1 - to a new range of 5 percent to 9 percent for the second half of the year, versus the 4 percent to 8 percent range that had been set for the full year - were disclosed by Mr. Volcker in testimony to the House Banking Committee. **********Mr. Volcker's comments had the full attention of the credit markets, where short- and long-term rates have increased about a percentage point since early May. **********Many traders and economists have been worried that further rate increases were likely if the Fed tried to reduce M-1 growth to within the 4 percent to 8 percent target announced last February. M-1 consists of currency in circulation plus all kinds of checking accounts. **********Before the latest revisions, M-1 was more than $14 billion above the Fed's old growth target. However, the M-1 level reported on July 6 of $514.1 billion was only $2.7 billion above a level consistent with a 9 percent growth rate, measured from the second quarter of 1983 to the fourth quarter of 1983. Outlook Seen as Uncertain **********The wide swing in rates and the fact that there were as many sellers of notes and bonds as there were buyers was a sign of the still uncertain outlook for interest rates, analysts noted. **********Irwin Kellner, chief economist of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, noted that M-1 is likely to decline to within its new target soon. Once that happens, he said, traders might become less fearful that the Fed would soon tighten policy. ''If the markets can just relax, it would allow interest rates to fall,'' he said. **********Other economists, however, said they can already identify the forces that will eventually cause interest rates to rise, no matter what adjustments the Federal Reserve makes to its money supply objectives. **********''The clash between Federal deficits and private sector credit needs is still down the road,'' Mr. Kellner said. ''To be cynical, you might say that this exercise is like arranging the deck chairs on the Titanic.'' The Fed is just buying time before changes have to made in fiscal policy, he said. Sell Orders **********Government securities dealers said these conflicting views of future interest rate direction were reflected yesterday in the number of sell orders they received relative to buy orders. Major institutional investors - a critical barometer of market sentiment - were not noticeably more eager to buy long term notes or bonds, they noted. **********Some analysts said that any sustained improvement in note and bond prices might not come until the Fed shows some sign that it is encouraging a lower rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market. **********Yesterday, the funds traded at 9 3/8 percent for most of the day.  The day's activity in the Treasury market spilled over into the corporate sector, where three big new issues were introduced.  A group led by Morgan Stanley & Company said it would offer a twopart issue of Aaa-rated Australia bonds today. The $150 million of 11 3/8 percent bonds due in 1993 are offered at 99 1/4, to yield 11.503 percent, and $250 million of 12 1/8 percent bonds due in 2008 are offered at 99, to yield 12.25 percent. Mr. Prendes and seven other members of the Assembly said they received death threats between the morning and afternoon sessions of the Assembly.   Government Reports Successes **********SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 28 (Reuters) - Government troops have recaptured several towns and villages from guerrillas in El Salvador's northeastern Morazan Province, Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia said today. **********About 6,000 United States-trained troops penetrated guerrilla positions Thursday after resuming a drive that had been halted for six days, he said. **********He denied reports by the guerrillas that Honduran troops were helping in the drive. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.body_text: **********The Prudential Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, is selling $150 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds, with warrants attached to buy the stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven new regional telephone companies to be spun off Jan. 1. **********The lead underwriter for the offering, which is not available to United States investors, is Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. **********Bond issues that include stock ownership or are convertible into common stock are not uncommon, but it is rare for the stock to be unrelated to the issuer of the bonds. The only previous example of a debt security combined with unrelated stock was a Eurobond financing earlier this year by Dart & Kraft Inc., which offered warrants for shares of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company. **********William Hulton, a vice president in the London office of Prudential- Bache, said, ''We wanted to arouse investor interest in Europe, and we wanted a stock that would not dilute the high reputation of Prudential.'' **********For every $10,000 of Prudential debentures, the investor also buys seven warrants that may be exercised after 90 days and are good for five years. Each warrant allows the investor to buy 10 shares of the ''new'' A.T.& T. as well as one share in each of the seven new regional companies. The price of the warrants has not been set, but Mr. Hulton estimated they would be set at 13 to 17 percent above the closing price of ''old'' A.T.& T. stock tomorrow. **********Mr. Hulton also estimated that Prudential could have sold 10-year notes without A.T.& T. stock warrants with a yield of about 11 1/2 percent, or slightly lower than the yield on outstanding 10-year Treasury notes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/busin.body_text: **********Three middle-level economists in the Administration have been trying in vain since December to present to the Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs the inflationary dangers they believe are posed by the current 15 percent growth in the money supply. The council's 10 members include the Vice President, Secretary of State and Secretary of the Treasury. **********The three concerned economists are Beryl Sprinkel, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs; Lawrence A. Kudlow, assistant director of the Office of Management and Budget, and William Poole, member of the Council of Economic Advisers. **********''They got on the agenda, but then they put it off,'' said one knowledgeable economist in Washington. ''The postponement was at their request because of the budget, the economic report and the problems Beryl had with the Secretary, but it's not clear whether this eventually will go ahead.'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan reprimanded Mr. Sprinkel for his remarks at a Paris news conference this month. **********Mr. Poole declined to comment. Mr. Sprinkel and Mr. Kudlow did not return telephone calls.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/busin.body_text: **********A Dearth of Buying **********Why aren't people buying more? That's what economists have been asking themselves. Most of them have been counting on a surge in consumer spending to lead the economy out of recession. But there has been no surge. Instead, retail sales have posted three straight monthly declines - December, January and February. **********''On average, consumers were spending little more in the first two months of 1983 than they were last fall,'' said Karen L. Johnson, an associate economist at Citibank. She adds that even the Census Bureau's recent upward revisions in its monthly retail figures for 1977 to 1982 ''did not take away from the fact that in January and February of this year, spending really didn't go anywhere.'' **********All this has left economists scurrying for explanations. One factor cited by some is lower prices -for gasoline, food and other items - which can pull down sales figures even when unit sales increase.  Another factor, say Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette economists Gert von der Linde and Richard Hokenson, may be ''the inability of the Commerce Department to account for all the growth in the number of retail outlets as well as the introduction of new products, such as personal computers.'' The Rich Got Richer... **********How rich are the rich? Richer than they used to be, says Lawrence Chimerine, chairman and chief economist at Chase Econometrics, who sees this as another clue to the lower-than-expected consumer spending. **********He says there has been ''a dramatic shift in the distribution of income away from lower- and middle-income groups toward the upperincome group.'' The factors behind this shift include tax breaks weighted towards upper-income groups, Government budget cuts aimed primarily at the poor and near-poor, and unemployment and wage freezes concentrated mostly among middle-income and lower-income people. **********Since affluent people save a higher fraction of their incomes than less wealthy people, this means that more of the country's income is now being saved, and less being spent. Increasing the savings rate was one of the Reagan Administration's original goals. But Mr.  Chimerine notes that it has had ''a somewhat depressing impact on economic activity in the last year because consumption has not responded to income growth.'' ...And Kept On Spending **********The rich may be holding back a spending boom in a different way, too. Jay Schmiedeskamp, director of economic surveys for the Gallup Organization, notes that during a recession, virtually everyone becomes more cautious and cuts spending - both those who are unemployed or working fewer hours and those not directly affected.  When recession ends, typically the first spending to turn up is that of the more well-off people who have not been directly affected. **********This time, however, the script did not go according to plan. The group unaffected by recession did not curtail spending as it usually does, but continued to have a rather favorable attitude. ''In spite of the worst recession since World War II, this sector of consumer spending held up fairly well,'' Mr. Schmiedeskamp said. **********Since these people did not significantly reduce their spending during the downturn, there is little room for them to increase their spending now - and to provide the first surge in consumer purchases.  Spending by the more affected group will eventually come back, Mr.  Schmiedeskamp predicts, ''but will take more time.'' A Feeble Punch **********When consumers decide they are ready to spend, will they have the money? The picture is mixed. Net worth is up, but personal income growth has been anemic. Wages and salaries fell by one-tenth of a percentage point in February, after rising 1 percentage point in January. And Morgan Guaranty economists note that interest income, after rising by an average of 20 percent a year for the past five years, is now falling, as interest rates decline. Interest income accounts for nearly 15 percent of total personal income. **********As for net worth, the Morgan Guaranty Survey notes that the value of stocks, bonds and liquid assets held by consumers rose by more than $500 billion in the last six months of 1982, while net worth grew by $729 billion. The bank's economists caution, however, that consumer outlays are more influenced by after-tax personal income than by net worth. There may be a small psychological ''wealth effect,'' the Survey says, but the impact of higher net worth on spending will be small and spread out over time. Karen W. Arenson

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/16/busin.body_text: **********The Northrop Corporation, citing lower results from its services businesses, and reduced interest income, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 dropped 25.1 percent, while sales rose 25.7 percent. **********The Los Angeles-based manufacturer of military aircraft and commercial airliner parts said that net income in the latest three months fell to $12.8 million, or 84 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or $1.16 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/world.main_headline: TENSION HIGH IN GUATEMALA AS CHIEF IS PRESSED ON VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/world.print_headline: TENSION HIGH IN GUATEMALA AS CHIEF IS PRESSED ON VOTE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/20/world.body_text: **********Guatemala's President, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, appears to be facing his most serious political challenge since coming to power in a coup 15 months ago. **********According to politicians, diplomats and church and business leaders interviewed here, the key issue is the general's promise to restore ''authentic democracy'' that he made after annulling the results of national elections in March 1982. He did so on the ground that the voting had been fraudulent. **********In the last few weeks, pressure has mounted on the President to keep his promise, with an army general and church leaders publicly petitioning him to get the military out of government. The petitioners are also demanding the election of an assembly to draft a new constitution for this nation, which has known dictatorship for most of its history. **********Challenged by Guerrillas **********At the same time, the Rios Montt Government continues to be challenged by a loosely unified guerrilla movement. Although a drive on the rebels in the mountainous countryside, in which many Indians were killed, had been thought to confine guerrilla activity to a remote northwestern sector bordering the Mexican state of Chiapas, there have been reports of renewed fighting closer to the Guatemalan capital in the last few weeks. **********The calls for a return to civilian rule, while providing a unifying theme for opponents of General Rios Montt, mask the motives of a variety of special interests from extreme left to extreme right, according to Guatemalans and foreign diplomats here. Economic, social and religious tensions are all playing a part. So is the personality of the President, an evangelical Christian who has been described as part nationalist, part missionary; part soldier, part reformer; flamboyant and pious at the same time. Strong Rumors of a Coup **********''All the political parties are against him; the merchants, professionals and farmers oppose him; he has alienated the church, and his army is badly divided,'' Mario Sandoval Alarcon, head of the militantly far-right National Liberation Movement, said in an interview here Friday. **********''If he doesn't call elections in the next two or three weeks, he will be finished,'' said Mr. Sandoval, whose party is widely believed to be among those with the most to gain if General Rios Montt were to fall from power. **********Last week, the capital was so abuzz with rumors of a coup that on Friday the chief of the Guatemalan general staff, Gen. Hector Mario Lopez Fuentes, issued a public statement saying that no one in the army was thinking of overthrowing the Government. **********According to Mr. Sandoval, any military challenge to the President would not be likely to come from the generals, ''who are all his friends,'' but from younger officers. **********General Rios Montt has not been on good terms with the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy in this predominantly Catholic country.  Among the President's critics is Msgr. Ramiro Pelleter Samyoa, who last week was appointed, at least temporarily, the Archbishop of Guatemala after the death of Mario Cardinal Casariego y Acevedo on Wednesday. **********''I hope there will be no more attacks on the Catholic church by the Government,'' Monsignor Pelleter was quoted as having told an interviewer. Monsignor Pelleter is one of the church leaders who have petitioned General Rios Montt. **********The urban middle class of professionals and merchants, as well as some country landowners, are apprehensive about a new tax package that the Rios Montt Government promises to introduce. In a time of economic crisis attributable at least in part to falling prices worldwide for commodities on which Guatemala depends for export earnings - in particular, coffee - business leaders fear that their interests are not being looked after by a Government and bureaucracy packed as in no other time in recent history by military men. New Parties Formed **********Politically there is wide agreement that President Rios Montt has opened the way for a range of new parties and many, some no larger than committees, have begun to form in anticipation of elections. He is also credited with allowing the press greater latitude than it has usually enjoyed in the past. **********But at the same time, General Rios Montt has begun to set limits on political dissent. Last week he jailed for four days one political opponent, Mario Castijon of the National Renewal Party, a centerright group viewed by some Guatemalans as liberal in the absence of left-of-center parties. Dr. Castijon had criticized General Rios Montt for using his political power to aid his evangelical church. **********Politicians and diplomats here point out that it is to General Rios Montt's advantage to put off elections as long as possible in the hope that new parties will grow and weaken the power of the entrenched political groups. **********General Rios Montt, it is generally agreed, was robbed of the presidency in the election of 1974 when his Christian Democratic Party was pushed aside by a party further to the right. There are those here who suggest that the general, who has said he will not be a candidate in the future, may now want to claim the four years of power that he was denied almost a decade ago. **********The challenge from within the army came earlier this month from General Jose Guillermo Echeverria Vielman, who in an open letter to the President on June 5 that was read on national television and printed in the press, made an eloquent case for a return to the barracks. The general was then forcibly retired from military duty. 'Could Become a Hero' **********Political leaders will not discuss whether he is their chosen alternative to President Rios Montt. Alejandro Maldonada Aguirre, who heads the National Renewal Party, is quoted in the current issue of This Week, a privately published news letter on business and politics, as having said that General Echevarria ''could become a hero.'' **********Meanwhile, President Rios Montt has continued to insist that more time is required to prepare the country for an election free of fraud. He has promised that he will schedule voting for the second half of 1984 to choose a constituent assembly similar to the one elected in El Salvador last year. **********The widening opposition here says that is too long to wait for what is only the first step of a long process. ''They are coming at him from six sides,'' one diplomat said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/busin.body_text: **********The Canadian Government proposed legislation today to regulate the newspaper industry. The bill would limit the growth of newspaper chains, establish a national press council to hear complaints, and commit the Government to financing of up to $1 million a year to help newspapers establish foreign or out-ofprovince bureaus. **********Jim Fleming, whose duties as Minister of Multiculturalism in Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Cabinet include overseeing the news industry, said the bill would be introduced when Parliament resumes in September. **********Mr. Fleming told reporters the bill was not a threat to press freedom, saying, ''You can't have a free press if too much is owned by too few.'' But the president of the Canadian Daily Newspaper Publishers' Association, J.P. Callaghan, said some parts of the proposal might violate Canada's new Constitution. **********The proposed law would allow a group or individual to own newspapers with up to 20 percent of the daily national circulation. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/25/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Institutions Are Wary Of Futures
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/25/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Institutions Are Wary Of Futures
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/25/busin.body_text: **********IF the stock options and index markets are made to order for equities portfolio managers, which they are, then why do so few of the institutions use them? After all, where else can a pension fund, bank trust or mutual fund manager get such cheap ''insurance'' against a decline in the value of the institution's stock portfolio? **********''The fact is that out of the biggest 100 pension funds, which have $593 billion of the total of $750 billion of such tax-exempt funds under their management, only between 5 and 10 percent use these markets,'' said Louis I. Margolis, vice president in charge of the equities futures and options department at Salomon Brothers. **********Outwardly, the small number of institutional hedgers who use these markets is even more unusual, Mr. Margolis said last Friday, because most of the $300 billion of stocks they manage are the same ones included in the Standard & Poor's 500 options and futures. In fact, the performances of portfolio managers are usually measured against the S.& P. 500 index, he said. **********''Despite their intense interest in these markets, most managers are still inhibited by tangible and intangible restraints,'' he said. ''For one, many of the institutions lack hedging strategy systems. A surprising number lack the computers and other tools to set up and operate hedging systems.'' **********While large and experienced investment banking houses such as Salomon Brothers have the knowledge and mechanical tools, many of the big institutional investors are also inhibited by their lack of experience and mechanical tools to enter these markets. **********Also, the fact that the stock options and index markets include a great number of speculators still inhibits traditional portfolio managers, despite the fact that no market could exist without the vital speculative element that willingly assumes the risks the hedgers seek to avoid. **********''Far more important,'' Mr. Margolis said, is the fact that many institutions don't have hedging systems in place. They need performance measurements, evaluations and other means to find out how well they performed, not just whether they made money or not.'' **********Meanwhile, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the Chicago Board Options Exchange and Standard & Poor's last Friday reached an agreement to rename the C.B.O.E. 100 index options the S.& P. 100 options. The Chicago Merc will trade a futures contract on the S.& P. 100. In addition, the Options Exchange will list an option on the S.& P. 500 index. The options on the S.& P. 500 futures contract will continue to be traded on the Chicago Merc. **********Louis J. Horowitz, president and chief executive officer of the New York Futures Exchanges, a subsidary of the New York Stock Exchange, said of the Chicago agreement: **********''It is bound to broaden and deepen all index futures and options, thus making it more attractive to the institutions as well as private trader. In doing so, it will stimulate trading in all markets. This is important because an explosion of equities index and options trading is coming. This is why we are expanding our index futures and options markets this summer by adding an index options on 100 Big Board issues, which will be settled in cash, just as the C.B.O.E. is. We have learned that small means successful when it comes to index options.'' **********So has the Kansas City Board of Trade, which pioneered index futures, based on the Value Line average, in February 1982. Last week, the Kansas City exchange said it planned to introduce small ''job-lot'' versions of its present contract to better compete with its Chicago rivals. The minimum job lot would be one-fifth the size of the present futures, with five job lots equal to one regular contract. **********Mr. Horowitz was pleased by these moves of his rivals because it will encourage traders on the Big Board and its futures exchange, which are in the same building, to ''think stocks, index futures and options as parts of one vast market, which is what we really are, several exchanges under one roof.'' **********An example of the rapid integration of the stock market with the index futures and options, he said over the weekend, is being reflected in the increased volume and open interest in all index futures markets since the C.B.O.E. 100 index options began trading on March 11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of people were taken into custody for questioning today as the police hunted for members of a small but growing guerrilla insurgency that has prompted the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry to declare a 60-day state of emergency. **********The arrests, the police said, occurred mostly in and around Lima and Ayacucho, the departmental capital 200 miles southeast of here that has been the center of operations of leftist guerrillas belonging to a movement that calls itself Shining Path. More than 500 people were reportedly arrested and the roundup was said to be continuing. **********The army under the elected Government of President Belaunde Terry reports that 823 people have been killed since the beginning of the year in the fighting between Government forces and guerrillas, compared with about 200 in the previous two and a half years.  Officials say about two-thirds of the dead were guerrillas; the rest - soldiers, policemen and peasants - were said to have been killed by guerrillas. **********Guerrillas Strike in Lima **********Western diplomats and Peruvian political experts estimate that the Shining Path numbers no more than 2,000 guerrillas, with perhaps an equal number of sympathizers. **********Army leaders have predicted they will wipe out the guerrilla movement by the end of the year, but a heavy blow to their efforts was dealt on Friday by a guerrilla strike on this capital of five million people. Western diplomats here said the attack, estimated to involve more than 100 guerrillas, was spectacularly coordinated. **********The attackers blew up power pylons, blacked out much of the city, set off bombs near embassies and Government buildings and largely destroyed the sprawling Bayer Chemical industrial works with firebombs. Peruvians Express Concern **********The psychological effect appeared great. Recent polls have shown that despite an economic crisis, ravaging floods in the north and a debilitating drought in the south, Peruvians are most worried about the guerrillas. **********Many demand that the Government take harsher measures, and the nation's two weekly news magazines, Caretas and Oiga, both ran cover articles two weeks ago on the possibilities of a coup. They even speculated who the future cabinet members might be. **********President Belaunde Terry was elected in 1980 after 12 years of military rule, and according to sources close to him the specter of a coup has been a constant concern as he has tried to cope with the Shining Path insurrection. **********He did not accede to political pressure to send the army into the campaign against the guerrillas until December, reportedly hoping to limit the military's role. With the campaign against the guerrillas showing little success, the President has announced that he is studying the creation of a special police commando force to replace the army. Civil Liberties Suspended **********In what was widely interpreted here as a show of forcefulness, President Belaunde Terry declared the state of emergency Monday for the 60-day maximum allowed under the Constitution. The decree suspends most civil liberties, such as the rights of assembly and free speech. It is designed to allow the police to arrest guerrilla suspects and interrogate them for up to 15 days without charges. **********At a news conference on Sunday, the day before he issued his decree, the President said, ''All Peruvians should unite in this undeclared war against delinquents, mercenaries and dark forces of ideology that Peru fortunately rejects.'' He meant the Shining Path guerrillas, whom he does not refer to by name. **********The state of emergency was a particularly delicate step because it suspends the democratic principles Mr. Belaunde Terry has long upheld. He was overthrown and exiled by the military in a previous term as President in 1968. Hospital Strike Called Off **********The President's decree has had little visible effect on daily life in this capital. There are no tanks in the streets, and the police presence appears normal. **********However, a strike by hospital employees that had been paralyzing public hospitals was called off because of the measure, and a nationwide strike considered by Communist-controlled unions must now get Government approval, which seems unlikely. Even a mass rally planned for today by the President's own party, Popular Action, was called off. **********Reaction from the opposition has been muted. Many leaders of Peru's largest party, the Popular Revolutionary American Alliance, guardedly supported the state of emergency. They objected mostly to its being national in scope, arguing it should be limited to the problem areas, as a number of earlier states of emergency were.  Ayacucho has been under a state of emergency since December. **********The strongest complaints have come from the country's badly fractured Marxist parties.  ''The majority of the population does not have to suffer to fight such a tiny minority,'' Javier Diez Canseco, a leading Marxist member of Congress and vice president of the Parliamentary Human Rights Commission, said in an interview.

**********Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan returned home after three days in Paris today and said he was satisfied with his talks with President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy. He gave no details.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.main_headline: OPEC FAILS TO PICK SECRETARY GENERAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.print_headline: OPEC FAILS TO PICK SECRETARY GENERAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The 13 member nations of OPEC agreed here today to postpone the appointment of a Secretary General and to continue debate on long-term strategy at their next regular meeting in December. **********Neither issue was considered pressing enough to prevent adjournment of the semiannual meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. On Monday, the first day of talks, the ministers made the expected but pivotal decision to maintain the price structure and production quotas that the group had established in March after weeks of sometimes bitter negotiations. **********Many industry experts say that rising demand will allow OPEC to raise its production ceiling in the last quarter of the year, which would require a special meeting. **********The aggragate quota was set in March at an average of 17.5 million barrels a day through the end of this year. This was 2 million barrels below the quota of the previous months, but about 3 million more than OPEC members were then producing. Rise in Output **********Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, minister from the United Arab Emirates and the new president of the group, said at a news conference today that OPEC's current production was about 17 million barrels a day, or 500,000 more than recent industry estimates. **********The group also decided in March to lower its basic oil price by $5 a barrel, to $29, in an effort to bolster its fading markets. This, plus the spreading economic recovery, seems to have had the desired effect, in the light of the data supplied by Sheik Otaiba. **********Today, however, OPEC officials were reluctant to speculate about how long the March arrangements could be maintained.  ''There is no time limit,'' Sheik Otaiba said. ''It will be as long as the market has not improved in a way that would allow us to adjust the previous arrangements.'' **********But, he added in a personal aside, ''I myself believe that the price of oil should be kept at $29 until the end of 1985.'' Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the minister from Saudi Arabia, has expressed the same sentiment. Saudi Arabia is OPEC's biggest oil producer and the world's largest exporter. Fourth-Quarter Estimates **********Mr. Otaiba, who is also head of OPEC's market monitoring committee, said demand for oil from the group could rise to between 17.5 million and 19 million barrels a day in the fourth quarter. **********But he and other OPEC ministers expressed concern about the quality of the demand: whether it would reflect an end to the drawing down of inventories by oil companies in anticipation of lower prices, or a real growth in consumption. **********The ministers also questioned whether non-OPEC producers would attempt to meet any added demand. Liaison with oil exporters outside the group has widened: Mexico had observer status here, and Sheik Otaiba said Belkacem Nabi, minister from Algeria, would visit the Soviet Union for discussions. **********The conference communique said discussion of long-term strategy would be continued at the next general meeting to give a committee led by Sheik Yamani time to update its report in light of ''changing conditions.'' The meeting is scheduled for Dec.7 in Geneva. **********The report, which Sheik Yamani has been working on for several years, deals with OPEC's relations with consuming and developing nations and with non-OPEC oil producers. One key proposal is said to be a commitment to keep oil prices from rising through the end of 1985. **********The appointment of a new Secretary General to succeed Marc Saturnin Nan Nguema of Gabon became impossible when neither Iran nor Iraq would accept each other's nominees and no third candidate emerged. As a result, Sheik Otaiba will supervise the group's administrative affairs with the help of Fadhil J. al-Chalabi, the current Deputy Secretary General. **********The position is more prestigious than powerful because all major OPEC decisions are reserved to the member states. The 13 OPEC nations are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/busin.main_headline: Buying Fever Sweeps The Bullion Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; Buying Fever Sweeps The Bullion Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Precious metals prices shot up again yesterday as buying fever swept bullion markets on both sides of the Atlantic. Market analysts attributed the advances of the last two sessions to a combination of strong demand and technical factors in both the London and New York bullion markets. **********On New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday, the spot January gold futures jumped $13.60 an ounce, to $480.60, while the most active delivery, February, advanced $13.70 at $483.20. The gains virtually duplicated those of last Friday, when the latest rally in precious metals began. **********The spot silver futures climbed 42.5 cents an ounce, to $12.02, while the active March contract rose a like amount to $12.165.  Silver's gains were about 10 cents more than those posted last Friday. Many of the distant silver deliveries traded at the daily permissible limit of 50 cents an ounce, before some late profit taking trimmed prices. **********At the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot platinum contract, which also expires on Jan. 26, soared $18.40 an ounce, to $462, while all other active deliveries closed up the limit of $20 an ounce. **********''The latest rally started last Friday in London with a second gold fixing of $465, which broke the critical $460 line on the technical price charts,'' said Charles R. Stahl, publisher and editor of Green's Commodity Market Comments. **********Why $460? That was the low point of the current decline, reached on Nov. 12 after having reached a 1982 fixing high of $488.50 on Sept.  7. Subsequently, prices moved somewhat before returning to the $460 level last week. When Friday's final London fixing broke above that low, traders who follow computerized trend lines received their long awaited signal of a broad upturn, Mr. Stahl said, adding: **********''While the technical indicators point to $600 gold later this year, we believe the next objective will be $482-$486, which should provoke a correction, before the advance resumes.'' **********Howard Levine, vice president of ACLI International Commodity Services Inc., discussed the fundamentals in gold. ''Friday was the decisive day on the Comex as well because it reflected the end of what was a flood of longstanding cash offerings of bullion in the physical market earlier in the week,'' he said, adding: **********''When the physical market opened today, the amount of bullion offerings for cash was much lighter and, significantly, the sellorder prices weren't as closely bunched together as they were last week.'' **********Closely spaced sell or buy orders usually reflect the belief that prices will not move very much either way.  Paul Sarnoff, vice president of Paine Webber Futures, and a longtime precious metals bull, said: ''I continue to hold that silver will outperform gold and that we will see $15, perhaps even $20 silver this year. Why? Because silver, like platinum, has the added advantage of being an industrial metal as well as a hedge against inflation. As for platinum, supply-demand factors can only force prices up from current levels.'' **********Gold bullion prices, meanwhile, will continue to reflect the real or perceived rate of inflation, with lesser but still important influences being the strength of the dollar and the yields on competitive money market investment instruments, Mr. Sarnoff added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had arranged the takeover of the failed First Central Bank of Smithville, Tenn., by the City Bank and Trust Company of McMinnville, Tenn. **********Tennessee banking authorities closed the Smithville Bank Friday, citing excessive loan losses. **********In addition to assuming the failed bank's $18.3 million in deposits and other liabilities, City Bank and Trust agreed to pay the F.D.I.C. a purchase premium of $301,250. The F.D.I.C. said that it advanced City Bank and Trust $11.2 million in cash to facilitiate the deposit assumption, and that it retained $12.3 million in assets of the failed bank on which it hopes to recover a major portion of its cash advance. **********The Tennesse bank failure is the 30th this year, compared with 42 in all of last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/busin.body_text: **********After years of soaring and even overheated expansion, Texas's major banks are reeling from the first serious strains on their growth and profitability in more than a decade. **********Since the early 1970's, Texas bankers had been blessed by an unusually robust economy. The surge in oil and gas drilling, followed by a boom in real estate development, produced steadily higher profits for banks. Especially in the state's two money centers, Houston and Dallas, banks were benefiting from their high-yielding energy loans. And in an unprecedented wave of acquisitions, several of the state's bank holding companies grew geometrically by buying out smaller rivals. **********But since mid-1982, after the oil boom went bust and Dallas and Houston became overbuilt with ultra- modern, mirrored glass office buildings, Texas banks have come into disfavor on Wall Street. Especially in the wake of the collapse of the Penn Square Bank in neighboring Oklahoma, which had a huge portfolio of irrecoverable energy loans, banking industry analysts have expressed growing fears that some Texas banks might have similar problems. **********News Turns Grim And earlier this month, bank news that had seemed merely depressing abruptly turned grim. **********On Oct. 7, the Interfirst Corporation of Dallas, the state's No. 1 bank holding company, reported the largest quarterly loss in the history of American banking, $194 million. Only a week later, another large energy lender, the First National Bank of Midland, was closed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and finally sold to Republicbank of Dallas in the second-largest bank failure in the nation's history. **********The coalescence of two events so devastating raised an inevitable question: Are Interfirst and Midland merely symptoms of broader problems to come for Texas banking? **********''Reports of the death of the Texas economy have been greatly exaggerated,'' replies Ben F. Love, chairman of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. of Houston, the state's third-largest holding company. ''This is still a tremendous place to be in banking.'' **********Interfirst, which owns 66 banks in Texas, maintains that it will be profitable in the fourth quarter. Robert H. Stewart, chairman of Interfirst's flagship bank in Dallas, characterized the bank's third- quarter loss, as ''a bump in the road.'' **********''We've had some excesses in the oil and gas business, and it's going to take time for demand to catch up with supply,'' Mr. Stewart added. ''But the situation at Interfirst has stabilized, this state has a vibrant economy, and I'm quietly optimistic.'' **********Re-evaluation of Management **********At the same time, Interfirst, which has been one of the nation's fastest- growing bank holding companies, is serious re-evaluating its management. **********For most of the year, Interfirst had bridled at any suggestion that its loan portfolio might be flawed. But when it disclosed its third-quarter loss, it also announced that William Breedlove, who had been chairman of the holding company's Dallas bank, had been forced out and replaced by Mr. Stewart. **********''We have been unsatisfied with some of the management judgments,'' said Elvis Mason, Interfirst's chairman. In addition, Mr. Stewart said, Interfirst now has essentially completed its flurry of acquisitions in which it has acquired three dozen bank and doubled its assets since 1980. **********In June, Interfirst completed the largest acquisition in Texas banking history when it took over the First United Bancorp of Fort Worth, with $2.4 billion in assets. Mr. Stewart said that the only thing that would persuade Interfirst to consider other mergers would be a change in interstate banking laws that would allow it to purchase and operate out-of-state banks. **********Analysts say Interfirst, as well as a handful of other Texas banks that have been hurt by irretrievable energy loans, will have to slow their plans for growth and may lose market share to those with healthier loan portfolios. **********Sharply Lower Earnings **********Although no other large Texas bank has reported losses this year, the First City Bancorporation of Dallas, the state's fourth-largest bank holding company, reported that its third- quarter net income plummeted 84 percent, to $5.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from $32.6 million, or 95 cents a share, in the 1982 quarter. And No. 6, Southwest Bancshares Inc., reported that its third-quarter net income fell 44 percent, to $9.9 million, or 62 cents a share, from $17.6 million, or $1.16 a share. **********Like Interfirst, which took a $430 million write-off from its third-quarter earnings as a provision against loan losses, both First City and Southwest have cited serious problems with energy loans. First City, for example, increased its loan loss provision to $60 million at the end of the third quarter, compared to $17 million a year ago. **********And while analysts say they do not expect other Texas banks to follow the First National of Midland into collapse, the fallout of nonperforming energy loans may not be over. **********''I think the worst of it has been documented already, but we don't expect the full extent of the problems to be known until the fourth quarter,'' said Frank W. Anderson, a banking analyst at Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. in Dallas. **********Indeed, the headaches of Texas bankers could also spread to the state's sprawling real estate industry, which, fueled largely by oil growth, has left both Houston and Dallas with acute surpluses of commercial office space. **********''No doubt somebody is going to get hurt,'' said William Gibson, chief economist at Republicbank Dallas. **********Because of these problems, the major Texas banks are unlikely to return to the unusually high levels of profitability they sustained between 1978 and last year. In that five-year period, the seven largest banks in the state recorded an average return on assets - the most widely used measure of a bank's performance - of 1.1 percent, or 75 percent higher than the national average for large banks. Even at the end of the third quarter, these banks, excluding Interfirst, averaged a return on assets of six- tenths of 1 percent, still above the national average. **********Meanwhile, the senior officers at several Texas banks said they are broadening their loan portfolios to include the state's expanding electronics industry. They are also aggressively seeking new clients among entreprenuers and small businesses in Austin, San Antonio and other cities that are growing rapidly. **********''They've created tremendous wealth in Texas,'' said James McDerrmott, an analyst for Keefe, Bruyette and Woods in New York. ''These banks are very sound, and what we're seeing now is simply a detour from their traditional growth pattern.'' **********He added, ''The heady days of the the late 1970's and early 1980's are behind them, and it's going to take time for the wounds to heal.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.main_headline: STUDY FINDS INCREASE IN WORLD PRESS CONTROLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.print_headline: STUDY FINDS INCREASE IN WORLD PRESS CONTROLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.body_text: **********Government control of the press has increased significantly in most areas of the world in the past year, according to a new study presented to an international conference of representatives of independent news outlets that is taking place here this weekend. **********The study, drawn up by the London- based International Press Institute, an organization representing more than 2,000 newspapers and news organizations around the world, says journalists and broadcasters face reduced freedom and increased government harassment in Latin America, Asia, Africa and Eastern Europe. **********''There can be no doubt that in most parts of the world, press freedom became significantly more limited over the last year,'' the institute's president, Max L. Snijders, a Dutch editor, told the meeting, which has brought together nearly 90 editors and publishers from 25 countries. **********''In Latin America, Asia, Africa and Europe, governments have increased pressure on journalists, and are continuing to harass and to persecute them and often to close down papers they dislike,'' Mr. Snijders said.   Common Position Sought **********At their meeting here, called ''Voices of Freedom '82,'' press representatives from all over the world are trying to agree on a common position in advance of next month's general meeting of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in Paris. At this meeting, third world and Communist nations are expected to renew pressure for internationally approved curbs on press freedom. **********Two years ago the same group of editors and publishers held a similar meeting at this French alpine resort on the eve of the last Unesco general conference and issued ''the declaration of Talloires,'' a strong call for governments to defend press freedom against United Nations encroachment. **********Conference participants hope to issue a similar statement Sunday, and to review efforts to help developing countries build their own free and independent presses. **********At today's meeting, many speakers said Unesco was encouraging third world governments to reduce press freedom by saying they have a right to control the flow of information reaching their citizens and by pressing for international regulations governing journalists and the media.   Government Control Increases **********''Unesco debates are lending a respectability to government attempts to control the media,'' said Leonard R. Sussman, executive director of Freedom House, a United States organization that fights media censorship. **********The institute's new study says that in Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government has reimposed the press censorship practiced by the deposed Somoza Government. It added that in Argentina, the military authorities had regularly shut down newspapers and magazines or confiscated their issues, and many journalists have been imprisoned for their reporting while others have disappeared. **********In Turkey, the study says, the military authorities have also banned papers and fined and imprisoned journalists.   Harassment and Censorship **********In South Africa, the institute said, ''in a period of promised reform, there has been an apparent increase in detention and prosecutions and in harassment and censorship.'' **********The institute said that in Zimbabwe, ''press freedom appears to be under threat as the country moves ever nearer to a one-party state.'' In the Philippines the past year saw ''the country's first crackdown on the press since the lifting of martial law in January 1981,'' the institute said. **********The institute said that in India individual states introduce restrictive press legislation, and that in Ghana the press is run by what the Government calls ''civil servant journalists.'' The institute said that in Malaysia the Government will soon prevent foreign wire services from giving news directly to the local press.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.main_headline: EFFECTS OF PHONE STRIKE HIT EQUIPMENT MAKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.print_headline: EFFECTS OF PHONE STRIKE HIT EQUIPMENT MAKERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.body_text: **********With the strike against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in its second week, telephone equipment manufacturers who depend heavily on the continued health of the Bell System say the walkout is already hurting their operations. **********For most consumers, who use the highly automated parts of Bell's switching systems to complete their calls, the effects of the strike have so far been almost unnoticable. But for companies dependent on A.T.& T. personnel to connect them into the Bell network, and for those who supply Bell with cable, electronics and computer systems valued at millions of dollars, the walkout of 675,000 workers is already having a strong ripple effect. **********Yesterday, the Rolm Corporation, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of private branch exchanges, the switching systems used in most offices, indicated it could number among the strike's first casualties. **********Revenues and earnings for the fiscal first quarter, ending Sept. 30, will be ''adversely affected,'' the company said, because it was unable to link its PBX systems to the Bell network without phone company personnel. Rolm stock dropped $1.625 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $63.375. **********''We have systems that are all installed and ready to go,'' said Anthony V. Carollo, vice president and general manager of operating companies for Rolm, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif. ''But until Bell hooks them up to the outside world, they are just some very expensive intercom systems.'' **********In fact, industry experts say the experiences of telecommuncations companies in the past week illustrate how dependent the nation's communication infrastructure remains on the phone company, despite the rapid deregulation of the industry. In the case of Rolm and its competitors, the greatest hardship is the absence of Bell personnel to perform cut- overs, an industry term for splicing a company's internal data and voice communications system with Bell's trunk lines.  Bottom of Priority List **********The phone company has repeatedly said the managers filling in for striking workers would place new installations of equipment at the bottom of their priority list, in favor of keeping existing systems running. And while the situation will be alleviated somewhat once the strike ends, most telecommunications companies expect that long installation delays will continue after Bell's workers are back on the job. **********''We have been told that the rule of thumb is this: Every day the strike goes on, A.T.& T. gets two days behind in installations,'' Mr. Carollo said. **********Nonetheless, most analysts say that the strike should not cause lasting problems in the industry. ''As long as the strike does not drag on for months, this will only delay the revenue stream,'' said Anthony G. Langham, a vice president of Prudential- Bache Securities. ''Income that we thought would show up for this quarter will show up instead in the next quarter. It is not like losing business to a competitor.'' **********Indeed, Rolm officials said that the strike had not slowed the pace of new orders. And at Northern Telecom, a Canadian-based manufacturer of both PBX systems and central office switching equipment for the phone company, a spokesman said that there was no indication so far that business would be hurt.  Profits Noticeably Hurt **********But on Monday, Timeplex Inc., a company based in Rochelle Park, N.J., that designs electronic data communications equipment for the phone company and other customers, said its profits would be hurt noticeably by the strike. Its stock plunged $2, to $20, that day, on the New York Stock Exchange. Yesterday, its shares edged up 12.5 cents. **********Other small companies, especially distributors of telephone parts and systems, said it was too early to determine the impact of the strike. But they expected to see a decline in orders should the strike last longer than a month. **********Increasingly, the walkout is affecting businesses that find themselves in need of new telephone service. In Fremont, Calif., the Ferix Corporation, a research and development company specializing in magnetic printers, is scheduled to move into new headquarters next week. But a PBX system installed by Rolm has yet to be hooked up. **********''We are told that we are third on the list,'' said Richard DeMello, a purchaser for the company. ''But we don't know for sure. And we can't operate without phones.'' **********Should the strike put a crimp in telecommunications revenues, it would stall a relatively healthy recovery under way throughout the industry. Low capital spending last year meant that new telephone systems were delayed by many corporate customers, but analysts say orders have been up by nearly a third in the first half of 1983. **********Nonetheless, the business is growing increasingly competitive, especially as the industry repositions itself for the breakup of the Bell System on Jan. 1. At that time, companies such as Rolm and Northern Telecom will be competing directly with A.T.& T. Information Systems, the phone company subsidiary now entering the office communications market.
