https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Malta Negotiating With Hijackers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/world.body_text: **********A hijacked Libyan airliner with about 160 passengers and crew aboard remained encircled at the airport here tonight while Prime Minister Dom Mintoff negotiated with the hijackers from the control tower. **********The hijackers, believed to number three or four, warned they would blow up the plane unless their demands for fuel, food and medicine were met by a certain time, reports on the Maltese television said. **********According to unconfirmed reports, the hijackers have set such deadlines several times. **********The Maltese authorities say they will not meet any of the hijackers' demands until all passengers are released.  The plane, a Boeing 727 of Libya's national airline, landed here Sunday night after reportedly being diverted on a domestic flight from Sebha to Tripoli, the Libyan capital. The hijackers are reported to have said they intended to fly on to Morocco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.main_headline: MARINES MAY GET SAFER BEIRUT POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.print_headline: MARINES MAY GET SAFER BEIRUT POST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/27/world.body_text: **********Allied agencies reportedly have leads suggesting Iranian involvement in the bombings. Page A8. **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 - A senior Reagan Administration official indicated today that at least some marines in Lebanon would be redeployed from Beirut airport to safer places. **********The official, who is central to the policy-making process, said that the marines were in Lebanon to give confidence to the Government of President Amin Gemayel, but that this could be done from an ''expanded secure zone'' with more room for maneuver. He reiterated that the number of marines would not be increased nor their mission expanded. **********Concern over the American troops' exposed position at Beirut airport has redoubled since a truck bomb killed at least 219 marines on Sunday.    176 Marines Still Unidentified **********A Marine spokesmen said 176 servicemen remained unidentified, partly because many of them had been been asleep and had removed their dog tags. The Pentagon, while continuing to release the names of identified casualties, prepared today to make public the names of known survivors. (Page A9.) **********The senior official, speaking in a background briefing, said that President Reagan was urging Mr. Gemayel to form a government more representative of the diverse factions in Lebanon and more conscious of Syrian and Israeli interests. **********He said the success of the Gemayel Government hinged on its ability to be more credible in Syrian eyes and to satisfy Syrian interests. **********According to a number of officials, this will be the American strategy at Lebanese unity talks due to get under way in Geneva next Monday.  Secretary of State George P. Shultz said earlier this week that the United States was seeking a broader role in the present Christian-dominated Lebanese Government for the Shiite Moslems and the Druse, as a way of dealing with Syrian concerns.  The senior official said the main mission for the marines - as well as for French, Italian and British troops - was ''being there'' to establish stability and to provide time for the Lebanese Government to build its institutions. He insisted that progress was being made to these ends.  He said the international force in Beirut would continue to play this role. He described it as practical and sensible to undertake a more mobile and flexible disposition of the marines. **********This could be done in a variety of ways, he said. He mentioned additional fortifications and redeployment to more secure areas along the coast. He specifically spoke of the possibility of putting marines in villages where they could help with construction and sanitation.  In response to questions, the official did not say whether the multinational force was sufficient in size and mission to meet the goal of bringing about a stable Lebanon. Instead, he argued that withdrawal would make attainment of the goal impossible and that no Lebanese Government could be expected to have the necessary perseverance without it. **********His emphasis appeared to be on these forces' role as an adjunct to a diplomatic effort to accommodate Syrian interests. **********When asked what incentives could be offered to Syria to support a stable Lebanese Government, he said that Syria was interested in an Israeli withdrawal so that it would not have to face the Israelis on two fronts, in Lebanon and in the Golan Heights. He also said Syria had an important stake in a restored and strong Lebanese economy. **********He said that President Reagan believed that Syria had legitimate worries about its borders, and that the President would urge Mr. Gemayel to take these security interests into account. **********With regard to the existing Lebanese-Israeli agreement, opposed by Syria because it provides for Israeli withdrawal in return for Syrian withdrawal, the official said Syria could deal with its concerns ''in dialogue'' with the Lebanese Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.main_headline: BLACKS SEEN TO APPLAUD BOMB ATTACK IN PRETORIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.print_headline: BLACKS SEEN TO APPLAUD BOMB ATTACK IN PRETORIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/world.body_text: **********In virtually all their pronouncements on Friday's car bomb explosion in Pretoria, South African officials have emphasized the black casualties, apparently in the belief that sympathy among blacks for the outlawed African National Congress would give way to revulsion over the brutality of an urban bombing. **********However, soundings taken today among a rough cross-section of politically involved and also ordinary urban blacks indicate that the reaction among the section of the population that matters most to the African National Congress has been the opposite of what whites tend to assume. **********The state broadcasting monopoly and the press, as well as the Government officials, have tended to emphasize black casualties and to assume a convergence of white and black reactions to the attack.  Thus on Monday, when Defense Minister Magnus Malan pledged to avenge the dead be they ''white, black or colored,'' The Johannesburg Star commented in an editorial deploring the cycle of violence that ''South Africans mourn the Pretoria dead'' and ''perhaps even exult in the swift revenge at Maputo'' - the capital of Mozambique, which had just been the target of a reprisal attack. Leaders in 'Homelands' Quoted **********It was striking that the editorial drew no distinction between the reactions of whites and blacks. On a facing page, a headline declared, ''Black Leaders Damn Attack.'' That article quoted the reactions to the Pretoria blast only of officials in the black ''homelands'' that South Africa has created within its borders. **********This morning a commentary on the state radio declared that the Pretoria bombing had been ''universally condemned'' in South Africa by ''all communities and every sector of political opinion.'' **********But none of this has taken into account the reaction in the broad range of black opinion that can loosely be described as nationalist, in that it rejects any political settlement not based on full political rights for the majority. **********Questioned about reactions to the bombing, a black with wide contacts in political circles declared: ''People are jubilant. They long ago gave up any hope for peaceful change. What they are saying is that the African National Congress is finally hitting real targets. That is why you are having crowds of blacks drawn to the street where the bomb went off. They want to see the place where a white man died.'' Distrust of Press Cited **********Asked how they felt about the 8 blacks who were among the 18 people killed by the blast, the man replied that some blacks were so mistrustful of the official information outlets that they have taken comfort from a hypothesis that some of these dead might be the creation of Government propagandists. The reaction of others, he said, was that, ''We should just keep quiet about them and bury our dead.'' **********Another source replied to the same question by saying, ''I heard one man say, 'You can't separate the tea and the milk after they've been mixed.' They understand that there have to be black casualties in South African conditions.'' **********Older blacks who are often intensely religious and might be expected to recoil from bloodshed are also intensely loyal to the African National Congress, which was a legal movement in their youth, this man said. **********''They know how long it waited before it tried these kind of tactics,'' he said. Because of the sensitivity of the questions being asked - and the risk of official reprisals for any expression of support for ''terrorists'' - the interviews were conducted on the understanding that no one whose views were mentioned would be identified except in the most general terms. Criticism of Congress's Tactics **********The car bomb explosion has probably erased one of the most frequently voiced criticisms of the tactics of the African National Congress in black nationalist circles. This was that white strategists in its leadership were sending young blacks on ''suicide missions'' in which they were instructed to hit symbolic targets such as empty Government buildings. This time there is a widespread assumption, fostered in part by the pro-Government Afrikaans press, that the car bomb might actually have been set off by white members of the movement. **********Except among the most doctrinaire supporters of the ''black consciousness'' viewpoint, which rejects political alliances with whites, the immediate effect of the Pretoria bombing has apparently been to bolster support for the African National Congress, the sources all agreed. However, they said the early reaction and their assessment of it must both be regarded as tentative. **********Those questioned all appeared to subscribe to the general view that whites have relied on violence to maintain their power and that blacks had no choice but to respond in kind. The car bomb explosion was justified on two counts: as a reprisal for the attack last December by South African forces on African National Congress residences in Maseru, the capital of Lesotho, in which 42 people were killed, and as a strike against a military target. No Tally of Military Casualties **********The office buildings outside which the bomb went off housed South Africa's air force command. The Star's editorial estimated that about half the dead and injured worked for the armed forces in one capacity or another, but there has been no official tally of military casualties. **********The black reactions proved to be a mirror image of what whites have been saying to justify the strikes of the armed forces across the border. In each case, the deaths of bystanders is deplored but blamed on the extremism of the other side. ''It is unfortunate that innocent civilians were involved,'' a black social worker said, ''but the motive of the attack was very clear. The black fatalities are just part of the larger sacrifices that we as a nation have to face and accept.'' **********The mother of two young men who have left the country to join what is called ''the struggle'' commented: ''The boys have finally struck where it hurts most. This will make the Government realize that our sons are away from home and dearly want to return. There will never be an end to this as long as the gates to their country remain closed to them.'' Hope for Negotiation Voiced **********''You don't want to call the deaths of innocent people a good thing,'' a teacher observed, ''but maybe some people will begin to realize now how valuable all human life is and take steps to negotiation.'' **********Such justifications were sometimes streaked with foreboding. A man who offers tutoring in English in the black township of Soweto called the news of the bombing ''good but alarming.'' He said it signaled ''a bleak future for the country as a whole.'' **********A middle-aged security guard said he thought the fighting should be kept out of the cities, but added: ''It will make the Boers realize that these boys mean business too and have the guts to fight.'' Boer, the Afrikaans word for farmer, is sometimes used as a pejorative ethnic label by blacks. **********''They hit them! It was out of this world!'' said a 19-year-old school dropout who sounded exultant. ''The cops, the whites didn't expect a black man to strike so hard.'' A.N.C. GLANCE African National Congress History **********The African National Congress was founded in the Orange Free State in January 1912 ''to defend Africans against repression.'' In the early years, its orientation was reformist rather than revolutionary, and it tried to achieve its goals through legal political action only. In 1949 it adopted a ''Program of Action'' that included nonviolent civil disobedience. **********On March 21, 1960, a protest against laws requiring South African blacks to carry passes resulted in the shooting of nearly 300 blacks in Sharpeville. Subsequently banned, the group went underground. On Dec. 16, 1961, Nelson Mandela, a leader of the group, formed Umkhonto We Sizwe, which is Zulu for Spear of the Nation, a military command that began a campaign of sabotage against ''the symbols of apartheid,'' using, in particular, rocket attacks against police stations. **********Two years later, South African police found the underground headquarters of the African National Congress in Rivonia, a suburb of Johannesburg. Mr. Mandela and other leaders of the organization were arrested. In 1964, Mr. Mandela was sentenced to life in prison. He is in a maximum security prison near Cape Town. **********Several other leaders of the group, including its current president, Oliver Tambo, left the country to rebuild the organization abroad. **********For the rest of the 1960's, the exiled group concentrated on diplomacy and propaganda. Since the late 1970's, guerrilla and sabotage activities have steadily increased but the group has avoided indiscrimiate violence. The recent bombing in Pretoria, according to Thomas Karis, an expert on South African politics at the Graduate School of the City University in New York, ''marks a historic shift if it is the beginning of guerrilla action that harms civilian bystanders.'' Goals **********Mfanafuthi Makatini, head of the group's mission to the United Nations, where it has observer status, describes the organization as a national liberation movement whose goal is ''to defend Africans against repressive white laws.'' **********He said the group favors the creation of a democratic society ''for all South African people regardless of race, color or creed.'' It is an independent organization, he added, ''non-Communist but not anti-Communist.'' Mr. Makatini denied South African charges that the group is controlled by Moscow through its Communist members. Structure **********The ruling body of the group is the National Executive Committee based in Lusaka, Zambia. Its 18 members are South African blacks.  Below the National Executive Committee is the Revolutionary Council, whose members are leaders of the organizations in the A.N.C. alliance, including people of Indian or Asian origin and whites. The task of the Revolutionary Council is to carry out the program of the National Executive Committee. **********Below the Revolutionary Council are such organs as the military command and the information department.  The group receives money from many governmental and nongovernmental groups in the Communist bloc, Western Eu- rope and the third world. Leadership **********Nelson Mandela, 65 years old, is considered the leading figure in the organization despite his being in prison. Oliver Tambo, also 65 and formerly Mr. Mandela's law partner, is president. Alfred Nzo, a longtime activist, is secretary general. Thomas Nkobi is treasurer general. **********Several surveys indicate broad support for the group among South African blacks, but there are no official membership figures or claims.

Reed, vice president of administration; Thomas K. Chun, vice president and controller, and Ronald R. Schmidt, vice president of operations. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.main_headline: AS MUBARAK CRACKS DOWN ON GRAFT, BAKSHEESH LOSES A LITTLE OF ITS LUSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.print_headline: AS MUBARAK CRACKS DOWN ON GRAFT, BAKSHEESH LOSES A LITTLE OF ITS LUSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/world.body_text: **********A driver protested furiously on a chaotic main street this week as a Cairo traffic policeman scribbled a parking violation ticket. The driver's angry cries drew a crowd, most of whom sympathized with him. But the policeman was unmoved. **********The issuance of a ticket is an ordinary enough event in most places, but not here.  Baksheesh is endemic at all levels of society. The word is hard to translate; it can be a tip or a bribe. **********But in the driver's case it did not work. The ticket seemed to be a small sign of the change that the Government of President Hosni Mubarak is trying to bring to various levels of Egytian society. The President has said reordering the stumbling economy and making Egyptian society more equitable are his chief domestic goals. **********So far he has ordered a crackdown on corruption, and has moved to put into effect stricter housing legislation to curb a widespread flouting of building codes. He has also ordered a sharp cutback in imports of such luxury items as cosmetics and foreign cheeses as part of an effort to narrow the unfavorable gap between imports and exports. Numerous Foreign Trips **********At the same time, the Egyptian leader has been making foreign trips and apparently trying to show that Egypt is not in thrall to the United States despite a dependence on American loans and aid. **********On Thursday night Mr. Mubarak left on a 10-day trip to China, Japan, North Korea and Indonesia. Egyptian officials say the emphasis of the visits, particularly the one to Japan, will be to obtain economic and trade commitments. **********Aid from Japan has been running at about $180 million a year. This year Egypt is expected to receive about $210 million from Japan, mainly for agricultural and fishery projects, and an official announcement is expected during his visit to Tokyo. Mr. Mubarak is also said to be eager to persuade the Japanese to take a bigger financial role in Egyptian banking. **********In China, talks are due on intensifying agricultural and trade ties. Military aid is also on the agenda. In the past China has provided some warplanes and spare parts. In North Korea, Mr. Mubarak is due to discuss obtaining Soviet-made spare parts for aging Egyptian military equipment, and in Indonesia he is expected to stress Egypt's ties with third world countries. Cuts in Government Spending **********At a recent meeting with his economic aides, Mr. Mubarak said efforts must be made to cut Government outlays without raising the prices of subsidized basic commodities. In 1977, when prices on such subsidized items as bread, cooking oil and sugar were reduced, street riots erupted, resulting in many deaths and threatening to topple President Anwar el-Sadat. **********The economic outlook appears bleaker today than some months ago.  Projections for next year's Government budget, which has not yet been announced, indicate a deficit of nearly $2 billion, with about $500 million of that resulting from a drop in profits on Egyptian oil exports. Egypt recently cut its price for top-grade oil from $29 to $27 a barrel after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced agreement on a drop from $34 to $29 a barrel. **********Since coming to power after Mr. Sadat was assassinated at a military parade on Oct. 6, 1981, Mr. Mubarak has moved at a measured pace to bring about changes. **********His command over the unicameral Parliament, overwhelmingly dominated by his ruling National Democratic Party, seems firm. But he has received some criticism from opposition groups like the small Socialist Democratic Party because of his measured pace. A More Critical Press **********The Government-supervised Egyptian press is more critical and unfettered than it was in the last days of Mr. Sadat's rule. Lately the President has earned public approval because of his muchpublicized anti-corruption drive. **********The chief target has been Mr. Sadat's half-brother, Esmat, who rose during the Sadat Presidency from a $60-a-month bus driver to a man with a fortune estimated at $150 million. Esmet and three of his sons were sentenced in February to a year in jail by an ethics court, which also confiscated their property and that of seven other members of the family. **********The state prosecutor general is reviewing the case, which includes charges of illegal acquisition of land, influence peddling, black market dealings and the importation and sale of rotten food. Two members of the Egyptian Cabinet - Supply Minister Ahmed Nouh and Industry Minister Fuad Abu Zaghla - were forced to resign after their names were mentioned in the investigation of Mr. Sadat. **********The trial has sent shudders through a newly rich Egyptian class that gained enormous profits from President Sadat's open-door economic policy, an international move that brought a glut of foreign consumer items on the market from cosmetics to tape recorders. Steel Plants, Not Perfume **********Mr. Mubarak has said he will continue the policy but it has to be reordered to wipe out the heavy emphasis on consumer luxuries. He wants foreign investments that will help add steel plants and other components of a sturdy industrial base. **********According to Egyptian and diplomatic officials, Mr. Mubarak has ''a huge stake,'' as one put it, in what happens in Lebanon, although he is not a direct participant. **********Mr. Mubarak has been steadfast in his support of the Egyptian treaty with Israel despite calls in the Arab world for its abrogation. He has said the treaty is proof that peaceful tactics can work in the search for Middle East stability. **********But the current impasse in the talks on withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon has caused concern here that this argument is being weakened at a time of what seems to be improvement in Egypt's relations with Arab nations that broke ties because of the treaty. **********Mr. Mubarak has been calling for speedy action by Arabs to take up President Reagan's proposal last September for autonomy for Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip in association with Jordan. He has been addressing his call especially to King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, asserting that the crucial American voice in peace talks may be diminished as Presidential elections approach next year in the United States. **********In domestic affairs, President Mubarak's public style has been different from that of President Sadat. Mr. Sadat made a point of placing himself alone in the foreground, with his aides kept in the shadows. Mr. Mubarak has brought the officials into the picture, and diplomats here note that he thus can share any criticism and blame as well as praise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/busin.main_headline: BBC BROWN BOVERI APPOINTS U.S. HEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; BBC BROWN BOVERI APPOINTS U.S. HEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/busin.body_text: **********Klaus E. Agthe has been put in charge of the combined United States operations of BBC Brown Boveri, the Swiss producer of electric generation, distribution and control equipment. **********Mr. Agthe has been given the newly created posts of president and chief executive officer of the company's United States arm, with headquarters in New York. **********Brown Boveri operates four United States companies, and Mr. Agthe said they had been running more or less independently.  ''It's very difficult to manage from Europe, as we and other European companies here found out,'' Mr. Agthe said. ''Now we have a central focus, a uniform business approach, and we will go forward from there.'' **********Brown Boveri employs 3,000 people and generates sales of $400 million a year in the United States. Brown Boveri's strategy, in the homeland of the likes of General Electric and Westinghouse, is to look for special segments of the market. ''We don't intend to compete across the board,'' Mr. Agthe said. Europeans have long learned how to economize in energy use, he said, and have special technology to offer. **********Mr. Agthe, now 52, was born in what became East Germany. After World War II, he went to school in Berlin. Later he came to the United States and went to business school at Indiana University. **********But the best ''school'' he attended, he said, was after he went to work in West Germany for a company that was taken over by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation. Harold Geneen, I.T.T.'s leader, would conduct nightlong staff sessions at the company's offices in Brussels, and Mr. Agthe, as a young staff member, sat in. ''That was the best schooling I could ever have had,'' he said. **********In 1966 Mr. Agthe joined the Continental Group, a diversified packager, and rose to become a corporate vice president in charge of packaging operations and business development in Asia, Africa and the Middle East. He went to Brown Boveri from Continental.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Group Rotation And Moods
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Group Rotation And Moods
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.body_text: **********GROUP rotation continued to be the name of the game last week in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, meanwhile, finished at 1,225.71, down 14.03 points. **********Indicative of the market's fast-changing mood, the industrial average on Monday moved from an early 20-point gain to a 10-point loss at the close, in the wake of rumors that the Federal Reserve had miscalculated its money supply numbers. That brought a denial from the Fed, but it failed to impart any sense of direction to what seemed essentially a market without a rudder. **********The changing face of market favorites has persisted for most of this year. At various times, favorites have included interest-sensitive stocks, technology high-fliers, basic industry issues and ''hot new issues.'' While sustained gains have been virtually impossible for any individual sector, this group rotation has a way of correcting market excesses. **********But it has proven to be a puzzling environment for small investors and professional portfolio managers alike. At a private meeting of a dozen money managers on Friday, the prevailing sentiment was that stock prices would move higher over the next 6 to 12 months. However, some of these managers now are carrying larger-than-usual cash positions. **********In the first glorious year of the bull market, which began in August 1982, brokerage stocks were the top-performing group. This sector soared 255 percent, as measured by Standard & Poor's survey of 89 industries.  However, as proof of the market's changing leadership, most brokerage issues tumbled last week. The biggest casualty was Merrill Lynch, dropping 5 1/8 points, to 36 7/8, as the most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of the world's largest brokerage house sold two months ago at a record price of 56 1/2. **********Last week's sharp drop followed Merrill's disclosure that it would report ''substantially lower'' profits for the 1983 third quarter, compared with last year, because of a combination of lower trading volume, which translates into reduced commission income, and increased operating costs. **********Meanwhile, railroad stocks enjoyed their turn in the investment sun. Among other factors, railroads are perceived as beneficiaries of an improving economy. Two vast rail systems traded at new highs: CSX Corporation gained 5/8, to 72 5/8, after selling at a record price of 73 3/4. Burlington Northern, edging ahead 1/8, to 97 3/8, saw its shares trade at a high of 99 3/4 during the week. Individuals Still Buying **********While some large institutions have been taking profits and piling up a war chest of cash lately, individual investors continue to buy stocks. This pattern was borne out by the market's roller-coaster performance on Monday and, somewhat earlier, by the persistent appetite of individuals to buy stock on margin. **********The Big Board reported that margin debt of customers at its member firms rose to a record in August for the 11th straight month, to $19.1 billion, from the previous month's $18.9 billion. The number of margin account customers also set a new record - 805,000, up from 790,000 in July. **********A customer with a margin account is borrowing money from his broker, and the stock is used as collateral for the loan to help pay for the shares. The percentage of cash a person must put up to open a margin account is set by the Fed. Since 1974 this margin requirement has remained at 50 percent. **********Most technical analysts consider a rising tide of margin debt as a bullish sign. But the slim 1.2 percent increase between July and August could indicate that individuals are tempering their enthusiasm for stocks. A look at margin-debt figures indicates that individuals were somewhat slow to climb on the bull market's bandwagon, fueled initially in August 1982 by huge purchases on the part of pension funds and other institutional investors. Between the end of July 1982 and the end of September 1982, margin debt actually contracted, slipping by $520 million to reach $10.95 billion. Effect of Interest Rates **********The direction of interest rates, virtually everyone agrees, will set the tone for both stock prices and bond prices in the period ahead. Ronald A. Glantz, chief investment officer of Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., said last week that his firm continues to believe that interest rates will decline over the balance of 1983 and then increase next summer. **********''In any event, we advocate group rotation,'' he said in a strategy report. ''Basic industry seems to be in the middle of its relative move, capital goods have entered their move, and consumer nondurables appear to be next.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.print_headline: BRITAIN'S NUCLEAR BATTLE: THE POLITICAL LINES FORM; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/world.body_text: **********When Vice President Bush arrives in Britain next month at the end of his seven-nation European tour, he will find America's closest European ally torn with uncertainty about nuclear weapons and strategy. **********And when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, by far the Reagan Administration's staunchest European supporter, faces the British electorate later this year or early next, she will find herself challenged at every turn on the same issues. Apart from the domestic economy, they have become the central questions in British politics. **********In the past year, the old consensus over military policy has broken down. The Tories under Mrs. Thatcher are committed to the emplacement of American cruise missiles, the purchase of Trident missiles to replace the aging Polaris system and a generally tough line toward Moscow. The Labor Party under Michael Foot is equally committed to removing all nuclear weapons from Britain, whether British or American, and to vigorous pursuit of an arms-reduction pact with Moscow. **********Protest Has Grown **********The nuclear question has been thrust into the forefront of political debate here not only by the Labor Party but also by antinuclear pressure groups. The ''peace camp'' at Greenham Common, 50 miles west of London, started by a few women to protest the planned installation there later this year of Europe's first cruise missiles, has grown into a worldwide symbol of the drive to ''ban the bomb.'' **********In a sense, the appointment last week of Michael Heseltine as Minister of Defense was a measure of the seriousness with which the Prime Minister takes the growing antinuclear sentiment. He is not one of her intimates, and she probably would have preferred to give the position to someone else; Mr. Heseltine got it, according to Conservative leaders, because he was thought to be the man best equipped to lead the counterattack against Labor on disarmament. **********The change in assessment at 10 Downing Street is an important one.  As antinuclear sentiment built up in Britain during 1982, prominent Tories tended at first to dismiss it, as one Cabinet member last spring did as ''a lot of froth generated by the old pinko fringe.'' **********It is no longer possible to be so dismissive. In the latest Gallup poll, completed in mid-November, 72 percent of the electorate pronounced itself worried about nuclear weapons. Although two-thirds of the public said they opposed unilateral disarmament for Britain, almost a third favored it. And only 41 percent said they thought Britain's independent deterrent decreased the probability of a nuclear attack on this country, as against 52 percent who said the deterrent increased that possibility or had no effect at all. Archbishop Is Involved **********Prominent people in no way associated with the far left have also been voicing their concern. In his Christmas sermon, the Most Rev.  Robert Runcie, Archbishop of Canterbury, said a full-scale nuclear war was unwinnable, said it was madness even to contemplate such a war and applauded those who demonstrate against nuclear weapons. In February, the Church of England, which Dr. Runcie heads, will debate a new report of a working party on ''The Church and the Bomb'' that looks with favor upon disarmament with Britain acting alone. **********Many middle-of-the-road newspapers are devoting an increasing amount of space to the nuclear question. The Sunday Times, for example, described it as ''the most crucial issue for 1983'' in a New Year's editorial. The paper called for cancellation of the purchase of Trident, changes in the means of control of cruise missiles and much more serious bargaining with the Soviet Union on arms reduction. **********One of the important strands in antinuclear feeling in Britain is the fear that Moscow and Washington contemplate fighting a nuclear war on the soil of Western Europe. Alex Kitson, a Scottish labor union and political leader, puts it this way, ''When they talk about limited nuclear war in the States, they mean it would be limited to us.'' The Current Focus **********That feeling has coalesced around the 96 cruise missiles that are to begin arriving at Greenham Common - technically a Royal Air Force Base but actually under the control of the United States - sometime next winter. The women who set up the ''peace camp'' 15 months ago outside the base's main gate and have kept it going in fair weather and foul freely admit to making a basically emotional appeal to others who, as one of them said last week, ''don't want the world blown up.'' **********''The impetus for the campaign,'' commented Helen Swarbrick, one of the 30,000 women who linked hands in protest around the base last month, ''is the idea that we don't like violence rather than any sort of argument for or against the Americans being here or how many weapons we should have. It means you don't get mixed up in silly arguments about numbers. It's simplified and idealistic, but the goal and direction are clear.'' **********Gillian Booth, who has already spent two weeks in prison for her activites at the camp, adds: ''I would like to see all countries get rid of nuclear weapons, including Britain. But you can only bring pressure in the country that you happen to be living in.'' **********It appears inevitable that the protests will intensify as the election campaign and the arrival of the missiles comes closer. In addition, Mr. Foot, who had been following a fairly circumspect course, has recently put his prestige and that of his party behind the Greenham Common protestors with a visit to the camp, a Christmas present of a Cheddar cheese and an attack on Mrs. Thatcher's weapons policy in his New Year's message. Issue of Dual Control **********''At every twist in her attitude to the nuclear arms race,'' he said, ''our Prime Minister displays her refusal or her incapacity to understand what it means, and the terms on which she has agreed to station American cruise missiles here in Britain provided a truly strange commentary on the Thatcherite idea of national sovereignty.'' **********Playing on nationalistic feeling, Labor spokesmen, including Denis Healey, who opposes his own party's demand for Britain to act alone on disarmament, have been pressing the Government to insist on dual control of cruise missiles, such as that which applies to some weapons based on the Continent. Dual control would mean that no cruise missile could be fired without the approval of both British and American officials. **********Francis Pym, the Foreign Secretary, told Mr. Healey in the House of Commons that such control would be highly desirable but added that he could ''not give that assurance.'' A few days later, Secretary of State George P. Shultz, on a visit here, brushed the idea aside. But it has almost unanimous support among Labor M.P.'s and some backing among the Tory backbenchers. **********In addition, it is strongly advocated by Dr. David Owen, the former Labor Foreign Secretary who is now one of the leaders of the new Social Democratic Party. Dr. Owen, who abandoned his old colleagues in part because he could not stomach their so-called unilateralism, said the British people must be given the assurance that cruise missiles cannot be fired here without the approval of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. A Middle Position **********The Social Democrats are trying to carve out a position between the two major parties, favoring the abandonment of Trident like Labor, favoring the retention of American nuclear bases and an independent British deterrent like the Conservatives, and arguing, in a policy paper published over the weekend, that a decision on cruise deployment should await the outcome of the arms limitation talks in Geneva. **********Their allies, the Liberals, are officially committed to the abandonment of the independent deterrent, the renewal of which, through the purchase of the Trident, is thought likely to cost more than $15 billion. The party is split on the cruise missiles, with the Liberal Council opposing their deployment and the party leader, David Steel, making it clear that he does not feel bound by the council's stand. **********''For every party,'' a leading Liberal said at the end of last year, ''evolving a clear policy on cruise missiles and defending it vigorously is the primary business of the new political year.'' **********The missiles were originally intended to guarantee Western Europe's security in the face of Soviet SS-20's, and the plan to deploy them was conceived in part at the request of the Europeans. But now they are seen by growing numbers of people, here and elsewhere, as increasing the chances of war. Their defenders argue that they are necessary to maintain the nuclear balance and that if Europe refused them, some or all American troops might be pulled out of West Germany; their critics say that they would simply make it easier for the United States and the Soviet Union to fight a nuclear war without intercontinental missiles. Outlook for Mrs. Thatcher **********For Mrs. Thatcher, a hard road seems to lie ahead, even with the help of the rhetorical skills of Mr. Heseltine. At a time of mounting anxiety about nuclear weapons and at a time of increased spending on the garrison in the Falkland Islands, she must defend not only vast outlays for Trident but also the deployment of the cruise missiles. **********Some Cabinet members appear to be having second thoughts about Trident on economic grounds, although none so far has even semipublicly advocated a reversal of the decision to buy the system, and the Government is beginning to lose ground with usually friendly commentators. Malcolm Rutherford of The Financial Times said not long ago that Mrs. Thatcher was overextended in the whole area of military policy. **********If the Prime Minister and her associates can successfully paint Mr. Foot as an extremist who might pull Britain out of NATO or dangerously reduce the country's military capacities, she might win the argument. The country, as opinion polls show, is not yet unilateralist. But if, on the other hand, she retains a hard line on arms negotiation and shows no sign of responding to the nation's concern while Mr. Foot makes his appeal in relatively moderate terms, the issue could hurt the Conservatives at the polls and even, conceivably, help Labor to win. **********On the eve of taking up his duties at the Defense Ministry, Mr.  Heseltine said he intended to engage in a ''constructive dialogue'' with the antinuclear movement while keeping in mind the need to counter Soviet strength. To many, his comments sounded like the opening shot in a campaign to put a more politically acceptable face on Mrs. Thatcher's policies in preparation for the electoral battle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.main_headline: 8 FRENCH JETS HIT MILITIA POSITIONS IN LEBANON CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.print_headline: 8 FRENCH JETS HIT MILITIA POSITIONS IN LEBANON CLASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/world.body_text: **********French jet fighters attacked anti-Government gun batteries behind Syrian lines in mountains east of Beirut today, shortly after a barrage of rockets rained down on French and Italian troops in the capital. **********The air attack, flown by eight Super Etendard planes from the carrier Foch, marked the first time the French have become directly embroiled in fighting with the Syrian-backed Druse militiamen, Palestinian guerrillas and Lebanese leftists. **********It was also the first time that any of the American, French, Italian or British contingents of the international force here have introduced fighter planes into the conflict. 6 French Troops Wounded **********A French Embassy spokesman said the fighters ''retaliated against sources of fire that had inflicted damage on French forces in Beirut in the past few days.'' Today's rocket barrage landed in southeastern suburbs of the capital. **********Four French soldiers were wounded as the French Army headquarters was hit in the bombardment, a military spokesman said. He said two other French soldiers were wounded when gunmen tossed a grenade at their truck as it was crossing between East and West Beirut. The casualties brought to 50 the number of French soldiers wounded since the 2,000-member contingent arrived more than a year ago; 16 have been killed. **********Ammunition Depot Hit **********Eight or nine rockets scored direct hits on the Italian contingent's ammunition depot in the Hazmiye quarter, blowing up almost all munitions in it, an Italian spokesman said. He said there were no casualties. **********(In Washington, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a compromise formula that would permit the continued deployment of American troops in Lebanon for an additional 18 months. Page A16.) **********Western military sources said the French planes flew in two waves of four each around 5:15 P.M. With two fighters flying cover, the sources said, the others attacked a battery of six Soviet- made 130-millimeter guns just south of the Syrian-controlled village of Sofar, 12 miles southeast of the southern areas of the capital. **********According to the Christian Phalangist radio, the planes also hit artillery batteries behind Syrian lines near the village of Dur Shuweir. Not Clear Who Manned Guns **********The Western military sources said it was not clear whether the anti-Government artillery positions attacked by the French were being manned by Syrian, Druse, Palestinian or Lebanese leftist troops. Nor was it clear, the sources said, whether the positions were destroyed in the raids. **********Shortly after the French air strike, the makeshift Lebanese Air Force base at Jubail, 24 miles miles north of Beirut, was attacked by a barrage of rockets, as was the Lebanese Army position in Khalde, on the coastal road just south of the capital. **********In other military action today, Lebanese troops holding the town of Suk al Gharb, on a ridge overlooking Beirut, came under repeated attacks by the Druse and their allies through the day. The attacks were repulsed.   U.S. Reconnaissance Flights **********Two hours before the French air raids, American F-14 Tomcats from the aircraft carrier Eisenhower flew reconnaissance missions over the capital. American jets have been confined to such flights so far, although American warships shelled Druse and Palestinian troops on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of this week. **********On Monday, the French Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, criticized the United States for opening fire from naval vessels in support of Lebanese Army units defending Suk al Gharb. The shelling was undertaken under a policy authorized by President Reagan allowing the United States contingent to call in air or naval strikes in support of the Lebanese Army if the army is attacked in a way that endangers the Americans. **********Today, the French Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, announced in Paris that his Government had given French troops in Beirut permission to make use of their ''right to legitimate self-defense and to reply against the batteries that have taken as targets French objectives in Beirut.''  A French Decision **********The French decision to retaliate was made by them alone, just as the Americans alone decided when they wanted to use their naval guns. The French, Italian, British and American contingents of the international each have liaison officers stationed with the other three units to coordinate any military decisions they have made and to insure that they do not run into each other. **********But there is no overall commander making military decisions on behalf of the international force as a whole. General policy for the force is set once a week at a meeting, under Lebanese Government chairmanship, of the four Ambassadors and four commanders from the contributing countries. **********Meanwhile, some 600 to 700 Druse civilians took to the streets of West Beirut today in a campaign to win over American public opinion. **********Chanting ''Yankee go home!'' and marching behind a banner reading ''Lebanon - another Vietnam?'' they walked to the temporary United States Embassy offices next to the British Embassy and presented a letter of protest to Robert Phugh, the American deputy chief of mission. **********Almost all the banners and signs being carried by the marchers were in English, for the benefit of American television networks and photographers covering the march. It was one of the largest marches in Beirut since before the 1975-76 civil war.   'Pushing the Other Parties' **********The demonstrators complained in their letter, delivered by four leaders of their social welfare organization, the Permanent Bureau for the Druse Institutions, that the United States was siding with the Lebanese Christian Phalangists, ''thus pushing the other parties to seek closer alliances with external forces in order to insure their legitimate self-defense.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.main_headline: CARTER, IN ISRAEL, SAYS ARABS MOVE TOWARD PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.print_headline: CARTER, IN ISRAEL, SAYS ARABS MOVE TOWARD PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/13/world.body_text: **********Former President Jimmy Carter said today that there had been ''a great move toward moderation'' in the Arab world in the last three years. **********Speaking at a news conference at the end of a five-day visit to Israel, Mr. Carter also accused the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of having a ''narrow'' view of the Camp David accords as they apply to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. He said Israel could carry out on its own its limited version of selfadministration for the Palestinians. **********Mr. Carter spent today touring the West Bank by limousine, driving through the Arab town of Ramallah and the Jewish settlement of Maaleh Adumim. Scattered demonstrations followed him, but he said later that he had not seen any of them. Arab youths in Ramallah threw stones at automobiles following his motorcade, but no vehicles in his immediate party were hit. **********On Arab attitudes, he said that if current statements by Arab leaders were compared with those of three years ago, one could see that ''there's obviously a great move toward moderation, and a great move toward peace.'' **********In the absence of what he saw as a leader of vision like President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, Mr. Carter said the movement would be ''incremental, evolutionary progress toward peace.'' He expressed the hope that King Hussein of Jordan would enter talks. **********On Sunday, Mr. Carter is scheduled to cross the Jordan River to Amman, where he is to meet King Hussein. During the rest of his trip, he is to see King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon. **********Asked about the failure of the Camp David process to produce an agreement on Palestinian autonomy, Mr. Carter blamed both the Arab and Israeli sides. The first reason, he said, was ''the reluctance of the Jordanians and the Palestinians to come forward and negotiate, as was called for in the Camp David accords themselves.'' **********Second, he said, was ''the sharp disparity between the concept of full autonomy as offered by Prime Minister Begin and his Government on the one hand, as contrasted with the concept that both President Sadat and I had at the conclusion of Camp David.'' **********Asked if this did not point to a flaw in the Camp David framework, which allowed such varied interpretations of ''autonomy,'' Mr. Carter replied that hours had been spent during the talks ''looking in thesauruses, dictionaries, studying the history of other examples of autonomy around the world. I never considered that the definition of autonomy would be so narrow as has been preferred by the Israeli Government.'' **********Mr. Carter said the Israelis had put forward ''a long list of duties for which the Palestinians have been offered a very limited authority. In each instance, I believe, the Israelis have wanted to retain an absolute veto power.'' In some key areas, he said, such as water and land, ''the offer of autonomy did not remain.'' **********''My hope,'' Mr. Carter continued, ''is that with the possible joining of the autonomy talks by King Hussein and the Palestinians, this limited offer by the Israeli Government, which I considered when I was President to be inadequate, will be expanded.'' **********But in the meantime, he said, even that limited version could be put into effect by Israel. ''There's never been anything to prevent this, what I consider to be a very limited degree of autonomy, from being given unilaterally to those who live on the West Bank and Gaza,'' he said. ''It would be a very easy thing for the Israeli Government to do, it would be a true demonstration of a commitment to the concept of autonomy.'' The Israeli package, Mr. Carter said, ''could very easily be granted overnight.'' **********He said that seeing the Jewish settlements in the West Bank, many of which have now become high-rise satellite cities, had been discouraging.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/busin.main_headline: Less Oil Used By U.S. in '82
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/busin.print_headline: Less Oil Used By U.S. in '82
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/busin.body_text: **********The United States consumed almost 6 percent less oil in 1982 and cut oil imports by 20 percent compared with the previous year, the American Petroleum Institute reported today. **********The institute said total oil products supplied for the domestic market were 15.1 million barrels a day in 1981, down 5.5 percent from 1981. **********This reflected the recession and conservation efforts, the institute said. **********Crude oil imports fell 20 percent in 1982 from the previous year, to 3.3 million barrels a day. The institute said imports now make up 32 percent of United States oil supplies, down from 45 percent in 1979. **********United States domestic crude oil production rose 1 percent in 1982 from 1981, to 8.6 million barrels a day. The institute said most of the increase came from new production in Alaska, while production in the other states was unchanged. **********Crude oil stocks at the end of the year totaled 348.1 million barrels, down 4.2 percent from the end of 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/09/world.main_headline: WEINBERGER TO MEET SAUDI DEFENSE MINISTER IN PARIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/09/world.print_headline: WEINBERGER TO MEET SAUDI DEFENSE MINISTER IN PARIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/09/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger will meet in Paris this week with the Saudi Defense Minister to discuss the Middle East, according to American and French officials. **********The officials offered few details about the talks with the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan. Mr. Weinberger's trip to Paris, where he is expected Tuesday, also coincides with the arrival of Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq, who is also Foreign Minister, and a visit here by Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who arrived here today after a two-week trip to the Middle East. **********Mr. Shultz is scheduled to attend the annual ministerial meeting of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, and Mr.  Aziz plans to talk to French officials. Their presence in Paris, along with that of Prince Sultan, comes at a time of intense activity on the situation in Lebanon. **********The French Defense Ministry said today that it was replacing the 2,000 men of the Ninth Marine Infantry Division it now has in Beirut as part of the international peacekeeping force with elements from the Foreign Legion. Changeover to Start May 19 **********Although a statement said the changeover, to start May 19, was regularly planned, the Foreign Legion has been traditionally used by French governments in situations where there is an attempt to avoid casualties among regular army troops and conscripts. **********French news reports from the Middle East have concentrated in the past days on the worsening security situation in Lebanon, and the Defense Ministry announcement today said a five-vessel French naval unit was now in the eastern Mediterranean and ''if necessary, could head for Beirut at any moment.'' **********French sources said Mr. Weinberger would meet here with Defense Minister Charles Hernu. They noted, again without elaboration, that Prince Sultan, who will talk to Mr. Hernu on the possibility of new Saudi purchases of French weapons, would be in Paris at the same time. **********American officials have sought to portray Mr. Weinberger's meeting with Prince Sultan as a routine result of the establishment last year of a United States-Saudi military coordinating committee. Mr.  Weinberger is described as having a close personal relationship with the Prince. Arms From France **********The mission of the Iraqi Foreign Minister, whose visit comes at a time when Iraq's war effort against Iran appears in difficulty, was thought to be mainly involved with seeking new arms from France, which ranks as Iraq's second source of military supply, after the Soviet Union. **********The Iraqis, who have bought more than $3 billion worth of French arms in the last two years, largely with Saudi money and extensive credit, are now believed to be seeking five Super Etendard fighter planes armed with Exocet air-sea missiles. The missiles were those used with success by the Argentine Air Force against British ships in the Falkland war. **********Although the official Government position here is one of aiding Iraq as much as possible to avoid its defeat by Iran, there are some signs that the French Government is hesitant about providing the planes and missiles for fear they will used against shipping in the Persian Gulf. Iraqi attacks on Iranian offshore oil wells led to the enormous oil spills that did great ecological damage to the waterway this spring. **********The United States, according to French sources, has been quietly urged by Arab moderates to try to draw closer to Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/07/busin.body_text: **********Government and industry officials have denied a contention by the United States semiconductor industry that Japan is using unfair trade practices to dominate the world market in computer memory parts. **********A spokesman for the Japan Electronic Industry Association said Friday that the American charges were ''groundless,'' but declined to comment further. **********The report, released Thursday in Washington by leaders of the Semiconductor Industry Association, said that Japanese competition was draining the American microelectronics industry of profits, and that the Japanese were undercutting the United States industry on prices with the help of Government subsidies. **********Labor costs are not substantially different in the two countries, the study maintained. But it said the Japanese Government uses hundreds of millions of dollars in loans and grants, tax breaks and Government sponsorship of ''research cartels'' to encourage companies. **********An official of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry said there was nothing wrong with his Government's policy of subsidizing some industrial research.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Levi Strauss Organizes A Marketing Subsidiary **********Leo P. Isotalo was named yesterday to head a new unit of Levi Strauss & Company that will market its non- Levi's brands. **********Mr. Isotalo, 47, will be president of Battery Street Enterprises, a subsidiary that will market the diversified brands of Koret of North America, Oxxford, Rainfair and Resistol. **********Battery Street Enterprises will also be in charge of any new brands that Levi Strauss acquires. **********The San Francisco-based company said, however, that secondary brands such as David Hunter, currently associated with the domestic division, would not be affected. **********Mr. Isotalo, who is on a business trip to Brazil, is executive vice president of Levi Strauss International Group II, with responsibility for Canada, Latin America and Asia (Pacific). **********The company also announced that it was reorganizing its international group. Lee C. Smith, 41, was named executive vice president, Levi Strauss International, effective March 4. Currently, the company's international operations are divided into two groups. **********The restructured company will consist of the men's wear, women's wear, jeans and youth wear divisions, Levi Strauss International and Battery Street Enterprises. **********At Battery Street Enterprises, Raymond J. Kittelberger, 47, was named senior vice president and chief financial officer. **********Richard A. Banks, 44, was appointed to succeed Mr. Kittelberger as president of Koret of North America. Robert D. Rockey Jr., 42, succeeds Mr. Banks as president of Levi's women's wear.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/08/world.main_headline: Irish Electorate Votes On an Abortion Ban
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/08/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Irish Electorate Votes On an Abortion Ban
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/08/world.body_text: **********Only half of Ireland's electorate voted today on an amendment enshrining an abortion ban in the Irish Constitution. **********Opposition leaders reported widespread voting irregularities. **********Abortion, along with divorce and birth control devices, already is illegal in Ireland, where 94 percent of the population is Roman Catholic. But anti- abortionists want to write an abortion ban into the Constitution to prevent future challenges by liberals or the European Court of Justice. **********The issue split the country as seldom before. Yet the turnout in the referendum was low, with only an estimated 50 percent of the 2.4 million eligible voters casting ballots. Vote counting begins Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.main_headline: U.S. NAVY CAPTAIN IS SHOT DEAD BY TWO MEN IN AN ATHENS SUBURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.print_headline: U.S. NAVY CAPTAIN IS SHOT DEAD BY TWO MEN IN AN ATHENS SUBURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.body_text: **********A United States officer was shot dead today by unidentified gunmen on a motorbike., the Greek state radio reported. **********Reuters, quoting the police, reported that the officer was a United States Navy captain, George Tsantes.  He had been shot seven times on his way to work in Athens and his Greek driver, Nicolaos Veloutsos, was seriously wounded, the agency reported. **********(In Washington. the Defense Department confirmed that a United States Navy officer had been shot and killed in Athens, but it would not provide his name and said that the assailant was unknown.) **********The Greek state radio, quoting the police, said the two assailants opened fire on the officer as he sat in his car at a major traffic junction of the Athens suburb of Halandri. The shooting took place at 7:30 A.M. today. **********A United States Embassy spokesman, Peter Sinodis, said the officer was believed to be on his way to work when attacked. He said it was too early to provide any details as to the identity and exact rank or duty in Greece of the victim, adding that the United States Embassy would for the time being rely entirely on Greek police reports. **********''All we have been told at this stage is that an American officer has been shot, and that he is believed to be a general,'' Mr. Sinodis said. **********Anti-Americanism in Greece over the last few years has often led to American premises or vehicles being the target of attacks, but rarely have military personnel been the object of assassination attempts. **********The last victim was the local C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch, who was assassinated in 1975 outside his home. The culprit has not yet been discovered. **********The United States Embassy spokesman said he doubted reports that the victim in the shooting today was the naval and defense attache, Peter Theodorelos.  ''If it was the naval attache, we would have known.'' Mr. Sinodis said.  ''His office has informed us that he was not the man involved.'' **********There have been several similar attacks in the last few months, mainly involving Arab targets. A senior Palestine Liberation Organization official and aide of the P.L.O. leader Yasir Arafat was killed in Athens four months ago in an identical manner. Last week one Jordanian was killed and another seriously wounded in a street shooting.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Federal Judge Harold H. Greene today approved another major step in the divestiture of 22 local phone companies by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but criticized recent rulings by the Federal Communications Commission that will raise local phone rates. **********Judge Greene has approved the overall antitrust agreement between the Justice Department and A.T.& T. under which the divestiture is to take place early next year, and is now in the process of approving each step of the process. He has been scrutinizing the details of the divestiture as they are submitted to him for approval. **********In today's action, Judge Greene gave conditional consent to A.T.& T.'s plan to divide the nation into 161 geographical areas within which the divested local phone companies will offer service. Each of the local companies will have a number of districts, but will seldom handle service among their districts. That as well as interstate calling will be considered long-distance service, to be handled by A.T.& T. and other long-distance carriers. The judge also ordered some changes in the districts, including the splitting of the New York City zone. **********A.T& T.'Delighted' **********Pickard Wagner, a spokesman for the company here, said A.T.& T. was ''delighted'' at Judge Greene's 162-page opinion issued today and added that the complicated process for carrying out the divestiture appears to be ''on track.'' **********Phone calling between the zones, which are called LATA's, or local access and transport areas, after divestiture will generally be defined as long-distance calls, and such service will be handled not by the local phone companies but by A.T.& T. itself and the smaller, competing long-distance phone companies, such as the MCI Communications Corporation. **********Previously it had been proposed to include in the New York LATA a vast region including Long Island, New Jersey and New York State up to Poughkeepsie. Today Judge Greene approved a change that splits off Poughkeepsie into a separate LATA and ''will draw the Poughkeepsie LATA so as to absorb as much of the 914 number plan area as network considerations will allow.'' **********That would presumably extend the new LATA southward to include large segments of Westchester County and perhaps Rockland County, but details were not made available today. The confirguration of the Poughkeepsie LATA should be submitted to the Department of Justice and to the court within 15 days of the date of this opinion, the opinion said. **********The new New York district, to be serviced by the New York Telephone Company and also New Jersey Bell, will cover all phone customers in area codes 212, 516 and 201, and some in 914. **********The New York district is among 17 in A.T.&T.'s mid-Atlantic region. The 16 others were approved as proposed. F.C.C. Rate Actions Decried **********Judge Greene, in his actions today, looked with ''surprise and dismay'' on what he described as rising local phone rates that are resulting from the divestiture. He said the F.C.C. was responsible for authorizing local phone companies to raise revenue by imposing on customers monthly access charges for long-distance calls. **********Despite his strong misgivings about the F.C.C policies, Judge Greene said, he is unable to order any changes because the actions of the commission are not legally before him. **********The access charges, covering the interconnection of local and long-distance networks, would offset revenue that A.T.& T. says it has been giving its local subsidiaries over the years from longdistance revenue. Long-distance service is considered more profitable than local phone service. **********Judge Greene, however, said that while it may be a commonly accepted notion, it has not been proved that long distance service subsidizes local service. Even if it does, he said, the regulatory agency is not compelled to spread higher costs across local phone customers as the F.C.C. has ordered state regulators to do. **********The long-distance carriers should make up for revenue lost by local companies by means of higher charges they will pay the local phone companies for interconnections, Judge Greene said. **********The F.C.C. did not comment on Judge Greene's statements.  In ruling on the the geographic areas, Judge Greene approved five of the geographic regions as proposed for New England and ordered a division of the proposed Eastern Massachusetts area. **********In the South, the judge approved 57 areas, ordered the division of the Birmingham, Ala., region and the consolidation of two regions in Kentucky. **********In the Midwest, he approved 40 proposed regions, ordered the division of the Cleveland and Davenport, Iowa, regions; consolidated the two regions proposed for South Dakota, and consolidated one Illinois region. **********In the West, he approved 21 areas; consolidated two regions proposed for Utah and ordered a modification of the Los Angeles region. **********In addition, Judge Green withheld approval of several regions pending more information. These were Albany, Syracuse, St. Louis, Detroit, southeast Wisconsin, Chicago and proposed state line crossings in the New England states.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/busin.snippet: A mobile air sampler that can be operated anywhere on a highway or in a tunnel, instead of at a fixed point, for analysis of the concentration of pollutants was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
