https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/02/busin.body_text: **********A mobile air sampler that can be operated anywhere on a highway or in a tunnel, instead of at a fixed point, for analysis of the concentration of pollutants was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. **********The invention was made at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena by Curtis E. Tucker and Harold P. Holway. According to patent 4,377,949, a number of tubes are mounted in parallel fashion on a vehicle. The tubes have caps at both ends that can be removed to capture air and gas ''on the fly.'' Heretofore, the patent says, it has been common practice to use samplers at fixed sites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/10/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department's antitrust division tentatively supported motions today by the American Can Company and the Continental Can Company to end 33-year-old court orders entered against them. The court orders, dating from 1950, prevented the two companies from tying the sale or lease of equipment used to close filled cans to the sale of cans themselves. **********The orders also forbade the companies to discriminate among can customers with respect to credit, technical assistance or sales price, or to take over other container makers without court permission. **********In papers filed in the United States District Court in San Francisco, the Justice Department said the restrictions were no longer necessary and might be preventing the two companies from operating efficiently. **********The Justice Department asked the court to allow a 60-day period for public comment on the proposed terminations and said it reserved the right to withdraw its tentative approval.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/24/busin.print_headline: BAKER OPPOSES CONTINGENCY TAX; REAGAN DOUBTS RESTRUCTURING SOON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he opposes the idea of contingency tax increases starting in the 1986 fiscal year. **********Administration officials have confirmed that such a plan will be included in the budget President Reagan will announce next week.  The increases would go into effect if the Government's budget deficit is not shrinking rapidly enough by Oct. 1, 1985, when the 1986 fiscal year begins. **********''I don't close my mind altogether to a triggered tax increase or a triggered tax cut,'' said Mr. Baker. But the Tennessee Republican added that ''it is my personal view that that's not a very good idea.'' The Senator made his comments on ''Meet the Press,'' the NBC News television program. **********Military Spending Restraint **********Mr. Baker, who announced last week that he would not seek reelection in 1984, also said Congress would go further in cutting military spending in the 1984 fiscal year, slicing out at least $15 billion instead of the $8 billion the President has agreed to. The 1984 fiscal year, which begins next Oct. 1, will be the focus of the President's budget message. **********Mr. Baker's opposition to the contingency tax plan and his call for deeper reductions in military spending may signal a growing resistance to certain key portions of President Reagan's 1984 budget. **********The President has almost finished his budget proposals and is expected to outline many of the key elements in his State of the Union address. Mr. Reagan's budget is scheduled to be released next Monday. Needed to Reduce Deficit **********Administration officials acknowledged last week that, with current projections, they would need the contingency tax to get the deficit down to near $100 billion by 1988. This is about the size of the deficit, Administration officials said today, that the Administration expects to project for that year. **********Senator Bob Dole, the Republican chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, also opposes a contingency tax. But Senator Pete V. Domenici, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, supports the idea. **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, appearing on ''Face the Nation,'' the CBS News television program, indicated that major restructuring of the income tax system - which is expected to be a theme in the President's State of the Union Address Tuesday -is something that the Administration would not take action on soon. **********Administration officials said later that the Treasury would probably undertake a long-term study of proposals for a ''flat rate'' income tax. Such a tax would assess income taxes at a uniform rate - or at only a few different rates -and would eliminate most present tax deductions. Consumption Tax Is Pondered **********In addition, the officials said, there would be a similar study of a so-called consumption tax, which would be based on what people spend each year. **********Referring to the President's budget, Mr. Baker said Congress would not accept it outright, nor would they reject it summarily. ''We're going to examine it, and we're going to produce a Congressional budget,'' he said. **********Mr. Baker said Congrees ''is going to have to deal with those deficits if we intend to carry our part of the load.'' And he added, ''We're going to have to show a willingness to sacrifice in almost every sector of the Federal budget, and military simply can't be immune from it.'' **********Although Mr. Baker opposes the idea of a contingency tax, he said he would favor repeal of the indexing of income tax brackets to inflation. Such indexing is scheduled to begin in 1985, and repealing it could raise the additional revenues in future years that most budget officials, in both Congress and the Administration, argue will be needed to reduce deficits. But the revenue gain from repeal of indexing would fall short of the $135 billion that Administration officials say is in the contingency tax proposal. **********Treasury Secretary Regan described restructuring of the income tax as ''probably the dream and the goal of every Secretary of the Treasury once he's been in office more than two months.'' **********But it seems unlikely that much will be done in the near future, he indicated, and aides said he was trying to de-emphasize recent speculation about proposals to overhaul the tax code. **********''I would like to think that perhaps we could advance that somewhat,'' Mr. Regan said, adding, ''It's something that I'd like to study to see if we can accomplish it.'' **********The Secretary said interest rates would continue to decline this year, and he predicted that the banks' prime rate, now 11 percent, would drop. ''I do think that we'll probably see another couple of points, at least, on the prime,'' he said. But he remarked that rates might go up in 1984 if the economy expands. **********Although senior Administration officials said last week that the President had approved the contingency tax plan, Secretary Regan would not say so publicly. But he explained the reasoning behind the idea. **********''I'd have to say the perception has become the reality,'' he said. Speaking of the financial markets, he said: ''They are afraid that huge deficits will mean higher rates of interest in the United States. As a result, the interest rates are not coming down to the extent that we want. **********''So, therefore, we have to deal with these deficits,'' he concluded. ''One is to have less spending, and two is to increase revenues.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/world.main_headline: DEAD ARE REVERED AND LIVING WELL IN MADAGASCAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/world.print_headline: DEAD ARE REVERED AND LIVING WELL IN MADAGASCAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/world.body_text: **********The late Uncle Rakoto, a guidebook says, may begin feeling restless, neglected or just lonely, and will communicate this to his relatives, possibly by way of a dream. **********In response, the relatives will arrange a party, dressing him in silk, parading him through the town, drinking to his health and bringing him up to date on the gossip. Then they will put him back in his tomb until he calls for them again. **********To be an ancestor, the guidebook, ''A Glance at Madagascar,'' says, is to join the ranks of ''those beings now passed on but who remain an integral part of the Malagasy family and continue to exercise enormous power and influence.'' **********It may have started, a sociologist said, with a custom of burying the dead first in one sepulcher, and then moving the body a few years later, wrapping the bones anew in a shroud. Later, the celebration, a joyous event, became more frequent - and expensive. Don't Trifle With Rakoto **********These days a good-sized silk shroud costs the equivalent of $150, or three months' wages for a laborer.  But Uncle Rakoto, the guidebook suggests, is not to be trifled with, for ancestors can ''bring a calamity upon any family or community guilty of some violation of the ancestral customs or taboos.'' **********The taboos of this capital, which is encircled by swamps and paddy fields that press against its hills, are many.  Each house, according to a belief that no one seems to disown with any absoluteness, contains a corner for spirits where the north and east walls come together. **********Within the walls, too, there are said to be vectors of fate that change with the shifting of the moon, angles of destiny chronicled by astrologers who decided eons ago that some days are accursed and good for nothing and best left alone. Watch Out for Tuesdays **********Tuesday, in particular, is a day with nothing to recommend it, a day on which no funerals, weddings or work of a serious nature should be scheduled. Save them for Friday, a propitious day in all respects. **********The taboos, called fady, also dictate that a person coming from the north should avoid the west side of a house, that he should walk instead along the east side and come to the door from the south. **********The taboos and the reverence for the dead continue, undiluted by the passing of time or the incursions of missionaries who began the Christianization of the Malagasy. Of the current population of 10 million, roughly half are listed as Christians. **********In 1818 the London Missionary Society sent teachers who translated the Bible into Malagasy, a language that had not been transcribed into Roman characters. **********King Radama I, part of a monarchy destroyed by the French 77 years later, allowed the missionaries to go about their work. But his widow, Queen Ranavalona I, had Christians hurled 200 yards down the hilltop where she had her palace. The palace, built by a French architect, still glowers over the capital. Blessing Uncle's Bones **********Today once-foreign faiths coexist with the beliefs that grew before outside intrusion. A priest or pastor will, for instance, be invited to join Uncle Rakoto's party, blessing the bones before they are replaced in the family sepulcher. **********Superstitions introduced, according to some accounts, by missionaries have also lingered.  In the 19th century, when Jesuits were pitted against Freemasons, word was spread that the Masons were headed by a beast that fed on human blood and hearts. Thus, according to the story, the mpakafo, or heart-taker, usually a foreigner, would stalk the villages for involuntary donors. **********Recently an American here recounted how some village children had fled at his approach, believing him to be the mpakafo. He had been denounced as a heart-taker by a man with whom he had been at odds over onion-growing rights.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/busin.main_headline: LEADER OF TEXTRON UNIT NAMED WATERBURY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; LEADER OF TEXTRON UNIT NAMED WATERBURY CHIEF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/27/busin.body_text: **********An expert in the field of industrial fasteners has been named president and chief executive of the Waterbury Companies, a leading manufacturer of buttons based in Waterbury, Conn. **********The executive, Michael J. Tragakiss, joined Waterbury last week after 10 years at Textron Inc., the conglomerate based in Providence, R.I. Mr. Tragakiss, 50 years old, replaces L.P. Sperry Jr., who will remain as chairman of Waterbury until he retires. **********In its nearly 175 years of existence, the company's button group has become one of the largest such companies in the nation. In a telephone interview, however, Mr. Tragakiss said he plans to expand the company's business into gift buttons and mail orders, as well as overseas. **********Waterbury, which also has interests in plastics and aerosol sprays, already has a limited button business abroad.  ''I was intrigued with the opportunity here,'' Mr. Tragakiss said, when asked why he resigned from Textron to join Waterbury, a subsidiary of Talley Industries of Phoenix. ''It's a smaller, multinational conglomerate with tremendous potential. Any time you can make a product line grow, it has to be exciting.'' **********While most people may think of the button business as boring, he conceded, he finds it fascinating.  ''There is a tremendous amount of creativity in making buttons,'' he said. ''The designs of our buttons are jealously guarded and often copied.'' **********Immediately before joining the Waterbury Companies, Mr. Tragakiss was vice president and general manager of the Townsend Fastening Group of Textron. In this position, he supervised four plants in three states manufacturing specialty fasteners for the automobile industry, for railroads and for metal working industries. **********Prior to joining Townsend Fastening, Mr. Tragakiss headed Textron's fastener unit in Canada.  Mr. Tragakiss, who will move to Connecticut from Ellwood City, Pa., studied business administration at the University of Connecticut. He also attended the Advanced Management Program at the Harvard Business School.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.main_headline: SOUTH AFRICA MOVING TO WIDEN CONSCRIPTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.print_headline: SOUTH AFRICA MOVING TO WIDEN CONSCRIPTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.body_text: **********Young white immigrants and other foreigners who live here would be required to serve in the country's armed forces or lose the right to work here under a new bill proposed by the Government last week. **********A statement issued on Friday by the Minister of Defense, Magnus Malan, and the Minister of Internal Affairs, Frederik W. De Klerk, said that the proposed measure was a response to continuing resentment from young white South Africans at the fact that they have to enter the military for two years after leaving school while young immigrants do not. **********The Government said that immigrant groups welcomed the move. The proposal, which is to go before Parliament for approval some time next year before it can take effect, was endorsed by the spokesman for Johannesburg's Greek community, Peter Manikas. **********The white parliamentary opposition, the Progressive Federal Party, and the Federated Chamber of Industries also welcomed the move, but warned that it could increase the shortage in skilled manpower by making the country less attractive to skilled immigrants. The spokesman on defense issues for the Progressive Federal Party, Phillip Myburgh, also suggested that the measure might be followed by one requiring young Asians and men of mixed race, known as coloreds, to undergo military training.   Exemption From Conscription **********Like blacks, these groups have been exempt from military service, but their inclusion in power-sharing arrangements under a new Constitution here has led to speculation that they may also be conscripted. A military group is currently examining the issue. **********Under South African defense law, young white men have to undergo two years' continuous military training after they leave school, after which they must serve 720 days in occasional military duty over the next 12 years. They then may be required to serve occasionally in local military units until they reach the age of 55. **********Until now white immigrants have, after two years in the country, been able to take up permanent resident status - which allows them to work here - while not adopting South African citizenship, which would compel them to serve in the military. **********The proposed bill would affect all immigrants who have arrived in the country since 1978 and are between 15 and 25 years of age. Under the proposal, they would acquire permanent residence after five years, but this would automatically entail South African citizenship and hence military duty.   The Right to Work **********The only way they could avoid military service would be to refuse to become South African citizens - but they would then lose their permanent residence rights and, thus, their right to work. **********The proposed measure toughens a 1978 law that said immigrants ''might be forced'' to serve in the military after two years residence, but was never enforced. **********It is not clear how many immigrants would be affected by the new measure.  According to Government statistics, 140,000 white immigrants arrived here between 1978 and August 1982, the last month for which figures are available. **********The biggest groups were about 56,000 whites from Zimbabwe, mostly seeking to avoid living under a black Government there. and about 52,000 Britons fleeing that country's economic difficulties.   Immigrants From Britain **********Recently, British immigrants have been by far the biggest group, accounting for 45 percent of immigrants in the first months of 1982. **********The Government's proposal follows complaints by South Africans that immigrants were gaining an advantage over them in looking for employment while the South Africans went off to the military after school. **********The Government ministers referred to this in their statement, saying that military service ''evasion'' by immigrants had ''long been a source of dissatisfaction.'' In some cases, the ministers said, young immigrants had even ''advertised'' their ''favored position'' over South Africans,

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/world.main_headline: U.S. ACCEPTS TERMS FOR HUMAN RIGHTS AT MADRID MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/world.print_headline: U.S. ACCEPTS TERMS FOR HUMAN RIGHTS AT MADRID MEETING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/16/world.body_text: **********The United States agreed formally today to a compromise document on security and human rights to end the East-West conference in Madrid and possibly open the way for high-level Soviet-American meetings. **********The conference, which has been under way nearly three years, is expected to be finished in the next week. All that remains for discussion, American officials said, is a demand by Malta for a Mediterranean security meeting. The demand is opposed by most of the 34 other participants in the East-West meeting. **********American officials said Secretary of State George P. Shultz was tentatively planning to attend the signing ceremonies in Madrid and would use the occasion to confer with Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko of the Soviet Union. **********No date has been set. It is possible, because of August vacations in Europe, that the ceremony and a Shultz-Gromyko meeting might occur in September. **********This, officials said, could be preparation for an eventual meeting of President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. Reagan Supports Compromise **********Mr. Reagan issued a statement soon after the chief American delegate in Madrid, Max M. Kampelman, publicly announced American backing for the compromise document, which has not been made public. **********In citing some aspects of the compromise, the President said: ''The Madrid accord will add important new commitments to the Helsinki process, including provisions dealing with human rights, the trade union freedoms so tragically violated in Poland, terrorism, religious liberties, bring unification of families, free flow of information and more.'' **********The document is a follow-up step to the Final Act of the 1975 Helsinki Conference on European security and cooperation, signed by the United States, Canada, 32 European nations and the Vatican. **********The Helsinki document provided for measures to enhance security, economic cooperation, human rights and a flow of ideas and people between East and West. Communists Accused on Rights **********The Soviet Union and its allies have regularly been accused by Western nations of violating the terms of the accord by arresting human rights activists and increasing restrictions on rights of people to emigrate. **********In his statement, Mr. Reagan said: ''We have agreed to this concluding document, as we did in 1975, to the Helsinki Final Act itself, with no illusions about the nature of the Soviet Union or about the system which it seeks to impose over much of Europe.'' **********''Together with the Helsinki accord,'' he said, ''this agreement sets forth a clear code of conduct for all 35 states -a set of standards to which we and the other Atlantic democracies will continue to hold all those who will have pledged their word at Madrid.'' **********Mr. Kampelman spent the early part of the week in Washington gaining the approval of Mr. Shultz and Mr. Reagan for the Madrid document. **********In addition to what is contained in the document, American officials said the Soviet Union had given assurances that some detained dissidents would be released by the end of the year. **********Mr. Reagan said of the document: ''We will sign it with the hope that it will serve as a step toward achieving our objective of a more stable and constructive relationship with the Soviet Union.'' **********The document calls on nations to insure ''the right of workers freely to establish and join trade unions.'' It is not expected that the Soviet Union will establish nongovernment trade unions or that Poland will now reinstate the Solidarity union. **********The last issue that delayed acceptance of the document dealt with the American desire for a follow-up meeting dealing with questions of family unification and travel between East and West. **********The Soviet Union, aware that it would probably face criticism for its restrictions in this area, refused.  But last week, it agreed to a compromise suggested by Switzerland.  This provided that mention of the ''human contacts'' follow-up meeting be omitted in the text of the concluding document. **********But it would be included in a statement to be read by the chairman of the conference that day and published in the Soviet Union and other countries, along with the document text. **********Mr. Kampelman told Mr. Reagan he had assurances that all governments would regard this follow-up meeting with the same importance as seven others provided for in the text. Human Rights Are 'Hard Won' **********Mr. Reagan said results in the human rights field ''are often gradual and hard won, but they are necessary building blocks for a more secure and stable world.'' **********''The challenge remains,'' he went on. ''We must all consolidate and build on these gains. We must insure that good words are transformed into good deeds and the ideas that they embody are given concrete expression. Giving substance to the promises of Madrid and Helsinki will remain one of our prime objectives.'' **********There will also be a conference in Stockhom next January on confidence-building security measures in Europe. **********The Russians agreed to allow all military maneuvers in Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals to be reported to other signers of the accord. Previously, the Russians only had to report maneuvers in their territory within 150 miles of the western frontier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.main_headline: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS BUILD NEW, PRAGMATIC IMAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.print_headline: SPAIN'S SOCIALISTS BUILD NEW, PRAGMATIC IMAGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.body_text: **********A political gibe going the rounds in Madrid says that President Francois Mitterrand of France has done a great service to European Socialism by giving Spanish Socialists a good reason to pursue conservative economic policies. **********Eight weeks after Spain's Socialists were voted into power, the country's 40-year-old Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, and his equally youthful Cabinet are striving to develop a moderate, pragmatic image. That is especially true in their handling of Spain's deeply troubled economy. The Spanish view contrasts sharply with the doctrinaire left-wing policies that Mr. Mitterrand adopted when he took office in France 18 months ago. **********Banned by Franco **********The Socialist victories in France and Spain were both historic events, ending more than a generation in the political wilderness for both parties. In France, the Socialists had been in opposition since Gen. Charles de Gaulle came to power in 1957, while the Spanish Socialists, after losing the civil war in 1939, were banned during the years when Francisco Franco was in control. But the similarity between the parties ends there. **********France's Socialists came to power determined to carry out the radical changes they had promised. President Mitterrand, vowing to resist what he called ''the wall of money,'' nationalized banks and big companies, raised taxes on the rich and tried to spend his way out of the recession by increasing wages and Government spending. **********But within a year, the French economy had been brought to its knees by a double devaluation of the franc, a hemorrhage of reserves, galloping inflation and the collapse of business confidence. French unemployment today is higher than when Mr. Mitterrand took office and his Government has been forced into a humiliating policy reversal, switching to a classic austerity program that is even more rigorous than the one its conservative predecessor had followed. **********The Spanish Socialists also promised change during the campaign but Mr. Gonzalez defined this to mean simply ''making things work the way they should.'' Since then, the Spanish Socialists have taken economic actions that are the opposite of what Mr. Mitterrand did in his first months in power. Austere Measures **********The Spanish electricity supply system is to be nationalized, but nothing else. Taxes will be held steady, although collection is to be improved. Above all, by promptly devaluing the peseta, tightening monetary policy, sharply increasing fuel prices and calling for wage restraint, the Socialists have clearly indicated that austerity lies ahead. **********''Gonzalez was always a moderate, but what happened in France makes it easier for him to be pragmatic now,'' says Jose Diego Teirgeiro Ruiz, the chief economist at the Spanish Private Banks Association.  And Antonio Garrigues Walker, a prominent lawyer and secretary general of the new Spanish Liberal Party, agrees, saying, ''Mitterrand's experiment showed everyone in Spain there isn't any room for maneuver.'' **********The economic problems that Spain's Socialists inherited seem an inevitable legacy of the country's break with decades of Fascist rule. During the Franco years, the Spanish Government balanced its books, but in the six years since his death, deficit spending has ballooned as new democratic governments sought to meet the pent-up aspirations of the country's 34 million inhabitants. **********This year, the budget deficit will reach the equivalent of $8.5 billion - 5 percent of the economy's output and one of the highest levels in Europe. Inflation, although halved, to 15 percent a year, is still well above the European average. Jobless Rate at 16% **********Spain's international payments deficit, close to $5 billion last year, will narrow to about $4 billion in 1982. And although a preelection spending spree helped raise economic growth from four-tenths of 1 percent in 1981 to 1.5 percent in 1982, unemployment continued to rise and currently stands at two million, or 16 percent of the labor force, well above the European average. **********The man in charge of Spain's economy is Miguel Boyer, a Frenchtrained economist who has worked in the Spanish central bank and has run the planning department of the country's largest private company, the chemical conglomerate Union Explosivos Rio Tinto. **********As head of both the Finance Ministry and the former Ministry of Economy and Trade, now combined, Mr. Boyer is Spain's economic overlord. He is also the most vibrant symbol of the Socialists' moderate approach. **********At 44 years of age, Mr. Boyer is a little older than the Cabinet average of 41. In Spain, such youth is equated with a foreign education, openness to new ideas and a technocratic approach to governmental problems. Spain's new 17-man Cabinet, for example, includes three ministers educated at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. **********''Boyer is a social democrat not a Socialist,'' said Mr. Ruiz, the economist for the bank association. Quick Devaluation **********After he was appointed to the economic post, Mr. Boyer told friends he wanted to avoid what he perceived to be the mistake that Mr.  Mitterrand and Harold Wilson, Britain's former Labor Party Prime Minister, made by refusing to devalue their currencies early in their administrations, only to be forced to do so when the decision appeared a defeat for their policies. **********So Mr. Boyer devalued the peseta by 8 percent before the Socialists held their first Cabinet meeting and backed the measure with austerity measures, including higher compulsory reserve requirements to mop up bank liquidity and a big rise in the gasoline price. **********Within three weeks, about half the $2 billion that the Bank of Spain had spent supporting the peseta during the campaign flowed back into its coffers. **********But economists and bankers in Spain agree that the real challenges lie ahead. The Socialists want to cut inflation to between 12 and 13 percent in 1983 from 15 percent, and want to keep the budget deficit unchanged in peseta terms, implying a large decline in Government spending, after adjustment for inflation. **********At present, the Government is trying to persuade the unions to scale back 1983 wage demands. But it has decided to delay presenting the 1983 budget until after the municipal elections in March, suggesting that it may be planning more austerity measures if the wage talks go badly. 'The Real Challenge' **********Meanwhile, top Government officials and bankers privately concede that the Socialists cannot hope to meet their inflation and international payments targets without sacrificing their campaign promise of 2.5 percent growth in 1983 and the creation of 800,000 jobs over the next four years. ''Unemployment is bound to go on rising and this will be the real challenge for Boyer,'' one American banker said. **********The second economic challenge facing the Socialists is to get Spain into the Common Market in the hope of attracting more foreign investment and modernizing its industry. From a peak of $1.3 billion in 1980, new foreign investment has slumped to $800 million in 1982 and will probably fall further on the continued uncertainty over Common Market membership. **********Mr. Gonzalez wants a firm decision on membership by 1986, when the present parliamentary terms ends. But France, fearful of the competition its farmers would face from Spanish fruit and wine, is dragging its feet. Spain's Socialists may be a far cry from President Mitterrand in economic policy, but they still need his political support to accomplish their own more moderate goals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/busin.main_headline: MESA POSTS PROFIT ON STOCK SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/busin.print_headline: MESA POSTS PROFIT ON STOCK SALE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/busin.body_text: **********The Mesa Petroleum Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its stake in the Superior Oil Company back to Superior. The deal marks the third time in the last year and a half that Mesa has come away from a takeover opportunity without an acquisition but with a substantial profit. **********Mesa acquired about four million shares, or 3 percent of Superior, at an average cost of $34 a share earlier this year. Superior said it would buy the shares back at a price of $42 a share, yielding an indicated profit for Mesa of $32 million. **********7-Year Hands-Off Agreement **********As part of the deal, Mesa agreed to acquire no shares in Superior for a period of seven years. **********Mesa's founder and chairman, T. Boone Pickens Jr., was not available for comment on the agreement, a spokesman for the Amarillo, Tex., company said. A spokesman for Superior said the company also would have no comment. **********Mr. Pickens raised Mesa's stake in Superior last spring as the company became embroiled in a proxy fight over its approach to a takeover. **********''It was a very deft move by Mr. Pickens,'' said Alvin D. Silber, an oil industry analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Mesa was too small to make a tender offer for Superior; they just didn't have the resources. Mesa had this kind of outcome in mind.'' **********Superior, the nation's largest independent oil and gas producer, also has extensive agricultural, mining and contract drilling interests. **********Last year, the Houston-based company earned $223 million, or $1.75 a share, on $2.04 billion in revenue. In the last 12 months, its stock has traded at between $30 and $40 a share. **********A Split Over Takeovers **********The Superior fight that Mr. Pickens exploited pitted members of the founding Keck family against each other. Williametta Keck Day, daughter of the founder and sister of the company's former chairman and dominant stockholder, wanted to open the door for takeover offers. She was opposed by her brother. **********Mr. Pickens publicly supported her and, in late May, well over the half the shares voted were cast in her favor. **********In January, Mr. Pickens was rebuffed in an attempt to acquire the General American Oil Company of Texas. But Mesa said that it came away from that attempt with a profit of about $45 million. **********Mesa also made a profit of $45 million when it sold the Cities Service Company's stock it had acquired in an unsuccessful attempt to take over that company in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.main_headline: NEW TAPES SHOW KOREAN AIRLINER WAS EXPERIENCING RADIO TROUBLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.print_headline: NEW TAPES SHOW KOREAN AIRLINER WAS EXPERIENCING RADIO TROUBLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/world.body_text: **********Tapes made public by the Government today showed Korean Air Lines Flight 7 had radio troubles that forced it to relay two vital position reports to traffic controllers back in Alaska. **********The reports from the Boeing 747 jumbo jet were relayed by another South Korean 747 that took off from Anchorage 14 minutes behind it and, in one case, were also relayed by an Anchorage ground station monitoring lower radio frequencies. Reports From Key Checkpoints **********The reports from Flight 7 were sent when the crew reckoned they were at checkpoints about 300 and 900 nautical miles from the start of a key over- ocean airway. The airliner, with 269 people on board, was headed for Seoul by way of Japan but went off course and was shot down by a Soviet fighter off Siberia near the southern end of Sakhalin Island. **********In another development, the United States demanded compensation from the Soviet Union for the 61 Americans who were among those killed when the airliner was downed. But the Soviet Embassy refused to accept the American note, the State Department said. **********In Moscow, a Soviet news commentator for the official press agency Tass said a revised transcript of exchanges between Soviet fighter pilots and their ground control released by the State Department on Sunday had ''totally shattered'' American allegations that the fighters gave no warning to the Korean Air Lines 747 before shooting it down. (Page A10.) **********Technical experts said it was theoretically possible that Flight 7's communication problems could have been a result of mechanical malfunctions or atmospheric conditions. But the general immediate reaction was that the trouble was caused by the airliner's deviation from course to an area beyond the range of the VHF, or very high frequency, radio network. **********An industry specialist with access to key Government officials said that ''based on the Soviet information and looking at possible computer malfunctions, all indications are that they would have been expected to run into communications problems by getting out of radio range.'' **********On the other hand, there was earlier evidence that all had not been in good working order with the radio equipment aboard the plane. A Korean Air Lines supervisor in Anchorage was quoted as saying the pilot who flew the plane from New York to Anchorage had reported minor radio problems. **********In addition, the pilot of a South Korean plane that made the Pacific cross ing in the opposite direction from Flight 7 was reported to have been unable to radio Flight 7 when they passed in order to make a customary exchange of weather data. **********The State Department, in making public the tapes, took pains to note that the relaying of position reports was nothing to cause alarm to controllers responsible for monitoring the flight. **********The first indication from the transcripts of communications problems with Flight 7 came about an hour and a half after takeoff from Anchorage, when the airliner was due to report over a checkpoint called Nabie. The checkpoint is 282 nautical miles from the mandatory previous checkpoint and is the first such point along airway Red 20, a route that skirts within about 50 miles of Soviet territory en route to Japan. Normally, the airliner would eventually have made a dogleg turn to the right to cross Japan en route to Seoul. Attempts to Make Contact **********When Flight 7 failed to check in with the Anchorage traffic center on schedule at 30 minutes after the hour, a controller tried three times to make radio contact. **********If the plane replied, the words were unintelligible. The controller radioed, ''Korean Air 7, Anchorage center, how do you read?'' **********The tapes could not be clearly understood, but the best interpretation of the answer was, ''Well, wait a minute, call again please.'' **********Two minutes later, the Korean airliner following Flight 7 called the center, relaying word that Flight 7 had passed over Nabie and estimating it would be over the next checkpoint, Neeva, an hour and 14 minutes later. **********Neeva is 593 nautical miles from Nabie. These checkpoints are over water and are delineated by geographical coordinates inserted in the computerized, triply redundant prime navigation system on board. It is known as an inertial navigation system. **********Flight Station Relayed Message **********The tapes indicated the crew of Flight 7 must have realized they had not made direct contact with the center at Anchorage. Hence, at 44 minutes after the hour, Flight 7 checked in with the Flight Service Station at Anchorage on their high-frequency radio. This has much greater range than a VHF system, which a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman in Anchorage said was not designed to give coverage beyond about 150 nautical miles. VHF, however, can normally be used for direct VHF contact with Anchorage as far out as Neeva because remotely controlled relay stations have been installed within range on islands down the Aleutian chain. **********The Flight Service Station was asked to relay the position report to the air- traffic control center, which does not use high-frequency radio. **********Flight 7, after arriving over what the crew thought was Neeva nine minutes after their initial estimate, never made intelligible contact either with the Anchorage control center or with the nearby Flight Service Station. Flight 7's position report was again relayed by the sister Korean jumbo jet that had taken off behind it.   U.S. Demands Compensation **********Alan D. Romberg, the State Department spokesman, said today that John H. Kelly, the Acting Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, had presented Oleg M. Sokolov, the No. 2 official at the Soviet Embassy, with a note ''demanding compensation from the Soviet Union'' for the ''flagrant and unjustifiable breach of applicable principles of international law.'' **********The note, which was made public by the department, said the shooting down of an unarmed civilian airliner was ''a direct violation of internationally agreed procedures to be followed when an aircraft inadvertently intrudes on a state's territorial airspace.'' **********The note did not specify an amount of compensation but said the United States would supply details later. At the same time, Mr. Kelly sought to give a similar note to Mr. Sokolov on behalf of South Korea, which has no diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.  Mr. Romberg said that Mr. Sokolov ''refused to accept'' both notes and that Mr. Kelly ''refused to accept Mr. Sokolov's rejection.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Virginia Housing Bonds Will Yield 5.5% to 10% **********A $162.9 million Virginia Housing Development residential mortgage bond issue was priced by E. F. Hutton yesterday with yields ranging from 5.5 percent to 10 percent. **********The issue was rated Aa by Moody's, and underwriters expected an Ax rating by Standard & Poors. **********The bonds will be used to finance residential mortgage loans for individuals in the state and are backed by the State of Virginia. **********The issue included coupon serial bonds, coupon term bonds and capital appreciation bonds. The coupon serials were offered from 1984 to 1998. The 1984 bonds were priced at par to yield 5.50 percent. The 1993 bonds were priced at par to yield 9.20 percent and the 1998 bonds, also at par, were priced to yield 9.80 percent. The coupon term bonds due in 2004 were priced at par to yield 10 percent. **********The capital appreciation bonds are like zero coupon bonds in that the yield is paid at maturity. The 1984 bonds were priced at $983 per $1,000 issue to yield 5.5 percent at maturity. The bonds due in 2003 were priced at $143.73 per $1,000 issue to yield 10.3 percent at maturity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Vartan Picking Stocks Based on Value
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Vartan Picking Stocks Based on Value
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.body_text: **********WHILE many money managers nervously eye the erratic swings of the stock market, Leonard M. Heine Jr. patiently goes about managing $375 million for clients with an investment approach geared to value. **********It's a strategy that has paid off for the Management Asset Corporation of Westport, Conn., headed by Mr. Heine as founder and president. For the 5 1/2-year period ended Sept. 30, the firm showed a total return - market appreciation plus dividends - of 25 percent annually. This compared with a yearly gain of 18 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********''We look for bargains,'' Mr. Heine said in an interview. ''We may not hit many homers, but we tend not to strike out very often.'' **********The cornerstone of the firm's investment philosophy is ''valuation analysis,'' a system developed by the late Benjamin Graham, who with David L. Dodd co-authored ''Security Analysis,'' a classic book on investments. ''Buy value - it will out.'' That was Mr. Graham's credo and Mr. Heine follows it scrupulously, in contrast to some professional portfolio managers who describe themselves as value-oriented but do not adhere to the specifics of Mr. Graham's system. **********Management Asset screens 3,600 companies in its search for certain attributes. It seeks out companies with strong balance sheets whose stock prices are low in relation to historical levels. Each client portfolio, containing about 30 stocks, is diversified across a wide variety of industries. **********Once a stock is selected, the firm sets an ''investment value,'' or target selling price, and from that establishes a maximum buying level. The system calls for subtracting one-third of the investment value to arrive at a price above which the stock should not be bought. For example, a stock with an investment value of $75 a share would carry a maximum buying price of $50. **********''We want to achieve a gain of at least 50 percent, although it might take as long as several years for a given issue to reach that goal,'' Mr. Heine explained. At times, Management Asset is able to purchase stocks selling below their assigned buy levels, thereby achieving potential gains larger than 50 percent. **********Management Asset maintains a strict discipline on the sell side. Stocks are sold for only two reasons: when they reach pre-determined selling prices or when they no longer qualify for the required investment standards. **********The balance sheet analysis calls for a maximum allowable debt of 35 percent of a company's total capitalization. Also, there should be sufficient cash on hand to cover 12 months of total debt payments. Net quick assets - cash and equivalents plus receivables - must at least equal current liabilities. Finally, net working capital should be a minimum of $25 million. **********If a company qualifies on these balance sheet factors, Management Asset then determines the investment value of a company based upon its earnings growth for the past 10 years and its average earnings during the same period. For example, under the system devised by Mr. Graham, a company showing no growth over the past 10 years would be assigned a price-earnings ratio of 8 and one with growth averaging 15 percent, or more, annually would receive a maxiumum P/E ratio of 20. **********Then the P/E ratio is multiplied by the average earnings per share over the 10 years to arrive at the investment value of the company's stock.  Mr. Heine concedes that occasionally he has gone wrong in the past. ''We once took a big loss in Bird Inc., a producer of building materials, after the system said the company's balance sheet no longer met our requirements,'' he recounted. ''Unfortunately, I was depending upon my emotions rather than the system.'' **********There are times, too, when a stock is sold upon reaching its target price, only to climb substantially higher. Mercantile Stores provided one such example earlier this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/02/world.body_text: **********The Communist Party, judging the Williamsburg declaration on nuclear missiles to be too inflexible, has decided to step up its opposition to the installation of missiles in Italy and make it one of its main issues in the campaign for the June 26-27 elections. **********A source close to Enrico Berlinguer, the party's secretary general, disclosed he had conveyed this hardening of the party's attitude to the United States in a meeting today with two officials from the American Embassy. The meeting was arranged before the conference of the seven major industrial democracies took place last weekend. **********The party official said the Americans maintained it would be more dangerous not to install the missiles. American sources emphasized the view that talks with the Soviet Union in Geneva on the reduction of medium-range missiles in Europe would be successful only if the North Atlantic alliance held firm to its schedule on the Pershing 2 and low-flying cruise missiles. Under the schedule, the missiles will be installed by the end of the year if there is no agreement at the Geneva talks on mutual reduction. **********The Communist official said Mr. Berlinguer and the rest of the party leadership had hoped the United States and its allies would offer to continue the Geneva talks beyond the Dec. 31 deadline and suspend installation of the missiles as long as the talks continued. Sicily Base Raises Fears **********A base for the missiles in Comiso, Sicily, is being prepared and manned by United States troops. This makes Italy one of the main targets for Soviet attack, the party official said, and heightens the need for a more active campaign. ''Even if things seem quiet now,'' Giuseppe Boffa, a writer and member of the party's central committee, said, ''I don't think the actual installation of the missiles will go so quietly.'' **********He said there were reports from Communist leaders throughout the country that opposition to nuclear arms was a major preoccupation, particularly among young voters. It is apparent that this, perhaps more than the Williamsburg statement, caused the party decision to put the issue closer to the center of the election campaign. **********Party officials said in interviews that their main campaign concern would be to reach those who might be tempted to abstain or cast invalid ballots as a form of protest. Local party officials, as well as independent polling groups, note a rising tendency by voters disaffected with political institutions to comply with the compulsory voting law but to cast blank ballots. **********The source close to Mr. Berlinguer said Communists feared that their party might be the main loser if such a trend took hold.  ''The loss of belief in the possibility of change is a danger to the left, to the opposition,'' he said. ''Those who still place hope in the present situation, those who believe that the present system can still produce jobs and economic improvement, will still vote for the parties in power, the Christian Democrats and the Socialists. We must convince the young, the unemployed, the elderly, women, those who are unhappy today, that we represent hope and must gain their confidence.'' Declining Political Activity **********Party officials are clearly uneasy about declining organized political activity among young people. They have identified unemployment, particularly among the young, and nuclear arms as issues responsible for a widespread loss of hope in political institutions and are pitching their appeal to the disaffected. **********Italian antimissile activists, who are far less numerous than their British and West German equivalents, have accused the Communists of paying no more than lip service in opposition to the installation of missiles in Sicily. **********The Italian Communist Party, with 1.7 million members the largest in the West and with 30 percent of seats the second party in Parliament, is contending with its image as a permanent opposition party. **********''We need to project an image of a party of the left that can provide a government, not only a protesting left,'' said Mr. Boffa.  ''Not alone,'' he added, ''but with the Socialists and the other parties on the left.'' Socialists Reject Appeal **********The party's congress last March was held under the slogan of ''Democratic Alternative'' and appealed to the Socialist Party for an electoral alliance. Bettino Craxi, the Socialist leader, has rejected this appeal, although, the Communists say, the two parties' assessments of the economic and social problems and their proposed solutions are close enough to permit such a coalition. **********Mr. Craxi, whose party holds 9.8 percent of seats in Parliament, provoked elections a year earlier than necessary by withdrawing from the governing coalition headed by Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani, a Christian Democrat. Mr. Craxi has made no secret of his wish for elections, which he hopes will increase his party's total of seats and enhance his chances of being Prime Minister in the next governing coalition. **********Communist officials are bitter in assessing Mr. Craxi's attitude, which they describe as opportunistic when they are being polite. But hoping for results that might make a left-wing coalition government possible for the first time, they decline to speak their minds publicly. **********In any event, party leaders make clear their disdain for the position of the French Communist Party, which they feel was outsmarted by President Francois Mitterrand when it joined his Government at the expense of the Communists' own policies. ''The relationship of forces is reversed here,'' said Alfredo Reichlin, a party leader believed by many to be second to Mr. Berlinguer, in an allusion to the Communists' superior electoral strength. **********Despite this, Communist officials hinted they would be ready to join a cabinet headed by Mr. Craxi if the outcome of the voting raised a possibility of putting the Christian Democrats in opposition for the first time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/busin.body_text: **********It was never a secret that BTR, a giant British industrial conglomerate, wanted to expand further into energy-related activities, particularly in the United States. Nonetheless, the City of London, Britain's Wall Street, found BTR's bid on April 11 for Thomas Tilling, valued at about $900 million, something of an eyeopener: both the offer and its backing by City underwriters were among the largest in Britain's corporate history. **********Most analysts here think BTR has much in its favor. An unwavering 16-year climb in BTR's earnings led to pretax profits of $161 million in 1982. By contrast, at Tilling, a widely diversified energy and engineering company, profits have declined for the past four years.  After-tax earnings fell almost 50 percent in 1982, to $40 million, from $76 million in 1981. And an extraordinatry charge of $31.3 million for restructuring costs cut last year's net income to $8.7 million, from $65.9 million in 1981. **********Tilling's nastiest setback last year resulted from investments in Texas, where its oil and gas equipment division lost $25 million, after pretax profits of $37.7 million in 1981. **********''Initially, we would be interested in all of Tilling's U.S.  activities,'' Owen Green, the 57-year-old managing director of BTR, said recently. But it is clear that BTR particularly wants to snap up those Tilling businesses involved in the manufacturing and distribution of industrial products and components. **********BTR has offered to exchange 10 shares of its own stock for every 21 shares of Tilling's stock, with a cash alternative of $2.81 for each Tilling share. On April 11, the cash offer was valued at $818 million and the share exchange at $906 million. **********Tilling, which has appointed the merchant bankers S.G. Warburg & Company to help plot its defensive strategy, has rejected the bid as ''totally unacceptable'' and, indeed, the first fierce skirmishes have already erupted. Legal Skirmish in U.S. **********Lawyers for an Illinois-based insurance subsidiary of Tilling, the American Ambassador Casualty Company, tried to block BTR from buying any more Tilling shares by using a state law that requires court sanction for any change in ownership of an insurance company in the state. But so far the efforts have not been successful. **********As a result, BTR has continued to acquire Tilling shares on the open market and by Friday had increased its share of the outstanding stock from 6.9 percent to nearly 10 percent. **********Tilling's finance director, Francis R. Black, refuses to comment on whether Tilling is encouraging any counterbids to thwart BTR's attempted takeover. But Tilling has tried to encourage BTR's shareholders to reject the bid at a special meeting on May 9. **********Since Tilling embarked on its American buying spree six years ago - a time when it was considered a fast-moving, glamour stock - it has picked up an array of businesses. Among its major American subsidiaries are Clarkson Industries in New York, the U.S. Supply Company in Missouri and Clecon Holdings in Ohio. **********BTR has made about 20 acquisitions in the past 10 years, with three particularly successful ones in the United States, analysts say: SW Industries of Providence, R.I.; Huyck Corporation of Wake Forest, N.C., and Worcester Controls in Massachusetts. BTR Emphasizes Management **********''We bought Stowe Woodward for the management,'' said John Cahill, the Providence-based chairman of all these operations. And it is management that BTR and some analysts say is at the root of Tilling's troubles. **********''We see them as industrial bankers, not managers,'' said Mr. Green of BTR. ''Their philosophy is to generate enough cash to acquire companies and then leave them alone to run their own businesses.'' The result, he said, is that ''they don't make enough return on sales to support a progressive company.'' **********BTR, formerly British Tyre and Rubber, is known for its tight budgeting, central financial control and attention to detail, anaylsts say. **********Indeed, in the United States, BTR made a pretax profit of $65 million on sales of $240 million last year. Tilling reported pretax profits of only $23 million on sales of $1.29 billion. **********Tilling promises a significant increase in profits this year and describes the BTR bid as ''opportunistic,'' distorting the underlying value of the company. But BTR's merchant bankers at Morgan Grenfell & Company think the market will prove him wrong. **********BTR's share price closed Friday at $6.48, placing a value on Tilling, under the share swap offer, at $917.8 million. Tilling's share price closed Friday at $2.89, or 8 cents higher than BTR's cash offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.body_text: **********MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., a major newsprint supplier, introduced a 5 percent newsprint ''incentive allowance'' retroactive to July 1 for United States West Coast customers who purchase 100 percent of their annual contract tonnage. **********MacMillan said the 5 percent price reduction, applies to the list price of $468.50 a metric ton and will be credited quarterly. **********It said for purchases made during the second half of this year a contract level of ''half'' the annual volume will qualify for the incentive program. It said the company is prepared to rewrite contracts to reflect planned purchases in 1983 and for customers whose current contract calls for greater-than-required purchases from MacMillan. **********The company said the move is an attempt to secure ''realistic contract volume commitments'' with its customers, and that it is not asking its customers to violate contracts with other newsprint suppliers to take advantage of the incentive. **********British Columbia Forest Products Ltd., another newsprint concern here, said it would match any price incentive provided by MacMillan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/30/busin.body_text: **********Shares of the American Express Company, responding to rumors that the financial services concern might become a takeover target, leaped to fourth place among most-active issues on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, with more than 1.6 million shares traded. But the stock rose only 1/8, to 33 1/8. **********Speculation centered on Carl Lindner, chairman of the Penn Central Company, who reportedly was a big buyer of American Express. But Wall Street sources in a position to know said yesterday that they had not seen any trading by Mr. Lindner, and that he did not appear to own any shares. **********There were also rumors that Charles W. Knapp, chairman of the Financial Corporation of America, had also bought a large amount of American Express stock but his office said he was on vacation and unavailable for comment. **********Analysts said that while it was clear someone had bought a lot of American Express stock in the last two weeks - possibly as much as several million shares - a takeover seemed remote, largely because it would cost an estimated $10 billion. American Express has nearly 200 million shares outstanding. Analysts said investors would expect to get at least $50 a share.

He said Mr.  Papoulias would replace Ambassador Nicholas Karandreas, who resigned for personal reasons. It was not announced when Mr. Papoulias would assume his duties in Washington.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.main_headline: Reports Warn of Dangers of U.S. Oil Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.print_headline: Reports Warn of Dangers of U.S. Oil Policy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.body_text: **********The United States is likely to rely increasingly on oil from the Persian Gulf region in the 1980's, and the Reagan Administration's relaxation of precautions could seriously damage the economy in another embargo, a report to Congress said today. **********A separate report said that 10 states participating in a two-month test concluded that the Administration's free-market approach to the oil problem would turn an oil shortage into an economic disaster that would send oil prices to $98 a barrel. **********Assistant Energy Secretary William A. Vaughn said, however, that that test, coordinated by the International Energy Agency, showed that letting the free market determine the price of oil in a crisis would reduce consumer demand enough to curb the need for Government action on price or allocation. **********The agency is a group of 20 nations formed in 1974 to coordinate ways of minimizing the impact of future oil emergencies. **********The first study, conducted by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress, noted that the recession that hit the United States and other industrialized nations in 1981 and 1982 dampened demand for energy. **********But, it said, ''the oil glut of the last 18 months, to the extent that it has created a false sense of security, may have diminished the West's ability to prepare for a future disruption.'' **********In the aftermath of the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74 and the cutoff of Iranian oil in 1979, the United States undertook major efforts to encourage conservation and develop alternative energy sources. **********Since coming into office in January 1981, however, the Reagan Administration has placed more emphasis on market forces and on increasing the ability of the United States to respond militarily to a crisis that would threaten a cutoff of Persian Gulf oil. The research service said this amounts to ''a calculated risk.''
