https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new subsidiary, American Bell, is in a state of turmoil after only five months of operation. Developments today and Monday point to a scramble within American Bell to reduce costs and to eliminate troubling organizational problems that could retard its movement into new businesses. **********Today, A.T.& .T announced the resignation of Archie J. McGill, president of American Bell's Advanced Information Systems division, which sells equipment and computer services to business customers.  The resignation followed by a day a reorganization involving the other division of American Bell, the consumer products unit. **********The resignation of Mr. McGill, in particular, cast doubt on the future direction of American Bell, because he had for 10 years been the key executive charged with preparing the Bell System to compete in the new era of deregulated telecommunications. **********Mr. McGill's division was also undergoing a reorganization, and sources indicated that Mr. McGill left because he was going to be moved to a new position. Mr. McGill said in an interview, however, that he left because ''it was time to move on.'' 'I Never Intended to Stay Here' **********He said he considered his job of changing the orientation of Bell virtually finished and had discussed his desire to leave with Bell senior management a year and a half ago. **********''When I joined the Bell System, I never intended to stay here,'' Mr. McGill stated.  The 52-year-old executive came to A.T.& T. in 1973 after a rapid rise at the International Business Machines Corporation, and was charged with turning Bell from a sleepy monopoly into a marketingoriented company. Mr. McGill's aggressiveness angered old Bell hands,according to company insiders and former employees. Some said it was surprising he lasted this long. **********Some analysts said that his departure meant that the older, more stodgy Bell officials would regain power, setting back Bell's marketing efforts. **********''The same old A.T.& T. is entering deregulated business,'' said Harry Edelson of the First Boston Corporation. Others, though, said Mr. McGill had outlived his usefulness and that what was needed now was an operations man, rather than a strategist and catalyst for change. **********''There is a time for a dynamic leader to shake people up, but there is a time for that dynamic leader to step aside,'' said one former American Bell official, who asked not to be named. ''If the revolution doesn't end after a while, the rhetoric becomes meaningless.'' **********Another agreed: ''He turned the company around in terms of perspective. What was impossible was to get the products to match it.'' Big Loss Predicted **********American Bell officials said the company is close to meeting its financial targets for the year, but analysts predicted the company could lose $750 million, about $250 million more than they had expected. **********Indeed, the perception on Wall Street has changed dramatically since tthe settlement of the Justice Department's antitrust suit in January 1982. At that time, analysts expected the local operating companies, which are to be divested, to have financial problems, while A.T.& T., with its new American Bell, would be the glamour company. Now, owing to changes in the settlement agreement and troubles at American Bell, many analysts say the local operating companies will be better off. **********Mr. McGill's departure is expected to be followed by other resignations within American Bell. Also expected is a consolidation of staff positions in an attempt to trim overhead, which could lead to hundreds of layoffs in the company, which employs 28,000. **********Charles Marshall, the chairman and chief executive of American Bell, to whom Mr. McGill reported, said that Mr. McGill was not demoted or asked to leave. **********''There was no design to squeeze Arch out,'' Mr. Marshall said.  ''We wanted Arch to be with us in this business.'' However, he did say that American Bell was being reorganized and Mr. McGill's job had become superfluous. Mr. McGill, he said, then asked to leave. **********Mr. Marshall said he was hopeful, but not sure, that when the staff consolidation comes, layoffs could be avoided by transferring people to other divisions of A.T.& T. **********American Bell has been having problems getting products to market.  While American Bell conceived products and marketed them, it had to rely on two other Bell divisions, Western Electric and Bell Laboratories, for manufacturing and research, respectively. There was constant friction among the groups. Vertical Integration **********A.T.& T. is thus moving to vertically integrate operations to improve its performance. On Monday, it announced that most of the consumer products division would be moved into Western Electric. A similar reorganization is expected to take place with Advanced Information Systems being combined with the part of Western Electric that makes its products. **********According to Mr. McGill, American Bell will soon consist of only the Advanced Information Systems unit.  American Bell announced that Mr. McGill would be replaced by two people, who would divide management of the A.I.S. division.  Frank S. Vigilante, 53, formerly head of large and intermediate systems marketing, will be the division president for product planning and development. Mr. Vigilante, an outspoken man whose manner a reminds his colleagues of Mayor Koch, joined A.T.& T. in 1957 and spent most of his career in technical positions. **********Robert J. Casale, 44, who has been described by his associates as a quiet, reserved executive, will be division president for marketing and sales. Mr. Casale joined A.T.& T. in 1975 after 10 years with Xerox, Honeywell, Lockheed and Telex. **********Mr. McGill said he had not decided what he would do next. He said that politics ''is a possibility.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/world.main_headline: Lebanon Chief's Father Says Phalangists Weren't in Camps
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/world.print_headline: Lebanon Chief's Father Says Phalangists Weren't in Camps
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/12/world.body_text: **********Pierre Gemayel, leader of the Christian Phalange Party, denied in an interview published today that Phalangist militiamen were responsible for last September's massacre in two Palestinian refugee camps. **********The interview was conducted Wednesday, a day after the publication in Jerusalem of an Israeli judicial commission's report blaming Phalangist gunmen for the killings. The interview was published by the French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour. **********Mr. Gemayel, father of Lebanon's President, Amin Gemayel, said the killings ''were monstrous massacres.'' ''Even animals cannot commit such atrocities,'' he said, ''and we do not have such people in our ranks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.main_headline: ARABS AND JEWS OF ISRAEL: THE BIGOTRY RUNS DEEP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.print_headline: ARABS AND JEWS OF ISRAEL: THE BIGOTRY RUNS DEEP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/28/world.body_text: **********The 11-year-old Arab girl has freckles on her nose and wears a red ribbon at the top of a long braid that swings to and fro along her back. Her name is Amal Abu al-Jamiyya. Amal means hope. **********She has never seen a Jew without a gun. **********In the labyrinth of pathways that meander among the cold concrete houses of her slum, a refugee camp that has been under Israeli military occupation since six years before she was born, Amal sees only two kinds of Jews: uniformed soldiers and civilian settlers, usually when they are running through the camp after children who have thrown stones at Israeli cars and buses. **********She has never spoken to a Jew. She says she never wants to. **********''Do you like Jews?'' she is asked. **********''No.'' **********''Why not?'' **********''They attack our houses, breaking everything, building settlements.'' **********Why would she not want to talk with any Jews? ''Because they are our enemies.'' **********And what is her dream in life? ''To get back our land.'' **********How? ''Demonstrate.'' And then, after a moment's thought, this cute girl with freckles adds, ''We must use guns.'' **********Here, in a camp like this, Arabs' images of Jews are the harshest and most categorical of any held by those who live under Israeli control. Urban residents of the West Bank often display less hostility, or at least mask it with sophisticated argument. Arabs inside Israel proper, who are Israeli citizens themselves, are caught in complex ambivalence about the stereotypes they hold. **********But those in the Dheisheh camp, just south of Bethlehem, exist behind walls that have become metaphors for their isolation: the concrete barricades that the Israeli Army has recently erected across all the camp's exits to the main road to discourage stone-throwers. **********Although the 5,000 camp residents may leave and enter through a back way, they smile angrily when they call their slum their ''ghetto,'' relishing the opportunity to turn the language of Jewish suffering against the Jews.   Hatred Seethes Quietly **********And within the cloistered alleyways, inside the houses decorated with portraits of Lenin and Che Guevara and the outlawed Palestinian flag, a hatred of the Jews of Israel seethes quietly, intensely, beyond the power of the Israeli Army. Here, future ''fedayeen,'' or ''freedom fighters'' for the Palestinian cause are being indoctrinated, both by their elders and by their environment. **********Nadir al-Farat, 13, a boy with a film of hurt across his eyes, likes to throw stones. Jews have tried to talk to him. ''Sometimes soldiers call to speak with me,'' he says, ''but I refuse and run away.'' What does he want to be when he grows up? ''Fedayeen,'' he says firmly. The young men sitting around him in the room laugh in surprise and approval.  Across the pre-1967 border, inside Israel proper, the Arabs who have lived as Israeli citizens since 1948 are generally less militant politically, although they have their prejudices. Some say to each other, ''Don't behave like a Jew,'' by which they mean don't be arrogant or stingy. **********Common Stereotypes: Violence and Greed **********The common stereotypes of Jews held by Israeli Arabs also include violence, sexual permissiveness, greed, sneakiness, technological superiority and a lack of personal warmth, according to Arabs and Jews who have worked in the Arab communities. **********''There is awe of Jews, and envy,'' said Peter Schaktman, 23, an American Jew from Buffalo, N.Y., who is living in an Arab village as part of Interns for Peace, a program to increase Arab-Jewish contacts and understanding. To many Arabs, who judge by their own standards of effusive hospitality, ''Jews are cold, Jews are inhospitable,'' Mr. Schaktman said. **********Another intern, Susan Bandler, 24, of New York City, was told by an Arab man her age who became her friend that he could not believe she was Jewish. **********Violence is a heavy theme, both in Arab children's play and in their images of Jews. Street games of war involve fantasies of Arab-Jewish battles. Walid Sadik, a teacher and member of the town council of the Arab village of Taibe, northeast of Tel Aviv, and other Arabs say that their small sons and daughters, watching cowboy movies on television, think the Arabs are fighting the Jews.   Jews Blamed for Massacre **********After Lebanese Christian Phalangists massacred Palestinians in a Beirut refugee camp in September 1982, many Arab parents told their children that ''the Jews'' had done it. Mr. Schaktman, visiting an Arab home in a Galilee village, said he was asked by a 3-year-old girl, ''Did you kill them too?'' **********''When you say, 'Jew,' they immediately think of a violent policeman,'' said Khalil Samar, the principal of an elementary and junior high school in Tamra, an Arab village in the Galilee. ''If you ask a Jew, 'What do you think of an Arab?' they think terrorist or worse.'' **********Just as sexual fantasies run through Jews' stereotypes of Arabs, some Arabs find that their most emotional and complex contacts with Jewish society come in relations between the sexes. Here, each side is most vulnerable, and the wounds can be deep. **********''When I was a young guy I used to drive around in a Jeep and go into discos in Tiberius,'' said Samir Sabag, an Arab builder from a small village in the northern Galilee. His Hebrew was so fluent and his appearance such that many Jews thought he was Jewish. He used to like to dance with ''soldier girls,'' he recalled, Jewish women in the Israeli Army. **********''Once I was dancing with a girl soldier,'' he said, ''and she heard me speaking Arabic to a friend. She said, 'What? You're an Arab? I won't dance with you! I can't dance with you!' She backed away. **********''I said: 'You're not dancing with an Arab. You're dancing with a person.' '' He added, with a broad smile, ''It took me two to three weeks, and she was begging me to take her out.'' **********Dating a Jewish Woman Called Lesson in Racism **********For more than a year, Zohar Endrawos, 25, from the Arab town of Tarshiha, dated a young woman from the neighboring Jewish village of Maalot. ''Then I found out what racism was,'' he said. ''How many times I heard 'dirty Arab' from her parents, friends.'' **********During a lovers' quarrel, ''even my own girlfriend said to me once, 'This will teach me to get close to you barbarians,' '' he recalled. ''I could never have said that to her about her Jewishness.'' Still, Mr. Endrawos laces his political views with a fiery pride and bitterness. **********''In general,'' he said, ''Arabs are afraid of Jewish things - anything that's Jewish, they're afraid of. The education I received from my mother was to walk next to the wall and not cause any problems.'' He was determined to reject the advice. **********For Arabs, whose society is fraught with strict sexual taboos, relationships with Jews can be nothing more than the excitement of contact with a relatively permissive culture. Or they can grow out of an effort to leave something of their Arab identity behind, ''passing'' into what, in Israel, is the majority. **********One Jewish woman from Jerusalem, in the Galilee for a weekend, met a young man who tried to pass as a Jew as he began dating her. Despite his fluent Hebrew, she guessed he was an Arab, did not mind and confronted him with the fact. He had been afraid to admit it.   Arab Women More Restricted **********Virtually all such relations, including mixed marriages, occur between Arab men and Jewish women, since Arab women are mostly prevented from dating by the conservative traditions of their society. One exception - the daughter of an Arab Christian family in Haifa - told recently of her rejection by both Arabs and Jews as she was educated in Jewish schools, learned to read and write Arabic at a Jewish university, spent time with Jews and fell in love with a Jewish man. **********''My fellow Palestinian students ostracized me,'' she said in an Israeli radio interview. ''They called me a whore because I socialized with Jews and probably thought I was sleeping with most of them.'' **********She began living with her man, a right-winger; they decided not to buy a television set so they could avoid news broadcasts and thus avoid political fights. One day, she said, his Jewish friends got together with some Arab students and beat him up. **********Both his parents and hers resolutely opposed marriage, leaving her caught between two cultures. ''I don't know if it would have been good,'' she said. ''I don't know. But with an Arab boy it definitely won't work. Now I'm 28. I know that for an Arab boy, my stock has gone down. He can be crazy for me. His family won't go along with it.'' **********Some Arabs See Parallel With Jewish Experience **********Some Arabs see parallels between Jewish and Palestinian culture and between the Jewish and Palestinian experiences of rejection and suffering. But when Arabs speak of this, it is often with an underlying tone of contempt. **********''Both of us are arrogant,'' said Ibrahim Karain, a Palestinian journalist in East Jerusalem. ''We think ourselves distinguished in the Arab world, and they think themselves distinguished in the world as a whole.'' He laughed. Both peoples are intensely political, hard-working, devoted to education, he said. **********Jamil Hamad, a journalist from Bethlehem, disagreed. ''The Jewish arrogance is completely different from the Palestinian arrogance,'' he contended. Palestinians are willing to do any work to get ahead, he said. ''The Jewish arrogance was the product of a very mysterious thing: 'We are the chosen people.' It's an old business. **********''Part of the Jewish arrogance is the inferiority complex,'' Mr. Hamad continued. ''They are exporting a Jewishness to the Palestinians. You see how the Palestinian Jewishness is functioning. You see how the Palestinians of the West Bank are building universities, schools, developing folklore, exhibiting art. This is a Jewish business. You are making me a minority, but I am preserving my culture and identity.'' **********Of all the images of Jews that Arabs possess, the one that ignites the deepest fury among Israeli Jews is the parallel some Arabs draw between Jews and Nazis, the argument that what the Nazis did to the Jews, the Jews now do to the Palestinians. **********Arabs Widely Ignorant Of the Nazi Horror **********In some measure, this comes out of genuine ignorance among Arabs about the Nazi horror inflicted on European Jews; children on the West Bank learn nothing about it in school, and even Israeli Arabs do not seem to absorb the lessons they get. Miss Bandler, of Interns for Peace, said she knew a militant young Arab who used to equate Israeli Jews with Nazis until he went to a small museum on a kibbutz founded by survivors of the Warsaw ghetto. **********''He was very moved to see what Jews had suffered,'' she said. ''He didn't have that image at all: Jews were fighters, powerful.'' **********Last September, when two foreign correspondents visited Ansar, the Israeli prison camp in southern Lebanon, they heard the head of the prisoners' committee, a Palestine Liberation Organization officer named Salah Taamri, invoke the Nazi death camps in denouncing Israel. **********''Ansar is Auschwitz!'' the prisoners chanted as the reporters approached the fence. Cordelia Edvardson of the Swedish newspaper Svenska Dagbladet had been imprisoned in Auschwitz, but she did not tell Mr. Taamri that when she asked if he agreed with the prisoners' chant.   Comment by Begin Recalled **********''I can't agree and I can't disagree,'' he answered. Referring to former Prime Minister Menachem Begin, he added: ''When Begin said about us - animals on two feet - doesn't it bring an echo of what Hitler said about the Jews? To someone whose family got killed, the whole world is a Holocaust. Should anything be special because you are Jewish? Are they the chosen people of God, or are they the chaotic people of the devil?'' **********She never told him about having been in Auschwitz. Later, when her colleague asked why, she said, ''It would have been unfair. He was behind bars, and I was free.'' **********In the Dheisheh refugee camp, little Amal with the red ribbon in her hair was asked what she would talk about if she met a Jewish girl her age. ''Nothing,'' Amal replied. Wouldn't she be interested in knowing about the other girl's life? ''No.'' And why not? **********''Because I don't know her,'' Amal declared, ''and she doesn't know me.'' **********NEXT: The status of Israeli Arabs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/busin.main_headline: SOME ORIENTAL RUG DEALERS MOVING TO MEADOWLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; SOME ORIENTAL RUG DEALERS MOVING TO MEADOWLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/busin.body_text: **********For more than half a century, New York's Oriental rug district has been in old buildings and storefronts spread out over a section of midtown Manhattan that runs from 28th to 34th Streets and from Lexington to Fifth Avenue. **********But over the last few years, rapidly rising rents and a lack of room for expansion have made it increasingly difficult for many of the small-scale dealers who import handmade rugs and carpets to survive there. **********For a dozen of them, or about one- quarter of the city's Oriental rug trade, the solution will be to pack up their rugs and leave the district and the city entirely, moving across the Hudson River to a $6 million central merchandising and showroom facility designed just for the Oriental rug trade. **********The two-story, 157,000-square-foot structure is under construction at the Harmon Meadow mixed-use development rising in the Secaucus Meadowlands. **********The developer of the Oriental rug center, as well as a 500-acre office, industrial, retail and residential complex on the site, is Hartz Mountain Industries, the real estate development arm of the large pet food company.  Eugene Heller, president of Hartz Mountain, said he had not considered including an Oriental rug center at the Harmon Meadow until he was approached by a Manhattan real estate broker looking for space for a group of rug importers whose leases had either fallen due or were to expire soon. **********One of the importers is Jon S. Ansari, president of the Amiran Corporation at 460 Park Avenue South, one of the city's largest rug dealers. Mr. Ansari said the group had considered moving to several centralized properties within the rug district in Manhattan and farther downtown but that the deals had fallen through. **********At first Mr. Ansari was wary about transferring to Secaucus. ''My initial reaction was that as nice as the property was, it probably wouldn't work because we wouldn't be able to get the buyers to New Jersey,'' he said. **********But as he and some other dealers deliberated, rising rents effectively eliminated most of their other options. Mr. Ansari's lease expired last February. He was given a one-year extension, but faced a fivefold rent increase from the $3 a square foot he now pays. **********The new building in Secaucus will be rented for an average $8 a square foot, compared with an average of $15 to $20 a square foot in Manhattan. In addition, there is no occupancy tax in New Jersey and utility rates are lower. **********The building is expected to be completed by March. It will feature a 7,500-square-foot showroom and reception area as well as a conveyor belt system and a large loading dock. **********Many of the rug dealers expect it will take a year before they know if the move to New Jersey was the right one. But Albert Moomjy, president of the Mid-East Rug Corporation at 276 Fifth Avenue, and also a partner in the Einstein-Moomjy carpet stores, is already confident that most of the Oriental rug business will eventually relocate in Secaucus. **********''Some of the dealers don't feel the move will be too good because we're leaving the city, but I don't think so,'' he said. ''We will still be near New York. We won't be far from Newark Airport. We will have better loading facilities, there will be a modern hotel nearby, a Hilton at Harmon Meadow, and the whole atmosphere will be good.'' **********If all goes well, the new rug facility in Secaucus will be expanded by 56,000 square feet within three to five years to accommodate other dealers. **********But Daniel R. Hodges, president of the Oriental Rug Importers Association of America, and one of four partners who own Pande Cameron of New York Inc., at 200 Lexington Avenue, does not expect many other dealers to leave. He said that customers would not follow these dealers across the river. **********''Most of the buyers will still have to come into Manhattan proper, no matter what,'' he said. ''It's going to be difficult for them to turn around and go to New Jersey, too.'' **********In any event, Ahmad Momeni, president of a concern of that name, and one of the dealers moving to New Jersey to join Mr. Ansari as 51 percent equity participants in the project, feels he has little choice. **********''Basically, our industry is being forced out of this area by the high rents,'' he said, adding that when his five-year lease expires in February, the rent on his 15,000 square feet of space at 79 Madison Avenue will rise to $18 a square foot. When he signed his lease in 1978, the rent was $5 a square foot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Hudson's Bay Freezes Wages
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The Hudson's Bay Company, Canada's biggest trading concern, froze the wages of its 44,000 employees for an undetermined period. **********''We think the economy related to consumer industries will be very difficult for the next six months,'' a company spokesman said, adding that the only alternative would be to cut the company's work force. **********Company losses topped $118 million (United States) over the first nine months of last year, and the final figure for 1982 is also expected to be in the red.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/world.main_headline: Around the World; Pope, in Milan, Champions Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/world.print_headline: Around the World; Pope, in Milan, Champions Workers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II told Italy's leading industrialists today that inflation and recession must not obstruct the fight against unemployment and called for greater worker participation in the management of companies. **********In a speech at the Milan Industrial Fair, a center of international trade, he also said trade unions were an indispensable force in society. **********''I extend to you a heartfelt appeal to multiply and unify your efforts in the search to create new jobs,'' he told an audience that included Industry Minister Filippo Pandolfi; the Fiat chairman, Giovanni Agnelli, and the chairman of Italy's Confindustria employers association, Vittorio Merloni. **********On the third and final day of his pilgrimage to Italy's economic capital, the Pope said inflation and recession ''should never prevent a tenacious search for means to overcome both the causes of unemployment and the painful human situation which derives from it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.main_headline: Marcos Approves Raises And Tightens Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Marcos Approves Raises And Tightens Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/world.body_text: **********The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, hoping to calm mounting unrest, authorized a wage increase today and said crack troops will enforce anti- riot security in Manila. **********Maj. Gen. Josephus Ramas, chief of the army, announced the dispatch of the soldiers to Manila amid opposition plans for protests Nov. 27, on the birthday of slain opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. **********Since Mr. Aquino was shot Aug. 21 there have been demonstrations against the Government in the Philippine capital almost daily. The protests twice resulted violence that left 12 people dead. **********Meantime, Mr. Marcos approved a 19 percent increase in workers' daily pay, to $2.88, to cushion the impact of a 21.4 percent devaluation of the peso last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/busin.body_text: **********The first joint car-making venture between China and an American company is to start operations ahead of schedule next month and investors say they expect it will turn a profit the first year. The American Motors Corporation and the Chinese Government-run Peking Automotive Works have joined together to outfit a plant to build 20,000 four-wheel-drive jeeps during 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/04/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company, which said its business was hurt by the worldwide economic slowdown, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1982 plunged 80.6 percent, while revenues were off 14.4 percent. **********Dow, based in Midland, Mich., said that net income in the latest three months plummeted to $13 million, or 7 cents a share, from $67 million, or 35 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Sales dropped to $2.56 billion, from $2.99 billion. **********''This proved to be an extremely difficult operating quarter,'' said Paul F. Oreffice, Dow's president and chief executive officer.  ''Weak consumer demand and tight inventory control restricted Dow's operating rate to 63 percent of capacity, resulting in heavy fixed cost penalties.'' **********For the full year, Dow said, net income dropped 29.3 percent, to $399 million, or $2.07 a share, from $564 million, or $3 a share, in 1981. Sales slipped 10.5 percent, to $10.62 billion, from $11.87 billion. **********Mr. Oreffice said that Dow, the nation's largest chemical producer after E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, had withdrawn from major joint-venture petrochemical projects in Yugoslavia and Saudi Arabia. **********''Considering the current oversupply of basic chemicals in the international market, additional capacity is unwarranted,'' Mr.  Oreffice said. **********Dow said that earnings for the latest quarter reflected pretax write-offs associated with the dropping of the Yugoslav projects, Dow's withdrawal from Saudi Arabia, and various plant closings and projected cancellations. All of these totaled about $102 million. **********The company said that it had realized fourth-quarter pretax gains from the sale of Bio-Science Enterprises, a clinical laboratory business; Dow's Korean properties, and Apache Petroleum Company depositary units -which yielded $44 million, $7 million and $8 million, respectively. **********''A strong U.S. dollar abroad hindered our European market penetration and export trade in 1982,'' Mr. Orrefice said. Greyhound **********The Greyhound Corporation announced that net income in the fourth quarter dropped 21.9 percent, to $23.6 million, or 54 cents a share, from $30.2 million, or 67 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues dipped 2.5 percent, to $1.17 billion, from $1.20 billion. **********For the full year, earnings fell 25 percent, to $103.1 million, or $2.34 a share, from $137.5 million, or $3.05 a share, in 1981.  Revenues in 1982 were off 4.3 percent, to $4.5 billion, from $4.7 billion. **********John W. Teets, chairman and chief executive of the Phoenix-based Greyhound, said that the decline in net income was easily identifiable. ''There was a drop of nearly $30 million in Transportation Group results, which were down 59 percent for the year, including a 78 percent drop in the Greyhound Lines' U.S.  results.'' **********He added that ''competitive conditions within the industry, airline cut-rate fares and the economy'' were at the root of the decline. In addition to operating the nation's largest private bus system, Greyhound has interests in various financial, industrial and food services, and owns Armour & Company, a major meat and poultry processor, and the Armour-Dial Company, which markets consumer products. General Dynamics **********The General Dynamics Corporation said that its net income in the fourth quarter nearly doubled, to $64.1 million, or $1.17 a share, from $32.6 million, or 60 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. That 96.6 percent jump was complemented by an increase in sales of 50 percent, to $1.8 billion, from $1.2 billion. **********Results in the latest quarter included a provision of $6.9 million after taxes, or 13 cents a share, to cover anticipated costs associated with the closing of a coal mine. The 1981 fourth-quarter results included write-offs of $38.2 million, or 71 cents a share, after taxes, to cover cost overruns and excess overhead at its Electric Boat and Quincy subsidiaries and certain inventory adjustments in the parent company's commercial group. **********The diversified St. Louis-based aerospace concern said that for the full year earnings rose 7 percent, to $132.8 million, or $2.41 a share, from $124.1 million, or $2.25 a share, in 1981. Sales rose 25.5 percent, to $6.4 billion, from $5.1 billion. McDermott **********McDermott International, a leading energy services company based in New Orleans, announced that it had a loss of $239,000 in its third fiscal quarter ended Dec.31, compared with earnings of $48.5 million, or $1.32 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.  Revenues plunged 32.9 percent, to $805.2 million, from $1.20 billion a year earlier. **********''Marine construction and power generation markets continue to be highly competitive, and we believe that operating income from these two segments will be under pressure for the next several quarters,'' said J.E. Cunningham, chairman and chief executive of the diversified concern.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Ex-G.E. Officer to Head A Unit of John Brown **********Alastair C. Gowan, a former executive at the General Electric Company, has been named president of a major unit of John Brown P.L.C., a British manufacturing and engineering company. **********Mr. Gowan, who is 48 years old, will head the industrial products sector, which is based in Warwick, R.I., and includes the Leesona Corporation, a maker of machinery for plastics and textiles that Brown acquired four years ago. **********The sector has annual sales of $300 million. **********Mr. Gowan succeeds Robert G. Page, 63, who is retiring Jan. 1, the company said yesterday. Mr. Page will become a consultant and remain a director. **********Mr. Gowan joined John Brown in February as the sector's chief operating officer, with responsibility for the unit's plastics and textile machinery, machine tool, automation and electronics operations. **********Mr. Gowan said yesterday that the strategy had been to stress the company's machinery for manufacturing plastics over textile machinery, with the textile industry ''in the doldrums.'' **********Mr. Gowan was recruited by John Brown with the understanding that he would be Mr. Page's replacement. He previously worked for General Electric since 1960. He held several posts, many in Europe, and was a corporate vice president and general manager of the metallurgical business division when he left. **********Mr. Gowan, who is from Scotland, is a naturalized United States citizen. He received a bachelor's degree and doctorate in chemistry from the University of Aberdeen in Scotland. **********Mr. Page, who joined John Brown in 1974, plans an active retirement. The company said he would work on a wide variety of special projects as a consultant and would ''seek out more competitive sources for parts and materials, new business opportunities such as joint ventures, new product lines and the development of new markets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Dissidents Pick Bradford President
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.body_text: **********The Bradford National Corporation, a New York-based computer- services concern, has named a new president and chief executive officer aligned with a group of dissident stockholders who recently took control of the company. **********The new official is Alan Winters, 44 years old, who will succeed Roy B. Simpson, 60, on Sept. 15. Mr. Simpson, who has been president for eight months, will remain as a consultant. **********A group of stockholders led by William Siegel, who is also chairman of the Siegel Oil Company of Electra, Tex., won control of the company in June when Bradford agreed to end a proxy fight. Five new members were chosen with Mr. Siegel as chairman. Four members of the old board were retained. **********The dissidents said at the time that new management was needed to take advantage of opportunities in the financial services industry. **********A spokesman said that Bradford had been basically servicing its accounts but would now become more of a marketing organization and a ''go- getter.'' **********Mr. Winters, Bradford said, was hired to head a task force that is in the process of evaluating the company.  He is ''extremely well-qualified to hasten the future growth and direct the strategies,'' Mr. Siegel said of Mr. Winters in a statement. **********Mr. Simpson was named president in January when James L. Mann quit during what was termed a restructuring. Mr. Simpson was a senior vice president at the American Can Company until 1981. **********Mr. Winters is a certified public accountant and was formerly president and chief executive of Leslie's of Lester Melnick Inc., a retail chain in the Dallas area. **********Bradford's customers are banks, mutual funds, brokers and other financial institutions. Two years ago it got out of the business of supplying data-processing services for health care claims. Also in 1981, it sold its systems and administrative services divisions for $11.5 million after pleading guilty to Federal charges that it had falsified payment claims.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.body_text: **********TO make money, the truism goes, one has to spend money. But there are no such truisms about the amount of money that an individual should spend, or invest, in pursuit of more. The risk that any individual takes should be determined by a number of factors. **********Financial planners and investment advisers say the most important factor is age, which they view in three stages. **********The first is the accumulation of capital, a goal to be achieved - inevitably, through risk - in the early and middle years. The second is the preservation of capital, an object for which risk should be minimized. The third is the orderly distribution of capital. **********The consensus among financial planners is that the best time to take a sizable risk in the hope of a large reward is early in one's career. That way, ''there's lots of time to recover from one's mistakes,'' said Dennis J. Kelly, a financial planner with Janney Montgomery Scott, a New York brokerage firm. As the person enters middle age, there is less time to recoup losses but more financial responsibilities to be met. **********The investor's psychological tolerance for risk may be as critical as his or her age or financial status. ''There is an economic risk to all investments, and people should understand that,'' said James Avedisian, chairman of the personal financial planning group of Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. **********''Asked what they want, everyone will say 'more,' '' said Robert McKeveny, vice president, investments, for Scudder, Stevens & Clark, investment advisers in New York, ''but what is their ability to accept less for a period of time?'' Although their assets may be far larger, older people have less tolerance for risk. TAKING THE HIGH RISK **********The best candidate for a high-risk, high-reward investment, the experts say, is a young professional or business executive who has recently completed graduate school, is free of family responsibility, and has an income of $40,000 or more and assets of $10,000. If he or she also has ''the right psychological makeup, it's time to take a flyer,'' said Mr. Avedisian. **********He added that risk-taking is a form of recreation for many people. That may mean investing in high-technology stocks, or investing with friends on an apartment building. With only $10,000 in assets, it is unlikely that he or she has enough to make a down payment on a home, he said. **********The experts agreed that a young professional's top priority should be building equity. ''The emphasis should be on the rate on investing rather than the rate of return,'' Mr. Kelly said. Ideally, he said, the young person should keep the equivalent of a few months' salary in a money-market account with checking privileges, and invest the rest in a growth-oriented mutual fund. That strategy also gives the investor quick access to his money in the event a more inviting opportunity arises. **********There is disagreement among planners and investment advisers over whether young professionals should put the maximum $2,000 a year into an Individual Retirement Account, from which the money generally cannot be withdrawn until age 59 1/2 without a penalty. Some experts said it would be unwise for young people to place such a large percentage of their net worth in such an illiquid investment. **********Mr. McKeveny, however, said everyone should take advantage of the tax savings offered by I.R.A.'s. ''Uncle Sam's helping you save,'' he said. ''It's good discipline. And if you need to draw on those funds, the penalty is not that horrendous.'' TAKING HALF A RISK **********The issue of risk versus reward becomes more complex in the hypothetical example of a couple in their early 30's, with a joint income of about $85,000 and roughly the same amount in assets. If the couple have not already acquired a house, or if they want to improve their housing, planners say, this is the time. **********Mr. Kelly said such a couple should put down half of their assets on housing, ''a good, comfort level'' that will allow for a reasonable mortgage and enough liquidity for more equity- building investments. **********With the housing question resolved, the next issue becomes how best to invest the remaining assets, as well as any income the couple does not spend and the tax savings from their home, to pay for their children's college tuition in 10 or 15 years. Even at this point, the experts agree, the couple have a relatively long time and can afford to take on risk in order to seek above-average returns. **********Mr. McKeveny recommends that the couple put 10 percent of their assets into something highly liquid, such as a money-market account; 20 percent in long-term tax-exempt bonds, and 70 percent in riskier, growth securities. Mr. Kelly also recommends a three-way split, although he balances the equation differently: one-third in equities, such as stocks; one-third in fixed-income securities, such as bonds, and one-third in so-called tax- advantaged programs, such as a real estate or oil-and-gas partnership. Of the three investments, ''none is riskier than another,'' he said. The plan offers what the couple need at this point, he said: flexibilityand liquidity. At the same time, he recommends that the couple take the cash flow from their fixed-income securities and invest it in equities. If the couple have deferred buying I.R.A.'s, now is the time, Mr. Kelly said. **********Mr. Avedisian agrees that a tax-sheltering vehicle may be useful, but he stipulates that it becomes desirable only if the couple have more than $60,000 in taxable income. Further, he cautions that even tax shelters have risks. For one thing, the Internal Revenue Service sometimes disallows deductions that were intended to save taxes for investors. For another, the tax shelter itself, such as real estate, may fail to generate the hoped-for income if, for example, there is an oversupply of rental properties. Even so, Mr. Avedisian said, ''to the extent that risk can be alleviated with tax benefits, it can help.'' **********The couple can also minimize taxes by transferring some assets to their children through such devices as the Clifford Trust, in which any income is taxed at the children's bracket while the principal is retained by the parents. **********Experts said that, as a rule, people using a Clifford Trust should shun speculative investments in favor of such high- income vehicles as money-market accounts or corporate bonds. ''You want the principal to be there when you need it,'' Mr. Avedisian said. Besides, he added, ''the pressure to obtain a high rate of return is not so great when the tax rate is low.'' THE TRANSITIONAL STAGE **********With the children in college, the Clifford Trust, which freezes funds for 10 years, is no longer useful. But the hypothetical couple, who may then be in their 50's, with combined income of $150,000 to $200,000 and with $250,000 in assets, still need tax sheltering and equity accumulation as well as a good income. ''This is the transitional stage between preservation and distribution of assets,'' Mr. Kelly said. **********The couple ''might want to be less aggressive with investments than in the past,'' he said. ''Or, if they have been speculators, they might speculate with less money. If you make a mistake, you've got less time to recover.'' **********One investment instrument he recommends for affluent middle-aged investors is a series of bonds with different maturities, expiring, for example, in 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10 years. In that way, the investor can achieve an average interest rate over the entire period regardless of what happens to interest rates in the short term, he said. **********Another investment to consider at this point, Mr. Avedisian said, is tax-free municipal bonds, an instrument he would not have recommended for younger people because the bonds are income-oriented rather than growth-oriented. **********Financial planners and investment advisers note that middle-aged investors can continue to be somewhat aggressive. ''They have enough income and assets so that they can diversify and take risks,'' Mr. Avedisian said. **********Mr. McKeveny would shift their portfolio slightly, still keeping 10 percent in the money-market account but raising to 25 percent the amount in long-term tax-exempt bonds and lowering to 65 percent the portion in equities. Those equities would be less growth-oriented than the stocks for young professionals and young couples, but they would not necessarily be low- growth blue-chips, either. The middle- aged couple ''still have time to look for capital appreciation,'' he said. **********FOCUSING ON SAFETY **********But as the couple approach retirement, the third stage of their investment life, the experts say they should turn their attention to insuring a certain level of after-tax income for the future. The emphasis now is on safe, liquid, income-generating investments rather than higher- risk equity-building. **********''Retirees look at liquidity, even at the possible consumption of principal,'' Mr. Avedisian said. At the same time, the couple's investment strategy should be consistent with the distribution of their capital. **********The couple could now begin giving to their children those assets that would incur heavy estate taxes, or property with major growth potential, the experts suggested. For example, if the couple own a stock or a collectible that they believe to have substantial long-term growth potential, ''by giving it now, all appreciation is removed from the estate,'' Mr. Avedisian said. **********Another good candidate is a life insurance policy, which may have a relatively modest face value but would balloon upon the death of the owner. Rather than wait until then, the owner can give the policy to an heir as a gift, ''if they give it completely and irrevocably, and live for three years beyond that,'' Mr. Avedisian said. **********In any event, financial planners said, an elderly person with ample reserves would be well-advised to make each heir an annual gift of $10,000, the largest sum that will not incur Federal gift and estate taxes. A husband and wife could give $20,000 a year to each heir without tax penalty.  ''Gifting is the start of orderly distribution,'' Mr. Kelly said. **********In terms of new investments at this stage, the planners recommend such lower-risk instruments as money-market accounts, blue-chip equities and mutual funds. Mr. McKeveny suggests another portfolio shift, still with 10 percent in money-market funds, but with 40 percent in long-term tax-exempt bonds and 50 percent in blue-chip stocks. **********The stocks ''provide growing income through growing dividends,'' he said, ''and if the couple has to draw out in a depressed market, they've hedged themselves by putting in only half their assets.'' **********The couple are likely to remain in the highest tax bracket, and thus may want to shelter some of their income. Here, too, the experts recommend a relatively conservative strategy. **********If the couple choose a real estate tax shelter, for example, they should consider a rental property with long-term tenants rather than a shopping center. In any event, the investment ''should be no more than they can afford to lose without impairing their lifestyle,'' Mr. Avedisian said. **********Or, despite the taxes, they may sleep better with no shelter at all, he noted. ''Often people in retirement want to simplify their lives,'' he said. **********In the final analysis, financial planners and investment advisers caution, such imponderables as an individual's comfort with risk may be as critical as his or her income and wealth in formulating an investment strategy. And emotions aside, there is still wide variation among people who are nominally in the same financial category. **********''There aren't investments suitable for all people, as their priorities and tax situations can be very different,'' Mr. Avedisian said. Thus, while experts offer guidelines for personal investing, they underline that investing is personal. **********Financial Strategies for Three Stages of Life PrimaryWealth accumulationInvestmentvia regular monthlyObjectivessavings; InvestmentBasic Living$18,000ExpensesFederal &$9,000State TaxesMarginal36%Tax BracketInsuranceAppropriate levels of life and disability insurance should be reviewedEmergency$2,000 money-marketFundfund with checkingInvestment$5,000 growth mutualPortfoliofund for capital    A tax-managed trust is an investment company that buys shares in low-risk, high-yielding domestic companies and elects to be treated as a corporation under the tax laws, rather than as a mutual fund, so that the dividends it receives qualify for an 85 percent tax exclusion. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/12/world.main_headline: POPE, CITING HOPE FOR UNITY, TAKES PART IN LUTHERAN RITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/12/world.print_headline: POPE, CITING HOPE FOR UNITY, TAKES PART IN LUTHERAN RITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/12/world.body_text: **********Text of Pope's sermon, page A12. **********ROME, Dec. 11 - In an extraordinary ecumenical gesture, Pope John Paul II joined in a Lutheran service here tonight, the first time that a Pope had done so. **********John Paul's visit to the Evangelical- Lutheran Christ Church, in the year of the 500th anniversary of Martin Luther's birth, was brought about by a spontaneous invitation last year by a board member of the church during an encounter with the Pope. **********The visit was announced Nov. 11, the same day the Vatican issued a letter marking the birth of Luther in which the Pope praised his ''profound religiousness.'' **********Lutheran Church officials emphasized that the service was not an ecumenical one, but a normal Advent service. A Vatican official, however, stressed that all parts of the liturgy had been thoroughly discussed and approved by the Pope's representatives. **********The Pope, received with respect rather than enthusiasm by an invitation-only congregation of 400 people, preached a sermon on the theme of reconciliation of all Christians. But he also emphasized the many issues and practices that still separate Roman Catholics and Protestants. **********''So we see ourselves in the midst of all the evident separations that still exist in teaching and life, deeply linked in the solidarity of all the Christians of Advent,'' John Paul said in German, the language that Luther elevated in his break with a church whose only tongue was Latin. **********''We long for unity,'' the Pope continued, ''and we strive for this unity without letting ourselves be discouraged by the difficulties that may pile up along the way.'' **********In his only reference to Luther today, he said that five centuries after his birth, ''we see as if in a distance the dawning of the advent of a reconstruction of our unity and community.'' **********The service reached its ecumenical high point, in the view of some Catholics and Protestants, when the church's pastor, the Rev. Dr. Christoph Meyer, recited a prayer composed by Luther:    We poor sinners pray Thee, Lord, **********and plead: That You would through Your Holy **********Ghost Bring together all that is dispersed, Unite what is separated and make it **********whole. **********However symbolic the action of the Pope's praying in a Lutheran church, those who had hoped for a message that the Vatican was proceeding with greater urgency toward the ecumenical goals set forth by the Second Vatican Council in 1965 had to content themselves with the gesture of the visit. Many Protestants believe that the ecumenical drive sparked by Vatican II has lost impetus. **********But in a city where memories of the great sectarian struggles within Christianity are very long, the gesture was seen by scholars as a major historic act, whether or not any consequences flow from it. **********Some scholars recalled a bull issued by Pope Leo X in 1520, which challenged Luther to recant his heretical doctrines within 60 days or be excommunicated. In the violent language of that time, Leo wrote, addressing himself to Christ: **********''Listen to our prayers, for foxes have arisen seeking to destroy the vineyard whose wine press You alone trod. When You were about to ascend to Your Father, You committed the care, rule and administration of the vineyard, an image of the triumphant church, to Peter as the head and Your vicar and his successors. The wild boar from the forest seeks to destroy it, and every wild beast feeds upon it.'' **********The point was not lost on many of the Protestants in Christ Church tonight that the present successor of a Pope who had compared Luther to savage animals had come to pray in his church, bow to its altar and join with Pastor Meyer in reciting the Apostles' Creed and the Lord's Prayer. **********Dr. Meyer, who also preached a sermon of reconciliation, asked all Christians to strive to overcome a history in which ''so much was unbeautiful.'' The pastor noted pointedly that a different language was spoken today between the churches. **********The Lutheran Church made it clear that the invitation to the Pope was a concession on its part. Dr. Meyer said on several occasions since the visit was announced that it did not imply any measure of recognition of papal authority. The invitations that entitled visitors to penetrate the tight security cordon around the 70-year-old church off the Via Veneto specified that the service would be attended by ''the Bishop of Rome,'' and they avoided the word ''Pope.'' **********In his only direct address to his guest, Dr. Meyer, although speaking German, called him by his common Italian honorific, ''Santit a,'' or ''Holiness,'' preferring this to any title that might suggest submission. **********No applause greeted the Pope as he entered the church. Clapping is usual for him wherever he goes. But parishioners were eager to grasp the Pope's hand and respond to his courteous queries as he walked down the aisle on one side and then walked back up on the other to meet more people. Only then did he climb to the altar, bow and take his seat.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Two years ago, the Beatrice Food Company decided to rely heavily on its Tropicana Products Inc. orange juice subsidiary to provide big earnings, even if it would someday have to sell Tropicana under a Government order. **********Company officials determined that certain steps had to be taken despite a ruling by a Federal Trade Commission law judge that Beatrice's takeover of Tropicana was anticompetitive. **********''We decided that if we had to sell it, we should pay more attention to the company,'' said Douglas Stanard, corporate secretary and a vice president of Beatrice. ''And if we didn't have to sell it, we should still pay more attention to it.'' **********As it turns out, the company will not have to make the sale.  Yesterday, the F.T.C. overruled the decision of its law judge and voted to let Beatrice keep Tropicana. New Products Offered **********As part of its strategy, Beatrice named new managers and introduced several products, including frozen orange juice concentrates to compete with Minute Maid, the market leader. And last week, at the company's annual meeting, James L. Dutt, chairman, said Tropicana would play an increasingly important part in Beatrice. **********The food company, based in Chicago, is undergoing a broad reorganization, including the sale of 50 of its more than 250 companies.  Beverages, which could contribute $1.5 billion to the company's annual revenues of $9.2 billion, would depend on Tropicana to contribute more than 60 percent of the group's sales and 63 percent of its earnings, according to the reorganization plan. **********In coming months, ''Tropicana will support its products by increasing its advertising and promotional expenditures 35 percent, reflecting the largest marketing budget in the firm's history,'' the company said. **********John Biercusse, an investment analyst for Duff & Phelps in Chicago, said: ''I expect to see Tropicana become more active and aggressive.  Tropicana has solid earnings potential despite two poor years.'' Earnings Hurt by Weather **********Two years of freezing winters have hurt its earnings. ''They earned about $63 million in fiscal 1981, about $43 million in 1982 and $43 million in 1983,'' said William Leach, an analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''Tropicana has been very disappointing recently.'' **********Because Tropicana's earnings performance fell far short of expectations, Beatrice announced in February that it was taking a $190 million write-down of its Tropicana assets. Beatrice had been carrying as much as $300 million in Tropicana good will on its balance sheets. After the writedown, only about $100 million remained on Beatrice's books. **********In the year ended last Feb. 28, Beatrice's earnings plunged to $43.2 million, or 27 cents a share, from $390.1 million, or $3.80 a share, the year before. Revenues grew to $9.19 billion from $9.02 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/27/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; SAILING THE SEA AND DEDUCTING THE COST
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/27/busin.body_text: **********SOME call it ''the Loveboat bill.'' Others believe that it is an i mportant piece of legislation that will be a boon to American cruisel ines and provide more jobs for American workers. **********However it is perceived, a new law that went into effect at the beginning of 1983 broadens business-expense deduction rules for the tens of thousands of Americans who attend out-of-town conventions, meetings and seminars each year. Such gatherings now may be held on American-flag ships sailing between American ports. The ruling extends an earlier one under which deductions from Federal income taxes were restricted to business functions held in North America, as well as in American possessions, and were not allowed for trips outside the continent or aboard ship. **********''This may be the first crack in the dike,'' said Herbert Paul, a New York tax lawyer. Travel industry lobbyists are already mounting a drive to extend the regulations even further, to allow conventions to be held in foreign locations and on ships registered in countries other than the United States. As it stands now, only about four American ships are likely to take advantage of the ruling. **********Before packing your cruising togs, however, you should be aware of some significant limitations to the new deductibility. Although the Internal Revenue Service has not yet issued regulations implementing the law and may not do so for several months, the maximum deduction per individual per year has been set at $2,000. **********The I.R.S. noted that was the first time a dollar limit had been set on the amount that could be spent to attend a business meeting.  And it said that ''in the absence of regulations, it would appear'' that this limit applies to companies and associations that pick up the tab for such attendance, as well as to individuals who pay their own way. **********The conference report accompanying the legislation noted that if married taxpayers who filed a joint return each attended deductible cruise-ship conventions at a cost of $2,000, each could deduct the full amount, for a joint total of $4,000. But if one spouse spent $3,000 on such a cruise and the other did not attend, only $2,000 would be deductible, even when a joint return is filed. **********Furthermore, a spouse's expenses for travel, meals and lodging at a convention or meeting are not deductible unless the spouse serves what the I.R.S. considers ''a real business purpose'' and there is a ''need'' for his or her presence. Incidental services provided by the spouse - such as taking notes, carrying luggage or entertaining customers - are not sufficient for tax-deductible status. **********Two detailed statements must be attached to a tax return when a deduction is claimed. One signed by the taxpayer must list the number of days of the trip, the number of hours of scheduled daily business activity and the program of the meeting. Similar information must also be provided in a statement signed by an officer of the organization that sponsored the meeting. There are no requirements concerning the amount of time each day that must be spent on business, other than the I.R.S.'s standard requirement that the ''primary purpose'' of a business meeting must be business. **********Business gatherings were allowed to be held almost anywhere in the world until two years ago when the I.R.S. tightened rules following some highly criticized abuses of the deductibility benefit by individuals and groups. The I.R.S. at that time ruled that taxpayers who wished to meet in places other than in North America had to prove that it was ''as reasonable'' to hold a foreign conference as one closer to home if they wanted the tax deduction. **********''When you compare what other countries do, we were pretty tight,'' added Leon Nad, national tax partner of Price Waterhouse, who cited a study of deductibility in other countries done about two years ago by his certified public accounting firm. ''If you've got an opportunity to learn, I don't see any reason why the meeting cannot be on a ship.'' **********After intense lobbying by the American passenger shipping industry, however, the lame-duck session of Congress last year liberalized rules covering business-related meetings. This move to allow business meetings to be held on ships of United States registry traveling between American ports was fashioned by the part of the Highway Revenue Act of 1982 that amended Section 274(h) of the Internal Revenue Code. **********But because the I.R.S. ruling is still untested, some meeting organizers may be reluctant to plan a conference aboard ship for fear of bringing about an I.R.S. audit for their members. A number of planners indicated that even though it could cost less to bring their groups to a seaboard meeting than to one on land, they might hesitate to invite a tangle with a tax examiner by doing so. **********MORE than 125 cruise ships operate from the United States, but only 11 vessels sail under the American flag b etween domestic ports, according to Ford's International Cruise G uide. And because of the size of the ships required to stage i ndustry conventions or company conferences - even relatively small o nes - just four ships are likely to get the bulk of whatever new b usiness is attracted to cruising conventions. **********Two of them, the Independence and the Constitution, are operated between the West Coast and Hawaii by American Hawaii Cruises, based in San Francisco. The other two, the Delta Queen and the Mississippi Queen, run along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers and are owned by the Delta Queen Steamboat Company. **********''The interest level from meeting planners has been exceedingly high,'' said Dennis M. Myrick, cruise consultant for American Hawaii. ''We've recently hired two sales representatives that will do nothing but call on meeting planners.'' **********Stanley S. Thune, president of Cincinnati-based Delta Queen, is even more enthusiastic. ''This opens up a $20 million market to the United States flag vessels,'' he said. ''Our target is 15 groups for 1983 and 50 groups for 1984.'' He added, however, that the lead time on these business groups is anywhere from seven to 12 months, and that the real impact will start in November. **********Further lobbying attempts have started to convince Congress to liberalize the rules even more by allowing such meetings on other ships and in other countries. ''We believe that a convention should be deductible based on its legitimacy as a business meeting, not upon its location,'' said J.J. Doran Jr., manager of maritime and surface travel of the American Society of Travel Agents, one of the groups pushing for further changes. But he and others in Washington do not expect that the Government will quickly grant their wishes. ''We're working very hard to try to overcome the perception problems,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/08/world.body_text: **********Officials here said that a Chinese Air Force test pilot defected to South Korea today in a MIG-21 fighter plane, setting off air-raid warnings all over the country. **********The state radio interrupted programs to say the enemy was attacking by air in areas west of Seoul. The radio reported later that the alert was caused by the MIG-21 flown by the defecting pilot, Sun Dianjin, 46 years old. **********South Korean warplanes scrambled and escorted the Chinese MIG to an unnamed South Korean air base, where the pilot was said to have been taken for questioning. **********A Defense Ministry spokesman said the pilot had asked to be allowed to go to a third country to seek political asylum. The country was not named. **********In Taiwan a spokesman for the Nationalist Government, which has a standing reward offer of $2.5 million to any Chinese Air Force flier who defects with a MIG fighter, said it would welcome the pilot. **********The spokesman said that the defector was attached to a Chinese aviation test squad, and that he had told South Korean officials he was on a navigation training flight over northeast China when he decided to defect. **********The last Chinese Air Force pilot who defected to South Korea was Capt. Wu Yungkeng, 25, who arrived in October. He was granted political asylum in Taiwan, where he received $2.5 million worth of gold and became a major in the Nationalist Chinese Air Force.   North Korea Denies Spy Charge **********TOKYO, Aug. 7 (Reuters) - North Korea said today that a boat that South Korea said it had sunk Friday off of its southeastern coast was not a North Korean spy ship but a South Korean vessel fired on by its own side. **********The official North Korean news agency, monitored here, quoted the daily newspaper Rodong Sinmun as saying that the incident had nothing to do with North Korea. **********South Korea's Defense Ministry said Friday that it had sunk a North Korean spy boat off the southeastern town of Wolsong, killing five people. **********Rodong Sinmun said the sinking happened during South Korean war games.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.body_text: **********In the last few years, Atlas Industries has been transformed from a floundering, money-losing producer of simple electronics items into a highly profitable manufacturer of sophisticated parts for leading computer companies in the United States. **********Larry Tam, an analyst for Sun Hung Kai Research Ltd., called the turnaround ''just incredible.'' **********The change is largely attributable to American technology and management, brought into the company in 1980 when Albert J. Miller, an entrepreneur from California's Silicon Valley, bought control of Atlas and became its chairman. **********Analysts are also impressed by the company's prospects, and the principal reason can be summed up in three letters: I.B.M. **********Atlas recently signed a large contract to supply the International Business Machines Corporation with computer heads and assembled floppy- disk drives. The parts will be used in personal computers. Analysts say the contract will be worth more than $170 million over the next three or four years. **********'They're Pushing Us' **********Atlas executives would not disclose the size of the contract. But Mr. Miller, who was in Hong Kong recently, said: ''I.B.M. is talking about tremendous volume. They're pushing us.'' **********Though still tiny by international standards, the Hong Kong-based company is certain to expand dramatically, analysts say. In the year ended last March, Atlas's profits doubled, to $4.1 million, on sales of $32.4 million. **********For the current fiscal year, Atlas will again double its income, to $8.3 million on sales of $47.7 million, according to W. I. Carr Sons & Company. For the following year, Carr expects Atlas to earn about $12 million on sales of $100 million. Some analysts say the Carr figures are unduly conservative, predicting that profits next year will double again, to $16 million. **********Stock Price Up Sharply **********Investors, especially European- based institutions, have driven the price of Atlas shares up sharply, at a time when the Hong Kong market has been in the doldrums. In April 1982, Atlas stock sold for 6 cents a share, applying the current exchange rate of 7.8 Hong Kong dollars to the United States dollar. Recently, the stock has been trading at 70 cents a share. **********Atlas garnered the I.B.M. contract by gaining a top rating for quality and on-time delivery of computer heads in 1982, outperforming other foreign and American contenders. **********A computer head transfers electronic digital signals into magnetic impulses stored on computer tape and memory disks. It also works the other way, transferring the coded information stored as magnetic impulses back into digital signals for processing by the computer. The heart of the computer head is a small piece of ferrite, sliced microscopically thin and finely polished. **********A floppy-disk drive turns the magnetic disk at high speed and moves the head to various points on the disk, to pick up or put down information. **********Another Advantage **********Besides efficient production, Atlas has another advantage: It is not a Japanese company. The largest independent suppliers of computer heads are Japanese, including the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and the TDK Corporation. **********Although large American computer companies generally make heads themselves, they also buy them. Atlas makes heads not only for I.B.M. but also for Hewlett-Packard, General Electric, Burroughs's Memorex unit and Texas Instruments. **********''One of the reasons we're so busy is that all the big U.S. companies are uncomfortable with being dependent on Japan,'' Mr. Miller said. ''Ultimately, the Japanese manufacturers will do first and foremost what is good for Japan. And Japan's plans to rule the computer industry are no secret.'' **********The company produces ferrite material and conducts research and development through two subsidiaries in the Silicon Valley. But its main manufacturing operations are in Hong Kong, where labor costs are about $15 a day per worker compared with more than $15 an hour, benefits included, in the United States. **********The tax benefits in Hong Kong, with its maximum corporate tax rate of 16.5 percent, are also considerable. **********Labor Force to Increase **********To meet the demand for computer components, Atlas plans to add 1,000 workers to its payroll of about 2,000 in Hong Kong. But the biggest expansion will be in Malaysia, where the company is building a 500,000-square- foot complex in Penang, a free-trade zone offering tax breaks and other benefits for high-technology investments. In addition, Atlas is tripling the size of an existing plant in Malaysia, adding 85,000 square feet. **********The Penang complex will be an integrated plant, housing manufacturing, assembly, plastic injection molding and metal stamping and fabricating operations. **********To date, the Malaysian subsidiary has made consumer electronics components, but this month pilot production of floppy-disk drives began. Six I.B.M. engineers are now at the Malaysia unit, Mr. Miller said, ''to see that we learn to make the computer heads and drives properly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/24/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Now that the furor over the ''Japanning'' of America has subsided somewhat, a story I heard 50 years ago, as a senior engineering student at the University of Florida, may be timely. **********As the story goes, a group of Japanese industrialists visited the United States as guests of American industry. They were given the red carpet treatment designed to display the industrial might - including research and engineering - of American industry. **********After trips to a number of industrial units where the Japanese were seemingly awed by what they saw and heard, the visit ended at one of America's most highly regarded research and engineering laboratories. The piece de resistance was a harbinger of that laboratory's work in the field of microminiaturization - the smallest fully operable electric (AC) motor in the world; the diameter of the motor shaft was about that of a small sewing needle, one about fivetenths of 1 millimeter in diameter. **********The Japanese were obviously impressed, so much so that their leader asked if he might take the motor, which was enclosed in a glass case, back to Japan to show its scientists and engineers the great American accomplishment. After some thought, the director of the laboratory agreed. **********About six weeks later, a Japanese emissary returned the motor along with a message thanking the labortory director and suggesting that he examine the motor shaft. A cursory examination of the shaft revealed nothing; however, under a microscope the director discovered that the Japanese had drilled a hole longitudinally through the shaft, converting it from a solid one to a hollow one. **********Maybe there is something about the Japanese that we persist in overlooking, especially about the management of their research and engineering. And perhaps we should spend more effort in discovering what this something is rather than concentrating on what they do.  JOSEPH B. SMITH Jr. **********Knoxville, Md., June 25

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/01/busin.body_text: **********A Greenspan Fed? **********Alan Greenspan, a leading contender to replace Paul A. Volcker at the helm of the Federal Reserve Board, may not fit the mold of the ''President's man.'' Aides are arguing that Mr. Reagan must place his own man as chairman of the Fed when Mr. Volcker's four-year term runs out Aug. 6. **********But if the White House is looking for a different policy - either a little more adherence to the money supply or a push to get interest rates down further for the election year - Mr. Greenspan may not be the man. **********Friends of the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ford and outside adviser to President Reagan say he will be another Volcker. ''Alan's actions would not be significantly different from those of Mr. Volcker,'' one associate said. Mr.  Greenspan is not commenting, but he has said several times that Mr.  Volcker deserves reappointment. Nipping at the Heals **********One skirmish during the budget battle in the Senate next week will be over possible language in the Budget Resolution that would require the Federal Reserve to push for a stronger economic recovery. It represents another effort to chip away at the independence of the nation's central bank. **********Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, wants language that would direct the Fed to spur the economy onto a 6 percent or 7 percent recovery path this year, rather than the 4.7 percent pace the Reagan Administration and many economists are forecasting. **********The Fed is understandably wary of any effort by Congress to direct its policy, as is Jake Garn, the feisty Republican chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, who has complained to Senate Majority Leader Howard Baker that his territorial prerogatives, which include the Fed, are being violated. Mr. Garn is a strong supporter of Fed Reserve independence. Now the Budget Committee chairman, Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, who had expressed some interest in the directive language, may back off. **********The House has approved its own, albeit different, language that would force the Fed to set more specific economic objectives, including inflation and growth rates. Thus, it seems that Mr. Volcker & Company will need a substantial lobbying effort to keep their territorial prerogatives out of the hands of Congress. New Tune for Bond Sages **********The surge in the nation's key money supply figures had barely begun to slow down this month, but if you listened, there was an audible sigh of relief in the bond market, as short-term interest rates, which had been inching up, turned downward. Yet, some soothsayers didn't waste any time coming up with another cause of worry and disquietude - the Federal budget deficits. **********The worry is the same as it was at this time last year -the budget process could fall apart, leaving deficits of some $200 billion to $300 billion out through 1988 and the anticipation of this continued huge government demand for credit would push long-term interest rates higher, effectively stalling any recovery. **********But Alan Greenspan, who often comments on the markets himself, isn't sure the markets dance to every new tune the commentators play. ''I don't think markets switch back and forth, the commentators switch,'' he said, adding that the deficit threat has been around for a while but was easily forgotten by the commentators during the rapid decline in interest rates last year. This change, he said, ''raises serious questions about what the commentators know about the markets.'' Consumers on the Move **********One of the rules of economic forecasting of the last several years, which has not been followed too often, is expect the unexpected to happen. And, according to the rule, the consumer has not been spending during the initial months of the current recovery. Thus, the recovery is still limping along. **********Citing recent reports from retailers and higher auto sales for the first 20 days of April, Lawrence Chimerine of Chase Econometrics is now betting that the expected is happening - the consumer is beginning to spend. **********He says purchasing power is rising and will continue because of lower inflation, tax refunds and the 10 percent tax cut in July. The surge in the stock market is increasing net worth dramatically and is making consumers at least feel wealthier. Increases in housing starts and sales will spur spending for household goods, and the decline in layoffs recently is giving another shot in the arm to consumer confidence.
