https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.main_headline: BUSINESS STRUGGLES TO RAISE ITS PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS STRUGGLES TO RAISE ITS PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Even Alcoa, the world's largest producer of aluminum, has been powerless to dictate its own prices, let alone raise them. With demand cut by the recession, Alcoa could not find any takers when it offered raw ingots last year at 76 cents a pound. Buyers were finally enticed to ante up only after Alcoa offered discounts of nearly 40 percent. ''The most frustrating thing,'' sighed one Alcoa vice president, ''is how far prices have come unglued in the last two years.'' **********Whether it is Alcoa or AMAX, Weyerhaeuser or Armco Steel, American business is trying to regain command over prices and start - once again - to raise them. Recoiling from the devastating recession, business now sees the impending recovery as a time when an upturn in demand sets the stage for a similar upturn in prices. This has been the pattern following all other recessions. **********But the upward price move - a key to higher revenues and a restoration of corporate profits - may be nothing more than hope.  Most price increases are still in the planning stages, as business watches and waits for a break in demand. And, of the few that have been attempted - most notably a 6 percent rise in flat rolled steel - success has been elusive. Indeed, prices have fallen so far that it will take a recovery far more vigorous than the one expected in 1983 to give American business the price relief it is seeking. **********''Business cannot do much, desperate though it may be,'' said Otto Eckstein, president of Data Resources Inc., an economic consulting firm. ''Aluminum and steel are just dreaming. They are hoping for significant price increases, but how can they do it? They can't.'' Dreams aside, business claims the recession has dragged on for so long that the need is clearly there. Depressed prices have pushed corporate margins to the lowest levels in years and profits are still falling - by 30 percent alone in the fourth quarter. The situation in some industries has gotten so bad - copper, for instance - that below-cost prices have been the norm. And, in recent weeks, raw material prices have marched up, rising by some 9 percent since the end of December. **********Unlike previous recoveries, which brought rising prices, the turnaround of 1983 comes fraught with obstacles that will keep them down. American business is still operating at less than 70 percent capacity and unemployment remains above 10 percent. And, there are no signs of a quick turnaround. The Reagan Administration, fearing the return of double-digit inflation, has indicated it will move cautiously and steer clear of stimulative policies that would lead to a speedier recovery. In fact, most economists are predicting G.N.P.  growth rates of only 3 to 5 percent in the first year of the recovery, compared with 6 percent or more following past recessions. **********''Everything we've seen so far argues for a price rise that will be only modest,'' said Alan Greenspan, the New York economist who served as chairman of President Ford's Council of Economic Advisers. ''We may see a restoration of the price structure many of these companies had before the roof came in on them. That will reduced the possibility of bankruptcy in many basic industries, but it does not restore them to the type of vitality of two decades ago.'' **********While consumers may hail a moderation in price inflation, it is a mixed blessing for the economy. Slowly rising prices are certainly a harbinger of a long, sustained period of economic expansion, similar to the early 1960's. This is in contrast to the roller coaster cycles of the 1970's, when prices rose quickly only to be beaten back by a severe recession, which, in turn, was halted by an inflationary recovery. But price stability does not come without its costs: Corporate profits remain at low levels, there is less capitalfor reinvestment and unemployment will continue at high levels. **********''The good side is you can have a longer expansionary period than in the past,'' said Barry Bosworth, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution and former director of President Carter's Council on Wage and Price Stability. ''With price stability and unemployment you have set the stage for sustained expansion without having to worry about inflation. But, you won't grow rapidly and put a lot of people back to work. Even if you have a period of expansion, 11 million people will still be unemployed. How you feel about this depends on where you sit.'' IT is largely because the last recession was so deep, coupled with the cautious stance of the Adminstration, that the barriers to price increases are so large. A slow recovery means unemployment will remain stubbornly high - some predict it will be as high as 6 percent in 1988 - and idled plants will be slow to return, if at all. **********Excess capacity has a stifling effect on prices because it tempts businesses to keep them low in order to gain market share. And, the recession has so shattered the confidence of many businessmen that they will call back workers and restart factories only when they are certain the recovery is solid. ''Expanding capacity entails additional costs and there will be a great reluctance to do this until margins are sizable and healthy,'' said Joel Popkin, president of Popkin & Company, an economic consulting firm. **********In some ways, business enters this recovery in better shape than after other recessions. But these are ways that act to curb prices.  In their scramble to stay alive, many companies achieved permanent productivity gains over the last two years. Workers, fearful of losing their jobs, have reduced wage expectations from double- to single-digit levels. These trends have reduced the break-even point in many companies, making it easier to maintain margins without increasing prices. **********''During this recession, many businesses, probably most, have trimmed their fixed costs quite effectively,'' said Hugo Uyterhoeven, the Timken professor of business administration at Harvard Business School. ''They can spread their fixed costs over a larger volume during the recovery and increase their profitability without price increases.'' Productivity - output per man-hour has moved up as the recession forced business to cut overhead costs and squeeze production efficiencies.  Productivity rose 3.5 percent in the third quarter of 1982 and 2 percent in the fourth quarter, the Federal Government reports. Rising productivity represents a reduction in operating costs and acts to offset the impact of any wage increases. ''These efficiencies are a real fact of life,'' said Albert Matamoros, chief economist at Armstrong World Industries Inc., ''They will lessen the pressure for price increases and have a salutary effect on the bottom line.'' **********DESPITE these breaks, businesses, especially those in hard hit industries, still hunger for price increases. But, some say the only improvement in their profit margins may well come from cost reductions instead. Take steel, an industry currently operating at about half capacity. ''It's going to be difficult for us to get the price increases in the future that the industry could in the past,'' said Carl R. Fiora, president of the eastern steel division of Armco Inc.. ''Autos use less steel and our markets have shrunk. Couple that with all the capacity and it will make it difficult to obtain price increases. To stay in steel, we're going to have to look at costs, not prices.'' **********So far, the industry has been unsuccessful in getting its customers to accept their annouced 6 percent increase in the price of flat rolled steel, used in autos and appliances. ''We and our competition are having difficulty in the marketplace and it will take a while for that price increase to take effect,'' added Mr. Fiore. Given the prospect of ''wafer-thin to nonexistent margins'' in the steel business, Mr. Fiore said that any recovery means steel will ''come out of a depression and move into a recession.'' **********Clearly, hard pressed companies will push for price increases. ''A key factor is whether you look to increase prices in a recovery or keep them low to gain market share,'' said Mr. Popkin. ''I think that because of the pounding these industries took and the fact they they have now reduced their break-even point tremendously means that they will try to raise their prices and not be too concerned about market share.'' **********While they undoubtedly will get some price increases, whether they will get them in sufficient amounts is another matter. Walter K.  Joelson, chief economist for General Electric, predicts that companies will try to raise prices as much as they can but that their ability to do so is limited. ''It will dawn on all key actors that unless they raise their prices, all will go broke,'' said Mr.  Joelson. ''So many raw-material producers have been consistently losing that they have to do something. ''But people won't be able to raise prices that much,'' he added. **********There is some sign of movement on prices. The Producer Price Index, which measures price levels of food, capital equipment, consumer durables and gas and heating oil, increased 2.1 percent between January 1982 and January 1983. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 13 raw industrial commodities, which reflects spot prices, increased 9 percent between the end of December and the end of February. Copper prices have moved from a low of 68 cents a pound to around 84 cents, aluminum ingots have moved from a low of around 50 cent to about 62 cents, and the prices of linerboard, used in the making of corrugated containers, have moved up about 8 percent. **********The ability, however, to raise prices varies with the industry.  Peter J. McLaughlin, chief executive of the Union Camp Corporation, a paper manufacturer, believes that the $20 a ton increase in linerboard prices that the industry has announced will stick.  ''Business is improving and the increase looks good,'' he said.  Linerboard, which had been selling at $300 a ton in January 1981 has fallen steadily and is now priced at about $250 a ton. **********In the service sector, Sanford Weill, president of the American Express Company, which has the Fireman's Fund insurance subsidiary, predicts that insurance premiums will probably rise as interest rates push down the returns that casualty companies can expect on their investments. In the travel and entertainment card and traveler's check business, Mr. Weill anticipates no price increases, although he expects that increased volume will favorably affect these businesses. **********CONVERSELY, at Alcoa, Ronald R. Hoffman, vice president of flat rolled products, said his company anticipates little price relief through the first half of 1983. He said that aluminum orders have picked up, but it is difficult to determine whether this is a real turnaround or simply hedge buying by customers worried over upcoming industrywide wage negotiations. Also, increasing competition from European and Japanese aluminum makers - who were not in the market following the 1974-75 recession - promise to keep a lid on future prices. **********The effect of rapidly falling oil prices, on its face an antiinflation force, is still uncertain. ''It's hardly something we can count on just yet,'' said Harold E. May, a vice president on the corporate staff at Du Pont, which bases about 70 percent of its chemical business on hydrocarbons. ''Our suppliers have been screaming that their backs are to the wall and even if oil prices fall we shouldn't look for lower prices.'' **********WITHOUT price inflation, corporate profit margins may still not reach pre-recession levels and will probably remain lower than in past recoveries. **********''Proft margins should be a heck of a lot better, but they still won't get back to where they were in the 1978-79 period,'' said Mr.  Matamoros. Added G.E.'s Mr. Joelson: ''I have a suspicion that while 1983 will look good in comparison to a stagnant 1982, you will still have a poor recovery of corporate profits. Even a 20 percent increase leaves profits that are poor compared to corporate requirements and to what corporations enjoyed in the past.'' **********The long-run danger in marginal corporate profits is that business will be reluctant, or unable, to make the long-term investment in capital equipment that is needed if the recovery is to be sustained.  ''There's a limit on how fast you can improve productivity after the first blush of the recession is over,'' added Mr. Joelson. ''And you need capital spending for sustained productivity increases. Many companies would be happy to increase capital outlays. But they just don't hve the funds or the profits.'' **********Mr. Greenspan warns that corporations are faced with a ''peculiar problem'' because of continued high long-term interest rates. The financial markets are expressing uncertainty over whether inflation has truly been contained and this has resulted in capital costs that are still too high for sustained reinvestment. **********''There is a deep-seated ambiguity in the marketplace on inflation,'' said Mr. Greenspan. ''Some of the markets believe the downturn in interest rates is a short-term phenomenon to be reversed in two years. There is still a high inflation premium on long-term rates. The markets are not favorable to capital investment and that's the major problem with respect to recovery in this cycle. **********''In the short run, the recovery will be a lot more formidable than a lot are expecting. But, because of long-term inflation expectations, long-term rates won't come down enough to keep up that kind of pace.'' COPPER PRODUCERS SEE A BETTER DAWN **********The long night for copper producers may be coming to an end. But, while copper prices have already increased 40 percent from their lows of last year, they are still below break-even levels for many American producers. Copper is currently priced in the spot market at just above 70 cents a pound, while the average domestic production costs are around 90 cents to $1.00 a pound. **********Copper, used in construction, autos and consumer goods, was hard hit during the recession, and the recent run-up in price reflects the expectation of a turnaround in these industries. ''Whether this continues depends on the economic follow through,'' said R. Douglas Moffat, a metals analyst with the First Manhattan Company. ''This should take a lot of pressure off a lot of companies that have been not so slowly bleeding to death.'' **********It hasn't only been companies. In Arizona, the nation's largest copper producer, continuing waves of layoffs during the recession furloughed about 12,000 of that state's 26,000 copper workers.  American producers are currently operating at about 65 percent capacity, with many mines still closed and virtually no money going into capital reinvestement. **********Domestic copper producers have suffered at the hands of foreign competitors over the last two years. American producers are penalized by high labor and production costs and, because our reserves have been mined longer than in other countries, by a lower grade ore.  Competition comes mainly from third world countries - Chile, Zaire, Zambia and Peru - whose Government-owned mines were kept running at full capacity while domestic mines were closed. **********The main force setting spot copper prices is the commodity markets in New York and London, which are heavily influenced by speculators.  And, for companies, this is a frustration. ''Copper prices don't always run with the economy, but according to people's future expectations,'' said Harry B. Carson, president of the copper division at Amax Inc. ''Prices in the short run are controlled by speculators and not by utilization or by the industry itself. In the equation of copper, costs really don't affect the price.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/05/busin.body_text: **********Edmund W. Littlefield, a former chairman and chief executive officer of Utah International Inc., the giant mining concern based in San Francisco, has been named a senior adviser at Dillon, Read & Company, the New York-based investment banking house announced. **********Under the terms of the appointment, which is effective immediately, Mr. Littlefield will provide Dillon, Read with advice on its capital formation activities. **********''I don't pretend to be an investment banker,'' he said in a telephone interview from his office in San Francisco. ''But Dillon, Read was interested in getting someone who had broader management experience to provide advice in venture capital and leveraged buyout situations where a company might want to raise capital.'' **********Mr. Littlefield, 69, seems well qualified for his new job. He was at the helm of Utah International in 1976 when the General Electric Company purchased it for $2.17 billion, then the largest corporate acquisition in American history. **********Seven years later, Mr. Littlefield, who is currently chairman of the company's executive committee, a member of its board and a member of the board of directors of General Electric, found himself involved in selling Utah International again. **********Last January, Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Australia's giant steel and natural resources company, agreed to purchase Utah International for $2.4 billion in cash. The deal is expected to be completed later this year. **********In addition to his directorship at General Electric, Mr. Littlefield sits on the boards of Federated Department Stores, the Southern Pacific Company, the Industrial Indemnity Company and the Wells Fargo Corporation, holding company for the Wells Fargo Bank. **********But it may have been his connections with the Bechtel Corporation that led him to Dillon, Read. Bechtel, the privately held construction company, is the largest shareholder in Dillon, Read. **********Mr. Littlefield is on the senior advisory board to the Bechtel Group, a four-man committee that also includes Irving Shapiro, former chairman of the Du Pont Company; Frank Cary, former chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, and Harold J. Hays, former chairman of Standard Oil of California. **********''My association with Bechtel explains in part the decision to join up with Dillon, Read,'' Mr. Littlefield said.

The spokesman was identified as Baruch Marzel. **********A second militant arrested was identified as Rabbi Israel Ariel, a leader of the violent protests against Israel's return of Sinai to Egypt last year. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/busin.main_headline: ADMIRED AND DERIDED, AGEE SURGED TO THE TOP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/busin.print_headline: ADMIRED AND DERIDED, AGEE SURGED TO THE TOP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/09/busin.body_text: **********For most of his fast-paced career, William M. Agee has been perceived as a gambler, a man who enjoyed taking a flier and usually won. But the 45-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Bendix Corporation pushed his luck hard when he tried to acquire Martin Marietta last summer, and yesterday, in resigning from the presidency of the Allied Corporation, Bill Agee cashed in his chips. **********It was the denouement of the ambitious takeover campaign led by Mr. Agee last summer, a complex four-way corporate war that ultimately concluded with Allied's acquisition of Bendix. It was also, at least temporarily, the halt of a career that the business community, Wall Street and the public had come to follow with admiration or derision, but always with keen interest. **********The best-known aspect of that career was his relationship with Mary E. Cunningham, who resigned from Bendix in 1980 amid speculation of a romantic involvement with her boss, and whom Mr. Agee married last year. Beyond that, Mr. Agee had also alienated some of Bendix's senior directors, and had been attacked by businessmen and financial analysts for his short-term, ruthless management style. For a time, however, the blame was outweighed by the praise for Mr. Agee's transformation of Bendix from a humdrum auto components manufacturer to a company with a foothold in the new technologies. **********Some of the criticism undoubtedly stemmed from envy of Mr. Agee's rapid corporate rise. Born in Boise, Idaho, he joined the Boise Cascade Corporation in 1963, a newly minted Harvard M.B.A., and was senior vice president by 1971. At the age of 36, he was recruited by W. Michael Blumenthal, then chairman and chief executive of Bendix, to be executive vice president and chief financial officer. **********When Mr. Blumenthal was named Treasury Secretary by President Carter in 1977, Mr. Agee took over. But when Mr. Blumenthal left the Carter Administration in 1979, Mr. Agee did not invite him to rejoin the Bendix board - an omission that reportedly irritated the older man, now chief executive of the Burroughs Corporation. In 1981, three directors who served on both the Bendix and the Burroughs boards resigned from Bendix, while a fourth left Burroughs - in effect, severing the longtime ties between the Detroit-area companies. Reconstructed Chairman's Role **********As Bendix's chief executive, Mr. Agee reconstructed the office of chairman, delegating the day-to-day decisions to others while he concentrated on acquisitions and strategy issues. **********He shifted Bendix's emphasis from automotive parts to advanced production machinery, strenthening its aerospace and electronics businesses. He acquired a stake in Asarco Inc., a major metals producer, just as metal prices were bottoming out, then sold out at the right time. He also sold Bendix's sizable forest products operations. The divestitures gave Bendix a fund of more than $500 million that Mr. Agee, until a better investment came along, invested in high-yielding money market securities. **********Mr. Agee's actions generally drew praise on Wall Street, which admired the timing of his divestitures and admired the company's bottom line. Not everyone applauded his approach, however. Lee A.  Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, complained that Mr.  Agee, by celebrating short-term returns, cast aspersions on the business of manufacturing. **********It was thought to be only a matter of time, however, until Mr.  Agee unloaded his cash for a major acquisition. Bendix's disclosure last March that it had bought 7 percent of the RCA Corporation's stock touched off speculation that Mr. Agee would make a bid for the rest of the company. Whether that was Mr. Agee's intention is unclear, because RCA immediately mounted a strong defense; it remarked pointedly that Mr. Agee had ''not demonstrated the ability to manage his own affairs, let alone someone else's.'' Romantic Involvement Criticized **********The RCA comment was a none-too-thinly veiled reference to Mr.  Agee's relationship with Mary Cunningham, the 29-year old Harvard M.B.A. who in a brief time at Bendix had risen quickly to be vice president of strategic planning. In an attempt to quash gossip that a romantic involvement had led to Miss Cunningham's promotion, Mr. Agee had denied the rumors at a meeting of 600 employees - a head-on confrontation that only heightened the talk and, two weeks later, led Miss Cunningham to resign. **********Mr. Agee and Miss Cunningham, now a vice president at Joseph E.  Seagram & Sons, were married last year, but the relationship continued to attract attention. Bendix's bid for Marietta was reportedly conceived by the couple, and Miss Cunningham's presence during some of the negotiations - in what came to be described as ''the Bill and Mary show'' - amazed and angered a number of the participants. **********To the end, Mr. Agee continued to defend his bid for Marietta. But to outsiders who knew Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the Allied chairman, it seemed likely that his career at Allied would be short-lived. Mr.  Agee may have been thinking that, too, when he and Miss Cunningham gave an interview to Fortune magazine last October. In a mellow mood, the pair disclosed their ''dream'': a little company called Semper (Latin for always), incorporated in Delaware and with a broad charter to do consulting or supply venture capital or anything that would allow them to work together. Miss Cunningham ''heads it up,'' Mr. Agee said. ''I'm the second principal officer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/28/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; 2 Key Subjects At Roundtable
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/28/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; 2 Key Subjects At Roundtable
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/28/busin.body_text: **********THE Business Roundtable, the lobbying organization made up of the chief executives of 200 of the country's biggest corporations, will consider urging that President Reagan soften his positions on two issues to which he has been most committed - tax indexation and military spending. The businessmen fear that the vast Treasury borrowing necessary to finance the budget deficit will squeeze them out of the credit markets just as the economy is beginning to revive. **********Both subjects will be on the agenda when the Roundtable's 45-member policy committee meets Tuesday in New York.  On indexation, committee members endorse the principle of denying the Treasury the tax windfall it gets when inflation forces taxpayers into higher brackets. Since seeing the President's $200 billion deficit projection in the budget for the fiscal year 1984, however, the committee will consider proposing that the President postpone the Jan. 1, 1985, date when indexation is scheduled to take effect. The committee will also consider proposing a trigger - maybe inflation of 3 or 4 percent - before indexation would be allowed. **********Many members of the Roundtable, including some military contractors, also feel that the President's scheduled increase in military spending should be scaled down. So far, the policy committee has been unable to reach a consensus on taking a strong antimilitary position, but the growth of the deficit appears to have alarmed the members. **********If the Roundtable does agree to ask for restraints in military spending, it is unlikely to specify which programs need scrutiny on the ground that only the Pentagon has enough information to make such choices. The policy committee's decision is binding on the full membership of the Roundtable, but it might not be announced for a week or two. Money Market Accounts **********Federal banking regulators, having recently authorized banks and savings institutions to offer individuals insured accounts to compete with money market mutual funds, will meet Tuesday to consider opening the accounts to corporate customers, too. **********Analysts say it seems unlikely that the regulators will let the corporations in. For one thing, lobbyists for the banks oppose such a move, as shown by comments submitted to the Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee. This is the panel of Federal banking regulators who will be voting on the matter. **********Just as important, says Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, ''there has been no pressure from the corporate sector for this kind of action.'' Mr. Martin emphasized that he was speaking only for himself and not for Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, who will be voting on the proposal as a member of the committee. Money for the S.E.C. **********Earlier this month, during House hearings on the Securities and Exchange Commission's budget request, several Congressmen suggested to John S.R. Shad, the S.E.C. chairman, that he was perhaps being a bit too amenable to cutbacks recommended by David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget. **********Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat and subcommittee chairman, remarked wryly that the ''chairman in the sky,'' John D. Dingell, might have some additional comments about Mr. Shad's budget request. **********Representative Dingell, chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, has now spoken, and he does not seem too pleased about the S.E.C.'s presentation. In a letter to Mr. Shad, the Michigan Democrat wrote: ''I will vigorously oppose any cuts in your budget and, for a number of reasons, I must particularly oppose staff reductions in those divisions responsible for enforcement and review of disclosure documents sent to investors.'' **********Mr Dingell continued, ''The current recession provides ample opportunities for fraud and other serious abuses.'' He said this was not the time for such cutbacks in a ''chronically underfinanced'' agency. Experts on Tender Offers **********An industry panel to recommend changes in Federal rules on tender offers will be announced today by the S.E.C. Among the 15 members expected to be named are two of Wall Street's leading merger lawyers: Joseph Flom of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom and Martin Lipton of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. Brock and His Aides **********Congress recently authorized Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, to have a third deputy, based in Washington. Mr.  Brock has hired, subject to White House clearance and Senate confirmation, Robert E. Lighthizer, the former Covington & Burling lawyer who is chief counsel of the Senate Finance Committee. Mr.  Brock's Geneva deputy, Michael B. Smith, will move into the other Washington slot. The new deputy in Geneva is expected to be Peter Murphy, who has been chief textile negotiator. Moving up to run the Finance Committee staff will be Rod A. DeArment, who has been deputy chief and who was also at Covington & Burling.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/04/busin.body_text: **********One of the Baldwin-United Corporation's major creditor banks said yesterday that Baldwin was in default on the payment of part of $100 million worth of debentures. **********The debentures are held by the First National Bank of Chicago, and the $100 million they represent were not included in a standstill agreement that Baldwin negotiated in April with its creditors. Under that agreement, payment of $630 million of Baldwin's $900 million in short-term debt was postponed for 93 days, until July 10, so that Baldwin, a conglomerate made up principally of insurance subsidiaries, could seek ways to raise money. **********In a statement, First Chicago said that Baldwin's failure to make payment on a debenture tendered on May 27 ''triggered a right by the trustee to accelerate the maturity of all remaining debentures under the indenture.'' Validity to Be Contested **********In Cincinnati, Baldwin said it would contest the validity of the notice it received from First Chicago, asserting that the notice is not authorized by the agreement covering the debentures. **********First Chicago did not announce the amount of the debentures on which it sought payment yesterday. But banking sources said the amount in question was less than $2 million of the total of $100 million. First Chicago assumed trusteeship of the debentures two years ago, when Baldwin incurred the debt. **********Bankers involved in the 93-day moratorium agreement, which has given Baldwin breathing time on debt payments, expressed surprise at First Chicago's decision, given that Baldwin's financial problems are complex and that its new management team, installed three weeks ago, is still not wholly familiar with the company's problems. **********''We were surprised that this problem, which is a serious matter, surfaced at this time,'' one banker said. ''This is another $100 million in debt that has to be addressed. We knew it was out there, but we didn't think it would be called now.'' President Was Replaced **********Last month Baldwin's president, Morley P. Thompson, was replaced by Victor Palmieri, whose company, Palmieri & Company, specializes in reviving ailing concerns. A number of Mr. Palmieri's colleagues joined the upper echelons of Baldwin's management, and the company retained Mr. Palmieri's company as a financial adviser. **********First Chicago's action took place a day after a key Baldwin subsidiary, the MGIC Investment Corporation, reported sharply lower operating earnings in the first quarter. Next week, Mr. Palmieri and other Baldwin executives are scheduled to meet with the two bank groups that hold the $900 million of short-term debt. **********At that meeting, which will also be attended by insurance commissioners from a number of states where Baldwin policies are sold, Mr. Palmieri is expected to outline possible solutions to the company's financial crisis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/world.main_headline: 6 OPEC NATIONS AGREE TO REDUCE THEIR OIL PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/world.print_headline: 6 OPEC NATIONS AGREE TO REDUCE THEIR OIL PRICES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/world.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia said today that it and five other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to a reduction in the price of Saudi Light crude, which determines the price that other OPEC members charge for their oil. **********The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, warned the other seven members of OPEC that if they did not accept the planned price cut -believed to be $4 a barrel - the six stood ready to slash prices further. **********If the OPEC nations, which produce about a third of the world's oil, fail to coordinate their prices, recent reductions by Britain, Norway and Nigeria could set off a price war, aggravating economic uncertainty and jeopardizing bank loans to the poorer oil exporters. **********There were indications that those risks could lead non-OPEC members to join any move by the 13 nations to stabilize world oil prices.  Although Sheik Yamani refused to put a figure on the price cut, it was reported in industry circles here that the major Persian Gulf producers would agree on a new basic price of about $30 a barrel for Saudi Light, down from the current $34. **********Sheik Yamani was speaking in Riyadh after two days of talks in the Saudi Arabian capital with the oil ministers of Kuwait, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Iraq. He said Indonesia had been consulted about the plan and supported it. **********Oil ministers from Venezuela and Libya are expected in Riyadh on Thursday.  Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister from the Emirates, said the six OPEC members involved in the Riyadh consultations would ask for a full meeting of the group in Vienna or Geneva next week to discuss the price proposals. **********He also said ''coordination'' talks would be opened with the North Sea oil producers and Mexico, which are not OPEC members, the Emirates news agency reported. He was quoted as saying that there were ''encouraging indications favoring the creation of some kind of definitive coordination between producers within and without OPEC.'' Talks in London **********Indeed Venezuela, which has long tried to be a mediating presence within OPEC, has already begun such consultations. Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines, Humberto Calderon Berti, was traveling to London after meetings with Government officials in Mexico. And officials of the British Government and the British National Oil Corporation also said meetings might take place Thursday. **********(A spokesman in London for a major British oil company called such efforts unique, saying that they reflected the fact that, ''individually, companies and groupings may be unable to prevent what could be a considerable slide in oil prices.'' (''International coordination may be the only answer left,'' this official added. (A Mexican oil delegation was also on the move, with consultations scheduled in Paris Thursday with representatives from oil-producing countries, a spokesman for the state oil company said in Mexico City.) **********Saudi Arabia called the Riyadh meeting after Nigeria broke ranks with the rest of OPEC last Saturday and cut its basic oil price by $5.50 a barrel, to $30, and threatened further reductions if any other producer tried to undersell its oil. Nigeria made its move after two non-OPEC producers, Britain and Norway, cut the cost of their North Sea oil to $30.50 a barrel. **********The Persian Gulf countries, industry sources here say, are trying to head off the danger of a downward price spiral by persuading the rest of OPEC to agree on lower prices and to defend them by accepting output quotas. ''If the others don't accept this, the Gulf will have to cut by more than intended,'' Sheik Otaiba said. **********Sheik Yamani also hinted that the six were ready to take a tough stand with other OPEC countries if they did not agree to exercise greater discipline, saying that the exact size of the proposed cut for Saudi Light ''depends on circumstances.'' **********Oil experts say the Persian Gulf states would ''win'' any price war because their large reserves of oil and money and their tiny populations meant they could always afford to undersell OPEC's poorer and more populous members. Reasserting Role **********As world oil demand has slumped, several OPEC countries have been producing more than the market could absorb and giving buyers discounts in a bid to increase their share of the world market. **********Continuing disagreement over pricing and overall production led to the breakdown of last month's OPEC meeting in Geneva. Iran, Algeria and Libya called on Saudi Arabia and the other Persian Gulf states to reduce their own production instead, and Nigeria refused to reinstitute the $3-a-barrel premium its oil traditionally earned over the Saudi Light marker price because of its superior quality and proximity to Western markets. ---- Latin American Pact **********QUITO, Ecuador, Feb. 23 (Reuters) - Ecuador has joined Venezuela and Mexico in an agreement to avoid competitive price cuts, sources at Ecuador's oil ministry said today. **********They said the oil minister, Gustavo Galindo, had arranged Ecuador's strategy with Venezuela and Mexico, which is not in OPEC, over the telephone when Mr. Calderon Berti, the Venezuelan minister, was in Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/01/world.body_text: **********It's been a century and a half since the world's first public passenger rail service was introduced on 38 miles of track between Stockton and Darlington. These days, the British rail system has 11,000 miles of track, but it also has mounting deficits, labor disputes, worsening service and shaky revenues. **********Another in a series of reports on the declining state of its finances set off some grumbling recently and has been seized upon by the Labor opposition as an issue to be kept alive as Britain heads for a national election some time this year or early in 1984. **********The report, produced by a committee headed by Sir David Serpell, was commissioned last year by the Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to find ways to reduce the nationalized rail system's annual subsidy of about $1.2 billion a year. **********One of several recommendations says a drastic reduction in passenger service could turn British Rail into a streamlined system capable of turning a profit of about $50 million a year instead of running in the red year after year. **********To achieve this goal it would require reducing the rail lines from the existing 11,000 miles to 1,600 miles. Such a step would sever rail service in Scotland north of Glasgow and Edinburgh and eliminate most branch lines outside of London and the corridors to Liverpool and Newcastle. **********While this was the most extreme of several possible reductions in service considered by the report, it was the one seized by Labor as evidence to support its charge that Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Government was ignoring the social consequences of its push to restore to the private sector services that were nationalized under postwar Labor leadership. **********It is not thought likely that the Thatcher Government will undertake a major reduction of the rail system before an election.  Yet it appears inevitable that the provincial branch lines will face some pruning, since their operation accounts for more than half of the entire system's losses. **********In the far reaches of Scotland and Wales, where decisions reached in London are usually received with scorn and suspicion, there is growing concern that the branch lines are safe only until the election. **********''It is not only the 30,000 railway jobs in Scotland which must be defended,'' Andrew Barr, Scottish divisional officer of the National Union of Railwaymen, said in commenting on the Serpell report, ''but any hope of an industrial regeneration in Scotland is dependent on us having an efficient and substantial rail service.'' **********In Inverness concern has been expressed over how a remote and rugged region like the Scottish Highlands could survive without trains. **********On the branch line to Kyle of Lochalsh one day in January, an electronics salesman from Manchester named Barry Jenkins said his territory would shrink considerably without train service in Scotland. **********''It's impossible in a practical sense to depend on driving by car in the winter around here,'' he said, nodding in the direction of snow-powdered crags that the train was passing. ''Without trains, the people themselves will have to step back a century to when the hill folk were isolated.'' **********The dangers of driving in the Highlands, as in Wales, in the winter are well known. The roads are narrow and the hills are steep. Every so often someone gets caught in a sudden storm and freezes to death. **********Construction of better roads, argues David Martin, community development officer with the Scottish Council of Social Service, will be more expensive than continued subsidies for the branch lines, in addition to making additional demands on the environment. **********The real problem, he says, is that, because the country cannot decide if public transportation is a business or a public service, the resulting confusion has ''done much to fudge the issue for investment in this sector.'' **********The real problem, he says, is that, because the country cannot

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/22/busin.body_text: **********In 1950, Eiji Toyoda decided that if Japan was to have an automobile industry, his company had better learn how to make them properly. To do that, he naturally went to the United States, where he spent a month or so touring American auto plants, observing the latest machines and manufacturing methods in action, taking notes all the while. **********Last week, Mr. Toyoda, the 69-year-old chairman of the Toyota Motor Corporation, was back in America to sign a joint-venture agreement with the General Motors Corporation to make small cars in California for which the Japanese company will supply the design, engine, transmission, manufacturing expertise and chief executive. **********As the 50-50 venture with G.M. indicates, Mr. Toyoda learned his car-making lessons well in the United States three decades ago - all to well, Detroit executives must think. Various studies have estimated that Toyota can produce and ship a small car to America for between $ 1,500 to $2,000 less than detroit can make a comparable model. **********Mr. Toyoda, a graduate of Tokyo University's department of mechanical engineering, has been responsible for much of the considerable emphasis placed on manufacturing efficiency at Toyota.  Mr. Toyoda, the newphew of the founder of the Toyota Group, Sakichi Toyoda, joined the Toyoda Automatic Loom Works Company in 1936 after graduating from college. But he was transferred to the car-making company a year later, when it was founded, and the letter d in the family name was changed to t in the corporate named because it sounded better for a consumer product, they decided. **********Toyota is known as a very traditional Japanese concern, and its success lies mostly in attention to detail and doing a myriad of little things correctly, both on the manufacturing and marketing sides of the business. **********Mr. Toyoda sets the corporate tone. ''He's known for being very conservative,'' said Peter G. Wolff an analyst for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Ltd. in Tokyo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/31/world.print_headline: SUPPORT FOR POLISH AUSTERITY PLAN IS SOUGHT AT RALLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/31/world.body_text: **********Poland's rulers called more than 2,000 workers and Communist Party activists to a rally today aimed at mustering support for the new three-year austerity plan. **********It appeared to be a difficult task, since the plan, presented to Parliament last week, calls for hard work and a reduction of waste to make up for a shortage of labor and raw materials. **********''This meeting should find a lasting place in our history,'' Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said at the rally in the Palace of Culture and Science. ''Our road is bumpy. There are bitter thoughts and hard talk.'' **********The authorities concede that they have few consumer goods to offer as an incentive for more work. Another problem is that the work force remains embittered by the outlawing of the independent trade union Solidarity. **********In the view of Western economic analysts, the three-year plan appears likely to make matters worse. It includes new tax measures that may discourage private enterprise, particularly among private farmers, who grow more than three-quarters of the food. **********Today's meeting came as a part of a publicity campaign on behalf of the new plan. The controlled press has been describing the rally as a historic gathering of ''activist workers.'' **********Western reporters were barred. A Government press official said later that the rally was a closed meeting called by the party's Central Committee and and would be adequately reported by press and television. **********Scores of dusty buses with license plates from all over Poland were parked outside. A half dozen police trucks and a radio-equipped mobile command truck stood nearby. **********The Polish press agency said half of the 2,300 worker representatives at the rally were not party members. The agency said innovators of solutions to production problems, foremen, executives and most members of the Polish leadership were present. **********Among the leaders, Kazimierz Barcikowski, a senior Politburo member, and Zbigniew Szalajda, a Deputy Prime Minister, delivered speeches exhorting workers to support the plan. **********''These measures will not be popular, but they are indispensible,'' Mr. Barcikowski said.  Press editorials called for support. But a commentary in the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita noted: ''It is not a pleasant task for a journalist to try and explain to his readers that they will have to pay for getting the country out of the crisis with a reduction of their own living standards.'' **********Meanwhile, one of the figures of the early days of Solidarity, Anna Walentynowicz, received a suspended 15-month sentence - in effect a three-year probation - on charges of attempting to organize strikes under martial law. Mrs. Walentynowicz is the crane operator whose dismissal sparked the Gdansk shipyard strike of 1980 that preceded the formation of the union. **********The prosecution at the trial in the northern town of Grudziadz had asked for a three-year sentence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The United States Attorney's Office yesterday turned over to a Federal court 12 hours of what it termed potentially ''embarrassing'' videotapes that are said to show Japanese businessmen trying to buy trade secrets belonging to I.B.M. **********The tapes had been prepared for the industrial espionage trial of the sole remaining defendant in a case involving Hitachi Ltd. of Japan and the International Business Machines Corporation. **********Thomas Mangen, an attorney representing the defendant, Tom Yoshida, told United States District Judge Spencer Williams in San Jose on Monday that his client was prepared to go to trial May 16 and would not plead guilty. **********The decision surprised prosecutors, who believed that Mr. Yoshida would plead guilty to prevent disclosure of the tapes, taken by F.B.I. agents. **********Mr. Yoshida, president of NCL Data of Santa Clara, Calif., was indicted with Hitachi and 13 others last June 30. They were charged with conspiracy to transport stolen computer secrets from the United States to Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/busin.main_headline: TACTICS OF A MAVERICK MONEY MANAGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; TACTICS OF A MAVERICK MONEY MANAGER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/busin.body_text: **********SHORTLY after the start of stock market **********trading last Monday, pension fund manager **********Robert Torray bet his head trader $5 that the Dow Jones industrial average would close with a loss for the day. A tough wager to win, considering that the bulls already were roaring and that the Dow was up nearly 20 points at the time. **********Mr. Torray is used to betting against the crowd, though. He is continually doing so with the $2 billion in assets - $1.6 billion of which is for equity- oriented accounts - that he manages for 30 corporate, union and municipal pension funds at his firm, Torray & Clark, in Bethesda, Md., just outside Washington. And, more often than not, he is right, as was the case last Monday when the rally evaporated and the Dow fell almost 11 points. **********By sticking to a contrarian investment philosophy that eschews what is in vogue, Torray & Clark has earned the reputation of being one of the savviest investment management firms around and one of the most courageous. Its current investment stance, for instance, clearly sets it apart. **********At a time when most money managers are close to fully invested as they eagerly await the second stage of the bull market, Torray & Clark has about half of its equity portfolio parked in cash investments. It's been that way now for more than six months. And Mr. Torray vows it will stay that way until he sees much of the speculative fever wrung out of the market. ''I just don't think it's worth the risk to confirm the popular view that the market is going to 1,500 or 2,000,'' he said. **********Swimming against the investment tide has paid off for the 46-year-old Mr. Torray, who set up Torray & Clark near his home in Chevy Chase in the early 1970's with David Clark, now 41 years old, a fellow refugee from the money management arm of a brokerage firm. The company's overall performance for its stock and bond portfolios is one of the best among pension fund managers: Its average gain of 15.8 percent a year for the 10 years ending December 1982 far outpaced the Standard & Poor's 500 index average of 6.7 percent and the Salomon Brothers high-grade corporate bond index return of 6.1 percent for the same period. In this year's first half, Torray & Clark outperformed the S.& P. despite its limited commitment to equities. **********Among the big Wall Street trading houses, Torray & Clark is known as one of the few firms that will buy giant blocks of stock when everyone else is selling and will sell when everyone else is buying. Throughout the darkest days of the 1982 bear market, Torray & Clark frequently was one of the only bidders for large blocks of stock. **********One of its biggest positions was in the beleaguered savings and loan group, where it bought between one and three million shares of a number of stocks such as H.F. Ahmanson and Great Western Financial. It has reduced those positions, including a three-million-share block of Fannie Mae and a block of one and a half million shares of Gibraltor Savings of Texas, for a profit of more than $40 million to investors, says Mr. Torray. **********Mr. Torray makes no pretense at being able to pick the bottom or the top of the market. Describing an investment style that would terrify most money managers, Mr. Torray says matter-of- factly that ''on balance, most of the stocks we buy go down after an initial purchase, sometimes as much as 50 percent. So we continue to buy them.'' **********The key, he points out, is that the firm is ''extremely patient.'' Out of about 300 stock positions held since 1971, only 16 have been closed out at a loss. And even the losses were minor, he says. **********Like any other investor, Mr. Torray looks for stocks that he thinks are undervalued. But in his case, the stocks have been pounded down, are selling well below their book value per share and usually have a high yield. A typical candidate is a company with depressed earnings, operating below its potential in an essential industry. After screening out possible bankruptcy situations, Mr. Torray takes his plunge because these kinds of companies, he says, always bounce back. ''Either management takes action, the economy turns around, the company is taken over, or new management is put in place,'' he says. **********The trouble with the investment business in general, says Mr. Torray, is that ''everyone is looking for the big winners and wants short-term results. If the information suggests that the outlook is bright and that the present is favorable, they don't realize that all this is already reflected in the share price.'' **********Mr. Torray also faults Wall Street for becoming too mired in detail. ''I personally think investing is a very simple business. With a little common sense and patience anyone can do well at it. Most people make it too difficult and out think themselves.'' Indeed, Mr. Torray appears to rely more on his own experience and gut feeling when buying and selling stocks. Mr. Torray, whose official title is president and chairman, spends a good deal of time traveling in the firm's corporate jet and limousine to quarterly meetings with clients. Mr. Clark, on the other hand, is an analyst by background and is more the expert on the nitty- gritty details of the stocks the firm owns. He is executive vice president and shares responsibility for investment decisions with Mr. Torray. **********THE firm's current holdings of $800 million in stocks are concentrated in only 28 positions, many of which make Torray & Clark the largest shareholder. It holds over two million shares each of three steel companies - Bethlehem, Republic and Armco - and giant blocks of a number of other heavy industrial companies, such as Clark Equipment, Cleveland Cliffs, Crown Zellerbach and International Paper. ''They're all dull, but they have a lot of earnings leverage,'' says Mr. Torray. Although he does not expect to sell any of his major holdings until there is a big surge in prices, he adds, ''I wouldn't buy any of these now at their current prices.'' **********If he is convinced that present holdings are no longer undervalued than why doesn't he sell them and go 100 percent in cash? Reponds Mr. Torray, ''Fifty percent in cash is pretty extraordinary to begin with. We could be wrong on a timing basis so we owe it to our clients to be hedged.'' **********Mr. Torray is convinced that sooner or later the market will fall out of bed. ''I've seen it happen before, regardless of all the talk now about the emergence of a new era. And how can you really argue that this time we are much better off?'' **********Nor does he buy the case for technology stocks. ''Year in and year out people have said about technology that it will save us and change the face of the earth,'' he said. ''That's nothing new. Sure there are a lot of good things out there. When you get a massive entry of interest, however, competition gets intense for the companies and investors bid up the stocks. It all gets to be ridiculous.'' **********The only thing that will bring Torray & Clark back in as a big buyer of stocks is for the market as a whole to drop below the 1,100 level on the Dow from today's 1,200 or so - with the type of washout that makes a number of industries and stocks begin selling as if the Dow fell from 1,200 to 700, says Mr. Torray. Until then, he said, ''Things have gone too far too fast. We are in one of those phases when people just want to speculate. It's best to just sit here and do what's right.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/03/busin.body_text: **********Howard A. Fine, who until last week was president of New York- based Norwegian American Cruises, has been named president and chief executive officer of Miami-based Costa Cruises Inc. **********Mr. Fine, who steps into a newly created post at Costa, had his former responsibilities sold out from under him. **********Norwegian American, a subsidiary of Leif Hoegh & Company of Norway, sold its two cruise vessels, the Sagafjord and Vistafjord, to Britain's Cunard Line for $73 million. **********Costa, a unit of Costa Amatori of Genoa, operates a fleet of nine cruise ships out of Miami. According to the 41-year-old Mr. Fine, the company stresses ''European service'' and the ''traditional'' type of vessel. New ships coming into service today are too ''plastic,'' he said. **********Mr. Fine, who says service has always been important to him, spent much of his career in the hotel industry. In 1971 he joined Britain's Trusthouse Forte Hotels, where he stayed for 10 years, rising to the post of president of its United States and Canadian marketing divisions. Before that, he worked for Sonesta International Hotels and British Railways. **********Mr. Fine said he would help Costa - which says it is the world's largest cruise line - develop a clear identity. He will also help it expand through acquisitions and improvement to its existing fleet, he said.Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/12/world.main_headline: A BLEAK LIFE GETS BLEAKER FOR SCOTTISH FISHERMEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/12/world.print_headline: A BLEAK LIFE GETS BLEAKER FOR SCOTTISH FISHERMEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/12/world.body_text: **********On the bad days, when the North Sea can suddenly boil up under a gale and throw a mountain of foaming water at a fishing boat, and a catch of whiting and haddock freezes to the pitching deck before it can be moved into a hold, the men of Pittenweem return early to port and brood about the future. **********It was never an easy life for those from the harbor villages along the north shore of the Firth of Forth who work the fishing boats.  Diesel engines, depth sounders and thermal underwear made it more efficient and warmer but the eternal problem of facing a hostile sea to hunt fish still tested the men in a way that machine operators in the Glasgow mills would never experience. **********The danger and the pride remain. But the rewards for Scottish fishermen seem to be slipping away. Herring has long been protected in the North Sea because of overfishing, and the furor with Iceland over cod fishing a decade ago closed the richest waters for cod. **********Then there appeared the more efficient foreign fleets operated not only by Northern Europeans but also by Russians, Americans, Japanese and Koreans. These fleets from distant places mainly prowl the richer ocean depths and banks. But a Scottish captain working out of Pittenweem can push his work boat to the Dogger Banks off the Northumberland and Yorkshire coasts and run into Bulgarian freezer ships loading up on mackerel and the purse nets of large Polish trawlers swallowing whole shoals of sprat in one gulp. Competition and Concessions **********For the Scottish fisherman, working a relatively small 50-foot trawler, the competition and the fishing concessions granted to Britain's trading partners when the country joined the European Economic Community in 1972 seemed as ruinous as today's cost of diesel fuel. **********A new Common Market fishing policy was to go into effect on Jan. 1. It was hoped that it would overcome many British objections and end nearly a decade of contention over the distribution of fishing rights in the North Sea. **********Denmark, however, refused to sign the agreement, and the other nine nations were left to enforce their own provisions, with Britain determined to keep the fishing boats of uninvited members outside its 12-mile territorial waters. **********Into this setting sailed Kent Kirk, a handsome and wealthy Dane who owns two large commercial fishing vessels and is a Conservative member of the European Parliament. With a retinue of 30 reporters accompanying him, Captain Kirk said he was challenging the British ban - defying his own Government's wishes in the process - by fishing for sprat inside the 12-mile limit. 'A Media Stunt' **********His own Minister of Fisheries called Captain Kirk's plan ''a media stunt,'' and expressed hope that ''sense will return after heads cool down.'' Along the quay at Pittenweem, harsher words were heard. **********Ken Brereton, the captain of the 50-foot stern trawler White Heather, reflected the general view along the Scottish coast by saying that Mr. Kirk was ''doing it for his own political future back in Denmark.'' **********''Denmark had no concessions inside British waters before Jan. 1 and they have none now,'' said Robert Allen of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation. ''Kirk wants to open an entire new ball game. He takes the view that as of Jan. 1 all bets are off. We take the view that after 10 years of participation in the E.E.C. there should be strong legislation to protect British fishing.'' **********''After all,'' Mr. Allen continued, ''Britain brought a huge chunk of water into the community and Denmark has gotten access to a large share of fish available in the community's fish pond.'' Modern Fishing Methods **********There is also a feeling here that the Danes, because of highly advanced methods, do not play fair in other ways.  ''Ninety percent of the Scottish inshore catch goes for human consumption,'' explained Andrew Wyse, a big fisherman with an openfaced smile and dark curly hair who is captain of the trawler Emulate. ''The Danes' whole economy is based on industrial fishing, turning the catch into fish meal to feed to livestock and to fatten their pigs for better bacon.'' **********But in one way, Mr. Wyse, 45 years old, strikes a tone much like that of the 34-year-old Dane who netted so much publicity this week by ignoring the fishing ban. In the old days, Captain Wyse said, when there were no restrictions other than a man's ability and the size of his boat, Scottish trawler fleets ranged far across the North Atlantic from Norway to Iceland to put cod onto British tables and into the hot frying oil of fish and chip shops. Now most of the cod is imported into Britain. **********The restrictions on cod fishing put the large trawler fleets out of business, and most of Scottish fishing is now in the hands of skipper-operators whose number is placed at about 1,700 fiercely independent survivors. 'All the Costs Went Up' **********''Even with the cod taken away from us things were going pretty well until three or four years ago when -Wham!'' He slammed a fist into a meaty palm for emphasis. ''All the costs went up.'' **********Moreover, he said, the dockside price of fish was stuck at 1979 levels despite the rising cost of everything else. ''Other European fleets have more efficient boats and use all kinds of dodges to push their fish in Britain and knock the cream off the top of our market with our own fish,'' he said, shaking his head with the irony of it all. **********''The common fisherman, in my view,'' Captain Brereton said earlier, ''would've been much better off if we'd never seen the Common Market.'' **********European influence has always been felt in Pittenweem, a port with trading activities dating back to the 12th century, and where Celtic history is scrawled in ancient caves along the coast where the round hills shoulder down to the water. The sloping roofs of the village at the waterfront are made of pantiles, slate-like rocks used centuries ago by Norwegian, Dutch and Danish trading ships as ballast, and left on the shore at Pittenweem when the vessels were filled with Scottish grain. **********The modern world intrudes on Pittenweem. It may come in the form of American tourists asking directions to the Royal and Ancient Golf Club at St. Andrews, 11 miles to the north, or in the dark shape of a British nuclear submarine knifing up the Firth to the naval base at Rosyth, or in the distant cooling tower of a nuclear power plant rising on the opposite shore. A few miles outside Pittenweem is the northeastern end of the band of electronics and microchip plants that extends southwest to Glasgow to form what the Scots delight in calling Silicon Glen, one of the few bright developments in an otherwise gloomy economic picture. More Chances Taken **********For the fishermen, however, there is no other path except the one leading out the mouth of the wide Firth and into the open sea.  ''The danger now is that more and more captains are feeling the pinch and taking their boats out in weather when they should stay in port,'' Captain Wyse said. ''They are taking chances now that they never took before.'' **********And the North Sea is a very unforgiving body of water.  Last week two Scottish fishermen were lost in a fierce sea, fishing not only in bad weather but also close to the holidays, when most boats stayed in port. **********For the moment, however, the greater fear is the day when, for reasons having nothing to do with the elements, the fleet from Pittenweem will stay in port and stop going to sea, and then men and their sons will have to look to Glasgow or beyond for their future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/world.main_headline: U.S. EXPERT'S VIEW: 'TOO MUCH BREAD, LITTLE WINE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/world.print_headline: U.S. EXPERT'S VIEW: 'TOO MUCH BREAD, LITTLE WINE'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/world.body_text: **********Gordon Craig, an American scholar who specializes in German history, said yesterday that he had seen excerpts from the first four installments of a coming series of articles in Stern, the Hamburg weekly, that are based on what the magazine says are newly discovered diaries kept by Hitler. **********Although he said that so far the material contained ''too much bread and little wine,'' Professor Craig, author of ''The Germans,'' said it was too early to determine whether the material would alter to any degree any well-documented facts about Hitler, the Third Reich or the conduct of World War II. **********He said a colleague, Professor Gerhard Weinberg of the University of North Carolina, went to Zurich last week as a consultant to Newsweek magazine with Maynard Parker, a Newsweek editor, to look at the actual diaries, which Stern is trying to sell for translation in the United States to American and other publications. Professor Weinberg, author of ''The Foreign Policy of Hitler's Germany,'' left on a flight to Germany yesterday and could not be reached for comment. **********Professor Craig, who is now teaching at Stanford but who was reached at a meeting of the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia, said he could not personally vouch for the authenticity of the diaries. But he said Hugh Trevor-Roper, who has the title Lord Dacre, the British historian and author of ''The Last Days of Hitler,'' saw the diaries and told German scholars that he ''stakes his reputation on their authenticity.'' **********The Times of London is to carry an article by Lord Dacre and include material similar to that in Stern, he said. The British historian was at the opera in London last night and could not be reached for comment. **********''Professor Weinberger told me he is also convinced that the diaries are authentic,'' Professor Craig said. ''There have been handwriting, ink and paper tests that hold up,'' he said. On the evidence so far, I have no reason to doubt the authenticity of the diaries. There are 55 notebooks, all in Hitler's handwriting, with every page signed by him.'' **********Some installments of the Stern material are said to contain only a small number of quotations from the diaries. The early sections of the Stern material discuss the flight of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy, to Britain and the evacuation of the British from Dunkirk, Professor Craig said. Later material, including anything relating to the Holocaust, has not yet been seen, he added. **********''Nothing in the citations documenting the diaries struck me as not being authentic,'' Professor Craig said. ''My assumption is that they are authentic. The question of whether there is sensational material remains to be seen. However, even if it contains the flattest stuff, the discovery of Hitler diaries would still be sensational for that reason alone.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Recuperation For the Dow
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Recuperation For the Dow
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/15/busin.body_text: **********THE stock market stuck its foot through a support level last Monday and then proceeded to repair the damage - at least for the time being. The Dow Jones industrial average was able to finish the week virtually without change. It closed at 1,182.83, down 0.46. **********Until Monday the industrial average had held firm at 1,180 in the face of repeated selling squalls since the middle of April. But the support gave way Monday when the Dow plunged 20.23 points, to 1,163.06. Rising interest rates caused the crack in stock prices. The prime rate at commercial banks, the most visible of all short-term interest rates, was raised by half a point, to 11 percent, the highest since early January. **********One saving grace to Monday's sell-off was the relatively low volume. Only 71.5 million shares changed hands in that session on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Professionals who watch the activity of institutional investors say that bids to buy stock have dried up substantially in recent weeks. However, selling pressure from the institutions also appears to be largely absent so far. Showing of Mutual Funds **********The first anniversary of the bull market in stocks, duly observed last Friday, marked a banner year for mutual funds. The typical equity, or stock-oriented, fund displayed a total return of 68.21 percent over the last 52 weeks, according to Lipper Analytical Services. This total return, consisting of market appreciation plus dividends, compared with 63.12 percent for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the same period. **********Funds that invest in technology issues - a stellar group in the market, although lately it has shown signs of profit-taking - provided the best individual results. Placing first was the Alliance Technology Fund, up 171.20 percent. Close behind came the Fidelity Select Technology Fund with a gain of 170.93 percent. **********The Lipper service, which tracks the performance of 538 mutual funds, reported that growth funds investing in small companies showed the best results of any single group. The average total return for these funds was 97.65 percent. In second place appeared the gold funds, up 93.71 percent. Capital appreciation funds, which are allowed to buy stocks on margin and to use other leveraging techniques, came in third among the groups, up 83.77 percent. **********The strength in mutual funds that mine their gains from precious metal stocks might surprise investors. But the gold funds benefited from the rising price of bullion during the last half of 1982 from what were sharply depressed levels and, to a lesser degree, from the renewal of inflation fears as the economic recovery gained momentum. **********The poorest performing sector consisted of fixed-income funds. On average, the total return for these funds, which emphasize bonds in their portfolios. was 24.16 percent - ordinarily a very creditable record for any 52-week period. Metromedia's Steep Drop **********Not many listed stocks can plunge 110 points in two days. But Metromedia Inc., the highest- priced issue on the New York Stock Exchange, did just that on Monday and Tuesday, when it closed at 390. **********Causing the decline was an article in Barron's, the business and financial weekly, that criticized Metromedia's accounting for the disposal of Foster & Kleiser, its outdoor advertising unit, to a limited partnership last November. The author was Abraham J. Briloff, professor of accountancy at the Baruch College of the City University of New York.  What Mr. Briloff said in substance was that the transaction constituted a financing rather than a sale. When that question was put to a Wall Street executive familiar with the mysteries of accounting, he said the critical element was whether or not the partnership is obligated eventually to sell the assets. **********According to the agreement, the partnership will have the choice in 1987 of either offering the assets back to Metromedia - which holds the right of first refusal - or offering to purchase the remaining assets of Foster & Kleiser. That would seem to indicate that the partnership is not necessarily required to sell, since it has a choice of buying certain assets instead. In any event, accountants have been known to disagree, just like stock market analysts. **********Investors in Metromedia, a broadcasting company whose shares traded at 4 1/4 in 1974, appeared to shed some of their accounting worries as the week wore on. The stock rose in the final three sessions, closing at 445, for a net loss of 55 points on the week. **********Susan V. Watson, an analyst at E. F. Hutton & Company, told clients Wednesday that the price decline repesented an opportunity ''to resume accumulation of Metromedia shares.'' **********Tomorrow, meanwhile, marks the effective date for a 10-for-1 split in the stock.
