https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.body_text: **********When Robert Else 3d took over his father's bus company, King Coal Trailways, five years ago, it was a small line serving only Northumberland County here. It had one passenger bus, which carried a total of 5,000 people that year, and 24 school buses. Revenue came to $360,000. **********Now Mr. Else has a fleet of 13 passenger buses and expects revenue of about $2 million from 53,000 passengers. He also has the authority to operate in 48 states if he wants to. **********He owes much of this growth to his own ambition, but much of it, also, was made possible by the Bus Regulatory Reform Act, which went into effect in November 1982. The law made it easier for carriers to acquire new routes and gave them greater freedom to set fares. **********The act was aimed at bringing some deregulation to the bus industry, as earlier laws had for the airline, railroad and trucking industries. **********While some of the larger carriers have added lines and dropped unprofitable ones, analysts largely agree that most of the action since the law went into effect has been among the smaller bus companies. More than 1,000 of them have gained authority to operate in the 48 contiguous states. **********'Little Guy' Helped **********''It was the little guy who was already started who has been able to expand his operations under the law,'' Mr. Else said during an interview in his cramped office in a small white frame house on Route 61. The office is on the outskirts of Mount Carmel, population 10,000, which had thrived before the anthracite coal industry went into decline. **********In part it has been easier for the smaller, but already established bus lines to expand than it has been for start-up lines with larger ambitions, according to Richard Klem, the associate director of the office of analysis for the Interstate Commerce Commission. **********To expand in the charter and tour business a carrier already in operation generally had only to add buses and drivers, Mr. Klem said. **********Starting an intercity carrier, on the other hand, would take terminals, ticket agents and feeder traffic from local carriers, thus raising the costs and start-up risks considerably, he said. **********''The charter people are the most active,'' he added, ''with many doing well.'' **********Largest Lines in Dispute **********While the small carriers are expanding, however, the nation's No. 1 and No. 2 carriers, Greyhound Lines Inc. and Trailways Inc. and its associated carriers, respectively, are locked in a bitter dispute that the I.C.C. is expected to resolve in January. **********Trailways, through an appeal to the I.C.C., has been able to hold up most of the new route authority being sought by Greyhound since the enactement of the deregulation law.  In a decision that left neither side happy, Paul S. Cross, an I.C.C. administrative law judge, ruled last June 29 that Greyhound should be awarded the routes it seeks. **********He disagreed with Trailways and some of its affiliates that Greyhound, which now accounts for 65 percent of the intercity bus traffic, should first be investigated by the I.C.C. to determine if it was already too powerful a monopoly to get additional route authority. **********Greyhound's Size an Issue **********The administrative law judge also disagreed with Trailways' arguments that Greyhound, because of its size, could easily overwhelm any competition on the routes it sought. But he said the I.C.C. should undertake a study of Greyhound to determine whether it was so dominant that it could overwhelm such carriers as the Trailways system, which now accounts for about 25 percent of the intercity traffic. **********Both sides have appealed to the commission. **********While the large carriers are preoccupied with their legal struggle, many small operators such as Mr. Else have thrived under deregulation. ''All in all,'' he said, ''deregulation has helped us an awful lot.'' **********After the law was passed, he paid a fee of $800 to the I.C.C. and early last year acquired authority to operate in 48 states, and he plans to draw passengers from a wider area. **********The ease with which the application went through, he said, was in sharp contrast to the routine and long delays before deregulation. **********Protests From Competition **********He recalled that when he wanted to expand in 1979 and 1980 he did not even bother to apply to the commission. What typically would happen, he recalled, was that competing companies would file a protest to his application, saying they were already giving sufficient service. **********That would stop the new route application cold, he said, and often lead to months of agency wrangling. The tendency of the I.C.C., he added, was to side with the existing companies and deny the new routes. **********The result was that instead of working through the I.C.C., many companies just bought routes from other carriers. And in July 1980, the 33- year-old Mr. Else did just that, paying more than $50,000 to another local carrier, Capitol Trailways, to extend his authority to six counties. **********His company, which by then had expanded to five passenger buses, got another break in early 1982 when Trailways, in anticipation of deregulation, decided to turn over some of its marginal routes to smaller carriers. **********Twenty-nine of these marginal areas were transferred to about 20 smaller carriers, according to Ted Knappen, a vice president of Trailways. ''In a deregulated environment,'' he said, ''we had to concentrate our assets on routes where we could be profitable.'' **********Nonunion Drivers **********Smaller companies such as King Coal have been able to make money where bigger carriers like Trailways could not, Mr. Else said, because they used nonunion drivers and had lower office overhead and maintenance costs. **********In addition, he said, the smaller lines are frequently more familiar with the territory and thus able to generate more traffic than Trailways could, with its staff concentrated in the larger cities.  So, Mr. Else said, for a nominal $100 payment, Trailways gave him the route from Williamsport, Pa., to Philadelphia. Also for a fee of $1,500 a year his line became part of the Trailways national system, able to use the bigger company's name, terminals, maintenance facilities and marketing expertise. ''They try to help you grow,'' Mr. Else said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/09/busin.body_text: **********Martin S. Feldstein, President Reagan's chief economist, said today that the growth of the nation's money supply has become excessive and it ''has to be brought down'' to contain incipient forces of renewed inflation. **********He added, however, that it was ''nonsense'' to think that the Administration felt the economy was growing too fast. He said that the growth of the money supply could be reduced without thwarting the economy's recovery. **********Mr. Feldstein's comments were made in a statement and an interview before today's announcement of a $3 billion decline in the nation's money supply in the latest reporting week. The drop followed two weeks of sharp increases. **********His remarks were intended in part to dispel fears in the financial community and the Republican Party hierarchy that the Administration supports slowing the recovery in order to prevent the inflation rate from rising above its current subdued pace of under 5 percent. **********Fearing that the Federal Reserve is preparing to force a sharp new tightening of the money supply, perhaps early next week, the financial markets have been pushing up interest rates and provoking a selling wave in the stock market. Such activity, the Administration believes, is an overreaction to the Administration's goals and could by itself derail the recovery that began in December. **********Mr. Feldstein, who is the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, released a statement this morning in response to recent reports that the Administration was concerned that the economy was growing too fast and wanted the Federal Reserve to cool it off. ''Any notion that I think the current growth rate is too fast is just nonsense,'' Mr. Feldstein said in the statement. ''The current pace of expansion is both natural and welcome at this stage in the recovery. Although it is of course possible to have growth that is too fast and that causes an increase in the rate of inflation, we are definitely not growing too fast at this time.'' **********Since last December, the basic money supply has been growing at an annual rate of 13 percent, far above the range of 4 to 8 percent that the Federal Reserve has set as a desirable target to avoid excessive inflation and to encourage the economy's expansion. **********Such increases in the money supply, Mr. Feldstein said later in a telephone interview, worry the Administration. ''It isn't bad for a month or two,'' he added, ''but it's clear that having it go on for month after month is undesirable, and it has to be brought down.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Big city bankers said today that smaller regional banks were fleeing their international lending responsibilities and warned that if the trend continued it could touch off a world financial crisis. **********They said that smaller banks, both in this country and abroad, were frightened by the magnitude of the global debt problem and its potential impact. **********''The real problem today is that some of the newer entrants in international lending - smaller banks, regional banks - are running away at a time when it is extremely important to broaden the population of willing lenders,'' said George Vojta, chief financial officer of Phibro/Salomon Brothers. **********''We're making considerable efforts to keep them involved,'' said George J. Clark, executive vice president of Citibank. ''We have to explain to them that when they get into sovereign risk lending they no longer have the luxury of pulling out because such action could cause a world liquidity crisis.'' **********Mr. Vojta said, ''I expect to see a lot of jawboning, and in the end I think they'll come round.'' These remarks, during interviews at an International Development Conference here, coincided with efforts by international authorities and money center bankers to keep smaller banks from making less credit available to Brazil than they used to. **********The governor of Brazil's central bank, Carlos Langoni, said at a Washington news conference that his country now faced a $1.5 billion shortfall in interbank credit lines. **********About half of the 450 banks that had such lines out to Brazil in 1982 have refused to cooperate with a request by the International Monetary Fund to restore them, according to monetary sources. **********Speaking for the smaller banks, Kenneth A. Guenther, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association of America, commented, ''A lot of them have to remain in the game if the international debt problem is to be resolved over the short and medium term.'' **********He said that legislation approved by the House Banking Committee on May 9 ''put the fright of death into these banks when they were already scared out of their life.'' The bill would hamper bank earnings by requiring noninterest-bearing reserves to be set aside against loans outstanding to countries that are unable to repay without restructuring or additional borrowing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/world.print_headline: TOP MOSLEMS ISSUE A WARNING TO MARCOS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/world.body_text: **********A group of prominent Filipino Moslems warned President Ferdinand E. Marcos today to heed calls for national reconciliation or risk a revival of Moslem separatism in the Philippines. **********The group of 11 Moslem political leaders, including three former senators, announced their support for a plan of unity and expanded political freedom that was first proposed several weeks ago by Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, who is a determined critic of the 18-year-old Marcos Government. **********Saying that Filipino Moslems have ''no desire to be dragged into the impending chaos'' that they foresee, the leaders threatened to reassert old Moslem claims to a ''Moro nation'' in the southern islands of the Philippines ''unless national reconciliation with justice for all is speedily effected.'' **********They referred to Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the oppposition figure who was assassinated here on Aug. 21, as a martyr who had supported Moslem demands for greater autonomy.   Panel Nominee Delays Decision **********In another development, a lawyer and politician whom Mr. Marcos named last week to be the new chairman of the commission of inquiry into the Aquino assassination said after a meeting with the President that he was not yet ready to accept the appointment. **********The appointee, Arturo Tolentino, a member of the National Assembly from Mr. Marcos's ruling party, was quoted tonight on Manila television stations as having told the President he would accept the job only if the commission was entirely reconstituted and given a new legal mandate. **********Mr. Tolentino did not detail his conditions, nor was the President's response made known. The first chairman, Enrique M. Fernando, the Chief Justice of the Philippine Supreme Court, resigned Sept. 30 because of legal challenges to his impartiality. He is a Marcos appointee. **********The commission of inquiry last met publicly on Sept. 12. It is scheduled to resume public hearings on Monday. **********In their message to Mr. Marcos, the group of Moslem leaders urged a ''grant of general amnesty for all political offenses.'' **********Task Force Detainees, a human rights group here, estimates that the Government is now holding 1,200 prisoners on sedition and similar charges. Many of the prisoners are Moslem rebels, while 40 are said to be Roman Catholic priests and nuns. **********Demonstrators Face Charges **********Nearly 100 anti-Government demonstrators have been charged in the last two weeks with inciting sedition or rebellion. Most were arrested during violent riots set off by the killing of Mr. Aquino. The maximum penalty for such crimes is death, according to a recently released presidential decree. **********Today's ''Manifesto of the Moslems of the Philippines Supporting the Call for National Reconciliation and Unity'' was signed by former Senators Ahmad Domocao Alonto, Salipada K. Pendatun and Mamintal Tamanao al-Haj and by eight other well-known Moslems. **********Their move was seen here as an expansion of the opposition to President Marcos. Since the slaying of Mr. Aquino, various forms of public protest have caught up businessmen and bankers as well as clerics, students and politicians. **********The opposition also expanded quietly in another direction today, into Manila's slums. **********After a midday mass for Mr. Aquino at the Santo Nino Church in the poor neighborhood of Tondo north of the Pasig River, several thousand local residents and supporters of Mr. Aquino gathered in the plaza outside the church to hear speeches denouncing the Government.  There was no violence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.print_headline: SHARON'S NEW ROLE: GADFLY IN CABINET; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/29/world.body_text: **********The departure of Ariel Sharon from the post of Defense Minister appears to have changed the way the inner circle of the Israeli Government makes policy. **********There has been more consultation among key ministers in the two months since Mr. Sharon resigned, and a calmer, more collegial atmosphere in most deliberations, according to well-placed officials. **********Mr. Sharon remains in the Cabinet, but mainly as a gadfly, with little of the influence that once made him the second most powerful man in Israel. **********At Cabinet meetings and public gatherings, he has adopted an increasingly critical line toward Government policies, arguing against the flexibility brought by his successor, Moshe Arens, in negotiations with Lebanon and relations with the United States. **********Mr. Sharon was forced to resign in February on the recommendation of the state commission that found him and leading military officers ''indirectly responsible'' for the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut by Lebanese Christian Phalangists last September. For about a month after his departure, he stayed in partial eclipse, making few public statements. In the last month he has begun to make himself heard again. Calls for Toughness **********Mr. Sharon's calls for toughness seem to have had some effect on the tone of debate, but they have not yet overwhelmed a new tendency toward calm reason and pragmatism in the Government's inner circle.  Quietly and without fanfare, Mr. Arens has induced Prime Minister Menachem Begin to abandon some of Mr. Sharon's tactics and positions. **********As a figure on the political right, Mr. Arens is able to get away with some conciliatory policies. He is reported to have instructed the army to refrain from the brutality toward Arabs in the West Bank that became customary under Mr. Sharon, and the results have been seen in more restrained handling of recent demonstrations. **********Soldiers have been less quick to shoot at stone-throwing Arab youths. Mr. Arens has also warned armed Jewish settlers in the territory not to take the law into their own hands. **********The tone of Israeli-American relations has improved, and working meetings with the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, are described by officials as calmer and more courteous. As former Ambassador to the United States, Mr. Arens is credited with having a good feel for American attitudes and sensibilities. Issue of Sharing War Data **********When he wanted to make a gesture to improve American-Israeli relations, for example, he chose to act on his own to undo a tangle that had been created by his predecessor on the issue of sharing information on the performance of Soviet- and American-made weapons in the war in Lebanon. **********As Defense Minister Mr. Sharon had refused to provide the data to Washington unless the United States agreed formally not to transfer the information, even to its European allies, without Israeli approval. **********This was done out of both calculation and pique. He was concerned that the information could find its way into the hands of the Arab countries. He was annoyed that the United States had not been more supportive of Israel's demands for a residual military presence in southern Lebanon after the withdrawal of foreign troops. And he was angry that the Reagan Administration had held up a sale of 75 F-16 fighter planes to Israel. **********When Mr. Arens came from Washington into the Defense Ministry, he took a different tack, however. He asked Israeli intelligence to what extent the Pentagon already had the information, according to an Israeli with extensive military contacts. The answer came back that most of the key data were already known to the United States. So Mr.  Arens proposed that Israel offer the information without a formal agreement, relying instead on similar agreements signed after previous wars. Key Demands Scaled Down **********Mr. Arens has also scaled down Mr. Sharon's key demands in the talks with Lebanon on a troop withdrawal. The idea for five observation posts in southern Lebanon, manned by 750 Israeli soldiers and intelligence agents, has been dropped, although Israel is still demanding joint patrols in the area with the Lebanese Army. **********There is some indication that the new Defense Minister would be willing to make deeper compromises but that the political balance in the Cabinet will not allow it. Mr. Arens had no role in planning the war, and thus no personal stake in the realization of its goals. But he is a determined hawk who believes the war was justified, at least in its most limited aim of routing the Palestine Liberation Organization from within range of Israel's northern border. **********The political reputation of the rest of the Cabinet, especially of Prime Minister Begin, is intertwined with the outcome of the war, however. These men do not want the Israeli public to think that what was gained on the battlefield is being lost at the negotiating table. **********Consequently, when Mr. Sharon warns in Cabinet meetings against abandoning the security demands in southern Lebanon, he is being heard. And even when he does not speak out, everyone knows his views. ''He is like a shadow,'' one official said. ''He sits in the Cabinet meetings, and everyone knows he is watching.'' Sharon Met With Haddad **********Several weeks ago Mr. Sharon visited southern Lebanon and had himself photographed with Maj. Saad Haddad, the Lebanese militia commander whom Israel wants as commander of a southern Lebanese Army brigade. Mr. Sharon warned against letting Major Haddad down. **********Several days ago Mr. Sharon met privately with Mr. Begin, who is said by associates to have a soft spot for the former general and to respect his military analysis. **********Monday night, before Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in Israel Wednesday, Mr. Sharon told a political meeting in Tiberias that the United States was trying to block Israel from realizing the full gains of the war. He declared at a recent Cabinet session that Israel should be retaliating against guerrillas who have been attacking Israeli troops in Lebanon. **********These and other activities have shown how thoroughly Mr. Sharon abhors a vacuum. He is described as immensely frustrated as a Minister Without Portfolio, for he has nothing to do but to talk. He is expected to do more and more of that.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/world.body_text: **********Parliament today rejected an opposition motion demanding the dismissal of Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff, who is accused of accepting bribes to influence a decision on tax waivers for the Flick holding company. **********He has denied the charge. **********By a vote of 274 to 196, Parliament defeated the motion by the opposition Social Democrats, who said Mr. Lambsdorff, whether innocent or guilty, stained the Government's reputation by remaining in his post. **********The Government appears to be hoping the Lambsdorff affair will subside during the long legal procedure of indictment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Time Inc. reported yesterday that losses from discontinued operations had reduced net earnings in the third quarter by 13.9 percent, to $30.3 million, or 47 cents a share, from $35.2 million, or 55 cents, a year earlier. **********Revenues rose 12.4 percent, to $983.5 million, from $875.3 million. **********Operating income from the magazine division, video operations and forest products businesses rose substantially, while the books division reported a slight decline. Income from continuing operations rose 4.3 percent in the quarter, to $38.7 million, or 60 cents a share, from $37.1 million, or 58 cents, a year earlier. **********The reduction in net income reflected operating losses, the costs of closing TV-Cable Week, a television listings magazine that Time began in April and shut last month, and a provision for losses on the anticipated sale of Time's interest in a subscription TV service in the Boston area. **********Sale of Joint Venture **********Time announced Tuesday that it had agreed in principle to sell its share in the joint venture to a Dallas company. A Time spokesman said this allowance for losses accounted for most of the $8.5 million loss from discontinued operations in the quarter; the comparable loss figure a year earlier was $1.9 million. **********The quarter was ''a little below expectations,'' said Alan Kassan, an analyst with First Manhattan. Even excluding TV-Cable Week, he said, the magazine group's profits ''were not up as much as expected, maybe because of paper costs.'' **********Magazines Strong **********Excluding TV-Cable Week, Time said, its magazines had strong gains in advertising and circulation revenues. The division's revenues rose 17.8 percent, to $245.1 million, from $208.2 million. Magazines reported an operating loss of $8.7 million, compared with an operating profit of $10.8 million a year earlier. That reflected a third-quarter loss for TV-Cable Week of $29.1 million, compared with one of $700,000 in 1982. **********Revenues of the company's forest products operations rose 11.1 percent, to $318.5 million. Operating income more than tripled, to $21 million, from $6.9 million. **********Video operations had operating income of $57.6 million, up 17.6 percent, on revenues of $282 million, up 28.7 percent. Time cited growth in subscribers at Home Box Office, the largest pay-TV program service, and American Television and Communications, the second-largest multiple systems operator.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.body_text: **********SOMETIMES a single question from the floor at a meeting can spotlight a career trend. D. Quinn Mills, professor at the Harvard Business School and a member of the National Commission on Employment Policy, in a recent Harvard Business Review article, described just such an occurrence at the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Company, whose workers received voting stock in exchange for concessions on wages and rules. **********''At a recent meeting of one local,'' Professor Mills wrote, ''a worker asked a visiting national union official if the steelworkers union research department planned to analyze an issue raised at the company's annual meeting and advise the members how to vote their stock. The official was a bit taken aback. 'I don't know the answer.  But if you want us to, we probably will.' '' **********So, Professor Mills concluded, unions slowly are moving into the role of investment adviser for members. Will such advice require a different breed of analyst? **********''Yes,'' Professor Mills commented in a telephone interview. ''I think it will.'' And possibly it will require a new dimension in teaching. He said that for about three or four years professors at Harvard have been introducing the concept of wage concessions into pertinent courses from the management aspect, but not from that of the workers. **********''There is a big problem now,'' he said, noting that the worker-employees are not financially sophisticated. ''An enormous communications problem. The union might have some analysts, but my guess is that right now the unions are having to find staff to communicate with Wall Street analysts.'' **********As a result of the recession, several companies have been ''saved'' by takeovers by employees who receive ownership in the form of stock. Suddenly, shareowner capitalists have been created out of worried workers trying to assure their jobs. In an agreement with Eastern Airlines just reported, pilots may get a 21 percent stock ownership in return for work-rule and benefits concessions designed to keep Eastern viable. **********In some cases, employees are getting stock in healthy companies, as a work incentive or bonus, or in lieu of higher wages. At People Express, the young airline that is flying high in an industry plagued with earnings problems, almost everyone in the company owns stock. **********Meanwhile, there also appears to be a growing trend for more employee stock ownership plans and more employee participation.  Usually stock plans involve voluntary payroll deductions of 1 percent to 10 percent of gross weekly pay. Thus workers can quickly accumulate considerable stock positions. **********The popularity of individual retirement accounts also indicates widespread worker interest in investing for the future.  Worker-stockholders might have a lot to ponder.  What is the competition doing? How can the company compete with the Japanese and other foreign nations? Is management doing an effective job? Is management too highly paid? Can wage increases be made now?  If we forgo wage increases, will that help the stock price? **********Another provocative thought might be this: If dividends are raised, the stock price might go up. But the cost of raising the dividend might be at a price that brings workers a smaller increase in wage rates. Yet if the stock price goes up, the company's credit rating might improve and it might be able to borrow money at a lower interest rate for working capital and permanent investments in new plant and machinery. **********Managers often talk about the bottom line, while stockownerworkers, wary about their jobs, might be more interested in the longer term. **********James Balog, senior executive vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the brokerage firm, agrees that investment analysis of a company largely owned by workers requires a different outlook. **********''Yes, I think the investment has to be analyzed differently,'' he said. ''The tone of the analysis might involve a longer-range view.  Analysts might look at more of the ramifications of a particular investment conclusion - the impact on borrowing capacity, for example. **********''There would be a ripple effect of a stock recommendation - the credit rating, the impact on the community. The analysts would have to be almost like sociologists. They would have to consider uniformity of action. Would the worker-shareholders act like a herd and sell at the same time?'' **********Mr. Balog also commented on the broadening trend toward more worker ownership. It affects not only older industries such as steel, where workers have made concessions in exchange for stock, but in some new industries such as high technology, as well as service industries such as airlines, where equity is being given in exchange for accepting lower wages to give a company a head start. **********Mr. Balog speaks of what Peter Drucker, the management expert, calls ''pension fund socialism.'' Mr. Drucker has estimated that by 1985 American workers participating in pension plans will indirectly own 50 percent equity in American business. This raises the question of the influence they might exert. **********Both Mr. Balog and Professor Mills agree that the new kind of analysis requires individuals who can understand the tradeoffs within the particular company or industry. **********As the recession ends, the age of concessions by labor unions to help achieve better productivity perhaps will end, but the age of the worker-stockholder probably is just gaining momentum. With it there will be a demand for a different type of investment analysis - and analysts who can look at individual industries, and the economy in general, through a worker's eyes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose slightly in March, continuing a pattern of moderate increases in recent months, it was reported yesterday by Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********The Consumer Price Index for the area was up two-tenths of 1 percent in March on a seasonally adjusted basis, he said. Since the end of 1982 it has risen at an annual rate of 1.9 percent, he added, while over the last year the area's consumer prices have increased by 6 percent. **********The March index, Mr. Ehrenhalt explained, reflected higher grocery store food prices and higher apparel costs, which were largely offset by a sharp drop in energy prices. Restaurant Meal Prices Off **********The rise in food prices was four-tenths of 1 percent last month, based on an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the food-at-home component. But restaurant meal prices inched down two-tenths of 1 percent over the month. Among the food-at-home index components, Mr.  Ehrenhalt said, the ''volatile'' fruits and vegetables index rose by 1.9 percent in March with increases for tomatoes and fresh fruits partly offset by declines for lettuce and frozen vegetables. The cost of meats, poultry and fish, which usually goes down in March, rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month. **********Apparel prices, typically higher at this time of year as spring lines are introduced, went up 1.7 percent in March. Mr. Ehrenhalt attributed the increase primarily to a 4.4 percent rise in women's and girls' apparel. Prices for men's and boys' clothing were up 1.5 percent, and footwear was up 1.2 percent. **********The medical care index rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent over the month as a result of increases for professional services, including physician and dentist fees, hospital and other medical services, prescription drugs, and related increases in health insurance premiums. Drop of 2 Percent for Energy **********The sharpest price declines last month were in the energy area.  Over all, there was a drop of 2 percent in March following drops of 1.9 percent in February and 1 percent in January. In the last three months, energy prices have declined by 4.8 percent, as compared with a 1.2 percent rise for all other index components. **********Mr. Ehrenhalt said that the price drop for energy reflected a decline of more than 4 percent in motor fuel and residential fuel oil prices. Natural gas charges were also down over the month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/27/world.main_headline: A GAZA TOWN IS A CASUALTY OF THE PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/27/world.print_headline: A GAZA TOWN IS A CASUALTY OF THE PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/27/world.body_text: **********Ahmed Hammad stood in Israeli-held territory and gazed through four chain-link and barbed-wire fences, past a blacktop security road and across 50 yards of cleared no man's land into Egypt, where his brother's wife and children were waving to him. **********He shouted greetings. They shouted back, the bigger boys lifting the little ones so they could see their uncle through the tangle of metal. ''It is very hard and very sad,'' Mr. Hammad said. **********This used to be the bustling center of the Palestinian town of Rafa, once jammed with concrete houses and shops and dusty alleys.  Now it is dead and silent and sorrowful, bulldozed into a swath of emptiness and flanked by armed soldiers and guard towers -monuments to the paradox of peace. **********Rafa, with a population of 60,000, has been a divided city since April 25, when Israel completed its withdrawal from Sinai, pulling back to the international border as delineated in 1906 by Turkey, Britain and Egypt. The withdrawal fulfilled the provisions of the Israeli-Egyptian peace treaty signed in 1979, but it also reestablished a frontier that had been essentially ignored for a generation, splitting Rafa and bringing a maddening hardship to its residents. **********Modern Rafa, situated at the southern edge of the Gaza Strip, began as a small town in Palestine under the British mandate, and it grew and spread and spilled over into adjacent Sinai without regard to the 1906 boundary. **********''The shops have been so carefully erected by far-seeing tradesmen on the exact boundary,'' C. S. Jarvis, British Governor of Sinai, wrote in 1936, ''that so far no customs official has been able to decide what constitutes smuggling and what does not. Technically, the mere act of cooking beans in the kitchen and eating them in the living room is an offense against the law of contraband.'' **********After the 1948 war between Israel and the Arabs, Egypt controlled both Sinai and the Gaza Strip, and residents had little trouble crossing back and forth. Sinai and the Gaza Strip changed hands together in the 1967 war, shifting into Israeli control, and Rafa remained whole. **********The border is now a broad scar. It on a stretch of beach, climbs to an Israeli watchtower on a dune, then moves inland across the desert sands, its course vividly marked by the security road on which Israeli jeeps patrol between an electronic fence and unending rolls of concertina wire. The scar cuts from the desert through the town and out the other side, again into the wilderness. **********An old woman in black sits alone by the fence, staring across, waiting for relatives to appear on the other side. A young woman in a white scarf stops picking oranges in the orchards that press against the border zone, and smiles and laughs and flirts through the fence with two Israeli soldiers who have brought their jeep to a halt. Mediators Between Two Sides **********''You flirting?'' the soldiers are asked.  ''Yes, with both sides,'' the driver laughs. ''We are the mediators.'' Up the line a bit, a group of women in black sit sobbing. Sheik Tasaleh Zourob, a leader of the town, has died on the Israeli side, and much of his family, on the Egyptian side, has not been allowed to cross over to his funeral, the women say. **********According to Brig. Gen. Dov Sion, Israel's representative to the joint military commission with Egypt, eight members of the family asked to cross and were allowed to do so. Perhaps others were turned away by the Egyptians, he said. **********Under procedures agreed to by Israel and Egypt, the fence has a small gate for a few Rafa residents with special permission to cross. A couple of dozen, who live on one side and own property on the other, may cross daily. Thirty-two people cross from Egypt into the Gaza Strip every Sunday to work for a week in administrative jobs, then return home on Friday. Some Refugees May Return **********Residents of Camp Canada, a refugee settlement on the Egyptian side, have been granted permits to work in the Gaza Strip for several weeks at a time. They were originally Gaza Strip residents who were moved into a camp that ended up on the Egyptian side and who are eventually to be moved back to a Gaza camp called Tel El Sultan. **********The Sultan camp, a warren of cinderblock structures near the beach, is the new home for the 300 families whose houses were bulldozed when the security strip was made. They were paid compensation by Israel, General Sion said, and took a good deal of their old houses' construction materials to build anew. **********Israel originally proposed that the security zone be drawn around Rafa, either putting the town wholly inside or outside Israeli jurisdiction. Egypt refused. Israel then considered leaving the border as little more than a chain-link fence through the town. But security men were afraid it would be too easy for guerrillas to infiltrate, roof to roof, alley to alley. So the swath was cut. At present there are no plans to change the border. **********Now, General Sion said, about 70 to 80 infiltrators are caught a month, here and elsewhere along the border. Most, he said, are looking for jobs in Israel, are smuggling or are visiting relatives.  But some are armed, would-be terrorists. Israel has asked Egypt to step up its patrols and has asked the multinational force to help. **********On the Israeli side Ahmed Zourob, 14 years old, stared through the fence. ''I would like to see my grandmother,'' he said, ''because I love her very much.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/busin.body_text: **********A wireless system for polling audiences was patented this week for the General Electric Company by Roy E. Anderson, Richard L. Frey and James R. Lewis of the Research and Development Center in Schenectady, N.Y. **********The system patented, No. 4,377,870, lets the members of an audience move around, as each carries a small, portable transmitter that sends pulses over several frequencies. **********The answers to questions or selections of candidates are tabulated and displayed. Prior systems had the voting units attached to seats and wired to a central tallying machine. **********In one form, spoken comments from the audience can be transmitted by the hand-held unit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/busin.body_text: **********The inflation rate in Canada declined in December for the seventh consecutive month and finished the year at 10.8 percent, the Government said today. The drop in December, of one-half a percentage point, to an annual rate of 9.3 percent, was due largely to a fall in food and transportation costs, it said. Last summer mandatory wage and price controls were introduced for the public sector, pegging wages to a 6 percent ceiling for the first year and 5 percent for the second.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/29/world.body_text: **********Seven of Britain's nine major national newspapers were back on the streets tonight after a three-day printers' dispute. But the two others - The Sun and The Times - said they would not resume publication until the printers promised to work normally. **********The printers went out Friday in a dispute that began over the hiring of nonunion labor at a small plant in northwestern England five months ago and that has become a test of the Conservative Government's new laws to curb union power. **********Five newspapers - The Times, Daily Express, Daily Mirror, Morning Star and The Sun - dismissed their printers Sunday night when they returned to work but refused to pledge not to walk out again. **********Four of the papers - Daily Mail, The Daily Telegraph, Financial Times and The Guardian - resumed publication Sunday night, and tonight all but The Times and The Sun followed suit. **********Spokesmen for The Times and The Sun said they had still received no assurances from the union and so would not publish. The three that resumed publication tonight said that they had received enough assurance to rehire the printers and resume publication. **********The dispute of the printers' union, the National Graphical Association, is with the Messenger Group in Warrington, a suburb of Manchester. The dispute began when the group, which publishes six weekly advertising give-away papers, dismissed six union printers who went on strike to protest the use of nonunion labor. **********The union brought in hundreds of members from other plants to picket the company and force it to accept a closed shop. Although the picketing did not disrupt distribution of the Messenger, the group's chairman took the union to court for violating the 1982 Employment Act. **********The act, written by the Conservative Government, outlawed picketing by workers except at their own places of employment and made unions liable for damages for illegal strikes and picketing. **********A High Court judge fined the union $225,000 and ordered its assets, worth $16.6 million, seized Friday when it refused to pay. That trigggered Friday night's walkout. **********Representatives of the Messenger group held three hours of talks this afternoon with leaders of the printers' union at the Government's Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration office in Manchester. An arbitrators' statement said there was no agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.main_headline: President of Mohasco Named Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; President of Mohasco Named Chief Executive
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The Mohasco Corporation yesterday named its president and chief operating officer, Herbert J. Broner, to the additional post of chief executive. **********Mr. Broner, 55, succeeds Stanley I. Landgraf in the post. Mr.  Landgraf, 57, remains chairman.  Mohasco, wich headquarters in Amsterdam, N.Y., manufacturers and distributes carpets and furniture under several brand names. It has been suffering in the recession but yesterday reported that it earned $1.7 million in the first quarter in contrast to a loss of $2.6 million in the same period a year ago. Sales increased 9.6 percent, to $144.4 million, in the quarter. **********Mr. Broner said yesterday that he was encouraged by strength in domestic earnings.  Mohasco has a Mexican unit that has been ''absorbing the blows of the Mexican economy,'' Mr. Broner said, but he added that ''our major weakness really has been that we never made the money we should have made on domestic operations.'' **********He sees that changing now. ''This is a company with potential, but it doesn't happen overnight,'' he said. ''It takes changes, it takes time and proper timing.'' **********Gulf and Western Industries, which has a 27 percent stake in Mohasco,has announced a divestiture program and has been selling its interests in some companies, but it has not indicated whether it would sell its Mohasco interest, and Mr. Broner said he had no information regarding any decision. **********Mr. Broner entered the home furnishings business after graduating from Middlebury College in 1949. He worked for the Hecht Company in Washington and the Rowe Furniture Corporation of Salem, W.Va., **********He joined Mohasco in 1968 and made a mark there by developing its Cort furniture rental unit over eight years into a 61-store chain. He was named executive vice president of Mohasco in 1980 and later that year became its president and chief operating officer. **********Mr. Landgraf, who served as chairman and chief executive since 1980, said in a statement that Mr. Broner had ''an extensive record of successful accomplishments in the interior furnishings industry'' and that during the last three years ''his contributions have been outstanding.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; DOWNTOWN FLUSHING GETS HIGH-RISE CONDOMINIUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/busin.body_text: **********After building four low-rise condominium projects in Queens during the last four years, the Briarwood Organization has embarked on its first high-rise condominium, an 80-family building in downtown Flushing. **********This project of the Riso family, which has been building homes, offices, stores and factories in Queens for 69 years, is a 10-story building across the street from the municipal parking lot at 37th Avenue and Union Street. **********It is called the Towers. With 10 months of work behind them, the construction crews are topping off the building, and a sales office will open shortly after Labor Day. Occupancy is to begin in late October. **********A sign announcing the sales went up six weeks ago. ''We have received more than 400 inquiries since then, and that is a tremendous response,'' said Vincent L. Riso, the third generation of his family to head the real estate management and construction company. It was founded by his grandfather Luigi Riso in 1914. His brother Raymond and his uncle Dominick also are officers of the company. **********Among the inquiries was one from the Chinatown Planning Council, a nonprofit body seeking possible residences for Chinese families. The growth of Flushing's Asian population - largely Chinese and Korean - has been among the fastest in the nation. **********The impact of the Korean influx, for example, prompted the owner of another multiple-dwelling condominium in Flushing to change its name from Wisteria Gardens to Seoul Plaza. **********Although residential space is at a premium in Flushing, Mr. Riso said the Towers was ''the only new high-rise condo presently available'' in that northeastern Queens neighborhood. **********But around the corner, on Union Street between 37th Avenue and Northern Boulevard, construction has begun on a detached row of 10 to 12 town houses, with two apartments above ground-level stores. And a 15-story condominium building on Main Street south of its juncture with Kissena Boulevard is in the planning stage, the Queens office of the Planning Department said. **********Mr. Riso has lived most of his 49 years in Bayside, which adjoins Flushing to the east. One- and two-family houses mark the quiet tree-lined side streets in both communities, but on the larger avenues there are garden apartments and larger multifamily buildings, many of them with the full services associated with luxury buildings. **********No soaring skyscrapers cut off the light or mar the green foliage and low-profile dwellings, office buildings and stores. From the third floor of the Towers, one can see a church spire, the crenelated tower of an armory and the Gothic tower of a high school rising above the trees. **********The Towers sits on three-quarters of an acre that was formerly occupied by an automobile dealership and car storage lot.  A few blocks away are the Main Street subway stop (terminus of the IRT No. 7 line) and the Flushing station of the Long Island Rail Road. **********The 80 units, with either north or south exposure, consist of 10 one-bedroom and 70 two-bedroom apartments. Each of the 10 floors contains one one-bedroom and seven two-bedroom units. The building is set back from the property line, and cars can approach the entrance on a semicircular driveway. **********The one-bedroom units, which will cost from $115,000 to more than $130,000, will have 750 square feet of space divided among the bedroom, a bathroom, kitchen and living-dining area. **********The two-bedroom units, which will be priced from $130,000 to more than $150,000, will have 950 square feet of space divided among the two bedrooms, one and a half bathrooms, kitchen and living-dining area. All apartments will be equipped with dishwashers, clothes washers and driers, and those above the second floor will have terraces. **********Homeowners at the Towers will benefit from the fact that the project was built under the Section 421A tax abatement program. This program provides for initially low property taxes that will increase gradually over a 10-year period to the maximum set by law. **********As work on the Towers nears its end, the Briarwood Organization is preparing to embark on its first real estate venture in Manhattan - construction of a 108-unit condominium project on the West Side. The multiple dwelling will consist of one- , two- and three-bedroom apartments with selling prices, Mr. Riso said, averaging about $175 a square foot, compared with $140 a square foot at the Towers. **********Mr. Riso said Briarwood's Manhattan venture, in the West Side urban renewal area at Columbus Avenue and 89th Street, would be the first residential development in the area to be built as a condominium at market rates. The company, he said, plans to take title to the vacant property soon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.main_headline: CBS REALIGNS OFFICERS IN BROADCASTING UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.print_headline: CBS REALIGNS OFFICERS IN BROADCASTING UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/17/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc. announced a realignment of the top management of its broadcasting operations yesterday, elevating the presidents of CBS News and CBS Sports to new corporate positions with expanded duties. **********With these shifts, the day-to-day responsiblities for the various CBS broadcast divisions are divided among four executive vice presidents rather than the two who hold them now - forming, in effect, an office of the president. **********Gene Jankowski, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, said that the corporate realignment was designed to broaden the experience of the company's top broadcasting executives. **********''It gives them something they are familiar with, plus areas where they can learn something,'' he said. ''My hope is that within a year they will have increased their flexibility and can go in any direction.'' **********In announcing the changes, Mr. Jankowski said that Van Gordon Sauter, president of CBS News for the last 18 months, and Neal Pilson, president of CBS Sports for nearly two years, had been appointed executive vice presidents of the CBS Broadcast Group. Mr. Sauter will be responsible for the network news division and the five CBS-owned television stations, and Mr. Pilson will supervise the sports division and the CBS radio stations.   Positions Redefined **********At the same time, the jobs of the two current executive vice presidents of the Broadcast Group have been significantly redefined. Thomas F. Leahy will take charge of CBS Entertainment as well as the network's advertising sales and relations with the CBS affiliated stations. Previously, Mr. Leahy was responsible for the CBS radio and television stations. **********James H. Rosenfield has been designated senior executive vice president for finance, operations and development. Previously, Mr. Rosenfield was directly responsible for entertainment, sports, advertising sales and affiliate relations. **********Edward M. Joyce, currently executive vice president of CBS News, will become president of the news division. No new president of CBS Sports has been named. **********Mr. Jankowski said that the creation of a new post overseeing news within the corporate echelon reflected the increasing number of hours that the network is devoting to news. ''With Ed as president and Van in the Broadcast Group, it will give more executive management attention to the process of network news,'' he said. **********For much of the current year, the CBS Broadcast Group - which usually accounts for more than 85 percent of the company's earnings - has been caught in a cost squeeze caused by lower than expected advertising. **********Consequently, Mr. Jankowski initiated a hiring freeze in May and called for cost-cutting in all CBS divisions. **********In the second quarter of this year, the Broadcast Group reported pretax income of $103.3 million, down slightly from $102.7 million in the period a year earlier. In announcing those results, Thomas H. Wyman, chairman of CBS, said that the cost- cutting efforts had kept profits even with the previous year, despite lower demand for the network's advertising time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/09/busin.body_text: **********Hickory Farms of Ohio, a chain of 560 shops in malls, will move its advertising account, expected to bill $10 million next year, to the Louisville, Ky., office of McCann-Erickson next Jan. 1. **********The former agency was Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago. **********Hickory Farms specializes in cheeses and sausage, and 311 of the stores are franchised. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/23/world.body_text: **********Twenty-three people were reported killed and as many as 100 others kidnapped in outbreaks today between Druse and Christian factions in the Shuf Mountains south of Beirut. **********The area, the scene of many exchanges in recent months between the two groups, is under the control of Israeli troops.  The Government-sponsored Voice of Lebanon radio said at least 14 Druse and 9 Christians were killed in shelling and gunfire in villages in the area. **********Israeli military officials said they did not think the violence was related to the signing last week of the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement. Syria, which has an estimated 40,000 to 50,000 troops in Lebanon, has denounced the accord. **********Without the withdrawal of the Syrians as well as the estimated 10,000 to 15,000 Palestinian guerrillas in Lebanon, the agreement is regarded as void because Israel says its troops, estimated at 25,000 to 30,000, will not leave unless the Syrians and the Palestinians pull out at the same time. Druse Reported Killed by a Mine **********The latest incident in the Shuf area began Saturday when a Druse sheik was reportedly killed after stepping on a land mine.  The death of the sheik in the village of Kfarhim resulted in Druse partisans' forming a roadblock and kidnapping Christian motorists.  Armed Christians retaliated, setting up roadblocks and taking Druse drivers hostage. **********Tonight the Lebanese authorities tried to organize an exchange of the kidnapped motorists.  Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan issued an appeal for both sides in the region to use restraint ''at these crucial times'' while the Lebanese-Israeli withdrawal pact was scrutinized by Arab countries in light of Syria's opposition. **********The area of violence has been under the control of the Israelis since they invaded Lebanon last June. On several occasions in the past the Israelis arranged an end to the hostilities by moving in reinforcements. Gemayel Meets With Druse **********The renewed violence occurred as President Amin Gemayel met with Druse leaders about the withdrawal pact.  Today's incident was regarded by a senior political analyst here who has closely monitored violence in Lebanon as one of the worst in recent months. **********A spokesman for the Israeli Army based in East Beirut said the Israeli military was ''doing all it can to restore calm to the area.'' The Israeli Army had previously scheduled a tour of the Shuf region Monday for foreign correspondents, most of whom are being brought from Israel. **********According to the Israeli spokesman, the latest outbreak was not related to the withdrawal accord and was an isolated incident in a region that has been the scene of fighting for years. **********''It was sparked off by a freak incident,'' an Israeli official said, referring to the land-mine explosion. ''It takes little to reignite the old fights.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/busin.body_text: **********INDIVIDUALS in recent years have begun to imitate sophisticated institutional investors, dividing their investments between bonds and stocks. The bonds offer stable cash flow and current yields well in excess of recent inflation. The stocks offer potential capital gains. **********While bonds will never match the performance of a hot stock, few bonds ever suffer the steep declines possible in the stock market. Even if the value of the bond declines, the holder will still receive the same semiannual interest payments as before. For example, when the Consolidated Edison Company of New York and the Chrysler Corporation were going through bad times, both companies continued to make all interest payments on their bonds, but were forced to suspend dividend payments on their common stock. **********''That's the beauty of the bond market,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., who was lamenting the recent decline of his firm's stock along with other brokerage issues. ''In the bond market, all you basically worry about is the direction of interest rates. There is none of this business of picking the right group of stocks.'' **********There are two basic categories of bonds, those issued by corporations and the Federal Government with interest payments subject to the Federal income tax, and those issued by states and local governments with interest payments exempt from the Federal tax. **********Most individuals find the tax-exempt market to be the most attractive sector because the Federal income tax does not apply. However, there are situations in which higher-yielding Treasury and corporate issues may be more attractive. For example, Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans are exempt from income tax until the money is withdrawn, so the tax-exempt advantage of municipal bonds would be wasted. **********Although the $2,000-a-year limit on an individual's contribution to an I.R.A. is small by the standards of the Treasury and corporate market, the size of those accounts will increase in several years to a level where a large amount might be shifted to bonds. Even in the early years of an I.R.A. account, Treasury issues can be bought in odd-lots with minimum denominations of $1,000 either through the Federal Reserve or through a bank or securities dealer. Corporate bonds cannot generally be bought in amounts of $2,000, but small investments are possible in many mutual funds that invest in corporate and Treasury issues. **********While the bond market offers more price stability than stocks, there is some risk of price fluctuations. ''I compare bonds to the end of a clock pendulum,'' said Frederick J. Stoever, president of Stoever, Glass & Company, a New York- based municipal securities firm. ''Long- term bond prices swing in the widest arc, while prices of shorter-term issues do not swing so much.'' The second kind of risk - default - is small in comparison to the volume of issues sold - only about two- tenths of 1 percent of all state and local government bonds - but it is major to the buyers of the affected issues, and the default of the Washington Public Power Supply System created anxiety among many other investors. **********The attraction is yields. Bond market investors face an environment in which yields are high not just in contrast to the standards of the past 40 years, but also in contrast to the recent inflation rate of less than 4 percent. **********Allen Sinai, an economist at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, said in a recent paper that bond yields were likely to range from 4 1/2 percentage points to 7 percentage points above the inflation rate through 1985. Uncertainty about the economy, inflation, Federal budget deficits, Federal Reserve policy and private credit demands all contribute to the abnormally high level of interest rates, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.main_headline: DISQUIET IN DENMARK IS JUST UNDER THE VENEER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.print_headline: DISQUIET IN DENMARK IS JUST UNDER THE VENEER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/world.body_text: **********Like other European capitals filled with tourists this summer, Copenhagen has a sheen of plenty. Swedes, Germans, Americans and others move in a serpentine mass along pedestrian shopping streets past gleaming shop windows filled with expensive goods and delicacies. **********Underneath the sheen, however, there are economic and social problems, among them unemployment running at a rate above 10 percent. But Denmark's jobless, buoyed by a wide array of social welfare benefits, are said to be confident that life can be cushioned without major sacrifice. **********The austerity program introduced by the center-right coalition that took over leadership of the Danish Government last fall has cut about as deep as is politically possible in a welfare state that now gives a jobless couple with no dependents about $225 a week in addition to subsidized housing and a host of other benefits. **********The minority coalition led by Prime Minister Poul Schluter, a Conservative, continues to grow in popularity on the strength of its moves to check Government spending. Without much outcry from the Social Democrats, who have been in opposition since last fall, the new Government ended the index-linking of wages and welfare benefits. It also won an agreement from trade unions not to seek wage increases above 4 percent. Lectures on Spending **********Real economic growth is expected to continue at the present annual rate of about 2.5 percent, a level that Government economists say will pay the costs of maintaining one of the most advanced and stable societies in Europe but one that apparently would not ease unemployment by creating new jobs. **********Foreign debt still represents about 25 percent of the gross national product.  ''Whenever bankers visit Denmark they lecture us about our spending,'' Erik Hoffmeyer, director general of the National Bank of Denmark, said in an interview. ''From the outside we are considered an unstable economy, but there is now broad political support in Denmark for the Government's austerity program.'' **********The bankers' concern led to the lowering of Denmark's bond rating this year from AAA to AA-plus, a move that reflected the belief that austerity had not gone far enough. **********In the view of many, however, if Denmark is forced by a return of high interest rates into an attempt to cut further in social spending, the Schluter Government would be placed on a collision course with Social Democrats. Because the coalition holds only 66 of Parliament's 179 seats, a vote on the question would be expected to force a general election. Missiles Are an Issue **********In any election campaign, the Social Democrats would be expected to benefit from the continuing dispute in Denmark over the plans by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to begin deploying new American intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe in December unless the Soviet Union and United States reach an agreement on limiting such arms in Geneva. The Schluter Government supports the NATO decision, but in May a Social Democratic resolution adopted by Parliament compelled it to press for an extension of the deadline. **********This enforced ''wavering on the deployment issue,'' a coalition member said in an interview, has not only embarrassed the Schluter Government but has also been causing much trouble in the Netherlands, where public support is in a delicate balance. He said that ''if an election was necessary this year'' the coalition could not afford to let missiles become the central issue. **********Beyond the political impact of chronic high unemployment, there is growing concern over the social consequences among young Danes. With five million people in a small land mass, Denmark has prided itself on order and an affluence that eliminated poverty and clear class divisions. **********However, young Danes, like others of their generation in Europe, are more inclined today to see themselves as victims in a society that can no longer provide jobs for them. Among small signs of unrest among them are groups of young people in Copenhagen called the B-Zed who are taking over unoccupied housing and resisting police attempts to remove them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.main_headline: POLITICAL STAR IS BORN AGAIN IN PORTUGUESE ELECTION: MARIO ALBERTONOBRE LOPES SIARES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; POLITICAL STAR IS BORN AGAIN IN PORTUGUESE ELECTION: MARIO ALBERTONOBRE LOPES SIARES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.body_text: **********Many here show a trace of amazement when they speak of the comeback of Mario Soares. Not that the 58-year-old Socialist leader has ever really been away. For the last four years he has been an irrepressible figure on the political scene, but in the opposition. **********His return to power means a slight shift to the left. It reestablishes him, along with the nonparty President, Gen. Antonio Ramalho Eanes, as one of the two people in Government who count. **********''I think, finally, that there was just no one else around,'' a leftist political writer said. ''In the past people have wished for too much and seen too little. So they are turning to him out of pure hope but also out of desperation.'' A Mixed Review as Leader **********Mr. Soares first became Prime Minister in the 1976 elections, beating back a Communist takeover attempt after the 1974 armysponsored revolution. In June 1978 his minority Government was dismissed rather curtly by President Eanes, who thereby gained his longstanding enmity. **********Mr. Soares's tenure got mixed reviews - the promises had been lofty, there was a bit of nepotism, and the corruption that is endemic to politics here seemed more visible because so many committees were appointed to investigate it. But after three years of drifting rule by a center-right coalition it began to look better and better to many Portuguese. **********Mr. Soares had a lot going for him in the present campaign. The deepening economic crisis produced a toss-the-rascals-out psychology; the right-wing parties were feuding and in disarray, and the pro-Soviet Communists were tarnished by antinationalism. **********Then, too, Mr. Soares is not a parochial figure. His years as Foreign Minister in the post-coup Government and his position as vice president of the Socialist International since 1976 mean that he can justifiably speak, as he often does, of ''mon ami Mitterrand'' and ''mi amigo Filipe,'' references to the Prime Ministers of France and Spain. International stature counts for a lot in a small country. **********And Mr. Soares is a natural politician. Cherubic, slightly pudgy, his gray hair neatly coiffed, he performs brilliantly on the stump, donning rubber boots to wade through markets and hug fishmongers, resting his hand gently on the shoulder of a farmer, cutting the air dramatically with his right hand when he exhorts a crowd. In the Path of His Father **********Mario Alberto Nobre Lopes Soares was born in Lisbon on Dec. 7, 1924. His father, Dr. Joao Soares, struggled against the Salazar dictatorship for four decades, undergoing long periods of imprisonment and exile. **********The son followed the same path. He studied history, philosophy and law at the University of Lisbon and the Sorbonne. He was active in the antifascist movement and in 1946 helped found the Democratic Youth Movement in Portugal. In 1947, disillusioned by the show trials in Eastern Europe, he broke with the Communist Party. **********Mr. Soares married Maria Barroso, a leading actress, in prison in 1949. They have a 33-year-old son, Joao, and a 30-year-old daughter, Isabel. **********Mr. Soares went to jail at the age of 19, the first of 12 imprisonments and four and a half years of exile he was to suffer under Salazar. As a lawyer he defended opposition activists of all stripes, from Communists to African nationalists. **********In 1968, Mr. Soares was sent into exile to the African island of Sao Tome. Ten months later, in the ''false spring'' that followed Salazar's death, the regime of Marcello Caetano allowed him back to attend the funeral of his father, but he fell foul of the authorities again and within a year was forced to leave. Based in Paris, he taught at the Sorbonne and the University of Rennes, wrote his most important political works and, in West Germany in 1973, founded the Portuguese Socialist Party.  The coup of April 25, 1974, brought him back to Portugal in triumph. **********Perhaps the most rightist of Western European Socialist leaders, he has noticeably toned down any hint of radicalism in the campaign. He has also had to fend off the charge, from his old enemies, the Communists, that he is the candidate favored by the United States.  ''They attack me because I say that friendship with Washington is an essential condition of our foreign affairs,'' he said. He added, with a subtle dig at the Communists' pro-Soviet stance, ''I reply that everyone has the friends he wants.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/world.main_headline: MITTERRAND VIEWS PEACE IN CHAD AS AIM BUT COMBAT AS POSSIBILITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/world.print_headline: MITTERRAND VIEWS PEACE IN CHAD AS AIM BUT COMBAT AS POSSIBILITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand said today that French troops had been sent to Chad to ''bring peace,'' but he warned that, if threatened by Libyan-backed rebels, they could go on the offensive. **********The President's statements, his first full exposition of policy since fighting flared in the Central African nation two months ago, appeared as a question- and-answer interview in Le Monde. The questions were not submitted in advance, but the text was personally reviewed by the President before its publication this afternoon. **********The interview came amid a growing public debate over France's military buildup in Chad. It also came as Paris pressed a diplomatic effort designed to avoid a clash with Libya. The commitment by France is rapidly becoming larger than any in Africa since the Algerian war two decades ago. **********President Mitterrand sought to justify both the timing and the rationale behind the deployment. He also stressed the need for a negotiated solution among the Chadian antagonists themselves and seemed to want to put to rest a diplomatic dispute with the United States over the sending of American Awacs surveillance aircraft to the Sudan, which borders on Chad.   Of Partition and Federation Asserting that France's role was to safeguard Chad's independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity, Mr. Mitterrand ruled out eventual partition of the country, a situation that now exists on the battlefield. Such a solution, he said, could plunge all of Africa, with its fragile boundaries and ethnic rivalies, into ''a tragic period of general instability.'' **********But in what could have been a significant hint of a possible negotiating objective, he observed that ''federation often conforms more to reality than a formal unity that is always broken.'' **********The idea of a federation in Chad between the desolate, Moslem north and the somewhat more productive, Christian and animist south has been broached in 17 years of civil war. But it is anathema to the Government headed by Hissen Habre, a northerner. The thrust of Mr. Mitterrand's statements appeared directed toward the Libyan regime of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, which is sustaining the rebels against Mr. Habre's forces. **********It was a message balanced between prudence and firmness. The President recalled Libya's concern for a secure southern boundary, but he spoke in no uncertain terms of ''Libyan aggression,'' which he said is what brought the French intervention.   'Our Troops Will Riposte' **********He made it clear that France would not tolerate any attempt by the anti- Habre forces, led by former President Goukouni Oueddei, to move beyond their northern stronghold. **********''If threatened, our troops will riposte,'' he said, ''and in order to defend themselves better, they will not limit their response to defensive measures alone.'' **********He also noted that French soldiers, which have been estimated at 3,000 and are backed up by eight war planes stationed in the capital, Ndjamena, are now in a position to react ''militarily and quickly to a new offensive.'' **********Chadian officials, pressing France to deepen its commitment, have reported Libyan tanks moving south from Faya- Largeau, the northern oasis seized by the rebels more than two weeks ago. **********By implication Mr. Mitterrand rejected any prospect that the French would help the Habre forces retake the north. ''Our troops cannot be regarded as an additional force submitted to a strategy in whose determination they have not taken part,'' he said. ''France will not allow itself to be led where it does not want to go.''  Hernu Is on His Way to Chad **********In discussing the need for talks involving Mr. Goukouni and Mr. Habre, an idea that both Chadians have ignored, he noted that it was time for a ''deep conversion'' with Mr. Habre. **********As the interview appeared, it was announced that the French Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, was on his way to Chad ''to inspect the French forces.'' It was thought highly likely that Mr. Hernu would meet with Mr. Habre to impress upon him the deterrent intent behind the French military presence and the urgency of agreeing to negotiate. **********Mr. Mitterrand insisted that it was the presence of the French forces, who arrived after Faya-Largeau fell, that brought about a halt in the fighting. The lull has now lasted 12 days. **********He devoted considerable attention to fending off domestic criticism that he had not acted soon enough. There had to be clear-cut evidence of external aggression, he said, so the world could see that ''the will for war and domination was that of Libya and not of France.'' He also argued that the delay made military sense, allowing the French to deploy their forces in a defensible position and with adequare supply lines. **********Mr. Mitterrand, who had criticized intervention by previous governments and told African leaders in May of last year that France would no longer play the role of ''a gendarme'' in Africa, insisted that the deployment was not ''neo-colonialist.'' Rather, he said, it was a question of coming to the aid of a menaced and long-standing ally, a former colony.   The Dispute With Washington **********He next turned to the dispute with Washington over his claims that the Americans applied undue pressure to intervene and sent the Awacs planes without informing France. **********Mr. Mitterrand repeated his assertion that France had not asked for the planes. He said there had been general talks on Chad - the Americans were ''very concerned with us,'' he said - and he confirmed reports that he had met with Vernon A. Walters, a former Deputy Director of Central Intelligence. The reports said this occurred on Aug. 6 and 7, the days the planes were sent. **********He added that France was grateful for information on Libyan movements supplied by the Americans. The planes have since been withdrawn and, as if to close the chapter, Mr. Mitterrand said: ''Things are back to normal.'' **********Chad Awaits Mitterrand Text **********NDJAMENA, Chad, Aug. 25 - A Government spokesman said today that Chad would wait for the full text of President Mitterrand's statements before reacting. **********In response to questions, however, the spokesman, Information Minister Mahamat Soumalia, appeared to express disappointment, saying France's interpretation of its military role in Chad remains ''too restrictive, it does not satisfy us or comply with our expectations.'' And he declined to comment on the visit by Defense Minister Hernu of France, who arrived here tonight. **********The Chadian Government has repeatedly urged France to take part directly in the fighting.
