https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/26/world.main_headline: Gandhi Party Defeated In a Stronghold
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/26/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Gandhi Party Defeated In a Stronghold
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/26/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi won elections in four northern states today, but her estranged daughter-in-law led opposition parties to victory in the Indian leader's stronghold of Utter Pradesh. **********The Parliament and state assembly elections were seen as a test of Mrs. Gandhi's popularity across northern India amid rising prices and unemployment. **********The victories and reverses will not seriously affect Mrs. Gandhi's domination of Parliament's 542 lower- house seats, where she maintains a two-thirds majority. **********The special elections were for three lower house districts and 11 state assembly constituencies in five states. **********Mrs. Gandhi's party won strong victories in Bihar, Haryana, Rajasthan and West Bengal, official results showed. But her party suffered reverses in her traditional stronghold of Uttar Pradesh. There, in India's most populous state, the Janata Party gained the one contested Parliament seat. **********Mrs. Gandhi lost one state assembly seat to the party of her estranged daughter-in-law, Maneka Gandhi, whose Rashtriya Sanjay Manch party - the Platform for Sanjay's Ideas - is based on her husband's ideology. **********The Prime Minister evicted Maneka from their joint household last year during arguments about who should be groomed as India's next leader after Sanjay died in a plane accident.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.main_headline: SALVADOR KILLING IS CLAIMED BY LEFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.print_headline: SALVADOR KILLING IS CLAIMED BY LEFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/28/world.body_text: **********A leftist guerrilla group said today that it was responsible for the killing of a United States military officer here Wednesday, calling it a ''patriotic operation,'' and warned against the ''useless sacrifice of American soldiers.'' **********Western military officals said that the assassination of Lieut.  Comdr. Albert A. Schaufelberger 3d, the deputy commander of the American Military Group here, and other rebel actions in the countryside marked the beginning of a stepped-up offensive by the rebels. **********Calling the assassination an act of ''national defense,'' the announcer on Radio Farabundo Marti, the station of the most radical leftist guerrilla group, said that ''it is the adventurist policies of the warlike Ronald Reagan that is producing this new harvest.'' **********The broadcast said the statement was issued by the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front, which is the umbrella organization of five guerrilla groups. **********However, the radio station is operated by, and generally speaks only for, the Popular Liberation Forces, the most radical and the largest of the five guerrilla groups. So far, Radio Venceremos, the station for the Liberation Front, has not made an announcement. Calls Killing 'Patriotic' **********The announcer said that on May 25 an urban commander of the Liberation Front completed a ''patriotic operation'' by killing Commander Schaufelberger, whom the announcer described as heavily armed. **********Commander Schaufelberger, who was also head of security for the military group and the naval section, was shot and killed Wednesday evening after he had pulled up along a circular drive at the University of Central America to pick up a female friend. **********''We will continue our decisive struggle for peace and democracy,'' the announcer said. ''We open the roads for political solutions, but in our search for peace we are accompanied by arms.'' **********Donald Hamilton, the United States Embassy press officer, said he was ''not surprised'' by the announcement. He added, however, that the embassy would continue its investigation of the killing. Effort to Disrupt Campaign **********Several other officials said they would be confident that it was the left if the guerrillas took responsibility for it on a regular broadcast. Indeed, some were concerned that if the left did not make an announcement, that the evidence would point to the far right.  ''That would be a bigger problem,'' said one military offical. **********Official military sources said they believed the guerrillas killed Commander Schaufelberger in an effort to disrupt an upcoming military campaign, which has been heavily dependent on American advisers. **********The plan, which is scheduled to begin in the next couple of weeks, entails a major military sweep of two provinces, followed by civic action programs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.main_headline: U.S. WAS LESS EMPHATIC IN REJECTING MISSILES PROPOSAL, AIDES SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.print_headline: U.S. WAS LESS EMPHATIC IN REJECTING MISSILES PROPOSAL, AIDES SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.body_text: **********Although both the United States and the Soviet Union later disavowed a proposed understanding on intermediate-range missiles worked out in private at Geneva last summer, Washington did not close the door quite as firmly as Moscow, Reagan Administration officials disclosed today. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz sought to signal Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko last Sept. 28 that the understanding was inadequate but that the highly secret channel that had produced it should be kept open, the officials said. **********In diplomatic parlance, they said, this meant that if Moscow had more to say outside the formal negotiating sessions, Washington was ready to listen and maybe even retreat from President Reagan's ''zero-zero solution.'' Under this plan, the United States would forgo deployment of 572 cruise and Pershing 2 missiles in Europe if the Soviet Union scrapped all its intermediate-range missiles targeted on Western Europe. **********Essence of the Compromise **********According to details provided by the officials, the essence of the proposed compromise was to allow each side an equal number of missile launchers in Europe, with the United States being allowed a greater number of warheads on these missiles. But none of the American warheads could be carried by the Pershing 2 missiles that could reach Soviet territory in about six minutes; only warheads carried by the slower cruise missiles would be permitted. The Russians would retain their monopoly of quick-off-the-mark, highly destructive missiles. **********American negotiators will return to Geneva next week with instructions to hold to the original zero-zero formula. An important factor for the Administration will be the West German elections set for March 6. The Reagan Administration hopes the incumbent conservative Government will retain power and reaffirm willingness to accept deployment of the new American missiles in West Germany. **********As previously reported, the proposed understanding on the missiles issue began with a walk in the woods on July 16 by Paul H. Nitze, the American negotiator, and Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, the Soviet negotiator. **********At the time, the Soviet Union had about 250 SS-20's and 250 older SS-4's and SS-5's trained on Europe and almost 100 SS-20's aimed at China and Japan. The United States had no comparable missiles, but was planning to deploy 108 Pershing 2's and 116 launchers carring 464 cruise missiles. **********The understanding that Mr. Nitze and Mr. Kvitsinsky committed to paper called for limiting each side to 75 launchers. Counting three warheads for each Soviet SS-20 and four missiles for each American cruise-missile launcher, that gave the United States 300 warheads as against 225 for the Russians. **********As compensation, the United States was to forgo deployment of all Pershing 2's and be restricted to the torpedo-shaped cruise missiles, which fly close to the ground and take two to three hours to reach Soviet territory from European locations. **********The number of Soviet SS-20's aimed at Asia was to be frozen at 90, meaning Moscow could not complete nine sites under construction. By the same token, 162 missiles and aircraft from the independent French and British forces were not to be included in the agreement. A Mostly Positive Reaction **********The understanding also called for limiting each side to 150 mediumrange nuclear-capable aircraft. This included Badgers, Blinders and Backfires for the Soviet Union and F-111's and FB-111's for the United States. **********The understanding was disclosed to only a few top officials in Washington, where the initial reaction was said to be mostly positive. But William P. Clark, the national security adviser, sent a note to Mr. Shultz criticizing Mr. Nitze's deviation from instructions. **********Mr. Shultz was described as upset about a lack of discipline, but felt that the private discussions should be continued. A number of his subordinates were said to be angry that anything had been done without consultation with European allies, as clearly required by past agreements. Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, officials said, posed no objections. **********The first to raise strong reservations was Army Chief of Staff Edward C. Meyer, over concern about the elimination of the Pershing 2, an Army project. Completely Unacceptable **********Administration officials said President Reagan then directed the State Department to inform the Russians that the Nitze understanding was inadequate, particularly because of the ban on Pershings. It is not clear whether this directive was carried out at all, or before Mr. Shultz met with Mr. Gromyko at the United Nations on Sept. 28. **********At that meeting, Mr. Shultz was said to have stated that while the two sides had not agreed on how to advance the negotiations through private talks between Mr. Nitze and Mr. Kvitsinsky, this way of doing business outside the formal negotiating sessions was very important and should be pursued. Mr. Gromyko was said to have merely nodded, saying nothing. **********Two days later, on Sept. 30, the negotiations resumed in Geneva, and Mr. Kvitsinsky told Mr. Nitze that the understanding was completely unacceptable, that Moscow's initial and public position stood. He said that French and British forces had to be included in any agreement and that stricter limits had to be placed on the growth of all North Atlantic Treaty Organization nuclear-capable aircraft. **********Mr. Nitze's instructions called on him to respond that the United States stood firmly behind Mr. Reagan's zero-zero proposal, but that private explorations for agreement should continue. As it soon turned out, however, neither Mr. Kvitsinsky nor Mr. Nitze had anything new to say. **********In the harder line that followed, some officials said that Soviet negotiators in the companion strategic arms talks threatened last fall to walk out if the United States deployed any missiles. The threat has not been repeated, and American negotiators have never taken it seriously. **********In November, the Russians again changed their tone and publicly offered to limit their European-aimed missiles to French and British levels. Washington rejected that plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Prices of long-term bonds fell sharply yesterday and interest rates rose, reflecting a growing conviction that chances have faded for a near- term decline in rates. **********By late in the day, the bellwether 12 percent Treasury bond due in 2013 was offered at 100 5/8, its lowest price since early November. The decline of about 7/8 point in the price of the Treasury bond, which is a benchmark for a wide variety of other interest rates ranging from corporate bonds to home mortgages, raised its yield to 11.92 percent from 11.80 percent. A week ago, the 12 percent issue was offered at 102 22/32 to yield 11.66 percent. **********The rise in interest rates also depressed the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.89 points, to 1,261.89. (Page D10.) **********''There has been a less-than-subtle shift in psychology lately,'' said a senior offical at one Government securities dealer. Trading volume in the Treasury market remained light, he said, except for a modest increase in selling by institutional accounts. **********Samuel Thorne, a senior vice president at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, an investment advisory firm and manager of mutual funds, said that prices could easily continue to decline in the near term because of unwanted inventory in the hands of securities dealers, the absence of investor demand and ''the totally ridiculous Treasury refunding in the last week of the year.'' **********The stronger-than-anticipated rate of economic growth this year continues to be the most widely cited reason for recent increases in interest rates. Investors in fixed-income securities have apparently concluded that this strength will hasten the day when corporate credit demands expand strongly and put more upward pressure on interest rates. **********Stronger Economy Cited **********''The economy is stronger than we expected,'' said Elwood Haake, a vice president and manager of fixed-income portfolios at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. ''We still expect a few quarters of subnormal growth next year, but it is hard to expect evidence of that developing during the next few weeks or months.'' **********When the economy slows, Mr. Haake and many other analysts still expect that short-term and long-term interest rates will fall. ''The decline will just be from a higher level than expected,'' the Chicago banker said. **********Jeffrey Parker, president of the Technical Data Corporation in Boston, said that the recent pattern of price changes - which are closely followed by many speculators and traders - ''indicate that prices are headed lower.'' When the 12 percent Treasury bond fell below 100 3/4, he said the chart formations pointed more clearly toward lower prices and higher yields. **********In recent days, several analysts have estimated that yields will rise prior to the Treasury's auctions of four- , seven- and 20-year securities in the holiday-shortened week beginning Dec. 26. Because many potential buyers will be absent or noncommittal until after their January investment strategy meetings, securities dealers will set lower prices and higher yields at the auctions to protect themselves from loss. **********If prices continue to decline, analysts at Merrill Lynch concluded in commentary published yesterday that ''at the end of this month'' Treasury issues ''should be attractively priced and provide a good opportunity for investors.'' **********''Sure we are going to buy long bonds again someday,'' Mr. Thorne said. ''Right now, a 12 1/2 percent to 13 percent yield seems like a reasonable risk,'' as long as there are no signs of a significantly weaker economy. **********Short-Term Rates Rise **********Short-term interest rates also increased yesterday, though there was no indication of any change in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. **********''Whether or not the Fed is tightening, or Paul Volcker is smiling or frowning does not have a heck of a lot to do with the outlook for the market over the next few weeks,'' Mr. Thorne said. **********In the money markets, rates on Treasury bills rose by almost a tenth of a percentage point in some cases, with the three-month issue bid at 9.03 percent late in the day, up from 8.94 percent. **********The sharpest increases in interest rates was in large negotiable bank certificates of deposit in denominations of $1 million and more, where yields rose as much as a quarter of a percentage point as many New York City banks have been active issuers. **********In the last week, Treasury bill rates have increased only about a fifth of a percentage point, but the yields on three- and six-month certificates have increased nearly half a percentage point, to 9.75 percent and 10.05 percent, respectively.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.main_headline: South Korean President Shuffles His Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; South Korean President Shuffles His Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.body_text: **********President Chun Doo Hwan replaced the Deputy Prime Minister and the Interior Minister, one of his closest associates, in a Cabinet shuffle announced today. **********A presidential spokesman said Deputy Prime Minister Kim Joon Sung, who also was Economic Planning Minister, was succeeded by former Commerce Minister Suh Suk Joon, an American-educated economist. **********Interior Minister Roh Tae Woo, a former army general, was replaced by former Defense Minister Choo Young Bock. Mr. Roh played a leading role in helping Mr. Chun to power after the assassination of President Park Chung Hee in 1979. **********Mr. Roh had been regarded by many as the most powerful man in South Korea after the President. Government sources said he was being given a new job as chairman of the organizing committee for the 1988 Olympics in Seoul.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/world.body_text: **********In meetings this week with a high official of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Foreign Minister Andrei A.  Gromyko appears to have refused to throw the Kremlin's weight behind Yasir Arafat, head of the guerrilla movement. **********A report in the Soviet press today about Mr. Gromyko's meeting with Farouk Kaddoumi, the foreign affairs specialist in the P.L.O.'s Executive Committee, made no mention of Mr. Arafat, even though there had been reports that Mr. Kaddoumi had come to Moscow to prepare a visit by Mr. Arafat. **********Instead, the statement contained a Soviet demand that the P.L.O.  put its house in order and ''strengthen cooperation'' with ''progressive Arab countries,'' an apparent allusion to Syria. **********''The Soviet side expressed its firm opinion about the impermissibility of strife and internecine dissension among the Palestinians faced with the Israeli aggressor, for they weaken the forces of the Palestinians, disunite the ranks of Arabs,'' the statement said. ''Discord within the P.L.O. can and must be overcome by political means, through a dialogue.'' Message to Arafat Unpublished **********When Mr. Arafat first came under challenge from within his Fatah organization and the P.L.O. demanding a more militant leadership, Moscow reportedly sent him a message of support. But in contrast with the message sent while he was warring with Israel last summer, this message was never published. **********Since Mr. Arafat quarrelled recently with Syria, the Soviet leadership has kept aloof from the struggle.  Western analysts here presumed that Mr. Arafat's visit had been called off by Moscow, and the tone of the message to Mr. Kaddoumi further strengthened speculation that the Kremlin had decided against supporting the P.L.O. leader, especially while he is at odds with Syria, Moscow's chief ally in the Middle East. **********Mr. Arafat's visit to Moscow would inevitably have included appeals for help in his dispute with President Hafez al-Assad, the Syrian leader. The analysts believe the rift in the Palestine Liberation Organization has posed serious problems for the Soviet Union's longstanding hopes for a major role in an Arab-Israeli settlement. Moscow Fears Split in P.L.O. **********Moscow's hopes have been based on its costly support of Syria and the P.L.O. A division in the Palestinian movement that might put half the P.L.O. under the control of Damascus and the other half possibly closer to Jordan could, in the view of diplomats, seriously weaken Moscow's position. **********Thus, the analysts believe Moscow has adopted a neutral stance for the moment, coupled with strong demands for a quick resolution of the conflict. **********Most diplomats suspect Moscow would settle for a new collective leadership in the P.L.O. rather than have the movement split.  Moscow's stance on the P.L.O. dispute is in sharp contrast with its pronouncements on the civil war in Chad.  In that war, the Kremlin has openly leaned toward the insurgents backed by Libya, describing Goukouni Oueddei, the rebel leader, as ''Chairman of the Transitional National Unity Government,'' and Hissen Habre, President of Chad, as ''the present head of the Ndjamena Government.'' **********Press reports on the strife have publicized advances by the rebel forces and have repeatedly criticized France and Zaire for helping the Government side. **********Yesterday, Tass approvingly quoted the French Communist newspaper L'Humanite that any foreign intervention would lead to ''further escalation and internationalization of the conflict.'' **********But Moscow has given no sign that it is prepared to go directly to the aid of the rebels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/27/world.body_text: **********Israel's Foreign and Defense Ministers met with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today as the Reagan Administration continued its efforts to find a formula for the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. **********Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who came to Washington at the request of President Reagan after Prime Minister Menachem Begin canceled a visit scheduled for this week, talked with Mr. Shultz and other top Administration officials for more than three hours. **********American and Israeli officials said the main topic of the talks was Israel's announced plan to withdraw its forces in Lebanon to more secure positions. **********State Department officials, who have been seeking a way to break the deadlock over Lebanon, said they did not expect any breakthroughs. Partition of Lebanon **********The Reagan Administration fears that a partial Israeli withdrawal, coupled with Syria's refusal to depart, would lead, at least temporarily, to the partition of Lebanon. **********President Reagan, speaking at a news conference this evening, said he hoped Israel's partial withdrawal would not lead to partition. He said that, as long as the withdrawal was the first phase of a total pullout, he thought it could help break the impasse created by Syria's refusal to withdraw. **********Mr. Reagan added that Israel had assured the United States that they viewed the partial withdrawal as part of an eventual removal of all these forces from Lebanon. He said the partition of Lebanon would be ''awful.'' **********During a visit to Washington last week, President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon warned that a partial Israeli withdrawal could jeopardize the security agreement between Israel and Lebanon that was signed in May. Terms of Withdrawal Accord **********As part of the agreement, Israel promised to withdraw all its forces from Lebanon if Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization did the same. **********Last week the Israeli Cabinet gave unanimous approval to plans to withdraw Israeli troops from the Beirut suburbs and the Shuf mountains and redeploy them on a new line in the south based on the Awali River. **********Israel plans to pull back in stages and to complete the move by winter. The pullback would remove the forces from areas where they have been caught in a crossfire between Lebanese Christian and Moslem Druse militias and have been vulnerable to terrorist attacks. **********Israeli leaders have said they will not move their forces from eastern Lebanon, including the Bekaa, the eastern valley where they are deployed in some cases within several hundred yards of Syrian forces. These positions also put Israeli artillery within range of Damascus, the Syrian capital. **********When Israel and Lebanon signed the security pact, the Reagan Administration hoped that it would induce Syria to discuss pulling its forces out. But Syria denounced the agreement and has refused to consider withdrawal talks, saying Lebanon asked Syria to send in troops to help quell internal disorder whereas Israel invaded Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.main_headline: U.S. IS SENDING AFRICAN NATIONS MORE ARMS AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.print_headline: U.S. IS SENDING AFRICAN NATIONS MORE ARMS AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, concerned about Soviet and Cuban involvement in Africa, has quietly doubled military aid to key countries in the region. **********Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker, head of the Bureau of African Affairs and the key American policy maker for the region, said military aid now represents about 20 percent of overall American aid to sub-Saharan African countries. **********The bulk of American aid, he said in an interview this week, is designed to alleviate the critical balance-of-payments deficits in most African countries, many of which are facing their worst economic crisis in 40 years. The crisis was fostered by drought, declining food production, rising birth rates and paltry foreign exchange earnings from such traditional export products as cocoa and rubber, the prices of which are depressed on the world market. **********Broader Pretoria Ties Sought **********Key pro-Western countries, such as the Sudan, Kenya, Somalia and Liberia, received the bulk of American aid.  At the same time, the Administration has made efforts to broaden ties with South Africa in what Administration officials acknowledge is a significant break from Carter Administration policies, which they describe as having had a ''civil rights tone'' shaped somewhat by Andrew Young, the former chief delegate to the United Nations. **********Administration officials acknowledge that they have been stung by strong domestic criticism of their policy, especially from blacks who say the United States is acting in complicity with South Africa. **********Administration officials said it was partly in an attempt to blunt such charges that Under Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the third-ranking official in the State Department, made a speech on June 24 criticizing the Pretoria Government. In the speech he characterized South Africa's official policy of racial discrimination as ''morally wrong.'' **********The Administration is actively lobbying against a bill sponsored by opponents of the Administration's Africa policies that is to come up in the House of Representatives in mid-July. It would bar the United States from voting in favor of a $1 billion International Monetary Fund loan to South Africa. **********In the interview, Mr. Crocker said there had been ''a kind of sterile discussion'' in the past about the poverty, hunger and corruption that afflict some African countries. **********''We have made it clear that the reasons for Africa's economic malaise are, to put it mildly, not only the external recession and low commodity prices, but a whole generation of economic mismanagement,'' said Mr. Crocker. **********Administration officials say the Soviet Union, Cuba and Libya are working to destabilize several African nations. The Soviet Union, these officials say, provides 60 to 70 percent of the arms used in Africa. There are an estimated 30,000 Cuban troops and civilians in Angola, and 13,000 Cuban military personnel in Ethiopia. Libya Backs Chad Rebels **********Libya supports rebel forces in Chad, and Pentagon officials say the objective seems to be to put pressure on the Sudan and ultimately on southern Egypt. **********To counter such threats, the Administration has sharply increased military aid to African nations. In 1980 military aid to the nations of sub-Saharan Africa totaled $78 million, compared to an Administration request for $201 million in security assistance in 1984. Economic aid also climbed, but not as steeply: from $694 million to $965 million in the same period. **********In addition, the United States, according to Administration officials, has been supportive of such recently independent leftist regimes as that of Zimbabwe, to which economic aid tripled, from $24.7 million in 1980 to a proposed $75 million in 1984. Relations have been strengthened with the Marxist Government of Mozambique, with an exchange of ambassadors set to take place soon. **********By contrast, the socialist Government of President Julius K.  Nyerere of Tanzania, which has been plagued by unrest and economic disarray, has met chilly treatment from the Reagan Administration.  Economic aid to Tanzania fell from $28 million in 1980 to a proposed $14 million in 1984. Policy on Southern Africa **********Although groups such as the 20-member Congressional Black Caucus have criticized the ''militarization of our approach to African assistance,'' as its chairman, Representative Julian C. Dixon, Democrat of California, said recently, it is the issue of Administration policy in southern Africa that has stirred the sharpest verbal attacks. **********Administration policy to the region is based on what Mr. Crocker calls ''constructive engagement.'' This essentially means refraining from continuous public criticism of the Pretoria Government and seeking closer diplomatic ties with South Africa. It is based on the premise that the establishment of a more trusting American relationship with South Africa would spur it to undertake internal changes, halt its support and military harassment of nearby states and end its occupation of neighboring Namibia. **********Under the Reagan Administration, the United States has increased the number of military attaches in South Africa, provided visas to ranking South African military and intelligence personnel, permitted the sale of a computer that has a potential dual use for nuclearrelated equipment and loosened controls on some exports, including electric-shock batons, to the South African military and police. **********It also used its veto to block United Nations Security Council resolutions condemning South Africa and allowed American companies to broker nuclear fuel deliveries to South Africa although it refuses to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. **********It is Namibia, also known as South-West Africa, that has dominated African policy in the last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/busin.body_text: **********Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor who has made a reputation by buying troubled companies and profiting from selling their assets, has ended his interest in the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation. **********A Securities and Exchange Commission filing in Washington indicated that a group headed by Mr. Jacobs had sold its 6.8 percent stake in the container maker, which is based in Los Angeles. **********Between Feb. 16 and March 28, Mr. Jacobs and his partners, Daniel T. Lindsay, Dennis M. Mathisen and Gerald A. Schwalbach, purchased 274,700 shares at prices from $12.997 to $20.75 a share. **********The filing indicated that Mr. Jacobs ''disposed'' of the stock last Tuesday, but did not say to whom the shares were sold or at what price. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/30/busin.body_text: **********By all appearances, Pepsico Inc. is a company on the defensive.  After years of earnings growth, profits at the nation's secondlargest soft drink bottler - after the Coca-Cola Company - fell 25 percent in 1982 and 42 percent in the first quarter of 1983. Fraud uncovered in its international bottling division in 1982 cost Pepsico millions of dollars and substantial embarrassment. Earlier this month, the company lost two top executives, each of whom was considered among the best in his field. **********Pepsico is tight-lipped about the setbacks, adding to the impression of a company embattled. Its chairman and chief executive officer, Donald M. Kendall, declined to be interviewed, although the company responded to written queries. **********Analysts Like New Products **********Despite Pepsico's defensive posture, most industry analysts said the company is coping with its problems and shows signs of surmounting them. Some are particularly impressed by Pepsico's management skills and a number of its recent product introductions, especially Pepsi Free, the cola drink that has won more than 50 percent of the caffeine-free market in the two years since its introduction. **********Pepsico also recently approved a change in its Pepsi-Cola softdrink formula - switching from sucrose to the less-expensive fructose sweetener -that is expected to provide savings and allow the beverage to be more competitive. **********''Pepsico may be having more troubles right now than Coca-Cola,'' said John C. Maxwell, an analyst for Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., ''but Pepsico management is top-notch and I'm optimistic that they can emerge from their problems.'' **********''The company is in a regrouping mold,'' said Lawrence Adelman, senior vice president and analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds. ''The key problems have been the overstatement of the foreign results, which hurt the 1982 earnings, and the massive peso devaluation in Mexico, which hurt Pepsico's sales.'' **********He added: ''Mexico is Pepsico's key foreign profit center for both soft drinks and snacks. But I think they will progressively come out of it.'' **********Mr. Adelman said that he foresees a 15 percent drop in earnings per share in the second quarter, a flat third quarter but ''a significant improvement in the fourth quarter, which will give them a good 1984.'' Frito-Lay Fraud **********In 1982, two years after it uncovered fraud in its Frito-Lay division, Pepsico discovered falsified profits reports in its Mexico and Philippines bottling subsidiaries. This forced the company to reduce previously reported net income by $92.1 million for the period Jan.1, 1978, through Sept.4, 1982. Besides dismissing four overseas senior managers, the company said in its 1982 annual report that it had adopted more centralized financial controls to prevent a recurrence. **********The profit decline and the bad publicity generated by the overseas accounting irregularities has clearly hurt Pepsico's stock. After reaching a 1982 high of $52 in the fourth quarter, it has since fallen to the mid-30's, closing at $36.125 on Friday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The biggest problem faced by Pepsico, along with the other soft drink makers, is the decline in the growth rate of beverage sales.  Last year, the increase in domestic unit sales for the industry was only 2 percent, down from 2.5 percent in 1981 and 3.1 percent in 1980. And foreign unit sales were flat in 1982, after growing at a rate of 3 percent in 1981 and 6 percent in 1982. **********The importance of beverage sales to Coca-Cola and Pepsico is clear. Coca-Cola derives 73 percent of its sales and 85 percent of profits from soft drinks. Pepsico's soft drink operations, its major revenue producer, account for 39 percent of sales and 31 percent of earnings, second only to the Frito-Lay division's contribution. **********Pepsico's net income fell 25 percent, to $224.3 million, in 1982, while sales rose 7 percent, to $7.5 billion. Coca-Cola's revenue rose 6 percent, to $6.25 billion, while its net increased 15 percent, to $512 million. Intensified Cola War **********The tougher market situation has led to an intensified war among the cola makers, with new soft drink products emerging, accompanied by multimillion-dollar promotion budgets. Coke and Pepsi have matched each other on a tit-for-tat basis since 1963 with various lowcalorie and caffeine-free drinks - and are working on yet newer variations. All this is being accompanied by marketing changes and efforts to strengthen both company-owned and franchise bottling systems. **********''In the soft drink industry, more has happened in the last 15 months than in the previous century,'' said Jesse Meyers, publisher of Beverage Digest, a newsletter in Greenwich, Conn. ''There have been new product introductions, new competition and many changes among the major players. But more seems to have happened at Pepsico's soft drink operations than elsewhere, so that the company is at the crossroads.'' **********The departures of two senior vice presidents, John Sculley, former head of the Pepsico's United States soft drink subsidiary, and Donald Smith, who headed up the food services subsidiary, came as a dramatic counterpoint to the lingering foreign scandal. While not involved in the scandal, both Mr. Sculley and Mr. Smith, analysts said, decided to pull up stakes because Pepsico's run of problems had removed some of the glow from their own futures at the company. **********Neither Mr. Sculley nor Mr. Smith could be reached for comment.  ''Sculley was the best man in the soft drink business and Don Smith is the best guy in the restaurant field,'' said Arthur Kirsch, an analyst for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ''Both were key players who could have succeeded Don Kendall.'' **********Industry watchers said Mr. Sculley will be sorely missed. Mr.  Meyers, for one, thinks that Mr. Sculley, who has become president of the Apple Computer Company, was ''the prime motivator, who sparked Pepsi into a hot No.2 contender.'' A Skilled Marketer **********A skilled marketer who obtained valuable shelf space for Pepsi-Cola in food stores and drew bottlers' loyalty, Mr. Sculley, 43 years old, is said to have wearied of the formality in Pepsico's international headquarters in Purchase, N.Y., and decided that he had ''done it all'' and should leave. He reportedly was also lured away by a $1 million bonus and a $1 million salary. **********Mr. Smith, 43, who became chief executive of Chart House Inc., a Louisiana restaurant concern and a leading Burger King franchisee, is widely considered to have been responsible for the major improvement in Pepsico's two fast-food chains, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell. **********But Pepsico, while certainly unhappy about the two departures, took comfort in its staff-building efforts.  ''We have the management talent to plan and execute the strategies that surely will result in our sustained growth,'' Mr. Kendall said recently. ''When John Sculley left, we were able to accelerate a reorganization plan and fill several key positions entirely from within.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A STRONG CURRENCY HAS ITS GOOD SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A STRONG CURRENCY HAS ITS GOOD SIDE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.body_text: **********-year-long appreciation of **********the dollar has been largely assessed by American economists and businessmen as harmful to the economy. **********The standard reasoning goes like this: Excessively high interest rates in the United States have been the main factor in driving up the dollar's exchange rate. This, in turn, has hurt our export- and import-competing industries and has led to huge trade and current-account deficits. These deficits have depressed the overall economy and were mainly responsible for the 1981-82 recession. **********There are serious flaws and misconceptions in this reasoning. In fact, the strong dollar has also had important positive effects, most notably in curbing inflation, which - in my view - outweigh the negative ones. **********As for the cause of the dollar's strength, the proposition that high or rising interest rates have been responsible is clearly contradicted by the experience of the past two years. **********In both 1981 and 1982, interest rates in the United States declined, but the dollar rose sharply. True, in the short term the dollar tends to strengthen when interest rates move up, and vice versa, but the movements have been highly asymmetrical. The dollar has tended to appreciate more than proportionately when interest rates have been rising and to decline less than proportionately when they have been trending downward. As a result, in the longer run interest rate and exchange rate trends have been moving in opposite directions. **********There are several reasons for this inverse relationship. **********First, it is not so much changes in interest rates but rather changes in interest rate differentials among various countries that determine exchange rates. Declines in American interest rates in 1981-82 were followed by declines in interest rates abroad, so these differentials remained largely constant. **********Second, a mirror image of the declining trend in United States interest rates over that period was the upturn in bond prices and, indirectly, the rally in the stock market, both attracting foreign capital here and thus, paradoxically, strengthening rather than depressing the dollar. **********Third, foreign capital has been flowing into the United States for political reasons, too, due to the greater political stability here. Fourth, the dollar's appreciation in some cases has reflected the weakness of other currencies rather than its own strength. And finally, the most important factor in the dollar's rise has been the spectacular decline in United States inflation, much greater than in most other countries. **********In short, as long as American inflation is under control and the political situation in the United States makes it a safe haven for foreign capital, the dollar will remain strong, no matter what happens to interest rates. Recent official intervention in exchange markets, aimed at resisting speculative upward pressures, is not likely to change much the dollar's position. **********CRITICS of the strong dollar hold the view that its appreciation has been harmful to the economy by hurting our export industries. There is no doubt that American exports have been on a declining trend over the past two to three years. However, this has not been so much due to the dollar's appreciation as to the prolonged worldwide recession, to the embargo on grain exports to the U.S.S.R. and to the retrenchment in several developing countries that are important markets for our products. **********The explanation lies in the structure of our exports, which have relatively low price elasticity. This is primarily due to their large capital goods component in high-technology products where price is not the most important determinant of demand. Also, in many lines of our agricultural exports the United States holds a dominant market position and is well able to fight foreign competition. Finally, one should not forget that about 20 percent of our exports go to Canada, and here the appreciation of our dollar versus the Canadian currency has been rather negligible. **********To be sure, many of our export industries have found their competitive positions deteriorating because of the rise in the dollar. But the macroeconomic extent of this deterioration has been much less than might have been theoretically expected. **********Even greater misconceptions prevail in assessing the impact of the rising current-account deficit on the overall economy. Many economists contend that this external deficit was the main cause of last year's decline in G.N.P. But this was mainly the result of the prevailing methodology of calculating the foreign balance in real terms, which leads to paradoxical distortions when there is a major shift in the terms of trade: The more favorable the terms of trade, the worse the foreign balance. **********Last year, largely due to the dollar's appreciation, our import prices declined while prices of our exports rose. But this favorable shift in the terms of trade resulted in depressing both the foreign balance and total G.N.P. in real terms. Official statistics for 1982 showed that the deterioration in the foreign balance (mainly due to the decline in export volume) was responsible for about 50 percent of the 1.9 percent decline in real G.N.P. But under a different methodology, taking into account the shift in the terms of trade, real G.N.P. would have shown a 1.2 percent decline and the impact of the foreign sector would have been only about 16 percent. **********While the negative effects of the strong dollar are being exaggerated, the positive ones tend to be overlooked. The most important positive consequence has been its contribution to curbing United States inflation. It is estimated that three to four percentage points of the total drop in the consumer price index can be attributed to the rise in the dollar's exchange rate. This has been achieved not only by the direct reduction of import prices, but also through a dampening influence on prices of domestically produced goods competing with imports. **********Moreover, the dollar's appreciation has had a strong effect on the overall improvement of the competitiveness of United States industry - it has forced both our export- and import- competing industries to cut costs to a larger extent than justified by cyclical conditions alone. In addition, the dollar's rise has had a beneficial effect on curbing inflation worldwide as exporters of products traded in dollars tended to reduce their prices not only because of weak demand, but also because they were exchanging their goods for an appreciating currency. Finally, industrial countries whose currencies depreciated vis- a-vis the dollar have gained competitive advantage in their exports; this tends to be often ignored by foreign leaders who criticize the dollar's rise. **********A strong currency is a mixed blessing for any country - it has its positive and negative effects. In my view, the dollar's strength has been, on balance, positive for the American economy and indirectly for the world economy as well. The Administration should resist pressure from foreign leaders to push the dollar down significantly. This would undermine confidence in the dollar, reverse the flow of foreign capital and reignite inflation. **********Mieczyslaw Karczmar is chief economist at the European American Bank in New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/06/busin.body_text: **********Japan's top agriculture official said today that his nation must reach a domestic consensus about expanding its quotas on beef and orange imports before resuming talks with the United States. **********Iwazo Kaneko, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, told Japanese reporters it could take two months for the ruling party and farm leaders to achieve such a consensus, the ministry said. **********Mike Mansfield, the United States Ambassador, met with Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe Monday and asked early resumption of the beef and orange talks. Negotiations broke down in Honolulu last October. **********In the past Mr. Kaneko always strongly opposed letting in any more beef and oranges from the United States. This seems to be the first time he has implied the possibility of an eventual compromise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister John Compton of St. Lucia, one of the least recognizable statesmen in this city two days ago, ended a visit to the Oval Office visit today, emerged to the midday sun outside the White House and was immediately swept up in a mob of news reporters. He was in plenty of time for the evening television news shows, a Reagan Administration official noted privately with satisfaction, and he was escorted by some of President Reagan's ranking advisers. **********''This is the Prime Minister's show - I don't want to get involved,'' Langhorne A. Motley, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, declared at the fringe of the crowd as the Prime Minister articulated the Caribbean nations' fear of the Cuban troops on Grenada. **********The Prime Minister's appearance on the White House driveway, for which the press office several times invited coverage, served to raise the topic of regional fears well in advance of President Reagan's prime-time television address tonight. **********The Cuban Troop Rationale **********The concern that Cuba might try to extend its influence to more of the Caribbean nations was not mentioned by Mr. Reagan on Tuesday when he first announced reasons for the American invasion of Grenada; he spoke then of concern for American lives and restoring the rule of law on the island. **********But the Cuban troop rationale was subsequently broached and emphasized by other Administration officials in a 24-hour period that preceded the President's speech. **********Newspaper columnists were privately summoned to the White House Wednesday evening, for example, to hear a contention from national security officials that a major Cuban military buildup had been discovered ''in the knick of time'' by the invading Americans. **********As a result, Administration officials saw this point of the unfolding story rise to headline status the next morning. In the process, it seemed to de-emphasize the question of whether the Administration had made a serious enough effort peacefully to protect the American residents of the island before resorting to invasion.   Attention to Minor Details **********The officials also emphasized minor details - for example, White House briefings offered a euphemism for invasion, ''predawn vertical insertion.'' At times, President's spokesman, Larry Speakes, responded with plain, smiling silence when an explicit answer was repeatedly requested at public news briefings. He chose to remain silent for more than a day on the question of how the President had reacted to the widespread criticism of the invasion from Western allies. There were also belabored attempts at relating even the most basic chronology of events. **********It was only near the end of a long, often fractious round of press briefings Wednesday that the White House finally confirmed that it had rejected 11th- hour messages from the Grenadian Military Council purportedly guaranteeing the safety of Americans on the island. The Administration's response came six hours after President Reagan had approved the invasion and five hours before it began, the White House press office said. **********Such is historically the pattern for an Administration under critical stress. In the course of the Grenada invasion and the explosion Sunday of the Marine Corps headquarters in Lebanon, officials say, the Administration's emphasis was clearly on protecting the President from being indentified with negative developments.   Avoiding Graphic Aspects **********Administration officials acknowledge that there are limits to such a strategy, with the President finally having to address the nation tonight on both Grenada and Lebanon. But the President's critics, including Democrats frustrated by the White House's talent for public relations, say they feel that Mr. Reagan's White House is particularly attuned to avoiding the more graphic aspects of negative news. **********Through three days of the invasion, for example, the White House, while saying American casualties were low, did not offer any figures on the casualties that American troops on the island had inflicted on others, whether combatants or civilians. Similarly, a question that rival politicians have been asking is whether the President will visit Dover, Del., when the first bodies of marines killed in the Beirut explosion are returned from Lebanon. The White House said tonight that there were no such plans. **********At heated periods such as this, the Administration often tries to defend its position by tracking telephone calls from the public to the White House and dividing them by some means into ''positive'' and ''negative'' tallies as a measure of popular support for the President.  When the phone counts were released today, the President was rated ''positive'' by a ratio of 5 to 2 on Grenada and 2 to 1 on Lebanon. The Grenada invasion drew more than 7,000 calls, while the Lebanon disaster, with a far greater loss of life, drew little more than 1,500.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/05/busin.body_text: **********Worldwide economic recovery and baking stability is at stake if a significant portion of $700 billion in debt amassed by developing nations should be repudiated, bankers and economists say. Political conflicts further complicate the issue. (A1.) **********Stockholders in Mexico's nationalized banks will receive interestbearing bonds to cover the shares they lost when the Government took over the institutions, the Finance Ministry announced. (D1.) The Economy **********Industrial orders and employment increased in June, the nation's purchasing managers reported in their monthly survey. Prices also edged up for the third month. (D1.) **********The Fed is considering proposals to increase the discount rate from its current level of 8.5 percent, analysts said over the weekend.  However, they said the central bank may defer such action to avoid a confrontation with Congress. (D1.) **********The Federal income tax system is drawing increasing criticism from taxpayers, members of Congress and intellectuals - but they remain far from united about what to do to improve it. (D4.) Companies **********Tiger International announced terms for its offer to exchange $112.5 million in debt for stock and warrants, as part of the refinancing agreement reached with lenders last week. (D3.) **********Three of six electrical contractors indicted on contract bid-rigging charges by a Federal grand jury in Pittsburgh on Saturday face earlier indictments involving nuclear plants in Washington.  (D5.) Markets **********The dollar rose sharply on world currency markets on the strength of an unexpected increase in the United States money supply. Gold prices were little changed. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.main_headline: TRAVEL AGENTS FACING AIRLINE COMMISSION RIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.print_headline: TRAVEL AGENTS FACING AIRLINE COMMISSION RIFT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/busin.body_text: **********The airline industry is in turmoil over how much to pay travel agents and corporate travel departments. More than $2 billion a year in commissions are at stake. **********On Wednesday, American Airlines notified more than 20,000 travel agents that beginning Sept. 19 it will cut commissions to 9 percent from the industry standard of 10 percent. **********Almost immediately, United Airlines and Continental Air Lines said they were reviewing their commissions. A decision on whether to make a similar cut is expected today. Spokesmen for Eastern and Delta said they, too, were reviewing agency commissions. **********More confusion, however, surrounds the fees paid to the travel departments within large corporations. These in-house departments book flights for employees traveling on company business. Industry sources said that in order to win more business as the economy recovers, airlines have worked out secret payment agreements - usually involving rebates or discount fares - with travel agents and corporations. **********The sources also said that the corporations themselves have worked out secret deals with travel agents. In retaliation, some airlines have said they will reduce or eliminate corporate commissions, which have been 3 percent. They said that the secret deals make planning difficult and hurt both airlines and travel agents. **********But Delta and Eastern, fearful that they could lose business because of the deals, went the other way, and raised corporate fees to 10 percent.  Trend Is Feared **********There is concern among airlines that Delta and Eastern's reasoning will prevail, and promote an industrywide trend that could lead to hundreds of millions of dollars a year in additional costs for an industry just recovering from the recession. **********''There is no justification for increasing the level of compensation for in-plant travel offices that are not open to the public, do not have to meet personnel standards, and which do not do advertising or sales development,'' said Randall Malin, an executive vice president for marketing at USAir, which last week cut corporate commissions to 2 percent. **********The search to find the right corporate commission began about 10 days ago, when Eastern announced it had uncovered cases of competitors' paying 10 percent to corporate travel departments, instead of the normal 3 percent. Eastern said that to be competitive it had no choice but to increase its rate to 10 percent. **********Delta, based in Atlanta, quickly followed suit. But USAir, based in Washington, called the increases a ''dangerous precedent'' and said it would lower its commission to 2 percent. **********Early this week, United said it would eliminate its corporate travel department commission. Both Continental and American announced yesterday that they did the same. **********At stake in the rift over commissions is billions of dollars a year, not to mention thousands of jobs and some lucrative corporate contracts between companies and travel agencies that often extend for years. **********The Air Transport Association of America, a Washington-based airline cooperative that supervises airline ticketing, estimated that the roughly 22,000 travel agencies nationwide handled $22 billion in airline tickets last year and collected $2.1 billion in commissions. Commissions, the association said, are 6.1 percent of airlines' total cash operating costs. Only labor and fuel are more costly. **********Although revenue and commission data for the roughly 500 big companies that have their own travel departments are unavailable, travel experts estimated they book about 5 percent of the $22 billion in tickets. **********Officials said that some companies have agreed to pay corporate travel departments the higher commissions if the corporations will fly with them. **********In other cases, airline executives said, full-service agencies have been given permission, in effect, to kick back part of their commission in return for promised business. **********And in other cases, they said, travel agencies and corporate travel departments have conspired against airlines in rebate schemes, agreeing to have the agency buy the ticket and earn a 10 percent commission. The agency and company then split the commission. 'Carpetbagger Agents' **********''There have been numerous case of carpetbagger agents going inside companies and setting up deals, stealing business from full-service travel agents and in some cases funneling commissions back to corporations,'' said Charles J. Kreinar, director of sales planning at USAir. ''Individuals doing this are cornering the corporate market. It is setting a dangerous precedent because it is triggering additional rebates and hurting full- service agents.'' **********Travel agent commissions have long been a politically charged issue. Last year agents protested when the Civil Aeronautics Board board ruled that they could not be the exclusive issuers of airline tickets. One effect of that ruling was that corporations, for the first time, could issue tickets without any support from agents. Traditionally, corporations have relied on agents for ticket validation. **********The travel agents, however, form the backbone of the airline distribution system, booking roughly two- thirds of all tickets sold. Some industry analysts said, therefore, that corporate commissions are being cut to appease regular agents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Lehman Loses Merger Officer **********Eric J. Gleacher, who helped found the mergers and acquisitions department at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. in 1978, has gone over to the competition at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Mr. Gleacher, 43 years old, will be one of six managing directors in Morgan's mergers and acquisitions department, which, he said, has 75 professionals and is the largest on Wall Street. **********For Mr. Gleacher, the Morgan position will be only his second career job. He joined Lehman Brothers 16 years ago after graduation from the University of Chicago business school. ''My only prior work experience was the U.S. Marine Corps,'' he said yesterday.

''Behind all those terrorist attacks there is the Soviet Union, working by proxy through Syria, which in turn manipulates the Palestine Liberation Organization,'' Mr. Sharon told reporters while on a visit here. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has resumed paying cash for imported grain after financing most purchases last year under short-term credit, United States Government and grain industry officials said today. **********They said they did not know for sure why Moscow had returned to its past policy as a cash buyer, but said the decision probably stemmed from the improved financial situation of the Soviet Union, the world's biggest grain importer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.body_text: **********Joshua Nkomo, the Zimbabwean opposition leader in exile here, said today that he would not return home in time to retain his parliamentary seat, which is being revoked because of his absence. The circumstances that made him fear for his life and flee last March 13 ''are still there,'' he said in a television interview. Even if he returns by next week's deadline, he said, he might not attend Parliament because he finds it ''appalling'' that it has done nothing about what he called Government troop brutality in his Matabeleland homeland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/04/busin.body_text: **********Saxon Industries said it had agreed to sell its Missisquoi division to the Boise Cascade Corporation for an undisclosed price. **********The division manufactures special grades of paperboard. The proposed transaction is subject to the approval of Federal Bankruptcy Court since Saxon is now operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. Saxon, which filed for reorganization last April, had said previously that it planned to restructure operations around its paper distribution and converting businesses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/10/busin.body_text: **********Clients of Epstein, Raboy Advertising began to learn yesterday that there would soon be a new man at the shop, none other than Shepard Kurnit, agency founder, corporate good citizen and frequently one of the voices of the industry's conscience. The 58-year-old executive will be leaving Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector, where he has been chairman, to fill a gap left by the death in December of Mitchell Epstein, chairman of Epstein, Raboy. **********Richard H. Raboy is president. Late yesterday the Calet, Hirsch shop announced that Neil Calet, Peter Hirsch and Larry Spector have bought out their former partner. C.H.K.& S. was formerly DKG Advertising (where Mr. Raboy was once copy chief), which stood for Delehanty, Kurnit & Geller. Although it never was a giant in billings, it has always had a formidable creat ve reputation. Shep Kurnit, as he is known thoughout the business, started as an art director and his first venture into entrepreneurship was with his own art studio. **********Epstein, Raboy bills about $25 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Beltran Corporation said an involuntary petition for Chapter 11 reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act had been filed against its Acton Foodservices Corporation subsidiary in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Massachusetts. **********Beltran said the unit would continue to operate. Acton lost $106,000 before taxes in the first six months of the 1983 fiscal year, on sales of $57 million. **********Beltran also reported earnings for the second quarter ended March 31 of $198,000, compared with a $148,000 loss in the 1982 period.  Revenues dropped to $42.5 million, from $79.1 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/world.body_text: **********Melina Mercouri, the Greek Minister of Culture, brought her campaign for the recovery of the 2,400-year-old Elgin marbles to Britain today. **********''I thought that, before the official demand was made, the English should be aware that this is a moral issue between two friendly countries,'' the former actress said in an interview before informal talks with British officials, including Lord Belstead, minister of state in the Foreign Office. **********The Greek Government decided last week to ask Britain to return the marbles, which were taken from the Parthenon by an English aristocrat and have been displayed at the British Museum for 170 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/world.main_headline: SPANISH UNITE AGAINST TERRORISM AND FOR A VICTIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/world.print_headline: SPANISH UNITE AGAINST TERRORISM AND FOR A VICTIM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/22/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of thousands of people marched through the streets here tonight in a silent demonstration to protest the death of an army captain kidnapped and killed by Basque guerrillas. **********Simultaneous demonstrations occurred in cities throughout the country as up to a million people took to the streets. In Madrid, members of all political parties united behind a banner opposing E.T.A., the Basque guerrilla organization. It read, ''Against Terrorism, Against E.T.A., For Freedom, For Peace, For Spain and Its Constitution.'' The police estimated the number of demonstrators in Madrid varied from 300,000 to 500,000 people. **********Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez did not attend the demonstration. A spokesman said he was monitoring developments throughout the country. Deputy Prime Minister Alfonso Guerra led the march in his place.   A Reminder to the Army **********The nationwide demonstrations against terrorism and in support of democracy and the Spanish Constitution were widely seen here as a reminder to the army, which was enraged by the murder of the officer, that the people of Spain support their elected Government. **********The march ended a national day of protest. At noon, factories, businesses, schools and hospitals throughout Spain observed a minute of silence to honor the captain, a pharmacist. In some cities, cars and buses stopped and people stood silently with heads bowed. Immediately afterward, the nation's drugstores closed for two hours. **********A similar demonstration is planned Saturday in the Basque city of Bilbao. Two contending factions decided to march together, and a large turnout is expected. They came together Thursday night after the terrorists took another victim, a 50-year-old baker they accused of being a police informer. **********On Thursday the Socialist Government announced plans to station more policemen in the Basque region and to consider tougher penalties for terrorist activity. The slain military officer was Alberto Martin Barrios, a 39-year-old father of three.   The Kidnappers' Demands **********Captain Martin Barrios was seized Oct. 5 on his way to work by a small faction of the E.T.A. called the Eighth Assembly of the group's political-military wing. He was the 33d person killed by Basque terrorists this year. He is the 37th military officer to have been killed since 1970 and the first to have been kidnapped. **********The kidnappers demanded the release of nine guerrillas facing court- martial in Catalonia for a 1980 attack on a garrison near Barcelona. A few days later they also demanded that an E.T.A. communique condemning the trial be read over state-owned national television. The Government rejected both demands. **********Faced with a 36-hour deadline to broadcast the communique and with the frantic pleas of Captain Martin Barrios's family, many major newspapers printed the communique. The state television broadcast a short resume of it and promised to broadcast all of it when the captain was released. **********The deadline passed without word from the Eighth Assembly. On Wednesday morning, responding to a phone call, Red Cross workers went to the outskirts of Bilbao were they found the body in an abandoned cabin. He had been gagged and shot in the head at close range. He had several days growth of beard, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.main_headline: U.S. SEEMS TO BE TARGET OF NEW STRAIN OF TERROR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.print_headline: U.S. SEEMS TO BE TARGET OF NEW STRAIN OF TERROR
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that this mornings's truck-bomb attack against the United States Embassy in Kuwait appeared to be linked to recent warnings of possible terrorist strikes against American installations here and aboard. **********Those warnings, which intelligence agencies began to report last month, led to increased security at the White House and the State Department. **********The officials said that the attack in Kuwait seemed to be confirmation that the United States has become the leading target for a new strain of terrorism in the Middle East. **********The attack, they said, was almost identical to terrorist strikes earlier this year against the American Embassy in Beirut and United States Marine headquarters in Lebanon. **********'Some Kind of Threshold' **********A truck bomb exploded outside the embassy in Beirut in April, killing 63 people, including 17 Americans. On Oct. 23, a Mercedes truck carrying explosives crashed into the Marine headquarters at Beirut International Airport, killing 240 American servicemen. **********''Many of us,'' a senior intelligence official said, ''have the feeling that we have crossed some kind of threshold and have become the primary target for terrorists in the Middle East.'' **********In today's attack, officials said, a Mercedes truck packed with explosives crashed through the main gate of the American Embassy compound and detonated outside an embassy annex, destroying that building and causing extensive damage to other offices. **********Intelligence officials said there appeared to be a pattern to the suicide attacks in the Middle East that suggests they are being coordinated by Moslem groups, but the officials said there was no hard evidence to support that theory. **********Administration security officials said today that additional defenses against terrorist attacks, particularly truck bombs, might be needed at Government buildings.   Defenses Had Been Improved **********State Department officials said that the Embassy in Kuwait increased security in recent months after receiving threats, but that the improved defenses were ineffective today against the fast- moving truck that smashed through an entrance gate and speeded past armed guards before it exploded 50 yards inside the American compound. **********Alan D. Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said the embassy ''tried to take appropriate security precautions, especially in the aftermath of the recent bombings in Beirut.'' He declined to discuss specific security improvements. **********He added, however, that ''embassies by their nature must be accessible to the public and cannot be made into armed fortresses.'' **********''This limits the type of protective measures that can be taken,'' he said. **********The use of large, bomb-laden trucks represents a major change in terrorist tactics in the Middle East, intelligence officials said. If the attacks are coordinated and supported by government authorities, the officials said, the danger is even greater. **********Reagan Administration officials have said there is some evidence to suggest that Iran and Syria are providing assistance to terrorist groups and may have helped plan the attacks in Lebanon earlier this year. **********Last week, President Reagan told a group of political supporters that as many as 1,000 terrorists, many from Iran, were available in Lebanon to conduct suicide-bombing attacks. **********Mr. Reagan, according to White House officials, said, ''We have information right now that they have marshaled a force, particularly of Iranians in Lebanon, that numbers up to 1,000 who are willing to sacrifice their lives in a kamikaze attack.''  A Different Phenomenon **********A senior Administration official, referring to the suicide attacks, said, ''It's a different kind of phenomenon, because even in the height of the P.L.O.'s terrorist activities, they didn't really have people in one-way missions.'' **********The official added: ''This is very serious, and difficult to deal with. There's very little you can do, other than to try to have the best intelligence possible.'' **********Other Administration officials said the most ominous thing about the new terrorist tactics was that they appear to have been coordinated to some extent by foreign governments as an instrument of policy. **********''It's very different from having terrorist groups operating on their own,'' one intelligence official said. ''When you link terrorism to the resources of a government, the possibilities are frightening.'' **********Intelligence reports received several days before Thanksgiving warned that a pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem group in Lebanon, called the Islamic Amal, appeared to be preparing for terrorist attacks against United States installations in the Middle East and possibly Washington, intelligence officials said. **********Administration officials have accused the group of involvement in the attacks against the American Embassy and the Marines in Beirut. **********When the reports were received, entrances to the White House were blocked by dump trucks loaded with sand, and driveways leading to the State Department garage were filled with cars and trucks. Permanent cement barriers were later installed outside some White House entrances. **********Administration officials confirmed today that the White House is protected by surface-to-air missiles capable of shooting down suspicious aircraft flying toward the Executive Mansion, but they refused to say whether the air- defense system was recently installed or has been in place for some time.
