https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/05/busin.body_text: **********The big spender who thrived on borrowed money has turned into a loser. His opposite, the conservative saver who for years watched his nest egg being nibbled away by inflation, suddenly is a winner. There are other losers, too: poor people, small businesses and homeowners. And there are many winners: travelers, money market funds and people seeking greater convenience. **********The tables have been turned by the many ways that banking has been deregulated, with many usury laws eliminated and most Federal restraints removed on what commercial banks and savings institutions may pay on small deposits. Although deregulation is far from complete, it already has affected virtually everyone. **********As a result of deregulation of interest rates, individuals and small businesses have received an estimated $40 billion more than they would have earned from ordinary passbook savings accounts, on which banks were not allowed to pay more than 5 1/4 percent and thrift 5 1/2 percent. This has sharply increased the institutions' cost of funds. **********Small bankers complain that rate deregulation has come so fast that adjusting to it is difficult.  ''A lot of banks were hurt because, slam-bang, $400 billion moved out of low-yielding accounts in one year,'' said Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents small banks. **********Most bigger banks, however, seek broader powers. They want to enter the insurance business and underwrite tax-exempt bonds and even corporate securities. Savings banks and savings and loan associations have already been allowed to perform many new services, such as accepting making commercial loans. **********The services that commercial banks may offer have not been expanded substantially, but they have moved into some fields - such as stock brokerage - that they avoided in the past. **********Here is a tally of who has won and lost so far: **********The Losers **********SMALL BUSINESSES. Because banks now must pay higher interest rates on consumer deposits, they have increased the interest rates they charge on loans. In the past, many local businesses and farmers had been insulated from rising interest rates in the general economy because their banks could recycle low-cost savings deposits. **********LOW-BALANCE DEPOSITORS. The cost of most bank services has risen sharply. For individuals with large balances, the increased interest they get offsets the higher fees and interest rates that banks are charging. But for people with relatively low balances, the increases in bank charges has been greater than the increase in interest earned. They may represent as much as four-fifths of the population.  POOR PEOPLE. The poorest people are faring the worst. Many, if not most, banks have imposed monthly or quarterly fees on savings accounts with small balances. For example, the Dime Savings Bank of New York charges $1 a month on any passbook savings account with less than $500. So a family with $100 in such an account would wind up the year with only $88 of principal. The reason for the imposition of this fee, and sharp increases in many other fees, such as for money orders, is to offset the increased costs of consumer deposits. **********HOME BUYERS. Partly as a result of deregulation, it has become far more expensive, and more risky, to buy a home. Without assurance of low-cost money, financial institutions have become less and less willing to make long-term, fixed-rate mortgages. Instead, they are asking home buyers to accept floating-rate mortgages or to pay premiums for fixed- rate loans. Even though low-cost deposits have now all but disappeared, banks still must support their high-overhead branch networks, which were established to attract such deposits. **********AGGRESSIVE BANKS. Some economists argue that the higher cost of deposits has prompted many banks to make riskier loans to earn higher returns. If too many of those loans turn sour, some banks could end up with severe problems. **********OLD-LINE INDUSTRIES. As banks enter new fields, such as stock brokerage, they pose new competition for companies that traditionally have been in that area. And banks often have the important advantage of being able to raise money more cheaply in the national money markets. **********BANK EMPLOYEES. The higher cost of running a bank has forced most banks to cut costs and streamline their businesses. As a result, banks across the country have been reducing their staffs. **********The Winners **********HIGH-BALANCE DEPOSITORS. The most dramatic result so far of financial deregulation has been the higher rates of interest available to individuals and small businesses. **********MONEY FUNDS. Money market mutual funds, operated by securities firms and never subject to Government interest restraints, gave the public an alternative to the regulated banks. Because these money funds were draining hundreds of billions of dollars from the banking system, the banking industry and its regulators were forced to deregulate interest rates far more quickly than they preferred. **********BUYERS OF FINANCIAL SERVICES. As more institutions are allowed to offer a broader range of services, increased competition should prove a boon to consumers. In some areas, this already has driven interest rates on deposits higher. In addition, the entry of banks into the discount brokerage business has made it easier for individuals to shop for lower-cost brokerage services. **********CONVENIENCE SEEKERS. Deregulation can make banking more convenient by making it possible for individuals to do all their financial shopping at one ''store.'' And as deregulation proceeds, consumers may be able sit in their homes and shop for specific services across the nation via electronics. **********BANK EMPLOYEES. Although deregulation is displacing many workers from such routine jobs as tellers, it is also opening more interesting jobs. Many employees are getting an opportunity to develop more challenging skills, involving such technologies as automation and communications. **********TRAVELERS. A growing number of states, such as those in New England, have passed laws permitting regional interestate banking. In response, banks in one state have been buying banks in other states. Thus, a customer of a bank in, say, Boston, would be able to do business with affiliated banks throughout New England.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.main_headline: TURKEY PUTS QUAKE DEATH TOLL AT 980
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.print_headline: TURKEY PUTS QUAKE DEATH TOLL AT 980
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.body_text: **********Turkey's martial law command said today that the death toll in an earthquake that struck this eastern region near the Soviet border Sunday had reached nearly 1,000. **********The command announced a death toll tonight of 980; final figures were expected Tuesday. **********Meanwhile, President Kenan Everen toured the region as Turkish Army units and relief workers, aided by a team of Swiss dogs, dug in the rubble of several villages for more victims. **********Because a landslide had cut the road, General Evren was unable to visit Koyunoren Koy, where 126 people reportedly died. But he stopped at another badly damaged village, Koprukoy. **********Horasan township, a farming and grazing area 50 miles east of Erzurum, was the most severely hit area, with 17 villages badly damaged. In two villages, Muratbag and Kizlarkale, the death toll reached nearly 400.   A Report on the Losses **********General Evren listened with apparent concern to a report by the military command on the losses of Horasan township. **********There was no casualty total because it was said that all the deaths were not known. But the report said 17 percent of the housing in the area of 50,000 inhabitants was damaged and 7,000 new houses were needed. Equally important for local inhabitants was the loss of 46 percent of their livestock. **********The army seemed to have the situation well in hand. Military convoys have distributed food, medicine, blankets and tents to most of the needy villages in the area.   'We Cannot Recover the Lives' **********President Evren told a crowd at Narman, north of here, that relief was coming from all over the country. The state radio broadcast an official appeal today for blood donors. **********''We will replace all your material losses, but we cannot recover the lives,'' he said, adding, ''Would to God it will not happen again.'' **********A local official said it was the worst earthquake to hit the Erzurum area since 1952. **********Some Turkish journalists expressed concern that the tragedy would happen again because of the way local houses are built with heavy stones coated with mud and roofops made of mud. **********In the village of Sekerli, 300 of 500 houses were badly damaged, with many stone walls flattened. Yet the mosque and several modern concrete houses remained intact. **********''We were afraid to spend the night in our home because the ground moved again last night,'' a woman said as she pointed to cracks in the walls of her home. **********Outside, men dug stakes into the black mud for new white tents donated by Red Crescent, the equivalent of the Red Cross. The villagers said they had only 50 tents and more were needed. **********One obstacle to the relief operation is the early winter weather. Last night heavy snows covered the mountains, cutting off some villages. **********Many people refused to spend the night in their homes, preferring the open air. Few villagers could be seen fleeing the area, however. **********On the main squares and along the highway where General Evren traveled, men with grim faces held umbrellas and waited. When the President arrived, they cheered him, seemingly putting aside the tragedy. **********Only rarely were clusters of women seen with bundles of household goods and children waiting along the road for someone to take them somewhere. **********U.S. Offers Relief Aid **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) - The White House announced today thagt the United States had offered emergency relief assistance to Turkey. The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, said Turkey had made no specific aid request.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/world.main_headline: U.S. BIDS GEMAYEL BROADEN HIS BASE TO UNIFY LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/world.print_headline: U.S. BIDS GEMAYEL BROADEN HIS BASE TO UNIFY LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/02/world.body_text: **********The United States today urged President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon to widen his political base and to extend his army's control in the south. He was told that those steps could help persuade Syria to join Israel in withdrawing troops from Lebanon. **********Mr. Gemayel was also told, a senior official said, that the United States had ''no magical wand'' to bring about the withdrawal and that it was up to the Lebanese Government to act. **********The Lebanese President was asked to be as forthcoming as possible in bringing opposition leaders into the Government and in dealing directly with Israel in expanding the Lebanese Army's presence in the Israeli-occupied south, the official said. **********Measures Aimed at Syria **********In talks with President Reagan, Vice President Bush and Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mr. Gemayel was told that only in this way could he show the strength needed to convince the Syrians that it was in their interest to work out a formula for withdrawal. **********Violence continued in Lebanon today,and a Druse religious leader was slain at his home in Beirut by an unidentified gunman. The Lebanese Army extended the nightly curfew and said violators would be shot. (Page A8.) **********In Amman, Jordan, King Hussein said he was prepared to resume talks with Yasir Arafat on a joint Jordanian- Palestinian approach to negotiations with Israel on the future of the West Bank and Gaza. (Page A9.) Gemayel Seeks U.S. Backing **********When Mr. Gemayel arrived here on Wednesday, his aides said he needed American help to persuade Israel to alter the terms of its agreement of May 17 with Lebanon on the terms for an Israeli troop withdrawal in conjunction with a Syrian withdrawal. **********Syria and its supporters in Lebanon have called for abrogation or substantial revision of the agreement. Israel has refused to alter it and today Mr. Reagan affirmed his commitment to the accord as it stands. **********Mr. Gemayel said after meeting with Mr. Reagan that they were exploring ''going beyond the letter of the law to set up the most appropriate mechanism and conditions for the achievement of our common interests and policy objectives.'' This was a day with little optimism shown by Americans and Lebanese. The senior American official said in a briefing, ''There is a long way to go and both sides approach the situation without euphoria.'' The United States, he said, does not have ''a grand plan, a magical wand that will be waved to get the May 17 agreement implemented.'' **********''There has to be a series of steps,'' he added, ''some ways worked out, a major part of which is going to be the demonstration by the Lebanese Government that it has confidence in itself, the confidence of its people and of its army, to start moving into the unoccupied areas and to the occupied areas of the country.'' **********The unoccupied areas are the Shuf Mountains southeast of Beirut, where the Lebanese Army clashed in September with the Druse inhabitants. The reference to the occupied areas was to Israeli-occupied southern Lebanon. **********The senior official said that, as a result of talks here with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, the Israelis were ready to discuss giving the Lebanese some responsibility in the south. **********The United States and Israel agreed, one American official said, that the Gemayel Government was too passive and had not paid enough attention to the complaints of the opposition. **********The Druse and Shiite Moslem factions are under Syrian influence, and the official said that, if the Gemayel Government were to make an effort to offer them a significant role, it would be a test of whether Syria was interested in ''settling for half a loaf'' in Lebanon or wanted simply ''the whole loaf.'' **********Lebanese unity talks in Geneva in early November ended with the decision that President Gemayel should visit various countries to seek alterations in the Israeli withdrawal agreement, which is opposed by Syria because it gives certain concessions to Israel in return for withdrawal. **********But Mr. Reagan said today after his meeting with Mr. Gemayel: **********''We stand by the May 17 agreement as the best and most viable basis for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon.'' **********Without mentioning Syria, he added, ''And once again, I appeal to the other external forces to leave Lebanon.'' **********Addressing Mr. Gemayel on the subject of Lebanese unity, Mr. Reagan said: **********''Your efforts to broaden the base of your Government, bringing in Lebanon's many communities, will do much to rebuild a stable and prosperous Lebanon. It will do much to restore confidence in the future. It will do much to stop the loss of so many innocent lives.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/busin.body_text: **********Eastern European nations, badly in need of export revenue to repay their $73.5 billion debt, are losing the battle for markets in industrialized Western nations to aggressive competitors from the developing nations of Asia and Latin America, according to experts attending a conference here on East-West economic ties. **********The participants agreed that only a revival of exports to Western countries could earn the Eastern bloc the hard, or convertible, currency it needs to repay even part of its debt. And the consensus was that prospects for such growth remained gloomy. **********Some representatives, mainly from Eastern bloc countries, said repayment of the debt is now secondary to the revival of the region's trade necessary for a full-scale recovery of the world economy. **********'The Main Problem' **********''The main problem,'' said Jozef Pajestka, director of the Institute of Economic Science at the Polish Academy of Sciences, ''is that the indebted nations cannot repay their debts even if they starve themselves to death.'' **********Mr. Pajestka disclosed the results of a study by Polish economists showing that a moratorium on repayment of Poland's foreign debt until 1990 would increase the amount it owes the West to $61 billion from about $27 billion today. **********With annual export earnings projected to increase to about $8 billion, the study's authors said repayment of what Poland owes would be virtually impossible. **********Asked whether Poland considered refusing repayment, to use export earnings to pay for imports of raw materials and semi-finished products its industry badly needs, Mr. Pajestka replied, ''Whoever refuses payment first will be punished severely to set an example. No, we will go on paying, even if it's only a few cents of the interest.'' Relaxation Seen **********The two-day conference, sponsored by the Vienna Institute for Comparative Economic Studies, to mark the institute's 10th anniversary, ended Thursday. The meeting coincided with what some experts viewed as a gradual relaxation of the Reagan Administration's resistance to increased trade with the Eastern bloc. **********That is reflected in the recent visit of Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block to Moscow to conclude a grain agreement; the granting of an export license for construction equipment to the Caterpillar Tractor Company, and a decision not to invoke economic sanctions to punish Moscow for the downing of a Korean airliner. **********Despite Poland's huge payments difficulties, representatives from several countries in the East and West said a recovery of Eastern Europe's trade balance last year opened the prospects for a gradual resumption of bank credits. **********Noting that Eastern bloc countries achieved a hard currency trade surplus for the first time since the late 1960's, albeit by drastically reducing their imports, Professor Friedrich Levcik, the Institute's director, said the ''adjustment process is well under way.'' Down From $77.1 Billion **********Indeed, the surplus meant the Eastern bloc could cut its cumulative hard currency debt to $73.5 billion from a peak of $77.1 billion in 1981, Professor Levcik said, as four countries - the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, East Germany and Rumania - reduced their foreign debt burdens, and Hungary and Czechoslovakia halted the growth of theirs. **********Allen J. Lenz, director of the Commerce Department's Office of Trade and Investment Analysis, said a recent Commerce Department study of the relative competitiveness of Eastern bloc countries on Western industrialized markets showed that ''East European export performance has not been particularly impressive over the past several years.'' **********Mr. Lenz said calculations of the Eastern European share of the imports of 14 leading Western industrial countries from 1975 to 1981 showed that Eastern Europe's market share declined in 22 of 30 non-oil product groups, including clothing, organic chemicals and furniture. **********By contrast, 10 of the biggest debtor nations in the developing world, including Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and Yugoslavia, expanded their market shares in 23 of the 30 product groups. Excluding Poland from the study, he said, did not markedly improve the picture. The Soviet Union, the group leader, demonstrated little skill in broadening its exports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.main_headline: THRIFT INSTITUTIONS EXTENDING ROLE AS EQUITY PARTNERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; THRIFT INSTITUTIONS EXTENDING ROLE AS EQUITY PARTNERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.body_text: **********As the state and Federal governments relax banking regulations, allowing thrift institutions to broaden their activities, the shift has had an indirect effect on real estate development. **********As mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations start to offer more attractive accounts to their depositors, as well as to increase the amount of their assets used for investment purposes, their growing involvement as equity partners in real estate development is getting a boost. **********''Equity participation in real estate projects by mutual savings banks is not an entirely new phenomenon,'' said Richard Pokriefke, a spokesman for the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. But, he added, the new law ''has given mutual savings banks more freedom to look for ways to improve their earnings and capital positions.'' **********State banking regulations stipulate that savings banks may invest no more than 5 percent of their assets, while committing the other 95 percent to loans, especially mortgages. But a law passed in April allows the thrift institutions to invest an additional 3 percent through their service corporations. Thus, savings and loan associations have assumed a broader role as equity partners in development projects. **********''It is an investment area that is getting a lot of attention,'' said William Foley of the New York League of Savings Institutions.  He added that savings and loan associations had been involved in real estate equity participation since 1978 through the Thrift Association Service Corporation. **********While the league has no figures that show in detail how many savings banks had invested how much money as equity partners, Mr.  Foley said the range of this participation covered both commercial and residential projects in primary construction financing, rehabilitation and land development. **********In Mr. Foley's view, the lender is probably the most important link in the chain of events that make a real estate deal happen. But when they are restricted to being mortgage lenders, he said, banks are not receiving the maximum benefit for their part in the deal. ''Equity participation gives them a bigger piece of the pie,'' he said. **********The joint venture announced recently by the Bowery Savings Bank and the Georgetown Group, a privately held, diversified real estate consulting and investment company headed by Marshall Rose, illustrates the scope of the commitment being made by some thrift institutions as equity investors. Mr. Rose is the former president of the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation. **********In a 10-year partnership, the Bowery will provide the capital and the Georgetown Group will provide the real estate knowledge. The Bowery, through its BSB Venture Corporation, has committed $100 million for projects in the metropolitian area, primarily for the purchase of existing underutilized properties for development and resale. **********The venture is not Bowery's first as an equity participant in real estate projects, nor is it its first venture with the Georgetown Group, said Ellis T. Gravette, chairman of the Bowery. ''But through this partnership, we are expanding our activites in this area and we will be involved in not just one but a series of real estate ventures in an ongoing way for 10 years or more.'' **********Mr. Rose has acted as real estate development consultant for the Bowery in recent years. He was president of Arlen, the parent company of Korvette Stores, in the 1970's. **********The partnership's first investments in the city were the purchases of buildings in the Madison Square Park area at 141 Fifth Avenue, on the southeast corner of 21st Street, and at 880 Broadway, on the southeast corner of 19th Street. **********The Fifth Avenue building is a 13-story structure with about 110,000 feet of rentable space. The Broadway building, with six floors, has 90,000 square feet of rentable space. Both are loft buildings that will be upgraded for office use, Mr. Rose said, and designed to appeal particularly to advertising agencies, graphic artists and other businesses that need flexibility in space planning. **********''We are excited about the potential of the Madison Square area,'' he said. ''It is a cross between midtown and Soho, and the various new residential and commercial development projects have made it one of the most interesting new neighborhoods in Manhattan.'' **********The Bowery has also formed equity partnerships with real estate concerns in the Southwest and in the Southeast, Mr. Gravette said.  These ventures will focus on land development, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.main_headline: Mrs. Gandhi Says India Does Not Have the Bomb
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Mrs. Gandhi Says India Does Not Have the Bomb
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India does not possess the atomic bomb but is going ahead with a nuclear development program for peaceful purposes. **********''I hope you are all aware that our nuclear program is prompted not by military objectives but by developmental necessity,'' Mrs. Gandhi said at the opening session of the World Energy Conference. **********''We are opposed to nuclear weapons and do not have any.'' **********India exploded an atomic device in 1974, setting off fears of a nuclear race with Pakistan. Pakistan has denied rumors it is developing an atomic weapon with the help of Arab countries. **********The energy conference drew delegations from 70 countries. In addition, representatives were sent from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the World Bank, the European Economic Commission, the International Monetary Fund and the International Atomic Energy Agency.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.main_headline: 4,000 PALESTINIANS EVACUATE TRIPOLI ON GREEK VESSELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.print_headline: 4,000 PALESTINIANS EVACUATE TRIPOLI ON GREEK VESSELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/world.body_text: **********Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, sailed from this northern Lebanese port today in a white-hulled Greek ferry escorted by French naval vessels.  In all, five Greek ships took about 4,000 Arafat loyalists away from Tripoli, the second evacuation of P.L.O. fighters from Lebanon in 16 months. **********Mr. Arafat, who had been under siege for six weeks by Syrian-backed dissidents within the P.L.O., left without a farewell message to sympathizers or a final public appearance. He was heading for exile, probably in Tunisia, as a guerrilla chieftain without a battlefront for his followers to contest. **********Final Act in P.L.O. Rebellion **********Arab analysts said the evacuation of Mr. Arafat in effect represented the final act of a Syrian-backed rebellion that has stripped away his uncontested position as the leader of a united Palestinian movement. **********Volley after volley from automatic rifles and rocket-propelled grenades echoed and crashed around Tripoli's battered harbor as the Palestinian guerrillas and their Lebanese Moslem allies bade a traditional, cacophonous farewell to one another. The firing into the air went on for about two hours.  The volleys reached a climax at Mr. Arafat's departure and, in individual cases, when television cameras were focused on the guerrillas. But the Palestinian leader, still officially the chairman of the P.L.O., did not venture from a heavily guarded white station wagon until the huge stern door of the Odysseas Elytis had closed on him. **********Revolt Started in May **********The rebellion against Mr. Arafat started in May when middle-ranking officers in his organization, Al Fatah, the biggest of the Palestinian groups, accused him of favoritism in the appointment of field commanders and of other abuses. The rift followed serious political infighting within Palestinian ranks over what was seen as Mr. Arafat's preference for negotiation rather than armed struggle against Israel. **********As the revolt widened, Arafat loyalists were pushed back from strongholds in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, and this port became their last redoubt. Today, it also became a symbol of Syrian and rebel success in forcing Mr. Arafat to abandon his last toehold in a country bordering Israel and to acknowledge his loss of control of the majority of Palestinian forces. **********The bulk of Mr. Arafat's once-loyal guerrillas are based in Syria and Lebanon and are believed to total 10,000, vastly outnumbering Mr. Arafat's men. **********Second Pullout in 16 Months **********Mr. Arafat's first pullout from Lebanon occurred 16 months ago, on Aug. 30, 1982, after the Israelis invaded the country and forced the P.L.O. leader to leave Beirut. He left then with a veneer of honor and victory painted over his departure, arguing that his forces had triumphed by withstanding an Israeli onslaught without collapsing. **********The departure today had no such overtones of celebration. Some of Mr. Arafat's fighters expressed bitterness that this time it had been an Arab nation and fellow Palestinians who forced the involuntary departure, not Israel.   'Fighters, Not Tourists' ''We feel very bitter because of the Arab tyrants,'' one guerrilla said. ''We have been treated unjustly. We are fighters, not tourists to travel around in ships. My correct position is not in Sudan or Yemen or Tunis, it is near Palestine. But the Arabs do not want us to take up our true position.'' **********Another guerrilla, who gave his name as Abdul Malik Mohammed, said: ''They want us to drop our guns, but a political revolution will not solve our problems. The Arab nation wants to take Palestinians' own decision. They want to kill us. We are very angry, each of us. It is very bad and miserable.'' **********A third combatant, Abdul Bari, a Moslem from Bangladesh, said: ''We are being forced. Now we have nowhere to fight.'' **********In the evacuation last year, the Palestinian guerrillas were not allowed to take their families with them. This time, 500 noncombatants joined the exodus, creating sometimes incongruous scenes.   Diapers and AK-47's **********Along the dockside, pummelled by recent Israeli naval bombardments, one Palestinian escorted his family, carrying an AK-47 rifle in one hand and a plastic-wrapped pack of baby's diapers in the other. **********Women in olive green drabs, rifles slung over their shoulders, clutched feeding bottles and babies in blue jump suits.  In one pile of belongings waiting for shipment, a toddler had been seated against a pile of blankets, framed by a rocket launcher and a light machine-gun, as if irrevocably ensnared in the Middle East's cyclical violence. **********Other families faced different destinies. At the dockside, as the air filled with the persistent, ear-splitting crackle of rifle fire, a woman sat alone and wept, gazing at the vessel transporting her husband. Her son, about 5 years old, was sitting by her side on a low wall. He took one look at her and, barely old enough to understand fully the cause of the tears, he cried, too. **********The Palestinians still under Mr. Arafat's leadership are traveling to destinations including Yemen, Algeria, Tunisia, the Sudan and possibly Iraq. The dispersal further weakens Mr. Arafat's position, Arab political analysts said, despite the publicity surrounding his departure. **********''Arafat has now been cut off from the main fighting force of the guerrillas,'' one analyst said, ''He is also away from any front near Palestine. It is virtual exile.''  'A Kind of Legitimacy' **********The analyst pointed out, however, that Mr. Arafat is still the legitimate chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********''That gives him a kind of legitimacy, without military power,'' the analyst said. ''In the Arab context, what counts is who controls the military, not popularity or legitimacy or anything else.'' **********By this argument, the rebels under Col. Saed Musa have yet to establish themselves as a valid alternative, and so both sides will now seek to lay claim to credentials - Mr. Arafat by a political and diplomatic rear-guard action, the rebels by their firepower. **********Israeli warplanes circled over Tripoli today, drawing occasional and ineffective antiaircraft fire as the evacuation got under way, but there was no repetition of the Israeli naval bombardments on Palestinian positions that had gone on for the previous 10 days.   French Stand Guard **********The French escort of the Greek vessels, reportedly numbering five corvettes and the aircraft carrier Clemenceau, apparently accompanied the Greek vessels as a deterrent to further Israeli naval action. The French provided the naval escort at Greece's request. French planes took to the air from the Clemenceau to guard the evacuation. **********The Greek vessels, chartered by the P.L.O. at a reported cost of $2.5 million, flew the United Nations flag as they entered the port. Once the ships moored, Palestinian guerrillas hoisted their own green, white, red and black banner alongside that of the world body.   Lebanese Inherit Heavy Weapons **********In negotiations before his departure, Mr. Arafat agreed to leave his heavy weapons behind. Some weapons seem to have been smuggled aboard the Greek vessels, but most of the heavy equipment apparently fell into the hands of his Lebanese allies, a Moslem fundamentalist group called the Islamic Unification Movement. Now that the Palestinians have left Tripoli, a prevalent view is that fighting will at some stage resume among the nine factions in the city, some of which receive Syrian support. **********The Palestinians did not leave entirely as paupers. Along with their AK- 47 rifles, they took with them trucks, jeeps, Mercedes sedans, bottled water, suitcases full of clothes, attache cases, ammunition, beds, blanket rolls, tenting equipment, bananas and tangerines.   Portraits of Arafat **********The Palestinians who arrived at the port bore tiny portraits of Mr. Arafat encased in clear plastic around their necks. Some also wore similar emblems in the shape of Israel, with Mr. Arafat's face imposed on it. While their relationship with the Lebanese Moslem militiamen seemed cordial, the attitude of the Lebanese police at the port was less friendly. **********As the firing reached a particular crescendo and Palestinian guerrillas waved V-for-victory sings that did not reflect their plight, one Lebanese policeman turned to a colleague, shrugged and made a circular movement with his index finger by his forehead, a universal gesture depicting insanity. **********There were curiosities. One of the vessls transporting the Palestinians, the Vergina, was owned, according to Lloyd's Register in London, by the Israeli Government from 1964 to 1976, when it was named the Dan.   Fighting Ends for a Briton **********Among the departing guerrillas was an unlikely fighter for the Palestinian cause, a 26-year-old British carpenter who said he enlisted ''partly out of ideological conviction'' with Al Fatah five weeks ago. He received makeshift basic training in the fighting around Tripoli and now found himself on his way to an uncertain future in Yemen. **********Wearing a black and white headdress, an AK-47 rifle slung around his neck, the Briton, Ian Davison of South Shields in northeast England, said he wanted to fight Israel for a year or two and then return home to England.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Southwest Bancshares and the Mercantile Texas Corporation asked the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to halt trading in their shares, amid rumors of a merger between the two Texas banks. **********The companies said separately that they had requested a halt in trading pending an announcement. **********Both banks said they expected to make an announcement this afternoon. **********Securities analysts said that a merger appeared likely. Because Mercantile Texas is concentrated in Dallas, and Southwest Bancshares is in the Houston area, a merger ''would make for a strong organization in two of the major Texas markets,'' said Sandy Flanagan, a banking analyst with Rotan Mosely in Houston. **********Mercantile Texas is a bank holding company whose lead bank is the Mercantile National Bank of Dallas, the fifth-largest bank in Texas.  The company also owns 26 other Texas banks and nonbanking subsidiaries. Total assets last year were $10.2 billion. **********Southwest Bancshares is a holding company that owns Bank of the Southwest, the sixth largest in Texas. It also owns 35 smaller banks. Total assets are $7.1 billion. **********Before trading was halted, Southwest Bancshares had jumped $2.50, to $27.125, and Mercantile Texas had fallen $1.125, to $30.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/busin.main_headline: Sheraton Officer Gets Howard Johnson Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Sheraton Officer Gets Howard Johnson Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The Howard Johnson Company has named Manuel M. Ferris, a Sheraton executive, to the newly formed position of president of its hotel group. **********Mr. Ferris, who is 50 years old, has been president of the North American division for the Sheraton Corporation, which is a unit of the ITT Corporation. **********Howard Johnson has embarked on a big hotel expansion and Mr. Ferris is ''critical to it,'' said G. Michael Hostage, Howard Johnson's chairman and president, adding, ''He will play a major role in our aggressive expansion into larger full-service hotel properties.'' **********These full-service hotels are not typical of Howard Johnson. They will have more meeting rooms and other business amenities. One will be opening Aug. 9 in Westborough, Mass., and it will be a four-story beige structure - with no orange roof. **********Mr. Ferris, who was vacationing yesterday, was responsible for Sheraton's extensive growth over the last few years, the Howard Johnson statement said. He joined Sheraton in 1971 as a regional sales manager. **********Before that, Mr. Ferris was with the Hotel Corporation of America, now the Sonesta International Hotels Corporation, as general manager of several properties and general sales manager of the company. He is a graduate of Boston University and its business school. **********Howard Johnson, a unit of the Imperial Group of Britain, operates 500 hotels and motor lodges in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico. It is based in Braintree, Mass.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/06/busin.body_text: **********New York State's spring borrowing, traditionally the nation's largest single tax-exempt financing, will be managed by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, investment bankers said yesterday. State officials said the note sale, scheduled for mid-April, will total nearly $4 billion. **********In recent years, the job of managing the dozens of firms that will underwrite the state's borrowing has been rotated. Citibank managed underwriters for the $3.5 billion financing in 1982. Merrill Lynch had this job in 1981 and Salomon Brothers in 1980. **********New York State sells several billion dollars worth of notes in the second quarter of every calendar year because that is when it spends about 40 percent of its budget, but receives only 20 percent of its revenues. The temporary cash shortage is bridged by selling tax and revenue anticipation notes that mature over periods ranging from a few months to a year. **********The spring financing is separate from a $500 million sale of 11-month notes to finance this year's budget deficit. This offering is tentatively scheduled for the week of Jan. 17.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/11/world.body_text: **********Rebel forces battled for seven hours over the weekend with the civil defense force here and put to death members of the local militia, according to several residents of this town in southern El Salvador. **********In all, 13 members of the civil defense force and 2 civilians were killed in the battle, which started at 10 P.M. on Thursday and continued until early Friday, the residents said. **********The rebels' Radio Venceremos said eight men had been put to death after the attack in Nueva Granada. It said they had been killed because they belonged to a paramilitary death squad. Residents, on the other hand, put the number slain at five. **********In the past, the guerrillas have occasionally killed civil defense members who were unpopular with the townspeople. However, a woman who lives near the Nueva Granada town square said these five men were not unpopular. **********Nueva Granada, an agricultural town of about 6,000, is in the northern corner of Usulutan, a southern province of El Salvador where the military launched a major offensive last week. Most of the Special to the New York Times military's estimated 4,000 troops are based in southern Usulutan. Military and Civic Program **********The offensive is part of the country's National Plan, a combined military and civic program to clear Usulutan and the neighboring province of San Vicente of guerrilla base camps. According to the plan, which first began in San Vicente a month ago and only recently started in Usulutan, once the provinces are considered secure, the Government will start large-scale economic development programs. **********Despite a distance of only 20 miles between Nueva Granada and a town where troops are based, military reinforcements did not arrive in Nueva Granada until 10 A.M. on Friday, or after the rebels had left with a mortar and several cases of ammunition, according to the residents. The reinforcements left the same afternoon. **********When reporters arrived at the town on Saturday afternoon, some of the residents were waiting on the edge of town, afraid that the rebels were returning. ''Don't go any further because they are in there,'' said a peasant wearing a bright yellow shirt and carrying a machette. **********A young man who lives on a corner of the town square near a trench used by the civil defense forces said the battle had been long and fierce.  ''There were hundreds of them'' he said. ''There was not much we could do.'' **********The man, who said he was a driver, asked that his name not be used because he was on a ''list'' and that the guerrillas would kill him the next time they returned. **********The driver and several other residents said the guerrillas had captured five members of the civil defense militia, tied their hands behind their backs and killed them on the corner of the road that leads out of the city. The other men, he and the other residents said, were killed in battle. **********Oscar Cruz, one of the residents of the town, said: ''Five were killed together. The others were killed in fighting.'' Others confirmed the account. Guerrilla Communiques Found **********One member of the civil defense force, who seemed to be in a daze, said the civil guards were ''overwhelmed'' by the rebels. The young man spent five hours hiding from the rebels in a latrine. ''I had to to save my life,'' he said. **********Communiques calling on the soldiers to desert were found in the town. They were similar to communiques left near the Quebrada Seca bridge in San Vicente, where the military has said that 42 soldiers were put to death after a battle on May 25. Such communiques were not found, however, in Cinquera, in the northern province of Cabanas, where military officers asserted that 14 members of the civil defense were slain by rebels earlier that month. **********Before these incidents, the insurgents had made a practice of taking and releasing prisoners, and the three reports of prisoners being put to death could indicate that there has been a change in the rebels' strategy, according to Salvadoran military officials and American diplomats in El Salvador.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Stress on Growth At Bank of Boston **********The Bank of Boston Corporation, which made William L. Brown its chairman last January, has never been small potatoes. After doing business in Boston for 199 years, it ranks as the nation's 18th largest bank-holding company. ''We've always been dominant,'' the 61-year-old executive says, ''and New England has always had our first attention.'' **********Now, under Mr. Brown's leadership, the Boston-based holding company is growing faster than ever by acquiring banks in other New England states. It announced an agreement in principle on Tuesday to buy the RIHT Financial Corporation for $120 million. RIHT is the holding company of the Rhode Island Hospital Trust National Bank and the third largest bank holding company in Rhode Island. Within the past two months, the Bank of Boston has also reached agreements to buy smaller bank-holding companies in Connecticut and Maine. **********When all three acquisitions are completed, the Boston holding company will add slightly more than $4 billion to its current asset base of $18.7 billion, and will become the nation's 14th largest banking group. And will there be other acquisitions of New England banks? ''I certainly hope so,'' Mr. Brown says. **********Bank of Boston's swift expansion should not be attributed solely to some masterstroke by Mr. Brown, who served as president of the holding company for 12 years before being made chairman. During that period, he was credited with developing the bank's lucrative business in lending to high-technology companies scattered along Boston's Route 128. Mr. Brown, who has a master's degree in business administration from Harvard University, went to the work for the bank in 1949. **********The acquisition of banks in neighboring states has been made possible by a change in Massachusetts law that allows interstate banking on a reciprocal basis with other New England states. That means Bank of Boston can buy banks in other New England states that allow their banks to acquire lending institutions in Massachusetts. **********This regional bias, Mr. Brown said, will eventually change. ''I'm certain interstate banking will come,'' he added, referring to the long-conjectured changes in Federal law that would break down all barriers to interstate banking nationwide. ''It is not a question of if, but when.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/13/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Communist party newspaper Pravda has rejected the possibility of combining American proposals with aspects of Yuri V. Andropov's latest offer to produce an accord on reducing medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe. **********In an editorial prepared for publication in Friday's issue, Pravda noted that President Reagan had pledged to give serious study to the offer Mr. Andropov put forward last week. The paper said this appeared to mean that the United States would like to ''adapt'' the central aspect of the Soviet proposal, a readiness to use warheads as well as the number of missile launchers as the basic accounting units, to the existing American offer. **********''A negative answer can be given to this question right away,'' Pravda said.  It said that the Soviet and American offers at the Geneva talks on reductions of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe were incompatible. **********''These are mutually exclusive things,'' it said. ''All this is perfectly understood in Washington, although they make believe that they are going to look for solutions at the negotiating table.  Another farce intended to take in the naive is being staged.'' **********The editorial, which was taken as an authoritative reflection of Kremlin views, was distributed in advance by the press agency Tass.  It offered a gloomy assessment of the Geneva talks, which resume Tuesday after a recess. Not a Millimeter Closer **********It called the situation ''far from heartening'' and said the two sides had not drawn closer ''even by a millimeter'' in the year and half of talks. **********''There is a chance to reach agreement in Geneva because there is an objective basis for it,'' the paper said.  It contended that the United States had blocked progress because it did not want an accord that would prevent the deployment of 572 Pershing-2 and cruise missiles, set to begin in Europe in December under a plan of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********The newspaper said that the United States delegation would be bringing as its ''luggage'' Mr. Reagan's so-called interim proposal, put forward in a speech on March 30. **********The American proposal calls for cuts in existing Soviet deployment and the planned American deployment to an equal but unspecified number of warheads. This would allow the United States to deploy at least some of its weapons, while requiring the Soviet Union to dismantle some of its 600 medium-range missiles, including 243 triple-warhead SS-20's. **********The Soviet position is that rough parity already exists between East and West in medium-range weapons and that the introduction of American missiles would upset the balance. **********Mr. Andropov, speaking at a Kremlin dinner last week, modified an earlier proposal for reductions in the medium-range weapons now deployed by the Soviet Union and the Atlantic alliance, meaning essentially the forces of Britain and France and the so-called forward-based medium-range planes of the United States. **********He said Moscow was prepared to count not only the numbers of medium-range missiles and planes capable of delivering nuclear warheads, but the number of warheads themselves. U.S. Favors Counting Warheads **********Although the United States now also favors using numbers of warheads as a measure, it insists that the British and French missiles represent national forces that are not part of the alliance arsenal and therefore not a topic for discussion in the Geneva talks. **********The cautious welcome that Mr. Andropov's proposal received in Washington was described by Pravda as an attempt ''to delude the gullible'' into thinking that the United States was interested in an accommodation. **********The newspaper said that ''the essence of the approach adopted by the United States and NATO regrettably remains the same'' since the Western alliance continued to reject the inclusion of British and French forces in the count. **********As long as Washington holds to this stand, Pravda said, ''naturally no solution of this question is possible.'' In addition, Pravda cited American insistence on a global accord that would include deployments in the Asian part of the Soviet Union as well as in Europe. **********''The question of reductions in Soviet missiles in the Asian part of the U.S.S.R. is again being dragged into the talks, although it has no relation at all to the subject,'' the paper said. **********Pravda reiterated earlier warnings that the introduction of American medium-range missiles into Western Europe would set off a ''chain reaction'' of countermeasures by the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies. The measures were not specified.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.main_headline: TURKISH CYPRIOT LEADER: RAUL RAIF DENKTASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; TURKISH CYPRIOT LEADER: RAUL RAIF DENKTASH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.body_text: **********Rauf Denktash has been the virtually uncontested leader of the Turkish Cypriots on Cyprus for 20 years. Thus it probably was no surprise to radio listeners on the eastern Mediterranean island to hear his voice proclaim the establishment yesterday of an independent Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus.  In a recent interview with a Turkish newspaper, Mr. Denktash had said that ''the Greek Cypriot is the legitimate party in the eyes of the world and Turkish Cypriots are not to be their equals.'' **********''This is a view we must destroy,'' he declared. ''We shall be equal to them.'' **********It was Mr. Denktash who, in February of 1975, proclaimed a Turkish Federated State of Cyprus and then went on to win a landslide victory the next year in an election for the presidency of the autonomous Turkish Cypriot administration that was the predecessor of the newly declared republic. **********The only nation to recognize that administration was Turkey, and again yesterday it was Turkey alone that moved to recognize the new entity on the troubled island.   A 'Charismatic Conservative' **********Mr. Denktash, a stocky, bald man who was once described as a ''charismatic conservative,'' had moved into a commanding position among Turkish Cypriots, who are vastly outnumbered by Greek Cypriots, even before Cyprus won its independence from Britain in 1960. **********But his emergence as the dominant leader did not come until an attempt in 1963 by the Greek Cypriot leadership under Archbishop Makarios to change the island's delicately balanced Constitution led to violence between the two ethnic groups. **********United Nations forces moved in to keep the peace and a ''green line'' was established to separate the relatively modest area then held by the ethnic Turks from the far larger area held by the Greek Cypriots. That division held until 1974 when Turkey, responding to a coup supported by Athens that temporarily deposed President Makarios, invaded the island and seized 40 percent of its territory. **********Over the last two decades, Mr. Denktash, who is now 59 years old, has served as the principal negotiator for the Turkish Cypriots in the talks with a series of Greek Cypriot leaders that took place on the island, in Western Europe and at the United Nations to find a solution to the situation. But nothing worked.   Negotiated With Old Friend **********One of the Greek Cypriot leaders with whom Mr. Denktash spent many hours in negotiation in the decade before the Turkish invasion was Glafkos Clerides. The two men had grown up together during the British colonial days and remained good friends even after the island became divided. **********Mr. Denktash frequently observed that Mr. Clerides was ''a fair-minded man'' but he insisted that President Makarios, deeply distrusted by the Turkish Cypriots, would sabotage any agreement that the two old friends might achieve. Archbishop Makarios died in 1977 and Spyros Kyprianou succeeded him as President. **********Mr. Denktash, who does not have the same warm relationship with Mr. Kyprianou, is said to feel that he is more than equal as a political leader to the Greek Cypriot President. **********Rauf Raif Denktash was born in Paphos, in southwestern Cyprus, on Jan. 27, 1924, a son of a judge. After attending the English School in Nicosia, the island's capital, he won a scholarship and studied law at Lincoln's Inn in London. He was admitted to the bar there in 1947. **********Mr. Denktash was married in 1949 to the daughter of a Turkish Cypriot pharmacist in Nicosia. They have two sons and twin daughters.   Served in British Administration **********After years of practicing law in Nicosia, he became a crown counsel and then acting solicitor general of Cyprus under British rule. In 1957 he resigned as solicitor general to concentrate on working for the survival of the Turkish Cypriot identity in the political turmoil and violence that preceded independence for the island. **********When he left the British Government's service, Mr. Denktash became chairman of the Federation of Turkish Associations on the island. With independence for Cyprus, he became president of the Turkish communal chamber in Cyprus's Parliament. **********Amid the violence that tore the populace apart in December of 1963, Mr. Denktash and the other Turkish Cypriot ministers withdrew from the Government. However, despite the island's division, Mr. Denktash later was re-elected as the head of the Turkish chamber and since 1973 has served as Vice President of Cyprus, although both positions are largely nominal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/world.main_headline: REAGAN CERTIFIES SALVADOR FOR AID: HAILS PROGRESS DESPITE 'OBSTACLES'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/world.print_headline: REAGAN CERTIFIES SALVADOR FOR AID: HAILS PROGRESS DESPITE 'OBSTACLES'
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/22/world.body_text: **********President Reagan certified to Congress today that despite ''great obstacles'' El Salvador was not only making progress on human rights but was also laying the foundation for democratic government. **********Such a certification on progress in human, political and economic rights in El Salvador is required every six months as a condition for continuing military aid to that country. At stake is $25 million in military aid Congress has approved for this fiscal year, but the Administration may seek an increase later this year, officials said. **********The 67-page report sent to Congress this afternoon ''describes the beginning of a process of building democratic structures and principles,'' the report said. **********'It Is Progress Nonetheless' **********''The situation is not perfect and the progress was not as great as desired,'' the document continued. ''But it is progress nonetheless.'' **********The certification was expected, and several human rights groups and critics of the Administration's policy criticized the decision even before the report was issued. **********The report said that ''despite great obstacles, many still beyond its immediate control, the Government of El Salvador has made progress'' in each of the areas specified in the 1981 law that mandated certification. ''No major reverses were registered'' in El Salvador's commitment to progress on human rights, the report said. **********The report acknowleged, however, that ''human rights abuses continue'' and that ''further development of democracy and the protection of human rights are not to be taken for granted.'' **********Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, and Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, stressed two areas of concern as they outlined the report's conclusions. **********They cited first what the report called the ''systematic ineffectiveness of El Salvador's criminal justice procedures, particularly in cases originating in political violence,'' and second the ''need for further improvement in military discipline, which must be strengthened within individual security force units on a nationwide basis.'' **********Mr. Enders cited El Salvador's release of two Salvadoran officers implicated in the murder of two American land redistribution consultants in January 1981 as a key example of the failure of that country's criminal justice system. **********But he said that there had been significant progress in efforts to prosecute the accused murderers of four American churchwomen in El Salvador in December 1980. **********This assertion was challenged by Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, who has acted as a link with the slain women's families. Tonight she called the certification an ''outrage.'' **********The report noted that ''political violence continued to diminish - although at a slower rate than at the time of the previous certification.'' It attributed this to ''increased consciousness by the Government of the importance of more effective action on human rights, including formation of new institutions for this purpose.'' **********Specifically, the document said civilian deaths due to political violence had fallen from 800 a month in late 1980 to 200 a month in the last six months of 1982. But the report noted that the rate of decline in the country has slowed in the past six months. 'Slow Progress' Noted **********When asked about higher death estimates presented by some human rights organizations, Mr. Enders replied that the higher figures included deaths of guerrillas and others insurgents killed in fighting. By contrast, the Administration's figures, based largely on embassy surveys of deaths reported in four daily newspapers, were limited to civilians whose deaths were attributed to political violence. **********The Administration also maintained that ''efforts to control abuses by members of the armed forces were the subject of increased attention by the Government of El Salvador'' and continued to show ''slow progress.'' **********For example, the document said the Salvadoran armed forces maintain that 80 percent of about 33,000 active duty personnel in the military and security forces have received human rights instructions from the International Committee of the Red Cross. **********The Administration said the redistribution of farmland to peasants, a program whose future was in doubt during the previous certification period, was ''vigorously relaunched.'' More than 20 percent of El Salvador's farmland has been redistributed to 65,000 peasants, the report said. Report Signed by Shultz **********Finally, it cited progress in the nation's effort to establish democratic structures. ''The process rooted in the March 1982 Constituent Assembly elections proved resistant to minority or individual efforts at manipulation,'' the report concluded. **********The report was based on interviews and information accumulated by American Embassy officials and by other State Department officials from the human rights and Latin American bureaus. It was then screened by an interagency group and signed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. **********The Administration's certification decision was swiftly denounced by several legislators and by civil liberties and human rights groups. The American Civil Liberties Union said in a statement that Salvadoran Government forces or paramilitary groups aligned with them were responsible for at least 5,339 political murders in the past year. **********''The number of reported and verified political murders demonstrates that the human rights situation is worse than ever,'' the A.C.L.U. and Americas Watch, a human rights group, concluded in a joint statement. ''Unmistakable physical evidence of torture, starvation and malnutrition'' were charged today by a team of seven American doctors and nurses who returned this week from a visit to El Salvador. The trip, sponsored by eight health groups, including the American Public Health Association, included tours of hospitals, clinics, prisons, and a refugee camp. **********The medical team, which visited the country two years ago, was attempting to investigate the disappearances of health workers and other reported abuses. They said they found a marked deterioration in conditions in El Salvador since their previous visit.   Salvador Hails Certification **********SAN SALVADOR, Jan. 21 (AP) -Salvadoran officials are pleased with the Reagan Administration's determination that it is making progress in curbing human rights abuses, a Government spokesman said today. **********''All Government officials have received news of the certification with much pleasure because it is consistent with the progress that has been made in our country, despite the abnormal situation,'' said a presidential spokesman, Alfonso Salazar, alluding to the civil war with leftist guerrillas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/busin.main_headline: BUYING A CAR ABROAD, AND OTHER MYTHS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/busin.print_headline: PERSONAL FINANCE; BUYING A CAR ABROAD, AND OTHER MYTHS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/11/busin.body_text: **********IT used to be a favored scheme among young **********Americans touring Europe: They would buy a **********car and drive it around for most of the summer, then ship it home and end up with a new foreign car for substantially less money than it would have cost from an American dealer. That is still an option for those seeking to save money on a foreign car, but the process has become much more complicated since the heyday of the Volkswagen Beetle. **********''Before 1973, shipping was relatively inexpensive,'' said Jean Gabella, assistant general manager of overseas sales for Renault U.S.A. But the energy crisis, which led to increases in both shipping costs and car prices, ''has changed the story,'' Mr. Gabella noted. It now costs $500 to $600 to ship a car from Western Europe to the United States. Moreover, marine insurance may add another $400 and customs duties $600 to the total. And these costs can increase substantially, since they are based on the price of the car. For these reasons, Mr. Gabella said, buying a car abroad does not really pay because ''there is very little savings for your average car buyer - if any at all - if the car costs less than $10,000.'' **********For more expensive cars, however, buying abroad can still mean savings. The disparity between the United States price and the European factory prices can be sizable, so transportation costs will eat up proportionately less of the savings. The Mercedes 190E, for example, which sells for about $23,000 here, can be bought in Germany for about $12,000, without air conditioning, sun roofs and all the other gadgets that are standard in the United States market. With those accessories, it is $19,100 at the factory in Germany. **********The trouble is, you cannot just walk into a foreign automobile showroom and plunk down your money. First of all, cars made for the domestic market in Japan and Britain are built for driving on the left side of the road. Moreover, if you ship a car to the United States, you will have to post bond to insure that you will modify the car to American standards for pollution-control and safety. **********If the car has a gasoline engine, that means you must install a catalytic converter and other pollution-control devices. You may also have to change the bumpers or the glass in order to meet American safety standards. These changes can cost several thousand dollars, offsetting the the cost savings of buying abroad. Moreover, the installations may also constrain the performance features that attracted you to the car in the first place. And your tampering with the engine will prompt the manufacturer to void the warranty. In addition, you may have problems getting certain parts in this country, since different engines are used in foreign cars marketed here than in the same cars sold in domestic markets abroad. **********If you really want to buy your car abroad, the way to do it, Mr. Gabella said, ''is to go to an authorized dealer in this country and place your order that way.'' Most of the European automobile manufacturers - but not the Japanese car makers - have ''direct purchase'' or ''tourist delivery'' programs. You can go to a dealer in the United States and put down a deposit on a car that will be produced abroad to your specifications. The car usually can be picked up at the factory four to six weeks later. **********THESE programs have taken on a bit of ritual. **********Mercedes-Benz, for example, provides those **********wishing to pick up their cars at the factory near Stuttgart with vouchers good for taxi rides from downtown to the plant. The company serves its customers breakfast or lunch at a special reception area and gives them a tour of the factory. Americans buy 3,000 Mercedes a year in this manner. And since many of them are auto buffs, according to Fred Chapman of Mercedes-Benz of North America, all this ''adds an extra dimension'' to their purchase. **********And it saves them money. The Mercedes 190E that is $23,000 at United States dealers can be picked up at the factory for about $19,100. The Mercedes 300SD, which sells for $39,500 in the United States, can be had at the factory gate for $32,800. Generally, the more expensive the car, the bigger the savings through this direct purchase plan. **********Volvo has a particularly attractive offering, the Volvo DL4A. The model can be bought in Sweden for $11,715, compared with $12,800 in the United States, and Volvo will pay the cost of shipping it to most American points. **********Even with free shipping, Herbert Levitt, sales manager of Volvo Freeport Ltd. of Long Island, said, ''Just going to Europe to buy a car is not the wisest thing to do.'' But it begins to make more economic sense, he noted, when an individual is planning a vacation in Europe. ''If you're going to rent a car and drive it around for a while,'' Mr. Levitt said, you can save a couple of hundred dollars a week by driving your own newly-purchased car instead. **********For those planning a vacation in Europe, Renault's Mr. Gabella pointed out that his company has a ''vacation-lease'' program that may enable the tourist to obtain use of a car for less than what rental agencies charge. In this program, a vacationer basically buys - through lease payments - a newly produced Renault in France, drives it, and then by prearrangement ''sells'' it to a Renault dealer, a procedure that has tax advantages for the French automobile industry, but does not reimburse the vacationer for his lease payments. That vacationer could obtain a Renault 5 GTL - sold as Le Car in the United States - for 22 days for about $490, or $769 for 30 days. The car is fully insured, is not subject to the 18.6 percent tax on rental cars, and can be returned to any of six major French cities. **********The mechanisms of buying, shipping and insuring a car overseas are well established. But the days when thrifty graduate students could think about getting a car on the cheap during a summer abroad are over. These days, buying a car in Europe makes sense only for those who can afford both a decidedly upscale car and a vacation abroad in the same year. **********Harvey D. Shapiro is a New York writer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/20/busin.body_text: **********After two days of decline, stock prices rose yesterday in moderate trading.  The Dow Jones industrial average, which had fallen 2.41 points on Monday and 12.02 on Friday, closed 7.22 higher yesterday, at 1,197.12, and the New York Stock Exchange index closed at 95.48, up 0.52. Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was 0.88 higher, to 164.83. Advancing stocks led declines, with 946 issues higher and 653 issues lower on volume of 74 million shares, up from 69.1 million. **********Explaining yesterday's price rise, Philip Roth, vice president and technical market analyst at E.F. Hutton & Company, said, ''Since the primary reason for the decline was the weak bond market, the stabilization and rally in the bond market yesterday was a reason for improvement in stocks.'' **********Robert D. Hill, senior vice president and portfolio manager at Chemical Bank, said prices edged higher because the ''anticipation of higher interest rates has been discounted.'' He added, ''Now people are looking at earnings developments and responding by buying the stocks with good earnings reports.''A.T.& T. Is Most Active **********The most active issue yesterday was American Telephone and Telegraph, which closed down 1/4, to 61 7/8. Analysts said investors are actively trading the issue as they rethink their position on the breakup of the company. **********Northern Indiana Public Service, another active issue, closed up 1/8, to 14. It is one of the utilities that analysts expect to have higher third-quarter earnings due to increased electrical use inspired by record high temperatures. **********Another active issue, Goodyear Tire, closed down 5/8, to 28 5/8. A block of 487,200 shares was crossed by Goldman, Sachs in a portfolio shift. **********General Instruments slid 4, to 44, after a brokerage firm analyst lowered the company's earnings outlook.  Pillsbury, which called off its bid to buy Stokely-Van Camp, closed up 1/2, to 56 5/8, and Stokely closed unchanged at 76 1/8. Quaker Oats, whose bid for Stokely topped Pillsbury's, closed up 1/8, to 45 1/4.Technology Strength **********Technology issues showed strength, with International Business Machines closing up 1, to 120 7/8. Data General, which announced that it would introduce a new computer system today, jumped 5 1/8, to 65 7/8. Honeywell closed 3 1/4 higher, at 117 3/4. **********The American Stock Exchange index closed up 1.59, to 240.71, on volume of 6.711 million. Advances numbered 328 and declines 275. The most active issue, Dataproducts, closed up 2 1/8, to 27, after the company announced that it had signed an agreement with 3M jointly to develop a nonimpact computer printer. **********The Nasdaq market index closed at 311.17, up 0.88.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/27/world.body_text: **********Former President Reynaldo B. Bignone has been forbidden to leave Argentina by a federal judge investigating the disappearance and presumed death of a man in 1978. **********General Bignone, a retired major general who stepped down from the presidency two weeks ago to end nearly eight years of military rule, was one of more than 20 retired police and army officers banned from leaving the country in telegrams sent out over the weekend by Judge Luis Cordoba of San Martin, a Buenos Aires suburb. **********General Bignone was the head of a military information group in the First Army Corps when the man, Alfredo A. Giorgi, a technician with the National Industrial Tehnology Institute, disappeared. **********General Bignone was indicted last week in a separate case involving the disappearances of two Communist draftees while under his command as head of a military college.
