https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.main_headline: COMPUTER ROUTE TO THE EXECUTIVE SUITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.print_headline: COMPUTER ROUTE TO THE EXECUTIVE SUITE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/27/jobs/.body_text: **********MARIO NIGRO is an exemplar for ambitious students of computers. He i s the senior vice president of operations at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, F enner & Smith Inc., the nation's largest brokerage firm. He sits on i ts board of directors and has more than 7,800 people in his charge a nd a spacious office on the 37th floor of One Liberty Plaza in l ower Manhattan. Mr. Nigro is, in fact, a paradigm for his p rofession - a one-time computer programmer who was able to break o ut of strict information processing and into high-level management o f a major corporation. **********The prospects for management-level jobs for computer programmers and systems analysts have, in the past, been limited almost entirely to computer departments. But this seems to be changing. As computers enter almost every corner of business, the executive with a broad grounding in the area will have more and more of an edge over his or her uninitiated colleague. Moreover, the explosion in demand for computer systems is creating a disproportionate number of new managerial positions in what is often called management information services, or M.I.S. **********''There are very few disciplines today in which you can go so high so fast as in M.I.S.,'' Mr. Nigro said. ''In other disciplines, such as marketing or sales, you typically have to go through a long series of steps in the hierarchy to get to a high level of management. Our data-processing department brings the stars up fairly quickly.'' **********Of the 50 highest managerial positions at Merrill Lynch, Mr. Nigro said, seven were currently occupied by those with a background in data processing. **********''M.I.S. people are recession-proof,'' said Peter J. Schementi, vice president for management information services at CBS Inc. ''I could not think of a more rewarding career. Its prospects are very strong.'' **********Mr. Schementi said CBS generally hired recent college graduates with majors in computer science and put them on a distinct career path. They begin by doing rudimentary programming on a project team, he said, ''and there we'll find out how technically able the person is.'' **********Sometimes after only a few months, the next step is to a position as systems analyst, who is more concerned about designing a computer system to meet the need of a specific application, such as revenueand profit-forecasting, than about detailed programming. This is often a crucial step, because as a systems analyst one gets direct exposure to a company's enterprises. And it is the person who knows a company's business best who gets ahead. **********The next level is that of a systems manager, who has the responsibility of developing new computer systems for business applications and has systems analysts as well as programmers reporting to him. **********''In a place like CBS, your M.I.S. people have to know the broadcasting and records business, and the more they know, the better your computer systems will be,'' Mr. Schementi said. ''Therefore, we do a lot of cross-fertilization, switching systems people from records to radio to the network to corporate.'' **********Studies by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics confirm the optimism of systems analysts and M.I.S. managers. In a recent study, the bureau projected that the number of systems analysts (including managers) employed in this nation by 1990 would be more than 70 percent above the levels of 1980. **********During the same period, overall employment was projected to grow only 20 percent, and all professional and technical employment to increase only 22 percent. According to the survey, demand for computer programmers will also be strong, although not so strong as the demand for systems analysts. The Labor Department forecasts employment growth among programmers will be more than 50 percent. **********''The area of systems analysts is one of the hottest occupations of the 1980's,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, New York regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''It's an area that will increase even more than all other computer occupations.'' He added that the demand had created a substantial shortage of systems analysts and that colleges ''were not turning out enough computerscience graduates.'' **********Stuart E. Madnick, a professor of management science at the Sloan School of Management of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, confirmed the need. ''There is a shortage of available systems analysts of about 25 percent,'' he said. ''There is more demand on the analyst level, and while programmers are relatively easy to train, an analyst can only get there with experience.'' **********Frank S. Beckman, chairman of the department of computer and information science at Brooklyn College, said that the biggest influx of students in his department's graduate program - almost 60 percent - consisted of those with degrees in fields other than computer science. ''The job opportunities are so much better in computing in spite of the recession,'' Professor Beckman said. ''They'll be exploding again as soon as we get out of this recession, because the explosion in hardware is so tremendous.'' **********With the increasing demand for systems analysts, salaries inevitably rise. Mr. Schementi said that a systems trainee at CBS earned $14,000 to $18,000 a year to start, and ''goes into six figures'' for those at the top levels. At Merrill Lynch, Mr. Nigro said, recent college graduates are paid about $22,500 a year, while experienced systems analysts get between $30,000 and $35,000. **********Not everyone is recommending that ambitious students begin in management information services.  ''I think we will see the real fast-trackers being put in charge of M.I.S. for a time on their way up,'' said Michael Treacy, assistant professor of management at the Sloan School. On the other hand, he added. ''top-notch M.I.S. people are hard to come by, and if you have one, why move him out of M.I.S. into operations?'' **********Mr. Treacy said, however, that in fields such as banking or brokerage, a company's operations were so closely tied to data processing that operations were often an extension of M.I.S. ''It would be harder to imagine an M.I.S. guy at Owens-Illinois running its bottle plant,'' he said. **********Mr. Nigro said that at Merrill Lynch there were two courses open for systems people: one for those who choose to be professional technicians for their entire careers and one for those using computer systems as a stepping-stone to management. ''As long as we compensate the professional programmers well and provide them with a good atmosphere, they are very happy,'' Mr. Nigro said. ''But for those aiming for management, they do not like a stable environment.  You have to give them an opportunity to move throughout the company and finally from systems into operations. The key is to make sure you allow for both, or else you lose a good technician and gain a poor manager.'' **********Mr. Nigro said he was impressed by the professionalism of computerscience college graduates. But at the same time, he said, Merrill Lynch is hiring graduates with liberal-arts backgrounds as long as they are ''bright.'' He added that Merrill's data-processing department hires between 30 and 40 people right out of college each year. **********But as to planning a career in corporate management that goes beyond the top levels of M.I.S., Mr. Nigro stressed the need to move outside of data processing into the company's core business, such as sales or marketing, by about age 30 to 32. ''The trap is that the person does not broaden his exposure before it is too late,'' Mr.  Nigro said. **********''We are going to see more M.I.S. people taken out of the pure M.I.S. function and placed in an operating unit in a core business responsibility,'' said Mr. Schementi of CBS. ''Finally, the smartest one will get to the top.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A DISGUISED 'BONANZA' FOR FARMERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A DISGUISED 'BONANZA' FOR FARMERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/04/busin.body_text: **********-making has **********long marked public policy for **********agriculture. Long ago Henry Wallace, the New Deal Secretary of Agriculture, was not satisfied just to put corn in bins. He had to have an Ever-Normal-Granary. **********When President Eisenhower sent food to hungry people abroad, as much to spare storage costs here as to help the starving in other countries, the show was embroidered as Food for Peace. **********John R. Block, the incumbent Secretary of Agriculture, found himself last winter with an over-accumulation of grain and cotton that he had helped bring about. He then joined the phrase-making crowd. To farmers who would sit out 1983, partially or wholly, he offered payment-in-kind, or PIK. The in-kind coinage was ingenious. The largess offered farmers was not to be ''dirty'' money but ''clean'' commodities. Some farmers would even get back the grain or cotton they had produced the year before. **********But the inventiveness did not end there. Mr. Block said that since the in-kind commodities were either in the Government's hands or due to find their way there, it would be costless to ship them back to farmers.  PIK was conceived not as farm aid but as ''in relief of John Block.'' Although bumper 1982 harvests and weak demand had made the oversupply worse, the Secretary's discomfiture in the winter of 1982-83 was to a large extent self-induced. Because his ideological belief in avoiding Government intervention set him against programs that reduced acreage and supported farm price, he had helped write a weak 1981 farm law and then chose to apply it flimsily in 1982. This was his first mistake. **********Trying to wiggle out of his bind, he then made his second mistake by overcorrecting the situation. He chose to be as generous in 1983 as he had been niggardly in 1982 by making the terms of PIK highly attractive. Farmers, liking gold in their teeth (though some were truly hard pressed financially) rushed to sign up. Many offered even more acreage than they were asked for. In all, Secretary Block accepted some 80 million idled acres under PIK, and in so doing converted the program from a Block bail-out to a farmers' bonanza. **********YET so much idled land risked **********damaging markets, especially **********in the case of drought, which in fact happened. Also, the size of the program swamped the local office staffs to such an extent that they could not effectively police whether farmers were protecting their idled land from erosion, which was part of the PIK agreement. **********The PIK experience teaches three lessons. First, in administration of an economic program, ideology must never be allowed to interfere with operational judgment. Any governmental commitment to underpin farmers' prices and incomes must be accompanied by effective governmental measures to keep production in bounds. Competence and brass knuckles, not ideological fervor, are needed. The more so because farmers, bless 'em, are masters at milking Government programs, and a Secretary of Agriculture must be a master at frustrating them. **********Before a second lesson is drawn, a caveat must be inserted in Secretary Block's defense. He did not write the 1981 farm law; Congress did. And he did not dream up the lax terms and generous promises (price support levels) of the 1982 program. Various farm leaders authored and promoted them. Mr. Block's sin was to listen. **********The second lesson applies to all farm law. Voluntary agricultural programs that control supplies will either be of limited effectiveness or exceedingly costly. Voluntary plans of the usual type (not PIK) will not reduce production very much because any rise in market prices benefits both participants and nonparticipants in the plan. The attraction of gambling on a free ride will always keep a sizable portion of farmers from taking part in a program. **********This shackling effect of the free rider syndrome can be offset only by offering farmers a nonshared emolument. In other words, an individualized payment. It can be in dollars or in-kind. This recourse will get bigger participation, as PIK did in 1983, but it will also increase cost to Government astronomically. **********A moral follows. At a time of big surplus, supply can be controlled effectively without incurrring excessive Government cost only by requiring farmers to accept mandatory controls on what they market. Farmers cannot expect henceforth to be paid as handsomely as they were in PIK of 1983, for taking action that is in their collective best interest anyway.  The third lesson is addressed to all future Secretaries of Agriculture. In charting a farm program course, an allowance must always be made for the fickleness of nature. Drought can come at any time. We veterans of the Washington farm scene have learned that lesson at least five times in the past 50 years. It's a shame that each new Administration, oblivious to farm program history, must learn it anew. **********Harold F. Breimyer, a professor of agricultural economics at the University of Missouri at Columbia, worked in the Department of Agriculture from 1936 to 1966.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/03/busin.main_headline: Finance Minister Keeps Japanese Budget Lean
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/03/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Finance Minister Keeps Japanese Budget Lean
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The way Japan decides on a national budget, as it did last week, is akin to an elaborate and grueling Kabuki play. This time, the man at center stage was Noboru Takeshita, Japan's Minister of Finance. **********In the last gasp of the budget-making exercise, Mr. Takeshita held court, as other Cabinet members trooped into his sitting room, bowed and explained at length why the commonweal would be imperiled if their ministries did not receive a few more yen than had been allotted the previous year. **********But Mr. Takeshita, who holds a black belt in judo, rarely budged.  On Thursday, the Cabinet approved a $216.2 billion budget for the fiscal year 1983, which begins April 1, just 1.4 percent more than the previous year. The increase is the smallest since 1955. **********In overseeing the crafting of such an austere spending program, Mr. Takeshita, who is 58, showed himself to be firmly in the conservative mainstream of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party on the issue of fiscal policy. Japan runs a large budget deficit in relation to total Government spending. One of the goals of the party's mainstream is to whittle down those deficits, which are running at more than $40 billion. **********Opponents both at home and abroad argue that, given Japan's high savings rate, it can fund current debts and more without fueling inflation. Thus, they believe Japan should give its economy a fiscal stimulus to increase growth, raise imports and ease trade frictions. **********Mr. Takeshita does not agree with this. In December, Mr. Takeshita said that to ''persevere'' in the budget-curbing endeavors was the only reasonable path. **********Mr. Takeshita's stance on fiscal policy is hardly surprising. He is leading member of his party's largest faction, led by Kakuei Tanaka, a former Prime Minister. He is widely acknowledged as one of the ''new leaders'' in the party, and a strong candidate to be prime minister in the next election in 1984. He has served in several key Government posts before, including a previous stint as Finance Minister, and has been elected to the lower house of Parliament nine times from his home district in Shimane Prefecture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.main_headline: CASHING IN ON THE NEW BUSINESS OF BANKING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.print_headline: CASHING IN ON THE NEW BUSINESS OF BANKING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.body_text: **********WEARING a bright red dress and fingering a long string of beads, Elaine R. Bond is not the typical banker. But what makes her different is not the brightness of her dress nor her sex, but what she does. For she neither makes loans nor takes deposits. She is an expert in computerization and communications. Her jargon is not that of a banker. It is that of a wizard in electronic communications. **********Before the 47-year-old Mrs. Bond joined Chase Manhattan in 1981, she had spent her career with International Business Machines. Now, as a senior vice president at Chase, she oversees the bank's use and programming of computers. About 120 professionals report to her directly, up 30 percent in the last two years. **********Mrs. Bond reflects the fact that banking has become so diversified that it is almost impossible to define a bank, let alone a banker. For banks are no longer organizations that sit back, take in deposits and make loans to businesses. Instead, they have become aggressive sellers, whether of loans, deposits, brokerage services or highly sophisticated electronic funds transfer services. **********A bank needs not only lending officers, tellers and bookkeepers, but all sorts of salesmen and technicians, ranging from specialists in telecommunications and computers, like Mrs. Bond, to those whose forte is taxes or direct-mail sales. **********This diversification has forced changes in hiring practices. It used to be that banks considered it a mark of failure to hire people from outside the institution. But today banks hardly have a choice, considering the diversity of their needs. **********''About half our staff was brought in from outside the bank,'' Mrs. Bond said. And of those that were recruited from other areas of the bank, ''all have come from the telecommunications community,'' she noted. Mrs. Bond predicted that demand would remain strong in banking for all sorts of technicians in electronics, especially for ''analysts who can help laymen become more self-sufficient in getting and submitting information.'' **********''The changes taking place in banking have opened up many job opportunities, away from the historic lines of their business,'' said John P. Lynch, vice president of Paul R. Ray & Company, a ''head-hunting'' firm. ''It's been especially apparent in the consumer-products area, where banks have been aggressively hiring people from companies like Procter & Gamble and major food-processing companies.'' **********Most analysts expect job demand, under way at all levels, to rise considerably for some time. A study of executive demand by Korn/Ferry International, a leading headhunting firm, found that since 1980 the financial-services industry had accounted for the largest demand for executives throughout the country. **********''The competition among financial-service companies is fiercer than ever with banking, insurance companies, savings and loans and brokerage houses all crossing over into one another's turfs,'' said Windle B. Priem, managing director of Korn/Ferry's financial-services division. **********''Our executive demand in that industry grew by 12 percent last year and we're beyond that in 1983. We expect the trend to carry over for the next three years,'' Mr. Priem said. He attributed it to decentralization by the large commercial banks, their diversification into new businesses and their expansion across the country.  Mr. Lynch of Ray & Company, who said the financial industry remained the best steppingstone toward a successful career (a recent survey by his firm showed that more than 22 percent of 300 top-paid executives in the nation began their careers in finance), said there was a growing awareness among banks and other financial institutions of the importance of marketing. **********This change reflects a totally new environment, where the banking business has become far more aggressive and competitive. Unlike the past, when banks considered it impolite to try to take a customer from another bank, competition is fierce today, not only among banks themselves, but between banks and other organizations that have been moving into the financial business. Some sectors of the financial industry itself have gained substantial new powers and suddenly are faced with the need to hire experts for which the institutions previously had no need. **********That has been the case for the thrift industry, which consists of savings banks and savings and loan associations. A law enacted last year gave them far broader powers. Before it was passed, the thrift institutions were largely confined to accepting savings deposits from individuals and making mortgage loans. Now, they are allowed to make commercial loans and take commercial deposits. As a result, there has been a great increase in in demand for commercial lending officers. In the last 14 months, for example, the Dollar-Dry Dock Savings Bank has hired 25 officers from commercial banks. **********Commercial banks, too, have been moving into new areas. David E. Dougherty, now 33, left the investment-banking firm of Kidder Peabody three years ago to join the Bankers Trust Company. He was hired to form a group designed to raise money for state and municipal governments and for corporations that are eligible to raise funds in the tax-exempt markets. **********Like most other major banks, for many years Bankers Trust had underwritten bond issues for tax-exempt organizations when these issues were sold at public auction. But Mr. Dougherty's job was to bring Bankers Trust into a new business of raising such money through privately negotiated transactions. And that had been the exclusive realm of the investment banks. ''It was an opportunity to start a new department,'' Mr. Dougherty said. **********IN the last three years, Mr. Dougherty, **********who is now senior vice president, has **********added 12 professionals to his staff, including a bond lawyer, a former finance director of Wilmington and a former executive director of the New York City Housing Development Corporation. **********''This is only the beginning,'' Mr. Dougherty said. ''By the end of this decade, all the major money center banks will have public-finance experts. It's an evolution that's already in progress.'' **********At the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, which has a large branch network, Irving Margol, executive vice president, said that ''10 years ago, we hardly cared what college graduates majored in, but today we're looking for people with a business or marketing background.'' **********''When we promote someone from within, through the management-training system,'' he said, ''we look for market-driven types - people who are interested in selling and cross-selling.'' **********Mr. Margol added that ''today, we have strategic planning and marketing departments that didn't exist 10 years ago.'' **********''We're also hiring product managers who typically would have gone to a Procter & Gamble or a consumer-product company,'' he said. ''We're developing new products. We're looking at our customer needs and designing and developing products. The product-development people manage a product through its introduction and, if there's a sales force necessary to support it, they become the sales force.'' **********Security Pacific, like most major banks, is owned by a holding company that operates throughout the country. The holding company is not subject to laws that prohibit banks from operating across states lines. Thus, through its holding company, Security Pacific Corporation, the company has a nationwide network of consumer- and commercial-finance companies. **********''The holding company is a new world,'' Mr. Margol said. ''We now have a discount-brokerage business, a venture-capital business, a mortgage-banking business and a leasing business,'' and ''close to 2,000 people in our data-processing business.'' **********The growing opportunities in the banking business may be illustrated by the following list of jobs at Citicorp, which did not offer them a decade ago: **********- Electronic mail manager, who trains employees to use electronic mail system. **********- Satellite communications specialist. The bank now owns its own transponders on a satellite. **********- Electronic banking account officers. They market cash-management system and electronic mail systems to outsiders. **********- Cash-management consultants, who consult with corporate treasurers around the world to help them manage their cash flow. **********- Credit scorers. These have developed complicated mathematical systems to determine individual creditworthiness. **********- Electronic data-processing auditors, who audit computer systems. **********- Telecommunications lawyer. **********- Systems analysts who developed automatic teller machines. **********- Sales representatives, comparable to account executives at securities firms, to manage an individual's personal assets. **********- Salesmen for at-home banking via television and computer. **********- Telephone salesmen for banking services outside New York State. **********- Director of information services, who markets sales of financial information. **********- Salesmen for selling time to the public on Citicorp computers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/25/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that his Government and military forces would allow no more unauthorized demonstrations. **********The President, in a speech on television, warned that his orders to the military would apply to businessmen and Roman Catholics as well as to Communists and radicals. **********Videotapes of Businessmen **********Mr. Marcos said the authorities had pictures and videotapes of businessmen ''in coats and ties'' breaking the law in recent demonstrations, and he warned that the police would track them down. **********Referring to a private meeting Friday with Jaime Cardinal Sin, the Archbishop of Manila, Mr. Marcos said he was ''not against'' the Cardinal's proposal of a broadly based advisory council that would lead the Philippines toward reconciliation. **********Mr. Marcos said in his 20-minute address from the presidential palace: ''Advisory? Why not? I will listen.'' He added, however, that ''the Government and the presidency'' would give up none of their powers. **********Cardinal Sin, the most popular and influential prelate in this largely Catholic country, is believed to have urged Mr. Marcos not only to agree to a powerful advisory council but also to hold free elections soon and to ease censorship of the press.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.print_headline: FINANCE NEW ISSUES; S.& P. Rating For SmithKline
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/03/busin.body_text: **********Standard & Poor's gave a preliminary AA-plus rating yesterday to SmithKline's $250 million of debt securities being issued under the shelf registration rule. **********The rating agency also raised to AA-plus from AA the rating on the company's outstanding $100 million of notes due in 1984. **********Standard & Poor's said that the high ratings reflected SmithKline's success with its Tagamet ulcer drug. At the same time, the rating agency said that the company's diversification into analytical instruments had reduced its reliance on Tagamet, which currently represents about a quarter of the company's sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.main_headline: SOVIET SAID TO ADD TROOPS IN CUBA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.print_headline: SOVIET SAID TO ADD TROOPS IN CUBA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.body_text: **********Senior Government officials said today that the Soviet Union had increased the number of its troops in Cuba in recent weeks. The move has confused and worried the Reagan Administration. **********The officials said that the number of troops had risen from 2,600 to 4,300, but that it was not known whether the additional forces were in Cuba to train alongside Cuban troops and then return home, to take part in a normal rotation of units, or to add permanently to the Soviet garrison. **********A Pentagon duty officer, when asked about the development, said, ''We don't have any comment.'' Whatever the mission of the Soviet forces, they would not appear to be a direct threat to the United States with its vastly superior air, naval and ground forces in the Caribbean. **********But the presence of the additional troops may increase tension in the region and cause new diplomatic anxieties for the Reagan Administration as it seeks to contain Soviet and Cuban influence in Central America. **********The report of additional troops comes as shipments of Soviet arms and supplies to Cuba continue at high levels and as new arms supplied by the Soviet Union have appeared in Nicaragua. **********It comes as the insurgents in El Salvador, backed by Nicaragua and Cuba, continue to harass the United States-supported Salvadoran Government. **********The report also comes as the Reagan Administration, after months of floundering in the formulation and execution of policy in Central America, has begun to reassign key officials here and in Central America. **********The Soviet ground unit, believed to be an infantry combat brigade, has been in Cuba since the time of the 1962 missile crisis. Its presence was a dormant issue until the summer of 1979 when President Carter said its continued presence in Cuba was unacceptable. His comment was largely ignored by Moscow. **********In addition to the ground forces, the Soviet Union has stationed several warships, including submarines, in Cuba from time to time.  Soviet bombers and reconnaissance planes frequently fly along the eastern seacoast of the United States on the way to and from Cuba.  Trawlers and other small ships that watch United States naval activity in the Atlantic and Caribbean also call at Cuban ports for fuel and supplies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********Four computer companies - NCR, Honeywell, Burroughs and Control Data - yesterday reported higher earnings for the third quarter, with NCR reporting record profits on strong orders. **********NCR Inc.'s net income jumped 40.1 percent, to $70.2 million, or $2.55 a share, from $50.1 million, or $1.87 a share, in the quarter a year before. Revenues increased 4.5 percent, to $878 million, from $840.1 million. **********Charles E. Exley Jr., president and chief executive officer of NCR, which has headquarters in Dayton, Ohio, said ''the surge in orders occurred in the company's major geographic markets - the United States, Europe and the Far East - and across all major product categories.'' Honeywell **********Honeywell Inc., based in Minneapolis, said earnings rose 33.3 percent, to $58.4 million, or $2.55 a share, from $43.8 million, or $1.96 a share, in 1982's third quarter. Revenues increased 4.5 percent, to $1.4 billion, from $1.34 billion. **********Edson Spencer, chairman and chief executive officer, said the company had benefited from cost savings in its information systems business, where the operating profit was up sharply. Burroughs **********The Burroughs Corporation reported that earnings advanced 15.5 percent, to $42.5 million, or $1.01 a share, from $36.8 million, or 87 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenues inreased 2 percent, to $1.04 billion, from $1.02 billion. **********W. Michael Blumenthal, chairman and chief executive officer of Burroughs, which is based in Detroit, said that ''while economic activity in the United States is gaining momentum, progress in the rest of the world is mixed.'' He added, ''The unexpectedly strong dollar continues to negatively impact our results.'' Control Data **********The Control Data Corporation, which has headquarters in Minneapolis, reported that earnings rose 4.9 percent, to $40.7 million, or $1.05 a share, from $38.8 million, or $1.03 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues rose 9.1 percent, to $1.2 billion, from $1.1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/world.body_text: **********A Hitler Anniversary Recalled at Reichstag **********WEST BERLIN, Jan. 30 (Reuters) - West German political leaders today marked the 50th anniversary of Hitler's accession to power with calls to learn from the past and warnings of current dangers facing the country. **********''We cannot and will not shirk our responsibility for the past,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl said at a gathering at the Reichstag building in West Berlin, once the site of the German Parliament. **********Mr. Kohl said the democratic parties had failed to counter Hitler, who became Chancellor on Jan. 30, 1933.  ''Too many shirked their responsibility for bitter truths and painful consequences,'' he said. ''The decay of power was first of all a decay in responsibility.'' **********''In the name of Germany, the face of humanity was shamed,'' he added. --- **********JERUSALEM, Jan. 30 (Reuters) -President Yitzhak Navon, at a ceremony marking the 50th anniversary of the Nazis' rise to power, called today for strengthening Israel, which he said ''represents all that Hitler tried to destroy.'' **********Mr. Navon made brief remarks at an emotional ceremony at the Yad Vashem memorial. ---- **********TEL AVIV, Jan. 30 (AP) - A grenade was thrown tonight at the West German Embassy here, causing no injuries but damaging a car parked outside the building, the police said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the attack.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.main_headline: 3 Group Vice Presidents Get Colgate Promotions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  3 Group Vice Presidents Get Colgate Promotions
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.body_text: **********The Colgate-Palmolive Company said yesterday that it had promoted three executives to executive vice president in a move it said was designed to broaden management. **********William S. Shanahan, 43, J. Dale Sherratt, 45, and John M. Watkins, 43, join Roderick L. Turner, 51, in the executive vice president ranks. **********The three previously held the title of group vice president. **********Mr. Shanahan and Mr. Sherratt will continue to report to Reuben Mark, Colgate's president and chief operating officer, and Mr. Watkins will continue to report to William W. Powell, senior executive vice president and chief development officer. **********Mr. Shanahan, who joined Colgate in 1965, has operational responsibilities for Colgate's worldwide business. Mr. Sherratt, a native of Canada who joined the company in 1962, is also president of the Kendall Company, a health-care and hospital- supply subsidiary. Mr. Watkins, a native of Britain, is in charge of global strategic and business development plans. He has been with Colgate since 1964.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/24/busin.body_text: **********The National Steel Corporation has reached a ''definitive agreement'' to sell its Weirton division to employees, which would create the largest employee-owned company in the nation, officials said. **********A Weirton spokesman, Chuck Cronin, said a ''full disclosure document'' summarizing the agreement had been mailed to mill workers, clearing the way for a vote next month on the proposal. **********Mr. Cronin said the document expands upon a tentative agreement between National Steel and its employees last March. That agreement called for the workers to buy the plant's fixed assets for $66 million, with an additional $200 million in liabilities to be paid off over 28 years. **********Once West Virginia's largest employer, with more than 12,000 employees, Weirton's work force has dropped to about 7,000 active workers, with another 3,000 on indefinite layoff. Although the tentative agreement was reached March 12, delays in putting the document together postponed scheduled votes in the past three months. **********National announced in March 1982 that it wanted to sell its Weirton division because it was only ''marginally profitable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/02/busin.body_text: **********T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, has agreed to pay Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb a $1 million fee - and possibly as much as $7.5 million - for advice in a proxy fight against the Gulf Oil Corporation, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed. A 15-page agreement disclosed that Mesa would pay the first $1 million as a retainer by next July. The rest would become due, among other reasons, if a group headed by Mr. Pickens makes a profit on a nearly 18-million-share block of Gulf stock it owns or if Mesa is taken over.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Sales of new cars by domestic auto makers rose by 21.1 percent in the first 10 days in December, the manufacturers reported today. **********The six major domestic manufacturers sold a total of 173,062 new cars in the Dec. 1-10 period. Last year sales totaled 142,895. There were nine selling days in the both periods. **********The seasonally adjusted annual selling rate was set at 7.3 million vehicles, up from 6.4 million at the same time in 1982 and even with the 7.3 million rate at the end of November. The daily selling rate rose to 19,229 units, from 15,877. **********David Healy, an automotive analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, said the sales period was ''remarkable for its lack of change'' over the last three months. ''There just is no real improvement in the sales rate over all even though production and inventory have picked up'' from the severe shortages of last summer, he said. **********Inventories Increase **********Inventories increased to a 55-day supply, from a 48-day stock early in November. There were shortages in some areas, notably in the better-selling, large car lines. The auto makers like to keep 55 to 60 days' supply on hand. **********Another analyst, Scott Merlis of Shearson/American Express, disagreed slightly with the immediate outlook for sales. ''We've been watching these 10-day sales more closely lately and while this is no surge, the level is still healthy,'' he said. ''There's no question that all is well with Detroit's recovery. We expect sales to be hitting the 7.5 million-and- over levels in the next few periods.'' **********An analyst at the Ford Motor Company agreed. ''Within the context of the current economic conditions, these are good, solid sales,'' the analyst said. ''They're not spectacular, but they're not bad for 1983.'' **********Ford showed the most improvement in the early December period, with sales of 45,230 new cars, up 29.3 percent from 34,971 last year. General Motors dealers delivered 101,004 units, up 19.4 percent from 84,620 a year ago. **********Chrysler Up 6 Percent **********Sales by the Chrysler Corporation rose 6 percent, from 18,303 in 1982 to 19,408 this year. The American Motors Corporation estimated it sold 4,200 cars, versus 3,400 last year, a 23.5 percent increase. Volkswagen of America's sales fell 28.7 percent on deliveries of 1,141 versus 1,601 in the 1982 period. The American Honda Motor Company, which began producing cars in this country this year, sold 2,079. **********In the Jan. 1-Dec. 10 period, with 290 selling days both years, G.M.'s sales of 3,832,040 were up 14.6 percent from 3,343,552 last year, and Ford sales of 1,477,114 were up 16.3 percent from 1,270,091. **********Chrysler sales increased 22.2 percent, to 793,129, from 649,052 units and A.M.C. sales jumped 77.5 percent, to 181,213, from 102,076. VW sales of 79,947 versus 86,734 last year were off 7.8 percent. American Honda sales totaled 37,175. Together, the six companies sold 6,400,618 new cars in the year to date, up 17.4 percent from 5,451,505 last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/20/busin.body_text: **********The Nuclear Regulatory Commission recommended today that Congress remove the limit on how much the nuclear industry might have to pay victims of an accident at a reactor. Current Federal law limits the liability to $570 million. **********The commission also proposed that individual nuclear plants be required to pay up to $10 million a year after an accident into the nationwide fund through which victims would be reimbursed. They currently may be asked to make a one-time payment of up to $5 million per accident into such a fund. **********The changes, the commission said, would help insure full compensation for victims, while making it less likely that the Federal Government would have to make contributions of its own. All five commissioners concurred in the recommendation. **********The Price-Anderson Act, which sets the $570 million liability limit, was enacted in 1957 as an amendment to the Atomic Energy Act. It was intended to address the threat to private investors of potentially enormous claims, and to provide an adequate pool of funds for victims of an accident. The act, twice renewed by Congress, expires in 1987. Debate on the issue is expected to start next year. **********The act's liability limit derives from a two-part system. Liability insurance of $160 million is purchased by utilities, a figure the commission said should be raised to $200 million to reflect inflation. The remaining $410 million of the liability limit would come from charging each of the 82 licensed nuclear plants a fee of up to $5 million to cover damages from an accident at any of the plants. **********The agency is suggesting that, to increase the level of coverage, each nuclear plant would be subject to an assessment of $10 million a year for as many years as necessary. **********Donald Winston, a spokesman for the Atomic Industrial Forum, the principal trade association for the nuclear industry, said: ''The industry is not particularly opposed to the change but we want to analyze how it would be paid for.'' **********Statute of Limitations **********The commission also recommended that the act's 20-year statute of limitations be extended to 30 years because of the risk of latent cancer. **********The Price-Anderson Act was invoked after the accident at the Three Mile Island reactor near Harrisburg, Pa., in March 1979. Claims totaling $29.5 million were paid to small businesses in the area and to pregnant women and their families who were urged to move, and for a post-accident health survey. **********Senator Gary Hart, a Democrat from Colorado and a critic of Price- Anderson, said in a statement that he was pleased that the nuclear agency had recommended removing the ceiling on liability. But, he argued, when utilities share the liability, there is less incentive to build safe nuclear plants.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/world.main_headline: TALKS BY SHULTZ AND BEGIN CENTER ON HADDAD'S MILITIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/world.print_headline: TALKS BY SHULTZ AND BEGIN CENTER ON HADDAD'S MILITIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/30/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin discussed with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today a possible compromise on the role of Maj. Saad Haddad, the southern Lebanese militia commander, Israeli and American officials said. Major Haddad's future has been one of the chief unresolved issues in the negotiations on an Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon. **********The officials said Mr. Shultz informed Mr. Begin that President Amin Gemayel and other Lebanese officials had told him on Thursday in Beirut that they would consider allowing Major Haddad to remain in southern Lebanon in a lesser role than that of overall commander of the forces that will be in control of the border region. **********A senior aide to the Israeli Prime Minister said that in the meeting with Mr. Begin, Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Moshe Arens, Mr. Shultz was given an Israeli response that is ''a kind of compromise, a shift on a limited point.'' He said that when the Secretary of State returns from transmitting this to the Lebanese on Saturday ''we might be able to find an agreed solution.'' **********The Israelis had been insisting that Major Haddad be allowed to remain in charge of the forces in the south, but today an Israeli Defense Ministry official said that what was important was that Major Haddad have a ''leadership role'' and be rewarded for his previous service as Israel's ally in blocking the Palestine Libertion Organization in the south of Lebanon. Both Sides Want Agreement **********This was the first day during Mr. Shultz's diplomatic shuttle in which he took the lead and did most of the talking, summarizing for Israeli leaders his views of each side's positions after his initial visits to both capitals. **********According to participants, Mr. Shultz said he was convinced that both Israel and Lebanon wanted an agreement, the first step toward the possible removal of Israeli, Syrian and P.L.O. forces from Lebanon. **********Participants in today's meetings said that Mr. Shultz told the Israelis that time was working against the parties and urged the Israelis to do what was necessary to find compromises with the Lebanese. **********The concern expressed by Mr. Shultz and also by Israelis and Lebanese in recent days is that Syria, heavily rearmed by the Soviet Union, might refuse to go along with its previous pledge to withdraw its forces if the Israelis did the same. Suggests Syria Might Renege **********A senior Israeli official said that there had been reports from Damascus suggesting that Syria would refuse to withdraw if Lebanon signed any accord with Israel calling for an end to the state of war or for regulating commerce and security matters, issues now close to agreement. **********There were also some sharp disagreements during the day, officials said. A senior Defense Ministry official said the United States ''has played a less than positive role'' by encouraging the Lebanese to believe they can handle the security questions in southern Lebanon through cooperation with the United States and not in close collaboration with Israel. **********The official stressed that Israel had to be satisfied with the security arrangements in southern Lebanon for any accord to be achieved and that Israel did not believe the Lebanese forces alone could guarantee that security. **********American officials, in their briefing, repeated their concern that Lebanese sovereignty be insured and strengthened, and their confidence that the Lebanese Army, now being retrained by American military officers, was capable of maintaining the security in southern Lebanon by itself. Disagree on Supervisory Roles **********Lebanon and Israel have agreed on the setting up of joint supervisory teams in southern Lebanon, but have different views on their roles. Mr. Shultz told the Israelis that the Lebanese believe the teams should be limited to inspecting compliance of the agreement, and if the teams detect any possible terrorists should call in Lebanese forces. **********Maj. Gen. Ehud Barak, Israel's military chief of intelligence, told Mr. Shultz that the joint teams should be able to go after the infiltrators and attack them without having to wait for Lebanese units, a participant in the meeting said. **********In addition to discussing the role of Major Haddad, Mr. Shultz and the Israelis discussed the use of members of the United Nations force in Lebanon as ''observers'' at Palestinian refugee camps near Sidon and Tyre. They would help insure the security of the inhabitants of the camps and make it easier to gain the withdrawal of the estimated 10,000 P.L.O. guerrillas from Lebanon at the same time as Israeli and Syrian forces are supposed to leave. **********The Israelis have resisted proposals in the past to put members of the United Nations force in charge of camp security for fear that they might not do enough to prevent Palestinian guerrillas from using the camps for training. Under the formula being discussed, the Lebanese Army would be charged with blocking a revival of the P.L.O., but the United Nations forces would be there to prevent a repetition of last September's massacres at Palestinian camps near Beirut, Israeli officials said. **********In describing today's talks, a senior Foreign Ministry official said, ''We do have a sense that we are making progress.'' Mr. Shultz was more circumspect. He said they were ''inching forward.'' He jokingly said outside Mr. Begin's home that perhaps they had advanced ''an inch and a half.'' Later, when asked about progress, he said, ''Maybe another three-quarters of an inch.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/world.main_headline: 8 NATIONS PROPOSE A WAY TO BREAK THE EAST-WEST IMPASSE AT MADRID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/world.print_headline: 8 NATIONS PROPOSE A WAY TO BREAK THE EAST-WEST IMPASSE AT MADRID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/world.body_text: **********Arguing that detente itself was at stake, eight neutral countries proposed a series of compromises today to break the East-West deadlock that has dogged the conference on security and cooperation in Europe, now in its third year. **********But the proposals that they advanced before the 35-nation meeting appeared to fall short of what the West had been demanding to support human rights in the Soviet bloc. The initial response from Western representatives was guarded and cool. **********The proposals did not include provisions to halt the expulsion of foreign reporters, to stop jamming of foreign radio broadcasts, to permit free unions the right to strike or to allow ''Helsinki monitor groups'' - groups of citizens inside countries who check on their compliance with the 1975 Helsinki accords. These provisions were among 14 amendments proposed by the Western nations last November. 'Equally Dissatisfactory to All' **********Today's initiative for a final agreement here came from Austria, Cyprus, Finland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Sweden, Switzerland and Yugoslavia. Once before, in December 1981, the eight countries drew up a document to try to bring the conference to a successful conclusion, but it was lost in a wave of charge and countercharge that followed the crackdown in Poland. **********At a news conference after the closed session, representatives of the eight sought to depict the compromise as the best one possible in the current impasse. ''We consider it a balanced document,'' said Ljubivoje Acimovic of Yugoslavia. ''It should be satisfactory to all participating states - or equally dissatisfactory to all. Everyone has to sacrifice something.'' **********Justifying the omission of some of the human rights amendments, which they said they themselves favored, the neutrals said some of them - such as prohibitions against expelling journalists or the right to set up monitoring groups - had run into insurmountable opposition from the Soviet Union. Politics was the art of the possible, they suggested. **********The representatives emphasized what they called important advances. They included provisions insuring access to foreign missions, upholding freedom of religion and pledging international cooperation against terrorism. Western demands for greater latitude for foreign journalists were watered down somewhat. **********''We got 30 or 40 percent, not 100 percent,'' said Dr. Franz Ceska of Austria. ''But we believe the 30 or 40 percent is worthwhile.'' 'Thin on Human Dimensions' **********Western representatives said their public response would await a caucus Wednesday, but privately some indicated reservations. ''Many of our amendments appear in diluted form or are omitted altogether,'' said one Western European diplomat. ''The result is thin on the human dimensions.'' **********The compromise also does not note that Western foreign ministers appeared before the session to register a condemnation of martial law in Poland. It speaks of the right of workers to ''establish and join trade unions'' but does not mention the right of unions to join in a federation or the right to strike, as did the Western proposals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/28/busin.body_text: **********Gordon Peter Getty got there the classic way. He had wealthy parents. Sam M. Walton did it by selling things cheap. J.R. Simplot did it with potatoes, Robert Vesco fled with millions. **********All did what most Americans only dream about doing - they struck it rich - and they all show up on the second annual Forbes 400 list, a gossipy and not scrupulously precise ranking of the richest people in the country compiled for the latest issue of Forbes magazine. **********Though studded with the fabled names that one associates with Rolls-Royces and Tiffany paper clips - Rockefellers, Hunts, Mellons - the Forbes list proves that a lot of unknowns have also made good. **********One imagines that Mr. Walton, for example, could safely stroll into most any bank, save those in Bentonville, Ark., and cause no stir. But Forbes has him as the second-richest man in America. **********The 65-year-old Mr. Walton got his training at the J.C. Penney Company, then struck out on his own. He now owns control of the Wal-Mart discount stores, based in Bentonville. His estimated worth is $2.15 billion. He drives a pickup truck. **********He is not the only surprise in the latest Forbes tally. It has been assumed for years among those who never have to count their millions that nobody is richer than Daniel Keith Ludwig, the man known as the father of the supertanker. **********By Forbes's calculations, however, Mr. Ludwig is only the third-richest man in the country. He was No. 1 last year, but he was passed by Mr. Getty, son of the late billionaire oilman John Paul Getty, with an estimated worth of $2.2 billion. **********If there is a lesson to learn from such a list, it might be how best to accumulate canyons of gold. Although real estate, oil and media properties continued to be major sources of fortunes, it was the red-hot stock market that was the big cash cow.  Perot Recoups **********Some 25 stock fortunes more than doubled, and 35 more gained at least 50 percent. The biggest winner was Leslie Wexner, who heads The Limited Inc. His net worth, based on closing stock prices of Aug. 24, more than quadrupled. H. Ross Perot, famous for once losing $1 billion on paper when the stock market went the wrong way, got all that back. He vaulted from a worth of $325 million last year into the billionaire class. Sam Walton's Wal-Mart stock more than tripled. **********How do you lose canyons of gold? Forbes can tell you that, too, by examining the 74 people knocked off last year's list. The oil glut pinched the fortunes of several. George Lucas, despite the success of his film ''The Return of the Jedi,'' slipped off because of a divorce settlement. **********Thirteen members of last year's list - including the mob figure Meyer Lansky - fell off because they died. **********It is also getting harder to keep pace with the big money people. Last year, $100 million was enough to make the roster. This year it took $125 million. **********There were some new faces, whose sagas would hearten any youngster with big eyes. Take Kyupin Philip Hwang. He arrived from Korea with $50 and scrubbed dishes in a Lake Tahoe casino to pay for a college education. He founded a home computer company called Televideo Systems in his garage. After going public in March, his worth swelled to $600 million.  French Fries Patent **********J. R. Simplot got rich by owning the patent to frozen french fries. Donald Hall did it with greeting cards. Mr. Vesco, the fugitive financier, made the 400 by disappearing with millions. **********One of the more precarious fortunes on the list is that of Marc Rich, the Swiss commodities trader, who is under indictment on tax evasion charges. **********Incidentally, Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine's editor in chief, is ranked 400th on the list. No net worth is given. He says that any number would be considered ''real,'' rather than an estimate like the others, and he does not know his real worth. **********The rich list is not universally loved by those who wind up on it. Nobody likes to have their finances bared, especially if they might be concerned about kidnappers or charity seekers. **********''Last year, I thought it was one of the greatest jokes I ever heard,'' Lamar Hunt said. ''They create in the public mind some fairy tale type of situation.'' **********Though Forbes put Mr. Hunt's wealth at $1 billion last year, it said that government inquiries indicated he was not that well off and so dropped him to $500 million. What does Mr. Hunt say about that? ''I had a tough year, I guess.'' **********Louis Ward, the head of Russell Stover Candies, who got on at $200 million, was less than pleased. ''I think that sort of thing is wrong in America,'' he said. ''I feel that lists such as this don't serve any worthwhile purpose.'' **********''It endangers my family,'' said Arnold Bernhard, who founded Value Line, which evaluates stocks. ''You know how many racketeers there are in the country who will come after you if they think you have deep pockets? After last year's list, I was inundated with calls. People say, if you've got all that money, give us some.'' **********One member of the 400 sued Forbes. Kenneth Davis Jr., part of the oil family, asked a court in Fort Worth to order Forbes to delete his name from the list because his privacy was being invaded. The judge, however, rejected the request.  'Price of Being Rich' **********As for criticism of the list, James Michaels, Forbes's editor, says, ''This is part of the price of being rich in an open society.'' **********Forbes does not contend that its list is complete. A number of people on it this year would have been included last year had Forbes known about them. ''The head of Computerland we overlooked last year,'' Mr. Michaels said, talking about William Millard. ''I happened to be sitting next to someone at a dinner who was talking about Computerland. I ran back and did a little arithmetic and said, by golly, we better get him on our rich list.'' **********To show how times have changed, Forbes also recapped a survey from a 1918 issue proclaiming the 30 richest Americans. At that time, a piddling $50 million made that list. On top was John D. Rockefeller, whose fortune was computed at $1.2 billion and whose was put at $31.70 a second. Nobody else was close. Second place was occupied by Henry Clay Frick, the coke and steel executive, at $225 million, with Andrew Carnegie third, at $200 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/17/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce today that it will soon begin using aspartame in Diet Coke, the extraordinarily successful soft drink introduced nationally in January. **********Earlier this month, G. D. Searle & Company announced that it had agreed to supply Nutrasweet, its brand name for aspartame, to Coca-Cola. **********Coca-Cola will thus be the first soft drink company to use the low-calorie sweetener. Aspartame was approved by the Food and Drug Administration last month for use in soft drinks. Diet Coke is currently sweetened with saccharine, which is cheaper than aspartame but has an aftertaste. The presence of saccharine also mandates that the packaging carry a health warning to consumers. **********Use of aspartame is expected to raise sales of Diet Coke, which is already the nation's best-selling low-calorie soft drink.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/busin.main_headline: Head of Showa Venture At Diamond Shamrock
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Head of Showa Venture At Diamond Shamrock
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Allan J. Tomlinson, president and chief operating officer of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, is stepping down to lead a Diamond Shamrock venture with Showa Denko of Japan. **********Mr. Tomlinson, 50, will become chairman and chief executive of a company being formed with the big Japanese petrochemical concern. **********He will be succeeded at Diamond Shamrock by J.L. Jackson, 51, who has been president of the company's coal unit since 1979. **********The 50-50 venture with Showa Denko will be in agricultural chemicals and animal health products. Both companies, Mr. Tomlinson said, will bring in established products and worldwide marketing capabilities. He estimated 1983 sales at $350 million. **********Diamond Shamrock, a Dallas oil and gas company, has been working with Showa Denko for 15 years on various projects. ''I got to know them very well,'' Mr. Tomlinson said, ''and one of the bases for my taking this job was that they specifically asked if I would be willing to take it on. It's a tremendous opportunity in terms of building a worldwide business and in running my own show.'' **********Mr. Tomlinson, a chemical engineer, has been president and chief operating officer of Diamond Shamrock since 1980. He joined the company in 1968, when it was based in Cleveland. Now he will be returning to that area: the new venture's headquarters will be in Concord Township, Ohio, at Diamond Shamrock research facilities. **********Mr. Jackson will also take Mr. Tomlinson's seat on the board. He is a petroleum engineer ''who brings a broad operating background in oil and gas as well as coal to his new assignment,'' said W.H.  Bricker, Diamond Shamrock's chairman and chief executive. **********Robert E. Garbesi is to replace Mr. Jackson as president of the coal unit, which is based in Lexington, Ky.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/world.body_text: **********Swedish customs officials have found a second consignment of goods believed to be part of a highly advanced American-made computer system that the Reagan Administration says was being smuggled to the Soviet Union. **********Bjorn Eriksson, general director of the Customs Authority, said three cases of equipment that arrived in the port of Malmo in the last few days were being investigated by his officers. **********Government computer experts today bagn examining four containers of equipment that arrived in the neighboring port of Helsingborg two weeks ago from South Africa to determine whether it included war materials. **********Another part of the same shipment consisting of three comtainers was seized Nov. 11 on a Swedish vessel in Hamburg, West Germany, at the behest of United States officials who said they were being sumggled to the Soviet Union in violation of the Export Control Act, which bans shipments of munitions, armaments and critical technology to Moscow. **********American customs officials said last Sunday that the shipment constituted a roomful of computer equipment that could be used in a wide range of civilian and military projects, including operation of a missile guidance system.   Goods Came 'From Abroad' **********Mr. Eriksson said the Malmo goods came ''from abroad'' but not from South Africa. ''We have reason to believe they are connected with the containers in Helsingborg,'' he said in an interview. **********There were also indications that the Swedish recipients of the goods, who have still not come forward, intended to forward them to another country, Mr. Eriksson said. He did not elaborate. **********On Tuesday the Swedish Government banned the import of war materials from South Africa after a preliminary inspection of the Helsingborg containers. **********A report by the Swedish news agency TT said the Malmo goods had arrived by air from a non-European country and were taken to the port by truck. It did not give a source for that information. **********The equipment, for an advanced system known as a VAX 11/782, was manufactured by the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass. According to the company, the VAX 11/782 sells for between $1.5 million and $2 million. **********The computer system was legally shipped under a United States-approved license to a priavte company in South Africa, according to William Green, Deputy Asssistant Commissioner for Enforcement for the United States Customs Service. **********He said the total of seven containers seized in Hamburg and Helsingborg constituted the ''largest illegal shipment we've intercepted.''  Dilemma for the Swedes **********Diplomats here said the computer affair had caused a dilemma for the Swedish government, which did not want to compromise the country's neutrality but at the same time did not wish to damage relations with the United States. **********In particular, Sweden did not want its own purchases of sophisticated equipment from the United States jeopardized, as happened several years ago when a Swedish company supplied Moscow with radar components for a new airfield. **********The United States retaliated then by delaying delivery of missiles ordered by the Swedish air force. **********Washington appeared reasonably satisfied with Sweden's handling of the computer affair so far, the officials said. **********The Times of London reported this week that a secret agent of the Soviet K.G.B. in South Africa had engineered the plan to smuggle the computer into the Soviet Union. **********It identified the agent as Richard Mueller, a German native, and said he had ''secretly diverted'' the shipment to forward it to the Soviet Union. South Africa's Commissioner of Police, Gen. Johann Coetzee, was quoted as saying that Mr. Mueller was ''lying low'' in Austria. **********Last Sunday, Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, said: ''I believe the equipment involved is a computer or several computers, we are not quite sure. The Soviets have made a persistent and all too successful effort to obtain Western technology.'' **********In a televised interview he added: ''I believe that the Swedish Government is now looking into whether the illegalities of the transaction will enable them to return the shipment to the United States.'' **********Negotiations with the Swedish company and the Swedish Government had been going on since Friday, according to Mr. Green, who described them as sensitive.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/04/busin.main_headline: Security Pacific Plans Bank in South Dakota
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/04/busin.print_headline: Security Pacific Plans Bank in South Dakota
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/04/busin.body_text: **********The Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles, seeking further expansion into insurance and other financial services, announced yesterday that it would soon file an application to start a statechartered bank in South Dakota, which recently enacted a law that permits state-chartered banks to own insurance companies. **********Citicorp has already announced its intention to purchase a small state-chartered South Dakota bank as a way to enter the insurance business. Its application must be approved, however, by the Federal Reserve Board, and the Fed has been reluctant to allow banks to engage in a major way in the insurance business. **********If Citicorp should prevail, however, other banks want to be in line. William F. Ford, executive vice president of Security Pacific, the nation's 10th-largest bank holding company and the parent of the Security Pacific National Bank, said that the outcome of the Citicorp application to the Fed would determine whether Security Pacific and others would succeed. **********The First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles also announced plans to buy a South Dakota bank as a way of getting into insurance. It is seeking the Big Stone State Bank of Big Stone City, a community of some 700 people. No other state allows a bank to own an insurance unit. **********State legislatures have been a major target recently in the drive by banks to gain more freedom to deal in securities and insurance.  Several states either have passed or are considering laws that would greatly expand powers of banks to engage in financial services. Securities Industry Opposition **********The securities industry is fighting these moves and its trade group, the Securities Industry Association, has cited Security Pacific, Citicorp and Bank America as the most aggressive of the banks. **********On the Federal level, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has urged state legislators and Federal regulators to impose a moratorium on mergers between banks and nonbanks until Congress can tackle the problem. Mr. Regan said Federal authorities should overrule already passed state legislation that relaxes restrictions on the services banks can offer. **********Mr. Ford of Security Pacific, who is the administrator of the bank holding company's specialized financial services group, said Security Pacific planned to file the South Dakota application within 60 days.  Then, he said, it might take an additional 120 to 180 days for consideration by the Fed. **********He said the new bank would be planned in the Sioux Falls area, where the Security Pacific Finance Corporation, a subsidiary, already has an office. The bank would build its own portfolio instead of taking over an existing one, as in Citicorp's case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/09/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met today with top advisers for eight hours, but there was no indication afterward concerning the date of the next general election. **********There has been speculation that Mrs. Thatcher might call elections as early as next month.  But before the meeting today, at the Prime Minister's country residence of Chequers, Mrs. Thatcher told a radio interviewer she would not be pushed into a decision. Senior ministers and Conservative Party officials who attended the meeting today gave no hint of Mrs. Thatcher's plans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.main_headline: SHULTZ IS WILLING TO STAY IN MIDEAST TILL PACT IS SIGNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.print_headline: SHULTZ IS WILLING TO STAY IN MIDEAST TILL PACT IS SIGNED
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/26/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was ready to shuttle between Israel and Lebanon as long as necessary to conclude an agreement on the terms of withdrawal of Israeli forces from Lebanon. **********In a news conference aboard his Air Force plane flying here from Washington, Mr. Shultz said his mission was ''a very doable thing'' because an Israeli withdrawal was ''in both the Israeli and Lebanese interests.'' **********''And anyway, as a negotiator and mediator you have to be optimistic,'' he said. ''You have to think it will succeed. Otherwise you won't get anywhere.'' **********Meeting With U.S. Envoys **********Soon after arriving in Cairo, Mr. Shultz met with Philip C. Habib and Morris Draper, the special American Middle East envoys, and with American Ambassadors to nine Middle Eastern nations, including Israel, to discuss his negotiating tactics. **********Mr. Shultz, who is usually subdued about his plans, seemed eager to give an optimistic outlook for what may be an intensive round of talks trying to persuade the Israelis to accept security guarantees in southern Lebanon that fall short of having Israeli soldiers or the Israeli-backed militia of Maj. Saad Haddad remain there. **********He must also work out with the Lebanese and Israelis language on future relations that allows the Lebanese to avoid appearing to have agreed to any formal normalization. Remarks Differ From Kissinger's **********Mr. Shultz's statements contrast with those of former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, who began the shuttle diplomacy in the Middle East in 1974 and usually avoided any semblance of public optimism. Mr. Kissinger once remained in the area 35 days to negotiate a Syrian-Israeli accord, and Mr. Shultz's aides said they would not rule out a trip of that length. **********Asked why he decided to visit the Middle East now instead of earlier to try to break the months-old impasse, Mr. Shultz said, ''It is just our judgment that the issues have got to a point where the injection of a new face or a thing of that kind will be helpful.'' **********''So here I go,'' he said. He said he had no assurance of a deal from the Israelis or the Lebanese. When asked if he would stay until there was an accord, he replied: **********''Yes. I'm prepared to work at it as long as it seems there's a chance to accomplish something. And I hope that there can be some accomplishment fairly reasonably.'' 'To Do Whatever Is Necessary' **********Once an accord on the security and political terms are worked out between Israel and Lebanon, Mr. Shultz said, he will seek a similar arrangement between Lebanon and Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization so that Israelis, Syrians and P.L.O. leave Lebanon on an agreed timetable. **********Asked if he would engage in ''shuttle diplomacy'' for as long as necessary, he said, ''Oh, sure, I'm prepared to do whatever is necessary by way of movement back and forth.'' **********This is Mr. Shultz's first Middle East trip since taking office last July and is his first concerted negotiating effort.  Mr. Shultz said he hoped Arab leaders would make it possible for King Hussein of Jordan to join American-sponsored negotiations.  ''As I read the cable traffic, there is a lot of head scratching and a feeling that says maybe we're letting a train go out of the station and we don't know when the next one will be,'' he said of the Arabs' attitude. **********Mr. Shultz said Mr. Reagan had assured King Hussein that all he had to say was that he was ''ready to sit down with Israel and negotiate'' but, in the American view, he need not join the talks until there was a freeze on Israeli settlements in the West Bank. **********Mr. Shultz considered making Morocco his initial stop but decided on Cairo because Egypt is celebrating the anniversary of the recovery of the final bit of Israeli-occupied Sinai. Mr. Shultz is using his visit to underscore the gains accruing to the only Arab country to make peace with Israel. ---- Talks Are Suspended **********BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 (AP) -Lebanon and Israel suspended their troop withdrawal talks today for the duration of Mr. Shultz's visit, officials said. **********Spokesmen for both sides told reporters after a day of talks at nearby Khalde that the talks would be renewed according to developments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/world.main_headline: Parliament Dissolved, Vote to Be Set in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Parliament Dissolved, Vote to Be Set in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/05/world.body_text: **********President Sandro Pertini dissolved Parliament today, clearing the way for early general elections in June as demanded by Italy's Socialist Party. Political leaders will meet Thursday to negotiate the date. **********It was the fourth Parliament in a row to be dissolved before the end of its five-year term.  The crisis arose after the Socialists, hoping to pick up major gains in early voting, withdrew their support from Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani's four-party coalition. That led to the resignation last Friday of Mr. Fanfani's Government, Italy's 43d postwar Cabinet, after only five months in office. **********President Pertini signed the decree dissolving Parliament after meeting with the leaders of the Senate and Chamber of Deputies, according to a statement from the Quirinal Palace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/09/busin.body_text: **********Conoco Inc. expects domestic demand for petroleum products to increase 2.5 percent next year, Ralph Bailey, the company's chairman, said today. **********Conoco's near-term forecast shows flat gasoline demand in 1984, mainly because of improving car mileage, he told delegates to the National Oil Jobbers Council convention. **********But demand for distillates, he said, is likely to rise 4.6 percent, based on normal winter use of heating oil and a big increase in diesel fuel consumption as the economic recovery spurs highway transportation. **********After six years of steady decline, Mr. Bailey added, Conoco projects a 10 percent rise in demand for residual fuel oil in 1984 if winter temperatures are normal. The forecast by Conoco, a subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, also assumes strong growth in sales to utilities for increased power generation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.main_headline: RENAULT TO DOUBLE STAKE IN MACK TRUCKS, TO 45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.print_headline: RENAULT TO DOUBLE STAKE IN MACK TRUCKS, TO 45%
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Renault Holding, the French auto company, is to pay $100 million to more than double its stake in Mack Trucks Inc. and take over its management from the Signal Companies, Renault and Signal said yesterday. **********Under a letter of intent, Renault will raise its interest in the truck manufacturer to 45 percent, from 20 percent. The $100 million is to be paid to Signal over three years. **********The agreement is a major step in Signal's plan to divest itself of Mack Trucks, which has been losing money heavily. Mack's $1.29 billion in sales last year accounted for a quarter of Signal's revenues, but Mack had a loss of $32.3 million. **********Signal has been undergoing a major restructuring since its acquisition by Wheelabrator-Frye Inc., which was completed in January. Signal plans to concentrate in aerospace operations, electronics and engineering. **********Forest N. Shumway, Signal's chairman and chief executive officer, said in April that Renault had expressed an interest in increasing its stake in Mack to 45 percent and that talks were then under way.  In the first quarter, Signal decided to account for Mack as a discontinued operation; its quarterly results included a $108 million writedown to reflect this. **********Arvid Jouppi, an industry analyst, said yesterday that the takeover was part of a trend in which heavy truck manufacturing in the United States was moving increasingly into foreign hands. With White Motors owned by Volvo and Freightline trucks operated by Mercedes, he said, the only remaining domestically controlled heavy truck makers are International Harvester and Paccar. **********Renault also owns 46 percent of the American Motors Corporation.  Signal said Renault would also receive a warrant to purchase an additional 15 percent of Mack, raising its stake to 60 percent. Mr.  Shumway said the remaining 40 percent would be sold through a public offering. The French company purchased an initial 10 percent interest in Mack Trucks in 1979 and raised that stake to 20 percent last year. **********''Renault has a tremendous desire to become an international automotive and trucking company and could only do it through its investment in both A.M.C. and Mack Trucks,'' Mr. Jouppi said.  American Motors had announced its intention to sell its A.M.C.  General, a truck producer in South Bend, Ind., which could offer another opportunity for Renault, he said. The proposed sale requires approval by regulatory agencies.
