https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/18/busin.body_text: **********After months of parliamentary impasse, the Senate approved today a compromise bill that would authorize the United States to commit an additional $8.4 billion to the International Monetary Fund. The Senate, on a 67-to-30 vote, sent the legislation back to the House, which had approved, with great reluctance, a different I.M.F. bill earlier this year. **********The Senate-passed version was part of a larger legislative deal negotiated over several weeks among House Democrats, the Senate Republican leadership and the Administration. One of the most politically sensitive aspects of the I.M.F. bill was the Senate-approved language that would let the United States support fund loans to South Africa under certain tightly defined conditions; the House bill includes a broad prohibition on such loans. **********The Senate vote was a victory for President Reagan, who has termed the increased contribution essential for the stability of the international monetary system. Opponents have said it merely represents a bailout for commercial banks' imprudent loans to developing countries. **********But although the House Democratic leadership has agreed to the delicately structured Senate compromise bill, it was not certain that a floor majority could be mustered. **********House action on the package, which includes not only the added $8.4 billion in deposits for the fund - in addition to the current $14.6 billion commitment - but also authorization for $15.6 billion in housing programs, may hinge on the wording of the South Africa amendment. The House was expected to vote Friday or Saturday before adjournment for the year. **********The $8.4 billion United States commitment is part of a call by the I.M.F. to its 146 member nations to raise an additional $42 billion for loans. **********The compromises represented the culmination of six weeks of negotiations by Senate Banking Committee Chairman Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, who managed the bill on the Senate floor, House Banking Committee Chairman Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island, Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan and Budget Director David A. Stockman. To win Congressional approval of the I.M.F. bill, the Administration agreed to a bigger housing bill than it wanted and the Democrats insisted that the two authorizations be joined in one bill. **********First Housing Authorization **********The bill enacted today as part of the I.M.F. package would represent the first housing authorization by Congress in three years. **********The original House version, which passed by a margin of only six votes, ordered the United States representative at the I.M.F. to vote against any loans to South Africa. **********This language was unacceptable to both the Administration and the Senate. As a result of compromises worked out late yesterday by the negotiators, the United States is to ''actively oppose'' loans to South Africa unless the Secretary of the Treasury certifies in writing at least 21 days in advance of any such loan that the money would: **********- Benefit economically ''the majority of the people.'' **********- Reduce the ''severe constraints on labor and capital mobility.'' **********- Reduce ''other highly inefficient labor and capital supply rigidities.'' **********It was uncertain how members of the Congressional black caucus and others in the House who are actively opposed to apartheid policies would react to this language. Most members of Congress see no political advantage to themsevles to support I.M.F. funding and so are inclined to vote against the funding if there may be political risk. **********But the Democrats would risk losing the housing authorization if they toppled the compromise bill because of their feelings about apartheid. **********Loans to Communist Countries **********The House had also voted that the United States representative at the I.M.F. oppose loans to Communist countries. The Senate bill would let the United States vote for such loans if the Secretary makes findings like those required for South Africa. **********A sign of some of the difficulties the legislation faces in the House came tonight with a letter to the President from 50 Representatives serving notice that they could not support the bill because of what they said were the high interest rate policies of the Federal Reserve and the Administration. The organizer of the letter was Jack Kemp, Republican of Buffalo, who has generally been an Administration supporter. **********Debate Over Effect **********During today's debate, which ran for nearly six hours, opponents led by two conservative Republican Senators, William L. Armstrong of Colorado and Gordon J. Humphrey of New Hampshire, argued that the bill would only make the international monetary situation worse by increasing the mountain of debt in the world. **********''The banks have dug themselves into a hole and should dig themselves out of it,'' said Senator Armstrong. **********On the other side, Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois and chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said that ''by taking this positive action we avoid a worldwide depression.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/18/busin.body_text: **********The National Semiconductor Corporation agreed to acquire Data Terminal Systems Inc. in a twostep transaction valued at up to $50 million, the companies said today. They said National Semiconductor would offer $8 a share for up to 4.31 million, or about two-thirds, of Data Terminal's shares. **********They said the second part of the transaction called for a merger, with holders of remaining Data Terminal shares receiving $7.25 a share. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Data Terminal fell $1, to $7.50, and National Semiconductor closed unchanged, at $28. **********Data Terminal also granted an option to National Semiconductor to buy Data Terminal shares equal to 18.4 percent of its shares outstanding at $8 each on the date of the transaction. **********The offer is expected to begin this week and will last for 25 business days. It requires that a minimum of 2.7 million Data Terminal shares be tendered and not withdrawn. **********Analysts said National Semiconductor's planned acquisition was an effort to broaden its point-of-sale business with the supermarket industry and to gain entry into new markets. The company's primary business is semiconductors, but analysts said that in the latest quarter, point-of-sales, or electronic cash registers, performed the best. **********James Barlage, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that on a pretax basis, the point-of-sales were the only area solidly in the black in the fiscal second quarter. The company lost $3.4 million in the second quarter, ended in December. **********Analysts said that Data Terminal had been hurt by an image problem. It lost $2.9 million in the fiscal year 1981 and more than $10 million in the fiscal year 1982. Mr. Barlage said he believes National Semiconductor will be able to cut back Data Terminal's overhead costs and operate the company more efficiently.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********They are seeing it in the elegantly dressed shoppers, already lugging their brightly wrapped holiday gifts and packing the aisles in Saks and Bloomingdale's and Macy's and Lord & Taylor. They are seeing it in the weeknight crowds that have crammed the parking lots to overflowing at Kings Plaza in Brooklyn, and Roosevelt Field on Long Island and the Bergen Mall in New Jersey. **********With only 10 shopping days left, retailers in the New York metropolitan area are saying that Christmas sales here appear to be even stronger than in many other cities that are also doing extremely well. **********The area's reported sales gains are averaging 12 percent, although they range from 5 to as much as 30 percent over the period last year. Other strong areas, Boston for example, are reporting average increases of up to 10 percent. **********City's Stores in the Lead **********The New York area's largest stores are enjoying the largest year-to-year gains. But the big surprise is that stores in the city are doing perceptibly better than many in the suburbs. This is a change from the pattern earlier in the year, and many merchants said it might well be due to the influx of holiday tourists.  ''Since the day after Thanksgiving, we have had the biggest sales increases of the year, so that December so far has been an outstanding month,'' said Arthur Reiner, chairman of Macy's New York. **********''The response crosses all income brackets, judging by our sales results,'' he said. ''But if anything is outstanding, it's the sales of the better or more luxurious type of goods.'' He declined to specify Macy's increase, but sources close to the company said it exceeded 15 percent. **********Marvin Traub, chairman of Bloomingdale's, said the season was ''extraordinarily good, with sales 15 to 20 percent over last year.'' He added that the chain's Manhattan store was running ''particularly strong,'' and ''all of our departments, from moderate to higher priced, seem to be sharing in the excellent performance.'' **********''It's a splendid season,'' said Joseph E. Brooks, chairman of Lord & Taylor. ''In our New York store, business is up 18 percent and in the area it's up 13 percent.'' **********'An Upscale Mentality' **********He said the gains were on top of an 11 percent sales increase last Christmas. People have ''an upscale mentality these days,'' Mr. Brooks said. ''They may have bought a $20 sweater for a gift last year. This year it's $25 and $30.'' **********The record rain Monday and Tuesday sharply reduced shopper traffic, costing merchants an estimated 15 percent of the business that they had hoped to ring up this week. **********Yesterday, however, business resumed its solid pace. And some store executives said that in spite of the retailing axiom that ''If you lose it, you've lost it,'' they expected that the losses from the rain would be recouped.  ''We've had an excellent season so far, with sales up 30 percent, but the rain hurt,'' said Leon Atkind, chairman of NBO Stores, the men's wear discounter. ''We think, though, that the rain slowdown means a tremendous surge of traffic this weekend.'' **********'We're Already Gaining Back' **********Robin Farkas, chairman of Alexander's Inc., said: ''We did well when it wasn't raining. Today we're already gaining back. We expect a very good Christmas, barring any more rain or a big snow.'' **********In the suburbs, the heavy traffic at the large shopping malls yesterday and before the rain was ample evidence of a strong season. **********At the Roosevelt Field Shopping Center in Garden City, L.I. - one of the area's largest malls, with 190 stores including Macy's, J. C. Penney, Alexander's and Gimbels - retailers were reporting sales increases of 7 percent to 30 percent from the period last year, with the average running about 10 percent. **********Yesterday, the mall was clogged with thousands of shoppers, part of the 500,000 that Roosevelt Field draws weekly during the holidays, about double its regular traffic. **********A Story About Santa **********And no matter how hard the mall's administration tries, some glitches occur. Roosevelt Field is featuring two Santa Clauses this year, one at each end of the mall. The center's management carefully instructs each Santa that children could be disillusioned if both were seen together. The instructions, therefore, are that when one Santa goes up the escalator, the other is to use the elevator. **********But one bright 8-year-old who had just left one Santa, raced up an escalator to catch the other coming down on the opposite side. ''I just saw you back there,'' the boy said, apparently not too disillusioned. ''How did you get here so fast?'' **********At the Galleria in White Plains, Martin C. Lally, general manager of the 150-store center, reported an average 15 percent increase in seasonal sales. ''Our night traffic is stronger than usual,'' he said. ''We're planning to stay open until 8 P.M. Christmas Eve, against 6:30 normally, and if the weather holds up, that should be the biggest day of the year.'' **********The Galleria has had ''tremendous traffic'' when it wasn't raining, and ''an exceptional'' weekend, Mr. Lally said. The crush of customers at times defied merchants' ability to serve them. At one point, for instance, The Glass Oven, a bakery in the mall, ran out of dough. The baker had to start working at 3 o'clock the next morning to knead a new batch. **********In Brooklyn, at the Kings Plaza Shopping Center, the two main stores, Macy's and Alexander's, had heavy traffic yesterday. A center spokesman said, ''The season is very positive here so far and things look promising.'' **********And the 4,800-car parking lot at the Bergen Mall, in Paramus, N.J., was also packed yesterday. The main stores, Stern's and Ohrbach's, and 80 smaller ones are having ''a very good season,'' according to Lois Grillo, a mall executive. **********The mall was enjoying ''more consistently good business'' than a year ago when things ''quieted down'' in mid-December, she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/19/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON CHEMICAL reagents invented by two scientists at the University of Colorado in Boulder are described as accelerating the production and increasing the purity of DNA, the basic raw material of genetic engineering. **********Marvin H. Caruthers and Serge L. Beaucage were granted patent 4,415,732 and assigned it to University Patents Inc. of Norwalk, Conn. **********Under licenses already granted, both the reagents and an automated DNA synthesizer are being marketed. **********Applied Biosystems Inc. of Foster City, Calif., and Beckman Instruments Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., are distributing the compounds and the instrument, often called a gene machine. **********Using the reagents, the synthesizer is described as providing useful fragments of genes in less than a day at a fraction of the cost of traditional methods. **********DNA stands for deoxyribonucleic acid. The newly patented reagents are formally known as phosphoramidite compounds. University Patents describes them as helping to convert genetic engineering to a true industrial process. **********University Patents evaluates inventions on behalf of its university clients to determine if the new technology is patentable.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/busin.body_text: **********Marc Rich & Company International Ltd., the commodity trading firm that has spent the last year and a half resisting prosecutors' requests for subpoenaed documents, yesterday asked a Federal judge for 12 more days to produce the documents. **********But in a court hearing, a visibily irritated Judge Leonard B. Sand rejected the request. The documents had been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury investigating possible tax evasion by Marc Rich & Company A.G., which was the parent firm of March Rich International. **********Instead, the judge ordered Marc Rich International to turn over all requested documents in the United States by the close of business yesterday. **********And he gave the firm until Monday morning to produce any remaining documents under subpoena. Most of the other documents are in Zug, Switzerland, where Marc Rich International had been based before it was sold and renamed Clarendon Ltd., itself now based in Zug. **********''By 10 A.M. Monday, New York time, the documents must be in transit,'' the judge said at a hearing at the United States Court House in lower Manhattan.  Hauling Documents to Court **********It was not immediately clear if Clarendon had complied with the court's request to relinquish some documents yesterday. Sources close to the case, however, said that about 5 P.M. workmen began hauling boxes of documents from Clarendon's 650 Fifth Avenue headquarters to the courthouse in Manhattan. **********Prosecutors and defense attorneys spent more than an hour yesterday fighting over how long it should take to produce all the documents. The Government began subpoenaing the papers in March 1982 as part of its investigation into whether Marc Rich A.G. had used an oil pricing scheme to reduce its 1981 United States income taxes. **********At one point in the hearing, Peter Fleming Jr., a Clarendon attorney, suggested that it would be imprudent to heed the Government's request to transport documents from Switzerland without photocopying them because the documents could be lost. ''Suppose the plane crashed,'' Mr. Fleming said. **********''I think one way to avoid that would be to have Mr. Fleming on the plane,'' responded Jane W. Parver, an Assistant United States Attorney in charge of the Major Crimes unit. **********''I don't want to take that risk,'' Mr. Fleming said. One-Day Extension **********In making his order to produce some documents by the end of business yesterday, Judge Sand in effect gave Clarendon a one-day extension. The judge had originally said that documents in the United States had to be in prosecutors' hands by Tuesday. He ordered that deadline after United States agents, acting on a late-night tip Monday, halted a jet at John F. Kennedy International Airport and seized two steamer trunks crammed with documents that they said came under the subpoena.  At yesterday's hearing, attorneys for Clarendon told the judge that they had been unable to meet his Tuesday deadline because its clerical staff simply did not have enough time to duplicate the papers. The attorneys asked to deliver all papers, in and outside the United States, by Aug. 22. **********Judge Sand, however, angered by what he considered delaying tactics, refused the requests. **********''We are not dealing here with a mom-and-pop grocery store,'' Judge Sand said. ''We are dealing here with a worldwide commodity-trading firm, which, I have been told, uses telexes, telephones - in short, all the devices of modern communication.'' **********After hearing a request from Clarendon attorneys that the attorneys be permitted to travel to Switzerland, where Clarendon is based, and assemble documents themselves, the judge said, ''I can't begrudge anyone wanting a trip to Switzerland.'' But he added, ''What I am trying to suggest is that 99 percent of the documents in question can be produced by a reasonably intelligent secretary or clerk. It doesn't require legal skills or your supervision until a later date.'' **********Clarendon attorneys had until 9:30 A.M. yesterday to review documents in the heavy, black steamer trunks seized at the airport. But the attorneys permitted the deadline to pass, and the trunks were placed in the custody of the prosecutors. **********According to Miss Parver, the documents in the trunks, which were sealed after being taken from the plane, will be given to the grand jury investigating Marc Rich A.G. But since the papers are the object of a subpoena, they will remain secret unless Judge Sand orders they be made public.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Dean Richard R. West and Prof. Dennis E. Logue of Dartmouth questioned our ideas about managers' role in our nation's faltering industrial competitiveness (''The False Doctrines of Productivity,'' Jan.9, and ''A Plea to Reject Economic Fashion,'' Jan.16). While we welcome debate on these issues, we believe that their comments are misleading in a number of important respects. **********Their case rests on three main arguments: American managers cannot be criticized for short-term thinking because investment in plant and equipment has actually been increasing over the period we consider; the degree of management responsibility for our current industrial problems can be appraised through the analysis of a few financial indices, and such financial tools as discounted cash flow analysis cannot be blamed for our faltering competitiveness because they are in no way biased against long-term investment. **********Mr. West and Mr. Logue begin by pointing out that the rate of growth in manufacturing investment was greater between 1972 and 1980 than in earlier years. They argue that this is evidence of United States management's long-term orientation, and chide others to ''look at the facts.'' Let's do that. **********Investment in manufacturing plant and equipment is highly cyclical, and accurate comparisons across time periods are possible only if one's numbers are based on similar points in the business cycle. The figures cited by Mr. West and Mr. Logue extend from the bottom of one cycle (1972) to the top of another (1980), leading to a clear overstatement of the increase in investment relative to long-term averages. **********A less-biased comparison would look at periods whose end dates were all at similar points in the business cycle. Comparing investment in the 1960-1970 decade (from peak to peak in the cycle) with investment in the 1970-1980 period (also peak to peak) shows that the growth in manufacturers' investment in plant and equipment has actually slowed substantially. Between 1960 and 1970, these peak expenditures increased by roughly 100 percent; between 1970 and 1980, the increase was only 50 percent. Valley expenditures showed a similar trend. **********More worrisome, Mr. West and Mr. Logue use figures for gross investment rather than net investment, which more accurately reflects additions to our capital stock over and above replacement needs. Increasing sales and workers, for example, usually require additional investment. The ratio of net equipment investment to G.N.P., which corrects for these factors, has clearly declined in recent years: from 0.022 in 1965-69 to 0.019 in 1970-74, to 0.018 in 1975-79. **********Unfortunately, even if we are investing as much as we formerly were, there would still be problems if our international competitors are investing more in capital equipment and are doing so more wisely. They are! For example, the Japanese auto producer invests about $50,000 per worker, while ours invest roughly $40,000. Moreover, the level of investment in auto production is higher than that in most other United States industries. **********The second argument made by Mr. West and Mr. Logue - that management responsibility for our problems can be determined by analyzing a few financial indices - is really related to their first. But it is both dangerous and misleading to hinge an argument over solutions to American competitive problems on the interpretation of historical plant and equipment ratios or research and development rates. The time has passed when managers could stand in fortress America and render judgments based upon how we used to do it. More forwardlooking strategic and competitive analysis is required; the alternative is complacency. **********Their third and final argument is that discounted cash flow and other financial techniques are neutral in application. Our field research shows quite the opposite, that in practice such techniques exhibit subtle and systematic biases that emphasize short-run over long-run investments. **********This bias arises partly because discounting techniques tend to be used by managers as a decision rule - a yes/ no basis for judging investment proposals - rather than as simply one more source of information to be evaluated in making investment decisions. The existence of such a screen often chokes off discussion of new projects at fairly low levels within the organization, where a new investment's strategic impact is seldom fully appreciated. It also creates an incentive to distort one's estimates in order to meet the desired rate of return. We continue to believe that for certain kinds of projects, like research and development programs, such financial tools have become more of a liability than a benefit.  WILLIAM J. NATHY ROBERT H. HAYES DAVID A. GARVIN Harvard Business School Boston, Jan.24  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.
