https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/world.main_headline: PARLEY IN BERLIN COMPARES THE 80'S TO THE 30'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/world.print_headline: PARLEY IN BERLIN COMPARES THE 80'S TO THE 30'S
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/16/world.body_text: **********An international conference to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Hitler's rise to power drew a parallel today between the current world financial crisis and arms race, and the Great Depression and rearmament that led to the rise of Nazism and World War II. **********On the last day of a three-day conference, Prof. Karl W. Deutsch of Harvard University cautioned that the ''experience of 1929-1933 showed that there are traditional, accepted forms of economic policy that are meant to stabilize the economy, while destabilizing society itself.'' **********''It was a problem then, it is a problem now,'' he said.  The often highly charged discussions, which took place in the reconstructed Central Hall of the Reichstag, a stone's throw from the wall that divides East and West Berlin, ended this afternoon with an emotional debate in which some historians aggressively defended postwar West Germany against the charge that it failed to come to grips with its Nazi past by repressing the memory of Nazi atrocities. **********Hitler Became Chancellor in '33 **********The conference, which was attended by some 1,200 people, about onethird of them professional historians from several countries, was a central event in West Germany's commemoration of Jan. 30, 1933, when Germany's aged President, Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg, named Hitler as Chancellor. **********From the beginning, plans for the commemoration have been clouded by controversy, involving charges that West Berlin's conservative government eliminated financing for events with a leftist slant. **********The conference was organized by Berlin's Historical Commission, the Institute for Contemporary History, in Munich, and the German Society for Parliamentary Questions, in Bonn. **********On Friday, parallels between the economic crisis of the early 1930's and current economic difficulties emerged in discussions centering on the causes for Germany's economic crisis that paved the way for Hitler. **********Prof. Knut Borchardt of Munich University argued that German industrialists were driven to accept Hitler because excessive wage increases in the 1920's, which outstripped productivity growth, diminished industry profits and created the widespread unemployment that preceded the Nazi takeover. Cuts in Government Spending **********Other historians, however, said Germany's persistence in stabilizing its economy by reducing Government spending, a recipe favored by some economists today, produced the disastrous unemployment situation. **********''Why was there no Government spending?'' asked Gerald Feldman, an American historian.  Prof. Hans Mommsen of Bochum University in West Germany, said, ''Even if its real effect was limited, it might have boosted confidence and halted the downward spiral.'' **********In discussions today centering on European diplomacy in the years before World War II, Professor Deutsch said world leaders then were victims of a ''cognitive catastrophe'' caused by a ''chain reaction of ignorance.'' **********''Britain allowed Germany to rebuild its air force, not knowing that the planes would one day bomb Coventry,'' he said. ''Russia signed a pact with Germany, not knowing that German armies would one day devastate Russia itself.'' Another example, he said, was America's ignorance of Japanese intentions to bomb Pearl Harbor. An Emotional Debate **********Noting similarities with current conditions, Mr. Deutsch said European leaders in the 1930's were ''like drivers on a fog-shrouded superhighway; they simply refused to slow down, before there was a massive collision.'' **********In a lecture closing the discussion today, Hermann Lubbe, a professor of history at Zurich University, sparked an emotional debate and some booing and catcalls by asserting that what seemed like West German silence about its Nazi past in the 1950's was the ''necessary quiet within which the subjects of the Nazi Reich could be transformed into the people of the Federal Republic.'' **********Charles Maier, a historian at Harvard, called the speech a ''scandal,'' adding, ''You don't end a conference recalling the rise of Nazism by saying, but we were right to forget about it for 20 years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.main_headline: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Computers Take Aim At Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.print_headline: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Computers Take Aim At Schools
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/30/busin.body_text: **********NEXT week, as children trudge back to school, a little-known British computer company will begin its push to get its own product enrolled in America's classrooms. **********Acorn Computers Ltd., which dominates the British educational market, will start an aggressive marketing campaign touting its computer as the one that American school systems ought to buy. The company recently set up a United States subsidiary, the Acorn Computers Corporation, in Woburn, Mass., with the intent of emerging as the leader in school sales. **********Most computer companies sell to all markets. Schools mean no more to them than any other market, sometimes less. Although Acorn, too, will sell its system to anyone willing to pay for it, the company plans to position itself as a specialist in education. In its ads, it calls its product ''the only computer that majors in education.'' **********To implant Acorn in the educator's consciousness, the ad agency of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver has drummed up a $3 million-plus advertising and marketing campaign that begins next Tuesday. Full-page ads will appear in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Boston Globe, and additional ads will follow in a variety of educational journals and computer publications. Acorn is also setting up learning centers at dealers to teach potential customers about the system. **********The ads are decidedly nontechnical. They stress the fact that Acorn alone is specializing in the educational field and play off Acorn's success on the other side of the Atlantic. **********The computer is called the British Broadcasting Corporation's Microcomputer System. Designed by educators at Cambridge University, it won a competition staged by the British Government designed to further computer literacy. **********It will sell for a suggested list price of $995. The computer is essentially the same one sold in Britain, which has captured more than 80 percent of the British school market. Built into it are voice synthesis, color graphics, word processing and a local-area networking capability that allows it to be connected to other machines. **********When Acorn decided it wanted to come over here, members of the Levine, Huntley agency rolled up their sleeves and did a market overview of the computer field. Among other things, they found that computers had an estimated market penetration of 30 percent in the education field in 1981 but that that was projected to expand to 86 percent by 1986. That sounded good. **********Levine, Huntley also liked the fact that rival computer makers did not zero in on education, leaving a niche open for Acorn. ''We're trying to present them as an educational company, not a computer manufacturer,'' said Harold Levine, the chairman of the agency. **********Though deliveries of the computer will not start until next month, Acorn says that it has already lined up $8 million worth of business and expects to sell 30,000 to 50,000 systems in its first year in this country. Before long, it hopes to be the market leader. **********At the moment, Commodore enjoys an estimated 32 percent of the education market, the most of any manufacturer, while Apple has 28 percent and Tandy 14 percent. **********Acorn expects to have some 200 software packages available next month for use with its system, and eventually to compile a library of 800 titles. To make sure the software is just what teachers want, the company has established an Educational Advisory Board, composed of national educators, to write guidelines and then review software packages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.main_headline: ANDROPOV'S PRE-EMINENCE IS STRESSED ON SOVIET TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.print_headline: ANDROPOV'S PRE-EMINENCE IS STRESSED ON SOVIET TV
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/world.body_text: **********Yuri V. Andropov was absent again today when the Soviet leadership assembled for the winter session of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal legislature. But other developments, including a television news show, reinforced indications that he remained the pre-eminent leader. **********It was the third time that illness had caused Mr. Andropov to miss a major political event, but this time there was little surprise. **********After he failed to attend a two-day meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee earlier in the week, continuing a four-month absence from public view that also kept him from the Revolution Day festivities Nov. 7, there were few who expected him to appear. **********Other signs indicated that the leadership was eager to discourage any notion that indisposition might force him to surrender power. One came in an unusual show of backing for Mr. Andropov that formed the centerpiece of the evening television news. **********About 20 minutes of the half-hour show was given over to film of voters in a Moscow electoral district nominating Mr. Andropov as a candidate in the single-slate elections for a new Supreme Soviet scheduled for March. Although such sequences have been shown in the past, there has rarely been such emphasis on an otherwise routine event. **********Another indication of concern to shore up confidence in his leadership came when a reporter for United Press International approached a senior Soviet official outside the Supreme Soviet chamber in the Kremlin. **********A United Press International dispatch based on the discussion identified the official as a member of the Central Committee staff and quoted him as having said that Mr. Andropov was recovering in a hospital from an illness that would not have required hospitalization for a younger man. **********According to the dispatch, the official sought to play down the seriousness of the ailment by saying that, contrary to Western reports, the problem was not related to the kidneys. **********The official said the situation was ''complicated'' by the party leader's age. Mr. Andropov is 69. **********The tenor of the endorsement offered by voters in the Proletarian election district suggested a concern to present Mr. Andropov's position as secure. **********One of half a dozen speakers shown on the television news, a worker named Konstantin N. Malin, identified as a Hero of Socialist Labor, told fellow workers at the nomination meeting that Mr. Andropov embodied Communist ideals of diligence, humanitarianism and experience. **********Mr. Malin, who works in the ZIL automotive plant, said the text of a economic speech delivered Monday in the Central Committee session on Mr. Andropov's behalf, read as though he ''were right here in the factory,'' sharing workers' problems. **********Addressing Mr. Andropov by first name and patronymic, in Russian fashion, Mr. Malin said: **********''Dear Yuri Vladimirovich, you can rest assured that the working class supports with all their heart the policies laid down by you and by the Central Committee.'' **********Apart from Mr. Andropov, all the members of the Politburo attended the Supreme Soviet session, with Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov sitting on the dais in the seat normally occupied by Mr. Andropov. **********Beside him was Konstantin U. Chernenko, the second-ranking party leader, followed by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov. **********The younger members of the Politburo - Mikhail S. Gorbachev, 52; Grigory V. Romanov, 60, and Vitaly I. Vorotnikov, 57 - sat in the row behind. **********Diplomats focused attention on Mr. Vorotnikov, a bespectacled figure with a thick sweep of black hair. Relegated in 1979 by Leonid I. Brezhnev to the post of ambassador to Cuba,Mr. Vorotnikov came back to the Soviet Union last year and has rapidly risen to the top under Mr. Andropov's aegis as Premier of the Soviet Union's Russian Republic and now a full member of the Politburo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/world.main_headline: Reactor Leaks Tritium At a Station in Canada
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/world.print_headline: Reactor Leaks Tritium At a Station in Canada
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/05/world.body_text: **********A nuclear reactor in Pickering, Ontario, leaked a small amount of radioactive tritium after an accident that began Monday, the Canadian authorities announced yesterday, prompting officials in Ontario and in New York State to step up air sampling. **********The Ministry of Labor for the province of Ontario notified the New York State Health Department by telephone yesterday morning that the reactor, which is east of Toronto, on Lake Ontario, had leaked about 16 curies of tritium, which the ministry said ''slightly exceeded one percent of the release limit'' set by the authorities. **********The ministry said the plant's primary cooling system began leaking at a rate of 210 gallons a minute on Monday but the rate was reduced as the reactor was cooled and depressurized. **********The ministry told the Health Department that ''controlled releases of steam will continue for some time.'' In response, the Health Department activated its air-sampling system in upstate New York, said Peter Slocum, a spokesman. **********Asked if there was cause for concern in New York, Mr. Slocum said, ''Not at this time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; 672 Turks Banned From Seeking Office
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/world.body_text: **********Turkey's military rulers today banned 672 prospective candidates, most of them former members of Parliament and columnists on right-wing newspapers, from running in general elections Nov. 6. **********A total of 883 candidates were proposed to the election board and then the ruling National Security Council. **********Of these, 400 candidates were put forward by the three political parties allowed to contest the elections, and 483 were independents. **********The rightist Motherland and National Democracy parties and the center-left Populist Party have one week to propose fresh names because of the vetoes by the military rulers, who can bar anyone they deem unfit for politics.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/15/busin.body_text: **********A $30 million offering of Mediq Inc.'s 9 1/2 percent convertible debentures due in 2003 was offered yesterday at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The debentures are convertible into the company's common stock at a price of $18.60 a share.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.body_text: **********Ambivalence, requests for anonymity and reluctance to comment were the reactions yesterday of some United Nations diplomats who were asked to discuss the cancellation of a trip to the United Nations by the Soviet Foreign Minister and the legality of the decision to bar Soviet diplomatic flights from New York's main commercial airports. **********The cancellation on Saturday came after the Governors of New York and New Jersey refused to allow Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to land in an Aeroflot airliner at either Kennedy or Newark International Airports. The Soviet Union said the United States had not guaranteed his safety or the proper handling of his plane. **********None of the diplomats would say whether they believed the United States was violating the 36-year-old Host Country Agreement, in which it pledged that ''Federal, state or local authorities of the United States shall not impose any impediments to transit to or from'' the United Nations. **********Speaking generally, T. T. B. Koh, the chief delegate of Singapore, said, ''I feel a bit ambivalent but, on balance, it is not a good thing to close two civilian airports to the plane that would have carried Gromyko.''  'Revulsion' Recognized **********''I understand the feeling of revulsion here and everywhere toward the Government of the Soviet Union for its conduct over the Korean plane incident,'' Mr. Koh said, referring to the Soviet Union's downing of a South Korean airliner with the loss of 269 lives. ''But as New York City is the host city of the U.N., it should not deny the normal facilities which enable foreign diplomats to attend meetings.'' **********''It is incumbent upon the host country or host city,'' he concluded, ''to allow representatives of all member states to come, however obnoxious we may think their views are.'' **********Ahmed Tawfik Khalil, the chief representative of Egypt, said, ''The situation in which we find ourselves, from the U.N.'s point of view, is regrettable.'' **********''The General Assembly is the General Assembly,'' Mr. Khalil said. ''It is a meeting place that has always been an opportunity for the greatest number of countries to meet and to continue their dialogue. In this light, what really concerns us is the general principle.''  A British View **********The first secretary of the British Mission, Roderic M. J. Lyne, said: ''The British Government has taken action against Aeroflot of a broadly similar nature to the United States. We understand and sympathize with that decision.'' **********One Western European diplomat noted that other travel plans had been made by the Soviet delegation, which is expected to arrive for the Tuesday opening of the General Assembly - most likely through Mexico City. **********''We know Mr. Gromyko could have come,'' said the official, who asked that his name not be used. ''It is a trifle disingenuous to blame the problem on the United States when the rest of the Soviet delegation will come.'' **********United States officials said Mr. Gromyko might have flown into either Kennedy or Newark Airport on an airline other than Aeroflot or have traveled aboard a military aircraft to a military air base. **********But a Western diplomat who spoke on condition that he not be identified in any other way said, ''Once we get into this game, we'll get strong demands to move the U.N. out of the U.S. because it can't provide the necessary facilities.''  'A Very Mixed Triangle' **********An official at the Israeli mission said the diplomatic imbroglio proved that ''when relations between the U.S.S.R. and the U.S. are tense, it spills over into the U.N. **********''It is a very mixed triangle,'' he said. **********Chief delegates from Canada and India said yesterday they could not comment, as did the deputy delegate of Japan. The head of Uganda's mission said it was his policy not to grant telephone interviews. **********A telephone caller to the homes of chief representatives from China, Cuba, France and South Korea was told in each case those diplomats were not in. There was no answer through the day at the homes of the chief delegates from West Germany and Mexico.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/13/world.main_headline: Iran Trying to Recruit Doctors From Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/13/world.print_headline: Iran Trying to Recruit Doctors From Europe
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/13/world.body_text: **********Iran is sending teams of specialists to Western Europe to recruit doctors to replace those who have left the country since the 1979 revolution. **********At the same time the Teheran Government is offering incentives for Iranians working in Europe and the United States to return. **********It has pledged that specialists who return would have a comfortable life and would be free to set up in business. But, according to the Teheran radio, the Iranian Parliament also enacted a law last month enabling the Government to confiscate the property of exiles if they do not return within two months. **********An advertisment in a recent issue of Imam, the Government's English-language journal, said the Health Ministry would be sending teams to Britain to invite doctors to work in Iran. **********A spokesman for the Iranian Embassy said in an interview that the advertisement applied only to Moslem doctors and those from third world countries. The embassy has received 140 applications, the spokesman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS FORUM; CHANGE, YES-BUT NOT NOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/busin.body_text: **********The question of consolidation of bank regulatory agencies is not new, but the Congress should not be asked to resolve this issue under current circumstances with the entire financial system in flux. **********Specifically, the banking industry should not, at this time, be tossed into the hands of one giant regulator. The industry is complex, and the nature of its services and the delivery of these services are in rapid change. **********The act of consolidating regulatory authority into a giant agency would itself contribute to greater confusion. Market forces work naturally toward the efficiencies that consolidation seeks to achieve. And while the concept of an umbrella agency has the appearance of simplification and efficiency, the single agency just might prove to be more cumbersome. **********There is room for improvement of the existing system. The ''safety and soundness'' of the banking system should be enhanced by change, and there is no doubt that change will occur. Regulations have already changed dramatically without changing the basic structure and responsibilities of the regulators themselves. **********The issue of consolidation is probably of more interest at this time to the regulators than it is to the regulated. Most banking organizations deal with more than one regulator, and the matter of multiple regulators is not their major priority. **********Ultimately, we will have a reorganization of responsibilities in the bank regulatory structure. At that time, Congress would be wise to consider maintaining, in some fashion, the marriage between supervisory policy and monetary policy at the Fed. A divorce of these two responsibilities could weaken the ability of the central bank to provide a stable financial system for our country. **********Furthermore, a total separation of supervisory policy from monetary policy could weaken the commercial banking system. It is important that some degree of intimacy between sizable commercial banking institutions and their ''lender of last resort'' be encouraged, especially so that lender is able to respond in the event that problems arise. **********The banking industry is changing, and regulations are changing with it. An abrupt change at this time in the regulatory structure would be counterproductive. As we head eventually into a fundamental reorganization of our regulators, a significant degree of Federal Reserve Board authority over both central bank policy and supervisory responsibilities must be maintained.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/31/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; FOR MUNICIPALS, THE BIGGEST DEFAULT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/31/busin.body_text: **********Default finally came at the Washington Public Power Supply System, and bondholders of some $2.25 billion now have little hope of ever getting their money back. It was the biggest municipal default in history - one expected since the State Supreme Court earlier in the month upheld a lower court ruling that 88 utilities were not obligated to meet payments on the bonds. ''The money just isn't in the till,'' said a power system spokesman, after the system had informed Chemical Bank that it could not pay its debts on partially completed nuclear plants Nos. 4 and 5. The default should make it much more difficult for other municipalities in the Pacific Northwest to borrow money. Now brokerage firms and the supply system itself are bracing for a possible avalanche of lawsuits from debt holders. **********Paul Volcker warned that public and private sector borrowing demands are beginning to clash, the Fed reported a $1.3 billion rise in the money supply and the stock and credit markets plummeted. The market ended a poor week by falling 17 points Friday, closing at 1,199.72, off more than 30 points. In the credit markets, anticipation of the huge upcoming Treasury financing pushed prices lower and rates higher, as dealers looked for levels that would attract investors. **********Telephone rates will rise, as a result of a Federal Communications Commission decision to permit local telephone companies to add $2 a month to the bills of residential customers next year for access to long-distance lines. The move will begin the process of dismantling the 50-year-old subsidy that long-distance service has provided for local service. Businesses will be charged up to $6 a month extra starting next year. **********Judge Harold Greene will be pleased to note that at least two of the seven soon-to-be regional telephone companies will use the Bell name that he reserved for them. ''BellSouth'' will adorn the stationary and buildings of the regional company serving nine Southeastern states and ''Bell Atlantic'' will be the payee on the monthly checks of those in six middle-Atlantic states and the nation's capital. Nevertheless, three regionals have eschewed the Bell name for a more high-tech flavor: Nytex (New England and New York), U S West (14 Western states) and Ameritech (five Middle Western states). **********The rush for Texas banks by Texas banks is on. Mergers are being announced almost weekly. First came two friendly deals: InterFirst and First United Bancorp created a $22 billion entity; then Mercantile Texas and Southwest Bancshares joined in a $18.1 billion holding company. Next Texas Commerce Bancshares made an unfriendly offer for Texas American Bancshares - a potential $23 billion combination. (Texas America rejected the bid of $50 a share but did not rule out a higher price.) Now First City Bancorp is buying Cullen/Frost Bankers for $288 million, creating a $19.6 billion unit. Analysts say fears of competition from financial services companies such as Sears Roebuck and the approach of interstate banking has sparked the merger mania. **********Drysdale Indictments. Two officers of the defunct Drysdale Government Securities Corporation and a former senior partner at Arthur Andersen & Company were indicted on criminal charges by a New York grand jury. Joseph V. Ossorio, Drysdale's charmain, and David J. Heuwetter, its chief trader, were accused of stealing more than $270 million from the Chase Manhattan Bank and $20 million from Manufacturers Hanover. Warren Essner, the accountant, was charged with issuing false financial statements, which failed to show the firm was ''insolvent the day it opened for business,'' in February 1982, according to Robert Morgenthau, Manhattan District Attorney. **********Washington Wrapup. The Government will sell the 14.4 million Chrysler warrants it owns to the public and not give them back to the auto maker, as Lee Iacocca had asked. The sale will bring in some $200 million ... The House and Senate passed a bill that would kill the withholding tax on interest and dividends. President Reagan is expected to sign it ... The Soviet Union agreed to buy at least nine million metric tons a year of American wheat for the next five years. The new grain agreement is 50 percent larger than the one that expired in 1981. On the news, grain prices rose sharply ... The Government's index of leading indicators rose 1 percent in June, its 11th increase in the last 12 months. **********Steel Band. United States Steel reported a $112 million quarterly loss. At the same time the company said it had pretax profits of $167 million, which were consumed by taxes, interest payments and other expenses. Bethelehem Steel had grimmer news, a $92.7 million loss and no good pretax results. If U.S. Steel can import steel from Britain, Wheeling-Pittsburgh says it can import steel from Brazil.  The No.8 steelmaker is negotiating a $40 million deal with Brazil's state-owned steel company. **********The Return of Detroit. New car sales by the Big Three rose 38 percent in mid-July, and General Motors and Ford Motor reported huge profits, continuing the trend set by Chrysler the week before.  G.M.'s second-quarter surplus totaled $1.02 billion, almost double the year-earlier period, and Ford's earnings were $542.2 million, more than double its 1982 quarter. The weak No.4, American Motors, reported a loss of $79 million in the second quarter. **********Problems are brewing for Ford, however. The National Traffic Safety Highway Administration urged Ford to recall hundreds of thousands of Escorts, Lynxes, EXP's and LN7's because of fire hazards and brake fluid leakage. **********Deals and Wheels. Brascan Ltd. of Toronto is after Scott Paper again, seeking to amend a 1981 standstill agreement and increase its stake in the American paper company to 50 percent from its current 23.7 percent. Scott opposes the move ... There was hope for International Harvester, as the head of its truck division said Harvester was operating at break-even levels ... Financier Irwin Jacobs made a revised takeover bid for troubled Kaiser Steel - $270.8 million, or $44.50 a share in cash and stock. The company accepted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.main_headline: Rebels in P.L.O. Report Striking Israelis Often
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Rebels in P.L.O. Report Striking Israelis Often
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/18/world.body_text: **********Palestinian guerrillas opposed to Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that they and Lebanese ''resistance forces'' fighting under a joint command had carried out most of the recent attacks on Israeli soldiers in Lebanon. **********Jihad Saleh, speaking for the Arafat opponents in Al Fatah, the largest of the eight groups in the P.L.O., told reporters that Al Fatah's September Martyrs' Regiment had just joined the six-week-old rebellion against Mr. Arafat. **********The dissidents, who oppose what they view as Mr. Arafat's moderate policies, said in a statement today: ''We affirm, for the first time, that we have made the major effort against the Israeli occupation forces, along with the forces of the Lebanese resistance movement and other Palestinian forces that believe in the continuation of the armed struggle in Lebanon.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Canadian oil companies that went on a takeover binge after the Government decided to ''Canadianize'' ownership of the industry performed far worse last year than other oil companies, a federal agency has found in a survey. **********The Petroleum Monitoring Agency said Tuesday that the acquiring companies had losses totaling $600 million (Canadian) in 1982, in contrast to profits of $500 million in 1981. **********Meanwhile, profits of foreign-controlled companies fell 19 percent, and profits of Canadian companies that did not join the wave of takeovers fell 14 percent. **********The acquisitions were a result of Canada's National Energy Program, which granted special exploration subsidies to Canadian-controlled companies and required that Canadian ownership of a producing oil or gas field on federal lands must be at least 50 percent. The acquiring companies' debt load became enormous.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/12/world.main_headline: Millions Are Surprised By Start of Ramadan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/12/world.print_headline: Millions Are Surprised By Start of Ramadan
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/12/world.body_text: **********Ramadan, the Moslem holy month of fasting from surise to sunset, arrived today one day earlier than expected and caught millions of Moslems off guard. **********Half an hour after midnight a special television broadcast announced that religious astronomers in Saudi Arabia had sighted the crescent new moon Friday evening, meaning that Ramadan had to begin today, not Sunday as predicted earlier. **********During Ramadan all eating, drinking and smoking are forbidden from dawn to dusk. Children, pregnant women, travelers and the sick are exempt. **********In Cairo vans with loudspeakers toured the streets and warned that fasting must start at dawn. Millions struggled from bed to make traditional predawn feasts that had been scheduled for Sunday. **********In villages runners dashed from house to house with the news. But thousands, if not millions, of Moslems were thought to have received the message too late - after a daylight breakfast. **********The confusion was heightened in Egypt by an abrupt suspension of summer time during Ramadan, with clocks put back one hour to Egyptian standard time. The idea was to make sunset, and the evening meal, come a littler sooner. **********Accordingly, the television announcement said, clocks should go back immediately. This brought extensive disarray to airline schedules and business plans during the morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/world.print_headline: VENEZUELA SHOPPING SPREE: TOO MUCH GOOD LIFE?; The Talk of Caracas
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/world.body_text: **********The Venezuelan national anthem calls on citizens to ''follow the example of Caracas,'' but if they did so today, the country would become one fed on Chinese cooking, transported in eight-cylinder American limousines and dressed in Italian designer clothes. **********''When I go into a store and ask if something is good, the answer comes back, 'Oh, yes, it's imported,' '' said a French woman who lives here. **********An exhibition that opened March 17 honoring Simon Bolivar, the country's most cherished national symbol, is mounted on panels brought here from Switzerland. **********Much of the money that poured into Venezuela during its oil boom went to buy foreign things and in the process converted Caracas into a metropolis of office towers and modern apartment buildings with little feel of its region. ''They've changed around the Plaza Venezuela five times in the last 30 years,'' Andres Duarte Vivas, a businessman here, said of one of the city's historic squares. **********''This is the Latin city that's not really here,'' a diplomat said. ''It's like some of the Arab oil capitals. Money has moved it.'' In Caracas's case that is not all bad. It does not have the wrenching poverty of other Latin American cities, and social tensions are lower. But it also does not have the graciousness of fellow Andean capitals like Quito, Bogota and La Paz. There are fewer quaintly offered courtesies here and more people in a hurry. **********''I saw a traffic jam at 5:45 this morning, and I haven't heard anyone say 'thank you' yet, so I must be back in Caracas,'' an American returning here from abroad one recent morning told a local friend. **********Despite a network of multilevel highways and elaborate cloverleafs, the vehicular snarls of Caracas are the stuff of legend. There are certain times of day that people simply cannot venture to get one place from another, although even such planning doesn't always help. **********''I remember talking to traffic experts once, and they told me that Caracas was a city where congestion never really peaks, it just rose and fell 10 percent,'' said Kim Fuad, director of the Englishlanguage newspaper, The Daily Journal. **********Many Caraquenos drive with their left arms out the window ready to plead with a neighboring motorist for entry into another lane. The fact that the gesture works, however, testifies to a patience and politeness among drivers in Caracas not seen elsewhere in Latin America. Here cars slow down instead of speeding up when they spot stranded pedestrians trying to cross the street. **********The local statistics have led people like former Planning Minister Ricardo Martinez to despair, ''There is no solution for Caracas's problems.'' There are more than 600,000 automobiles to clog its arteries, and nearly four million people live here. By the year 2000 it is expected that there will be six million people. **********The mountains that ring the city prohibit any spreading out of the population beyond the 77-square-mile basin, and the only direction to move has been up. More than 40 percent of Caracas's residents live in high-rises. Another 30 percent inhabit brick buildings in chockablock hillside slums known as ranchos. **********Jobs and relatively high wages attracted thousands of immigrants here from Colombia, Ecuador, the Dominican Republic, Guyana and Trinidad. ''This was a responsibility that no other Latin city has had to take on,'' Arturo Uslar Pietri, a leading Venezuelan intellectual, said. ''One of the ranchos is called Guayaquilito, and in another, they hoist the Colombian flag each morning.'' **********Aura Mayoral, a former television producer, said her channel used to have trouble conducting opinion-gauging interviews in the street because so many people who were stopped downtown were not Venezuelans. **********City fathers have made headway in recent years in improving public services that regularly used to leave vast sections of Caracas without power or water. Garbage no longer clutters streets as it once did since private haulers were contracted to cart it away. By the end of March, 8.7 miles of a proposed 26-mile-long subway will be functioning. **********A year-round mean temperature of 68.4 degrees, average humidity of 78 percent and a steady breeze justifies Caraquenos' claim to living in ''eternal springtime,'' even if the only things permanently in bud seem to be new high-rises. **********In fact, in those parts of the city that concrete has not covered over, wild orchids, acacias and other flowers bloom in such abundance that the guide to the city published by the Venezuelan American Association of University Women includes a list of varieties that are dangerous. Eating the seeds of a tree called the monkey cup, it warns, can cause baldness. **********A Swiss-built cable car used to carry people up past the flowering hillsides of the 7,000-foot-high Avila overlooking the city and down the far slope to the Caribbean shore, but it broke down in 1977 and has been in disrepair since. The Effect of Oil **********The case is one that is repeated through many reaches of modern-day Venezuelan life. Oil money gave the country access to expensive equipment, but the management skills were not here to keep the machinery functioning. **********''Petroleum killed off our creativity, our imagination and our productiveness,'' said Valmore Acevedo, a member of the Venezuelan Senate. **********He and his colleagues legislate in a lovely complex of period architecture, one of only several left in Caracas. In front is the leafy Plaza Bolivar surrounding an equestrian statue of the Liberator, who was born 200 years ago in a house just blocks away that is one of the city's few genuine tourist attractions. **********Pollution has driven off many of the original birds of the valley, and pigeons have taken their place. Their favorite roosting spot is the top of the statue itself, and Caraquenos enjoy pointing out that Bolivar's head is turned to the side and his expression is squeamish.  'City of the Red Roofs' **********Each morning Henrique Winckeljohann, a 70-year-old retired Government worker and native of Caracas, puts a flower in his lapel, sets his fedora at a rakish angle and comes to the plaza. ''I'm taking care of my Liberator,'' he said. ''I tried to persuade the Government to put repellent on the statue. Imagine that happening to the greatest man of the Americas.'' **********Like many Caraquenos, he spoke longingly of the ''city of the red roofs'' that no longer exists. ''One problem here is that we all talk about the city that was, not the one that is,'' Mr. Fuad, the newspaperman, said. **********That could change now that new @foreign-exchange controls have reduced the value of Venezuelan currency by 78 percent against the dollar and made frequent escapes from the city much more expensive.  Its movers and shakers will be spending more time here. **********Though its quality of life is superior to other overgrown Latin American boom towns like Mexico City and Sao Paulo, Caracas enjoys the worst reputation with outsiders, and local residents also seem to delight in complaining about it. There is no ''I Love Caracas'' spirit around. **********The French resident said she knew a French couple who recently filled an evening's conversation with gripes about living in Caracas. ''Finally I asked them how long they had stayed here,'' she said.  ''You know what they said? Fourteen years.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/28/busin.body_text: **********''IM learning new words,'' said Barry **********Diller, and he listed a few: Laser **********disks. Returns of books. Caps on salaries. NBA rules. **********Mr. Diller, the chairman of the Paramount Pictures Corporation since 1974, is more comfortable with the peculiar vocabulary of motion pictures and television. But in the months since he became head of the newly formed leisure- time group of Gulf and Western Industries, Paramount's parent, he has been studying the lexicons of computers, publishing and sports - and of divestiture. **********Last week, he helped negotiate the sale of part of Gulf and Western's video game business to Bally Manufacturing. The agreement, under which Gulf and Western will retain software design, ''is consistent with the rhythm of the businesses we think we know and do well,'' he said in an interview interrupted continually by summonses to the meeting with Bally officers and Gulf and Western's chief executive, Martin Davis. Mr. Diller gloated, ''It's perfect.'' **********No one is in a better position than the intense, prematurely bald Mr. Diller to speak knowledgeably about the leisure businesses that Gulf and Western ''does well.'' In the decade since he was brought in by the formidable Charles Bluhdorn to run Paramount, the 41-year- old Mr. Diller has built what is widely regarded as perhaps the best-run, most stable and most consistently successful movie company in Hollywood. **********''Under Barry Diller, Paramount has become one of the world's greatest entertainment companies,'' said A. D. Murphy, director of the motion picture producing program at the University of Southern California. ''Barry is probably the most successful executive in the film business today, and deservedly so,'' said Robert Montgomery of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, a leading entertainment lawyer, who has usually been on the opposite side of negotiations from Mr. Diller. **********''Unlike other studios, Paramount has proved that a conglomerate can own a movie company and do it successfully,'' noted Arthur Rockwell, an analyst with Crowell, Weedon, a Los Angeles brokerage firm. **********Now, Mr. Diller's challenge is to duplicate that record with the other entertainment companies that make up one of the three divisions into which Mr. Davis, the successor to the late Mr. Bluhdorn, partitioned the company earlier this month. The others are financial services and consumer products. **********Which of the three groups emerges as the largest and most important, after the divestitures planned by Mr. Davis, remains to be seen. Many analysts believe that the financial-services group has more potential for growth than does entertainment. Still, Mr. Diller is generally regarded as one of the three key executives at Gulf and Western under Mr. Davis - who himself is a former chief operating officer of Paramount.  The foundation of the leisure-time group remains Paramount, which accounted for more than half of the group's $1.4 billion in revenues in the 1982 fiscal year; Paramount's contribution to the group's operating profits of $118.3 million were not disclosed, but analysts suspect that it was disproportionately large. **********The group now also includes Simon & Schuster, the book publisher; Madison Square Garden, which has the New York Knickerbockers, New York Rangers and cable television programming; the software design and research remains of Sega Enterprises; and Famous Music Corporation, a music publishing company. **********WHATEVER changes Mr. Diller makes in those businesses, he will make gradually, he emphasized. And he is not giving away whatever plans he has formed. He does acknowledge that he has ambitions for Simon & Schuster, and he turned down a feeler from by its president, Richard Snyder, to buy the company. The publisher, which has concentrated in trade and mass-market books, including the Silhouette romances, should ''become a leader in textbooks,'' probably through acquisition, Mr. Diller said. **********He also disclosed that he has discussed the possibility of starting ''from the ground up'' some consumer magazines. And he confirmed that he is negotiating to buy Time Inc.'s share of USA Network, an advertiser-supported cable network in which Paramount is a partner with Time and MCA, the parent of Universal Studios. Paramount is still seeking a way to compete in cable with Time's powerful Home Box Office, following the recent collapse, under the weight of the Justice Department's antitrust division, of its would-be consortium with MCA, Warner Brothers, Showtime and The Movie Channel. **********Mainly, however, Mr. Diller speaks of areas in which the companies, all of them in the entertainment and information business, can help each other. The ideal is ''Star Trek,'' the syndicated television series that yielded two hit movies, spun off a series of Simon & Schuster books and will result in a video game, to be released this fall. **********Mr. Diller has organized brainstorming sessions to explore more connections between movies and video games. Sega, in turn, can supply Simon & Schuster with educational and entertainment software to distribute, he said. And if it keeps the rights to its games, Madison Square Garden can be a source of programming for its own cable subscriber or for USA Network or for a regional pay-television network that might be established sometime in the undefined future. **********''I want to be in the rights business in everything,'' Mr. Diller said. ''Rights are programs, programs are ideas and ideas are value.'' **********One reason that such opportunities have been ignored in the past, Mr. Diller said, ''is that nobody had the knowledge'' of all the operation. For example, although Simon & Schuster published Jane Fonda's best-selling aerobic-exercise book, the enormously successful videocassette spun off by the book was produced elsewhere. **********On another occasion, two years ago, Madison Square Garden had proposed to sell its interest in USA Network, which was only breaking even, and had received a go-ahead from Gulf and Western, when Paramount ''luckily, luckily, by pure accident, heard about it,'' Mr. Diller recalled. ''And we said, 'You can't do it!' '' He scrambled to put together the three-way partnership. ''It was saved,'' he said, adding ruefully, ''there were a lot that were lost.'' **********At Paramount, Mr. Diller has had plenty of practice in both developing new properties and mining existing ones. By the time he arrived at Paramount - two years after its ''Godfather'' triumph, when it captured 22 percent of domestic theater rentals - the studio's fortunes had sunk. ''It took longer to turn than I expected,'' Mr. Diller said, and he contemplated resigning. Then, in 1978, the studio released ''Saturday Night Fever'' and ''Grease'' and took in 24 percent of domestic rentals. **********That was the last time, under Mr. Diller, that Paramount climbed to the top of the pole. But in each subsequent year, it has had enough reasonably successful films or an outright blockbuster to secure it second place in domestic rentals - the distributor's share of box-office receipts, after the exhibitor takes his percentage - among the major studios. **********In the movie industry, that is considered an extraordinary run. ''They never have a really bad year,'' said Mr. Montgomery, the lawyer. ''If there's no blockbuster, there are always two or three films that pull them through. Barry has a pretty sensible way of filling a schedule.'' **********This year's schedule is fairly exemplary. There were no pre-sold blockbusters, such as a sequel to ''Star Trek'' or to ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.'' But there was ''Flashdance,'' an unheralded movie with relatively unknown actors, that - like ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' last year - became an unexpected success. **********Such pictures are ''the kind of movie I love - inexpensive, with no heat,'' said Mr. Diller. A film with ''heat,'' he explained, is a sequel that has to meet the expectations raised by the first blockbuster. Next summer will bring two ''hot'' movies: ''Star Trek 3'' and ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,'' a sequel to ''Raiders,'' budgeted at a reported $30 million. Will they be blockbusters? ''You won't hear those words from my mouth,'' he vowed. **********PARAMOUNT'S winning streak is more than luck, Mr. Diller said, but neither does he have a formula for picking the right films. ''In my opinion, you have more assurance of succeeding with a movie because you believe in it,'' he said, ''than if you make it because you believe it has the elements, such as the right names, to succeed.'' **********But at the same time, he hedges his bets. The stellar example of creative movie financing is Paramount's ''Reds,'' whose $38 million budget was provided through a tax-leasing deal with Barclays Bank in Britain. The ingenious financing method, combined with an unforeseen change in dollar-sterling exchange rates, amply covered the cost of a film that otherwise ''broke even, plus change,'' Mr. Diller said. ''I'm proud we made 'Reds,' '' he added. ''I'm also proud we protected ourselves in every way known to man.'' **********ANOTHER factor behind Paramount's enviable moviemaking **********record, according to experts, is the company's expertise in marketing and distributing its films. ''Paramount is probably the strongest distributor out there,'' said Mr. Rockwell of Crowell, Weedon. ''They have the relationships with the exhibitors and they know what tracks - tiers of theaters - to pick.'' Paramount's consistently good performance has also endeared it to exhibitors, he added. **********Paramount, and Mr. Diller, have also been cited for expertise in promoting new films, particularly movies - such as ''Flashdance,'' ''Grease'' or ''Staying Alive'' - from which the soundtrack is played on radio and MTV to attract interest.  ''Every time Paramount opens a film, it's like a St. Patrick's Day parade,'' said Mr. Murphy of the University of Southern California. ''There's no doubt a Paramount film has opened.'' And while it advertises heavily, Paramount favors spots on local television over upfront network buys, as a more efficient way of reaching its target audience. **********The box office is only part of any movie's income, of course, and Paramount is good at tapping other sources. United International Pictures, a two-year-old partnership of Paramount, MGM/UA and Universal for the distribution of their films abroad, is very profitable, according to analysts. **********In the video cassette business, a relatively new source of revenue for movie companies, Paramount has taken the lead in slashing prices and making up in volume what it loses in margin. The strategy, combined with a succession of hit movies, has paid off: Paramount has two of the top three best-selling cassettes (''48 Hours'' and ''An Officer and a Gentleman'') and 6 of the 20 most popular rentals (''48 Hours,'' ''Officer,'' ''Airplane,'' ''Airplane 2,'' ''Grease'' and ''Star Trek 2''). **********Historically, Paramount has also been one of the strongest movie studios in the production of made-for-television movies and series, with ''Winds of War,'' ''Shogun,'' ''Joanie Loves Chachi,'' ''Happy Days,'' ''Laverne & Shirley'' and ''Taxi.'' Those series were even more valuable as syndication properties; Paramount has received windfalls from the syndication of ''Star Trek,'' ''Mork & Mindy,'' ''Happy Days'' and ''Laverne & Shirley.'' **********When it made its selections for the fall season recently, however, the networks chose only two of Paramount's 13 proffered pilots, and canceled three hours. As a result, this autumn Paramount will have only two and a half hours on the networks, including holdovers ''Cheers,'' ''Family Ties'' and ''Happy Days.'' ''That's a rather poor performance for Paramount,'' said Mr. Rockwell of Crowell, Weedon. Mr. Diller agreed. **********''We have to be competitive in that area, and we will be,'' he said, noting that he had named a new head of television production. But meeting network demands, he said, ''just wore us down. We'll service them, but I'd rather deepen in other areas.'' **********The area Mr. Diller has in mind is the production of original programming for syndication to independent stations. Its two earliest ventures - ''Solid Gold,'' a weekly one-hour music-and-dance show, and ''Entertainment Tonight,'' a daily half-hour entertainment news program - can be as lucrative as the syndication of ''Happy Days,'' Mr. Diller said, and their success has inspired him to plan a more ambitious schedule. **********In the autumn, he will add ''Taking Advantage,'' a business program made with McGraw-Hill. By next summer, Mr. Diller hopes to put together a mini- network, a three-hour block of entertainment - including a two-hour theatrical film or a Paramount made-for-television-movie, and an hour of Paramount- produced situation comedy or dramatic series - and sell it to a large number of independent stations, to be broadcast in prime time. **********''I want to make our own things and put them on the air,'' he said. **********FROM SMALL TOBIG SCREEN **********In an era when virtually every movie company chief executive seems to be a lawyer or a former talent agent, Barry Diller is an exception. Born in San Francisco, he dropped out of U.C.L.A. after four months - ''I always knew I wanted to get into entertainment'' - and worked briefly in the lower echelons of William Morris, the talent agency, before joining the American Broadcasting Companies in 1966. **********Until he joined Paramount eight years later, Mr. Diller spent his career at ABC, rising to vice president in charge of prime- time entertainment. At the age of 26, Mr. Diller made his reputation by pioneering a new form of programming, ''The Movie of the Week,'' a 90-minute feature that ABC bought for only $400,000, half of what the networks had been paying for two-hour made- for-television movies. In 1972, he introduced another innovation, the mini-series, and secured rights to ''Roots'' for ABC. **********Two years later, Gulf and Western Industries' Charles Bluhdorn hired Mr. Diller as chairman and chief executive of Paramount Pictures, leapfrogging him over Frank Yablans, then its president. Mr. Yablans, now vice chairman and chief operating officer of MGM/UA, resigned two months later. **********At the time, the rumor was that Mr. Yablans had been passed over because of an unflattering magazine article, but Mr. Diller maintains that he had already been discussing the move with Mr. Bluhdorn for several months. **********Although Mr. Diller's appointment was a surprise at the time, no one in the industry now questions his ability or dedication. He is widely described as brilliant, very hard-working and a tough negotiator. **********''A lot of people don't like him,'' said Robert Montgomery, an entertainment lawyer with Paul Weiss, who does not include himself in that group. ''They think he has a cruel mouth,'' he added, referring to remarks that Mr. Diller has made during heated negotiations. **********However, Mike Nichols, who has agreed to direct his next film, ''Heartburn,'' at Paramount, describes Mr. Diller as ''fair and enthusiastic and supportive. He knows as much about how you make a picture,'' Mr. Nichols added, ''as anyone at any studio.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/22/busin.body_text: **********A former stock-dividend manager for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges involving the embezzlement of more than $18 million. **********The guilty plea was made by John Efler, who was described by Federal prosecutors as ''the central figure'' in the huge embezzlement from Prudential-Bache. Mr. Efler waived his right to a grand-jury indictment and pleaded to criminal charges filed by United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani. **********Four of Mr. Efler's confederates have previously pleaded guilty to related fraud charges in the case. **********Investigation Continuing **********The investigation is continuing, according to Shirah Neiman and William J. Schwartz, the prosecutors conducting the case in Federal District Court. They said the embezzlement scheme had included ''other insiders within Bache as well as outsiders who laundered money.'' **********In a cooperation agreement with the prosecutors, Mr. Efler promised to testify for the Government and to return as much of the embezzled money as he could. It was uncertain how much money would be recovered. **********A spokesman for Prudential- Bache, Peter Costiglio, said after the scheme was uncovered that none of the embezzled money came from customer accounts and that all of the losses were covered by insurance. **********From the summer of 1981 until October 1983, the criminal charges said, Mr. Efler and several others carried out a conspiracy to embezzle millions of dollars from Prudential-Bache and to divide the proceeds among themselves. **********Dividend Checks Involved **********Mr. Efler admitted in court yesterday that he had improperly caused Prudential-Bache to issue $18.9 million in checks to various sham companies set up by his confederates in the embezzlement scheme. **********As a section manager in the dividend department, Mr. Efler arranged for the checks to be issued as dividends and interest on stocks and bonds that were supposedly held for the companies in Prudential-Bache accounts. He pleaded guilty to conspiracy, two fraud charges and a charge of transporting stolen money. **********Judge Richard Owen is scheduled to sentence him on March 2, when he could face up to 10 years in prison on one charge, up to five years on each of the others and a total of $22,000 in fines. **********Mr. Efler, who is 38 years old and lives in Whitestone, Queens, has been in jail since his arrest on Oct. 11. He is being held in lieu of $1 million bail. **********Four others who pleaded guilty earlier admitted that they had received the checks that Mr. Efler ''wrongfully caused to be issued'' and that they had shared in the proceeds with him and others.  The four are Robert Chiacchio of Staten Island, Peter Sapone of Manhattan, Larry Monteforte of Edison, N.J., and Lawrence Artese of Queens. Each could face up to five years in prison on several charges. They also signed cooperation agreements promising to testify and return any of the embezzled money in their control.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.body_text: **********The Communications Satellite Corporation yesterday announced the election of three new officers ''to improve its ability to organize and articulate strategic business activities'' and to make Comsat a more market- driven company. **********John L. McLucas, president of Comsat's world systems division since 1980, will assume the new position of executive vice president and chief strategic officer, reporting to the president and chief executive officer. He will be responsible for the development and integration of Comsat's strategic business planning, corporate outreach, marketing, new business activities and relations with the International Telegraphic Union. **********Mr. McLucas, 63, has been with Comsat since 1977, first as president of the Comsat General Corporation, a subsidiary, and later as executive vice president of international communications and technical services. **********Before joining Comsat, he was head of the Federal Aviation Administration from 1975 to 1977. Before that he served as Secretary of the Air Force, and he also was president of the Mitre Corporation, a not-for-profit systems analysis organization, and HRB-Singer, a Singer Corporation subsidiary that produces electromagnetic signal systems. **********Joel R. Alper, who became executive vice president of the world systems division earlier this year, will succeed Mr. McLucas as president of the division. It is the company's largest business, providing technical and communications services through the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization (Intelsat), maritime communications services through the International Maritime Satellite Organization (Inmarsat) and research and development programs through Comsat Laboratories. **********Mr. Alper, now 45, joined Comsat in 1974 as a senior adviser in the international affairs division. From 1981 to 1983 he was vice president of communications services in the world systems division and United States representative to Intelsat. **********Before Comsat, Mr. Alper spent 12 years with TRW Systems, and earlier he worked at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at the California Institute of Technology. **********Comsat also announced that Stephen M. D. Day, 38, would assume responsibility for corporate development, which includes strategic planning, acquisitions and divestitures. He succeeds George Billings, who has been vice president for corporate development since 1982 and is leaving to pursue other business interests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc. said it had withdrawn from a six-month-old **********agreement with Columbia Pictures Industries, Home Box Office Inc. and the 20th Century- **********Fox Film Corporation to offer **********cable programming services **********overseas. CBS decided that foreign **********pay-TV ventures do not fit in **********with the company's business **********plan, George Schweitzer, CBS **********Broadcast Group vice president, said. **********He said the CBS **********decision ''involves no strain at **********all'' between CBS and the three **********other United States companies, **********each of which has joined CBS in **********other businesses. The president of Home Box **********Office, Frank Biondi Jr., said **********he did not know whether a new **********partner would be sought to replace CBS, or whether the remaining partners would divide **********the CBS stake. Under the agreement announced in June, the four companies planned to hold 49 percent of a British venture with **********London-based Goldcrest Films **********and Television Ltd. Subsequently, some of the American partners said they planned to **********form similar ventures in other **********foreign countries, seeking a **********local partner in each. CBS will not lose money, Mr. **********Schweitzer said, because the **********British venture was not yet **********under way.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/24/busin.body_text: **********Brazilian officials were planning to meet with 40 medium-sized international banks at a conference here of the Inter-American Development Bank in an effort to convince them to purchase portions of a $4.4 billion loan that the world's largest banks already have made to Brazil. **********Carlos Langoni, head of Brazil's central bank, said that the entire loan was currently held by only 170 of Brazil's largest creditors. **********He said that the aim of drawing many of Brazil's smaller private creditors into the loan was to lure them back into a normal lending relationship with the country. **********The $4.4 billion credit was signed Feb. 25, Brazilian delegates said. The banks have already disbursed $2.5 billion of the total and have promised to issue the balance in equal parts next June, September and December, they added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve is expected to release rules early next week that would require the nation's 17 largest bank holding companies to keep their primary capital at least equivalent to 5 percent of their assets, banking sources said yesterday. **********Primary capital includes stock, surplus profits, capital reserves and loan loss reserves. **********The action would be the result of a compromise between the Fed and members of Congress who have been demanding that measures be taken to bolster banks' capital as a result of the high level of loans to financially troubled countries. **********As of the first quarter, nine of the top 15 bank holding companies had primary capital in excess of 5 percent of assets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.main_headline: ITALIAN JUDGE VISITS BULGARIA IN INQUIRY ON PAPAL SHOOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.print_headline: ITALIAN JUDGE VISITS BULGARIA IN INQUIRY ON PAPAL SHOOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/world.body_text: **********The judge investigating the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II in 1981 flew to Bulgaria this week to discuss what a lawyer said were new developments in the case. **********The judge, Ilario Martella, left Rome on Monday and was expected to stay in Sofia, the Bulgarian capital, for about a week, judicial sources said today. **********The unexpected trip came a matter of days after Mehmet Ali Agca, the man convicted of attacking the Pope, made his first public statement that the Bulgarian secret services and the K.G.B., the Soviet Government's intelligence agency, were behind the shooting. **********''Something important has happened in the case,'' said Guiseppe Consolo, the attorney representing Sergei Antonov, a Bulgarian airline official imprisoned in Italy for suspected complicity in the attack. **********''There are definitely new developments,'' he said, but added that he could not elaborate.  Judge Martella, heading the 14-month-old investigation into the May 13, 1981, shooting in St. Peter's Square, was accompanied to Bulgaria by Deputy State Prosecutor Antonio Albano, an officer of the European police organization Interpol, an Italian judicial official and an interpretor. **********Among those questioned in Sofia by the judge was Bekir Celenk, a Turkish businessman wanted on suspicion of complicity in the shooting. **********Mr. Consolo said he had submitted four written requests asking Judge Martella to travel to Bulgaria but that the judge had always refused. **********''Our best witnesses are there, but he never wanted to go,'' Mr.  Consolo said. ''But now, it's different.'' Mr. Agca told reporters Friday that Mr. Antonov, 35 year old, was in St. Peter's Square with him the day he shot and wounded the Pope.  He also said he had been trained ''by special experts of international terrorism'' in Syria. **********Mr. Antonov's arrest in Rome last Nov. 25 on charges of complicity was said to have resulted from Mr. Agca's confession in the shooting.  Mr. Agca, 24, also named two members of the Bulgarian Embassy staff as his accomplices, but both left Italy before the authorities could question them. **********Although Friday was the first time Mr. Agca had spoken publicly about the case, sources said he had repeatedly made similar accusations against the Bulgarians and the K.G.B. under questioning by the authorities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/07/world.body_text: **********Lech Walesa said today that he would launch what he said would be ''more effective'' tactics to restore the outlawed Solidarity labor union on Dec. 16. **********But, at a news conference at a church near the Lenin Shipyard here, the Nobel Peace Prize winner refused to give specific plans, other than to stress they would be '' exclusively peaceful. '' **********''We want to reach the maximum number of people possible,'' Mr. Walesa said. ''Maybe I'll be transmitting my message from jail, maybe I'll be on Polish state television.'' **********While the award of the prize to Mr. Walesa Wednesday was a spur to the morale of beleaguered Solidarity supporters - and an embarrassment to the Polish authorities - it will be difficult for Mr. Walesa to translate this into action.   Re-evaluation Suggested **********Although Solidarity still commands the emotional loyalty of millions of Poles, the Government has been effective in crushing the union and discouraging many of its supporters. A number of recent articles in the clandestine press have called for a re-evaluation of strategy, arguing that the political opposition must prepare itself for a long underground struggle. **********The Government, in its first extensive reaction today, published and broadcast a commentary saying that every opportunity was being taken to foment unrest here and accusing the Nobel Prize committee of ''allowing itself to become a tool in the game of confrontation against Poland and socialism.'' **********Standing before signs in St. Bridget's Church with the word ''Nobel'' spelled in flowing Solidarity-style script, with the red and white Polish flag growing out of the letters, the proud Mr. Walesa said that the award had really been given ''to the Polish people.'' **********''Doctor, doctor, laureate,'' he said, listing his honorary titles. ''I will always remain Lech Walesa.''  Monument's Anniversary **********''These new things - well, I have spoken of them before but they have not been made specific,'' was as close as he came to defining his plans for Dec. 16, the anniversary of the 1981 dedication of the monument by the shipyard gates honoring workers killed protesting food prices in 1970. **********''We have always celebrated that holiday,'' he said. Last year when he announced he would make a speech, the police kept him quiet by putting him in a car and driving around all day. **********''I am not a politician. I do not participate in politics; I am a union man,'' he insisted, when asked about the political impact of the award, adding almost in the next breath that he would continue to ''fight for my ideals, but by a peaceful means.'' **********Solidarity and the Government, he said, were ''doomed to agree.'' **********But he said he was ''ashamed of what is happening in my country that people were jailed or fired from their jobs'' for supporting Solidarity and ''ashamed that the union was dissolved.'' **********Mr. Walesa said he had not decided whether he would go to Norway to receive the award. In the past, he has been worried that if he leaves the country, the authorities will not let him come back.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/19/busin.body_text: **********The Far West Financial Corporation agreed to aquire the Bekins Company, the moving and storage concern, for $81.9 million, the companies said. **********Under the accord, which requires a final agreement, Far West would buy all 3.9 million Bekins shares in a tender offer if more than 90 percent of Bekins's shares were submitted. **********At $21 each, that would total $81.9 million. **********If less than 90 percent of the shares are tendered, Far West would buy up to 46 percent of the shares in the tender offer. The remaining shares would be acquired in a cash merger. **********Bekins, based in Glendale, Calif., is the fifth-largest interstate mover in the country. Far West is controlled by the Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia. **********The deal requires approval by the boards of both companies, which are scheduled to consider a final agreement Tuesday, the companies said. **********The Belzberg family last week had offered to acquire 100 percent of Bekins stock at $20 a share, but the Bekins board rejected the offer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.main_headline: Reagan-Thatcher Tape Is Fraudulent, U.S. Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Reagan-Thatcher Tape Is Fraudulent, U.S. Says
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/30/world.body_text: **********A tape recording of a purported telephone conversation between President Reagan and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that was circulated in Western Europe this spring was faked, possibly by the Soviet intelligence service, the State Department said today. **********''This type of activity fits the pattern of fabrications circulated by the Soviet K.G.B., although usually they involve fake documents rather than tapes,'' the department said in written response to reporters' questions. **********A technical analysis of the tape revealed that the voices were those of President Reagan and Mrs. Thatcher, the State Department said. But it said the recording was not of a conversation. **********''We checked with the White House, which advised that no such conversation took place,'' the statement said.
