https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/07/busin.body_text: **********The 22 Bell System companies met a courtimposed deadline today for certifying they will treat competitors equally in states where regulators authorize intrastate long-distance competition. **********The Bell companies and their parent, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, also filed comments with United States District Judge Harold H. Greene defending a decision of the Federal Communications Commission that will ultimately raise local phone rates. **********That ruling involves a new procedure for shifting more of the expense of building and operating local phone networks to local subscribers, instead of relying on subsidies paid by long-distance callers through their long-distance rates. **********Judge Greene had criticized that F.C.C. ruling as shifting too large a portion of local expenses to subscribers. A.T.& T. and the Bell companies countered that the commission had correctly noted that the current system was prompting large telephone users to build their own networks to avoid paying the built-in subsidies. **********The separate filings by A.T.& T. and the Bell companies follow Judge Greene's ruling on April 20 on a key part of the companies' plans for breaking up the Bell System next Jan. 1. **********A.T.& T. is required by an antitrust settlement to give up ownership of its 22 wholly owned Bell companies. It is being allowed to retain most of its long-distance operations as well its manufacturing unit, the Western Electric Company, and Bell Laboratories. **********Separately, A.T.& T. urged Federal regulators to loosen their grip over the market for international ''private line'' telephone circuits. Such circuits are leased exclusively to a single customer and can be used for either telephone traffic or the transmission of computer data.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.main_headline: THE END OF ONE-STOP SHOPPING FOR TELEPHONES AND SERVICES Making Some Sense of the Divestiture
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.print_headline: THE END OF ONE-STOP SHOPPING FOR TELEPHONES AND SERVICES Making Some Sense of the Divestiture
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/29/busin.body_text: **********Q. Much of the discussion of the **********A.T.& T. divestiture suggests **********that it will create many problems. Does breaking up the company really make sense? **********A. It is probably fair to say that none of the parties to the antitrust suit envisioned the outcome quite the way that it has turned out. **********The divestiture plan that finally resulted has been criticized on many counts. Some other plan could undoubtedly have been devised, but no plan would have pleased everyone. To some, no change would seem a more attractive alternative than the current plan. But it is unlikely that the Bell System would have remained in place forever. Increased competition and other changes were beginning to occur even before the breakup was agreed upon. **********At midnight Saturday, the giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company will be broken into eight parts, ending a seven- year antitrust suit filed by the Justice Department. Seven of the new companies, the Bell regional operating companies, will provide local service. The eighth, the ''new'' A.T.& T., will provide equipment and long-distance service. The breakup will mean innumerable changes for consumers and businesses. In question and answer form, here is a discussion of those changes: **********Making Some Sense of the Divestiture **********Q. Much of the discussion of the **********A.T.& T. divestiture suggests **********that it will create many problems. Does breaking up the company really make sense? **********A. It is probably fair to say that none of the parties to the antitrust suit envisioned the outcome quite the way that it has turned out. **********The divestiture plan that finally resulted has been criticized on many counts. Some other plan could undoubtedly have been devised, but no plan would have pleased everyone. To some people, no change would seem a more attractive alternative than the current plan. But it is unlikely that the Bell System would have remained in place forever. Increased competition and other changes were beginning to occur even before the breakup was agreed upon. **********Q. Will the divestiture help or **********harm consumers? **********A. Individuals are likely to find the results a mixed bag, with some changes that are to their benefit and some that are not. **********On the positive side, consumers are likely to find more choice in telephone equipment as well as lower prices on that equipment. The quality of long- distance service offered by some of A.T.& T.'s lower-priced competitors should improve in the next few years, as well. And A.T.& T.'s long-distance rates are likely to fall. **********On the negative side, there is sure to be widespread confusion, particularly in the short run. Consumers are also likely to find it inconvenient to have to deal with more than one vendor when they are used to going to one company for everything. Long-distance directory assistance calls may carry a 75-cent charge per call, and local phone rates may rise more quickly than they may have. **********Q. The United States has the **********best phone service in the world. **********Is this going to deteriorate with **********the breakup? **********A. There is no easy answer to this question. There have been some slip- ups in recent months. But A.T.& T. has had to do two jobs at once - maintaining service at the same time it was coping with divestiture. Some recent service problems are also directly attributable to a strike this summer at A.T.& T. It is hard to predict how well the system will work once divestiture is complete and the companies can concentrate on operations. A.T.& T. executives say there is no reason why service should not be as good as before, but some observers are skeptical. **********Q. Will individual users be affected directly by the breakup? **********A. Yes. In the past, users could deal with one company - A.T.& T. - for everything related to telephone service. Now there will be different companies for buying a phone, paying phone bills, ordering phone service, requesting repairs. The phone bill will reflect this splintering, with separate pages, and in some cases separate bills, for local service, for long-distance services and for equipment rental, if applicable. **********Q. Which company will provide **********what services? **********A. The local phone company - the same one customers have always dealt with - will continue to handle local service matters. It will continue to be responsible for dial tones, for the telephone lines leading to individual phones and repairs on those lines, for local service, and for local directory listings. While the local company will be responsible for connecting customers to the phone system, it will not necessarily provide the phones themselves. But phones will be available in many places, and after buying or renting one, the customer can simply plug it into a jack. **********For long- distance service, the customer will have to go to a different company altogether, either the new A.T.& T. or one of its competitors, such as MCI or GTE-Sprint. **********The First Big Choice: Rent or Buy? **********Q. Where will telephones be **********sold? **********A. Phones are being sold in as many places, and in much the same way, as other consumer goods. They are available in electronics stores such as Radio Shack, in department or discount stores, such as Gimbels or K Mart, in specialized phone equipment stores, such as the Phone Center stores run by the new A.T.& T., and even by mail order. Some local phone companies will be selling equipment as well as service. **********Phone prices range from less than $10 for simple models to hundreds of dollars for sophisticated phones that might store certain numbers and offer automatic dialing. **********Q. Will rental phones still be **********available, or will everyone have **********to buy a phone after Jan. 1? **********A. On Jan. 1, the telephones that have been rented to users by the local phone companies will become the property of the new A.T.& T. Consumers will be given the option of continuing to rent, buying the telephone, or turning in the telephone and buying one elsewhere. A.T.& T. must continue to lease phones at least through Jan. 1, 1986, and other companies may offer rented phones as well. **********Those wishing to continue to rent phones from A.T.& T. will not have to do anything differently. The monthly rate, however, may change. In the past, local companies each set their own charges. Now, A.T.& T. will have one set of national rates. A traditional rotary phone, for example, will cost $1.50 per month, while other types of phones will cost more. At least one state, New York, is allowing its local phone company to impose a monthly surcharge on the equipment rented from A.T.& T. **********In areas that have had relatively expensive monthly prices, the monthly rental charge will fall. But in areas where rates have been low, the rental rates will rise. **********Q. Does it still make sense to **********rent a telephone? **********A. Many types of phones can be purchased for less than the cost of renting one for a year or two. If it makes sense to rent any telephones, it may be the more expensive, sophisticated phones, particularly if technology keeps advancing and new features become available each year. People who do not want to be troubled by handling any repairs may also prefer to rent, since companies that rent phones generally assume responsibility for repairs. **********Q. What factors should be considered in choosing a telephone to **********buy? **********A. Selecting a telephone will be little different from buying a toaster or radio. The numerous products in the various stores will lend themselves to comparison shopping. There will probably be books and articles that talk about the products that are available and how to choose among them. As in any buying decision, shoppers will probably want to weigh price considerations against quality, and to take into account such factors as warranties and convenience and ease of repair. **********In addition, consumers seeking a Touch-Tone-type phone should make sure that a push-button phone produces the proper tones. Many types of phones with push buttons operate on a rotary system. **********Non-A.T.& T. phones have a Federal Communications Commission number, usually found on the bottom. That number should be registered with the local phone company when the phone is installed. **********Q. Is the phone provided by **********A.T.& T. really any different **********from the other, less expensive **********phones that are advertised? **********A. When all phones were owned by A.T.& T. and leased to customers, A.T.& T. found it in its best interest to build the sets to last at least 20 or 30 years. The plastic was thick enough to withstand repeated dropping and the phone could be sent back for reconditioning three or four times and still look like new. Connections were gold-plated to ensure that they, too, lasted. **********As phones become more of a consumer item, purchased by price-conscious shoppers, most companies - including A.T.& T. - are likely to build less expensive sets that do not last as long. There is nothing, however, to preclude one or more companies from making a sturdy telephone. **********Q. How can extensions be **********added? **********A. The local phone company can provide the extra outlet, but the telephone will not automatically be provided at the end of that line. Individuals may also install their own wire to create extensions. **********Q. What if an existing telephone is wired directly to a phone **********line instead of plugged into a **********jack? Will the phone company **********convert the line into one that can **********be plugged in? How much of a **********charge would there be, if any? **********A. If a phone is attached directly to a wire - known as hardwiring - rather than being plugged in, it probably does not matter unless it must be repaired, replaced or moved. The simplest way to detach the phone is just to cut the wire attached to the phone at some point close to the wall. **********The phone can be reattached in a number of ways. It can be hardwired again, or the hardwiring can be converted to a modular jack wth a kit that costs only a few dollars. All new telephones are likely to come with lines that plug into jacks.  PICK UP CONSUMER 2 **********When Something Doesn't Work  Q. What happens when there is **********a problem with a phone? **********A. First, it must be determined whether the problem is in the phone line or in the phone itself. If the problem is in the phone line, the local telephone company is responsible for fixing it, so long as the phone company has installed the line. If the problem is in the phone, the responsibility for fixing it depends on whether the phone is owned or leased. **********Q. How is it possible to tell **********whether the problem is in the **********phone or in the wire? **********A. If there is more than one telephone on the line, check all of them. If they all do not work, the problem is probably in the wire. If only one of them does not work, the problem may be in the phone, but not necessarily. With modular phones, try switching one that works with one that does not to check. **********If the problem appears to be in the wire, call 611 and the local phone company may be able to test it at no charge and put it back in service. **********If a telephone company repair person makes a service call and the problem turns out to be in the telephone rather than the wire, the repair person will not fix the phone but will still charge for the visit. **********Q. What about repairs on a leased phone? **********A. If the phone is leased from A.T.& T., a Phone Center store will replace it without charge. If no Phone Center store is convenient, the phone can be mailed to an A.T.& T. service center. **********Q. What about repairs on a pur chased phone? **********A. If the phone was purchased from a local phone company or from A.T.& T. Information Systems before Dec. 31, 1983, or if it was purchased from A.T.& T. at any time, the local A.T.& T. Phone Center or A.T.&T. service center can handle repairs. If the phone is still under warranty, it will be fixed or exchanged free of charge. **********If the phone is no longer covered by warranty, a Phone Center will exchange it - for a price - for a completely refurbished phone. The charge will depend on the type of phone. A traditional rotary phone, for example, would cost $29.95, while a Trimline Touch-Tone phone would cost $49.95. **********Another alternative for a phone purchased from A.T.& T. but no longer under warranty would be to send it to an A.T.& T. service center for repair. The charge, depending on the repair needed, would be between $12 and $22, plus postage. But only the specific problem will be corrected; no other work will be done. **********Q. How about repairs on phones not bought from A.T.& T.? **********A. Each manufacturer and each store has its own warranty and repair policies that should be considered at the time of purchase. **********Q: Is it really worth having a phone repaired, or is it better just to buy a new phone? **********A. This is a decision that must be made on a case-by-case basis. Factors to be taken into account include the original cost of the broken phone, the cost of a replacement phone, the estimated cost of repair, and the inconvenience involved. If the machine is very sophisticated and cost several hundred dollars and the problem is in a button, it probably makes sense to have it repaired. If, on the other hand, the phone is a simple one and the problem a serious one, it may make sense to get a new phone. **********The Bills: Some Higher, Some Lower **********Q. Does the breakup of A.T.& T. mean that the prices of local service and types of service will change? **********A. Each local telephone company will be free to devise and price the services it offers, with the approval of the state regulatory commission. Nothing in the divestiture plan decrees that types of service and prices must change, although local companies will probably have to place more emphasis on their own profitability in the future than they did when they were part of Ma Bell's brood. **********Q. Are rates going to rise? By how much? **********A. The average monthly phone bill today amounts to $37, of which $11.38 is for local service. Any increases in the near future are likely to be in local rates, and not long-distance rates. In fact, A.T.& T. has said that it will probably lower its long-distance rates by an average of 10.5 percent next spring. **********Local rates are likely to rise, although increases will vary from region to region. **********Q. Is it possible to find out what rate changes, if any, are sched uled in a particular area? **********A. The simplest way to find out is to ask the local phone company. Another alternative is to contact the state regulatory commission. **********Q. Will phone companies have to offer some kind of basic serv ice for people who cannot afford to pay higher prices? **********A. To date, there is no Federal rule requiring that companies offer such service. But most companies do offer some kind of inexpensive budget option. Phone company executives point out that nothing restricts such plans to people with low incomes, and often they are chosen by consumers who make limited numbers of local calls and find that this type of plan makes sense. **********Q. There's been a lot of talk about a plan to impose a new monthly telephone fee - or ac cess charge - on residential cus tomers. Is it really necessary? A. When it became apparent that the local phone companies would be spun off from A.T.& T., it also became apparent that their local charges alone would not provide sufficient revenues. **********In the past, when local service and long-distance service were provided by A.T.& T., a portion of the revenues collected for long-distance service was channeled to the local companies. Some say it is appropriate that long-distance companies pay for their use of the local lines used to complete a long-distance call. **********Now that the local phone companies will be independent from A.T.& T.'s long-distance service, an in-house transfer of funds is no longer feasible, although the money to help support the local companies and to pay for the long-distance companies' use of their lines must be collected, one way or the other. The sum could have been gathered entirely from A.T.& T. and other long-distance carriers, which would have collected it from their users through higher fees. But this presented a problem: Holding long-distance prices high would have encouraged heavy users to set up their own long-distance systems, a phenomenon known as bypass. **********Instead, the F.C.C. devised a system of access charges, under which the long-distance carriers would pay some fees to the local phone companies for use of their phone lines, and individual phone users would pay the rest. **********Q. Where does the access charge plan stand now? **********A. Originally, the F.C.C.'s access charge plan was to have been put into effect Jan. 1. It was pushed back, however, and is now set to take effect April 3, unless the F.C.C. changes its mind again or Congress intervenes. The House has passed a bill that would kill the $2-a-month residential access charge that is now called for, but the Senate has not yet taken up comparable legislation. **********Q. Will there continue to be a **********difference between what the local **********telephone company charges for **********rotary dial service and tone serv ice? How much will it be? **********A. Since each local telephone company sets its own rates, it is impossible to generalize. But to take one example, in New York, where there is a $2.09 additional monthly charge for tone service, New York Telephone has filed a proposal with state regulators to decrease that amount by 20 percent, to $1.67.  PICK UP CONSUMER 3 **********When Something Doesn't Work  Q. What happens when there is **********a problem with a phone? **********A. First, it must be determined whether the problem is in the phone line or in the phone itself. If the problem is in the phone line, the local telephone company is responsible for fixing it, so long as the phone company has installed the line. If the problem is in the phone, the responsibility for fixing it depends on whether the phone is owned or leased. **********Q. How is it possible to tell **********whether the problem is in the **********phone or in the wire? **********A. If there is more than one telephone on the line, check all of them. What about repairs on a **********leased phone? **********A. If the phone is leased from A.T.& T., a Phone Center store will replace it without charge. If it is wired directly into a wall outlet, the wire can be cut so it can be brought in. The Phone Center will then exchange it for a phone with a plug-in wire. But then the socket at home will have to be converted with a jack kit. If no Phone Center store is convenient, the phone can be mailed to an A.T.& T. service center. **********Q. What about repairs on a purchased phone? **********A. If the phone was purchased from a local phone company or from A.T.& T. Information Systems before Dec. 31, 1983, or if it was purchased from A.T.& T. at any time, the local A.T.& T. Phone Center or A.T.&T. service center can handle repairs. If the phone is still under warranty, it will be fixed or exchanged free of charge. **********If the phone is no longer covered by warranty, a Phone Center will exchange it - for a price - for a completely refurbished phone. The charge will depend on the type of phone. A traditional rotary phone, for example, would cost $29.95, while a Trimline Touch-Tone phone would cost $49.95. **********Another alternative for a phone purchased from A.T.& T. but no longer under warranty would be to send it to an A.T.& T. service center for repair. The charge, depending on the repair needed, would be between $12 and $22, plus postage. But only the specific problem will be corrected; no other work will be done. **********Q. How about repairs on phones **********not bought from A.T.& T.? **********A. Each manufacturer and each store has its own warranty and repair policies that should be considered at the time of purchase. **********Q: Is it really worth having a **********phone repaired, or is it better just **********to buy a new phone? **********A. This is a decision that must be made on a case-by-case basis. Factors to be taken into account include the original cost of the broken phone, the cost of a replacement phone, the estimated cost of repair, and the inconvenience involved. If the machine is very sophisticated and cost several hundred dollars and the problem is in a button, it probably makes sense to have it repaired. If, on the other hand, the phone is a simple one and the problem a serious one, it may make sense to get a new phone. **********More Options In Long-Distance **********Q. What kind of changes will **********occur with long-distance service? **********A. For now, A.T.& T. will continue to provide long-distance service as it has in the past. Technically, the local phone company will provide long-distance service within nearby areas, while long-distance companies will provide service over the longer stretches. **********What will change first is the billing. Long-distance calls will be included on a separate bill because A.T.& T. will no longer be related to the company that provides local phone service. For a while, at least, A.T.& T.'s long-distance bill will be included in the same envelope as the local phone bill because the local companies will be serving as billing agents for A.T.& T. **********Q. Where do the other long-distance companies come in? **********A. A growing number of companies offer long-distance service in competition with A.T.& T. The largest of these competitors are MCI and GTE- Sprint. **********Between now and 1986, the connections between these other long-distance companies and the local phone lines will be upgraded so they are comparable to those of A.T.& T. When that happens, the local company will notify consumers of their long-distance options with a request that within a three-month period one be selected. There is also likely to be an option where a consumer will be allowed to choose among multiple carriers by dialing a four-digit access number before the long-distance number. **********Q. What will happen to consumers who do not make a choice? **********A. In that case, the local phone company will decide which long-distance company will provide their service. At this time, it appears that some of the local companies may direct the business to A.T.& T., while others may try to divide the business proportionately among competing companies. **********Q. Once a long-distance provider is selected, can the selection be changed? **********A. Yes. But once other long-distance carriers have equal access to the local phone lines, it will be up to the local phone companies to decide whether to levy a fee when someone wants to change long-distance services. New York Telephone, for example, has filed a request that it be allowed to charge $26.21 each time a customer wants to shift. **********Q. How do the other long-distance services differ from **********A.T.& T.'s? **********A. Currently, there are several differences. The competing carriers offer less expensive service, but the quality of hookup is generally not as good as A.T.& T.'s and the service is not available to callers everywhere. Also, the other services can be used only with a tone phone, or with a tone converter that fits over the mouthpiece of a rotary phone. And users of the other services have to dial more digits. **********To use MCI, for example, a caller must dial a 7-digit local phone number to reach MCI, then a 5-digit code number, and finally the 10-digit long- distance number. **********In addition, the competing carriers generally do not offer operator assistance, so calls cannot be made person- to-person or collect. **********When the other long-distance carriers are given equal access, however, many of these differences are likely to disappear. **********Q. Should a user with an average long-distance phone bill of **********less than $20 a month switch to **********one of A.T.& T.'s competitors? **********A. It may pay at least to consider what the competitors offer, especially after their connections are of equal quality. But it may also pay to look at the competitive packages now if the quality of the connection is not of paramount importance. **********Information on the various calling packages can be found in advertisements or by calling some of the long- distance companies. **********Phone Credit Cards Changing, Too **********Q: Will customers who have **********Bell credit cards still be able to **********use them after Jan. 1? **********A: Yes. Some local companies may send out replacement cards, however. In January, the new A.T.& T. will also be sending its own new credit cards to 47 million customers now holding Bell System cards. These will be good for charging local and long- distance calls from any telephone in the United States and approximately 150 other countries. **********The new A.T.& T. cards may also be used to charge calls directly by inserting them into special ''Card Caller'' phones the company will be installing in public places, such as airports and hotel lobbies. **********Some of the competing long-distance carriers also offer credit cards, with differing terms and availability. **********Q: Is there a charge for obtaining an A.T.& T. card? **********A: No, but there is a service charge for using the card to place a call. For interstate calls, the charge ranges from 60 cents to $1.05 a call. Fees for intrastate calls will depend on charges set by the local telephone companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Four of the nation's largest retailers yesterday reported sharp increased earnings in their first quarter as a result of improved sales, higher margins and better internal controls. **********The biggest gainer was the K Mart Corporation, with a more than seven-fold gain in net income. The Allied Stores Corporation had more than a fivefold surge in its net; the May Department Stores Company had 76.5 percent higher profits, and the Dayton-Hudson Corporation had a 4.6 percent earnings increase. **********''All the results showed that inventory and expenses are under excellent control and therefore there is a good flow-through of the relatively favorable sales performances,'' said Jeffrey M. Feiner, retail analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. ''While the rate of the earnings gains for the remainder of 1983 isn't likely to be as great, we still look for industry profits to increase 15 to 20 percent this year over last year,'' Mr. Feiner said. **********K Mart **********K Mart, the second-largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, reported a $44.6 million profit, or 35 cents a share, for the quarter, up from $5.9 million, or 6 cents a share, in first quarter last year. It was the company's second-highest net for a first quarter since 1979's $45.6 million. **********First-quarter sales rose 9.2 percent, to $3.93 billion, from $3.6 billion in the comparable period last year.  Bernard M. Fauber, K Mart chairman, said that gross profit margins rose to 27.5 percent, compared with 27.1 percent, ''primarily due to benefits from K Mart's improved merchandising programs, increasing consumer demand and the lesser impact of inflation on our cost of merchandise sold.'' **********Sales at K Mart's comparable stores - those at least one year old -rose 7.3 percent over the quarter a year earlier.  On Monday, the J.C. Penney Company, the third-largest retailer, reported an 11.5 percent gain in net income on only 1.7 percent higher sales. Allied Stores **********Net earnings at Allied Stores rose to $13.1 million, or 63 cents a share, from $2.4 million, or 12 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. Sales advanced 13.7 percent, to $761.5 million, from $669.7 million. **********Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer, commented: ''The easing of inflationary pressures, declining interest rates and the slight improvement in the employment outlook have bolstered consumers' confidence, and this has been reflected in the strength of our business.'' **********Mr. Macioce also said, 'We are most optimistic with respect to the business outlook for the rest of this year.'' May Department Stores **********May Department Stores had a net income of $20.3 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $11.5 million, or 40 cents a share, in the 1982 first quarter. **********Sales for the quarter increased 15.3 percent, to $846.8 million, from $734.4 million in last year's first quarter.  Comparable store sales rose about 10 percent.  ''The good earnings performance was a result of strong store-forstore sales throughout all segments of our business,'' said David C. Farrell, president. He said that while margins continued under pressure, ''expense management and control were excellent, resulting in a very positive earnings flow-through.'' Dayton-Hudson **********Dayton-Hudson reported that net income was $22.7 million, or 47 cents a share, compared with $21.7 million, or 45 cents a share, in the first quarter last year. **********The company said that this year's quarter included $953,000 of income from discontinued operations; last year's quarter included $5.3 million of income from discontinued operations and a net gain of about $2.5 million on the sale of six jewelry companies. **********First-quarter revenues from continuing operations were up 22.3 percent, to $1.37 billion, from $1.12 billion in last year's first quarter. ---- Earnings tables, page D6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.print_headline: FINANCE NEW ISSUES; Niagara Mohawk Files Bond Issue
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.body_text: **********The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced from its Syracuse headquarters that it had filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $100 million of first mortgage bonds. **********The proceeds will be used to finance the utility's construction program and to reduce short-term debt. Terms and underwriters are to be named later. **********Niagara Mohawk serves about 1.4 million electricity customers and 400,000 gas customers in an upstate area from Lake Erie to New England and from Canada to Pennsylvania.

He is not expected to hold talks here on Brazil's $59.3 billion in commercial debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.print_headline: ISRAELI, AT LUNCH WITH P.L.O., SUPPORTS A PALESTINIAN STATE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.body_text: **********A left-wing Israeli legislator attended a luncheon today with a representive of the Palestine Liberation Organization and urged the creation of a Palestinian state in the West Bank. **********The Israeli, Charlie Bitton, the lone Member of Parliament of the Black Panther Party, endorsed virtually every plank in the P.L.O.  program. In conversation and toasts, Mr. Bitton urged the United States to encourage Israel to bargain directly with the P.L.O. and also called on Israel to return to its old borders, slash military spending and hand over to the Palestinians lands taken after the 1967 war. **********''I am ashamed of my Government and its political platform,'' Mr.Bitton said.  Mr. Bitton, 32 years old, is from Morocco and sees himself as the champion of ''a cheated community,'' the Sephardic Jews who came to Israel from Arab countries. **********His luncheon host, Hatem Hussaini, the P.L.O.'s deputy observer at the United Nations, embraced Mr. Bitton and called him ''a brother'' in a common struggle, but carefully avoided any suggestion that the P.L.O. would be willing to live side by side with a state of Israel. **********Mr. Bitton, who was elected to the Israeli Parliament on a common ticket with its three Communist members, said he was convinced that the lot of Sephardic Jews in Israel would not improve until military spending was cut. **********Sephardic Jews, he said, need ''better education, better housing, work.'' He said this could not happen ''without a drastic reduction of the defense effort.'' **********''The bigger Israel's borders become,'' he said, ''the less security we have, and we get a constant increase in the defense budget. The creation of an Arab Palestinian state alongside Israel and peace between peoples, we see this would bring about an immediate drastic reduction of the defense budget. We would no longer face enemies. Those funds would go to positive creative uses, to increase the welfare of the people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/15/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell by $1.1 billion in the week ended Oct. 5. Analysts hailed the sharp drop as the strongest evidence in weeks that the money supply was under control. **********''It was positive news for a decline in interest rates,'' said Maria Ramirez, money market economist at Merrill Lynch Economics. **********Reflecting this sentiment, Government securities prices rose sharply and interest rates fell in late trading after the Fed announcement. The price of a key long-term issue - the 12 percent bond due in 2013 - shot up by 1 1/2 points, or about $15 for each $1,000, to 104 2/32. That brought the yield down to 11.50 percent from 11.65 percent Thursday. **********Credit market trading this week, until the money supply announcement, had been dominated by a belief among traders that the Federal Reserve's monetary policy had been tighter than previously thought and the Fed was therefore putting upward pressure on interest rates. As a result, yields generally rose and prices fell until late yesterday. **********Control of Supply Cited **********''The Fed has achieved control over the money supply,'' said Elliott Platt, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, of the new money supply report, which put M-1 at $517.2 billion on Oct. 5. He and other economists said the Fed now had room to ease monetary policy, a policy that could lead to lower rates. **********Miss Ramirez added: ''We have seen a constant weakness reported in the monetary aggregates over the last two months, and since they are well within all the targets, these numbers afford the Fed the feasibility to ease up over the coming weeks.'' **********Short-term rates also declined in response to the monetary reports. The rate on the three-month Treasury bill fell to 8.65 percent after trading at 8.76 percent late Thursday. The one- year bill rate fell to 8.92 percent after trading late Thursday at 9.07 percent. **********The Treasury's two-year note that will be auctioned next Wednesday was offered on a when-issed basis at 10.51 percent, a decline from 10.72 percent late Thursday. **********The Fed has set a growth target for M-1 of 5 to 9 percent for the rest of this year. The decline announced yesterday put M-1 growth at 7 percent, or $2 billion above a 5 percent growth rate, the low end of the Fed's range. M-1, a measure of money considered readily available for spending, covers cash in public hands and most types of checking accounts. **********During all of September, M-1 rose by $700 million, or at a rate of less than 7 percent annually, the Fed reported yesterday. This decline in growth ''means we might have a slightly negative money supply for the month of October,'' said Mr. Platt, who expects decreases in M-1 for the rest of the month. **********The Federal Reserve also reported that two wider measures of the money supply were well within the Fed's monitoring range. It said that M-2, which includes M-1 plus money market deposit accounts and various savings deposits, rose by $8.8 billion to $2,145.7 billion, in September. M-2 is now at the midpoint of the Fed's 7 to 10 percent growth goal. **********M-3 Up by $15.5 Billion **********M-3, which includes M-2 plus large time deposits, rose by $15.5 billion in September to $2,544 billion. This figure is about $10 billion below the upper end of the Fed's growth target of 6.5 to 9.5 percent. **********Bernard M. Markstein 3d, a financial economist at Chase Econometrics in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., said the decline in M-1 ''appears to be the result of the Fed maintaining its level of restraint from the previous weeks together with the end of the quarterly technical factors.'' He said that, while he did not think the Fed eased monetary policy in September, ''it is easing now very moderately.'' **********Robert J. Genetski, an economist at the Harris Bank, Chicago, said the latest figures would help get ''interest rates back in control and give the Fed more room to take a slightly more expansionary step without worrying about inflation.'' **********The money supply report came amid a modest rally on the credit markets, spurred by a decline in the Federal funds rate, the cost of interbank overnight loans. **********Traders said the decline in the funds rate to 9.25 percent yesterday, after hovering at 9.38 to 9.50 percent for most of the week, was a welcome sign that credit policy might be less restrictive. After the money supply report was released, the rate fell to 9 percent. **********In addition, market sentiment improved on the news that inflation in September, as measured by the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, rose by a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, less than analysts had predicted. With inflation under control, the Fed is less likely to rein in credit availability through a policy that enccourages higher interest rates. **********''The Fed moved early to make sure there was no explosive rise in inflation this year and this is being interpreted contructively in the credit market,'' Mr. Genetski said. **********In other data, the Fed also reported that business loans rose by $1.55 billion. Economists said the total business borrowing was still considered low for a recovery period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/busin.main_headline: NAMING OF DRUGS IS NO EASY TASK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/busin.print_headline: NAMING OF DRUGS IS NO EASY TASK
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/14/busin.body_text: **********Dyazide probably won't kill weeds. Zantac never appeared as an alien invader on ''Star Trek.'' And ''Mylanta!'' is not what Scarlett O'Hara exclaimed when she saw her favorite Georgia city in flames. **********All these unusual words are names of drugs. With thousands of drugs on the market and thousands of names already patented, it is no easy task for one of the companies in the highly competitive multibillion-dollar pharmaceutical industry to come up with a title that will make a doctor or suffering consumer reach for its medicine. **********There are several ways of going about it. Some are logical and methodical and involve polling physicians. Some are creative and spontaneous and require sitting around over a few beers. And some are combinations of both approaches. **********In the end, what often pops out is an abbreviation. Take Ridaura, a gold-based drug for treating arthritis that the SmithKline Beckman Corporation, its manufacturer, hopes to introduce soon in the United States. The first three letters, rid, stand for remission inducing drug. Au is the chemical symbol for gold. And ra stands for rheumatoid arthritis. **********Tagamet, SmithKline's ulcer medicine taken by 30 million people around the world since it was introduced in 1976, is a combination of two ideas. Tag is short for antagonist, since the drug fights distress. Met was plucked from the chemical name of the compound cimetidine. **********Who knows what the British were thinking when Glaxo Ltd. of London dubbed its ulcer medicine Zantac.  ''It's just a name we invented,'' shrugged Geoffrey Potter, a spokesman for Glaxo Ltd. Americans are likely to be hearing more about Zantac in the near future; the drug, a Tagamet competitor, recently obtained provisional approval from the Food and Drug Administration. Some drug industry analysts think that Glaxo's new product may give ulcers to the makers of Tagamet. **********''It has no particular connection to the drug or the way it works,'' Mr. Potter said of the name. ''It's short and memorable and doesn't conflict with other people's trade names. The big problem in the pharmaceutical industry is to find an acceptable name that doesn't mean something it shouldn't in a foreign country. There's no real magic to it. It's often sheer slog.'' **********Similarly, at Roche Laboratories, a division of Hoffman-LaRoche Inc., they try to pick names that please the eye and ear. Valium, the tranquilizer responsible for over a billion dollars in sales, ''has a soothing sound,'' a company spokesman, John Doorley, said. **********Naming a drug can take up to several months. The marketing division of a pharmaceutical company selects several possibilities, whittling down a list that may have emerged from a brainstorming session or a computer run, or both. The short list is then sent to the lawyers, who must search trademark records to make sure those names have not already been used. **********One company, Searle Pharmaceuticals, tests the surviving candidates on druggists and physicians to see how easy each name is to spell, pronounce and remember, and to check on the connotations each one has. **********This is often instructive. After Searle invented a new artificial food sweetener a few years ago, it tested the generic name aspartame, asking potential users what they thought aspartame did. ''It came back as either a treatment for hemorrhoids or headaches,'' recalled Richard L. McGraw, a spokesman for Searle. ''We ditched the name.'' **********Opinions vary on how critical the name of a drug really is. 'A Sophisticated Market' **********''It's a sophisticated market. We don't see the name as being responsible for the use of the drug,'' said Fritz Frommeyer, a spokesman for Eli Lilly & Company. **********''It takes seven to ten years and $70 million to come up with a new prescription drug,'' said Roche's Mr. Doorley. ''The name is the easy part.'' **********But what of Dyazide and Mylanta? Dyazide is for high blood pressure, and is the most prescribed drug in the United States, according to Robert A. Holland, a spokesman at SmithKline. The first part of the word is from diuretic, which describes the action of the drug in reducing fluid in the body, and the second is from hydracholorathiazide, an ingredient. **********And Mylanta is an over-the-counter antacid (hence anta) that joined another product of Stuart Pharmaceuticals, Mylicon.  Stuart also produces a vitamin and mineral supplement for pregnant women called Stuartnatal 1 + 1. Natal refers to birth, but 1 + 1 does not refer to mother and child. Rather, it stands for one grain of iron and one milligram of folic acid. Kathy Tridente, a company spokesman, said she could vouch for the product herself. **********''My dog loved the pills,'' she confided. ''She knocked over the bottle and ate every one of them. She had a lot of spunk there.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.main_headline: NEW U.S. ROLE SEEN AFTER P.L.O. FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.print_headline: NEW U.S. ROLE SEEN AFTER P.L.O. FIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the outcome of the struggle within the Palestine Liberation Organization was certain to have ''major implications'' for the future of the American- sponsored peace efforts in the Middle East. **********Mr. Shultz pointed to a recent statement by King Hussein of Jordan, who said that if the P.L.O. fell under Syrian domination there was a legitimate question of whether it could continue to speak for the Palestinian people. Mr. Shultz's remarks were in a speech delivered tonight before the Council of Jewish Federations and Welfare Funds in Atlanta. **********King Hussein declined earlier this year to enter American-sponsored talks with Israel because he could not gain the endorsement of Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman who is fighting for survival in northern Lebanon against a group of Syrian-backed rebels. **********Some State Department officials have said King Hussein might take courage from the P.L.O. struggle and decide to enter negotiations without waiting for a P.L.O. endorsement. But Mr. Shultz avoided going that far in his assessment of the possible results of the P.L.O. strife. **********He said the outcome of the fighting ''is sure to have major implications for Jordan, the Palestinians and the future of the peace process.'' **********The United States, he said, will always keep the door open for negotiations in line with President Reagan's Middle East initiative of Sept. 1, 1982. **********Mr. Shultz said that some people ''have already written off the peace process for the next year'' but that this was a mistake. **********''They think we will shy away from the sensitive issues of the Middle East during a Presidential election year,'' he said. ''Well, they are wrong. Ronald Reagan has no intention of letting the search for peace lapse. We cannot afford to. Let it never be said that the United States was too busy practicing politics to pursue peace.'' **********In the speech, Mr. Shultz made a strong appeal for paying more attention to the problems of Palestinians living in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which are under Israeli control. **********''The Palestinians have been victimized above all by their self-appointed leaders and spokesmen who, for decades, have chased the illusion of military options and foolishly rejected the only possible path to a solution: direct negotiations,'' he said. ''The utter failure of rejectionist policies ought to be obvious by now.''  Better Treatment Urged **********He said it was important that the Palestinians be treated better than they are now if a peaceful solution is to be reached. **********''If their acceptance of a peaceful future with Israel is to be nurtured,'' he said of the Palestinians, ''they must be given some stake in that future by greater opportunities for economic development, by fairer administrative practices and by greater concern for the quality of their lives.'' **********In explaining the United States marines' continued participation in the international force in Beirut, Mr. Shultz said that if American troops were driven from Lebanon, ''our role as a force for peace would be that much weakened everywhere.'' **********''Friends who rely on us would be disheartened and would be that much less secure,'' he said. ''Moderates in the Arab world whom we are encouraging to take risks for peace would feel it far less safe to do so. The rejectionists would have scored a victory, confirming the value of reliance on the Soviet Union. Israel's security would be jeopardized.''  Support and Criticism **********Mr. Shultz repeated United States expressions of strong support for Israel and also repeated criticism of Israeli settlements in the West Bank. He added that the Administration believes that Israel must negotiate peace in the region, based on Mr. Reagan's speech of Sept. 1, 1982. **********He said ''military might and control of territory have prevented defeat on the battlefield, but true security and peace of mind can come only when Israel has gained the acceptance and recognition of its neighbors.'' **********''That is why, even as we assist Israel's capacity to defend itself militarily, the promotion of Arab-Israeli peace through negotiation is the No. 1 priority of our policy and our efforts in the Middle East,'' he said. **********Mr. Shultz said that ''a strong Israel is not only a guarantor of security for the Jewish people, but also a powerful force for freedom and a strategic partner to America and the West.'' He added, ''By helping Israel we also help ourselves.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/busin.body_text: **********AS the corporate annual meeting season reaches its peak, some stockholders who own shares through a dividend reinvestment plan are worried about whether they will receive proxies to vote for the election of directors and other matters. **********In most cases, proxies are sent on schedule by the banks acting as dividend reinvestment agents for these plans, but there have been situations where, because of an additional step involved, proxies and other material from the corporation did not reach shareowners so that they could cast their ballots on time. **********When a company operates a dividend reinvestment plan, its stockholders have the option of taking dividends in additional common stock instead of cash. Most of these stockholders have certificates for the shares they started with, as well as owning shares through the plan, and will at least receive a proxy for the originally held shares. **********The proxy material for the shares held in the plan, however, may be delayed in reaching the stockholders because corporations send them to the plan rather than directly to the owners. When proxies from owners of stock through a plan do not arrive in time to be counted, many corporations automatically vote the shares in the same way that the shareholder voted his original shares. **********But if you sold your underlying shares and hold only shares in the plan, there is a chance that you may not get a proxy card in time for your vote to be counted. Robert Pyle, vice president and counsel of the American Society of Corporate Secretaries, advises individuals anxious about such a possibility to call or write the company and ask that the situation be looked into. ''Generally, companies are trying to get as large a vote as possible,'' he said. **********Robert D. Ferris, a managing director of Georgeson & Company, an investor relations firm, said that, to be absolutely certain of receiving proxies, participants in a dividend reinvestment plan could also ask to have the shares in the plan registered in their name.  ''You can take a certificate for full shares out of the plan in most cases if you are that concerned,'' he added. **********Another concern of some stockholders when receiving material for an annual meeting is the format of the proxy cards through which voting takes place for issues to be considered. Complaints have been voiced that when matters recommended by the board of directors are listed on the proxies of certain companies, the first column is ''for'' and the second is ''against.'' On the other hand, matters that are opposed by the directors of these companies have the columns reversed, with ''against'' appearing before ''for.'' **********The Securities and Exchange Commission does not require corporations to place these columns in any particular order. Its rule 14A-4 states only that ''means shall be provided in the form of proxy whereby the person solicited is afforded an opportunity to specify by boxes a choice between approval or disapproval of or abstention with respect to each matter or group of related matters referred to therein as intended to be acted upon.'' Thus care in reading the cards accompanying proxy statements is the investor's own responsibility. **********The corporate secretaries' society notes that only an infinitesimal number of the proxies that it has studied reverse the order of the boxes for proposals made by independent stockholders. ''I don't see any reason not to do it in the customary way,'' Mr. Pyle said. **********However, Robert A. Byrne, senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, which serves as transfer agent for many companies, said: ''The format of the proxy is at the discretion of the corporation soliciting the proxy. There are as many theories as to formats as there are corporate secretaries and counsels. A lot of managements are very, very sensitive to the percentage of return and percentage of vote.'' **********Any fraction against management proposals or for stockholder proposals ''is considered by some chairman as a slap in the face,'' he added. Bank Money Fund Questions **********The rapid growth of money market deposit accounts in banks since they began being offered last December has raised some questions about aspects of bankers' procedures when handling these accounts.  For example, objections have been raised by customers who make a deposit in their account on a Saturday and find that interest is not credited until the following Monday. **********The policy at many banks appears to be the same whether the deposit is made in an automatic teller machine or at one of the relatively few branches that are open on Saturdays. In New York, both the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company credit accounts on Monday, while Citibank has two different arrangements.  Deposits in existing Citibank accounts do not begin earning interest until Monday, but new accounts go into effect on the Saturday that they are opened. **********Sheldon D. Golub, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association, said that the procedure was usually reversed by banks when money was withdrawn from money market accounts on a Saturday. ''If you took a cash withdrawal on Saturday, you would most likely stop losing interest on Monday,'' he said. ''So you get the benefit of the float.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.main_headline: JAPANESE ISLANDERS BRUSH OFF A VOLCANO'S TANTRUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.print_headline: JAPANESE ISLANDERS BRUSH OFF A VOLCANO'S TANTRUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/01/world.body_text: **********It had rained overnight, and after the water hit the still- hot lava, broad waves of steam wrapped part of Miyake Island in blue- gray gauze. **********The unmistakable smell of sulfur rose, too, but an old woman said that only a visitor would notice. It was a lot worse a few days ago, she said. Along the roads loomed giant hills of black ash, gifts from the island's volcano, Oyama, which has erupted three times in the last four decades. **********If ash and porous rock were marketable, Miyake Island, 110 miles south of Tokyo in the Pacific Ocean, would be in the midst of a boom. Instead, the 4,300 residents might as well adopt the shovel as their symbol. **********For the last few weeks they have done little but dig out from under Oyama's latest outburst, a spectacular tantrum on Oct. 3 that sent lava pouring out of 17 craters and shot pillars of black smoke 33,000 feet into the air.   Like Outstretched Fingers **********The lava cut a 1,500-foot-wide swath down the mountainside and then spread like outstretched fingers, enveloping the village of Ako in Miyake's southwest corner. **********Actually, villagers say, it could have been worse. An eruption in 1940 killed 11 people, and another one in 1962 injured several dozen.  This time, thanks to an efficient evacuation plan, the 1,336 villagers escaped without harm, but 400 houses were buried under as much as 100 feet of molten basalt that reached temperatures of 2,000 degrees Fahrenheit. **********Most villagers live now in barracks-like shelters set up elsewhere on the island, waiting for prefabricated houses to be ready for them in late November. But none have any doubts about their plans after that: Once the tons of lava cool, they will build permanent homes - or what passes here for permanence - right next to the houses that were buried.   'You're in Control' **********It never occurred to Shuichi Kamakawa to do anything else. His grandfather lived in Ako, and the grandfather's grandfather before him. **********''Here, you can find jobs and make a living according to your own abilities,'' said Mr. Kamakawa, who ran a small guesthouse. ''You're in control of your own life.'' **********Of course, he agreed, Oyama also exerts some control. But then he shrugged and muttered a phrase heard often on the island: ''Shikata ga nai'' - ''There is nothing we can do about it.'' **********This urge to return to a scene of probably recurring disaster is more than just a phenomenon familiar in, for instance, southern California, where cliff dwellers watch heavy rains wash their houses down to the sea and then rebuild in the very same place to await the next storm. It is even more than Japanese acceptance of natural disaster, including volcanoes, which are not in short supply. There are 67 considered to be active in Japan, or one-tenth the world total, according to the Government.   Villagers Stay Put **********What really motivates the islanders is not that they live on Miyake but rather in Ako, or in Tsubota or in the three other villages scattered across the 34 square miles of ponds and tall grass. A person from Ako would not be happy in Igaya, and so he will stay put and that is that, residents say. **********Not surprisingly, there are rivalries among the villages. In a bureaucratic anomaly, the entire island falls under the jurisdiction of the Tokyo metropolitan government. To keep animosities to a minimum, Tokyo rotates its Miyake headquarters from village to village each year. **********Cooperation seems to be the rule since the latest Oyama eruption, which not only inundated Ako but also covered the fields and houses of Tsubota with a blanket of black ash two feet deep in places. Still, one Tsubota man groused the other afternoon about how demanding he thought Ako residents had become as a result of their new misfortune.   A Touch of Venus **********From the air, western Miyake resembles the photographs of Venus, with vapors rising from a barren landscape. Enormous rocks hurled from the mountain had formed a new island just off the southern tip of Miyake, but the ocean has begun to swallow it, and it is expected to disappear soon. **********Perhaps a third of the island is covered by ash or hardening lava. Men and women scrape the ash from the roadways, and eventually it will be piled atop mountains formed from the ashes of the 1940 and 1962 eruptions. **********What on Oct. 3 had been a forest thick with trees is now a wide black scar dotted with what appears to be bleached sticks. The snaggled tops of lifeless trees poke through the pumice, which has cooled considerably but whose surface temperature is still nearly 200 degrees Fahrenheit in places. **********Shuichiro Inoue, who heads relief operations for the Tokoyo metropolitan government, estimates damages at nearly $100 million, with the authorities already having provided more than $4 million in aid in addition to private contributions.   A Habitat for Birds and Tourists **********The island depends on tourism and some dairy farming for its survival. Its thick woodlands and marshes make a fine habitat for wild birds, and tourists particularly enjoy visiting here in the late spring and summer. **********Even before Oyama erupted once again, younger people had decided Miyake was not for them. The population has declined gradually but inexorably since 1962, from more than 7,000 to the present 4,300. **********Older folks, such as Mr. Kamakawa, have no intention of leaving, although he has also had enough of the mountain's whims. ''Probably like all the other changes in society today, these eruptions are coming more and more frequently,'' he said with a laugh. **********Yoshie Sasaki said that at the age of 48 she had no plans to move either. She was sitting in a snack bar called the Phoenix, in the same seat, she said, that she had occupied when the volcano exploded. **********''For myself,'' Mrs. Sasaki said, ''I don't have the will to leave.'' Then she looked at one of her eight grandchildren, who was sitting next to her. ''But when I think of them,'' she said, ''I'd like them to get out of here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/14/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********We've been annoyed a long time over the A.T.& T. suit, but the self- righteous William G. McGowan has made us boil over (''Struggling to Make the Breakup Work,'' July 17). Who does he think he is, telling thousands of small shareholders of A.T.& T. that they should be ''punished'' because he happened to get a suit decided in his favor which will certainly enrich him? ( **********The article noted that, according to a decision issued before the A.T.& T. case was settled, A.T.& T. had violated antitrust laws. Mr. McGowan, chairman of MCI Communications, had commented, ''If you violate the law, the shareholders should be punished.'' **********) **********A.T.& T. had been satisfactorily regulated under Federal law for many years. Neither the public nor its stockholders asked the Government to, in effect, sue itself. All Mr. McGowan has done is to attack the incomes of all those ''widows and orphans'' who now hold uncertain A.T.& T. paper, to make the future of telephone service dimmer and the rates for it certainly much higher. **********Yet all that Mr. McGowan, this Galahad of commerce, can find to say of his destructive spoilerism is ''much ado about nothing.'' I sincerely hope the result of his greed is a resounding business failure. FLORENCE AND ARTHUR DE SANTIS Bayside, N.Y., July 19 **********The writers are owners of 60 shares of A.T.& T.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/24/world.body_text: **********The Government called on Poles today to work harder as it presented to Parliament a three-year austerity plan for dealing with the country's economic ills. **********Under it, workers face longer hours, higher prices, new taxes and the loss of such treasured privileges as first crack at buying the goods they make. **********Warning that ''the material basis of the national existence'' was endangered, the Government listed Poland's troubles as including its $26 billion indebtedness to the West, the Western policy of sanctions imposed after the imposition of martial law in December 1981, ''a significant regression in the standard of living'' and a generally unfavorable worldwide financial climate. **********The Government also cited investments in projects that could not be completed and an imbalance between a surplus of money in some hands and a shortage of consumer goods. **********1985 Plan Below 1980 Level **********It appeared, however, that even if the austerity goals were fulfilled by the end of 1985, the level of production would be less than it was in 1980, the year when economic unrest led to the formation of the Solidarity union movement. **********The economic program is aimed at increasing industrial production by 14 to 16 percent, mainly by higher productivity and more efficient management. **********During today's session, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, moved two generals into key posts.  Mieczyslaw Moczar, 70 years old, was retired from his post as chairman of the Supreme Chamber of Control, a watchdog agency. A Communist guerrilla commander under the German occupation in World War II, he was a tough in-fighter in political battles over the years and was associated with the anti-Semitic purges of the late 1960's. **********He was replaced by Gen. Tadeusz Hupalowski, who had been Minister of Administration, Local Economy and Environmental Protection. The new Minister of Administration is Gen. Wlodzimierz Oliwa, the commander of the Warsaw garrison. Walesa Summoned on Finances **********Meanwhile, Lech Walesa, the former Solidarity leader, said by telephone that he and his wife, Danuta, had been summoned to appear before tax inspectors in Gdansk on Friday. He had previously been questioned about union finances. **********Here in Warsaw, the former Solidarity press spokesman, Janusz Onyszkiewicz, who was released from internment in December, was briefly taken into custody by the security police as he was drinking coffee with a Western reporter. Mr. Onyszkiewicz, who was later released, was among former Solidarity officials who met with Mr.  Walesa in a Warsaw church on Sunday. **********The crux of the austerity program outlined today is to get more work out of a labor force that is hampered by a shortage of raw materials and inefficiency. Workers are also frustrated by high prices and by the consumer goods shortage and are resentful over the crushing of the hopes raised by Solidarity before it was outlawed last year. **********''Labor productivity in Poland is very low,'' Janusz Obodowski, the planning chief, told Parliament.  Noting that other developed countries were two or three times more efficient in their production, he called not only for harder work but also for conservation of energy, fuel and raw materials. **********According to the P.A.P. press agency, he denounced the ''simplistic approach to equality, false egalitarianism and aspiration toward identical or very similar renumeration for all, regardless of the quantity and quality of work, qualifications, skills and experience.'' **********''This is a dangerous and anarchistic tendency that political opponents tried to implant into Polish society over the last few years,'' he said. **********The austerity program includes a drive against graft and profiteering.  Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak said Tuesday that an inquiry was under way into a trade deal that he said had defrauded the treasury of $1 million. He reported inquiries under way ''against 482 millionaire criminals whose property had no basis in legal income sources.'' Labor Shortage Is a Problem **********Mr. Obodowski, the economic planner, said ''the primary source of the crisis lies in departing from principles of socialist management.'' **********One problem is a shortage of workers, with almost every factory understaffed, sometimes by hundreds of jobs. This is largely caused by a program to encourage early retirement to cut down on malingering and make way for younger workers. **********According to official statistics, 550,000 people have chosen early retirement since August 1981. At the moment, there are 256,800 unfilled jobs and only 7,000 applicants, the Government says. **********Another problem is that the output of consumer goods has not kept up with purchasing power, especially among higher-income groups like private farmers and coal miners. **********One of the major goals of the program is to reduce reliance on imported food, particularly wheat. but private farmers, who now have piles of worthless zlotys, are holding back their wheat. **********The Government program calls for stopping work on hundreds of half-built factories and for concentrating instead on small-scale projects such as cottage industries, getting pensioners to work part-time, and encouraging workers to work overtime and on days off. **********The program envisions attempts to hold managers accountable for the efficiency of their businesses.  ''The Government does not promise an immediate way out of the crisis,'' Mr. Obodowski said. '' No one anywhere has a prescription.  That would be tantamount to charlatanism. But this does not mean passivity. We will be working with the greatest energy. '' **********Mieczyslaw Mieszczankowski, an economist, has presented a gloomier assessment, telling the newspaper Zycie Warszawy earlier this week: ''Please remember that this is one of the biggest catastrophes in world economic history. Even though we are rising from the bottom, a slight upward movement will not change the fact that we are still deep in the crisis.'' **********A delegation of Western bankers is here this week to see whether there is any prospect of getting payment on the interest on Poland's debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The New Jersey Casino Control Commission has approved plans by the Del E. Webb Corporation to sell its Claridge Hotel and Casino for $42.7 million to investors searching for tax shelters, the company said. **********The investment group will lease the building to another company, which will then hire Webb to operate the facility. The investors bought minimum shares of $100,000 in the project, but will be able to claim tax deductions totalling $250,000 over the next five years, officials said. The Claridge, the city's smallest gambling hall, lost $30.4 million in 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.main_headline: CONRAIL NET UP DESPITE REVENUE DIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.print_headline: CONRAIL NET UP DESPITE REVENUE DIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/21/busin.body_text: **********The Consolidated Rail Corporation yesterday reported a 16.7 percent rise in net income to $97.2 million, or $3.66 a share, for the second quarter, from $83.8 million, or $3.31 a share, a year before. **********The earnings increase came despite an 18 percent drop in revenues, which totaled $778.4 million in the latest quarter, compared with $958.9 million in last year's second quarter. Conrail has been decreasing its overhead by cutting back on its work force and phasing out track that is no longer useful. **********The second-quarter profit included income from the sale of tax benefits of $3.4 million, compared with $27.6 million a year earlier.  L. Stanley Crane, Conrail's chairman, has estimated that earnings for all of 1983 could total about $200 million, much better than he was expecting earlier this year. **********He has also said that, unlike past periods, most of the earnings will come directly from operations and not from the sale of tax credits. Union Pacific **********The Union Pacific Corporation reported second-quarter earnings of $98.9 million, or 80 cents a share, down 1.2 percent from earnings of $100.1 million, or $1.04 a share, in the second quarter last year. **********Revenues for the quarter totaled $2.09 billion, up 36.6 percent from $1.53 billion in the similar quarter of last year.  Last year's net income included a gain of $29.8 million from the sale of the common stock of IC Industries but did not include the earnings of the Missouri Pacific Corporation and the Western Pacific Railroad Company, which were acquired last Dec. 22. **********Second-quarter earnings for last year, stated as if the merger had been in effect, would total $147.8 million, or $1.21 a share, and revenues would be $2.18 billion. **********The consolidated railroad earnings for the second quarter totaled $63.6 millon, down slightly from $66.8 million a year before.  The Champlin Petroleum Company, a subsidiary, had second-quarter earnings of $25 million, down 24 percent from $32.9 million. This was a sharp turnaround, however, from Champlin's loss of $42.8 million in the first quarter of 1983. **********''In the second quarter, the railroads and Champlin posted solid income gains over the first quarter,'' William S. Cook, the president and chief executive officer, said in a statement, ''as consumeroriented traffic improved and refinery margins moved into the black.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/world.body_text: **********A strong earthquake rocked northern Japan today in the same region where 102 people were killed last month in a major quake that sent 10-foot waves crashing ashore. There were no reports of casualties or significant damage, the police said. In Hong Kong the Royal Observatory estimated the quake's intensity at 6.9 on the open-ended Richter scale and said its epicenter was in the Sea of Japan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.main_headline: A.T.& T. Lists Prices for Phones
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.print_headline: A.T.& T. Lists Prices for Phones
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/30/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today announced ''a guaranteed price list'' that shows consumers how much they would pay to buy the telephone they now rent if they wait until next year to make a decision. It lists the standard rotary dial instrument for $19.95. **********In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, the telephone giant noted that customers of its local Bell System companies in 34 states already have the option of buying the telephones now in their homes. **********After the Bell System is broken up on Jan. 1, the ownership of those phones will switch from the local companies to A.T.& T. But that change will not affect a consumer's right to purchase the telephone or to continue renting it, A.T.& T. said. **********The company proposed to guarantee its price list for selling rental phones after the breakup for ''at least two years.'' The price list shows the maximum charge for a standard rotary phone will be $19.95; for a standard Touch-Tone phone, $41.95; for a Princess rotary phone, $39.95; for a Princess Touch-Tone, $49.95; for a Trimline rotary, $44.95, and for a Trimline Touch-Tone, $54.95. **********The company also unveiled its price list for those consumers who want to continue leasing their phone after the breakup. That list shows the monthly rental fee for a standard rotary phone will be $1.50; for a standard Touch-Tone, $2.85; for a Princess rotary, $3.15; for a Princess Touch-Tone, $4.05; for a Trimline rotary, $3.45, and for a Trimline Touch-Tone, $4.60.
