https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; Battle Brewing On Trade Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; Battle Brewing On Trade Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/31/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON ''LOOK for blood on the floor before this is over,'' said one key Administration figure as the hawks and doves of East-West trade circled over the Export Administration Act of 1979. The legislation, under which President Carter and President Reagan have imposed foreign policy trade sanctions against the Soviet Union, will expire Sept. 30 unless it is renewed. **********At the sub-Cabinet level the hawks, led by Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, and Richard N. Perle, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Policy, have already moved to toughen the statute. **********At higher levels and in the international business community there is dismay over the way things are headed. Clashes have already been reported at the Commerce Department. **********Business organizations are pressing a campaign to limit extraterritorial application of foreign policy controls and to try to get sanctity of contracts accepted as a principle for exporters of nonagricultural goods - both hot issues that were raised with the implementation of sanctions against the Soviet gas pipeline. **********Farmers have already won a Presidential pledge that their contracts will be honored if signed 60 days before any new embargo. Business wants a similar commitment, arguing that the United States position as a supplier is on the line. **********The Brady-Perle faction seeks to make the law even more restrictive. For example, foreign availability would become less of a factor than it is now in weighing the need for controlling a specific product. **********The Administration had hoped to have a position ready for hearings next Thursday before the Senate Banking Committee chairman, Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, himself a hawk who wants to set up a separate control agency. **********Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, is set to testify. With the outlook dim for any agreement by then, chances are that Mr. Olmer will have to fudge. Interest Withholding Attacked **********A campaign to repeal the Federal Government's plan to collect a 10 percent witholding tax on most dividend and interest payments appears to be succeeding beyond anyone's reasonable expectations. The banks and savings institutions that have mounted a vigorous lobbying effort to kill the measure before it becomes effective next July 1 are now talking optimistically of swift Congressional action. **********So far this year, more than 220 Representatives - a majority of the House - as well as 24 Senators have signed on as sponsors or cosponsors of legislation to repeal the law. Congressmen who co-sponsor a bill do not necessarily vote for it, but even this rally against the withholding provision is braoder than had been expected. **********The new law provides that income tax is to be withheld from interest and dividends at a flat rate of 10 percent, with certain exemptions for the elderly and the poor. It is intended to assure that taxpayers pay what they owe on interest and dividend income. An estimated 15 percent of them do not do so now, costing the Treasury about $3 billion a year. **********From the beginning, banks have railed furiously against the law, protesting that the paperwork would prove overwhelming. Even before the new regulations came out last November, the American Bankers Association circulated letters to its 13,100 members exhorting them to mobilize stockholders and customers to ''set up a clamor.'' **********This seems to be working, as banks across the country are urging depositors to badger their Congressmen. Some offices on Capitol Hill say they are receiving a steady flow of letters. **********Most lobbyists acknowledge, however, that they still have a tough fight ahead, especially since the Government needs every dollar of revenue it can get. The withholding measure, which was passed last summer as part of the three-year, $99 billion tax bill, had strong support from the Internal Revenue Service and from several Congressional sponsors, including Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. Briefcases **********- Gary N. Horlick, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration, is favored to succeed Donald E. deKieffer as general counsel at the Office of the United States Trade Representative. **********- Bill Brock, the trade representative, is telling friends he wants to stay the course with President Reagan and has no plans to run for the Senate seat now held by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. The Tennessee Republican has said he will not seek re-election.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.main_headline: PARLIAMENT IN BONN IS DISMISSED TO MAKE WAY FOR EARLY ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.print_headline: PARLIAMENT IN BONN IS DISMISSED TO MAKE WAY FOR EARLY ELECTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/08/world.body_text: **********President Karl Carstens dissolved Parliament today and, bowing to the wishes of the nation's political parties, called an early general election for March 6. **********The decision had been expected since Chancellor Helmut Kohl intentionally lost a confidence motion on Dec. 17 to open the way to new elections. **********Unlike most West European heads of Government, the West German Chancellor does not have the discretion to force new elections when he chooses. Some legal experts have accused Mr. Kohl of abusing the spirit of the West German Constitution, which has many safeguards to insure governmental stability. **********The President, who, like the Chancellor, is a Christian Democrat, was reported to harbor doubts about the confidence-motion device, but he voiced none in a televised speech this evening. **********He observed that all parties had expressed to him their wish for new elections and that, as President, he was not in a position to judge the motivations of deputies who had expressed a lack of confidence in Chancellor Kohl. **********''Many believe that the situation after March 6 could be more difficult than it now is,'' the President said, alluding to fears the election may not produce a stable majority in the lower house of Parliament. ''But such uncertainty is involved with nearly every election.'' Prospects for the Election **********The thrust of the President's remarks was to lend constitutional legitimacy to the confidence-motion device, rendering the West German Constitution more flexible for future political impasses. **********Most opinion polls indicate the the Christian Democrats taking just about 50 percent of the vote. Their junior coalition partners, the Free Democrats, have been consistently polling less than the 5 percent of the popular vote needed to return to Parliament. **********A recent poll by the well-regarded Allensbach Institute gave the Christian Democrats 51.1 percent, the opposition Social Democrats 38.6 percent, the Green movement 6.3 percent and the Free Democrats 3.6 percent. **********But no major polls have been disclosed since the Social Democrats won an unexpected majority in state elections in Hamburg on Dec. 19.  The Hamburg election suggested that the conservative Kohl Government was vulnerable to accusations that it was siding with the affluent against the poor. It also suggested that the electorate may be volatile now when unemployment is increasing and cutbacks in social spending are in prospect. Free Democrats Soften Tone **********Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the Free Democrats' leader, has begun to soften his tone toward the Soviet Union in remarks that appear to be aimed at an anxious electorate. **********In a party statement issued today, Mr. Genscher called the Warsaw Pact's offer of arms reductions and a nonaggression pact ''noteworthy and remarkable,'' and he declared that ''the East-West dialogue is in full swing.'' **********Mr. Genscher also suggested that alternatives to the Reagan Administration's so-called zero solution at the Soviet-American nuclear arms reduction talks in Geneva should be considered. Under the zero solution the North Atlantic Treaty Organization would forgo its planned deployment of 572 cruise and Pershing 2 medium-range missiles in Western Europe starting late this year if the Soviet Union dismantled its comparable weapons. **********Public opinon polls and soundings by politicians indicate that many West Germans oppose the stationing of a new generation of nuclear weapons here and would greatly prefer to see a breakthrough in the Geneva talks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/world.main_headline: SHULTZ AFTER A YEAR IN OFFICE:LOOKING FOR A SUCCESS ABROAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/world.print_headline: SHULTZ AFTER A YEAR IN OFFICE:LOOKING FOR A SUCCESS ABROAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/01/world.body_text: **********As Secretary of State George P. Shultz begins his second year in office, he remains to all appearances a cautious and philosophically conservative man in what many officials still see as an inexperienced and divided Administration. **********So far, senior Administration officials say, President Reagan's major accomplishment has been to build momentum in military and domestic economic policy. Many officials attribute their having avoided lasting failures and catastrophes to this momentum, as well as to Mr. Reagan's good luck and Mr. Shultz's ability to heal breaches with friendly countries. **********Now, with international problems simmering and with Presidential primaries not far off, the officials say Mr. Reagan and Mr. Shultz are looking for foreign policy successes. These could include arms control treaties with the Soviet Union, a workable policy in Central America, European support for new medium- range missile deployments in December and movement in Middle East talks beyond the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement. That accord may never go into effect unless Syria reverses course and agrees to pull out. **********3 Recent Decisions by Reagan **********Some officials are asking themselves whether the Administration as it is now - its top personnel and procedures for making decisions - has the skill and unity to produce such successes. **********Three recent decisions by Mr. Reagan suggested that Mr. Shultz's bureaucratic position had been weakened. **********A new high-level arms control group was set up under the chairmanship of William P. Clark, the national security adviser. It in effect supercedes the interdepartmental group that had been led by the State Department. **********New Mideast Envoy Named **********Also, Robert C. McFarlane, Mr. Clark's deputy, was named instead of a State Department official to succeed Philip C. Habib as the President's special envoy to the Middle East. **********Officials said Mr. Shultz's candidate for the Habib job had been Donald H. Rumsfeld, President Ford's Defense Secretary. The reasons for naming Mr. McFarlane remain unclear, in light of the key role he has been playing in East- West issues and the prevailing judgment in the Administration that negotiations in the Middle East are not likely to make significant progress in the next year and a half. **********And Mr. Shultz's power over developing long-range policy on Central America, at least, was called into question by Mr. Reagan's appointment of former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger as chairman of a Presidential commission to study that area. This ran counter to the much advertised prominent role that Mr. Shultz was supposed to play in framing policy on Central America.  Some officials, particularly those in the State Department, say they look to Mr. Shultz to stitch together what has been, in effect, two contending Administration foreign policies - that of the doctrinaire conservatives who resist any compromise with the Soviet Union and that of the pragmatic conservatives who are willing to bend to pressures at home and from friendly countries abroad. The President himself is seen by these officials as being of both minds. **********Other officials, including some who appreciate Mr. Shultz, find him to be part of the problem. They say that he, too, is torn between the two philosophies. They contend that, like other senior officials, he remains cautious and unsure of his ground on many issues and that he feels fully comfortable only in his own field, international economics. **********Shultz Lists His Priorities **********Mr. Shultz said in an interview recently that his priorities for the rest of the Administration would be maintaining American military and economic strength; dealing with the Soviet Union; paying more attention to ''our own neighborhood'' in Central and South America and Canada, and the Middle East. **********He said Soviet-American relations were ''a major theme that dominates any Administration's foreign policy because it's so central.'' **********Asked about Mr. Reagan's pledge to restore the Soviet-American military balance before negotiations, Mr. Shultz said, ''I think we're in a good position to negotiate.'' He added, ''Whether it's exactly restored or not, certainly we have improved our situation greatly.'' **********''One of the things that I knew before but I have realized more intensively since being in office is the sense in which everything is connected,'' he went on, sitting, shirt-sleeved, on a satin sofa in his large, formal office.   'See Connections Early' **********''There is such a thing as a world view that you have to somehow find your way to,'' he said, ''and the creative acts are ones where you do see connections early and pursue them.'' **********To make progress in Soviet-American relations, there is talk among key Administration officials of possible changes in the National Security Council staff and among certain top Pentagon officials in the fall. **********In recent months, it would appear, Mr. Reagan has shown more flexibility and less pronounced hostility toward the Soviet Union, and there have been some changes in the Administration's arms control proposals, more activity concerning possible negotiations in Central America, an easing of restrictions on technology transfers to China and improvement of relations with Israel. **********But these steps do not constitute abandonment of the tough positions of the Administration's first two years, nor are they sufficiently decisive to produce breakthroughs. Many officials are waiting to see whether Mr. Reagan will press for some foreign policy success - perhaps a meeting with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.   Efforts on Arms Control **********As several high-ranking Administration officials acknowledged, even if Mr. Reagan ordered greater efforts to reach an arms control treaty with Moscow, it is far from clear that he and his senior aides realize how many compromises it would require, that they have the confidence in their knowledge of the subject to make those compromises and that they could overcome the officials they placed in the bureaucracy who oppose such a treaty.  Whatever the situation in the Administration, Mr. Shultz said recently that the Soviet Union would have to negotiate seriously on arms control. Moscow's effort, he argued, ''to derail deployments'' of our missiles in Europe ''as distinct from negotiating them away, has failed now.'' **********Asked what incentives are being offered to the Russians, he responded: ''Our own strength and purpose are there, and to the extent they feel that, barring an agreement, they have to accept very high costs and very great risks, then there's an incentive for an agreement. I think that the stakes have definitely been raised.'' **********Doctrinaire conservatives and bureaucrats say it is not at all clear that Mr. Reagan's top advisers are now any more knowledgeable about the world than his original team.   Shultz Lacks Haig's Experience **********Mr. Shultz does not have the foreign- affairs experience of his predecessor, Alexander M. Haig Jr. The same is said of Mr. Clark, the national security adviser, who replaced Richard V. Allen, and of Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who succeeded Gen. David C. Jones. **********Some officials said National Security Council meetings rarely last more than an hour, in part because Mr. Reagan prefers short sessions but also because those present do not have much background beyond their briefing papers. For example, a meeting in May to review the position on strategic arms reductions ended after less than an hour. **********Officials throughout the Administration sense that precisely because those in the leadership know they do not know very much, they do not like to make big decisions. Because of this, the decision- making system is weighted against big or bold steps. As in the first two years, most activity centers on the third tier of policy makers, the assistant secretaries and their equivalents.   Running Battles **********At this level there continue to be running battles, sometimes over apportioning areas of responsibility and sometimes on substance and language, on arms control and Central America. Most of these go unresolved for months until they reach the National Security Council. The decisions handed down from there, the officials said, tend to be ambiguous or narrow, so the fighting goes on. **********This has been the case, officials said, on most issues regarding Soviet-American relations and possible contacts with leftist forces in Central America. **********Decisions on other issues are put off, officials said, because they are deemed ''too hot to handle.'' This was the case with a memorandum Mr. Shultz sent to the President in mid-March calling for wide-ranging talks with the Soviet Union. After three months Mr. Clark told the State Department that it should convert the memorandum into an options paper. Even after this was done, no meeting was held. **********It was into this sort of situation that George Shultz stepped a year ago. He made immediately clear to his staff that he was determined to end the rancor that had existed between Mr. Haig and virtually all other agencies and departments. **********State Department officials say Mr. Haig used to return from the White House and relate a decision by the President, then his aides would tell him why it was bad or Mr. Haig himself would complain and make efforts to change the decision. By contrast, the officials said, Mr. Shultz conveys the decisions and when his aides complain he says,''Get on the team.''  Shultz Described as Methodical **********Key State Department officials are generally careful in what they say to reporters about the White House, as are White House officals about the State Department. They do not want to stir up problems or, worse, be accused of stirring them up. Feelings are raw between key Shultz aides and key aides to Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger. **********Mr. Shultz's aides describe him as others have: conservative, methodical and calm; as an incrementalist, a problem-solver and a mediator. He even kept his equanimity recently when Mr. Reagan dismissed Thomas O. Enders, the Assistant Secretary for Inter- American Affairs.  Leaks from the White House held that Mr. Enders was perhaps too eager for talks with Central American leftists and that he and the State Department were more ''cookie pushers'' than policy managers. **********By all accounts, Mr. Shultz's views are virtually identical to Mr. Haig's. In most cases that has meant positions similar to those advocated by senior Foreign Service officers. But unlike Mr. Haig, he does not push those positions that are contrary to what he thinks are Presidential inclinations. Unlike Mr. Haig, he subordinates himself at every opportunity to Mr. Reagan. **********Like Mr. Haig, Mr. Shultz has taken to sounding hard-line themes in Congressional testimony. Both men went out of their way to take tough positions with Congressional critics on Central America and Soviet policy. Both Secretaries felt, according to aides, that it was important for them to show ideological fidelity to Reagan political campaign themes in this forum. **********Admired in Congress **********In Congress, the prevailing judgment as that Mr. Shultz is the soundest Administration voice on foreign affairs. It is a potential power base that Mr. Shultz has not used, aides say, for fear of running a lobbying operation against the White House. **********Among Weinberger aides, Mr. Shultz is seen as a captive of the State Department, which these aides characterize as following the paths of least resistance, leading to capitulation. **********In the White House, Mr. Shultz's loyalty is much admired, but there is an uneasiness about his not having produced a success. It is rare to hear, as was often heard a year ago, ''Let George do it.'' But the White House shows little sign of giving Mr. Shultz latitude to move when he has asked for it. **********In the State Department, Mr. Shultz continues to be praised and respected, with some reservations. **********His defenders argue that international economics is the most important aspect of international affairs over the long run, and that Mr. Shultz has his priorities right. **********Some State Department activists are concerned that Mr. Shultz is not disposed to fight day in and day out for the kind of decisive action needed for a major international breakthrough.   Compromises on Arms Control **********The defenders noted that Mr. Shultz was a main force behind recent compromises on arms control talks and that he and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige pushed through a loosening of restrictions on technology transfers to China over the opposition of the Pentagon and the staff of the National Security Cuncil. **********The defenders said they and Mr. Shultz were perplexed that his virtues seemed to have been transformed into vices by critics and complainers. Mr. Shultz's calm is now sometimes portrayed as passivity, his team-playing as unwillingness to fight for what he believes, and his mediation skills as proceduralism at the expense of substance. **********Mr. Shultz is aware, his defenders said, that time is running out on diplomacy, that once Presidential primaries begin room for maneuver is limited. They said Mr. Shultz would concentrate his energies more on East-West relations and Central America. **********Mr. Shultz, in the recent interview, added to this the Middle East. He said: ''I don't see anything wrong with our policies, and I haven't heard anybody propose a better alternative policy. The problem is not in the policies; the problem is in the difficulties in bringing them to fruition.'' **********Mr. Shultz is not going to move on all of these fronts, his aides said, by going to war with the White House. As he sees it, Mr. Haig tried this and failed. Mr. Shultz will try to use quiet persuasion on Mr. Reagan. As Mr. Shultz is fond of saying, ''It is Mr. Reagan's policy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.print_headline: WEEK IN BUSINESS; NEW ESMARK OFFER CONVINCES NORTON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/busin.body_text: **********Esmark sweetened its bid for Norton Simon, the company accepted the offer and David Mahoney is getting richer. The price tag is about $34 a share, or $918 million, plus Esmark gets a ''right of first refusal'' to buy any of Norton Simon's companies for one year. This will probably discourage Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts and last week's newcomer - Anderson-Clayton - from pursuing their own takeover bids.  As for Mr. Mahoney, right, his ''motivation all along has been to get the best deal for the shareholders,'' his spokesman said. And Mr.  Mahoney is no small shareholder. His 718,513 shares will be worth some $25 million under the new deal - $3.5 million more than the value under his initial $29 a share offer. Moreover, his five-year, $9 million employment contract will be honored, even though he will probably leave the company after the acquisition. **********More sweeteners. Lenox finally acquiesced to a $3 a share improvement in Brown-Forman's takeover bid -$90 a share, or $408 million. The china and crystal maker was evidently uncertain about the effects of its ''poison pill'' defense and was concerned about a possible flood of lawsuits by angry shareholders. Lenox chairman John S. Chamberlain will be elected to the Brown-Forman board. Of the coming merger, W.L. Lyons Brown Jr., president of the distiller and winemaker, said, ''I suppose Bolla wine could be served in Lenox crystal.'' **********A cheer went up at Sotheby's when it learned that Philip Taubman, the Michigan real estate developer, had persuaded General Felt owners, Marshall Cogan and Stephen Swid, to halt their takeover attempt of the British auction house. Felt will sell its 29.9 percent stake in Sotheby's to Mr. Taubman at $10.66 a share - a $10.6 million profit for General Felt. **********The third stage of the tax cut, which should pump some $30 billion of additional spending and savings into the economy over the next 12 months, took effect last Friday amid continuing signs that economic growth is surging. The President's economic advisers raised real growth figures for all of 1983 to 5.5 percent, up from 4.7 percent, and estimated that the faster pace of recovery would shave as much as $15 billion off the budget deficit. But they also see an unemployment level of 9.6 percent for the last three months of 1983. **********Sales of new homes rose 4.3 percent in May to their highest levels in three years, while in the same month the Index of Leading Economic Indicators was up 1.2 percent, new orders for factory output rose 1.9 percent and machine tool demand was up 28 percent. **********Turkey economics? House Speaker O'Neill's proposed $700 cap on the third and final stage of the President's tax cut failed in a 55-to-45 Senate vote. But will the opponents of the tax cut get back at Mr.  Reagan in the fall when Congress - to his displeasure - will decide whether to raise some $12 billion in new taxes called for by the recently passed budget resolution? Republican Senator Bob Dole, charman of the Banking Committee, seemed skeptical. ''My point is,'' he said, ''that a lot of these turkeys who voted for the budget resolution won't vote for the real thing.'' **********Ray Dirks was vindicated. The Supreme Court ruled that the insurance analyst did not misuse insider information in 1973 when he tipped clients of the impending collapse of the Equity Funding Corporation, an insurance fraud scheme that cost investors millions of dollars. It was a strong defeat for the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had censured Mr. Dirks for violating securities laws. In supporting Mr. Dirks's actions, the court set a new, more liberal interpretation for what constitutes illegal insider trading. **********The stock market worried about interest rates all week, falling almost 33 points early on and regaining less than half of the loss by Friday's close. The Dow finished down more than 16 points, to 1225.26. Interest rates, which were erratic during most of the week, soared on Friday after the Federal Reserve reported a surprising $600 million rise in the money supply. **********Bank deregulation moved ahead, as President Reagan's deregulation committee eliminated all ceilings on the interest rates that banks can pay on time deposits with maturities from 32 days to 2 1/2 years and asked Congress to permit banks and thrift institutions to pay interest on business checking accounts. The committee also eased penalties on early withdrawals from time deposits. As for the lowly passbook savings accounts, its interest ceilings of 5 1/4 percent to 5 1/2 percent will remain until 1986. **********Bethlehem Steel found $500 million in innovative financing for modernizing two of its plants. The Voest-Alpine Group, an Austrian state-owned company, will build efficient continuous casters for the struggling No. 2 U.S. steelmaker, which will in effect lease the units. The funds will come from a group of banks and the Austrian government. Bethlehem not only benefits from modernization, it will not carry the loans on its books. Moreover, the first payments are not due until 1986. **********Coming and Going. Thomas F. Grojean resigned as president of the faltering Tiger International. Mr. Grojean had been expected to become chairman within a few years ... ''Smiling Jack'' Gallagher, founder of Dome Petroleum and famed Beaufort Sea driller, gave up the helm to J. Howard MacDonald, who had negotiated a billion-dollar rescue program for Dome that saved it from bankruptcy ... Gerald Tsai, the mutual fund wizard, became vice chairman of American Can and part of its newly formed office of the chairman. He also was responsible for American Can's purchase of a 5 percent stake in Paine Webber ... Richard M. Morrow will succeed John E. Swearingen as chairman of Indiana Standard. **********Potpourri. Baldwin-United narrowly avoided bankruptcy again. Five creditor groups agreed to a standstill agreement covering more than $1 billion of its debt ... G. Heileman Brewing agreed to return $1 million in profits it made on Olympia Brewing stock as settlement of an S.E.C. charge that it illegally used insider information in its stock purchase ... Imasco dropped its $1.11 bid for Canadian Tire.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/25/busin.body_text: **********Archer-Daniels Upheld On Redemption Method **********A Federal judge has ruled that the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company's early redemption of $125 million in debentures was properly funded from the proceeds of a common stock offering and was in compliance with the terms of the offering, company officials said yesterday. **********The ruling, by Judge Leonard Sand in United States District Court in Manhattan last Friday, came in a suit brought last month by Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The investment banking firm had contended that Archer-Daniels improperly used borrowed funds to redeem the 16 percent debentures, which were due in 2011. **********According to Paul M. Dodyk, an attorney representing Morgan Stanley, the judge has still to decide whether the redemption complied with Federal and state securities laws. He added that Morgan Stanley would probably appeal the finding that the redemption was in accord with the terms of the debentures. **********The lawsuit is of interest to many investors and securities dealers because it tests the ability of corporations to retire high-interest debt long before its stated maturity. **********Some holders of the Archer-Daniel debentures were surprised by the redemption call and contended that it was a violation of the company's promise not to refund the debentures before 1991 with funds borrowed at an interest cost below the 16.08 percent cost of the debentures.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/23/busin.body_text: **********In a step to promote commercial operations in space, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration signed an agreement yesterday with Fairchild Industries for the development of a privately owned space platform on which industrial and Government customers could rent slots for payloads. **********The $200 million platform, called Leasecraft, is to be designed and built by Fairchild with its own funds. The space agency, for its part in the joint venture, will provide technical support and two free trips on the space shuttle - one to deliver the platform into earth orbit in 1987 and another, six months later, for shuttle astronauts to service the platform. **********After that, Fairchild would pay for shuttle trips at the going rate for commercial users. Such trips would deliver the experiment packages of Fairchild's rental customers and bring back any scientific and industrial materials produced.  Accord Signed in Washington **********The agreement was signed in Washington by James M. Beggs, the NASA administrator, and Edward G. Uhl, Fairchild's chairman and chief executive officer. **********Mr. Uhl said Leasecraft should put the United States ''in the lead in facilities available for space manufacturing, and offers the promise of profitable business for potential customers, for NASA and for Fairchild.'' **********A company spokesman, John E. Heaney, said Fairchild was talking to a number of potential customers, but ''nothing is signed.'' The company, he said, intends to start with one platform and ''go from there.'' **********One potential customer is the team of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Johnson & Johnson, which on recent shuttle flights has tested a process for producing pharmaceuticals in the microgravity environment of space. Other companies are reported to be weighing plans for orbital production of rare alloys and ultrapure crystals for semiconductors. **********10 Years of Operation Sought **********According to preliminary designs, Leasecraft would weigh 12,000 pounds and measure about 15 feet long, 15 feet wide and 14.5 feet thick and contain modules to supply electrical power, communications and data processing and an orbital maneuvering capability. **********Customers that leased space aboard it would pay according to the size, duration and servicing requirements of their experiment or processing plant. The space shuttles would visit the platform every few months. **********NASA has recently signed or is negotiating several such arrangements that involve private investment in space. A West German aerospace company, Messerschmidtt-Boelkow- Blohm, has already built a similar but smaller and less maneuverable platform that was flown on a shuttle mission in June. **********The European Space Agency is developing a platform for experiments and production facilities that is called Eurca, for European Recoverable Carrier, and is expected to be lofted by a shuttle in 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/25/busin.print_headline: Advertising; National Journal Has New Goals
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/25/busin.body_text: **********THE National Journal, a weekly published in Washington, is as serious in the magazine field as Peak Freans are in the land of cookies. And if you don't believe it check the annual subscription price, $455. You can't get much more serious than that. **********Started without advertising in the fall of 1969 by Anthony C.  Stout, a Wall Street lawyer, the publication decided to change its ways last September to save subscribers from a rate increase. And, apparently, management is just as serious about advertising since the advertising cost per thousand rate is $580 for a black-and-white ad compared with a similar investment in Fortune, which would be only $32. **********However, since the circulation of National Journal is only about 5,000 the total cost of an ad does not come as anything of a shock to the heavyweight organizations that are being talked to by John Fox Sullivan, the 39-year-old president and publisher, and Roger Kranz, 32, the ad director. **********Those are of the stripe of I.T.T., the Edison Electric Institute, General Motors, the Tobacco Institute, Ford and the American Council of Life Insurance, and they want to get their messages before the powers that be. National Journal's special pride is reaching readers of that kind, and Mr. Kranz, who was founder and publisher of the Washington Journalism Review, has been known to travel with a properly underlined printout of his subscriber list that can be whipped out at the appropriate moment. **********''One-third of of the circulation is with the Government on all levels -anybody in the White House that counts - and 450 go to Capitol Hill,'' he said on a recent visit to the capital of advertising. There is also an average household income of $75,300 that is fairly impressive. **********Mr. Sullivan said: ''It is edited for policy makers in Government and the private sector who have a keen interest in the making of Government policy. I see us as covering this country's biggest business, and that's Government.'' **********He and Mr. Kranz last summer had set a goal of 200 ad pages for this year, a goal they achieved in January. So now they are aiming higher. **********But they have also declared themselves as opponents of clutter and say they are determined to limit advertising to 20 percent of the magazine. And no product advertising, please, unless it is for books. **********While one might think that in this economy any publication that restricts itself to thought-provoking rather than hard-selling ads might well find itself stricken from media schedules, Mr. Kranz maintains that as media lists are being cut back so are sizes of target audiences, and that falls right into the sphere of influence of the publication that calls itself ''Your inside track to the nation's policy makers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/28/busin.body_text: **********When Andreas Papandreou's Pan Hellenic Socialist Movement came to power in Greece two years ago, George A. Tsatsos, one of the country's leading industrialists, tried to establish cordial relations with the new administration. **********The effort, he now acknowledges with a wan smile, did not work. Indeed, he has become the prime target in what Western diplomats see as a Government campaign to discredit private industry by blaming it for both Greece's deepening economic malaise and the Socialists' failure to make good on many promises. **********Mr. Tsatsos used to be managing director of Heracles General Cement, Europe's biggest cement producer and one of Greece's few successful big companies. Its sales totaled $350 million last year - equivalent to almost 1 percent of the Greek economy's total output. He and his family are the company's largest private shareholders, with about 20 percent. **********Government's Press Tirade **********At first, Mr. Tsatsos said, he tried to make peace with the Socialists by never criticizing them and by calling on Prime Minister Papandreou and his Cabinet members to discuss economic problems. **********In September, however, the Government opened a tirade in the press against business corruption in general. **********Soon afterward, the Government accused Mr. Tsatsos and 12 other top Heracles executives of $100 million worth of fraud and currency smuggling. Legal proceedings against them began, and they were prohibited from leaving the country. **********The Heracles executives, denying any impropriety, resigned. They complained that the Government had pronounced them guilty without holding a trial. A new board of directors, appointed by the Government, took control of the company. On the Athens stock market, Heracles shares slumped to $4 from $14. **********Allegations of Secret Fund **********The attack on Heracles is one of several Government actions that have created fear and uncertainty in the Greek business community. **********In a newspaper interview, for instance, Prime Minister Papandreou said right-wing Greeks had set up a secret $120 million fund in Chicago with the aim of undermining the Greek economy. Opposition leaders demanded proof, but nothing more has been heard of this charge. **********With 50 percent of Greek production already in state hands, ministers talk of ''socializing'' the private sector and say they are seeking industrialists guilty of ''economic sabotage.'' **********The Minister of National Economy, Gerasimos Arsenis, has said he knows of 45 bank directors - not identified - who have made ''abusive loans.'' And he has promised that the Government, already nationalizing the pharmaceutical industry, will take control of Peiraki-Patraiki, a troubled textile company.   A Warning to Companies **********The Socialist press regularly publishes the names of companies that supposedly are about to suffer the same fate as Heracles. After France's Socialist Government asserted that it had obtained a list of foreigners with secret accounts in a major Swiss bank, Prime Minister Papandreou said he had asked President Francois Mitterrand for a copy of the list. **********The Greek business community has begun to strike back. In a speech in October, Theodore Papalexopoulos, president of the Greek Industries Federation, denounced the attack on Heracles, saying it had ''caused serious damage'' to the company and to society as a whole. **********He said Government threats were creating an impression ''that nationalization, in one form or another, of all private enterprises is imminent and that we are moving toward an economy that will have central control of all activities.'' **********'Grave Consequences' Seen **********Such a climate, he went on, ''destroys not only entrepreneurial creativity but also the ability to operate on a day-to-day basis, with grave consequences for the whole economy.'' **********Mr. Tsatsos describes the attack on his company as ''political.'' The Government always knew what Heracles was up to, he declared, since it controls the company through a 40 percent stake held by the state-owned National Bank, which has four directors on the company's board.

Mossinghoff, Assistant Secretary of Commerce and head of the Patent and Trademark Office, was one signer of the agreement. ''This is a landmark event for the patent offices,'' he said. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/19/world.main_headline: U.S. SEES CHAD AS A PORTENT OF QADDAFI'S AMBITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/19/world.print_headline: U.S. SEES CHAD AS A PORTENT OF QADDAFI'S AMBITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/19/world.body_text: **********Reagan Administration officials said today that they regarded the conflict in Chad as a major test of wills with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader. They assert that Colonel Qaddafi had made no effort to disguise his plan of controlling Chad and of eventually unifying all African Moslems under the Libyan banner. **********Because of the Libyan's declared goal of a greater Islamic state and his disdain for the independent African countries created from former European colonies, the Administration deems the situation in Chad very serious. **********Officials said today that if Colonel Qaddafi, working through Goukouni Oueddei, former President of Chad, was able to overthrow the Government of Hissen Habre, the likely result would be problems for nations such as the Sudan, Niger, Nigeria, Egypt, Cameroon, the Central African Republic and Senegal, all of which are pro-Western and all of which feel, in varying degrees, threatened by Libya. **********Libyans Bolstering Troops **********There is a pause in the fighting in Chad, but American officials said that, having helped Chad rebels seize about half the country, Libya was now rushing in additional forces for a possible offensive against Ndjamena, the capital city. **********So far, there are about 3,500 Libyan soldiers in Chad, along with tanks and armored personnel carriers, backed by bombers and fighters based in Libya or in the disputed stretch of frontier called the Aozou Strip, seized by Libya from Chad in 1973. **********In addition, the rebel forces, under former President Goukouni, have about 1,500 lightly armed troops. There are also believed to be a further 1,000 or 1,500 armed men assigned to the Libyan-led Islamic Legion in Chad, officials said. **********The forces of Mr. Habre total about 3,000, officials said, and they are bolstered by a growing French force that may reach 2,000 and 2,000 Zairians. The United States, which has supplied military aid, has flown two Awacs reconnaissance planes to the Sudan for possible use if France - which has a security treaty with Chad - decides to commit fighter planes in defense of its former colony.   We Are Coming to a Crunch' **********''I guess you could say we are coming to a crunch,'' one Administration official said. ''Qaddafi may try to push on further south, or he might be planning to partition Chad and avoid a battle with the French, but even that would be unacceptable to us and to everybody else since that would permanently destablize Chad and put Libyan troops right on the western borders of the Sudan.'' **********''American policy is for Libya to get out of Chad,'' he said. ''The Libyans should not be in Chad. We have to show the Libyans they cannot win in Chad. We also have to do what we can to get the Africans united in pressing Qaddafi out.'' **********Colonel Qaddafi has sent troops into Chad before, but each time was prevailed upon to withdraw, most recently in 1981, when by a twist of history, Mr. Goukouni, then President, asked him to pull his forces out. **********Mr. Goukouni, however, lost out several months later in a power struggle with Mr. Habre, a former colleague from northern Chad who turned against him many years ago.   C.I.A. Backed Habre With Money **********The United States at one time backed Mr. Habre with Central Intelligence Agency funds when he was operating out of the Sudan and Libyan forces were in Chad. **********But when the Libyans departed, the United States urged him not to continue his civil war with Mr. Goukouni, and instead work toward unifying Chad, a senior Administration official said. Mr. Habre rejected this advice. **********Mr. Goukouni then fled Chad and made his way to Libya once again to seek help from Colonel Qaddafi. Early this year, American and French intelligence noticed large-scale movements of troops and equipment toward Libya's border with Chad.   Qaddafi's Book Is Cited **********In describing their interpretation of Colonel Qaddafi's designs, experts on Libya begin with his so-called ''Green Book,'' which sets forth the revolutionary ideology that the Libyan leader calls the ''third universal theory.'' **********In it, he advocates a restructured world. And that explains, officials say, Libya's backing for subversive or revolutionary and terrorist groups in such places as Latin America, Northern Ireland and the Philippines. **********He has placed his emphasis, however, on Africa, and in the belt that cuts across the continent below the Sahara, where more than half the population is Moslem. In Chad, for instance, 50 percent of the population is estimated to be Moslem, the rest Christian or tribal. In Niger, the percentage of Moslems is 85 percent, in the Sudan, 60 percent. **********''As Qaddafi sees it, since the Arabs are already spiritually united through the Koran, there is a connection between Arab unity and Islam,'' a leading Nigerian scholar, Oye Ogunbadejo, writes in the current issue of International Security, a journal published at Harvard. ''Only the artificial political boundaries, created by the former colonial powers, and the reactionary regimes in the Arab states prevent the realization of total unity.'' **********Colonel Qaddafi has been accused of financing or directing subversive plots in such varied countries as Morocco, Niger, the Sudan, Egypt, Tunisia, Ghana, Upper Volta, Nigeria, Gambia, Somalia, Senegal and Mali. He has also been accused by the United States of sending assassination teams abroad and of providing safe haven for many known terrorists, including the plotters of the 1972 Munich Olympics massacre. **********Mr. Ogunbadejo and others have said that, given the discontent inside Libya, the signs of occasional mutiny in his 55,000-man army, and his vast $13 billion arsenal, Colonel Qaddafi seems almost eager to embark on foreign adventures to distract his people.   Special Attention From U.S. **********The Reagan Administration, from the start, has singled out the colonel for special attention. It has severed relations with Libya, and banned imports of oil from there. But although France has also reacted with concern to Libyan moves in Africa, it has refused in part for economic reasons to treat Colonel Qaddafi as a pariah. It buys oil from Libya and argues that it is important to keep lines of communication open with the Libyans. **********In addition to this specific difference, President Francois Mitterrand of France has sought to distance his policy toward Chad from Washington's. But American officials in the White House, Pentagon and State Department all said today that American and French policy has been closely coordinated. **********One State Department official, with long experience in French affairs, said: ''I can't remember a crisis with better consultation between Paris and Washington.'' **********''Mitterrand's problem is that it is a tenet of French policy not to be seen marching arm in arm with America,'' the official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/12/busin.body_text: **********A Federal appeals court has ruled that a company may not dismiss an employee solely because he would not lobby for the legislation his employer supported. **********The case was brought by John Novosel, formerly a district claims manager for the Nationwide Insurance Company in Butler, Pa. **********In October 1981, Nationwide circulated a memorandum asking all employees to lobby the Pennsylvania House of Representatives in support of a bill to reform the state's no-fault insurance system. **********Mr. Novosel refused to participate in the lobbying effort and privately stated his opposition to the bill. He was dismissed Nov. 18, 1981. Although he had worked at Nationwide since December 1966, he was covered neither by a personal employment contract nor by a union contract - a status known as employment at will, which has traditionally meant that the employee can be dismissed at any time for any reason. Recently, though, more and more courts have recognized exceptions to that doctrine. **********Examples of Wrongful Discharge **********For example, many courts have ruled that the company is guilty of wrongful discharge when an employee is dismissed for refusing to perform tasks that are against public policy. In past cases, employees have been protected when they have refused to perjure themselves or have blown the whistle on corporate wrongdoing. **********In the Novosel case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, said that an attempt to control an employee's political expression was also against public policy, so that political adherence to the employer's views could not be made a condition of employment. **********''This case raises a whole new area for employers to be concerned about: whether they can terminate employees for what they say or what political actions they take,'' said Charles Bakaly, a California lawyer who specializes in defending management in labor cases. **********''It goes further than any case I've ever seen in upholding employees' First Amendment rights,'' he said. ''From this decision, it would not be much of an extension to say that workers have the right to tell their boss that he stinks, or to go on television and announce that the company's products are no good. The ramifications of this decision are incredible.'' **********Focus on Political Expression **********Although the Novosel decision, issued on Oct. 26 and written by United States Circuit Judge Arlin M. Adams, mentioned general free- speech concerns, it focused mostly on freedom of political expression. **********''The protection of an employee's freedom of political expression would appear to involve no less compelling a societal interest than the fulfillment of jury service or the filing of a worker's compensation claim,'' the opinion said. ''An important public policy is in fact implicated wherever the power to hire and fire is utilized to dictate the terms of employee political activities.'' **********Mr. Novosel's complaint ''discloses no plausible and legitimate reason for terminating his employment, and his discharge violates a clear mandate of public policy,'' the court said. **********Since the Circuit Court decided only the legal principle that such a firing might be illegal, the case was sent back to the trial court for further proceedings to determine the facts of Mr. Novosel's particular case. **********Richard C. Polley, the lawyer who represented Nationwide, said the company would ask the court for a rehearing by all the judges on the circuit. ''We think the decision is an aberration,'' he said. ''This wasn't just an employee not supporting the legislation, it was an employee who opposed it and went to upper-level company personnel to express his views against it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.body_text: **********The second- and third-ranked jobs at the Department of Energy are expected to be filled within weeks, after being vacant for months. **********Candidates Chosen For Energy Posts Danny J. Boggs, 38 years old, is President Reagan's candidate for Deputy Secretary of Energy, the No. 2 position, and William P. Collins, 37, is expected to be confirmed by the Senate as Under Secretary, the third- ranked job. **********Mr. Boggs, assistant director of the White House's Office of Policy Development and a special assistant to the President, would replace W. Kenneth Davis, who left in January. The salary would be $69,800 a year. **********Mr. Boggs has long been a proponent of energy price decontrol and has worked extensively on energy and natural resource issues, particularly those involving natural gas. **********Before joining the White House office, Mr. Boggs practiced law with Bushnell, Gage, Reizen & Byington. In 1977, he became deputy minority counsel on the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, where he worked extensively on the natural gas and electric utility portions of the President's National Energy Act. **********In 1975-76, he worked as assistant to the chairman of the Federal Power Commission, where he was involved in natural gas pricing, electric utility policy and Alaska gas transportation. In 1973, he was assistant to the Solicitor General of the United States. **********He graduated from Harvard University in 1965 and from the University of Chicago Law School in 1968. **********Mr. Collins, who testified last week at a confirmation hearing before the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources, said he would consider energy conservation and the promotion of renewable energy technology his primary areas of responsibility as Under Secretary. The position pays $68,400 per year. **********''I believe we should pay at least as much attention to barrels of oil equivalents saved through prudent use of energy as we do to energy production, and that conservation in itself can be viewed as a national resource,'' Mr. Collins said in his statement to the committee. If confirmed, he would replace Guy Fiske, who left the department in June 1982. **********Mr. Collins, now staff vice president for political affairs at the National Association of Home Builders, has been involved with energy and environmental issues since 1973, when he was legislative director for then- Representative Alan Steelman of Texas. **********During that time, he was the chief Republican staff member involved in the creation of what was then the House Environmental Study Conference and worked on projects involving strip mining, water and power projects, and solar, wind and geothermal energy. **********He continued his work on energy- related issues in 1977 as administrative assistant for Representative Ron Marlenee, Republican of Montana, whose district was concerned with such issues as coal, oil and gas extraction. In 1979, he left Capitol Hill to join the home builders' group. **********Mr. Collins grew up in Bitteroot Valley, Mont., graduated from University of Montana and did postgraduate work at the International School of Law in Arlington, Va., and at the American University in Washington, D.C., in business administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.main_headline: PRITZKER SAID TO SEEK BRANIFF BACKING ON DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.print_headline: PRITZKER SAID TO SEEK BRANIFF BACKING ON DEAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, will meet with officials of Braniff International today in Dallas to ask them to approve his offer to revive the airline and to get their authority to negotiate directly with secured creditors, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday. **********Last week Mr. Pritzker offered to invest $35 million - $20 million in cash and $15 million in loans - in the airline, which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, in exchange for a controlling stake in Braniff and the right to manage the company. **********Today's meeting with the Braniff board has been scheduled for 2 P.M. Braniff also faces a deadline today of filing a reorganization plan with the Bankruptcy Court in Fort Worth. It was not immediately clear whether Braniff would ask the court for a postponement in view of the continuing negotiatons. **********The source said that the main disagreement between Mr. Pritzker and the secured creditors was over the amount that would be paid to them in leasing the 31 airplanes that Mr. Pritzker wants to use to get the airline flying again. The secured creditors, therefore, asked Mr.  Pritzer to get authority from Braniff's board of trustees giving him the right to negotiate directly with the secured creditors. **********Mr. Pritzker has told creditors he wants to rent the Braniff planes for $70,000 a month per airplane, plus 17 1/2 percent of any profit up to $100,000 per airplane per month. **********Although the creditors had earlier this year agreed to a similar proposal by PSA Inc., an airline based in California, the source said that they now wanted more for the rental of the airplanes in Mr.  Pritzker's venture. **********The source said that Mr. Pritzer's position was that if the Braniff board agreed, he would then negotiate further with the secured creditors. The source said, however, that if the board did not give him the authority, the deal would be dead. **********Some of the secured creditors indicated after a meeting last Friday that they were unhappy with the way Mr. Pritzker had structured his proposal because he is asking for 80 percent of the common stock and authority to run the new airline. The source said that if the venture should fail under Mr. Pritzker's plan, the planes would still belong to the secured creditors, who would get an estimated 70 cents to 80 cents on every dollar owed if Braniff were liquidated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/22/busin.body_text: **********The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved, 25 to 17, a bill aimed at forcing foreign auto makers to establish factories in this country. **********The so-called domestic content auto bill now goes to the Ways and Means Committee, which has jurisdiction for 30 days before it can be brought to the House floor. **********The Reagan Administration strongly opposes the legislation, which sets limits on the percentage of foreign-made components in cars and trucks sold in this country. **********Representative Dennis E. Eckart, Democrat of Ohio, said he expected the bill to be taken up by the House ''sometime after Labor Day.'' But he conceded that, even if it passed the House, it had ''little chance in the Senate.'' **********In addition to setting domestic content limits, the bill would create a Government-appointed Automobile Industry Advisory Council to study industry problems and form a strategy for increasing United States auto production. The amended bill sets auto content limits for any maufacturer with United States car and truck sales of more than 100,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.main_headline: PENTAGON GETS TOUGH ON LATIN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.print_headline: PENTAGON GETS TOUGH ON LATIN POLICY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, despite the objections of some top State Department officials, has decided to go on the attack against Congressional opposition to its Central America policy, according to senior Administration officials. **********The new stance, which represents a break with past efforts to reach an accommodation with Congress on Central America, is scheduled to be outlined in a policy speech on Monday by the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, Fred C. Ikle, the third ranking official in the Pentagon. **********The tone of the speech, which Mr. Ikle is to deliver to the Baltimore Council on Foreign Affairs, includes some of the harshest criticism of Congress by the Reagan Administration on this or any other foreign policy issue, Administration officials said. They said it was endorsed last week by White House aides over the opposition of some State Department experts on Latin America. An advance text was made available by a foreign policy adviser involved in its preparation. **********It says, in part, ''As long as Congress keeps crippling the President's military assistance program, we will have a policy always shy of success.'' It also says: ''The President's policy for Central America has not been given a chance to work. Congress has denied the President the means to succeed.''  'An Arsenal for Insurgency' **********In addition, the speech offers the clearest statement to date by the Administration on United States opposition to the Nicaraguan Government. **********''We must prevent consolidation of a Sandinista regime in Nicaragua that would become an arsenal for insurgency,'' the text says. ''If we cannot prevent that, we have to anticipate the partition of Central America. Such a development would then force us to man a new military front line of the East-West conflict, right here on our continent.'' **********Senior Administration officials said the speech will be the kickoff for an intense Administration campaign this fall to fight for increases in security assistance to El Salvador and Honduras and against a cutoff in American support for Nicaraguan rebels. **********Congress has not completed action on a series of requests for supplemental security assistance for El Salvador and Honduras for the current fiscal year, but the Senate and House committees involved have approved less than half of the $110 million in extra money asked for El Salvador. The House voted last month to end support for Nicaraguan rebels.  'We're Fed Up' **********''We've had it with the opposition in Congress,'' a senior Administration official said today. ''We're fed up with their interference on one hand and their lack of support on the other and we intend to fight for what we think is a minimum American commitment in the region.'' **********The decision to go on the attack, which was reportedly supported by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, William P. Clark, the White House national security adviser, and William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, appears to end a protracted debate within the Administration about how best to deal with Congress on Central America. **********The State Department has advocated using a conciliatory posture to try to negotiate compromises with Congress on security assistance and support for Nicaraguan rebels. **********This tactic was openly ridiculed by Defense Department officials, including Mr. Ikle, who argued that the best way to handle Congress was to hold out for the Administration's goals and make Congress take responsibility if American policy failed. **********Administration officials see the coming fight as a crossroads for American policy in Central America. They are particularly concerned that a failure to obtain continued financing for Nicaraguan rebels in the 1984 fiscal year, which begins next month, will lead to a serious setback for United States interests in the region. The Administration has requested $50 million to finance rebel activities in fiscal 1984. Warning of a 'Second Cuba' **********The House, which has voted to cut off financing for the Nicaraguan rebels in fiscal 1983, is not expected to approve any money for the operation in budget bills for 1984. The Republican-controlled Senate, which has not supported last month's House cutoff, is likely to vote to extend the financing, forcing the two houses to resolve the issue when the budget legislation comes up for compromise negotiations between the House and Senate. **********The text of Mr. Ikle's speech warns that a failure to extend financing could allow Nicaragua to become a ''second Cuba'' that would pose a direct military threat to its neighbors. In a direct slap at the House vote to cut off money for the rebels, the text says, ''The House, in effect, voted to establish a sanctuary for the Sandinistas.'' It goes on to charge that a failure by Congress to continue financing for the rebels would be tantamount to creating ''safe havens'' for terrorist and insurgent attacks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.main_headline: U.S. IS EXPLORING NEW VATICAN TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.print_headline: U.S. IS EXPLORING NEW VATICAN TIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration said today that it was exploring the establishment of stronger relations with the Vatican. **********The State Department confirmed that it was consulting with officials at the Vatican on the question of closer relations. Alan D. Romberg, the department spokesman, said this was in accord with an amendment to the latest State Department budget measure. The amendment, quietly enacted this year by Congress, repealed an 1867 law barring Federal funds for a diplomatic mission to the Vatican. **********''The Administration would be making a very serious mistake,'' said the Rev. Jerry Falwell, head of Moral Majority. ''It would be a serious violation of the 207-year policy of this Government and a clear violation of the principle of the separation of church and state.'' **********Historically, attempts by past Administrations to explore closer Vatican ties have been rejected amid controversy over the church-state issue. Congressional proponents of the new measure, which was accepted by President Reagan in signing the appropriations bill, argue that Pope John Paul II, in his vociferous opposition to human rights abuses in Poland, has been acting as a leading statesman worthy of closer representation.  No Personal Comment President Reagan has not commented personally on the issue. Like his predecessors, he now has a personal representative to the Vatican, William A. Wilson. Mr. Wilson has opened discussions on stronger ties with the Vatican, according to Administration officials. **********Larry Speakes, the President's spokesman, was asked today about closer ties and replied that the Administration was ''moving in that direction.'' But he said any change ''would not go as far'' as the designation of a full ambassador to the Vatican. **********In the view of the sponsor of the amendment, Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, the Vatican is ''a sovereign state'' led by ''a powerful force for democracy in the world.'' In debating the issue, he called on Congress to end the ''awkward charade'' and permit closer secular ties. **********The National Council of Churches, which includes 31 church organizations, has long been on record against Vatican relations. Its position in recent years dates to the Truman Administration's attempt to establish formal relations. Carol Fouke, the council's director of news services, said the council considered any Vatican ties an abrogation of the principle of ''according all religious bodies the same status'' in the eyes of the Government.  'An International Voice' **********In the Congressional debate, Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana, argued in favor of closer ties. He cited the Pope's activities on behalf of Poland, contending, ''Under the courageous leadership of Pope John Paul II, the Vatican state has assumed its rightful place in the world as an international voice.'' **********Mr. Falwell, a Protestant leader whose own ventures into the ''social issues'' of politics have frequently been endorsed by Reagan Administration officials, said the anti-Communist argument focusing on Poland was a falacious enough reason for setting up Vatican relations. **********The amendment is advisory in effect and does not mandate closer ties. It repeals the 1867 funding ban and permits the President to study the matter.

The shelling tapered off at dawn. **********Gunners fired five artillery or mortar rounds at a United States Navy support ship off Beirut today, but the rounds fell short of the ship and it did not return the fire, American officials said. A Pentagon spokesman, Lieut. Col. Erik Opgall, said in Washington that the lightly armed, noncombat ship was not damaged. **********Other sources identified the ship as the Fairfax City, which is providing support for the marines in the peacekeeping force in Beirut. There was no indication where the shelling came from. **********During the Christian-Druse clashes, Lebanon asked the special United States envoy, Morris Draper, for American help in getting Israel to stop the fighting in Israeli-controlled mountain regions about seven miles east and southeast of the capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone left here today on a 10-day, 5-nation tour of Southeast Asia during which he is expected to shore up confidence in the region with offers of economic aid. **********Officials said he would also use the trip to criticize Vietnam's attacks on camps of refugees and guerrillas on the Thai-Cambodian border this month and to express full support for non-Communist nations in the region. **********Mr. Nakasone is to give a total of about $800 million in aid to the Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand on a tour that is also scheduled to take him to Singapore and Malaysia. **********''Since he is doing this there is really no political issue to fight over in this tour,'' a Foreign Ministry official said. ''All that matters to the Southeast Asian countries is how much aid Japan can give.'' **********These nations negotiated hard for new aid packages in recent months after Mr. Nakasone rushed through a $4 billion aid package for South Korea in January, the largest single amount of aid ever granted by Japan at one time. **********Japanese officials said the Government here was unable to meet all requests from Southeast Asia, but they said Tokyo made a special effort to comply, knowing that economic aid is considered vital by the United States, Japan's major ally. ---- **********JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 30 (UPI) - Prime Minister Nakasone arrived here today on the first stop of his tour.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.main_headline: CHAD SAYS IT HAS RETAKEN EASTERN OASIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.print_headline: CHAD SAYS IT HAS RETAKEN EASTERN OASIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.body_text: **********The Government said tonight that its troops, pressing a counteroffensive begun over the weekend, had retaken an eastern oasis lost to Libyan-backed insurgents on Friday. **********Information Minister Mahamat Soumailia said troops loyal to President Hissen Habre had recaptured the oasis of Oum Chalouba. He said Government troops were also fighting in and around the strategic town of Abeche, south of Oum Chalouba, and that ''a very important victory'' was near. **********The minister said counterattacking Government soldiers had captured 300 prisoners and seized heavy weapons from insurgent forces of former President Goukouni Oueddei. 400 Soldiers Reportedly Freed **********Mr. Soumalia also announced the freeing of 400 Government soldiers who were taken prisoner when the insurgents captured the northern town of Faya-Largeau last month at the beginning of their drive south toward Abeche. Abeche, which is situated 400 miles east northeast of here, is connected by road with Ndjamena. **********These minister's statements came hours after Western diplomats said information reaching them indicated that the Government's prospects for turning back the insurgents had apparently improved over what they were last week. **********If the minister's statements are confirmed, the Government troops appear to have scored a dramatic turnaround from last Friday, when the insurgents, in addition to taking Oum Chalouba, broke through defenses at Biltine to the south. They drove into Abeche over the weekend. Troops Said to Regroup **********At a news conference earlier in the day, Mr. Soumalia acknowledged that Government troops had pulled out of Abeche on Friday and said about half of the 30,000 people living there had also left. But he said Government troops had then regrouped and started a counteroffensive with the help of reinforcements against an insurgent force that he put at 1,500 men. **********He said Abeche was now ''partly under Government control, partly under the control of the rebels.'' He said many residents who had fled were beginning to return. **********Mr. Soumalia declined to give the number of Government troops committed to the battle. But he said French-supplied military equipment was increasingly being deployed. French Intervention 'Necessary' **********In answer to a question, the minister said intervention by French troops was ''more necessary now than ever.'' Echoing President Habre's recent appeal for such aid from France, which governed Chad as a colony until 1960, Mr. Soumalia said the Government would welcome as many troops as the French ''care to give us.'' **********A similar request was issued early this morning by an Imam, Sheik Mohammed Badawi, after prayers in the capital's Grand Mosque.  Speaking ''on behalf of all Chadian Moslems,'' he asked for direct intervention from Paris. **********Later, rumors of successes by Government forces swept the capital -some said Abeche itself had fallen -and thousands of people took to the streets shouting and cheering. There were some shouts that former President Goukouni had been captured, but the Information Minister said tonight that this was not true, although many other prisoners had been taken. **********Widespread rumors that some of these prisoners were on display in the capital's main square brought thousands of jubilant Habre supporters into the area. But there were no prisoners in view when Western reporters arrived.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.main_headline: HIJACKED IRAN JET LEAVES KUWAIT WITH 185 HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.print_headline: HIJACKED IRAN JET LEAVES KUWAIT WITH 185 HOSTAGES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.body_text: **********Hijackers seized an Iranian jetliner on a domestic flight on Wednesday and flew it to Kuwait, where they released 186 women, children and old men before taking off for Paris with 185 hostages still aboard, officials said. **********There was no immediate word on whether the hijackers had made any demands.  Numerous groups opposed to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, operate out of Paris, including one led by former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who escaped from Teheran in July 1981 aboard a hijacked Iranian military plane. **********The Kuwaiti Government said 63 women, 48 children and 75 elderly men were freed seven hours after the Boeing 747 landed.  During negotiations with officials in the airport control tower, the jet was refueled and barriers that had been erected on the runway to prevent an unauthorized takeoff were removed. Asylum Not Sought **********The jumbo jet, capable of intercontinental flights, took off for Paris at 1:57 A.M. today, an official in the control tower said.  ''They gave out the direction and as soon as they took off they said they were going to Paris,'' the official said. Asked if the hijackers specifically mentioned Paris, he replied, ''Yes.'' **********Airport authorities said the hijackers - five or six in number - apparently were Iranians who hijacked the jet on a flight between Teheran and Shiraz, a summer resort in southern Iran 450 miles south of Teheran and 300 miles east of Kuwait. **********They did not ask for political asylum in Kuwait, Interior Minister Nawaf Ahmed Jaber said. He added that the plane had been allowed to land for ''humanitarian reasons'' because it was running out of fuel. **********A report carried by the state-run Kuwaiti press agency said the plane was carrying 371 passengers.  The Kuwaiti negotiating team consisted of Mr. Jaber, Minister of Communications Issa Mazedi and a Foreign Ministry Under Secretary, Rashid Abdul Aziz Alrashid. Envoy Not Involved **********Officials said that the Iranian Ambassador to Kuwait, Ali Shams Ardekani, was not directly involved in the negotiations and that the Kuwaitis had not been in contact with the Iranian Government. **********There was no immediate comment from Iran and a spokesman for Iranair in Kuwait said in a telephone interview, ''Teheran air traffic control told us not to give any information.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/03/busin.body_text: **********Petromin, Saudi Arabia's state-run oil company, has told Japanese importers that it cut its price for liquefied petroleum gas by $10 a ton, to $270, effective Aug. 1, the Nippon Petroleum Gas Company said today. **********This followed a request by a group of 10 Japanese importers and distributors for a price reduction of $50 to $60 a ton. **********Nippon Petroleum said Japanese importers expected a further reduction in Saudi Arabia's price for the gas, known as LPG, in the coming month. **********Japan has contracted to buy about 900,000 tons of the gas a year from Saudi Arabia on long-term direct deals. Imports from Saudi Arabia account for about 60 percent of Japanese consumption of the liquefied gas.
