https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Ted Bates International has consolidated its British and Continental European operations into Ted Bates Europe and has brought back G. Bruce McLaren to run it as president and chief operating officer. He will be based in London, working with Armand de Malherbe, head of operations on the Continent since 1970 and now chairman of the consolidated unit. **********Robert E. Jacoby, chairman of Ted Bates Worldwide, said the structure will be of special importance to such global clients as Mars, Colgate and Seiko. **********Mr. McLaren, 39, came to Bates in 1969 after having worked for Ogilvy & Mather, and by the time he left in 1975 he was a senior vice president and member of the board. From then until April 1982, he was president of the three-office Atlantic division of Bozell & Jacobs, from which he resigned because of traditional ''philosophical differences.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.main_headline: MATTEL EXPECTS TO POST LARGE LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.print_headline: MATTEL EXPECTS TO POST LARGE LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Just three years after it ventured beyond toys to compete in the promising video game and home computer markets, Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its electronics division would lead the company to a pretax loss of ''significantly more than $100 million'' for the first half of 1983. **********Mattel will apparently be the third home electronics manufacturer to report second-quarter losses in excess of the worst predictions of industry analysts. On Thursday, Warner Communications reported that it had lost $283 million in the quarter because of poor performance in its Atari unit, and on Friday, Texas Instruments said it had lost $119 million in the same period. **********All three companies have been caught in a spiral of price cutting and sharply diminished sales in what a year ago was a booming home entertainment market, consisting mostly of video games and lowpriced computers. **********While industry experts say they expect a healthy demand to emerge for inexpensive home computers once the machines are capable of performing sophisticated tasks, they express doubts that video games will prove to be more than a fad. **********Mattel, noting its fiscal second quarter does not end until July 30, cautioned that ''the magnitude of the second-quarter operating loss is not yet fully determinable.'' **********But analysts suggested that the recent experiences of Atari and Texas Instruments made it likely that Mattel's second-quarter pretax loss may exceed the $100 million mark. In the first quarter, ended April 30, the company lost $20.4 million on sales of $197 million. In last year's second quarter, Mattel earned $17.1 million on sales of $329.7 million. **********In yesterday's statement, Mattel said that ''actions are being taken to minimize operating losses in the electronics division.'' Spencer Boise, a company spokesman, declined to elaborate, but a month ago Mattel laid off about 260 workers in its Hawthorne, Calif., headquarters. Industry analysts speculated yesterday that more layoffs would be required for the company to reduce its overhead. **********''After what happened to Warner and Texas Instruments, this announcement does not surprise me,'' Edward J. Atorino, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said yesterday. ''Mattel had a disastrous first quarter, and the second quarter just got worse.'' **********Mattel makes the Intellivision home video game line, which at one time appeared as if it might make a strong showing against Atari, once the leader of the video game market. ''The company had a product advantage at one time, and could have made some strategic moves,'' noted Martin Romm, an analyst with the First Boston Corporation. Squeezed by Coleco **********But the company lost its chance, Mr. Romm said, and was quickly squeezed by Coleco, which introduced a highly popular video game system. Coleco was the only video game machine manufacturer to report a profit in the second quarter. It said earnings rose 23 percent, to $9.1 million; sales rose 45.5 percent, to $126.3 million. **********There were also indications yesterday that Mattel was considering getting out of the home computer business, which it entered earlier this year. The company is currently test marketing the Acquarius, its first computer, in Los Angeles, Chicago, Atlanta and Detroit. ''We will continue to support the Intellivision product category,'' Mr.  Boise said. But he said the company ''was currently reassessing'' its support for computer products. **********The Acquarius, to be sold for about $200, was plagued with technical problems even before it was delivered to stores in its test markets. And it was delivered at a time when retailers across the country are seeking to dump their inventories of unsold home computers and the software cartridges that fit them. Shift in Executive Group **********If the company abandoned its home computer efforts, it would mark the first shift in policy since Mattel reported the resignation of Joshua W. Denham, president of the electronics division, two weeks ago. At that time, the company said it was installing a new executive group to better ''manage and market our products in the face of a volatile market.'' Mr. Boise would not say if the resignation was linked to the projected second-quarter loss, and Mr.  Denham could not be reached for comment. **********Yesterday Mattel's stock closed at $9, down 62 1/2 cents. The company said that its other operating divisions have remained profitable and that Mattel Toys U.S.A. and Mattel Toys International ''have record bookings to date.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/26/busin.body_text: **********Assets Gap Up 7.8% in '82 **********WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) - The gap between American assets invested overseas and foreign assets in the United States grew by 7.8 percent last year, the smallest increase in four years, the Government said today. **********The Commerce Department said American assets abroad increased $117.3 billion last year, to $834.2 billion, while foreign assets in the United States increased $105.1 billion, to $665.5 billion. **********The difference - $168.6 billion in the United States' favor - was up $12.2 billion and was the smallest gain since an increase of $3.3 billion in 1978, the department said. In 1981, the gap widened by $35.8 billion, the department said. **********The report said strong bond and stock market rallies in the second half of the year contributed to a $17.9 billion increase in foreign holdings of American securities other than Treasury Department securities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.main_headline: AIDES SUED AT DEFUNCT THRIFT UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.print_headline: AIDES SUED AT DEFUNCT THRIFT UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/12/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation yesterday sued the top officers and directors of the defunct New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association, accusing them of self-dealing and failure to manage the association prudently. **********Thomas P. Vartanian, the F.S.L.I.C.'s general counsel, said that similar suits were being prepared against officers and directors of ''9 or 10'' other savings and loan associations, whose deposits were insured by the agency and which were forced into mergers to avoid failure. **********Last February, a similar suit was filed against the First Savings and Loan Association of Suffolk, Va.  According to a news release issued yesterday by the F.S.L.I.C., New York and Suburban had $500 million in assets and was failing when it was forced by the agency to merge into another New York City institution, the Anchor Savings Bank, on May 29, 1981. So far, the F.S.L.I.C. has provided $137 million in such assistance. **********The suit, which was filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, charges that, for 16 months, the directors of New York and Suburban refused to allow the F.S.L.I.C.  to merge the failing thrift unit into a stronger institution unless the agency and the successor institution ''agreed to the continued employment of the president and chairman of the board.'' **********The suit does not state the amount being sought. The F.S.L.I.C.  said that it would ask the court to set the figure, but Mr. Vartanian noted that the suit says the association lost $35 million while the directors delayed a merger for 16 months. **********''We don't try to sue everybody because their financial institution could not weather the financial crisis,'' said Ralph Christy, the agency's deputy counsel. But he said the F.S.L.I.C. would act when it believed the management and directors of an association had acted imprudently. **********Mr. Vartanian said that ''the board feels very strongly in this area; the protection for deregulation has clearly got to be strong enforcement against those who abuse the responsibilities that deregulation implies.'' **********He added that, in the future, ''suits will range from golden parachutes while the institution was insolvent, and negligent management, to action against officers and directors, and in some cases their lawyers, for criminal violations.'' Payments to Officers **********Edgar M. Cini was chairman and Dorothy L. Whitford was president of New York and Suburban. Neither could be reached for comment last night. The directors named in the suit were Ralph Bandes, Peter W.  Diffendale, George C. Fechtmann, Dante L. Ferrari, Seymour J. Lourd, Frederick M. Messner Jr., Thomas J. Abruzzi and Ernest L. Haas. Only Mr. Bandes, an attorney, could be reached. He said that he had not heard about the suit and that he could not comment on it. **********The suit also charges that ''at a time that the association was insolvent and sustaining large operating losses, the directors engaged in self-dealing and violated a written agreement with the bank board by approving substantial salary increases to its president and chairman of the board and fee increases to its directors,'' according to the news release. The bank board is the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the nation's savings and loan associations. **********The suit also says that during the same period ''directors inappropriately voted to pay the president and chairman of the board more than $124,000 in accrued vacation pay in violation of the association's own established policies,'' the release said. **********In addition, the suit charges that the directors refused to comply with directives from the bank board relating to how New York and Suburban accounted for losses taken on trading in so-called Ginnie Mae securities. The suit says that the board asked the thrift institution to write the entire losses off immediately, but that instead it amortized the losses over a period of time.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.main_headline: GEMAYAL ASSERTS DRUSE CHIEF SEEKS TO SPLIT LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.print_headline: GEMAYAL ASSERTS DRUSE CHIEF SEEKS TO SPLIT LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.body_text: **********President Amin Gemayel's Government accused the leader of the Druse today of trying to partition the country by setting up a local administration in Druse- controlled areas and by appealing to soldiers of the Lebanese Army not to carry out orders. **********For his part, the Druse chieftain, Walid Jumblat, went out of his way to emphasize that his decision to set up a local administration, announced Saturday, was taken to provide basic public services to people living in the war- shattered areas under his control. He also emphasized he would welcome any help the central Government could provide. This move, he added, was not meant to be a prelude to the establishment of a Druse ''ministate.'' **********'Conscientious Objectors' **********But Mr. Jumblat raised some suspicions about his ultimate intentions in the minds of senior Government officials today when he visited several hundred Druse soldiers who had gone to Hammana, a Syrian-occupied town some 18 miles east of Beirut. The soldiers there are acting as ''conscientious objectors,'' refusing to take part in any attempt by the Lebanese Army to use force to impose its authority over Druse-controlled areas. **********The several hundred Druse soldiers who have asked to be relieved of fighting responsibility make up only a small part of Lebanon's 34,000-man army. In a speech at the Hammana barracks, Mr. Jumblat called on all Lebanese Army soldiers to follow the Druse example and refuse to fight. **********In a hastily called meeting with reporters this evening, Farouk Jabber, a presidential adviser, said of Mr. Jumblat's actions: ''I reckon it is an attempt to really partition Lebanon on a cantonlike basis. There are many indications that what Mr. Jumblat is doing is trying to realize his part of the Syrian strategy at the moment in Lebanon.'' **********Conference Hopes Dampened **********The exchange of charges between Mr. Jumblat and the Gemayel Government dampened hopes for a quick convening of the proposed national reconciliation conference, which is to bring together Lebanon's factional leaders in an attempt to find a solution to the country's conflicts. **********Neither a date nor a location for the proposed conference has been agreed upon yet, and as one senior official put it: ''The dialogue at this point is at zero. The situation is so dangerous. If Jumblat attacks the Government and army and sets up his own administration, what are we going to discuss?'' **********The latest conflict between Mr. Jumblat and the Gemayel Government began Saturday morning in Beit Eddin, 18 miles southeast of Beirut in the heart of the Shuf Mountains, where Mr. Jumblat addressed a gathering of Druse leaders. **********'Civilian Administration' **********In a prepared statement read to the gathering, Mr. Jumblat announced it had been decided to set up a ''civilian administration'' in the Shuf and Aleih regions controlled by the Druse. It would handle civilian affairs ''during the extraordinary conditions the country is now living through'' and would serve as a Druse pressure bloc to get the Government to extend more services to their areas ''when peaceful conditions are established,'' the statement said. **********The administration would consist of a general assembly made up of the military forces in the regions and representatives from each village, overseen by a higher administrative committee. **********Mr. Jumblat appeared to be genuinely suprised today at the reaction by the Gemayel Government to this announcement, which he saw as a natural response to the human problems in the Druse-controlled areas. **********The Druse have long argued that the central Government has neglected economic development in their districts, while lavishing it on Christian regions. In addition, as a result of the fighting in the last year in the Shuf and Aleih regions, roads, water, electricity and all social services are badly in need of repair. Travelers through the Shuf on Saturday found Druse gunmen in some areas exacting a $2 toll from drivers to pay for the repair of roads.   Basic Services for Citizens **********''Everybody is afaid of this so-called local administration,'' Mr. Jumblat told reporters today in Hammana. ''We have undertaken these measures yesterday just to facilitate for the citizens of the Shuf some basic things: water, electricity.'' **********He added: ''It is not a separatist movement, and we are ready to cooperate with the state. I don't know why Amin Gemayel suddenly woke up at 12 P.M. and decided we were announcing some partition. That is ridiculous.'' **********For reasons that are not immediately clear, it was not until midnight Saturday that Mr. Gemayel was made aware of Mr. Jumblat's announcement. When he did learn of it, he called an emergency meeting of his top advisers, the state-run Beirut radio said. **********By this morning, pro-Government newspapers were on the streets with large headlines complaining about Mr. Jumblat's ''partitionist'' plans. Both the state-run radio and the Christian Phalangist radio picked up the theme, as Mr. Gemayel held a series of meetings with senior Government officials and national political figures.   Christian Ministate **********Several Lebanese political analysts said the Government was overreacting to Mr. Jumblat's move. The presidential adviser, Mr. Jabber, was asked why the Government was so concerned about Mr. Jumblat's moves while it seemed to ignore the ministate that has been run for the last eight years by the Christian Phalangist militia, which was founded by President Gemayel's father, Pierre. Mr. Jabber avoided answering the question. **********Senior Government officials explained that they had evidence that the Syrians wanted to set up local administrations loyal to them in all the Syrian- controlled regions of Lebanon, and they see Mr. Jumblat's actions as serving this Syrian plan. They also see his moves as satisfying Israel's stated objective of creating a Druse-controlled buffer zone between Israeli troops and the Syrians and Palestinians. **********Mr. Jumblat did little to allay Government suspicions about his ultimate aims when he visited the Lebanese Army garrison in Hammana today. The barracks is in a Syrian-controlled area where there is only a token Lebanese Army presence. In the past two weeks, the Commander in Chief of the Lebanese Army, Maj. Gen. Ibrahim Tannous, has allowed some 270 Druse soldiers and 30 Druse officers to go the Hammana barracks so they would not be faced with the choice of having to either fight their fellow Druse or leave the army. **********According to Defense Ministry sources, General Tannous proposed a compromise under which he agreed to treat the Druse soldiers as ''conscientious objectors,'' provided they stayed in the Hammana barracks and did not take up arms against the Lebanese Army.   Appeal for Support **********Mr. Jumblat told the cheering crowd of several hundred soldiers, the vast majority of them said to be Druse: ''We are appealing to all the soldiers and officers to join us. We as politicians and they as soldiers stick to the fact that the Lebanese Army should remain united, but it should not be used before the national reconciliation, and it should not be used in purely internal Lebanese issues.'' **********The soldiers in the garrison issued a list of demands that called for, among other things, the return of all Lebanese Army units to their barracks until national reconciliation had been achieved and a serious review of the army's command structure in order to prevent its involvement in internal affairs and ''its bias in favor of one faction, which is now the case.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; MORE CONFIDENCE ON RATE FALL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The credit markets grew more confident last week that interest rates were likely to decline this year. After a few days of inactivity, the credit markets closed with a flurry as investors were eager buyers of new corporate issues, while prices rose modestly for Treasury issues. **********Although not all of the $1 billion of corporate issues were instant sell-outs, analysts said that the overall reception was good. Many of the major issues were not announced until Thursday, or even Friday in the case of $200 million of Aaa/AA+-rated 11 percent debentures of the Atlantic Richfield Company. **********The market's ready acceptance of $1 billion of new corporate issues last week was proof that investors still see good value in bonds, even though a sharp drop in interest rates is not expected anytime soon. **********Richard Bianco, head of the fixed-income trading area at Dillon, Read & Company, said that ''investors are buying bonds more for income and not as much because of prospects for capital gains. I still expect some capital gains, but that is no longer the main attraction.'' Changed Outlook on Inflation **********One reason for the change in investor attitude is the changed outlook for inflation. Not only are bond yields high compared with recent inflation rates, but they are also high compared with the inflation that is expected in the future. **********Expectations that inflation will not accelerate were confirmed in a recent poll of 497 institutional decision makers by Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at A.G. Becker-Warburg Paribas Becker Inc. Survey respondents included investment officers, corporate financial officers, bank portfolio managers, stock portfolio managers, economists and other analysts. **********The consensus of this group was that inflation during the next 10 years will rise at an annual rate of 6.3 percent, which would be down from 6.6 percent in December 1982 and well below the 8.8 percent annual price increases expected during the next 10 years in an October 1980 survey. A breakdown of the inflationary expectations showed that while prices were expected to rise by only 4 1/4 percent in the 12 months ending December 1983, the price gains would increase in later years. **********Comparing the 10-year inflation outlook with the 10.47 percent yield on 10-year Treasury notes at the time of the survey resulted in a real interest rate of about 4 percent, half the 8 1/4 percent real interest rate in September 1981. Bullish on Markets **********Mr. Hoey's survey also showed that decision makers were bullish on the stock and bond markets, as three-fourths of the survey group expected to reduce their holdings of cash or near-cash securities during the next three months. About four-fifths of the respondents expected stocks to outperform bonds during the next 12 months. **********The bullishness of institutional investors may bode well for the stock and taxable bond markets, but it could have less of an impact on the tax-exempt bond market where individuals account for an estimated three-quarters of all purchases. **********''Income tax payments are very much on the minds of investors, and the recent increase in buying of municipal bonds can be traced directly to concern over how little income the tax system allows the general public to keep,'' said S.E. Canaday Jr., a vice president at John Nuveen & Company. 'Too Much Too Soon' **********Even though the general trend is for lower yields later in the year, Mr. Canaday said the ''current rally seems to be a little too much too soon.'' As the April 15 income tax payments fade in memory, he said the heavy supply of new tax-exempts could cause prices to fall slightly. **********The latest economic and banking statistics give no definitive clues to future changes in interest rates. The economy is recovering, as shown by the 1.1 percent increase in industrial production for March, but analysts say that an increase in credit demands and inflationary pressures might still be a few quarters away.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.main_headline: Yugoslavia Says Albania Threatens to Use Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Yugoslavia Says Albania Threatens to Use Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/21/world.body_text: **********The Yugoslav Government accused Albania today of ''openly threatening to use force'' against it and demanded an end to what it termed Albania's hostile policy. **********A protest note handed to the Albanian Ambassador, Lika Seiti, also attacked Enver Hoxha, the head of Albania's ruling Communist Government since 1944, and accused him of making ''monstrous fabrications'' about Yugoslavia to divert attention from his own problems. **********This was an allusion to Mr. Hoxha's recent assertion that his Prime Minister for 27 years, Mehmet Shehu, had been a spy for Yugoslavia. Albania said in December 1981 that Mr. Shehu had committed suicide while in a state of depression, but the Yugoslav press suggested that he was the victim of a power struggle with Mr.  Hoxha. **********The Yugoslav protest said Albania's leaders were ''flagrantly'' interfering in Yugoslavia's internal affairs by giving support to ethnic Albanian dissidents in the south Yugoslav province of Kosovo.  It said this was tantamount to a ''call for the overthrow of the constitutional order of Yugoslavia.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/world.main_headline: AT A LAGOS MART: LET THE BUYER BEWARE OF TRAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/world.print_headline: AT A LAGOS MART: LET THE BUYER BEWARE OF TRAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/20/world.body_text: **********Since coming to the Yaba railroad market two years ago, Omegah Boniface has followed the same routine almost every day: arrive at 7:30, lay out the display of clothing and materials in the little stall and on boxes that spill out beyond, then wait for the customers to show up. **********The only other thing Mr. Boniface needs to remember is to keep an ear cocked for trains and to make sure that he, his customers and his goods are off the tracks by the time any comes barreling through. **********''I don't know, I suppose you could say it's dangerous,'' Mr. Boniface acknowledged. ''But we are watchful here and we know how to dodge.'' **********A Most Laissez-Faire Capital **********In most cities of the world, a place like the Yaba railroad market would certainly seem outlandish and would probably be prohibited. In this most laissez-faire capital, however, hardly anyone gives it a second thought. **********The market consists of a hundred- odd wood, cinderblock and corrugated metal stalls pressed close against either side of a half-mile stretch of railway tracks near the station at Yaba, a congested neighborhood of crumbling buildings crisscrossed by open sewers and blotched by hills of rubbish. **********From the stalls, Mr. Boniface and the other merchants spread their wares directly onto the rails, where the customers, well-heeled and down-at- the-heel alike, meander about, browsing and haggling. Other traders who have no stalls just set up folding tables on the rails. **********There are shirts and pants, shoes and socks for sale, as well as sheets, pillowcases, towels and brightly printed material by the yard. Soda, fruits, vegetables and bread are also sold on the tracks, and now and then a barber will give a customer a trim between the whistles of the trains. **********When that whistle blows, the entrepreneurs of Yaba casually and quietly pick up their things and move off to one side - or at least to the next track over - until the train has passed.   The Rent Is Cheap **********The mother of the Yaba market is economy. At most markets in Lagos, the rental of a stall costs as much as 100 naira, or $135 at the official rate of exchange, and the rent may be demanded many months in advance. At Yaba, the selling space is practically free. **********''Years ago the police would come and beat you and try to make you close down,'' said a trader who asked not to be named. ''Now we dash them a little,'' he said, using the local term for giving a bribe, ''and it has been a year since they stopped worrying us.'' **********''It still works out much cheaper to be here than to rent a stall in Tejuoso or Jankara,'' he added, referring to two of Lagos's best-known official markets.   Members of the Ibo Tribe **********Nearly all the traders at Yaba belong to the Ibo tribe, people from the region of Nigeria formerly known as Biafra.  Many Ibos came to Lagos in search of a living after the Nigerian civil war at the end of the 1960's, a war that successfully crushed the Biafran independence movement and left the region poor and starving. **********A few set themselves up as textile merchants along the railroad tracks near the Yaba station, a convenient location for many neighborhood commuters. In time other Ibo traders joined them, and before long Yaba won a reputation as a bargain-hunter's paradise. **********''Everything is much cheaper here,'' said John Bolingo, a merchant. ''See this shirt? In a shop it would cost you 35 naira. But here? Twenty-two naira. Maybe I could even sell it to you for 20. That's why everybody comes to Yaba. Senators, legislators, all kinds of officials.''  The Traffic Jam Traders **********There are other traders in this city who make their living in an equally thrifty but no less precarious fashion, selling such goods as sunglasses, video and audio cassettes, fruit, biscuits and magazines on the highways during Lagos's notorious traffic jams. **********''Most of those boys are Ibos, too,'' said Arthur Uchegibo, a Yaba textile trader. ''It's a risky business, but we are an industrious people and used to fighting to survive.'' **********A senior British diplomat here said that when he first arrived in Lagos he avoided the traffic jam traders. ''I thought they'd probably take my money and run or something,'' he said. ''But it's just the opposite. They run after you to give you your change. It must be a sort of code of honor among them. And it's a bloody convenient way to shop.'' **********There is some disagreement about just how perilous it is to be a roadside or railroad track salesman. ''People get killed here sometimes,'' said Chief Patrick Anani, the stationmaster at Yaba. But he could not recall the last time anyone had actually been hit by a train. **********''The people who say it's dangerous are just trying to get rid of us,'' Mr. Uchegibo said. ''We know what we're doing. We know when the trains are coming and we have no trouble getting out of the way.'' **********Mr. Boniface added: ''And what if it is dangerous? Where else are we to go? This is our livelihood. We have no other.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Spain Will Reshape Military Command
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/28/world.body_text: **********The Spanish Government has approved plans to overhaul the chain of command in the armed forces to bring them more firmly under Government control, a Government spokesman said today. **********The measures, decided at a Cabinet meeting Wednesday night, are designed to strengthen the role of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and his Cabinet in deciding military policy, the spokesman said. **********The move followed the dismissal last month of a senior army general who criticized the Government, raising fears that some sectors of the armed forces were not fully reconciled to Spain's new democracy. **********Under the proposed changes, the existing post of president of a joint commission of army, navy and air force chiefs of staff would be replaced by a single military chief of staff.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The Hyatt Hotels Corporation today introduced a computer terminal that allows guests to check in and out of its hotels by using a credit card. ''Response from our guests has been very positive,'' Pat Foley, Hyatt Hotels president, told a news conference. **********''You can learn to operate it almost Instantly.'' The first terminals have been in use at the Hyatt Regency Chicago for one month, and plans are to introduce it at others of the company's 70 hotels in the United States, and 41 hotels outside the country. The hotel terminals, manufactured by the NCR Corporation, are similar to an automated bank teller. The customer inserts a credit card, the system checks it against lost or stolen cards, asks the customer if the name and address are correct, allows a choice of bed size and then assigns a room. The terminal spits out a reservation card, which the customer takes to a separate counter where a room key is waiting.  The terminals, which cost $29,000 each, print out an itemized bill at checkout and the charges are automatically forwarded to the credit card company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.main_headline: Nicaragua Will Pursue Rebels in Border Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.print_headline: Nicaragua Will Pursue Rebels in Border Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/02/world.body_text: **********The Nicaraguan Army will pursue rebels who attack across Honduran and Costa Rican border areas it considers ''no man's lands,'' Defense Minister Humberto Ortega said today. **********''Our army will repel armed attacks of the counterrevolutionaries wherever they may come from,'' he said, ''because the aggression comes from border points that are considered no man's lands.'' **********The Defense Minister made the comments as he toured draft registration centers. Nicaragua began the first military draft in its history today, registering youths from 17 to 22 years of age in a move expected to add 15,000 soldiers to the armed forces. **********Mr. Ortega said the action by the army ''does not mean that we will pursue counterrevolutionaries to San Jose, Tegucigalpa or Miami, but yes, we will pursue them in territory that is considered no man's land near our borders.'' **********Two rebel groups are fighting Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista Government - the Honduras-based Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which says it has 7,000 to 10,000 troops in the north and receives support from the United States, and the Costa Rica-based Revolutionary Democratic Alliance, which says it has 3,700 fighters in the south.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/16/busin.body_text: **********The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, a bank holding company, said yesterday that it was selling two floating-rate note issues totaling $250 million through Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., as sole underwriter. **********One issue consisted of $150 million of notes with a maximum maturity of nine years and the interest rate set at 75 basis points, or hundredths of a point, above the bond equivalent rate determined by the auction results of 90-day Treasury bills. Another $100 million of notes, also with a final maturity in 1992, has its interest set at 50 basis points above the bill rate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.main_headline: HOUSE PANEL CUTS REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR SALVADOR AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.print_headline: HOUSE PANEL CUTS REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR SALVADOR AID
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/world.body_text: **********A House Appropriations subcommittee today approved $30 million in additional military aid for El Salvador, half the amount asked by President Reagan. **********''If we gave the $60 million, we would have lost all our leverage,'' Representative Clarence D. Long, chairman of the panel, the Foreign Operations subcommittee, said after the 7-to-5 vote.  ''There will be no more dollars until we see measurable progress.'' **********In the compromise, proposed by Mr. Long, the committee attached four conditions to the appropriation: **********- Appointment by the President of a special envoy with ambassadorial rank to help the Salvadorans hold free, fair and safe elections. **********- Review by the Administration of all evidence pertaining to the murder of four American churchwomen. **********- The opening of prisons and detention centers to ''unnanounced and unrestricted'' inspection by the Red Cross. **********- Release of political prisoners and early enactment of an amnesty law.  Administration officials said Mr. Reagan had asked former Senator Richard B. Stone of Florida to become the special envoy. (Page A13.) Wednesday night, Mr. Reagan is to address a joint session of Congress on the problems of Central America.  Immediately after the vote today, Mr. Long distributed copies of a letter from Secretary of State George P. Shultz that acknowledged the Administration's intent to comply with the committee's conditions.  Mr. Long, a Maryland Democrat, visited El Salvador last weekend and said he had found ''a real willingness on the part of the leadership of El Salvador to come to grips with their problems, especially on human rights.'' **********In his letter, Mr. Shultz sought to answer Congressional criticisms of Salvador's treatment of political prisoners. He also said he had ordered a high-level inquiry into the slaying of the churchwomen in 1981. More broadly, he said the Administration was promoting judicial changes in El Salvador. **********The committee earlier rejected, 7-5, a Republican move to provide the full $60 million requested by the President, and then voted 6-6 against a Democratic move to delay action for 90 days. The swing vote on Mr. Long's compromise proposal was cast by Representative Matthew F. McHugh, Democrat of New York, sponsor of the unsuccessful proposal to delay action, who said that rejection of Mr. Long's proposal would enable the Administration to spend the full $60 million. **********The committee action capped a day of intensive congressional activity concerning Central America. The Senate held a closed, 90-minute session in which members of the intelligence committee were questioned concerning Administration activities in the region. **********Mr. Reagan meanwhile met with members of the House intelligence committee, including several who spent recent days in Central America, to lobby against a Democratic proposal that would cut off covert military aid to Nicaraguan rebels and instead provide overt aid to friendly nations to help stop weapons flowing to guerillas in El Salvador. The committee is scheduled to meet Thursday on this proposal. 'We Have a Problem' **********Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts, was asked afterward whether he still believed that the Administration had violated a prohibition - of which he was the author -against providing covert aid for the purpose of overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government. ''I think we're beyond that question now,'' he said. **********The real question, he said, was ''whether the activities there are really in the interests of the United States.'' Pressed on whether he thought the law had been violated, Mr. Boland responded, ''My own judgment is that we have a problem with it.'' **********The House subcommittee vote came six weeks after Mr. Reagan asked for $110 million in additional military aid for El Salvador, of which $60 million was to be diverted from aid already appropriated and $50 million was to be in a new appropriation.  The Senate Foreign Operations subcommittee approved diversion of the entire $60 million, but the Senate Foreign Relations committee recommended only $30 million and attached conditions. The House Foreign Affairs commiteee has disapproved the $50 million in new aid, and the matter is still pending in the Senate Foreign Relations committee. **********Voting for Mr. Long's $30 million compromise today were: Democrats: Mr. Long, Mr. McHugh, Mr. Wilson.  Republicans: Mr. Kemp; Mickey Edwards, Oklahoma; Bob Livingston, Louisiana; Jerry Lewis, California.Voting against the compromise: Democrats: Mr. Obey; Sidney R. Yates, Illinois; William Lehman, Florida; Julian C. Dixon, California; William H. Gray, Pennsylvania.  Republicans: None.  Lieut. Gen. Wallace H. Nutting, the senior United States commander in Latin America, has recommended increasing the number of American advisers in El Salvador from 55 to about 150 and eventually to about 250, according to people who attended private meetings between him and visiting members of Congress this year. Administration officials say some senior Pentagon officials support an increase to 175 advisers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.main_headline: EX-U.S. OFFICIAL CITES EASE IN LEAVING GRENADA DAY BEFORE INVASION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.print_headline: EX-U.S. OFFICIAL CITES EASE IN LEAVING GRENADA DAY BEFORE INVASION
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.body_text: **********The former director of President Reagan's national commission on Social Security said today that he flew out of Grenada on a chartered plane last Monday, a day on which the White House contended that it could not evacuate Americans because the Grenadian international airport was closed. **********The White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, has cited the closing of Pearls Airport in Grenada as one factor in the Administration's assessment that the situation on the island had become so chaotic that an invasion was necessary to rescue Americans and prevent their being taken hostage. **********But Robert J. Myers, the retired chief actuary of the American Social Security system, who went to Grenada on a technical mission for the Organization of American States on Oct. 13, said he flew out of Pearls Airport on Monday on one of four small charter flights carrying about 30 people. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Myers said that there had been no difficulty leaving and that he had been told other flights left the island that morning when a four-day curfew was lifted. **********Canadian Embassy officials here also reported that they knew of several flights in and out of Pearls Airport on Monday through information from the Canadian High Commission, or embassy, in Barbados.One official said Canadian efforts to charter a plane from the Leeward Islands Air Transport Company to fly out 40 Canadian citizens from Grenada before the invasion had been blocked not by closing of the Grenadian airport but by a political decision of the Caricom group, the 13-nation Caribbean economic organization, to sever air links with Grenada. **********Owned by Caribbean Governments **********The Leeward Islands Air Transport Company is owned by the governments of Caricom, he said, so that the decision last week of the Caricom governments to sever air links with Grenada caused cancellation of the company's normal flow of scheduled daily flights to Grenada as well as blocking the company's charters. **********Previously, American officials had asserted that the interruption of regular flights and the problems encountered by the Canadian charter flight were evidence that the Grenadian airport was not operating reliably on Monday and thus helped justify the Administration's decision to use force Tuesday. **********''We did not know who was in charge there,'' Mr. Speakes said Wednesday. ''What they told us, we simply did not trust. There was no way we could be at all assured that their promises would have been kept.'' Without offering evidence, he insisted then and again today that the Grenadian airport was closed Monday. **********Caricom's temporary air embargo of Grenada followed the killing of former Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada, the imposition of a military curfew on Grenada on Oct. 19 and the closing of the airport that day. But Canadian officials and Mr. Myers reported that the curfew was eased on Saturday during daytime and lifted completely at 6 A.M. last Monday. **********Last weekend, morever, four American diplomats had flown to Grenada to meet with the leftist military rulers of the island and were told that Grenada's Revolutionary Military Council would reopen the airport Monday. Mr. Speakes said later that the United States felt it could not trust the offer because the airport would not permit landings and Washington was uncertain who was in control of the island. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Myers described fairly normal airport routines in operation Monday afternoon. He said Grenadian customs officials were processing departures normally, stamping passports and collecting airport taxes. He said four small, privately operated charter planes all evidently based on nearby islands had flown into Grenada and flew out of Pearls Airport between 2 and 6 P.M. **********''We went through the usual customs formalities and paid the airport tax,'' he said. ''There were no armed guards at the airport. There were just the usual customs officials. Nobody with a rifle.''  Left on 9-Seat Plane **********He and his wife, Ruth, left on the last of the four planes, a two-engine, nine- seat white Islander plane that had been originally chartered by the local office of the Scotia Bank. They shared the plane with two other men in Grenada on O.A.S. business, one a Jamaican and the other from Colombia, as well as a Caribbean banker, his wife and two children. **********American diplomats in Barbados have said American efforts to arrange an evacuation charter Monday broke down when Grenadian officials asked for six hours' advance notice of the plane's landing time and said they could not promise the safety of Americans en route from their residences to the airport. Mr. Myers said he had not encountered any violence traveling to the airport from the Spice Islands Inn, where he and his wife had stayed.
