https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The Children's Television Workshop, already the publisher of three successful magazines for youngsters, is now going to join the developing crush in the computer magazine field. Its planned publication, Enter, will be the first it has had that will accept advertising. **********Enter will have a 10-a-year frequency aimed at the 10-to-16-yearold computer buff. Although ad rates have not be set as yet, they will be based on a circulation rate base of 200,000. The first issue is scheduled for September. **********Myles Grossman, who has been brought in to be ad director, promised that advertising guidelines would be strict and that claims would require verificiation. Nina Link is publisher of all of the Workshop's magazines. **********Ira Wolfman, the editor, is going to present a package made up of career-opportunity stories, news of developments in the computer field, and profiles of people in the computer and video game field.  Issues will also carry games, quizzes, puzzles and ''simple programming challenges.'' **********The other Children's Television Workshop magazines are Sesame Street, with a circulation of 1.2 million; The Electric Company magazine, with 360,000, and 3-2-1 Contact magazine, with 302,000. **********Now Big Bird is going after the big bucks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/13/busin.body_text: **********Consumers took on $4.41 billion more in installment debt than they paid off during June, the biggest monthly increase since the Government began keeping track in 1943, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. **********The gain was led by increased car financing, which rose a net $1.9 billion, the report said. **********''Americans essentially are expressing their confidence in the staying power of this recovery by their willingness to go into debt and purchase autos and other durable goods that they put off buying for the last three years,'' said Van Jolissaint, of Evans Economics Inc. **********According to Mr. Jolissaint, the credit report was consistent with other Government reports for June, which showed increases in personal income and in consumption, including gains for sales of durable goods. **********Durable goods are items such as cars and refrigerators that are expected to last three or more years and are relatively costly; thus they often are bought on credit.  Downturn in July **********In July, sales of autos and other durables fell from their June level in what economists said was an inevitable slowing of the surge in consumer spending earlier this year. **********The June expansion in installment credit followed gains of $2.69 billion in May and $2.27 billion in April. **********The gain from May to June amounted to an annual growth rate of 15 percent, the highest rate since September 1979, when credit expanded 16.2 percent at an annual rate. The annual rate of growth for June's increase in auto credit was 18 percent, the Fed said. **********The Fed said the annual rate of growth in the second quarter rose to 11 percent from 7 percent in the first quarter and 4 percent for all of 1982.  Revolving Debt Up 22% **********The report said outstanding debt for revolving credit accounts rose $1.21 billion, after gaining $514 million in May. That was a 22 percent annual rate of increase for the category, which also includes some auto loans from dealers. **********Other credit such as cash loans from banks and savings and loans rose $1.07 billion, or an annual 9.8 percent gain, after rising $852 million in May, the Fed said. **********The report includes most short- and medium-term lending, but excludes long-term credit such as home loans. The figures are adjusted for normal seasonal variations. **********Before adjustment, the report said, consumers had $353 billion in outstanding credit in June, up 6.3 percent from $332.3 billion in June of last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/17/busin.body_text: **********The typically lavish, traditional menu, put together by Breadline, a Manhattan caterer, for a party last week featured turkeys with sage and sausage stuffing, glazed hams in pecan sauce, sauteed cinnamon apples, sugared cranberries in gin, and profiteroles - tiny cream- or custard-filled pastries - stacked in the shape of a Christmas tree. The party, for around 100 employees of the Merona Sport Company, was held in a loft decorated in authentic turn-of- the-century French trappings. **********Meanwhile, Mike Roman, president of Mixing Bowl Ltd., in Chicago, has ordered and will be dishing up 2,000 pounds of boneless chicken breasts, 1,200 pounds of tenderloin beef, 700 pounds of mushrooms, 600 pounds of baking hams and 420 heads of broccoli this holiday season. He will also serve 1,200 loaves of his special zucchini bread. **********Mr. Roman, the people at Breadline Catering Inc., and most other caterers declined to predict just how profitable this holiday season may be. But they did say it is one of their busiest ever. And nearly all of their work, they said, is for business customers. **********''We're doing around 25 percent of our year's business in December,'' said Boyce Brawley, part-owner of Breadline. ''Most are corporate parties of 500 to 1,000 people, where corporations are saying 'thank you' to their clients or employees.'' **********Breadline is what is known in the trade as an ''outside caterer'' - it brings its food to lofts, houses, yachts and other places, wherever someone is throwing a party. That is in contrast to hotels and restaurants that may also do special events, but mainly in their own establishments. **********Catering for a thousand people can ''easily'' cost $100,000 this year, Mr. Brawley said. Prices range ''from $25 per person for a cocktail party with assorted hors d'oeuvres, to $100 per person for a sitdown meal with full service, depending on the company's style and the time of day.'' **********And if clients are inclined toward expensive imports - Norwegian salmon, Russian caviar, and fresh fruits from New Zealand and Australia, and the pricier French champagnes are big at this time of year - the bill is, naturally, higher. **********Aside from the tension and round- the-clock work involved in turning tons of raw food into succulent holiday fare, the caterers' biggest headache is finding the people to do it all. **********Mr. Roman's company, for example, which had sales of $1.3 million last year, must triple its staff for December and therefore advertises widely for temporary help. Others, such as the Silver Palate in Manhattan, a wholesale and retail outlet, recruit assistants from a list of holiday reserves that includes ''out-of-work actors, students or freelance journalists,'' said Ellie McGowan, the catering coordinator. **********And what do these folks earn? ''Almost $90 for their first four hours of work on Christmas and New Year's,'' she said. ''This is probably our busiest time, and with Christmas, Thanksgiving and New Year's all within a month of each other, it's just a rat race.'' **********In addition to ''executing parties'' at Christmastime, the Silver Palate prepares and sends gourmet gift baskets, packed with their own chutneys, preserves, mustards and baked goods, that cost from $25 to $250. **********'Corporate Gift Giving' **********''This is a time for corporate gift giving, '' Mrs. McGowan said, citing clients such as Time Inc., Lehman Brothers and Compton Advertising. **********And regular caterers are so busy at this time of year that many companies seek out ''design'' consultants such as Harriette Rose and her husband, Dr. Martin Katz, owners of Gourmet Advisory Services in New York. They do not cook. Instead they call themselves ''party planners,'' and arrange the menu and decor for individual parties, preside over the results and charge 15 percent of the final bill as a consultation fee. **********Mrs. Rose, looking splendid in a gold lame gown one evening last week, was keeping close track of the all-desserts Christmas buffet she had put together for a real estate developer's 200 clients at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York. More than 3,000 individual desserts and glazed fruits, including 400 assorted chocolate truffles and Moroccan crepes, freshly prepared before the guests, were the stars of this show. **********Teeth in Jeopardy **********''They're going to walk in here and their teeth are going to fall out,'' Mrs. Rose said as she surveyed the scene just before the guests began arriving. ''I want the lights down and the ashtrays in place,'' she instructed. ''I want the mood in here.'' **********The mood is pretty good at the Vista International Hotel in New York's World Trade Center, where many of the holiday parties in the city's financial district are catered. **********''People's businesses have turned around this year,'' said Roger Davis, director of food and beverages at the hotel, a Hilton International affiliate. ''There's been an upturn in the economy and there's a much healthier attitude to spending. I certainly can't attribute it to anything else.'' **********The Vista's banquet halls and restaurants are expected to take in $1.4 million this month alone, about $400,000 more than average. **********''We've had to triple our bar and banquet service, and probably will double our profits over last year,'' Mr. Davis estimated. ''On Tuesday we had 1,650 people from a Wall Street investment house. That brought in $128,000.'' **********In the last three weeks alone, the Vista has ordered about 40 ''steamship rounds'' of beef, each weighing around 85 pounds and serving 250 people, Mr. Davis said. Beer orders have doubled to 4,800 bottles a week; orders for white wine have jumped to nearly 1,900 bottles a week. Scotch, twice as popular as other liquors, is running at about 900 quarts a week. **********Caterers of all kinds in the United States had sales of $814 million in 1982 and will reach at least $880 million this year, according to the National Restaurant Association. With the recovery under way in the service sector, catering sales are expected to achieve growth rates of 10.5 percent this year and 10.7 percent in 1984. A recent Department of Commerce survey found that there were 3,320 ''social caterers'' in the United States. **********Despite their expense, Christmas parties remain a ritual. ''These parties are really business tools, reaffirming a company's relationship with employees or clients,'' said Mr. Brawley of Breadline. **********Even so, some employees, at least, have mixed feelings about them. **********''It was a fine party,'' said one who attended the gala Christmas celebration put on by Ogilvy & Mather International, the advertising agency, at the Roseland Ballroom in New York last year, ''but I would have liked the money in my paycheck much more.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.main_headline: Paris Reports Sending More Arms to Chad
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Paris Reports Sending More Arms to Chad
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/01/world.body_text: **********French officials said today that the Government had delivered 200 tons of military equipment to Chad since rebel forces captured a town in the north of the country last week. **********Previous reports had put the total at 35 tons. **********The officials said seven cargo planes containing arms, ammunition and vehicles had been flown to Ndjamena, the capital, in the last few days. The officials said France's continuing arms deliveries to its former colony were intended to replace equipment lost in the battle for the northern town of Largeau. **********France has pledged firm support for the Government of President Hissen Habre and has accused Libya of disrupting the region by helping the rebels led by former President Goukouni Oueddei.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.print_headline: U.S. FAILURE WITH SYRIANS; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/07/world.body_text: **********The inability of Secretary of State George P.  Shultz to make any apparent headway with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon leaves the country partitioned between Israel and Syria indefinitely, with the Lebanese Government's control limited to parts of Beirut. **********For the short run, State Department officials said, American efforts will probably be limited to what one official called ''damage control'' - maintaining contacts with Syria through the joint ''working groups'' agreed to by the Syrians today and trying to insure that Israel and Syria avoid a direct clash in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, where their forces are virtually head to head. **********The lack of progress reported by Mr. Shultz has seemed to undercut American prestige in the region. The Lebanese and the Israelis, who both agreed to the terms for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon at the urging of Mr. Shultz in May, are expressing concern privately and publicly over the American inability to obtain comparable results from the Syrians. **********The Israelis privately are accusing the United States of mishandling the situation. They are now saying that Mr. Shultz and his special envoy, Philip C. Habib, spent too much time trying to get them to agree to terms and not enough in pressing the Syrians to agree. They said Mr. Shultz and Mr. Habib assured them that if they agreed to withdraw, Syria would follow suit, assurances the Israelis say were unfounded. **********The Lebanese, under pressure from Syria not to agree to anything with Israel, are worried now that the United States will not be able to prevent the Israelis from reducing their forces and setting up a permanent zone of occupation in southern Lebanon, which would encourage Syria to remain permanently in its sector as well. **********White House and State Department officials said they wanted to wait for a full report from Mr. Shultz before commenting, but they remarked that they were not surprised at Mr. Shultz's reporting that he was unable to persuade Mr. Assad to be more forthcoming. They said there never was any expectation by Mr. Shultz or his senior advisers that he would achieve a breakthrough on this brief trip. Shultz Decided to Make Stop **********Nevertheless, they said that Mr. Shultz, by the time he reached Pakistan last Saturday on his round-the-world mission, decided that it would be more useful to stop in the Middle East than to fly over it. He recommended to Mr. Reagan, then in California, that he go to Syria and the other key countries in the region for a firsthand, unfiltered view of Syria's reasons for refusing to withdraw. Mr.  Reagan agreed. The White House said at the time that Mr. Reagan had talked with Mr. Shultz on the phone. Officials said that in fact, Mr. Shultz talked only with Robert C. McFarlane, the deputy chief of the National Security Council staff. **********What Mr. Shultz heard from Mr. Assad today, officials said, was apparently what Syria has been saying publicly for weeks: Syria is determined not to let Lebanon's agreement with Israel take effect.  The pact, in which Israel agreed to withdraw only when Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization did also, would give Israel political, economic and security concessions from Lebanon. Syria's Condition for Pulling Out **********Syria says the accord would move Lebanon into Israel's sphere of influence. Since Syria can block the carrying out of the accord by refusing to leave Lebanon, the Syrians say they will agree to withdraw only if the Israelis do so without any concessions. This would not be acceptable to the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, which has justified its invasion of Lebanon 13 months ago on the ground that it stands to gain virtual normalization of relations with another Arab country. **********Having been rebuffed by the Syrians both this time and when Mr.  Shultz met with Mr. Assad in May, the Reagan Administration must review its policy, officials said. Mr. Shultz's inclination, his aides say, is to be patient and assume that something can eventually be worked out and that contacts with Syria, Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries must be maintained in the hope that in time the Syrians will change their position. **********But one Administration official said today that such an appproach would play into Syria's hands by building up Mr. Assad without any certainty of success for the United States. One official said that in his view the United States was too conciliatory. He said that after the Syrians refused to receive Mr. Habib in May, it was a mistake for Mr. Shultz to go ''cap in hand'' to Syria today without Mr. Habib along. Mr. Shultz told reporters that Mr. Habib asked not to accompany Mr. Shultz. New Approach and U.S. Politics **********The official said he expected some White House officials to consider a different approach, particularly as they become more involved in planning a possible Reagan re-election campaign. They would try to take advantage of the relatively harmonious relations with Israel and to blame the Arabs, particularly the Syrians, who are heavily armed by the Soviet Union, for the lack of progress in the Middle East. **********This same argument can be used, they said, to explain the setback to the Administration's other major Middle East diplomatic initiative - Mr. Reagan's call last Sept. 1 for negotiations on the Palestinian question. The Reagan plan has, in effect, been shelved since King Hussein of Jordan decided in April not to join negotiations because the P.L.O. refused to give him its backing. **********In both initiatives, the effort to have Syria withdraw from Lebanon and the Reagan plan, the Administration counted on Saudi Arabia's behind-the-scenes influence to help. But in each case the Saudis were unable or unwilling to do much for the Americans. **********Saudi officials have said privately that although they give millions of dollars to Syria and the P.L.O., they are no more able to force them to do anything than the United States is able to get Israel to stop building settlements on the West Bank or to withdraw on its own from Lebanon.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/14/busin.body_text: **********A sharp decline in world oil prices could hurt the nation's banks more because of their loan exposure to the energy industry than because of their loans to oil-producing countries. **********This conclusion, which emerges from interviews with bankers and economists in the United States and overseas, sees the potential for many commercial energy producers and related companies to be squeezed by a steep drop in energy prices. This, in turn, could cause large losses at many banks that are active energy lenders, and the failure of some. **********At the same time, banking experts point out, direct loans to the energy producing countries are relatively safer because the major industrial nations would likely mount rescue operations to prevent any from collapsing. **********A sharp decline in the price of oil is considered possible in coming months because of the world's reduced energy requirements and the resulting disagreements among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries about how to defend prices. **********Richard O'Brien, a London-based economist for the American Express International Banking Corporation, estimates that the banking industry could withstand an oil-price drop to $25 a barrel, an assumption shared by many bankers. American refiners paid an average price of $33 a barrel for imported oil in the fourth quarter of 1982. **********Even so, most bankers refuse to discuss the possibility that the average price of oil could drop below $25. ''A price of $25 to $26 a barrel is worst-case thinking,'' said William D. Breedlove, vice chairman of the Interfirst Corporation, the biggest bank holding company in Dallas and a major regional lender to the energy industry. **********Although accurate figures are hard to come by, it is estimated that American banks have at least $35 billion on loan to domestic energy companies, compared with about $43 billion to less-developed countries that are heavily dependent on oil revenues. Banks throughout the world are believed to have at least $70 billion on loan to energy companies and about $119 billion to oil-and-gas producing third world countries. **********But where such heavily indebted oil producers as Mexico and Venezuela would likely be helped by the leading industrialized countries should their revenues fall sharply, bankers note that there is little chance of such a rescue operation being mounted for the hundreds of small and medium-sized companies that might be pushed into bankruptcy by a price decline - or for the banks that lend to them. **********In fact, several American banks last year were able to avoid substantial write-offs of their loans to foreign governments only with the help of Federal aid and central bank intervention. Even so, some had to report large losses on loans to commercial borrowers overseas. **********At home, too, many banks last year had to write off large amounts of commercial energy-related loans. Such problems, for example, led to the failure of two medium-sized banks - the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City and the Abilene National Bank of Texas - and to huge losses that severely shook several larger ones. Neither the Government nor the Federal Reserve System intervened to save the banks or to soften their losses. **********Last month, the GHR Energy Corporation, a Louisiana oil and gas producer that is the nation's third-largest privately held industrial concern, filed for Chapter 11 under Federal bankruptcy laws as the result of lower demand and prices for its high-cost oil. GHR owed $375 million to American and foreign banks. **********''Obviously, everyone has to be concerned, but the prospects of a crisis are dim,'' said Mr. Breedlove. More than 30 percent of Interfirst's business loans are to the oil and gas industry. No Reliable Numbers **********James McDermott Jr., director of research for Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a securities firm that specializes in bank stocks, stressed that the paucity of information made any predictions difficult.  ''You try to get aggregate figures and you go crazy,'' Mr. McDermott said. **********The Federal Reserve compiles some statistics, though. At the end of 1982, it says, the nation's large banks had $29.6 billion on loan to what it describes as ''mining'' companies. Economists believe that most of this total, in fact, was to oil and gas producers. In addition, the Fed reports that banks had $5.6 billion on loan to domestic petroleum refiners. **********These figures, however, do not include American bank loans to foreign energy producers, or loans by foreign branches of American banks to domestic and foreign energy producers. They also exclude many loans made to companies that provide goods and services to the energy industry. **********More reliable figures are available for bank loans to developing countries that are dependent on oil and gas exports.  The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company estimates that banks worldwide have $64.4 billion on loan to Mexico (with American banks accounting for $25.2 billion); $27.2 billion to Venezuela ($10.7 billion); $8.2 billion to Indonesia ($2.4 billion); $7.7 billion to Algeria ($1.2 billion); $6.7 billion to Nigeria ($1.2 billion), and $4.7 billion ($2.2 billion) to Ecuador. Loans Put at $70 Billion **********Bank economists concede they have less reliable figures about loans to energy companies. Abraham Gulkowitz, a vice president and economist of the Bankers Trust Company, estimates that total bank lending to the energy industry worldwide might be about $70 billion, unchanged from the level a year earlier. But some of this total is overlap, or loans already included in the borrowing figures for countries. **********The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the nation's fourthlargest bank, had almost $5 billion on loan to the energy industry at the end of 1982, up 20 percent from the previous year.  Few other major banks disclose their loans to the oil industry, but each is believed to have several billion dollars in energy loans outstanding. **********In oil-producing areas such as Texas and Oklahoma, banks are particularly vulnerable to declines in the price of oil because a disproportionately large part of their portfolios are accounted for by energy loans. According to data compiled last year by Mr.  McDermott, energy loans accounted for at least 30 percent of total loans at many bank holding companies in Texas. Service Loans Vulnerable **********In many cases, bankers observe, it is harder to collect debts from companies that service the oil companies than from the producing companies. ''We can stand some price drop on the exploration and production side,'' said Michael Hegarty, senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, ''but what gets hurt is the service sector.'' **********But oil- and gas-producing companies can also be highly vulnerable, especially if they are operating in high-cost areas. Last year's big energy-related losses came from production and service companies that operated in highly speculative regions. **********Perhaps as much from wishful thinking as from scientific analysis, bankers contend that the price of oil will not plummet, that the OPEC countries will reach agreement on pricing and that even if they do not, market forces will keep the price of oil from falling too low. **********Bankers emphasize, however, that even if the price of oil were to stay above $25, no one knows for sure what the effects would be on the banks. **********''Every bank presumably is running its own numbers and sorting out its own position, and no bank is going to tell any other bank where it stands,'' said Edward L. Hoyt, vice president of Morgan Guaranty.  ''Therefore, it is almost impossible to make generalizations.'' Banks Hazy on Own Portfolios **********Further clouding any attempt to draw conclusions from the numbers is the fact that many banks have problems analyzing their own portfolios. One banker, who asked not to be identified, explained that a single loan can sometimes involve thousands of properties and as many as 50 different oil prices. ''Who's got time to analyze it?'' he asked. **********Indeed, much depends on how a bank's energy loans are structured and to whom they are made. Understandably, bankers are most confident about loans to major multinational oil companies, with their vast and diversified resources. The outlook becomes far more complicated when loans to medium-sized and small companies are considered. **********Critical elements that come into play are the amount of taxes that must be paid and other overhead costs. These vary widely from project to project. **********A rule of thumb is that the more a company pays in taxes, the less it would be hurt by a drop in the oil price. The after-tax cost of an $8 decline in the price of a barrel of oil for an American company paying a ''windfall-profit'' tax of 70 percent and income taxes of 50 percent would be only $1.20, bankers say. Role of Tax Exposure **********The other $6.80 would be absorbed by Federal, state and local governments. A company with lower taxes, but higher overhead costs, would be much more vulnerable. **********Thus, the inability to generalize about the cost of producing a barrel of oil compounds the problem of determining the impact of a lower oil price. But the main problem today is that, until last year, most oil and gas loans were made on the premise that energy prices would continue to rise sharply. **********According to William E. Pelley, senior vice president of Bankers Trust's energy group, and Herbert W. Krupp, vice president, banks usually provide loans to finance new drilling and exploration projects only when they are secured by existing producing properties. **********Before a loan is made, engineering studies determine the size of the oil or gas reserves and the rate at which these reserves could be retrieved. Mr. Krupp says the margin of error seldom exceeds 10 percent or 15 percent, but some mistakes are made. Estimating Reserves **********Using such reports, a bank determines how much oil will be produced, usually over 15 years. The bank then estimates the perbarrel price for that entire period. Until last year, the estimates had been for dramatic increases. In 1980, for example, Bankers Trust estimated that the price of oil would rise at a rate of almost 10 percent a year, to $90 a barrel by 1990. **********Based on these estimates, and after subtracting overhead costs, the bank would determine how much money the property would clear over the life of the well. The ''conservative'' banks usually were willing to lend half this amount. Thus, if the estimates were correct, the property would generate double the income needed to pay the loan. As the borrower made principal payments, however, the coverage increased. **********But with the possibility of a sharp decline in the price of oil and in other energy prices, the estimates on which the loans were based could be far from the mark. In the worst cases, even excluding the expense of debt repayments, the costs of running a well would be so much higher than the current price of oil that it would have to be closed and the loan written off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.print_headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES; A Pennsylvania Issue Is Priced
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/25/busin.body_text: **********An $85 million Commonwealth of Pennsylvania capital improvement general obligation issue was won in competitive bidding by the First Boston Corporation. **********The bonds were priced to yield 5 percent in 1983 and 9.35 percent in 2002. **********Moody's rated the bonds A and Standard & Poors rated them A+.  All were serial bonds, with a 12 percent coupon on the issue due in 1983 that was priced at 103.14 to yield 5 percent. The serial bonds due in 1998 have a 9 percent coupon priced at 98.35 to yield 9.20 percent. The serial bonds due in 2020 have a 7.50 percent coupon and were priced at 83.54 to yield 9.35 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/busin.body_text: **********Earlier this year, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation obtained from the Philippines what appeared to be one of its circuit breakers, a widely used device that automatically cuts off electric power in case of overloading to prevent fire and shocks. **********It bore the Westinghouse trademark, was the correct size and shape and carried the right serial number. But testing showed it to be a dangerous fake, incapable of doing what a genuine Westinghouse circuit breaker should do. **********That is just one example of large- scale industrial counterfeiting that was presented at a meeting here last month of American and European manufacturers intent on bringing the phenomenon under control. **********Government Action Sought **********In a communique after the meeting, they called on their governments to take stronger action against the pirating of patented, trademarked products. **********''What is frightening is the extent to which counterfeiting is jeopardizing the health and safety of consumers, not just their pocketbooks,'' said James L. Bikoff, president of the International Anticounterfeiting Coalition, which represents 135 major American corporations and trade associations. **********As every summer visitor to Italy knows, the counterfeiting of expensive brand-name goods like handbags, clothes and cosmetics has been going on for a long time. The Louis Vuitton bags and Pierre Cardin belts on sale in the street markets of Florence at a fraction of their cost elsewhere were made in the city's suburbs, not in Paris. **********Shift to the Third World **********The new development is that now third world countries are turning out billions of dollars worth of fake industrial goods that bear the trademarks of famous companies but are usually of inferior quality. **********Last year, for example, the Singapore Air Force returned a load of brake parts for its Strikemaster aircraft to the British manufacturer, Dunlop, complaining that they did not work. Testing showed they were fakes, made of weak steel and constituting, in the words of a British court, ''a serious danger to the public.'' **********Spare parts, industrial components, processed foods and patented drugs are now all being counterfeited on an increasing scale. According to a study prepared by the Commission of the European Community, trade in pirated goods now accounts for about 2 percent of total world trade and is starting to make a serious dent in the sales of established companies, adversely affecting their employment and exports. **********Estimates of Losses **********Mr. Bikoff puts the value of worldwide trade in forged automobile parts alone at $12 billion a year. The American motor parts industry reckons that counterfeiting has cost it 14,000 jobs, while the European industry says it has lost 6,000 jobs. **********Swiss watch makers estimate that 100 million fake Swiss watches are sold annually for about $500 million. The French perfume industry estimates annual losses from counterfeiting at $62 million, or 10 percent of turnover. Worldwide sales of pirated records and tapes are put at $1 billion a year. **********Faced with this growing threat, Western manufacturers have decided to press their governments to put into effect on their own a proposed new international code that would give their customs services authority to seize forged goods and either prosecute the importers or assist the genuine manuacturer in bringing legal action. **********The code was drawn up by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based body that oversees world trade, and presented to last November's ministerial meeting of GATT. But third world opponents prevented its adoption. **********Delegates at Meeting **********The decision to urge unilateral action putting the code into effect was taken at last month's conference here, which was organized by the International Chamber of Commerce. Delegates included the European Association of Branded Product Industries, representing 1,600 companies; the Anti-Counterfeiting Group, which is predominantly British; the Swiss Watchmakers Federation, and the International Federation of Phonogram and Videogram Producers. **********Delegates reported that the biggest sources of counterfeit industrial goods were Taiwan, the Philippines and South Korea, together with Mexico and other Latin American countries. But Italy, Spain and Morocco were also listed. Although many of these countries have laws protecting foreign patents and trademarks, Western manufacturers said, they seldom enforce them, and obtaining court judgments against a local infringer is difficult and costly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.main_headline: Manila Eases Curbs On Opposition Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Manila Eases Curbs On Opposition Mayor
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.body_text: **********An opposition mayor has been transferred from a stockade to house arrest after President Ferdinand E. Marcos heeded protests from Jaime Cardinal Sin about the mayor's three-month detention. **********Gen. Alfredo Olano, regional military commander in Cebu, said Mayor Aquilino Pimentel would be escorted to his home in Cagayan de Oro, on the island of Mindanao, 130 miles southeast of Cebu and about 500 miles southeast of Manila. **********Mayor Pimentel has been charged with murder and rebellion after his arrest in April on Mr. Marcos's orders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.main_headline: French Court Releases Libyan Wanted in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; French Court Releases Libyan Wanted in Italy
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/world.body_text: **********A French court ordered today that a jailed Libyan sought by Italy be released because Italy had not provided extradition papers. **********The Libyan, Rashid Said Mohamed Abdullah, 34 years old, was arrested in Paris on Oct. 7 on a Milan warrant charging him with murder and illegal possession of arms. **********He was accused of the 1980 murder in Milan of Azzedin Laheri, a Libyan merchant and opponent of the Tripoli Government who reportedly refused to return to Libya. **********Soon after the Oct. 7 arrest, Libya prevented 37 French citizens from leaving Tripoli. They were allowed to leave several days later. The French said the events were unconnected. **********The request for Mr. Abdullah's release was made on the ground that Italy had not officially asked for extradition within 20 days of the arrest, as is laid down in the French-Italian extradition treaty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/world.main_headline: Polish Advisory Group Calls for an Amnesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Polish Advisory Group Calls for an Amnesty
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/10/world.body_text: **********A citizen's advisory body set up by the authorities called today on the Government to lift martial law completely and grant amnesty to political prisoners. **********The advisory body, the Patriotic Movement for National Rebirth, urged the Government to ''lift martial law and pass regulations to make it possible for those convicted of violating martial law and people in hiding to return to work and civic life.'' **********It did not suggest a date for lifting martial law, which was declared Dec. 13, 1981, and suspended seven months ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/21/world.body_text: **********France's Minister of Foreign Trade, Michel Jobert, resigned today, saying he had not been given enough authority to carry out his assignment to close France's foreign trade deficit. **********Mr. Jobert is the first key minister to quit President Francois Mitterrand's Government.  The development came as Mr. Mitterrand and top Government officials held a hectic round of meetings on economic policy and the flagging negotiations in Brussels on the Common Market's monetary system. **********On Monday, European heads of government are to gather in Brussels for a regular two-day summit meeting that is expected to be dominated by discussions of the currency crisis. **********Premier Could Be Affected **********The high-level meetings in Paris were seen as a prelude to France's first Cabinet shake-up since the Socialists assumed power 22 months ago, a shuffle that officials said could involve the appointment of a new Prime Minister to replace Pierre Mauroy. **********Mr. Mitterrand will address the nation on Wednesday, and his spokesman said this evening that the President might announce Cabinet changes then. Discussion of an impending Cabinet shake-up has dominated the news here since the Socialists suffered substantial, but not overwhelming, losses in municipal elections that ended last Sunday. **********After Mr. Jobert's announcement of his resignation, the Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, flew back to Paris from Brussels, where talks on the revaluation of European currencies remained deadlocked. **********Prime Minister Mauroy returned to Paris from his political stronghold, Lille, soon after being installed for a new term as Mayor there. Mr. Mauroy's arrival was 24 hours ahead of schedule. **********Mr. Jobert's resignation removes from the Government the only minister who was not a member of one of the three parties of the left - the Socialists, the Communists and the Movement of Left Radicals. He is the leader of a small party of his own, the Movement of Democrats. Had Role in Key Decisions **********Mr. Jobert was involved in some of the Mitterrand Government's most disputed decisions, including the contract signed with the Soviet Union to bring gas to Europe through a pipeline from Siberia built with European credit and using European technology. It was also Mr.  Jobert who decided to subject imported Japanese videorecorders to intense inspections at an understaffed customs house in Poitiers.  This protectionist move choked off the flow of the foreign-made videorecorders to France for some time. **********But over all, France's foreign trade deficit has gone up dramatically, amounting in January alone to about $1.4 billion. In his statement explaining his resignation, Mr. Jobert said he had taken ''a rather poorly delineated post'' and lacked the means to undertake ''a coherent and effective policy.'' **********Today's discussions among Government leaders focused heavily on the talks in Brussels, whose outcome will strongly influence both the course of the next phase of Mr. Mitterrand's presidency and the makeup of any new Cabinet. **********An agreement to devalue the franc - it would be the third devaluation since Mr. Mitterrand took office -would probably be part of an overall austerity program aimed at curbing inflation and reducing the foreign trade deficit. Devaluation Opposed **********In the Brussels discussions, Mr. Delors is defending the French position opposing devaluation. But the Finance Minister, an ideological centrist who is regarded in political circles as the favorite to succeed Mr. Mauroy, hinted at a new round of austerity today after the second of two meetings he held with Mr. Mitterrand. **********Mr. Delors said he was preparing ''economic and social measures which should permit us to improve our performance and significantly reduce our external trade deficit.'' **********Mr. Mauroy, who has been reported by associates to be less sympathetic than Mr. Delors to a new austerity program, nonetheless underlined the importance of continuing ''an implacable struggle against inflation'' in an address at Lille this morning. **********''We should all be conscious,'' he said, ''that as long as the rate of inflation in France is higher than that of our principal partners - above all the Federal Republic of Germany - our money will be menaced.'' **********But there are members of Mr. Mitterrand's Socialist Government, particularly on the left, who favor leaving the European monetary system and pursuing a ''go it alone'' strategy that could involve protectionism. Delors Popular With Bankers **********These opponents of devaluation and further austerity measures also point to the possibility that an American economic recovery, combined with lower oil prices, could pull France out of its economic doldrums. **********Should the Government pursue such a strategy, Mr. Mauroy might stay on, or would probably be replaced by someone other than Mr. Delors, whose centrism has made him popular among bankers and other businessmen and unpopular with left-wing Socialists and with the Communist Party, which holds four ministries in the current Cabinet. **********Mr. Mitterrand has been described by aides as favoring a more austere policy to curb imports and inflation, and today's statements by Mr. Mauroy and Mr. Delors were seen here tonight as further indications that such a policy was in the offing. **********However, the Communist Party, which suffered substantial losses in the municipal elections, has issued a steady stream of statements supporting the Government's original, more left-wing agenda, statements seen as pressure against further austerity measures. Communists' Position Weak **********Many politicians here believe the Communists are in too weak a position to leave the Government now. If they should withdraw, Mr.  Mitterrand's administration would still have a working majority in Parliament majority but might face difficulties from the labor union movement, where the Communists are strong. **********Devaluation of the franc is also a special source of fear here for the political left, which has historically seen devaluations used by political conservatives as a symbol of an inability of the left to run the economy. **********As if to underline this fear, Francois Leotard, secretary general of the center-right Parti Republicain, said today that he feared ''that we will have tommorow a lessened and diminished franc, and thus a lessened and diminished Government.'' 'Important Things' Foreseen **********Speculation that a ministerial shake-up would be announced today was fueled by Mr. Jobert's resignation and Mr. Delors' announcement this morning that he had to leave the Brussels talks because ''important things will happen today in Paris and one must be there.'' The Government's official journal was also warned to be ''on alert'' for publication of a special issue on Monday. **********But early this evening, Michel Vauzelle, Mr. Mitterrand's spokesman, said that no announcement of Cabinet changes was forthcoming. He added that the President ''would probably allude to Cabinet changes, if such should be the case,'' in a televised speech to the country Wednesday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.main_headline: 90 ARE KILLED AS JETLINERS COLLIDE ON MADRID RUNWAY IN HEAVY FOG
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.print_headline: 90 ARE KILLED AS JETLINERS COLLIDE ON MADRID RUNWAY IN HEAVY FOG
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.body_text: **********Two Spanish jetliners collided in heavy fog on a takeoff runway here this morning, killing about 90 people and injuring more than 30 of the approximately 45 survivors. It was the second airline disaster here in 10 days. **********The collision, which occurred at 9:50, touched off explosions and fires on both aircraft. One, Iberia Airlines Flight 350, was a Boeing 727 bound for Rome with 93 people aboard, 40 of them Japanese tourists. The other, **********Flight 134 of Spain's domestic Aviaco line, was a DC-9 bound for the northern Spanish city of Santander with 42 people aboard. **********According to airport officials, the Iberia jet had been cleared for takeoff and was moving down the runway at 150 miles an hour when it crashed into the Aviaco plane, which had taxied onto the same runway and crossed its path. Officials said that the Aviaco pilot had received permission to move into position for departure but that he apparently did not follow the proper route, which would have brought him behind the Iberia aircraft. **********All 37 passengers and 5 crew members on the Aviaco jet were killed, and the plane reportedly disintegrated. Of the 93 people on the Iberia jet, 45 survived, including the pilot and all 8 other crew members, according to the Ministry of the Interior Civil Protection Agency, which investigates accidents.  The agency said the figures were not final, however. Of the 40 Japanese on the Iberia plane, only three couples on their honeymoons survived. **********King Returning From U.S. **********On hearing of the plane collision, King Juan Carlos I decided to cut short a visit to the United States. The King, who went to New York with Queen Sofia on an unofficial visit, received an honorary doctor of laws degree from New York University today and was to have met in Washington Thursday morning with President Reagan. **********Some of the survivors from the Iberia plane, which was torn in two, walked off with scant injuries. At least 12 of the survivors did not require hospitalization, and the pilot, Capt. Carlos Lopez Barranco, was reported by officials to be recuperating at home. **********Others were hospitalized in four Madrid hospitals. One person was in critical condition with burns covering 45 percent of his body. **********People at the airport when the crash occurred said the fog was so thick that employees hurrying to the runway area could not see the planes. A survivor running from the burning planes suddenly appeared and showed them where to go. **********Bodies and charred bits of clothing and debris were found scattered around the burned remnants of the planes. Rescue workers gathered burned and mutilated bodies from the plane's hulk and covered them with blankets. **********'Plane Was Torn Apart' **********Survivors said the fire began almost immediately after the crash. **********''The plane was torn apart,'' said one survivor. ''I jumped out through a hole, over the flames. I tried to help others but the crew told me that the plane could explode at any moment and I must not go back in.'' **********Pedro Villar, another survivor, said: ''I was reading and suddenly there was a crash, and fire immediately, only seconds after the crash. I didn't lose consciousness. I took off my seat belt and jumped out.'' **********Mr. Villar said it took more than 20 minutes for firefighters and ambulances to arrive. **********All the survivors were said to have been sitting in the front of the plane. The Iberia pilot, seeing the Aviaco plane in his path, apparently tried to avoid the crash, but he told an Italian passenger who survived that he had no time to maneuver. It is not clear whether he tried to make an emergency takeoff or swerved before the collision. **********(The pilot crawled from the damaged cockpit, helped two other survivors out and repeatedly shouted, ''The runway was mine!'' United Press International reported.) **********Enrique Baron, the Minister of Transport and Communication, said at a news conference that the visibility was 300 yards and that in accordance with airport regulations for that visibility, the airport was not closed. **********Incoming Planes Diverted **********Other aviation officials said the greatest danger in fog is for planes that are landing. For that reason, they said, several incoming flights were diverted to other airports in Spain. **********The crash was the second in the Madrid area since Nov. 27, when a Boeing 747 of the Colombian airline Avianca crashed on its approach to Madrid, killing 181 people. **********Airport officials compared the crash today with the worst catastrophe in aviation history, which occurred in 1977, also on Spanish territory. On that occasion, two Boeing 747's, a KLM and a Pan American, collided on the takeoff runway in the Canary Islands at the airport of Santa Cruz de Tenerife, killing 583 people. **********In that disaster, however, one of the pilots began his takeoff without permission from the control tower. Today, both airliners had permission to move.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/23/busin.body_text: **********GAYLE HOLCOMB, a professional music teacher in Frankfort, Ky., was granted a patent this week for a ''talking'' metronome. A metronome usually controls the timing of musical instruments by repeated clicks audible to the players but the Holcomb invention does the regulation by its synthetic speech. **********A student musician can time a musical instrument by the speed of enunciation of the words delivered by the artificial voice. The new metronome includes a speech synthesizer, a programmed microprocessor, an audio amplifier and a speaker. **********Mr. Holcomb assigned patent 4,380,185 to V-T Rhythms Inc., a company he controls that is offering licenses to manufacturers.  In a telephone interview, Mr. Holcomb said that he expects his invention to relieve music teachers, who now count audibly to help students get the correct rhythm, of this work.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/world.main_headline: ISRAEL DISMISSES CHARGE IT PLANS TO STRIKE SYRIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/world.print_headline: ISRAEL DISMISSES CHARGE IT PLANS TO STRIKE SYRIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin today dismissed allegations that there was a threat of war with Syria, saying a Soviet warning of such a danger was ''artificial.'' **********''I do not think Syria is going to attack us,'' Mr. Begin told reporters. **********''We certainly have no intention whatsoever of attacking Syria. All these threats have a totally artificial basis.'' **********He added: ''It should not be taken lightly but there's no call to get panicky. Such things have happened before.'' Wednesday's formal Soviet statement, a form usually reserved for matters the Kremlin considers to be of pressing importance, implied that the Soviet Union and its allies would support Syria in the event of an Israeli attack, but did not say what form such assistance might take. Israeli Leaders Puzzled **********The Soviet warning puzzled Israeli leaders, and one official said he believed it was aimed more at the United States than at Israel.  The official, who requested anonymity, said Israel's initial analysis of the Soviet statement was that it was intended to signal Washington that all Middle East arrangements must have Soviet assent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has been fined $6,000 for shipping violations blamed for a fire last week at the Chem-Nuclear waste dump near Barnwell, S.C., state officials said. **********The company has also been ordered to develop a new system for packing waste containers before resuming shipments to the low-level nuclear waste site. Westinghouse said it had no comment. **********Heyward Shealy, chief of the Department of Health and Environmental Control's bureau of radioactive health, said a shipment of zirconium tubes apparently rubbed together during transit, igniting debris in a trench where wastes were buried. The Aug. 11 fire was put out within minutes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.main_headline: U.S. AIDE BLAMES CHINA FOR DELAYING ARMS DEALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.print_headline: U.S. AIDE BLAMES CHINA FOR DELAYING ARMS DEALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/world.body_text: **********A senior State Department official said today that there had been no sales of American military equipment so far to China because the Chinese had been seeking special treatment before they would agree to buy any arms. **********In a briefing for reporters in advance of the arrival this afternoon of Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian, the official said that even though the Reagan Administration had told the Chinese it was willing on a case-by-case basis to consider the sale of certain arms, the Chinese were insisting on first being given an umbrella list of what arms they would be permitted to buy - something Washington as a rule does not do for any country, the official said. **********Mr. Wu's long-planned three-day trip came as the Administration grew concerned about a possible rise in tension in northeastern Asia after the explosion in Rangoon on Sunday that killed some South Korean officials and that President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea said was meant for him. **********The subject of possible arms sales was discussed at length during Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's recent visit to Peking. Washington is seeking a closer strategic relationship with China. **********The senior official, explaining for the first time what the obstacles were, said that during Mr. Weinberger's trip, the Chinese gave the American side a long list of military equipment and asked which items they would be allowed to buy. ''The Chinese really want treatment that is, in fact, different from what any other country that purchases military arms from us receives,'' he said. **********''Our normal procedure is to wait until there is a negotiated contract, expressing a specific intent to buy something and then decide on a case by case basis whether the license will be approved,'' he said. ''What the Chinese are looking for are some indications of what things we will approve before they get into that kind of negotiation.'' **********He said the United States understood that the Chinese had ''some understandable sensitivities about asking for a whole range of things and being turned down,'' and had said in general terms that the United States would be willing to sell antiarmor and antiaircraft weapons. **********The official also said the United States had told the Chinese that ''doing it by lists is not the way to do it.'' **********''What we need to do is have some understanding of what functions, what missions we might work together and help you perform, and if we had an idea of those missions, then we can give you a list that you might not even know about,'' he said. But so far, the Chinese have wanted to avoid such intimate strategic discussions, he said. **********The senior official said Chinese reluctance to accept American legal constraints had produced another set of problems in going ahead with publication of new trade regulations approved by President Reagan recently for liberalizing the sale to China of high technology that might have military application, such as high-speed computers. The Chinese welcomed the determination putting them in a separate ''friendly, but nonallied'' category, but have balked at complying with American restrictions. **********Under American law, the Chinese have to give assurances that they will not transfer such technology to any other country without American approval. But so far, the Chinese have not agreed to do so. **********Mr. Wu, who was in Canada on a similar official mission, will have a private dinner at the home of Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Bethesda, Md. On Tuesday Mr. Wu will meet at the White House with Mr. Reagan. **********While in Washington, Mr. Wu will also confer with Vice President Bush, Mr. Weinberger, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige and other Administration officials, as well as with members of Congress. Mr. Wu is receiving the most attention given any visiting foreign minister by the Reagan Administration, American officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/busin.body_text: **********The Medical 21 Corporation and the Surgicare Corporation, two Texas- based operators and developers of outpatient surgical centers, said yesterday that they had agreed in principle to merge in a pooling-of-interests transaction. **********The merger would make the combined company the country's largest owner and operator of ambulatory surgical facilities. **********The new company would have 24 operational centers, eight additional centers under development, and letters of intent to acquire two additional operational centers. **********Terms of the agreement, which are subject to various approvals, provide that shareholders of Medical 21 will continue to hold one share of the company for each existing share of Medical 21. Shareholders of Surgicare will receive 0.818 a share of the company for each existing share of Surgicare. **********Medical 21 made an initial public stock offering of 1.65 million shares at $22 a share last June 28, and Surgicare made an initial public stock offering of 1.2 million shares at $18 a share on Oct. 6. **********Medical 21, which is based in Dallas, has about 4.6 million shares of common stock outstanding and Surgicare, which is based is Houston, has about 3.7 million shares outstanding. Yesterday, Medical 21 was quoted at $20.50 bid in over-the-counter trading, while Surgicare's bid price was 15. **********William B. Stanberry Jr., currently president and chief executive of Surgicare, would become chairman of the merged company, which has not yet been named. Donald E. Sten, president and chief executive of Medical 21, would become president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.main_headline: GOVERNOR OF PUERTO RICO SUPPORTS REAGAN ON INVASION OF GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.print_headline: GOVERNOR OF PUERTO RICO SUPPORTS REAGAN ON INVASION OF GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/04/world.body_text: **********The Governor of Puerto Rico yesterday strongly defended the United States invasion of Grenada and said it would serve as a check on the expansion of Cuban influence in the Caribbean. **********''I think the President had no other choice but to intervene,'' Governor Carlos Romero-Barcelo said during a news conference at the Sheraton Center in New York. ''If he hadn't intervened the Eastern Caribbean would have been at the mercy of Cuba.'' **********Mr. Romero also cited a possible threat to the safety of American citizens on Grenada and the desire of ''democratic states'' in the Caribbean for United States intervention, as factors justifying the invasion. **********''If he hadn't intervened, Caribbean states would have felt abandoned,'' the Governor said of Mr. Reagan. ''They would have asked, 'Why be friends with the United States?'''  'A Blow to Cuba Itself' **********''This is a blow to Cuba itself to realize that the United States is willing to intervene,'' Mr. Romero said. ''Other Caribbean states will not feel left alone now. When Cuba puts pressure on them they know they have something to fall back on.'' **********Mr. Romero, who is a leading spokesman for Hispanic people in the United States and an advocate of full statehood for Puerto Rico, added that the ''immense majority'' of Puerto Ricans supported the invasion as an action which had ''ended the Cuban adventure in Grenada.'' **********The Governor said United States military bases on Puerto Rico had been used by American troops involved in the invasion, but that he did not know how many troops had come from the bases. **********A Pentagon spokesman said in an interview that the United States has two military facilities on Puerto Rico, the Roosevelt Roads Naval Base and Roosevelt Roads Naval Air Station. The spokesman refused to specify what role the bases had played in the invasion of Grenada or the number of United States troops that may have used the bases during the invasion. **********According to figures supplied by the Pentagon, 3,442 American military personnel are normally stationed in Puerto Rico, including 150 marines. But the number can swell to over 10,000 during special military exercises, a Pentagon spokesman said. **********Asked what United States policy in Central America should be in the wake of the Grenada invasion, Mr. Romero recommended support for democratic governments. Asked if the United States should consider direct military intervention in Central America as well, he said, ''No, no, no.'' He added that invasion is ''the ultimate, the last solution.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/01/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Ministers of Greece and Turkey met for more than two hours on Thursday in an effort to improve relations. **********A statement after the meeting, in Strasbourg, France, said they had agreed ''to abstain from any action that might have a contrary effect'' on the effort to improve ties. **********Foreign Minister Yannis Haralambopoulo told reporters on his return here on Friday that the meeting had achieved ''a new step'' in relations. The Turkish Foreign Minister, Ilter Turkmen, said he was ''optimistic for the future.'' **********The ministers agreed to continue their talks and another meeting was scheduled to coincide with a foreign ministers' conference of the Atlantic alliance in Paris in June.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Brazil is the country that might have become another Japan. Instead, it is flat broke, with a broken spirit and an empty treasury. **********The Brazilian ''miracle'' - the spurt of growth from the late 1960's to the late 1970's - became the economist's model of the way to manage expansion from agrarian stagnation to the newly industrialized stage. **********Now, however, Brazil is in its third year of recession, and the country that once was the world banking system's ideal borrower pleads for loans just to pay the interest on its debts. **********How Brazil fell to a position where it is known best today for the weight of its $92 billion foreign debt, larger than that of any other country, is a matter that absorbs all those who have a stake in the country - Brazilians themselves and the industrial world, which relies for much of its own prosperity on the health of developing countries such as Brazil. **********Leading Brazilians both inside and outside the Government cite the effects of the sharp rise in oil prices during the 1970's on an economy that had been building its future on imported oil. They blame Western banks for heaping an insupportable burden of loans on the country. And they blame the United States for incurring budget deficits of $200 billion a year that have forced up world interest rates and hence affected the ability of Brazil to make interest payments. **********Ultimately, however, they blame Brazil's technocrats, the people who took the bankers' money. **********The technocrats were the planners, economists, engineers and technicians whom the military dictatorship, itself reluctant to govern, appointed to run the economy after the generals seized power in 1964. The technocrats are elected by no one, and in time they became accountable to no one, their critics say. **********''They became the owners of the truth,'' said the head of one of Brazil's biggest industrial companies, a man who depends on Government contracts for much of his business and therefore asked not to be named. ''They believed too much in themselves.'' **********Target of Cartoons **********The technocrats get little praise now for their part in the Brazilian ''miracle.'' Ant^onio Delfim Netto, the planning minister and No. 1 technocrat, is an almost daily target of newspaper cartoons. **********''There's a drought in the northeast, and there's flooding in the south,'' one current joke goes, ''so the technocrats decided that, on average, everything is fine.'' **********The technocrats are largely faceless to most Brazilians. They number in the thousands and proliferate in the second and third levels of government, especially in such ministries as finance, agriculture, mining and industry. Many come from the universities. **********Some Leading Technocrats **********They include Finance Minister Ernane Galveas; Celso Affonso Pastore, who is president of the central bank; the heads of some of the country's biggest state-owned companies, and a few retired generals, such as Jose Costa Cavalcanti, president of the second-biggest Government company, the Electrobras utility. **********Some Brazilians say that others share responsibility for the economic reversals. **********''It was the whole regime - the military, the technocrats and the industrialists,'' said Edmar Bacha, an economist at Catholic University in Rio de Janeiro who is now a visiting professor at Columbia University. ''All of them chose not to go for prudent management and opted instead for the crazy policies of Delfim Netto.'' **********'Pharaonic Projects' Cited **********The technocrats' errors, in the view of many Brazilians, involved Pharaonic projects, many of which were conceived to protect Brazil from future oil-price shocks. **********For example, until the current economy forced them to postpone some, the Government-owned power utilities were building enough plants - hydroelectric, nuclear and coal - to produce more power than Brazil is expected to need well beyond the year 2000. **********In addition, a multibillion-dollar railroad, with many costly bridges and tunnels, is being built alongside a railroad that, critics contend, might have been rehabilitated at much lower cost. **********And a huge mineral development project called Carajas, which could make Brazil the world's leading producer of bauxite and aluminum, is under construction. Some businessmen praise Carajas, but others contend it should have waited until some of the other projects had started repaying loans. **********The technocrats are also blamed for Brazil's system of indexation. This program attempts to synchronize the entire economy - wages, prices, interest rates, rents - with inflation. **********Indexation was conceived partly to curb inflation. But as Brazil's foreign trade accounts turned negative, the Government resorted to repeated devaluations of the cruzeiro. **********With the devaluations, the cost of imports rose correspondingly. This raised the cost of living, helping to create more inflation that was fed back into the system of indexation. **********Many in Brazil also accuse the technocrats of creating an industrial dise quilibrium that has made Brazil excessively dependent on imports. **********To reduce the impact of imports, the technocrats sought to build an industry diversified enough to produce all the country's consumer goods. However, their critics charge, imports kept rising because the industries still had to import machinery, components and raw materials. **********Critics also charge the technocrats with creating state-owned companies that became overstaffed and less efficient than privately owned companies. **********The technocrats guided Brazil into important industries - steel, oil, banking, heavy construction, mining and transportation - and then established state-owned companies in those industries. **********State-owned banks now handle half the banking in Brazil. State-owned manufacturing companies account for a third of the revenues of the country's 500 biggest companies, up from 15 percent at the end of the 1960's. **********When the world recession forced layoffs, losses and many bankruptcies on much of the private sector, the protected state companies were largely untouched. **********The technocrats are also accused of favoring middle-income Brazilians. Many in this class, employees of the state or state-owned companies, received special benefits, notably year-end bonuses of one, two or three months' pay. **********The wages of the middle class and the rich rose faster than those of the lowest paid, widening an already broad gap in income distribution. **********Outside Factors Are Blamed **********The technocrats publicly acknowledge few missteps. ''We are a victim of factors in the outside world,'' Mr. Galveas said. The main one at the moment, he said, is the American budget deficit and high interest rates. **********Indeed, few Brazilians would undo much of the work of the technocrats. They have constructed one of the developing world's most sophisticated networks of roads, banking, telecommunications and electric power to service a widely diversified industrial base that could enable Brazil to outperform most other countries in a world upturn. **********And with the power plants, the now widespread use of domestically produced alcohol for automobile fuel and the redoubled development of domestic sources of oil, the technocrats have cut in half the country's dependence on imported oil. **********''You don't want to be too harsh,'' said a senior Western diplomat here of the technocrats. ''They were doing things that had never been done before. But they took some gambles, in energy, mining and internal development, that required great sums of money and long payback periods. A lot of those projects are still soaking up money.'' **********Response to 1979 Oil Shock **********Some prominent Brazilians who see far more gains than losses in the technocrats' programs nevertheless cite one important error - the technocrats' response to the second oil shock of 1979 - for the severity of the country's current economic plight. **********''There were three options then,'' said Roberto Campos, former Ambassador to the United States and Britain and a member of the Government's Social Democratic Party in the Brazilian Senate. **********Brazil might have merely accepted a recession, as the industrial countries did, he said. It might have accepted a reduction of growth, as did developing Asian countries, among them Taiwan and South Korea. ''This was the prudent option,'' Mr. Campos commented. Instead, he said, Brazil, like Mexico and Venezuela, sought to suppress imports and attempted, less aggressively, to promote exports. **********'Should Have Reversed Gears' **********''Brazil,'' he added, ''financed its adjustment rather than adjusted. This was not irrational at the time. You could still get good interest rates. Our mistake was in adhering to that option when it became apparent that it was incorrect. We should have reversed gears.'' **********Even within the Government the technocrats are now under fire. One of the few popular ministers, Helio Beltrao, resigned in November. The Minister for Social Welfare and the man in charge of ''debureaucratization,'' a successful program to reduce paperwork required of the nation's citizens, Mr. Beltrao cited cuts in his welfare budget for his resignation. **********In public comments a few weeks earlier, Mr. Beltrao described the technocrats as men with a ''vision of an imaginary country not at all our own.'' He said they had been ''dominated by the fascinating exercise of abstract planning, by the optical illusion of centralized decisions and macroeconomic theories, by the rapture of important and sophisticated decisions, incompatible with our reality and the reality of our modest standards and the incomes of our people.'' **********Dispute on People's Needs **********The technocrats are also charged with ignoring the needs of the population in the drive to industrialize Brazil. **********''They were trying to imitate the development of the advanced world and failed at improving the life of the people, said Celso Pe,canha, the leader of the small Labor Party in the House of Deputies and former governor of the state of Rio de Janeiro. **********''The straight road to development is the education of the people,'' Mr. Pe,canha said. ''Today we have 7.5 million children, 7 to 14, who don't go to school because they have to work so they can have enough to eat. Eighteen million Brazilians are illiterate - 25.5 percent of the population. This is the central problem of Brazil.'' **********Moving Toward Democracy **********Brazilians now believe they can see the demise of the all-powerful technocrat in President Joao Baptista Figueiredo's commitment to ''abertura,'' the process of restoring democratic government. **********The economic crisis has accelerated the process. To placate the International Monetary Fund and Western commercial banks, the technocrats imposed three anti-inflation plans to restrict the rate of wage increases. The Government had to withdraw them, however, in the face of widespread opposition from a newly vocal Congress that was popularly elected last year in one of the important steps along the route toward abertura. **********Finally, in October, the Government, the technocrats and the leaders of Congress negotiated a plan that the legislators would accept. **********And with the recent acceptance by the I.M.F. of Brazil's new austerity program, the country can expect to get more than $11 billion in fresh loans. That aid, plus signs that the incipient recovery of the world economy is spreading, would seem to assure some relief for Brazil. **********But businessmen and economists here question whether the economy built by the technocrats has the strength to deal with the fundamental imbalances. **********''Brazil accepts adversity as long as it sees a solution,'' said Peter Landsberg, former chairman of the country's biggest private company, Shell Brazil, the Shell oil subsidiary in Brazil. ''But we see no solution.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/world.main_headline: CENTRAL AMERICAN NATIONS REFUSE TO JOIN U.S. BOYCOTT OF NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/world.print_headline: CENTRAL AMERICAN NATIONS REFUSE TO JOIN U.S. BOYCOTT OF NICARAGUA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/26/world.body_text: **********Four Central American nations, despite their hostility toward Nicaragua, have refused to join the Reagan Administration's informal economic boycott of the Sandinista Government, officials in the region say. **********Central America, including Nicaragua, is facing its most serious economic crisis in years and must improve its economic cooperation, the officials said in interviews last week. **********The Reagan Administration, in what it says is part of an effort to keep Managua from supplying arms to rebels in El Salvador, has cut off United States aid and much of United States trade with Nicaragua and blocked Managua's requests for several crucial international loans. **********Washington has also asked the West European donors to Nicaragua to stop their aid to the Sandinistas, diplomats from West Germany and the Netherlands have said in recent interviews. While helping Nicaragua, the Europeans give virtually no aid to Guatemala and El Salvador. **********U.S. Has Not Asked Boycott **********Although the Reagan Administration had not explicitly asked the Central American nations to join a boycott against Nicaragua, the officials said that by stressing the need for regional cooperation, they are effectively telling Washington they cannot afford to support a policy of trying to isolate the Managua regime. **********'We cannot cut Nicaragua off, because it is a matter of our own survival,'' said Carlos Manuel Castillo, President of Costa Rica's Central Bank, ''if Central America is going to pull through, it will be all of us together.'' **********''There are military-run and state- run economies,'' Mr. Castillo added, ''but we need each other, no one can do this alone.'' **********In contrast with the bitter political exchanges among the neighbors, the Finance and Planning Ministers of Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua recently held a series of meetings to talk about how to reactivate their economies and to obtain more international aid.   Keep Economic Ties Separate **********The idea, a Guatemalan economist close to the talks explained, is to try to keep the economic relations ''as normal as possible.'' **********Despite their expressed dislike for Nicaragua's leftist policies, Government officials from El Salvador and Guatemala said their Governments' position was also to keep economic relations separate from politics. **********In a rare gesture, the five nations, including Nicaragua, agreed on a single spokesman and a common position at a meeting to discuss aid with members of the international financial community in Brussels from Sept. 13 to 15. **********The meeting included representatives from the United States, Western Europe and Latin America and from financial institutions like the Inter- American Development Bank and World Bank. **********In an interview last week, Mr. Castillo, the spokesman for the group, said the meeting produced no new aid commitments, but this had not been its immediate purpose. **********''Above all it was meant to show our genuine collective presence, strange as it may be,'' said Mr. Castillo. ''Regional cooperation was always important to us, but it may be even more relevant now.''  Economies Closely Linked **********The economies of Central America have long been closely linked and cater to each others needs. **********But as the fighting and financial crisis worsened, the regional trade dropped from $1.3 billion in l98l to $750 million in l983. The amount of private capital that has fled the region is believed to add up to $4.5 billion over the past four years. **********According to Mr. Castillo, real income in Costa Rica, Guatemala and Honduras has dropped to the level of 1976, but in El Salvador and Nicaragua it has dropped to the level of 20 years ago. **********''We have come to a very dramatic conclusion,'' Mr. Castillo said. ''Central America would need $19 to $23 billion, depending on interest rates, just to recover the income levels of l980 ten years from now. **********''Since by no stretch of the imagination can we count on such foreign aid,'' he added, ''the best we can hope for is a decade of economic standstill.''
