https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/06/busin.body_text: **********The largest United States gasoline marketers have raised wholesale prices by up to 3.3 cents a gallon this week in a trend that is expected to continue until the oil industry recoups its losses from recent price wars. **********The Mobil Corporation lifted its wholesale gasoline price by a half-cent to 3.3 cents a gallon in scattered Middle Western markets and from seven-tenths of a cent to 2 cents on the East Coast. **********Exxon U.S.A. raised its prices by a half-cent to 1 cent in selected United States markets; Texaco Inc. went up 1 cent in St.  Louis and Chicago; the Amoco Oil Company lifted its prices by a halfcent to 2 cents in most of the country, and the Shell Oil Company increased its distributor prices by a half-cent in some Middle Western states.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.main_headline: ANTITRUST CHIEF OFFERS GUIDELINES ON RESEARCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.print_headline: ANTITRUST CHIEF OFFERS GUIDELINES ON RESEARCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/11/busin.body_text: **********William F. Baxter, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, offered business executives specific benchmarks today that should make it easier for them to judge when companies can do joint research without violating the law. **********Mr. Baxter's statement, probably the most explicit ever made on the subject by any Administration, could be another incentive to increased joint research and development efforts by American companies. Many business executives have complained that American antitrust laws have helped undermine the nation's ability to compete successfully against Japan and other foreign countries. **********Leaving Room for Competitors **********Mr. Baxter, while inclined to belittle this contention, nonetheless described in detail the circumstances under which it would be unlikely that joint ventures would be challenged. **********In general, he declared, such collaborations are likely to be permissible when the participants account for no more than half of an industry and when their joint efforts would still leave room for four to six competing ventures in the field. **********''That should be regarded as per se O.K.,'' Mr. Baxter, Assistant Attorney General for the antitrust division, told a meeting sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers. **********It is often argued, Mr. Baxter observed, that joint ventures pose a danger of exclusivity because some company that would like to participate is left out. But the real problem - if there is one - is not whether such ventures are too exclusive but whether they are too inclusive, he said. If an entire industry were to combine to do research and development, he said, this would amount to repealing the patent system that has been devised to foster competitive innovation. **********Mr. Baxter warned that collaborative research should be done by groups no bigger than is necessary to take maximum advantage of the economies of scale. In doing so he made it clear that measurements of industry participation should not necessarily be confined to American companies but should take into account other producers throughout the world. **********James P. Carty, an antitrust specialist for the manufacturers group, praised Mr. Baxter's formulation as likely to provide some additional ''comfort'' for corporate officials contemplating joint ventures. **********He and other participants in the conference, however, took issue with Mr. Baxter's broader contention that United States antitrust law is a negligible factor in the nation's trade deficit - $19 billion last year - with Japan. **********''A lot of people feel it has a chilling effect,'' Mr. Carty said.  The Administration's legislative proposals on antitrust matters include a provision that makes joint research efforts subject to a so-called rule of reason. This, in effect, means that each case can be examined and argued individually in contrast to per se cases in which certain behavior, such as price-fixing, is illegal on its face. **********Mr. Baxter's package calls on Congress also to abolish treble damages for private antitrust suits in per se cases, limiting recovery to actual damages suffered. **********Products are protected much better than processes, he noted, prompting another element of the Administration bill to extend the patent on a process to the product that results from it. Under present law, foreign companies are able to obtain a patented process, develop a product from it and then sell the product in this country with impunity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/world.main_headline: WHITE SENATOR IS SLAIN BY ATTACKERS IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/world.print_headline: WHITE SENATOR IS SLAIN BY ATTACKERS IN ZIMBABWE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/05/world.body_text: **********A white Zimbabwean senator, his daughter and a British citizen who was visiting them were slain by 20 to 30 assailants who attacked their farm in Matabeland Province Sunday night, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman identified the attackers as anti-Government rebels. **********The legislator's wife was seriously wounded in the attack, the spokesman said.  The senator, Paul Savage, 60 years old, his daughter Colleen, 20, and a friend from Britain died instantly in a hail of gunfire, according to the spokesman. The visitor's name was withheld until next-of-kin are informed, but it was believed she was a young woman. **********The ranch is about 80 miles south of Bulawayo, the provincial capital. A white farmer, his wife and two teen-age granddaughters were killed by rebels 95 miles west of Bulawayo two weeks ago. At Least 130 Killings Reported **********Government officials have said that at least 130 people, including more than 30 whites, mostly farmers and miners, have been killed by rebels in Matabeleland in the last year. **********The Government has blamed the Zimbabwe African Peoples Union, the opposition party led by Joshua Nkomo, for the trouble. The party, which is based in Matabeleland, has denied the charges, saying it does not know who the dissidents are. **********The Government sent troops into Matabeleland three months ago to crush the rebels. Zimbabwean church leadrs have accused the troops of killing and maiming hundreds of innocent people. **********But the Minister of Supplies, Enos Nkala, declared at political meetings in Matabeleland over the weekend that the atrocities had been carried out by dissidents. Ranch Workers Ordered to Leave **********Senator Savage was a member of former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's Republican Front Party.  The attackers first ordered all the workers on the Savage farm into the hills, the spokesman said, then surrounded the home, where the Savages and the visitor were having a barbecue, ''and ordered them to raise their hands.'' When their hands were up, the rebels opened fire, he said. **********After the massacre, the rebels ransacked the Savage house and stole a large amount of property, the spokesman said.  He said it was thought that one of the attackers had been killed accidentally during the shooting and had been buried in a shallow grave nearby by his companions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/world.main_headline: A Soviet Military Attache Is Expelled by Norway
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; A Soviet Military Attache Is Expelled by Norway
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/23/world.body_text: **********Norway expelled the assistant military attache at the Soviet Embassy in Oslo today on charges of military espionage. **********The Foreign Ministry said the attache, Lieut. Col. V.F. Zagrebnev, had been declared persona non grata and ordered out of the country.  He was given a few days to leave, officials said. **********No details of the spying charges were disclosed.  Since l970, Norway has expelled 15 Soviet citizens for espionage.  Colonel Zagrebnev was the latest of more than 50 Soviet diplomats expelled by Western nations or countries friendly to the West this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Angolan Rebels Report Capture of 17 Europeans
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.body_text: **********Pro- Western rebels in Angola said today that they captured 5 British and 12 Portuguese citizens in attacks on Government positions in eastern Angola on Sunday. **********A communique from the rebel group, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, said the 17 had been seized in raids on Kazombo and Kavungu and on a bridge over the Zambezi River in the Moxico Province. **********A rebel spokesman said he believed the foreigners were technicians working on development projects. **********The rebels reported other attacks on Government positions and Cuban military convoys as part of an offensive begun on Nov. 2. The objective of the offensive, expected to last six months, is to take control of Lunda Province and to penetrate Luanda Province.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/18/busin.main_headline: Stocks Edge Down As Trading Slows; Dow Up 0.97, To 1,116.97
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/18/busin.print_headline: Stocks Edge Down As Trading Slows; Dow Up 0.97, To 1,116.97
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices dropped moderately yesterday as growing concern over the outlook for oil prices and profit taking weakened the list in slower trading. **********In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that advanced by 911 to 672. Stocks responding to specific news developments posted the largest price changes. **********However, the Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 leading companies, managed to close up 0.97 point, to 1,116.97, after being in the minus column for most of the session. **********The two other major market indexes, which are much more broadly based than the Dow average, ended lower. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks lost 0.21, to 86.22, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 0.21, to 149.59. **********Turnover on the Big Board slumped to 70.3 million shares from 83.6 million on Wednesday as institutional participation dropped. Concern About OPEC **********Analysts said that investors were fearful that the pricing and production agreement reached on Monday by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would not hold and that oil prices would decline further. **********Among the weaker energy issues yesterday, Ashland Oil, which projected a loss for its second quarter ended March 31, tumbled 1 7/8 points, to 29; Atlantic Richfield, the volume leader, dropped 1 3/8, to 38; Phillips Petroleum slipped 1 7/8, to 30 3/4, and Standard of Indiana fell 3/4, to 39 3/4. **********''The weakness in the market today also reflected moves by many investors in cashing in their recent profits,'' said Wayne Nordberg, chairman of the investment policy committee of Prescott, Ball & Turben. The Dow has soared about 340 points since mid-August. **********Mr. Nordberg said the continuing stream of disappointing corporate earnings reports also helped to depress stock prices yesterday.  Cooper Laboratories advanced 2 3/4, to 74, after its board voted a 2-for-1 stock split and recommended a dividend increase. The directors said they would consider an initial public offering of a minority interest in its Cooper Biomedical Inc. unit in late May. **********Flow General lost 1 1/4, to 12 3/4, after disclosing that it did not expect to make a profit for the March quarter. The company had losses in each of its last three quarters. Parker Pen Down **********Parker Pen, which had forecast a loss for its fourth quarter and for the year ended Feb. 28, was down 1 1/8, to 15 3/4. **********Most of the technology issues ended with minor price changes. Among the exceptions were Texas Instruments, which added 1 3/4, to 162 3/4, and the NCR Corporation, which gained 1 1/4, to 106 3/4. **********PPG Industries advanced 1 point, to 61, following its announcement that it would have substantially higher sales and profits for its first quarter. **********Federal Express rose 7/8, to 79 7/8, buoyed by its announcement that it handled 31 percent more packages last month than in the period last year. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dropped 2.53, to 379.11. Frequency Electronics was down 4, to 36 1/4, on the news that its net for the third quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to 26 cents a share from 34 cents a share the year before. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index eased 0.65, to 264.01.  news that its net for the third quarter ended Jan. 31 fell to 26

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/21/busin.body_text: **********Despite mildly optimistic forecasts from Government officials and central bankers in Frankfurt, West German business investment is locked in a holding pattern that economists and bankers say could retard early economic recovery. **********Bankers and economists suggested in interviews that the sluggish spending reflects partly a wait-and-see attitude preceding Germany's March 6 Federal elections, and partly a conviction that the worldwide recession and continuing high real interest rates tarnish prospects of a return on real assets. **********''Bonds are yielding 8 percent, on the Euromarket even more, while inflation is headed toward 3 percent,'' said Dieter Wermuth, chief economist at Citibank, in Frankfurt. ''You never had a recession ending with those rates.'' **********Investment Growth in '84 **********A study prepared by Mietfinanz, one of Germany's largest capital goods leasing concerns, released in January, said capital goods investment in the 13 major industrial sectors would likely shrink 6.7 percent this year. A major reason for the shrinkage, the study said, was political uncertainty. Because of the long lead time for capital goods investments, it said, investment growth could not be expected before 1984. **********The March 6 election pits the present coalition Government of conservative Christian Democrats and Free Democrats against the Social Democrats, traditional proponents of deficit spending to finance generous welfare programs. Also opposing the conservative Government are the Greens, a coalition of environmentalists, pacifists and opponents of nuclear power, whose platform contains a no-growth economic plank that unsettles German businessmen. **********The flagging investment rate led to a recent bitter exchange of charges by the Christian Democrats, who attributed it to fear of electoral gains by the Social Democrats and Greens, and denials by their opponents. **********The investment lag remains a disturbing trend on an otherwise brighter economic horizon. For 1982, the current account surplus was equivalent to $578.5 million, ending a string of deficits beginning in 1979, when exports failed to offset a skyrocketing oil bill.  Consumer prices rose only 3.9 percent, after 5.9 percent in 1981, enabling bank interest rates to decline dramatically. Businessmen Doubtful **********''Businessmen just have to know who will be running the country the next four years,'' said Peter von Elten, a vice president at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in Frankfurt. ''They need clear directions.'' **********Bankers note, however, a growing hesitancy among businessmen toward both major parties, because of overriding policy similarities and because of recent Christian Democratic policy shifts that seem to reflect uncertainty on economic policy. **********The coalition Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, which took office last October, embarked on a policy of budget austerity, coupled with efforts to shift Government budgeting from consumptive spending, like welfare, to ''investive spending'' aimed at rebuilding the nation's industrial base. **********Finance Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg, chief architect of Government policy, has listed as its major elements a $1.04 billion, two-year housing program; public works projects, including construction of power plants and a nationwide cable communications network; and corporate tax relief, to favor business investment, to be paid for by a repayable loan, or tax, to the Government by high-income groups. **********''We have waited a long time for this kind of fundamental reorientation,'' Otto Wolff von Amerongen, head of the Chamber of Industry and Commerce, exulted as he commented on Government policy at the group's annual meeting recently. **********Nevertheless, the business community was unsettled in January by the announcement that the Christian Democrats, if re-elected, planned to convert the repayable loan to a direct tax. Some bankers also questioned the Government's economic priorities. **********Economists at Frankfurt's Dresdner Bank said the decision to emphasize housing starts was wise from a political standpoint, because of the immediate multiplier effect in creation of jobs and purchases of construction equipment and building materials. **********But they said housing was essentially a consumer product, so the program failed to carry out the Government's promised shift from consumptive to capital goods investment. Moreover, they said, doubts remain among experts whether Germany has a real housing need. Optimistic Note **********There were also doubts about the extent that fiscal policy alone could alleviate the investment slump. ''Because of public sector deficits, fiscal policy is dead,'' said Mr. Wermuth of Citibank.  ''When tax receipts were ample, we didn't get rid of deficits, especially by cutting claims on gross national product.'' **********One spark of optimism among bankers was the prospect of declining oil prices, which they said would bolster the payments situation of countries that are traditional purchasers of Germany's export goods. **********Flagging export orders, crucial to Germany's economy, which depends on exports for nearly one-third of the gross national product, have deepened the current recession. **********But the bankers cautioned that export growth as a result of lower oil bills in nonoil exporting countries would not come immediately, meaning there would be little real effect before 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/08/busin.body_text: **********For at least three well-known off- price clothing merchandisers, the time was right for taking their family-owned businesses public over the last six months. But that window on Wall Street may be closing, analysts say, as the retailing industry moves into a recovery. **********Last May the 66-unit Dress Barn went public, raising $17 million for the Jaffe family. In June, the 31-unit Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corporation went public, rising $66 million for the Milstein family. And a month ago, in a leap from garment district obscurity to publicly owned company, Sy Syms Merns sold about three million newly issued shares of stock in the Syms Corporation, making himself about $44 million. **********It is not merely a coincidence that Syms and other family companies chose this particular time to cash in. According to the National Retailing Merchants Association, the off-price business is ''hurtling toward maturity at a record pace.'' **********Fastest Growing Segment **********Already accounting for about 6 percent of the clothing sold in the United States, it is growing faster than any other segment of the retailing business, according to Walter Loeb, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. Over the next five years, he estimates, the industry will grow by about 15 percent a year. By the end of the decade, off- price merchandising is expected to triple, to $20 billion. **********Syms, with an estimated $185 million in sales for 1983, is a mid-sized off-price company. One of the largest, the 75-store Marshalls chain, which is owned by the Melville Corporation, has 1983 estimated sales, for example, of $1.1 billion. Other giants are Mervyn's, a division of the Dayton- Hudson Corporation, with 83 off-price stores, and the Zayre Corporation's two off-price chains, T. J. Maxx and Hit or Miss. Scores of new off-price retailers - some of them extensions of the garment manufacturers - have also gotten into the business. **********Other Retailers Join Trend **********In addition, regular retailers are beginning to join the low-price trend for competitive reasons. According to Stanley Marcus, a marketing consultant and chairman emeritius of the stylishly high-priced Neiman-Marcus department stores, ''customers will not buy in stores that make fools of them by selling the same articles for $50 or $60 more.'' **********Mr. Merns, who is known as Mr. Syms, knew this simple truth about consumers in 1959 when he opened his first Syms discount store in New York City. Some of the merchandise in his ''no frills'' stores are irregulars and seconds. But some of it is the same merchandise that found in department stores, only cheaper. **********Price brings in the customers. And using this premise, Syms - a name that comes from the combination of Sy Merns' first name and the first and last letters of his surname - has built an 11-apparel store chain with net income of $7.5 million on sales of $147.2 million in 1982. With stores from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Peabody, Mass., Syms plans to open three more by the end of 1984. **********Volume Is Essence of Business **********The essence of the off-price business is volume, but its health depends on supply. Some manufacturers still call ''off-price'' retailers undertakers, because of their relationship with manufacturers. When the economy slips into a recession, manufacturers look to off-price retailers to keep their factories running. **********Manufacturers routinely work ahead by 18 months. If such a manufacturer has over-ordered fabric and then the orders do not come in, he may be faced with the problem of too much fabric. He can sell it to a jobber for 20 percent of its cost. Or, he can sell it to an off-price discounter for the full price. **********The condition of such a sale usually involves the manufacturer making goods at cost for the off-price retailer. This keeps the factory open and the employees working. The off-price merchandiser, as a consequence, gets his goods at a much lower price than if he had made an order in advance. **********Move Toward Diversification **********Sy Syms, who has worked with manufacturers for 20 years, is counting on their loyality during the current retailing upturn. But the 57-year- old executive is also hedging his bets, should the popularity of off-price merchandising fade. **********In 1980, Mr. Syms bought A. Sulka & Company, a 90-year-old London haberdashery, which sells $2,500 silk- lined cashmere dressing gowns and other luxury clothing. This high-margin, high-overhead business contrasts sharply to the Syms image, but provides the company an escape route. These are not businesses that will merge, the company said. **********For the owners of Dress Barn, Burling Coat Factory and Syms, the overriding advantage of taking their companies public was that it meant no change in company control. Company president, Elliott S. Jaffe, and his family retained 47.5 percent of the Dress Barn. Monroe G. Milstein and his family still own 65.22 percent of the Burlington Coat Factory. And, Mr. Syms kept 82.3 percent of his company and most of the money from the public sale of stock. **********Stock Prices Are Flat **********In each case, movements in the prices of the stock have been relatively flat. The Dress Barn opened at $23 a share on the over-the-counter market in May, and its bid price yesterday was the same. Burlington Coat opened in June at $28 a share, went as high as $41, and reached its low of $26 yesterday on the over-the-counter market. And in Syms' short trading history, its stock has fluctuated between a high of 17 7/8 and a low of 15 1/4, closing yesterday at 15 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Such stock offerings are common among entrepreneural companies in which the founders or their families want to raise money without losing corporate control. The owners sell only a portion of the stock they own to the public. Sometimes the money goes toward expansion; in other cases, when the founder sells his own holdings, the proceeds go to him. **********In the Syms Corporation offering, the $44 million in proceeds went to Mr. Syms, who still owns 56.9 percent of the shares outright and controls another 25.1 percent as the sole voting trustee of a trust established for his branch of the Merns family.  Mr. Syms runs his operation almost single-handedly. Last year he paid himself $575,000 as chairman and chief executive officer, $226,619 as head of the Syms Advertising Agency and the corporate Mr. Syms paid the private Mr. Syms $645,259 for a store lease. **********Total Control of Board **********Even though the company is public, Mr. Syms is able to personally elect all of the directors of the company and to approve all corporate transactions without minority shareholder approval. **********The Syms Corporation, which was incorporated in New Jersey on July 11, 1983, has three subsidiaries: the off-price chains called Syms Inc., five high-priced A. Sulka & Company stores and Syms Advertising. The advertising company, which produces ads written by Mr. Syms featuring the executive, his daughter Marcy and his son Robert. The Syms slogan is: ''An educated consumer is our best customer.'' **********Four of Mr. Syms' six children work for the company. Three of his sons are vice presidents and his 32- year-old daughter, Marcy Syms Merns, is the $45,000-a-year president. **********Mr. Syms has an older brother named George Merns, who has a chain of conventional discount clothing stores under the Merns name. Mr. Syms joined his brother in the 1950's, but broke away in 1959 to start his own stores under the Syms name. George Merns has no corporate involvement in Syms. **********Because the company is required by the Securities and Exchange Commission to refrain from public comment for 90-days following the offering, none of the Merns family could grant interviews.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/24/busin.body_text: **********Venezuela's Finance Minister, Arturo Sosa, said today that he would apply for loans from the International Monetary Fund next week to help his country's debtburdened economy. Speaking to reporters after a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mr. Sosa said, ''Using the fund has always been part of the plan.'' **********Mr. Sosa said his country's ability to make payments on $13 billion of foreign debt this year was hampered by the decline of oil prices. Venezuela is a major oil exporter. **********In another development, the executive board of the I.M.F. has decided to let Mexico have $325 million as a second disbursement, monetary sources said. The I.M.F. approved a $3.7 billion loan for Mexico in December and dispensed about $100 million of it at that time. **********The I.M.F. has also agreed to lend Zambia $104.8 million to help it counter a shortfall in export earnings.  Meanwhile, the World Bank announced a $11 million loan for a technical assistance project in Congo.  In addition, the World Bank and the International Development Association approved a $250.7 million loan and a $147 million credit for India. **********The World Bank also approved a $45 million agricultural loan to Honduras.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.main_headline: BRITISH PRINTERS ARE ORDERED TO CALL OFF STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.print_headline: BRITISH PRINTERS ARE ORDERED TO CALL OFF STRIKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/13/world.body_text: **********A judge ordered the country's largest printers' union today to call off a nationwide 24-hour strike that the union had set for Wednesday. **********The judge, Philip Otton, handed down the order in response to a request from seven London-based national newspapers and a regional newspaper company. **********The 132,000-member National Graphical Association responded with a plea to other unions for full backing of its strike call. **********The printers' union secretary, Joe Wade, requested support from the 11 million-member Trades Union Congress, the British equivalent of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which was meeting tonight to discuss the request.   6 Printers Were Dismissed **********The printers' union hopes a national walkout will compel Selim Shah, the owner of a small company that prints local giveaway newspapers in Lancashire, to take back six union members he dismissed after they struck to enforce a closed-shop agreement. **********On Sunday, after his national council decided to call the strike, Mr. Wade said it was the only way his members could show their ''outrage'' at what he described as Mr. Shah's efforts to destroy his union. **********Britain's Employment Secretary, Tom King, said he would not intervene in the dispute, but urged the union to call off its action. **********Mr. King said in the House of Commons that a strike would do nothing to resolve the union's dispute with Mr. Shah, who is not a member of the Newspaper Proprietors' Association. The Cabinet minister said a strike would imperil the existence of some newspapers and throw many printers out of work. **********The union has been fined $973,000 for illegal picketing of Mr. Shah's Stockport Messenger company at Warrington, and its $15.8 million in assets were frozen by the courts to insure payment. **********The union also faces damage claims of $4.3 million from the proprietors' association for losses incurred when the union shut down most nationally circulated newspapers for two days last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/world.main_headline: PORTUGUESE CRISIS STALLS TALKS ON U.S. BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/world.print_headline: PORTUGUESE CRISIS STALLS TALKS ON U.S. BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/30/world.body_text: **********Portugal's Government crisis has stalled negotiations with the United States on the status of a strategic air base in the Azores and on an American request for its first military installations on the Portuguese mainland. **********The four-year lease of the Lajes Air Base in the Azores, regarded by American military experts as an important refueling stop for planes sent to Europe, the Middle East and Africa, expires Feb 4. If, as seems likely, a renewal agreement is not ready then, an extension of one year can take effect. **********With a caretaker Government in charge, negotiations for mainland installations are more problematic. According to official Portuguese sources, Washington has asked permission to build a satellitetracking station and to use several bases on the mainland in exchange for more military aid. **********Under the current agreement the United States gave Portugal $60 million in military aid. In a related agreement it has also given $80 million in economic aid in the last four years to the Azores, a mid-Atlantic archipelago first used for bases by the British in World War II. President Reagan is seeking to increase military aid to Portugal to $90 million this fiscal year, a 50 percent increase. Crisis Has Wide Effects **********Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao's resignation in December, because of fighting in his rightist parliamentary coalition, plunged the country into political uncertainty. President Antonio Ramalho Eanes has called an early general election and has asked the caretaker Government to remain long enough to pass urgently needed legislation. Mr. Balsemao agreed to remain in office temporarily but has questioned whether a caretaker administration can pass major bills, including an austerity budget. **********In addition to leaving ministries without operating money, the crisis has stopped progress on several important issues, including talks on Portugal's entry into the European Common Market and on a loan from the International Monetary Fund. **********The military agreement with the United States, which started in 1951 and was renewed four times, is a major source of military and economic aid. Formal negotiations for renewal began in Lisbon on Dec. 6, but a subsequent session set for Jan. 10 did not take place because of the political situation. **********Complicating the negotiations, from the American standpoint, is the Portuguese insistence on reaching agreement first on the Azores base and then dealing with the other requests. **********''The items are separable,'' Mr. Balsemao said in an interview.  ''We have an agreement concerning the Azores. We are ready to negotiate a new agreement. That's one item. Another is eventual requests by the U.S. for facilities outside the Azores. Our position is they have to be considered separately.'' What Portugal Wants **********In return for granting the other requests, he said, his Government wants help re-equipping the armed forces and a comprehensive labor agreement for people working in the bases. The American negotiators are expected to argue that the Administration has a better chance of persuading Congress to go along with a package agreement covering both the Azores and the mainland installations. **********The situation with regard to United States access to bases in Spain appears to be a major factor in the Portuguese negotiations, with Washington searching for possible alternatives now that a Socialist Government has taken over in Madrid. **********A new five-year agreement that gives the United States the right to station 12,000 military personnel at four bases in Spain was signed in July 1982 by the previous Government but has not been ratified by the Spanish Parliament. The Socialist Government has indicated a willingness to follow through on it provided some modifications are made. Most of them refer to provisions in the draft agreement tied to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The new Government has frozen Spain's integration into the military structure of NATO while it examines the question of whether or not to join the alliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/busin.body_text: **********With yields for Treasury notes and bonds near their highest levels of the year, investors shunned the credit markets yesterday as they awaited testimony by Paul A. Volcker that might shed light on the direction of interest rates. **********In advance of Mr. Volcker's testimony this week before the Senate Banking Committee, which will hold hearings on his reappointment as the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, interest rates barely moved in light trading of government securities. **********Traders and investors also said they were awaiting indications later this week of any decisions on monetary policy taken at today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, a Federal Reserve panel that sets monetary policy. 8 1/2 Percent Since December **********Although much of the discussion in the financial markets has focused on the likelihood of an increase in the discount rate that the Fed charges on loans to banks, many Fed watchers warned that it could decide to raise short-term rates without increasing the discount rate from the 8 1/2 percent level at which it has remained since last December. **********''The public is afflicted with discount rate phobia,'' said George Hester, a vice president in the government securities division at Paine Webber Inc. Even if rates for overnight bank loans continue to fluctuate around 9 1/4 percent, Mr. Hester added, ''that does not mean that the Fed has to raise the discount rate'' to that level. **********Concern over the discount rate was underscored last Thursday when Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, publicly urged that the Fed not change the rate. Changes in the discount rate are often considered a signal of Fed policy. Unsure on Credit and Rate **********By using moral suasion to prevent commercial banks from borrowing at the Fed's discount window, many analysts said the central bank could raise short-term interest rates, but leave the discount rate unchanged. Currently, analysts are uncertain if the Fed will make credit scarce enough to cause short-term rates to rise further, and are even more unsure about the future of the discount rate. **********In yesterday's trading, overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market were at 9 1/8 percent most of the day, down slightly from the 9.39 percent average for the week ended July 6, but well above the level of 8 1/2 percent to 8 3/4 percent that prevailed for most of the first half of the year. **********Among short-term securities, the average rates for Treasury bills at yesterday's auction were little changed from last week's sales.  The three-month issue averaged 9.07 percent, down from 9.10 percent last week, while the six-month issue averaged 9.26 percent, up from 9.2 percent. The six-month rate was the highest since Sept. 20. **********Based on the auction results, the maximum rate for six-month savings certificates offered by banks and thrift institutions rises to 9.51 percent from 9.45 percent. The maximum rate for three-month certificates is the same as the average of the three-month bill issue. Doubt on Announcement **********In advance of Mr. Volcker's upcoming appearances, many analysts doubted that the Fed would announce an increase in the discount rate. ''When rates are going up, you expect the Fed to be more reluctant to take prominent actions such as raising the discount rate,'' one trader said. ''It's just the opposite of last year, when the Fed was cutting the discount rate and wanted to call attention to the fact that rates were coming down.'' **********If the highly visible discount rate is to be increased soon, analysts estimated it would likely happen after Mr. Volcker's Congressional appearances, but before the Treasury announces on July 27 a huge $15.75 billion financing that may include a record $4 billion of 30-year bonds. **********Many economists said that low inflation might still point to lower bond yields later this year or next. However, Edward J. Sawicz, an economist at the Discount Corporation of New York, commented that, in the immediate future, the prospects for increased short-term rates are hurting the bond market. ''Even if the Fed raises short-term rates, some investors will wonder if the increases are enough'' to slow money supply growth and prevent inflation from rising in future months, he said. Near Year's Lowest Levels **********Among Treasury note and bond issues outstanding, prices declined by an eighth of a point or less, and remained close to their lowest levels of the year. The 10 1/2 percent notes due in 1987 were offered at 98 18/32, to yield 10.96, compared with the average price of about 99 5/8, to yield 10.62 percent, at an auction in late June. In the long-term bond market, the 10 3/8 percent issue due in 2012 was offered at 92 1/8, to yield 11.3 percent. The high price for the 10 3/8 percent bond was in early May when it was at 101, to yield 10.26 percent. **********In the tax-exempt market, dealers said that prices were firm in light trading yesterday. Among this week's major financings, a $89 million issue of Aa-rated Minnesota general obligation bonds was postponed to Wednesday from today. Investment bankers estimated that Minnesota bonds due in 2003 would be sold with a yield of about 9 1/4 percent under current market conditions. **********''The supply of new issues is extremely light, and it looks like it is going to stay that way for the next two to three weeks; unfortunately, demand is almost equally as light as the supply,'' said S.E. Canaday Jr., a vice president at John Nuveen & Company, a municipal bond firm. Dearth of Electric Bonds **********One reason for the light supply in the tax-exempt market has been the dearth of electric revenue bonds in the wake of the problems experienced by the Washington Public Power Supply System. Since the Washington State Supreme Court held a month ago that the system's contracts were invalid, there have been no major borrowings by agencies whose bonds are backed by their sales of electricity to municipalities. **********There has been a flurry of financing by housing agencies to fill the void left by the electric revenue bonds, with many recent issues selling well with a yield of about 10 percent for bonds due in 25 to 30 years. **********Following are the results of yesterday's auctions of new threemonth and six-month Treasury bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures) 3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/world.main_headline: SHAMIR SAYS U.S. ACCORD WILL AID LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/world.print_headline: SHAMIR SAYS U.S. ACCORD WILL AID LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the newly strengthened strategic cooperation between Israel and the United States ''can go a long way'' toward restoring Lebanese independence and persuading Syria to give up hopes of dominating Lebanon. **********In a speech to the National Press Club at the end of his three-day visit here, the Israeli leader echoed previous comments by President Reagan, calling Lebanon ''a test case.'' **********''It is a challenge to the free world and to its resolve and capacity to meet aggression and subversion with firmness and determination,'' he said. **********Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who accompanied Mr. Shamir here, said this morning that the major impact of the agreement by Israel and the United States to set up a committee to develop military planning and other activities was that ''we have reached the point where U.S. and Israeli policy in Lebanon will be coordinated.'' **********When asked if there might be joint United States-Israeli action against Syria, Mr. Arens refused to rule anything out. ''If there will be a military challenge, I guess all possibilities are open.'' **********''If there were to to be a military challenge from the Syrians, then we would have to sit down'' and discuss it with the Americans, he said.  Senior Israeli and American officials were virtually unanimous today in declaring that a central reason for the new moves was to bolster the Government of President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon and to press the Syrians to agree eventually to join Israel in withdrawing troops from Lebanon. **********A senior State Department official said that as a result of the talks, American officials were now satisfied that the Israelis had come out of a period of retrenchment and self-imposed isolation that had led them to withdraw some of their troops from Lebanon in September against the advice of the United States and Lebanon. **********Mr. Gemayel arrived in Washington tonight for talks with President Reagan on Thursday to discuss the deadlocked situation in Lebanon and look for ways to hasten troop withdrawals. **********In advance of his arrival, Israeli and American officials stressed that they had no intention of altering the terms of the May 17 Israeli-Lebanese agreement by which Israeli troops would leave at the same time as Syrian forces. The Syrians have called for the abrogation of the accord. **********The announced steps for closer military relations between Israel and the United States drew criticism from Arab spokesmen. **********Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Arabian envoy, met with President Reagan this morning to deliver a letter from King Fahd, and later told reporters, ''We strongly believe that Israel is a strategic liability to America, not an asset, and their behavior in the past has not improved by good-will gestures from this country.'' **********The Saudis want the United States to persuade the Israelis to set a timetable for withdrawal from Lebanon, thereby, in the Saudi view, making it easier for the Syrians to pull out.  Clovis Maksoud, the Arab League representative here, said that although Arabs ''have always been able to live with a U.S. tilt towards Israel,'' the formation of ''a U.S.-Israeli strategic axis in the wake of Mr. Shamir's visit is such a qualitative change that will jolt the Arabs into a painful reassessment of Arab-U.S. relations, a definite lowering of expectations and a confirmed perception that the U.S. can no longer be a mediator or a broker.'' **********Syrian Comment on Accord **********DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 30 (UPI) - Syria said today that President Reagan's pledges of military and economic cooperation with Israel were aimed at allowing Israel to wage war. **********''The purpose behind this agreement is to strengthen Israel and to make it the sole military power in the region in order to maintain a constant state of war and carry on frequent aggression against the Arabs,'' a broadcast on the official Damascus radio said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.main_headline: COMMODITIES Iranian Threat Lifts Oil; Grain and Soybeans Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES Iranian Threat Lifts Oil; Grain and Soybeans Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/11/busin.body_text: **********Fears that renewed tension between Iran and Iraq could interrupt the supply of a significant portion of the world's petroleum prompted a rally in the prices of oil futures yesterday. **********Prices jumped following reports of the sale of five French jet fighters to Iraq, said Lois Peltz, a heating oil analyst in New York with Merrill Lynch Commodities Inc. She noted that Iran had threatened to interrupt the flow of oil through the Persian Gulf, from which about 17 percent of the world's petroleum is supplied, in response to the reported sale of the jets. **********Grain and soybean futures closed mostly lower despite a late rally on the Chicago Board of Trade. **********Harvest and Farmers' Sales **********Victor Lespinasse, a grain analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that the early selling was encouraged by progress made in the harvest over the weekend and by reports of increased sales by farmers on cash markets. In addition, he said, the late slide in prices Friday encouraged selling by traders who watch trends on price charts. **********Soybean prices led the late rally.  Dale Gustafson, a grain analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., noted that the late buying was set off by speculation that rain forecast for midweek would delay the harvest. **********Cattle prices were mixed and live hogs and frozen pork bellies were lower in active trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Hogs and bellies were under pressure because of a very heavy slaughter, said Chuck Levitt, a livestock analyst in Chicago with Shearson/American Express. **********Precious metals were steady in quiet trading on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Prices fell slightly in early trading, then stabilized and recovered late in the session to close with slight gains. **********The late rally was supported by the renewed Iran-Iraq tension and by the weakness of the dollar against major foreign currencies, said Bill O'Neill, a metals analyst in New York with Rudolph Wolff Commodities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/12/world.body_text: **********The Salvadoran Defense Minister said today that the Government battle death toll more than doubled in the last year of fighting against leftist guerrillas. **********The Minister, Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova, said guerrillas killed 2,292 soldiers and officials between July 1, 1982, and June 30 of this year, compared with 1,073 deaths reported for the same period in the previous year. **********He said 6,487 Government soldiers were killed or wounded in that period and 328 soldiers and officers were missing in action. Those combined figures nearly doubled the 3,801 soldiers killed, wounded or missing in the earlier period. **********Meanwhile, the Provisional President, Alvaro Magana, visited the United States carrier Ranger and witnessed a powerful display of aerial might as the 80,000-ton flagship cruised off the Pacific coast of Nicaragua. **********Mr. Magana told reporters aboard the Ranger, ''After looking at that exhibition, I'm very glad these officers are on my side.'' **********He witnessed 28 takeoffs of F-14 Tomcat fighter planes, Vikings, Intruders, Hawkeyes, Corsairs, Prowlers and Seakings that are among the 74 aircraft on the carrier's deck. **********Asked how he felt about the presence of the fleet, Mr. Magana replied, ''I feel I am not alone.'' **********The Ranger, cruising about 100 miles south of San Salvador and 100 miles west of the Managua, the Nicaraguan capital, is the flagship of the battle group that arrived last month to Central American waters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.main_headline: INDIA IS SLOWLY WINNING ITS WAR ON ILLITERACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.print_headline: INDIA IS SLOWLY WINNING ITS WAR ON ILLITERACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/20/world.body_text: **********At one end of the open veranda of a crumbling building that once served as the village council hall, nine elementary school- aged children sat cross-legged on burlap mats following their teacher in unison, counting in Hindi. **********Other children wrote numbers and letters with brushes on black slates in white ink. Inside the building, older children worked at arithmetic. **********The school and others like it are playing a key role in a gradual transformation that is taking place in rural India. **********Basic schooling is expanding at a rapid rate in the Indian countryside, where three-quarters of India's people live. Planners expect that universal education will soon be a fact for children up to 10 years old. **********Literacy rates are rising steadily as a result, particularly among the younger generations. Already, say those who live in this hamlet of 500 people in the middle of the Ganges plain, the shift in attitude that comes with literacy is under way. **********A measure of this transformation was provided by a small group of boys lounging outside the school where the students were doing their arithmetic. Their fathers needed them to work in the fields, they said, so they could not go to school. **********When India became independent 36 years ago, these boys would have represented the majority, especially here in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state, where illiteracy, overpopulation, poverty and disease are especially prevalent. **********Those doing their lessons inside the school would have been part of a small minority, representing only 1 or 2 of every 10 children their age. **********Today, the proportion is almost exactly reversed: the boys standing around outside represent only about 2 or 3 in 10; those inside, 7 or 8 in 10. **********The major reason, said Munni Lal, the 42-year-old elected headman of a group of three villages of which Naubasta is one, is that most parents have realized that education helps young people to get better jobs, to get off the farm and move to the city. **********There are, however, limits to the change. So far, the free schooling is confined to primary education, the first five years of school. **********Nationally, 83 percent of all children in that age group are enrolled in school, against 35 percent in 1947. The Government expects this figure to reach 95 percent soon. **********At higher grade levels, enrollment is much lower: 40 percent in the middle- school grades of sixth through eighth, and 22 percent in high school. **********Moreover, the enrollment level for girls is much lower than for boys: 66 percent nationally in first through the fifth grades, compared with 99 percent for boys. It is only 27 percent for girls in grades sixth through eighth, compared with 52 percent for boys. **********In rural areas, female literacy is estimated at less than 20 percent. Female school attendance is rising, however, and perhaps half the girls in Naubasta now attend school. **********By spending some $4 billion a year on education - second only to defense - India has been able not only to expand educational opportunities since independence but to do it in the face of a population that has roughly doubled, to more than 700 million. **********The national literacy rate, a bare 16 percent at independence, has more than doubled, to 36 percent, according to the 1981 census. But that figure includes children under 5 years old, so the effective rate is higher, officials say, perhaps 42 percent. Among Indians 10 to 25 years old, it is estimated at better than 50 percent. **********In Naubasta, the real expansion in schooling has come largely within the last decade. In 1947, there was one primary and one intermediate school serving the three villages. **********The Naubasta primary school, which has an enrollment of 120 and an average daily attendance of 70, was established in 1969. Three more primary and middle schools were established, in 1975, 1976 and 1977, and three months ago a nursery school opened.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.main_headline: MOST WEST BANK ARABS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.print_headline: MOST WEST BANK ARABS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/14/world.body_text: **********Leading Palestinians living under Israeli occupation are blaming a variety of parties for the breakdown in talks between King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Some are still hoping for a renewal of the Jordanian-P.L.O. dialogue on entering American-sponsored negotiations with Israel over the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Depending on their political viewpoints, some Palestinians hold Israel responsible for discouraging negotiations by continuing construction of Jewish settlements in the territories. Most blame the United States for failing to force Israel to halt the settlements.  Some pro-Jordanians blame Palestinian radicals for refusing to abandon their illusions and confront political reality. And some pro-P.L.O. figures blame King Hussein for resisting the creation of a Palestinian state and seeking merely to reoccupy the West Bank. **********On Sunday, King Hussein issued a statement of frustration with the P.L.O., asserting that the organization had withdrawn from understandings reached earlier on a joint approach with Jordan to possible talks. Evidently, hard-line Palestinian factions had rejected the concept of Jordan's negotiating on the P.L.O.'s behalf. Time May Be Running Out **********The collapse of the effort has distressed many West Bank and Gaza Palestinians, who fear that time for compromise is running out in the face of the extensive settlement construction by the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin. About 30,000 Jews now live on the West Bank, where about 800,000 Arabs reside, and about two-thirds of the land has been effectively declared off-limits to Arab construction, residence or agriculture. **********The plan put forward by President Reagan last September called for a freeze in Israeli settlements and the eventual transfer of at least parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip to Palestinian rule in association with Jordan. But it opposed a Palestinian state. The Palestinian National Council, the governing arm of the P.L.O., rejected the plan, as did Prime Minister Begin. **********There is a widespread conviction among Palestinian Arabs that the Israelis want to make life miserable for them and thereby drive them out of the territories. **********This was reinforced by reported remarks Tuesday by the outgoing Chief of Staff of the Israeli Army, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan. Israeli radio, television and newspapers quoted him as telling Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee that for every incident of stone-throwing by Arab youths, 10 settlements should be built. ''When we have settled the land,'' he was quoted as saying, ''all the Arabs will be able to do about it will be to scurry around like drugged roaches in a bottle.'' Acute Disappointment **********As a result, there has been growing support in the territories for a more moderate P.L.O. and Jordanian position as a possible way out from under Israeli occupation. Such a position envisioned accepting peaceful coexistence between Israel and a Palestinian entity on the West Bank and Gaza. The failure to achieve this has been met with acute disappointment. **********''I think this is the end,'' said Jamil Hamad, a Palestinian journalist from Bethlehem, ''and it's a very terrible end, a frightening end. He who says no to the Reagan plan should offer me, as an occupied man, an alternative, a hope. I think the Reagan plan, the Hussein readiness to talk, demonstrated a hope. Think of me as a Palestinian, occupied. What kind of hope are you offering me? Who is going to give me hope? It's very, very frightening.'' **********Former Mayor Rashad al-Shawa of Gaza said he did not see how King Hussein could act alone, without P.L.O. support, especially in the face of the Begin Government's determination to settle and hold the territories. ''He is afraid, and he's justified in being afraid, that he'll burn himself without accomplishing anything,'' he said. **********''I think it is very unfortunate that such a situation has arisen,'' he continued. ''I think it is a grave mistake that such a breakdown should take place.'' **********''But on the other hand, I feel that the undecided action taken by the United States has encouraged the extreme elements to take still more extreme stands and to influence the moderates. The United States has within its power sufficient influence to stop Israeli settlement in the territories. Merely to talk about doing its best to stop the Israeli settlements - I don't believe that is serious enough for us who call ourselves moderates.'' Trust in the United States **********Criticism of the United States for failing to influence Israeli policy is a pervasive theme in Palestinians' assessments of the impasse. **********''The United States is powerful,'' said Mustafa Natshe, the acting Mayor of Hebron, on the West Bank, ''but they don't use their power in the right way.'' Washington could have cut aid to Israel and forced a halt in settlement, he contended, in which case ''there would be more trust in the United States, and I think things would have been changed between King Hussein and the P.L.O.'' **********''That's ridiculous,'' Mr. Hamad countered. ''I believe the Reagan Administration was willing to exert pressure on Israel to stop settlements'' if King Hussein offered to negotiate. ''Why are they not saying that the Soviet Union is responsible for sabotaging this effort, which is more logical?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/16/busin.main_headline: More Credibility Is Aim Of Power System Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; More Credibility Is Aim Of Power System Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The appointment Friday of Donald Mazur, 49, as managing director of the Washington Public Power Supply System's financially troubled nuclear construction program is expected to pave the way for a smooth management transition. **********Mr. Mazur will succeed Robert L. Ferguson, who announced several months ago that he would be retiring for heath reasons on June 3.  Analysts believe that because Mr. Mazur, formerly the power system's No.3 in command as director of projects, is known and respected by other personnel that his appointment would stem the recent exodus of top managers. **********The power system undertook the construction of five nuclear power plants in Washington several years ago on behalf of 88 untilities that would ultimately purchase their output. It has since scrapped two of the units - No.4 and No.5 - amid huge cost overruns and projections of declining demand for electric power. And on Friday it warned that it was likely to default on $15.6 million in interest payments due to bond holders of those units. **********Mr. Mazur, in a telephone interview yesterday, said he would focus his attention on bringing the remaining units on line. He said he expected that unit No.2 would be ready by February, unit No.3 by December 1986 and unit No.1 in 1991. **********Undermining this goal, however, would be the expected default in June on $2.25 billion on bonds used to partly construct the two terminated nuclear reactors, which would pull down the power system's entire nuclear construction program. **********Mr. Mazur said that his new job would not bring any more pressure than his previous position at the power system. ''Three years ago, on my first day on this job, I was in the hot seat establishing credibility and schedule performance. Being a project manager is a hot seat position, period.'' **********He said that that one of his major goals was to build credibility, and that is one reason he is trying to get unit No.2 on line - because it would be put to rest doubts that the utility can accomplish what it has promised to do. He also said that he is not planning on bringing in a lot of new people, but is prepared to seek help in specific areas, including financing. **********Mr. Mazur had been a hand-picked member of the transition team when Mr. Ferguson became managing director in 1980. Previously he had been a group leader for field engineering on construction of the Department of Energy's fast-flux breeder reactor at Hanford, Wash. In the late 1970's, Mr. Mazur had been a trouble-shooter for the Department of Energy's once-beleagured strategic petroleum reserve program in Louisiana.
