https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/23/busin.main_headline: WITH INFLATION DOWN SHARPLY, INDUSTRIAL NATIONS ARE CASTING ABOUT FOR ; WAYS TO GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/23/busin.print_headline: WITH INFLATION DOWN SHARPLY, INDUSTRIAL NATIONS ARE CASTING ABOUT FOR ; WAYS TO GROW
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/23/busin.body_text: **********PARIS WHEN Beryl Sprinkel, the Under Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, urged industrial nations toward ''credible economic expansion'' at a meeting of finance ministers in Paris last week, European financial leaders thought the economist was signaling a change in the Reagan Administration's fiscal policies, from a preoccupation with inflation to a drive for growth. **********That interpretation was short-lived. In Washington, Martin S.  Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, quickly responded: ''I don't believe there is any basis for believing that there has been any change in current Administration policy.'' And Marc E. Leland, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, under orders from a reportedly outraged boss, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, said Mr. Sprinkel was ''speaking for himself.'' **********That spat remains to be resolved. Nonetheless, the Europeans are clearly rooting for the United States to demonstrate a greater concern for the financial strains that the industrial world's longlived recession has caused and the potential for the recession to escalate into a depression. **********The Europeans cheered in late summer, when Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, seemed to shift Fed policy onto a more stimulative course. And they have watched eagerly as the Reagan Administration has wrestled to prepare an economic game plan for 1983 that would insure a quick and lasting recovery for the weak United States economy. **********The Europeans themselves are groping for a strategy that will bring their major industrial economies that same result: growth, without the risk of another virulent bout of inflation. Several countries have already begun to walk this course; Sweden and Austria, for instance, have carefully aimed discretionary public spending at boosting investment, rather than at increasing personal consumption, while Belgium, Denmark, Finland, France, Italy and Sweden have all either introduced wage and price freezes or refused to raise wages automatically in line with inflation. **********Last week, the ministers of the so-called Group of 10, the 10 wealthiest Western countries, and Switzerland, asked the International Monetary Fund and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to develop by late spring proposals for economic growth that would not reignite inflation. **********THE O.E.C.D., an organization of 24 industrial nations, will make its recommendations when its ministers meet in Paris in May, the I.M.F. when its ministers gather in Washington in June. The Europeans are convinced -and they hope the United States is, too - that the fight against inflation has gone far enough, indeed, too far, and that the dangers posed by international debt and a stagnant world economy now far outweigh the dangers of inflation. ''Is there an increasing asymmetry of risk? That is the question,'' said Silvia Ostry, one of the architects of the O.E.C.D.'s economic policies. **********The Europeans' hunt for a growth policy is a variation on an old theme -the ''locomotive'' strategy of 1977 and 1978, in which the three most successful Western industrial nations - the United States, West Germany and Japan - were expected to push or pull weaker nations into prosperity by expanding rapidly themselves. Their growth would generate demand for exports in less prosperous nations throughout the world, leading eventually to a chain reaction of growth around the globe. That strategy, which rested on the Keynesian theory that a large fiscal stimulus should be applied to the whole economy, was proposed by a panel of economists headed by Paul McCracken, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under former President Richard M. Nixon. But the locomotive stalled on rising oil prices and was sidetracked completely by the dollar crisis of 1979. **********Now, the O.E.C.D. is casting about for a more sophisticated approach, under which any stimulus would be carefully channeled into noninflationary areas and would be combined with other measures designed or intended to make economies function more efficiently - and with less inflation - as they move toward full employment. **********The view in Europe is that the choice is simple, and inexorable.  Either those countries that have gotten a grip on inflation - and now have what the Europeans call a ''margin of maneuverability'' - address the international debt crisis, and finance a gradual adjustment to create a larger market for exports, so that third-world countries can export and import more, or they rely on a ''marketplace adjustment,'' which the Europeans fear could be jolting. In a marketplace adjustment, this view holds, private banks would cease to lend, the poorer nations would be forced to reduce or eliminate imports and a depression would ensue. Economists see Poland and other East European countries, which have canceled many orders with the West, as examples of what might happen to curtail world trade if the financial situation is not eased soon by a return to growth in the major industrial nations. **********To the Europeans, there is no real choice. The only option for policy makers is growth. That was the message that came out of last week's meeting in Paris of finance ministers from the Group of 10, and Switzerland. It was the message the Europeans thought they heard from Washington through Mr. Sprinkel. **********His remarks about third-world debt and recession anticipated the ministers' final communique, issued Tuesday, in which they acknowledged that faster growth is needed to expand world trade, and reduce debt problems and unemployment. **********There is no point in giving the I.M.F. more money to finance a gradual reduction in third-world debts unless these countries can export and expand their earnings as well, economists have warned.  Nonetheless, the finance ministers agreed to increase to $19 billion from $7.1 billion the amount of money their countries will make available to heavily indebted countries. **********And so the locomotive has been rolled forth again, this time sporting what the O.E.C.D. calls a ''differentiated'' outlook for the Western economies. In the United States, Japan, West Germany and Britain, inflation has come down sharply and current rates are roughly comparable. Yet growth prospects differ. The United States seems headed for a mild recovery with growth in the 2 to 3 percent range. Japan may do a little better. But the German economy, shaken by falling exports and political uncertainty, is likely to contract for the third consecutive year, and Britain faces near-stagnation. **********Unlike 1977, there is a feeling now among O.E.C.D. economists that any new recovery strategy must be more subtle.  The O.E.C.D.'s specific recommendations, to be made in May, are of course still unknown. But they were foreshadowed last month, when a panel of 26 economists brought together by the Washington-based Institute for International Economics and chaired by its director, C. Fred Bergsten, produced its own blueprint for ''a coordinated economic recovery strategy.'' The panel's report is very close, O.E.C.D. sources say, to what they hope to propose in May. **********This time, the O.E.C.D.'s emerging tactic, labeled ''The Differentiated Recovery Strategy,'' is an attempt to work out for each major country a set of detailed policy prescriptions that meet governments' concerns and which, when put together, would do more to promote recovery than what any nation could do alone. And, the economists are betting that there will not be a shock of higher oil prices to get in the way of growth this time around. **********IN fact, all Western governments have already started to stimulate their economies through a relaxation in monetary policy and lower interest rates. ''Germany, Britain and Switzerland are all now following mildly stimulative monetary policies,'' said Hans Maast, chief economist at the Swiss Credit Bank in Zurich. So far, Mr. Maast argues, this relaxation is free from inflationary dangers because oil prices are weak, personal savings are increasing and trade unions, shellshocked by rising unemployment, are keeping wage claims moderate. **********Yet the power of the financial markets in the United States is keeping the Federal Reserve on what one O.E.C.D. economist called ''a knife edge.'' Too much laxity could arouse inflationary fears, push interest rates up, boost the dollar and force European countries to jack up their rates again to protect currencies. **********Dr. Klaus Wieners, chief economist at the Westdeutsche Landesbank in Dusseldorf, West Germany, says that further monetary relaxation offers the most credible strategy for securing faster expansion, because restrictive budgetary policies could be politically difficult for governments. **********A key element in the emerging European approach to growth policy will be to to encourage countries that have already won the battle against inflation to divide their deficits into two parts, an ''automatic'' deficit, which is created by recession and will disappear with it, and a ''discretionary'' deficit, which results from specific governmental policies that can be controlled. This division should help governments focus attention on the parts of the budget they can increase directly to spur recovery. **********THE strategy would be to move ahead rapidly with such stimulus, but with care. The Bergsten panel urged that money go for infrastructure projects, such as repairing bridges and highway systems and not for new social programs that are difficult to curtail or cancel when the economy picks up. The O.E.C.D. believes such discretionary government spending should be carefully aimed at boosting investment rather than personal consumption, as some of members countries have already done. **********However difficult the challenge of persuading governments to adopt a coordinated recovery strategy, there is a growing belief that the world promises to pay a heavy price for its present economic performance. The Bergsten panel said, ''The perpetuation of stagnation raises the specter of a breakdown of the world economic order.'' Contributing to that breakdown is the inability of thirdworld countries to repay their debts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/29/busin.body_text: **********Texas Instruments Inc., battered by its second huge quarterly loss, announced yesterday that it was ending production of its 99/4A home computer and pulling out of the home computer business. **********''In order to limit further financial drain on T.I., we have made the decision to withdraw from the consumer home computer business,'' the company said in a statement attributed to Mark Shepherd Jr., its chairman, and J. Fred Bucy, president. **********That announcement came simultaneously with the company's report that it had lost $110.8 million in the third quarter of this year, after a $119.2 million loss in the second quarter. The latest loss was in contrast to net income of $36.9 million, or $1.57 a share, in last year's third quarter. **********Loss on Computers **********In home computer operations alone, the company lost $330 million before taxes, including a write-off associated with pulling out of the business. In the second quarter, it lost $183 million on home computers, bringing total losses in two quarters to more than $500 million. **********The statement said that production of the company's home computer would cease in November and that there would be ''significant'' layoffs at the company's home computer operations.  The company said it would also substantially lower the price on the 99/4A to help clear remaining inventory from the store shelves. The computer now sells for a $149 retail price plus a $50 rebate. **********Business Model Continued **********Texas Instruments said it would continue to make and sell its Professional Computer, a more expensive personal computer designed primarily for business use. It also said it was remaining in the calculator business. **********The company did not specify how many layoffs it would have or what the price cuts would be. Charles W. LaFara, a large mail order distributor of the home computer products in Oklahoma City, said that he had heard from T.I. employees that there would be 4,000 layoffs and that the price of the computer would be reduced to $47 wholesale, from $147, with the rebate removed. ''I think I'm going to be sick,'' Mr. LaFara said. **********The pullout raises the prospect that existing owners of the T.I. home computer will find it more difficult to obtain servicing and new programs to run on the machines. There are more than a million owners of the low- priced machine, making it by some estimates the second most widely owned computer, after the Commodore VIC-20 and ahead of the Apple II. **********Texas Instruments said that it would continue to provide service for the machine. It did not say who would provide software for the machine, but it appeared clear that new software would be developed only if other companies thought they could make money doing it. **********Home computer sales are estimated to represent less than 10 percent of the company's revenues, which fell in the third quarter to $1.01 billion from $1.05 billion in the same period last year. Not counting consumer electronics, revenues climbed 11 percent, the company, whose major product is semiconductor chips, said. **********The announcement marked the latest casualty in the home computer and video game businesses. Although demand for home computers is growing rapidly, supply has been growing even faster, leading to oversupply and steep price cuts. Mattel Inc. has already pulled back on plans to market a home computer, and there is speculation in the industry that Warner Communications' Atari is also considering withdrawing from the market. **********New Companies Entering **********At the same time, new companies are entering the business, moving it in a new direction. Coleco Industries recently started shipping its Adam, and the International Business Machines Corporation is expected to introduce its home computer next week. Both these new machines are in the $600 to $1,200 price range and are more useful than the computers like the 99/4A, which is limited to playing games and some simple tasks unless a lot of equipment is added. **********While many industry analysts had speculated that T.I. would pull out of the home computer business, the company has been insisting it would stay in. Less than two months ago, it hired a Procter & Gamble executive to revamp its consumer operations. Yesterday's announcement was, therefore, something of a surprise, especially coming just before the heavy Christmas selling season. **********Texas Instruments said that retail sales of the 99/4A were disappointing and that there was still excess inventory on retail shelves, which limited new orders and led to an operating loss in the quarter. ''With this situation continuing into October, it became clear that fourth-quarter demand would not be sufficient to prevent large additional losses,'' the company said. **********''The first nine months of 1983 have been the most difficult period in the history of T.I.,'' the two officials said in the statement. ''We believe that, with the painful, but correct, decision to withdraw from the consumer home computer business, that period has now ended.'' **********Favorable Response Expected **********The company's withdrawal from home computers is bound to be greeted favorably on Wall Street. Analysts have long noted that, even though home computers are only a small part of T.I.'s business, the losses were so large as to outweigh the profits from all other divisions combined. **********Analysts have also often said that T.I., whose other businesses include semiconductor manufacturing, larger computers, seismic exploration and defense electronics, is not cut out for consumer business. It withdrew from digital watch business two years ago. **********The Dallas electronics company, with 1982 revenue of $4.33 billion, said that its loss came at a time when its businesses other than consumer products were improving. For the first nine months of 1983, T.I. lost $222.9 million, in contrast to a profit of $101.5 million in the first nine months of 1982. Revenues climbed slightly to $3.28 billion from $3.22 billion. **********Painful Saga Ended **********The withdrawal from the home computer business marks the end of a saga that has been embarrassing and painful for Texas Instruments from the start. The company in 1979 was one of the first to market a computer strictly geared toward home use, as opposed to office use. But the machine, which sold for $1,150, was too expensive and was a failure. **********Starting in the middle of 1982, however, prices began dropping to as little as $100 for essentially the same machine that sold for $1,150 a few years earlier. Sales of the Texas Instruments home computers, as well as those of other manufacturers, started soaring late last year, and it looked like the T.I. home computer was on its way to success at last. **********This year, however, Texas Instruments ran into problems in February when it had to withdraw its computer from the market briefly because of an electrical problem. It also started losing money because prices were too low, while Commodore International, its chief rival, could continue to produce its VIC-20 at the same low price for a profit. The Texas Instruments computer also ran into problems because other computers had more software. **********Earlier this month, it was learned that T.I. did not plan to introduce a more powerful home computer, the 99/8, that it had been previewing to retailers for more than six months. **********T.I. is not the only home computer manufacturer to have problems. In addition to Mattel's pullback and delays in getting Atari computers to market, Coleco was late shipping its Adam computer, meaning it will fall far short of its sales goals for the year. And Commodore, the only company that has been profitable, is now running into problems because of a shortage of disk drives and what retailers say is a high defect rate in its Commodore 64 computer. **********The home computer field thus resembles a battle in which all sides kill one another off and no one is left standing. This will make the path clearer for I.B.M. At the same time, ironically, there might be a shortage of home computers in stores this Christmas because of the carnage wrought by the previous oversupply. a $149 retail price plus a $50 rebate.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Note and Bond Prices Jump; Rates on Bills Are Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply yesterday with traders encouraged by rumors that the Federal Reserve was leaning toward further reductions in short-term interest rates, and by signs that the economy was not recovering as quickly as has been expected. **********By late in the day, government securities dealers were no longer talking about a ''glut of unsold issues'' and were quoting sharply higher prices and lower yields for short- and long-term Treasury securities. **********Rates on Treasury bills, for example, fell by more than an eighth of a percentage point, with three- and six-month issues bid at rates of 8.16 percent and 8.26 percent, respectively. The greatest price gains came in the note and bond market, where issues due in 1990 and beyond rose by a point or more. The new 3- , 10- and 30-year Treasury issues sold last week were all traded at prices higher than those set at last week's auctions. **********The initial price jumps came early in the morning, and were based on reports that the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A.  Volcker, expects that interest rates will continue to decline. Since monetary policy makers at the Fed met this week, traders concluded that Mr. Volcker's comments mean further reductions in short-term interest rates. **********While there was no doubt that press reports influenced trading yesterday, many analysts noted that there were still no signs that the Fed had taken actions to reduce interest rates. The overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, a closly watched benchmark for other short-term interest rates, traded around 8 1/2 percent yesterday, the same level as in the past five weeks. Relatively High Rates **********Mr. Volcker has been well aware that current interest rates ranging from 9 to 11 percent in the Treasury market are unusually high relative to a 5 percent inflation rate that shows no signs of increasing. For that reason, some analysts said that a comment by Mr. Volcker that interest rates are too high need not be a signal that declines are imminent. **********Morgan Stark, a senior vice president at Chemical Bank, commented that Mr. Volcker's thinking may have changed little in recent months. ''But the market felt less threatened,'' he said, since many analysts have been warning recently that the Federal Reserve might raise short-term rates in an effort to reduce growth of the money supply.  ''The Fed still has the problem of how to get interest rates down without inducing inflationary behavior,'' Mr. Stark added. **********Economists at Ried, Thunberg & Company, an advisory firm that specializes in interpreting Federal Reserve actions, said in a publication yesterday that the inflationary potential of recent money supply growth will not suddenly disappear when the Fed announces today new definitions for some money supply measures. They doubted that ''the Fed can redefine'' the money supply measures ''and immediatley follow up with a further ease in monetary policy - and retail credibility.'' Retail Sales Figures a Factor **********In the afternoon, prices received more impetus when the Commerce Department announced that retail sales in January rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, well below the increases of 1 percent or more that market participants expected. The small increase, combined with a downward revision in December's retail sales, showed that the economic recovery is still not strong. A weak economy would provide more reason for the Fed to foster lower interest rates, traders said. **********In the tax-exempt market, prices improved yesterday, though not quite as much as in the Treasury market. For the week, prices rose slightly. **********Among recent long-term issues, the 10 7/8 percent bonds due 2008 of the Municipal Assistance Corporation were traded among securities firms at a price as high as 99 3/4, and were offered among dealers at a price of 99 7/8. The Baa-1/A-rated bonds were publicly offered earlier this week at 100. **********Among high-grade general obligation bonds, underwriters said that there was a modest pickup in demand for a $50 million issue of Texas bonds that had been repriced to increase yields by about a tenth of a percentage point. Originally, the Aaa-rated bonds were offered by a Bankers Trust group with yields ranging from 5.75 percent in 1987 to 7.25 percent in 1993 and 8.3 percent in 1998.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/07/busin.body_text: **********The Labor Department and Merrill Lynch & Company are caught up in a dispute over whether the nation's largest securities firm compromised its independence in evaluating the assets of an insurance company owned by Allen M. Dorfman, a longtime associate of organized crime figures. **********The dispute arises out of the desire of the health and welfare fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to buy Amalgamated Insurance Agency Services Inc., which had handled the union's claim processing for 30 years. **********Amalgamated was owned by Mr. Dorfman, who was murdered gangland style last January, a month after he was convicted on charges of conspiring to bribe a United States Senator. Before his murder, the teamsters' fund wanted to buy out Mr. Dorfman's business in order to purge itself of past charges of engaging in unlawful activity. **********According to the Labor Department, Merrill Lynch's involvement in the Amalgamated evaluation in 1982 was part of ''a charade of respectability.'' **********Merrill Lynch told the teamsters' fund that Amalgamated was worth $10.75 million. But the Labor Department says that for the fund to pay that amount ''would constitute a serious waste of fund assets,'' according to a court filing. The department says the assets are worth no more than $1 million, and that there was ''no substance or foundation'' for the investment firm's appraisal. **********Merrill Lynch's attorney, in a letter sent to the Labor Department last Friday, countered that the department's charges were ''one-sided, unfair and unjustified.'' **********The teamster fund paid $250,000, plus expenses, to Merrill Lynch for what it asked to be an independent evaluation of Amalgamated. **********''We are continuing to discuss with Labor Merrill Lynch's role,'' said George W. Lehr, executive director of the Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Health and Welfare Fund, the full title of the teamsters' fund. He added that the fund's trustees would decide at their meeting in Chicago later this month what action, if any, to take against Merrill Lynch. **********Merrill Lynch's role in evaluating Amalgamated was a factor in the firm's losing a bid to manage the assets of the teamsters' pension fund, which was awarded recently to Morgan Stanley & Company. **********Mr. Lehr, a former Kansas banker, was brought into the fund several years ago when it was the subject of numerous Federal investigations. He has attempted to eliminate the practices and associations that had led to investigations of criminal activity by the fund. As part of this effort, he was seeking to remove Amalgamated from Mr. Dorfman's control. **********The agreement signed by the health and welfare fund and Merrill Lynch provided that in evaluating Amalgamated, Merrill Lynch would meet with representatives and lawyers for the fund and Amalgamated ''together and not separately.'' **********According to the Labor Department, however, there were ''unauthorized ex parte communications'' between Amalgamated and Merrill Lynch, ''apparently in an attempt to cause'' Merrill Lynch ''to arrive at a higher valuation.'' An ex parte communication is one in which not all relevant parties are present. **********Asked why the fund and Mr. Dorfman did not simply negotiate a figure - the usual manner in which a buyer and seller agree on a price - Mr. Lehr said, ''With all the past dealings, the past allegations and all the litigation, any such dealings would be tainted and would not be acceptable to Congress, to the public, to the Department of Labor.'' **********Mr. Lehr explained that Merrill Lynch had been selected because ''it was the single best name available among investment bankers - certainly one of the four or five best.'' **********The fund even insisted that it pay the entire $250,000 - as opposed to splitting the cost with Amalgamated - ''because we didn't want anyone to accuse us of being influenced by Dorfman,'' Mr. Lear explained. **********Now, in spite of the fund's efforts, it has become involved in another imbroglio, in which Merrill Lynch's independence is being questioned. **********The fund and Amalgamated had agreed to be bound by the evaluation placed on Amalgamated's assets by an investment banking company. The contract further provided that ''to insure that the value determined is fair and reasonable, the investment banking firm shall be independent of and shall not be deemed to represent either of the parties.'' **********Recommendation Disputed **********According to Mr. Lehr, Merrill Lynch was recommended to the fund by Albert Jenner, founder of one of Chicago's largest law firms, Jenner & Block. A partner in Mr. Jenner's law firm, Michael Rovell, who represents Mr. Dorfman's estate, denied that anyone in the firm had recommended Merrill Lynch to the fund. **********Mr. Jenner, acting as attorney for Mr. Dorfman and Amalgamated, had already asked Merrill Lynch to act as consultant to his law firm on the evaluation, according to court documents. **********The approach had been made to Henry Meers, managing director of Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets in Chicago, the investment banking unit of Merrill Lynch. Mr. Meers had known Mr. Jenner for more than 50 years. **********With Jenner & Block lawyers, Mr. Meers specifically discussed the value of the Amalgamated assets, as well as the methods by which the assets could be evaluated, in order to arrive at a higher value, according to court papers. **********Mr. Meers, when he began discussions with the fund, did not advise it of these prior contacts, according to the Labor Department. **********The prior discussions between Jenner & Block and Merrill Lynch have come to light in a lawsuit in which the Department of Labor and the fund have charged that Mr. Dorfman defrauded the fund of $13 million. **********The suit, which is pending in the United States District Court in Chicago, involves a variety of complex issues, and it is not at all certain what the specific result would be if the court agrees with the department's contention that the assets were overvalued. **********Merrill Lynch is not a party to the litigation. As part of the proceedings, however, the fund and the Labor Department, as plaintiffs, took the deposition of Mr. Meers. They are planning to take Mr. Jenner's deposition next week, Mr. Rovell said. **********Value Defended by Merrill **********During the deposition, in response to a question by Mr. Rovell, Mr. Meers said that he was not influenced by his relationshp with Mr. Jenner, that there was ''no question in my mind'' that Merrill Lynch acted professionally and that $10.75 million was a fair value to the fund. **********When the Labor Department attorney, Page H. Jackson, was questioning Mr. Meers about the relationship between Merrill Lynch on the one hand and Jenner & Block and Amalgamated on the other, Mr. Meers's attorney objected. **********''What does it have to do with anything?'' David T. Pritikin asked. **********''It basically goes again to the independence of Merrill Lynch White Weld in the matter, and I think goes to the credibility of the value determination made,'' Mr. Jackson said. **********At the request of Merrill Lynch, Judge Hubert L. Will has placed the deposition and 53 documents, including memorandums of discussions between Mr. Jenner and Mr. Meers, minutes of Merrill Lynch meetings and papers relating to the evaluation process, under a protective order, which means they are not part of the public record. **********Earlier Discussions Held **********Merrill Lynch turned down the offer from Jenner & Block to act as adviser to the transaction at a meeting on Dec. 14, 1981 according to Mr. Meers. Among the reasons given by Mr. Meers in his deposition were that Merrill Lynch lacked the necessary expertise and that ''we did not want to be Dorfman's banker.'' **********A few weeks later, however, Merrill Lynch accepted what was essentially the same assignment when the offer came from the fund. **********Merrill Lynch declined to comment about any of the matters covered in the deposition because it is under a protective order. The firm provided a letter written by its attorney, Mr. Pritikin, to the Labor Department last Friday. Among other things, Mr. Pritikin explained that Merrill Lynch had accepted the offer from the fund because it ''believes that by performing its agreed role in the fund-Amalgamated transaction, Merrill Lynch would contribute to the realizations of efficiencies and reforms sought to the fund's management and by the Department of Labor.'' **********Mr. Pritikin also pointed out that in reaching its determination of the value, Merrill had retained Arthur Andersen & Company. The Chicago- based accounting firm was paid by the fund for its services. Arthur Andersen is also outside auditor for Jenner & Block. **********Arthur Andersen concluded that Amalgamated was worth $9.7 million. The Labor Department, in one of the court filings that is public, contends that ''the $9.7 million figure in Arthur Andersen's report does not represent fair value to the fund, fair market value or then-current market value of the assets transferred to the fund.'' **********Arthur Andersen determined that Amalgamated's computer software was worth $5.9 million. But the Labor Department contends that its worth to the fund was ''significantly less'' than $750,000. Arthur Andersen also determined that Amalgamated's work force was worth $3,579,000. The Labor Department contends that the value ''is less than $900,000.'' **********A spokesman for Arthur Andersen, who asked that his name not be used, said the firm was ''not familiar with the specifics of the allegations'' by the Labor Department - they were filed with the court in Chicago on Nov. 18 - and therefore could not comment. **********Another line of questioning pursued by the Labor Department during the course of Mr. Meers's deposition related to how and why Merrill Lynch added $1 million to the Arthur Andersen figure. **********The department's lawyer said, during the deposition, that the $10.75 million figure appeared in the final report and only one other place - Mr. Meers's file. **********Asked where the $10.75 million figure in his file came from, Mr. Meers answered: ''That could easily come when I might have been on the phone and just wrote it down or suggested to somebody else. I haven't any idea what this relates to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Japan and the United States held discussions today on the possibility of shipping Alaskan oil across the Pacific to Asia, diplomatic sources said. **********The talks were the latest in a series on energy cooperation between the countries following the visit to Washington earlier this year of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. **********United States legislation prohibits the export of Alaskan oil by any company, foreign or domestic, but the Reagan Administration has said it wants this tight clamp at least partially lifted. **********The oil could go to any country around the Pacific rim, but Japan would probably be the major importer, the sources said.  During the talks the United States representatives suggested that exports should be limited to 200,000 barrels a day from total daily production of around 1.6 million, but that any newly discovered oil would not be subject to restrictions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.main_headline: ARAB BANK BOYCOTT OF DATA LINKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.print_headline: ARAB BANK BOYCOTT OF DATA LINKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.body_text: **********Arab banks in the oil countries of the Persian Gulf are boycotting the leading international system for transferring money around the world because 10 Israeli banks have become members, according to banking and business sources here. **********Western banks that are established in Bahrain, which is the banking center for the Persian Gulf region, are reluctantly going along with the boycott. They say it would be difficult for them politically to join a communications system that the Arab banks oppose. The Western banks also say that the Bahrain Government would probably use its telecommunications monopoly to stop them from being members. **********The communications system is called Swift - an acronym for the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunications. Using computers, codes and satellite links, about 1,000 banks are able to transfer billions of dollars every day between customer accounts in more than 40 countries. The cost is lower and the security is greater than would be possible by using ordinary telex messages. Current Practice **********Banks in Bahrain now communicate with other banks around the world by mail, telephone and telex. ''There is no communications and clearing system as sophisticated as Swift available anywhere in the Gulf,'' one British banker said. Several other interbank systems exist, but they cover smaller areas than Swift, and as yet no serious attempt has been made to bring them into the Persian Gulf area. **********Last summer, Bahrain, which has more than 100 banks, most of them foreign, abruptly withdrew applications to join the Swift system after learning that a number of Israeli banks had been admitted as members just ahead of them. Local banks in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia also withdrew. **********Attempts by Swift executives to reopen negotiations have proved fruitless, according to sources here. Two Islamic countries, Morocco and Tunisia, are already Swift members, however; they joined before the Israeli banks became members. **********''The Israelis got a foot in the door first, and then we found the Gulf state banks were not interested any more,'' said Charles Reuterskiold, an executive at Swift's Brussels headquarters, in a telephone interview. ''We are a nonpolitical organization. We just don't know what to do,'' he added. Swift is a nonprofit group owned by its member banks. 10 Israeli Banks **********The Israeli banks that joined the Swift system are: Bank Hapoalim, Bank Leumi Le-Israel, Bank of Israel, Barclay's Discount Bank, First International Bank of Israel, Israel Discount Bank, Israel General Bank, Maritime Bank of Israel, Union Bank of Israel and United Mizrahi Bank. **********Admitting the Israeli banks appears to have cost the Swift system 50 to 60 members in the Arab world, many of them Western-owned, according to estimates circulating here. **********But the boycott will put fast-growing Arab banks at a disadvantage by not being able to use what is accepted as the best financial communications linkup in existence. **********''We need fast, secure communications like everybody else, but Swift has become a sensitive issue,'' a leading Arab banker here said. A Question of Cost **********Banks in Bahrain that are owned by American, European and Japanese banks are forced to go along with the boycott, sources say, contending that Swift would not be economical for them if only a few joined and shared the high cost of installing computers and communication apparatus. **********There are nearly 100 non-Arab banks in Bahrain, including almost all the leading American banks. Foreign banks are barred from Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Cement from Australia and Japan is being sold in the United States for substantially less than fair market value, the Government said today. **********The Commerce Department disclosed that an investigation of complaints filed almost a year ago by the United States cement industry and the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations had shown that portland hydraulic cement from Australia was being sold in the United States at 136 percent below prices for which it was sold in the home market. **********It added that cement from Japan was being sold at prices ranging from 35.5 percent to 43.5 percent below fair market value. **********Imports of cement from Australia in 1982 amounted to 116,000 tons valued at $4 million, said Lawrence J. Brady, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Trade Administration. Imports last year from Japan totaled 87,000 tons and were valued at $3.2 million, he added. **********As a result of the finding, cash deposits or bonds will be required from United States companies that import the cement. If the United States International Trade Commission finds that low-priced imports harm American industry, the Commerce Department will order anti- dumping duties. If no injury is found, the investigation will be ended.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/world.body_text: **********A Soviet newspaper today criticized China more harshly than at any time since moves toward better relations between the two countries began last year. **********The Government newspaper Izvestia said Peking, despite avowals of readiness to improve relations, had persisted in a policy of ''anti-Sovietism.'' **********A commentary noted the ''atmosphere of normalcy'' that had been achieved in two rounds of talks and reiterated readiness to improve ties. But it said Chinese words and deeds were having a negative impact. **********''This country is prepared actively to contribute to progress in Soviet-Chinese relations that would serve the interests of the U.S.S.R. and the People's Republic of China and the cause of peace and friendship among all nations,'' the commentary said. ''The Soviet people have a right to expect a similarly constructive approach from the Chinese side.'' Criticism Avoided Recently **********Apart from an article earlier this year accusing China of harboring territorial claims, Moscow has avoided criticism in the eight months since high-level talks resumed. **********Yuri V. Andropov and other Soviet leaders have spoken positively of China, and officials have talked about ''substantial detente.'' The Izvestia commentary was disseminated by the press agency Tass over its English service, indicating that the Government favored wide circulation abroad. Western diplomats said the timing of the article might have been related to tension along the Chinese-Vietnamese frontier and to Vietnam's offensive against Chinesebacked Cambodian rebels near the Thai border. **********But while these frictions may have provided an occasion for the attack, the diplomats said, the article reflected general disillusionment at the course of the Soviet-Chinese talks. Soviet officials have been conveying a similar message to Western officials. **********''They are much less optimistic than a few months ago,'' a diplomat said. ''They will persist in the talks, but there is a realization that breakthroughs are going to be hard to achieve. In the meantime, they are reminding China that Moscow's rhetoric can be every bit as tough as Peking's.'' **********The Izvestia article depicted the Chinese as having responded to Soviet good will with a two-sided policy that combined declarations of concern for better relations with ''the cultivation of unfriendly views and ideas.'' **********''Judging by articles in the Chinese press,'' the commentary said, ''the people in Peking have not yet given up attempts at using some of the attributes of anti-Sovietism, which for many years, especially in the bad times of the Cultural Revolution, poisoned the atmosphere of Soviet-Chinese relations. Anti-Sovietism has never been and cannot be of benefit to the Chinese people.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/28/world.body_text: **********Since Pope John Paul II's visit here early this month, the number of political murders in this country has dropped dramatically, a top Salvadoran churchman said today. **********Auxiliary Archbishop Gregorio Rosa Chavez, delivering the weekly homily in the capital's Metropolitan Cathedral, said there were 47 murders during the week of March 18 to March 24. **********The church's Legal Aid Society said last year that 6,000 people were killed in politically related violence in the country, an average of about 115 a week. In recent weeks the church has put the figure at 90 to 100 a week. **********''This drop is an echo of the hope brought to us by the Holy Father,'' the Auxiliary Archbishop said.  During his visit here in the first week of March, the Pope said there must be an end to the violence and war ''between brothers.'' So far, more than 35,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in El Salvador's 40-month civil war between leftist guerrillas and Government troops and right-wing militias.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/22/busin.body_text: **********The Osborne Computer Corporation has been sued by 26 investors who contend they were duped by the company's assurances about its financial status and future. **********But United States District Judge Marilyn Hall Patel said the suits, filed Tuesday, came too late to block three banks from collecting $8 million in letters of credit from 16 of the investors. **********The letters, payable in 72 hours, had been used to secure $10 million in loans to Osborne, which on Sept. 13 sought court protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/04/world.print_headline: CHADIANS MOP UP AROUND 2 DESERT OUTPOSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/04/world.body_text: **********The fighting in northeastern Chad has ceased, a Government spokesman said today, but ''cleanup operations'' are continuing just north of two desert outposts. **********Information Minister Mahamat Soumaila repeated earlier assertions that 3,000 Libyan-backed rebels on Friday attacked Government positions near Oum Chalouba and Kalait, about 500 miles northeast of here. **********He said 800 rebels had been killed and 600 taken prisoner. Among those killed or captured, he said, were a large number of Sudanese who had worked in Libya and had been recruited into Libya's Islamic Legion. **********Only 15 Government troops were wounded in the fighting, he added. There was no independent confirmation of the Government report because foreign journalists have not been allowed to visit the area. **********Western diplomatic and intelligence sources have confirmed that the fighting took place and that it was initiated by the rebel side. But they suggested that the Government's figures were exaggerated. The attacking force, they said, probably had no more than 600 men. The count of dead and captured was also thought to be smaller than the Government reported. **********At least some of the fighting was reported to have taken place south of Oum Chalouba, as close as 25 miles to the French positions at Arada. But this was denied by Mr. Soumaila, who said all of the fighting had occurred north of Oum Chalouba. **********There was also disagreement over the role played by the French Air Force. Western diplomats said French Jaguar planes had flown ''low and loudly'' over the rebel column, ''scaring'' the rebel troops and causing them to attack in disarray. **********Both Mr. Soumaila and the French military spokesman, Maj. Yvon Verroneau, denied French planes had buzzed or otherwise interacted with the attacking force. **********Recent broadcasts from the Bardai radio, the rebel station, have said Jaguars not only buzzed but also bombed the insurgents. This was denied by the Chadian and French spokesmen. **********Friday's attack was the first outbreak of fighting since French troops arrived in Chad on Aug. 11 in response to repeated appeals from President Hissen Habre. **********Some Western analysts believe that the rebel forces were testing the strength of Chadian defenses in the single area where Government troops are stationed north of the French line, stretching from Salal to Ati to Abeche and Arada. **********Others suggested that the rebel assault had been intended to provoke a clash between French and Libyan forces, thus breaking the stalemate that has maintained since the French arrival. **********The use of a large number of Sudanese troops, who are presumed to be more expendable than Chadians, was cited in support of this theory. **********There have been rumors that the French and Libyan Governments have at least tacitly agreed not to face each other in combat. **********The French military spokesman would say only that his Government continued to maintain diplomatic contacts with the parties in the conflict. **********Major Verroneau repeated previous assertions that France's military role was limited to ''assistance, instruction and self-defense.'' **********''There is no reason for us to react if our forces are not in danger,'' he said. ''There was no danger to our forces yesterday so we did not react. It was a Chadian problem in which we played no part.'' **********This afternoon an American C-130 transport plane and a shipment of spare parts also arrived here. The aircraft and materiel represent part of the $25 million in military aid that has been pledged by the Reagan Administration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/busin.main_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE GOVERNMENT WAS TO BLAME, IN PART
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/busin.print_headline:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE GOVERNMENT WAS TO BLAME, IN PART
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/09/busin.body_text: **********LAST weekend, President Reagan signed into law a measure allowing t extile companies and children's sleepwear manufacturers, d istributors and retailers to file claims in the United States Court o f Claims for losses they incurred from the 1977 ban on Tris, the c hemical flame retardant. **********There are those who allege that this law is a ''bailout'' for industries who either made careless or indiscriminate decisions regarding the use of Tris. **********Let me set the record straight. This law, which I authored, allocates no money - not one penny - for direct compensation of textile companies, manufacturers of children's sleepwear, or retailers who suffered huge financial losses as a result of the Government's decision to ban Tris. **********Rather, it merely confers jurisdiction on the Court of Claims to hear cases regarding Tris-related losses due to the Government's ban. It is, above all, a simple and equitable way to provide these corporations with their day in court - an opportunity to prove they were damaged by conflicting government regulations regarding the use of Tris. **********One point should be made, however. Should some or all of these companies be successful in proving that they were legitimately damaged by the Government, the Congress would have to appropriate money at some later date to pay some or all of these claims. There is nothing wrong with that, since the Government would be responsible for paying damages it created. **********I sponsored this legislation because companies affected by the Tris ban made good-faith efforts to comply with the Government's mandatory flammability standards, and in doing so, suffered huge financial losses. **********Those companies' decisions to use Tris were based on the knowledge that the chemical had been tested and found to meet all the appropriate government standards at that time. Indeed, there was no credible and convincing evidence that Tris was, in any way, a health hazard. **********When the ban on Tris was first ordered, these same companies made good-faith efforts to comply with the law again, despite the fact that it meant a great deal of harm to them. **********This is, therefore, not an issue over the appropriateness of the Government's decision to recall products which are injurious, although some manufacturers maintained that Tris was banned without sufficient and convincing proof that it was indeed dangerous. Rather, this is a response to the clear-cut issue of conflicting Government regulations - cruel in their effect on corporations that acted in good faith to comply with the law. **********The question then is: Does the Government, at the very least, have a responsibility to hear these cases and to afford those who claimed they were injured by a regulatory action an opportunity to be heard? I believe the record will clearly show that the Government has such a responsibility. The legislation, of course, does not guarantee recovery of financial losses by those claiming injury, but merely insures their right to be heard. **********The history of why this legislation is necessary explains in part why Congress passed, and the President signed, the Tris legislation.WHEN the Commerce Department set mandatory standards to lessen the f lammable nature of children's sleepwear in 1972, Tris was one of s everal flame retardants available then that met those standards. Butf ive years later, at the request of the Environmental Defense Fund, t he Consumer Products Safety Commission banned the sale and further p roduction of all children's sleepwear containing the f lameretardant. The ban required manufacturers to repurchase any c hildren's clothing with Tris. **********Springs Mills, a textile company in my state, brought legal action against the commission. Following a May 1977 hearing, District Court Judge Robert F. Chapman issued a temporary injunction preventing the C.P.S.C. from enforcing its Tris regulations against Springs Mills.  And in the ensuing trial, Judge Chapman struck down the commission's ban against Tris. **********In his ruling, he found that ''Tris was the only flame retardant available to effectively treat polyester, acetate, and triacetate fabrics used for children's sleepwear, which would enable the sleepwear to comply'' with the Commerce Department's original standards on flammability. According to the court, ''this had the practical effect of the Federal Government ordering that Tris be used.'' **********''Now another department of the same government has not only banned Tris, but ordered the repurchase of articles containing it,'' he said. In his ruling, the judge also found that due process of law had been denied in the Tris ban. Yet, the days of Tris were effectively ended after all the publicity. **********On Jan.20, 1978, the Senate unanimously passed a bill to aid over 100 companies in their $50 million loss resulting from the actions of the commission. The bill would have given the Court of Claims jurisdiction to hear arguments by manufacturers, producers, distributors and retailers and to determine the amounts of loss. The House of Representatives passed this bill in October 1978 by a vote of 304 to 90. But President Carter ''pocket vetoed'' the bill in November. **********I then introduced legislation in the 96th Congress, and it was passed by a unanimous vote in the full Senate in December. But it died in the House Judiciary Committee. **********Then, in the 97th Congress, I reintroduced the legislation. Again the Senate passed it unanimously, and the bill finally cleared the House late last month. The President has since signed it into law.  Such bipartisan support for this law should tell us something about its fairness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********When Gerard Debreu strolls with close friends and colleagues through a wildlife preserve above the shore of the Pacific Ocean north of San Francisco, the conversation often weaves through the work of Marcel Proust and the music of Saint-Saens. **********''Over the years, I have become more and more of a purist,'' he explained today, describing his taste in arts and letters. **********That seems only fitting. The French-born economist, now in his 22d year at the University of California at Berkeley, made his mark on the profession 24 years ago in a 114- page monograph filled mostly with elaborate mathematical formulas. **********The book, ''Theory of Value: An Axiomatic Analysis of Economic Equlibrium,'' drew enthusiastic reactions from his peers. A reviewer for the American Economic Review, the paragon of economic journals, concluded that ''it would not surprise me if it turned out to be one of the few classics of our period.'' **********Professor Debreu, now 62 years old, is little known outside the economics profession, but when he was named today as the 1983 recipient of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, his colleagues regarded it as part of the natural course of events.  'An Economist's Economist' **********''Gerard Debreu is an economist's economist,'' said Bent Hansen, chairman of the economics department at Berkeley. ''His work is very abstract, very fundamental. But everybody in the profession quotes him and must demonstrate that they know his work.'' **********Kenneth J. Arrow, a Stanford University professor in economics and operations research, said Professor Debreu in recent years had made great strides in developing mathematical tools for discovering the prices at which supply meets demand in several complex economies. ''His work includes a number of major innovations with practical applications,'' Professor Arrow said. **********Herbert Scarf, a Yale University economics professor, said Professor Debreu is greatly concerned with how economic models are framed. This, as Professor Debreu pointed out, makes him an heir to the pioneering theories of the late John von Neumann, the originator of game theory. ''I have been greatly influenced by von Neumann,'' Professor Debreu said. **********At a morning news conference on the Berkeley campus, Professor Debreu reasserted his reputation as a pure researcher, saying he did not want to use the occasion to discuss his views of the Reagan Administration's economic policies. Enjoys the Academic Life **********He turns down consulting offers from the companies whose econometric forecasting models owe much to his life's work. ''I'd like to stay with basic research and the academic life, which I enjoy very much,'' he said. **********Professor Debreu said he was distressed that his Nobel award might imply to the general public that all is well with basic research in mathematics and economics. ''The present condition is alarming,'' he said, alluding to cutbacks in state and Federal financing of basic research at Berkeley and the National Science Foundation. **********Gerard Debreu was born July 4, 1921, in Calais, France. He was graduated from the Ecole Normale Superior in Paris in 1944. After receiving his doctorate in economics from the Universite de Paris in 1946, he served two years as a soldier in the French occupation forces in West Germany. **********He came to the United States in 1950 as a research fellow with the Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics, in Chicago, and moved with the foundation to Yale University in 1955. He went to Berkeley in 1962.  Lunch at Home Every Day **********He and his wife, Fran,coise, who were married June 14, 1945, live in the Berkeley Hills above the campus. They have two daughters, Chantal and Florence, and five grandchildren. **********Professor Debreu became a United States citizen in 1975. His friends describe him as ''very French'' in manners and interests. He lunches at home every day with his wife, an accomplished choral singer, and thrives on long hikes in the Point Reyes National Forest, in Marin County. **********''He is a great hiker, and has taken me to isolated spots to watch the sea lions,'' said Dr. Hansen, the department chairman. Professor Debreru is also very formal, Dr. Hansen added, ''very hard to penetrate for most people, but inside a very, very warm person.'' Berkeley students rate him a ''star teacher,'' Dr. Hansen said. Fascinated by Proust Work **********Beyond economics, Marcel Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past'' is one of Professor Debreu's continuing objects of fascination. ''No matter what happens in life, you can always find something in Proust that relates,'' Dr. Hansen said. He added that he thinks Professor Debreu might silently identify with Proust's ''obsession'' with developing, as he put it, ''a piece of intellectual work.'' **********Professor Debreu is now trying to link complexity theory, a new theory of algorithms, with the economic theory of information. But he said he thinks he keeps his work in better perspective than did the 19th-century French author. **********''My appreciation of Proust is in his style, subtlety and taste,'' Professor Debreu said. ''I prize conciseness very much, and that is certainly something that you cannot accuse Proust of. His compulsion, as you know, eventually killed him. I'll try to escape that fate.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund will set stiffer economic conditions on Venezuela's request for a $1.1 billion compensatory financing credit than it has on previous loans, financial sources said today. **********Venezuela has informed the I.M.F. it would apply for 100 percent of its quota under the Compensatory Financing Facility, or C.F.F.  Negotiations with the I.M.F. start next month. **********Banking sources said stiffer terms for I.M.F. assistance are likely to go down well with creditor banks, which are now discussing a rescheduling of Venezuelan debt. **********The sources said the decision to make the facility credits, intended to offset loss of export revenues, subject to stiffer conditions reflects a move to tighten I.M.F. lending in general. **********''The board of directors decided at its meeting last week that the C.F.F. had been granted too readily in the past, and that the terms should be made more strict,'' the sources said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/13/world.body_text: **********On a small farm in the Honduran countryside, 90 Nicaraguan men and boys are being treated for wounds suffered in the guerrilla war against the Sandinista Government. **********They range in age from 13 to the mid- 40's. Most belong to the largest of the anti-Sandinista groups, the 8,000- member Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which rented the farm from its Honduran owners. Others are from Misura, a group representing Indians from eastern Nicaragua, and the Nicaraguan Democratic Union, a group of several hundred. **********The one-story farmhouse, smelling strongly of disinfectants, has an operating room equipped with a white bed and a large lamp, with sheds outside serving as wards. Another room in the farmhouse has shelves full of American drugs and green oxygen bottles stacked in a corner. **********''All this equipment has been donated by friends,'' said a doctor identified only as Tomas. **********The doctor, a brisk man wearing shorts and combat boots, is in charge of two other doctors at the hospital. He said 16 doctors worked for the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which has two other hospitals in Honduras. **********The doctor said Cuban and Nicaraguan surgeons in Miami also volunteer their services for specific operations. There are also said to be 100 paramedics at the hospitals and in Nicaragua. **********''All these people are volunteers,'' said Edgar Chamorro, a director of the Nicaraguan Democratic Force, which like the other guerrilla groups gets money and arms from the United States. He said no one in the organization received a salary, although ''some members, officers with families to support,'' get monthly payments, according to need. **********Mr. Chamorro said his group suffered about 300 dead and slightly more wounded in the last year. **********Tomas said that before the Sandinista victory in 1979 he ran a pediatrics clinic in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital. He left for Miami, where he set up a new clinic before joining the guerrilla movement two years ago. **********''Our main problem is evacuation,'' he said, speaking of those wounded in the guerrilla war. ''It takes us several days to get them across the border.'' **********After traveling to Honduras on foot, the guerrillas are taken by jeep to the hospitals. The doctor said the hospitals received an average of 20 casualties a week. ''Their physical constitution is extraordinary,'' he said. **********Jilguero, a tall 18-year-old, who, like most of those interviewed asked to be identified only by his pseudonym, said he was wounded four months ago in the northern Nicaraguan province of Nueva Segovia. **********Tomas pulled back Jilguero's hair to reveal a deeply creased skull. ''AK round,'' the doctor said, adding that a surgeon would come from Miami to install a plastic plate in the guerrilla's skull. **********Jilguero rose slowly from his cot in a wooden shed to go outdoors, where a Spanish version of ''The Poseidon Adventure'' could be seen on a television set. **********Marvin, a 13-year-old Indian, was shot through the right hand a month ago when his patrol was ambushed in the village of La Vega Arenal in Jinotega Province. ''I can't fight now because of my fingers,'' he said, smiling. **********Chaqualin, a 16-year-old who spoke in a gravelly whisper, was shot in the left jaw in an attack on the town of Jalapa in May. ''My mother doesn't want part of her flesh to die, but she knows that there are Communists in Nicaragua,'' he said. He stopped abruptly, excused himself and went off to watch ''The Poseidon Adventure.'' **********Resting in a former chicken hutch, where about 20 men lay in bed, Simon, 19, said that as soon as his broken forearm healed, he would be ready to return to war. ''I like to fight because I love my country,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/06/busin.body_text: **********A late recovery enabled the stock market to erase some of its earlier losses yesterday and finish mixed in active trading. **********At the end of trading, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 5.29 points, to 1,270.53. **********In the overall market, however, stocks that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that rose by 873 to 729. **********The late upswing was attributed mostly to the midafternoon statement by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, who said there had not been any major change in the central bank's monetary policy. **********In the preceding three sessions the Dow average tumbled 20 points after climbing to a record 1,287.20 last Tuesday, mainly because of concern that the Fed might tighten its monetary policy. **********Turnover on the exchange contracted to 88.3 million shares from 95.3 million shares on Friday as institutional participation slackened somewhat. **********Dana P. Stewart, market analyst of Bear, Stearns & Company, said that the Dow average's recovery today was also helped by the gains in two bellwether issues, General Motors and International Business Machines, which had dropped sharply last week and by ''the late improvement in the credit markets were yields ended slightly lower.'' **********The two other major market indicators also finished higher. The exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks added 0.11, to 95.77, while Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 0.33, to 165.77. **********General Motors, which lost 2 7/8 points last week, climbed 1 1/4 points yesterday, to 74 1/4, buoyed by the news that its new car sales climbed 20 percent in late November. In the same group, Chrysler rose 1, to 29; Ford was up 1/2, to 42, and American Motors ended unchanged at 7 1/8. **********I.B.M. advanced 3/4, to 118 5/8, in active trading. Analysts attributed the gain in the stock mostly to bargain- hunting. **********The big gainer was Esquire, which jumped 6 5/8, to 23 5/8, after Gulf and Western agreed to purchase the 73 percent of Esquire it does not already own for $25 a share. G. & W. ended unchanged at 29 1/2. **********American Standard lost 3, to 31, and the Trane Company fell 3 1/4, to 42 3/4, following the news Sunday that American Standard would acquire Trane. Some analysts said the deal will dilute American Standard's earnings next year. **********Diamond Shamrock topped the most-active list and dropped 3 3/8, to 20 3/8. **********The ''old'' and ''new'' issues of American Telephone were the second and third most heavily traded on the exchange, respectively. The ''old'' A.T. & T. closed up 1/8, to 64 3/4, while the ''new'' stock closed unchanged at 20 3/8. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index eased 1.09, to 223.84. Dorchester Gas led the active list and climbed 3 3/4, to 20 1/4. On Friday, it agreed to a $580 million buyout offer from a financial group. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index lost 1.42, to 282.49.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/24/world.main_headline: SOME SALVADOR PRISONERS, FRESH FROM JAIL, SEEKING EXIT VISAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/24/world.print_headline: SOME SALVADOR PRISONERS, FRESH FROM JAIL, SEEKING EXIT VISAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/24/world.body_text: **********With her eyes starting to fill with tears, the 17-year-old pulled her hair down over her face. Her face was covered with sores, and she looked down at the floor as she told of spending nearly a year in a women's prison. **********''When I was in jail,'' she said, ''they tortured me to get the truth out of me. But what truth? I was never involved in anything.'' A neighbor, she said, had told the authorities of suspecting that she was a member of the leftist opposition. **********The young woman is one of about 40 Salvadorans living in a camp that is being run at the fairgrounds here by the country's new threemember Amnesty Commission. The camp is for prisoners released during a 60-day amnesty period that started in early May. A Need for a Safe Haven **********So far 496 prisoners have been freed, and 61 Salvadorans have come out of hiding and asked for amnesty. Most have gone directly to their homes. The camp is for those who feel a need for a safe haven for a time or a place where they can get help in obtaining jobs or visas for leaving the country. They stay an average of two weeks. **********Most of those interviewed at the camp said they believed they never should have been arrested in the first place. They also said they wanted to leave El Salvador as soon as possible. **********A 31-year-old man who had spent a year in jail hailed the legislation that offered the amnesty as ''a great thing.'' ''But those people who want to be subversives will never use the amnesty,'' he added. Arrests Are Continuing **********Some diplomats and church sources assert that, while the Government is freeing primarily innocent people, the police continue to arrest Salvadorans suspected of having political ties to opponents of the Government. **********At the same time, the Legal Aid Office of the Roman Catholic Archbishop here estimates that in the first four months of this year, 1,961 Salvadorans were killed by unknown assailants or disappeared.  The office contends that right-wing death squads or Government security forces were responsible for most of the deaths. **********In the last two weeks, armed men in civilian clothes arrested 15 Salvadorans in the Western provinces of Ahuachapan and Santa Ana.  They are being held by the National Police. **********One of the 15 - Dr. Marco Enrique Vasquez, who is from Ahuachapan -worked for a local army base and prison. He was arrested after he was said to have treated patients with connections to leftist organizations. **********Col. Reynaldo Lopez Nuila, director of the National Police, said the 15 arrests were part of a continuing investigation. In the last month, he said, the police have made 40 to 60 arrests. Under the country's state of siege law, suspects can be held 15 days without being charged. **********The colonel said that, upon arrest, a person may be visited by a doctor and by representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Government's Human Rights Commission. Families of three of the men arrested in Ahuachapan, however, said they were not notified of their son's or husband's whereabouts for several days. Life at the Camp **********At the Amnesty Commission's camp, there are haircuts to be had, new clothes to slip on, adequate food and a three-member commission that tries to put the former political prisoners or guerrillas at ease.  Nevertheless, nearly all the former prisoners interviewed said they believed they were not safe in El Salvador. Two prisoners who were released before the law went into effect were found dead here by the Red Cross; some reports said they had been killed by uniformed men. **********Dr. Kirio Waldo Salgado, a member of the Amnesty Commission, said 59 former political prisoners had been in contact with the panel, and he estimated that 80 percent of these were trying to obtain exit visas. **********It is unclear how many of the Salvadorans freed have already left the country. Mexico, Canada, Belgium and possibly Australia will accept political refugees, Dr. Waldo Salgado said. **********Like the young woman who was implicated by her neighbor, most of the former political prisoners say they are still confused as to how they managed to end up spending the last year in jail. **********One 21-year-old man sat with his mother and uncle waiting to be interviewed by the commission. He was a student a year ago when armed guards came to his home. He said he had never been involved in any political activities and was never accused of a crime in the 12 months that he spent in jail. **********''We were always supporters of the Government,'' said his mother, who was anxious to get her son a visa to leave the country. ''But we don't know what to think now.'' Forced to Join the Guerrillas **********A 30-year-old man at the Amnesty Commission's camp said he had been forced to join the guerrillas and stayed with them for 15 days before slipping away one evening. **********''I deserted because we were treated badly and poorly fed,'' he said.  Another of the men at the camp said he had narrowly missed being arrested by the National Police in Ahuachapan on June 10. His wife was in a hospital, he said, and he was visiting her when armed men went on a door-to-door search for the Salvadorans suspected of having ties to the left. **********The young man, who said he had been working with one of El Salvador's five guerrilla groups as a political agent, learned that the police had visited his sister's house. **********Afraid that he would eventually be arrested and killed, he said, he fled, riding on the back of a truck to San Salvador to seek out the Amnesty Commission.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.main_headline: SOVIET AIDE IMPLIES SAKHAROV IS MENTALLY ILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.print_headline: SOVIET AIDE IMPLIES SAKHAROV IS MENTALLY ILL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/09/world.body_text: **********A prominent Soviet official implied at a news conference today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner, was mentally disturbed. **********The official, Vitaly P. Ruben, who is chairman of one of the two houses of the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, called Dr. Sakharov ''a talented but sick man'' and said an article the physicist published in the West earlier this year had invited an American nuclear strike on the Soviet Union. **********''A sane person would not say such things,'' Mr. Ruben said, tapping his head with his forefinger in a gesture suggesting mental trouble. **********Dr. Sakharov's article, which was smuggled out and published in Foreign Affairs, warned the West against letting the Soviet Union gain a nuclear advantage. The Soviet press condemned the article, implying that Dr. Sakharov was a traitor. **********Mr. Ruben spoke at a news conference marking United Nations Human Rights Day. His remarks about Dr. Sakharov were in response to questions from Western reporters. **********The questions focused on Dr. Sakharov's banishment in Gorky in 1980 in an evident effort to isolate him from Western contacts. Gorky, a city of 1.4 million people, is closed to foreigners. **********Mr. Ruben, a former Premier and President of the Soviet Latvian republic, is chairman of the Soviet of Nationalities, one of the two chambers of Parliament. He said the order to exile Dr. Sakharov to Gorky stemmed from ''humane considerations'' involving his health. Those who issued the order ''sought to help a sick person,'' he said, and were concerned ''mainly for his peace of mind.'' **********Mr. Ruben occupies a position of little policy-making significance. Nonetheless, Western diplomats attending the news conference said they were concerned at the possibility that the remarks might reflect a view at higher levels in the Soviet hierarchy. **********The confinement of dissidents to psychiatric institutions has been a common expedient in recent years. Dr. Sakharov's wife, Yelena G. Bonner, has told Western reporters of her worry that the authorities might be planning to place her husband in an institution. **********At another point Mr. Ruben said the decision to exile Dr. Sakharov from Moscow was also intended to keep him from divulging secret information to Western ''emissaries, correspondents or whatever guise they may come in.'' Dr. Sakharov was a key figure in Soviet nuclear weapons development until he began publicly questioning policies in the late 1960's. **********His familiarity with secret data was also cited by Tass, the Government press agency, earlier this year when it disclosed an official decision to deny Dr. Sakharov permission to go abroad. The physicist has received numerous invitations to teach and conduct research in the West. **********During his time in Gorky, Dr. Sakharov has suffered from an old heart ailment, possibly aggravated by a hunger strike he undertook with his wife in 1981 in a bid to win approval for the emigration of his daughter-in-law to the United States. The bid succeeded, and the young woman now lives in Boston with her husband. **********Mr. Ruben said that, apart from being confined to the city of Gorky, Dr. Sakharov lived ''a normal life'' and was able to continue his research. The official also referred to medical treatment that he said the physicist was receiving. **********''The Soviet doctors are taking all necessary measures to restore his health,'' he said. ''They are treating him at home.''
