https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/14/busin.body_text: **********ANTHONY F. ISIDORE has left Isidore Lefkowitz Elgort, of which he was president, and opened the doors yesterday of Isidore & Paulson with Paul J. Paulson, former president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc., the New York office of DDB International. **********So ends the 15-year relationship of Tony Isidore, Marvin Lefkowitz and Robert K. Elgort that began at Young & Rubicam, where as a team they first won wide attention as creators of the ''Give a damn'' campaign for the New York Urban Coalition and the advertising that helped put John V. Lindsay in City Hall. **********Mr. Isidore's two former partners, Mr. Lefkowitz, the art director, and Mr. Elgort, who is a copywriter like Mr. Isidore, are joining Wells, Rich, Greene as group creative directors. **********The Isidore Lefkowitz Elgort agency, though, will remain a subsidiary of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, as it has been since 1979. But some of the accounts that had been there are now being served by the 15 employees at Isidore & Paulson in its space at 485 Madison Avenue. **********Those accounts, which Mr. Isidore thinks will be billing $11 million by year's end, are the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, KYW News Radio in Philadelphia and the First National Bank of Chicago, for which it is doing a special project. **********Additionally there is a client that cannot for the moment be named. And it was on this assignment that Mr. Isidore and Mr. Paulson, both 50 years old, test-marketed a partnership. They found, they reported in a joint interview yesterday, that they work well together. **********Actually, the two - brought together by a mutual acquaintance -had been having frequent conversations since December. The initial concept was that Mr. Paulson would join I.L.E. and supply the marketing muscle that had been missing from the beginning in 1973. **********That missing ingredient, Mr. Isidore says now, is what kept his old agency from making it. Despite its promise and good press, the shop never really did make the big time. **********Asked about this yesterday, he said: ''We didn't have an adequate defense against the big agencies. They have the marketing strength that small agencies can't respond to. Now we can offer an unusual combination of both.'' **********Mr. Paulson, who is president and chief executive of the new agency, while Mr. Isidore is chairman and creative director, had worked on Procter & Gamble business for 20 years, most of that time at Compton Advertising. When he joined D.D.B. in 1977 as a senior vice president-managing director, and when he was later named president of the New York operation, there were those who thought that D.D.B., renowned for all its traditional creative strengths, was trying to bolster up its marketing side. **********Mr. Paulson, a former Navy lieutenant, graduated from Ohio State and from the Wharton School, where Compton recruited him.  His new partner is a Rutgers graduate who worked at Rumrill-Hoyt before joining Y.& R. In 12 years there, he rose to copy chief.  When he and his two associates left Young & Rubicam in 1971, their first step was Lois Holland Callaway, where Mr. Isidore was president under George Lois, the chairman. **********The three left when they decided they knew how to run their own agency.  Mr. Isidore maintained that his parting with Della Femina, Travisano has been amicable. The top management of that agency is traveling on the Continent (how fashionable!) and could not be reached for comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/11/busin.body_text: **********The Justice Department's antitrust chief, William F. Baxter, was sharply criticized by members of a House subcommittee today, and one suggested that Mr. Baxter resign for failure to uphold the law. **********Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, accused Mr. Baxter of refusing to prosecute companies involved in price fixing. **********''I think that any public official who can't abide by or uphold the law should step aside,'' Mr. Hughes said. **********Mr. Baxter conceded that his department had not filed any suits involving vertical price fixing, in which a company illegally determines retail prices, but said he had instructed his staff to look for such cases. **********Mr. Baxter told the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Monopolies and Commercial Law that some ''unduly restrictive antitrust rules'' should be changed. **********Several Democrats, including the Judiciary Committee's chairman, Peter W. Rodino Jr. of New Jersey, said they feared the Reagan Administration was backing away from antitrust prosecution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Federal bank regulators today began operating the Fidelity Federal Savings and Loan in a rare takeover in the wake of an order last August that the institution stop improper business practices. **********The temporary cease-and-desist order was ''not sufficient to cure the problem'' so the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has decided to manage Fidelity until it is merged with a financially stronger institution, a spokesman for the bank board, Bob Moore, said Sunday night. **********Four of the institution's top officers were dismissed Friday after board officials arrived unannounced at Fidelity's downtown headquarters and five branches. **********''The bank board reached the judgment that the financial condition of the institution and the business practices of the management warranted the action we took by appointing a conservator,'' Mr. Moore said. **********While declining to discuss Fidelity's financial situation, Mr.  Moore emphasized that the institution would continue conducting business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/21/busin.body_text: **********AN observant person would probably conclude that marathon runners are not poor, and rarely blue-collar. Athletic activity that borders on self-induced torture seems to attract the well-to-do, the type that advertisers look for. **********If the degree of ruggedness somehow upgrades advertising audiences, and if you are an advertiser looking for an upscale market, then Lyn Lemaire has news for you. **********It is a six-issues-a-year magazine named Ultrasport that will concentrate on long-distance running, cycling, swimming and cross-country skiing. Other activities will be featured, too: sculling, for example, or even ballet dancing. **********''We're not about any one thing,'' the publisher said, ''but about people who have a mind-set about athleticism, are hooked on it.'' **********The first issue, January-February, is already printed and due at newsstands and sporting goods stores on Jan. 3. It is a professional and slick piece of work and contains 22 pages of advertising, mostly for running shoes and bicycles. **********The cover price is $2.50 and the annual subscription, $10.95. **********So far 22,000 have subscribed and the publisher, Endurance Sports Inc., in Boston, has set the rate base at 50,000. The subscribers are generally college-educated, in their 30's and with average incomes of $32,000. And research tells the publisher that the universe is about nine million. **********In a visit to New York the other day, Miss Lemaire said 200,000 is a likely short-range circulation goal. **********She understands her audience because she herself is a dedicated athlete. So much so that she chose not to follow in the footsteps of her late father, who was a lawyer, when she graduated from Harvard Law School last June. Her desire to combine work with pleasure led to the concept of Ultrasport, which was born during a phone conversation with Karen B. Maloney, formerly of Business Week and Inc. magazines and now marketing and circulation director. **********Miss Lemaire, 32 years old, swam long-distance as a teen-ager and later played on the women's basketball team at the University of California at Los Angeles, where she was graduated in 1974 Phi Beta Kappa. She turned to individual sports and specialized for a while in cycle racing. In 1979, she combined her skills and was the only woman to finish the Iron Man  Triathlon in Hawaii, a 2.4-mile ocean swim, a 112-mile cycle race and a full marathon. **********Her interest in such endeavors goes beyond the mere physical, as her master's degree in applied physiology and anatomy from Boston University would indicate. **********She thinks deep thoughts about sports and about why such solitary pastimes as long-distance running and swimming are so popular. ''The sense of satisfaction and accomplishment may be difficult to acquire otherwise, since everyone in most fields is dependent on the opinions of others,'' she said. **********Money for the adventure is coming from an investment by Robert S. Kretschmar's Seavex, an advertising representatives firm, and from a limited partnership established for the purpose. **********Some of the money went for subscription-solicitation brochures given out at marathon meets, and for ads with a similar purpose that appeared in 13 special-interest magazines. **********The results caused some optimism at headquarters. They were expected to bring a one-quarter of 1 percent response, but instead brought between four-tenths and five-tenths of 1 percent. **********Now the company has two direct- mail drops scheduled, one of 85,000 in January and one of 800,000 in July. Most will be sent to names on magazine subscription lists. **********The editor is Chris Bergonzi, 28, a graduate of Harvard and the Columbia School of Journalism, who once sold advertising for The Runner magazine and was editor of New York Running News. Mel Weinberger, the ad director, also worked for Runner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.main_headline: SILVER UP 5¦ AN OUNCE; GOLD FUTURES PRICES SLIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.print_headline: COMMODITIES; SILVER UP 5¦ AN OUNCE; GOLD FUTURES PRICES SLIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/17/busin.body_text: **********Silver futures traders waited in vain again yesterday for either the price to break through the $15-an-ounce level or for the threemonth advance to end in huge profit taking. Instead, the active near March contract closed up 5 cents an ounce at $14.75, after ranging between $14.89 and $14.67 on New York's Commodity Exchange. **********''The silver market has reached an awkward point,'' said Martin M.  McNeill, senior vice president of the Sinclair Group, a leading metals brokerage house. ''On the one hand, one finds the market extremely bullish; on the other, everyone knows that a major correction is inevitable.'' **********But waiting for a sizable retreat has been frustrating and costly since the latest advance in silver began last November, when the price jumped above the $9 level. Subsequent countdowns began just before and after the price of the metal reached ''whole numbers,'' or full dollars, Mr. McNeill said, noting: **********''From $10 onward, as the silver price neared or passed a round number, two things happened. One, those who had paper profits decided it was prudent to convert some of them into cash, while others sold the metal short, also in expectation of a correction. Although these moves tended to blunt the advance for a few days, they didn't halt the rally. Now the countdown is on the $15 level.'' **********Silver last sold for $15 an ounce in the early days of January 1981, a year after the metal fetched a record price of $50. Because silver is still selling at a third of its record level, most speculators do not think $15 is too high a price to pay for a metal that sold for below $6 last June 21, based on the near March futures contract. **********But even they are hesitant to climb aboard a rally that has not had a significant correction in three months, Mr. McNeill added.  Howard Levine, vice president and chief metals trader at ACLI International Commodity Services Inc., said the belief that prices would rise much further was based largely on the belief that any significant economic recovery would be beneficial to silver, which is basically an industrial metal. Mr. Levine said: **********''Many buyers also view silver as an inflation hedge, believing that the only way the industrialized nations and the poorer heavily indebted countries can solve their economic and financial problems is through massive reinflation.'' **********As for the failure of gold futures to rise with silver, as has been the pattern recently, he said: ''Gold has been under some pressure because of heavy Swiss selling the past two days. Whether these sales were on behalf of producing countries has not been ascertained as yet.'' **********Yesterday, the Comex spot February gold futures closed off 10 cents an ounce at $505.70, while the active April contract slipped 50 cents, to $511. ''As is the case with silver,'' Mr. Levine said, ''gold traders are also waiting for a correction and are wary of adding to positions over the $500 level until this happens.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.main_headline: LITTLE CHANCE SEEN OF CUTS IN DEFICITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.print_headline: LITTLE CHANCE SEEN OF CUTS IN DEFICITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/12/busin.body_text: **********With Congress returning to work Monday, the economic outlook is still good. But the chances for shrinking the Government's record budget deficits are fading. **********The curious twist is that, if the economy were getting worse, the fiscal outlook might be improving. As the situation stands now, the Government and the economy face the prospect of $200 billion annual budget deficits. **********Congressional leaders involved in the spending and tax decisions have acknowledged in interviews that the chances of raising taxes this fall or making further reductions in projected spending are very slim. **********At the same time, they say the failure to meet the tax and spending targets in the Congress's own budget outline could deal a serious blow to the budget process. Refusal to meet these objectives would be the first wholesale rejection of the budget process since the beginning of the Reagan Administration. **********While economists argue over whether the economy will suffer from this problem, nobody knows for sure what will happen. Said one Congressional economist who asked not to be named, ''There is a very strong possibility the recovery will continue through 1984 with these deficits. But the question is, should we take such a high risk?'' **********Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, said: ''I don't think we can do anything without the President's support. I believe the Administration will try to muddle through until the elections are behind them. I don't see any break in the stalemate.'' **********Today, on NBC News's television interview program, Meet the Press, Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and the chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, also spoke about a move to cut the budget deficit. ''I say this as candidly as I can,'' Mr. Dole said. ''Without the help of the President and the Speaker, it's going nowhere.'' **********There is no sign that the President, who has admantly opposed any tax increases this year or next, is going to change his mind. Last week, the Treasury's assistant secretary for tax policy, John E. Chapoton, said that even the President's standby tax increase proposal is ''dead for this year.'' That proposal asked Congress to approve this year a three-year, $145 billion package of tax increases that would become effective Oct. 1, 1985, if the deficits are still too high.  No Mandate From Constituents **********Representative James R. Jones, a Democrat and chairman of the House Budget Committee, as he was touring his Oklahoma district last week, said, ''Members are not going to come back with marching orders from their constituents to cut spending and raise taxes.'' **********Mr. Jones said that as of now he does not expect Congress will raise the $73 billion in taxes over three years or cut the $12 billion in spending called for in the budget resolution that Congress approved in June. ''We are going to try to dispense our obligations,'' he said of his committee. ''But trying and succeeding are very different things.'' **********The first signal of the inability of Congress to meet the requirements of the budget resolution is expected to come by Sept. 23, the deadline for committees in the House and the Senate to send their budget committees' proposals for tax increases and spending reductions. **********''I don't see how we can'' meet the deadline, said Mr. Rostenkowski, whose committee must propose the tax increases. Some staff aides in the House and the Senate expect the first move to be an extension of the deadline, but they think this will just delay the inevitable. **********Representative Leon E. Panetta, a Democrat from California and a member of the House Budget Committee, noted that ''It's a harmful blow for the budget process.'' **********If, for example, the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee refused to propose the tax increases called for in the budget resolution, the committees could bring their own proposals to the floor of the House and the Senate. But Mr. Jones and Mr. Rostenkowski acknowledged that the Democratic leadership in the House would be reluctant to take such a move because it would allow the President and other Republicans to use a vote for tax increases against the Democrats next year. **********''The leadership will have to weigh the budget process versus the political process,'' said Mr. Jones. **********In the first two years of the Reagan Administration, the prospect of large budget deficits galvanized Congress and the Administration into agreeing on additional spending reductions and tax increases. But this year there is no new momentum to work to reduce budget deficits because nothing went wrong with the economy during the summer recess.  Favorable Economic Data **********Before leaving in early August, Mr. Jones, Mr. Rostenkowski, Mr. Dole and others said it would take a sharp rise in interest rates or some other negative economic data to focus attention on the deficit and enable Congressional leaders to force the Administration into discussing both tax increases and spending reductions. **********But while interest rates began to rise some in August, they have declined slightly recently. And the data on the growing recovery are showing a vibrant, but not too strong, rebound, As a result, the stock market, taking heart, appears ready to move to another record high. **********With this deficit outlook, the pressure will fall mostly on the Federal Reserve, as it has in the past, to steer the course of the economy. Opinions differ on what will happen. **********Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the nation's central bank, has argued that the projected deficits will keep interest rates high, especially long-term rates, which will make the recovery slower than it would otherwise be. **********In addition, he contends that large deficits will bring nearer the day when interest rates are forced high enough, by the increased competition between Government and private borrowing, to shut down the recovery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/26/busin.body_text: **********As the latest entry in the expanding field of small computers, the Tandy Corporation will announce Tuesday a four-pound, $795 machine that is a text editor, bookkeeper, appointment calendar and telephone directory. **********Tandy calls the battery-powered device, the Model 100, an electronic notebook, largely for business executives on the road.  Analysts said yesterday that they were impressed by the machine, both because of the low price and because Tandy was bringing it to market ahead of an expected rush of Japanese competitors. **********Tandy is betting that the functions will satisfy the needs of most executives for a portable computer.  But the programs that direct the Model 100 are built into read-only memory chips. While this fixed programming reduces the cost and size of the machine, it makes it difficult to perform specialty tasks. **********Nor does the Model 100 have much memory capacity. The $795 model can store about 8,000 characters, or roughly four typewritten pages of text. For about $1,100, the company will offer a model with four times more memory. **********The Model 100 is about the size of a fat book, with a rectangular liquid crystal display screen across the top. The user can see eight lines at a time, each of them 40 characters long. **********While the keyboard feels like a typewriter, some of the more common text-editing tasks, such as moving paragraphs or deleting words, require several keystrokes. **********The most advanced feature is the telecommunications package, which will automatically dial the telephone and send and receive information from an office computer or another data base. **********''It is an interesting machine and it will do well,'' said Clive Smith, with the Yankee Group in Boston. ''Tandy's strategy is to have a product for every market and every niche. This machine really fills out the product line.'' **********The appeal to the business user marks a strengthening of the company's efforts to change its image. Tandy, which began as a leather products company, moved three decades ago into relatively inexpensive and lower-quality electronics products. **********In recent years, radios and resistors have taken a back seat to microcomputers at the company's 8,500 Radio Shack stores.  In 1978, when the company turned out its first desktop computers, largely for hobbyists, the sale of computer equipment accounted for 2.4 percent of its store sales; by June 1982, as the company introduced more sophisticated machines, that figure rose above 30 percent. **********Tandy executives said yesterday that the company chose not to attempt to pack more memory and functions into the Model 100 in order to keep costs down. The company plans to make other read-only memories. **********Some analysts speculated that software manufacturers would soon make programs on cartridges that could plug into the Model 100.  Japanese competition in this sector is heating up. Epson has announced a similar machine, but with a smaller screen and capable of performing fewer functions. The Nippon Electric Company is expected to offer a similar computer soon. **********Tandy's stock dipped earlier this week, after a strong performance for several months, following reports that its inventories were rising, sometimes an indication of poor sales. Yesterday it dropped 12 1/2 cents, to $55.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/world.main_headline: Steel and Ship Workers Protest in West Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Steel and Ship Workers Protest in West Germany
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/world.body_text: **********Thousands of West German steel and shipyard workers demonstrated here today in a protest against unemployment and the economic policies of the conservative Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. **********A rally at Bonn University drew crowds of between 85,000 and 130,000, depending on the source of the estimates. **********Organized by West Germany's huge IG Metall metalworkers' union, the protesters criticized Government strategies that are intended to return the nation's steel and shipbuilding industries to profitability. Union leaders said it signaled the start of stiffer labor resistance to the Government's austerity plans. **********Rudolf Judith, a union leader, said Government policies would eliminate 30,000 jobs in steel and 15,000 in shipbuilding by the mid-1980's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.main_headline: MUSIC SPARKS POLITICAL PROTEST OF CHILE YOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.print_headline: MUSIC SPARKS POLITICAL PROTEST OF CHILE YOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/03/world.body_text: **********A popular Chilean folk singer was ostensibly singing a love ballad, but it was the forbidden political meaning and President Augusto Pinochet's Chile that excited the young people crammed into the smoky cafe. **********''Come and participate,'' the singer, Payo Grondona, gently sang.  ''Mobilize all your ardor without repression.'' As he began the next line, ''Tenderness united will never be conquered,'' the audience erupted into a roar accompanied by clapping. The line was a play on the Chilean protest call, ''A people united will never be conquered,'' and they sang it over and over. **********It was an example of the growing popularity of what is called ''canto nuevo,'' or ''new song,'' a music of protest and a search for roots that reflects a political reawakening among Chilean young people. **********As in the 1960's in the United States, the stirring of young people and their music has grown here over the last two years to become a driving force behind the current protests by Chileans demanding a return to democratic rule. The protests have shaken this country, which has been ruled by General Pinochet since he overthrew the Marxist President, Salvador Allende Gossens, 10 years ago. **********Rodolfo Seguel, the jailed union leader who led two national protests in May and June, is only 29 years old. Many of the other union leaders who led copper miners in walking off their jobs two weeks ago in their first political strike against the Government were just as young. **********In recent months some university campuses have become hotbeds of protest. Teen-agers, many frustrated by the lack of jobs - unemployment now stands at a little over 20 percent - have turned at least a half dozen demonstrations into small riots over the last six months. **********Political leaders under the age of 40 are considered the untried youths of their field because political activity has been banned since General Pinochet took power. But it is these young political leaders who have been most vocal in assailing the Government in recent weeks while those who are older have for the most part been silent. **********''We watch with anguish how the existing institutions depart from our juridical history,'' 53 political leaders aged from 30 to 40 said in a statement issued last week. The institutions, the statement went on, ''make it impossible to return to an authentic democratic regime.'' Last Presidential Vote in '70 **********Roughly three million of this Andean nation's 11 million people are between the ages of 18 and 32, according to a 1981 census. They make up 40 percent of the country's eligible voters, but they have never voted in a presidential election. The last one, in 1970, was won by Mr. Allende. **********All Latin America has a history of youth-led uprisings. Student riots protesting against Mr. Allende were part of the chaos in this country that led to his overthrow. But Chilean campuses had been mostly quiet since then as the military took over the administration of both public and private universities. Many leftist student leaders were exiled, jailed or ordered by the Government to leave school. **********Most Chilean youths seemed to prefer a peaceful coexistence with the Government as they turned their attention to practicalities such as studies and jobs and, in the economic boom years of 1976 to 1981, cars and discotheques. **********But the economy is now in depression. The national income shrank 14 percent last year and unemployment soared. Many young Chileans say their political awakening came when they found they could not pay their university tuition or find jobs. **********Memories of the political chaos under Mr. Allende have also faded.  ''The Government's warnings of communism do not carry much weight with the young,'' said a Western diplomat. Youth Secretariat Established **********The Government had set out to enlist youths. The National Youth Secretariat was founded soon after General Pinochet seized power, but its attempts at political education and forming the ''Pinochet Youth Movement'' failed. The secretariat now sponsors mostly sports events. **********Some among the nation's youth support the Government. A conservative intellectual movement formed at Santiago's Catholic University in the late 1960's remains strong on some campuses.  Disenchanted with political parties, the movement calls for cooperation with the military to build a democracy in which business, labor and professional associations would largely replace parties, which have been suspended while the ban on political activity remains. **********The movement was an influence behind the economic and engineering ''whiz kids'' who took over many Government ministries after the 1973 coup. But it is becoming widely discredited as being collaborationist, and even many of the Government technocrats, now aged in their late 30's, are disillusioned. **********''When my job crosses the line to appear political, I quit,'' said a young, highly placed economic official. Music Has Greatest Impact **********The political protest began to emerge when young painters, poets and playwrights tested the limits of Government censorship, which bans anything the Government construes as political. But it is music that has the greatest impact because of its popular access. **********Adherents define canto nuevo as an attitude toward life. ''It is essentially humanist,'' Ricardo Garcia, an impressario and record producer, said in an interview. Mr. Garcia is considered the father of the music because his company produces most of the songs and coined the term for it. **********Its styles include hard rock, Andean Indian tunes and folk songs.  Themes range through the current economic problems, love, hometowns, humorous foibles and the arms race. Political topics usually enter the songs in the form of double-entendres. **********Canto nuevo is closely linked with similar music that has become popular among youths under the military Governments in nearby Argentina and Uruguay as well as mostly apolitical music out of Cuba.  Slant Is Often Leftist **********Its enthusiasts here include soldiers and officials, but it is young professionals and intellectuals who are quickly coming to dominate the music and give it a protest, often leftist, slant. Many self-exiled singers, such as Mr. Grondona, have been returning to add leadership. **********The Government has responded by prohibiting festivals of the music, limiting the amount of time it can be performed on television, and, last year, jailing Mr. Garcia, the record producer, for a week for releasing a song by an exiled singer. **********But the music nonetheless continues to be heard increasingly, often on private radio stations and widely circulated tapes, in church recitals and in the drafty, backstreet cafes such as the one here where young people huddled over hot wine into the early morning hours. **********''We're witnessing our time,'' Pato Valdivia, a popular 28-year-old singer said in an interview. ''Our work is not of yesterday and today, but of tomorrow.'' TO MY CITY (Written by the group Santiago of the New Extreme) Santiago, you're neither in the foothills nor on the sea. How are your streets now that they've taken your nights. Go, take your guitar, your voice will be shared by those who once had something to say. Sing, it's best if you come, for your voice is needed. https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.main_headline: 'DIARIES' OF HITLER IN THE WEST SINCE '45, LONDON PAPER SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.print_headline: 'DIARIES' OF HITLER IN THE WEST SINCE '45, LONDON PAPER SAYS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/02/world.body_text: **********The documents purported to be the secret diaries of Hitler are now said to have been in the West for nearly 40 years, The Sunday Times of London reported today. **********The paper, which bought publication rights from the West German magazine Stern, said the documents were originally thought to have been in a hayloft in East Germany since a plane carrying them crashed in 1945. **********A Stern reporter, Gerd Heidemann, who said he had obtained the 60 volumes of documents, told The Sunday Times that the papers had been retrieved from the burning aircraft and put in the hayloft at Bornersdorf, in the southeastern corner of East Germany, for only a few days. **********''Heidemann says that, in the chaos and confusion of the collapse of the Third Reich in 1945, a German officer succeeded in transporting the papers, held in a large case, to the West,'' The Sunday Times said. **********This officer, the newspaper said, kept the papers until giving them to Mr. Heidemann, and they are now lodged in a Swiss bank. The man, now over 70 years old, had insisted that his name never be made public, The Sunday Times quoted Mr. Heidemann as saying. **********The paper said it would go ahead with publishing excerpts from the documents later this month, ''unless on the balance of probability they are shown not to be authentic.'' **********Prominent historians, including a British biographer of Hitler, Hugh Trevor-Roper, who originally advised The Sunday Times that the diaries were genuine, have said they might be fakes. **********The Sunday Times, reporting on its own investigation into their authenticity, said today that it had found references to Hitler's having kept a diary in intelligence papers at the United States National Archives in Washington. **********One reference said a Nazi security official, Wilhelm Spacil, questioned by the Americans after the war, had asserted that he had heard of the diaries' existence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/10/busin.body_text: **********When the Postal Telegraph-Cable Company delivered what it claimed was the world's first singing telegram on Feb. 10, 1933, it may have been 50 years or so ahead of its time. The idea was good, but not good enough to save its telegraph business, and the company soon merged with Western Union. **********The idea, however, lived on. Today, after many lean years, the singing telegram has re-emerged as a multimillion-dollar business offered through a network of musical competitors - which typically charge $25 to $100 per delivery. And a substantial peripheral business in cookie-grams, balloon-grams, stripper-grams and the like has also sprung up. **********''In the first 30 years or so it was never done right - it really was not entertainment,'' observed Robert J. Jasper, who says ''starvation'' brought him to found a singing telegram company, Western Onion, four years ago. ''It was only in the last few years that companies like mine all over the country have made it entertainment. I call it vaudeville to go.'' **********But the singing telegram business has long had a touch of vaudeville. On July 28, 1933, a Western Union operator named Lucille Lipps sang ''Happy Birthday'' to Rudy Vallee. Mr. Vallee later recalled the episode as ''a phony stunt by the publicity people,'' although Western Union recalls it as the first singing telegram. **********Despite initial criticism by Western Union executives concerned with the propriety of the medium, the company's messengers delivered musical greetings in person until World War II. Singing by phone operators was resumed after the war, but faced declining popularity until Western Union dropped the service in 1974. **********Singing telegrams have seen a rebirth of sorts in the last decade.  Two New York companies, Music Box Musical Messages and Garrett-Gram, revived the idea in 1973, adding catchy lyrics and a Broadway-style delivery. The idea caught on fast, and dozens of companies entered the field. Even Western Union, which dropped its own service in 1974, has jumped back in, delivering about 50 orders a day via Music Box.  ''Times change and we discovered that there is a market,'' said Donald Detcher, a Western Union spokesman. ''There are novelties and fads of all sorts and all of a sudden they reappear. We simply respond to the public's demand to communicate.'' **********Some say the musical message boom peaked two or three years ago, but business today is still strong. Singing telegram operations with names like Fleeting Greetings, Otter Conspiracy and Telebelles dot the Yellow Pages in most major cities, and at least four companies deliver greetings nationwide. Selling Franchises **********The giant in the field, a Las Vegas, Nev., company called Eastern Onion, claims sales of more than $8 million a year from novelty telegrams of all kinds - or roughly 180,000 messages. It has sold 42 franchises at $15,000 to $25,000 apiece, plus 5 percent of revenues, and business ''is getting better and better,'' according to Jim Flatt, its president. **********The industry is not universally untroubled, however. One of the largest services, National Singing Telegrams Ltd., which also was once named Western Onion, dropped out of business last year, as have many smaller companies. And Mr. Jasper's Western Onion, a Spokane, Wash., service that specializes in tutu-bedecked serenaders, is being sued by Western Union over its name. **********More important, the business is crowded - perhaps overcrowded.  ''There must be thousands of really small singing telegram groups all over the country,'' said Mr. Flatt of Eastern Onion. ''You've got to freshen up your ideas all the time to stay in.'' **********Dick Miller, a former theatrical agent who founded Garrett-Gram in 1972, concurred. ''Everyone all over is doing singing telegrams, but a lot of them have gone out of business,'' he said. ''Three or four years ago it became more a trend than anything else, and now the trend is curbing back to reality. Because of the bad economy, people are sending singing telegrams carefully.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/world.main_headline: ARGENTINA MOVES TO CLEAR BARRIER TO TALKS ON LOANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/world.print_headline: ARGENTINA MOVES TO CLEAR BARRIER TO TALKS ON LOANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/06/world.body_text: **********A federal appeals court today removed a major obstacle to the resumption of the international negotiations needed to refinance Argentina's huge foreign debt and to keep fresh loans flowing into the country. **********The court stripped a local judge of jurisdiction over a case that had effectively blocked the signing of refinancing agreements for the $40 billion debt. Without those agreements, foreign banks have been unwilling for the past week to pay out new loans needed by Argentina to keep up with interest payments. More than $500 million in loans have been held up. **********The local judge, Federico Pinto Kramer of Rio Gallegos, a Patagonian city 1,300 miles south of here, also appeared to soften his stand. **********Banker Held for Two Days **********The judge released from jail Julio Gonzalez del Solar, the president of the central bank, who had been detained since Monday for questioning about a refinancing contract that the judge considered a violation of national sovereignty. Nevertheless, the judge said, the investigation of Mr. Gonzalez del Solar would continue. **********Foreign banks have frozen all fresh credits to Argentina since Judge Pinto Kramer ruled on Sept. 24 that planned refinancing agreements on much of the nation's $40 billion in foreign debt violated ''national sovereignty'' by giving New York State courts some jurisdiction over payment disputes. **********He specifically cited the refinancing of $200 million owed by Aerolineas Argentinas, the state airline. That contract was considered a model for agreements to refinance $5.5 billion in debts of other state entities. **********A Standard Clause **********The clause permitting jurisdiction to courts in New York, where many major bank lenders are situated, is standard in many international loan agreements. **********The judge's objections reflected the rising public criticism of the refinancing efforts, particularly the jurisdiction clauses, which have been publicly characterized as an affront to Argentina's sovereignty. **********Nevertheless, there has been no call for repudiation of the foreign debt. The major party candidates in the national election, scheduled for Oct. 30 and the first in a decade, have called for a postponement of negotiations until a civilian government takes office in January, in hopes of improving repayment terms. But they have also asserted that the debts would be repaid. **********The first signs of a solution to the cur rent refinancing crisis came early today when Enrique Billote, head of the appeals court in the Patagonian city of Comodoro Rivadavia, took jurisdiction of the case from Judge Pinto Kramer and told reporters that he considered the Government's appeal of the judge's ruling ''well founded.'' He expects to rule on the appeal this week. **********''It looks like we're on the road to a solution,'' said an American banker in Buenos Aires, who asked not to be identified. ''But the whole affair raises questions about the risk of lending to this country.'' **********For more than a week, according to foreign bankers and economic officials, Argentina has been on the brink of default because it has not kept up with interest payments on the $40 billion debt, the world's third largest. Top officials here of American banks said today that the arrears had risen to several hundred million dollars. **********Earlier Steps by Central Bank **********Last Friday, the central bank blocked the purchasing of dollars to take out of the country, a move intended to preserve foreign reserves. These have dwindled to $200 million, according to foreign diplomats, from more than $600 million a month ago. **********Today, the bank also ordered commercial banks to turn over dollars they receive in payment for Argentine exports. The banks otherwise could use the dollars to cover withdrawals from dollar accounts held in Argentine banks. **********Adding to the crisis atmosphere, many Argentines jammed banks today to try to make withdrawals from their dollar accounts, which are allowed only for certain savings deposits, for fear deposits might be nationalized. **********Diplomatic sourcess said there was as much as $700 million deposited in dollars in Argentine banks, although bankers said the amount has been dropping steadily. **********Depositors standing in lines outside banks said today that they feared the Government would nationalize dollar deposits altogether and convert them to pesos, as Mexico did in a similar crisis earlier this year. **********Mr. Gonzalez del Solar, the central bank president, had been held at Judge Pinto Kramer's ''disposition'' in Rio Gallegos, where he was flown after being taken into custody on Monday as he returned from a meeting in Washington of the International Monetary Fund. **********Charges May Be Filed **********The judge said today that he was considering charging the banker with ''prejudicing'' national interests in approving the debt contracts. The charge is one step below treason and conviction carries a jail sentence of up to 20 years. **********Judge Pinto Kramer said he had interrogated the banker this morning. **********''We cannot put the sovereignty of Argentina below the laws of New York State,'' the judge said. **********The judge, who is 39 years old, said he had been coming ''under pressure from all sides,'' receiving telephone calls and visits from officials, businessmen and politicians pressing him to either release or prosecute the bank president, depending on the caller's position in the growing political dispute here over the foreign debt. **********Judge Pinto Kramer said he would not be railroaded in his investigation. **********''I feel peaceful with myself,'' he said, ''because I know I am acting under the guidance of the law. I don't have anything to do with politics.'' **********As for Mr. Gonzalez del Solar, 67, a Harvard University graduate who has held top economic positions in many governments and in the International Monetary Fund, he spent last night in the Rio Gallegos jail, officials said. They said he was treated courteously.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/06/busin.body_text: **********Industrial production and the level of new orders rose in May, but the pace of the increases was slower than in April, corporate purchasing managers reported yesterday. **********In its monthly report on business, the National Association of Purchasing Management said the level of industrial expansion in May reflected a slowdown that ''comes a little sooner than it did after the last two recessions.'' The findings ''lend credence to the projection that this recovery will be more gradual,'' the group said. **********But Bernard Schoenfeld, an economist at the Irving Trust Company, said it was important to note that the economy was particularly strong in April. ''There were very few things that did not rise at a rapid pace in April,'' he said. 'Forward Momentum' Seen **********''The only exception was housing starts, and that was weatherrelated,'' he said. ''It looks like the forward momentum of the economy is being maintained.'' **********The group bases its report on a poll of purchasing managers at 250 industrial concerns. The executives are asked about the levels of new orders, production, employment and inventories at their companies, as well as the speed of deliveries from suppliers. **********The association said its composite index of industrial expansion stood at 55.1 percent in May, slightly lower than April's 57.1 percent reading. According to the group's method of tabulation, a reading above 50 percent on the index means the economy is expanding. **********The group said 33 percent of those executives polled reported higher production levels in May, compared with 37 percent in April, and 9 percent reported lower production levels, compared with 8 percent. New Orders on Rise **********New orders rose slightly, with 33 percent of the managers saying they had more orders in May than in the previous month, and 13 percent reporting a lower level of orders. In April, 40 percent had reported more orders, while 10 percent reported lower order levels. **********May employment levels remained flat, with 16 percent of the companies reporting increased personnel levels and another 16 percent reporting lower employment. In April, the poll had shown 18 percent of the companies adding personnel, with 17 percent cutting employment. **********Prices for industrial supplies rose, as they did in April, the association said: 28 percent of the managers reported higher prices in May, with only 4 percent reporting lower prices. **********Among products reported rising in price were fuel oil, aluminum, copper, steel, corn, gasoline and fine paper.  Most managers polled were more willing to commit themselves to purchase orders months in advance.  The group maintains that the speed of delivery is an important sign of overall economic activity because slow deliveries tend to mean that suppliers have backlogs of orders. In May, it said, supplier deliveries continued to slow down for the fourth consecutive month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.main_headline: AMERICAN ECONOMY SEEN UNAFFECTED BY REALIGNMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.print_headline: AMERICAN ECONOMY SEEN UNAFFECTED BY REALIGNMENT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/22/busin.body_text: **********The realignment of currency values in the European Monetary System -the third in the last 13 months -should quiet the foreign-exchange markets for the time being, bankers in New York said yesterday. They added that the realignment should have little direct impact on the American economy or the cost in this country, for example, of West German automobiles or French wines. **********''From the viewpoint of the dollar, this was a non-event,'' said Rimmer deVries, chief international economist for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. ''The realignment was strictly an internal European affair. The important issue for the U.S. is the overvaluation of the dollar in relation to the yen.'' **********More fundamentally, however, analysts said the turmoil in Europe's foreign-exchange markets in the last few days highlighted a basic weakness in the world economy: failure of the major industrial nations to coordinate their economic policies, particularly their monetary policies.Focus on Monetary Growth **********''The European Monetary System is a fundamentally flawed idea,'' declared Allan H. Meltzer, professor of economics at Carnegie-Mellon University and a prominent monetarist. ''It tries to fix foreign exchange rates without fixing monetary growth rates. It should be the reverse.'' Most economists - monetarist and nonmonetarist alike - agree that some policy coordination is necessary before currency stabilization can be achieved. **********On the broader economic issue, economists said unstable currency values had bred an uncertainty that slowed world trade last year for the second consecutive year, aggravating the world recession. **********According to the secretariat of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the physical volume of goods moving in international commerce fell 2 percent last year, while their dollar value was down 6 percent amid a decline in oil prices. **********''The uncertainty in the exchange markets is without parallel,'' said Eugene A. Birnbaum, a private economic consultant in New York.Paris-Bonn Tension Is Noted **********Mr. Birnbaum has long advocated returning to a fixed, but adjustable, system of foreign-exchange rates like the one set up at Bretton Woods, N.H., in 1944. That system collapsed in the early 1970's. **********The worldwide problem of monetary coordination and currency instability, economists said, was illustrated in the tension between France and West Germany this weekend. **********The French money supply, according to data published by the International Monetary Fund, grew at a rate of about 14 percent in 1981 and 1982 under the Government of President Francois Mitterrand. Many economists believe that this rapid monetary growth contributed to inflation in France. **********By comparison, the West Germans - under the administrations of both Helmut Schmidt and Helmut Kohl -have followed a much tighter monetary policy and thus have a much lower inflation rate and lower interest rates. West Germany's money supply rose at an average rate of less than 2 percent over the last two years, and inflation has averaged 5.25 percent.Comparison of Interest Rates **********Short-term interest rates in France have been averaging slightly over 13 percent this month, while those in West Germany were less than 6 percent. **********The 5.5 percent increase in the value of the mark and the 2.5 percent cut in the value of the French franc announced yesterday were intended to compensate for the price disparities that had developed because of the differing trends in the two countries. **********Horst Duisberg, who oversees foreign-exchange trading for the European-American Bank, said the effect of the currency realignment would depend a great deal on how much Mr. Mitterrand was willing to do to slow inflation in France. **********''We'll know more on Wednesday,'' Mr. Duisberg said, ''after Mitterrand makes his announcement. He has to do some unpopular things - raise taxes, cut imports and get inflation down.''Proposal for a 3-Nation Link **********Professor Meltzer has proposed that the central banks and governments of the United States, West Germany and Japan link their monetary policies in such a way as to eliminate inflation gradually. **********''Other countries that wish to do so could make a similar commitment,'' he said, ''or could fix their exchange rates in relation to one of the three currencies or could remain outside the system.'' **********He argued that the proposal would help reduce uncertainty and increase stability in a number of ways.  ''There is a stable framework for policy that reduces uncertainty about the future price level,'' Professor Meltzer said. ''Exchange rates are free to fluctuate, but long-term changes are limited by the commitment to stable policies. The system would adjust gradually to changes in the growth of output or the demand for money.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS;  Treasury Prices Up Modestly
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/22/busin.body_text: **********Prices rose modestly for short- and long-term Treasury securities yesterday, although market participants said many potential institutional investors were inactive and are waiting for Treasury auctions scheduled later this week and next. **********After opening lower, Treasury issues soon recovered, as traders were encouraged by a 9 1/4 percent rate for overnight loans in the federal funds market, down from the 9 3/8 percent average rate in recent weeks. Traders also noted that the Federal Reserve' willingness to arrange $2 billion of temporary purchases of Treasury securities for a customer account, when federal funds were trading at 9 1/4 percent, was a sign that the central bank was not trying to make reserves scarcer in the system. **********''The lower trend in the funds rate, coupled with the exectuion of customer repos when Fed funds were in the 9 1/4 percent area has erased some of the negative feeling in the marketplace about the current Fed policy stance,'' analysts at Merrill Lynch Economics Inc. said in commentary published daily. **********Small Steps Seen **********While economists disagree about whether the Fed will ease or tighten monetary policy, they agree that the adjustment is likely to come in small steps. Until there are clearer signs that Fed policy is being adjusted, many market participants are focusing on the heavy supply of Treasury issues between now and year-end. **********Besides the $8 billion of two-year notes to be sold today at a yield estimated at just over 10 1/2 percent, the Treasury announced yesterday plans to sell, on Nov. 29, $6 billion of notes due in five-years, two months. **********At yesterday's auction of Treasury bills, rates were slightly higher than a week ago, as the three-month issue averaged 8.81 percent, up from 8.78 percent, while the six-month issue averaged 8.96 percent, up from 8.91 percent. In advance of tomorrow's auction of one-year bills, the outstanding one-year bill was bid at a rate of 9.06 percent. **********In the long bond market, the bellwether 12 percent Treasury issue due in 2013 was offered at 102 15/32, up 7/ 32, to yield 11.69 percent. **********'Exerting Upward Pressure' **********Government securities dealers and economists are not the only ones who point to heavy sales by the Treasury as a reason for high and rising interest rates. The summary of the minutes of the Oct. 4 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee said that some members of the committee believed ''the Treasury's large borrowing needs were already exerting upward pressure on interest rates and that greater pressure could be expected if relatively large Treasury credit demands continued and were augmented by growing business demands for a substantial amount of external funds.'' **********The failure of Congress to pass the tax bill last week means that current law will not allow issuance of tax-exempt, single-family mortgage revenue bonds after Dec. 31. Investment bankers said yesterday that a flood of such issues is unlikely because many states have already issued their allotment of bonds, and because authorization for more single-family mortgage bond financings is expected to be one of the first items on the agenda when Congress reconvenes. **********Elsewhere in the tax-exempt market, a $40 million issue of pollution control revenue bonds issued by the New Hampshire Industrial Development Authority on behalf of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire was repriced to raise yields slightly. The bonds, which are not rated, carry some of the highest yields in the tax-exempt market, ranging from 12 1/4 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 13 3/4 percent in 2003. **********Investor Concern **********The high yields on the issue reflect investor concern about the financial health of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which will use proceeds to financing pollution control facilities for the Seabrook nuclear power project. Last week, the investor owned utility sold $100 million of 15 percent bonds due in 2003 which were offered at a price of 96.93 to yield 15.50 percent. The company's bonds carried speculative grade ratings of Ba-3 from Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Bx from the Standard & Poor's Corporation. **********A recent study by analysts at Shearson/American Express Inc. of nuclear power plants in which municipally owned utilities are involved noted that the Seabrook project has an above average rating from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, but there a great deal of uncertainty about cost and future financing. The most recent estimates by New Hampshire officials is that the two Seabrook units could cost more than $8 billion, making it the most expensive nuclear plant under construction, measured by cost per kilowatt. **********Following are results of yesterday's auctions of new three- and six- month Treasury bills: (000 omitted in dollar figures) Average Price **********Both these issues are dated Nov. 25. The three-month bills mature Feb. 23, 1984 and the six-month bills, May 24, 1984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.print_headline: NEW FIGHTING SAID TO FLARE BETWEEN P.L.O. UNITS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/19/world.body_text: **********New fighting was reported to have broken out today between Palestinian military units in eastern Lebanon as a rebellion against Yasir Arafat continued to spread.  Reports here said more military units had joined the mutiny against Mr. Arafat's leadership, (The Associated Press, quoting the Voice of Lebanon, a Christian radio station, said at least two people had been killed and an undetermined number wounded.) **********It was the second reported clash between rebels and guerrillas loyal to Mr. Arafat since a rift developed a month ago inside Al Fatah, Mr. Arafat's own group and the largest of eight factions in the P.L.O. **********The state-controlled Lebanese radio and television reported that artillery exchanges had erupted between rival guerrillas entrenched in Taalbaya and Jedita, towns in the Bekaa, a valley in eastern Lebanon. **********The Voice of Lebanon said pro- and anti-Arafat guerrillas had used heavy weapons, and a state of alert had been declared in Palestinian ranks. **********News of the clashes came only hours after Mr. Arafat's second in command, Khalil al-Wazir, was quoted as saying two companies of a P.L.O. battalion had refused to carry out orders although he had spent 19 hours trying to persuade them to give up the insurrection. **********A Palestinian battalion is made up of about 500 guerrillas. The two companies that reportedly mutinied are believed to total 150 guerrillas. **********Mr. Wazir, also known by the code name Abu Jihad, made the disclosure in an interview with the Kuwaiti newspaper Al Qabas.  His remarks confirmed earlier press reports from the Bekaa that guerrillas in the September Martyrs Battalion had rebelled and attacked a P.L.O. clinic at Taalbaya, about 35 miles east of here. A spokesman for Mr. Arafat said the clinic had eventually been recaptured by forces loyal to the P.L.O. chairman. **********The battalion derives its name from the month in 1970 when Palestinian guerrillas in Jordan fought King Hussein's army. The guerrillas were eventually forced to leave Jordan. **********A Lebanese newspaper, As Safir, reported today that pro-Arafat guerrillas tried but failed Friday night to seize a P.L.O. supply office in Damascus. **********The newspaper, known for close contacts with the guerrillas, said the attackers had withdrawn after two of them were wounded in the attempt. **********The target was one of six guerrilla supply centers captured by the rebels shortly after the conflict broke out.  At the military level, the rebellion is led by Col. Abu Musa, the deputy commander of the P.L.O.'s operations room. Seven other senior officers have joined his ranks. **********At the political level, the opposition to Mr. Arafat's 18-year-old leadership of Al Fatah is led by Abu Saleh, one of the group's top 10 figures. **********Mr. Abu Saleh, who is known for his leftist leanings, and his support for Syria, Libya and the Soviet Union, has set up an office in Damascus that speaks for the rebels. **********The mutiny was touched off May 17 by anger over Mr. Arafat's reorganization of the P.L.O.'s military command.  Other P.L.O. leaders later denounced Mr. Arafat's policy toward Israel and an overall Middle East settlement, accusing him of what Col. Abu Musa described as ''capitulating to American designs.'' **********The 44-year-old colonel has his headquarters in Al Manara, a small village in eastern Lebanon where a battalion of Al Fatah is stationed. **********There are about 6,000 Palestinian guerrillas in the Bekaa, and about 4,000 in northern Lebanon. Eastern and northern Lebanon are under the control of 40,000 Syrian troops. Rebel officers are believed to command a total of 2,000 guerrillas in the Bekaa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/busin.main_headline: Home Loan Bank Board To Lose Senior Member
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Home Loan Bank Board To Lose Senior Member
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is losing its most senior member with the resignation Sept. 1 of James J. Jackson. Mr. Jackson said the savings and loan industry is in a stronger position than it was last year, largely because of the board's efforts toward deregulation. **********Mr. Jackson, 34, joined the board in December 1981 a time when the thrift industry was at the height of its struggle. He worked with the former chairman, Richard T. Pratt, and the current charman, Edwin J. Gray, to deregulate the industry to allow it to compete more successfully in the market. **********The bank board is the chief Federal regulator of the more than 4,000 savings institutions in the United States. Since Mr. Jackson joined the board, it has undergone a complete turnover. Mr. Gray was nominated in March and the third member, Donald I. Hovde, was confirmed in June. President Reagan has not nominated a replacement for Mr. Jackson. **********''The industry is in a much stronger position today than before because it was going in the wrong direction,'' Mr. Jackson said.  ''It is still in a fragile position because of the vulnerability of the interest rate situation. But if interest rates do not rise appreciably, the industry will get stronger and stronger. **********''A year ago S & L's had difficulty getting people to invest in savings and loan stock,'' he added. ''But recently there's been a major conversion from mutual investments to stock, which shows greater confidence among consumers in savings and loans.'' **********Mr. Jackson came to the board after working 10 years in Texas at the Fidelity Savings and Loan Association in Port Arthur, Beaumont Savings and Loan in Beaumont, and the Republic of Texas Savings Association in Port Arthur. Before that he taught social studies at Port Arthur High School. **********Mr. Jackson said he was leaving the board for ''personal and family reasons'' and had not determined his plans. He said there was a strong possibility he would stay in the savings and loan industry, and that he might move back to Texas.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.main_headline: AS THE GERMAN ELECTIONS NEAR, THE CAMPAIGN HITS NEW LOWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.print_headline: AS THE GERMAN ELECTIONS NEAR, THE CAMPAIGN HITS NEW LOWS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/03/world.body_text: **********As an ethical exercise, the campaign has hardly been uplifting. But with the countdown starting for Sunday's vote, mudslinging, slander, innuendo and the manipulation of information have reached new lows. **********Bild am Sonntag, the mass-circulation flagship of the right-wing Springer chain, set the tone for the week on Sunday by interviewing a Bavarian veterinarian who disclosed that Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democrats' candidate for Chancellor, was a member of the Hitler Youth at the age of 17. **********At the time, many Germans were in the Hitler Youth - Chancellor Helmut Kohl was, too - but Bild's informant, Dr. Ernst Holler, asserted that Mr. Vogel was ''arrogant, arbitrary, authoritarian and humorless'' as he ordered underlings about and was ''something like the extended arm'' of Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda chief. **********Mr. Vogel and the Social Democrats immediately moved to sue the newspaper for defamation. Even for the sensationalist Bild, the article went too far and some 100 reporters and editors wrote a letter to the Social Democratic candidate disassociating themselves from it. 'False Impression' Regretted **********When the article first appeared, Ewald Struwe, Bild am Sonntag's chief editor, wrote a strident open letter to Mr. Vogel asserting that ''the German voters, in this hour of truth, have a right to know the full truth.'' But on Tuesday he meekly climbed down, declaring his regret over the ''false impression'' that the newspaper had been out to slander Mr. Vogel. **********It escaped hardly anybody's notice that Dr. Holler, the veterinarian, is a member of Franz Josef Strauss's conservative Christian Social Union. Mr. Strauss, who in campaign speeches has likened Social Democratic arguments to Nazi lies, declared Tuesday that newspapers should ''stop bringing up such stuff from the Third Reich'' unless it is serious. **********Heiner Geissler, the general secretary of the Christian Democrats, already has established himself as the campaign's fastest hipshooter. **********In January, he suggested the Social Democrats were ''criminals'' for their ''lies'' about a new rent law and he summoned ''all decent Germans'' to distance themselves from the party. Gleefully, the Social Democrats turned out bumper stickers and buttons proclaiming: ''I am an undecent German. I am not voting C.D.U.'' The initials stand for the German name of Mr. Kohl's party. Greens Charge Corruption **********On Tuesday night, in a television debate, Lukas Beckmann, a leader of the Greens, accused the established parties of ''corruption'' for accepting payoffs from the giant Flick conglomerate. The red-bearded Mr. Beckmann sported a fat button that carried the word ''Flick'' ringed by the initials of the big parties. **********Aroused, Mr. Geissler twice accused the Greens of getting donations, and then said, ''I would rather get donations from a German company than from the D.D.R.'' - the initials for Communist East Germany. Today the Greens said that if Mr. Geissler did not retract his accusation that they were subsidized by East Germany they would sue him. **********A spokesman for the Christian Democrats said today that Mr.  Geissler had no proof for his assertion, but a party statement added, ''It would certainly be interesting for the public to know how the Greens are financing their generous and certainly not inexpensive campaign.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/21/world.main_headline: LATIN ENVOY NOMINEE SAYS U.S. CAN'T IMPOSE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/21/world.print_headline: LATIN ENVOY NOMINEE SAYS U.S. CAN'T IMPOSE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/21/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's choice to serve as special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, told a Senate committee today that the United States would try to bring opposing groups in the region to the bargaining table but ''cannot impose'' a settlement or act as a negotiator. **********Saying that he was not optimistic about the prospects for success, Mr. Stone told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the proper American role as mediator was one of ''inducement, invitation and support rather than co-optation or domination.'' **********In a 90-minute appearance before the panel that had the atmopshere of a homecoming, Mr. Stone, a former Democratic Senator from Florida and member of the committee, was warmly greeted by his former colleagues and told his nomination as ambassador at large would win quick approval by the Senate. The committee chairman, Charles H.  Percy, Republican of Illinois, said Mr. Stone's nomination would probably be voted on by the committee at its meeting next Tuesday. **********Repeats Warnings on Aid **********In his testimony, Mr. Stone repeated previous warnings by the Reagan Administration that El Salvador faces a loss of United States aid if human rights abuses, particularly killings by rightist death squads, are not stopped. Mr. Stone, however, said he felt El Salvador was making progress on human rights. **********Specifically, he told the committee that Salvadoran Government officials had assured him that five former National Guardsmen accused of killing four American churchwomen in El Salvador in 1980 would be brought to trial this year. ''On my next visit to El Salvador,'' Mr.  Stone said, ''I will press as hard as I can for an early trial.'' **********Mr. Stone, in comments that he said were meant to reassure Central American nations that the United States would not try to dictate the terms of any peace agreements, stressed that governments in the region should be encouraged to pursue negotiating initiatives already under way. 'Let's Be a Friend' **********''My role is to foster and promote discussions, not to pre-empt them,'' Mr. Stone said. ''Let's be a friend and supporter rather than telling them what to do. The agenda for negotiations in Central America must be maintained by Central Americans. Efforts by the United States to be a negotiator could upset those initiatives.'' **********To make negotiations easier, Mr. Stone said he would visit Central America soon after he is confirmed by the Senate, and he told the committee that he would be willing to meet with guerrilla leaders in El Salvador in an effort to persuade them to sit down for discussions with Government leaders. **********He acknowledged that the chances of bringing the opposing parties together for substantive talks were remote. ''The odds are so long against this kind of approach coming to fruition,'' he said, adding, ''This is going to be a very difficult mission.'' 'It May Be Difficult' **********Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the panel's ranking Democrat, raised the only discordant note about Mr. Stone's suitability to serve as special envoy. ''You're going into this job with such a hard-line image it may be difficult for you,'' Mr. Pell said. **********Mr. Pell did not elaborate, but an aide said later that the comment was a reference to Mr. Stone's longstanding identification with Cuban-Americans in Florida, a bastion of anti-Communism, and his work as a lobbyist for the Guatemalan Government from February 1981 to March 1982. In that period the Guatemalan Government, headed by Gen.  Romeo Lucas Garcia, was severely criticized by the United States for human rights abuses. **********After the hearing Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a group that has generally opposed Reagan Administration policies in Central America, said: ''It is disgraceful that this nomination didn't get the close scrutiny that it deserves.  The issue at stake is Stone's integrity. He says he worked to improve Guatemala's human rights performance. Our information is that he was a paid agent for Latin America's worst human rights violator in order to lift the U.S. arms embargo against his client.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/20/busin.body_text: **********The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, a hospital with a double-A bond rating much esteemed by investors, has taken advantage of lower interest rates by announcing an early re-funding of bonds it sold last year when interest rates were much higher. **********The $260 million financing through the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group is the largest bond issue ever sold for one hospital, eclipsing a $228.2 million Cleveland Clinic sale last year. **********Although the bonds are technically issued by the State of Ohio, they are an obligation of the hospital itself, not the state. **********According to officials at Merrill Lynch, demand for the issue was strong, with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 8.9 percent in 1998, 9.05 percent in 2003 and 9.197 percent in 2015. The bonds to be re-funded carried interest rates as high as 13 1/4 percent. **********The original bonds had maturities of 1993, 1997, 2005, 2014 and 2015. With the re-funding, those issues will now be retired in 1992.  After the new financing, the old bonds will be collateralized by Treasury securities bought with the proceeds of the new issue. The backing of interest and principal payments of the Treasury securities would entitle the old bonds to a triple-A rating.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Selling Professionalism To Radio Listeners
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/24/busin.body_text: **********When the management of CBS-owned AM radio stations decided to develop a single unifying campaign -instead of having each of the seven stations doing its own advertising with its own agency - it was natural that the management should turn to Trout & Ries, the positioning agency. **********And those good people have come up with a campaign that will be good for five of the stations, the all-news stations. **********Convinced that those stations had the most professional radio news teams in their markets, the agency came up with a way of getting that idea of professionalism across to the public. **********A third-party endorsement would be the ticket, the creative thinkers decided. And who better than working news people? So the Roper Organization was retained and its people secured lists of holders of press credentials in the particular markets. A random sampling of 200 for each market was asked the question, ''What one radio station do you listen to most often for news?'' The client's stations were the consistent winners. **********So the campaign will have the headline, varying of course from city to city: ''The radio news that New York news professionals listen to most.'' **********The effort will be backed by $5 million to $6 million worth of advertising time and space - some of it barter -in newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor and transit. In other words, multimedia.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.main_headline: MOSCOW SAYS SHIFT IN U.S. ARMS STAND IS NO BASIC CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.print_headline: MOSCOW SAYS SHIFT IN U.S. ARMS STAND IS NO BASIC CHANGE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/10/world.body_text: **********A commentary by the Government press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's revised plan for strategic arms reduction was still aimed ''at gaining military superiority and pressing the Soviet Union into unilateral disarmament.'' **********Tass said Mr. Reagan's decision to revise the proposal for a limit of 850 long-range missiles on each side ''does not in any way affect the essence'' of his original offer, which was rejected by the Russians at talks in Geneva. **********(At the NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Paris, the United States made public a report aimed at showing that arms control had always been among the highest priorities of American administrations. Page A12. **********(In Bonn, Chancellor Helmut Kohl warned Moscow against trying to intimidate West Germany in an effort to forestall the deployment of new American medium-range missiles starting in December. Page A12.) Soviet Sees Two U.S. Objectives **********The Soviet press agency, in commenting on President Reagan's latest proposals on strategic arms limitation, said the plan to raise the proposed limit on missiles from 850 to possibly 1,200, according to Administration officials, while retaining the ceiling of 5,000 nuclear warheads for each side was intended to accomplish two goals. **********The first is to facilitate the deployment of two new types of missiles, one of them the MX, and the second is to force the Soviet Union to reduce its force of land-based missiles, which Tass called the backbone of the Soviet arsenal. **********The Soviet Union now has 2,350 strategic, or long-range, missiles, based on land and on submarines, and the United States has 1,600.  Because of the larger number of multiple warheads on American missiles, there is a rough balance in warheads, at 7,500 each. **********Tass said that Mr. Reagan's statement that he was adjusting his proposals to introduce new flexibility into the Geneva talks was ''mere words, and nothing more.'' **********''No desire to achieve a mutually acceptable accord, mentioned by the President, is in sight'' the agency said. ''On the contrary, his statement reveals something quite different - the aspiration to undermine by any means the principle of equality and equal security of the sides on which rested the talks on SALT I and SALT II.'' **********The reference was to the first and second strategic arms limitation agreements, the latter signed by President Carter but not approved by the Senate after the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.  The Tass commentary lacked the authority of an official government statement, but was considered to be an accurate reflection of the Kremlin's views. **********Tass said Mr. Reagan had ignored the proposals put forward by the Soviet Union, which include a 25 percent reduction in all nuclear weapons carriers, including missiles and bombers, and a ban on longrange cruise missiles. **********The Soviet Union has also proposed a freeze on existing arsenals while the talks continue, with an agreement eventually banning all new types of weapons and technological improvements to existing arsenals. Soviet Worried by Two Aspects **********Soviet assessments of the United States proposals have focused on two aspects. The Russians consider deep cuts in the number of missile launchers and a separate limit on land-based launchers an effort to emasculate their nuclear forces, two-thirds of which are land-based.  They also feel that the United States, by concentrating on missiles and excluding other types of weapons, is attempting to retain the freedom to deploy cruise missiles, the B-1 bomber and other advanced systems. **********The Tass commentary contended that Mr. Reagan, though relaxing the ceiling on launchers, still sought to limit Soviet land-based missiles. **********Tass said the President's latest offer was the result of a commitment to Congress to intensify efforts at Geneva in return for support for his plan to deploy 100 MX missiles. **********The other new type of missile to which Tass alluded appeared to be the Midgetman, a proposed small single-warhead mobile missile whose deployment over the next decade was urged by the arms commission that devised the plan to deploy an initial battery of MX missiles in existing silos.
