https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.print_headline: BONN VOTING: SECOND LOOK; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/08/world.body_text: **********Despite Sunday's electoral victory by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic-led coalition, Mr. Kohl and many Western diplomats here are talking in terms that suggest that the Reagan Administration should not interpret that victory as an openended or unqualified mandate to station new intermediate-range missiles in West Germany. **********Though the missile issue played a central role in the campaign, and served as a political shorthand for talking about the Western alliance and the United States, all parties agreed in their electoral post-mortems that Mr. Kohl won because many voters believed his coalition could pull West Germany out of its deepest economic trough since the war. **********''I'm afraid there will be a lot of misreading of the whole thing,'' a well-placed Western diplomat said today, with an eye on Washington. ''This just wasn't an election about stationing missiles.'' **********'This Hope Was Decisive' **********At a subdued news conference today, the Chancellor plainly linked the Christian Democrats' 48.8 percent share of the vote and the party's impressive in roads into working-class areas like the Ruhr to awakened hopes that his coalition could turn the economy around.  ''This hope was decisive for the election,'' Mr. Kohl said. **********Mr. Kohl twice turned aside suggestions that he had won a mandate to deploy 108 Pershing 2 and 96 cruise, or low-flying, missiles in West Germany. Instead, as he has throughout the campaign, he expressed the hope that the Christian Democrats' convincing victory would persuade the Soviet Union to reach an agreement with the United States at the Geneva medium-range missile talks. **********The goal of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at Geneva, he said, was not ''all or nothing'' - a catch phrase the Chancellor uses to distance himself from the Reagan Administration's ''zero option'' for abolishing all medium-range missiles in East and West. **********Mr. Kohl has said in public and private that if there is no choice - if the Geneva talks remain blocked - he will accept the missiles.  But there is no enthusiasm for this option, and he is now widely expected to press the Reagan Administration, without acrimony or publicity, to reach a compromise in Geneva. The Greens Promise Resistance **********Missile deployment at the end of this year raises some nasty scenarios. Having won 27 seats in Parliament, the Green Party, a coalition of pacifists and environmentalists, promised today to spearhead popular resistance to the new weapons. **********Moreover, in the wake of their defeat, the Social Democrats may well continue their leftward course on security issues, which so far has fallen short of outright opposition to the missiles. ''We could come to a situation in which we reject stationing,'' Karsten Voigt, the party's security spokesman, said today. **********Running up their second-best totals since West Germany held its first national elections in 1949, the Christian Democrats ended their reputation as a predominantly southern, Roman Catholic party. They outpolled the opposition Social Democrats in every region except the small city-states of Bremen and Hamburg. **********Even in North Rhine-Westphalia, where the Ruhr Basin steel industry is rooted and where the Social Democrats hold an absolute majority in the state legislature, Mr. Kohl's conservatives emerged as the biggest party. The victors' private polls showed that a majority of women and skilled workers voted for the Christian Democrats. End of 2 Decades of Growth **********The Social Democrats, by contrast, fell from the 42.9 percent of the vote that they won under Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in 1980 to 38.2 percent. This undid two decades of steady growth, throwing the party back to the level of 1961 when it took 36.2 percent of the vote in a losing struggle against Chancellor Konrad Adenauer. **********The ingredients of defeat included Mr. Kohl's insistent argument that 13 years of Social Democratic rule, which ended last autumn, were responsible for record unemployment and state debt. Many bluecollar workers seemed to feel that their jobs would be safer under the Christian Democrats. **********According to some politicians today, the Social Democrats and their candidate, Hans-Jochen Vogel, also alienated traditional working-class constituents by flirting with the Green Party, which favors no-growth, small-is-beautiful economic models. Mr. Vogel indicated that he would accept Green backing in Parliament to become Chancellor. Kohl Tapped Traditional Values **********While the Social Democrats' campaign was crafted by leftist intellectuals in Bonn who tried to tap a reservoir of West German patriotism, Mr. Kohl appealed to traditional middle-class values of hard work, savings and sacrifice and tried to evoke the pioneering spirit that helped reconstruct the country after the war. **********Mr. Kohl, who for a decade has been his party's leader, suffers a condescending press in Bonn, where he is portrayed as unsophisticated, rambling in speech and lacking any specific competence except politics. But the Chancellor, who considers himself Mr. Adenauer's spiritual heir, evidently connected with West Germany's broad middle class. **********A West German journalist, musing today over the extent of Mr.  Kohl's personal triumph, said, ''We have regularly underestimated him.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.main_headline: MIDDLE EAST PROSPECTS: ROOM FOR SPECIALISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.print_headline: MIDDLE EAST PROSPECTS: ROOM FOR SPECIALISTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/16/jobs/.body_text: **********CAIRO FOR decades, the Middle East has held a special allure for Westerners, with visions of Arabian sands, colorful Bedouins and romantic desert oases. But in the last 10 years, the nature of the enticement has been replaced by prospects of easy money in sheikdoms swimming in oil. Tens of thousands of Americans have come to the Arab world to work since 1973, when the price of oil began skyrocketing. **********Today the picture is changing again because an oil glut has generated economic contractions in the Arab oil states. Fewer large new contracts are being awarded; projects under way are being scaled back; Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, on paper, are running budget deficits. **********Nonetheless, job prospects for Americans - generally men - with special skills are still good, though more limited than before, according to private business representatives and American Embassy officials in Arab countries where Americans have traditionally worked. There are still a lot of foreign companies and expatriates doing business in the region, but there is definitely less growth, said Theodore A. Rosen, counselor for commercial affairs at the United States Embassy in Cairo. **********Mr. Rosen and other experts agree that job opportunities for younger Americans, especially those just out of college without work experience, are fewer. ''Those starry-eyed kids wandering around Turkey, Egypt and in North African and other easily accessible Arab countries hoping to find a good job are definitely taking a risk,'' Mr. Rosen said. Employers who are looking for younger people, he added, seem to prefer adventurous types who have knocked around the region a little and know how things work because they have made their own way. **********He urged those coming to the area without a firm job prospect to save enough money to get home in case they do not succeed. Have that round-trip ticket or a credit card ready, he counseled. **********A knowledge of Arabic is preferable, and in some jobs it is essential. This appears to be less important in a country like Egypt than in the Persian Gulf states. **********Some places where Americans have traditionally worked are no longer attractive, for political reasons or because of armed conflicts taking place within their borders. Lebanon, Iran, Iraq and Libya fall into this category. Syria is also not amenable to American workers. **********Analysts say that there are basically two categories of Arab countries in which Americans now work: accessible and restrictive. The distinction is tricky, because virtually all Arab states require entry visas, work permits and letters of sponsorship to work. But in accessible countries, such as Egypt, Turkey, Jordan and several in North Africa, it is still possible to enter without a job and look for one. **********In restrictive countries like Saudi Arabia and most of the gulf states, a firm job offer is required for entry. In addition, an American who comes to work in Saudi Arabia, officials say, must come alone. His family is permitted to follow three to six months later. **********Saudi Arabia and the gulf states, in particular, are under intense pressure to reduce the number of expatriates working in their countries. As a result, companies in the Arab world that are still hiring seek only foreigners with special skills and a lot of experience. **********For example, there is still a reasonably good market in Bahrain for American professionals with banking experience, according to George T. Boutin, American commercial attache in Manama, the capital. But Bahrain, like most of the the gulf states, is pursuing a campaign to hire more of its own nationals for mid-level positions. **********Kuwait is still recruiting bankers and other professionals such as investment analysts and computer technicians. But it, too, has drastically reduced spending, and Western diplomats report that some of the contracts awarded to the more than 1,000 Americans working in Kuwait are not being renewed, especially in the oil sector. **********THE same is true in Qatar, where about 200 Americans work. Talent is still sought, but in specialized areas, such as medicine and nursing. **********The largest American work force in the Arab world is in Saudi Arabia, where, according to embassy figures, some 65,000 Americans live. Expertise in agriculture is high on Saudi Arabia's wish list; the kingdom is actively encouraging investments in that field, and seeking people with foreign expertise to help the country become self-sufficient in food production. But company representatives say many Americans who have been working in Arabia are being replaced by South Korean and other foreign workers. **********The situation is the same in the United Arab Emirates, said one embassy official. Americans who demand at least a $50,000 salary, medical costs, school tuitions, a villa, home leave each year and other benefits are simply pricing themselves out of the market, he said. In the Emirates, the official said, the five American hotel chains employ almost no American managers or professional staff members.  In Israel, on the other hand, the job market seems somewhat more congenial to Americans. Israeli employment experts say, for example, that the country is eagerly seeking workers in two fields: engineering and computers. **********According to Michael Ziv, head of the overseas department of the Labor Ministry's bureau for the placement of professionals, the bureau receives about five job offers for every electrical engineer it handles, and about 10 offers for every computer professional. Mr. Ziv said the rapid growth of all technical professions in Israel had created such an enormous demand for industrial, electrical and chemical engineers, software developers, programmers and systems analysts, that ''in many places the development may have to stop if there is no increase in manpower.'' **********Newspaper articles in recent months have held that the country will need 5,000 engineers that it does not now have in the coming decades for the two main national projects on the drawing board: a canal between the Mediterranean and the Dead Sea, and the Lavi air force jet. **********The Israeli economy has a fairly healthy demand for several of the service professions, notably nurses and dentists, but a Labor Ministry official cautioned that Israel is primarily interested in giving jobs to Jews willing to settle there. The Israeli economy has a demand for several of the service professions, notably nurses and dentists, but Olga Rachmilevich, director of absorption for the Association of Americans and Canadians in Israel, said that American-trained accountants and bookkeepers generally had no problem finding jobs, and that the developing Israeli advertising industry had created some new demand for graphics and layout personnel. **********Skilled labor carries a high premium in Israel. Mrs. Rachmilevich said Israel even hired precision-instrument operators on a contractual basis from Britain. And unskilled labor, from hotel to construction workers, is also in demand.  Those interested in working in Israel should apply to the Jewish Agency, which coordinates immigration to Israel. Its headquarters is in New York City, with offices around the country. **********Jewish Americans are likely to encounter special scrutiny when they apply for jobs in Arab countries, though Arab governments assert that they are seeking only to keep what they term Zionists, not Jews, from working within their borders. **********Saudi Arabia and the gulf states strongly prefer male workers, no matter what the skill. In fact, male Arab, Moslem, Arabic- speaking workers have top priority virtually everywhere in the region. Women are at the bottom of the job spectrum in Arab countries, according to one gulf-based official who, like most when asked about jobs for women, did not want to be identified. **********Western women, even single, live and work in almost every country in the Arab world, but their numbers are few. Egypt appears to be the most receptive to female workers, but even here local resentment of foreign women supervisors is sometimes strong, officials and business people agree. **********Black Americans, business people say, do not seem to encounter any special problems working in the area, but like women, they are few in number. **********In general, Americans who want to work in the Arab world should seek such jobs in the United States. The Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, for example, recruits mainly in Texas. The same is true of the American University in Cairo, which has an office in Manhattan. Some oil companies send workers from Houston almost directly to oil rigs in the gulf. **********Virtually all the professionals here, whether they are engineers, managers or teachers, find their jobs in the United States, according to Ronald G. Wolfe, director of America-Mideast Educational and Training Services Inc., in Cairo. If they are hired locally, they will probably receive a local salary, which is shockingly low for some Americans, Mr. Wolfe added.  Job-seekers in the Middle East should be prepared for great competition. The rector of Gulf University in Bahrain told friends recently that he had received about 1,000 job applications for each opening. The intensity of the competition has helped drive down salaries for expatriate workers. Mr. Wolfe, for example, said he recently hired an assistant from the United States for $7,000 a year. The applicant agreed to pay her own air fare to Egypt. **********If you work here, you've got to read the contract carefully, Mr. Rosen of the United States Embassy warned. Living, including housing, in the Middle East is much more expensive than some people think. There are some exotic diseases in the region, and if you get sick, you might have to be flown to Europe. An $80,000-a-year salary in Saudi Arabia sounds good, but it might not be nearly as attractive if you have to pay $30,000 to $60,000 a year to rent housing, which he cautioned is a distinct possibility. **********But, Mr. Rosen said, there are lots of work opportunities in the Middle East for those who are persistent and patient. **********Commercial attaches, such as Theodore A. Rosen of the United States Embassy in Cairo, offer the following general advice for those seeking work in the Middle East: **********- Contact the Departments of State and Commerce in Washington and write to the embassy of the country in which you wish to work. Get from those nations' embassies a list of American companies operating in their areas, as well as information on visas and currency restrictions. **********- If there is a special business association in your area, get in touch. The Egypt- U.S. Business Council, for example, has an office at the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington. **********- Look for work with an American company that has extensive operations in the Middle East. You may not secure an immediate posting to the region, but many companies are eager to recruit people in America who wish to work abroad. **********- Talk to people in your town or city who have worked in the Middle East. Many jobs are secured through word of mouth. **********- Read business publications and newspapers' classified sections carefully: many companies recruit in this way, not just through headhunters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.body_text: **********An obsession with geology, visions of bounty, and a certain looniness - these and other unmistakable symptoms of oil fever are sweeping Ireland again. **********Three years ago, that fever was sparked by promising test drilling in deep and hostile Atlantic waters off Ireland's west coast. This time, the focus is off the south coast in the shallow, tamer Celtic Sea, where evidence is accumulating daily that the Gulf Oil Company has discovered a field that could finally bring hard- pressed Ireland into the ranks of the oil producing nations. **********''I don't want to contribute to the euphoria,'' said Edward A. Collins, the Trade and Energy Department minister responsible for oil development. ''The expert advice is that we can't reach any conclusions yet on recoverable reserves.'' **********Test Results Promising **********However, Gulf's flow and oil-quality data for the first tests and the field's location in shallow waters just 20 miles off the coast near Waterford have been such that even conservative oilmen have been saying privately they would be very surprised if the field was not exploitable. **********More important, perhaps, the find has included eye-opening results from previously untested zones of the Celtic Sea bed that date from the same geologic age as the most productive North Sea oilfields. Whether or not the Gulf block is a winner, the odds have shot up that others in the region could be. **********''We really are at the start of a new era,'' said Donald Sheridan, managing director of Atlantic Resources Ltd., the small Irish exploration company that owns a one-third interest in the block where Gulf is drilling. ''From the data that Gulf has published, we are undoubtably in a new oil province.'' **********The test drilling shows oil flowing at a rate of 10,000 barrels a day, including a large amount of high-quality light crude that is more valuable to refiners. These data, and reports about the zones in which the oil has been found, have convinced industry sources that there is a good chance the field can produce the 50 million barrels needed to make it profitable. **********Could Ease Import Costs **********Less-informed speculation has wandered as high as 300 million barrels and raised hopes that Ireland might be able to satisfy its need for 100,000 barrels a day for up to a decade. The country pays $1 billion annually to import oil and oil products and even a small find would have a major impact on Ireland's negative trade balance, according to Michael Scanlon, Mr. Collins's deputy at the Trade and Energy Ministry. **********Even if the discovery is all Ireland could hope for, it will be several years at least before oil could be marketed. Indeed, the final tests on whether the field is commercial will not be completed before next spring.  The Government is still formulating the tax mechanism for oil, although laws giving it a right to participate in up to a 50 percent stake and specifying royalties of 8 to 16 percent of sales value, depending on the production level, are already in place. **********In any case, the prospect of Irish oil has roused the normally somnolent Irish Stock Exchange, where trading has been frenzied. ''There's enormous speculation, far larger than anything I have ever seen before,'' said a partner at J.& E. Davy, Ireland's largest stockbroker, who asked not to be identified. ''It's several multiples higher than two years ago, when interest peaked in the Porcupine Basin off the west coast.'' **********Checks From Tourists **********The center of the speculation has been Atlantic Resources, which also has interests in several nearby blocks. But several other Irish oil exploration companies, including Aran Energy, Bula and Eglinton, have been caught up in the rising interest. One broker told an Irish newspaper that two American tourists had walked into his office and given him two certified checks for $10,000 each to invest. **********The activity has been mirrored on the London Stock Exchange, where some of the companies are also traded, and analysts say that interest has been intense. **********There are plenty of reasons why the investors have been mesmerized. To start with, some Irish newspapers have provided them almost daily with unusually accurate information on the drilling results, to the dismay of some of the oilmen involved. Gulf, Atlantic Resources, Union Oil (the third partner in the block), and the Government all deny being the source of the leaks. Whatever the source, the leaking has turned the exploration and stock market reaction into a running front-page story. **********A Colorful Cast **********There is also a fascination with the colorful cast at Atlantic Resources. The company was organized in 1981 by James Stafford, a well-connected entrepreneur from Wexford who has founded or been a key figure in six other oil companies, including Aran and Eglinton. **********His major early backer was Fitzwilton Securities Ltd., the investment firm headed by Anthony J. F. O'Reilly, president of the H. J. Heinz Company, an Irishman known at least as well here for his rugby exploits as for his subsequent rise through the executive ranks of the Pittsburgh-based food concern. **********Atlantic's board of directors was packed with influential Irish politicians and businessmen, all of whom made hefty profits when the company went public. Later additions to the board included John P. McEnroe, father of the tennis star, John McEnroe, who is reported to be an investor. **********While all of the Irish oil companies have seen their shares move up dramatically, Atlantic stands out. Following a disastrous new share issue in June, the stock had fallen to 42 Irish pence. Since mid-July, it has leaped on good news from the Celtic Sea to a peak of 675 pence. **********'A Possible Savior' **********Investors aren't the only ones taking the news seriously. ''In many respects, it's regarded as a possible savior here,'' said Desmond O'Toole, the real estate appraiser who heads the Chamber of Commerce in Waterford, the severely depressed manufacturing city that is nearest the oil find.  Waterford businessmen are already organizing to service the inevitable boom in offshore exploration and, they hope, production. **********Waterford is looking nervously over its shoulder at Cork, Ireland's second-largest city, which is almost as close to the field and already is the base for servicing the Kinsale natural gas field. Kinsale, which is operated by the Irish subsidiary of Marathon Oil, is Ireland's only domestic source of hydrocarbons and meets about 15 percent of the nation's energy needs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.main_headline: BURMA, UNDER GENERAL'S RULE, KEEPS TO ITSELF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.print_headline: BURMA, UNDER GENERAL'S RULE, KEEPS TO ITSELF
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/10/world.body_text: **********The bomb that killed at least 16 South Koreans and three Burmese today exploded in a closed and tightly ruled country that has only recently tried to strengthen its ties with such Western- leaning nations as South Korea. **********A socialist republic that is officially neutral, Burma has remained remarkably isolated from foreign journalists because of restrictions in effect since Gen. Ne Win seized power in 1962. But it is known to have a long and continuing history of political violence. **********Soon after seizing power, the general returned Burma to the isolation and autocracy it had known before Britain invaded and colonized it in the 19th century. Gradually he severed most ties with the rest of the world. **********Internally, Burma remains a police state, with the authority of the Government apparently only passively accepted in the core of the country it controls. In the far north, northeast and east, various ethnic insurgencies and a Communist guerrilla movement keep the central Government at a distance. **********Security measures are evident in and around Rangoon. The army conducts searches for weapons at suburban checkpoints, and a public park across the street from Rangoon's Shwe Dagon Pagoda remains fenced and empty most of the year. The reason, Burmese say privately, is that soldiers sometimes use the park as a parade ground and they are afraid that public access might expose them to bombs. **********Several of Burma's insurgent movements are extremely well armed. Fighting in recent months along the Thai frontier between the Burmese Army and several thousand ethnic Karen rebels disclosed that the insurgents had mortars and automatic rifles superior to those of the army. **********The Communist guerrillas in the far northeast have waged intermittent war against Rangoon since the late 1940's. The Communist Party of Burma has traditionally been linked to the Chinese. **********Little in terms of goods or information has lately entered Burma that the Government did not specifically request - unless it was smuggled in. And little news has emerged from the country. Visas for visiting journalists are rare, and pressures on local journalists to conform to the official interpretation of events are constant. The Burmese representatives of foreign news organizations are carefully watched. **********After a long and largely disastrous experiment in modeling the country's economy after those of Eastern Europe, General Ne Win shifted direction slightly in the mid-1970's. Burmese economic planners began taking an interest in production incentives and in financial aid and expertise from such countries as Japan, West Germany, the United States and South Korea. **********Burma's diplomatic ties with the West, and with Asian nations that see eye to eye with the West, have grown gradually friendlier in recent years. Relations with the Soviet Union have grown more formal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.main_headline: MRS. THATCHER CRITICIZES EUROPE ON FLIGHT 007
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.print_headline: MRS. THATCHER CRITICIZES EUROPE ON FLIGHT 007
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in her first public statement on the Soviet Union's downing of the Korean airliner, has criticized her Common Market and NATO allies for what she called their failure to fully censure the Russians for their actions. **********Mrs. Thatcher, who is ending a monthlong recuperation from eye surgery and leaves Monday on a two-day trip to the Netherlands and West Germany, made the comments in an interview that was shown over the weekend on Dutch television. **********She said Britain would have welcomed a longer ban on flights to and from Moscow than the present 14-day restriction and expressed her personal sense of fury at what she called the Soviet Union's barbaric act. **********''I find it incomprehensible and inexplicable that we were not able to get a clearer condemnation in Europe and clearer action in the wider NATO sphere,'' she said.   Carried by British Stations **********The interview was shown on British stations and it caused several members of the Labor Party opposition today to raise questions about the Prime Minister's physical condition after surgery in August to repair a detached retina.  They said she appeared haggard in the interview and suggested she might not be physically able to carry out this week's trip and another visit scheduled next week to Canada and the United States. **********''Mrs. Thatcher's physical appearance indicates she needs a long rest,'' said Martin Flannery, a left-wing Labor Member of Parliament from Sheffield. **********''Why did it take her 17 days to comment on the shooting down of the Korean airliner? What has been preventing such a voluble, talkative woman from commenting during this period? Everybody was wondering where she was. It seems completely out of character unless there is some other reason.''  'In Fine Fettle' **********Government sources said Mrs. Thatcher was ''in fine fettle'' and if her television appearance looked odd it may have been attributable to the poor lighting provided by the Dutch television crew that interviewed her here. **********The Prime Minister is scheduled to meet with Ruud Lubbers, the Dutch Prime Minister, and with the West German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, during her trip, during which she will also visit several British military bases. **********It is expected that she will seek reassurances that unity will be maintained on the decision to proceed with the deployment of American nuclear missiles by the end of the year. Most of them will be deployed on British, Dutch and German soil. **********Meanwhile, a top Soviet journalist said in an interview carried here today by the BBC that the first public reports coming out of Moscow on the downing of the jet were probably misleading. **********''I think in this respect our military people are guilty,'' said Prof. Viktor Afanasiev, editor in chief of Pravda. ''Probably they let some inaccuracies slip by. Perhaps they were not certain what had happened.'' **********Mr. Afanasiev, a member of the Communist Party's Central Committee, was interviewed here while he was on his way to a meeting of high-ranking Soviet military and foreign affairs experts in Edinburgh this week with British and American counterparts. He said he did not know why initial Soviet reactions to the incident were so inadequate. **********''This is my own simple version,'' he said. ''I cannot claim to know. I would not say I was very pleased with our first reports.'' **********The visit of the Russian delegation was approved by the Foreign Office despite the uproar over the Korean jet. The Russians are taking part in the ''Edinburgh Conference,'' which since 1980 has been a unofficial forum for contact between the Russians and the West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.main_headline: PROTESTANT PARTY LEADER SLAIN IN ULSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.print_headline: PROTESTANT PARTY LEADER SLAIN IN ULSTER
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/08/world.body_text: **********A prominent Protestant political leader in Northern Ireland was shot dead today as he walked to a Belfast university classroom to deliver a lecture on the law. **********The leader, Edgar Graham, 29 years old, was struck by six bullets fired at point-blank range by a young man in a jogging suit, who escaped with a companion into the campus of Queens University. The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the slaying. **********A message delivered to news organizations in Belfast said the assassination ''should be a salutary lesson to those loyalists who stand foursquare behind the laws and forces of oppression of the nationalist people.'' **********The killing of Mr. Graham, who was a member of the Northern Ireland Assembly and chairman of the Ulster Young Unionist Council, appeared to signal an important departure from recent I.R.A. tactics. For more than a year the paramilitary force has taken care to select targets associated with security forces in the British province as it sought to spread its political influence among more moderate elements of the Roman Catholic community. Shootings 'Counterproductive' **********When gunmen two weeks ago raided a Protestant church, killing three members and wounding seven, the I.R.A. disassociated itself from the shootings, calling them counterproductive for republican goals. **********Before Sinn Fein, the group's political arm, demonstrated surprising voter appeal among nationalists in voting for the Assembly, the I.R.A. had waged open warfare against loyalist politicians. In 1981, Robert Bradford, a Member of Parliament from the same South Belfast district represented by Mr. Graham, was murdered at a political meeting by I.R.A. gunman. That same year the 86-year old former Speaker of the old Northern Ireland Parliament, Sir Norman Stronge, was killed along with his son by the I.R.A. **********Last month the chairman of the Armagh District Council, James Armstrong, was killed by an I.R.A. bomb, but he had associations with provincial security forces. Mr. Graham had no such connections but was considered a strict advocate of law and order. **********James Molyneaux, leader of the Official Unionist Party, to which Mr. Graham belonged, called the killing a ''disaster for our party because he was an elected officer and one of our management team, a spokesman on home affairs specializing in legal matters and legislation dealing with terrorism. **********''Had Mr. Graham not been murdered,'' Mr. Molyneaux said, ''he would have become the leader of our party, such was his caliber.''  Voice of New Generation **********Other Unionists saw the slain man not so much as a political leader but as the voice of a new generation of educated Protestants who hold strong views on law and order and object to extremists on both sides of the sectarian conflict. **********Last month he said that he had information that he and five other leading Unionists were targeted for assassination by republican paramilitary forces who were trying to enlist loyalist extremists in the plot. **********In September, The Times of London printed a lengthy letter from Mr. Graham in which he strongly supported the use of informers in Ulster courts to obtain convictions of republican and loyalist terrorists. **********''The community as a whole in Northern Ireland,'' he wrote, ''is at last seeing the stranglehold of the terrorist organizations, on both sides, being broken.'' **********Mr. Graham's murder was expected to reinforce Unionist demands on London to step up security measures in the province. After the church shootings two weeks ago, the Official Unionist members of the Assembly, including Mr. Graham, withdrew from participation in the legislature until stronger measures were taken.   Honor Guard for Slain Man **********Last weekend, British Army special counterinsurgency forces shot and killed an I.R.A. suspect and wounded two others in the first undercover action taken as a result of the clamor raised by the Unionists. On Tuesday, the dead man was buried with an I.R.A. honor guard and Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, was a pallbearer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/14/world.main_headline: CUBA SETS FIVE DAYS OF MOURNING FOR ITS DEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/14/world.print_headline: CUBA SETS FIVE DAYS OF MOURNING FOR ITS DEAD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/14/world.body_text: **********Cuba declared five days of mourning today as it prepared for the return to Havana of Cubans killed resisting the American-led invasion of Grenada. **********The bodies were due to be flown to the capital today after identification in the eastern city of Holguin, where they were flown Saturday with several Grenadian dead. **********A Government communique did not give the exact number of Cuban dead, but earlier lists of the missing indicated the number could not exceed 24. **********National mourning will last until a mass rally is held Monday night in Revolution Square in which Fidel Castro is expected to speak. **********The communique said the people would pay tribute ''to their heroic sons who died as they worked in international solidarity with the people of Grenada, resisting the brutal aggression of imperialism towards that brother country.''  Workers Given Time Off **********Officials said all workers in the Havana area, except those in essential services, would be given time off to attend the rally, which is likely to attract hundreds of thousands of people. **********The monument to Jose Marti, the Cuban poet and revolutionary, in Revolution Square will be open for the public to pay last respects to the dead, the first Cubans killed in open combat with Americans. **********All places of public entertainment will be closed until Tuesday, when the national mourning will be replaced by three days of official mourning. Flags on public buildings will fly at half-staff, and schools will be closed Monday. **********The funeral rally will crown almost three weeks of bitter denunciations of ''Yankee imperialism'' and tributes to the resistance of the Cubans on Grenada, which was invaded Oct. 25. **********More than 750 Cubans were on Grenada, formerly ruled by a leftist Government closely allied to Cuba. The rest of the Cubans - the wounded and those taken prisoner - have all been flown home, and the return of the dead was the only thing to delay the mass rally.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Behind the Cabbage Patch Kids
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Behind the Cabbage Patch Kids
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/01/busin.body_text: **********WHEN someone telephones Richard & Edward's these days to speak to the president, Richard Schwarzchild, he has to assure Mr. Schwarzchild's secretary that he isn't looking for a free doll. **********On the other hand, when Steven Kolker, senior vice president, account management, is trying to arrange a meeting to make a new-business pitch he's told, ''O.K., if you bring along a free doll.'' **********What those people are talking about are the Cabbage Patch Kids, the ugly little dolls that have somehow seized the heart of the nation. **********Richard & Edward's client, Coleco Industries of Hartford, is having 200,000 of the kids made each week in the Orient and air freighting them back to the States where retailers can't keep enough in stock. **********The toy industry, which has just gone through an enormous change because of electronic gadgets, has been suddenly tipped on its ear by a simple little rag doll.  And 50-year-old Coleco, which normally seeks its fortune through electronic games, swimming pools and equipment and those noisy, squat plastic tricycles, has hit a phenomenal winner with its first doll. The R.& E. brass are predicting sales of more than three million in 1983, a record for doll sales in an introductory year. **********Yesterday in his office with Mr. Kolker, Mr. Schwarzchild, who had just arranged to stop advertising for the dolls until there were enough around to meet the demand, said he was expecting similar consumer excitement when advertising starts for Coleco's Adam computer. **********But first the conversation centered on the Cabbage Patch Kids. They are mass-produced, but no two are alike, thanks to different combinations of skin and eye color, hair color and style and clothing. And the two men are trying very hard to understand their phenomenal success. **********''If you treated a Shirley Temple doll as if it were alive, people would treat you as if you were crazy,'' said Mr. Schwarzchild, ''But because this is so ugly, it allows everybody to get into the fantasy that they are real.'' **********''The key,'' injected Mr. Kolker, ''was understanding that kids also want to feel one-of-a-kind and say to themselves, 'No matter how I look, I'm special.' '' **********They credit Alfred R.Kahn, senior vice president-marketing at Coleco, with realizing that there was something very special going on down in Cleveland, Ga. There, an artist named Xavier Roberts, who makes soft sculpture, had set up a truly different doll factory in 1977. He calls it Babyland General Hospital, and women dressed as nurses administer an adoption oath and supervise the signing of adoption papers for the dolls. Cigars are also handed out. **********But those dolls sell for $125 to $1,000, depending on the accessories, and are never called dolls, but ''little people.'' **********The version that is being mass- produced under a licensing agreement by Coleco are sold for $19.95 and up, and would not have been called dolls in the TV commercials either, but the networks insisted on it. The agency is just as interested as Mr. Roberts is in preserving the fantasy that the kids are born one night a year in the cabbage patch and he spends the rest of the year finding homes for them. **********The agency, after many focus- group interviews, created two 30-second spots, one extolling the kids and the other their accessories. It began running the spots in New York in June and then expanded advertising to new areas weekly, first to Philadelphia and Boston, and then to Chicago, Detroit and Minneapolis. Once the spots hit the network on Sept. 23, both network and spot TV were used. But because of the huge demand for the dolls, most of the ads have been pulled, and the only ones that are on now are the commercials in syndicated shows, which take a couple of weeks to pull. **********Coleco originally considered the doll as a Christmas toy, but the consumer excitement has caused a change of heart. The Cabbage Patch Kids are now a year-round item, and as soon as there is enough product, or when there is a new product, TV advertising will be unleashed once again.  Coleco became a Richard & Edward's client a year after the agency started in 1976, coming in from Helitzer Advertising, where both Mr. Schwarzchild and Edward Mandell, now executive vice president and creative director, had worked. **********Helitzer was also a toy specialty agency. And toys have been Dick Schwarzchild's calling since, after majoring in English at the University of Connecticut, he decided he didn't like being either a supervisor in a metal rolling plant in Flushing or a management trainee in a cigar-rolling plant in Wilkes-Barre. Instead, he opened a toy store in the latter location, right across the street from the area's biggest toy discounter. **********It wasn't long before he switched inventory to hobby items. That led eventually to a job as vice president for advertising and marketing with Aurora, the model car makers, and that led to Helitzer. **********So it is a man with considerable experience who says, ''There are four possible combinations. You can have a good product and bad promotion. A bad product and good promotion. A bad product and bad promotion or a good product with good promotion. These days you don't go to market without a good product and good promotion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.main_headline: Careers; More Jobs For Middle Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.print_headline: Careers; More Jobs For Middle Managers
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/13/busin.body_text: **********THE outlook has begun to brighten for job-seeking middle managers, those business people who earn anywhere from $35,000 to $100,000 a year. **********Jack Erdlen, executive director of the Employment Management Association, a group of personnel managers, says: ''Companies are coming back into the labor market cautiously, and the outlook for middle managers is hopeful. This is not a false alarm.'' **********During the recession, he noted last week, some managers were required to wear two hats, but now they intend to hire assistants.  Attrition was low, Mr. Erdlen said, resulting in relatively few openings as wary employees hung onto their jobs. **********Encouragement for middle managers is also provided by a host of management recruiting firms that regularly survey their clients. **********William E. Gould, executive vice president of the Association of Executive Search Consultants, recently said: ''Top-level positions are the first to come back in a recovery, followed by second-tier executives. The next category experiencing demand will be the middle management ranks, and then lower middle management will be picking up.'' In this breakdown, middle management includes salaries of $60,000 to $99,000, while lower middle management is below $60,000. **********According to the consensus, the reduction of senior staff positions has about ended, and corporations are beginning to fill executive vacancies and to revive lower middle management jobs that had been abolished. **********Management Recruiters International of Cleveland polled 1,850 personnel managers recently before predicting that ''hiring of management and professional people will skyrocket in the third quarter.'' **********Management recruiters are paid a fee by companies to fill individual executive and middle management posts for them. Most recruiters say they do not deal with unemployed managers but instead look for prospects who work for other companies. **********There is good news for middle managers from outplacement firms. In contrast to management recruiters, outplacement firms guide the dismissed employee, usually a top or middle manager, until a new job can be found. They provide the job seeker with advice and support to ease the trauma of being thrown out of work, as well as office space and a telephone. The company that is dismissing the manager pays the outplacement firm a fee for all this. **********Unemployed managers often tap the ''hidden'' job market, relying on suggestions from friends and interviews with companies that may have openings but do not advertise them. **********James E. Challenger, president of Challenger, Gra & Christmas, a Chicago-based outplacement firm, said job-seeking middle managers are ''better off than six months ago except for one group - the younger managers aged 38 through 43.'' He said: ''These are people who had advanced relatively fast in their companies, and they are having trouble finding jobs with equally good salaries. They used to be the group most in demand, but companies now are buying more experience with the same money.'' **********A younger middle manager, Mr. Challenger said, must generally look longer before finding a job - about four and a half months, compared with three and a half months for managers in other age groups. Women managers have a harder time finding jobs than men do, he said. And older job seekers in the 55-to-60 age bracket require anywhere from four and a half to five months to find work. **********Even during the darkest days of the recession, middle managers guided by outplacement firms were able to find jobs, Mr. Challenger said, although it took longer than now. **********More middle managers seeking jobs nowadays, he noted, are willing to move to another part of the country, and he estimated that 35 percent do have to move, compared with 20 percent before the recession. **********''Some companies that said they would not add people are adding them now,'' Mr. Challenger said. ''We know of a textile company that six months ago was not hiring anybody. It just hired two men at $42,000 and $55,000.'' **********More companies now show responsibility toward employees they displace, for whatever reason, and their use of outplacement is increasing. Staff members at a lower level sometimes benefit, Mr.  Challenger said. ''Why, we even handled one person with an $8,000 salary,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.main_headline: POPE PRAISES LUTHER IN AN APPEAL FOR UNITY ON PROTEST ANNIVERSARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.print_headline: POPE PRAISES LUTHER IN AN APPEAL FOR UNITY ON PROTEST ANNIVERSARY
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/06/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II, in a letter issued today, praised Martin Luther, the father of the Reformation who was excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church, saying the world is still ''experiencing his great impact on history.'' **********His comments were contained in a letter to the president of the Pontifical Secretariat for the Union of Christians, Johannes Cardinal Willebrands, to mark the anniversary of Martin Luther, whose 500th birthday will be celebrated next Thursday. The text of the letter was made public by the Vatican, **********In a related development, it was announced that Pope John Paul would preach on Dec. 11 in a Lutheran church here. The announcement was made by Christoph Meyer, the dean of the church, the Evangelical Lutheran Christoph Church, which has served the resident German community for 168 years. The service will be held in German, and the Pope will preach in the language of Martin Luther. **********The letter from the Pope to Cardinal Willebrands, was dated Oct. 31, 1983, the anniversary of the date in 1517 when Luther nailed his 95 theses on the door of the castle church of Wittenberg, Germany, giving birth to the Protestant Reformation. The Pope wrote the letter to Cardinal Willebrands, the Archbishop of Utrecht, in German. **********The Pope referred to Luther as the theologian who ''contributed in a substantial way to the radical change in the ecclesiastical and secular reality in the West.'' He continued: ''Our world still experiences his great impact on history.'' **********The Pope noted with satisfaction that the Protestant churches had declared the anniversary year to be an occasion that should serve ''a genuine ecumenical spirit'' and said that he saw this as a ''fraternal invitation'' to a joint reflection on the history and inheritance of Luther. **********Roman Catholic and Protestant studies have yielded a more balanced picture of Luther's personality and the realities of the 16th century, the Pope continued, and shown that ''the rupture in ecclesiastical unity cannot be reduced to the lack of comprehension by Catholic Church authorities or solely to Luther's lack of understanding of true Catholicism, even if both factors played a role.'' **********The Pope called for continued historical research, ''that does not take sides, motivated only be the search for truth,'' to provide ''a true image'' of Luther and the Reformation. ''Guilt, wherever it exists, must be recognized, on whichever side it is found,'' the Pope wrote.   Continue Search for Unity **********John Paul called on Cardinal Willebrands to continue the ecumenical dialogue in quest of restoration of Christian unity and offered a special prayer and blessing for this work. **********''The clarification of history that turns to the past and whose significance persists must go in equal steps with the dialogue of faith which we at present embark on to look for unity,'' the Pope wrote. **********The Pope said the anniversary year was ''an occasion to meditate, in Christian truth and charity, on that event engraved in history that was the epoch of the Reformation.'' **********''It is time that we distance ourselves from historic events and assure that they are often better understood and evoked,'' the Pope said. John Paul said Luther was a man of ''profound religiousness'' who was ''driven by the examination of eternal salvation.''  Papal Visit Arranged Last Year **********Mr. Meyer, the dean of the Lutheran church where the Pope will preach next month, said in a telephone interview that the Pope's visit had been arranged more than a year ago, when John Paul paid a Sunday afternoon call to the Roman Catholic parish in which the Lutheran church is situated. The Catholic authorities invited Mr. Meyer and the board members of his congregation to attend the service for the Pope. **********To Mr. Meyer's surprise, one of the board members approached John Paul and asked him whether he would participate in a Lutheran service during the anniversary year. The Protestant parson recalled tonight that he was even more surprised when the Pope answered ''yes.'' **********Two days later, Mr. Meyer said he attended an ecumenical service in the Pope's presence and used the occasion to approach John Paul to continue the earlier discussion. He said John Paul agreed quickly to hold the promised sermon in his church and specified that he wanted to do so during the Advent period, which he said was a time for penance and reflection. Dec. 11 is the third Sunday of Advent. **********In announcing the event tonight, a press agency of the Italian evangelical churches said that before the Pope's participation in the Lutheran service the Lutheran community of Rome would publish a statement that to receive the Pope in its church does not mean recognition of Papal authority over the Lutheran Church. **********Mr. Meyer said that he did not know the contents of the Pope's sermon but said it was reasonable to expect that it would contain a statement on Luther.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.main_headline: RACE FOR EXCHANGE'S TOP JOB The 22-member board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange is starting to consider a replacement for William M. Batten, the exchange's 74- year-old chairman and chief executive whose contract expires next May.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.print_headline: RACE FOR EXCHANGE'S TOP JOB The 22-member board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange is starting to consider a replacement for William M. Batten, the exchange's 74- year-old chairman and chief executive whose contract expires next May.
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/29/busin.body_text: **********Many people on Wall Street regard John J. Phelan Jr., the president and No. 2 man at the exchange, as a strong contender. But few are ready to say the race is over. **********William Milfred Batten, nicknamed Mil, became the Big Board's second paid chairman in April 1976. His original five-year, $2 million contract was to have expired in May 1981 but was extended three years in recognition of his accomplishments. **********Mr. Phelan, 52, a former specialist on the trading floor and the son of a specialist, became the exchange's full-time president and chief operating officer in May 1980. Known as somewhat volatile, he has been intimately involved in the modernizing of the exchange and is popular among several present and former directors. **********''I'm certainly one of the people who's one of John's fans in the exchange,'' said Roberta S. Karmel, a New York lawyer who joined the board in May. However, she called the question of Mr. Batten's successor ''very premature.'' **********According to Martha Redfield Wallace, a director whose term expired in May, Mr. Phelan is likely to be promoted, although he may end up sharing the top spot with someone who is more closely associated with business and government. **********Another former director, who asked not to be named, said, ''I think if you had any kind of vote while I was on the board, John Phelan was the overwhelming favorite.'' **********This source added that Mr. Phelan's fortunes might now be riding on the success of a new product that the exchange is introducing Sept. 23: an option on the New York Stock Exchange composite index. ''If you saw that thing turn into a bomb, which we obviously do not anticipate, he'd get the needle for it,'' the former director said. ''That would revive the N.Y.F.E. problem.'' **********This reference was to the New York Futures Exchange, a Big Board subsidiary that Mr. Phelan has headed since it began in August 1980. Several of its products have failed to arouse investor enthusiasm, and the New York Stock Exchange reported losing $2.9 million on the futures operation last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/10/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********John Sawhill is to be congratulated for his perceptive article ''The Reagan Plan Is Not Enough'' (March 27).  Many of the changes in the gas industry Mr. Sawhill advocates are contained in bills introduced by Congressman Joseph Addabbo and Senator John Heinz. **********The bills are not quick-fix, short-term solutions. They are very practical proposals for removing the causes of unresponsiveness (take-or-pay commitments, indefinite price escalators, etc.) by gas producers and gas pipelines to price signals from gas consumers. Furthermore, they encourage continued exploration and production for new gas reserves. **********Mr. Sawhill's assertion, however, that ''Congress will have to acknowledge that the lesson of natural gas regulation is not to do it better but not to do it at all'' is simplistic. Residential consumers cannot change fuels in response to market forces or pricing signals as readily as they can change their brand of soap or toothpaste.  Experience and logic dictate not more or less regulation, but what is reasonable and fair.   JAMES W. DUNLOP, Vice President, Brooklyn Union Gas, New York, March 30. The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters for publication should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.  Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Business Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/busin.main_headline: U.S. SAYS EX-AIDE STOLE ITS COMPUTER DATA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/busin.print_headline: U.S. SAYS EX-AIDE STOLE ITS COMPUTER DATA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/05/busin.body_text: **********A former economist with the Federal Reserve Board who left to work for a brokerage firm was charged today with illegally tapping the Federal Reserve's computer to obtain secret data about the nation's money supply. **********Federal officials said that soon after joining E. F. Hutton as a forecaster, the economist, Theode C. Langevin was caught by tracing the phone calls he made to the computer. Officials then let him tap into a computer programmed with phony money figures so that he could be caught ''with his hands in the cookie jar,'' an official said. **********Money supply data, if obtained in advance of its release each Friday by the Federal Reserve, would be of tremendous value to a forecaster working in a brokerage house that trades in stocks and bonds. Interest rates and yields of Government securities and bonds often move up or down when changes in the growth rate of the money supply are reported. **********Mr. Langevin, 34 years old, went to work for Hutton in New York after leaving the Federal Reserve on Nov. 19. But he was at Hutton for only 10 days before being asked to leave because of the allegations of his computer-tapping, according to Thomas Rae, Hutton's general counsel. **********At Hutton, Mr. Langevin was a ''Fed watcher,'' whose job was to predict Reserve policy and its impact on the the credit markets.  Information filed in Federal District Court here by an Assistant United States District Attorney, William S. Block, indicated that Mr.Langevin tried to gain access to the Federal Reserve's computers in late November, just after he had left the Reserve for Hutton. **********The information document, which is a little more than two pages long, said that Mr. Langevin had used the name of someone still working at the Federal Reserve and that person's access code to the computer to try to get at the money supply data by calling up the computer through the use of a terminal connected to a telephone.  Based on a normal procedure, according to former employees, Mr.  Langevin's computer access code, if he had his own, would have been canceled even before he left the Federal Reserve. **********Mr. Langevin is the first person to be formally charged with trying to get secret money supply data from the Federal Reserve computer system, and his case has raised questions about the security of the system. **********It also caused concerns in the financial markets because the information on the nation's money supply, if known before its official release, could give someone an early indication of the probable course of interest rates. That would provide an invaluable edge in playing the bond market. **********Officials said that the information in the dummy computer program was fabricated money supply data. The court filing did not say whether Mr. Langevin obtained accurate information in earlier attempts. Mr. Rae of Hutton said, however, that Mr. Langevin ''prepared no figures for Hutton nor were any of his figures used for Hutton's proprietary account or those of our customers.'' **********An official in the United States Attorney's office said that when an information document was filed in a felony case it often meant the defendant was expected to waive his right to a grand jury indictment and plead guilty to the charge. The maximum penalty for the charge of fraud by wire is five years in jail and a $1,000 fine. Hearing Expected Next Week **********A hearing is expected next week, the official said. Mr. Langevin, reached at his home in Laurel, Md., said he had no comment. His lawyer, Leslie G. Fein, also declined to comment. A spokesman for the Federal Reserve, Joseph Coyne, referred all questions to Mr.  Block. Mr. Block would not comment on the charges. **********Because neither Mr. Langevin nor his lawyer would comment, there is no indication whether Mr. Langevin will plead guilty. Former employees of the Federal Reserve who knew Mr. Langevin could not say why he reportedly tried to tap the computer. But some suggested that he might have ''ended up over his head'' in his new job as a ''Fed watcher,'' under considerable pressure to produce accurate forecasts of interest rate movements. **********Mr. Langevin worked at the Federal Reserve for almost seven years and for the last 18 months of his employment was an economist in the Federal Reserve's research and statistics division, according to the information. **********Former officials said that his job required him to gather bank deposit data used in computing money supply changes and he would have had access to the computer. But it could not be confirmed if Mr.  Langevin had access to the computer on his own while he worked at the Fed. Details Sketchy **********The details of what Mr. Langevin did are still very sketchy because no officials will comment on the record and little is said off the record. But, apparently, Mr. Langevin at some point after Nov. 12, according to the information, devised his scheme to tap the computer. **********The information document said that an attempt to tap the computer was made on or about Nov. 22, just days after he joined Hutton.  Officals indicated that there were other attempts, but the information is based on only one call. **********Officals said that the computer recognized this attempt but will not say how. After that, the Federal Reserve informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office here. Apparently, the phone lines into the computer were then fixed so that incoming calls could be traced. In this way, officials said, the code Mr. Langevin reportedly used was traced back to him at Hutton. **********It was then that Hutton officials were informed of the investigation, officials said, and then the dummy program was added to the computer. **********Mr. Rae of Hutton said that the company had cooperated with the F.B.I. and knew that Mr. Langevin was under investigation several days before he was asked to leave the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.print_headline: CASTRO AND FOREIGN POLICY: HIS OWN MASTER?; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/28/world.body_text: **********In a speech here Tuesday summarizing the accomplishments of his 25 years in power, Fidel Castro seemed to play down Cuban ties to the Soviet Union. ''Not in the past, not now or ever have we made decisions at a cost to others or expected others to fight for us,'' the Cuban leader said. **********A Cuban journalist, analyzing the remark later, suggested it was a message to those who believed that the Soviet Union, Cuba's economic underwriter, was also responsible for the defense of Cuba and its military involvement abroad. **********The crowd listening to the President applauded most enthusiastically at such references to the country's self-reliance.  Mr. Castro dwelt on what he said was an ''atmosphere of terror'' the United States was trying to create around Nicaragua, asserting it was seeking to deploy troops in Central America through military maneuvers now beginning in the region. He made no direct reference to the role of the Soviet Union in Cuba's development until he came to a series of fraternal greetings at the end of his speech. **********Isolating the 'Anglos' **********Realistic or not, the strategy outlined here this week by Mr.  Castro and by Deputy Foreign Minister Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, who talks frequently with Western journalists, is apparently aimed at several constituencies. **********Playing on a traditional theme of anti-Americanism in Latin America, the policy appears to seek the isolation of the hemisphere's ''Anglos'' symbolized by the United States. **********The policy also stresses the commitment of Cuba to what amounts to making the region safe for ''socialism'' -almost a mirror image of the Reagan Administration's emphasis on curtailing the spread of ''Communism.'' The stuggle going on in Central America, Mr. Castro said, was ''not local, but worldwide.'' **********Finally, the Cubans appeal to an economically strapped third world with assurances that the capitalist system is moribund - racked, Mr.  Castro said, by ''exploitation, racism, prostitution and drugs'' - and that the developing nations with their tightly controlled systems will be among the world's leaders ''within the next 25 years.'' Some Old Themes **********While the tenets of Cuba's foreign policy may not be new - Mr.  Castro said many similar things while chairman of the group of nations calling themselves nonaligned - they appear to weather well despite their reliance on well-worn anti-imperialist jargon. **********The Cuban leader's call for the isolation of the United States and the promotion of ''our Latin America'' has found more sympathetic ears since the war in the Falkland Islands, when the alignment of Washington with the British produced an outpouring of Latin American self-awareness. **********Even Nicaragua sided with Argentina during that war, despite the fact that Argentines were then training rebels trying to overthrow the Government in Managua. The Argentine advisers have now all but disappeared from Central America. **********During the war, Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, came to Havana for a conference and was warmly welcomed. Relations between the two nations have been better ever since, according to Cuban officials. **********Venezuelan diplomats also report some repairing of bad relations between Havana and Caracas after the war for what all Latin Americans call the Malvinas. Bolivar's Name Invoked **********On Tuesday Mr. Castro invoked the name of the Venezuelan-born liberator Simon Bolivar and drew him into the revolutionary pantheon.  Turning to the Communist world, Mr. Castro assured his allies that Cuba's revolution was always at heart a Communist revolution. He said it was the work of Marx, Engels and Lenin in conjunction with the thinking of the 19th-century Cuban hero Jose Marti that gave the Castro revolution its understanding of the problems facing Cuba and allowed the Cubans to develop ''many years ahead of the countries of Latin America.'' **********The threads of Cuba's policy come together on an issue like Nicaragua, which is portrayed as a poor nation sharing Cuba's revolutionary goals while being terrorized by the United States. **********Mr. Alarcon praised the efforts of the Contadora Group nations - Colombia, Mexico, Panama and Venezuela - to bring peace to Central America because they were working ''outside the inter-American system.'' Cuba was excluded from the Organization of American States in 1962. **********Important to the carrying out of Cuba's foreign policy in the third world as well as in Latin American and European capitals is a new generation of Cuban diplomats and development experts who have grown up or been educated during the Castro years. An international presence both militarily and in civilan advisory roles, they exude a self-confidence that third world and some Western diplomats say is very effective.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/23/world.body_text: **********In a rebuff to Prime Minister Menachem Begin's governing coalition, Parliament today elected Chaim Herzog of the opposition Labor Party as the next President of Israel. **********The Government's candidate was Supreme Court Justice Menachem Elon. Seven members of Mr. Begin's coalition did not support his candidate in the voting, which was secret. **********The 61-to-57 vote, with 2 blank ballots, was a setback for the coalition, but it seemed unlikely to have major repercussions. The Prime Minister, brushing off the defeat with a smile and the comment, ''C'est la vie,'' said he would not join several coalition legislators in support of early parliamentary elections unless all the small parties in the governing bloc agreed. The small parties fear a drubbing in an early election, so Mr. Begin's condition appeared to reduce the chances of one. **********Because the presidency is ceremonial and carries no governmental authority, the substantive effect of Mr. Herzog's victory is not expected to be great. Israel's five previous Presidents have stayed aloof from political issues of the day, acting only as symbols of the state, receiving ambassadors' credentials and the like. **********It has even been difficult to get public figures to accept the post. Until the current President, Yitzhak Navon of Labor, was elected in 1978, those chosen were generally considered not to have further political ambition. **********President Navon has revised that image by becoming a somewhat activist President and by emerging as a potential leader of the Labor Party after he leaves office in early May. **********As President, he has largely avoided divisive issues but has stepped in to adopt a moral tone at crucial moments. During the bitter election campaign of 1981, for example, when Begin supporters were disrupting Labor rallies, he pleaded for mutual respect. And after the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut by Lebanese Christian Phalangists last September, he called for the creation of an Israeli commission of inquiry, resisted by the Government. **********Mr. Herzog is a former general and a former diplomat whose tenure as chief delegate to the United Nations made him well known to Americans. An outgoing and congenial man, he is expected to keep the presidency energetic, highly visible and above politics. He began immediately to avoid partisanship, playing down the political significance of his victory and telling reporters that the secret ballot was intended precisely to minimize the political overtones of the election. **********''I already don't feel that I'm the opposition candidate anymore,'' he said. ''The Speaker of the Knesset informed me in the name of the Knesset that today I have been chosen by the whole Knesset, and from now on, that's how I'll act.'' **********He was elected with the minimum votes necessary - 61 of the 120-member house - on the first ballot, which surprised even Labor's floor manager, Uzi Bar-Am, who said that he had been confident but thought it would take at least two ballots. The corridors of Parliament were full of speculation afterward about who the seven defectors from Mr. Begin's candidate were. **********''There's a lot of poison out there because nobody knows who voted for Herzog,'' Nahum Barnea, editor of the weekly newsmagazine Kiteret Rashit, said. **********The Israeli radio reported that one member of Mr. Begin's Likud bloc, Meir Shitreet, said that the defectors should be weeded out of the coalition and that he would not oppose the use of lie detectors to identify them. **********Another Likud member, Roni Milo, resigned as acting coalition chairman, saying that all the coalition legislators had told him they would vote for Justice Elon. ''When you find yourself in a political framework in which you know at least seven men, if not more, lied brazenly, and these are also men who should accept the close and important decisions of the state, then it's very heavy, very hard,'' he said. **********Some coalition members were playing down the loss, saying Mr.  Herzog had won practically by default because other widely known public figures declined to run. **********The Government was left with Justice Elon, who was virtually unknown to the Israeli public. On the Labor side, Shlomo Hillel, a prominent legislator, turned down the post, leaving Mr. Herzog as the only Labor candidate. **********Mr. Herzog is to leave his seat in Parliament when he takes office May 5.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/03/busin.print_headline: SPEAKES'S TONE ANGERS REAGAN, OFFICIAL REPORTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/03/busin.body_text: **********Several former heads of the Council of Economic Advisers indicated that the current chairman had been too outspoken. Page 29. **********WASHINGTON. Dec. 2 - A senior White House official said today that President Reagan had been angered by the tone taken by Larry Speakes, his spokesman, in commenting on Wednesday about Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers. **********The official said Mr. Reagan objected to the manner, but not the substance, of Mr. Speakes's repeated criticism of Mr. Feldstein for his public insistence on the need to reduce the Federal deficit through tax increases. **********On Wednesday, in response to a question, Mr. Speakes said all of Mr. Reagan's aides were familiar with his position on these matters, ''with the possible exception of the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.'' **********Mr. Speakes also repeatedly pronounced Mr. Feldstein's name two different ways, provoking laughter from some reporters. And he joked that, although the economist was in attendance at a lunch with the President, ''maybe he won't make it to dessert.'' Mr. Reagan was reported by the White House official, who asked not to be identified, to have thrown down on his desk a copy of The New York Times reporting the Speakes comments, saying ''I don't like this. This is not the way I want to operate.'' The official said the President made the remark at a meeting with top aides on Thursday.  The official said: ''It's one thing to criticize Feldstein on the substance of the policies. He's been a problem for us. It's another thing to be sarcastic about it and mispronounce his name. It's another to make him a martyr.'' **********Two Pronunciations of Name **********Mr. Speakes said this evening that he had pronounced the name alternately as Feld-STINE and as Feld-STEEN because he had long had difficulty in remembering that Mr. Feldstein uses the Feld-STINE pronounciation. ''I frequently make that mistake,'' Mr. Speakes said. **********Mr. Speakes added that President Reagan had not informed him personally of any unhappiness with the comments he made Wednesday, but he said that others had told him Mr. Reagan was unhappy with the suggestion of ridicule implied in the repeated mispronounciation. He added that The Times had ''mishandled'' its account by suggesting that he was making fun of the name. **********''I would never ever make fun of anybody's name,'' Mr. Speakes said. ''My own name is vulnerable on that account.'' He added that the tone of ridicule at the briefing was set by the sarcastic questions of reporters. **********During the briefing, Mr. Speakes announced that Mr. Feldstein had not been invited to a high-level meeting then under way between the President and aides on the budget and economic issues. Told that Mr. Feldstein might in fact be in attendance, Mr. Speakes - amid much laughter - sent an aide to find out why he was there. **********Mr. Speakes's criticism of Mr. Feldstein had been provoked by recent speeches by the economist suggesting that the Federal deficit had grown because of tax cuts and increases in military spending, not because of increases in domestic spending.  This runs counter to Mr. Reagan's emphasis of blaming domestic spending programs for the deficit. **********Stand on Taxes **********In addition, Mr. Feldstein has pushed hard for a standby tax increase, to take effect in 1985 if Congress accepted the President's spending cuts, if the projected deficit was above 2.5 percent of the projected gross national product and if the economy was expanding. Mr. Feldstein, a former Harvard economist who joined the Administration last August, has made clear his view that the tax will be necessary. **********While the plan was supported by Mr. Reagan in January, the Administration has since played it down and raised questions about whether Mr. Reagan would resubmit it. **********Mr. Speakes's comment at the briefing on Wednesday, coupled with anonymous comments made by White House officials, suggested that Mr. Feldstein was under rising pressure to soften his warnings about the Federal deficit or resign. **********Mr. Feldstein, responding to the criticism by Mr. Speakes, said the next day that he would not resign unless asked to do so by Mr. Reagan. **********Mr. Speakes said tonight that it was decided 10 days earlier among top Presidential aides that the next time he was asked about Mr. Feldstein at a briefing, he should respond with a rebuke. ''The decision to put that out when asked was made at the highest level of the White House,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/08/world.body_text: **********In action previous to today's vote by the House Foreign Affairs Committee to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, Congressional committees took these steps: **********- On May 3 the House intelligence committee approved and referred to the Foreign Affairs Committee a bill that would force the President to stop, sometime during this fiscal year, all covert aid for the anti-Government forces in Nicaragua. The bill also authorized $80 million in this fiscal year and the next to help countries in Central America block the cross-border shipment of arms to leftist guerrillas. **********- On May 6 the Senate intelligence committee adopted a bill that would allow the Central Intelligence Agency to continue covert activities in Nicaragua until the end of the current fiscal year on Sept. 30. The President would have to submit a new plan for covert actions in the next fiscal year and the committee would have to vote approval. That provision is intended to force the Reagan Administration to be more explicit on what it hopes to accomplish in Nicaragua, according to Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, the committee chairman.
