https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/27/busin.main_headline: PROFITS OFF AT TEXACO, MOBIL, SHELL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/27/busin.print_headline: PROFITS OFF AT TEXACO, MOBIL, SHELL
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/27/busin.body_text: **********Three of the nation's largest oil companies reported lower fourthquarter earnings yesterday, blaming them on the weak demand for oil and slim profit margins in Europe. The Mobil Corporation said its earnings fell 52 percent, Texaco Inc. reported a 39.6 decline and the Shell Oil Company said its net income dropped 4.4 percent. **********For Mobil, the nation's second-largest energy concern after the Exxon Corporation, and for Texaco, which ranks third, the problems were most severe in oil production, refining and marketing abroad. As partners in the Arabian American Oil Company, or Aramco, which produces and markets much of Saudi Arabia's oil, they are forced to purchase crude from the Saudis at prices higher than competitors pay for similar quality oil produced by others. That has squeezed their profit margins for petroleum products refined from Saudi crude. **********Mobil and Texaco were also hurt by sharply reduced demand for refined products in Europe and the strength of the dollar, which reduced earnings in terms of dollars for petroleum products sold in foreign currencies. **********Analysts said they were not surprised by Shell's narrow earnings decline because the company, which ranks ninth among domestic energy concerns, confines its refining and marketing operations almost exclusively to this country. **********The reduced earnings reported by Mobil and Texaco came the day after both Exxon and the Standard Oil Company of California, also partners in Aramco, reported weak fourth-quarter earnings, in part because of the Aramco problem. **********''We're expecting some improvement in 1983, but that's premised on an expectation that oil prices won't break,'' said James S. Jordan, an analyst with Duff & Phelps. ''At the moment, it's almost impossible to predict anything. And in any case, we're not looking for anything like a strong environment'' for the major oil companies, he added. **********At Texaco, meanwhile, John K. McKinley, the company's chairman and chief executive officer, was critical of the OPEC nations' failure to reach a price and production agreement. ''The actions of the OPEC nations failed to recognize the realities of the marketplace,'' he said in a formal release. Mobil **********Mobil reported fourth-quarter net income of $282 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with $587 million, or $1.38 a share the year earlier. Revenues declined 10.5 percent, to $16.2 billion, from $18.1 billion. **********For the full year, Mobil said its earnings fell 43.2 percent, to $1.38 billion, or $3.31 a share, from $2.43 billion, or $5.72 a share. Revenues for the year fell 7 percent, to $63.8 billion, from $68.6 billion. **********The company said it suffered its sharpest earnings declines in its foreign operations, which produced 44 percent lower earnings for the year; in its chemical operations, where earnings were down 77 pecent, and in its Container Corporation of America subsidiary, which had a 60 percent earnings decline. **********One area of improvement, however, was in Mobil's ailing retailing subsidiary, Montgomery Ward & Company. Ward had a loss of $92 million for the year, Mobil said, but during the fourth quarter it had earnings of $16 million compared with a loss of $22 million in the fourth quarter a year earlier. Texaco **********Texaco Inc., said that net income in the fourth quarter fell to $306 million, or $1.18 a share, from $507 million, or $1.96 a share, in the same period a year earlier, Revenues in the same period slid 19.9 percent, to $11.7 billion, from $14.6 billion. **********Net income for the year, Texaco said, declined 44.3 percent, to $1.28 billion, or $4.92 a share, from $2.3 billion, or $8.75 a share, the year before. Revenues were off 19.1 percent at $48 billion, down from $59.3 billion a year earlier. Shell **********Shell Oil said that fourth-quarter profits fell to $438 million, or $1.42 a share, from $458 million, or $1.48 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues for the quarter fell slightly to $5.18 billion, from $5.19 billion in the same period the year before. **********Profits for the year, it said, fell 5.3 percent, to $1.61 billion, or $5.19 a share, from $1.7 billion, or $5.51 a share, a year earlier . Revenues fell 7.1 percent in the same period, to $20.2 billion, from $21.74 billion a year earlier. **********John F. Bookout, president, attributed last year's profit decline to lower sales and lower prices plus higher manufacturing costs that more than offset lower costs for raw materials. **********He said Shell was planning capital and exploratory outlays of $3.7 billion this year, about the same as in 1982, with domestic spending for exploration and production expected to account for about $2.8 billion, or slightly higher than last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/14/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates for bank money market accounts continued to rise in major cities in the week ended Wednesday, but dropped slightly in the New York area, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. **********The Monitor's nationwide average, based on a weekly survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, rose to 8.4 percent, up from 8.38 percent last week and 8.34 percent the week before. **********In the New York area, the average rate dropped to 8.62 percent, from 8.64 percent last week, based on a survey of 10 New York banks and savings and loan institutions. The weekly decline was the fourth since April 20. **********The New York decline reflected a change by Goldome Banks, which cut its rate to 8.75 percent, from 8.9 percent. Goldome also raised the rate offered at its Buffalo branches, to 8.5 percent, from 8.4 percent. **********New York rates remain the highest in the country, according to The Monitor. Philadelphia banks in the survey paid an average rate of 8.42 percent, and Los Angeles and Chicago banks paid an average of 8.37 percent. Detroit area banks paid the lowest rate, at 8.2 percent. **********Rates paid nationwide on Super-Now accounts, which give customers check writing privileges, averaged 7.09 percent, unchanged from the week before. In New York, the rate was 7.15 percent, up from 7.14 percent last week. **********Last Wednesday, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said that the money market mutual funds, which compete directly with the bank money market accounts, offered an average seven-day yield of 8.22 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/12/busin.main_headline: Your Money; Opening I.R.A.  Affects '82 Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/12/busin.print_headline: Your Money; Opening I.R.A.  Affects '82 Tax
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/03/12/busin.body_text: **********UPON figuring out your income tax now and finding that money is owed the Government, all may not be lost. There still may be a way of easing the tax bite. **********The Individual Retirement Account, of course, is the welladvertised vehicle. But there are ins and outs to setting one up just now for the 1982 tax year. Can a person deduct an I.R.A. on a return before actually buying one? What happens if you have already filed, have a fat return and now want to open an I.R.A. with that money? **********Generally speaking, contributions can be made to an I.R.A. to reduce the 1982 tax up until April 15, plus any extensions. ''It's one of the few things I can think of,'' said Thomas Sherman, personal finance planner at Coopers & Lybrand, ''that a person can do three and a half months after the end of the year and still have it affect the prior year's tax liability.'' **********The maximum contribution is 100 percent of earned income, up to a maximum contribution of $2,000. Persons with a nonworking spouse can contribute $2,250 and married couples who both work can put away $4,000. The latter, for example, would generate a $2,000 tax saving in the 50 percent bracket. **********The answer to whether a person who has already filed a 1982 Federal return can still take advantage of the tax benefit is ''yes.'' Simply open an I.R.A. and file an amended return on Form 1040X. That can be done until April 15, but no extensions are allowed if the return has already been filed. **********''Take a situation,'' said Samuel Murray of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting concern, ''where just shortly after the year you do a rough calculation and figure you've overpaid your taxes. You quickly file a return to get the refund. Then you hear you can get a $2,000 deduction for a contribution to an I.R.A. You could use the refund to open an I.R.A. and then file a 1040X to claim the deduction.'' **********People who claim a deduction for an I.R.A. on their return without actually opening one - but with the idea that they have until April 15 to do so - may run afoul of the Internal Revenue Service.  Theoretically, a refund could be generated with this deduction and the money utilized to open the I.R.A. ''This kind of makes the service a little irritable,'' Mr. Murray said. ''Your first return was fraudulent, they would say, because you showed a transaction that hasn't occurred.'' **********That is indeed the I.R.S.'s stand. Ellen Murphy, an I.R.S.  spokesman, said that ''a return is supposed to show completed transactions.'' Mr. Murray and Keith Rollins of Ernst & Whinney, another accounting firm, both dispute the I.R.S.'s reasoning, however. ''I feel,'' Mr. Murray said, ''that if at the time you filed the return you intended to contribute $2,000 to an I.R.A. and you did indeed on or before April 15 - I fail to see where the fraud is.  There's nothing in the statute that says you must make it no later than the time you filed the return.'' **********Mr. Rollins agreed, adding: ''If I've got a client in that situation who hasn't yet made the contribution I'm not going to tell him that it's wrong as long as he makes the contribution by April 15.'' **********Unless you are willing to challenge the I.R.S., however, it appears that the no-contribution, no-deduction policy prevails.  Financial advisers urge the opening of I.R.A.'s as a general proposition for most people. Earnings in the I.R.A. accumulate taxfree until they can be withdrawn - without penalty starting at age 59 1/2. Mr. Sherman of Coopers & Lybrand notes that, with changes coming in Social Security, people will be forced to rely more on their own assets in retirement. **********Shorter term, of course, the I.R.A. gets less attractive. Opening one to avoid paying taxes with the intent of ending it later in the year does not work well. A person might be willing to pay the 10 percent penalty if there could be a saving, say, of $1,000 in taxes, but when the I.R.A. account is closed the money goes back into gross income. ''At least you deferred the tax for another 12 months,'' Mr.  Murray said. ''There isn't a great advantage in doing it.'' Holding the money for at least two or three years, however, might at least put you ahead of the game with the cumulative return on investment.  The 10 percent penalty is ''not terribly severe'' if circumstances dictate that you get at the funds, Mr. Sherman said. **********Financial advisers say that people ought to get in on I.R.A.'s even if money must be borrowed to set one up. Borrowing costs are taxdeductible. **********Cindy Bailey, manager of the Chase Exchange, a financial advisory program at the Chase Manhattan Bank, said that, even though an I.R.A. might be financed with a personal loan carrying perhaps 17 to 19 percent interest, it is still worth it for people in higher brackets. ''Our experience here is that a lot of people find it easier to make the loan payments than to save on their own for the I.R.A.,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/02/busin.body_text: **********The disclosure statement mailed to the 80,000 creditors who have approved the Hyatt Corporation's plan to revive Braniff Airways contains a warning: ''There has never been an air carrier that has resumed an airline operation with as many as 30 aircraft following a reorganization under the Bankruptcy Code.'' **********The unprecedented nature of the attempt, approved yesterday by Federal Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers, is only one of numerous factors that make clear the extreme risk in trying to put Braniff back in the sky and keep it there, using the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport as its hub. **********Not only would a new Braniff need to offer fares and services that distinguish it from American and Delta, its two powerful rivals at Dallas-Fort Worth, but it also would have to break their stranglehold on the passenger traffic there. They control 80 percent of it. **********Test for Pritzker **********Airline executives and industry analysts said in interviews that the attempt to revive Braniff may be the toughest test to date for Hyatt's chairman, Jay A. Pritzker, whose marketing skills and ability to turn around troubled companies are widely acknowledged. **********''Just because he's been sucessful in the hotel business doesn't mean he can build an airline,'' cautioned the leader of one of Braniff's creditor groups who did not want to be identified. **********In fact, Mr. Prizker's enthusiasm for his reborn airline so far has outrun his ability to deliver a clear and detailed marketing strategy for it, according to the leaders of several creditor groups who spent months negotiating the current agreement. Mr. Pritzker has said only that he has not chosen a name for the new Braniff, that he would recruit the best management available and that the new carrier would offer more amenities than its competitors do. **********''It's pretty clear that when you have a freely competitive industry and you are in a commodity business you have to have a very special product or be a low-cost producer,'' said John V. Pincavage, the airline analyst for Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. **********High Ratings **********Michael Derchin, who follows airlines for the First Boston Corporation, said: ''I don't think there is any way they can come in just as a regular airline. Why would anyone want to switch from American and lose out on such things as their frequent flier program?'' He added that both American and Delta consistently score high in surveys on quality of service and customer satisfaction. **********That the two have carved out strong positions at the Dallas-Forth Worth Airport is beyond question. Last June, for example, American carried 63 percent of the passenger traffic there. It is also in the midst of a $76 million expansion program at the airport. Delta, which carried about 20 percent of the passengers, has a $39 million expansion under way. **********Any attempt by a newcomer to lure customers with heavily discounted fares would probably not work, the analysts say. The other carriers most likely would simply match the fares, just as they did when the old Braniff tried that gambit in the months before it filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on May 13, 1982. **********Braniff and Delta ''would not leave any breathing room,'' Mr. Derchin said. Both airlines are rich in cash, he noted, and would grind down a new carrier that tried to make it on lower fares alone. **********A Strategy Suggested **********Mr. Derchin and others think there is a strategy that might be successful for the new Braniff, though it would be difficult to put together. **********He pointed to Midway Airlines, based in Chicago, which has created a special service called Metrolink. The service, which began on June 19, provides five daily flights between Midway Airport in Chicago and La Guardia in New York and caters to the frequent business traveler. **********For prices below the regular coach fares of the major carriers, Midway offers two-abreast seating on its DC- 9-30's, more carry-on luggage space and better food, as well as schedules to attract the business traveler. **********Another carrier, Air 1, based in St. Louis, has been pursuing a similar business-traveler strategy since April 1. It offers what it describes as first-class service for the price of regular coach. **********The Link to Hyatt **********Although Mr. Pritzker and his management team are still drafting their strategy, he has indicated to various creditor groups that the new Braniff would cater to the business traveler. It would also be closely tied to the hotels of the Hyatt Corporation and would almost certainly use Hyatt's marketing arm to sell the airline. **********The new Braniff is expected to fly to most large cities in the Southwest, as well as major cities, such as Chicago and New York, in the Middle West and the East. **********There is wide agreement in the industry that with deregulation and the proliferation of discount fares many business travelers feel cheated. Most cannot book far enough in advance to qualify for discount fares, yet travel in the same seats and get the same food as the discount passengers. **********''There is a tremendous amount of dissatisfaction,'' Arthur C. Bass, chairman and chief executive officer of Midway, said in an interview. **********Under the plan approved by the creditor groups, Hyatt would assemble $70 million in capital and loans for the new airline. This was the amount that the former chairman of Braniff, Howard D. Putnam, said was the minimum needed to give the airline a chance to establish itself. **********According to the disclosure statement, about $27 million would have to be spent just on preparations, before the airline could put a plane in the air. The carrier, which has begun to recruit its executive staff, plans to hire 2,000 former Braniff employees. **********The 30 Braniff jets appear ready for service except for repainting, but analysts do not expect they will be flying before February. **********In its filing with the bankruptcy court earlier this year, Braniff estimated that in its first year of operations it would generate about $377 million in revenue and have a net loss of $14 million. By the following year, the carrier estimated that it would have a profit of $27 million. **********Much of this assumes that the airline's major unions will fulfill their promise of major wage concessions and flexibility on work rules. Salary and benefit levels will be a key to keeping the carrier's operating costs low enough to achieve the profits needed to keep flying. **********Its timing, however, could be fortunate. Mr. Pincavage of Paine Webber noted that airline travel has been recovering since last spring and that fare discounting has moderated. By early next year, he said, ''everyone should make some money and get away from the discounting problems.'' **********Judge Backs Plan **********FORT WORTH, Sept. 1 (Reuters) - Judge John Flowers of Federal Bankruptcy Court today confirmed the reorganization plan filed by Braniff, which filed for protection from creditors under the Federal bankruptcy law in May 1982. **********After hearing objections from representatives of the company's subordinated bondholders, the judge ruled that the plan was fair and equitable. Opponents of the plan have 10 days to appeal. Otherwise, Braniff can proceed with its reorganization.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/world.main_headline: SOMALIA ANNOUNCES INVASION OF 2 AREAS BY ETHIOPIAN FORCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/world.print_headline: SOMALIA ANNOUNCES INVASION OF 2 AREAS BY ETHIOPIAN FORCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/17/world.body_text: **********Somalia announced today that Ethiopian troops with air support had invaded the central part of the country at dawn today and that there were many casualties. **********There was no independent confirmation of the announcement, nor did the Ethiopian official press issue any similar reports. **********''All enemy invasions have been checked and heavy losses inflicted on them,'' the official Somali press agency quoted the Somali Defense Ministry as saying. Somalia has a military agreement with the United States, which supplied arms during fighting last summer with Ethiopia. **********''The Defense Ministry states that Ethiopian ground and air attacks are still continuing,'' the agency added, but did not say when the Government communique was issued. **********Soldiers from Ethiopia advanced three miles into Somalia at Mataban Qabno, in the Galgadud region, before they were ''forced to retreat,'' the agency said, again quoting the Defense Ministry. The other attack was on Dabad, in the Balambale area of Hiran region, the agency said. **********The areas said to have been invaded are north and northeast of Mogadishu, the capital.   State Dept. Aware of Reports Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, July 16 - A spokesman for the State Department said today that officials were aware of the reports of fighting between Ethiopia and Somalia but that there would be no immediate comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/31/busin.main_headline: STONE CONTAINER TO BUY FOREST UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/31/busin.print_headline: STONE CONTAINER TO BUY FOREST UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/31/busin.body_text: **********The Stone Container Corporation, a manufacturer of corrugated boxes and paper bags, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a large part of the forest products division of the Continental Group for $510 million. **********Included in the acquisition are three paper mills, 15 plants that make corrugated boxes, five plants that make paper bags, and long-term cutting rights on timberland owned by Continental. **********Roger W. Stone, chairman and chief executive office of Stone Container, based in Chicago, said the ''timing of this transaction is particularly advantageous'' because the ''signs clearly point to a significant cyclical upturn for our industry.'' He added that the box and bag plants being acquired, which are scattered across the country, would allow Stone Container to expand its markets in the Sun Belt. **********S. Bruce Smart Jr., Continental's chairman and chief executive officer, said the sale of the forest products operations would result in an ''improved balance sheet'' and lessen the impact of a ''cyclical business on our overall performance.'' **********The transaction ''is highly positive for both companies,'' said Arthur M. Stupay of Prescott, Ball & Turben. **********Continental, a diversified forest products, packaging, insurance and energy company, said it intended to use $288 million of the proceeds of the transaction in a tender offer to repurchase its own common shares. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said it would offer $48 a share for 6 million shares. Continental has 32.7 million common shares outstanding. **********Trading did not open in the shares of either company yesterday. On Monday, Continental shares closed at $43.275, down 12.5 cents, and Stone Container shares closed unchanged at $26.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/21/busin.body_text: **********ABC Earnings Decline 10.4% **********The American Broadcasting Companies reported yesterday that earnings fell 10.4 percent in the third quarter, to $31.8 million, or $1.08 a share, from $35.5 million, or $1.22, a year earlier. **********Revenues rose 8.6 percent, to $659.6 million, from $607.1 million. **********The company attributed its lower earnings to disappointing growth in television advertising revenue as well as to slightly higher losses at ABC Video Enterprises and a decline in interest income. **********Broadcasting revenues for the quarter were $569.6 million, up 8.6 percent from $524.6 million in the 1982 quarter. However, broadcasting profits declined 8.6 percent, to $71.9 million, from $78.7 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.main_headline: DEMOCRATS ASK CURB ON SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.print_headline: DEMOCRATS ASK CURB ON SOUTH AFRICA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/world.body_text: **********Six Democratic Presidential candidates, calling apartheid a ''unique and unconscionable system of legalized discrimination,'' endorsed legislation today that would place stringent economic limits on American relations with South Africa. **********In a letter to members of the House of Representatives, the six announced their support for legislation that would bar new bank loans to the South African Government, require American companies with more than 20 employees in South Africa to follow fair employment practices, and ban the importation of kruggerand and other South African gold coins into the United States. Last year the sale of such coins in this country amounted to $363 million. **********''It is time now to back up our opposition to apartheid with deeds as well as words, and to distance our nation'' from South Africa, the candidates said. They said the Reagan Administration's policies have ''produced neither substantial democratization within South Africa nor a settlement in Namibia, which South Africa continues to occupy in defiance of international law.'' **********The statement was the strongest so far by the Democrats against Administration policy in South Africa, and marks a substantial change from current American efforts to broaden ties with the Pretoria Government.   Aim Is to Modify Policy **********The signers of the letter were Walter F. Mondale, John Glenn, Gary Hart, Alan Cranston, Ernest F. Hollings and George S. McGovern. **********The legislation, sponsored by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, is an amendment to the Export Administration Act, which is scheduled to be taken up in the House next week. Mr. Solarz said that the proposal, if approved, would significantly ''modify our policy toward South Africa'' and underscore ''our opposition to the legally sanctioned system of racism in that nation.'' **********''We support enactment of this legislation,'' the six candidaters said, ''because it would fashion a more enlightened and effective policy toward South Africa that is based upon our commitment to democratic ideals and racial justice.'' **********They criticized the Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement,'' toward South Africa and said there had been no demonstrable change in the system of apartheid. ''Constructive engagement'' had meant, essentially, refraining from criticism of the Pretoria Government and seeking to engage South Africa in closer diplomatic ties. **********Its aim is based on the premise that the establishment of a more trusting American relationship with South Africa would spur its Government to undertake internal changes and end its occupation of neighboring South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.   'Lip Service' Charged **********Mr. Solarz's amendment, which includes a ''fair labor code,'' stipulates that United States companies with more than 20 employees must adhere to no segregation at the workplace, equal pay between whites and nonwhites, and nonwhite representatives in managerial and supervisory jobs. **********There are about 350 American companies in South Africa and they employ 100,000 workers, about 70 percent of them black. ''While some American firms have been in the forefront of progressive reform at the workplace,'' said Mr. Solarz, ''many others only pay lip service to fair employment principles.'' **********It is the ''fair labor'' part of the legislation that carries the most significant weight, Mr. Solarz said. **********There is no direct United States foreign aid to South Africa, other than technical assistance on nuclear energy programs. Last year United States loans to South Africa totaled $623 million. **********Aides to Mr. Solarz said the Congressman expects the House to approve the legislation next week, but its fate in the Senate remains unclear. The legislation, which has been the subject of extensive hearings, is also supported by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., United Auto Workers, American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and other groups.

Baldwin said it hoped that it could extend its short-term debt, about half of which is due Monday, intially through June 30, and that it eventually could reach an agreement on a longerterm financing plan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.main_headline: Acid Rain Study On Scandinavian Lakes
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Acid Rain Study On Scandinavian Lakes
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/06/world.body_text: **********Leading scientists in Britain, Norway and Sweden announced today that they were starting a limited five-year study into the effects of acid rain on Scandinavian lakes. **********The inquiry, set up by Britain's Royal Society, the Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters and the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, will study the relationship between levels of acid rain caused by sulfur dioxide from coal-fired power stations and factories and the composition of surface water. **********It will not study how industrial discharges create acid rain. It will not assess the degree to which reductions in British sulfur dioxide emissions would change the acidity of rainfall over the affected areas of Norway and Sweden.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.main_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Sundered Bell's Street Value
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.print_headline: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Sundered Bell's Street Value
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.body_text: **********how to play the whole and the parts upon the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company - got off to a rousing start yesterday. **********It began with the company's release of a 267-page ''information statement and prospectus'' as preparation for the start of when-issued trading next Monday in the eight corporations that will emerge. **********Meanwhile, A.T.& T.'s stock rose 87 1/2 cents, to $63.125, in consolidated trading on the New York Stock Exchange. It led the active list, with a volume of nearly 2.7 million shares. **********The actual divestiture is set for Jan. 1. It will result in a slimmed-down version of the current A.T.& T. and seven regional holding companies that will provide the bulk of the nation's local telephone service. A.T.& T. owners will receive one share in each of the seven regionals for every 10 shares of A.T.& T. they hold and, in addition, will retain their current number of parent company shares. **********''Right now, the only game in town until Monday centers on what the present A.T.& T. is worth,'' said Mark D. Luftig, the chief utility analyst of Salomon Brothers Inc. ''We're saying it's worth $68 a share by the end of the first quarter of 1984.'' **********Analysts were assigning their own set of values to A.T.& T. and its component parts prior to the biggest corporate breakup in this nation's history. **********At the First Boston Corporation, Harry Edelson said: ''I'm estimating the value of all the pieces at $65 and I think the price will get there soon. We put out a buy recommendation last week when A.T.& T. went below $62. The company's present dividend yield of around 8.5 percent provides a nice cushion.'' **********At Prudential-Bache Securities, James M. McCabe calculated the value of the A.T.& T. package at $71.60 a share. ''I think the sum of the parts will be trading in the low 70's shortly after the divestiture,'' he said. **********''If you buy the A.T.& T. stock now, my feeling is that sometime in 1984, if you add up all the pieces, you'll make money,'' said Howard W. Shawn of Cowen Asset Management, a unit of Cowen & Company. ''Just where you'll get the gain - from the new A.T.& T. or the regional companies - I don't know.'' **********Yesterday, the high-stakes game centered on taking estimates provided by A.T.& T.'s freshly released statistics for the eight new companies and arriving at some indicated value for the various stocks, which are to be issued by late February. Along with a wealth of other information, Ma Bell projected annual dividends and earnings for the various components. From that starting point, analysts worked out their various estimates of what prices the eight stocks might sell at after divestiture. **********Thus, depending upon the accuracy of the estimates, if either the new A.T.& T. or any of the seven regionals sell in the market at a price sufficiently below the anticipated worth, it would be construed as a buy. Conversely, if the price were sufficiently above the anticipated worth, it could be considered a sell. For each regional, of course, one share of the present A.T.& T. would represent one-tenth of the estimated price to conform with the divestiture formula. **********''One method of calculation uses the analyst's estimated yield for each of the eight companies and then divides that yield into 100 to get the reciprocal,'' Mr. McCabe said. ''Next you multiply that reciprocal figure by the company's indicated annual dividend to arrive at the price you think it is worth.'' **********Using this method, he arrived at a price of $20 for each share of the slimmed-down A.T.& T. parent. Mr. McCabe's estimated per-share worth of the seven regionals: Nynex, $67; Bell Atlantic, $80; BellSouth, $104; Ameritech, $67; Southwestern Bell, $66; U S West, $68, and Pacific Telesis, $64. ''My estimated prices for U S West and Pacific Telesis,'' he said, ''are probably relatively high in comparision to other projections.'' **********If his projected prices for the seven regionals are added up and then divided by 10, and the estimated price of the new A.T.& T. is added to this total, the sum comes to $71.60 a share for the package. **********At Salomon Brothers, Mr. Luftig used a different approach to arrive at his approximate $68 figure. The value of the new A.T.& T. by his method is $19.20 a share, estimated at roughly 9.5 times earnings. For the regionals, he took the annual dividend and divided that by an estimated yield to arrive at a price. The value of the total package works out precisely to $67.41. **********Mr. Luftig's exact per-share projections for the worth of each regional company: Nynex, $68.57; Bell Atlantic, $69.19; BellSouth, $94.55; Ameritech, $64.86; Southwestern Bell, $67.88; USWest, $61.71, and Pacific Telesis, $55.38. ''We dropped our estimate for BellSouth from $103 previously and raised the estimate for Pacific Telesis from $50,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/20/busin.main_headline: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER NARROWS LOSS IN PERIOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/20/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER NARROWS LOSS IN PERIOD
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company, struggling to avoid bankruptcy, reported yesterday that it had narrowed its loss in the second fiscal quarter to $159.1 million, from $201.1 million a year earlier. **********The Chicago-based company, which has been hurt by the protracted weakness of the agricultural equipment and truck market, said that the loss in the quarter ended April 30 included $69 million in onetime expenses associated with the restructuring of its operations and a $6 million loss from the sale of the company's constructionequipment business to Dresser Industries in November. **********Sales in the latest three months fell 27 percent, to $995 million, from $1.26 billion, the company said.  Donald D. Lennox, president and chief executive, said that the narrowing of the company's operating loss reflects the ''tremendous'' cost improvement generated by Harvester's restructuring program. He noted that the better results in the quarter came in the face of a 20 percent decline in industry demand for agricultural trucks and equipment. **********''We have taken nearly $1 billion of costs out of the company during the last 18 months, but there is still opportunity for more improvement, and we are aggressively going after the remaining problem areas,'' Mr. Lennox said. **********Eli S. Lustgarten, an analyst at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, said that by two key measures ''the company is performing quite respectably.'' He added, ''One is the ability of Harvester to limit the hemorrhaging during the continuing weak market conditions and two is the company's ability to maintain its market share.'' **********Harvester, which lost $1.64 billion in fiscal 1982, ended Oct. 31, last posted a profit in the 1979 fiscal year. This summer, the company is scheduled to renegotiate lending agreements covering $3.6 billion. **********During the first half of this fiscal year, Harvester sold its construction-equipment operations in the United States, Canada, West Germany and Singapore; its axle transmission operations in Fort Wayne, Ind., and its parts remanufacturing centers in Atlanta, Dallas, Mellrose Park, Ill., and Springfield, Mo. **********Harvester stock closed yesterday at 9 7/8, down 3/4 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/30/world.body_text: **********The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation creating Radio Marti, a Voice of America broadcast service intended to give Cubans news of their country and elsewhere. **********The legislation, approved by a vote of 302 to 109, was sent to President Reagan for his expected signature. **********The station will beam its programs from installations at Marathon in the Florida Keys. The bill authorizes expenditures of $14 million in fiscal 1984, which begins Saturday, and $11 million in fiscal 1985. **********To meet the concerns of Iowa Congressmen who feared that the powerful signal of station WHO in Des Moines would be jammed, Radio Marti will be broadcast at 1180 kilohertz on the AM band instead of the 1040 kilohertz that WHO uses. **********Two other Radio Marti proposals had passed House committees, but they were shelved in favor of a compromise version that passed the Senate earlier this month. That version came to the House floor under a rule that allowed no amendments and limited debate to an hour. **********Robert Sims, a spokesman for the National Security Council staff, said at the time of Senate passage that the compromise, which puts the Cuba service under the Voice of America, was ''not the bill the Administration had hoped for.'' **********Under President Reagan's proposal, Radio Marti would have been a separate entity patterned after Radio Free Europe to transmit programs challenging Cuba's version of the news.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/23/busin.body_text: **********Union rubber workers who agreed in December to cut wages and increase production at Uniroyal Inc.'s tire plant are credited with helping to bring some 600 employees back to work. Uniroyal said the facility would return to full production next Monday, using workers who were laid off in October. A shutdown of the plant was averted when workers agreed in mid-December to a package of concessions that included a $1.25 reduction in hourly wages and an increase in output by workers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/10/busin.body_text: **********McLouth Steel always seems to be a step ahead. It was an industry leader in using advanced technology. When hard times hit, it was the first steelmaker to file for bankruptcy reorganization. And last year, six months ahead of its bigger competitors, it won wage concessions from its workers. **********Now the Detroit-based manufacturer of flat-rolled steel is out front again, this time demonstrating that by slimming down and cutting costs, debt-ridden steel companies can survive. After accruing losses of more than $100 million since 1980, it expects to earn between $3 million and $5 million this quarter on sales of about $100 million. The company is now privately held and its figures cannot be verified. **********''Two years ago, I said we'd survive but no one believed me,'' said R. Milton Deaner, McLouth's president and chief executive, who joined the company after it filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws in 1981. ''We're not completely out of the woods, though.'' **********Revived as Private Company **********Seated in a conference room in the company's orange-brick headquarters in downriver Detroit, the soft- spoken, 59-year-old executive credited McLouth's new owner, Cyrus Tang, and an improved economy, for reviving the company. **********Mr. Tang, a Chicago-based industrialist, acquired McLouth's steelmaking assets in late 1982 by signing $46.5 million in 10- and 25-year notes with the company's secured creditors. The company's book value was $140 million and the replacement value was $1.2 billion. He then set up the McLouth Steel Products Corporation, a new privately held company. **********Mr. Tang, who was away on vacation, was unavailable for comment. **********Although McLouth's vital signs are much improved, the company is not without problems. It has little capital for modernization, its workers are clamoring for more say in how the mills are run and, like other domestic steelmakers, it is suffering from depressed prices. **********Was Ranked as 11th Largest **********McLouth has traditionally been the nation's 11th-largest steelmaker, but its current position is unclear. **********It entered the steel business in 1949 with the assistance of the General Motors Corporation, which wanted another local steel supplier. In the 1950's, McLouth sprinted ahead of its competitors in installing modern technology but, by 1981, a precipitous drop in steel demand and the heavy debt caused by installing modern steelmaking furnaces pushed McLouth into insolvency. **********Thanks to Mr. Tang's bargain- basement purchase of McLouth, the company's current debt ''is probably the lowest in the industry,'' said Mr. Deaner, who came to the company in 1981 from the National Steel Corporation. Shortly before the company filed for reorganization that year, its long- term debt stood at about $160 million. **********Savings in Reorganization **********Reorganization provided the new McLouth with another cost advantage. Freed from its former obligations, the company was able to relinquish its partnership interest in a Michigan iron ore property. **********Thus, while other domestic steelmakers must bear the costs of carrying large, underutilized iron ore reserves or long-term contracts to buy ore at high prices, McLouth has been free to shop around for ore just when prices have plummeted. This has saved the company about $2 million a month, Mr. Deaner says. **********McLouth also saves about $1 million a month by running its flat-rolling mills only at night, when electricity rates are cheaper. **********Mr. Tang was also able to wring wage concessions from his workers. After initially resisting, the workers agreed to reduce their average compensation to $18 an hour, from $23. Estimating that these concessions save McLouth $20 million a year, Mr. Deaner asserted: ''I don't think we could survive without them.'' **********Workers today say they feel ambivalent about the concessions, which they approved by a 3-to-1 margin. **********David Mullins, who works in McLouth's mill in Trenton, 15 miles south of Detroit, said: ''In my opinion, we gave up too much, but we did save our jobs.'' Mr. Mullins, a 30- year-old father of three, was called back to work last May after a 14- month layoff. **********Many workers feel that, along with the 15 percent stock ownership and 15 percent profit-sharing they received in exchange for their concessions, they should have a greater voice in how the company is run. **********Lower Sales to Auto Industry **********McLouth now sells only one-third of its steel directly to the auto industry, down from as much as 75 percent several years ago. According to Mr. Deaner, the shift reflects Detroit's output of fewer and smaller cars and the company's efforts to diversify its customer base to protect it from the auto industry's cyclical swings. **********Some analysts, however, suggest that the decline is a reflection on the quality of McLouth's steel, a factor largely caused by its inability to afford the latest in production equipment. ''Once upon a time, McLouth had state-of-the-art equipment, but no longer,'' said Charles A. Bradford, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. **********Mr. Deaner, conceding the need to upgrade McLouth's plant, said he ''dreamed'' of having $150 million to build a new galvanizing line to meet the auto industry's increased demand for rust-resistant steel. **********Pending modernization, however, McLouth's strategy is to guarantee market share by keeping its costs - and prices - down. Thanks to its lower costs for ore, debt and labor, and the higher productivity it realizes from its continuous casting equipment, it is able to produce steel more cheaply than most of its domestic competitors, although it will not divulge the figures. **********''Imports hurt us not so much with the volume, but with selling price,'' Mr. Deaner said. ''We've been forced to discount, and anyone who says he is not doing it is a liar.'' He predicts that because of increased volume, steel prices will rise by 5 percent to 10 percent early next year. **********With one of its two blast furnaces closed, McLouth is operating at 60 percent of capacity and shipping steel at the rate of 1.2 million tons a year, Mr. Deaner said. ''We're producing as much with 2,000 production employees now as we did with 3,000 a few years ago,'' he said. **********Asked whether the company could survive another 1982, Mr. Deaner said: ''I think so, but I don't want to think about it. Let's hope the industry never has that bad a year again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Pakistani Visits Soviet As Afghan Talks Near
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/11/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today, Tass reported. United Nations-sponsored talks between Pakistan and Afghanistan are scheduled to resume next week. **********Tass offered no substantive details of the meeting, but Mr. Yaqub Khan was quoted recently as having said that he did not expect a quick resolution of the indirect negotiations, which opened a year ago through a United Nations intermediary. The meeting is to resume in Geneva on Thursday. **********Tass said Mr. Gromyko ''positively estimated'' the fact that the talks were continuing. But he was further quoted as insisting that ''a political settlement is possible only on the basis of complete termination of armed and any other interference from the outside in the internal affairs of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.main_headline: Uganda Is Said to Free Hundreds of Prisoners
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Uganda Is Said to Free Hundreds of Prisoners
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/03/world.body_text: **********Hundreds of Ugandan prisoners and detainees have been freed, apparently in a move linked to the country's 21st independence anniversary next Sunday, witnesses said today. **********They said prisoners and detainees from Luzira Prison near Kampala were driven in two trucks today to the city center and released. A similar number were freed Saturday. **********Friends of some of those released said they included people rounded up as suspected guerrillas and former soldiers of Idi Amin's army who surrendered when he was overthrown in 1979. **********Celebrations are planned for Oct. 9, anniversary of the day in 1962 when Britain gave Uganda independence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/16/world.body_text: **********Turkey gave formal recognition tonight to the newly proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus and warned ''all concerned governments'' against taking a negative position toward the new nation. **********Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen expressed hope that the Greek Government would ''act with common sense.'' He emphasized that his Government would have preferred a solution to the Cyprus problem through the United Nations-sponsored negotiations between the island's two ethnic groups ''without arriving at the present state of affairs.'' **********The Turkish Government appeared to have been caught by surprise by the timing of the decision but considered the declaration to have been inevitable. Turkey's ruling National Security Council held an emergency meeting with Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu and Foreign Minister Turkmen. At a news conference after the meeting, Mr. Turkmen announced Turkey's decision to recognize the newly proclaimed nation. **********'Peaceful Settlement' Urged **********''We must now turn our attention to the search for a peaceful settlement,'' Mr. Turkmen declared. ''We hope that all concerned governments will contribute to efforts in that direction. The adoption of a negative attitude toward the newly established republic will only serve to eliminate the possibilities of agreement.'' **********This was viewed as a warning, particularly to Greece, that Turkey was ready to give its full backing to the new nation. Turkey has kept a force of 20,000 troops on Cyprus since the 1974 invasion with the aim of protecting the ethnic Turkish minority. Mr. Turkmen declared tonight that the presence of Turkish forces there was ''dependent on the will of the new republic'' and that the existing defensive alliance would remain in force. **********Mr. Turkmen received the Greek Ambassador twice today, at the ambassador's request, briefing him on developments in northern Cyprus and later notifying him of Ankara's decision to recognize the new government. **********Western diplomatic sources here were stunned by the news of the establishment of the Turkish Cypriot republic. Diplomatic sources believed that Pakistan and Bangladesh, which have close associations with Turkey, would also recognize the Turkish Cypriot nation.   De Facto Nation Since 1974 **********Diplomats pointed out that northern Cyprus had already existed as a de facto nation since the 1974 Turkish military invasion and the ensuing population exchange and had now been declared independent in law. **********In general they felt that the new nation could continue to function so long as it had Turkish economic, political and military backing but that this did not mean international recognition or admission to the United Nations. **********The Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, called on all Moslem nations last summer to recognize an independent Turkish Cypriot nation when the time came. Some Turkish sources believed that Saudi Arabia might recognize the new republic but they felt that most of the Arab countries would not want to jeopardize good relations with Greece. **********Mr. Denktash has repeatedly threatened to take action for several years but each time has been discouraged by the Turkish Government, which has insisted on giving the United Nations- sponsored talks a chance.   Turkey in an Interim Period **********Foreign Minister Turkmen declared that Turkish Cypriots could not be held responsible for the failure of nine years of negotiations and added that ''Turkish Cypriots enjoy the right of self- determination as much as the Greek Cypriots.'' **********Mr. Denktash chose this time to make his break from Greek Cyprus because Turkey is in what amounts to a period of interim rule, according to sources who met with the Turkish Cypriot leader recently. **********The Turkish military rulers are to hand over the Government to the leader of the conservative Motherland Party, Turgut Ozal, within two weeks following Mr. Ozal's recent election victory. Turkey's President, Gen. Kenan Evren, met today with Mr. Ozal and the leaders of the two opposition parties and briefed them on the Cyprus developments. **********Mr. Ozal refrained from commenting on the Cyprus situation except to quote a passage from his party's program that states, ''We are respectful of and support the decisions to be taken by the Turkish Cypriot community concerning its own position.''  Wide Support Voiced **********The Turkish Cypriot cause is a popular one in this country and statements of support have come from all sectors of the Turkish political spectrum. **********Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, who ordered the 1974 military invasion of Cyprus, approved the Turkish Cypriots' decision, which he said was a consequence of Greek intransigence. He said he felt the move would provide the necessary momentum to find a solution through establishment of a federal republic in Cyprus. **********The leader of the new Social Democracy Party, Cezmi Kartay, declared, ''The declaration of independence of northern Cyprus is inevitable and a natural consequence of the behavior of the Greek Cypriot community against Turkish Cypriots' rights and security.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/world.main_headline: REAGAN POLICY IN CENTRAL AMERICA: AFTER 2 YEARS, TOUGH TONE SOFTENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/world.print_headline: REAGAN POLICY IN CENTRAL AMERICA: AFTER 2 YEARS, TOUGH TONE SOFTENS
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/25/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, once given to tough statements about the need to confront insurgencies in Central America, has softened its tone. **********The new approach consists of substantial economic aid mixed with military assistance, support for democratic social change and a deliberate retreat from the Administration's early statements portraying the poor and weak countries of Central America as dominoes of the East-West conflict. Administration officials say the approach amounts, in some ways, to a bipartisan continuation of Carter Administration policies. **********But there are conflicting assessments both within and outside the Administration of how much the policy itself has really changed. Assertions of Progress **********State Department officials say that events in the region have taken a positive turn and that left-wing movements there have lost their momentum. In contrast to two years ago, Administration officials assert, guerrillas in El Salvador and Guatemala no longer threaten to topple the Governments there. Nicaragua's leftist Government, which has sought to blunt the powers of the Roman Catholic Church and the press, has lost considerable support at home and abroad. Costa Rica, Panama and Honduras are openly supporting American policy. **********''When the Carter Administration left, the situation was in total retreat and there was a state of panic that the region was going to turn into a bunch of little Nicaraguas,'' said one ranking State Department aide, a career official. ''Today that panic doesn't exist, and you find a symmetry unusual in foreign policy between the way we treat our adversaries and the way we treat our friends. You'll find us pressing for democratic reform in countries like Salvador and Guatemala and Honduras, while we push for precisely the same thing in Nicaragua.'' **********Critics and human rights activists strongly disagree. They contend that, in failing to press for negotiations with insurgents in El Salvador and adhering to a policy in Nicaragua designed to undercut the Cuban-supported Sandinist Government, the Reagan Administration has strengthened rightist forces in the region and stirred political polarization and unrest. **********''The policy is mindless, categorizing all left-wing movements in Central America as implacable enemies of the United States and legitimate targets for extermination,'' said Robert E. White, a career diplomat who served as Ambassador to El Salvador until his ouster in 1981. **********He said in an interview that the Administration was making a ''fundamental miscalculation'' in failing to negotiate with some groups and individuals on the political left who may have once been Marxists. ''We freeze them out,'' he said. ''We categorize them as permanent revolutionaries. We don't give them room to change. Central America is a fluid place, and we don't accept the notion that there may be important democratic elements on the left.'' 'Alienates Our Allies' **********Mr. White added: ''The Carter Administration insisted that negotiations between the Salvadoran Government and the revolutionaries was the road to peace, and the Reagan Administration rejects negotiations. By rejecting negotiations, it alienates our allies in the region and places our policy totally in pawn to the Salvadoran military, people who can't compromise, can't negotiate, because they have participated in so many killings. In any peace negotiations they would lose power and possibly something else.'' **********Elliott Abrams, Assistant Secretary at the State Department's Bureau of Human Rights, responded: ''One should always recall the fundamental change in American attitude towards Nicaragua and El Salvador took place in the last period of the Carter Administration.  It was under the Carter Administration that aid to Nicaragua was stopped and that military assistance to El Salvador was started.'' **********He added: ''There's a lot of myth-making now, but the fundamentals of Central American policy were apparent before Ronald Reagan even took office. In Nicaragua, we're not going to support the Sandinists while they're slowly strangling pluralism, and we're not going to try to force the Salvadoran Government to share power with a guerrilla movement dominated by Communists.'' **********Other Government officials, however, and some Republican Congressional aides privately criticize overall Administration policy in Central America as ''not terribly clear,'' ''not very well articulated'' and ''tremendously misunderstood.'' These critics point to confusion about the scale of American clandestine support for opponents of the Nicaraguan Government, including the so-called Somocists, or those aligned with the discredited Government of Gen.  Anastasio Somoza Debayle, who was overthrown in 1979. 'Misperception' of the Right **********''The support for the Somocists is stupid, and it's even more stupid because the Administration got caught,'' said one Republican aide on Capital Hill who asked to remain anonymous. **********William LeoGrande, a specialist on Latin America for the Senate Democratic Policy Committee, said the early months of the Reagan Administration were marked by a ''real misperception of what the right is in Central America.'' **********''There's a realization that it's not possible to side with the right and gain political support in Congress sufficient to let you proceed with your policy,'' he said. ''These two reinforcing policies have led them to a policy which is more in the middle. But the basic flaw in the policy is that there's still too much emphasis on the military dimension as opposed to the political dimension.'' **********Precisely what the Administration seeks in Central America is, in the words of Thomas O. Enders, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, ''an end to the export of subversion,'' from such countries as Cuba, and the ''development of democratic institutions in the region.'' Mr. Enders is the dominant figure in Central American policy, according to various Administration officials. Key Shapers of Policy **********Others who have key roles in shaping the region's policy include L. Craig Johnstone, head of the Office of Central American Affairs; Luigi R. Einaudi, head of the Office of Policy Planning Coordination at the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs; Mr. Abrams, head of the Bureau of Human Rights; Nestor Sanchez, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Inter-American Affairs, and Constantine Menges, national intelligence estimates officer for Central America at the Central Intelligence Agency. **********Gen. Vernon Walters, a roving envoy who operates in considerable secrecy, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, have also played roles in developing Central American policy. Officials say the National Security Council has been relatively muted in the shaping of that policy. **********The policy itself has passed through two distinct phases, which are labeled ''pre-Haig'' and ''post-Haig'' by State Department officials. From the first days of the Administration, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. made Central America, and especially El Salvador, a pivot of United States policy. Mr. Haig termed the situation ''global in character,'' and said Soviet-sponsored subversion spread by Cuban surrogates and the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua were threatening El Salvador as well as Honduras and Guatemala. **********What intensified the situation, Administration officials say now, was the potential for an anti-Soviet showdown in Central America and the threat of direct American involvement in the region - a threat that the Defense Department sought to quell. Pentagon officials argued that it did not make sense to take a military stand in such a potentially uncertain battleground as Central America, and that the option of interdicting Cuban Navy supply lines to guerrillas in Central America was unfeasible. Opposition to Military Moves **********''Haig used to say that he wanted to do more, but it was the Defense Department that was always opposing military moves,'' a State Department official said. ''They didn't like doing anything, he would say. Whenever he proposed something they had a thousand and one reasons why it couldn't be done. 'We don't have the ships, we don't have the men, we don't have this or that.' '' **********A knowledgeable Congressional aide normally sympathetic to Administration policy said: ''A lot of what the Administration said early on was counterproductive. It scared people. It was fuel for the propaganda mills of the Sandinists in Nicaragua. It created a heightened tension that might not have emerged had the policy been softer, lower-keyed.'' **********''There was an extraordinary amount of rhetoric, such as drawing the line against international Communism in El Salvador, and so forth, that overstated the nature of the problem and tended to put it in the nature of an East-West situation almost exlusively in terms of public perception,'' a ranking State Department official said. **********Recently, Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, noted that even when the war in Lebanon dominated the news last summer, the mail to her office from constituents in Kansas was dominated by one foreign policy issue: concern that American troops would get involved in Central America.  Administration officials now say that, contrary to popular impression, no serious consideration was given to a buildup of forces in the region. 'Emphasis on Economics' **********As Mr. Haig's successor, George P. Shultz ''sought to get away from the image that we see the problem solely in East-West terms,'' one aide said. ''I don't think you're going to see Shultz say that we're going to draw the line in Salvador.'' **********Another State Department official said, with a trace of criticism: ''It's difficult to see a Shultz Central American policy at this point, except for the quiet rhetoric and the emphasis on economics.  That is, in order for these countries to succeed militarily, in order for them to defeat the guerrillas, they have to succeed economically.'' LATIN/First and last add **********The cornerstone of Administration policy has been to press for economic and social development through the Caribbean Basin Initiative. But Washington's original partners in the project, Canada, Mexico and Venezuela, have dropped out. By late last year, despite strong last-minute pressure from the White House, Congress had only approved one part of the three-part package of aid for Caribbean and Central American nations: $350 million in emergency economic assistance. Proposals for trade preferences and investment incentives died during the lame-duck session of Congress, and Administration officials now say the issues will be raised in the 98th Congress. **********At this point, the Administration is proposing $82.5 million in military aid in the 1983 fiscal year to five countries in the region: Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Panama. **********This includes $61.3 million in military aid for El Salvador. As a condition for continuing military aid, President Reagan certified to Congress on Friday that El Salvador was making progress on human rights. No U.S. Aid for Nicaragua **********The Administration has requested $348.3 million in economic aid for Central America. El Salvador, which would receive $164.9 million, is the largest recipient of economic aid, followed by Costa Rica, which would get $95 million. Nicaragua is to receive neither military nor economic assistance from the United States. **********To Administration critics as well as policy makers, the region itself stirs ideological and political differences that seem difficult, perhaps impossible, to bridge. This month, for example, the Administration lifted the five-year-old embargo on arms sales to Guatemala and proposed the sale of $6.3 million in spare parts and other equipment for the nation's air force. **********Administration officials said the Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt had taken ''significant steps'' to end human rights abuses and was a considerable improvement over his predecessor, Gen. Romeo Lucas Garcia, whose repressive policies were anathema to both the Carter and Reagan Administrations. General Rios Montt seized power last March. **********Critics have charged that the Rios Montt Government has carried out numerous massacres in Indian villages in a major counterinsurgency offensive launched last July. ''The result is that the level of military action in the countryside is probably lower now than it was three or four months ago but the cost to the people has been immense,'' said Mr. LeoGrande of the Senate Democratic Policy Committee. Progress Cited in Honduras **********In the view of Administration officials, ''considerable progress'' has been made in Honduras, a nation with a relatively peaceful history and stable governments. But critics such as Richard E.  Feinberg, director of the foreign policy program at the Overseas Development Council assert that, in using Honduras as the key base to support covert activities against neighboring Nicaragua, and in stepping up American military aid to the nation, the Reagan Administration has weakened the authority of the year-old civilian Government and may tip the balance of power in the nation in favor of the military. There have been frequent border clashes between Honduras and Nicaragua. **********''Continuing support for democratic elements in Honduras has been diluted,'' said Mr. Feinberg, a specialist on Central America who worked at the State Department's Policy Planning Staff from 1977 to 1979. He added: ''Under Carter the attempt was to edge out the military Government in favor of a civilian government. Under Reagan the emphasis has been reversed.'' **********Even in Costa Rica, critics say, the normally peaceful, stable nation has been shaken by rightist and leftist terrorism. Although the nation has no army, it has received more than $2 million in United States equipment and training for its civil guard. This was largely prompted by border incidents and tensions with Nicaragua. **********Ultimately, critics say, tensions have been heightened in part by the Administration's failure to exploit certain democratic tendencies in the Nicaraguan Government, thereby moving the Sandinists closer to the Cubans and the Soviet Union. Anxious to Show Flexibility **********Administration officials, such as Mr. Enders, say Nicaragua has ''regionalized'' the conflict by supporting insurgents in El Salvador and expanding its ''terrorist and aggressive actions against Honduras and Costa Rica.'' **********In recent months Mr. Enders and other officials have been anxious to show flexibility, urging the Salvadoran Government to contemplate a ''political solution'' to the war, and blaming the guerrilla-led opposition for refusing to accept negotiations. At the same time the Administration has proposed a regionwide ban on the import of weapons and the use of foreign military advisers. **********''I think we're reacting like diplomats in any administration, a little bit by the seat of our pants,'' a State Department official said. ''There is a series of basic principles within which we're trying to work and, frankly, I think it's far more coherent and developed than much of our policy towards the rest of Latin America or the rest of the world.'' **********He added: ''Actually, what's most striking is the continuity of policy. There's been a dramatic change in personnel and of underlying philosophy. Yet both Administrations have found their choices proved to be fairly narrow, the instruments they had were quite limited.  People don't quite believe it, but there are limited economic and military resources for Central America.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.main_headline: FOR RUINED CHAD'S SURVIVORS: STEAK FILET AND COTES DU RHONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.print_headline: THE TALK OF NDJAMENA; FOR RUINED CHAD'S SURVIVORS: STEAK FILET AND COTES DU RHONE
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/11/world.body_text: **********As countries go, Chad has claims to fame that hold no joy. It vies, for instance, with Bhutan for the title of the wold's poorest country. It challenges Eritrea, almost, as the theater for Africa's longest-running chronicled battle and war.  Somehow, in this battered and potholed capital, where the wind sighs gently from the river and admits defeat to the desert's heat, it survives. And with style, too. **********''I am sorry sir,'' the waiter might say at a new restaurant, ''the Beaujolais is finished, but there is C^otes du Rh^one.'' There's ice cream, too, at $9 a liter, imported from France, and French cheese and filet steak. All this is in the street called Avenue Charles de Gaulle, where past battles have left buildings pocked and battered and ruined, unlit and heavy with menace, and in a country whose best fighting men are locked in murderous fighting against Libyan-backed insurgents, far to the barren north. **********African capitals often do not resmble capitals at war because wars are distant and invisible. Ndjamena is different. It looks like a place where the war was fought so bitterly that the conflict itself got tired of the city and moved on, abandoning its stunted creations to idle sightseeing - here the ruined cathedral; there the gendarmerie archway, shattered years ago; here the street lamp that fell on the sidewalk and no one moved; there the countless buildings sculpted not so much by human hand as by bullet and rocket, shell and grenade.   Safety in an Amulet **********That was the legacy of the fighting in 1980. The present conflict is here, too, in different ways. **********On the street the visitor might see young men, tired of eye, relieved to be safe, just back from the battle for Faya-Largeau. Around their necks they wear amulets, clustered on thongs of leather: military planning in the Western sense is not, appparently, sufficient protection for these desert fighters. **********Or, in one of the few restaurants, a group of men might enter, gaunt and spindly in the manner of their tribe. They wear robes of khaki and olive green and cloth wrapped around their heads like turbans, with pistols at their belts and, in one case, with backless wedge-heeled shoes. ''We are just simple soldiers,'' one says. ''We will return to the north when we are ordered to.'' They are the President's men. **********But there is more insidious testimony to the long years of war. In the market, hot and teeming, they sell Korans and canned fish and bolts of cloth and cool drinks and cigarettes and much, much more. All of it is imported, or smuggled. Nothing is produced here, save for cotton and beer in the south. **********The children, too, show their side of the story. **********In the city center a child, perhaps 1 year old, is carried on the back of an elder sister, perhaps 4 or 5. The young one's hair is fringed with a gingery halo, the sign that what food there is does not sustain it. Infants here, as elsewhere in Africa, die of measles. There is rinderpest and famine in parts of the land. The war drains the last drop of hope, but not the will to survive. **********Chadians are a bit like the Reagan Administration. Their Public Enemy No. 1 is the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. **********''If I had a gun, I would kill Qaddafi myself,'' says a 30-year-old accountant in a bar far from the side of the city where the foreigners usually stay. The taxi driver, with reverence for the language of colonialism, calls it ''the African quarter.'' **********The man has no gun and perhaps the bravado is that of a person whose desire for the glory of battle is balanced by relief at the remoteness of the contest. ''The war is 600 miles away,'' the man says, shouting across the insistent rock music that roars from rooms lit with red and eerie green light bulbs. ''That is why it does not affect us.'' **********Salvation is not seen as being available from within this bruised nation. ''We need help from our friends,'' the man says. ''You Americans must help us.'' Self-help, or reconciliation, seems not to be a factor in the calculation. **********The Libyans occupied Chad between 1980 and 1981. They were not liked, did not pay salaries or make the telephones work. Twenty years before, the people who put the phones in, the French, took down their tricolor for the last time after the colonial occupation. But some things remained. **********''We were civilized by the French,'' says the accountant in the bar, a statement at odds with some modern- day revisionist views of colonialism. In some African countries, like Uganda, war and insurgency reduce the visitors' diet to rice and water. Not here. The headwaiter at H^otel du Chari sports a bow tie and offers an array of salads and fish and meats and baguette bread that is acceptable to the French palate. A French diplomat, by a slip of the tongue, talks of ''the metropolis'' in France as if Chad were still a colony. The main street is, after all, Avenue Charles de Gaulle. **********But it is not so strong, the Frenchness, to dilute a style that has survived centuries at this junction of caravan trails and trade routes built on a bend in the river between desert and savannah. The authorities did not permit reporters to see French troops arriving here today, as if salvaging some pride from a forlorn reliance on a former colonial master. The people cross from here to Cameroon by dugout canoe, poled by thin men in stained white robes who use the stream for their boatmen's trade and as a place to bathe naked. **********Farther north, in the deserts, the manner is more Arab. President Hissen Habre, in the posters of him that adorn the city, displays the nation's three faces: in one portrait he wears a Western-style suit, in another his battledress, while in a third he is clad in white robes and skullcap. Chad, thus, is a place where modernity has been bolted, but loosely, onto longer traditions and perennial conflict. **********But now it is the 20th century that presses and impinges. Each day huge Starlifter military transports from the United States, seeming almost to pause and hover in the sky before landing, thunder into Ndjamena, laden with miltary supplies. French Transalls, on secretive missions, lumber off the runway for distant outposts not yet threatened but possibly imperiled. French technicians scurry around at the military air base assembling machine guns and helicopters. Zairian soldiers, sent by President Mobutu Sese Seko, guard the airport in characteristically brusque manner. ''You are a journalist?'' one says. ''Then go away.'' **********The Libyans have gone but the French are here, and the American flag flies from the towering tails of the Starlifters. The Libyans are in the north, the Zairians in the south on the Government's side. The slogan on the streets says, ''No sellout of Chad.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The first 1984 Renault Encore hatchback rolled off the assembly line at the American Motors Corporation's Kenosha, Wis., plant to the cheers of A.M.C. autoworkers, the company said.
