https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/04/world.body_text: **********Seven people, five of them police officers, were killed today during an anti-Government demonstration in Sind Province, official sources said. **********The army was called in to restore order in what appeared to have been the most serious incident to date in the civil-disobedience campaign that began Aug. 14. **********Two demonstrators and five policemen were shot dead in Moro, 168 miles north of Karachi. The sources said the police tried to break up the march at Moro with riot sticks and tear gas. **********A source from the opposition grouping of eight banned political parties, which has been organizing a civil-disobedience campaign against the Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, said a shot was fired from an unknown direction and that an exchange of fire broke out from both sides.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.main_headline: SOVIET COMMENT ON LEFTIST INROADS IN AMERICAS FOUND IN GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.print_headline: SOVIET COMMENT ON LEFTIST INROADS IN AMERICAS FOUND IN GRENADA
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/15/world.body_text: **********Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the Soviet Chief of Staff, reportedly told the Grenadian Chief of Staff in Moscow last March that, while two decades ago ''there was only Cuba in Latin America, today there are Nicaragua, Grenada, and a serious battle is going on in El Salvador.'' **********The remark is contained in what appears to be a photocopy of a memorandum prepared on the letterhead of the Grenadian Embassy in Moscow. The document was made public by the State Department today. **********It was one of 21 more documents that the department says were captured after the invasion of Grenada last month. An initial packet was made public Nov. 4. There are, according to department officials, thousands of documents still being processed. **********According to the report of Marshal Ogarkov's conversation with the Grenadian Chief of Staff, Maj. Einstein Louison, the Russian said Grenada should be ''vigilant at all times'' against possible American attack, but that he was confident the United States could not reverse the trend in the region.   Progressive Change' in the World **********''About the situation in the world, Marshal Ogarkov pointed out that the United States would try now and in the future to make things difficult for progressive change in all regions and continents,'' said the report, which was drafted by Bernard Bourne, the Grenadian Embassy's minister-counselor. **********''The Marshal said that, over two decades ago, there was only Cuba in Latin America, today there are Nicaragua, Grenada and a serious battle is going on in El Salvador. The Marshal of the Soviet Union then stressed that United States imperialism would try to prevent progress, but that there were no prospects for imperialism to turn back history.'' **********Marshal Ogarkov, who is a First Deputy Minister of Defense, was not reported to have made any further military commitment to Grenada. The previous documents disclosed military supply accords signed by Grenada with the Soviet Union, Cuba and North Korea.   Grenadian Was at Military School **********Major Louison, according to the memorandum, was in the Soviet Union for studies at a military school. The memorandum said ''the entire meeting was conducted in an atmosphere of warmth, friendliness, simplicity and unpretentiousness.'' **********''The meeting ended with warm embraces,'' it said. **********An underlying theme in the documents - and one of the reasons the Administration has decided to make them public - is the desire of the Grenadian Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop to strengthen military, economic and political ties with Communist nations. Mr. Bishop was replaced as leader in mid-October, and killed on Oct. 19, touching off the decision by the United States, at the behest of some Caribbean governments, to invade on Oct. 25. **********One document, labeled ''secret,'' is a summary of decisions taken in Havana on June 29, 1983, by the Cuban Communist Party and the New Jewel Movement, the ruling party in Grenada. It said the two parties shares ''the same convictions against imperialism, colonialism, neocolonialism, Zionism, and racism''and were seeking to coordinate their actions. **********Cuba pledged to train technicians and other specialists for making billboards and posters, running sound equipment at public meetings, taking photographs, drawing newspaper cartoons and opposing religion. **********Internal Grenadian party documents expressed concern with the political and economic situation in Grenada. This was also a feature of the earlier set of documents. **********One of the documents made public today indicates that Grenada was pressing the Soviet Union to give military and economic aid. The Soviet Ambassador informed Mr. Bishop on May 24 of plans to ship 3,000 uniforms, 2,000 spades, two coast guard boats as well as foodstuffs and oil products. **********The Soviet Union also agreed to sell 40 jeeps, 50 trucks, and five fire engines in 1983 and 1984, with payment of 15 percent one year after delivery and the rest over a period of 10 years at 4 percent interest. **********The ambassador also said that, pursuant to military aid agreement, 100,000 rubles ($130,000) worth of spare parts would be sent to Cuba, for use in Grenada. There was also discussion of the Soviet Union's supplying one military transport to Grenada. **********Mr. Bishop asked the ambassador for 20,000 tons of fertilizer as a free grant over the next five years, but the envoy said ''fertilizer is the only product never granted.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/19/busin.main_headline: A.T.& T.  Discloses Stock Plans; Consolidation Option Offered
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/19/busin.print_headline: A.T.& T.  Discloses Stock Plans; Consolidation Option Offered
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/19/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday elaborated on its plans to distribute stock in seven regional holding companies to its 3.2 million shareholders. The companies will result from the company's divestiture, which is scheduled for Jan. 1. **********A.T.& T. said in an announcement to be mailed to shareholders with their Aug. 1 dividend checks that it would offer shareholders who hold from 10 to 499 shares a consolidation option, allowing them to rearrange their regional company holdings. Such shareholders can sell shares in some regional companies and use the proceeds to buy shares in others. **********An A.T.& T. spokesman said that shareholders who own between 10 and 500 shares represent about 77 percent of all accounts. He said the consolidation option would reduce transaction costs. **********As previously announced, shareholders will receive one share in each of the holding companies for every 10 A.T.& T. shares they own, while retaining the same number of A.T.& T. shares. Shareholders holding less than 10 A.T.& T. shares, who are entitled to less than a full share in each regional company, will receive cash instead of a fractional share. Accounts with 500 or more shares will receive certificates for whole shares of regional company stock and cash for any fractional shares, the company said. Fee for Consolidation Option **********The company also said that in January all shareholders would receive a statement showing their A.T.& T. and regional company holdings. Those eligible will also receive an option card, returnable in mid-April, to rearrange their regional company holdings if they prefer to do so. **********A fee of 25 cents will be charged to exercise the consolidation option for every regional company share sold and another 25 cents for every share bought. The price of the regional company shares bought or sold through this method will be determined by the average of each company's high and low prices on the New York Stock Exchange on the day the option card is received. A.T.& T. has 930 million common shares outstanding. **********In addition, A.T.& T. said trading of its stock and the seven regional holding companies would begin on a when-issued basis in the second half of November. Distribution of stock in the regional companies is scheduled to begin in mid-February 1984. **********Each of the holding companies will offer a dividend reinvestment plan similar to A.T.& T.'s. The program allows shareholders to acquire additional stock at a discount and without paying brokerage fees. **********While it set about informing investors of its stock distribution, A.T.& T. said it was continuing to study the recent modifications to the overall plan of reorganization that were proposed by the Federal judge overseeing the case. One of those modifications was that A.T.& T. could no longer use the Bell name in corporate affiliates other than Bell Laboratories and foreign subsidiaries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/10/busin.body_text: **********Active trading in Tymshare Inc. was attributed by analysts and traders to reports that the company was an imminent takeover target. **********Tymshare, one of the biggest percentage gainers on the New York Stock Exchange, jumped $1.75, to $26.75. Volume totaled 258,700 shares. A Tymshare spokesman said that he had no comment on any takeover negotiations. Tymshare, a provider of computer information services, is based in Cupertino, Cailf. On Wednesday, Tymshare said it had appointed Goldman, Sachs & Company and Hambrecht & Quist as its financial advisers, and Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz as its special legal counsel to ''explore financial alternatives.'' That followed the acquisition by Wang Laboratories Inc. of 4.3 percent of Tymshare's stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/27/busin.body_text: **********At the Interior Department's latest - and largest - offshore leasing auction, held in New York yesterday, 12 oil companies, led by Shell Offshore Inc., the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation, bid on only 40 of the more than 4,000 blocks in the mid-Atlantic that were available. **********Together, the 12 companies placed 52 bids, totaling $86.8 million.  The high bids on the 40 blocks they sought came to $71.1 million.  The auction took place under something of a legal cloud, since three states, New York, Virginia and Maryland, have filed lawsuits to block the sale of hundreds of parcels among the 4,050 leases on the outer continental shelf in the mid-Atlantic. But only four tracts in contested areas ended up attracting bids, all of them in New York regions. **********Money to Be Put in Escrow **********In effect, the decision not to bid on tracts in the Maryland and Virginia regions makes moot the lawsuits in those two states, an Interior Department spokesman said. ''The money bid on the four contested tracts in New York will be put in escrow, and we are constrained from issuing leases on these tracts before the court makes a ruling,'' he added. A hearing date on the suit has not yet been set. **********Some analysts were surprised that the bids were as high as they were.  ''We weren't expecting anything big from this auction,'' said Suzanne W. Wright, an oil analyst at the First Boston Corporation.  ''Frankly, I am surprised they paid that much, given the disappointing results in the Baltimore Canyon, high exploration costs and the general state of the industry.'' Compared with the Gulf of Mexico, Alaska and California, Miss Wright said, ''this area is a laggard.'' 'Very High Risk Play' **********Another analyst, who asked not to be identified, characterized the area as ''a very high risk play for people who have a lot of money.'' **********''This area is much deeper water than the Baltimore Canyon,'' he added, ''but it has the potential for huge reserves.'' Considerably more interest is expected to be exhibited next month, when a lease auction for tracts in the Gulf of Mexico is scheduled to take place. ''Industry departments are building war chests in anticipation of that auction,'' Miss Wright said. **********The mid-Atlantic tracts embrace 22.7 million acres running from just south of Martha's Vineyard, Mass., to the North Carolina border. According to Interior Department estmates, about 700 million barrels of oil and 3,000 billion feet of natural gas lie under the seabed in the area. The leases are offered for a period of five years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/12/22/busin.body_text: **********The Toyo Kogyo Company, maker of Mazda vehicles, said today that its profit for the latest fiscal year rose 1 percent, to the equivalent of $114 million. **********Separately, the company, Japan's third-largest auto maker, said it planned to change its name to the Mazda Motor Corporation on May 1, to align its company name with that of its major product. Shareholders will vote on the name change Jan. 27. The company, which is based in Hiroshima, said that for the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, revenue rose 15.6 percent, to $5.8 billion. Vehicle sales, accounting for 91 percent of all sales, rose 15.4 percent, to $5.3 billion.

PATENTS;

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/24/busin.body_text: **********A supersonic biplane with variable-wing positions was patented for the Navy this week by Robert M. Taylor, an aerospace engineer in Washington. **********Patent 4,405,102 explains that the wing attached to the fuselage has forward and trailing end portions with upper and lower sections. The upper wing section is supported by the fuselage in a fixed position. The lower wing section can be rotated so that it provides short takeoff and landing, and can be kept parallel with the upper wing section for high-speed supersonic flight.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Short-Term Rates Are Steady
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/22/busin.body_text: **********Confusion over the near-term direction of interest rates sharply reduced activity in the credit market yesterday.  Dealers said that short-term Treasury discount rates were basically unchanged, while prices of long-term Treasury coupon issues closed moderately lower with attendant rises in yields after a late flurry of selling. Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds closed off as much as a quarter point in in equally dull trading. **********The confusion was heightened by warnings of further rises in short-term rates that were made yesterday by Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, before the Senate Banking Committee. **********Mr. Feldstein said that the current prime lending rate of 10.5 percent should normally be 2.5 percentage points above the Treasury bill rate, which is now just over 9 percent. Consequently, he said, a one-point rise in the prime rate could be expected at any time. Discount Rate Called Low **********Several prominent dealers agreed, saying that by the same token the Federal Reserve's discount rate of 8.5 percent, or 3 percentage points below long bond yields, was also too low to be sustainable for long. **********As the investors and dealers reassessed the interest rate structure, Three- and six-month Treasury bills were off one basis point, at 9.05 percent and 9.17 percent, respectively; the one-year bills inched up a basis point, at 9.27 percent. A basis point is onehundredth of a percentage point. The new 10 5/8 percent two-year notes fell to 99.32 from 10.62, which was the average yield produced at the monthly auction on Wednesday. **********At the longer end of the Treasury coupon issues, the 10 1/2 percent notes of 1988 slipped to 97 14/32 from 97 16/ 32; the 10 1/8's of 1993, to 94 4/32 from 93 9/32, while the benchmark long bond, the 10 3/8's of 2012, dropped to 91 25/32 from 92 5/32, with a concomitant rise in the yield to 11.34 percent from 11.30. **********Much of the late selling came after the Chicago financial futures markets closed. At the close there, the spot September Treasury bond futures were down 14/32 at 72 17/32, after having ranged between 73 2/32 and 72 16/32. Bill futures were steady, with the spot September contract closing at 90.70. **********''The retail buyers have demonstrated again today that they need higher yields before they will even take speculative positions, and when yields decline they sell,'' said Philip Braverman, bond market economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank. Bearish on Rates **********Dealers, he noted, remain bearish on rates and have become more fearful of inflation and are trying to reduce inventories or sell the market short. Noting that terms of the Treasury's early August refunding will be announced next Wednesday, Mr. Braverman said, dealers will have to lighten their stock further or sell more of it short before then as a precaution. **********(Yesterday, Treasury officials were in New York soliciting views of Government securities dealers on the auction terms.) ''The dealers are becoming preoccupied with the refunding, which may involve $15.75 billion of new paper, and with the prospects for higher yields, they prefer to lighten inventory and sell short, rather than be forced to do so afterward,'' Mr. Braverman continued. **********Many economists expect interest rates to ease or hold at current levels because of statements made by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, before Congress this week. They interpreted his testimony to mean that the central bank would not tighten credit further. Mr. Braverman, however, disagrees with that view. **********''I believe we will see further tightening. Although Mr. Volcker has rebased M-1 and increased other money supply targets, it does not preclude a rise in the discount rate or higher Federal fund levels,'' he said. **********Yesterday, the first day of the new banking week, this key interbank overnight lending rate remained steady at 9 3/8 percent.  Essentially, the Fed must serve as a counterweight to the growing inflation psychology that is overtaking investors in fixed-income securities because of the soaring Federal budget deficits and trade imbalances, Mr. Braverman stressed, adding: ''We believe that one way the Fed can serve as a counterweight to the inflation fears is by being less accommodative, while at the same trying to calm the fears of credit tightening.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/18/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********I cannot believe the situation is as simple as John Schreiner contends (''First Come the Bosses - Then the Jobs,'' Sept. 11). He asserts that there aren't enough jobs because there aren't enough entrepeneurs, and there aren't enough bosses because the tax system discourages them. **********He spends half his article sort-of suggesting that laziness or education that fails to teach risk-taking is to blame for not producing enough capitalists. Baloney. We have a surplus of adventurers who ''give it a go,'' but four out of five starting businesses go bust. Mr. Schreiner would have done better to analyze that problem rather than forward the notion that we Americans are getting lazy. **********Is that due to tax policy? Or is it lack of planning in a fiercely competitive environment? Isn't it partly lack of access to capital, skilled labor and markets? Tax policy is bogus. Even if Uncle Sam takes a greater percentage from me as my income goes up, I still take home more as I am successful in business. I get financial rewards. I also get the intangible rewards of seeing my ideas come to reality, seeing the respect from my community for being successful, seeing the joy in a worker's face when she gets the first paycheck. There is no lack of people who want to be bosses, and plenty of incentives. **********What we need is customers to buy their clever products and services. Demand goes up when people have money to buy with, not when they are out of a job because the job got shipped to Hong Kong or Japan, not when the Fed consciously constricts the supply of money. CHARLES GARLOW, Ossining, N.Y., Sept. 11

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/07/world.body_text: **********Israel marked the anniversary of its invasion of Lebanon today by bringing to a climax an intensive weeklong reexamination of the war, in which most of the major decision-makers have been interviewed by Israeli newspapers, radio and television.  The arguments have been familiar, the revelations tending to support the picture of a military machine hurtling forward beyond the control of the Cabinet. **********Predictably, former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, the chief architect of the war's ambitious political and military goals, said in several interviews that he would do it all again in the same way if he had a second chance. He accused other Government ministers of trying to evade their responsibility as the war has become less popular. **********The newspaper Maariv ran a special section, called ''The Unfinished War,'' full of allegations that major decisions were made by Mr.  Sharon without Prime Minister Menachem Begin's knowledge. In early August, when the Palestine Liberation Organization was still refusing to leave besieged Beirut, the paper said, Mr. Sharon, on his own, ordered a large mobilization of reservists. Interior Minister Yosef Burg, hearing about the call-up, telephoned Prime Minister Begin in the middle of the night, and Mr. Begin reprimanded the Defense Minister, Maariv reported. Authorization 'After the Fact' **********Deputy Prime Minister Simcha Ehrlich said in a television interview that in the third week of June the Cabinet approved the army's taking of the Beirut-Damascus highway, in the central region, only ''after the fact.'' **********With Mr. Begin in the United States at the time, Mr. Ehrlich was Acting Prime Minister. He said he had been told, inaccurately, that the Syrians had started the fighting that gave Israel cause to attack. ''Afterward I received reports from the front, from the field, that fire had been opened not just from the Syrian side,'' Mr. Ehrlich said, ''that is, that there had been provocations.'' **********Mr. Sharon's early vagueness about his specific goals has emerged as a major theme of the current discussions. Maj. Gen. Amir Drori, head of the northern command, was quoted today by Israeli radio as saying that the army could have performed better, with fewer casualties, if its objectives had been more clearly defined. Units could have moved more quickly, staged more amphibious landings and taken land routes to avoid enemy concentrations, he said. **********Some accounts suggest that Mr. Sharon either miscalculated or engaged in duplicity before the invasion. In a briefing of opposition Labor Party leaders April 6, 1982, two months before the war, Maariv reported, Mr. Sharon estimated that the operation would take only 48 hours and the army would be in Lebanon only a week. The Labor Party called today for a state commission of inquiry into all aspects of the war. Army Suffering Casualties **********Waiting for the Syrians and the P.L.O. to withdraw, the army is stuck in place, taking daily casualties from guerrilla attacks. Even the United States, which urged an Israeli withdrawal all along, has reportedly asked the Begin Government not to pull back from the volatile Shuf Mountain area, lest the Syrians and the P.L.O. move in to fill the vacuum. Israel has promised to consult with Washington and Beirut before taking any action. **********From the Government's supporters, there are brave calls to national unity, dramatic declarations that after ''Operation Peace for Galilee,'' Israelis in the north need no longer sleep in underground shelters during rocket and artillery attacks from the ''terrorists'' - the military units of the P.L.O. **********Neither the supporters nor the opponents of the war seem to have the stomach for doing the brutal arithmetic: In the four years between the previous Israeli invasion of southern Lebanon in 1978 and the invasion June 6, 1982, a total of 29 people were killed in northern Israel in all forms of attacks from Lebanon, including shelling and border crossings by terrorists, according to the army spokesman's office. In the year since the invasion, 490 Israelis have been killed in Lebanon. Border Quiet for a Year **********Israelis from across the political spectrum say they cannot be expected to pay a tribute in dead civilians for the sake of avoiding war. Still, opponents note that during the year before the invasion - from July 1981 to June 1982-the border was quiet. The cease-fire with the P.L.O. held. Rockets and artillery shells were fired only after Israeli planes bombed guerrilla positions in retaliation for terrorist attacks in Europe and elsewhere. **********For the first time, conscientious objection has taken root in Israel. A movement called ''There's a Limit'' has got the signatures of 2,020 soldiers -mostly reservists - on a refusal to serve in Lebanon. The organization has counted 61 soldiers whom the army has jailed for their refusal. **********And in all the interviews and editorials and private comments on this bitter anniversary, it is hard to find any new argument being offered on any side, anything that was not said almost a year ago, shortly after Israeli troops accomplished their invasion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/18/busin.body_text: **********Declaring that a national economic emergency exists, President Reagan signed an executive order last week that indefinitely extends export controls and other provisions of the Export Administration Act. **********Mr. Reagan acted under the 1979 International Emergency Economic Powers Act because the Export Administration Act, extended by Congress beyond its Sept. 30 expiration date, lapsed at midnight Friday. **********Congress has been trying to renew the act but the House of Representatives and the Senate disagree about some provisions. **********A White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the executive order would remain in effect ''until the law is reauthorized.'' Had Mr. Reagan not acted, the authority of the Government to prevent the shipment to unfriendly powers of strategically useful equipment and technology would have been in doubt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.main_headline: Two Directors Leave Oak Industries' Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Two Directors Leave Oak Industries' Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Oak Industries, an operator of pay television systems, said yesterday that two directors had resigned. The company has posted losses recently. **********Vincent T. Gorguze, 64, a director since 1978, left the board citing ''apparent divergent views regarding the revitalization of the company,'' a statement said. A spokesman at company headquarters in Rancho Bernardo, near San Diego, refused to elaborate. **********The other director, Blaine Huntsman, 46, who joined the board last month, left because he had inadvertently failed to comply with a technical disclosure requirement, Oak said. The requirement related to transactions between Oak and companies affiliated with him before he became a director, the company said. **********Oak said Mr. Huntsman's resignation had also been prompted by the ''possibility of concern over his independence as a director.'' Mr. Gorguze is chairman and chief executive of Sinclair & Rush, a St. Louis plastics manufacturer. His secretary said yesterday that he was traveling and could not be reached. **********Oak, which operates five subscription television systems and manufactures related equipment, has reported a loss totaling $37 million in the last two quarters and has said it expected a loss for the year. It recently put off plans to enter the direct broadcast satellite business. **********Its stock, however, has moved up recently on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts cited Oak's 50 percent interest in the movie ''Psycho II,'' which got off to a strong start at the box office. **********The company last year joined with Universal Studios in a pact for four feature films. ''Psycho II,'' which cost $4 million to $5 million to make, grossed $8.3 million in its first three days. **********Oak has said that its agreement with Universal stipulates that costs will be recovered first, meaning that much of Oak's share of the profits will not be realized until next year, even though they may eventually be substantial. The stock closed yesterday at $12, down 25 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Fallon McElligott Rice, founded about a year and a half ago in Minneapolis, has just added one of the state's most important corporate citizens to its client list. **********The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has assigned the agency, Titralac, a 20-year-old, over-thecounter antacid that has had no consumer advertising. **********That was when it was being marketed by Riker Laboratories of Northridge, Calif. Riker was acquired in 1969 by 3M. Things have slowly been changing since. **********Although this year will be given over to testing various advertising copy and weight approaches in test markets, the expectations of the agency are for a real consumer advertising campaign in 1984. **********Titralac in now part of 3M's Personal Care Products Department.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/20/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********The economy grew even faster in the second quarter than was originally estimated, the Commerce Department reported, and inflation was even lower. Officials said the G.N.P. grew at an annual rate of 9.2 percent, while prices rose at a 3.5 percent annual rate.  The last single quarter in which the economy grew faster with lower price increases was the fourth quarter of 1965, just before the military buildup began for the Vietnam War.  More good news was that corporate profits, after taxes, rose 14.8 percent, the largest increase in almost eight years. Concern was expressed, however, that unless budget deficits are reduced, high interest rates will slow recovery. (Page 1.) **********New orders for durable goods fell 3.6 percent in July, the first decline since February, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said the decline is evidence that high interest rates are forcing a slowdown in the economy. Officials observed, however, that the orders remain 24 percent above the level in October, considered the worst month of last year's recession. (33.) **********The Congressional Budget Office predicts stronger growth this year and next in its midyear report on the economy. But it still projects large future budget deficits, even if proposed countersteps are approved. The figures in the Congressional report closely paralleled those in the Administration's midyear report. (34.) **********Damage by Hurricane Alicia was estimated at $715 million to $1.65 billion as teams of insurance adjusters arrived in Houston to start processing homeowner and automobile claims. (7.) Glass damage in Houston's office skyscrapers was extensive, officials said, but could have been worse. Specialists urged a strengthening of the city's building codes, which some called lax. (7.) Markets **********The basic money supply declined $500 million for the week ended Aug. 10, the first such drop since June 29, the Federal Reserve reported. The decline, which exceeded expectations, touched off a rally that lowered interest rates. Credit market participants were cheered by the belief that the Fed, with monetary growth now slowing, would not move to tighten credit. (33.) **********Stock prices varied within a narrow range.  The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.73 points, to 1,194.21. In the overall market, however, declines slightly outnumbered advances. For the week, the Dow rose 11.38 points. (37.) **********The dollar was mixed, while gold prices fell $2 an ounce, to $418, in New York. (39.) Livestock futures prices were mixed. (39.)  International **********The Brazilian Government is under growing pressure at home to declare a moratorium on repayment of its $90 billion of foreign debt. The pressure, once confined to the opposition, now comes from businessmen, economists and legislators from the Government's party. Opponents of a moratorium include President Joao Baptisto Figueiredo and key members of his Cabinet. (1.) Companies **********The F.B.I. is investigating the possibility that the computers of at least two companies were penetrated by the same group suspected of gaining entry to a computer at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. In one case, the computer involved was run by Gaffney-Cline Associates, a Dallas-based petroleum advisory service. The other involved Canada Cement LaFarge of Montreal. (33.) **********Bancal Tri-State, in which the Rothschilds own a stake, raised hopes on Wall Street that it may be acquired. (34.) Today's Columns **********Brokers must now make a special report to the I.R.S.  about their customers' proceeds from the sale of stocks, bonds and commodities. The requirement provides a new weapon in the Government's battle against tax-evasion on Wall Street. Your Money. (34.) **********A new energy-saving method improves the operation of refrigerators, air conditioners and heat pumps. It reduces the stages needed in vapor refrigeration systems, and it allows heat pumps to be used in colder climates than are now practical. Patents. (43.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/09/28/busin.body_text: **********Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that a new policy on China trade was nearly complete and could sharply increase technology exports to China. **********Mr. Baldrige said that Government committees had nearly completed the so-called technological transfer guidelines and that the details would be made available after obtaining clearance from United States allies. **********He outlined the new guidelines at a hearing by a special House subcommittee on trade with China. **********The difficulties in obtaining clearances for exports of technology that could be used for military purposes has been ''the single most important impediment'' to developing trade with China, said the subcommittee chairman, Al Swift, a Washington Democrat. **********Mr. Baldrige said the new guidelines would be divided into ''green, intermediate and red zones,'' with green representing products that would receive routine clearances. ''Almost 75 percent of People's Republic of China applications will fall within the green zone,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/26/busin.main_headline: Interest Rates Continue Lower; Money Down $1.5 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/26/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Interest Rates Continue Lower; Money Down $1.5 Billion
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates declined in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday as traders and speculators remained optimistic that lower inflation will combine with Federal Reserve monetary policy to bring down short- and long-term interest rates. **********Some market participants were disappointed late in the day when the Federal Reserve did not reduce the discount rate it charges on loans to financial institutions from its current 8 1/2 percent. Such a cut would be an overt signal of the Fed's willingness to foster lower short-term interest rates. **********However, other Fed announcements in the late afternoon were enough to keep alive the hopes that the central bank would encourage lower interest rates. Another reason for optimism was seen in the fact that the rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market continued to decline, slipping to 8 percent from 8 1/4 percent the day before. **********Decline in Money Supply **********A $1.5 billion decline in the basic money supply, to $489.5 billion, for the week ended Feb. 16 was slightly larger than expected. Although Fed officials say they have de-emphasised the M-1 basic money supply measure in favor of more broadly defined measures that are announced only monthly, analysts still concluded that the latest week's decline bodes well for more moderate money supply growth in coming weeks. **********The M-1 measure, which comprises currency plus non-interest-bearing checking accounts, and interest-bearing checking accounts with unlimited withdrawal privileges, is slightly above a level consistent with the Fed's 1983 growth target of between 4 percent and 7 percent. **********But according to Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers, the Fed is not concerned with the rapid growth of money supply measures in recent weeks and has supplied enough funds to the banking system to keep rates from rising. **********''Moreover,'' Mr. Kaufman writes in the latest issue of Comments on Credit, ''official pronouncements seem to favor lower money market rates.'' Supplying Credit to Banks **********Other data published by the Fed showed that it continues to supply an ample supply of credit to the banking system. The provision of funds to the banking system is crucial to the direction of short-term interest rates, since a greater availability of funds would mean lower rates, while less availability would mean higher rates. **********In the week ended Wednesday, some banks held $400 million more reserves on deposit with the Fed than were required, while other banks borrowed an average of $96 million from the Fed discount window. The result was a combined net free reserve position of $304 million. **********By late in the day, prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower than the best levels set in the afternoon, with three and sixmonth Treasury bill rates reduced by a tenth of a percentage point, or less, to 7.87 percent and 7.9 percent, respectively. Bond and Note Prices Rise **********Prices of notes and bonds rose by 1/8 to 3/4 of a point. Among active issues, the new 9 7/8 percent notes due 1988 rose about 3/8, to a price of 100, to yield 9.88 percent, while the 10 3/8 percent bonds due 2012 rose to 98 7/8, to yield 10.49 percent. At one time, the bond issue was offered at 99 1/4; it is now trading at about the same level as early last November, when its average auction yield was 10.46 percent. **********Business credit demands grew slightly in the week ended Feb. 16, with large banks across the country increasing their loans outstanding by $247 million, while businesses raised another $367 million by selling commercial paper. Both measures of business borrowing remain well below the peak levels set in the fall of 1982. **********The money market accounts introduced at banks and thrift institutions last December continued to grow rapidly in the week ended Feb. 16, increasing $11 billion, to $267.4 billion. **********The inflow of funds to the new accounts has enabled commercial banks to reduce the amount of money they borrow through sales of large negotiable certificates of deposit. Large banks across the country reduced their certificates outstanding by $2.1 billion in the week ended Feb. 16.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.main_headline: TechnologySteven J. Marcus Getting Coal To Burn Clean
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.print_headline: TechnologySteven J. Marcus Getting Coal To Burn Clean
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/11/17/busin.body_text: **********IF acid rain is to be seriously reduced over the **********next decade, most experts agree, the job will depend largely on flue-gas desulfurization, or ''scrubbing.'' This is the only option that is both commercially available and capable of stopping much of the sulfur dioxide emitted by coal-burning power plants from escaping into the atmosphere. **********But scrubbing is costly and cumbersome, and it leaves prodigious quantities of sludge. Because it is an add-on system, treating a problem after the fact rather than preventing it, a scrubber has no effect on the combustion process itself. And although it accounts for more than 10 percent of a power plant's capital cost, it produces no electricity. **********So a better approach might be to burn coal more cleanly and efficiently in the first place. The greatest promise for the long term, says Richard E. Balzhiser, senior vice president of the Electric Power Research Institute, is to develop ''fundamentally different ways'' to get electricity from coal. **********The leading candidate is fluidized-bed combustion, in which fine particles of coal are fed into a bed of limestone. The mixture appears to percolate like a liquid, thus giving rise to the term fluidized, and much of the sulfur dioxide produced by the burning coal reacts with the limestone and is drawn off. **********The nominal reduction of sulfur dioxide in a fluidized bed is the same - about 90 percent - as the combination of scrubbers and conventional boilers. But the greatest promise of fluidized-bed boilers is their ability to burn many different kinds of fuel, from top-grade to run-of-the-mine coal, as well as a wide variety of solid wastes. **********Fluidized-bed units are being produced by established makers of conventional boilers such as the Foster Wheeler Corporation, the Babcock & Wilcox subsidiary of McDermott Inc., Combustion Engineering Inc. and the Riley Stoker Corporation, which is a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc. Other companies specializing in the new technology include the Johnston Boiler Company of Ferrysburg, Mich., which is a subsidiary of Stone International of Britain, and the Pyropower Corporation of San Diego, a member of the Ahlstrom group of Finland. **********Sales have been ''slow but substantial,'' says Herbert M. Kosstrin, principal process engineer with the engineering concern of Stone & Webster Inc., who estimates the total number sold to be ''in the hundreds.'' But Edward A. Zielinski, manager of fluidized-bed combustion development at Combustion Engineering, says that ''less than 15'' are of a type that could be useful for utilities. **********Indeed, fluidized-bed boilers are not yet commercially available in the sizes required for electric power plants. And for an industry in which reliability is of paramount importance, long periods of testing are needed first. Mr. Balzhiser of the Electric Power Research Institute estimates that at least 10 years will be required. **********In the United States, much will depend on two projects led by the institute, in cooperation with the Tennessee Valley Authority, the Duke Power Company and the State of Kentucky. The first, a pilot-scale generating station of 20 megawatts driven by a fluidized-bed boiler built by Babcock & Wilcox, is currently in the second year of a four- year test period near Paducah, Ky. Its results will be shared with the boiler industry to influence a larger demonstration project, a plant of about 160 megawatts, to be built at the same site. **********Progress in industrial and utility application is also being reported in Europe. In West Germany, a demonstration plant at Esertal powered by fluidized-bed technology is generating 129 megawatts of electricity, and another at Volklingen is being built to deliver 200 megawatts. ''We are motivated by the extensive damage that acid rain has done to our trees,'' says Heinz Riesenhuber, Bonn's Minister of Research and Technology, ''which to us is close to catastrophe.'' **********But these demonstrations largely involve the first generation of fluidized-bed boilers, which have exhibited problems such as incomplete combustion, lower-than-anticipated sulfur removal, a tendency to clog and sheer size. **********The inherent limitation of first-generation units, says Gordon B. Baty, president of Wormser Engineering Inc. of Woburn, Mass., is that combustion and desulfurization - two entirely different chemical reactions - take place in the same bed, meaning that each process must be compromised. His company's approach is to build boilers with two beds, one for each function, with consequent improvement in the efficiency of each. **********Another approach is the circulating bed, in which fuel and limestone recirculate throughout the reactor to extend the time, and thus the completeness, of combustion and desulfurization. This is being developed by two competitors: Pyropower and a joint venture of Combustion Engineering and the Lurgi Corporation of West Germany. **********A major impediment to progress is the depressed market. Utilities are simply not buying boilers, and William Axtman, executive director of the American Boiler Manufacturers Association, declines to predict when and how changes may occur. ''The boiler industry is just beginning to recover from the recession,'' he says. Analysts who watch the boiler industry tend to dismiss fluidized- bed combustion at present as ''a research and development'' market. **********Nevertheless, Wormser's Mr. Baty waxes confident, maintaining that there is nothing in principle to prevent rapid penetration. ''Fluidized beds today,'' he says, ''are where airplanes were in 1925 - post-Wright brothers but pre-DC3. And they don't involve twisting arms to buy scrubbers and hang them on obsolete pieces of equipment.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.main_headline: Reagan to Name Envoy to Mozambique
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Reagan to Name Envoy to Mozambique
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/07/12/world.body_text: **********President Reagan said today that he would nominate Peter Jon de Vos, a career diplomat, as the first United States Ambassador to Mozambique since the Marxist Government expelled American diplomats more than two years ago. **********State Department officials said the move was part of a general warming of relations with Mozambique, which accused American diplomats of spying in March 1981. **********They said Mozambique was trying to attract private investment in the West and had aided Western efforts to arrange a peaceful move to independence for South-West Africa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/31/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Still No Letup In Bull Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/31/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Still No Letup In Bull Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1983/05/31/busin.body_text: **********LAST August, when the budding rally in stock prices was only two sessions old and investors kept wondering if it was genuine, Albert M. Wojnilower of the First Boston Corporation forecast sharp declines ahead for interest rates. A day later, Henry Kaufman of Salomon Brothers weighed in with similar views and the bull market in equities, armed with the welcome opinions of Wall Street's two most prominent economists, was off and sprinting. **********Last week, fresh from a trip to Zurich and London where he met with representatives of financial institutions, Mr. Wojnilower summed up his views anew in New York. Most short-term interest rates are probably near their lows, he said, ''but although short rates may be higher a year from now, the net rise may only amount to 1 percent or so.'' **********Without setting any parameters, the First Boston economist went on to suggest that the most dynamic initial upthrust in stock prices since World War II still has room to run. ''Whenever institutional investors do not sense any serious risk of either rising interest rates or a renewed economic downturn,'' he stated, ''a speculative stock market climate is likely to predominate.'' **********Meanwhile, a look at market activity last week showed that the speculative spirit is alive and thriving. Last week, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange approaching 100 million shares daily, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 1,216.14, up 26.12 points.  Its record closing of 1,232.59 on May 6 represents a 58 percent advance since Aug. 12. **********While demand for some of the Big Board's better-known issues has slackened somewhat, recently, brokers report that individual investors are becoming more venturesome. This is underscored by swelling demand for smaller-capitalization issues, many of which trade on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market. Last week, the Amex market value index and the Nasdaq composite index both set record highs. These two indicators, moreover, virtually have doubled since the start of the rally last summer. **********Cyclical stocks -comparative laggards in the market's sustained recovery - ranked as the week's best performers, according to Salomon Brothers. The steel group rose 8.2 percent, followed by chemicals and papers, each posting gains in excess of 4 percent. Only 6 of 38 stock groups declined, led by drugs and tobaccos, down 6.1 percent and 5.8 percent, respectively. **********For the most part, the wisest course of action so far in this bull market has been for investors to ignore selling advice and simply to hold on to their stocks. During the last nine months, legions of investors, from canny professionals to rank amateurs, have repeatedly ignored the Wall Street maxim of ''cut your losses and let your profits run,'' only to glance with regret at still-rising prices of stocks they once owned. **********One of the week's best gainers on the Big Board was Stop & Shop Companies, which surged 10 3/4 points, to 95 3/4, after it forecast ''significantly higher'' profits for the newly ended quarter. Early last year, shares of the discount retailer and supermarket chain traded as low as 14 1/4. **********Over a longer time frame, the merit of not selling too soon was demonstrated again by the action of MCI Communications. In the latest week, the stock rose 4 7/8 points, to 49 1/4, in over-the-counter trading. This compares with a split-adjusted price of 50 cents a share six years ago. The long-distance telephone and telecommunications company denied rumors last week that it would be acquired by either American Express or General Electric. Analysts at Prudential-Bache Securities expect MCI to show a 30 percent annual growth rate over the next five years. **********Meanwhile, the overriding question on both Wall Street and Main Street remains, ''When is this bull market going to stumble?'' Indicator Digest, an investment advisory service, has noted that, on average, ''almost one year passes between the birth of a bull and any correction of 10 percent or more,'' as measured by the Dow. **********Analysts at Merrill Lynch have estimated that, allowing for periods of price weakness, ''the current cyclical bull market, which began in August 1982, should last until some time in the second half of 1984.'' That projection would be in keeping with the historical pattern whereby the final two years of a President's first term generally are the most rewarding period for stock market investment. **********At Goldman, Sachs & Company, portfolio strategists regard a market correction of around 10 percent from recent highs as ''inevitable,'' but they believe its duration will be short. ''To us,'' they said, ''the primary direction of stock prices is up, with another 15 percent or so advance expected over the next 12 to 15 months.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1983/04/11/busin.body_text: **********The Economy **********A long fight is expected over legislation to withhold taxes on interest and dividends. Although the Senate is expected to take up the sensitive repeal issue this week, Congressional leaders say a resolution may elude Congress for many months. (Page D1.) **********Taxpayers are rushing to establish I.R.A. accounts before the April 15 deadline for filing income tax returns. Banks and other financial institutions report a surge in last-minute efforts by savers to qualify for deductions on their 1982 taxes. (D1.) **********A breakthrough in standardizing computer ''language'' has been announced by computer scientists at New York University. The new system, developed for the military, will be able to translate the hundreds of computer languages now used by the Defense Department, and eventually will benefit other users. (D1.) Companies **********Network Affiliates is persuading personal-injury law firms and others to advertise their services on television. Thus far, 91 law firms are paying $10,000 each to put their names on the company's 30-second ''slice of life'' generic TV ads. (D1.) **********Thomson McKinnon's plan to buy a thrift institution, part of a move by the ''quiet brokerage house'' to enter the banking field, is also viewed as a new trend by brokerage houses.
